Shabbat



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The acts of <b>carrying out</b> from a public domain into a private domain or vice versa, which are prohibited <b>on Shabbat,</b> are primarily <b>two</b> basic actions <b>that comprise four</b> cases from the perspective of a person <b>inside</b> a private domain, <b>and two</b> basic actions <b>that comprise four</b> cases from the perspective of a person <b>outside,</b> in a public domain.
The mishna elaborates: <b>How</b> do these eight cases take place? In order to answer that question, the mishna cites cases involving a poor person and a homeowner.
<b>The poor</b> person <b>stands outside,</b> in the public domain, <b>and the homeowner stands inside,</b> in the private domain. <b>The poor person</b> lifted an object in the public domain, <b>extended his hand into</b> the private domain, <b>and placed</b> the object <b>into the hand of the homeowner.</b> In that case, the poor person performed the prohibited labor of carrying from the public domain into the private domain in its entirety. <b>Or,</b> the poor person reached his hand into the private domain, <b>took</b> an item from the hand of the homeowner, <b>and carried</b> it <b>out</b> into the public domain. In that case, the poor person performed the prohibited labor of carrying out from the private domain into the public domain in its entirety. In both of these cases, because <b>the poor person</b> performed the prohibited labor in its entirety, he <b>is liable and the homeowner is exempt.</b>
The mishna cites two additional cases. In these, the prohibited labor is performed by the homeowner, who is in the private domain: <b>The homeowner</b> lifted an item in the private domain, <b>extended his hand into</b> the public domain, <b>and placed</b> the object <b>into the hand of the poor person.</b> In that case, the homeowner performed the labor of carrying out from the private domain into the public domain in its entirety. <b>Or,</b> the homeowner reached his hand into the public domain, <b>took</b> an object <b>from</b> the hand of the poor person, <b>and carried</b> it <b>into</b> the private domain. In that case, the homeowner performed the labor of carrying from the public domain into the private domain in its entirety. In both of those cases, because <b>the homeowner</b> performed the prohibited labor in its entirety, he <b>is liable and the poor person is exempt.</b>
There are four additional cases where neither the homeowner nor the poor person performed the labor in its entirety, and therefore neither is liable: <b>The poor person extended his hand into</b> the private domain <b>and</b> either <b>the homeowner took</b> an object <b>from</b> his hand and placed it in the private domain <b>or</b> the homeowner <b>placed</b> an object <b>into</b> the hand of the poor person, and the poor person <b>carried</b> the object <b>out</b> into the public domain. In those cases and the two that follow, the act of transferring the object from one domain to another was performed jointly by two people, the poor person and the homeowner. Because each performed only part of the prohibited labor, <b>both of them are exempt.</b>
So too, in a case where <b>the homeowner extended his hand into the public domain and,</b> either <b>the poor person took</b> an object <b>from</b> the homeowner’s hand and placed it in the public domain <b>or the poor person placed</b> an object <b>into</b> the homeowner’s hand and the homeowner <b>carried</b> the object <b>into</b> the private domain. Because each performed only part of the prohibited labor, <b>both of them are exempt.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in our mishna: The acts of carrying out on Shabbat are two that comprise four. Similarly, <b>we learned</b> in the mishna <b>there,</b> in tractate <i>Shevuot</i>: <b>Oaths</b> on a statement, which, when violated, render one liable to bring a sin-offering <b>are two that comprise four.</b> The first two cases, which are mentioned explicitly in the Torah, are: One who swore that he would perform a specific action in the future and one who swore to refrain from performing said action. Based on an amplification in the language of the Torah, two more cases are added: One who swore that he performed a specific action in the past and one who swore that he did not perform said action.

Daf 2b

Similarly, with regard to <b>awareness of ritual impurity,</b> there <b>are two</b> cases <b>that comprise four.</b> It is prohibited for one who is ritually impure to enter the Temple or to consume a consecrated item. However, one who unwittingly violates this serious prohibition is obligated to bring a sacrifice for his transgression only if he was clearly aware of his ritually impure status both before committing the transgression and thereafter. The two cases of unwitting transgression in this area are: One who was aware and then forgot that he is ritually impure, and then either ate consecrated meat or entered the Temple, and subsequently recalled that he was ritually impure. Two additional cases are: One who was aware of his ritually impure status but was unaware that the food he was about to eat was consecrated and ate it, or he was unaware that he was about to enter the Temple and entered it.
<b>Signs of affliction by leprosy</b> are <b>two that comprise four.</b> The Torah (Leviticus 13) mentions two types of signs of affliction with regard to leprosy, <i>baheret</i> and <i>se’et</i>. Two additional, secondary signs of affliction were added. They are not as white as those delineated in the Torah. Consequently, there are derivatives of both <i>baheret</i> and <i>se’et</i>.
The mishna in <i>Shevuot</i> also mentions that the acts of <b>carrying out on Shabbat are two</b> basic actions <b>that comprise four.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different here that</b> our mishna <b>teaches: Two that comprise four inside and two that comprise four outside, and what is different there,</b> in tractate <i>Shevuot</i>, <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> with regard to transfers on Shabbat: <b>Two that comprise four, and nothing more?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Here,</b> in tractate <i>Shabbat</i>, which contains <b>the primary</b> discussion of the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of Shabbat,</b> the mishna <b>teaches the primary categories</b> of labor that are prohibited on Shabbat, including carrying out from the private to the public domain, and it <b>teaches the subcategories</b> of labor that are prohibited on Shabbat, including carrying from the public into the private domain. But <b>there,</b> in tractate <i>Shevuot</i>, which does <b>not</b> contain <b>the primary</b> discussion of the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of Shabbat,</b> the mishna <b>teaches the primary categories</b> of labor prohibited on Shabbat but <b>does not teach the subcategories</b> of labor.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the primary</b> categories of labor prohibited on Shabbat? They are acts of <b>carrying out</b> from the private domain to the public domain. However, the Gemara objects: The acts of <b>carrying out are</b> only <b>two</b> in number: There is the case of the homeowner who takes an object out of the private domain and places it in the hand of the poor person in the public domain and the case of a poor person who takes an object from the homeowner’s hand in the private domain and takes it out into the public domain. What are the two additional cases referred to by the phrase: Two that comprise four, in tractate <i>Shevuot</i>?
<b>And if you say</b> that the mishna in tractate <i>Shevuot</i> enumerates all four cases of carrying out, <b>among them</b> those <b>for</b> which there is <b>liability and among them</b> those <b>for</b> which there is <b>exemption,</b> including those mentioned in the second half of our mishna in which each individual performs only half of the prohibited labor, that is not feasible. The mishna in <i>Shevuot</i> <b>teaches</b> the prohibition of carrying out on Shabbat <b>parallel to the signs of affliction by leprosy. Just as there,</b> with regard to leprosy, <b>all</b> four <b>of them</b> are cases <b>for</b> which there is <b>liability, so too, here,</b> with regard to Shabbat, <b>all</b> four <b>of them</b> are cases <b>for</b> which there is <b>liability.</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Pappa said</b> that the difference between the manner in which the <i>halakha</i> is cited in tractates <i>Shevuot</i> and <i>Shabbat</i> must be understood as follows: <b>Here,</b> where it contains <b>the primary</b> discussion of the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of Shabbat,</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> both cases of <b>liability and</b> cases of <b>exemption,</b> meaning cases of carrying out for which one is liable by Torah law as well as those for which one is exempt by Torah law. However, <b>there,</b> where it does <b>not</b> contain <b>the primary</b> discussion of the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of Shabbat,</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> cases of <b>liability</b> but <b>does not teach</b> cases of <b>exemption.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What are</b> the cases of <b>liability?</b> They are acts of <b>carrying out</b> from the private domain to the public domain. The Gemara objects on the grounds that there <b>are</b> only <b>two acts of carrying out:</b> Carrying out while standing inside and carrying out while standing outside. What is the meaning of the phrase in <i>Shevuot</i>: Which comprise four? The Gemara answers: It is possible to arrive at a total of four. Cases of carrying in from the public domain to the private domain are also enumerated in tractate <i>Shevuot</i>. Consequently, there are <b>two</b> cases <b>of carrying out and two</b> cases <b>of carrying in.</b>
The Gemara objects: In <i>Shevuot</i>, the phrase: Acts of <b>carrying out, is taught</b> in the mishna, not acts of carrying in. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The <b><i>tanna</i></b> in <i>Shevuot</i> <b>also refers to carrying in as carrying out.</b>
<b>From where</b> do I know this? <b>From that which we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One who carries out</b> an object <b>from one domain to another is liable. Are we not</b> also <b>dealing</b> with a case <b>where he is carrying</b> it <b>in from the public domain to the private domain, and</b> nevertheless the mishna <b>characterizes it</b> as <b>carrying out?</b>
<b>And what is the reason</b> that the term carrying out is used to refer to an act of carrying in? <b>The <i>tanna</i> characterizes any</b> act that involves <b>lifting of an object from its place</b> and transferring it to another domain as <b>carrying out.</b> Carrying out does not refer only to carrying an object out from one’s house. Rather, it is a general depiction of moving an object from the domain in which it is located into another domain.
<b>Ravina said: Our mishna is also precise,</b> and its language leads us to the same conclusion, <b>as</b> the expression: Acts of <b>carrying out</b> on Shabbat, <b>was taught</b> in our mishna, yet <b>immediately</b> a case of <b>carrying in is articulated.</b> The first case listed in our mishna involves the poor person placing an object into the hand of the homeowner, which is a case of carrying in from the public to the private domain. The Gemara notes: Indeed, <b>conclude from this</b> that the term carrying out also refers to carrying in.
<b>Rava said:</b> The language of the <i>mishnayot</i> poses no difficulty. The <i>tanna</i> in both of these <i>mishnayot</i> did not teach: Acts of carrying out on Shabbat. Rather, <b>he taught: Domains</b> of Shabbat. The correct version of the mishna is: <b>The domains of Shabbat are two</b> that comprise four, and, according to this <i>tanna</i>, there are four instances of prohibited labor in these two domains, inside and outside.
<b>Rav Mattana said to Abaye:</b> The mishna speaks of two that comprise four inside and two that comprise four outside, for a total of eight. Yet there is a difficulty: <b>Are these eight</b> cases? <b>They are twelve.</b> Upon closer inspection, in the four cases in the latter part of the mishna, the homeowner and the poor person each performs an individual action contributing to the overall prohibited labor of carrying in or carrying out. Consequently, there are four actions in the first part of the mishna and eight actions in the second part.
Abaye responded: <b>According to your reasoning, they are sixteen</b> actions, as even in the first part of our mishna, the one who receives the object and the one who places the object each participates in the performance of a prohibited action. Therefore, there are a total of sixteen actions.
Rav Mattana <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>That is not difficult,</b> as <b>granted</b>,

Daf 3a

<b>the first section</b> of the mishna speaks of cases in which the one performing the actions is <b>exempt</b> from punishment by Torah law, <b>and</b> even by rabbinic law he is <i>ab initio</i> <b>permitted</b> to perform those actions. When the poor person or homeowner neither lifted nor placed the object, i.e., the object was placed into or removed from their hands by others, their role is insignificant. Therefore, <b>it was not taught</b> in the mishna, and those cases were not factored into the total number of acts of carrying from domain to domain. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>the latter section of the mishna,</b> where the person performing those actions is <b>exempt</b> by Torah law, but his actions are <b>prohibited</b> by rabbinic law, it <b>is difficult.</b> Since the Sages prohibited those actions, they should be included in the total in the mishna, which should be twelve, not eight.
Incidentally, the Gemara wonders: <b>Is there, in all</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat,</b> an act for which the mishna deems one <b>exempt and</b> the act is <b>permitted? Didn’t Shmuel say:</b> With regard to <b>all exempt</b> rulings in the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of Shabbat,</b> although one who performs the action is <b>exempt</b> by Torah law, his action is <b>prohibited</b> by rabbinic law. This applies to all cases <b>except for these three</b> cases for which one is <b>exempt and</b> he is <b>permitted</b> to perform the action: <b>Trapping a deer,</b> where he does not actually trap it, rather he sits in the entrance of a house that a deer had previously entered on its own, preventing its exit; <b>and trapping a</b> poisonous <b>snake</b> because of the danger that it poses; <b>and one who drains an abscess,</b> meaning one who lances the boil of pus and drains the liquid from it. If so, the cases in the first section of our mishna, where the ruling is exempt, must be understood as exempt but prohibited.
The Gemara answers: In these cases, too, the ruling is: Exempt and permitted. <b>When,</b> though, <b>was it necessary for Shmuel</b> to cite specific cases as exempt and permitted? It was necessary in <b>exempt</b> cases <b>where he performs</b> a defined <b>action. However,</b> there are <b>many exempt</b> cases <b>where he does not perform an action,</b> which are completely permitted.
The Gemara returns to Rav Mattana’s question: <b>In any case, there are twelve</b> actions that should have been enumerated in the mishna. The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>took into consideration</b> cases of <b>exempt</b> acts where the one who performed them could <b>come,</b> through <b>their</b> performance, <b>to incur liability</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> The mishna did <b>not take into consideration</b> cases of exempt acts where the one who performed them could <b>not come,</b> through <b>their</b> performance, <b>to incur liability</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> Here, only the instances where one lifts an object from its place are taken into consideration. Having lifted an object, if he continued, he could potentially incur liability to bring a sin-offering. Under no circumstances can one who merely places an object come to violate a more serious prohibition.
The Gemara asks about the mishna itself: In the latter section of the mishna, instances in which <b>they are both exempt</b> are enumerated. However, <b>wasn’t a prohibited labor performed between</b> the two of <b>them?</b> Since together they performed an act prohibited by a severe Torah prohibition, how is it possible that their partnership will result in both being exempt? The Gemara answers that <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said:</b> It is written: “And if one soul sins unwittingly <b>from the people of the land when he does it,</b> one of the laws of God that should not be done and he is responsible” (Leviticus 4:27). The verse’s emphasis on the words “when he does it” means: <b>One who does all of it,</b> i.e., the entire transgression, is liable <b>and not one who does part of it.</b> Therefore, <b>an individual, and he performed</b> an action in its entirety<b>, is liable.</b> However, <b>two</b> people, <b>and they performed</b> an action together<b>, are not liable,</b> as each one performed only part of the action. The Gemara comments: <b>It was also stated</b> in support of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion: <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Gamda said:</b> Amidst a discussion of these matters, <b>it emanated from the group</b> of Sages <b>and they said:</b> From the verse’s emphasis on <b>“when he does it”</b> it is derived: <b>An individual who performed it is liable.</b> However, <b>two who performed it are not liable.</b>
<b>Rav raised a dilemma before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: One <b>whom another</b> person <b>loaded with food and drink</b> on his back in the private domain on Shabbat, <b>and</b> he <b>carried them out</b> while they were still on his back, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the prohibition of carrying out on Shabbat? Clearly, one who lifts an object with his hand in the private domain, and carries it out into the public domain is liable, as he performed the complete act of carrying out. However, in the case of one who is laden with an object; is <b>moving his body</b> from its place in the private domain <b>considered like lifting the object</b> itself from its place? In that case, he would be liable. <b>Or, perhaps</b> it <b>is not</b> considered like lifting the object from its place, and therefore he would not be liable. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: He is liable, and it is not similar to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of one who had an object placed in <b>his hand</b> and carried it out to the public domain, with regard to which we learned in the mishna that he is not liable by Torah law. <b>What is the reason</b> for the distinction between these two apparently similar cases? <b>His body is at rest,</b> in a defined place. However, <b>his hand is not at rest.</b> Since a hand is not generally fixed in one place, moving it and even transferring it to a different domain without a bona fide act of lifting is not considered lifting. However, the body is generally fixed in one place. Moving it from its place is considered lifting in terms of Shabbat, and he is liable for doing so.

Daf 3b

<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said to Rav,</b> his sister’s son: <b>Son of great men, didn’t I tell you that when Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>is involved in this tractate do not ask him</b> questions <b>in another tractate, as perhaps it will not be on his mind</b> and he will be unable to answer? The dilemma that Rav asked was not related to the subject matter of the tractate which they were studying. <b>As, had</b> it <b>not been</b> for the fact that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>is a great man, you would have shamed him, as he would</b> have been forced to <b>give you an answer that is not an</b> appropriate <b>answer.</b>
<b>Now,</b> he was involved in another tractate. <b>Nevertheless, he answered you well, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who was laden with food and drink while it was still day,</b> before Shabbat began, and, consequently, did not perform the act of lifting on Shabbat, <b>and he carried them out</b> into the public domain <b>after dark</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable. Since,</b> as a rule, his body is fixed in one place, moving it is considered like lifting an object, and he is liable. <b>It is not similar to</b> lifting <b>his hand</b> and moving it from place to place. Since his hand is not fixed in one place, moving it is not considered lifting.
<b>Abaye said:</b> It is <b>obvious to me</b> that <b>the hand of a person</b> in and of itself, when he moves it out of the domain where he is located, <b>is</b> considered to be <b>neither like the public domain nor like the private domain,</b> even if it is the hand of someone standing in one of those domains. Proof that the hand <b>is not considered like the public domain</b> can be derived <b>from</b> the ruling of the mishna with regard to <b>the hand of the poor person.</b> As we learned with regard to the poor person who brought his hand carrying an object that he lifted from the public domain into the private domain and the homeowner took the object from his hand; the homeowner is not liable. Apparently, the hand of the poor person is not considered part of the public domain, even though he himself is located in the public domain. Proof that <b>it is not considered like the private domain</b> can be derived <b>from</b> the ruling of the mishna with regard to <b>the hand of the homeowner.</b> As we learned with regard to the homeowner who moved his hand carrying an object that he lifted from the private domain into the public domain and the poor person took the object from his hand; the poor person is not liable for carrying out from a private domain.
However, <b>Abaye raised a dilemma: What is</b> the ruling with regard to <b>the hand of a person</b> with an object in it, when that person reached his hand into a different domain? Does <b>it assume <i>karmelit</i></b> status? A <i>karmelit</i> is an intermediate domain established by the Sages that is neither a private nor a public domain. This dilemma is based on the fact that his hand left one domain and did not yet enter a second domain. In terms of practical <i>halakha</i>, the two sides of this dilemma are: <b>Did the Sages penalize him</b> and issue a rabbinic decree prohibiting him from <b>bringing</b> his hand with the object <b>back to</b> the domain where <b>he</b> is standing <b>or not?</b>
The Gemara says: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from that which we learned elsewhere, with regard to the question: What must one in the private domain do in a case where <b>his hand was filled with fruits and he extended it outside,</b> into the public domain? <b>It was taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i> that <b>it is prohibited</b> for him <b>to bring it back</b> into his house, <b>and it was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> that <b>it is permitted</b> for him <b>to bring it back. Is it not with regard to this that they disagree; that the Sage</b> in one <i>baraita</i> <b>holds</b> that his hand <b>is like a <i>karmelit</i>, and the Sage</b> in the other <i>baraita</i> <b>holds that it is not like a <i>karmelit</i>?</b>
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>No, everyone</b> agrees that <b>it is like a <i>karmelit,</i> and</b> yet, this is <b>not difficult,</b> as the difference between the <i>baraitot</i> can be explained in the following manner: <b>Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> prohibiting him from bringing his hand back, is referring to a case where he took it out at a height <b>below ten</b> handbreadths off the ground, within the airspace of the public domain. <b>And there,</b> the <i>baraita</i> permitting him to bring his hand back, is referring to a case where he took it out at a height <b>above ten</b> handbreadths off the ground, outside the airspace of the public domain. Consequently, the object is considered to be neither in the public domain nor in a <i>karmelit</i>.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> are both referring to a case where he took his hand out to the public domain at a height <b>below ten</b> handbreadths, <b>and</b> his hand <b>is not considered a <i>karmelit</i>. And</b> yet, this is <b>not difficult.</b> As <b>here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> permitting him to bring it back, is referring to a case where he took it out <b>while it was still day</b> on Shabbat eve. Since he extended his hand before Shabbat and, in doing so, did nothing wrong, the Sages did not penalize him and permitted him to bring his hand back on Shabbat itself. However, <b>there,</b> the <i>baraita</i> prohibiting him from bringing it back, is referring to a case where he took it out <b>after dark,</b> and Shabbat had already begun. Since there is an element of prohibition involved, the Sages penalized him and prohibited him from bringing it back.
The Gemara comments that this explanation is difficult. <b>On the contrary, the opposite is reasonable.</b> In the case where he extended his hand <b>while it was still day, when</b> even <b>were he to throw</b> the object from his hand into the public domain, <b>he would not incur liability</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering</b> because the object was lifted from its place on a weekday, <b>let the Sages penalize him.</b> However, in the case where he extended his hand after dark, <b>where were he to throw</b> the object from his hand into the public domain, <b>he would</b> thereby <b>incur liability</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering, let the Sages not penalize him.</b> Were the Sages to penalize him by prohibiting him from bringing his hand back, he is liable to drop the object in the public domain, and by doing so he would violate a Torah prohibition.
<b>And from</b> the fact that <b>we did not explain it that way,</b> but preferred the contrary distinction, <b>resolve</b> the dilemma raised by <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye,</b> whose dilemma is predicated on the same fundamental issue. <b>As Rav Beivai bar Abaye raised the dilemma: One who</b> unwittingly <b>stuck bread in the oven</b> on Shabbat, as bread was baked by sticking the dough to the sides of a heated oven, <b>did they permit him to</b> override a rabbinic prohibition and <b>remove it</b> from the oven before it bakes, i.e., <b>before he incurs liability</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering</b> for baking bread on Shabbat, <b>or did they not permit</b> him to do so? Removing the bread is also prohibited on Shabbat. However, its prohibition is only by rabbinic law. The fundamental dilemma is: May one violate a rabbinical prohibition in order to avoid violating a Torah prohibition or not?
Based on the above, <b>resolve</b> that the Sages <b>did not permit</b> one to do so. In resolving Abaye’s dilemma, the concern that one would likely throw the object from his hand, and thereby violate a Torah prohibition, was not taken into consideration. The one who extended his hand into the public domain was penalized by the Sages and prohibited to bring his hand back. Here too, resolve the dilemma and say that he may not remove the bread, even though he will thereby violate a Torah prohibition. The dilemma of Rav Beivai bar Abaye, which was thought to be unresolved, is thereby resolved. As a result, there is room for uncertainty whether or not the resolution of the previous dilemma, through which Rav Beivai’s dilemma would also be resolved, is valid. The Gemara rejects this difficulty: <b>That is not difficult.</b> It is possible that even though a resolution had not been previously found for the dilemma of Rav Beivai bar Abaye, that does not mean that it cannot be resolved <b>And,</b> indeed, as proof can be brought from the resolution of the other dilemma, <b>resolve</b> this dilemma as well.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>Actually, do not resolve</b> the dilemma, but, nevertheless, resolve the contradiction between the <i>baraitot</i> in the following manner. <b>Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> that taught that it is permitted to bring one’s hand back is referring to a case where he extended it <b>unwittingly. There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> that taught that it is prohibited for one to bring it back is referring to a case where he took it out <b>intentionally.</b> When he took it out <b>unwittingly, the Sages did not penalize him.</b> When he took it out <b>intentionally, the Sages penalized him</b> and prohibited him from bringing it back.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead, in order to resolve the contradiction that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>are</b> both referring to a case where he took his hand out <b>unwittingly. And here they disagree</b> with regard to the question: Did the Sages <b>penalize</b> an <b>unwitting</b> offender <b>due to an intentional</b> offender? <b>The Sage</b> who prohibits him from bringing his hand back <b>holds</b> that <b>they penalized</b> an <b>unwitting</b> offender <b>due to an intentional</b> offender. Therefore, even though he took his hand out unwittingly, they penalized him and prohibited him from bringing the object back so that he would not come to do so intentionally. <b>The Sage</b> who permits him to bring it back <b>holds</b> that <b>they did not penalize</b> an <b>unwitting</b> offender <b>due to an intentional</b> offender. Therefore, they did not prohibit him from bringing it back.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that, <b>actually, they did not penalize</b> an unwitting offender due to an intentional offender, <b>and</b> still, this is <b>not difficult,</b> and there is no contradiction. <b>Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> that permits bringing it back, is referring to bringing it back <b>to the same courtyard</b> where he is standing.

Daf 4a

<b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> that prohibits returning the object, is referring to bringing it <b>to a different courtyard, as Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman:</b> One who was standing in a courtyard on Shabbat, and <b>his hand was filled with fruits, and he extended it outside</b> into the public domain, <b>what is</b> the ruling with regard to whether or not he is allowed <b>to bring it back into the same courtyard</b> where he is standing? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: It is permitted.</b> And he asked him further: <b>What is</b> the ruling with regard to bringing it from the public domain <b>to a different courtyard? He said to him: It is prohibited.</b>
Rava asked about this: <b>And</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> one case <b>different</b> from the other? By definition, both courtyards are private domains, and there is no apparent halakhic difference between them in terms of Shabbat. Rav Naḥman answered jokingly: <b>When you eat a <i>kor</i> of salt</b> while thinking <b>it over,</b> you will know the answer. Actually, the answer is simple: <b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> that taught that it is permitted to bring it back to the same courtyard, said so because <b>his planned</b> objective <b>was not realized.</b> Since he sought to take an object out of his courtyard, requiring him to bring the object back to its original place is a penalty of sorts. However, <b>here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> that taught that it is prohibited to bring it back to a different courtyard, said so because <b>his planned</b> objective <b>was realized.</b> Therefore, it is prohibited to bring it back there.
Since Rav Beivai bar Abaye’s dilemma was mentioned in passing, the Gemara proceeds to discuss <b>the matter itself. Rav Beivai bar Abaye raised a dilemma: One who</b> erred and <b>stuck bread in the oven</b> on Shabbat, <b>did they permit him to</b> override a rabbinic prohibition and <b>remove it</b> before it bakes, i.e., <b>before he incurs liability</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering</b> for baking bread on Shabbat, <b>or did they not permit</b> him to do so?
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Abaye said to Ravina: What are the circumstances? If you say</b> that he stuck the bread to the oven <b>unwittingly and did not remember</b> either that today was Shabbat or that it is prohibited to do so on Shabbat, <b>to whom did they permit</b> to remove it? If he remains unaware that a prohibition is involved, it will not occur to him to ask whether or not he is permitted to remove the bread before it bakes.
<b>But rather, is it not</b> a case <b>where he then,</b> before it baked, <b>remembered</b> that it is prohibited? In that case, <b>is he liable</b> to bring a sin-offering? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>All those who</b> sin unwittingly and <b>are</b> therefore <b>liable</b> to bring <b>sin-offerings are only liable if</b> the <b>beginning</b> of <b>their</b> action <b>was unwitting and</b> the <b>end</b> of <b>their</b> action <b>was unwitting.</b> This means that throughout the entire action until its completion, the person remains unaware that his action is prohibited. Consequently, in our case, since he became aware that his action is prohibited while the bread was still baking, his very awareness exempts him from a sin-offering and removing the bread is no longer necessary to prevent him from incurring liability to bring a sin-offering.
<b>Rather,</b> say that that person stuck the bread in the oven <b>intentionally,</b> but afterward regrets having done so and does not want to violate the prohibition. However, if that is the case, the formulation of the dilemma is inaccurate. It <b>should have</b> said: <b>Before he comes to</b> violate <b>a prohibition</b> punishable by <b>stoning.</b> One who desecrates Shabbat intentionally is liable to be stoned, he is not merely liable to bring a sin-offering.
<b>Rav Sheila said: Actually,</b> it is referring to a case where he did so <b>unwittingly,</b> and the dilemma whether or not they permitted removing the bread is not with regard to the person who stuck it in the oven, as he remains unaware of his transgression. Rather, with regard <b>to whom</b> is Rav Beivai raising a dilemma whether or not the Sages <b>permitted</b> him to remove the bread? It is with regard <b>to others</b> who wish to spare the unwitting sinner from violating a Torah prohibition.
<b>Rav Sheshet strongly objected to this. And does one tell</b> another <b>person: Sin so that another will benefit?</b> Permitting one to violate a prohibition, even one prohibited by rabbinic law, in order to help another perform a mitzva is inconceivable. The same is true with regard to preventing another from violating a more severe prohibition.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: Actually,</b> it is referring to a case where he stuck the bread in the oven <b>intentionally. And say,</b> emend the text as follows: <b>Before he comes to</b> violate <b>a prohibition</b> punishable by <b>stoning.</b> Indeed, <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, would teach it explicitly</b> in that manner; not as a dilemma, but rather, as a halakhic ruling. According to his version, <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye said:</b> With regard to one who <b>stuck bread in an oven</b> on Shabbat eve, the Sages <b>permitted him to remove it</b> from the oven on Shabbat <b>before he comes to</b> violate <b>a prohibition</b> punishable by <b>stoning.</b>
We learned in the mishna several examples where <b>the poor person extended his hand:</b> One, when he placed an object into the hand of the homeowner and one, when he took an object from the hand of the homeowner. In those cases, we learned that he is liable to bring a sin-offering. The Gemara asks: <b>Why is he liable? Don’t we require</b> that halakhic <b>lifting and placing</b> be performed <b>from</b> and onto <b>the surface of an area</b> that is <b>four by four</b> handbreadths? A smaller area is not considered a defined place, and it is as if the object were not there at all; <b>and</b> a person’s hand <b>is not</b> that size. Why, then, is he liable?
<b>Rabba said: Whose</b> opinion <b>is it</b> in this mishna? It is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>we do not require a place of four by four</b> handbreadths. According to his opinion, even a smaller area is considered a significant place in terms of carrying out on Shabbat. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One who throws</b> an object <b>from the private domain</b> to <b>the</b> other <b>private domain and</b> there is <b>the public domain in the middle, Rabbi Akiva deems him liable</b> for carrying out into the public domain, <b>and the Rabbis deem him exempt</b> because the object merely passed through the public domain and did not come to rest in it.
This dispute can be explained as follows: <b>Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that <b>we say</b> that <b>an object in airspace is considered at rest.</b> In his opinion, an object that passed, even briefly, through the airspace of the public domain is considered as if it came to rest in that domain. Therefore, one who threw the object has, for all intents and purposes, lifted the object from the private domain and placed it in the public domain, and he is liable. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>we do not say</b> that <b>an object in airspace is considered at rest.</b> In their opinion, although he lifted the object from the private domain, it never came to rest in the public domain. Since he never placed it in the public domain, he is not liable. Regardless, according to Rabbi Akiva’s opinion, placing does not require a defined area. The mere presence of an object in the public domain accords it the legal status of having been placed there. Apparently, there is no requirement that an object be placed on a surface with an area of four by four handbreadths.
Initially, the Gemara wonders about the substance of Rabba’s opinion: <b>Is that to say that it is obvious to Rabba</b> that, <b>with regard</b> to whether or not <b>an object in airspace is considered at rest,</b>

Daf 4b

<b>and</b> it is in a case where the object passed <b>within ten</b> handbreadths of the ground that <b>they disagree? And wasn’t it raised as a dilemma by Rabba,</b> as it was unclear to him whether or not that is the correct explanation of the dispute between Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis? <b>As Rabba raised a dilemma: Do</b> those who dispute the matter of one who throws from a private domain to a private domain with a public domain in the middle <b>disagree</b> with regard to a case where the object was thrown <b>below ten</b> handbreadths off the ground, <b>and this is</b> the point over which <b>they disagree: Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that <b>an object in airspace is considered at rest, and the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>we do not say</b> that <b>an object in airspace is considered at rest? However,</b> if the object passed more <b>than ten</b> handbreadths <b>above</b> the public domain, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>he is exempt and everyone agrees</b> that <b>we do not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>throwing from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>passing.</b> There is a special <i>halakha</i> with regard to passing objects: One standing in a private domain who passes an object through a public domain to another private domain, even though the object did not come to rest in the public domain, his action is considered to have carried out. However, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to throwing is different.
<b>Or, perhaps they disagree with regard</b> to a case where the object passed <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>above</b> the ground, <b>and this is</b> the point over which <b>they disagree: Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that <b>we derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>throwing from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>passing</b> and considers them details of one <i>halakha</i>. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>we do not derive throwing from passing,</b> and, although one who passes the object in that case is liable, one who throws it is not. The <i>halakha</i> with regard to passing is a unique <i>halakha</i>, a Torah decree, and other cases cannot be derived from it. <b>However,</b> with regard to one who throws from one private domain to another via a public domain, if the object passed <b>below ten</b> handbreadths off the ground, <b>everyone agrees</b> that he <b>is liable. What is the reason</b> for this? Everyone agrees that an <b>object in airspace is considered at rest.</b> Since Rabba himself is uncertain as to the point of the dispute in that mishna with regard to one who throws an object, how can he determine Rabbi Akiva’s opinion in the matter of our mishna?
The Gemara answers: <b>That is not difficult.</b> It can be explained that, <b>after he raised the dilemma, it was later resolved for him</b> that the correct understanding is <b>that Rabbi Akiva</b> alone <b>holds</b> that an <b>object in airspace is considered at rest.</b>
However, there is room to question the parallel between Rabbi Akiva’s opinion and the case in our mishna. <b>Perhaps placing</b> alone <b>does not require</b> an area of four by four in order to be considered halakhic placing, <b>but lifting does require</b> a minimum of four by four handbreadths to be considered halakhic lifting. Perhaps placing, which is merely the conclusion of the prohibited labor, does not require the same conditions as lifting, which is the beginning and the essence of the labor of carrying out (Rashba). From Rabbi Akiva’s opinion, a conclusion may be drawn that an object in airspace is considered placed even without the surface area of four by four handbreadths. But, a conclusion may not be drawn that an object lifted from a surface lacking that area is considered lifted.
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef said: Whose</b> opinion <b>is it</b> in this mishna? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
The Gemara asks: To <b>which</b> of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi’s <i>halakhot</i> is Rav Yosef referring? <b>If you say</b> that he is referring to <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One who <b>threw</b> an object on Shabbat in the public domain from the beginning to the end of four cubits, <b>and it,</b> the object, <b>came to rest atop a projection of any size, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> him <b>liable, and the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt.</b> Apparently, this proves that, according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, there is no minimum area required for lifting and placing. This is the <i>halakha</i> to which Rav Yosef referred.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>There,</b> the explanation is according to what <b>we will need to say later in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Abaye,</b> as <b>Abaye said: Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is not dealing with just any situation. Rather, it is dealing with a special case where there is <b>a tree standing in the private domain and its boughs lean into the public domain, and</b> one <b>threw</b> an object from the public domain <b>and it rested</b> upon <b>the boughs</b> of the tree.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>we say: Cast its boughs after its trunk.</b> The tree’s branches are considered an extension of its trunk. Therefore, the entire tree is considered as a private domain, and one who throws onto it is liable. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>we do not say: Cast its boughs after its trunk.</b> Therefore, the boughs themselves are not considered to be a private domain, and one who throws atop them from the public domain is not liable. Since Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi considers the boughs of the tree like part of the trunk, something thrown atop the tree is considered as if it were placed on the trunk, which is four by four handbreadths. If so, one cannot conclude from here that there is no need for a significant area according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi.
<b>Rather,</b> it is possible that Rav Yosef referred to <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One who <b>threw</b> an object on Shabbat <b>from the public domain to the public domain and the private domain</b> was <b>in the middle, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> him <b>liable</b> for carrying out from domain to domain, and <b>the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt.</b>
<b>And Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> In that case, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that the one who threw the object is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings, as he violated two prohibitions: <b>One, due to carrying</b> from the public domain <b>into</b> the private domain, when the object passed through the airspace of the private domain; <b>and one, due to carrying</b> from the private domain <b>out</b> to the public domain. <b>Apparently, he requires neither lifting</b> from <b>nor placing upon an area of four by four</b> handbreadths, as not only is he liable for carrying the object into a private domain and placing it by means of passing through its airspace, but he is also liable for lifting the object from that private domain and bringing it to the public domain. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, neither lifting nor placing requires a significant area.
The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>Wasn’t it stated with regard to this</b> dispute <b>that Rav and Shmuel both said:</b>

Daf 5a

<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>only deemed</b> him <b>liable in the covered private domain,</b> with a roof, <b>as we say: The house is considered as one that is full?</b> The entire house with all its space is considered one unit, and each part of it is considered as if it is filled with actual objects. Therefore, an object passing through the house is considered as if it landed on an actual surface of at least four by four handbreadths. <b>However,</b> in a private domain <b>that is not covered,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi does <b>not</b> deem him liable.
<b>And if you say: Here too</b> our mishna is speaking <b>about a covered</b> domain, and therefore the lifting from and the placing on the hand are considered as if they were performed in a place that is four handbreadths; <b>granted, in a covered private domain</b> lifting from and placing in a hand are considered as if it were lifted from and placed onto an area of four by four handbreadths, <b>but in a covered public domain is he liable</b> at all? <b>Didn’t Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda say</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who carries an object four</b> cubits from place to place <b>in a covered public domain,</b> even though transferring an object four cubits in the public domain is like carrying out from one domain to another and prohibited by Torah law, in this case, he <b>is not liable?</b> The reason is that <b>since</b> the covered public domain <b>is not similar to the banners in the desert,</b> i.e., the area in which the banners of the tribes of Israel passed in the desert. The labors prohibited on Shabbat are derived from the labors that were performed in the building of the Tabernacle during the encampment of Israel in the desert, and the desert was most definitely not covered. Consequently, even according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion, it is impossible to explain that our mishna is referring to the case of a covered public domain.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Zeira said:</b> There must be a different source for our mishna. <b>Whose</b> opinion <b>is it</b> in our mishna? It is the opinion of <b><i>Aḥerim</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say:</b> One who <b>stood in his place</b> on Shabbat <b>and received</b> an object thrown to him from another domain, the one who threw the object <b>is liable</b> for the prohibited labor of carrying out, as he both lifted and placed the object. However, if the one who received the object <b>moved from his place,</b> ran toward the object, <b>and</b> then <b>received</b> it in his hand, he, the one who threw it, <b>is exempt.</b> That is because, even though he performed an act of lifting, the placing of the object was facilitated by the action of the one who received it, and therefore the one who threw it did not perform the act of placing. In any case, according to the opinion of <i>Aḥerim</i>, if <b>he stood in his place and received</b> the object, the one who threw it <b>is liable. Don’t we require placing upon an area of four</b> by four handbreadths <b>and there is none</b> in this case? <b>Rather,</b> certainly <b>conclude from this</b> that according to <i>Aḥerim</i> <b>we do not require</b> an area of four by four.
The Gemara rejects this: This is not a proof, <b>and</b> one could say: <b>Perhaps it is</b> specifically <b>for placing</b> that <b>we do not require</b> an area of four by four; <b>however, for lifting we require</b> an area of four by four in order to consider it significant. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>placing as well,</b> one could say: <b>Perhaps</b> it was performed in a manner in which <b>he extended the corners</b> of his coat <b>and received it, so</b> in that case <b>there is also placing</b> upon an area of four by four. Therefore, there is no proof from here.
<b>Rabbi Abba said: Our mishna is</b> speaking about <b>a</b> special <b>case where he received,</b> i.e., lifted, the object that was <b>in a basket [<i>teraskal</i>] and he placed it atop a basket.</b> In that case, <b>there is also placing</b> performed upon an area of four by four handbreadths. The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in the mishna: <b>His hand?</b> So how can you say that he received it in a basket? The Gemara answers: Emend the text of the mishna and <b>teach: The basket in his hand.</b>
The Gemara asks about this matter: <b>Granted,</b> when the <b>basket was in the private domain, but</b> if it was <b>a basket that was</b> placed <b>in the public domain,</b> doesn’t it immediately become <b>the private domain?</b> Presumably, the basket is ten handbreadths above the ground, and its surface is the requisite size for creating a private domain.
Since that is not the explanation given, <b>let us say</b> that this is a proof that our mishna is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: One who stuck a stick</b> into the ground <b>in the public domain, and</b> hung <b>a basket atop it,</b> and <b>threw</b> an object from the public domain, <b>and it landed upon it, he is liable,</b> because he threw it from the public domain into the private domain. Since the surface of the basket is four by four handbreadths and it is ten handbreadths above the ground, it is considered a private domain. Even though the stick, which is serving as the base for this basket, is not four handbreadths wide, since the basket is that wide, we consider it as if the sides of the basket descend in a straight line. Consequently, a type of pillar of a private domain is formed in the public domain.
Our mishna is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>as if</b> it were <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> in a case where <b>the owner of the house extended his hand outside and placed</b> an object <b>in</b> the basket in <b>the hand of the poor person</b> in the public domain, <b>why is he liable?</b> According to his opinion, the basket is considered a private domain and <b>he,</b> the owner of the house, <b>is</b> merely <b>carrying out from private domain to private domain.</b> This proves that the opinion of our mishna is not in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda.
The Gemara answers: <b>Even if you say</b> that our mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, there,</b> where we learned that a basket is considered like a private domain, was in a case in which the basket was <b>above ten</b> handbreadths off the ground. <b>Here,</b> in our mishna, the basket was <b>below ten</b> handbreadths off the ground. Even according to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, in a case where it is below ten handbreadths it is not considered a private domain, rather it is part of the public domain. Therefore, it is considered carrying out and he is liable.
The Gemara comments: Nevertheless, this explanation <b>is difficult for Rabbi Abbahu: Was</b> the language <b>taught</b> in the mishna: <b>A basket in his hand? His hand,</b> was <b>taught.</b> There is no reason to emend the mishna in that way. <b>Rather, Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> The mishna here is referring <b>to a case where</b> the poor person <b>lowered his hand below three</b> handbreadths off the ground <b>and received</b> that object in his hand. Below three handbreadths is considered, in all respects, to be appended to the ground and, therefore, a place of four by four handbreadths.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t</b> the mishna <b>teach:</b> The poor person <b>stands</b> outside? If he is standing, how is it possible that his hand is within three handbreadths of the ground? Rabbi Abbahu answered: It is describing a case where he is <b>bending down.</b> In that case, his hand could be adjacent to the ground even though he is standing. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that it is possible in a case where the poor person is standing <b>in a hole</b> and his hand is adjacent to the ground. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead a different depiction of the situation: The mishna is speaking about a case <b>involving a midget [<i>nanas</i>],</b> whose hands, even when standing, are within three handbreadths of the ground.
About all of these <b>Rava said: Did the <i>tanna</i> go to</b> all that trouble <b>in an effort to teach us all of these</b> cases? It is difficult to accept that the <i>tanna</i> could not find a more conventional manner to explain the <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The problem must be resolved by establishing the principle: <b>A person’s hand is considered like four by four</b> handbreadths <b>for him.</b> It is true that lifting and placing upon a significant place are required. However, even though a significant place is normally no less than four handbreadths, the hand of a person is significant enough for it to be considered a significant place as far as the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat are concerned. <b>And, so too, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A person’s hand is considered four by four</b> handbreadths <b>for him.</b>
<b>Rabbi Avin said</b> that <b>Rabbi Elai said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> One who <b>threw an object and it landed in the hand of another</b> who is in a different domain <b>is liable.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is he teaching us?</b> What halakhic principle is conveyed through this statement? Is it that <b>a person’s hand is considered four by four for him? Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> already <b>say that one time?</b> Why was it necessary to repeat it, albeit in a different context? The Gemara answers: It was necessary to teach the <i>halakha</i> cited by Rabbi Elai as well, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>this,</b> the principle that a person’s hand is significant, <b>applies only where he</b> himself <b>deemed his hand significant</b> by lifting or receiving an object with his hand. <b>However, where he did not deem his hand significant,</b> rather the object fell into another’s hand without his intention, perhaps the hand is <b>not</b> considered a significant place and he would not be liable. Therefore, <b>he teaches us</b> that the hand’s significance is absolute and not dependent upon the intention of the one initiating the action.
<b>Rabbi Avin said</b> that <b>Rabbi Elai said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> additionally: One who <b>stood in his place and received</b> an object that was thrown to him from another domain, the one who threw it <b>is liable.</b> However, if <b>he moved from his place and</b> then <b>received</b> the object, the one who threw it <b>is exempt. That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>. <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say:</b> If <b>he stood in his place and received</b> in his hand the object that was thrown from another domain, the one who threw it <b>is liable.</b> And if <b>he moved from his place and received</b> it, <b>he is exempt.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised a</b> related <b>dilemma:</b> One who <b>threw an object</b> from one domain <b>and moved from his place</b> and ran to another domain <b>and then received</b> the same object in his hand in the second domain, <b>what is</b> his legal status?
To clarify the matter, the Gemara asks: <b>What is his dilemma?</b> Didn’t one person perform a complete act of lifting and placing? <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said: His dilemma was</b> with regard to <b>two forces in one person.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan raised a dilemma with regard to one who performs two separate actions rather than one continuous action. Are <b>two forces in one person considered like one person, and he is liable? Or, perhaps they are considered like two people, and he is exempt?</b> This dilemma remains unresolved and therefore, <b>let it stand.</b>
<b>Rabbi Avin said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> If he <b>brought his hand into the courtyard of another and received rainwater</b> that fell at that time into his hand <b>and carried</b> it <b>out</b> to another domain, <b>he is liable. Rabbi Zeira objects</b> to this: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>to me</b> if <b>his friend loaded him</b> with an object, i.e., his friend placed an object in his hand, <b>and what is</b> the difference <b>to me</b> if <b>Heaven loaded him</b> with rainwater? In <b>neither</b> case <b>did he perform an</b> act of <b>lifting.</b> Why then should he be liable for carrying out from domain to domain? The Gemara answers: <b>Do not say: He received</b> rainwater, indicating that he passively received the rainwater in his hand. <b>Rather</b>, read: <b>He</b> actively <b>gathered</b> rainwater in his hand from the air, which is tantamount to lifting. The Gemara asks: In order to become liable, <b>don’t we require lifting from atop an area of four</b> handbreadths, <b>and</b> in this case <b>there is none?</b> How, therefore, would he be liable?
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya, son of Rav Huna, said:</b> It is <b>a case where he gathered</b> the rainwater <b>from atop</b> and on the side of <b>the wall,</b> so he lifted it from a significant place. Therefore, it is considered an act of lifting, and he is liable. The Gemara questions: <b>Atop a wall, too,</b> the rain <b>did not</b> come to <b>rest.</b> Rather, it immediately and continuously flowed. If so, the lifting was not from the wall at all. The Gemara answers: <b>As Rava said</b> in another context that the case involves <b>an inclined wall, here too</b> the case involves <b>an inclined wall.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And where was</b> this statement of <b>Rava stated?</b> It was stated <b>with regard to that which we learned in a mishna:</b>

Daf 5b

One who <b>was reading</b> a sacred <b>book</b> in scroll form on Shabbat <b>on</b> an elevated, wide <b>threshold and the book rolled from his hand</b> outside and into the public domain, <b>he</b> may <b>roll it</b> back <b>to himself,</b> since one of its ends is still in his hand. However, if <b>he was reading on top the roof,</b> which is a full-fledged private domain, <b>and the book rolled from his hand, as long as</b> the edge of the book <b>did not reach ten handbreadths</b> above the public domain, the book is still in its own area, and he may <b>roll it</b> back <b>to himself.</b> However, <b>once the book has reached</b> within <b>ten handbreadths</b> above the public domain, he is prohibited to roll it back to himself. In that case, <b>he</b> may only <b>turn it</b> over <b>onto the</b> side with <b>writing,</b> so that the writing of the book should face down and should not be exposed and degraded. <b>And we discussed this</b> <i>halakha</i>: <b>Why</b> must he <b>turn it</b> over <b>onto the</b> side with <b>writing,</b> and he is prohibited to bring the book back to himself? <b>Didn’t</b> the book <b>not</b> yet <b>come to rest</b> upon a defined area in the public domain? Even if he brought it back it would not constitute lifting.
<b>And Rava said:</b> It is referring to the case <b>of an inclined wall.</b> Because it is inclined, the scroll is resting upon it to some degree. However, that answer is not effective in explaining the case of gathering water. <b>Say</b> that <b>Rava said</b> that the legal status of the slanted wall is different, specifically <b>with regard to a book, as it is wont to</b> come to <b>rest</b> upon an inclined wall. In contrast, <b>is water wont to</b> come to <b>rest</b> upon an inclined wall? It continues flowing. Consequently, the question with regard to water remains.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> Here, it is referring to <b>a case where he gathered</b> the rainwater <b>from on top of a hole</b> filled with water. The Gemara asks: If he gathered it from on top of <b>a hole, it is obvious</b> that it is considered like lifting from a significant place. The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that since the water that comes down from the roof into the hole it is <b>water on top of water</b> and, perhaps, <b>it is not</b> considered <b>placing.</b> Therefore, <b>he taught us</b> that collecting water from on top of a hole filled with water is considered an act of lifting an object from its placement.
The Gemara comments: <b>And Rava follows his</b> standard line of <b>reasoning,</b> as <b>Rava</b> already <b>said:</b> It is obvious to me that <b>water on top of water, that is its placement,</b> and lifting the water from there is an act of lifting in every sense. It is also obvious that if <b>a nut</b> is floating <b>on top of water, that is not</b> considered <b>its placement,</b> and therefore lifting it from there is not considered an act of lifting. However, <b>Rava raised a dilemma:</b> In a case where <b>a nut</b> is <b>in a vessel, and</b> that <b>vessel is floating on top of water,</b> and one lifted the nut from the vessel, is that considered an act of lifting? The sides of the dilemma are: Do <b>we go according to the nut</b> and the <i>halakha</i> is decided exclusively based on its status, <b>and it is at rest</b> in the vessel? <b>Or perhaps, we go according to the vessel and it is not at rest, as it is moving</b> from place to place on the surface of the water. This dilemma remained unresolved, and therefore <b>let it stand.</b>
A similar dilemma was raised with regard to <b>oil that was floating on top of wine.</b> Oil does not mix with wine. Rather, it floats on top of it in a separate layer. Resolution of this dilemma is dependent on <b>a dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri and the Rabbis.</b> Is oil considered a discrete entity placed on the wine? Or, perhaps it is considered to be connected to the wine? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Oil that was floating on top of wine and one who immersed himself during the day touched the oil, he disqualified only the oil alone</b> and not the wine, as he only touched the oil and the oil does not render the wine impure. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says: They both are</b> considered <b>connected to each other,</b> and therefore they are both rendered impure through the same contact. The consideration of whether the oil and the wine are considered connected is the determining factor with regard to the laws of Shabbat as well.
<b>Rabbi Avin said</b> that <b>Rabbi Elai said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> One who <b>was</b> standing in the private domain or the public domain <b>laden with food and drinks</b> on Shabbat, and his intention was to carry them to another corner of the same domain, if once he began walking he changed his mind and exited that domain, <b>and he enters and exits</b> from domain to domain, even if he does so <b>all day long, he is exempt</b> by Torah law for carrying out on Shabbat <b>until he stands</b> still. Moving the object is not considered carrying out, since he did not intend from the outset to move himself in order to carry out. Therefore, only after he stands still can it be considered a bona fide placement, and only when he subsequently moves and walks would he incur liability.
<b>Abaye</b> added and <b>said: And that is</b> specifically <b>if he stopped to rest;</b> then it is considered placement. However, if he stopped to adjust his burden, it is not considered placement. The Gemara comments: <b>From where</b> did Abaye arrive at this conclusion? <b>From</b> that which <b>the Master said</b> with regard to the laws of carrying in the public domain: Although, by Torah law, one who transfers an object four cubits in the public domain is liable, if while transferring the object <b>he stopped to rest within four cubits, he is exempt.</b> By stopping to rest, he performed an act of placement in the middle of the transfer. As a result, he did not carry the object four complete cubits. However, if he stopped <b>to</b> adjust the burden on his <b>shoulders, he is liable,</b> as stopping in order to adjust his burden is not considered an act of placement. It is considered an action required to facilitate the continued carrying of that burden. On the other hand, after he walked <b>beyond four cubits,</b> if <b>he stopped to rest,</b> he thereby performed an act of placement and completed the prohibited labor, and <b>he is liable;</b> if he stopped <b>to</b> adjust the burden on his <b>shoulders, he is exempt.</b> From this <i>halakha</i>, Abaye learned that only when one stops to rest is it considered an act of placement in terms of the prohibited labor of carrying on Shabbat.
With regard to the essence of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s <i>halakha</i> about entering and exiting all day long, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> principle <b>is he teaching us</b> with this <i>halakha</i>? Is it to teach that one is exempt from bringing a sin-offering for performing the prohibited labor of carrying out on Shabbat when <b>the lifting of the object</b> from its place <b>from the first moment was not for that</b> purpose of carrying out, but for another purpose? <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> already <b>say it once? As Rav Safra said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who transfers objects from corner to corner</b> in a private domain, <b>and,</b> while carrying them, <b>he changed his mind about them</b> and <b>took them out</b> to the public domain, <b>he is exempt because the lifting at the first moment was not for that</b> purpose of carrying out to another domain. Why, then, was it necessary to repeat the same <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>They are</b> different <b><i>amora’im</i></b> who transmitted this matter. One <b>Sage said it in this language and</b> one <b>Sage said it in that language.</b> They chose different <i>halakhot</i> to relate the principle that Rabbi Yoḥanan stated a single time.
Since the issue of interruptions in the performance of the prohibited labor of carrying out was mentioned above, the Gemara proceeds to discuss a more complex related issue. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who carries</b> an object <b>out from a store,</b> which is a private domain, <b>to a plaza [<i>pelatia</i>],</b> which is a public domain, <b>by way of a colonnade [<i>setav</i>],</b> which is situated between the store and the public domain and whose legal status is that of a <i>karmelit</i>, <b>is liable,</b> as he carried out from the private domain to the public domain. <b>And ben Azzai deems</b> him <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the opinions. <b>Granted,</b> the opinion of <b>ben Azzai</b> makes sense, as <b>he holds</b> that <b>walking is considered like standing.</b> In other words, with each step, he is considered as if he came to a complete stop. Therefore, as he walked through the colonnade, which is neither a public domain nor a private domain, he came to rest there. Consequently, he did not carry from a private domain to a public domain; he carried into and out of a <i>karmelit</i>. <b>However, the Rabbis, although they hold</b> that <b>walking is not considered like standing,</b> their opinion is difficult. <b>Where do we find a comparable case</b> where <b>one is liable?</b> There is no direct transfer from domain to domain. The transfer is via a domain where there is no Torah prohibition. Where do we find that the Torah deemed one who carried out in that manner liable?
<b>Rav Safra said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> That is not an exceptional case,

Daf 6a

as the <i>halakha</i> there is <b>just as</b> it is <b>in</b> the case of <b>one who transfers an object in the public domain. There, even though as long as he takes it and walks</b> and does not place the object <b>he is exempt, is it not</b> the case <b>that when he places it he is liable?</b> Obviously, between the place where he lifted the object and the place where he placed the object, where there is liability, there lies an undefined area where, as long as he continues walking, he is exempt. <b>Here too, it is no different,</b> as in both cases an identical situation exists: If he places the object at the end of his path he is liable, despite the fact that the area in the middle is an exempt place.
The Gemara rejects this comparison: <b>Is this comparable? There, anywhere that he places</b> the object <b>is a place of</b> potential <b>liability.</b> That cannot be described as two places of liability with an exempt domain between them, as the area between them is also a place of potential liability if he were to place the object there. On the other hand, <b>here, if he places it in the colonnade, it is an</b> absolute <b>exempt domain.</b>
Again the question arises: Where is there a precedent of liability for transferring an object through an exempt domain? The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> it is possible to cite a different precedent: The <i>halakha</i> here is <b>just as</b> it is <b>in</b> the case of <b>one who transfers an object</b> in the public domain <b>from the beginning of four</b> cubits <b>to the end of four</b> cubits exactly. <b>There, is it not</b> the case <b>that, even though were he to place it within four cubits</b> of where he stands<b>, he is not liable</b> because within four cubits, the complete prohibited labor of carrying in the public domain was not performed; and nevertheless, <b>when he places it at the end of four cubits he is liable? Here too, it is no different.</b> It can be said that there is a strip of exempt domain between the lifting and the placement.
Again the Gemara rejects the analogy: <b>Is that similar? There,</b> in the public domain, <b>for this man it is an exempt domain,</b> as it is within four cubits of the place that he lifted the object. However, <b>for the entire world, it is a place of</b> potential <b>liability,</b> as the space itself is a public domain and it could be beyond four cubits for someone else who placed it there, and he would be liable. <b>Here,</b> on the other hand, the colonnade <b>is an exempt domain for the entire world.</b> There is no comparison between an absence of liability that stems from the fact that the prohibited labor was not completed and an unconditional exemption dependent solely on the nature of the domain in question.
<b>Rather,</b> it is possible to cite a different precedent: The <i>halakha</i> here is <b>just as</b> it is <b>in</b> the case of <b>one who carries out</b> an object <b>from the private domain to the public domain through the sides of the public domain.</b> The sides of a public domain are narrow strips located adjacent to the houses where the multitudes do not congregate. <b>There, is it not the case that, even though if one were to place</b> an object <b>on the sides of the public domain, he is exempt and,</b> nevertheless, <b>when he places it in the public domain he is liable?</b> If so, <b>here too, it is no different.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa strongly objects</b> to this explanation: <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> that <b>the sides of the public domain are</b> a type of independent domain and <b>not considered the public domain,</b> that precedent is similar to our case. <b>However,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, who said that the sides of the public domain are considered a</b> full-fledged <b>public domain, what is there to say?</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Ika, said to him: Say</b> that <b>you heard that Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov said</b> that <b>the sides of the public domain are considered a public domain in a place where there are no stakes [<i>ḥipufei</i>]</b> separating the houses and the courtyards from the actual public domain to prevent the public from damaging the walls of the houses. <b>However, in a place where there are stakes, did you hear him</b> say that the legal status of the sides is that of the public domain itself? <b>Therefore, it is similar to that</b> case of the colonnade, and consequently it serves as a precedent for liability when carrying through an exempt domain.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Ben Azzai disagreed with regard to carrying out the object while walking through the colonnade. In his opinion one who carries it out is exempt. Yet, <b>he agrees</b> with the Rabbis that <b>in</b> a case where <b>one throws</b> an object from the private domain to the public domain through a colonnade he is liable, as it is tantamount to carrying out directly from domain to domain. <b>That</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who carries out</b> an object on Shabbat <b>from a store to a plaza via a colonnade is liable.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is identical with regard to all means of transferring an object from domain to domain via a colonnade. <b>The same is true for one who carries out, and one who carries in, and one who throws, and one who extends</b> his hand from domain to domain. <b>Ben Azzai says: One who</b> walks and <b>carries out and one who</b> walks and <b>carries in are exempt,</b> as he is considered to have come to rest in the colonnade. On the other hand, <b>one who extends</b> his hand with the object <b>and one who throws</b> the object, whose actions are uninterrupted, <b>are liable.</b>
In order to explain the essence of the laws of domains on Shabbat, the Gemara cites what <b>the Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>, that there are <b>four domains for the</b> <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat: The private domain, and the public domain, and</b> two additional domains: The <b><i>karmelit</i>,</b> which is like neither the public domain nor the private domain, <b>and an exempt domain,</b> which does not fall into the category of domains.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>And what is the private domain? A ditch which is ten</b> handbreadths <b>deep and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, as well as a fence which is ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide; that is a full-fledged private domain.</b> The criteria for a private domain are that it must be an area of four by four handbreadths, with a ten-handbreadth difference in elevation from the surrounding environment.
<b>And what is the public domain? A main street [<i>seratia</i>] and a large plaza as well as alleyways [<i>mevo’ot</i>], which are open</b> on both ends to the public domain, connecting between main streets; <b>that is a full-fledged public domain.</b> With regard to those domains: <b>One may not carry out from the private domain</b> of <b>this</b> kind <b>to the public domain</b> of <b>this</b> kind, <b>and one may not carry in from the public domain</b> of <b>this</b> kind <b>to the private domain</b> of <b>this</b> kind. If he did so <b>unwittingly, he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> If he did so <b>intentionally,</b> and there were no witnesses to his act, and he was not forewarned, <b>he is liable</b> to receive the punishment of <b>excision</b> [<b><i>karet</i></b>]. If he was forewarned and there were witnesses to his transgression, he is punished with the court-imposed capital punishment <b>and stoned.</b>
<b>However, a sea and a valley and a colonnade and the <i>karmelit</i></b> all enter into the general category of <i>karmelit</i>, which <b>is neither like the public domain,</b> because the multitudes are not congregated there, <b>nor like the private domain,</b> as it has no partitions. Rather, the Sages instituted that cases like these should be considered an independent domain. <b>One may not carry and place</b> an object <b>in it</b> beyond four cubits, just as it is prohibited to do so in the public domain. <b>And if he</b> nevertheless <b>carried and placed</b> an object <b>in it, he is exempt,</b> as it involves no Torah prohibition. <b>And one may neither carry from it into the public domain nor from the public domain into it,</b> as it is not the public domain. <b>And one may neither carry from the private domain into it nor from it into the private domain,</b> as it is not the private domain. <b>And if he carried out</b> from the private domain or <b>carried in</b> from the public domain, <b>he is exempt,</b> as it involves is no Torah prohibition.
Similarly, there is a type of private domain which, by rabbinic law, has the legal status of a <i>karmelit</i> or a public domain. <b>Courtyards</b> shared <b>by many and alleyways that are not open</b> on both sides are private domains that are somewhat similar to the public domain because many people congregate there. For this reason, the Sages issued a decree prohibiting carrying within them. However, if <b>they placed an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> i.e., a joining of courtyards, to transform a common courtyard into a single domain, or a merging of alleyways to merge a common alleyway shared by several courtyards into a single domain, <b>they are</b> all <b>permitted</b> to carry objects from their houses into the courtyard or from the courtyard into the alleyway, respectively. However, if <b>they did not place an <i>eiruv</i>, they are prohibited</b> to do so.
An example of the fourth domain listed in the <i>baraita,</i> the exempt domain is: <b>A person standing on the threshold may take</b> an object <b>from the homeowner</b> standing in the private domain <b>and may give</b> an object <b>to him.</b> Similarly, while standing there, <b>he may take</b> an object <b>from a poor person</b> standing in the public domain <b>and may give</b> an object <b>to him</b> because there is no element of prohibition or liability in carrying and carrying out in an exempt domain on Shabbat. There is no prohibition <b>as long as he does not take</b> the object <b>from the homeowner</b> in the private domain <b>and give it to a poor person</b> in the public domain, or <b>from a poor person and give to the homeowner,</b> as by doing so he facilitated transfer from domain to domain. <b>And,</b> however, <b>if he took</b> an object from one <b>and gave</b> it to the other, certainly no labor prohibited by Torah law was performed, and all <b>three of them are exempt.</b>
<b><i>Aḥerim</i> say:</b> Not every threshold is an exempt domain. Some are not sufficiently isolated from the surrounding domains. Sometimes, <b>a threshold serves as two domains;</b> at times the public domain and at times the private domain, as in different circumstances it is subsumed within the adjacent domain. Therefore, <b>when the doorway is open,</b> the threshold is an extension of the house and considered to be a private domain. <b>If the doorway was locked,</b> it is considered <b>like the outside,</b> like part of the public domain. This applies when the threshold is not an independent domain. <b>And if the threshold was ten</b> handbreadths <b>high</b> above the public domain <b>and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, it is a domain unto itself,</b> i.e., a full-fledged private domain discrete from the house.
