It was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i> with regard to the definition of a private domain that <b>the Master said,</b> with added emphasis: <b>This is the private domain.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> was this emphasis added <b>to exclude?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>To exclude this</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Furthermore, Rabbi Yehuda said: One who has two houses</b> opposite each other <b>on two sides of the public domain,</b> if he chooses, <b>he may</b> create a private domain for himself in the public domain. He may <b>place</b>

Daf 6b

<b>a</b> ten-handbreadth high <b>post from here,</b> perpendicular to the public domain. This creates a symbolic wall which, in the <i>halakhot</i> of alleyways, has the legal status of a wall. <b>And,</b> he may place <b>an</b> additional <b>post from here,</b> on the other side, and that has the same legal status as if he closed the public domain on all of its sides. <b>Or,</b> he can implement a different solution appropriate for alleyways by placing <b>a beam</b> extending <b>from here,</b> from one end of one house, to the end of the house opposite it. This creates a symbolic partition across the width of the street. <b>And,</b> he may place <b>a beam</b> extending <b>from here,</b> from the other side of the house. According to Rabbi Yehuda, in that way, one is permitted to <b>carry</b> objects <b>and place</b> them <b>in</b> the area <b>between</b> the symbolic partitions, as he would in a private domain. The Rabbis <b>said to him: One may not place an <i>eiruv</i> in the public domain in that</b> way. One who seeks to transform a public domain into a private domain must erect actual partitions.
The Gemara questions the language of the <i>Tosefta</i>: This is a full-fledged private domain. <b>And why did they call it full-fledged?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say: When do the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Yehuda</b> and say <b>that it is not the private domain? This applies only</b> with regard to the prohibition <b>to carry</b> there on Shabbat. By means of these partitions, it was not rendered a full-fledged private domain to the point that one is permitted to carry there. <b>However,</b> conceivably, with regard to the prohibition <b>of throwing</b> from the public domain to this place, the Rabbis <b>agree with</b> Rabbi Yehuda that the area between the partitions would be considered a private domain by Torah law and it would be prohibited. <b>Therefore,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> that according to the Rabbis it is not a private domain at all.
It was also taught in the <i>Tosefta</i> with regard to the definition of a public domain that <b>the Master said,</b> with added emphasis: <b>This is the public domain.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> was this emphasis added <b>to exclude?</b> The Gemara answers: Here, the <i>Tosefta</i> came <b>to exclude another</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. As we learned</b> in a mishna: The Sages permitted those ascending to Jerusalem on the Festival pilgrimage to place posts serving as symbolic boundaries around the wells, in order to render the wells and their surroundings a private domain. That way, the pilgrims could draw water from the wells even on Shabbat, as they became private domains. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If the path of the public domain</b> passes through the area of the wells and the posts and <b>obstructs them, he</b> must <b>divert it to the sides,</b> so that the passersby will not pass through there. In his opinion, many people passing through that area negates the private domain formed merely by means of symbolic boundaries. <b>And the Rabbis say: He need not</b> divert the path of the public domain. The emphasis in the <i>Tosefta</i>: This is the public domain, teaches that only the specific areas listed there fall into the category of a public domain; however, a well around which partitions were established is no longer in the realm of public domain, even if the multitudes continue to walk through that area.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why do they call it full-fledged?</b> The Gemara answers: This emphasis was unnecessary. But, <b>since he taught the first clause</b> of the <i>Tosefta</i> employing the term <b>full-fledged, he also taught the latter section</b> employing the term <b>full-fledged</b> in the interest of uniformity.
With regard to the places characterized as the public domain, the Gemara asks: <b>And include</b> the <b>desert</b> among the places considered a public domain? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is the public domain? A main street, and a large plaza, and open alleyways, and the desert? Abaye said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>here,</b> where it enumerated the desert among the public domains, it refers to <b>the time when Israel was dwelling in the desert,</b> and it was an area frequented by the multitudes. And <b>here,</b> where the desert was not enumerated among the public domains, refers to <b>this time,</b> when multitudes do not congregate there.
It was also taught in the <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>the Master said: If he carried out</b> an object on Shabbat from the private domain to the public domain or vice versa, if <b>he carried in,</b> if he did so <b>unwittingly, he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> If he did so <b>intentionally</b> and there were no witnesses to his act and he was not forewarned, <b>he is punishable</b> from the hand of Heaven with the punishment of <b><i>karet</i>.</b> If he was forewarned and there were witnesses to his transgression, he is punished by the court <b>and stoned.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Unwittingly, he is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering;</b> it <b>is obvious</b> that one who violates the serious transgression of desecrating the Shabbat unwittingly is liable to bring a sin-offering. The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary for</b> the <i>tanna</i> to teach that if he did so <b>intentionally</b> he <b>is punishable with <i>karet</i> and stoned.</b> Since he needed to cite those cases because they involve a novel element, he also cited the case where he performed the transgression unwittingly, in order to complete the picture.
The Gemara asks: <b>That is also obvious,</b> as the Torah states explicitly that one who desecrates Shabbat intentionally without witnesses and forewarning is punishable by <i>karet</i>, and that when there are witnesses and forewarning he is executed by stoning. The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> came <b>to teach us in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rav, as Rav said: I found a hidden scroll in the house of Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> in which matters of Oral Torah were briefly summarized, <b>and in it was written: Isi ben Yehuda says: The primary categories of prohibited labor</b> on Shabbat <b>are forty-less-one, and he is liable only for one.</b> This expression is unclear, and it would seem that it means that one who performs all of the prohibited labors is only liable to bring one sin-offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>The primary categories of prohibited labor are forty-less-one?</b> The mishna proceeded to enumerate those labors. <b>And we discussed it: Why do I need this tally</b> of forty-less-one? It would have been sufficient for the mishna to merely list the prohibited labors. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The number is also significant, in order to teach us <b>that if he performed all of</b> the prohibited labors <b>within one lapse of awareness,</b> during which he remained unaware of the prohibition involved, <b>he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for each and every one</b> of the prohibited labors separately. Consequently, the statement of Isi ben Yehuda cannot be understood as suggested above.
<b>Rather, say</b> as follows: There are forty prohibited labors less one, and <b>he is not liable for one of them.</b> Among those labors, there is one unspecified exception for which one is not liable to be executed by stoning and merely violates a negative prohibition. <b>That</b> which the <i>Tosefta</i> mentioned with regard to one carrying out on Shabbat being liable for <i>karet</i> and stoning, <b>teaches us: This</b> labor of carrying out from domain to domain, <b>is among those</b> prohibited labors with regard to <b>which there is no uncertainty</b> and it is clear that one is liable for <i>karet</i> and stoning for its violation.
It was also taught in the <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>the Master said: However, a sea, and a valley, and the colonnade, and the <i>karmelit</i></b> all enter into the general category of <i>karmelit</i>, which <b>is neither like the public domain nor like the private domain.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And is a valley neither like the private domain nor like the public domain? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna in tractate <i>Teharot</i>: <b>The valley, in the days of summer,</b> which is a time when the multitudes frequent it, nevertheless, it <b>is</b> considered <b>the private domain</b> with regard <b>to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat,</b> as according to the parameters of domains of Shabbat it remains in the realm of a private domain. <b>And,</b> still, it is considered like <b>the public domain</b> with regard <b>to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>ritual impurity,</b> where there is a distinction between a place frequented by the multitudes and a place that the multitudes do not frequent. While <b>in the rainy season,</b> the winter, when multitudes do not frequent the fields, the valley is considered like <b>the private domain for this,</b> Shabbat, <b>and for that,</b> ritual purity. A valley is a private domain and not a <i>karmelit</i>.
<b>Ulla said: Actually,</b> the valley <b>is a <i>karmelit</i>; and why does</b> the mishna <b>call it the private domain? In order</b> to emphasize that <b>it is not the public domain,</b> as the mishna in tractate <i>Teharot</i> did not enter into the details of the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat. It merely underscored the distinction between the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat and the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual purity.
Rav Ashi said:

Daf 7a

The valley discussed in the mishna in <i>Teharot</i> is unusual, as it refers to <b>a case where it has partitions</b> that are ten handbreadths high surrounding it. <b>And in accordance with that</b> which <b>Ulla said</b> that <b>Rav Yoḥanan said: An enclosure [<i>karpef</i>],</b> a large courtyard that is not contiguous with the house and does not serve a direct purpose for the house, that is <b>greater than</b> a field that produces a crop of <b>two <i>se’a</i>, that was not</b> originally <b>surrounded</b> by a fence <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>residence,</b> but with a partition to protect his belongings, <b>and even</b> if it is as large as a field that produces a crop of one <b><i>kor</i>,</b> thirty times the size of a <i>se’a</i>, <b>and even two <i>kor</i>,</b> it is still considered a private domain. <b>And,</b> consequently, <b>one who throws</b> an object <b>into it</b> from the public domain on Shabbat <b>is liable. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>It is a partition</b> that surrounds the enclosure and its legal status is like that of a partition in every sense, <b>except that it is lacking residents.</b> Even though the Rabbis were stringent with regard to this enclosure because of the lack of residents and prohibited carrying in it as if it were a <i>karmelit</i>, that does not negate its primary legal status; by Torah law it is a full-fledged private domain. The same is true with regard to the aforementioned valley. The valley is a large area surrounded by partitions erected for the purpose of protection and thereby assumes private domain status.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> in explanation of the mishna, <b>Rav Ashi did not say in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ulla,</b> as he provided a reason for it. <b>However, what is the reason that Ulla did not say in accordance with his</b> own <b><i>halakha</i></b> that he cited in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan? The Gemara answers: Ulla could have <b>said to you: If</b> the mishna is referring to a case where <b>it has partitions,</b> would it <b>call</b> that place <b>a valley? It is an enclosure.</b> The implication of the word valley is that there are no partitions at all. <b>And Rav Ashi</b> defends his opinion by saying: The language <b>taught</b> in the mishna is: <b>The private domain</b> and not a <i>karmelit</i>. Therefore, his explanation more closely approximates the language of the mishna.
In the <i>Tosefta,</i> the list of places whose legal status is that of a <i>karmelit</i> also includes <b><i>karmelit.</i></b> The Gemara asks: <b>Aren’t they, all</b> the other places listed there, i.e., a sea, a valley, and a colonnade, <b>a <i>karmelit</i> too?</b> If so, what is this <i>karmelit</i> that is prominently mentioned here? The Gemara answers: <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: This</b> addition of <i>karmelit</i> <b>was only necessary</b> in order to teach the case of <b>a corner adjacent to the public domain, where, although at times the multitudes push</b> their way <b>in and enter it, since its use is inconvenient it is considered a <i>karmelit</i>.</b>
Similarly, <b>when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Between the pillars</b> alongside the public domain <b>is judged like a <i>karmelit</i>. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Although the multitudes stride there, since they cannot walk</b> in it <b>in a direct manner,</b> uninterrupted, <b>it is considered like a <i>karmelit</i>. Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> The same is true for <b>the bench that is before the pillars</b> upon which the merchants place their wares; it <b>is judged</b> to be <b>like a <i>karmelit</i>.</b>
The Gemara comments: According <b>to the one who said</b> that <b>between the pillars</b> is considered like a <i>karmelit</i>, <b>all the more so a bench</b> is considered a <i>karmelit</i>. However, according <b>to the one who said</b> that <b>a bench</b> is a <i>karmelit</i>, one could say that that <b>is</b> so specifically with regard to <b>a bench</b> because <b>its use is inconvenient. However,</b> the space <b>between the pillars, whose use is convenient,</b> would <b>not</b> be considered a <i>karmelit</i>. <b>Another version</b> of that statement: <b>However, between the pillars where, at times, the multitudes stride there is considered like the public domain.</b>
With regard to the question to what degree does the use of the multitudes determine whether a specific place is considered a public domain, the Gemara cites the <i>halakha</i> that <b>Rabba bar Sheila said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> If <b>an upright brick</b> was placed <b>in the public domain and one threw</b> an object from a distance of four cubits <b>and he stuck</b> the object <b>to its side, he is liable</b> for throwing in the public domain. But if the object landed <b>atop</b> the brick, <b>he is not liable.</b> Because the multitudes do not step on the brick, it is not a full-fledged public domain.
It was <b>Abaye and Rava, who both said: And that is</b> specifically when that brick <b>is</b> at least <b>three</b> handbreadths <b>high,</b> as then <b>the multitudes do not step on it,</b> and, therefore, even though the brick is standing in the public domain, it is considered an independent domain. However, <b>thorns and shrubs, even though they are not three handbreadths high,</b> are not considered part of the public domain. Since people do not walk on thorns, those areas cannot be considered part of the public domain. <b>And Ḥiyya bar Rav said: Even</b> the place where there are <b>thorns and shrubs</b> in the public domain, if they were low, the place is considered part of the public domain. <b>However,</b> a place in the public domain where there are <b>feces</b> is <b>not</b> considered part of the public domain, as people do not walk there. <b>And Rav Ashi said: Even</b> a place in the public domain where there are <b>feces</b> is considered part of the public domain, since ultimately people who are rushing to work do not take care to avoid it and will step on it.
<b>Rabba from the school of Rav Sheila said: When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: There is no <i>karmelit</i> less than four</b> handbreadths. <b>And Rav Sheshet</b> added and <b>said: And</b> the <i>karmelit</i> <b>extends up to ten</b> handbreadths. With regard to the formulation of Rav Sheshet, the Gemara wondered: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>And extends up to ten? If you say that</b> it means <b>if there is a partition ten</b> handbreadths <b>high</b> surrounding it <b>then it is</b> considered <b>a <i>karmelit</i>, and if not, it is not</b> considered <b>a <i>karmelit</i>. And</b> is it <b>not</b> a <i>karmelit</i>? <b>Didn’t Rav Giddel say</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav said: A house that does not have</b> walls <b>inside it</b> that are <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high, and</b> with <b>its roofing it reaches</b> a height of <b>ten</b> handbreadths above the ground; <b>on its roof, one may carry on all of it,</b> as its roof is a private domain in every sense, <b>and inside it, one may only carry four cubits,</b> as inside, the height is insufficient to render it a private domain, and it retains <i>karmelit</i> status? Apparently, even an area less than ten handbreadths high has the legal status of a <i>karmelit</i>.
<b>Rather, what is</b> the meaning of Rav Sheshet’s formulation: <b>And extends up to ten?</b> Apparently, <b>up to ten</b> handbreadths <b>is that which is</b> within the parameters of <b>a <i>karmelit</i>, and above ten</b> handbreadths <b>is not a <i>karmelit</i>. And as Shmuel said to Rav Yehuda: Keen scholar [<i>shinnana</i>], do not be</b> involved with questions <b>in the matters of Shabbat above ten</b> handbreadths. The Gemara elaborates: With regard <b>to what <i>halakha</i></b> and in the context of what issue did Shmuel make this statement? <b>If you say</b> his intention was that <b>there is no private domain above ten</b> handbreadths, <b>didn’t Rav Ḥisda say:</b> One who <b>stuck a stick in the</b> ground of <b>the private domain and threw</b> an object from the public domain <b>and it landed atop it, even</b> if the stick was <b>a hundred cubits high, he is liable, since the private domain extends up to the sky?</b> Apparently, there is a private domain even above ten handbreadths.

Daf 7b

<b>Rather,</b> suggest that Shmuel meant that <b>there is no public domain above ten</b> handbreadths. <b>It is a mishna,</b> and why would he repeat an explicit mishna? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who throws</b> an object <b>four cubits</b> in the public domain, and the object came to rest <b>on a wall</b> standing in the public domain <b>above ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, it <b>is as if he were throwing</b> an object <b>in the air</b> and it never landed. If it came to rest <b>below ten handbreadths</b> off the ground, it <b>is as if he were throwing</b> an object <b>to the ground.</b> That is an explicit mishna stating that the area of the public domain does not go beyond ten handbreadths off the ground.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that Shmuel’s statement was referring to <b>a <i>karmelit</i>; there is no <i>karmelit</i> above ten handbreadths. And,</b> if so, <b>the Sages were lenient with regard to</b> a <i>karmelit</i> and applied <b>some leniencies of the private domain and some leniencies of the public domain.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Some leniencies of the private domain: That if there is an area of four</b> handbreadths, <b>then it is a <i>karmelit</i>, and if</b> there is <b>not</b> an area of four handbreadths, <b>it is merely an exempt domain. Some leniencies of the public domain: That until</b> a height of <b>ten handbreadths, it is a <i>karmelit,</i> above ten handbreadths is not a <i>karmelit</i>.</b>
<b>To</b> the matter <b>itself:</b> It was mentioned above that <b>Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav said: A house that does not have inside it</b> walls that are <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high, and</b> with <b>its roofing it reaches</b> a height of <b>ten</b> handbreadths above the ground; <b>on its roof, one may carry on all of it,</b> as its roof is a private domain in every sense, <b>and inside it, one may only carry four cubits,</b> as inside the height is insufficient to render it a private domain and it retains <i>karmelit</i> status.
With regard to this <i>halakha</i>, <b>Abaye said: And if he dug</b> out an area of <b>four by four</b> handbreadths <b>in</b> the floor of the house <b>and</b> in the place where the digging took place, its height to the ceiling <b>reaches ten</b> handbreadths, the house becomes a private domain, and <b>it is permitted to carry in the entire</b> house. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Since the dug out area is a private domain, the rest of the house is ancillary to it, <b>and it assumes the</b> legal <b>status of the holes of the private domain, and the holes of the private domain,</b> although they lack the measure of a private domain, <b>are considered like the private domain</b> itself. <b>As it was stated:</b> Everyone agrees that <b>the holes of the private domain are</b> considered <b>like the private domain;</b> since they are subsumed within the private domain, they are judged to be like it. However, they disagreed with regard to <b>the holes of the public domain. Abaye says: They are considered</b> to be <b>like the public domain. And Rava says: They are not considered</b> to be <b>like the public domain;</b> they are either a <i>karmelit</i> or an exempt domain.
<b>Rava said to Abaye: According to you, who said</b> that the <b>holes of the public domain are considered like the public domain, in what</b> way <b>is it different from this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>As when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: This</b> addition of <i>karmelit</i> to the <i>Tosefta</i> <b>was only necessary</b> to teach the case of <b>a corner adjacent to the public domain. And,</b> according to your opinion, <b>let</b> this corner <b>be like the holes of the public domain,</b> and its legal status should be that of a public domain itself and not that of a <i>karmelit</i>. Abaye answered: There is a distinction between the cases. <b>There,</b> the corner, <b>its use is not convenient; here,</b> the holes of the public domain, <b>their use is convenient.</b> Since it is convenient to utilize the holes of the public domain, and they are in fact utilized, they are a public domain in every sense.
The Gemara raised an additional difficulty for Abaye’s opinion: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna with regard to <b>one who throws</b> an object <b>four cubits</b> in the public domain, and the object came to rest <b>on a wall</b> standing in the public domain <b>above ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, it <b>is as if he were throwing</b> an object <b>in the air</b> and it never landed. If it came to rest <b>below ten handbreadths</b> off the ground, it <b>is as if he were throwing</b> an object <b>to the ground,</b> and he is liable. <b>And we discussed</b> this <i>halakha</i>: <b>What is</b> the reason that when the wall is not ten handbreadths high it is <b>as if he threw it to the ground?</b> The object <b>did not</b> come to <b>rest</b> on the wall, as presumably the object hit the wall and then fell to the ground. Since there was no act of placement, he did not perform the prohibited labor of carrying in the public domain.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>they learned</b> this mishna as referring to a case <b>when</b> he threw <b>a juicy cake of figs</b> that sticks to the wall and remains there. <b>And should it enter your mind</b> to say that <b>the holes of the public domain are considered like the public domain, why do I need to establish</b> the mishna as referring to the case <b>of a juicy cake of figs? Let us establish it</b> simply as referring to the case <b>of a</b> run-of-the-mill <b>stone or object, and</b> that it <b>came to rest in a hole.</b>
<b>Sometimes</b> Abaye <b>would answer</b> the question by saying that <b>a stone or object is different</b> from a juicy fig <b>in that they come back</b> when they are thrown and do not come to rest in the hole. Therefore, it was simpler to establish the mishna in the case of a fig. <b>And sometimes he would answer it</b> by saying that the mishna is referring to <b>a wall that has no hole. And from where</b> does he find support for this explanation? <b>From that which we learned in the first clause</b> of the mishna: <b>One who throws above ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, it <b>is as if he is throwing in the air</b> and it never landed. <b>And if it should enter your mind</b> to say that we are speaking here <b>about a wall that has a hole in it, why</b> should it be <b>as if he threw it in the air</b> and it never landed? <b>It rested in a hole,</b> and that hole is a private domain, as it is above ten handbreadths, and in that way the prohibited labor of carrying in was performed.
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>the mishna</b> is referring to a case <b>where</b> holes <b>do not have</b> an area of at least <b>four by four</b> handbreadths, which is common for holes in the wall, and therefore the holes have exempt domain status, <b>didn’t Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said: One who threw</b> an object <b>above ten handbreadths and</b> the object <b>went and came to rest in a hole of any size, we have arrived</b> in this matter <b>at the dispute between Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis?</b> The decision whether or not there is a prohibition here depends on an analysis of that dispute. <b>Rabbi Meir holds</b> that in all cases where a certain minimum area is required for a specific <i>halakha</i> to take effect and the existing area is smaller, if, theoretically, circumstances would allow to carve out and create an area of the requisite size, <b>one</b> considers it as if he <b>carves out</b> the space <b>to complete</b> it<b>,</b> i.e., the space has the legal status as if it was actually enlarged. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>one does not carve out</b> the space <b>to complete</b> it. Rather, the legal status of the area corresponds to its actual size. Consequently, according to Rabbi Meir, if an object landed in a small hole, one considers the area as if it were carved out to complete the hole to four by four handbreadths, and its legal status is like that of a private domain in every sense. <b>Rather, can we not conclude from</b> the mishna that maintains that one who throws an object onto a wall above ten handbreadths it is as if he threw it in the air, that it is referring to <b>a wall that has no hole in it,</b> and the possibility of carving out the space was never raised? The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it.</b>
The Gemara again returns to the <b>matter</b> that was mentioned above in passing <b>itself [<i>gufa</i>]. Rav Ḥisda said:</b> One who <b>stuck a stick in the</b> ground of <b>the private domain, and</b> an object that he himself threw from the public domain <b>rested atop it, even</b> if that stick was <b>a hundred cubits high, he is liable.</b> The reason for this is <b>because the private domain rises up to the sky.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that when <b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> his statement, it was <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. The <i>tanna’im</i> disagreed with regard to a similar issue, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One who <b>threw</b> an object on Shabbat in the public domain, <b>and</b> the object <b>rested on a projection of any size, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems him liable and the Rabbis deem him exempt. Consequently,</b> only according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is there no need for the object to come to rest on an area of a specific size, and therefore the statement of Rav Ḥisda with regard to the stick can only be in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s opinion.

Daf 8a

Regarding this assertion, <b>Abaye said: In the private domain, everyone agrees</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda,</b> i.e., that the private domain is considered one entity filled from the ground to the sky. <b>However, here</b> this <i>baraita</i> is referring to a special case involving <b>a tree standing in the private domain and its boughs lean into the public domain, and</b> one <b>threw</b> an object from the public domain <b>and it rested</b> upon <b>the boughs</b> of the tree. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>we say: Cast its boughs after its trunk.</b> The tree’s branches are considered an extension of its trunk, therefore the entire tree is considered a private domain, and one who throws onto it is liable. <b>And the</b> Rabbis <b>hold</b> that <b>we do not say: Cast its boughs after its trunk,</b> and therefore the boughs themselves are not considered to be a private domain, but rather an exempt domain, and one who throws atop them from the public domain is not liable.
<b>Abaye said: One who threw a round</b> reed <b>barrel into the public domain,</b> and the barrel is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and</b> its diameter <b>is not six</b> handbreadths <b>wide, is liable.</b> Since its diameter is less than six handbreadths, its area can fit the area of four handbreadths squared. Therefore, this barrel is considered an object, and if he threw it from the private domain to the public domain he is liable. However, if the diameter of the barrel was <b>six</b> handbreadths <b>wide, he is exempt.</b> Since the area of the barrel is greater than the area of four handbreadths squared, it is considered an independent private domain, and he did not perform an act of throwing an object from one domain to another domain.
<b>Rava said: Even if it was not six</b> handbreadths <b>wide he is exempt. What is the reason</b> for this? He is exempt because <b>it is impossible that the ends of the reeds</b> protruding from the weave of the barrel <b>will not extend above ten</b> handbreadths. Consequently, the entire barrel never entered the public domain, as part of it remains in a non-liable place, i.e., ten handbreadths off the ground of the public domain.
If <b>he turned</b> the barrel that is less than six handbreadths wide <b>over on its mouth,</b> i.e., if he threw it with its mouth facing down, even if the barrel was only <b>seven</b> handbreadths <b>and a bit</b> high, <b>he is</b> still <b>liable,</b> as the legal status of this barrel is equivalent to that of any other object that lands there. However, if the height of this barrel was <b>seven and a half</b> handbreadths, he is <b>exempt.</b> Within three handbreadths of the ground, the principle of <i>lavud</i> takes effect: An object within three handbreadths of the ground has the legal status of being connected to the ground. The sides of the barrel extend to the ground and then it is considered as if the barrel already touched the ground of the public domain, even though it is actually still three handbreadths away, while its upper part remains an exempt domain. It is as if this was a barrel higher than ten handbreadths.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Even</b> if the height of the barrel was <b>seven and a half</b> handbreadths, <b>he is liable,</b> as the sides of the barrel are not considered to be higher than they are in reality. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The reason is because <b>partitions are made</b> exclusively <b>for the inside</b> of the barrel. The sides of the barrel play no role beyond the barrel itself, and therefore there is no room to extend the sides by means of the principle of <i>lavud</i>. Therefore, if the barrel itself is not higher than ten handbreadths, it is merely an object.
<b>Ulla said: A pillar</b> that is <b>nine</b> handbreadths high, standing <b>in the public domain, and many</b> people adjust the burden on their <b>shoulders upon it, and one threw</b> an object from the private domain <b>and it rested atop</b> the pillar, <b>he is liable. What is the reason</b> for this? It is based on this principle: Anything protruding from the public domain: If it is <b>less than three</b> handbreadths off the ground, and the <b>multitudes step on it,</b> it is considered to be part of the ground. If it is <b>from three to nine</b> handbreadths, <b>they,</b> the multitudes, <b>neither step on it nor</b> adjust the burden on their <b>shoulders</b> on it, and it is not considered part of the public domain. However, a protrusion <b>nine</b> handbreadths high, <b>certainly</b> the multitudes adjust the burden on their <b>shoulders on it.</b> Since the multitudes utilize it, it is considered a public domain, despite its height.
Based on Ulla’s statement, <b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: A hole</b> in the ground of the public domain, which is several handbreadths deep, <b>what is</b> its legal status? Is it also considered, in accordance with Ulla’s principle, part of the public domain? In general, with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, there is no distinction between an area elevated above its surroundings and an area depressed below its surroundings. Rav Yosef <b>said to him: And the same</b> is true <b>in a hole;</b> these <i>halakhot</i> apply. <b>Rava said: In a hole,</b> these <i>halakhot</i> do <b>not</b> apply. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Since <b>use under duress is not considered use,</b> and the use of a pit even if it is nine handbreadths deep is inconvenient, and it is not comparable to a pillar of the same height.
<b>Rav Adda bar Mattana raised an objection to Rava’s</b> opinion from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One whose basket was placed in the public domain</b> and it was <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four wide, one may neither move</b> an object <b>from it to the public domain nor from the public domain to it,</b> since its legal status is that of a private domain. If it were <b>less than that</b> height, <b>one may carry</b> from it to the public domain and vice versa. The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>And the same</b> is true <b>for a hole. Is this</b> statement <b>not</b> referring <b>to the latter</b> clause of the <i>baraita</i>: One may carry from a pit which is less than ten handbreadths deep to the public domain? This supports the opinion of Rav Yosef, that a hole is subsumed within the public domain. Rava rejected this: This statement is <b>not</b> referring to the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i>, but rather <b>to the first</b> clause of the <i>baraita</i>: It is like a basket in that one may not carry from a hole ten handbreadths deep to the public domain because it is a full-fledged private domain. However, no conclusion may be drawn with regard to a hole less than ten handbreadths deep.
Rav Adda bar Mattana <b>raised</b> another <b>objection</b> to Rava’s opinion from what was taught in a different <i>baraita</i>, which deals with the laws of joining of borders:

Daf 8b

One who <b>intended to establish his Shabbat</b> abode <b>in the public domain</b> at a specific site must place food sufficient for two meals for that site to be considered his legal residence. <b>And</b> if <b>he placed</b> the food used for <b>his <i>eiruv</i> in a pit above ten handbreadths,</b> i.e., less than ten handbreadths below ground level, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> If he placed the <i>eiruv</i> <b>below ten handbreadths</b> from ground level<b>, his <i>eiruv</i> is not an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> Because the pit is a private domain and he may not carry the <i>eiruv</i> from that private domain to a public domain, where he has established his residence, the <i>eiruv</i> is invalid.
The Gemara seeks to clarify the details of this case. <b>What are the</b> exact <b>circumstances? If you say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to a pit that has ten</b> handbreadths in depth and the phrase: And he placed it <b>above</b> ten handbreadths, means <b>that he raised</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>and placed it</b> within ten handbreadths of ground level, and the phrase: <b>Below</b> ten handbreadths, means <b>that he lowered</b> the <i>eiruv</i> <b>and placed it</b> ten handbreadths or more below ground level, <b>what</b> difference does it make <b>to me</b> if the <i>eiruv</i> is <b>above</b> ten handbreadths <b>and what</b> difference does it make <b>to me</b> if it is <b>below</b> ten handbreadths? In any case, the pit is a private domain, and the principle states that the private domain extends from its lowest point to the sky. There is no difference whether the <i>eiruv</i> was placed higher or lower. In any case, <b>he is in one place,</b> in the public domain, <b>and his <i>eiruv</i> is in another place,</b> in the private domain. Since he cannot take the <i>eiruv</i> out of the pit, his <i>eiruv</i> is not an <i>eiruv</i>.
<b>Rather,</b> is the <i>baraita</i> <b>not</b> referring to a pit <b>that does not have in it</b> a depth of <b>ten</b> handbreadths? And the <i>baraita</i> should be understood as follows: If he placed his <i>eiruv</i> below ten handbreadths, refers to a pit whose lowest point is ten handbreadths or more below ground level. If he placed his <i>eiruv</i> above ten handbreadths, refers to a pit that is less than ten handbreadths deep and is not a private domain. <b>And,</b> with regard to that case<b>, it was taught</b> that <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is an <i>eiruv</i>. Consequently, usage under duress</b> in a pit that is less than ten handbreadths deep <b>is considered usage,</b> and a pit of that kind is a full-fledged part of the public domain.
Rava suggested various responses to this objection. <b>At times he would answer him</b> that it is referring to a case where both <b>he and his <i>eiruv</i> are in a <i>karmelit</i>,</b> i.e., that he intended to establish residence in a <i>karmelit</i> and placed his <i>eiruv</i> there. The pit is less than ten handbreadths deep, and consequently, both he and his <i>eiruv</i> are in the same domain. <b>And why does</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>call</b> his place of residence <b>the public domain? Because it is not the private domain.</b>
<b>And at times he would answer him</b> that it is referring to a case where <b>he was,</b> indeed, <b>in the public domain and his <i>eiruv</i> was in a <i>karmelit</i>,</b> as a pit that is not ten handbreadths deep is not part of the public domain, rather it is a <i>karmelit</i>. With regard to the question, how can this be considered a legitimate <i>eiruv</i> as it is forbidden to carry from a <i>karmelit</i> to a public domain as well, this <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi<b>, who said: Anything that</b> is prohibited on Shabbat and its prohibition is not by Torah law, rather it <b>is due to a rabbinic decree [<i>shevut</i>],</b> the Sages <b>did not issue the decree</b> to apply <b>during twilight,</b> which is neither definitive day nor definitive night. Consequently, at the time that the <i>eiruv</i> was placed in the <i>karmelit</i> it was permissible for him to carry it to the public domain. Since an <i>eiruv</i> takes effect even if it is fit for use just one moment during twilight on Shabbat eve, his <i>eiruv</i> is effective.
<b>And</b> Rava said to Rav Adda bar Mattana: <b>Do not say that I am just putting you off</b> with these answers. <b>Rather,</b> what <b>I am saying to you</b> is <b>accurate.</b> The opinion that usage under duress is not considered usage is a bona fide opinion and the suggested answers are appropriate explanations of that <i>baraita</i>. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>If there was a swamp and the public domain passes through it, one who throws</b> an object <b>into it</b> at a distance of <b>four cubits is liable</b> just like anyone who carried four cubits in the public domain. <b>And how</b> deep <b>is</b> this <b>swamp?</b> It is <b>less than ten handbreadths.</b> The mishna adds: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>a swamp that the public domain passes through it, one who throws four cubits into</b> the swamp <b>is liable.</b>
The difficulty concerning the repetition of the same topic with virtually identical words is clear, and therefore: <b>Granted,</b> it is possible to explain, that <b>swamp swamp was repeated twice; one</b> case <b>is</b> referring to <b>the summer, and one</b> case <b>is</b> referring to <b>the rainy season. And it is necessary</b> to emphasize that this ruling is in effect both in the summer and in the winter. <b>As, had</b> the mishna <b>told us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>in the summer,</b> we would have said that since <b>people commonly</b> pass through the swamp <b>to cool themselves,</b> it is considered part of the public domain. <b>However, in the rainy season I would have said</b> it is <b>not</b> part of the public domain. And conversely, <b>had</b> the mishna <b>told us</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>in the rainy season,</b> I would have said that <b>since he is filthy</b> anyway, <b>it happens that he</b> is not cautious and <b>enters</b> into the swamp. <b>However, in the summer,</b> when he is not dirty with mud, I would have said that it is <b>not</b> part of the public domain. Therefore, <b>it was necessary</b> for the mishna to repeat swamp twice, to teach us that this <i>halakha</i> applies at all times.
<b>However, why do I need</b> the mishna to state <b>twice</b> that the public domain <b>passes</b> through that swamp? <b>Rather, shouldn’t one conclude from this</b> that <b>passage</b>, even when it is <b>under duress,</b> and not free and easy, <b>is considered passage,</b> but <b>usage under duress is not considered usage?</b> It was necessary to emphasize that the public domain actually passes through it. If the multitudes do not pass through it and it was only used under duress, it would not have been considered a public domain. The Gemara concludes: Indeed <b>conclude from this.</b>
Somewhat related to the case of the barrel discussed earlier which was a case of moving an object without liability, the Gemara cites that <b>Rav Yehuda said: That bundle of reeds that he stood upright and threw down, stood upright and threw down repeatedly, he is not liable</b> for carrying it four cubits in the public domain <b>until he lifts it</b> off the ground. As long as he did not lift it from the ground, even though he moved it a long way, he did not perform the acts of lifting and placing which are prohibited by Torah law, as at least one part of the bundle always remained on the ground.
<b>The Master said: A person standing on the threshold may take</b> an object <b>from the homeowner</b> standing in the private domain <b>and may give</b> an object <b>to him.</b> Similarly, while standing there, <b>he may take</b> an object <b>from a poor person</b> standing in the public domain <b>and may give</b> an object <b>to him</b> because there is no element of prohibition or liability in carrying in and carrying out in an exempt domain on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>This threshold, what</b> is it; to what type of threshold is it referring? Different thresholds have different halakhic status.
<b>If you say</b> that it is referring to <b>a threshold</b> that is <b>the public domain,</b> i.e., the threshold of an alleyway that is fewer than three handbreadths off the ground and is not covered, and the post that demarcates the parameters of the alleyway is situated between the public domain and the alleyway, how can the <i>Tosefta</i> say that <b>he may take</b> an object <b>from the homeowner? Isn’t he carrying out from the private domain to the public domain?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> say that the <i>Tosefta</i> is referring to <b>a threshold</b> that is <b>the private domain,</b> in a case where it is covered, or it is situated between the post that demarcates the parameters of the alleyway and the private domain, or it is ten handbreadths high and its area is at least four by four handbreadths. How then can the <i>Tosefta</i> say that <b>he may take</b> an object <b>from a poor person? Isn’t he carrying in from the public domain to the private domain?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> say that the <i>Tosefta</i> is referring to <b>a threshold</b> that is a <b><i>karmelit</i>,</b> i.e., it is not ten handbreadths high and it is four by four handbreadths; how can the <i>Tosefta</i> say that <b>he may take and give</b> even <b><i>ab initio</i>? Ultimately,</b> in this case, <b>there is nevertheless a prohibition.</b> Even though a <i>karmelit</i> does not engender liability by Torah law, carrying from it is prohibited by rabbinic law and is certainly not permitted <i>ab initio</i>.
<b>Rather,</b> say that the <i>Tosefta</i> is referring to <b>a threshold</b> that is <b>merely an exempt domain,</b> and therefore there is no prohibition at all. In what circumstances is it an exempt domain? <b>In a case where it does not have</b> an area of <b>four by four</b> handbreadths, and it is therefore not considered a domain with regard to liability on Shabbat. <b>And</b> that <i>halakha</i> is <b>similar to that</b> statement made <b>when Rav Dimi</b> came from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia and he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A place that does not have</b> an area of <b>four by four handbreadths</b> and is set apart, <b>it is permissible for</b> both <b>the people of the private domain and for the people of the public domain to</b> adjust the burden on their <b>shoulders upon it</b> on Shabbat, <b>as long as they do not exchange</b> objects between them from one domain to the other domain.
<b>The Master</b> also <b>said</b> in the <i>Tosefta:</i> A person standing on the threshold may take an object from the homeowner and give an object to him, and he may take an object from the poor person or give an object to him, <b>as long as he does not take</b> the object <b>from the homeowner and give</b> it <b>to a poor person</b> or <b>from a poor person and give</b> it <b>to the homeowner. And,</b> however<b>, if he took</b> an object from one <b>and gave</b> it to the other, certainly no labor prohibited by Torah law was performed in that case, and all <b>three of them are exempt.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Say that this will be a conclusive refutation of Rava’s</b> opinion, <b>as Rava said: One who transfers an object from the beginning of four</b> cubits <b>to the end of four</b> cubits <b>in the public domain, even though he transferred it</b> above the upper boundary of the public domain

Daf 9a

<b>via</b> the airspace <b>above it,</b> i.e., he raised the object more than ten handbreadths above the ground of the public domain, which is an exempt domain, still <b>he is liable</b> for carrying in the public domain. On the other hand, in the <i>Tosefta</i> it says that if the object passed through an exempt domain, he is exempt by Torah law from punishment for passing it from domain to domain. The Gemara rejects that refutation as there is room to distinguish between the cases: <b>There,</b> in the <i>halakha</i> stated by Rava, the object <b>did not come to rest</b> in an exempt domain; it merely passed through its airspace. However, <b>here,</b> when transferred via the threshold, the object <b>came to rest</b> in an exempt domain, and as a result, the act of carrying out was divided into two separate actions, neither of which involves a Torah prohibition.
Later in the <i>Tosefta</i>, <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say:</b> Depending on the circumstances, <b>a threshold serves two domains: When the entrance is open,</b> the threshold is subsumed within the house and <b>it is</b> considered to be a private domain <b>like the inside</b> of the house. And when <b>the entrance is locked,</b> the threshold is not subsumed within the house, and <b>it is</b> considered to be a public domain <b>like the outside.</b>
The Gemara wonders: When the entrance is open the threshold is considered to be like a private domain, <b>and</b> is this so <b>even though it does not have a post</b> on its side? <b>Didn’t Rav Ḥama bar Gurya say</b> that <b>Rav said: The opening</b> in the wall, i.e., the doorway, <b>requires another post</b> in order <b>to permit</b> carrying there? A symbolic partition must be established at the side of the opening for that doorway to be considered closed and render carrying within it permissible like a full-fledged private domain. In the <i>Tosefta</i>, no mention was made of the need for a post of that kind.
<b>And if you say</b> that the <i>Tosefta</i> is referring to a threshold <b>that does not have</b> an area of <b>four by four</b> handbreadths, which is not considered an independent area and therefore does not require a post, <b>didn’t Rav Ḥama bar Gurya say</b> that <b>Rav said</b> explicitly: <b>The opening, even though it does not have</b> an area of <b>four by four</b> handbreadths, <b>requires another post</b> in order <b>to permit</b> carrying there?
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Here we are dealing with the threshold of an alleyway</b> open to the public domain on only one side. Although, by Torah law, it is considered a private domain, the Sages required him to establish a fourth symbolic partition on the side open to the public domain. This alleyway was covered, and this covering extended to part of the threshold in a manner that <b>half of it is covered and half of it is not covered, and the covering is</b> over the part of the threshold <b>toward the inside.</b> In that case, if <b>the entrance is open,</b> its legal status is <b>like</b> that of <b>the inside,</b> as it is considered as if there were a partition extending from the edge of the roofing above to below, based on the halakhic principle: Lower the partition. The opening of the alleyway is thereby sealed, rendering it a private domain. However, when <b>the entrance is locked,</b> it is no longer possible to consider the covering as a partition, and therefore the part of the threshold that is beyond the locked door of the alleyway <b>is</b> considered <b>like the outside,</b> i.e., like a public domain.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Actually,</b> we can say that <b>we are dealing with the threshold of a house, and</b> in a special circumstance, <b>a case where he covered</b> the threshold <b>with two beams.</b> Furthermore, <b>neither this</b> beam <b>is four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>nor is that</b> beam <b>four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>and there is not</b> a gap of <b>three</b> handbreadths <b>between this</b> one <b>and that</b> one<b>, and</b> there is a <b>door between</b> the two beams. In this case, when <b>the entrance is open,</b> since there is a space of less than three handbreadths between the beams and, based on the principle of <i>lavud</i>, any space less than three handbreadths is considered non-existent, the two beams are considered to be one wide beam. It is considered as if there were a partition extending from the edge of the roofing above to below, based on the halakhic principle: Lower the partition. The threshold is thereby sealed and considered a full-fledged private domain <b>like the inside.</b> However, when <b>the entrance is locked,</b> the two beams do not join together to become one anymore. Since the door creates a separation between them and the outer beam is less than four handbreadths wide, it is not considered a roof from which a partition extends to the ground, and the area under this beam <b>is</b> considered to be a public domain <b>like the outside.</b>
The Sage also said in the <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>if the threshold was ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> by four handbreadths <b>wide, it is an independent domain,</b> even if it was inside a private domain. The Gemara comments: <b>This supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi, as Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi said that Rabbi Meir used to say: Any place that you find two domains,</b> i.e., two places, each of which is sufficiently distinct to be an independent domain, <b>and</b> even though <b>they are</b> halakhically <b>one domain,</b> i.e., <b>in a case</b> where <b>a pillar</b> that is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> by four <b>wide</b> is standing <b>in the private domain,</b> even though the pillar is a private domain based on its measurements, <b>it is prohibited</b> by rabbinic law <b>to</b> adjust a burden on one’s <b>shoulders upon it</b> and to lift an object from the ground of the private domain and place it atop the pillar, as the pillar is deemed by its measurements to be an independent domain. It is prohibited by <b>a decree</b> issued by the Sages <b>due to a</b> similar situation, the case of a <b>mound</b> of that size <b>in the public domain.</b> In the public domain, lifting an object from the ground and placing it on the mound constitutes a violation of the Torah prohibition of carrying out from the public domain to the private domain. Therefore, the Sages prohibited placing an object on a pillar even in the private domain.

Daf 9b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> After having dealt with the limited and defined topic of the <i>halakhot</i> of carrying out on Shabbat, the mishna begins to deal with the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat chronologically, beginning with activities that one may not perform prior to the onset of Shabbat. With regard to one’s daily conduct, the mishna says: <b>A person may not sit before the barber adjacent to</b> the time of <b><i>minḥa</i> until he recites</b> the afternoon <b>prayer. And a person may not enter the bathhouse and may not</b> enter <b>to</b> work in <b>a tannery</b> [<b><i>burseki</i></b>]. <b>And</b> he may <b>neither</b> begin <b>to eat</b> a meal <b>nor to</b> sit in <b>judgment</b> until he prays. <b>And</b> however, <b>if they</b> already <b>began</b> engaging in those activities, <b>they need not stop</b> and recite the <i>Amida</i> prayer. The <i>tanna</i> articulated a principle: <b>One stops</b> engaging in all of these activities <b>to recite <i>Shema</i> and one does not stop to</b> recite the <i>Amida</i> <b>prayer.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> First, the Gemara seeks to clarify: <b>Which “adjacent to <i>minḥa</i>,”</b> in other words, adjacent to which <i>minḥa</i> is the mishna referring? There is a difference between the time of greater <i>minḥa</i> [<i>minḥa gedola</i>], which begins approximately a half hour after noon, and the time of lesser <i>minḥa</i> [<i>minḥa ketana</i>], which begins approximately two and a half hours before sunset. The Gemara elaborates: <b>If you say</b> that it is prohibited to perform all of these activities adjacent <b>to <i>minḥa gedola</i>, why not? Isn’t there</b> still <b>much time</b> remaining <b>in the day? Rather,</b> the mishna means <b>adjacent to <i>minḥa ketana</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: In that case, <b>if they started, they need not stop. Let us say that this will be a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: Once the time of the afternoon prayer has arrived, it is prohibited for a person to taste anything before he recites the afternoon prayer.</b> The implication is that even if one began to eat he must stop.
Rather, that explanation is rejected and the Gemara says: <b>Actually</b> the mishna is referring to <b>adjacent to <i>minḥa gedola</i>,</b> and the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi is dealing with adjacent to <i>minḥa ketana</i>. In response to the question: If the mishna means adjacent to <i>minḥa gedola</i> isn’t there significant time remaining in the day? The Gemara explains that each of the activities enumerated in the mishna is performed in an especially time-consuming manner. When the mishna said: A person may not sit before the barber, it was referring <b>to a haircut of ben Elasa,</b> whose haircut was very complicated and required several hours to complete. When the mishna said: A person may <b>not</b> go <b>into the bathhouse</b> adjacent to <i>minḥa</i>, it was referring <b>to all matters</b> involved in a visit to <b>the bathhouse;</b> not only washing, but also washing one’s hair, rinsing, and sweating. <b>And</b> he may <b>not</b> enter <b>the tannery</b> adjacent to <i>minḥa</i>, the reference is to <b>a large tannery</b> where there are many hides that require tanning and he must initiate the tanning process from the beginning. <b>And</b> he may <b>not</b> enter <b>to eat,</b> the reference is <b>to a big meal,</b> which lasts a long time. <b>And</b> he may <b>not</b> enter <b>to</b> sit in <b>judgment,</b> refers to a judge who enters at <b>the beginning of</b> the <b>trial,</b> and, generally, it will take a long time until a verdict is reached.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said:</b> Indeed the mishna can be explained as referring to <i>minḥa gedola</i> and <b>actually,</b> even <b>our</b> ordinary <b>haircut</b> is prohibited. <b><i>Ab initio</i>, why may he not sit</b> before the barber adjacent to the time of <i>minḥa</i>? Due to <b>a decree lest the scissors break,</b> and considerable time pass until they repair the scissors or obtain others. When the mishna said: A person may <b>not</b> enter <b>the bathhouse</b> adjacent to <i>minḥa</i>, it is prohibited even if he is entering <b>just to sweat. <i>Ab initio</i>, why</b> may he <b>not</b> enter? Due to <b>a decree</b> issued by the Sages <b>lest he faint</b> in the bathhouse and considerable time elapse until he recovers. <b>And</b> he may <b>not</b> enter <b>the tannery</b> adjacent to <i>minḥa</i>, even if he intends <b>just to examine</b> the skins. <b><i>Ab initio</i>, why</b> may he <b>not</b> enter? Due to the concern that <b>perhaps he will notice damage to his merchandise and become anxious</b> and come to restore what was ruined. <b>And</b> he may not enter <b>to eat a meal</b> adjacent to the time of <i>minḥa</i> is referring even <b>to a small meal. <i>Ab initio</i>, why</b> may he <b>not</b> enter? There is concern that <b>perhaps he will come to extend</b> his meal for a long time. <b>And</b> he may <b>not</b> enter <b>to</b> sit in <b>judgment</b> adjacent to the time of <i>minḥa</i>, the mishna is referring even <b>at the conclusion of</b> the <b>trial. <i>Ab initio</i>, why</b> may he <b>not</b> enter? Due to concern that <b>perhaps he will find a reason,</b> contrary to what he originally thought, <b>and will overturn the verdict</b> completely, necessitating the restart of the trial from the beginning.
We learned in the mishna that if he began one of the aforementioned activities, haircut, bath, tannery, meal, and judgment, he is not required to stop. The Gemara asked: <b>From when is</b> it considered <b>the beginning of the haircut? Rav Avin said: From when he places the barber’s wrap over his knees. And from when</b> is it considered <b>the beginning of the bath? Rav Avin said: From when</b> the one entering the bathhouse to bathe <b>removes his</b> outer <b>wrap,</b> his cloak. <b>And from when</b> is it considered <b>the beginning of</b> his visit to <b>the tannery? From when he ties</b> the leather apron <b>between his shoulders</b> (<i>Me’iri</i>). <b>And from when</b> is it considered <b>the beginning of eating? Rav said: From when he</b> ritually <b>washes his hands</b> for the meal. <b>And Rabbi Ḥanina said: From when he loosens his belt.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And they do not disagree.</b> Rather <b>this,</b> the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina, who said that the beginning of the meal is considered from when he loosens his belt, <b>is for us,</b> for the people of Babylonia, who are accustomed to close their belts tightly, and therefore the beginning of the meal is when one loosens his belt. <b>And that,</b> the statement of Rav, who said that the beginning of the meal is considered from when he ritually washes his hands, <b>is for them,</b> the people of Eretz Yisrael who did not close their belts tightly, and therefore only when one washes his hands does the meal begin.
Similarly, <b>Abaye said: Those Babylonian Torah scholars, according to the opinion of the one who said: The evening prayer is voluntary, once one</b> of them <b>loosens his belt, we do not impose upon him</b> to stop his meal and pray. And the Gemara wonders: <b>And according to the opinion of the one who said that the evening prayer is obligatory, we do impose upon him? Doesn’t everyone agree that the afternoon prayer is obligatory? And we learned in our mishna that if they started eating, they need not stop. And</b> with regard to that <i>halakha</i>, <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> The beginning of the meal is <b>from when he loosens his belt.</b>

Daf 10a

The Gemara responds that there is a difference between the cases. <b>There,</b> at the time of the afternoon prayer, <b>drunkenness is uncommon,</b> as it is unusual to drink excessively during the day. However, <b>here,</b> in the case of the evening prayer, <b>drunkenness is common,</b> and therefore there was room to issue a decree requiring one to interrupt his meal to recite the evening prayer. <b>Alternatively,</b> it is possible to explain that <b>with regard to the afternoon prayer, since its time is fixed, he is anxious, and he won’t come to be negligent</b> and forget to pray. However, with regard to the <b>evening prayer, since all night is the time for the evening prayer, he is not anxious, and he will come to be negligent. Rav Sheshet strongly objects to this: Is it a burden to tie his belt?</b> In addition, if it is a burden, <b>let him stand that way,</b> without a belt, <b>and pray.</b> The Gemara answers: It is necessary to wear a belt while praying, <b>since it is stated: “Prepare to greet your God, Israel”</b> (Amos 4:12). One must prepare and adorn himself when standing before God.
Since the verse: “Prepare to greet your God, Israel,” was cited with regard to the obligation to prepare and adorn oneself before prayer, the Gemara cites that indeed <b>Rava bar Rav Huna would don</b> expensive <b>socks and pray</b> and <b>he said</b> he would do this as it is written: <b>“Prepare to greet</b> your God, Israel.” On the other hand, <b>Rava</b> would not do so; rather, in his prayer <b>he would remove his cloak and clasp his hands and pray. He said</b> that he would do so <b>as a slave before his master,</b> who appears before him with extreme submission. <b>Rav Ashi said: I saw</b> that <b>Rav Kahana, when there is suffering in the world, would remove his cloak and clasp his hands and pray.</b> And <b>he said</b> that he did so <b>as a slave before his master. When there is peace in the world, he would dress, and cover himself, and wrap himself</b> in a significant garment, <b>and pray,</b> and <b>he said</b> that he did so in fulfillment of the verse: <b>“Prepare to greet your God, Israel.”</b>
Speaking of prayer, the Gemara relates that <b>Rava saw Rav Hamnuna, who was prolonging his prayer. He said</b> about him: <b>They abandon eternal life,</b> the study of Torah, <b>and engage in temporal life,</b> prayer, which includes requests for mundane needs. The Gemara explains: <b>And</b> Rav Hamnuna <b>held that the time</b> for <b>prayer is distinct and the time</b> for <b>Torah is distinct.</b> The time that one devotes to prayer is not at the expense of the time devoted to Torah study. Similarly, the Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya was sitting before Rabbi Zeira and they were engaged in</b> the study of <b><i>halakha</i>. The time for prayer</b> was approaching and <b>it was getting late and Rabbi Yirmeya was hurrying</b> to conclude the subject that they were studying in order to pray. <b>Rabbi Zeira read</b> this verse as applying <b>to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>“One who turns his ear from hearing Torah, his prayer is also an abomination”</b> (Proverbs 28:9).
We learned that if one enters to sit in judgment adjacent to <i>minḥa</i>, he need not interrupt the trial and pray. The Gemara clarifies: <b>From when is</b> it considered <b>the beginning of</b> a <b>trial? Rabbi Yirmeya and Rabbi Yona</b> disagreed. <b>One said</b> that it begins <b>from when the judges wrap themselves</b> in their prayer shawls, as judges were accustomed to do before sitting in judgment. <b>And one</b> of them <b>said</b> that the beginning of judgment is <b>from when the litigants begin</b> articulating their claims. The Gemara comments: <b>And they do not disagree.</b> Rather, <b>this</b> <i>amora</i>, who says that it is from when the litigants begin, refers to a case <b>where they were</b> already <b>engaged in</b> a previous <b>trial,</b> and the judges were already wrapped in their prayer shawls. <b>And that</b> <i>amora</i>, who says that it is from when the judges wrap themselves in their prayer shawls, refers to a case where <b>they were not engaged in</b> a previous <b>trial,</b> and, as a result, the trial begins when they wrap themselves in the prayer shawls.
Speaking of judgment, the Gemara relates that <b>Rav Ami and Rav Asi would sit and study between the pillars</b> beneath the study hall. <b>And each and every hour they would knock on the bolt of the door and say: If there is</b> someone <b>who</b> has a case that <b>requires judgment, let him enter and come</b> before us. The Gemara also relates that <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna would sit in judgment all day and their hearts would grow weak</b> from hunger. Therefore, <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Rav from Difti taught them</b> a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “And it was the next day and Moses sat to judge the people <b>and the people stood over Moses from the morning until the evening”</b> (Exodus 18:13). <b>Does it enter your mind that Moses would sit and judge all day long?</b> If so, <b>when was his Torah</b> study <b>accomplished? Rather,</b> surely the verse is coming <b>to tell you: Any judge who judges a true judgment truthfully, even if</b> he sits in judgment only <b>one hour, the verse ascribes to him as if he became a partner to the Holy One, Blessed be He, in the act of Creation,</b> as by means of a true judgment he upholds the world (<i>Me’iri</i>). This conclusion is derived by means of a verbal analogy [<i>gezera shava</i>]: <b>It is written here: “And the people stood over Moses from the morning until the evening.” And it is written there,</b> in the act of Creation: <b>“And it was evening and it was morning, one day”</b> (Genesis 1:5). The evening and part of the morning are considered a whole day. With regard to this issue as well, it is sufficient for the judges to sit in judgment for only part of the day and there is no need for them to starve themselves by sitting in judgment all day.
The Gemara questions further: <b>Until when do they sit in judgment?</b> What is the usual time that court adjourns? <b>Rav Sheshet said: Until mealtime,</b> noon. <b>Rav Ḥama said: What is the verse</b> that alludes to this? <b>As it is written: “Woe to you, land that your king is a lad and your ministers eat in the morning. Happy are you, land that your king is free and your ministers eat on time in strength and not in drunkenness”</b> (Ecclesiastes 10:16–17). He interprets the verse: The ministers in a proper country sit to eat only after they engaged <b>in the strength of Torah</b> and in judgment <b>and not in the drunkenness of wine.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Eating in <b>the first hour</b> of the morning is the time of <b>eating for <i>Ludim</i>,</b> who are members of a nation of cannibals, and they are ravenous and hurry to eat. <b>The second</b> hour is the time of <b>the eating of robbers.</b> Since they spend the night stealing, they eat early in the morning. <b>The third</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for heirs,</b> i.e., people who inherited a lot of money and do not work for their sustenance. Their only preoccupation in the early hours of the morning is eating. <b>The fourth</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for workers. The fifth</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for all people.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rav Pappa say that the fourth hour is mealtime for all people? Rather,</b> emend the statement and say: The <b>fourth</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for all people.</b> The <b>fifth</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for workers</b> who do not have time to eat beforehand. The <b>sixth</b> hour is the time of <b>eating for Torah scholars</b> as, until then, court is in session. The Gemara adds: One who eats <b>from then on</b> is <b>as</b> if he is <b>throwing a stone into a barrel,</b> meaning that by then it does not contribute to the body’s health. Abaye said: <b>We only said that</b> eating from the sixth hour on is not beneficial, <b>when he did not taste anything in the morning; however, if he tasted something in the morning, we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said: A person may,</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>recite his prayer in the bathhouse.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from what was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who enters the bathhouse,</b> in the first room, <b>a place where</b> all <b>people stand dressed,</b> it is like any other place and <b>reading</b> the Torah <b>and prayer</b> are permitted there, <b>and, needless to say,</b> in that room <b>greeting</b> [<b><i>shalom</i></b>] <b>others</b> is permitted. And he may <b>don phylacteries</b> there, <b>and, needless to say,</b> if he was already donning phylacteries <b>that</b> he need <b>not remove</b> them.
In the next room, <b>a place where people</b> dress and undress and they <b>stand</b> both <b>naked and dressed, greeting</b> others <b>is</b> permitted <b>there.</b> However, <b>reading</b> the Torah <b>and prayer are not</b> permitted <b>there. And</b> if one was already donning phylacteries there, <b>he need not remove</b> the <b>phylacteries.</b> However, <b>he may not don</b> phylacteries there <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>
In the innermost room, which is <b>a place where people stand naked, greeting</b> others <b>is not</b> permitted <b>there, and, needless to say, reading</b> the Torah <b>and prayer</b> are prohibited there. <b>And</b> if he is donning phylacteries there, <b>he</b> must <b>remove</b> the <b>phylacteries, and, needless to say, he may not don them</b> there <i>ab initio</i>. Apparently, the <i>Tosefta</i> contradicts the statement of Rav Adda bar Ahava as he was, no doubt, referring to the innermost room in the bathhouse, which alone is referred to simply as a bathhouse, and, according to him, one may pray there <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara answers: <b>When Rav Adda bar Ahava said</b> his <i>halakha</i>, he was referring <b>to</b> an empty <b>bathhouse in which there are no people.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina say:</b> With regard to <b>the bathhouse in which they said</b> that it is prohibited to pray, the prohibition exists <b>even though there are no people in it?</b> With regard to <b>the bathroom in which they said</b> that it is prohibited to pray, the prohibition exists <b>even though there are no feces in it.</b> Certainly, since the place serves a repugnant purpose, it is inappropriate to pray there at any time.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, when Rav Adda made</b> his statement, he was referring <b>to a new</b> bathhouse that had not yet been used for bathing. The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Ravina raise a dilemma</b> before Rav Adda with regard to this matter: A place that <b>one designated as a bathroom,</b> what is its legal status as far as praying there is concerned? Is <b>there designation</b> as a significant and determining factor in this case? Or, is <b>designation not a</b> halakhically significant <b>matter? And</b> the dilemma <b>was not resolved for him. Is the same not true with regard to the bathhouse?</b> Doesn’t the same dilemma exist there? The Gemara answers: <b>No, perhaps</b>

Daf 10b

<b>the bathroom is different, as it is disgusting.</b> Once a place is called a bathroom it is disgusting and no longer fit for prayer. However, until he actually bathes in a bathhouse it remains fit for prayer.
It was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>There is no greeting [<i>shalom</i>] others</b> permitted in the bathhouse. The Gemara comments that <b>this</b> statement <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Hamnuna in the name of Ulla, who said: It is forbidden for a person to greet [<i>shalom</i>] his friend in the bathhouse because</b> Shalom is one of the names of God, as <b>it is stated:</b> “And Gideon built there an altar for God <b>and he called Him Lord Shalom”</b> (Judges 6:24). Therefore, it is prohibited to utter the word <i>shalom</i> in a dishonorable place.
The Gemara asks: <b>But if so,</b> words connoting <b>faithfulness are also forbidden to say in the bathroom, as it is written “The faithful God</b> who keeps the covenant and the kindness” (Deuteronomy 7:9). <b>And if you say</b> that <b>it is</b> indeed <b>so,</b> that it is forbidden to use the language of faithfulness in the bathroom, <b>didn’t Rava bar Meḥasseya say</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said</b> that <b>Rav said: It is permitted to say faithfulness in the bathroom?</b> The Gemara answers: There is a difference between the terms: <b>There, the name</b> of God <b>itself is not called</b> in <b>that</b> way, <b>as we translate it</b> as <b>“the faithful God.”</b> However, <b>here, the name</b> of God <b>Himself is called Shalom, as it is written: “And he called Him Lord Shalom.”</b> It is not an adjective, but a holy name in and of itself.
Incidental to the halakhic statement in his name, the Gemara also cites another statement that <b>Rava bar Meḥasseya said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who gives a gift to another must inform him</b> that he is giving it to him. <b>As it is stated:</b> “Only keep My <i>Shabbatot</i> for it is a sign between Me and you for your generations <b>to know that I am God Who sanctifies you”</b> (Exodus 31:13). When the Holy One, Blessed be He, gave Shabbat to Israel, He told Moses to inform them about it. <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“For I am God Who sanctifies you,”</b> meaning that <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses: I have a good gift in My treasure house and Shabbat is its name, and I seek to give it to Israel. Go inform them</b> about it. <b>From here Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: One who gives</b> a gift of <b>bread to a child needs to inform his mother</b> that he gave it to him. The Gemara asks: <b>What does he do to</b> the child, so that his mother will know that he gave him a gift? <b>Abaye said: He should smear him with oil or place blue shadow around his eye</b> in an obvious manner. When the mother of the child notices and asks him about it, he will tell her that so-and-so gave him a piece of bread. The Gemara asks: <b>And now that we are concerned about witchcraft</b> involving oil or eye shadow, <b>what</b> should one who gives a gift do? <b>Rav Pappa said: He should smear him with</b> food of <b>the same type</b> that he gave him to eat.
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> itself, the Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rav Ḥama bar Ḥanina say: One who gives a gift to his friend need not inform him,</b> as God made Moses’ face glow, and nevertheless <b>it is stated</b> with regard to Moses: <b>“And Moses did not know that the skin of his face shone when He spoke with him”</b> (Exodus 34:29)? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. When</b> Rav Ḥama bar Ḥanina said that he need not inform him, he was referring to <b>a matter that is likely to be revealed. When</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said that he needs to inform him, he was referring to <b>a matter that is not likely to be revealed.</b> The Gemara asked: If so, <b>isn’t Shabbat likely to be revealed,</b> as it will be necessary to inform them of Shabbat together with the other mitzvot? Why was Moses asked to inform them about Shabbat separately? The Gemara answers: <b>The giving of its reward is not likely to be revealed,</b> and it was necessary to inform them about so extraordinary a gift.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Ḥisda would take in his hand two gifts of</b> the priesthood separated from <b>an ox. He said: Anyone who comes and tells me a new <i>halakha</i> in the name of Rav, I will give</b> these gifts <b>to him. Rava bar Meḥasseya said to him, Rav said as follows: One who gives a gift to his friend needs to inform him, as it stated: “To know that I am God Who sanctifies you.” He gave</b> the gift <b>to</b> Rava bar Meḥasseya. Rava bar Meḥasseya <b>said</b> to Rav Ḥisda: <b>Are the <i>halakhot</i> of Rav so beloved to you?</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: Yes.</b> Rava bar Meḥasseya <b>said to him, this is what Rav said: Fine wool is precious to those who wear it</b> (Rav Ya’akov Emden), meaning only a person who is used to delicate items can appreciate their quality. Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him</b> excitedly: <b>Did Rav say that? The latter</b> statement <b>is preferable to me more than the first. And if I were holding another</b> gift <b>I would give</b> it to <b>you.</b>
<b>And Rava bar Meḥasseya said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said</b> that <b>Rav said: A person should never distinguish</b> one of <b>his sons</b> from <b>among</b> the other <b>sons</b> by giving him preferential treatment. <b>As, due to the weight of two <i>sela</i> of fine wool [<i>meilat</i>] that Jacob gave to Joseph, beyond what</b> he gave <b>the rest of his sons,</b> in making him the striped coat, <b>his brothers became jealous of him and the matter unfolded and our forefathers descended to Egypt.</b>
<b>And Rava bar Meḥasseya said that Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said Rav said: A person should always seek and dwell in a city whose settling</b> took place in the <b>recent</b> past, meaning that it was recently established, <b>as due to the fact that its settling is recent its sins are few,</b> as its residents have not yet had the opportunity to commit many sins there. <b>As it is stated</b> that Lot said to the angel: <b>“Behold, here is this city that is close to run away to and it is small”</b> (Genesis 19:20). <b>What is</b> the meaning of the word <b>close? If you say: That it is close</b> in distance <b>and</b> truly <b>small,</b> why did he need to say that to the angel? <b>Didn’t they see it? Rather,</b> the meaning of the word close must be <b>because its settling was close,</b> that it had been recently settled, and therefore <b>its sins were few. Rabbi Avin said: What is the verse</b> that teaches us that Zoar was newer than the other cities? <b>As it is written: “I will escape there please [<i>na</i>]”</b> (Genesis 19:20); the <b>numerological value</b> of <b><i>nun alef</i></b>, the letters of the word <i>na</i>, is <b>fifty-one, while Sodom</b> was <b>fifty-two</b> years old. <b>And</b> Sodom’s <b>tranquil</b> period

Daf 11a

during which they committed their sins was altogether <b>twenty-six</b> years, as it is written: <b>“Twelve years they served Chedorlaomer and thirteen years they rebelled, and in the fourteenth year</b> Chedorlaomer came” (Genesis 14:4–5). The twelve years plus the fourteen years during which they were enslaved were not years of tranquility, leaving only twenty-six tranquil years when they were sinful.
<b>And Rava bar Meḥasseya said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said</b> that <b>Rav said</b>: <b>Any city whose roofs are higher than the synagogue</b> will <b>ultimately be destroyed</b> because of the contempt shown the synagogue. Allusion to this is from that <b>which is stated: “To uplift the house of our God and restore its ruins”</b> (Ezra 9:9).
