The Sages did not determine a measure for the water disqualifying a ritual bath <b>until two weavers came from the Dung Gate in Jerusalem and testified in the name of Shemaya and Avtalyon that three <i>log</i> of drawn water disqualify the ritual bath, and the Rabbis upheld their statement</b> against the opinions of the great Sages of Israel, Hillel and Shammai. The Gemara emphasized their occupation and the place that they lived to underscore that, despite the fact that their occupation was despised and their place was contemptible, there is no preferential treatment when it comes to Torah.
<b>And another</b> dispute between Hillel and Shammai is that <b>Shammai says: All women, their time is sufficient,</b> i.e., a woman who notices that she saw blood of menstruation but did not feel the flow beforehand, need not worry that perhaps the flow of blood began before she saw it, and it is sufficient if she assumes ritual impurity status beginning at that moment. <b>Hillel says: From examination to examination,</b> i.e., a woman who saw blood, if she does not know when the menstrual flow began, she is considered impure retroactive to the last time she examined herself and found herself to be ritually pure, <b>and even</b> if the examination took place <b>several days</b> earlier. Anything that she touched in the interim becomes ritually impure. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is <b>neither in accordance with the statement of this</b> one <b>nor in accordance with the statement of that</b> one; <b>rather,</b> the principle is: <b>A full day,</b> twenty-four hours, <b>reduces</b> the time <b>from examination to examination,</b> i.e., if her final self-examination took place a long time before, she need only concern herself with ritual impurity for the twenty-four hour period prior to noticing the blood. <b>And from examination to examination reduces</b> the time <b>from a full day,</b> i.e., if she examined herself in the course of the previous day and discovered no blood, she was certainly ritually pure prior to the examination.
The Gemara asks: <b>And are there no more</b> disputes between them? <b>Isn’t there</b> what we learned that <b>Hillel says</b> that it is permitted <b>to lay hands</b> on the heads of offerings sacrificed on a Festival, and one performs no prohibited labor and does not desecrate the Festival by doing so; <b>and Shammai says not to lay hands?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When Rav Huna said</b> his statement, he was referring to disputes <b>where there is no dispute</b> between the great <b>Sages</b> who predated them <b>concomitant with theirs.</b> The dispute with regard to laying hands on the Festival is ancient, and their predecessors, Sages dating back to the beginning of the era of the pairs, already disputed it.
The Gemara asks further: <b>Isn’t there</b> also the dispute with regard to <b>one who harvests</b> grapes in order to take them <b>to the press</b> and stomp them as to whether or not the liquid that seeps out of the grapes is considered as having seeped out willfully and renders the grapes susceptible to impurity? <b>Shammai says: It has become susceptible, and Hillel says: It has not become susceptible.</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>Except for that one, as there,</b> although they originally disagreed, ultimately <b>Hillel was silent</b> and did not respond <b>to Shammai</b> and ultimately accepted his opinion.
Earlier it was mentioned that <b>Yosei ben Yo’ezer of Tzereida and Yosei ben Yoḥanan of Jerusalem decreed impurity upon the land of the nations and upon glass vessels.</b> The Gemara asks: Was it these two Sages, who were among the first Sages in the era of the pairs, who issued these decrees? <b>Wasn’t it the</b> Sages who lived in the final <b>eighty years</b> of the Second Temple period who <b>issued</b> these <b>decrees?</b> As <b>Rav Kahana said: When Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, fell ill,</b> the Sages <b>sent to him: Rabbi, tell us two or three statements that you</b> once <b>told</b> us <b>in the name of your father.</b>
<b>He sent to them: This</b> is what my <b>father said: One hundred and eighty years before the Temple was destroyed, the evil kingdom</b> of Rome <b>invaded Israel. Eighty years before the Temple was destroyed, they decreed impurity on the land of the nations and on glass vessels. Forty years before the Temple was destroyed, the Sanhedrin was exiled</b> from the Chamber of Hewn Stones <b>and sat in the stores</b> on the Temple Mount. With regard to the last statement, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> are the <b>halakhic</b> ramifications of this statement? <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Avdimi said: To say that they no</b> longer <b>judged cases of fines.</b> The Gemara wonders: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> that they no longer judged <b>cases of fines?</b> Even several generations after the Temple was destroyed they continued to judge cases of fines in Eretz Yisrael. <b>Rather,</b> emend and <b>say: That they no longer judged capital cases.</b> The authority to impose the death penalty was stripped from the Sanhedrin, and therefore they willingly left the Chamber of Hewn Stone. Since the Sanhedrin no longer convenes in its designated place, the <i>halakha</i> is that it no longer has the authority to judge capital cases (<i>Tosafot</i>).
In any case, we learned that the Sages of the last eighty years before the destruction are the ones who decreed impurity on the land of the nations. <b>And if you say</b> that Yosei ben Yo’ezer and Yosei ben Yoḥanan <b>were also there during</b> those <b>eighty years, wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Hillel, and</b> his son <b>Shimon,</b> and his grandson <b>Gamliel, and</b> his great-grandson <b>Shimon filled their</b> position of <b><i>Nasi</i> before the House,</b> while the Temple was standing, for <b>a hundred years, while Yosei ben Yo’ezer of Tzereida and Yosei ben Yoḥanan were much earlier</b> than Hillel?

Daf 15b

<b>Rather,</b> this decree was issued in stages. First, Yosei ben Yo’ezer and Yosei ben Yoḥanan <b>came and issued a decree</b> that <i>teruma</i> that comes into contact with <b>a clump</b> of earth of the land of the nations is <b>to</b> be <b>burned</b>, <b>and</b> they decreed <b>nothing</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i> that enters into <b>the air</b> space of the land of the nations. <b>The Sages of</b> the final <b>eighty years</b> prior to the destruction of the Temple <b>came</b> and <b>issued a decree</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i> that enters into <b>the air</b> space of the land of the nations that its legal status is <b>in abeyance,</b> and it is not burned.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that there was one decree</b> issued immediately <b>to</b> subject <i>teruma</i> to <b>burning? Didn’t Ilfa say:</b> With regard to <b>hands,</b> from <b>the beginning their decree</b> was that <i>teruma</i> that comes into contact with them is <b>to be burned?</b> The Gemara infers from this that, with regard to <b>hands</b> alone, <b>the beginning</b> of <b>their decree was</b> to render <i>teruma</i> that came into contact with them impure <b>to</b> the point of <b>burning; however,</b> with regard to <b>other matters,</b> they did <b>not</b> immediately issue so severe a decree.
<b>Rather,</b> the stages of the decree were as follows: Yosei ben Yo’ezer and Yosei ben Yoḥanan <b>came</b> and <b>decreed</b> that any item that came into contact with <b>a clump</b> of earth is <b>to be in abeyance, and</b> they decreed <b>nothing</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i> that enters into <b>the air</b> space of the land of the nations. <b>The Sages of</b> the last <b>eighty years came</b> and were stringent by one more level; <b>they decreed</b> that <i>teruma</i> that came into contact with <b>a clump</b> of earth of the land of the nations is <b>to be burned, and,</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i> that enters into <b>the air</b> space of the land of the nations, its legal status is <b>in abeyance.</b>
The Gemara asked further: <b>And still</b> is the matter clear? Didn’t <b>the Sages</b> issue this <b>decree in Usha,</b> many years after the destruction of the Temple? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>For six</b> cases of <b>uncertain</b> impurity <b>one burns the <i>teruma</i></b> which came into contact with them:<br><b>For the uncertain</b> case <b>of <i>beit haperas</i>,</b> meaning <i>teruma</i> that entered a field where a grave was plowed and the location of the bones of the corpse is unknown, and it is uncertain whether or not the <i>teruma</i> became impure;<br><b>And for the uncertain</b> case <b>of earth that comes from the land of the nations,</b> whose impurity itself has the status of uncertain impurity. Therefore, <i>teruma</i> that came into contact with it also has the status of uncertain impurity;<br><b>And for the uncertain</b> case <b>of the clothes of an <i>am ha’aretz</i>.</b> Since an <i>am ha’aretz</i> is not careful with regard to purity, we are concerned lest a menstruating woman touch his clothes. Due to that uncertainty, his clothes are considered impure with a severe degree of impurity. If <i>teruma</i> came into contact with them there is uncertainty with regard to whether or not they became impure; <br><b>And for the uncertain</b> case <b>of vessels</b> that are not his <b>that are found.</b> Since he does not know whether or not those vessels are impure, if <i>teruma</i> came into contact with them, there is uncertainty whether or not they are impure;<br><b>And for the uncertain</b> case <b>of spittle,</b> as perhaps it is the spittle of a <i>zav</i> and transmits impurity by Torah law. If <i>teruma</i> came into contact with it there is uncertainty whether or not it is impure;<br><b>And for the uncertain</b> case <b>of a person’s urine,</b> even though it was <b>adjacent to the urine of an animal,</b> there is room for concern that perhaps it is the urine of a <i>zav</i>, and impure by Torah law. If <i>teruma</i> came into contact with it, there is uncertainty whether or not it is impure.<br>In all of these cases, the Sages established that <b>for their definite contact,</b> when it is clear that these came into contact with <i>teruma</i>, <b>and although</b> there is <b>uncertainty with regard to their</b> essential <b>impurity,</b> i.e., it is uncertain whether or not these items are impure, <b>one burns the <i>teruma</i></b> that came into contact with them.
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: Even in a</b> case of <b>uncertain contact;</b> if it was <b>in the private domain one burns</b> <i>teruma</i> that came into contact with it, as with regard to impurity by Torah law an uncertainty that developed in a private domain is also ruled impure. According to Rabbi Yosei, these decrees, even though they are fundamentally cases of uncertainty, are sufficiently stringent that the Sages applied Torah law to them. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> Since these cases are only impure by rabbinic decree, in a case of uncertain contact <b>in the private domain, one</b> does not burn the <i>teruma</i> but rather <b>places</b> it <b>in abeyance.</b> While <b>in the public domain, they are ritually pure.</b>
<b>And Ulla said</b> with regard to <b>these six uncertain</b> cases: <b>In Usha</b> they instituted how one must act in terms of practical <i>halakha</i>. If so, a clump of earth from the land of the nations transmits impurity from the time of the Usha ordinances and not from eighty years prior to the destruction of the Temple. Rather, Yosei ben Yo’ezer and Yosei ben Yoḥanan <b>came and decreed</b> that if <i>teruma</i> came into contact with <b>a clump</b> of earth from the land of the nations, its legal status is <b>in abeyance</b> and one does not burn it, <b>and upon</b> <i>teruma</i> that entered the <b>air</b> space of the land of the nations they decreed <b>nothing. And the Sages of</b> the last <b>eighty years</b> of the Temple <b>came</b> along and <b>issued a decree upon this,</b> earth, <b>and upon that,</b> air, that in both cases the <i>teruma</i> <b>is in abeyance. And</b> the Sages of the city of <b>Usha came</b> along and <b>decreed</b> that <i>teruma</i> that came into contact with <b>a clump</b> of earth from the land of the nations is <b>burned. And</b> <i>teruma</i> that entered the <b>air</b> space of the land of the nations, <b>as it stood, it</b> continues to <b>stand</b> in abeyance. They did not impose any greater stringency in this matter.
One of the matters mentioned above was the decree of impurity on glass vessels. With regard to <b>glass vessels, what is the reason that the Sages decreed impurity upon them? Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>Reish Lakish said: Since the beginning of the manufacture</b> of glass vessels <b>is from sand, the Sages equated them to earthenware vessels.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But if</b> what you say is <b>so,</b> if the Sages truly equated the impurity of glass vessels to the impurity of earthenware vessels, <b>there should not be purification in the ritual bath for</b> glass vessels, just as there is no purification for earthenware vessels. <b>Why,</b> then, <b>did we learn</b> in a mishna with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of immersing vessels: <b>And these</b> materials <b>interpose in vessels,</b> i.e., if they were stuck to the vessel when it was immersed the vessel is not purified: <b>The pitch and the myrrh</b> that were stuck <b>on glass vessels</b> obstruct their immersion. Apparently, glass vessels are purified in a ritual bath.
The Gemara answers that glass cannot usually be purified in a ritual bath. However, <b>with what are we dealing here? With</b> a special <b>case where</b> the glass vessels <b>were perforated and he dripped</b> molten <b>lead into them</b> to seal the hole. This <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: Everything follows</b> the nature of <b>the facilitator,</b> i.e., if an object that is not fit for use on its own is reinforced with a different material that facilitates its use, the entire object assumes the legal status of that material. Therefore, since the substance that sealed the holes in these glass vessels is lead, which can be purified through immersion like other metals, these glass vessels can also be purified in a ritual bath. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Glass vessels that were perforated and one dripped lead into them; Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir deems them ritually impure and the Rabbis deem them ritually pure.</b>
The Gemara asks further: <b>But if</b> that is <b>so,</b> and glass vessels are equated with earthenware vessels,

Daf 16a

<b>they should not become impure from their outer</b> side. <b>Why,</b> then, <b>did we learn</b> this in a mishna? With regard to <b>earthenware vessels and vessels made from natron</b> [<b><i>neter</i></b>], the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>their impurity are equal</b> in that <b>they become impure</b> if a primary source of impurity enters their airspace, <b>and,</b> once impure, <b>they render</b> food that enters their airspace <b>impure from their air</b> space. <b>And they become impure from behind,</b> i.e., if a primary source of impurity enters into the bottom of the vessel, where there is an empty space and a receptacle, the vessel becomes impure. However, earthenware vessels <b>do not become impure from their outer</b> side, i.e., if a primary source of impurity came into contact with the outer side of the vessel, the inside of the vessel does not become impure. <b>And the breaking</b> of earthenware vessels <b>renders them pure.</b> By inference, specifically <b>natron vessels and earthenware vessels are those whose</b> <i>halakhot</i> of <b>impurity are equal,</b> as is their status. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>other matters</b> that is <b>not</b> the case. Why, then, were glass vessels not listed together with those vessels? The Gemara answers: <b>Since if</b> the glass vessels <b>broke they have</b> the capacity to be <b>repaired,</b> as the glass can be liquefied and recast into a new vessel, the Sages <b>equated them to metal vessels</b> that can also be liquefied and recast.
The Gemara asks: <b>But if so,</b> if glass vessels were truly equated with metal vessels, then broken glass vessels that were liquefied and recast <b>should reassume their previous impurity, like metal vessels. As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Metal vessels,</b> both <b>their flat</b> vessels, which have no airspace, <b>and their receptacles,</b> which have airspace, <b>are</b> all <b>impure</b> if they came into contact with a primary source of ritual impurity. If <b>they broke, they</b> thereby <b>became purified.</b> However, if <b>one remade</b> the broken vessels into new <b>vessels, they reassume their previous impurity. While, with regard to glass vessels, we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Wooden vessels and leather vessels and bone vessels and glass vessels, their flat</b> vessels <b>are pure</b> when they come into contact with impurity, <b>and</b> only <b>their receptacles are impure.</b> If <b>they broke, they</b> thereby <b>became purified.</b> However, if <b>he remade</b> the broken vessels into new <b>vessels, they</b> can <b>become impure from that point,</b> when they were recast, <b>forward.</b> By inference: <b>From that point forward, yes,</b> they become impure; <b>retroactively, no,</b> they do not reassume their previous impurity. Apparently, there is no <i>halakha</i> of previous impurity as far as glass vessels are concerned.
The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> entire <b>impurity of glass vessels is</b> by <b>rabbinic decree, and previous impurity,</b> which takes effect on recast metal vessels, <b>is by rabbinic decree. With regard to impurity by Torah law, the</b> Sages <b>imposed</b> a decree of previous <b>impurity. With regard to impurity by rabbinic law, the</b> Sages <b>did not impose</b> a decree of previous <b>impurity.</b> The Sages did not impose the decree of previous impurity, which is by rabbinic decree, on glass vessels whose fundamental impurity is itself only by rabbinic decree.
The Gemara asks further: <b>Their flat</b> vessels <b>should in any case become impure.</b> Since the impurity of <b>flat metal vessels is by Torah law,</b> isn’t it appropriate, therefore, to decree this impurity on flat glass vessels by rabbinic decree? The Gemara answers: <b>The Sages made a distinction with regard to</b> glass vessels, <b>in order to prevent burning <i>teruma</i> and consecrated items for</b> coming into contact with <b>them.</b> Through this distinction between glass vessels and metal vessels, everyone will understand that the impurity of glass vessels is not by Torah law. They will not come to burn <i>teruma</i> and consecrated items that came into contact with impure glass vessels; rather, their legal status will remain in abeyance.

Daf 16b

<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> There was never a need to equate glass vessels and metal vessels. <b>Actually,</b> glass vessels are <b>likened to earthenware vessels</b> in every sense. <b>And</b> that <b>which was difficult for you, that</b> if so, glass vessels, like other earthenware vessels, <b>should not become impure from</b> contact of <b>their outer side</b> with a source of ritual impurity; <b>since</b> in glass vessels <b>its inner side looks like its outer side,</b> the legal status of the outer side was equated with that of the inner side, as there is no visible separation between them.
We learned that <b>Shimon ben Shataḥ instituted</b> the formula of the <b>marriage contract for a woman and decreed impurity upon metal vessels.</b> The Gemara asks: Aren’t <b>metal vessels</b> impure <b>by Torah law, as it is written: “But the gold, and silver,</b> and the bronze, and the iron, and the tin, and the lead. Anything that came in fire, make it pass through fire and it will be pure, but with the water of sprinkling it will be purified and anything that did not come in fire make it pass through water” (Numbers 31:22–23)? The Gemara answers: This ordinance of Shimon ben Shataḥ with regard to the impurity of metal vessels in general <b>was only needed with regard to previous impurity</b> reassumed by metal vessels after they are recast. <b>As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving</b> Shimon ben Shataḥ’s sister, <b>Shel Tziyyon the queen, who made a wedding feast for her son. All of her vessels became impure, and she broke them and gave them to the smith, and he welded</b> the broken vessels together <b>and made new vessels. And the Sages said:</b> What she did was ineffective, as all the vessels <b>will reassume their previous impurity.</b>
With regard to the essence of the matter, the Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that they imposed a decree of previous impurity on metal vessels? The Gemara answers: <b>Due to a fence</b> constructed to maintain the integrity of <b>the water of a purification offering,</b> the Sages <b>touched</b> upon <b>it.</b> In order to purify a vessel that came into contact with a corpse, one is required to have the water of a purification offering sprinkled on the vessel on the third day and the seventh day after it became impure, as it is written: “He should be purified with it on the third day and on the seventh day he will become pure, and if he is not purified with it on the third day and on the seventh day he will not become pure” (Numbers 19:20). This involves a significant inconvenience. If people will prefer to break or damage impure metal vessels in order to purify them more easily, the use of water of a purification offering will become obsolete. As a result, the Sages decreed that metal vessels will remain impure until they undergo the purification process.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to the one who said</b> that <b>they did not say</b> the decree of previous impurity on metal vessels <b>with regard to all</b> forms of <b>impurity; rather, they only said</b> the decree <b>with regard to the impurity</b> caused by contact with a <b>corpse,</b> it works out <b>well.</b> In the case of impurity caused by contact with a corpse, the Sages issued this decree because its purification process is demanding. It requires immersion and sprinkling of the water of a purification offering on the third and the seventh days. However, with regard to other forms of impurity, whose purification is accomplished by means of immersion alone, a person will not break a vessel in order to avoid immersion. Consequently, there is no need to institute a decree in those cases.
<b>However,</b> according <b>to the one who said</b> that <b>they said</b> the decree of previous impurity in metal vessels <b>with regard to all</b> forms of <b>impurity,</b> which includes those forms of impurity that do not require sprinkling of the water of a purification offering for their purification, <b>what is there to say</b> as a rationale for the decree? <b>Abaye said:</b> Shimon ben Shataḥ instituted <b>a decree</b> due to the concern <b>that perhaps he would not perforate</b> that vessel with a hole large <b>enough to</b> render <b>it ritually pure.</b> To purify a vessel by breaking it, one must make a hole large enough to ensure that the vessel will no longer be able to hold the contents that it was designed to hold. Abaye explained that Shimon ben Shataḥ’s concern was that one who values the vessel will not break it sufficiently to render it ritually pure.
<b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>a decree lest they say</b> that <b>immersion on the</b> same <b>day is sufficient for</b> this vessel to be purified. People will be unaware of the manner in which the metal vessel became pure, and they will assume that its purity was achieved by means of immersion and not by means of breaking. That will lead them to the conclusion that any vessel becomes pure immediately upon immersion, and there is no need to wait for sunset, contrary to Torah law. Therefore, the Sages decreed that repaired vessels retain previous impurity. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> the reasons of Abaye and Rava? The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> difference <b>between them is</b> found in a case <b>where he broke</b> the vessel <b>completely.</b> If there was concern that perhaps he will not perforate it sufficiently, there is no longer room for concern. However, if there was concern lest people say that immersion is effective on that day, there remains room for concern.
To this point, several, but not all, of the eighteen decrees were enumerated. The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the other</b> decree? The Gemara answers: <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna in tractate <i>Mikvaot</i>: <b>One who places vessels under the</b> drain <b>pipe</b> in order <b>to collect rainwater,</b> the water collected in the vessels is considered drawn water. This is true <b>both</b> in the case of <b>large vessels</b> which, due to their size, do not become impure, <b>and</b> in the case of <b>small vessels. And even</b> if they were <b>stone vessels and earth vessels and dung vessels,</b> made from dry cattle dung, which are not considered vessels in terms of ritual impurity and do not become impure at all, this ruling applies. The water in the vessels is considered drawn water in all respects. If it leaked from those vessels and flowed into a ritual bath that had not yet reached its full measure, forty <i>se’a</i>, and filled it, <b>the</b> water <b>invalidates the ritual bath.</b> The Gemara adds that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>both</b> in a case where <b>one places</b> the vessels beneath the drainpipe with premeditated intent to collect the water flowing through it <b>as well as</b> in a case where <b>one forgets</b> the vessels there and they are filled unintentionally; this is <b>the statement of Beit Shammai. And Beit Hillel deem</b> the ritual bath <b>pure,</b> i.e., fit to complete the full measure of the ritual bath, <b>in</b> a case where <b>one forgets</b> the vessels. <b>Rabbi Meir said: They were counted</b> in the attic of Ḥananya ben Ḥizkiya <b>and Beit Shammai outnumbered Beit Hillel. And</b> Rabbi Meir said that <b>Beit Shammai agree</b> with Beit Hillel that <b>in</b> a case where <b>one forgets</b> vessels <b>in the courtyard</b> and they fill with rainwater, the water is <b>pure. Rabbi Yosei said: The dispute still remains in place,</b> and Beit Shammai did not agree with Beit Hillel at all.
<b>Rav Mesharshiya said:</b> The Sages <b>of the school of Rav say: Everyone agrees that if he placed</b> the vessels in the courtyard <b>at the time of the massing of the clouds,</b> a sign that it is about to rain, just before it began to rain, then the water in the vessels <b>is impure,</b> unfit, as he certainly intended that the water fill the vessels. If one placed the vessels <b>at the time of the dispersal of the clouds,</b> and then the clouds massed together, and then rain fell and the vessels filled with the rainwater, <b>everyone agrees</b> that the water <b>is pure.</b> It is fit to fill the ritual bath to its capacity because at the time that he placed the vessels under the drainpipe his intention was not that they fill with rainwater. <b>They only disagreed</b> in a case where he <b>placed them at the time of the massing of the clouds, and</b> the clouds <b>dispersed,</b> and rain did not fall then, <b>and</b> only later the clouds <b>massed again,</b> and rain fell and filled the vessels. In that case, this <b>Sage,</b> Beit Hillel, <b>holds</b> that because the clouds dispersed after he placed the vessels, <b>his thought</b> to fill the vessels with water <b>was negated.</b> The vessels remained in the courtyard due to his forgetfulness, and when they filled afterward it was not his intention that they fill. <b>And</b> this <b>Sage,</b> Beit Shammai, <b>holds</b> that <b>his thought was not negated,</b> as his original intention was ultimately fulfilled despite the delay in its fulfillment.
The Gemara wonders: Indeed, according to Rabbi Meir, another decree was added to the total. However, according <b>to Rabbi Yosei, who said</b> that in this case <b>the dispute still remains in place,</b> the tally of eighteen decrees <b>is lacking. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The decree that the <b>daughters of</b> the <b>Samaritans</b> [<b><i>kutim</i>] are</b> considered to already have the status of <b>menstruating women from their cradle,</b> their birth, <b>they issued on that day.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that any female who sees blood of menstruation is impure, regardless of her age, even if she is a day old. The Samaritans did not accept that <i>halakha</i>. Consequently, it is possible that there were girls among them who saw blood of menstruation before their coming-of-age, and the Samaritans ignored their impurity. Therefore, due to this uncertainty, the Sages decreed impurity on all daughters of the Samaritans from birth.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is</b> the <b>other</b> decree? The Gemara answers that another decree is <b>as we learned</b> a halakhic tradition in a mishna that <b>all movable objects with the width of an ox goad,</b> a long stick for prodding and directing a plowing animal, <b>transmit impurity.</b> If one side of the object was over a corpse and the other side of the object was over vessels, the vessels become impure due to the impurity of a tent over a corpse. <b>Rabbi Tarfon said:</b>

Daf 17a

<b>I will bury my sons</b> if <b>this is</b> not <b>a truncated <i>halakha</i>, i.e., that the one who heard</b> it, <b>heard</b> a halakhic ruling concerning a different situation <b>and erred.</b> He thought this <i>halakha</i> was established with regard to the following: Movable objects with the thickness of an ox goad transmit impurity to another vessel when the movable object is over both the source of impurity and the vessel at the same time. However, the original <i>halakha</i> is as follows: If <b>the farmer was passing and his ox goad was on his shoulder and one side of</b> the ox goad <b>covered the grave,</b> the Sages <b>deemed</b> the ox goad itself <b>impure due to</b> the impurity <b>of vessels that cover a corpse.</b> Any object located over a grave becomes impure. However, just because the ox goad itself became impure, this does not necessarily mean that it transmits impurity to other objects.
<b>Rabbi Akiva said: I will correct</b> and explain the <i>halakha</i> so <b>that the statements of the Sages will be upheld</b> as they were originally said, and this <i>halakha</i> will be explained as follows: <b>All movable objects transmit impurity to the person carrying them</b> if the objects are at least as thick as an ox goad. As will be explained below, there is room to decree that a round object with the circumference of an ox goad should have the legal status of a tent over a corpse. Something that serves as a covering over a corpse not only becomes impure itself, but also transmits impurity, as it is written: “Anything that is in the tent will become impure for seven days” (Numbers 19:14). Therefore, even the person carrying the ox goad becomes impure due to the ox goad. <b>And,</b> however, movable objects that covered the corpse bring impurity <b>upon themselves</b> by means of this makeshift tent <b>at any size,</b> and there is no minimum measure. <b>And,</b> however, those objects that cover the corpse do not transmit impurity <b>to other people</b> who are not carrying them. <b>And</b> the same is true with regard to <b>vessels,</b> unless the width of these vessels is at least <b>one handbreadth.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yannai said: And the ox goad that they mentioned</b> is specifically one in which <b>its width is not a handbreadth and,</b> however, <b>its circumference is a handbreadth, and they,</b> the Sages, <b>issued a decree on its circumference due to its width.</b> If its width was a handbreadth it would transmit impurity as a tent by Torah law. Therefore, they issued a rabbinic decree with regard to an object whose circumference is a handbreadth. This is another of the eighteen decrees.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according <b>to Rabbi Tarfon, who said: I will bury my son</b> if <b>this is</b> not <b>a truncated <i>halakha</i>,</b> the tally of the decrees <b>is lacking,</b> and there are not eighteen. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The decree that the <b>daughters of</b> the <b>Samaritans are</b> considered to already have the status of <b>menstruating women from their cradle, they issued on that day. And in the other</b> matter of drawn water, <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> and thereby the tally of the decrees is complete.
<b>And another</b> of those decrees is the matter of <b>one who harvests</b> grapes in order to take them <b>to the press. Shammai says: It has become susceptible, and Hillel says: It has not become susceptible. Hillel said to Shammai:</b> If so, <b>for what</b> purpose <b>do they harvest</b> grapes <b>in purity,</b> i.e., utilizing pure vessels, as in your opinion, since the grapes are susceptible to impurity by means of the juice that seeps from them, care must be taken to avoid impurity while gathering; <b>and,</b> however, <b>they do not harvest</b> olives <b>in purity?</b> According to your opinion that liquid that seeps out renders the fruit susceptible to impurity, why is there not a similar concern with regard to the liquid that seeps out of olives?
Shammai <b>said to him: If you provoke me</b> and insist that there is no difference between gathering olives and grapes, then, in order not to contradict this, <b>I will decree impurity on the gathering</b> of olives <b>as well.</b> They related that since the dispute was so intense, <b>they stuck a sword in the study hall, and they said: One who</b> seeks to <b>enter</b> the study hall, <b>let him enter, and one who</b> seeks to <b>leave may not leave,</b> so that all of the Sages will be assembled to determine the <i>halakha</i>. <b>That day Hillel was bowed and was sitting before Shammai like one of the students.</b> The Gemara said: <b>And</b> that day <b>was as difficult for Israel as the day the</b> Golden <b>Calf was made,</b> as Hillel, who was the <i>Nasi</i>, was forced to sit in submission before Shammai, and the opinion of Beit Shammai prevailed in the vote conducted that day. <b>And Shammai and Hillel issued the decree, and</b> the people <b>did not accept it from them. And their students came</b> and <b>issued the decree, and</b> the people <b>accepted it from them.</b>
As to the essence of the matter, the Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> they decreed that liquids that seeped from the grapes unintentionally render the grapes susceptible to impurity? <b>Rabbi Ze’iri said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> The Sages issued <b>a decree</b> due to concern <b>lest he gather</b> the grapes <b>in impure baskets.</b> The impurity of the vessel would accord the liquid in it the status of a liquid that renders food items susceptible to impurity.
The Gemara asks: This <b>works out well,</b> according <b>to the one who said</b> that <b>an impure vessel accords liquids</b> in it the halakhic status as if they were placed there willfully, and they render foods susceptible to impurity even if he did not want the liquids in the vessel. However, according <b>to the one who said</b> that <b>an impure vessel does not accord liquids</b> that status, <b>what can be said</b> in explanation of the decree? <b>Rather, Rabbi Ze’iri said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said</b> the following: The reason is not as we suggested; rather, this is <b>a decree</b> instituted by the Sages <b>lest he gather them in pitched baskets,</b> which are sealed. Since liquids that seep out of the grapes do not spill out of the baskets, it is opportune for him to have the liquids seep out of the grapes as he thereby accelerates the production of wine in the press. Because the seeping of the liquid is opportune, it renders the grapes susceptible to impurity.
<b>Rava said:</b> The reason for the <b>decree</b> is <b>due to the</b> case of liquid that squirted out when one separated clusters of grapes that were <b>stuck together</b>. Since he did so by his own hand, consciously and willfully, the liquid that seeps out renders the grapes susceptible to impurity. Just as <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: Sometimes a person goes to his vineyard</b> in order <b>to ascertain whether or not the grapes have reached</b> the time for <b>gathering, and he takes a cluster of grapes to squeeze it, and he sprays</b> the juice <b>onto</b> the <b>grapes.</b> Based on the quality of the juice, he determines whether or not the grapes are sufficiently ripe. If so, this grape juice was squeezed by his own hand willfully and it renders the grapes susceptible to impurity, as even <b>at the time of gathering</b> it is conceivable that the <b>liquid is still moist upon</b> the grapes.
Since all eighteen decrees decreed that day have not yet been enumerated, the Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what is <b>the other? Said</b>

Daf 17b

<b>Tavi the bird hunter [<i>rishba</i>]</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The decree that <b>growths of <i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., produce that grows from <i>teruma</i> that was planted in the ground, are considered <i>teruma</i>, the Sages <b>also issued on that day.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this decree? <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: A decree due to pure <i>teruma</i> in the hand of a</b> non<b>-</b>priest <b>Israelite.</b> One who seeks to avoid giving <i>teruma</i> to a priest would plant it in the ground and thereby negate its <i>teruma</i> status. To prevent him from doing so, the Sages decreed that that which grows from the <i>teruma</i> is also considered <i>teruma</i>. Consequently, one would gain nothing by replanting the <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Rava said: If they are suspected of that, let them refrain from separating <i>teruma</i></b> altogether. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> We know that with regard to <b>an Israelite,</b> as opposed to a Levite, fundamentally <b>it is possible to perform</b> the mitzva of <i>teruma</i> by separating merely <b>one grain of wheat, in</b> accordance with the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> who said that by Torah law there is no fixed measure for <i>teruma</i>. By separating one grain of wheat as <i>teruma</i> for all the wheat on the threshing floor, one fulfills his obligation. <b>Since he</b> nevertheless <b>did not</b> take advantage of that possibility to exempt himself from the obligation of separating <i>teruma</i>, <b>he is trustworthy,</b> and there is no reason to suspect that he will seek to avoid giving <i>teruma</i> to the priest by planting it. <b>Rather,</b> the reason for <b>the decree</b> is <b>due to impure <i>teruma</i> in the hand of a priest.</b> A priest is forbidden to eat impure <i>teruma</i> and he is required to burn it. However, the priest is permitted to derive benefit from its burning. The Sages were concerned <b>lest he keep</b> the impure <i>teruma</i> <b>with him</b> until the season of sowing and sow his field with it, <b>and,</b> as a result, <b>he encounter a stumbling-block</b> because over time he is liable to forget that the <i>teruma</i> is impure and eat it.
With regard to the total of eighteen decrees, the Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what is <b>the other</b> decree? <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ami said in the name of Ulla:</b> In a case of <b>one who</b> was carrying a purse with money in it on Shabbat eve, and <b>it got dark</b> for him <b>on the way,</b> the Torah law permitted him to carry the purse in increments, each of which is less than four cubits. However, the Sages issued the following decree: It is prohibited to carry in increments; <b>he</b> should <b>give his purse to a gentile</b> accompanying him. This decree was <b>also issued on that day.</b>
<b>And the other</b> decree: The Sage <b>Bali said</b> that <b>Avimi of Sanvata said:</b> The decrees with regard to gentiles that prohibit <b>their bread, and their oil, and their wine, and their daughters are all</b> one decree <b>of the eighteen matters.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well</b> according <b>to Rabbi Meir,</b> as according to his opinion the Gemara already enumerated eighteen decrees. <b>However,</b> according <b>to Rabbi Yosei,</b> who holds that the dispute remains with regard to the matter of vessels in the courtyard, <b>they are</b> only <b>seventeen.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> also <b>that</b> statement of <b>Rav Aḥa bar Adda, as Rav Aḥa bar Adda said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said:</b> The Sages <b>issued a decree</b> prohibiting eating <b>their bread due to their oil. And</b> they issued a decree prohibiting <b>their oil due to their wine.</b> Consequently, there are two separate decrees.
The Gemara wonders: They issued a decree <b>on their bread because of their oil.</b> In <b>what</b> way <b>is the</b> prohibition on <b>oil stronger than</b> the prohibition on <b>bread? Rather,</b> say that <b>they issued a decree</b> prohibiting <b>their bread and their oil due to their wine. And</b> they issued a decree prohibiting <b>their wine due to</b> the fact that it leads to familiarity, and people will come to marry <b>their daughters. And</b> they issued a decree prohibiting <b>their daughters due to something else,</b> idolatry. <b>And</b> they further issued a decree <b>on something else,</b> idolatry, <b>due to something else.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <b>something else</b> alluded to here? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: They issued a decree on a gentile baby,</b> according him the legal status <b>that he transmits impurity</b> as one <b>with the</b> legal status <b>of a</b> great <b><i>zav</i>,</b> who experienced three emissions, even though he did not experience an emission. This was in order to distance Jewish children from gentile children so <b>that a Jewish boy should not be accustomed to be with</b> a gentile <b>in homosexual relations.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> according <b>to Rabbi Meir</b> it is difficult <b>as well,</b> as <b>they are</b> now <b>nineteen</b> decrees. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Meir <b>counts</b> the decrees of <b>food</b> items <b>and vessels that became impure</b> through contact <b>with liquids as one.</b> Consequently, according to Rabbi Meir, too, there are only eighteen decrees.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In this mishna there is a fundamental dispute between Beit Hillel and Beit Shammai: Must one begin refraining from actions prohibited on Shabbat on Shabbat eve? Or, may one initiate an action prior to Shabbat, even if he knows that it will continue on its own on Shabbat itself? These are the details of that dispute: <b>Beit Shammai say: One may only soak</b> dry <b>ink</b> in water <b>and</b> dry plants, which produce <b>dyes,</b> in water <b>and vetch</b> for animal food to soften them in water on Shabbat eve, adjacent to Shabbat, <b>if</b> there is clearly <b>sufficient time for them to soak</b> for their designated purpose <b>while it is still day,</b> before Shabbat begins, and their continued soaking on Shabbat will have no effect. <b>And Beit Hillel permit</b> doing so. <b>Beit Shammai say: One may only place bundles of</b> combed <b>flax inside the oven</b> on Shabbat eve if there is sufficient time <b>so that they will be heated while it is still day. And</b> one may <b>only</b> place <b>wool into the</b> dyer’s <b>kettle if</b> there is <b>sufficient time for</b> the wool <b>to absorb the dye</b> while it is still day. <b>And Beit Hillel permit</b> doing so.
<b>Beit Shammai say: One may spread traps</b> for an <b>animal and birds and fish only</b> if there is sufficient time remaining in the day <b>for them to be trapped</b> in them <b>while it is still day, and Beit Hillel permit</b> doing so even if there is not sufficient time remaining in the day. <b>Beit Shammai say: One may only sell</b> an item <b>to a gentile</b> on Shabbat eve, <b>and</b> one <b>may only load</b> a burden on his donkey <b>with him, and</b> one <b>may only lift</b> a burden <b>on him if</b> there remains <b>sufficient time for</b> the gentile <b>to arrive to a near place</b> prior to Shabbat, and the Jew will play no role in the performance of a prohibited labor by the gentile on Shabbat. <b>And Beit Hillel permit</b> doing so. <b>Beit Shammai say: One may not give skins to a</b> gentile <b>tanner, nor clothes to a gentile launderer, unless</b> there is <b>sufficient time for</b> work on <b>them to be completed while it is still day,</b> before Shabbat begins. <b>And in all of them Beit Hillel permit</b> doing so <b>with</b>

Daf 18a

<b>the sun,</b> i.e., as long as the sun is shining on Friday. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: The</b> ancestral <b>house of</b> my <b>father,</b> the dynasty of <i>Nesi’im</i> from the house of Hillel, <b>was accustomed to give</b> its <b>white clothes to a gentile launderer</b> no fewer than <b>three days before Shabbat. And,</b> however, <b>these,</b> Beit Shammai, <b>and those,</b> Beit Hillel, <b>agree that,</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>one may load the beam of the olive press</b> on the olives on Shabbat eve while it is still day, so that the oil will continue to be squeezed out of the olives on Shabbat. So too, one may load the <b>circular wine press</b> to accelerate the process of producing wine from the grapes.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Before clarifying the matters themselves, the Gemara seeks to determine: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who holds that merely <b>adding water to ink</b> without any additional action <b>constitutes its soaking,</b> and one is liable for doing so on Shabbat, as he performed an act of kneading, one of the primary categories of labor? <b>Rav Yosef said: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>one</b> person <b>adds the flour and</b> another <b>one adds the water</b> into one vessel, <b>the latter one is liable</b> for kneading the dough, which is a prohibited labor on Shabbat, even though he did not actually knead the dough; that is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: He is not liable</b> for the prohibited labor of kneading <b>until he</b> actually <b>kneads</b> the dough. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, merely soaking the dough in water is considered a prohibited labor.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>And perhaps Rabbi Yosei only stated</b> that actual kneading is required to be liable for performing the prohibited labor of kneading <b>in</b> the case of <b>flour, which can be kneaded; however, ink, which cannot be kneaded, say</b> that its soaking is considered a full-fledged prohibited labor, and <b>he will</b> therefore <b>be liable,</b> even according to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei. The Gemara rejects this: <b>It should not enter your mind</b> to say so, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>one places the ashes and one adds the water, the latter one is liable,</b> although he did not knead them. That is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says:</b> He is not liable <b>until he</b> actually <b>kneads</b> them. Apparently, according to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, he is only liable for committing the prohibited labor of kneading on Shabbat if he actually kneads the mixture, as he stated his <i>halakha</i> even with regard to ashes, which cannot be kneaded.
The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps, what is</b> the meaning of <b>ashes [<i>efer</i>]</b> mentioned here? Perhaps it is <b>soil [<i>afar</i>], which can be kneaded.</b> In that case he is not liable until he actually kneads the mixture. However, with regard to ashes, which cannot be kneaded, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, also holds that even if he did not actually knead the mixture he is liable. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Wasn’t</b> the dispute <b>taught</b> in one <i>baraita</i> with regard to <b>ashes, and wasn’t it taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> with regard to <b>soil?</b> In both cases, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, disagreed. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Were they taught next to each other?</b> Had both of these <i>baraitot</i> been taught together, it would have been truly possible to arrive at the conclusion that Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, disagrees both in the case of ashes and in the case of soil. However, since the <i>baraita</i> that speaks about ashes was taught elsewhere by a different <i>amora</i> who cited it in the name of Rabbi Yosei, the difference in language does not prove that Rabbi Yosei disagrees in both cases.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One may open</b> a canal that passes adjacent to a garden <b>on Shabbat eve at nightfall,</b> so that <b>water</b> will flow <b>into a garden</b> and the garden <b>continuously fills</b> with water <b>all day long</b> on Shabbat. <b>Similarly, one may place incense,</b> perfumed herbs placed on coals to produce a fragrance, on coals <b>beneath the clothes on Shabbat eve and</b> the clothes <b>may be continuously perfumed all day long. And,</b> similarly, <b>one may place sulfur beneath the</b> silver <b>vessels</b> on <b>Shabbat eve at nightfall</b> for the purpose of coloring the vessels, <b>and they may be continuously</b> exposed to <b>sulfur all day long. And one may place an eye salve [<i>kilor</i>] on the eye and a bandage [<i>ispelanit</i>]</b> smeared with cream <b>on a wound</b> on <b>Shabbat eve at nightfall, and</b> the wound <b>may continuously heal all day long</b> on Shabbat. <b>However, one may not place wheat kernels into the water mill unless</b> he does so in a way <b>so that they will be ground while it is still day</b> on Friday and not on Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that the <i>baraita</i> prohibited a mill and permitted other prohibited labor? <b>Rabba said: Because it makes noise</b> and the public will hear the mill grinding on Shabbat. Although no prohibited labor is being performed, doing so displays contempt for Shabbat. Therefore, the Sages prohibited it. <b>Rav Yosef said to</b> Rabba: <b>And let the Master say</b> a better reason, <b>due to the</b> obligation to ensure the <b>resting of utensils.</b> Even the utensils of a Jewish person may not be used for prohibited labor on Shabbat. <b>As it was taught</b> in halakhic midrash, the <i>Mekhilta</i>: That which is stated: <b>“And in all that I said to you, take heed”</b> (Exodus 23:13), is an allusion to matters mentioned in the Oral Torah. It comes <b>to include the resting of utensils</b> on Shabbat. <b>Rather, Rav Yosef said:</b> The reason for the prohibition of the mill on Shabbat is <b>due to the resting of utensils.</b>
Since the obligation of resting utensils on Shabbat was mentioned, the Gemara says: <b>Now</b> that <b>you said</b> that <b>Beit Hillel also hold</b> that <b>resting utensils</b> on Shabbat is required <b>by Torah law,</b> with regard to <b>sulfur and incense</b> on coals that are placed under silver vessels and clothes, respectively, <b>what is the reason that</b> the Sages <b>permitted</b> this on Shabbat? Isn’t that performed on Shabbat in utensils? The Gemara answers: <b>Because</b> the utensil itself <b>does not perform an action</b> when the incense or sulfur is burning. With regard to the <b>bundles of flax, what is the reason that they permitted</b> placing them in the oven on Shabbat eve at nightfall to dry, even though the oven is performing a prohibited labor on Shabbat? <b>Because it does not perform an action;</b> rather, on the contrary, <b>it sits idle</b> in its place and the prohibited labor occurs on its own. However, with regard to <b>traps of an animal, and a bird, and a fish, which perform a</b> bona fide <b>action</b> of trapping, <b>what is the reason that they permitted</b> spreading them on Shabbat eve at nightfall? The Gemara explains: <b>There too,</b> it is referring <b>to a fish hook and nets [<i>kokrei</i>], which perform no action.</b> They stand in place, and the fish comes to them and is trapped. Indeed, a trap that performs an action is prohibited.
<b>And now that Rav Oshaya said</b> that <b>Rav Asi said: Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who states that the obligation of <b>resting utensils</b> on Shabbat <b>is by Torah law?</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>is Beit Shammai and not Beit Hillel.</b> Consequently, according <b>to Beit Shammai, whether</b> the utensil <b>performs an action or whether it does not perform an action, it is prohibited. And</b> according <b>to Beit Hillel, even though it performs an action, it is</b> nevertheless <b>permitted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And now</b> that <b>you said</b> that according <b>to Beit Shammai even though</b> the utensil <b>does not perform an action it is prohibited, if so,</b>

Daf 18b

with regard to <b>placing incense and sulfur</b> beneath clothes and silver vessels, respectively, <b>what is the reason Beit Shammai permitted</b> this? The Gemara answers: The case under discussion was not one where the incense was placed in a vessel; rather, <b>there,</b> the incense <b>was placed on the ground,</b> and therefore there was no utensil that was obligated to rest. The Gemara asks further: <b>A tub</b> in which fruit or grains are placed to ferment into beer, and where they stay for an extended period; <b>and a</b> Shabbat <b>lamp; and a pot</b> in which food is being cooked, which they place on the fire while it is still day; <b>and a spit [<i>shapud</i>]</b> on which they placed food to roast while it is still day; <b>what is the reason Beit Shammai permitted</b> placing them on Shabbat eve while it is still day even though the prohibited labor continues over time, including on Shabbat? The Gemara answers: These are cases <b>where he declares</b> the utensils <b>ownerless.</b> According to Beit Shammai, the utensils must be declared ownerless while it is still day. Once the utensils are declared ownerless, they no longer belong to a Jew and, consequently, there is no obligation to let them rest.
The Gemara asks: Based on these conclusions, <b>who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>who taught this</b> <i>Tosefta</i> <b>that the Sages taught: A woman may not fill up a pot with pounded wheat and lupines,</b> a type of legume, <b>and place them in the oven</b> to cook on <b>Shabbat eve at nightfall. And if she placed them</b> in the oven, not only may they not be eaten on Shabbat itself, but even <b>at the conclusion of Shabbat they are forbidden for a</b> period of <b>time</b> that would be <b>sufficient for them to be prepared,</b> i.e., the time it takes to cook the dish from the beginning, so that he will derive no benefit from a prohibited labor performed on Shabbat. <b>Similarly,</b> the <i>Tosefta</i> said: <b>A baker may not fill a barrel of water and place it in the oven on Shabbat eve at nightfall</b> to boil the water that is in the barrel, <b>and if he did so,</b> even <b>at the conclusion of Shabbat it is forbidden for</b> the period of <b>time</b> that would be <b>sufficient for it to be prepared</b> from the beginning. <b>Let us say</b> that this <i>Tosefta</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai and not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Even if you say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel,</b> in those cases the Sages issued <b>a decree</b> due to concern <b>lest</b> the one cooking <b>stoke</b> the <b>coals</b> on Shabbat in order to accelerate the cooking.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> with regard to <b>incense and sulfur,</b> the Sages <b>should also issue a decree</b> that prohibits placing them beneath clothes and silver vessels, respectively, on Shabbat eve at nightfall. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in that case, <b>he will not stoke them, as if he stokes them smoke will rise into</b> the garments and the silver, <b>and that is damaging for them.</b> The smoke from the wood will ruin the fragrance and the coating of sulfur. The Gemara asks further: With regard to <b>bundles of flax,</b> the Sages <b>should also issue a decree.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There, since wind is damaging for them, he does not expose them,</b> and he will not come to stoke the coals. The Gemara asks further: With regard to <b>wool</b> placed <b>in the</b> dyer’s <b>kettle,</b> the Sages <b>should also issue a decree. Shmuel said:</b> The mishna is referring <b>to a pot that is removed</b> from the fire, where there is no concern lest he stoke the coals. The Gemara still asks: <b>Let us be concerned lest he stir</b> that same pot, thereby accelerating the cooking, which is prohibited by Torah law. Rather, the mishna is referring <b>to</b> a pot that is <b>removed</b> from the fire <b>and sealed with clay</b> spread around its cover to prevent it from opening.
The Gemara comments: <b>And now</b> that <b>the Master said</b> that in these cases the prohibition of placing the pot on the fire is due to <b>a decree</b> issued by the Sages <b>lest he stoke the coals;</b> with regard to <b>this pot of raw meat, it is permitted to place it in an oven</b> on <b>Shabbat eve at nightfall. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Since it is not fit for</b> consumption during <b>the night,</b> as it will not be cooked by then, <b>he diverts his thoughts from it and will not come to stoke the coals. And</b> the same is true of <b>cooked meat; it is permitted</b> to place it on the fire on Shabbat eve at nightfall. Since it is reasonably cooked, one will not come to stoke the coals to cook it more. Meat that is <b>cooked and not</b> sufficiently <b>cooked is prohibited,</b> as there is concern lest he come to stoke the coals. <b>And if he threw a raw bone into</b> this pot, he may <b>well</b> do so, as due to the bone he will not remove the meat to eat it in the evening.
<b>And now that the Master said</b> that <b>anything for which wind is damaging one does not expose,</b> one could say that with regard to <b>meat of a kid</b> and an oven whose opening <b>is sealed with clay,</b> he may <b>well</b> place it there on Shabbat eve at nightfall. Since the meat of the kid cooks quickly and the opening of the oven is sealed, there is no concern lest he come to stoke the coals. If it is the meat <b>of a ram</b> [<b><i>barḥa</i></b>] <b>and</b> the opening of the oven is <b>not sealed with clay, it is prohibited</b> to place it there on Shabbat eve at nightfall. The above are cases where the ruling is clear. However, with regard to the case of the meat <b>of a kid and</b> the opening of the oven is <b>not sealed with clay,</b> or the case <b>of a ram and</b> the opening of the oven is <b>sealed,</b> there is a dispute. <b>Rav Ashi permitted</b> placing it in the oven on Shabbat eve at nightfall, <b>and Rav Yirmeya from Difti prohibited</b> doing so. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ashi, who permitted</b> placing it there on Shabbat eve at nightfall, <b>wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>one may not roast meat, an onion, and an egg</b> on Shabbat eve <b>unless</b> there is <b>sufficient time for them to be roasted while it is still day?</b> Apparently, one may not place meat that is not sufficiently roasted in an oven on Shabbat eve. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the meat <b>of a ram and</b> the opening of the oven is <b>not sealed with clay.</b> However, in other cases it is permitted.
<b>Others say</b> that with regard to the meat <b>of a kid, whether</b> it is in an oven that is <b>sealed</b> or <b>whether</b> it is in one that is <b>not sealed,</b> everyone agrees that he may <b>well</b> do so. With regard to the meat <b>of a ram,</b> when the opening of the oven is <b>sealed,</b> one may <b>well</b> do so <b>too</b>. <b>Where they disagreed</b> was <b>in</b> the case of the meat of <b>a ram and</b> the opening of the oven was <b>not sealed. Rav Ashi permitted</b> placing it in the oven on Shabbat eve at nightfall, <b>and Rav Yirmeya from Difti prohibited</b> doing so. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ashi, who permitted</b> this, <b>wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>one may only roast meat, an onion, and an egg</b> on Shabbat eve <b>if</b> there is <b>sufficient time for them to be roasted while it is still day?</b> Apparently, one may not place meat that is not sufficiently roasted in an oven on Shabbat eve. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> the case of <b>meat</b> roasted directly <b>on the coals.</b> In that case, there is greater concern that he will come to stoke the coals. <b>Ravina said:</b> With regard to <b>that raw gourd,</b> one may <b>well</b> place it in a pot on the fire on Shabbat eve at nightfall. The reason for this is that <b>since the wind is damaging for it, it is considered like the meat of a kid.</b>
The full text of the <i>baraita</i> is: <b>Beit Shammai say: One may only sell</b> an item <b>to a gentile</b> on Shabbat eve, and one may only load a burden onto his donkey with him, and one may only lift a burden onto him if the destination of the gentile is near enough that there remains sufficient time for the gentile to arrive at a place near there prior to Shabbat. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that elaborated upon this dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel with regard to selling to a gentile on Shabbat eve: <b>Beit Shammai say: A person may not sell his object to a gentile, and lend</b> it to <b>him, and loan him</b> money, <b>and give him</b> an object <b>as a gift</b> on Shabbat eve, <b>unless</b> there is <b>sufficient time for him,</b> the gentile, <b>to reach his house</b> while it is still day. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> He is permitted to do this if there is sufficient time <b>for him to reach a house adjacent to the wall</b> of the place where he is going. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> It is permitted to give an object to a gentile on Shabbat eve if there is <b>sufficient time for him to exit the entrance of</b> the Jewish person’s <b>house.</b> What the gentile does afterward is irrelevant. <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said: That is the statement of Rabbi Akiva; that is the statement of Beit Hillel. Rabbi Akiva came only to explain the statement of Beit Hillel.</b> The <i>tanna</i> whose version of Beit Hillel’s statement was: Until he reaches the house adjacent to the wall, held that Beit Hillel’s opinion was similar to Beit Shammai’s opinion. Rabbi Akiva came to elucidate the actual opinion of Beit Hillel.
<b>The Sages taught</b> a similar principle in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to another tannaitic dispute. <b>Beit Shammai say: A person may not sell his leaven to a gentile</b> on Passover eve <b>unless he knows that</b> the leaven <b>will be finished before Passover. And Beit Hillel say: As long as it is permitted</b> for the Jew <b>to eat</b> leaven, <b>it is</b> also <b>permitted for him to sell it</b> to a gentile. The Jew ceases to be responsible for the leaven sold to a gentile from the moment it is sold. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda says:</b>

Daf 19a

With regard to <b>Babylonian <i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> a spice that contains leavened bread crumbs, and <b>all kinds of <i>kutaḥ</i>, it is prohibited to sell</b> it to a gentile <b>thirty days before Passover.</b> Because <i>kutaḥ</i> is used exclusively as a spice, it lasts longer than other foods.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may,</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>put food before the dog in the courtyard</b> on Shabbat, and we are not concerned that the dog may lift it and carry it out to the public domain. If the dog <b>lifted it and exited</b> the courtyard, one need <b>not attend to him</b>, as he is not required to ensure that the dog will eat it specifically in that courtyard.
<b>On a similar note,</b> the <i>baraita</i> continued: <b>One may place food before the gentile in the courtyard</b> on Shabbat. If the gentile <b>lifted it and exited, one need not attend to him.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need this as well? This</b> case <b>is the same as that</b> case. The <i>halakhot</i> with regard to the dog and the gentile are identical, as Shabbat prohibitions do not apply to either of them. The Gemara answers: There is a distinction. <b>Lest you say</b> that in <b>this</b> case, the case of the dog, responsibility for its food <b>is incumbent upon</b> the owner of the courtyard who owns the dog. <b>And</b> in <b>this</b> case, the case of the gentile, responsibility for his food <b>is not incumbent upon</b> the owner of the courtyard. Therefore, in a situation where there is concern that Shabbat will be desecrated, there is room to say that one may not give the gentile his food. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that in that case, it is also permitted.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>A person may not rent his utensils to a gentile on Shabbat eve,</b> as it appears that the Jew is receiving payment for work performed on Shabbat. However, <b>on the fourth and on the fifth</b> days of the week <b>it is permitted. On a similar note, one may not send letters in the hand of a gentile on Shabbat eve.</b> However, <b>on the fourth and on the fifth</b> days of the week <b>it is permitted.</b> Nevertheless, <b>they said about Rabbi Yosei the priest, and some say</b> that they said this <b>about Rabbi Yosei the Ḥasid, that</b> a document in <b>his handwriting was never found in the hand of a gentile,</b> so that a gentile would not carry his letter on Shabbat.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not send a letter in the hand of a gentile</b> on <b>Shabbat eve unless he stipulates a set sum of money for him.</b> In that case, anything the gentile does with this letter is not in service of the Jew, but rather on his own, since his payment is stipulated in advance. <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> One may only give a letter to a gentile on Shabbat eve if there is sufficient time <b>for</b> the gentile <b>to reach his house</b> before dark. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> If there is sufficient time <b>for him to reach the house adjacent to the wall</b> of the city to which he was sent.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t he stipulate a set</b> price? What difference does it make whether he reaches the city on Shabbat eve or on Shabbat? <b>Rav Sheshet said,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying as follows: And if he did not stipulate a set</b> price for the task, <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> One may only give a letter to a gentile on Shabbat eve if there is sufficient time <b>for</b> the gentile <b>to reach his house</b> before dark. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> If there is sufficient time <b>for him to reach the house adjacent to the wall</b> of the city to which he was sent.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t you say in the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, that <b>one may not send</b> a letter unless he stipulated a set price? Without stipulating a set price, one may not send a letter at all. The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as it is possible to explain that <b>this,</b> where we learned that one is permitted to give a letter to a gentile on Shabbat eve even if he did not stipulate a set price, is in a case <b>where the house of the mail carrier [<i>bei doar</i>] is permanently located in the city. And this,</b> where it is permitted to give a letter to a gentile only if he stipulated a set price, is in a case <b>where the house of the mail carrier is not permanently located in the city.</b>
<b>The Sages taught: One may not set sail on a ship fewer than three days before Shabbat,</b> to avoid appearances that the Jew is performing a prohibited labor on Shabbat. <b>In what case is this</b> statement <b>said?</b> In a case where he set sail <b>for a voluntary matter; however,</b> if he sailed <b>for a matter</b> involving a <b>mitzva,</b> he may <b>well</b> do so. <b>And,</b> even then, <b>he</b> must <b>stipulate with</b> the gentile ship captain that this is <b>on the condition that he rests,</b> i.e., stops the ship, <b>and</b> even if the gentile <b>does not rest. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: He need not</b> stipulate. <b>And</b> sailing on a ship that is traveling <b>from Tyre to Sidon,</b> a short journey by sea, <b>is permitted even on Shabbat eve.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One may not lay siege to cities of gentiles fewer than three days before Shabbat,</b> to avoid the need to desecrate Shabbat in establishing the siege. <b>And if they</b> already <b>began</b> establishing the siege fewer than three days before Shabbat, <b>they need not stop</b> all war-related actions even on Shabbat. <b>And so Shammai would say:</b> From that which is written: “And you should build a siege against the city that is waging war with you <b>until it falls”</b> (Deuteronomy 20:20), it is derived that the siege should be sustained “until it falls.” Consequently, the siege must continue <b>even on Shabbat.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said:</b> The ancestral house of my father, the dynasty of <i>Nesi’im</i> from the house of Hillel, <b>was accustomed</b> to give its white clothes to a gentile launderer no fewer than three days before Shabbat. <b>It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>Rabbi Tzadok said: This was the custom of the house of Rabban Gamliel: They would give white clothes to the</b> gentile <b>launderer three days before Shabbat, and</b> they would give him <b>colored</b> clothes <b>even on Shabbat eve.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And from their statement we learned that white</b> garments <b>are more difficult to launder than colored ones,</b> as in white garments every stain is more conspicuous.
On a related note, the Gemara relates that <b>Abaye gave this dyed garment to the launderer.</b> Abaye <b>said to</b> the launderer: <b>How much do you want</b> as payment <b>to</b> wash <b>it?</b> The launderer <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>Same as for a white</b> garment. Abaye <b>said to him:</b> You cannot deceive me in this matter, <b>as the Sages already preceded you,</b> as it was taught in the <i>baraita</i> which garment is more difficult to wash. On this topic, <b>Abaye said: One who gives clothing to the launderer, he should give</b> it to <b>him by measure and he should take</b> it back <b>from him by measure.</b> In <b>that</b> way, <b>if it is longer,</b> it is an indication that the launderer <b>caused him a loss</b> because <b>he stretched</b> the garment. <b>And if it is shorter, he</b> certainly <b>caused him a loss</b> because <b>he shrunk it.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>these,</b> Beit Shammai, <b>and those,</b> Beit Hillel, <b>agree</b> that <b>one may load</b> the beam of the olive press and the circular wine press. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different about all</b> of the cases in the mishna, <b>where Beit Shammai issued a decree</b> prohibiting <b>them, and what is different about the beams of the olive press and the circular wine press that</b> Beit Shammai <b>did not issue a decree</b> prohibiting them? The Gemara answers: <b>Those</b> cases, <b>where if he performed them on Shabbat he is rendered liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, Beit Shammai issued a decree</b> prohibiting <b>them</b> on <b>Shabbat eve at nightfall.</b> However, in the cases of <b>the beams of the olive press and the circular wine press,</b> where even <b>if he performed them on Shabbat he is not rendered liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> Beit Shammai <b>did not issue a decree.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who holds that <b>anything that comes on its own,</b> and not as the result of an action, it may <b>well</b> be done on Shabbat? <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>the garlic and the unripe</b> grapes, <b>and the stalks</b> of wheat <b>that he crushed while it was still day, Rabbi Yishmael says: He may</b> continue tending to them and <b>finish after it gets dark,</b> as after the crushing is completed these items are placed beneath a weight, so that the liquids will continue to seep out. <b>And Rabbi Akiva says:</b>

Daf 19b

<b>He may not finish. And</b> the <i>amora</i> <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> Our mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> the <i>tanna</i>. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>honeycombs that he crushed on Shabbat eve and</b> the honey <b>came out on its own</b> on Shabbat day, <b>it is prohibited to eat</b> the honey, like anything that was prepared on Shabbat. <b>And Rabbi Elazar permits</b> eating it on Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina, what is the reason he did not say</b> in accordance with the explanation of <b>Rabbi Elazar?</b> Apparently, Rabbi Elazar’s explanation in the mishna is more accurate. The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yosei could have <b>said to you</b> that <b>there,</b> in the case of the honeycombs, <b>it is food from the beginning and it is food at the end,</b> as honey is considered food. Therefore, there was no squeezing of liquid from food at all. However, <b>here,</b> in all of the cases in the mishna, <b>from the beginning</b> they were <b>food and now</b> they became <b>liquid,</b> and that is the definition of squeezing. <b>And Rabbi Elazar</b> could have <b>said to you</b> in response to this assertion: <b>We heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar permitted olives and grapes as well. As when Rav Hoshaya from Neharde’a came, he came and brought a <i>baraita</i> with him,</b> in which it was taught: <b>Olives and grapes that he crushed from Shabbat eve and</b> the liquids <b>seeped out on their own,</b> the liquids <b>are prohibited. Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon permit</b> those liquids. The Gemara answers that <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Rabbi Ḥanina did not know</b> this <b><i>baraita</i>.</b>
On the other hand, the Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Elazar, what is the reason he did not say</b> in accordance with the explanation of <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina,</b> that our mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yishmael? The Gemara answers: Rabbi Elazar could have <b>said to you: Wasn’t it stated</b> that <b>Rava bar Ḥanina said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Here it is referring <b>to</b> items that <b>lack grinding,</b> i.e., when the garlic and the unripe grapes were not ground in a pestle at all, everyone agrees that it is prohibited to place them in a manner that causes their liquids to come out on their own on Shabbat. The case <b>where they disagreed</b> was where they were already completely ground, but they were still <b>lacking</b> additional <b>pounding; and these</b> cases in our mishna <b>are also considered as</b> if they were <b>lacking grinding.</b> The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina issued a</b> practical <b>ruling in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b> and permitted a person to finish tending to them even after dark.
Since the Gemara raised issues related to the olive press, it cites other connected matters: <b>Oil of olive pressers and mats of olive pressers,</b> which they use in their work, <b>Rav prohibited</b> moving them on Shabbat since they are set aside for a specific purpose, and it is prohibited to move an item set aside and designated for a defined purpose on Shabbat. <b>And Shmuel permitted</b> doing so, as according to Shmuel, the legal status of set-aside [<i>muktze</i>] does not apply in most cases. Along the same lines, they disagreed with regard to <b>those mats</b> used to cover merchandise transported <b>on a ship. Rav prohibited</b> using them because they are set aside <b>and Shmuel permitted</b> using them. Similarly, <b>Rav Naḥman said: A goat</b> raised <b>for its milk, and a ewe</b> that is raised <b>for shearing its</b> wool, <b>and a chicken</b> raised <b>for its egg, and oxen</b> used <b>for plowing,</b> all of which are designated for purposes other than eating, <b>as well as dates used for commerce;</b> in all of these <b>Rav prohibited</b> using them for food, or slaughtering them even on a Festival due to the prohibition of set-aside. The reason for this is that during the day, before Shabbat, he had no intention of eating them, as he set them aside for a different purpose. <b>And Shmuel said: They are permitted,</b> as in his opinion there is no prohibition of set-aside. The Gemara comments that <b>they disagree in the dispute of</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon</b> with regard to the issue of <i>muktze</i>.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>this student who issued a ruling in</b> the city of <b>Ḥarta De’argiz</b> that items that are set aside are permitted, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> and <b>Rav Hamnuna excommunicated him.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Don’t we hold</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon?</b> Why, then, did Rav Hamnuna excommunicate him? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> incident <b>was in the place of Rav</b> and the student <b>should not have done this;</b> even if the accepted ruling is lenient, the city was under Rav’s jurisdiction, and the student’s public ruling, contrary to Rav’s opinion, was a blatant display of disrespect. Incidentally, the Gemara relates a story involving <b>these two students: One would rescue</b> from a fire <b>with one vessel and one would rescue with four and five vessels,</b> as it is permitted to rescue one’s belongings from a fire on Shabbat. They disagreed with regard to whether it is preferable to carry just one vessel and go back and forth several times, or to carry several vessels and go back and forth fewer times. <b>And they disagree with regard to the</b> same issue that was the subject of the <b>dispute of Rabba bar Zavda and Rav Huna</b> elsewhere.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> This mishna enumerates actions that may only be performed on Shabbat eve if the prohibited labor will be totally or mostly completed while it is still day. <b>One may only roast meat, an onion, or an egg if</b> there remains <b>sufficient</b> time <b>so that they could be roasted while it is still day. One may only place</b> dough to bake into <b>bread in the oven</b> on Shabbat eve <b>at nightfall, and</b> may only place <b>a cake on the coals, if</b> there is time <b>enough that</b> the <b>surface</b> of this cake or bread <b>will form a crust while it is still day. Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> Enough time so <b>that its bottom</b> crust <b>should harden,</b> which takes less time. However, in a case that is an exception, <b>one may,</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>lower the Paschal lamb</b> into the oven on Shabbat eve <b>at nightfall,</b> so that its roasting is completed on Shabbat if Passover eve coincides with Shabbat eve. <b>And one may,</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>kindle the fire in the bonfire of the Chamber of the Hearth</b> in the Temple on Shabbat eve, adjacent to the start of Shabbat, and allow the fire to spread afterward throughout all the wood in the bonfire.

Daf 20a

<b>And,</b> however, <b>in the outlying areas,</b> meaning in all of Eretz Yisrael outside the Temple, it is prohibited to light a bonfire on Shabbat eve, unless there is sufficient <b>time for the fire to take hold in most of</b> the bonfire, while it is still day. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: With</b> a bonfire of <b>coals,</b> even in the outlying areas one is permitted to light the fire on Shabbat eve at nightfall, even if the fire only spread to <b>any amount</b> of the bonfire. The coals, once they are kindled, will not be extinguished again, and there is no concern lest he come to tend to them on Shabbat.
