And if he did not recite</b> it, <b>we require him to return</b> to the beginning of the prayer and repeat it. <b>And</b> on those days, <b>there is no <i>kiddush</i> recited over the cup</b> of wine at the start of the day, <b>but there is mention</b> of the day recited <b>in Grace after Meals,</b> in accordance with Rav’s opinion. <b>Days</b> on <b>which there is no additional offering, i.e., Monday, and Thursday, and fast days, and</b> non-priestly <b>watches [<i>ma’amadot</i>],</b> have a different legal status as detailed below.
Before drawing a conclusion, the Gemara seeks to clarify: <b>Monday and Thursday, what is their purpose</b> in this discussion, i.e., why are Monday and Thursday mentioned here if no special prayers are recited on those days? The Gemara explains: <b>Rather,</b> certainly the reference is to <b>Monday and Thursday and Monday</b> that are <b>fast days</b> for rain <b>and of <i>ma</i>’<i>amadot</i>.</b> On those days, in the <b>evening, morning, and afternoon prayers, one recites eighteen</b> blessings <b>and recites</b> a passage <b>pertaining to the event</b> of the day, i.e., the fast, <b>in</b> the blessing: <b>Who listens to prayer. However, if one did not mention</b> it, <b>we do not require him to return</b> to the beginning of the prayer and repeat it. <b>And,</b> on those days, <b>there is no <i>kiddush</i> recited over a cup</b> of wine, <b>and there is no mention</b> of the day recited <b>in Grace after Meals.</b>
<b>An</b> additional <b>dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the ruling with regard to the obligation <b>to mention Hanukkah in</b> the <b>additional prayer</b> on Shabbat during Hanukkah or on the New Moon of Tevet, which falls during Hanukkah? The sides of the dilemma are: Do we say that <b>since</b> Hanukkah <b>has no</b> additional prayer <b>of its own,</b> and the additional prayer has no connection to Hanukkah, <b>we do not mention</b> it? <b>Or, perhaps it is</b> the essence of <b>the day that is obligated</b> in the mention of Hanukkah, in which case there is no distinction between the various prayers, and it should be mentioned <b>in</b> all <b>four prayers,</b> including the additional prayer on Shabbat and the New Moon. There is a dispute: <b>Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda both said: One does not mention</b> it. <b>Rav Naḥman and Rabbi Yoḥanan both said: One mentions</b> it.
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: This</b> opinion of <b>Rav Huna and Rav Yehuda</b> is <b>Rav’s</b> opinion, as <b>Rav Giddel said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In the case of <b>the New Moon that occurs on Shabbat, the one who recites the portion from the Prophets [<i>haftara</i>] on Shabbat need not mention the New Moon</b> in the blessing, <b>as, if</b> it <b>were not Shabbat, there would be no</b> reading from <b>the Prophets on the New Moon.</b> The <i>haftara</i> is unrelated to the New Moon, and therefore the New Moon is not mentioned in the blessing. The same should be true with regard to mention of Hanukkah in the additional service on the New Moon, as, if it were not the New Moon, he would not be reciting the additional service on Hanukkah. Therefore, when he recites the additional prayer, he need not mention Hanukkah.
The Gemara rejects this comparison. <b>Is</b> this <b>comparable? There,</b> reading from the <b>Prophets</b> is <b>not at all part of</b> the service <b>on the New Moon. Here, there is</b> mention of Hanukkah <b>in</b> the <b>evening, morning, and afternoon prayers. Rather,</b> it is <b>comparable to this:</b> As <b>Rav Aḥadvoi said</b> that <b>Rav Mattana said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> On <b>a Festival that occurs on Shabbat, one who recites the portion from the Prophets during the afternoon service on Shabbat need not mention the Festival, as, if</b> it were <b>not Shabbat, there would be no</b> reading from the <b>Prophets during the afternoon service on a Festival.</b> If so, even though there is a <i>haftara</i> during the morning service on a Festival, since they do not read from the Prophets in the afternoon, the reading is considered totally unrelated to the Festival and one does not mention the Festival. The same is true with regard to Hanukkah. One does not mention Hanukkah in the additional prayer.

Daf 24b

The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with any of these <i>halakhot</i>; rather,</b> it is <b>in accordance with that which Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> On <b>Yom Kippur that falls on Shabbat, one who recites</b> the day’s <b>closing prayer [<i>ne</i>’<i>ila</i>] must mention Shabbat</b> even in that prayer, although <i>ne</i>’<i>ila</i> is not recited every Shabbat. The reason for this is that on Yom Kippur, the <b>day</b> itself <b>is obligated in four prayers,</b> i.e., morning, additional, afternoon, and closing. When it occurs on Shabbat, one must mention Shabbat in each of the prayers. Apparently, on a day that has a unique character, that character is manifest in all sacred aspects of the day; those engendered by the day itself as well as those engendered by other factors.
The Gemara challenges this: It is <b>difficult,</b> as there is a contradiction between one <b><i>halakha</i></b> and another <b><i>halakha</i>.</b> On the one hand, <b>you said</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi. And,</b> on the other hand, <b>we hold</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava,</b> which contradicts the first <i>halakha</i>, <b>as Rava said:</b> On <b>a Festival that occurs on Shabbat, the prayer leader who descends before the ark</b> to recite the prayer abridged from the seven blessings of the Shabbat <b>evening</b> <i>Amida</i> <b>prayer need not mention</b> the <b>Festival, as, if it were not</b> also <b>Shabbat, the prayer leader would not descend before the ark</b> to recite this prayer during <b>the evening prayer on a Festival.</b> The Gemara reverts to the previous assumption that an element that does not arise from the essential <i>halakhot</i> of the day is considered foreign to it and is not mentioned.
This challenge is rejected: <b>How can you compare? There, actually, even on Shabbat,</b> the prayer leader <b>need not</b> repeat the prayer, just as the prayer is not repeated any other evening. <b>It was the Sages who instituted</b> repetition of the prayer <b>due to</b> concern for potential <b>danger.</b> The Sages sought to slightly delay those leaving the synagogue to enable people who came late to leave together with the rest of the worshippers. This was necessary because synagogues were often located beyond the city limits, and it was dangerous to walk alone at night. This repetition of the prayer does not stem from the obligation of the day but was instituted for another purpose. <b>However, here,</b> on Yom Kippur, <b>it is the day that is obligated in four prayers,</b> and therefore on each day that there are added prayers, one must mention the events that occurred on that day in those prayers just as he does in all the standard prayers.
<b>And</b> we learned in the mishna that <b>one may not</b> light <b>with the sheep’s tail</b> or with fat. Naḥum the Mede says that one may light using cooked fat. And the Rabbis say that one may not light with it whether or not it is cooked. The Gemara asks: Isn’t the opinion of the <b>Rabbis identical</b> to the unattributed opinion of the <b>first <i>tanna</i></b> in the mishna? The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them is</b> with regard to what <b>Rav Beruna said</b> that <b>Rav</b> said that one may light with cooked fat to which oil was added. One of the <i>tanna</i>’<i>im</i> accepts this opinion as <i>halakha</i> and permits lighting with it, and the other prohibits it, <b>and</b> the opinions <b>are not defined.</b> Although it seems from the formulation of the mishna that they differ on this point, it is unclear what the opinion of each <i>tanna</i> is.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In continuation of the previous mishna, this mishna adds that <b>one may not light with burnt oil on a Festival,</b> as the Gemara will explain below. With regard to lighting Shabbat lamps, there were Sages who prohibited the use of specific oils. <b>Rabbi Yishmael says</b> that <b>one may not light with tar [<i>itran</i>] in deference to Shabbat</b> because tar smells bad and disturbs those in the house. <b>And the Rabbis permit</b> lighting <b>with all oils</b> for lamps as long as they burn properly; <b>with sesame oil, with nut oil, with turnip oil, with fish oil, with gourd oil, with tar, and</b> even <b>with naphtha [<i>neft</i>]. Rabbi Tarfon says: One may light only with olive oil</b> in deference to Shabbat, as it is the choicest and most pleasant of the oils.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the statement of the mishna that one may not light with burnt oil on a Festival, the Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara answers: <b>Because,</b> in general, <b>one may not burn consecrated items on a Festival.</b> With regard to the fundamental principle that one may not burn consecrated items on a Festival, the Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Ḥizkiya said, and</b> one of the Sages <b>from the school of Ḥizkiya taught the same,</b> that which <b>the verse said: “And you shall let nothing of it remain until morning; but that which remains of it until morning</b> you shall burn with fire” (Exodus 12:10), requires explanation. <b>As the Torah did not need to state until morning</b> the second time. It would have been sufficient to state: But that which remains of it you shall burn with fire. Rather, <b>why does the Torah state until morning? The verse comes to provide him</b> with <b>the second morning for burning.</b> Leftover meat of the Paschal lamb is not burned on the following morning, which is a Festival, but rather on the following day, the first of the intermediate days of the Festival. From there it is derived that burning consecrated items on a Festival is prohibited.
<b>Abaye said:</b> This is derived from another verse, as <b>the verse said: “This is the burnt-offering of each Shabbat on its Shabbat”</b> (Numbers 28:10). Only the burnt-offering of Shabbat is sacrificed on Shabbat, <b>and not a weekday burnt-offering on Shabbat, and not a weekday burnt-offering on a Festival.</b> Apparently, performing this mitzva is prohibited even on a Festival, since it was not explicitly enumerated among the actions permitted on a Festival.
<b>Rava said:</b> This is derived from a different verse, as <b>the verse said</b> with regard to the laws of a Festival: “No manner of work shall be done in them, save that which every man must eat, <b>that alone may be done by you”</b> (Exodus 12:16). From the word <b>that,</b> it is derived that for sustenance, one is permitted to perform prohibited labor on a Festival, <b>but not</b> for <b>facilitators</b> of sustenance. Although cooking is permitted, actions that involve prohibited labors for the purpose of facilitating cooking are prohibited. From the word <b>alone,</b> it is derived: <b>And not circumcision</b> performed <b>not at its</b> appointed <b>time,</b> i.e., a circumcision may be performed on a Festival only if it is on the eighth day. A circumcision that was postponed may not be performed on a Festival. It is possible <b>that</b> license to perform the postponed circumcision on a Festival could have been <b>derived by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference.</b> Therefore, the verse explicitly prohibited doing so. The same is true with regard to burning consecrated items. Although the Torah commands burning consecrated items, it was not permitted on a Festival since there is no obligation to do so specifically on that day.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> It is derived from a different source. In the verses that speak of the Festivals, as opposed to the term <b>Shabbat,</b> the term <b><i>shabbaton</i></b> (Leviticus 23:24) appears.

Daf 25a

The latter term is a positive <b>mitzva</b> to rest. <b>And,</b> if so, observance of <b>a Festival is</b> a mitzva that was commanded with both <b>a positive mitzva</b> to rest <b>and a prohibition:</b> “You shall do no manner of servile work” (Leviticus 23:8). <b>And</b> there is a principle that <b>a positive mitzva,</b> e.g., burning consecrated items whose time has expired, <b>does not override</b> a mitzva that was commanded with both <b>a prohibition and a positive mitzva,</b> e.g., observance of the Festival.
By inference, the conclusion is that, specifically <b>on a Festival,</b> lighting with burnt oil <b>is prohibited.</b> During the week one may <b>well</b> do so. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this distinction? It would be reasonable to say that it is prohibited to derive any benefit from <i>teruma</i> that became ritually impure. <b>Rav said: Just as there is a mitzva to burn consecrated items that became ritually impure, so too, there is a mitzva to burn <i>teruma</i> that became ritually impure, and</b> the <b>Torah said: While it is being destroyed, derive benefit from it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Where did the Torah say</b> this? Where is there an allusion to this in the Bible? The Gemara answers: It can be derived <b>from</b> the statement of <b>Rav Naḥman,</b> as <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: The verse said: “And I, behold, I have given you the charge of My <i>terumot</i>”</b> (Numbers 18:8). From the amplification of the plural: My <i>terumot</i>, it is derived that <b>the verse is speaking of two <i>terumot</i>, one <i>teruma</i> that is ritually pure and one <i>teruma</i> that is ritually impure. And God said: “</b>I have given <b>you,”</b> i.e., <b>it shall be yours,</b> and you may derive benefit from it. Since there is a stringent prohibition against eating it, the benefit permitted is <b>to burn it beneath your cooked dish.</b> Similar forms of benefit may also be derived from burning <i>teruma</i>.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead an alternative manner to derive this <i>halakha</i>, from the statement of <b>Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It is written in the confession of the tithes: <b>“</b>I have not eaten thereof in my mourning, <b>neither have I destroyed from it while impure”</b> (Deuteronomy 26:14). By inference: <b>From it you may not destroy, but you may destroy the oil of <i>teruma</i> that has become ritually impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> differently: <b>From it you may not destroy, but you may destroy</b> and derive benefit from burning <b>consecrated oil that became ritually impure.</b>
The Gemara responds: That possibility is unacceptable. Is it <b>not an <i>a fortiori</i> inference? If</b> with regard to <b>the tithe which is lenient, the Torah said: Neither have I destroyed from it, while impure, items consecrated</b> to the Temple, <b>which are</b> more <b>stringent, all the more so</b> that it is prohibited to burn it while ritually impure.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>If so,</b> that this matter is derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, then, with regard to <b><i>teruma</i> as well, let us say</b> that <b>it is an <i>a fortiori</i> inference,</b> as <i>teruma</i> is more stringent than tithes. If it is prohibited to benefit from tithes while they are burning, all the more so would one be prohibited to benefit from the <i>teruma</i> while it is burning. The Gemara answers: <b>Doesn’t it say: From it?</b> From there it is derived that there is an item excluded from the prohibition of burning in ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that led you to conclude that “from it” comes to exclude <i>teruma</i>? Perhaps “from it” comes to exclude consecrated items. The Gemara replies: <b>It is reasonable</b> that <b>I do not exclude consecrated items</b> from the prohibition against benefiting from its burning, as with regard to consecrated items there are many stringent elements. <b>Their</b> Hebrew acronym is <b><i>peh</i>, <i>nun</i>, <i>kuf</i>, <i>ayin</i>, <i>kaf</i>, <i>samekh</i>,</b> which is a <b>mnemonic</b> for <b>the following terms. <i>Piggul</i>:</b> With regard to an offering, if, during one of the services involved in its sacrifice, i.e., slaughter, receiving the blood, bringing it to the altar, sprinkling it on the altar, the priest or the one bringing the offering entertains the thought of eating the sacrifice at a time that is unfit for eating, it is thereby invalidated. <b><i>Notar</i>:</b> Meat of a sacrifice that <b>remained</b> beyond its allotted time may not be eaten and must be burned. <b><i>Korban me</i>’<i>ila</i>:</b> One who unwittingly derives benefit from consecrated items is required to bring a guilt-<b>offering for misuse of consecrated items. <i>Karet</i>:</b> The punishment of one who eats consecrated items while ritually impure is <i>karet</i>. <b><i>Asur le</i>’<i>onen</i>: An acute mourner,</b> i.e., one whose relative died that same day and has not yet been buried, <b>is prohibited</b> to eat consecrated items. None of these <i>halakhot</i> applies to <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, consecrated items are more stringent than <i>teruma,</i> and therefore it is consecrated items that are not excluded from the prohibition against deriving benefit while ritually impure.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>On the contrary, it is <i>teruma</i> that I would not exclude</b> from the prohibition, <b>as,</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i>, there are many stringent elements represented by the acronym <b><i>mem</i>, <i>ḥet</i>, <i>peh</i>, <i>zayin</i>,</b> which is a <b>mnemonic</b> for the following: <b><i>Mita</i>:</b> One for whom <i>teruma</i> is prohibited who ate it intentionally is punishable by <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven. <b><i>Ḥomesh</i>:</b> A non-priest, for whom <i>teruma</i> is prohibited, who unwittingly ate <i>teruma</i> is obligated to pay its value to the priest plus <b>one-fifth</b> of the sum.

Daf 25b

<b>And,</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>does not have</b> the possibility of <b><i>pidyon</i>: redemption,</b> as, once it is sanctified, it may not be redeemed and rendered non-sacred. And it is <b>prohibited to <i>zarim</i>: non-priests</b> may not eat it. These stringencies do not apply to consecrated items. The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, <b>those</b> stringencies that apply to consecrated items <b>are more</b> numerous than those that apply to <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, it is appropriate to be more stringent with consecrated items and exclude impure <i>teruma</i> from the prohibition against deriving benefit when burning it.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead a different reason, without counting the number of stringencies: <b>Consecrated items are</b> more <b>stringent because</b> one who eats them while ritually impure is <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>,</b> while in the case of <i>teruma</i> the punishment is death at the hand of Heaven. In this regard, the Torah is more stringent vis-à-vis consecrated items than it is vis-à-vis <i>teruma</i>. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that there is a different proof that one is permitted to benefit from <i>teruma</i> while it is burning. As <b>the verse said:</b> “The first fruits of your grain, of your wine, and of your oil, and the first of the fleece of your sheep <b>shall you give him”</b> (Deuteronomy 18:4). The Sages derived from this verse: Give the priest <i>teruma</i> that is ritually pure, that is fit for <b>him</b> to consume, <b>and</b> do <b>not</b> give the priest <i>teruma</i> that is suitable only <b>for his fire,</b> to be burned. <b>By inference,</b> ritually impure <i>teruma</i> <b>is suitable for his fire,</b> i.e., a priest may derive benefit from it.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yishmael says</b> that kindling a lamp on Shabbat with tar is prohibited. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Rava said: Because its odor is bad</b> the Sages issued a <b>decree</b> prohibiting the use of tar, <b>lest one forsake</b> the light <b>and leave. Abaye said to him: And let him leave.</b> What obligation is there to sit next to the light? Rava <b>said to him: Because I say</b> that <b>kindling Shabbat lights</b> is <b>an obligation,</b> and one is required to eat specifically by that light in deference to Shabbat. As <b>Rav Naḥman bar Rav Zavda said, and others say</b> that it was <b>Rav Naḥman bar Rava</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>Rav said: Kindling the Shabbat lamps</b> is <b>an obligation,</b> whereas <b>washing</b> one’s <b>hands and feet with hot water in the evening</b> prior to Shabbat is merely <b>optional. And I say:</b> Washing is not merely optional; it is a <b>mitzva</b> even though it is not an obligation.
The Gemara asks: <b>What mitzva</b> is there? The Gemara explains that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: This was the custom of Rabbi Yehuda bar Elai:</b> On <b>Shabbat eve,</b> they <b>would bring him a bowl full of hot water and</b> he would use it to <b>wash his face, hands, and feet, and he would wrap himself, and sit in</b> linen <b>cloaks with ritual fringes, and</b> he was <b>like an angel of the Lord of hosts.</b> He did all this in deference to Shabbat. <b>And</b> the Gemara relates that <b>his students,</b> who also sat wrapped in linen cloaks, <b>would conceal the corners of their garments from him</b> so that he would not see that they did not have ritual fringes on their garments. <b>He said to them: My sons, did I not teach you</b> with regard to the obligation to attach ritual fringes to <b>a</b> linen <b>cloak: Beit Shammai exempt</b> the linen sheet because at least part of the ritual fringes is always made from wool, and there is a Torah prohibition against a mixture of wool and linen that applies even to ritual fringes? <b>And Beit Hillel obligate</b> linen sheets in the mitzva of ritual fringes, as they hold that the positive mitzva of ritual fringes overrides the prohibition of mixing wool and linen. <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel,</b> and therefore the sheets require ritual fringes. <b>And</b> the students <b>held:</b> Although it is permitted by Torah law to attach ritual fringes to a linen garment, the Sages issued a <b>decree</b> that one may not do so <b>due to garments</b> worn at <b>night.</b> The Sages were concerned lest a person wear this cloak at night. Since one is not obligated in the mitzva of ritual fringes at night, he would be wearing the prohibited mixture of wool and linen at a time when he is not fulfilling the mitzva of ritual fringes. Therefore, attaching ritual fringes made of wool to a linen garment is prohibited, even to a garment worn during the day.
Since bathing as preparation for enjoyment of Shabbat was discussed, the Gemara cites the homiletic interpretation of the verse describing those heading into exile: <b>“And my soul is removed far off from peace, I forgot prosperity”</b> (Lamentations 3:17). <b>What</b> is: <b>And my soul is removed far off from peace? Rabbi Abbahu said: That is</b> the lack of opportunity to engage in <b>kindling the Shabbat lights,</b> which a refugee is unable to do. <b>I forgot prosperity, Rabbi Yirmeya said: That is</b> the lack of opportunity to bathe in <b>the bathhouse. Rabbi Yoḥanan said: That is</b> the lack of opportunity to engage in <b>washing one’s hands and feet in hot water. Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa said:</b> Prosperity <b>is a pleasant bed and</b> the <b>pleasant bedclothes that are on it,</b> which are not available in exile. <b>Rabbi Abba said: That is a made bed, and a wife adorned,</b> i.e., worthy of and suitable (Rashba) <b>for Torah scholars.</b>
Incidental to the discussion of prosperity, the Gemara mentions that on a similar topic, <b>the Sages taught: Who is wealthy? Anyone who gets pleasure from his wealth,</b> that is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. The letters <i>mem</i></b> (Meir), <b><i>tet</i></b> (Tarfon), <b><i>kuf</i></b> (Akiva), <b><i>samekh</i></b> (Yosei) are a <b>mnemonic</b> for the <i>tannaim</i> who expressed opinions on this matter. <b>Rabbi Tarfon says:</b> A wealthy person is <b>anyone who has one hundred vineyards, and one hundred fields, and one hundred slaves working in them. Rabbi Akiva says: Anyone who has a wife whose actions are pleasant. Rabbi Yosei says: Anyone who has a bathroom close to his table.</b>
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: One may not light</b> on Shabbat <b>with sap from balsam trees [<i>tzori</i>].</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Rabba said: Since its pleasant smell diffuses,</b> the Sages were concerned <b>lest</b> one forget and come to <b>take</b> some sap <b>from it</b> on Shabbat. That is tantamount to extinguishing the lamp, as removing oil from a burning lamp curtails the amount of time that it will burn. <b>Abaye said to him:</b>

Daf 26a

<b>Let the Master say</b> a different reason: <b>Because</b> tar <b>is volatile,</b> i.e., it is liable to evaporate quickly and cause a fire. The Gemara answers: <b>He stated one</b> reason <b>and another: One, because it is volatile</b> and potentially dangerous; <b>and, furthermore,</b> due to <b>a decree lest one take</b> sap <b>from it.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>A mother-in-law who hated her daughter-in-law said to her: Go adorn yourself with balsam oil. She went</b> and <b>adorned herself. When she came,</b> her mother-in-law <b>said to her: Go light the lamp. She went</b> and <b>lit the lamp. She caught fire and was burned.</b>
Since balsam oil was discussed, the Gemara cites the verse: <b>“But Nebuzaradan the captain of the guard left of the poorest of the land to be vinedressers and husbandmen”</b> (Jeremiah 52:16). The Gemara explains the verse: With regard to <b>vinedressers, Rav Yosef taught: These</b> poorest of the land were <b>the balsam collectors</b> in the south of Eretz Yisrael, in the expanse <b>from Ein Gedi to Ramata. And</b> the <b>husbandmen; these are the trappers of the snail [<i>ḥilazon</i>],</b> from which the sky blue dye is produced in the north of the country, in the area <b>between the Promontory of Tyre and Ḥaifa.</b> Only a small number of poor people could barely eke out a living from these tasks, which involved mere gathering.
<b>The Sages taught: One may not light with ritually impure untithed produce [<i>tevel</i>] during the week, and needless to say</b> one may not light with it <b>on Shabbat. On a similar note, one may not light with white naphtha during the week, and needless to say</b> one may not light with it <b>on Shabbat. Granted,</b> with regard to <b>white naphtha,</b> its prohibition is understandable <b>because it is volatile</b> and potentially dangerous. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>ritually impure <i>tevel</i>, what is the reason</b> that the Sages prohibited lighting with it?
The Gemara answers that <b>the verse said: “And I, behold, I have given you the charge of My <i>terumot</i>”</b> (Numbers 18:8). From the fact that <i>terumot</i> is plural, the Sages derived that <b>the verse is speaking of two</b> <i>terumot</i>: <b>Both</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>that is ritually pure and</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>that is ritually impure. Just as</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i> that is ritually pure, you,</b> the priest, <b>have</b> permission to benefit <b>from it only from the time</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>was separated and onward, so too,</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i> that is ritually impure, you have</b> permission to benefit from <b>it only from the time</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>was separated and onward.</b> Since a portion of the untithed produce is <i>teruma</i> that has not yet been separated, it is prohibited even for a priest to use it.
The Gemara proceeds to discuss <b>the matter</b> of the <i>Tosefta</i> <b>itself,</b> the case of lighting with sap from balsam trees on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: One may not light with <i>tzori</i></b> on Shabbat. <b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar would also say: <i>Tzori</i>,</b> which is one of the component spices of the incense in the Temple, <b>is merely the sap</b> that emerges <b>from balsam trees,</b> and is not part of the balsam tree itself. <b>Rabbi Yishmael says: Anything that originates from the tree, one may not light with it;</b> only materials that do not come from trees may be used. <b>Rabbi Yishmael ben Beroka says: One may only light with</b> a substance <b>that emerges from the fruit. Rabbi Tarfon says: One may only light with olive oil alone.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri stood on his feet and,</b> contrary to this statement, <b>said: And what shall the people of Babylonia, who have only sesame oil, do? And what shall the people of Medea, who have only nut oil, do? And what shall the people of Alexandria, who have only radish oil, do? And what shall the people of Cappadocia, who have neither this nor that but only naphtha, do? Rather, you have</b> a prohibition <b>only</b> with regard to those substances with regard to <b>which the Sages said: One may not light with them.</b> All other oils are permitted.
<b>And one may light with fish oil and tar. Rabbi Shimon Shezuri says: One may light with gourd oil and naphtha. Sumakhos says: Among the</b> substances <b>that emerge from the flesh</b> of living beings, <b>one may light only with fish oil.</b> The Gemara asks: The opinion of <b>Sumakhos</b> is identical to the opinion of the <b>first <i>tanna</i>,</b> who also permits lighting with fish oil. The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to what <b>Rav Beruna said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> One is permitted to use molten fat to which oil was added for lighting. They disagree with regard to this <i>halakha</i>; however, their opinions <b>are not defined</b> and it is unclear which of them permits using it and which prohibits using it.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Anything that emerges from the tree</b> does <b>not have</b> the legal status of an area of <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths. Even if it is three by three fingerbreadths, it is not considered sufficiently large to become ritually impure. <b>And,</b> therefore, <b>one may roof</b> his <i>sukka</i> <b>with it,</b> as the roofing of his <i>sukka</i> may not be made from any material that can become ritually impure. This is the case for everything that originates from a tree <b>with the exception of linen,</b> which has a unique legal status. <b>Abaye said:</b>

Daf 26b

<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> and the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael</b> essentially <b>said the same thing,</b> even though they said it in different ways. The Gemara elaborates: The statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> is <b>that which we said:</b> The only fabrics woven from plant materials that are considered bona fide fabrics are those made of linen. <b>What is</b> the statement of the <b><i>tanna</i> from the school</b> of <b>Rabbi Yishmael? As it was taught</b> in <b>the school</b> of <b>Rabbi Yishmael: Since</b> the word <b>garments is stated in the Torah unmodified,</b> without stating from what materials those garments were made, <b>and the verse specified in one of</b> its references to garments, in the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity of leprosy, <b>wool and linen:</b> “And the garment in which there will be the plague of leprosy, whether it be a woolen garment, or a linen garment” (Leviticus 13:47), the conclusion can be drawn: <b>Just as below,</b> when it mentions a garment in the case of leprosy, the Torah is referring to one made of <b>wool</b> or <b>linen, so too, all</b> garments mentioned in the Torah are those made from <b>wool</b> or <b>linen.</b> Other fabrics are not classified as garments.
In contrast to Abaye, who viewed the opinions expressed by Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar and the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael as expressing the same idea, <b>Rava said</b> that the two opinions are not identical. <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> when the cloth is <b>three by three</b> handbreadths, <b>with regard to other garments</b> that are neither wool nor linen. <b>As Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> says explicitly: If it is less than three by three fingerbreadths, indicating that he <b>is of</b> the opinion that a cloth that is three by three handbreadths that is suitable for use even by wealthy people can become ritually impure. In his opinion, the uniqueness of linen fabric is not that it can become ritually impure, but rather that a linen rag, even if it is very small, can become ritually impure. The <i>tanna</i> <b>of the school of Rabbi Yishmael is not of</b> the opinion that other garments can become ritually impure.
<b>In any case,</b> based on the above, <b>everyone agrees</b> that, clearly, <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths <b>in</b> a <b>wool</b> or <b>linen</b> garment can <b>become ritually impure with</b> the impurity of <b>leprosy.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? The Gemara responds that it is derived <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to this matter. When the Torah states: <b>Garment,</b> unmodified, <b>I have</b> derived that <b>nothing other</b> than a whole <b>garment</b> can become ritually impure. However, with regard to a cloth that is <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths, <b>from where</b> do I derive that it is also included in this <i>halakha</i>? <b>The verse states: “And the garment</b> in which there will be the plague of leprosy” (Leviticus 13:47). From the addition of the word: And the garment [<i>vehabeged</i>], it is derived that all woven swatches are subsumed within the category of garment in this matter. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> perhaps <b>say</b> that it comes <b>to include</b> a woven garment that is <b>three by three</b> handbreadths? The Gemara answers: That is inconceivable. <b>Is that not</b> derived through <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference?</b> As, <b>now,</b> even the threads of the <b>warp</b> or the threads of the <b>woof</b> can <b>become ritually impure, is it necessary</b> to mention that a cloth <b>three by three</b> handbreadths can become ritually impure as well? A garment that is three by three handbreadths is comprised of several warp and woof threads that can themselves become ritually impure.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>If so,</b> then <b>let us also derive</b> a cloth that is <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths through the same <b><i>a fortiori</i> inference</b> from the warp and woof threads. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that this <i>a fortiori</i> inference is flawed. Threads woven into fabric do not maintain their previous status as they are no longer suitable to be used as warp and woof threads. <b>Rather,</b> cloths that are <b>three by three</b> handbreadths, <b>which are suitable</b> for use <b>by both the wealthy and the poor</b> as they are multipurpose cloths, can <b>be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference,</b> as they are certainly more significant than the warp and woof threads and they become ritually impure. However, cloths that are <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths, which <b>are suitable for</b> use by <b>the poor</b> but <b>are unsuitable for</b> use by <b>the wealthy, are not derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference.</b> Therefore, <b>the reason</b> that they can become ritually impure is specifically <b>because it was written in the Torah. Had it not been written in the Torah, we would not derive</b> it <b>through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference.</b>
The Gemara also asks: Indeed, there is amplification in the Torah, derived from the term: And the garment, which is a generalization that comes to expand upon the details that follow. <b>And say</b> that it comes <b>to include</b> the ruling that cloth that is <b>three by three</b> handbreadths <b>in garments</b> made of materials <b>other</b> than wool or linen can become ritually impure. The Gemara answers: That is inconceivable. <b>The verse said: A garment of wool</b> or <b>linen,</b> indicating that a garment made of <b>wool</b> or <b>linen, yes,</b> it becomes ritually impure; a garment made of <b>other materials, no,</b> it does not become ritually impure. The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> that <b>when</b> the verse <b>excluded,</b> it excluded specifically a garment that is <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths; <b>however,</b> a garment that is <b>three by three</b> handbreadths <b>can become ritually impure.</b> The Gemara replies: <b>Two exclusions are written;</b> once it is stated: “A garment of wool or linen” (Leviticus 13:59), and it is also stated: <b>“Whether it be a woolen garment, or a linen garment” (</b>Leviticus 13:47). <b>One</b> verse comes <b>to exclude</b> cloth of <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths, <b>and one</b> verse comes <b>to exclude</b> cloth of <b>three by three</b> handbreadths, to emphasize that a garment made of a material that is neither wool nor linen cannot become ritually impure at all. This corresponds to Abaye’s opinion that garments not made of wool or linen cannot become ritually impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, who said</b> that the practical difference <b>between</b> the two opinions is with regard to cloth <b>three by three</b> handbreadths <b>in other garments, that Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar is of</b> the opinion that they can become ritually impure, whereas the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael is not of</b> the opinion that they can become ritually impure, in the case of a cloth that is <b>three by three</b> handbreadths <b>in other garments,</b>

Daf 27a

<b>from where does Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> derive that it can become ritually impure? The Gemara answers: In his opinion, it <b>is derived from</b> the verse that speaks of the ritual impurity of creeping animals: <b>“Or a garment,</b> or skin, or sack” (Leviticus 11:32). The additional “or” comes to include items that are not generally included in the definition of garment. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: From the fact that it says <b>garment, I have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than <b>a</b> whole <b>garment;</b> however, a swatch that is <b>three by three</b> handbreadths <b>in other garments, from where</b> is it derived that it can become ritually impure? <b>The verse states: Or a garment.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And Abaye,</b> who says that everyone agrees that other garments do not become ritually impure at all, <b>this</b> phrase: <b>Or a garment, what does he do with it</b> and what does it come to add? The Gemara answers: <b>He needs it to include</b> a small swatch of fabric that is <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths made <b>of wool or linen.</b> Despite its size, <b>it can become ritually impure from</b> contact with <b>creeping animals.</b>
<b>And Rava</b> holds that there is no need for the verse to discuss that matter explicitly, as <b>the Torah revealed in the case of leprosy</b> that it is considered to be a garment, <b>and the same is true with regard to</b> the ritual impurity of <b>creeping animals.</b>
<b>And Abaye</b> holds that one cannot derive the <i>halakhot</i> of creeping animals from the <i>halakhot</i> of leprosy, as <b>there is room to refute</b> that comparison in the following manner: <b>What</b> comparison is there to <b>leprosy,</b> which has more stringent <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity, <b>as</b> even the <b>warp and woof</b> threads alone <b>can become ritually impure from it,</b> which is not the case with regard to ritual impurity from creeping animals? Therefore, even small scraps can become ritually impure from leprosy.
<b>The other</b> <i>amora</i>, Rava, <b>says: If it should enter your mind</b> to say that <b>leprosy is more stringent,</b> then <b>the Torah should have written</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to creeping animals, and let leprosy be derived from them.</b> Ultimately, the two <i>halakhot</i> are paralleled to one another in the Torah. It would have been simpler to explicitly write the laws of creeping animals and to derive leprosy from them. Since that is not the case, it is proof that the <i>halakhot</i> of creeping animals can be derived from leprosy.
<b>The other</b> <i>amora</i>, Abaye, said that this contention is fundamentally unsound, as <b>leprosy could not be derived from creeping animals because there is room to refute</b> this idea and challenge: <b>What</b> is the comparison <b>to</b> the ritual impurity of <b>creeping animals,</b> which is more stringent than the ritual impurity of leprosy, <b>as</b> the creeping animal <b>makes one ritually impure</b> even <b>in</b> a case where it is <b>a lentil-bulk,</b> which is not true of other types of ritual impurity? Therefore, verses were necessary to teach about the ritual impurity of both creeping animals and leprosy.
<b>Abaye said: This</b> statement of the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael diverges from another</b> statement of the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, as</b> the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> From the fact that the verse says <b>garment, I have</b> derived <b>nothing other than</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a garment of wool or linen</b> can become ritually impure. However, <b>from where</b> is it derived to <b>include</b> garments made of <b>camels’ hair and rabbits’ wool, goats’ hair or</b> the types of silk, <b>the <i>shirayin</i>, the <i>kalakh</i>, and the <i>serikin</i></b> among the fabrics that can become ritually impure? <b>The verse states: Or a garment.</b> The word “or” serves as an amplification to include all types of fabric.
Whereas <b>Rava said:</b> There is no need to say that there is a dispute in this case between two <i>tanna</i>’<i>im</i> from a single school. Rather, <b>when this <i>tanna</i> from the school</b> of <b>Rabbi Yishmael,</b> quoted above, <b>is not of</b> the opinion that there is ritual impurity <b>in other garments,</b> it is only with regard to a swatch that is <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths; however, with regard to a cloth that is <b>three by three</b> handbreadths <b>he is</b> of the opinion that it becomes ritually impure. His previous statement came to exclude a small garment from becoming ritually impure. This statement is referring to a larger garment that is three by three handbreadths.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t Rava</b> the one who <b>said</b> above that, in the case of <b>three by three</b> handbreadths <b>in other garments, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar is</b> of the opinion that they can become ritually impure, whereas <b>the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael is not</b> of the opinion that they become ritually impure? The Gemara answers: <b>Rava retracted that opinion</b> in order to reconcile the opinions of the <i>tanna</i>’<i>im</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead a different answer: <b>Rav Pappa said this</b> statement and not Rava. Since Rav Pappa was the primary disciple of Rava, the Gemara attributed his statement to Rava.
<b>Rav Pappa</b> himself understood the first statement of the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael and <b>stated</b> it in a completely different manner. In his opinion, the derivation from the <i>halakhot</i> of leprosy, which concluded that <b>even all</b> nonspecific mentions of garments in the Torah refer to wool or linen, came <b>to include</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>diverse kinds,</b> the Torah prohibition to wear clothing made from a mixture of wool and linen threads. He sought to prove that the <i>halakhot</i> of prohibited mixtures of threads apply only to wool and linen. The Gemara asks: Why does he require this derivation with regard to the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds?</b> The fact that the prohibition is limited to wool and linen is <b>explicitly written,</b> as it is stated: <b>“You shall not wear diverse kinds, wool and linen together”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:11). The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, an additional derivation was necessary, as <b>it would have entered your mind to say</b> that <b>this,</b> the restriction of the prohibition of diverse kinds to wool and linen, <b>applies</b> specifically to a case when one uses them together <b>in the manner of wearing</b> them; <b>however, in</b> merely <b>placing</b> the garments upon oneself, <b>any two kinds are prohibited.</b> Therefore, it was necessary to derive that the garment mentioned is restricted to wool and linen.
This claim is rejected: <b>And is it not an <i>a fortiori</i> inference? Just as</b> in the case of <b>wearing</b> the garment, <b>where one’s entire body derives benefit from</b> the <b>diverse kinds, you said</b> that <b>wool and linen, yes,</b> are included in the prohibition, <b>other materials, no,</b> are not included; in the case of merely <b>placing</b> the garment upon himself, <b>all the more so</b> that the <i>halakha</i> should not be more stringent. <b>Rather,</b> certainly the <i>halakha</i> that was attributed to <b>Rav Pappa is a mistake,</b> and he did not say it.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</b> also <b>said</b> that those statements of the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael do not refer to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity. They refer to another topic. In his opinion, the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael came to say that just as the <i>halakhot</i> of leprosy are limited to garments made from wool or linen, <b>so too, all</b>

Daf 27b

garments mentioned in the Torah are made from wool and linen. This comes <b>to include</b> the law of <b>ritual fringes;</b> the obligation of ritual fringes applies only to those materials. The Gemara asks: Why is that derivation necessary? With regard to <b>ritual fringes it is written explicitly: “You shall not wear diverse kinds, wool and linen</b> together” (Deuteronomy 22:11); <b>and</b> juxtaposed to it, <b>it is written: “You shall make for you twisted fringes</b> upon the four corners of your covering, with which you cover yourself” (Deuteronomy 22:12). From the juxtaposition of these two verses it is derived that the mitzva of ritual fringes applies only to garments to which the laws of diverse kinds apply. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak responded that the matter is not so clear, as <b>it could have entered your mind to say in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rava. As Rava raised a contradiction:</b> On the one hand, <b>it is written:</b> “And that they put with the fringe of each <b>corner</b> a thread of sky blue” (Numbers 15:39); apparently, the threads of the ritual fringes must be of the same <b>type</b> of fabric as the <b>corner</b> of the garment. <b>However,</b> in Deuteronomy, in the laws of ritual fringes, <b>it is written</b> in juxtaposition to the laws of diverse kinds: <b>Wool and linen together.</b> The ritual fringes may only be made of those materials. <b>How</b> can <b>that</b> contradiction be resolved? Rather, Rava says: Ritual fringes made of <b>wool and linen exempt</b> the garment and fulfill the obligation of ritual fringes <b>whether</b> the garment is <b>of their own type,</b> wool or linen, <b>whether it is not of their own type.</b> Whereas with regard to <b>other types,</b> a garment of <b>their</b> own <b>type, they exempt;</b> a garment <b>not</b> of <b>their</b> own <b>type, they do not exempt. It would have entered your mind</b> to explain this <b>in accordance with</b> the approach of <b>Rava.</b> Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught us</b> that the obligation of ritual fringes applies only to wool and linen and not to other materials.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said</b> to <b>Rav Ashi: According to</b> the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, what is different about ritual impurity that</b> he <b>includes other garments</b> not made of wool and linen <b>because it is written: Or a garment,</b> which is a term of amplification? <b>Here too,</b> in the matter of ritual fringes, <b>say that</b> it comes <b>to include other garments from</b> the phrase: Of your covering, <b>with which you cover yourself.</b> Rav Ashi answered: <b>That</b> amplification is necessary <b>to include the garment of a blind person</b> in the obligation of ritual fringes. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita,</i> with regard to ritual fringes it is stated: “And it shall be unto you for a fringe, <b>that you may look upon it</b> and remember all the mitzvot of the Lord” (Numbers 15:39). The phrase: That you may look, comes to <b>exclude a night garment,</b> which cannot be seen and is therefore exempt from the mitzva of ritual fringes. The <i>tanna</i> continues: Do <b>you say</b> that the verse comes to <b>exclude a night garment? Or is it only</b> to <b>exclude the garment of a blind person</b> who is also unable to fulfill the verse: That you may look upon it? The <i>tanna</i> explains: <b>When it says</b> in Deuteronomy: Of your covering, <b>with which you cover yourself, the garment of a blind person is mentioned,</b> as he too covers himself with a covering. If so, <b>then how do I fulfill</b> the exclusion: <b>That you may look upon it?</b> It comes to <b>exclude a night garment.</b>
The Gemara asks: Since there is one verse that includes and another verse that excludes, <b>what did you see</b> that led you <b>to include a blind person and to exclude a night garment</b> in the obligation of ritual fringes? The Gemara answers: <b>I include the garment of a blind person because it is,</b> at least, <b>visible to others, and I exclude a night garment because it is not</b> even <b>visible to others.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And say</b> that this amplification does not come to include a blind person’s garments, but rather, as Rava said, <b>to include other garments</b> not made from wool or linen in the obligation of ritual fringes. The Gemara answers: <b>It is logical</b> to say that since the Torah <b>is standing</b> and discussing a garment made of <b>wool</b> or <b>linen,</b> it <b>is</b> certainly <b>including</b> another garment made of <b>wool or linen.</b> Therefore, an amplification with regard to the garment of a blind person made of wool or linen is derived. However, when the Torah <b>is standing</b> and discussing a garment made from <b>wool</b> or <b>linen,</b> is it reasonable to say that it <b>is including other garments</b> with them? Rather, other garments are certainly not derived from there.
The Gemara returns to discuss the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, who disqualified even small cloths from being used as roofing in the <i>sukka</i> because they can become ritually impure. <b>Abaye said: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar and Sumakhos said the same thing.</b> The Gemara specifies: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar; that which we stated</b> above. <b>Sumakhos; as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Sumakhos says:</b> A <i>sukka</i> that he <b>roofed with</b> roofing made from <b>spun</b> thread <b>is disqualified because</b> spun thread <b>can become ritually impure from leprosy.</b>
<b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is Sumakhos’ statement? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Warp and woof can become ritually impure from leprosy immediately</b> after they are spun; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: The warp</b> can become ritually impure only <b>after it is removed</b> from the cauldron in which it is boiled, <b>and</b> it is only <b>the woof</b> that can become ritually impure <b>immediately. However, the bundles of unprocessed flax</b> can become ritually impure <b>after they are bleached</b> in the oven and their processing is at least half-completed. Sumakhos, the student of Rabbi Meir, adheres to his position.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Of <b>all</b> substances <b>that emerge from the tree, one may light only with flax</b> on Shabbat (<i>Tosafot</i>) because the other substances do not burn well. <b>And</b> of <b>all</b> substances <b>that emerge from the tree, the only</b> substance <b>that becomes ritually impure</b> with impurity transmitted by <b>tents</b> over a corpse <b>is flax.</b> If there is a dead body inside a house or a tent that is made from any materials that originate from a tree, everything in the house becomes ritually impure. However, only in the case of flax does the tent itself become impure.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna mentioned flax as a material that comes from a tree. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>flax is called a tree?</b> Based on appearance, it does not resemble a tree at all. <b>Mar Zutra said:</b> It is derived from that which the <b>verse said: “And she had taken them up to the roof and hidden them under the trees of flax”</b> (Joshua 2:6).
<b>And</b> we also learned in the mishna that with regard to <b>any</b> substance <b>that emerges from the tree, the only</b> substance <b>that becomes ritually impure</b> with impurity transmitted by <b>tents</b> over a corpse <b>is flax.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>learned</b> a verbal analogy [<i>gezera shava</i>] between the word <b>tent,</b> written in the context of ritual impurity, and the word <b>tent,</b>

Daf 28a

written in the context of the <b>Tabernacle. It is written here,</b> in the discussion of the laws of ritual impurity: <b>“This is the law: When a man dies in a tent,</b> every one that comes into the tent, and everything that is in the tent, shall be impure seven days” (Numbers 19:14), <b>and it is written there: “And he spread the tent over the Tabernacle,</b> and put the covering of the tent above upon it; as the Lord commanded Moses” (Exodus 40:19). <b>Just as below,</b> with regard to the Tabernacle, the tent was made <b>of linen</b> and <b>is considered a tent, so too, here,</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity imparted by a corpse, only a tent made <b>of linen is considered a tent.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> so, derive the following from that same verbal analogy: <b>Just as below</b> the linen threads in the Tabernacle were specifically threads that were <b>twisted</b> and <b>the threads were folded six times, so too, here,</b> in all of the <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to a tent over a corpse, the threads must be <b>twisted and their threads folded six times. The verse states</b> the word <b>tent, tent</b> several times to <b>amplify</b> and include even a tent made of linen not identical to the Tabernacle. The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the repetition of the word <b>tent, tent</b> several times <b>amplifies, even all things</b> should be included among those items that can receive ritual impurity as a tent. The Gemara answers: This amplification cannot be that far-reaching, as, <b>if so,</b> the <b>verbal analogy</b> of tent, tent, that teaches us to derive the tent over a corpse from the Tabernacle, <b>what purpose does it serve</b> if everything is included? Rather, certainly the amplification is not absolute. Through the combination of the verbal analogy and the amplification, it is derived that this <i>halakha</i> applies specifically to linen.
<b>And</b> perhaps <b>say: Just as below,</b> in the Tabernacle, there were <b>beams</b> supporting the tent, <b>so too, here,</b> in the laws of ritual impurity, a tent made of <b>beams</b> should also be considered a tent. The Gemara responds that <b>the verse said: “And you shall make the beams for the Tabernacle</b> of acacia wood, standing up” (Exodus 26:15). From the language of the verse, it is derived that the <b>Tabernacle,</b> i.e., the curtains alone, is <b>called Tabernacle, and</b> the <b>beams are not called Tabernacle,</b> because they merely facilitate the Tabernacle. The Gemara rejects this: <b>But if that is so,</b> based on an analysis of the language of the verse, it says there: <b>“And you shall make a covering for the tent</b> of rams’ skins dyed red and a covering of <i>teḥashim</i> above” (Exodus 26:14), then in <b>that</b> case, <b>too,</b> say that <b>the covering is not considered a tent.</b> If so, <b>however,</b> what of <b>the dilemma raised by Rabbi Elazar:</b> With regard to <b>the hide of a non-kosher animal</b> over a corpse, <b>what is</b> the ruling? <b>Can</b> it <b>become ritually impure as a tent over a corpse?</b> If the covering of the Tabernacle is not considered a tent, <b>now, the hide of a kosher animal</b> that covered the Tabernacle <b>cannot become ritually impure.</b> If that is so, <b>is it necessary to mention that the hide of a non-kosher animal</b> cannot become ritually impure? The Gemara answers: The cases are not comparable because <b>it is different there,</b> in the case of the covering of animal hides, <b>because the verse subsequently restored</b> its status as a tent by uniting the tent and its covering, <b>as it is written: “They shall bear the curtains of the Tabernacle, and the Tent of Meeting, its covering, and the covering of <i>taḥash</i> that is upon it”</b> (Numbers 4:25). The verse <b>juxtaposes the upper to the lower</b> covering; <b>just as</b> the <b>lower</b> covering <b>is considered a tent, so too,</b> the <b>upper</b> covering <b>is considered a tent.</b>
Rabbi Elazar’s dilemma was mentioned above, and now the Gemara discusses <b>the matter itself. Rabbi Elazar raised a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>the hide of a non-kosher animal</b> over a corpse, <b>what is</b> the ruling? <b>Can it become ritually impure as a tent</b> over a corpse? The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is</b> the essence of <b>his dilemma? Rav Adda bar Ahava said: The <i>taḥash</i> that existed in the time of Moses is</b> at the crux of Rabbi Elazar’s dilemma. <b>Was it non-kosher or was it kosher? Rav Yosef said: What is his dilemma?</b> Didn’t <b>we learn</b> explicitly: <b>Only the hide of a kosher animal was deemed suitable for heavenly service?</b> Certainly, the <i>taḥash</i> was a kosher species.
<b>Rabbi Abba raised an objection. Rabbi Yehuda says: There were two coverings</b> for the Tabernacle, <b>one</b> made <b>of the reddened hides of rams and one of the hides of <i>teḥashim</i>. Rabbi Neḥemya says: There was</b> only <b>one covering</b> for the Tabernacle, half of which was made of rams’ hides and half from the hides of <i>teḥashim</i>. <b>And</b> <i>teḥashim</i> <b>were similar to the</b> species of undomesticated animals called <b><i>tela ilan</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t a <i>tela ilan</i></b> a <b>non-kosher</b> creature? The Gemara emends this statement: <b>This is what</b> Rabbi Neḥemya intended <b>to say:</b> It was <b>like a <i>tela ilan</i> in that it was multicolored;</b> however, it was <b>not an</b> actual <b><i>tela ilan</i>. There,</b> the <i>tela ilan</i> is <b>non-kosher, and here,</b> the covering of the tent was made from <b>kosher</b> animals. <b>Rav Yosef said: If so, that is</b> the reason <b>that we translate</b> the word <i>taḥash</i> as <b><i>sasgona</i>,</b> which means <b>that it rejoices [<i>sas</i>] in</b> many <b>colors [<i>gevanim</i>].</b>
<b>Rava said</b> that the proof that <b>the hide of a non-kosher animal becomes ritually impure in a tent over a corpse</b> is derived <b>from here, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that it is stated in the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity of leprosy that the leprosy could be: “Either in the warp, or in the woof, whether they be of linen, or of wool; or in a hide, or in any thing made of hide” (Leviticus 13:48). The verse could have simply stated: <b>Or hide,</b> and it said instead: <b>Or in a hide.</b> The Sages said: These words, or in a hide, <b>amplify</b> to include <b>the hide of a non-kosher animal</b> as well as hide <b>that was afflicted in the hands of a priest,</b> i.e., before the owner showed it to the priest there was no leprosy but it became leprous while in the hands of the priest, that they too become ritually impure. If <b>one cut</b> pieces from each of these types <b>and made of them a single</b> cloth, <b>from where</b> is it derived that it can become ritually impure? <b>The verse states</b> from the broader amplification: <b>Or in anything made of hide.</b> The Gemara remarks: <b>There is</b> room <b>to refute</b> this parallel, rendering it impossible to derive the laws of ritual impurity imparted by a corpse from the laws of leprosy. <b>What</b> is the comparison <b>to leprosy</b> with regard to which the Torah is stringent, <b>as</b> even <b>the warp and woof</b> that have not been woven into a garment <b>can become ritually impure from it,</b> which is not the case in impurity imparted by a corpse?
<b>Rather,</b> one could say that <b>he derived</b> it <b>from</b> the laws of the ritual impurity of <b>creeping animals,</b> as it is stated with regard to them: “And upon whatsoever any of them, when they are dead, does fall, it shall be impure; whether it be any vessel of wood, or garment, or hide, or sack, whatsoever vessel it be, with which any work is done” (Leviticus 11:32). <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: From the use of the word <b>hide, I have</b> derived <b>nothing other</b> than the fact that <b>the hide of a kosher animal</b> becomes ritually impure from contact with a creeping animal; however, <b>from where</b> is it derived that <b>the hide of a non-kosher animal</b> can become ritually impure? This is derived from the amplification, as <b>the verse states: Or hide.</b> Since, with regard to the ritual impurity of creeping animals the laws of the hides of kosher and non-kosher animals are identical, it is derived that this is also true with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity imparted by a corpse. Once again, the Gemara says: <b>There is</b> room <b>to refute</b> this derivation and say: <b>What</b> is the comparison <b>to creeping animals,</b> as their legal status is stringent <b>because</b> they <b>become ritually impure</b> even if they are as small <b>as a lentil-bulk,</b> which is not true in the case of a corpse? In order for a corpse to transmit ritual impurity, it must be larger, an olive-bulk. Therefore, the Gemara says: If so, the case of <b>leprosy can prove</b> that the fact that creeping animals that are a lentil-bulk transmit impurity is not a factor in whether or not a non-kosher animal hide can become ritually impure. Leprosy that is a lentil-bulk does not transmit impurity and, nevertheless, the hide of a non-kosher animal becomes ritually impure from it. <b>And the derivation has reverted</b> to its starting point. <b>The aspect of this</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case <b>and the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case, as each case has its own unique stringencies. However, <b>their common denominator is that hide,</b> in general, <b>is ritually impure in</b> both cases, <b>and</b> the Torah <b>rendered the hide of a non-kosher animal equal</b> to <b>the hide of a kosher animal</b> in that it becomes ritually impure. <b>I will also bring</b> the additional <i>halakha</i> of a <b>tent over a corpse</b> made of the <b>hide of a non-kosher animal, and in</b> that case as well, <b>the hide of a non-kosher animal will be rendered equal to the hide of a kosher animal.</b>
<b>Rava from Barnish said to Rav Ashi: There is</b> still room <b>to refute</b> this statement and say: <b>What</b> is the comparison to leprosy and creeping animals? Their <b>common denominator is that they</b> both <b>transmit ritual impurity when smaller than an olive-bulk.</b> Can <b>you say</b> the same <b>in the case of a corpse, which only transmits ritual impurity when</b> it is at least <b>an olive-bulk?</b> Therefore, despite the differences between them, these two <i>halakhot</i> are both more stringent than the laws of ritual impurity imparted by a corpse, and the status of a non-kosher animal hide cannot be derived from them.
<b>Rather, Rava from Barnish said</b> it can be derived in the following manner:

Daf 28b

<b>It is derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from goats’ hair.</b> Although goats’ hair <b>does not become ritually impure from leprosy,</b> it does <b>become ritually impure as a tent over a corpse;</b> with regard to <b>the hide of a non-kosher animal that becomes ritually impure from leprosy, is it not the case that it becomes ritually impure as a tent over a corpse?</b>
Since the conclusion was that the hide of even a non-kosher animal can become ritually impure as a tent over a corpse, it is not necessary to assume that the covering of the Tabernacle was made specifically from the hide of a kosher animal. <b>And,</b> if so, <b>that which Rav Yosef taught: Only the hide of a kosher animal was suitable for heavenly service, for what <i>halakha</i></b> is that relevant, as it is clearly not relevant to the Tabernacle? The Gemara replies: This <i>halakha</i> was stated with regard <b>to phylacteries,</b> which may be prepared only from the hide of a kosher animal. The Gemara asks: <b>Phylacteries?</b> Why did Rav Yosef need to state that <i>halakha</i>? It is <b>written explicitly with regard to them:</b> “And it shall be for a sign unto you upon your hand, and for a memorial between your eyes, <b>that the law of the Lord may be in your mouth”</b> (Exodus 13:9). The Sages derived from there that the phylacteries must be prepared <b>from that which is permitted</b> to be eaten <b>in your mouth.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains that this <i>halakha</i> of Rav Yosef was said only with regard <b>to the leather</b> of the boxes that house the phylacteries, which must be crafted from the hide of a kosher animal. It was not referring to the parchment on which the portions of the Torah inserted into the phylacteries are written. The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Abaye say:</b> The obligation to make a letter <b><i>shin</i></b> protruding <b>on the phylacteries</b> of one’s head is a <b><i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai?</b> Since Torah law addresses the boxes of the phylacteries, presumably their legal status is parallel to that of the parchment and the prohibition against preparing them from the hide of a non-kosher animal is by Torah law as well.
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains that Rav Yosef’s <i>halakha</i> comes to teach that one must <b>tie</b> the parchments upon which the portions of the Torah are written in the phylacteries <b>with</b> a kosher animal’s <b>hair, as well as sew</b> the phylacteries <b>with</b> a kosher animal’s <b>sinews.</b> The Gemara asks: The source of <b>these</b> <i>halakhot</i> is <b>also</b> a <b><i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The requirement that <b>phylacteries</b> must be <b>square</b> is a <i>halakha</i> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai,</b> as is the requirement that they must be <b>tied with their hair and sewn with their sinews.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the Gemara says that Rav Yosef came to teach with regard <b>to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the straps</b> of the phylacteries. The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yitzḥak say:</b> The <b>straps</b> of the phylacteries must be <b>black</b> is a <i>halakha</i> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Although we learned</b> this <i>halakha</i>, which states that the straps must be <b>black, did we</b> also <b>learn</b> that they must be from <b>kosher</b> animals? Rav Yosef was certainly referring to straps when he said that all heavenly service must be performed with the hides of kosher animals.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the halakhic conclusion reached <b>about</b> this matter of the <b><i>taḥash</i> that existed in the days of Moses? Rabbi Ela said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said</b> that <b>Rabbi Meir used to say:</b> The <b><i>taḥash</i> that existed in the days of Moses was a creature unto itself, and the Sages did not determine whether it was a type of undomesticated animal or a type of domesticated animal. And it had a single horn on its forehead, and</b> this <i>taḥash</i> <b>happened</b> to come <b>to Moses for the moment</b> while the Tabernacle was being built, <b>and he made</b> the covering for <b>the Tabernacle from it. And</b> from then on, the <i>taḥash</i> <b>was suppressed</b> and is no longer found.
The Gemara comments: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it is said</b> that the <i>taḥash</i> <b>had a single horn on its forehead, conclude from this</b> that it was kosher, <b>as Rav Yehuda said</b> in a similar vein: The <b>ox that Adam, the first</b> man, <b>sacrificed</b> as a thanks-offering for his life being spared, <b>had a single horn on its forehead, as it is stated: “And it shall please the Lord better than a horned [<i>makrin</i>] and hooved ox”</b> (Psalms 69:32). The word <i>makrin</i> means one with a horn. The Gemara asks: On the contrary, <b><i>makrin</i> indicates</b> that it has <b>two</b> horns. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> Despite the fact that it is vocalized in the plural, <b>it is written <i>mikeren</i></b> without the letter <i>yod</i> to indicate that it had only a single horn. The Gemara asks: If so, <b>let us resolve from</b> the same <i>baraita</i> that just as it was derived from the ox of Adam, the first man, that an animal with one horn is kosher, derive that an animal with one horn <b>is a type of domesticated animal.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since there is</b> the <b><i>keresh</i> which is a type of undomesticated animal, and it has only a single horn, it</b> is also possible <b>to say</b> that the <i>taḥash</i> is <b>a type of undomesticated animal.</b> This dilemma was not resolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The wick of a garment,</b> i.e., cloth made into a wick for a lamp, <b>that one folded it</b> into a size and shape suitable for a wick, <b>but did not</b> yet <b>singe it</b> slightly in order to facilitate its lighting, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> This wick is <b>ritually impure.</b> With regard to the laws of ritual impurity, it can, like other garments, still become ritually impure <b>and one may not light with it</b> on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: It is ritually pure and one may</b> even <b>light with it</b> on Shabbat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, with regard to ritual impurity,</b> the reasons for their disagreement are clear and <b>this is</b> their <b>dispute: Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that <b>folding</b> alone <b>is ineffective</b> in altering the identity of the garment <b>and it retains its original status.</b> It can become ritually impure like any other garment. <b>Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that <b>folding is effective, and it negates</b> its garment status, and therefore, it can no longer become ritually impure.
<b>However, with regard to lighting</b> on Shabbat <b>what is</b> at the crux of their <b>dispute? Rabbi Elazar said</b> that <b>Rav Oshaya said, and Rav Adda bar Ahava said likewise: Here we are dealing with</b> a cloth that is <b>precisely three by three fingerbreadths and we are dealing with a Festival that occurred on Shabbat eve. And everyone is of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said that on a Festival one may</b> only <b>kindle</b> a fire <b>with</b> whole <b>vessels,</b> as it is permitted to carry them and they do not have set-aside [<i>muktze</i>] status; <b>however, one may not kindle</b> a fire <b>using broken vessels,</b> i.e., vessels that broke on the Festival. Since they broke on the Festival itself, they are classified as an entity that came into being [<i>nolad</i>] on the Festival, and the <i>halakha</i> prohibits moving them. <b>And,</b> similarly, <b>everyone is of</b> the opinion that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ulla,</b> as <b>Ulla said: One who lights</b> a lamp <b>must light most</b> of the wick <b>that protrudes</b> from the lamp. Based on these assumptions, the dispute in the mishna can be understood as follows: <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that <b>folding</b> alone <b>is ineffective</b> in negating the wick’s vessel status, <b>and once</b> one <b>lights</b> only <b>a small part of it, it</b> thereby <b>becomes a broken vessel,</b> as part of it burns and the remainder is less than three by three fingerbreadths. A smaller cloth is no longer considered significant. Since he is required to light most of the protruding wick and, as mentioned above, it is prohibited to light broken vessels, he may not light the folded garment. <b>And Rabbi Akiva held</b> that <b>folding is effective and,</b> immediately when he folded it, the garment <b>no longer has the status of a vessel.</b> It was not considered a vessel even before he lit it, <b>and when he lights</b> it, it is as if <b>he were lighting plain wood,</b> not a vessel that broke on the Festival.
<b>Rav Yosef said, that is what I learned: Three by three exactly. And I did not know to what <i>halakha</i></b> this was relevant. Rav Yosef received from his teachers that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case of three by three exactly, and he did not know why it was significant to establish the <i>baraita</i> in a case of exactly three by three and no more.
The Gemara adds incidentally: <b>And from the fact</b> that <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava interpreted</b> this mishna <b>in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, conclude from this</b> that <b>he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. Did Rav Adda bar Ahava</b> actually <b>say this? Didn’t Rav Adda bar Ahava</b> himself <b>say:</b>

Daf 29a

<b>When a gentile carved out a</b> vessel the size of a <b><i>kav</i></b> from a <b>piece of wood</b> on a Festival and thereby rendered it a new vessel, <b>a Jew may burn</b> the vessel <b>on a Festival</b> <i>ab initio</i>. <b>And why</b> may he do so? This new vessel that was made from the wood <b>is</b> an object that <b>came into being [<i>nolad</i>]</b> on a Festival, and is set-aside [<i>muktze</i>]. Since Rav Adda bar Ahava permitted doing so, apparently he holds that the laws of set-aside do not apply on a Festival, contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda. The Gemara answers: Rav Adda bar Ahava <b>said this</b> statement <b>in</b> explanation of <b>the statements</b> of <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Akiva</b> in the mishna; <b>however, he</b> himself <b>does not hold that way.</b> Although he explained the opinions in the mishna in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, he himself does not hold that that is the <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rava said, this is the reasoning</b> behind <b>Rabbi Eliezer’s</b> opinion with regard to lighting the wick: <b>Because</b> he holds <b>that one may neither light</b> on Shabbat <b>using a wick that is not</b> slightly <b>singed</b> and prepared for lighting <b>nor light with rags that were not singed</b> before Shabbat. If a person singes the wick slightly before lighting it, it will burn well. A wick that has not been singed does not burn well and will not show the appropriate deference to Shabbat. The Gemara asks: If so, <b>that which Rav Yosef taught: Three by three exactly, to what <i>halakha</i></b> is it relevant? According to Rava’s explanation, the precise size of the garment used in making the wick is irrelevant. The Gemara responds: Rav Yosef’s statement was <b>with regard to</b> another <b>matter,</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>ritual impurity. As we learned</b> in a mishna in tractate <i>Kelim</i>: <b>Three by three</b> fingerbreadths <b>that they stated</b> as the smallest sized garment that can become ritually impure, <b>excludes the</b> portion used for the <b>hem,</b> i.e., those threads that emerge at the edge of the garment and are sewn into a hem; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon. And the Rabbis say: Three by three exactly,</b> even including the hem. That is the context of Rav Yosef’s statement: Three by three exactly.
With regard to the statement cited above, <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> that there is a dispute between the <i>tanna</i>’<i>im</i> on this issue: <b>One may</b> only <b>kindle</b> a fire <b>with</b> whole <b>vessels and one may not kindle</b> a fire <b>with broken vessels;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And Rabbi Shimon permits</b> kindling a fire even with broken vessels. An additional <i>halakha</i>: <b>One may kindle</b> a fire <b>with</b> whole <b>dates</b> on a Festival, and if <b>he ate them, he may not kindle</b> a fire <b>with their pits</b> as they are set-aside; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And Rabbi Shimon permits</b> kindling a fire with the pits. Furthermore, <b>one may kindle</b> a fire <b>with</b> whole <b>nuts</b> on a Festival, and if <b>he ate them, he may not kindle</b> a fire <b>with their shells;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And Rabbi Shimon permits</b> doing so.
The Gemara comments: <b>And it was necessary</b> to cite all three of these cases because each teaches a novel idea. <b>As, had</b> Rav <b>taught us</b> only <b>the first</b> <i>halakha</i>, we would have thought that it is specifically <b>in that</b> case, with regard to burning broken vessels, that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that it is prohibited, <b>as initially</b> it was <b>a vessel and now</b> it is a <b>broken vessel, and therefore it is</b> considered an object that <b>came into being [<i>nolad</i>] and prohibited; however, dates, initially</b> there were <b>pits</b> in the dates <b>and now</b> they remain <b>pits, say</b> that one may <b>well</b> do so. <b>And had</b> Rav <b>taught us</b> only with regard to date <b>pits I would have said</b> that they are prohibited because <b>initially</b> they were <b>concealed</b> within the fruit <b>and now</b> they are <b>exposed,</b> it is a case of an object that came into being and prohibited. <b>However, nutshells, which initially</b> were <b>exposed and now</b> are <b>exposed,</b> as they were before, <b>say</b> that one may <b>well</b> do so. Therefore, it was necessary to teach all of these cases.
<b>And</b> the Gemara adds: <b>This</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>Rav was not stated explicitly; rather, it was stated by inference</b> based on conclusions drawn from Rav’s actions and not from his explicit statements. There was an instance where <b>Rav ate dates</b> on a weekday and <b>threw</b> the <b>pits into the oven. Rabbi Ḥiyya said to him: Son of noblemen,</b> the <b>corresponding</b> action, throwing pits into an oven, <b>is prohibited on a Festival.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Did</b> Rav <b>accept</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from him or did he not accept</b> it <b>from him?</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear: When Rav came</b> from Eretz Yisrael <b>to Babylonia, he ate dates</b> on a Festival <b>and threw their pits to the animals</b> so that they may eat them. <b>Wasn’t it</b> a case involving <b>Persian</b> dates, which are quality dates whose fruit comes completely off the pits, leaving the pits with no trace of fruit? Ostensibly, they are completely set-aside as they are of no use at all to people. <b>And</b> the fact that Rav threw the pits to the animals indicates that <b>he did not accept</b> this <i>halakha</i> from Rabbi Ḥiyya, and he holds that there is no prohibition in that case. The Gemara replies: <b>No,</b> this is a case involving <b>Aramean</b> dates whose fruit does not come off completely, and remnants of the date remain attached to the pit. These pits, <b>since they are</b> still <b>fit for use due to their mother,</b> i.e., the fruit itself, one is permitted to carry them.
