The study of Torah is the mitzva practiced both day and night. <b>And it is written</b> with regard to this punishment: <b>“When I break your staff of bread, ten women shall bake</b> your bread in one oven, and they shall deliver your bread again by weight; and ye shall eat, and not be satisfied” (Leviticus 26:26). <b>And it is written: “Even because they rejected My ordinances,</b> and their soul abhorred My statutes” (Leviticus 26:43). All of these punishments result from breaching the covenant of the Torah and the perversion of justice.
<b>Due to the sin of an oath</b> taken <b>in vain and a false oath, and desecration of</b> God’s <b>name, and desecration of Shabbat, wild beasts abound</b> in the world, <b>and</b> domesticated <b>animals cease</b> to exist, <b>and human beings decrease</b> in number, <b>and the roads become desolate, as it is stated: “And if in spite of these [<i>be</i>’<i>eleh</i>] things you will not be corrected unto Me,</b> but will walk contrary unto Me casually” (Leviticus 26:23). <b>Do not read of these [<i>be</i>’<i>eleh</i>]; rather,</b> due to a vain <b>oath [<i>be</i>’<i>ala</i>]. And it is written</b> that the punishment for this is: <b>“And I will send the beast of the field among you,</b> which shall rob you of your children, and destroy your cattle, and make you few in number; and your ways shall become desolate” (Leviticus 26:22). <b>And it is written with regard to a false oath: “And you shall not swear by My name falsely, so that you desecrate [<i>veḥillalta</i>] the name of your God:</b> I am the Lord” (Leviticus 19:12). <b>And it is written with regard to desecrating the name of God: “And you shall not desecrate [<i>teḥallelu</i>] My Holy Name”</b> (Leviticus 22:32). <b>And it is written with regard to desecrating Shabbat: “Every one that desecrates it [<i>meḥaleleha</i>] shall surely be put to death”</b> (Exodus 31:14). <b>And derive</b> by means of a verbal analogy [<i>gezera shava</i>] <b>desecration [<i>ḥillul</i>] of Shabbat from desecration [<i>ḥillul</i>] of a false oath.</b> Just as punishment for a false oath is desolation and wild beasts, one receives the same punishment for desecrating Shabbat and the name of God.
<b>Due to the sin of bloodshed, the Holy Temple is destroyed, and the Divine Presence leaves Israel, as it says: “So you shall not pollute</b> the land wherein you are; for blood, it pollutes the land; and no expiation can be made for the land for the blood that is shed therein, but by the blood of him that shed it. <b>And you shall not defile the land which you inhabit, in the midst of which I dwell;</b> for I the Lord dwell in the midst of the children of Israel” (Numbers 35:33–34). However, if <b>you defile</b> the land, <b>you will not inhabit it, and I will not dwell in it.</b>
<b>Due to the sin of prohibited sexual relations, and idol worship, and</b> failure to let the land <b>lie fallow</b> during <b>the Sabbatical and Jubilee Years, exile comes to the world and they exile</b> the Jewish people from their land, <b>and others come and settle in their place. As it is stated</b> with regard to illicit sexual relations: <b>“For all these abominations have the men of the land done,</b> that were before you, and the land is defiled; that the land expel not you also, when you defile it, as it expelled the nation that was before you” (Leviticus 18:27–28). <b>And it is written: “And the land was defiled, therefore I did visit the iniquity thereof upon it,</b> and the land expelled her inhabitants” (Leviticus 18:25). <b>And it is written: “That the land expel not you also, when you defile it,</b> as it expelled the nation that was before you.”
<b>And with regard to idol worship it is written: “And I will cast your carcasses</b> upon the carcasses of your idols” (Leviticus 26:30). <b>And it is written: “And I will bring your sanctuaries unto desolation,</b> and I will not smell the savor of your sweet odors” (Leviticus 26:31). <b>“And you will I scatter among the nations,</b> and I will draw out the sword after you; and your land shall be a desolation, and your cities shall be a waste” (Leviticus 26:33).
<b>With regard to</b> the sin of failure to observe <b>the Sabbatical and Jubilee Years it is written: “Then shall the land be paid her Sabbaths, as long as it lies desolate, and you are in your enemies’ land;</b> even then shall the land rest, and repay her Sabbaths” (Leviticus 26:34). <b>And it is written: “As long as it lies desolate it shall have rest;</b> even the rest which it had not in your Sabbaths, when you dwelt upon it” <b>(</b>Leviticus 26: 35).
<b>Due to the sin of vulgar speech, troubles abound, and harsh decrees are renewed, and the youth among the enemies of Israel,</b> a euphemistic reference to Israel, <b>die,</b> and <b>orphans and widows cry out</b> for help <b>and are not answered, as it is stated: “Therefore the Lord shall have no joy in their young men, neither shall He have compassion on their fatherless and widows; for everyone is ungodly and an evildoer, and every mouth speaks wantonness. For all this His anger is not turned away, but His hand is stretched out still”</b> (Isaiah 9:16).
The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>But His hand is stretched out still? Rabbi Ḥanan bar Rava said: Everybody knows why the bride enters the wedding canopy.</b> There is no secret revealed. <b>Nevertheless, anyone who speaks vulgarly</b> about it, <b>even if they,</b> on High, <b>sealed for him a decree of seventy years of good</b> fortune<b>, they will reverse it to bad</b> fortune because of this sin. And <b>Rabba bar Sheila said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Anyone who speaks vulgarly, they deepen Gehenna for him, as it is stated: “The mouth that speaks perversity is a deep pit</b>: he that is abhorred of the Lord shall fall therein<b>”</b> (Proverbs 22:14), i.e., Gehenna is deepened for one who speaks vulgarly. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Even</b> one <b>who hears</b> vulgar speech <b>and is silent</b> is punished, <b>as it is stated: “He that is abhorred of the Lord shall fall therein,”</b> even if he himself does not speak at all.
And in a similar vein, <b>Rav Oshaya said: Anyone who</b> prepares <b>himself to</b> commit <b>a sin, wounds and bruises emerge on him, as it is stated: “Sharp wounds for one devoted to evil</b>; so do stripes that reach the inward parts” (Proverbs 20:30). <b>And not only that, but</b> he <b>is sentenced to</b> suffer from the disease of <b>edema [<i>hidrokan</i>], as it is stated: So do stripes that reach the inward parts. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: A sign</b> indicating one who <b>committed</b> a sin is the disease <b><i>hidrokan</i>,</b> which afflicts the inner parts.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>There are three types of <i>hidrokan</i>:</b> The one that comes as punishment <b>for sin</b> is <b>thick; and</b> that which is the result <b>of hunger is swollen</b>, but not as thick; <b>and</b> the one caused <b>by witchcraft</b> is <b>thin,</b> and the flesh of the sick person becomes thin in other places.
The Gemara relates: <b>Shmuel HaKatan fell ill with</b> <i>hidrokan</i>. <b>He said: Master of the Universe, who will draw lots,</b> meaning, who will be able to determine that this <i>hidrokan</i> is not the consequence of sin? <b>He was cured. Abaye</b> also <b>fell ill with</b> <i>hidrokan</i>. <b>Rava</b> testified and <b>said</b> about him: <b>I know about Naḥmani,</b> Abaye, <b>that</b> he <b>starves himself</b> and that his <i>hidrokan</i> is the result of hunger. The Gemara relates that <b>Rava fell ill with</b> <i>hidrokan</i>, and they asked: <b>But Rava</b> did not starve himself, and there is no reason to suspect him of sin, and we cannot say that he contracted <i>hidrokan</i> because he did not relieve himself on time. Rava knew to relieve himself, as it is <b>he</b> who <b>said: More have been killed</b> due to the <b>chamber pot</b>, because they were not careful about relieving themselves in a timely manner, <b>than those swollen</b> due to <b>starvation.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rava is different because the Sages compel him</b> to remain in place <b>against his will while he</b> lectures. Since he could not relieve himself, he became sick with <i>hidrokan</i>.
On a related note, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>there are four signs: A sign of sin is <i>hidrokan</i>, a sign of gratuitous hatred is jaundice, a sign of arrogance is poverty,</b> and <b>a sign of slander is <i>askara</i>.</b>
<b>The Sages taught: <i>Askara</i> comes to the world</b> as punishment

Daf 33b

<b>for</b> neglecting to separate <b>tithes. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, says:</b> <i>Askara</i> comes as punishment for <b>slander. Rava said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi</b> who said it: <b>What is the verse</b> that alludes to this? <b>“But the king shall rejoice in God; every one that swears by Him shall glory; for the mouth of them that speak lies shall be stopped”</b> (Psalms 63:12). The punishment for lying is that the mouth will be stopped. <i>Askara</i> affects the mouth along with other parts of the body.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> those who were sitting in the study hall: Did <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, say</b> that <i>askara</i> comes as punishment only <b>for slander, or perhaps he said</b> it was <b>also for slander? Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>When our Sages entered the vineyard in Yavne, Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, and Rabbi Shimon were there, and a question was asked before them</b> with regard to <b>this plague</b> of <i>askara</i>: <b>Why does it begin in the intestines and end in the mouth? Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ila’i,</b> who was <b>the head of the speakers in every place, responded and said: Even though the kidneys advise, and the heart understands, and the tongue shapes</b> the voice that emerges from the mouth, still, <b>the mouth completes</b> the formation of the voice. Therefore, the disease begins in the same place that slander begins and it ends in the mouth. <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, responded and said:</b> This disease ends in the mouth <b>because one eats with it non-kosher things.</b> They immediately wondered about this: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> to say that <i>askara</i> is caused by eating <b>non-kosher food?</b> Are those who eat non-kosher food so numerous? <b>Rather,</b> it comes as a punishment <b>for eating</b> foods <b>that were not</b> ritually <b>prepared,</b> i.e., were not tithed. <b>Rabbi Shimon responded and said:</b> This disease comes as a punishment <b>for the sin of dereliction in</b> the study of <b>Torah.</b>
<b>They said to him: Women will prove</b> that dereliction in the study of Torah is not the cause, as they are not obligated to study Torah and, nevertheless, they contract <i>askara</i>. He answered them: They are punished because <b>they cause their husbands to be idle</b> from the study of Torah. They said to him: <b>Gentiles will prove</b> that this is not the cause, as they also contract <i>askara</i> even though they are not obligated to study Torah. He answered them: They are also punished because <b>they cause Israel to be idle</b> from the study of Torah. They said to him: <b>Children will prove</b> that this is not the cause, for they are not at all obligated to study Torah and they also suffer from <i>askara</i>. He answered them: They are punished because <b>they cause their fathers to be idle</b> from the study of Torah. They said to him: <b>School children will prove</b> that this is not the cause, as they study Torah and, nevertheless, they suffer from <i>askara</i>.
The Gemara answers: <b>There</b>, it must be understood <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Guryon,</b> as <b>Rabbi Guryon said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Yosef, son of Rabbi Shemaya,</b> who said it: <b>At a time when</b> there are <b>righteous people in the generation,</b> the <b>righteous are seized</b>, i.e., they die or suffer, <b>for</b> the sins of <b>the generation. If there are no righteous people in the generation, school children,</b> who are also without sin, <b>are seized for</b> the sins of <b>the generation</b>. <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Ze’iri said, and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Nezira said: What is the verse</b> that alludes to this? <b>“If you know not, you fairest among women, go your way forth by the footsteps of the flock</b> and feed your kids, beside the shepherds’ tents [<i>mishkenot</i>]<b>” (</b>Song of Songs 1:8). <b>And we say</b> in explanation of this verse: They are the <b>lambs that are taken as collateral [<i>hamemushkanin</i>],</b> which is etymologically similar to the word <i>mishkenot</i>, <b>in place of the shepherds.</b> If the shepherds and leaders of the generation corrupt the multitudes, young children die because of their sins. With regard to the dilemma, <b>conclude from it</b> that Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, <b>said</b> that the illness of <i>askara</i> <b>also</b> results from <b>slander,</b> as the <i>baraita</i> provides an additional cause of the illness. The Gemara comments: Indeed, <b>conclude from it.</b>
In this <i>baraita</i> Rabbi Yehuda is described as head of the speakers in every place. The Gemara asks: <b>And why did they call him head of the speakers in every place?</b> The Gemara relates that this resulted due to an incident that took place <b>when Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Yosei and Rabbi Shimon were sitting, and Yehuda, son of converts, sat beside them. Rabbi Yehuda opened and said: How pleasant are the actions of this nation,</b> the Romans, as <b>they established marketplaces, established bridges,</b> and <b>established bathhouses. Rabbi Yosei was silent. Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai responded and said: Everything that they established, they established only for their own purposes. They established marketplaces, to place prostitutes in them; bathhouses, to pamper themselves;</b> and <b>bridges, to collect taxes from</b> all who pass over <b>them. Yehuda, son of converts, went and related their statements</b> to his household, <b>and</b> those statements continued to spread until <b>they were heard by the monarchy. They</b> ruled and <b>said: Yehuda, who elevated</b> the Roman regime, <b>shall be elevated</b> and appointed as head of the Sages, the head of the speakers in every place. <b>Yosei, who remained silent, shall be exiled</b> from his home in Judea as punishment, and sent <b>to</b> the city of <b>Tzippori</b> in the Galilee. <b>And Shimon, who denounced</b> the government, <b>shall be killed.</b>
Rabbi Shimon bar Yoḥai <b>and his son,</b> Rabbi Elazar, <b>went</b> and <b>hid in the study hall. Every day</b> Rabbi Shimon’s <b>wife would bring them bread and a jug of water and they would eat. When the decree intensified,</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>said to his son: Women are easily impressionable</b> and, therefore, there is room for concern <b>lest</b> the authorities <b>torture her and she reveal our</b> whereabouts. <b>They went and they hid in a cave. A miracle occurred</b> and <b>a carob</b> tree <b>was created for them as well as a spring of water. They would remove their clothes and sit</b> covered <b>in sand up to their necks</b>. <b>They would study</b> Torah <b>all day</b> in that manner. <b>At the time of prayer, they would dress, cover themselves, and pray, and they would again remove their clothes afterward so that they would not become tattered. They sat in the cave for twelve years. Elijah</b> the Prophet <b>came and stood at the entrance to the cave</b> and <b>said: Who will inform bar Yoḥai that</b> the <b>emperor died and his decree has been abrogated?</b>
<b>They emerged</b> from the cave, and <b>saw people who were plowing and sowing.</b> Rabbi Shimon bar Yoḥai <b>said:</b> These people <b>abandon eternal life</b> of Torah study <b>and engage in temporal life</b> for their own sustenance. The Gemara relates that <b>every place that</b> Rabbi Shimon and his son Rabbi Elazar <b>directed their eyes was immediately burned. A Divine Voice emerged and said to them:</b> Did <b>you emerge</b> from the cave in order <b>to destroy My world? Return to your cave. They again went</b> and <b>sat</b> there <b>for twelve months. They said: The judgment of the wicked in Gehenna lasts</b> for <b>twelve months.</b> Surely their sin was atoned in that time. <b>A Divine Voice emerged and said</b> to them: <b>Emerge from your cave. They emerged. Everywhere that Rabbi Elazar would strike, Rabbi Shimon would heal.</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>said to</b> Rabbi Elazar: <b>My son, you and I suffice for the</b> entire <b>world,</b> as the two of us are engaged in the proper study of Torah.
<b>As the sun was setting on Shabbat eve, they saw an elderly man who was holding two bundles of myrtle branches and running at twilight. They said to him: Why do you have these? He said to them: In honor of Shabbat.</b> They said to him: <b>And let one suffice.</b> He answered them: <b>One</b> is <b>corresponding to: “Remember</b> the Shabbat day, to keep it holy” (Exodus 20:8), <b>and</b> one is <b>corresponding to: “Observe</b> the Shabbat day, to keep it holy” (Deuteronomy 5:12). Rabbi Shimon <b>said to his son: See how beloved the mitzvot are to Israel. Their minds were</b> put <b>at ease</b> and they were no longer as upset that people were not engaged in Torah study.
<b>Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir,</b> Rabbi Shimon’s <b>son-in-law</b>, <b>heard and went out to</b> greet <b>him. He brought him into the bathhouse and</b> began <b>tending to his flesh. He saw that</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>had cracks in</b> the skin on <b>his body. He was crying, and the tears fell from his eyes and caused</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>pain.</b> Rabbi Pineḥas <b>said to</b> Rabbi Shimon, his father-in-law: <b>Woe is me, that I have seen you like this.</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>said to him: Happy are you that you have seen me like this, as had you not seen me like this, you would not have found in me this</b> prominence in Torah, <b>as</b> the Gemara relates: <b>At first, when Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai would raise a difficulty, Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir would respond</b> to his question with <b>twelve answers. Ultimately, when Rabbi Pineḥas ben Ya’ir would raise a difficulty</b>, <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai would respond</b> with <b>twenty-four answers.</b>
Rabbi Shimon <b>said: Since a miracle transpired</b> for me, <b>I will go</b> and <b>repair something</b> for the sake of others in gratitude for God’s kindness, <b>as it is written: “And Jacob came whole</b> to the city of Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan, when he came from Paddan-aram; and he graced the countenance of the city” (Genesis 33:18). <b>Rav said,</b> the meaning of: And Jacob came whole, is: <b>Whole in his body, whole in his money, whole in his Torah.</b> And what did he do? <b>And he graced the countenance of the city;</b> he performed gracious acts to benefit the city. <b>Rav said:</b> Jacob <b>established a currency for them. And Shmuel said: He established marketplaces for them. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: He established bathhouses for them.</b> In any event, clearly one for whom a miracle transpires should perform an act of kindness for his neighbors as a sign of gratitude. <b>He said: Is there something that needs repair? They said to him: There is a place where there is uncertainty with regard to ritual impurity</b>

Daf 34a

<b>and the priests are troubled</b> by being forced <b>to circumvent it,</b> as it is prohibited for them to become ritually impure from contact with a corpse. There was suspicion, but no certainty, that a corpse was buried there. Therefore, they were unable to definitively determine its status. Rabbi Shimon <b>said: Is there a person who knows that there was a presumption of ritual purity here?</b> Is there anyone who remembers a time when this place was not considered ritually impure, or that at least part of it was considered to be ritually pure? <b>An Elder said to him: Here ben Zakkai</b> planted and <b>cut the <i>teruma</i> of lupines.</b> In this marketplace Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Zakkai, who himself was a priest, once planted lupines that were given to him as <i>teruma</i>. On that basis, the conclusion can be drawn that it was definitely ritually pure. Rabbi Shimon, like Jacob, <b>also did so</b> and took steps to improve the city and examined the ground (<i>Tosafot</i>). <b>Everywhere that</b> the ground <b>was hard, he pronounced it ritually pure</b> as there was certainly no corpse there, <b>and every place that</b> the ground <b>was soft, he marked it</b> indicating that perhaps a corpse was buried there. In that way, he purified the marketplace so that even priests could walk through it.
<b>A certain Elder said</b> in ridicule and surprise: <b>Ben Yoḥai purified the cemetery.</b> Rabbi Shimon got angry and <b>said to him: Had you not been with us, and even had you been with us and were not counted with us</b> in rendering this ruling, what <b>you say is fine.</b> You could have said that you were unaware of my intention or that you did not agree or participate in this decision. <b>Now that you were with us and were counted with us</b> in rendering this ruling, you will cause people to say that Sages are unwilling to cooperate with one another. <b>They will say:</b> If competing <b>prostitutes</b> still <b>apply makeup to each other</b> to help one another look beautiful, <b>all the more so</b> that <b>Torah scholars</b> should cooperate with each other. <b>He directed his eyes toward him and</b> the Elder <b>died.</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>went out to the marketplace</b> and <b>he saw Yehuda, son of converts,</b> who was the cause of this entire incident. Rabbi Shimon, <b>said: This</b> one <b>still has</b> a place <b>in the world? He directed his eyes toward him and turned him into a pile of bones.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> There are <b>three things a person must say in his home on Shabbat eve at nightfall</b> and not before. The mishna elaborates: He should ask the members of his household, <b>have you tithed</b> the crop that required tithing? <b>Have you placed the <i>eiruv</i></b> for joining the courtyards and joining the Shabbat borders? If you have done so, <b>light the lamp</b> in honor of Shabbat. The Sages stated a principle: If the time arrives on Friday when there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether it is <b>nightfall</b> and <b>uncertainty</b> whether it is <b>not</b> yet <b>nightfall, one may not tithe</b> the crop that has <b>definitely</b> not been tithed, <b>and one may not immerse</b> ritually impure <b>vessels</b> in a ritual bath to render them ritually pure, <b>and one may not light the</b> Shabbat <b>lights. However, one may tithe <i>demai</i>,</b> doubtfully tithed produce, which must be tithed due to mere suspicion. <b>And one may place an <i>eiruv</i> and insulate the hot water</b> to be used on Shabbat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara attempts to clarify: <b>From where are these matters,</b> that one must ask these questions in his home at nightfall of Shabbat, derived? <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said</b>: As <b>the verse said: “And you shall know that your tent is in peace; and you shall visit your habitation, and shall not sin”</b> (Job 5:24). From here it is derived that one should visit his habitation, i.e., ask in his home, so that he will not come to sin. <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said: Although the Sages said</b> that there are <b>three things a person should,</b> indeed he is required to, <b>say</b> in his home on Shabbat eve at nightfall, <b>one must say them calmly so that</b> the members of his household <b>will accept them from him.</b> If he says them harshly, his family members may mislead him and cause him to sin. <b>Rav Ashi said: I did not hear this</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna, but I fulfilled</b> it <b>based on</b> my own <b>reasoning.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> mishna <b>itself is difficult,</b> as it contains an internal contradiction. On the one hand, <b>you</b> stated initially that there are <b>three things a person must say in his home before Shabbat at nightfall,</b> and this means: <b>At nightfall,</b> i.e., before nightfall, <b>yes,</b> he should say those things; when there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether it is <b>nightfall</b> and <b>uncertainty</b> whether it is <b>not</b> yet <b>nightfall, no,</b> he should not say them. Even if one were to ask then, it is no longer permitted to correct these matters. <b>And then it taught:</b> When there is <b>uncertainty</b> whether it is <b>nightfall</b> and <b>uncertainty</b> whether it is <b>not</b> yet <b>nightfall, one may place an <i>eiruv</i>.</b> One may correct the situation even then. Why did the mishna restrict asking these questions to an earlier time?
Incidentally, prior to answering this question, the Gemara lists all of the other <i>halakhot</i> in tractate <i>Shabbat</i> stated by the Sage who answers the question, with the <b>mnemonic: Self, pruning, bird, cord, silk.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> This is <b>not difficult</b> and there is no contradiction here. <b>Here,</b> at the beginning of the mishna, where it indicates that the <i>eiruv</i> can only be placed while it is still day, it is referring <b>to</b> the <b>joining of Shabbat boundaries,</b> which is based on a Torah law. Therefore, one must place this <i>eiruv</i> while it is definitely day. And <b>here,</b> where the mishna said that it is permitted even when it is uncertain whether or not it is already nighttime, it is referring <b>to</b> the <b>joining of courtyards,</b> which is more lenient and based merely on a stringency.
In connection to this, the Gemara cites the <i>halakha</i> that <b>Rava said</b> in order to emphasize the rabbinic aspect of the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>eiruv</i>: One <b>to</b> whom <b>two people said: Go and place an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> a joining of courtyards (Rabbeinu Ḥananel), <b>for us. For one</b> of them <b>he placed an <i>eiruv</i> while it was still day, and for one he placed an <i>eiruv</i> at twilight,</b> when it is uncertain whether it is day or night. <b>The one for whom he placed an</b> <i>eiruv</i> <b>while it was still day had his <i>eiruv</i> eaten during twilight, and the one for whom he placed an <i>eiruv</i> during twilight had his <i>eiruv</i> eaten after nightfall.</b> The principle is as follows: Whether or not an <i>eiruv</i> takes effect is determined at the moment that Shabbat begins. If one placed the <i>eiruv</i> beforehand, and it remains intact at the moment Shabbat begins, the <i>eiruv</i> is in effect. However, if the <i>eiruv</i> that was placed at the appropriate time was eaten during twilight, it is problematic. Twilight is a period of uncertainty. There is uncertainty whether it is day, and consequently the <i>eiruv</i> was not in place at the moment that Shabbat began, or whether it is night, and it was in place. In the latter case, there is still uncertainty as to whether or not the <i>eiruv</i> was in place prior to Shabbat, so that it could take effect at all. In that case, Rava ruled that <b>both of them acquired</b> the <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b>
The Gemara is surprised by this: <b>Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, this ruling is difficult. <b>If</b> the <b>twilight</b> period <b>is</b> considered <b>day,</b> let <b>the latter</b> one <b>acquire</b> his <i>eiruv</i>, but let <b>the first one not acquire</b> his because his <i>eiruv</i> was eaten while it was still day. <b>And if</b> the <b>twilight</b> period <b>is night, let the first one acquire</b> his <i>eiruv</i>, but <b>let the latter one not acquire</b> his <i>eiruv</i> because his was not placed before Shabbat. In any event, it is impossible for the <i>eiruv</i> in both of these cases to be valid. The Gemara answers this according to Rava’s position: The status of <b>twilight is uncertain,</b> as it is unknown whether it is day, or night, or both, <b>and uncertainty</b> in the case of a <b>rabbinic</b> ordinance is ruled <b>leniently.</b> Therefore, in both cases the <i>eiruv</i> is acquired.
<b>And Rava said: Why did they say</b> that <b>one may not insulate</b> hot water even <b>in something that does not add heat</b>, but only retains the pre-existing heat, <b>from nightfall</b> on Friday? It is <b>a decree lest one</b> come to <b>boil</b> the pot on Shabbat. <b>Abaye said to him: If so</b>, if it is due to concern that one may boil it, then <b>during twilight we should also issue a decree</b> and prohibit insulating in something that does not add heat. Rava <b>said to him:</b> During twilight, there is no reason to be concerned because at that time <b>most pots are boiling,</b> as they have just been taken off of the fire. Later at night the pots cool down and it is conceivable that one may come to boil them in order to restore the heat.
And Rava said:

Daf 34b

<b>Why did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that <b>one may not insulate</b> hot water for Shabbat <b>in something that adds heat, even while it is still day?</b> It is <b>a decree lest one come to cover it in hot ashes that contain</b> a glowing <b>ember.</b> People may not differentiate between addition of heat by means of hot ashes and other additions of heat. <b>Abaye said to him: Let him insulate</b> it with hot ashes, what is the problem? Rava answered him: It is <b>a decree lest one come to stoke the coals</b> in order to make them burn on Shabbat and thereby violate a Torah prohibition.
<b>The Sages taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> which discusses the range of problems that arise with regard to the twilight period. <b>Twilight</b> is a period of <b>uncertainty.</b> It is uncertain whether it consists of both <b>day and night,</b> it is <b>uncertain</b> whether <b>it is completely day,</b> and it is <b>uncertain</b> whether it is <b>completely night.</b> Therefore, the Sages <b>impose the stringencies of both days upon it</b>. If there is a stringency that applies on either of the days, one is obligated to adhere to it during the twilight period.
Nevertheless, the definition of twilight is uncertain. <b>And what is twilight? From when the sun sets, as long as the eastern face</b> of the sky <b>is reddened</b> by the light of the sun. If <b>the lower</b> segment of the sky has <b>lost</b> its <b>color, and the upper</b> segment <b>has not</b> yet <b>lost</b> its <b>color,</b> that is the <b>twilight</b> period. If <b>the upper</b> segment <b>has lost</b> its <b>color, and</b> its color <b>equals</b> that of <b>the lower</b> one<b>, it is night;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Neḥemya says:</b> The duration of the twilight period is <b>the time</b> it takes <b>for a person to walk half a <i>mil</i> after the sun sets. Rabbi Yosei says: Twilight</b> does not last for a quantifiable period of time; rather, it is <b>like the blink of an eye: This,</b> night, <b>enters and that,</b> day, <b>leaves, and it is impossible to calculate it</b> due to its brevity.
It was taught in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>the Master said:</b> The Sages <b>impose the stringencies of both days upon</b> twilight. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> was this stated? <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> With regard to the <b>matter of ritual impurity, as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to a <i>zav</i> who <b>saw</b> an emission for <b>two</b> consecutive <b>days during twilight,</b> it is unclear whether it should be considered as if he only saw the emission for a single day, as perhaps twilight of the first day was part of the following day, and twilight of the second day was part of the previous day; or, whether it should be considered as two days, attributing each twilight to either the previous or the following day; or, whether it should be considered three days, as it is possible to view the twilight period as two days. By Torah law, a <i>zav</i> who saw two emissions is ritually impure, and all of the stringencies of a <i>zav</i> apply to him. If he sees a third emission, he is liable to bring an offering as part of his purification ritual. Therefore, this <i>zav</i>, with regard to whom there is uncertainty whether he saw emissions for one day, two days, or three days, has <b>uncertain</b> status <b>with regard to both ritual impurity and to sacrifice.</b> If <b>he saw</b> an emission <b>one day during twilight,</b> he has <b>uncertain</b> status <b>with regard to ritual impurity</b> because it may be considered two days.
The Gemara comments on the <i>baraita</i> cited by the Gemara. <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is itself difficult,</b> self-contradictory. Initially <b>you said, what is twilight? From when the sun sets, as long as the eastern face</b> of the sky <b>is reddened</b> by the light of the sun. By inference, <b>if the bottom</b> segment <b>lost</b> its <b>color, and the upper</b> one <b>has not lost</b> its <b>color, it is night. And then</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>taught:</b> If <b>the lower</b> segment of the sky has <b>lost</b> its <b>color, and the upper</b> segment <b>has not</b> yet <b>lost</b> its <b>color,</b> that is the <b>twilight</b> period. There is an apparent internal contradiction in the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> In order to resolve the contradiction, <b>unify</b> the two statements <b>and teach</b> it as follows: <b>What is twilight? From when the sun sets, as long as the eastern face</b> of the sky <b>is reddened</b> by the light of the sun. If <b>the lower</b> segment of the sky has <b>lost</b> its <b>color and the upper</b> segment <b>has not</b> yet <b>lost</b> its <b>color,</b> that is <b>also</b> the <b>twilight</b> period. Only if <b>the upper</b> segment <b>lost</b> its <b>color, and</b> it <b>equals</b> that of <b>the lower</b> one, is it <b>night. And Rav Yosef</b> said that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said</b> otherwise: <b>From when the sun sets, as long as the eastern face</b> of the sky <b>is reddened</b> by the light of the sun, it is <b>day.</b> If <b>the lower</b> segment of the sky has <b>lost</b> its <b>color, and the upper</b> segment <b>has not</b> yet <b>lost</b> its <b>color,</b> that is the <b>twilight</b> period. If <b>the upper</b> segment <b>lost</b> its <b>color and</b> it <b>equals</b> that of <b>the lower</b> one, it is <b>night.</b>
<b>And</b> the Gemara remarks: In this dispute over the precise definition of twilight both Rabba and Rav Yosef <b>follow their</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> stated elsewhere. <b>As it was stated: What is the measure</b> of the duration <b>of twilight? Rabba said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The time it takes to walk <b>three parts of a <i>mil</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>three parts of a <i>mil</i>? If you say</b> that it refers to <b>three halves of a <i>mil</i>, let him say a <i>mil</i> and a half. Rather,</b> if you say that it means <b>three-thirds of a <i>mil</i>, let him</b> simply <b>say</b> one <b><i>mil</i>. Rather,</b> it means <b>three-quarters of a <i>mil</i>. And Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The duration of twilight is <b>two parts of a <i>mil</i>.</b> Again the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b>two parts of a <i>mil</i>? If you say</b> that it means <b>two halves of a <i>mil</i>, let him</b> simply <b>say</b> one <b><i>mil</i>. Rather,</b> if you say that it means <b>two-quarters of a <i>mil</i>, let him say</b> instead: <b>Half of a <i>mil</i>. Rather,</b>

Daf 35a

it means <b>two-thirds of a <i>mil</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between them? The</b> practical difference <b>between them</b> is <b>half of one-sixth [<i>danka</i>],</b> i.e., one-twelfth of a <i>mil</i>. Their disputes are consistent, as the duration of twilight according to Rav Yosef is shorter than its duration according to Rabba.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> with regard to the legal status of <b>a wicker vessel</b> their dispute <b>is the opposite.</b> In that case, the size of the vessel permitted by Rav Yosef is larger than the size of the vessel permitted by Rabba. <b>As Rabba said</b> with regard to <b>a wicker vessel with a capacity of two <i>kor</i>, one is permitted to move it</b> on Shabbat. <b>And one with a capacity of three <i>kor</i>, one is prohibited to move it</b> on Shabbat. It is much larger than the dimensions of a vessel and one is only permitted to move vessels on Shabbat. <b>And Rav Yosef said:</b> A vessel <b>with a capacity of three <i>kor</i>, one is also permitted</b> to move it, and only <b>one with a capacity of four <i>kor</i>,</b> it <b>is prohibited</b> to move.
<b>Abaye said: I raised the dilemma before my Master,</b> Rabba, <b>when it was practical,</b> when I actually needed to know what to do, <b>and he did not permit me</b> to move <b>even</b> a vessel <b>with a capacity of two</b> <i>kor</i>. The Gemara explains: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did Rabba issue his practical halakhic ruling? <b>In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this</b> <i>tanna</i> that <b>we learned</b> in the mishna discussing the laws of ritual purity: <b>A round straw barrel, and a round barrel</b> made <b>of reeds, and the cistern of an Alexandrian ship,</b> which is a large vessel placed on a boat and filled with potable water, <b>although</b> these vessels <b>have bottoms,</b> i.e., they are receptacles, since they <b>have a capacity of forty <i>se’a</i></b> of liquid, <b>which is the</b> equivalent of <b>two</b> <i>kor</i> of <b>dry</b> goods<b>,</b> they are <b>ritually pure.</b> Even if they come into contact with a source of ritual impurity, they do not become impure. Beyond a certain size, containers are no longer considered vessels and, consequently, cannot become ritually impure. Rabba held: Since with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity a vessel of two <i>kor</i> is not considered a vessel, it may not be moved on Shabbat. With regard to this mishna, <b>Abaye said: Learn from it</b> that <b>the surplus</b> of dry goods in a vessel relative to liquids <b>is one-third</b> of the contents of the vessel. It says in the mishna that a vessel that can hold forty <i>se’a</i> of liquid holds two <i>kor</i> of dry produce, which is the equivalent of sixty <i>se’a</i>.
The Gemara relates: <b>Abaye saw</b> that <b>Rava was gazing westward</b> on Shabbat eve to determine whether or not the sky was red and whether or not it was twilight. Abaye <b>said to</b> Rava: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that twilight <b>is from when the sun sets, as long as the eastern face</b> of the sky <b>is reddened</b> by the light of the sun? Why, then, are you looking westward? Rava <b>said to him: Do you hold</b> that the reference is actually to <b>the eastern face</b> of the sky? <b>No,</b> it is referring to <b>the face</b> of the sky <b>that causes the east</b> to <b>redden,</b> i.e., the west. <b>Some say</b> a different version of that incident. <b>Rava saw</b> that <b>Abaye was gazing eastward. He said to him, do you hold</b> that the reference is to <b>the actual eastern face</b> of the sky? The reference is to <b>the face</b> of the sky <b>that causes the east to redden,</b> i.e., the west. <b>And your mnemonic is a window</b>, as it is on the wall opposite the window that one can see how much sunlight is shining through.
With regard to that which was taught in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Neḥemya says:</b> The duration of twilight is <b>the time</b> it takes <b>for a person to walk half a <i>mil</i> after the sun sets. Rabbi Ḥanina said: One who wants to know</b> the precise measure of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya’s</b> twilight should do the following: <b>Leave the sun at the top of</b> Mount <b>Carmel,</b> as when one is standing on the seashore he can still see the top of Mount Carmel in sunlight, <b>and descend and immerse himself in the sea, and emerge, and that is Rabbi Neḥemya’s measure</b> of the duration of twilight.
Because of its similarity to Rabbi Ḥanina’s statement, the Gemara cites that which <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said: One who wants to see Miriam’s well,</b> which accompanied the Jewish people throughout their sojourn in the desert, should do the following: <b>He</b> should <b>climb to the top of</b> Mount <b>Carmel and look out, and</b> he will <b>see</b> a rock that looks <b>like a sieve in the sea, and that is Miriam’s well. Rav said: A spring that is portable,</b> i.e., that moves from place to place, is <b>ritually pure</b> and is regarded as an actual spring and not as drawn water. <b>And</b> what is a movable spring? <b>It is Miriam’s well.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> During <b>Rabbi Yehuda’s twilight,</b> ritually impure <b>priests</b> who want to immerse themselves during the day to become ritually pure, so that sunset will follow immersion and they will be permitted to eat <i>teruma</i>, <b>can</b> still <b>immerse</b> themselves <b>during</b> that period. According to this opinion, twilight is still considered to be day. The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is that true? <b>If you say</b> that it is <b>in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda</b>’s own opinion, his opinion cited above is that twilight is a period of <b>uncertainty.</b> Therefore, one who immerses at that time may not eat <i>teruma</i> until after the sunset of the following day. <b>Rather,</b> the reference is to <b>twilight</b> of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei. Priests</b> can <b>immerse then,</b> as Rabbi Yosei considers that time to still be day, and sunset will follow.
The Gemara asks: It is <b>obvious</b> that according to Rabbi Yosei they are immersing themselves during the day. The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that the <b>twilight</b> of <b>Rabbi Yosei is subsumed within</b> and takes place at the end of the twilight <b>of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> When the twilight of Rabbi Yehuda ends, Rabbi Yosei’s twilight is also over. It is already night, sunset of that day has already passed, and there is no sunset to enable them to eat <i>teruma</i>. Therefore, <b>he teaches us</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda’s twilight ends, and</b> only <b>thereafter</b> does <b>Rabbi Yosei’s twilight begin.</b>
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda with regard to the matter of Shabbat, and the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei with regard to the matter of <i>teruma</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> concerning the statement that <b>the</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda with regard to the matter of Shabbat,</b> as like all other cases of uncertainty, the ruling is <b>stringent</b> with regard to Torah prohibitions. <b>However, with regard to <i>teruma</i>, what is</b> the case under discussion? <b>If you say</b> that it is referring <b>to</b> the matter of <b>immersion,</b> immersion is also a case of <b>uncertainty</b> with regard to a Torah law. Why would the ruling be more lenient in that case than in the case of Shabbat?

Daf 35b

<b>Rather,</b> it must be that the reference is with regard <b>to eating <i>teruma</i>. Priests may not eat <i>teruma</i> until twilight is completed, which according to Rabbi Yosei’s</b> opinion is slightly later than it is according to Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion.
With regard to the period of twilight, <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> When one can see <b>one star</b> in the evening sky, it is still <b>day; two</b> stars<b>, twilight; three</b> stars, <b>night. That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: When one can see <b>one star</b> in the evening sky<b>,</b> it is still <b>day; two</b> stars<b>, twilight; three</b> stars, <b>night. Rabbi Yosei said:</b> This is <b>neither</b> referring to <b>large stars that are visible</b> even <b>during the day, nor to small stars that are visible only</b> late <b>at night. Rather,</b> it is referring to <b>medium-</b>sized stars.
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Zevida, said: One who performs a prohibited labor during two twilights,</b> one between Friday and Shabbat and one between Shabbat and the conclusion of Shabbat on Saturday night, <b>is liable</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering</b> for performing a prohibited labor on Shabbat <b>whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it. Whether we say that twilight is day or night, certainly one of those labors was performed on Shabbat. <b>Rava said to his servant: You, who are not expert in the measures of the Sages, when the sun is at the top of the palm trees, light the</b> Shabbat <b>lights.</b> His servant asked him: <b>What</b> should we do <b>on a cloudy day,</b> when the sun is not visible at the top of the trees? Rava said to him: <b>In the city, watch the roosters</b> because as evening approaches they sit on their beams. <b>In a field,</b> watch <b>the ravens</b> because they return to their nests as evening approaches. <b>Alternatively,</b> you can watch <b>the plants [<i>adanei</i>]</b> that turn westward in the evening. When they begin to turn westward evening is approaching.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>They sound six blasts on Shabbat eve</b> to announce that Shabbat is approaching. The Gemara details what each blast signifies. The <b>first blast</b> is in order <b>to stop the people from work in the fields.</b> The <b>second</b> blast <b>is to stop</b> those who are working in <b>the city, and</b> to inform the proprietors to close the <b>stores.</b> The <b>third</b> is to inform them <b>to light the</b> Shabbat <b>light;</b> that is <b>the statement of Rabbi Natan. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi says:</b> The <b>third</b> blast is to inform those who don phylacteries throughout the day <b>to remove</b> their <b>phylacteries,</b> as one does not don phylacteries on Shabbat. <b>And he pauses</b> after the third blast for the length of <b>time</b> it takes to <b>fry a small fish or to stick bread to the</b> sides of the <b>oven.</b> One who forgot to do so and needs those foods for Shabbat may do so then. <b>And he sounds a <i>tekia</i>, and sounds a <i>terua</i>, and sounds a <i>tekia</i>, and he accepts Shabbat.</b> It is then that Shabbat begins in every sense.
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: What shall we do to the Babylonian Jews?</b> They stray from the custom, <b>as</b> they <b>sound a <i>tekia</i> and a <i>terua</i>,</b> and <b>they accept Shabbat during the <i>terua</i>,</b> i.e., upon hearing the blast of the <i>terua</i>. The Gemara asks about this: Do the Babylonians really <b>sound</b> only <b>a <i>tekia</i> and a <i>terua</i></b> and no more blasts? If so, <b>there are</b> only <b>five</b> blasts and not six, as it was taught in the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rather,</b> the correct version is: <b>They sound a <i>tekia</i>, and they again sound a <i>tekia</i>, and</b> then they <b>sound a <i>terua</i>, and they accept Shabbat during the <i>terua</i>.</b> They do so because they continue <b>the custom of their fathers that was handed</b> down <b>to them.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda taught to Rav Yitzḥak, his son:</b> The <b>second</b> blast that is sounded before Shabbat is to inform people <b>to light the light.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion did he say this? It is <b>neither in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan nor in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. Rather,</b> certainly he told him that the <b>third</b> blast is in order to inform people <b>to light the light, and in accordance with whose</b> opinion did he say this? It is in accordance <b>with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan.</b>
On a similar note, <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> in greater detail: <b>Six blasts are sounded on Shabbat eve.</b> When <b>one begins sounding the first <i>tekia</i>, the people standing</b> and working <b>in the fields refrained from hoeing, and from plowing and from performing all labor in the fields. And</b> those <b>workers</b> who work <b>close</b> to the city <b>are not permitted to enter</b> the city <b>until</b> those who work <b>farther</b> away <b>come, so that they will all enter together.</b> Otherwise, people would suspect that the workers who came later continued to work after the blast. <b>And still,</b> at this time, the <b>stores</b> in the city <b>are open and</b> the <b>shutters</b> of the stores, upon which the storekeepers would arrange their merchandise in front of the stores, remain <b>in place.</b> When <b>he began sounding the second blast, the shutters were removed</b> from where they were placed <b>and the stores were locked and</b> in the homes, however, <b>hot water was still</b> cooking <b>on the stove and pots</b> remained <b>in place on the stove.</b> When <b>he began sounding the third blast,</b> the <b>one</b> charged with <b>removing</b> food from the stove <b>removed</b> it, <b>and</b> the <b>one</b> charged with <b>insulating</b> hot water for Shabbat so that it would not cool off <b>insulated</b> it, <b>and</b> the <b>one</b> charged with <b>kindling</b> the Shabbat lights <b>lit. And</b> the one sounding the <i>shofar</i> <b>pauses for</b> the amount of time it takes to <b>fry a small fish or to stick bread to the</b> sides of the <b>oven, and he sounds a <i>tekia</i>, and sounds a <i>terua</i>, and sounds a <i>tekia</i>, and accepts Shabbat.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina, said: I heard that</b> a person who was pressed for time and <b>comes to light</b> Shabbat lights <b>after six blasts may light</b> without concern, as even the moment of the sixth blast is not yet Shabbat. Proof for this is <b>that the Sages provided the sexton of the synagogue a period</b> of time <b>to take his <i>shofar</i>,</b> which he used to sound the blasts on a tall roof in the middle of the city, <b>to his house.</b> Clearly, during that interval it is not yet Shabbat. He <b>said to him: If so</b>, then <b>you have rendered your statement</b> subject <b>to circumstances,</b> and it would not apply uniformly to all. Shabbat would start at a different time in each place based on the distance between the site where the <i>shofar</i> is sounded and the home of the sexton. <b>Rather,</b> Shabbat began immediately after the final blast with no pause in between. <b>The sexton had a concealed place on top of his roof,</b> where he would sound the <i>shofar</i>, <b>in which he would place his <i>shofar</i> because</b> the consensus is <b>that one may move neither the <i>shofar</i> nor the trumpets</b> on Shabbat.
The Gemara asks with regard to this last <i>halakha</i>: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>the <i>shofar</i> may be moved</b> on Shabbat, <b>and the trumpets may not be moved? Rav Yosei said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> as one could say that <b>here,</b> where moving a <i>shofar</i> was permitted, it is referring <b>to</b> a <i>shofar</i> belonging to <b>an individual.</b> Because it has a use even on Shabbat, it may be moved. <b>There,</b> where moving a <i>shofar</i> was prohibited, it is referring <b>to</b> a <i>shofar</i> that belongs to <b>a community.</b> Because it has no use on Shabbat, it is, therefore, considered set-aside [<i>muktze</i>]. <b>Abaye said to him: And in</b> the case of <b>an individual, for what</b> permitted action is a <i>shofar</i> <b>fit</b> to be used on Shabbat? It is fit for use <b>since it is suitable to give water with it</b>

Daf 36a

<b>to a child.</b> Because the mouth of a <i>shofar</i> is bent, one can pour a little water at a time. If so, a <i>shofar</i> belonging <b>to the community is also suitable to feed</b> water <b>to a poor infant</b> whose sustenance is provided by the community. <b>And furthermore, that</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Just as one may move the <i>shofar</i>, so too one may move</b> the <b>trumpets,</b> is contrary to that which was taught previously that there is a difference between moving the <i>shofar</i> and moving the trumpet. In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is that <i>baraita</i>? <b>Rather,</b> this is <b>not difficult,</b> as it can be explained that these three <i>baraitot</i> correspond to the three opinions with regard to these <i>halakhot</i>. <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits moving the <i>shofar</i> but not the trumpet, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that the laws of set-aside apply to these items on Shabbat and one may not move a utensil whose only function is prohibited. Since a trumpet has no permitted use on Shabbat, it may not be moved. On the other hand, one is permitted to move a <i>shofar</i>, which can be used to feed a child. And <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits moving both a <i>shofar</i> and a trumpet, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who holds that the <i>halakhot</i> of set-aside do not apply to utensils of this kind on Shabbat. Whereas <b>this</b> other <i>baraita</i>, which prohibits moving both a <i>shofar</i> and a trumpet, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> who holds that one may not use a utensil whose primary function is prohibited on Shabbat, even for a permissible purpose.
However, this explanation raises a slight difficulty with regard to the statement that one may move neither a <i>shofar</i> nor a trumpet. There was no need to mention the trumpet. If one may not move a <i>shofar</i>, certainly he may not move a trumpet. However, it can be explained as follows: <b>What is</b> the <b><i>shofar</i></b> mentioned in this <i>baraita</i>? It refers to <b>trumpets, in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rav Ḥisda, as Rav Ḥisda said: These three objects, their names changed since the Holy Temple was destroyed.</b> That which was called <b>trumpet</b> was called <b><i>shofar</i></b> in later generations, and that which was called <b><i>shofar</i></b> was called <b>trumpet</b> in later generations. The <i>baraita</i> that was cited employed the style that switches trumpet and <i>shofar</i>, and they were mentioned in that order. Incidentally, the Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical halakhic <b>difference</b> whether a <i>shofar</i> is called <i>shofar</i> or trumpet? The Gemara answers: It is significant with regard <b>to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>shofar</i> of Rosh HaShana.</b> On Rosh HaShana one fulfills his obligation only by sounding a <i>shofar</i>. If one comes today and asks what instrument he should use to sound the requisite blasts, he should be told to use a trumpet.
The second object whose name was changed: That which was called <b>willow [<i>arava</i>]</b> was called in later generations <b><i>tzaftzafa</i>,</b> and that which was called <b><i>tzaftzafa</i> was</b> called <b>willow.</b> Here too the Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical halakhic <b>difference</b> that emerges from the name change? The Gemara answers: With regard <b>to</b> the mitzva of the four species, referred to by the name of one of the species, as taking the <b>palm branch,</b> as one of the four species is a willow branch, not a <i>tzaftzafa</i>.
The third item whose name was changed: That which was called <b><i>petora</i></b>, originally meaning a large table, was called in later generations <b><i>petorata</i>, and that which was called <b><i>petorata</i>, orginally meaning a small table, was called <b><i>petora</i></b> in later generations. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical halakhic <b>difference</b> that emerges from the change of name? The Gemara answers: With regard <b>to</b> the laws of <b>buying and selling.</b> A person who orders a <i>petora</i> should know that he ordered a small table and not a large one.</b></b>
<b>Abaye said: We too shall speak</b> and comment on changes in the meaning of terms in our generation. What was called <b><i>huvlila</i>,</b> the first stomach of animals that chew their cud, is, in recent generations, called <b><i>bei kasei</i>,</b> the name of the animal’s second stomach. Similarly, what was once called in the past <b><i>bei kasei</i></b> is called <b><i>huvlila</i></b> in recent generations. <b>What is the</b> practical halakhic <b>difference</b> that emerges from this change of names? <b>With regard to a needle that is found in the thick</b> wall <b>of the second stomach.</b> In the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>tereifot</i>, one is prohibited to eat animals with a life expectancy of less than a year. It was established that if a needle punctured the wall of the second stomach <b>from</b> only <b>one side,</b> the animal is <b>kosher.</b> If the needle penetrated through the wall in a manner visible <b>from both sides,</b> the animal assumes the halakhic status of a <b><i>tereifa</i>.</b> In the first stomach, even if the needle penetrated only one side of the wall, the animal assumes the halakhic status of a <i>tereifa</i>. Therefore, it is crucial to distinguish between the first and the second stomachs.
<b>Rav Ashi said: We too shall speak</b> of matters whose name changed over the generations. The city that, in biblical times, was called <b>Babylon</b> was called <b>Bursif</b> in later generations, and <b>Bursif</b> was called <b>Babylon</b> in later generations.

Daf 36b

<b>What is the practical</b> halakhic <b>difference</b> that emerges from this change of names? It is in the area <b>of women’s bills of divorce.</b> With regard to bills of divorce, special care is devoted to ensuring that the name of the place where the bill is written is not altered. Therefore, it is important to be aware that Babylon underwent a name change in later generations.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a stove that was lit</b> on Shabbat eve <b>with straw</b> or <b>with rakings,</b> scraps collected from the field, one may <b>place</b> a pot of <b>cooked food atop it</b> on Shabbat. The fire in this stove was certainly extinguished while it was still day, as both straw and rakings are materials that burn quickly. However, if the stove was lit <b>with pomace,</b> pulp that remains from sesame seeds, olives, and the like after the oil is squeezed from them, <b>and</b> if it was lit <b>with wood,</b> one may <b>not place</b> a pot atop it on Shabbat <b>until he sweeps</b> the coals from the stove while it is still day <b>or until he places ashes</b> on the coals, so that the fire will not ignite on Shabbat. <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> Even after one has swept away the coals, it is only permitted to place <b>hot water</b> on it, as it is sufficiently hot and does not require additional cooking, <b>but not cooked food.</b> Since, in general, one prefers that food will cook more, there is concern lest he come to ignite the fire by stoking the coals. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> Both <b>hot water and cooked food</b> may be placed. <b>Beit Shammai say: One may remove</b> a pot from the stove on Shabbat <b>but</b> may <b>not return</b> it. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> One may <b>even return it.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The students <b>raised a dilemma</b> with regard to the explanation of the mishna. <b>That</b> which we learned in the mishna: One may <b>not place, does it</b> mean that <b>one may not return</b> a pot that he took off the fire and wishes to return on Shabbat; <b>however, to leave</b> the pot from Shabbat eve into Shabbat, <b>one may leave</b> it <b>even though</b> this stove <b>is not swept</b> of its coals <b>and</b> its coals <b>are not covered with ashes? And,</b> according to this, <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is it</b> in this mishna? <b>It</b> is the opinion of <b>Ḥananya. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>Ḥananya says: Any</b> food <b>that</b> has already been cooked to the extent <b>of the food of ben Drosai,</b> who would only cook his food the minimum amount necessary, <b>one is permitted to leave it atop a stove</b> on Shabbat <b>even though</b> the stove <b>is not swept and not covered with ashes. Or perhaps,</b> that which <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: One may not place, means one may not <b>leave</b> it on the fire from Shabbat eve. <b>And if</b> the coals in the stove were <b>swept</b> or <b>covered with ashes, yes,</b> one may leave the pot on the stove. <b>And if not, no,</b> one may not leave it, <b>and all the more so</b> one may not <b>return</b> it to the stove on Shabbat under any circumstances.
In order to resolve this dilemma, the Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this <b>from the</b> fact <b>that two sections were taught in our mishna.</b> In the first, <b>Beit Shammai say: Hot water but not cooked food. And Beit Hillel say:</b> Both <b>hot water and cooked food.</b> And in the second, <b>Beit Shammai say: One may remove</b> it <b>but may not return</b> it. <b>And Beit Hillel say: One may even return</b> it. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that when <b>we learned</b> in the mishna that one may not place it means that it is prohibited <b>to leave</b> it; in that case, the mishna <b>is teaching as follows:</b> With regard to <b>a stove that was lit with straw</b> or <b>with rakings, one may leave cooked food on it.</b> If it was lit <b>with pomace</b> or <b>with wood, one may not leave</b> the cooked food on it <b>until he sweeps</b> the coals <b>out</b> while it is still day <b>or until he places ashes on it. And what may they leave? Beit Shammai say: Hot water but not cooked food. And Beit Hillel say:</b> One may leave both <b>hot water and cooked food</b> on it. <b>And just as</b> they <b>disagree with regard to leaving</b> a pot on the stove, <b>so too,</b> they <b>disagree with regard to</b> whether or not it is permitted <b>to return</b> it to the stove. <b>As Beit Shammai say: One may take</b> the pot from the stove on Shabbat <b>but may not return</b> it to the stove at all. <b>And Beit Hillel say: One may even return</b> it.
<b>However, if you say</b> that when <b>we learned</b> in the mishna that one may not place, it means that it is prohibited <b>to return</b> it, then the mishna <b>is teaching as follows: A stove that was lit with straw</b> or <b>with rakings, one may return cooked food onto it.</b> If it was lit <b>with pomace</b> or <b>with wood, one may not return</b> cooked food to it <b>until one sweeps</b> the coals <b>out</b> while it is still day <b>or until one places ashes</b> on them. <b>And what may they return? Beit Shammai say: Hot water but not cooked food. And Beit Hillel say:</b> Both <b>hot water and cooked food. Beit Shammai say: One may remove but may not return. And Beit Hillel say: One may even return.</b> If in the first section the question of what may be returned was already addressed, <b>why do I need this additional</b> dispute in the second section? The gist of Beit Shammai’s statement that cooked food may not be returned to the stove is that one may remove but may not return. Apparently, the mishna can only be understood in accordance with the first explanation. The first clause discusses leaving and the latter clause discusses returning.

Daf 37a

The Gemara rejects this proof. <b>Actually, you can say</b> that in the first clause of the mishna <b>we learned to return and</b> the mishna is <b>incomplete.</b> A clause must be added to the mishna, <b>and it teaches the following:</b> With regard to <b>a stove that was lit with straw</b> or <b>rakings, one may return</b> a pot of <b>cooked food to it.</b> If it was lit <b>with pomace</b> or <b>with wood, one may not return</b> a pot to it <b>until one sweeps</b> the coals out while it is still day <b>or until one covers</b> the coals <b>with ashes. However, to leave</b> the pot on the flame on Shabbat, <b>one may leave it, even though it is not swept and not covered with ashes.</b> Through this addition, the continuation of the dispute can be understood as follows: <b>And what may they leave? Beit Shammai say: Hot water but not cooked food. And Beit Hillel say:</b> Both <b>hot water and cooked food.</b> Furthermore: <b>And that return that I said to you</b> at the start of the mishna <b>is not according to everyone. Rather,</b> it too <b>is</b> subject to <b>a dispute</b> between <b>Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, as Beit Shammai say: One may remove but not return. And Beit Hillel say: One may even return.</b> The dilemma with regard to the interpretation of the mishna has not been resolved.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another resolution to this dilemma from that which <b>Rabbi Ḥelbo said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said</b> that <b>Rav said: They only taught</b> that placing is permitted with regard to a stove as far as placing a pot <b>atop it</b> is concerned. <b>However,</b> placing a pot <b>inside it</b> is <b>prohibited. Granted, if you say</b> that <b>we learned returning</b> in the mishna, <b>that is why there is a</b> halakhic <b>difference between</b> placing a pot <b>inside it and</b> placing a pot <b>atop it.</b> If one returns it on Shabbat, placing it inside a stove that might have burning coals, there is concern that Shabbat would be desecrated. Therefore, it was only permitted to place cooked food atop the stove. <b>However, if you say</b> that <b>we learned leaving</b> in the mishna, <b>what is</b> the difference <b>to me</b> whether it is <b>inside</b> the stove and <b>what is</b> the difference <b>to me</b> whether it is <b>atop it?</b> Ultimately, he does nothing on Shabbat with the hot ashes in the stove. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Do you think</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥelbo is referring to the first clause</b> of the mishna? No, he <b>is referring to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, which states: <b>And Beit Hillel say that one may even return. And</b> with regard to this <b>Rabbi Ḥelbo said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said</b> that <b>Rav said: They only taught</b> that one may return the cooked food <b>atop</b> the stove; <b>however, inside it</b> is <b>prohibited.</b> If so, there is still no resolution to the dilemma.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from that which was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: In the case of <b>two adjoining stoves</b> that share a common wall, in <b>one</b> of them, the coals were <b>swept</b> or <b>covered with ashes, and</b> in <b>one</b> the coals <b>were not swept and not covered with ashes;</b> the ruling with regard to leaving a pot atop them on Shabbat is as follows: <b>One may leave</b> food <b>atop</b> the one that was <b>swept</b> or <b>covered with ashes, and one may not leave</b> food <b>atop the</b> one <b>that was not swept and not covered with ashes. And</b> to the crux of the matter, <b>what may one leave? Beit Shammai say: Nothing at all.</b> They dispute the <i>halakha</i> cited above. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> One may leave <b>hot water but not cooked food.</b> However, if one <b>removed</b> the cooked dish from atop the stove, <b>everyone,</b> Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, <b>agrees</b> that <b>one may not return</b> it atop the stove; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b> According to the tradition that he received, that is the issue disputed between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that the dispute is different. <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> One may leave <b>hot water</b> on it <b>but not cooked food. And Beit Hillel say:</b> One may leave both <b>hot water and cooked food.</b> Furthermore, <b>Beit Shammai say: One may remove</b> a pot from the stove on Shabbat <b>but may not return</b> it. <b>And Beit Hillel say: One may even return</b> it.
<b>Granted, if you say</b> that the case <b>we learned</b> in our mishna was with regard to <b>leaving</b> the pot on the stove, in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is <b>our mishna? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. However, if you say</b> that the case <b>we learned</b> in our mishna was with regard to <b>returning</b> the pot to the stove, in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is <b>our mishna?</b> It is <b>neither</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda nor</b> with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir. If</b> you say that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> it is <b>difficult for Beit Shammai in one</b> respect. In our mishna, Beit Shammai permit some use of a stove on Shabbat; while according to Rabbi Meir in the <i>baraita</i>, Beit Shammai prohibit any use. <b>And for Beit Hillel</b> it is difficult <b>in two</b> respects. According to our understanding of the mishna, Beit Hillel permit both hot water and cooked food, contrary to Rabbi Meir’s version of their opinion as stated in the <i>baraita</i>. Similarly, in our mishna, Beit Hillel permit returning the pot to the stove, contrary to Rabbi Meir’s version of their opinion. <b>If</b> you explain that our mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, it is <b>difficult</b> with regard to the issue of <b>sweeping</b> the coals <b>and covering</b> them <b>with ashes.</b> In the mishna, both Beit Hillel and Beit Shammai allow leaving it on a stove whose coals were not swept or covered with ashes. According to Rabbi Yehuda in the <i>baraita</i>, apparently a stove whose coals are neither swept nor covered with ashes may not be used at all. Since this interpretation leads to contradictions, it is preferable to explain the mishna in accordance with the other approach, so that the mishna will at least correspond to one opinion.
This claim is rejected: <b>Actually, you can say</b> that the case <b>we learned</b> in our mishna was with regard to <b>returning</b> the pot to the stove, <b>and our <i>tanna</i></b> in the mishna <b>holds in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda in one</b> matter, <b>and disagrees with him in one</b> matter. <b>He holds in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda in one</b> matter, with regard to the matter of <b>hot water and cooked food, and</b> what may be <b>taken</b> from the stove <b>and</b> what may even be <b>returned. And</b> he <b>disagrees with him in one</b> matter: <b>While our <i>tanna</i></b> in the mishna <b>held</b> that <b>to leave</b> a pot on a stove is permitted <b>even though it is not swept or covered with ashes, Rabbi Yehuda held: With regard to</b> permitting one <b>to leave</b> a pot on the stove <b>as well,</b> if the stove was <b>swept or covered with ashes, yes,</b> it is permitted; <b>if</b> it was <b>not</b> swept or covered with ashes, <b>no,</b> it is prohibited.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to a stove that was neither swept nor covered with ashes, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to permitting one <b>to lean</b> a cooked dish <b>against it,</b> so that it may be heated from the sides of the stove? The dilemma is: Was it only placing a pot <b>inside it and atop it</b> that <b>is prohibited,</b> but <b>to lean</b> the pot <b>against it</b> he may <b>well</b> do so? <b>Or, perhaps,</b> leaning <b>is no different</b> and it is prohibited in every case.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: If there are <b>two adjoining stoves, one</b> that was <b>swept</b> or <b>covered with ashes and one that was not swept and covered with ashes, one may leave</b> cooked food <b>atop</b> the stove that is <b>swept and covered with ashes</b> on Shabbat. Apparently, it is permitted to lean a pot on a stove that was not swept, <b>even though heat rises to it from the other</b> stove. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Perhaps that</b> case of two adjoining stoves <b>is different. Since</b> the pot <b>is elevated, the air affects it</b> and cools it. Therefore, it is not comparable to actually leaning it against the stove.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another resolution to this dilemma from that which <b>Rav Safra said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya said:</b> If there is a stove whose coals <b>one covered</b> with ashes on Shabbat eve <b>and it</b> subsequently <b>reignited</b> on Shabbat, <b>one may lean</b> a pot <b>against it, and leave</b> cooked food <b>on it, and remove</b> food <b>from it, and</b> even <b>return</b> food <b>to it. Conclude from this</b> the following with regard to <b>leaning, as well:</b> If <b>he covered</b> them <b>with ashes, yes,</b> if <b>he did not cover</b> them <b>with ashes, no,</b> as the Gemara is speaking about a stove whose ashes were covered properly during the day. The Gemara rejects this proof too. <b>And according to your opinion, that which was taught: One may remove</b> the food <b>from it,</b> would you say there too that if <b>he covered them, yes,</b> and if <b>he did not cover them, no?</b> Everyone agrees that it is permitted to take the pot off of the stove even if it is not swept or covered with ashes. <b>Rather,</b> it must be understood that <b>he taught</b> permission <b>to remove</b> the pot <b>due to</b> the fact that it taught permission <b>to return</b> it. <b>Here too, it taught</b> permission <b>to lean</b> the pot <b>due to</b> the fact that it taught permission <b>to leave</b> the pot on the stove. Consequently, a conclusion cannot be drawn that leaning a pot on an unswept stove is prohibited.
The Gemara is astonished by this comparison. <b>How can you compare</b> them? <b>There, one removes</b> the pot from <b>and returns it</b> to <b>one</b> and the same <b>place.</b> Therefore, <b>it taught removing due to returning,</b> as one cannot return a pot before he removes it. <b>However, here,</b> where <b>one leans</b> the pot <b>is in one place and</b> where <b>one leaves</b> the pot <b>is in one,</b> another, <b>place,</b> there is no connection between the two. If the <i>tanna</i> did not intend to teach that leaning is permitted only on a swept stove, there would be no reason to mention permission to lean in conjunction with permission to leave. In any event, this is not an absolute proof, and the dilemma has not been resolved.
The Gemara asks: <b>What conclusion was reached</b> with regard to this dilemma? <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this from that which was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: With regard to <b>a stove that was lit with pomace</b> or <b>with wood, one may lean</b> a pot of cooked food <b>against it; however, one may not leave</b> a pot inside it <b>unless</b> the stove is <b>swept out</b> or <b>covered with ashes. Coals that dimmed or on which a strip of</b> thinly <b>beaten flax was placed</b> and the fire did not ignite, <b>it is as</b> if it were <b>covered with ashes,</b> and one need not add more ashes to it. In any case, the conclusion is drawn from here that one is permitted to lean a dish of cooked food against a stove, even though it is not covered with ashes or swept out.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rav Oshaya said:</b> With regard to a stove that <b>he covered with ashes and</b> that <b>reignited</b> on Shabbat, <b>one may leave hot water that was</b> already <b>completely heated and cooked food that was</b> already <b>completely cooked upon it.</b> In that case, there is no need for additional cooking, and therefore there is no concern that one might come to stoke the coals and ignite the fire.

Daf 37b

<b>Conclude from this</b> <i>halakha</i> that even when it is food that <b>shrivels and improves</b> by remaining on the fire, it is nevertheless <b>permitted</b> to leave it. The food is already completely cooked and there is no concern lest one come to stoke the coals and ignite the fire. Rabbi Oshaya did not distinguish between different types of foods in permitting this. The Gemara rejects this conclusion: <b>Here,</b> it <b>is different</b> because <b>he covered</b> the coals in the stove <b>with ashes,</b> and that is the reason that he is permitted to leave food on the stove. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what</b> purpose was there <b>to say</b> this <i>halakha</i>? Is it to teach that if the coals are covered with ashes, there is no room for concern? That is obvious. The Gemara answers: The case where he covered it with ashes and it <b>reignited</b> on Shabbat <b>was necessary</b> and required additional articulation. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>since it reignited, it returns to its original status</b> and is prohibited, therefore <b>it taught us</b> that this is not the case.
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> With regard to a stove that <b>he</b> swept out or <b>covered with ashes</b> before Shabbat <b>and</b> subsequently <b>reignited</b> on Shabbat, <b>one may leave hot water that</b> was already <b>completely heated and cooked food that</b> was already <b>completely cooked upon it, even if</b> the <b>coals</b> were <b>from</b> the wood of <b>a broom</b> tree, which are very hot and long-burning. If so, <b>conclude from this</b> that even if food <b>shrivels and improves</b> while on the stove, it <b>is permitted</b>. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Here,</b> in this case, <b>it is different</b> because <b>he covered it with ashes.</b> Therefore, it is permitted to leave it on the stove. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, what</b> was the purpose <b>of saying</b> this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: Mention of the case where he covered it with ashes and it <b>reignited</b> on Shabbat <b>was necessary.</b> The Gemara challenges that explanation: <b>This</b> case <b>is identical to the</b> previous <b>one.</b> Why did Rabbi Yoḥanan find it necessary to repeat what was already said? The Gemara responds that there is a novel element in his statement. It <b>was necessary</b> to teach the case of <b>coals</b> from the wood of <b>a broom</b> tree. Even in a case of especially hot coals it is permitted.
<b>Rav Sheshet said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> With regard to <b>a stove that was lit with pomace</b> or <b>with wood, one may leave hot water on it even if</b> the water <b>has not</b> yet <b>been completely heated, and</b> the same is true for <b>cooked food</b> even <b>if it was not</b> yet <b>completely cooked.</b> However, if <b>one removed</b> the food from the stove, <b>one may only return</b> it <b>if he sweeps</b> the coals out of the stove while it is still day, <b>or if he places ashes</b> on the coals. The reason for mentioning this <i>halakha</i> is because <b>he holds</b> that in <b>our mishna we learned</b> with regard to <b>returning</b> the cooked food to the stove; <b>however,</b> with regard to <b>leaving</b> a pot on top of the stove, if it was placed there while it was still day, <b>one may leave it</b> on the stove <b>even if it is not swept and not covered with ashes.</b>
<b>Rava said: We</b> already <b>learned both</b> aspects of Rav Sheshet’s <i>halakha</i> and there is no need to teach us something that was already stated explicitly in the mishna. <b>We</b> already <b>learned</b> that it is permitted <b>to leave</b> a pot on the stove. <b>One may not put bread into the oven at nightfall and</b> may <b>not</b> place <b>cake on top of coals unless</b> there is enough time before Shabbat <b>that its surface will form a crust.</b> However, if <b>its surface already formed a crust</b> before Shabbat, <b>it is permitted</b> to leave it even in an oven that was not swept and not covered with coals. Likewise, <b>we also</b> already <b>learned</b> in our mishna the second aspect of Rav Sheshet’s <i>halakha</i> that it is permitted <b>to return</b> the pot to the fire, as <b>Beit Hillel say: One may even return. And</b> it is clear that <b>Beit Hillel only went so far as permitting</b> the return of the pot <b>in</b> a stove that is <b>swept</b> or <b>covered with ashes; however, in one that is not swept</b> or <b>covered with ashes,</b> they did <b>not</b> permit doing so.
