<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Although</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>one may not place a vessel beneath a hen</b> preparing to lay an egg on Shabbat on an inclined surface, in order <b>to receive its egg</b> and prevent it from breaking when it falls; <b>however,</b> they permitted <b>overturning a vessel onto</b> an egg on Shabbat <b>so that it will not</b> be trampled and <b>break. Rabba said: What is Rav Ḥisda’s reason? He holds</b> that <b>a hen is likely to lay its egg in a garbage dump</b> and people or animals will oftentimes step on it, <b>but it is not likely to lay its egg on an inclined surface</b> where the egg could roll down and break. <b>And in a common</b> case of <b>preservation,</b> the Sages <b>permitted</b> overturning a vessel onto the egg that is located in the garbage dump to protect it from being broken. <b>And in an uncommon</b> case of <b>preservation,</b> i.e., placing a vessel beneath a hen to receive its egg so that it would not roll down an inclined surface, <b>they did not permit</b> doing so.
<b>Abaye raised an objection</b> to Rabba’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> is it so that <b>in an uncommon</b> case of <b>preservation they did not permit</b> taking steps to protect the object on Shabbat? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One whose <b>barrel of untithed produce [<i>tevel</i>],</b> which may not be eaten until it is tithed, <b>broke on top of his roof</b> on Shabbat, <b>may bring a vessel and place it beneath</b> the barrel so that the untithed produce is not lost. Even though eating untithed produce is prohibited on Shabbat, they permitted carrying a vessel to preserve it even in the uncommon case of a barrel that breaks. Apparently, even in an uncommon case of preservation the Sages permit taking the necessary steps. Rabba answered: This too, is a common case of preservation because it is an instance of <b>new barrels [<i>gulfei</i>], which commonly break.</b>
Abaye <b>raised</b> another <b>objection</b> to Rabba’s opinion from the last mishna in this chapter: <b>One may place a vessel beneath the</b> oil <b>lamp</b> in order <b>to receive</b> burning <b>sparks</b> of oil that drip from the burning wick even though this is not common. Rabba answered: <b>Sparks are also common</b> and therefore, it is a common case of preservation.

Daf 43a

Abaye <b>raised</b> another <b>objection to</b> Rabba’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may overturn a bowl on the</b> oil <b>lamp</b> so that the flame <b>will not set</b> fire <b>to the beam.</b> Apparently, the Sages permitted moving a vessel, even though this is not a common case of preservation. Rabba answered him: This is a case <b>of low</b>-ceilinged <b>houses in which fires are common.</b>
<b>And</b> it is <b>likewise</b> difficult from a mishna: <b>The beam</b> of a roof <b>that broke, one may support it with a bench and with the lengths of a bed</b> frame so that it will not fall. Even though this is an uncommon case of preservation, it is permitted. Rabba answered: This is a case <b>of new beams, which commonly break.</b> This too is a common case of preservation.
And Abaye raised another objection from a mishna: <b>One may place a vessel beneath a leak</b> in the ceiling <b>on Shabbat.</b> Apparently, even an uncommon case of preservation is permitted. Rabba answered: This is a case of <b>new houses, which frequently leak.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: This is the reasoning</b> of <b>Rav Ḥisda,</b> who allowed covering a hen’s egg, but not placing a vessel underneath the hen, in order to receive the egg when it is laid: <b>Because</b> by receiving the egg in the vessel, <b>he negates a vessel’s preparedness.</b> Initially, the vessel was available for any use. Since it now contains an egg that may neither be used nor moved, the vessel too may no longer be carried. It is tantamount to breaking the vessel.
<b>Abaye raised an objection</b> to Rav Ḥisda’s opinion, just as he had to Rabba’s opinion, from the <i>Tosefta</i>: One whose <b>barrel of untithed produce,</b> which may not be eaten until it is tithed, <b>broke</b> on Shabbat, <b>may bring another vessel and place it beneath</b> the barrel so that the untithed produce is not lost. Even though eating untithed produce is prohibited on Shabbat, they permitted carrying a vessel to preserve it even in the uncommon case of a barrel that breaks. Apparently, one is permitted to negate the vessel’s preparedness. Rav Yosef <b>said to him:</b> This is not difficult. Fundamentally, <b>untithed produce is available for</b> use on <b>Shabbat. As, if one sins and prepares it</b> for use by tithing it on Shabbat, it is <b>prepared</b> and may be eaten and carried.
Abaye raised another objection from a mishna: <b>One may place a vessel underneath the</b> oil <b>lamp</b> in order <b>to receive</b> the burning <b>sparks</b> of oil that drip from the wick. Once the vessel is filled with the drops of oil, it will no longer be available. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: Sparks have no substance.</b> They burn and dissolve as they fall into the bowl and do not accumulate. Therefore, the vessel may still be used.
<b>And</b> he <b>also</b> raised another objection from a mishna: <b>A beam that broke, one may support it with a bench and with the lengths of a bed</b> frame so that it will not fall. By doing so, he negates the preparedness of the bench or bed frame. He answered: This is a case <b>in which</b> the bench <b>is loosely</b> supporting the beam and not supporting its entire weight. <b>If one wants</b> to do so, <b>he can take</b> the bench. Therefore, the preparedness of the bench is not negated.
And he also raised another objection from a mishna: <b>One may place a vessel beneath a leak</b> that is dripping from the ceiling <b>on Shabbat.</b> The dripping water has no use and is set-aside; therefore, the water negates the vessel’s preparedness. He answered him: This is a case <b>of a leak that is suitable</b> for drinking. Since it has a use, one is permitted to carry the water that is in the vessel. Consequently, he does not negate the vessel’s preparedness by placing it beneath the leak.
And he also raised another objection from a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One may overturn a basket in front of chicks</b> so that <b>they can climb on and climb off</b> of it. By doing so, he negates the vessel’s preparedness due to the chicks, as moving them is prohibited on Shabbat. The Gemara answers: Rav Yosef <b>holds</b> that it <b>is permitted to move</b> the basket on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>it is prohibited to move</b> the basket? The Gemara replies: This prohibition was stated <b>when they are still on it;</b> however, once the chicks climbed off the basket, it may be carried immediately. The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>even though they are no longer on it, it is prohibited</b> to move the basket? Consequently, the vessel’s preparedness is negated. <b>Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> That <i>baraita</i> is referring to the unique case <b>where</b> the chicks <b>remained on top of</b> the basket <b>for the entire twilight</b> period on Shabbat eve. This is in accordance with the principle: <b>Since it was set aside</b> from use during <b>twilight</b> of Shabbat eve, <b>it was set aside for the entire day</b> of Shabbat. The status of every vessel, i.e., whether or not it may be used on Shabbat, is determined at twilight.
With regard to the basic <i>halakha</i> of a hen that lays an egg on Shabbat, <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: Just as one may not place a vessel beneath a hen</b> on Shabbat in order <b>to receive its egg, so</b> too, <b>one may not overturn a vessel onto</b> the egg <b>so that it will not break.</b> The Gemara explains that <b>he holds: A vessel may only be carried</b> on Shabbat <b>for</b> the sake of <b>an object that may be carried on Shabbat.</b> Since the egg may not be carried on Shabbat, it is prohibited to carry a vessel for its sake. The Gemara <b>raises all of these objections</b> that were raised to Rav Hisda’s opinion, which permitted doing so. <b>And he answered:</b> All of those <i>halakhot</i> are referring to cases <b>where</b> one needs to move the vessel that he is using for the set-aside item, because he <b>requires its location.</b> This is in accordance with the principle that once it is permitted, for whatever reason, to move any vessel, one may place it anywhere he chooses.
To clarify whether or not the opinion of Rabbi Yitzḥak is valid, <b>come</b> and <b>hear</b> what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>both an egg that was laid on Shabbat and an egg that was laid on a Festival, one may neither move</b> it <b>to cover a vessel with it, nor to support</b> the <b>legs of a bed with it. However, one may cover it with a vessel so that it does not break.</b> This is contrary to Rabbi Yitzḥak’s opinion. <b>Here too,</b> it is referring <b>to</b> a vessel that one seeks to move because he <b>requires its location.</b> Since he was permitted to move it from its place, he is also permitted to cover an egg with it.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an additional proof from that which we learned: <b>One may spread mats on top of stones on Shabbat.</b> Apparently, it is permissible to move a vessel for the sake of something that may not be moved on Shabbat. The Gemara responds: This is a case <b>of rounded rocks that are suitable to</b> be used in <b>the bathroom.</b> Therefore, it is permitted to carry them on Shabbat.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof from that which we learned: <b>One may spread mats on top of bricks on Shabbat.</b> Bricks may not be used on Shabbat. Nevertheless, one is permitted to carry mats for the sake of bricks that are prohibited for use on Shabbat. The Gemara replies: This is referring to a case of bricks that are not set aside for construction, but <b>are left over from a</b> completed <b>building and are suitable</b> for people <b>to lean on them.</b> Consequently, they are like other household vessels, and moving them and moving mats to protect them is permitted.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof for this from that which we learned: <b>One may spread a mat over a beehive on Shabbat in the sun due to</b> the need to protect it <b>from the sun, and in the rain due to</b> the need to protect it <b>from the rain, as long as he does not intend to trap</b> the bees by covering them. In any event, apparently it is permitted to move a mat for the sake of the beehive even though the beehive itself may not be moved on Shabbat. The Gemara rejects this: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case <b>where there is honey</b> in the beehive. He is permitted to cover it for the sake of the honey. <b>Rav Ukva from Meishan said to Rav Ashi: Granted,</b> you could say this <b>in the summer,</b>

Daf 43b

<b>as there is honey</b> in the beehive during the summer. However, <b>during the rainy season in which there is not honey</b> in the beehive, <b>what can be said</b> according to Rabbi Yitzḥak to explain why it is permitted to cover the beehive at that time? The Gemara answers: This <i>halakha</i> <b>is only applicable</b> in order to permit covering the beehive for <b>those two honeycombs</b> that remain in the hive even during the rainy season so that the bees can feed off of them. The Gemara asks: <b>Aren’t</b> these honeycombs <b>set aside</b> for the bees alone? The Gemara responds: This is a case <b>where one thought of them</b> before Shabbat and, in his mind, prepared them to be eaten. The Gemara asks: By inference, if <b>one did not think about them, what</b> would be the ruling? It would be <b>prohibited</b> to cover the beehive.
<b>If so, this</b> <i>tanna</i> <b>who taught</b> in that same <i>baraita</i>: <b>As long as he does not intend to trap</b> the bees, <b>let him distinguish and teach with regard to</b> that same <i>halakha</i> <b>itself: In what case are these matters stated,</b> that one is permitted to cover the hive? It is in a case <b>where he thought of them</b> before Shabbat. <b>However, if he did not think of them,</b> it is <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This teaches us</b> a novel understanding. <b>Even though he thought of them</b> before Shabbat, it is only permitted <b>as long as he did not intend to trap</b> them.
With regard to the matter itself, the Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, he does not hold</b> that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside.</b> Consequently, there is no distinction between the different beehives. <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, when</b> he <b>does not have intention</b> to trap the bees, <b>what</b> of it? <b>Doesn’t</b> Rabbi Yehuda hold that even an <b>unintentional act is prohibited?</b> The Gemara replies: <b>Actually,</b> this <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. What</b> does: <b>And as long as one does not intend to trap</b> the bees, mean? It means <b>that one should not make</b> the mat <b>like a trap.</b> He must <b>leave space so that</b> the bees <b>will not get trapped on their own.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that it can be resolved differently: <b>Did</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach: In the summer and in the rainy season?</b> Actually, <b>it taught: In the sun due to the sun and in the rain due to the rain.</b> That can be interpreted as follows: <b>In the days of Nisan and in the days of Tishrei, as</b> then <b>there is sun</b> shining <b>and there is</b> also <b>cold</b> weather; <b>and there is rain and there is honey</b> in the beehives.
<b>Rav Sheshet said to</b> the Sages: <b>Go out and tell Rabbi Yitzḥak</b> in Eretz Yisrael: <b>Rav Huna already explained your <i>halakha</i> in Babylonia.</b> There is nothing novel in the principle that you established that a vessel may only be moved for the sake of something that may be moved, <b>as Rav Huna said: One may make a partition for the dead for</b> the benefit of <b>a living person, and one may not make a partition for the dead for</b> the benefit of the <b>dead person.</b> It is prohibited to move objects for the sake of a corpse because it is prohibited to move the corpse itself on Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical application of this <i>halakha</i>? As <b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda said, and likewise</b> the Sage, <b>Sheila Mari taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A corpse that is laid out in the sun</b> and there is concern that it will putrefy and smell, what can be done? <b>Two people come and sit beside it.</b> After a while, when <b>they</b> feel <b>hot from beneath</b> them, <b>this</b> one <b>brings a bed and sits on it and that</b> one <b>brings a bed and sits on it</b> on either side of the corpse, as they are permitted to carry the beds for their own use. When <b>they</b> feel <b>hot from above</b> them, <b>they bring a mat and spread it over their</b> heads. Then, <b>this</b> one <b>stands his bed up</b> so the mat will remain resting atop it <b>and slips away and leaves, and that</b> one <b>stands his bed up and slips away and leaves, and a partition is then created</b> over the corpse as if <b>on its own</b> without erecting it directly for the sake of the corpse. Apparently, the Sages did not permit carrying a mat to cover a corpse for the sake of the corpse. They only permitted doing so in an indirect manner for the benefit of the living.
Incidental to the mention of <i>halakhot</i> related to a corpse on Shabbat, the Gemara cites an amoraic dispute in which <b>it was stated: A corpse that was laid out in the sun, Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: One turns it over from bed to bed</b> until it reaches the shade. <b>Rav Hanina bar Shelamiyya said in the name</b> of <b>Rav: One places a loaf</b> of bread <b>or an infant on</b> the corpse <b>and moves it.</b> The corpse becomes a base for an object that one is permitted to move on Shabbat and, consequently, one may move the corpse due to the permitted object. The Gemara adds: In a case <b>where there is a loaf or an infant, everyone agrees that it is permitted</b> to use that method to move the corpse. <b>Where they argue</b> is in a case <b>where he does not have</b> a loaf or an infant. <b>One Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds: Moving</b> an object <b>in an atypical manner is considered</b> a bona fide act of <b>moving.</b> Therefore, one may not move the corpse by passing it from bed to bed. <b>And the</b> other <b>Sage,</b> Shmuel, <b>holds</b> that moving an object in an atypical manner <b>is not considered moving.</b> Therefore, it is permitted to move a corpse by passing it from bed to bed.
With regard to this dispute between Rav and Shmuel, the Gemara remarks: <b>Let us say</b> that this dispute is <b>parallel</b> to a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>. The Rabbis said: <b>One may not rescue a corpse from a fire</b> on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Lakish said: I heard that one may rescue a corpse from a fire.</b> The Gemara seeks to clarify the matter: <b>What are the circumstances? If there is a loaf or an infant</b> available, <b>what is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of the first <i>tanna,</i></b> who prohibited rescuing the corpse from the fire? <b>If there is not</b> a loaf or an infant, <b>what is the reason</b> of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Lakish</b> who permits rescuing the corpse from the fire? <b>Rather, is it not</b> that <b>they disagree over moving</b> an object <b>in an atypical manner? As</b> this <b>Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>moving</b> an object <b>in an atypical manner is considered moving.</b> Therefore, it is prohibited to rescue the corpse in that manner. <b>And this Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Lakish, <b>holds</b> that <b>moving</b> an object <b>in an atypical manner is not considered moving.</b> Therefore, it is permitted to rescue the corpse in this manner. The amoraic dispute deals with an issue already disputed by the <i>tanna’im</i>. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, everyone,</b> both <i>tanna’im</i>, <b>agrees that moving</b> an object <b>in an atypical manner is considered moving. Rather, this is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda ben Lakish: Since a person is agitated about his deceased</b> relative and is concerned about maintaining the dignity of the dead,

Daf 44a

<b>if you do not permit him</b> to move the corpse in an atypical manner, <b>he will come to extinguish</b> the fire. The Sages permitted performing an act prohibited by rabbinic law so that one will not come to transgress a Torah prohibition. <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Sheila said</b> that <b>Rav Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Lakish with regard to</b> the issue of rescuing <b>a corpse</b> from a fire.
We learned in the mishna that <b>one may not make use of</b> the oil that drips from the candle on Shabbat <b>because it is not among</b> the oil <b>prepared</b> from Shabbat eve for use on Shabbat. With regard to this same issue, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The remaining oil that is in the lamp or in a bowl</b> in which a wick was burning <b>is prohibited</b> for use on Shabbat. However, <b>Rabbi Shimon permits</b> using the remaining oil as, according to his opinion, there is virtually nothing prohibited due to the prohibition of set-aside.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The dispute in this mishna seems to be a local one; however, it is the key to several <i>halakhot</i> in the area of the prohibition of set-aside [<i>muktze</i>]. <b>One may move a new</b> oil <b>lamp</b> on Shabbat <b>but not</b> an <b>old</b> one that was already used. A lamp that was used is covered with soot and unsuitable for use. It is therefore considered set aside from use due to its disgusting nature. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: All</b> oil <b>lamps may be moved</b> on Shabbat <b>except for an</b> oil <b>lamp</b> that is <b>burning on Shabbat,</b> due to the concern that it might be extinguished.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> the dispute in the mishna in greater detail in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One may move a new</b> oil <b>lamp</b> on Shabbat <b>but not an old one;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says: All</b> oil <b>lamps may be moved</b> on Shabbat <b>except for an</b> oil <b>lamp that they kindled on</b> that <b>Shabbat.</b> Rabbi Meir does not hold that one must distance himself from objects that are disgusting. However, since the lamp was burning on Shabbat, it may not be moved, as it is an object set aside due to prohibition for the entire Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> All lamps may be moved <b>except for an</b> oil <b>lamp</b> that is <b>burning on Shabbat.</b> If the flame <b>was extinguished, one is permitted to move it. However, a cup and a bowl and a lantern</b> that are full of oil with a wick lit in them, <b>one may not move them from their place</b> even after the flame is extinguished. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: One may supply</b> himself with oil <b>from an extinguished candle and from the oil that drips</b> from the lamp, <b>and even while the lamp is burning.</b>
<b>Abaye said: Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Shimon, holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>his father in one</b> matter <b>and disagrees with him in one</b> matter. <b>He holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>his father in one</b> matter, <b>as he is not</b> of the opinion that moving <b>set-aside</b> objects is prohibited. <b>And he disagrees with him in one</b> matter; <b>as his father holds</b> that <b>if</b> the flame <b>was extinguished, yes,</b> he may move it, if <b>it was not extinguished, no,</b> he may not move it. <b>And</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>holds: Even though</b> the flame <b>was not extinguished,</b> it is permitted to carry the lamp and to use the oil that drips from it. In his opinion, doing so in no way extinguishes the flame and it is in no way comparable to extinguishing the flame.
Following Rabbi Shimon’s statement, it was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>However, a cup, and a bowl, and a lantern, one may not move them from their place.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is different about these,</b> that even Rabbi Shimon prohibits moving them? <b>Ulla said:</b> In <b>the latter clause</b> of this <i>Tosefta</i>, <b>we came</b> back <b>to</b> explain the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who prohibits moving items that are set-aside.
<b>Mar Zutra strongly objects to</b> Ulla’s explanation: <b>If so, what</b> is the meaning of the word <b>however</b> in the phrase: <b>However,</b> a cup and a bowl, etc.? Rabbi Yehuda prohibited moving an oil lamp as well. In what way could the legal status of a bowl be any different? <b>Rather, Mar Zutra said: Actually,</b> this must be explained differently. That phrase was stated by <b>Rabbi Shimon. And when Rabbi Shimon permitted</b> moving a lamp, that was <b>in</b> the case of <b>a small lamp, which he has in mind,</b> i.e., he is certain that the flame will be extinguished on Shabbat and that he will have the opportunity to use the remaining oil that day. <b>However, these,</b> the bowl and the lantern, <b>which have much</b> oil, <b>no,</b> he does not expect them to be extinguished and he sets them aside from use for the entire Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Using <b>the remaining oil that is in an</b> oil <b>lamp or in a bowl is prohibited</b> on Shabbat, <b>and Rabbi Shimon permits</b> using it. Apparently, Rabbi Shimon does not distinguish between a candle and a bowl. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> where Rabbi Shimon permitted <b>a bowl,</b> was specifically in a case where it is <b>similar to a lamp,</b> i.e., a small bowl in which the flame will quickly extinguish. <b>Here,</b> where Rabbi Shimon prohibited using the oil remaining in a bowl, it is referring to <b>a bowl that is similar to a cup,</b> which is large.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said: A</b> metal <b>candlestick [<i>pamot</i>] that was kindled on Shabbat, according to</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>who permits</b> moving a lamp, <b>it is prohibited</b> because it is large. Whereas, <b>according to</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>who prohibits</b> moving a lamp, a metal candlestick <b>is permitted</b> because it does not become disgusting (Rabbeinu Ḥananel). The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda is of</b> the opinion that an object that is <b>set-aside [<i>muktze</i>] due to repugnance</b> may not be moved, and <b>he is not of</b> the opinion that an object that is <b>set-aside due to prohibition</b> may not be moved, and therefore permits moving the candlestick? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: All metal candlesticks may be moved</b> on Shabbat <b>with the exception of a candlestick that was kindled on Shabbat</b> itself? Apparently, he prohibits moving the metal candlestick, not because it is disgusting but because it is set-aside due to prohibition. <b>Rather, if it was stated, it was stated as follows, Rabbi Zeira said: A</b> metal <b>candlestick that was kindled on Shabbat, everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is prohibited.</b> One that <b>was not kindled</b> on Shabbat, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is permitted</b> because it is neither set aside due to prohibition nor set aside due to repugnance.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: A bed which one designated to</b> place <b>money</b> upon it <b>may not be moved</b> on Shabbat because it is set-aside. It is prohibited even though it no longer has money upon it. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak raised an objection to</b> Rav Yehuda from our mishna: <b>One may move a new</b> oil <b>lamp</b> on Shabbat <b>but not</b> an <b>old</b> one.

Daf 44b

He explains his objection: <b>And just as a lamp, which</b> is <b>made for this</b> purpose, for lighting, <b>when he did not light it, he is permitted to move it, a bed, which is not made for that</b> purpose, for placing money on it, <b>all the more so</b> moving it would be permitted. <b>Rather, if it was stated, it was stated as follows: Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: A bed that one designated for money</b> to be placed upon <b>it,</b> if <b>one left money upon it</b> one day, it becomes designated for that purpose and <b>it is prohibited to move it</b> on Shabbat. If <b>one did not leave money upon it, it is permitted to move it</b> on Shabbat. A bed, which <b>one did not designate for money</b> to be placed upon it, if <b>there is money upon it</b> on Shabbat itself, <b>it is prohibited to move it</b> on Shabbat. If <b>there is not money on it, it is permitted to move it. And that is</b> only <b>when there was not</b> money <b>on it during</b> the <b>twilight</b> period between Shabbat eve and Shabbat. If there was money on it at that time, the bed itself becomes set aside due to prohibition for the entire Shabbat, even if the money fell off the bed in the course of the day.
<b>Ulla said: Rabbi Eliezer raised an objection</b> to Rav’s statement from that which we learned in a mishna. This mishna deals primarily with the laws of ritual impurity and discusses the relationship between a wagon and its undercarriage [<i>mukheni</i>], the system of wheels and the frame at the base of the wagon. And the Sages said: The wagon’s <b>undercarriage, when it is detachable</b> from the wagon, it is <b>not</b> considered <b>connected to it</b> and they are considered independent units as far as the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity are concerned. <b>And it is not measured with it.</b> This refers to calculating the volume of forty <i>se’a</i>, as a vessel with a volume larger than forty <i>se’a</i> does not have the legal status of a vessel and cannot become ritually impure. <b>And</b> the undercarriage likewise <b>does not protect</b> together <b>with</b> the wagon <b>in a tent</b> over <b>the corpse.</b> A large wagon is considered a tent in and of itself and the vessels inside the wagon do not become impure if the wagon is over a corpse. However, the undercarriage is not included with the wagon in this regard. If a hole in the wagon is sealed by the undercarriage, it is not considered sealed with regard to preventing ritual impurity. <b>And,</b> likewise, <b>one may not pull</b> the wagon <b>on Shabbat when there is money upon it.</b>
By inference: <b>If there is not money on it,</b> one is <b>permitted</b> to move the wagon <b>even though there was</b> money <b>on it at twilight.</b> In this mishna, the prohibition is contingent exclusively on whether or not there is money on the wagon at that time. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who is not of</b> the opinion that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside. And Rav holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> Since according to Rabbi Yehuda there is a prohibition of set-aside, the wagon became set aside from use during the twilight period and remains prohibited for the entire Shabbat.

Daf 45a

The Gemara adds: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> to say that <b>Rav holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as Rav said: One may place a lamp atop a palm tree</b> on Shabbat eve to burn <b>on Shabbat, and one may not place a lamp atop a palm tree on a Festival. Granted, if you say</b> that <b>Rav holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> in this matter; <b>that is</b> why there is a <b>distinction between Shabbat and a Festival.</b> Since the lamp is set-aside [<i>muktze</i>] on Shabbat one will not come to carry it. Since one is permitted to carry a lamp on a Festival, there is concern that one might climb the palm tree or make use of the tree on the Festival and thereby transgress the rabbinic prohibition against making use of something connected to the ground on a Festival. <b>However, if you say</b> that Rav <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who maintains that the lamp is not set-aside even on Shabbat, <b>what</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> between <b>Shabbat and a Festival?</b> Ostensibly, there should be no distinction between the two.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>Rav</b> really <b>hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> that it is prohibited to move an object that is set-aside? <b>Didn’t they raise a dilemma before Rav: What is</b> the ruling with regard to <b>moving a Hanukkah candle from before the <i>ḥabarei</i>,</b> Persian Zoroastrian fire priests, <b>on Shabbat?</b> Those priests prohibited lighting fires on certain days. In order to prevent them from discovering that he lit Hanukkah candles it was necessary to quickly move them. <b>And he said to them:</b> One may <b>well</b> do so. Apparently, Rav does not hold that there is a prohibition of set-aside. The Gemara answers: This is not a proof, as <b>exigent circumstances are different</b> and Rav permitted this due to the danger involved. <b>As Rav Kahana and Rav Ashi said to Rav</b> on this matter: Is <b>that the <i>halakha</i>?</b> He said to them: <b>Rabbi Shimon is worthy to rely upon in exigent circumstances</b> like this one.
On this same matter <b>Reish Lakish raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yoḥanan: Wheat</b> kernels <b>that he sowed in the ground</b> that have not yet taken root and he could still gather them, <b>and eggs that</b> were placed <b>beneath the hen</b> and the incubation process has begun, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in these cases? Would Rabbi Shimon agree that in these cases it is prohibited for use on Shabbat? One side of the dilemma is: <b>When is Rabbi Shimon not</b> of the opinion that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside?</b> In a case <b>where</b> one did <b>not reject</b> the object <b>with</b> his own <b>hands,</b> i.e., he did not perform an action setting the object aside. However, in a case <b>where he rejected it with</b> his own <b>hands, he is of</b> the opinion that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside.</b> When he sowed the wheat, he rejected it with his own hands. The same is true with regard to the egg; by placing it under the hen to hatch, he actively rejected it. The other side of the dilemma is: <b>Or, perhaps there is no difference</b> between the cases and Rabbi Shimon holds that there is no prohibition of set-aside in either case. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: There is only</b> a prohibition of <b>set-aside, according to Rabbi Shimon,</b> in the case of <b>oil that is in the lamp while it is burning. Since it was set aside for its mitzva,</b> the lighting of Shabbat candles, and it was also <b>set aside for its prohibition,</b> it is prohibited due to the concern that one might inadvertently extinguish the flame if he moves it while it is burning.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>he not hold</b> that the prohibition of set-aside applies to an object <b>set aside</b> only <b>for its mitzva</b> without any prohibition? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who roofed</b> the <i>sukka</i> <b>in accordance with its halakhic</b> requirements <b>and decorated it</b> for aesthetic purposes <b>with colored hangings and tapestries, and hung</b> as decorations <b>nuts, peaches, almonds and pomegranates, and grape branches, and wreaths made of stalks, wine, oils, and fine flour, it is prohibited to supply</b> himself <b>from them until the conclusion of the last day of the Festival.</b> Since they were all set aside for the mitzva of <i>sukka</i>, all other uses are prohibited. <b>And if one stipulated</b> at the time that he hung them in the <i>sukka</i> that he is not designating them exclusively for this purpose, but he intends to use <b>them</b> for other purposes as well, their use <b>is entirely in accordance with his stipulation.</b> He is permitted to use them as he chooses.
<b>And from where</b> do we know that this unattributed <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon?</b> We ascertained this from a comparison to a <i>baraita</i> that was taught by Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef. <b>As Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef taught before Rabbi Yoḥanan: One may not take wood from the <i>sukka</i></b> that was constructed for shade <b>on</b> any <b>Festival,</b> even if the wood fell from the <i>sukka</i> on the Festival. Because it is prohibited to destroy the <i>sukka</i> on the Festival, it was set aside before the Festival for the entire duration of the Festival. <b>Rather,</b> one may take wood only <b>from what is beside</b> the <i>sukka</i>, i.e., bundles of wood that are not being used for the <i>sukka</i>. When he placed them there, his intention was to use them during the Festival. <b>And Rabbi Shimon permits</b> taking wood even from the <i>sukka</i> itself, since he holds that there is no prohibition of set-aside. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon <b>agree that</b> taking wood from <b>the <i>sukka</i></b> constructed <b>for the <i>Sukkot</i> festival is prohibited during the Festival. And if one stipulated about</b> the wood that he will be able to use it during the Festival, <b>everything is in accordance with his stipulation.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Shimon prohibits using an object that was set aside due only to a mitzva, even though it was not set aside due to a prohibition. Therefore, the Gemara emends Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement: There is no <i>halakha</i> of set-aside according to Rabbi Shimon except in a case <b>similar to oil in the candle.</b> It is not necessary that there be both a prohibited labor and a prohibition due to the mitzva. Rather, <b>since it was set aside for the mitzva</b> alone, it is thereby <b>set aside for the prohibition.</b> It <b>was also stated: Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: There is only</b> a prohibition of <b>set-aside according to Rabbi Shimon in</b> a case <b>similar to oil in the candle while it is burning; since it was set aside for its mitzva, it was set aside for its prohibition.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: There is only</b> a prohibition of <b>set-aside according to Rabbi Shimon</b> in the cases of <b>dried figs and raisins alone.</b> The case of one who takes figs and raisins up to his roof in order to dry them in the sun is the only situation in which Rabbi Shimon holds that they are prohibited on Shabbat due to the prohibition of set-aside. Since in the initial stages of the process they emit a bad odor and are unfit for consumption, one consciously sets them aside. The Gemara challenges: <b>And other items</b> are <b>not</b> included in the prohibition of set-aside? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One who <b>was eating figs and left</b> some over <b>and took them up to the roof to make them</b> into <b>dried figs,</b> and likewise one who was eating <b>grapes and left</b> some over <b>and took them up to the roof to make them</b> into <b>raisins, one may not eat</b> them on Shabbat <b>unless he designates</b> them to be eaten before Shabbat. Otherwise, they are prohibited as set-aside. <b>And you</b> would <b>say the same with regard to peaches, and quinces, and all other types of fruit</b> that one left out to dry. It is prohibited to eat them all on Shabbat due to set-aside.
The Gemara seeks to clarify: <b>Whose</b> opinion <b>is</b> it in the <i>baraita</i>? <b>If you say</b> that it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> this <i>baraita</i> is superfluous. <b>If</b> in a case <b>where one did not reject it with</b> his own <b>hands, he holds</b> that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside,</b> in a case <b>where he rejected it by</b> his own <b>hand, all the more so</b> that it is prohibited. There is no need to articulate the <i>halakha</i> in this unique case.
<b>Rather, isn’t this</b> <i>baraita</i> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon?</b> Apparently, he expands the <i>halakhot</i> of set-aside beyond dried figs and raisins. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Actually,</b> this <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> who holds that there is a prohibition of set-aside. <b>And</b> the case cited here, where he was <b>eating</b> figs, <b>is necessary</b> in order to teach us a novel <i>halakha</i>. <b>It may enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since one was in the course of eating, he does not require</b> prior <b>designation;</b> and if he changed his mind he may immediately retrieve the dried figs that he placed on the roof. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that <b>since he brought them up to the roof, he diverted his attention from them</b> and they are completely set-aside.
On the same topic: <b>Rabbi Shimon bar Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>raised a dilemma before</b> his father, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi:

Daf 45b

<b>Unripe dates</b> that are placed in baskets to ripen and until they are ripe can only be eaten with difficulty, <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, what is</b> their legal status as far as moving them on Shabbat is concerned? Are they considered set-aside? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: There is only</b> a prohibition of <b>set-aside according to Rabbi Shimon</b> in the cases of <b>dried figs and raisins alone.</b>
The Gemara challenges this: <b>And</b> does <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>not hold</b> that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna that on a Festival, before they are slaughtered, <b>one may neither give water to,</b> in order to ease removal of their hides, <b>nor slaughter</b> non-domesticated, <b>desert</b> animals, animals that are always grazing in the fields? Since people do not generally tend to them, they are considered set-aside and may not be used. <b>However, one may give water to and slaughter domesticated animals. And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>these are</b> non-domesticated, <b>desert</b> animals: <b>Any</b> animals <b>that leave</b> their sheds <b>on Passover and</b> only <b>enter</b> their sheds with the advent of the <b>rainy season. Domesticated</b> animals are <b>any</b> animals <b>that go out to graze beyond the</b> city <b>limits, and come and sleep within the</b> city <b>limits. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: These and those are</b> both <b>domesticated. And these are</b> the non-domesticated, <b>desert</b> animals that are prohibited due to the prohibition of set-aside: <b>Any</b> animals <b>that graze in the grazing area and neither enter the town during the summer nor during the rainy season.</b> It is these animals that it is prohibited to give water to or slaughter on a Festival. Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that there is a prohibition of set-aside even in the case of animals.
Several resolutions are proposed to this contradiction: <b>If you wish, say</b> that <b>these</b> non-domesticated animals that graze in the grazing areas throughout the year <b>are also</b> considered <b>like dried figs and raisins.</b> Even Rabbi Shimon would agree to this <i>halakha</i>. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: When Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi told his son that answer, <b>he was saying it to him in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, and he</b> himself <b>does not hold</b> that way.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: In that <i>baraita</i>, <b>he spoke to them in accordance with the statement of the Rabbis,</b> and this is how his statement must be understood: <b>In my opinion I do not hold</b> that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside at all.</b> However, <b>according to your</b> opinion, <b>at least agree with me that</b> animals that leave their sheds <b>on Passover and</b> only <b>enter</b> their sheds with the advent of the <b>rainy season are domesticated. And the Rabbis said to him: No,</b> those <b>are non-domesticated</b> animals.
As to the essential dispute with regard to the laws of set-aside, <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: They said that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> who holds that there is no prohibition of set-aside. The Gemara asks: <b>Did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say this? Didn’t an Elder</b> from <b>Keruya, and some say</b> that he was from <b>Seruya, raise a dilemma before Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> With regard to <b>a hen’s roost, what is</b> its legal status as far as <b>moving it on Shabbat</b> is concerned? Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: Isn’t</b> the roost <b>made exclusively for hens</b> to be inside it? Since it is not designated for use by people, moving it is prohibited. Apparently, he holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda with regard to set-aside. The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> With a special case, <b>when there is a dead chick in</b> the roost. Moving the roost is prohibited due to the dead chick, which is set-aside.
The Gemara continues to ask: This <b>works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Mar bar Ameimar in the name of Rav, who said: Rabbi Shimon agreed in</b> the case of <b>animals that died</b> on Shabbat, <b>that they are prohibited</b> on Shabbat due to set-aside. <b>However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Mar, son of Rav Yosef, in the name of Rava, who said: Rabbi Shimon was in disagreement even in</b> the case of <b>animals that died,</b> and said that <b>they are permitted</b> and are not prohibited as set-aside, <b>what can be said?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case <b>where there is an egg</b> that was laid on Shabbat in the roost. Because it was laid on Shabbat it is considered set-aside, and using the egg is prohibited. The thought of using it never entered anyone’s mind before Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rav Naḥman say: One who is of</b> the opinion that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside, is</b> also <b>of</b> the opinion that there is a prohibition of an object that <b>came into being</b> on Shabbat or on a Festival; and one <b>who is not of</b> the opinion that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside, is</b> also <b>not of</b> the opinion that there is a prohibition of an object that <b>came into being.</b> This case is no different than other cases of set-aside. The Gemara responds: This is referring to a case <b>where</b> the roost <b>has an egg with a chick in it.</b> Even Rabbi Shimon would agree that moving an egg of that sort is prohibited since it is fit for neither human nor animal consumption.
This explanation was cited to explain that Rabbi Yoḥanan could hold in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. However, <b>when Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rabbi Yosef, came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> that there is a prohibition of set-aside. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> that there is no prohibition of set-aside. <b>Rav Yosef said: That is</b> what <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: They said that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> The inference is: <b>They said; however, he</b> himself <b>does not hold</b> that <b>this</b> is the <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: And you</b> yourself <b>did not hold that Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> rules <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> even before Rav Yitzḥak came and cited this statement in his name? <b>Didn’t Rabbi Abba and Rabbi Asi happen</b> to come <b>to the house of Rabbi Abba who was from</b> the city <b>Haifa, and a candelabrum fell onto Rabbi Asi’s cloak and he did not move it? What is the reason</b> that he did not lift it? <b>Is it not because Rabbi Asi was a student of Rabbi Yoḥanan, and Rabbi Yoḥanan holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who holds</b> that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside?</b> Apparently, Rabbi Yoḥanan holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda.
Rav Yosef <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>Candelabrum you say;</b> are you citing a proof from the case of a candelabrum? <b>A candelabrum is different</b> because there is a unique <i>halakha</i> in that case. <b>As Rabbi Aḥa bar</b> Rabbi <b>Ḥanina said</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Reish Lakish issued a ruling in</b> the city of <b>Sidon: A candelabrum that can be moved in one of his hands, one is permitted to move it</b> on Shabbat. However, if it is so heavy that one must move it <b>with his two hands, it is prohibited to move it. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: We have</b> permission to carry <b>only in the case of an</b> oil <b>lamp, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> However, with regard to a candelabrum, <b>both</b> one <b>that is carried in one hand</b> and one <b>that is carried in two hands, it is prohibited to move it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that there is a unique prohibition in the case of a candelabrum? <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef both said: Since a person</b> usually <b>designates</b> a fixed <b>place for it</b> due to its size and its use, it is considered a built-in part of the house, and moving the candelabrum is like dismantling the house. <b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: A groom’s canopy</b> is an object <b>for</b> which <b>a person designates a</b> set <b>place, and,</b> nevertheless, <b>Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya:</b> With regard to a <b>groom’s canopy,</b>

Daf 46a

<b>it is permitted to assemble it and it is permitted to dismantle it on Shabbat.</b> If a permanent object like that one may be assembled on Shabbat and there is no concern for the prohibition of building, all the more so it should not be considered building and dismantling in the case of a candelabrum. <b>Rather, Abaye said:</b> Here it is referring to a special candelabrum made <b>of joints,</b> removable parts, and there is concern lest it fall and break into its component parts when it is moved, and one may come to reassemble it, which would be tantamount to crafting a vessel on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if it is referring to that type of candelabrum, <b>what is the reason</b> for the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish who permits</b> moving the candelabrum?
The Gemara replies: It is not referring to a candelabrum that can actually be dismantled. Rather, <b>what</b> is the meaning of <b>joints? Similar to joints,</b> i.e., <b>there are grooves in it</b> and it appears as if it is made of different components. <b>Therefore,</b> in summary: With regard to a candelabrum made of actual <b>joints, both</b> one that is <b>large</b> and one that is <b>small, it is prohibited to move it. In addition,</b> a <b>large</b> candelabrum <b>that has grooves,</b> everyone agrees that it is prohibited to move it by rabbinic <b>decree,</b> which was issued <b>due to</b> a <b>large</b> candelabrum made of <b>joints.</b> Because it is common for a large candelabrum to be made of joints, if one saw someone carrying a large, grooved candelabrum, he would mistakenly assume that it had joints due to the similarity between them, and would mistakenly permit carrying a large candelabrum actually composed of joints. <b>Where</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish <b>disagree</b> is <b>in</b> the case of a <b>small</b> candelabrum <b>that has grooves. This Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>we issue a decree</b> prohibiting moving even a small, grooved candelabrum due to a large one. <b>And this Sage,</b> Reish Lakish, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not issue a decree.</b> Because a small candelabrum is not typically made of joints, everyone realizes that the grooves are strictly decorative.
The Gemara questions: <b>And did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say that</b> the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda? <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan state</b> the following principle: <b>The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with an unattributed mishna? And we learned</b> in the mishna that discusses ritual impurity of a wagon with a detachable undercarriage: The wagon’s <b>undercarriage, when it is detachable</b> from the wagon, it is <b>not</b> considered <b>connected to it</b> and they are considered independent units as far as the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity are concerned. <b>And it is not measured with it.</b> This refers to calculating the volume of forty <i>se’a</i>, as a vessel with a volume larger than forty <i>se’a</i> does not have the legal status of a vessel and cannot become ritually impure. <b>And</b> the undercarriage likewise <b>does not protect</b> together <b>with</b> the wagon <b>in a tent</b> over <b>the corpse.</b> A large wagon is considered a tent in and of itself, and the vessels inside the wagon do not become impure if the wagon is over a dead body. However, the undercarriage is not included with the wagon in this regard. If a hole in the wagon is sealed by the undercarriage, it is not considered to be sealed with regard to preventing ritual impurity. <b>And,</b> likewise, <b>one may not pull</b> the wagon <b>on Shabbat when there is money upon it.</b>
By inference: <b>If there is not money on it,</b> one is <b>permitted</b> to move the wagon <b>even though there was</b> money <b>on it at twilight.</b> An object that was set aside at twilight is set aside for the entire Shabbat. In this mishna, moving the wagon is permitted. Clearly, the unattributed mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, who holds that there is no prohibition of set-aside. Why, then, did Rabbi Yoḥanan, who always rules in accordance with an unattributed mishna, not rule in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon? <b>Rabbi Zeira said: Let our mishna</b> apply only to a case <b>in which there was no money on</b> the wagon <b>throughout</b> the entire duration of <b>twilight.</b> This strained interpretation is accepted <b>so as not to contradict</b> and reject <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: One time, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>went to</b> the town of <b>Deyosfera, and issued a ruling with regard to a candelabrum in accordance with</b> the ruling that <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> made <b>with regard to an</b> oil <b>lamp.</b> This description is insufficiently clear, therefore <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Does this mean that <b>he issued a ruling in</b> the case of a candelabrum, <b>like</b> the ruling that <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> made <b>in</b> the case of <b>an</b> oil <b>lamp, to permit</b> moving it? <b>Or, perhaps, he issued a ruling in</b> the case of <b>a candelabrum to prohibit</b> moving it, <b>and</b> in another case he ruled <b>in accordance with</b> the ruling that <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> made <b>in</b> the case of <b>an</b> oil <b>lamp, to permit</b> moving it. There was no resolution found to this dilemma and therefore it <b>stands</b> unresolved.
It is told that <b>Rav Malkiya happened</b> to come <b>to the house of Rabbi Simlai and moved an</b> extinguished oil <b>lamp, and Rabbi Simlai became angry,</b> as in his opinion it is prohibited to move an oil lamp because it is set-aside. Likewise, <b>Rabbi Yosei the Galilean happened</b> to come <b>to the place of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, and moved an</b> oil <b>lamp, and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, became angry.</b> The Gemara also relates that <b>Rabbi Abbahu, when he happened</b> to come <b>to the place of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, he would move an</b> oil <b>lamp.</b> However, <b>when he happened</b> to come <b>to the place of Rabbi Yoḥanan, he would not move an</b> oil <b>lamp.</b> The Gemara wondered: <b>Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it there is a difficulty. <b>If he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, let him act in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> everywhere and refrain from moving the lamp. <b>And if he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, let him act in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> everywhere and move the oil lamp. The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it can be explained that Rabbi Abbahu <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon; however, in deference to Rabbi Yoḥanan he did not act</b> accordingly, so as not to act contrary to his ruling in the place where he was the authority.
With regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of moving lamps on Shabbat, <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> With regard to <b>an</b> extinguished <b>oil lamp, it is permitted to move it,</b> whereas a <b>naphtha</b> lamp, <b>it is prohibited to move it.</b> Since the smell of naphtha is unpleasant, the lamp is used exclusively for lighting. Therefore, moving it is prohibited. <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef both said:</b> With regard to <b>a naphtha</b> lamp, <b>too, it is permitted to move it.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Avya happened</b> to come <b>to Rava’s house. His feet were dirty with clay</b> and <b>he put them on the bed before Rava. Rava became angry</b> at him for dirtying the bed and, therefore, <b>sought to torment him</b> with questions that he could not answer. Rava <b>said to him: What is the reason</b> that <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef both said</b> that with regard to <b>a naphtha lamp, too, that it is permitted to move it?</b> Rav Avya <b>said to him: Since it is suitable to cover a vessel with it.</b> Rava <b>said to him: But if that is so, all pebbles</b> in the yard <b>may</b> also <b>be carried</b> <i>ab initio</i> on Shabbat, <b>since it is suitable to cover a vessel with them.</b> Rav Avya <b>said to him:</b> There is a distinction between these cases. <b>This,</b> the lamp, <b>the status of a vessel</b> applies <b>to it</b> and there are leniencies that apply to vessels with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of set-aside. <b>These,</b> the pebbles, <b>the status of a vessel does not</b> apply <b>to it,</b> as they are a raw material. Carrying them is prohibited unless designated for a specific purpose before Shabbat. <b>Was it not taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that

Daf 46b

<b>bracelets, nose-rings and rings,</b> although it is prohibited to go out into the public domain wearing them on Shabbat, <b>they are like all the vessels that may be moved in the courtyard;</b> in the private domain, one may move them and they are not set-aside. <b>And Ulla said: What is the reason</b> that it is permitted to move nose-rings in the yard? It is <b>because the status of a vessel</b> applies <b>to it.</b> Apparently, vessel status is sufficient to permit moving it on Shabbat. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Thank God</b> that <b>Rava did not embarrass Rav Avya</b> and Rav Avya managed to successfully answer Rava’s questions.
<b>Abaye raised a contradiction before Rabba</b> citing two sources with regard to set-aside on Shabbat. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the remaining oil that is in an</b> oil <b>lamp and in a bowl</b> in which a wick was lit, it <b>is prohibited</b> to use it on Shabbat <b>and Rabbi Shimon permits</b> using it. <b>Apparently, Rabbi Shimon is not of</b> the opinion that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside. And a contradiction is raised</b> from a parallel source, in which the Sages discussed the <i>halakha</i> of the firstborn of a kosher animal that developed a blemish on a Festival. The firstborn must be examined to determine whether or not that type of blemish disqualifies the animal from being sacrificed as an offering. If it is disqualified, it may be redeemed, slaughtered, and eaten as non-sacred meat on the Festival. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Any</b> firstborn animal <b>whose blemish is not perceptible before the Festival is not among</b> the animals <b>prepared</b> prior to the Festival for use on the Festival, and it is prohibited to slaughter it. Apparently, an item not prepared in advance has set-aside status according to Rabbi Shimon.
Rabba said to him: <b>How can you compare</b> these cases? <b>There,</b> in the case of the lamp, <b>a person sits and anticipates when his candle will be extinguished.</b> It is clear to him that it will be extinguished, and he can safely assume that a certain amount of oil will remain in the lamp or the bowl. <b>Here,</b> does <b>a person sit and anticipate when a blemish will befall</b> his animal? The owner of the animal <b>says: Who says that a blemish will befall</b> his animal? <b>And</b> even <b>if you say that a blemish will befall it, who says that a permanent blemish</b> that would enable it to be slaughtered <b>will befall it? And</b> even <b>if you say that a permanent blemish will befall it, who says that a Sage will</b> agree to <b>engage</b> in examining the blemish? Since there are so many uncertainties involved, if the blemish is not perceptible before the Festival, the possibility of the firstborn animal becoming available does not enter a person’s mind at all.
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raised an objection</b> to this last point from that which we learned in a mishna: <b>One may nullify vows on Shabbat.</b> A woman who vowed that certain food is prohibited to her, her husband can nullify her vow on Shabbat. <b>And</b> likewise <b>one may request</b> that a Sage find an opening <b>to</b> dissolve his <b>vows,</b> i.e., a factor that the one taking the vow failed to take into account or an element of regret, if that nullification or dissolution is <b>for the purpose of Shabbat.</b> The question arises: <b>And why,</b> after a man has nullified his wife’s vow, should she be permitted to eat that food? When the woman vowed not to eat that food, she consciously set it aside. Even if some way to dissolve the vow is found, the food should remain set-aside. On the basis of the same uncertainty that was raised above, <b>say: Who says that</b> her husband <b>will</b> agree to <b>engage</b> in nullifying her oath? Perhaps he will refuse to nullify it.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of vows, it can be explained <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rav Pineḥas</b> said <b>in the name</b> of <b>Rava,</b> who came to explain some of the fundamentals of the <i>halakhot</i> of vows, <b>as Rav Pineḥas said in the name</b> of <b>Rava: Every</b> woman <b>who takes a vow,</b> it is from the outset contingent <b>on her husband’s consent that she takes the vow.</b> Since she knows that her husband has the ability to nullify it, her vows are not absolute and their final validation comes only through her husband’s agreement. When a woman vows, she does not set aside the food absolutely from potential use.
Moreover, the Gemara cites proof for this from that which was taught: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: One may request</b> that a Sage dissolve his <b>vows for the purpose of Shabbat on Shabbat,</b> i.e., one who vowed on Shabbat that eating on that day is prohibited for him. <b>And why</b> is he permitted to eat something that was prohibited to him by his vow? <b>Say</b> again: <b>Who says that</b> the <b>Sage will</b> agree to <b>engage</b> in dissolution of <b>his</b> vow? Consequently, one has certainly diverted his attention from the food, set it aside, and it should be prohibited to eat it. The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, there is a difference, as <b>there,</b> in the <i>halakhot</i> of vows, even <b>if</b> the <b>Sage does not</b> agree to <b>engage</b> in dissolution of <b>his</b> vow, <b>he</b> can <b>suffice</b> with renouncing the vow <b>before three common people.</b> Even though it is preferable to have a Sage dissolve his vow, in exigent circumstances one may turn to a court of three common people to dissolve it. He will certainly find a way to dissolve his vow. However, <b>here,</b> in the case of the firstborn animal, <b>who says that</b> the <b>Sage will</b> agree to <b>engage</b> in examination of the blemish? In the <i>halakhot</i> of firstborn animals only an ordained Sage, who received special license to do so, is authorized to verify that it is a permanent blemish and permit redemption and slaughter of the animal as a non-sacred animal.
<b>Abaye raised a contradiction before Rav Yosef: Did Rabbi Shimon</b> actually <b>say</b> that when a lamp <b>is extinguished,</b> it <b>is permitted to move it</b> on Shabbat? By inference: After <b>it is extinguished, yes,</b> moving it is permitted; so long as it <b>is not extinguished, no,</b> moving it is prohibited. <b>What is the reason</b> that it is prohibited to move a burning candle? It is due to concern that <b>perhaps, as he moves</b> the lamp, the flame <b>will be extinguished.</b> However, is Rabbi Shimon really concerned that a flame will be extinguished under those circumstances? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon stated</b> a principle: <b>An unintentional act,</b> a permitted action from which an unintended prohibited labor ensues on Shabbat, since he did not intend to perform the prohibited action, <b>is permitted? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>Rabbi Shimon says: A person may drag a bed, chair, and bench</b> on the ground, <b>as long as he does not intend</b> to <b>make a furrow</b> in the ground. Even if a furrow is formed inadvertently, one need not be concerned. Since that was not his intention, there is no prohibition according to Rabbi Shimon. Consequently, according to Rabbi Shimon there should be no prohibition in moving a burning candle, even though it may be extinguished. Since that is not the intention of the one moving it, no prohibition would be violated.
The Gemara answers that there is a distinction between the cases: In <b>every</b> case <b>where if</b> he <b>intends</b> to perform the action, <b>there is a prohibition by Torah law,</b> e.g., extinguishing a candle; even <b>when he does not intend</b> to do so, <b>Rabbi Shimon issued a decree</b> prohibiting it <b>by rabbinic law.</b> However, in <b>every</b> case <b>where</b> even <b>if</b> he <b>intends</b> to perform the action, <b>there is</b> merely <b>a prohibition by rabbinic law,</b> e.g., digging a furrow which is not a full-fledged act of plowing that is prohibited by Torah law, but is prohibited only by rabbinic law, <b>when he does not intend</b> to perform the action, <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> even <b>permits</b> performing this action <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> to this distinction from that which we learned in a mishna: <b>Clothing merchants</b> who sell garments made of diverse kinds, a prohibited mixture of wool and linen, <b>may sell them as they normally would</b> to gentiles. A merchant may place the garments he is selling on his shoulders and need not be concerned about the prohibition against wearing diverse kinds, <b>as long as</b> the merchant <b>does not intend</b> to benefit from the garments <b>in the sun</b> as protection <b>from the sun, or in the rain</b> as protection <b>from the rain. However, the modest</b> people, those who are particularly meticulous in their performance of mitzvot, would <b>suspend</b> the wool and linen garments <b>on a stick behind them. And here, isn’t it</b> a case where <b>if</b> one <b>intends</b> to wear the clothing, <b>there is a prohibition by Torah law,</b> and even so <b>when</b> he <b>does not intend</b> to wear it, <b>Rabbi Shimon permits</b> it <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Shimon does not distinguish between cases on that basis.
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> a different explanation for Rabbi Shimon’s prohibition in the case of an oil lamp:

Daf 47a

<b>Leave the candle, oil, and wick, since</b> they <b>became a base for a prohibited object.</b> Even Rabbi Shimon agrees that a flame burning on Shabbat is set-aside. Since it is prohibited to move the flame, moving the lamp, oil, and wick is also prohibited.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said</b> that <b>Rabbi Romanus said: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permitted me to carry a coal pan with its ashes. Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Asi: Did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say that? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>A person may carry his son</b> in his hands <b>and</b> even if the son has <b>a stone,</b> which is prohibited to carry, <b>in his hands; or,</b> one may carry <b>a basket with a stone inside it? And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: We are dealing with a basket that is full of fruit.</b> Due to the fruit, carrying the stone is also permitted. <b>The reason</b> for the leniency is because <b>there is fruit inside</b> the basket; <b>however,</b> if <b>there is no fruit inside it, no,</b> one may not move it. With regard to the coal pan that is filled with ashes, how can moving it be permitted according to Rabbi Yoḥanan?
<b>“He was astonished for a while”</b> (Daniel 4:16) and could not find an answer. <b>And,</b> ultimately, Rabbi Asi <b>said: Here, too,</b> it is referring to a case where the coal pan <b>has bits</b> of frankincense that were not yet burned. Due to those bits, moving the pan is permitted. <b>Abaye said: Are</b> small <b>bits in the house of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>significant?</b> Since they are not significant, they are nullified by the ashes and the mixture is entirely unsuitable for use.
<b>And if you say:</b> The bits <b>are suitable</b> for the <b>poor.</b> We will explain that the value of an object is determined not by its context, but by its intrinsic value. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that there is a difference with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity between garments belonging to poor people, which can become ritually impure even if they are very small, and garments belonging to the wealthy, which are not considered significant unless they contain a larger amount of fabric? Garments the size of <b>poor people’s clothing</b> are <b>for the poor,</b> and garments the size of <b>rich people’s clothing</b> are <b>for the rich; however,</b> clothes of <b>the poor for the rich are not</b> significant. Apparently, the significance of an object is determined by its context and its owner. <b>Rather, Abaye said</b> an alternative explanation: The <i>halakha</i> here is <b>just as</b> it is <b>in</b> the case of <b>a chamber pot of feces.</b> Since it is disgusting, removing it from the house is permitted, even though clearly there is no use for it.
<b>Rava said:</b> There are <b>two answers to</b> reject <b>this</b> analogy: <b>One, a chamber pot with feces is disgusting, and</b> the coal pan <b>is not disgusting. And furthermore: A chamber pot with feces is uncovered</b> and smells, <b>and</b> the coal pan <b>is covered. Rather, Rava said</b> an alternative explanation: <b>When we were at the house of Rav Naḥman we would move a coal pan [<i>kanuna</i>] on account of the ashes, and we did this even though there were broken pieces of wood on it.</b> Since the ashes can be used to cover filth, it is not set-aside and the coal pan may be moved due to the ashes. Even if there were also broken sticks on the pan that are useless, nevertheless they are nullified by the ashes. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to this last remark from that which was cited previously: <b>And</b> Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon <b>agree that if there were fragments of a wick in</b> the lamp, <b>that it is prohibited to move</b> it. Apparently, these fragments are not null and render the entire lamp set-aside. <b>Abaye said:</b> No proof can be cited from that <i>baraita</i> because <b>they taught</b> it <b>in the Galilee,</b> where oil is abundant and inexpensive. That is why broken wicks are not nullified relative to the oil (Rav Nissim Gaon).
The Gemara relates that <b>Levi bar Shmuel found Rabbi Abba and Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya, who were standing at the entrance of Rav Huna’s house.</b> Levi bar Shmuel <b>said to them: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>reassembling a weaver’s loom,</b> which was typically a collapsible frame, <b>on Shabbat? He said to him:</b> It may <b>well</b> be done. <b>He came before Rav Yehuda,</b> asking him the same question, and Rav Yehuda <b>said</b> to him that <b>Rav and Shmuel both said: One who reassembles a weaver’s loom on Shabbat is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> as he performed a labor prohibited by Torah law on Shabbat.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of Levi bar Shmuel from the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who reassembles the branch of a</b> disassembled <b>candelabrum on Shabbat is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> With regard to <b>the plasterer’s pole,</b> which has several component parts, <b>one may not reassemble it</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>and if he reassembled it, he is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering, <b>although it is prohibited. Rabbi Simai says:</b> With regard to <b>a rounded horn,</b> which is a trumpet that can be dismantled and whose assembly is complicated, one who reassembled it <b>is liable.</b> However, <b>a straight horn,</b> which is easy to assemble, one who assembled it <b>is exempt.</b> Apparently, assembling an object that consists of several components on Shabbat is prohibited by Torah law, and one is liable to bring a sin-offering for doing so. The Gemara answers: <b>They said</b> that it is permitted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A bed frame,</b> which is a wooden frame through which the ropes of the bed were interlaced, <b>and the legs of the bed, and the archer’s tablets [<i>skibas</i>],</b> which refers to the part of a bow upon which one pulls the arrow back, if they were detached from the bed or from the bow, <b>one may not reassemble</b> them, <b>and if he reassembled</b> them <b>he is exempt.</b>

Daf 47b

<b>However,</b> doing so is <b>prohibited. And one may not fasten</b> the pieces together forcefully, <b>and if he fastens</b> them, <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering</b> for performing a labor prohibited by Torah law. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: If it was loose</b> and could be assembled with ease, <b>it is permitted.</b> Rabbi Abba and Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya relied on this opinion.
The Gemara relates: <b>In the house of Rav Ḥama,</b> Rava’s grandfather, <b>there was a collapsible bed,</b> similar to a weaver’s loom, <b>and they would reassemble it on a Festival. One of the Sages said to Rava: What is your opinion?</b> Do you hold that this <b>is allowed</b> because <b>it is building in an atypical manner?</b> In other words, one is not performing the prohibited labor of building since it is was not performed in the standard manner? <b>Although there is no Torah prohibition, there is, in any case, a rabbinic prohibition.</b> Rava <b>said to him: I hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> who said that <b>if it were loose, it is permitted</b> even <i>ab initio</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may place a vessel beneath the</b> oil <b>lamp</b> in order <b>to receive</b> burning <b>sparks</b> of oil that fall from the lamp so that they will not cause a fire. <b>And he may not place water into</b> the vessel <b>because he</b> thereby <b>extinguishes</b> the sparks.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: How is it permitted to position this vessel to receive the sparks, <b>doesn’t he</b> thereby <b>negate</b> the <b>vessel’s preparedness?</b> It is no longer prepared for any use on Shabbat as the sparks accord it set-aside status. The opinion that negating the preparedness of a vessel is prohibited has already been stated. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: Sparks have no substance.</b> They burn immediately and do not leave behind any trace of oil in the vessel. Therefore, the vessel remains suitable to be moved.
<b>And</b> we also learned in the mishna that <b>one may not place water into</b> the vessel situated beneath the candle <b>because he</b> thereby <b>extinguishes</b> the sparks. The Gemara remarks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>we learned</b> an <b>unattributed</b> mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who <b>said</b> that even an action that <b>causes extinguishing</b> indirectly <b>is prohibited?</b> The extinguishing in this case, where water was placed into a vessel, was not accomplished by means of a direct action. His action only caused it to extinguish indirectly.
The Gemara rejects this question in astonishment: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> it in that manner? <b>Say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei said</b> that indirectly causing extinguishing is prohibited <b>on Shabbat; on Shabbat eve did he say</b> this? <b>And if you say</b> that <b>here, too, it is</b> referring to a case where he placed water in the vessel <b>on Shabbat, wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may place a vessel underneath an</b> oil <b>lamp to receive sparks</b> that fall from the lamp <b>on Shabbat, and, needless to say,</b> placing it there is permitted <b>on Shabbat eve? And one may not put water into</b> the vessel <b>because he will</b> thereby <b>extinguish</b> the spark, even if he placed it there <b>on Shabbat eve, and, needless to say,</b> doing so is prohibited <b>on Shabbat</b> itself. Apparently, the prohibition in the mishna is not at all connected to Rabbi Yosei’s approach. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: Even if you say</b> that this mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, it is different here because,</b> in this case, he is not only causing the spark to extinguish. He is <b>hastening its extinguishing,</b> as the sparks are extinguished immediately when they fall into the water (Rabbeinu Ḥananel). In this matter even the Rabbis would prohibit doing so.

When a pot is removed from the fire on Shabbat eve it may be insulated in materials that preserve its heat, but not in materials that increase its heat. Raising the temperature of a pot is tantamount to cooking. The <i>mishnayot</i> that follow list those materials in which such a pot may be insulated on Shabbat eve and those materials in which it may not be insulated.<br><br><strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>In what may one insulate</b> a pot of cooked food on Shabbat eve, <b>and in what may one not insulate</b> it? <b>One may neither insulate</b> it <b>in the solid residue</b> of produce that has been pressed free of its oil, <b>nor in manure, nor in salt, nor in lime, nor in sand, whether</b> those materials are <b>moist</b> or <b>whether</b> they are <b>dry.</b> All of these materials spontaneously generate heat when piled for an extended period. Therefore, they add heat to a pot insulated in them.
<b>And</b> one may <b>neither</b> insulate a pot <b>in straw, nor in the residue of grapes</b> that have been pressed for their juice, <b>nor in soft material,</b> e.g., from tattered clothing, <b>nor in grass, when these</b> materials <b>are moist. However, one may insulate</b> a pot <b>in them when they are dry.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Did we learn</b> with regard to <b>the residue of olives</b> in the mishna, <b>but</b> the residue <b>of sesame</b> seeds that were pressed for their oil, which produces less heat, may <b>well</b> be used for insulating food on Shabbat eve? <b>Or, perhaps, we learned</b> with regard to the residue <b>of sesame</b> in the mishna, <b>and all the more so</b> insulating food in the residue <b>of olives</b> is prohibited?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from what <b>Rabbi Zeira said in the name of one</b> of the Sages <b>of the school of Rabbi Yannai:</b> With regard to <b>a basket in which one insulated</b> food in a permissible manner, e.g., in dry soft material or the like, <b>it is prohibited to place it upon the residue of olives. Conclude from this</b> that <b>we learned</b> with regard to the residue <b>of olives</b> in our mishna; however, insulating food in the residue of sesame is permitted.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Actually, I</b> can <b>say to you</b> that <b>with regard to</b> actual <b>insulation,</b> the residue <b>of sesame is also prohibited.</b> However, <b>with regard to</b>

Daf 48a

<b>causing heat to rise,</b> i.e., heating food that is not actually insulated in it, but merely resting upon it, the residue <b>of olives causes heat to rise.</b> Therefore, it is prohibited even to place cooked food upon it. However, the residue <b>of sesame does not cause heat to rise</b> to that extent. Therefore, it is permitted to place food upon it.
The Gemara relates an anecdote somewhat relevant to the previous discussion: <b>Rabba and Rabbi Zeira happened</b> to come <b>to the house of the Exilarch</b> on Shabbat, and <b>saw this servant who placed a jug [<i>kuza</i>] of</b> cold <b>water on the mouth of a kettle</b> filled with hot water. <b>Rabba rebuked him</b> for having acted contrary to the <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rabbi Zeira said to</b> Rabba: <b>How is</b> this case <b>different</b> from placing <b>an urn on top of</b> another <b>urn,</b> which is permitted on Shabbat? Rabba <b>said to him: There,</b> when he places one urn on top of another urn, <b>he</b> merely <b>preserves</b> the heat in the upper urn; therefore, it is permitted. <b>Here,</b> in the case where he places the jug of cold water on the mouth of a kettle, <b>he is generating</b> heat in the water in the upper vessel; therefore, it is prohibited.
The Gemara continues: Rabba <b>then saw</b> that same servant <b>spread a kerchief [<i>dastodar</i>] over a vat</b> of water <b>and place a cup</b> used to draw water from the vat, <b>on</b> the kerchief. Once again, <b>Rabba rebuked him</b> for having acted improperly. <b>Rabbi Zeira said to him: Why</b> did you rebuke him?
