Rabba <b>said to him: Now, see</b> what will happen. <b>Ultimately, he saw that</b> the servant <b>was squeezing</b> out the water that was absorbed by the kerchief, thereby violating a Torah prohibition. Nevertheless, Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: How is this</b> case <b>different from</b> that of a <b>cloth [<i>parvanka</i>],</b> which one is permitted to spread over a vat even on Shabbat? Rabba <b>said to him:</b> There is a distinction between the two cases: <b>There,</b> in the case of the cloth, <b>he is not particular about it;</b> even if it gets wet, he will not come to squeeze it dry. <b>Here,</b> with regard to the kerchief, <b>he is particular about it,</b> and he will wring it so that it will not remain wet.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And</b> one may <b>neither</b> insulate a pot <b>in straw</b>, nor in the residue of grapes that were pressed for their juice, nor in soft material. <b>Rav Adda bar Mattana raised a dilemma before Abaye:</b> With regard to swatches of <b>soft material in which he insulated</b> a pot, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to moving</b> that material <b>on Shabbat?</b> Ordinarily, swatches of materials of that kind are set-aside because they have no use. Therefore, moving them on Shabbat is prohibited. Do we say that since they are now being used to insulate a pot, they assume the legal status of a utensil, which may be moved on Shabbat?
Abaye <b>said to him:</b> Just <b>because he does not</b> now <b>have a basket of straw</b> in which to insulate his food, <b>does he stand up and renounce his basket of soft material?</b> Obviously, he would have preferred to insulate his food in straw, as it is less expensive. The only reason that he used that material was because there was no straw available at the time. However, he does not want the swatches of material to be used for any other purpose, lest it be ruined. Therefore, it remains set-aside.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say</b> that the following <i>baraita</i> <b>supports him: One may insulate</b> a pot of food on Friday afternoon <b>in woolen fleece, in combed wool, in tabs of</b> wool dyed <b>purple, and in</b> swatches of <b>soft material; however, he may not move them.</b> Apparently, this is in accordance with the opinion of Abaye.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>If that is the reason, there is no</b> conclusive <b>argument,</b> as <b>it is saying</b> in the <i>baraita</i> <b>as follows: If,</b> however, <b>he did not insulate</b> a pot <b>in them, he may not move them</b> on Shabbat. In that case, they remain earmarked for their own purpose and are therefore set-aside [<i>muktze</i>].
The Gemara questions this last assertion: <b>If so, what</b> is the reason <b>to say</b> that? Obviously, those materials are set-aside. The Gemara explains: <b>Lest you say</b> that all these materials <b>are suitable</b> for one <b>to sit on them,</b> and, consequently, their legal status is that of utensils, which may be moved. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so, and they may not be moved due to the prohibition of set-aside.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Ḥisda permitted returning stuffing to the pillow</b> from which it had fallen <b>on Shabbat. Rav Ḥanan bar Ḥisda raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may untie the neck opening</b> of a shirt <b>on Shabbat</b> if it had been tied by the launderer; <b>however, one may not open</b> a new neck opening for the first time on Shabbat. <b>And one may not place soft material into a pillow or into a cushion on a Festival, and, needless to say,</b> one may not do so <b>on Shabbat.</b> This <i>baraita</i> contradicts the ruling issued by Rav Ḥisda.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>new</b> pillows, whereas <b>that,</b> the statement of Rav Ḥisda is referring to <b>old</b> pillows. Stuffing a pillow for the first time on Shabbat is prohibited because by so doing one fashions a new utensil. However, if the stuffing fell out of the pillow, refilling the pillow is permitted even on Shabbat.
The Gemara notes: <b>That</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not place soft material</b> as stuffing <b>into a pillow or into a cushion on a Festival, and needless to say</b> one may not do so <b>on Shabbat.</b> However, if the stuffing <b>fell out, it may be replaced</b> even <b>on Shabbat, and needless to say</b> that doing so is permitted <b>on a Festival.</b>
Having raised the issue of opening a collar, the Gemara cites that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who opens</b> a new <b>neck opening</b> in a shirt <b>on Shabbat,</b> by cutting through the fabric and threads that kept it closed, <b>is liable to bring a sin-offering.</b> By creating the opening, he renders the shirt fit to wear, thereby fashioning a utensil on Shabbat.
<b>Rav Kahana strongly objects to this:</b>

Daf 48b

<b>What is</b> the difference <b>between this and the stopper of a</b> wine <b>barrel,</b> which the Sages permitted piercing on Shabbat in order to serve wine to guests? There, too, by piercing the stopper, he fashions a utensil. <b>Rava said to him:</b> The cases are not comparable: In <b>this</b> case, the neck opening of a shirt, it is considered a <b>connection,</b> i.e., it is an organic part of the weave of the fabric; whereas in <b>that</b> case, the stopper of the barrel, it is <b>not</b> considered a <b>connection.</b> Even though the stopper is sealed in place in the barrel, it is a separate entity. When the stopper is pierced, no new vessel is fashioned.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raised a contradiction before Rabbi Zeira. We learned</b> in a mishna: <b>The basting of launderers,</b> garments that a launderer sewed together with loose, temporary stitches to avoid losing them; <b>and a ring of keys; and a garment that was sewn with</b> a thread of <b>diverse kinds,</b> e.g., a woolen garment that was stitched with linen thread, which must be pulled out; even though they are attached only temporarily, as they will all eventually be separated, it is considered <b>a connection with regard to</b> issues of <b>ritual impurity.</b> If a source of ritual impurity comes into contact with one of the garments, they all become ritually impure, <b>until one</b> actually <b>begins to untie them,</b> thereby indicating that he does not want them attached. <b>Apparently,</b> even when these items are <b>not in use,</b> e.g., after the launderer finished laundering the clothes, it is <b>also</b> considered <b>a connection.</b>
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a different mishna: With regard to <b>a stick that one made into an axe handle,</b> it is considered <b>a connection</b> between the stick and the axe <b>with regard to</b> issues of <b>ritual impurity when in use.</b> If the axe comes into contact with a source of ritual impurity, the stick also becomes ritually impure, and vice versa. By inference: Only <b>when</b> the axe is actually <b>in use, yes,</b> it is considered a connection; <b>when</b> the axe is <b>not in use, no,</b> it is not considered a connection.
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>There,</b> in the case of the axe, <b>when not in use, a person is likely to throw</b> the stick <b>into the wood</b> pile, as he is not particular about keeping them together. Therefore, it is not considered a connection with regard to ritual impurity. <b>Here,</b> with regard to the items listed in the first mishna, even <b>when not in use, he prefers</b> that they remain attached. In <b>that</b> way, <b>if they get dirty, he can launder them again,</b> as it is easier to wash one connected unit than several smaller swatches of fabric. Therefore, it is considered a connection with regard to ritual impurity.
<b>In Sura, they taught this</b> following <b><i>halakha</i> in the name of Rav Ḥisda; in Pumbedita, they taught</b> it <b>in the name of Rav Kahana, and some say,</b> it was taught <b>in the name of Rava: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught this matter stated by the Sages:</b> The status of <b>anything connected to</b> an object <b>is like</b> that of the object with regard to ritual impurity?
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The <i>tanna</i> in question <b>is Rabbi Meir, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>The receptacle</b> for <b>the cruse</b> of oil, <b>and the receptacle</b> for <b>the spices, and the receptacle</b> for <b>the lamp that are in the stove become ritually impure through contact,</b> i.e., if the wall of the stove becomes ritually impure through contact with a creeping animal, the receptacles also become ritually impure. However, these receptacles <b>do not become ritually impure through air</b> space, i.e., if the creeping animal were inside the stove but did not come into contact with its walls, the stove itself becomes ritually impure, but the receptacles do not; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> the receptacles <b>ritually pure,</b> even if the creeping animal came into actual contact with the stove.
The Gemara analyzes this dispute: <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon; he holds</b> that these receptacles <b>are not</b> considered <b>like the stove</b> itself, and therefore they do not become ritually impure when the stove becomes ritually impure. <b>However,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> it is difficult. <b>If</b> he holds that <b>they are</b> considered <b>like the stove</b> itself, then <b>even</b> if the creeping animal was <b>in the</b> stove’s <b>air space,</b> the receptacles <b>should also become ritually impure. If</b> he holds that <b>they are not</b> considered <b>like the stove</b> itself, then <b>even</b> if the creeping animal came <b>into contact</b> with the stove, the receptacles <b>should also not become ritually impure.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> by Torah law, the receptacles <b>are not</b> considered <b>like the stove</b> itself, <b>and the Sages are the ones who issued a decree</b> that <b>they</b> become ritually impure due to their proximity to the stove. The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the Sages <b>issued a decree</b> that they become ritually impure, then <b>even</b> in the case where the creeping animal does not come into contact with the walls of the oven, but is merely <b>in</b> its <b>air</b> space, the receptacles <b>should also become ritually impure.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>The Sages made a</b> conspicuous <b>distinction, so that</b> one will <b>not come to burn</b> his <b><i>teruma</i> and</b> other <b>consecrated items because of it.</b> There is a severe prohibition to destroy <i>teruma</i> or consecrated items. If <i>teruma</i> becomes ritually impure, there is an obligation by Torah law to burn it; however, <i>teruma</i> that is ritually impure only by rabbinic decree is still fit by Torah law and may not be destroyed. Since there is concern that people will come to burn <i>teruma</i> even when doing so is prohibited, the Sages made a distinction, imposing ritual impurity on the receptacles only if the source of impurity came into physical contact with the walls of the stove, and not if it merely entered the stove’s airspace. In that way, it is clear that the ritual impurity is by rabbinic decree, and one will not come to burn <i>teruma</i> and consecrated objects due to that impurity.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>scissors</b> made <b>of</b> component <b>parts</b> that are made to come apart <b>and the blade of a</b> carpenter’s <b>plane,</b> which can be removed from its handle, it is considered <b>a connection</b> between the components <b>with regard to</b> contracting <b>ritual impurity.</b> If one part becomes ritually impure, the other part becomes ritually impure as well. <b>However,</b> it is <b>not</b> considered <b>a connection with regard to</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the water of a purification offering. When water of purification is sprinkled on these implements in order to purify them from ritual impurity contracted through contact with a corpse (see Numbers 19:17–19), the water must be sprinkled on each part individually.
The Gemara asks: <b>Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, there is a difficulty: <b>If it is</b> considered <b>a connection,</b> it should be so considered <b>even</b> with regard <b>to sprinkling;</b> and <b>if it is not</b> considered <b>a connection,</b> it should <b>not</b> be so considered <b>even</b> with regard <b>to ritual impurity. Rava said: By Torah law, when in use,</b> it is considered <b>a connection, both</b> with regard <b>to ritual impurity</b> and with regard <b>to sprinkling. And when not in use,</b> even if the parts are now together, since they are made to eventually come apart and are typically dismantled, it is <b>neither</b> considered <b>a connection</b> with regard <b>to ritual impurity nor</b> with regard <b>to sprinkling.</b>

Daf 49a

<b>And the Sages issued a decree</b> that it should be considered a connection <b>with regard to ritual impurity</b> even <b>when not in use, due to ritual impurity when in use.</b> If one component becomes ritually impure, the other component becomes ritually impure as well. <b>And,</b> as a further stringency, they issued a decree that it is not considered a connection <b>with regard to sprinkling</b> even <b>when in use, due to sprinkling when not in use.</b> The water of purification must be sprinkled on each part individually.
The mishna listed several materials in which food may not be insulated on Shabbat eve <b>when</b> those materials <b>are moist. A dilemma was raised</b> before the Sages: Is the mishna referring specifically to materials that are <b>moist due to their own</b> natural state, <b>or</b> is it referring <b>perhaps</b> even to materials that <b>are</b> now <b>moist due to something else,</b> e.g., because they were soaked by liquid?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from the materials listed in the mishna: <b>And</b> one may <b>neither</b> insulate a pot <b>in straw, nor in the residue of grapes</b> that have been pressed for their juice, <b>nor in soft materials, nor in grass, when these</b> materials <b>are moist. Granted, if you say</b> that the mishna is referring to materials that are <b>moist due to something else,</b> this can be <b>well</b> understood, as all of these materials can get wet. <b>However, if you say</b> that it is referring to materials that are <b>moist due to their own</b> natural state, <b>where do you find soft materials</b> that are <b>moist due to their own</b> natural state? Wool is dry in its natural state. The Gemara rejects this argument: The mishna is referring to a case where the material is made <b>from</b> wool <b>plucked</b> from <b>between the thighs</b> of the animal, as that wool is usually damp from sweat.
The Gemara continues with a similar question: <b>And that which Rabbi Oshaya taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may insulate</b> a pot of hot food on Shabbat eve <b>in a dry garment and in dry produce, but not in a moist garment or in moist produce. Where do you find</b> a ruling pertaining to <b>a cloth that is moist due to its own</b> natural state? The Gemara answers: Here too, the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where the cloth was made <b>from</b> wool <b>plucked</b> from <b>between the thighs</b> of the animal. The wool was spun and the cloth was woven while the wool was still moist. Consequently, there is no conclusive proof whether the materials listed in the mishna are prohibited only when naturally moist or even if they are moist due to another source.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One</b> may <b>insulate</b> a pot of hot food on Shabbat eve <b>in clothing, in produce, in doves’ wings, in a carpenter’s wood-shavings, and in the chaff of fine flax. Rabbi Yehuda prohibits</b> doing so when it is <b>fine, and permits</b> doing so when it is <b>coarse.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Since doves’ wings were mentioned in the mishna, the Gemara cites a related story: <b>Rabbi Yannai said:</b> Donning <b>phylacteries requires a clean body, like</b> that of <b>Elisha, Man of Wings.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the statement that donning phylacteries requires a clean body? <b>Abaye said:</b> It means <b>that one may not break wind</b> while donning <b>them. Rava said:</b> It means <b>that one may not sleep in them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And why did they call</b> Elisha <b>Man of Wings? Because on one occasion the evil kingdom of Rome issued a decree against Israel that,</b> as punishment, <b>they would pierce the brain of anyone who dons phylacteries.</b> Nevertheless, <b>Elisha would don them and</b> defiantly <b>go out to the marketplace.</b> One day, <b>an official [<i>kasdor</i>]</b> who was appointed to enforce the decree <b>saw him;</b> Elisha <b>ran</b> away <b>from him, and</b> the official <b>ran after him. When</b> the official <b>reached him,</b> Elisha <b>removed</b> the phylacteries <b>from his head and held them in his hand.</b> The officer <b>asked him: What is that in your hand?</b> Elisha <b>said to him:</b> It is merely <b>a dove’s wings.</b> A miracle was performed: <b>He opened his hand, and,</b> indeed, it <b>was found</b> to be <b>a dove’s wings. Therefore,</b> in commemoration of this miracle, <b>they</b> would <b>call him Elisha, Man of Wings.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is different</b> about <b>doves’ wings from</b> those of <b>other birds</b> that led Elisha to say that he had doves’ wings in his hand? The Gemara answers: <b>Because the congregation of Israel is likened to a dove, as it is stated:</b> “You shall shine as <b>the wings of a dove covered with silver</b> and her pinions with yellow gold” (Psalms 68:14). <b>Just as this dove,</b> only <b>its wings protect it</b> and it has no other means of protection, <b>so too the Jewish people,</b> only <b>mitzvot protect them.</b>
We learned in the mishna: One may insulate food on Shabbat eve <b>in a carpenter’s wood-shavings,</b> and in the chaff of fine flax. Rabbi Yehuda prohibits doing so when it is fine, and permits doing so when it is coarse. <b>A dilemma was raised</b> before the Sages: Is the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda referring to the carpenter’s wood-shavings,</b> or is it <b>referring to the chaff of flax?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: The</b> legal status of <b>the chaff of fine flax is like</b> that of <b>manure,</b> i.e., it adds heat. The Gemara comments: <b>Conclude from it</b> that Rabbi Yehuda <b>is referring to the chaff of flax.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may insulate</b> cooked food on Shabbat eve <b>in</b> animal <b>hides and may move</b> those hides on Shabbat. So too, one may insulate food <b>in wool fleece and,</b> in contrast to hides, <b>one may not move</b> the fleece. <b>How,</b> then, <b>does one act</b> if he insulated food in fleece, and now wishes to remove the pot? <b>He lifts the cover,</b> which he is permitted to move, <b>and</b> the fleece <b>falls</b> by itself. He need not even touch it.
<b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says:</b> If he placed the pot in <b>a basket</b> filled with fleece, <b>he leans</b> the basket <b>on its side</b> so that the fleece will fall to the side <b>and takes</b> the pot. Otherwise, there is concern <b>lest</b> the wool collapse when <b>he lifts</b> the pot from the basket. <b>And</b> then, <b>he will be unable to replace</b> the pot, as it is prohibited to move the wool to make room for the pot, since the wool is set-aside. <b>And the Rabbis</b> disagree and <b>say: He may take</b> the pot <b>and</b> afterward <b>replace it.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Yonatan ben Akhinai and Rabbi Yonatan ben Elazar sat, and Rabbi Ḥanina bar Ḥama sat with them, and they raised</b> the following <b>dilemma:</b> Did <b>we learn</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna that only <b>the hides of a</b> common <b>homeowner</b> may be moved; <b>however,</b> the hides <b>of a craftsman,</b> whose profession is processing hides, <b>since he is particular that they</b> not be ruined because they are essential to his work, <b>one may not move them</b> on Shabbat? <b>Or, perhaps, we learned</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna that even <b>the hides of a craftsman</b> may be moved, <b>and all the more so</b> that hides <b>of a</b> common <b>homeowner</b> may be moved.
<b>Rabbi Yonatan ben Elazar said to them: It</b> stands to <b>reason</b> that <b>we learned</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna with regard to <b>the hides of a</b> common <b>homeowner; however,</b> hides <b>of a craftsman</b> may not be moved, since <b>he is particular about them. Rabbi Ḥanina bar Ḥama said to them</b> that <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said as follows:</b>

Daf 49b

<b>My father was a tanner, and</b> one Shabbat <b>he said: Bring</b> me <b>hides and we will sit on them</b> (Rabbeinu Ḥananel). In other words, even the hides of a craftsman may be moved on Shabbat.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to wooden <b>boards</b> belonging <b>to a homeowner, one may move them</b> on Shabbat; <b>however, those</b> belonging <b>to a craftsman, one may not move them. And if,</b> however, <b>he thought to place bread upon them for guests, both these,</b> the boards of the homeowner, <b>and those,</b> the boards of the craftsman, <b>may be moved.</b> Apparently, the raw materials of a craftsman may not be moved on Shabbat. The Gemara answers: Wooden <b>boards are different</b> in <b>that one is particular about them</b> that they not be damaged. Hides, on the other hand, are not damaged when one sits on them.
The Gemara cites another proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which was taught in a different <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>hides, whether</b> they are <b>tanned or whether</b> they are <b>not tanned, it is permitted to move them on Shabbat.</b> The Sages <b>said that tanned</b> hides have a unique legal status, distinct from the status of hides that have not been tanned <b>only with regard to ritual impurity.</b> Only tanned hides become ritually impure. <b>What, is it not</b> saying that <b>there is no difference</b> whether they are hides belonging to <b>a homeowner and there is no difference</b> whether they are hides belonging to <b>a craftsman;</b> in both cases they may be moved on Shabbat? The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring exclusively to hides <b>belonging to a homeowner.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> with regard to hides <b>belonging to a craftsman, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is it true that <b>they may not be moved</b> on Shabbat? <b>If so, that which was taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: The Sages <b>said that</b> the legal status of <b>tanned</b> hides is distinct from the status of hides that have not been tanned <b>only with regard to ritual impurity; let</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>distinguish and teach within</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat <b>itself,</b> and say: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that there is no distinction between whether or not the hides were tanned, <b>said?</b> It was stated specifically <b>with regard to</b> hides <b>belonging to a homeowner. However, with regard to</b> hides <b>belonging to a craftsman, no,</b> if they were tanned they may not be moved. The Gemara answers: Since <b>the entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is speaking with regard to</b> hides <b>of a homeowner,</b> it would have been forced to elaborate at greater length to introduce the distinction with regard to the hides of a craftsman than it did to introduce the distinction with regard to ritual impurity.
The Gemara notes that this issue is <b>parallel</b> to a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>hides belonging to a homeowner, one may move them</b> on Shabbat, <b>and those of a craftsman, one may not move them. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> With regard to <b>both these,</b> the hides of a homeowner, <b>and those,</b> the hides of a craftsman, <b>one may move them.</b>
The Gemara relates that those same Sages who sat and discussed the issue of hides, <b>sat again and they raised a dilemma: That which we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>The primary categories of labor,</b> which are prohibited by Torah law on Shabbat, <b>are forty-less-one; to what does</b> this number <b>correspond?</b> That is to say, what is the source of this number?
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina bar Ḥama said to them: They correspond to the labors in the Tabernacle.</b> All types of labor that were performed in the Tabernacle are enumerated as primary categories of labor with respect to Shabbat. However, other labors, even if they are significant, are not enumerated among the primary categories of labor since they were not performed in the Tabernacle. <b>Rabbi Yonatan, son of Rabbi Elazar, said to them</b> that <b>so said Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Yosei ben Lakonya:</b> They <b>correspond to</b> the instances of the words <b>labor, his labor, and the labor of, that</b> appear <b>in the Torah</b> a total of <b>forty-less-one</b> times.
<b>Rav Yosef raised a dilemma:</b> The term his labor is written with regard to Joseph: “And it came to pass about this time, that he <b>came into the house to do his labor;</b> and there was none of the men of the house there within” (Genesis 39:11). <b>Is it</b> included <b>in the count</b> of the thirty-nine instances <b>or not? Abaye said to him: And let us bring a Torah scroll and count</b> the instances of the word labor and thereby determine whether or not there are thirty-nine instances without that one. <b>Didn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> in a case of similar uncertainty: <b>They did not move from there until they brought a Torah scroll and counted them?</b>
Rav Yosef <b>said to</b> Abaye: I cannot reach a conclusion relying solely on a count because there is another instance of the term labor, whose meaning is not clear to me. The reason <b>I am uncertain is because it is written</b> with regard to the Tabernacle: <b>“For the labor they had was sufficient</b> for all the work to do it, and too much” (Exodus 36:7). The question arises whether or not <b>this</b> mention of labor <b>is</b> included <b>in the count</b> of thirty-nine instances, i.e., whether or not it refers to actual labor. <b>And</b> if it does, <b>that</b> verse with regard to Joseph should be understood <b>in accordance with the</b> opinion of the <b>one who said</b> that the expression, to do his labor, is a euphemism. It means that it was <b>to attend to his needs</b> and engage in relations with Potiphar’s wife that <b>he entered.</b>
<b>Or, perhaps,</b> the verse relating to Joseph: <b>“He came into the house to do his labor,” is</b> included <b>in the count,</b> and it refers to actual labor. <b>And this</b> verse: <b>“The labor they had was sufficient,” is saying the following: That they completed the</b> preparatory <b>labor,</b> i.e., they brought all the materials, not that they engaged in the actual labor. Let the uncertainty <b>stand</b> unresolved.
With regard to the matter itself, <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that the thirty-nine labors of Shabbat <b>correspond to the labors</b> performed <b>in the Tabernacle. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One is only liable for</b> performing <b>a labor to which there was a corresponding</b> labor <b>in the Tabernacle. They sowed</b> in order to grow dyes for the Tabernacle, <b>and</b> therefore <b>you may not sow</b> on Shabbat. <b>They reaped, and</b> therefore <b>you may not reap</b> on Shabbat.
<b>They lifted the boards from the ground</b> in the wilderness, which is a public domain, and placed them <b>into the wagon,</b> which is a private domain, <b>and</b> therefore <b>you shall not carry</b> objects <b>in from the public domain to the private domain</b> on Shabbat. <b>They lowered the boards from the wagon to the ground, and</b> therefore <b>you shall not carry</b> objects <b>out from the private domain to the public domain</b> on Shabbat. <b>They took</b> boards and other objects <b>out</b> and passed them <b>from wagon to wagon,</b> i.e., from one private domain to another private domain, <b>and</b> therefore <b>you shall not take</b> objects <b>out from</b> one <b>private domain to</b> another <b>private domain</b> on Shabbat.
The Gemara expresses astonishment with regard to the last clause of the <i>baraita</i>: One who takes an object out <b>from</b> one <b>private domain to</b> another <b>private domain, what</b> prohibited labor <b>is he</b> thereby <b>performing?</b> The Gemara answers: It was <b>Abaye and Rava who both said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava</b> who said: This is referring to taking an object out <b>from</b> one <b>private domain to</b> another <b>private domain via the public domain,</b> as the space between the two wagons in the wilderness was a public domain.
We learned in the mishna: One may insulate food <b>in wool fleece, and he may not move it. Rava said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> that fleece may not be moved on Shabbat <b>applies only</b> to a case <b>where one did not insulate</b> food <b>in it.</b> Only in that case is it set-aside. <b>However, if one insulated</b> cooked food <b>in it, he may move it.</b> By insulating food in the fleece, he indicated that he intends to use it on Shabbat.
<b>A certain Sage</b> for whom it was <b>his first day</b> in that study hall <b>raised an objection to Rava</b> from our mishna: <b>One may insulate</b> food <b>in wool fleece, and one may not move</b> it. <b>How,</b> then, <b>does he act</b> if he insulated food in wool fleece and now wishes to remove the pot?

Daf 50a

<b>He lifts the cover,</b> which he is permitted to move, <b>and</b> the wool fleece <b>falls</b> by itself. Contrary to Rava’s statement, even wool fleece in which a person insulated food may not be moved on Shabbat.
<b>Rather, if it was stated, it was stated as follows: Rava said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> that wool fleece may not be moved on Shabbat <b>applies only</b> in a case <b>where one did not designate it for insulating</b> food. <b>However, if he designated it for insulating</b> food, <b>one may move it,</b> as in that case, it is no longer set-aside.
<b>It was also stated</b> that <b>when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Ya’akov said</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi ben Shaul said</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> that wool fleece may not be moved on Shabbat <b>applies only</b> in a case <b>where one did not designate it for insulating</b> food. <b>However, if one designated it for insulating</b> food, <b>he may move it.</b>
<b>Ravina said:</b> In fact, Rava’s statement can be understood as it was originally understood, i.e., one who insulated food in wool fleece may move it because it is considered designated for insulating food. In the mishna that indicates otherwise <b>they taught about</b> wool fleece taken from a merchant’s <b>shelves [<i>heftek</i>].</b> That wool was certainly not designated for insulating food. It will be returned to those shelves to be sold. Therefore, it is set-aside for that purpose and may not be moved on Shabbat, even if it is used to insulate food. <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>wool fleece</b> taken from a merchant’s <b>shelves, one may not move it</b> on Shabbat. <b>And if a homeowner prepared</b> the fleece <b>to use it, one may move it.</b>
With regard to the question of what can be done to permit use of items ordinarily set-aside on Shabbat, <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana taught</b> the following <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav:</b> With regard to <b>hard branches of a palm</b> tree <b>that one cut for</b> fire <b>wood</b> or for construction, <b>and</b> then <b>he reconsidered their</b> designation and decided to use them <b>for sitting, he must tie</b> the branches together on Shabbat eve. This allows him to move them on Shabbat like any other household utensil. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: He need not tie</b> them together and, nevertheless, he is permitted to move them. Rabba bar bar Ḥana <b>taught</b> the <i>baraita</i>, <b>and he said</b> about <b>it</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b>
On that same topic, <b>it was stated</b> that <b>Rav said: He ties</b> the branches together on Shabbat eve. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> If he merely <b>has in mind</b> on Shabbat eve that he wishes to sit on them on Shabbat, he need not tie them together. <b>And Rav Asi said:</b> If he even briefly <b>sits</b> on them on Shabbat eve, sitting on the branches is permitted the next day, <b>even though he did not tie</b> them together <b>and even though he did not have</b> that <b>in mind.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, Rav, he stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the unattributed opinion of <b>the first <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>and Shmuel, too, he stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. However, in accordance with whose</b> opinion did <b>Rav Asi state</b> his opinion? Apparently, he disagrees with both <i>tanna’im</i> who expressed an opinion on the issue.
The Gemara explains: Rav Asi <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One may go out</b> into a public domain on Shabbat <b>with combed flax [<i>pakorin</i>] or combed wool</b> covering a wound, <b>when he</b> previously <b>dipped them in oil and tied them</b> to the wound <b>with twine.</b> If <b>he did not dip them in oil</b> or <b>tie them with twine, he may not go out</b> into the public domain <b>with them. And if he went out with them for a brief period</b> on Shabbat eve <b>while it was still day, even if he did not dip</b> them in oil or <b>tie them with twine, he is permitted to go out with them</b> on Shabbat. Apparently, there is a <i>tanna</i> who maintains that using an item before Shabbat enables one to use it on Shabbat as well. No additional steps are necessary.
<b>Rav Ashi said: We too have also learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Straw that is</b> piled <b>on a bed</b> to be used for fuel or mixed with clay is set aside for that purpose and may not be moved. Therefore, one who seeks to lie on the bed <b>may not move</b> the straw <b>with his hand, but he may move it with his body,</b> as this is not the typical way of moving straw. <b>However, if that</b> straw had been designated as <b>animal feed, or if there was a pillow or sheet</b> spread <b>over it</b> on Shabbat eve <b>while it was still day</b> and he lay on it before Shabbat, <b>he may move it with his hand.</b> Apparently, even brief use before Shabbat suffices to permit use on Shabbat as well. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that there is a tannaitic opinion in accordance with which Rav Asi stated his opinion.
The Gemara asks: <b>And who is the</b> unnamed <b><i>tanna</i> who disagrees with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> in the <i>baraita</i> cited above? He holds that in order to use palm branches for sitting, one must perform an action, e.g., tie them together, before Shabbat? The Gemara answers: It is <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akiva, as when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Ze’iri said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akiva once went to a certain place</b> on Shabbat eve <b>and found</b> there <b>hard branches of a palm</b> tree <b>that they had cut for</b> fire <b>wood. And he said to his disciples: Go out and have in mind</b> that you will use them <b>so that we</b> will be permitted to <b>sit on them tomorrow,</b> on Shabbat. <b>And,</b> Ze’iri added, <b>I do not know if</b> the house where Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akiva went <b>was the house of</b> a wedding <b>feast or if it was the house of mourning.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that</b> Ze’iri <b>said:</b> I do not know <b>whether it was the house of</b> a wedding <b>feast or the house of mourning,</b> it may be inferred that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>specifically</b> to <b>the house of mourning or the house of a feast because</b> they <b>are preoccupied</b> with other matters and do not have time to tie the wood. <b>However, here,</b> in ordinary circumstances, if <b>he tied</b> the branches together, <b>yes,</b> it is permitted to sit on them on Shabbat; if <b>he did not tie</b> them together, <b>no,</b> it is not permitted.
<b>Rav Yehuda said: A person may bring a basket full of earth into</b> his house on Shabbat eve, pour it on the floor, <b>and use it for all his needs</b> on Shabbat, e.g., to cover excrement. <b>Mar Zutra taught in the name of Mar Zutra Rabba: That</b> applies <b>only if he designated a</b> specific <b>corner</b> in his house for the earth.
<b>The Sages said before Rav Pappa: In accordance with whose</b> opinion was this last ruling taught, that designating a place for the earth is sufficient to permit its use on Shabbat? It must have been taught <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> with respect to palm branches, <b>as if it was</b> taught <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, didn’t they say</b> that in order to permit use of an object that is set-aside on Shabbat, <b>we require an action,</b> e.g., tying the palm branches together? Thought alone is insufficient.
<b>Rav Pappa said to them: Even if you say that</b> the <i>halakha</i> was taught in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, the Rabbis stated</b> their opinion <b>that we require an action, only with regard to something with which it is possible to perform a</b> preparatory <b>action. However,</b> with regard to <b>something with which it is not possible to perform a</b> preparatory <b>action, no,</b> they did not require an action. Since it is not possible to perform a preparatory action with the earth, one is permitted to use the earth by means of thought alone.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say that</b> this issue, whether or not an action is required in that case, is <b>parallel</b> to a dispute among <b>the <i>tanna’im</i>.</b> As it was taught in one <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may clean utensils</b> on Shabbat <b>with any</b> type of cleaning agent, <b>except for silver utensils with cream of tartar [<i>gartekon</i>],</b> as that not only polishes the silver, but also smooths it. By inference: Cleaning with <b>natron and sand is permitted.</b>
<b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: Cleaning with <b>natron and sand is prohibited</b> on Shabbat? <b>What, is it not that they disagree with regard to this</b> following point? <b>That</b> one <b>Sage,</b> who prohibits use of sand on Shabbat, <b>holds</b> that <b>an action is required</b> in order to permit the use of items that would otherwise be set-aside on Shabbat. Since it is impossible to perform an action with sand, its use is prohibited. <b>And</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> who permits use of sand, <b>holds</b> that <b>an action is not required.</b>
The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>No, everyone agrees</b> that <b>an action is not required; and,</b> nevertheless, it is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which prohibits use of sand and natron, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda; that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits their use, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which prohibits use of sand and natron, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who said</b> with regard to the laws of Shabbat in general that <b>an unintentional act is prohibited.</b> It is prohibited to perform an otherwise permitted action from which an unintended prohibited labor ensues. Therefore, cleaning a silver utensil with sand or natron is prohibited because he thereby unintentionally smooths the utensil, which is prohibited on Shabbat. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits the use of sand and natron, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that <b>an unintentional act is permitted.</b>
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>In what</b> manner <b>did you establish that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which <b>permits</b> the use of sand and natron? You established it <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> If so, <b>say the latter clause</b> of that same <i>baraita</i>: <b>However, one may not wash his hair with them</b> on Shabbat. <b>And, if</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, he permits</b> doing so. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna:

Daf 50b

<b>A nazirite,</b> for whom it is prohibited to cut his hair, <b>may wash</b> his hair with sand and natron <b>and separate</b> it with his fingers; <b>however, he may not comb</b> it, as combing will certainly cause hair to fall out. Apparently, Rabbi Shimon permits washing hair even in a case where it is prohibited to cause hair to fall out; in his opinion, the fact that washing one’s hair might inadvertently cause that to happen is not a source of concern.
<b>Rather,</b> both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita,</i> which disagree with regard to cleaning silver utensils with sand and natron, are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that an unintentional act is prohibited. <b>And</b> there are <b>two <i>tanna’im</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> They disagree with regard to Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion. <b>This <i>tanna</i>, in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, holds</b> that sand and natron <b>scrape</b> and smooth the utensils. Therefore, their use on Shabbat is prohibited. <b>And that <i>tanna</i>,</b> also <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, holds</b> that sand and natron <b>do not scrape</b> and smooth the utensils. Therefore, their use on Shabbat is permitted.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>How did you establish</b> that <i>baraita</i>? It was <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> If so, <b>say the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>But his face, his hands, and his feet,</b> it is <b>permitted</b> to wash with sand and natron. <b>Doesn’t he</b> thereby <b>cause hair to fall out?</b> It should be prohibited according to Rabbi Yehuda.
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> that the permission to wash one’s face with sand and natron refers to <b>a child; and if you wish, say</b> instead that it refers to <b>a woman; and if you wish, say</b> instead that it refers to <b>a eunuch.</b> All of them have no facial hair, and that is why there is no concern that use of sand and natron to clean their faces will cause hair to fall out.
The Gemara continues: <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> Washing one’s face with <b>powdered frankincense</b> (Rav Hai Gaon) <b>is permitted</b> on Shabbat, even if he has a beard, as it does not cause hair to fall out. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> Washing with the <b>solid residue of jasmine</b> from which its fragrant oil was squeezed <b>is permitted. Rava said:</b> Washing with <b>ground pepper is permitted. Rav Sheshet said:</b> Washing with <b><i>berada</i> is permitted</b> on Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>berada</i>? Rav Yosef said:</b> It is a mixture of <b>one-third aloe, one-third myrtle,</b> and <b>one-third violets. Rav Neḥemya bar Yosef said: Everywhere that there is</b> a mixture with <b>no majority of aloe,</b> it may <b>well</b> be used. Even if the mixture contains more than a third aloe, as long as it constitutes less than a majority, it does not cause hair to fall out.
The Sages <b>raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>splitting olives</b> on a rock <b>on Shabbat</b> in order to wash with the oil that oozes from them (<i>ge’onim</i>)? <b>He said to them: And did they permit</b> doing so <b>on a weekday?</b> Rav Sheshet <b>holds</b> that crushing olives in that manner is prohibited even during the week <b>because</b> it involves <b>ruining food.</b> After the olives are split in that manner, they are no longer fit for consumption.
The Gemara comments: <b>Let us say</b> that Rav Sheshet <b>disagrees</b> with the opinion <b>of Shmuel. As Shmuel said: A person may perform all his needs with bread,</b> and he need not be concerned that it might be ruined. The Sages <b>said</b> in response: Rav Sheshet does not necessarily disagree with Shmuel. Using <b>bread</b> does <b>not</b> render it <b>disgusting</b> and inedible; splitting <b>these</b> olives renders them <b>disgusting</b> and inedible.
The Gemara relates that <b>Ameimar, Mar Zutra, and Rav Ashi were sitting</b> on Shabbat, <b>and they brought <i>berada</i> before them</b> for washing. <b>Ameimar and Rav Ashi washed</b> with it; <b>Mar Zutra did not wash. They said to him: Doesn’t the Master hold in accordance with that which Rav Sheshet said:</b> Washing with <b><i>berada</i> is permitted</b> on Shabbat? <b>Rav Mordekhai,</b> who was also there, <b>said to them: Except for him, the Master;</b> i.e., do not draw conclusions from Mar Zutra, <b>as he does not hold</b> that one is permitted to use <i>berada</i>, <b>even on a weekday.</b>
Mar Zutra <b>holds in accordance with that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person may scrape off</b> dried <b>excrement crusts and scabs of a wound that are on his flesh because of</b> the <b>pain</b> that they are causing <b>him.</b> However, <b>if</b> he does so in order <b>to</b> clean and <b>beautify himself, it is prohibited.</b> According to the <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i>, it is prohibited to adorn or beautify oneself, as the verse: “Neither shall a man put on a woman’s garment” (Deuteronomy 22:5) prohibits dressing or conducting oneself in the manner of women.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> Ameimar and Rav Ashi, who permit use of <i>berada</i>, <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>do they hold?</b> They hold <b>in accordance with that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A person must wash his face, his hands, and his feet every day for</b> the sake of <b>his Maker, as it is stated: “The Lord has made everything for His own purpose”</b> (Proverbs 16:4). Every beautiful thing that exists in the world sings the praise of God Who created beautiful things. Therefore, it is appropriate for one to beautify himself in praise of God.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says:</b> If he placed the pot in <b>a basket</b> filled with fleece, <b>he leans</b> the basket <b>on its side</b> so that the fleece will fall to the side of the pot, <b>and takes</b> the pot. Otherwise, there is room for concern <b>lest</b> the wool collapse when <b>he lifts</b> the pot from the basket. Then he will be unable to replace the pot. It is prohibited to move the fleece to make room for the pot, since the fleece is set-aside. However, the Rabbis disagree and say: He may lift the pot and afterward replace it. <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said: Everyone agrees,</b> even the Rabbis, <b>that if the cavity</b> in which the pot had been placed <b>was destroyed,</b> its walls having collapsed inward, <b>it is prohibited to return</b> the pot to the basket.
The Gemara asks, based on what <b>we learned</b> in the mishna. <b>And the Rabbis say: He may lift</b> the pot <b>and</b> afterward <b>replace it.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>What are the circumstances? If the cavity</b> in which the pot had been placed <b>was not destroyed, the Rabbis say fittingly</b> that it is permitted to replace the pot; why would Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya prohibit the practice? <b>Rather, is it not</b> that the Rabbis permit returning the pot <b>even though the cavity was destroyed?</b> Apparently, that is the subject of the dispute in the mishna.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, actually,</b> everyone agrees that if the cavity was destroyed, it is prohibited to return the pot to the basket. The mishna is dealing with a case <b>where</b> the cavity <b>was not destroyed, and here</b> the <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree with regard to</b> whether or not <b>one</b> need be <b>concerned</b> lest, if one is allowed to remove the pot from the basket without tilting it to the side, the cavity be destroyed and he will come to return the pot to the basket anyway. One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, <b>holds</b> that <b>one</b> need be <b>concerned lest the cavity be destroyed</b> and he return the pot anyway; <b>and</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> a reference to the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that <b>one</b> need <b>not</b> be <b>concerned</b> about that.
The Gemara records several rulings with regard to placing an object into another object that is set-aside. <b>Rav Huna said:</b> With regard to <b>this</b> fragrant <b>daffodil branch</b> that was kept in a pot of moist earth in the house; if on Shabbat eve one <b>inserted it</b> into the earth, then <b>pulled it out, and then inserted it</b> again into the earth, <b>it is permitted</b> to pull it out again on Shabbat. By inserting it and then pulling it out, he has already widened the cavity in which the branch was placed. There is no room for concern that when he pulls it out again on Shabbat he will cause earth to shift from its place. <b>And if</b> he did <b>not</b> do so on Shabbat eve, <b>it is prohibited</b> to pull it out on Shabbat.
<b>Shmuel said: This knife that is</b> stored <b>between bricks; if one stuck it</b> between the bricks on Shabbat eve, <b>pulled it out, and then stuck it</b> between the bricks, <b>it is permitted</b> to pull it out on Shabbat. <b>And if</b> he did <b>not</b> do so on Shabbat eve, <b>it is prohibited</b> to pull it out on Shabbat.
<b>Mar Zutra, and some say Rav Ashi, said:</b> Placing a knife <b>between</b> the branches of <b>a hedge of reeds</b> (<i>ge’onim</i>) may <b>well</b> be done and there is no concern lest one come to cut the reeds when he removes it.
<b>Rav Mordekhai said to Rava: Rav Ketina raised a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinions of Rav Huna and Shmuel from that which we learned in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who conceals a turnip or radish</b> in the ground <b>beneath a vine</b> for safekeeping, <b>if some of its leaves were showing,</b> allowing access to pull the turnip or the radish from the ground, <b>he need neither be concerned;</b>

Daf 51a

<b>due to diverse kinds,</b> i.e., that he violated the prohibition of planting food crops in a vineyard, as he did not commit an act of planting; <b>nor due to</b> concern that he violated the prohibition against working the land during <b>the Sabbatical</b> Year; <b>nor due to tithes,</b> i.e., that it would be considered as if he picked it from the ground and would be obligated to tithe it; <b>and they may be taken</b> from the ground <b>on Shabbat.</b> Even if most of the turnip or radish is underground, it is permitted to pull it from the ground on Shabbat. One need not be concerned about causing the earth to move. Apparently, this contradicts the opinions of Rav Huna and Shmuel, who were concerned about causing earth to move on Shabbat. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinions of Rav Huna and Shmuel.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one did not cover</b> a pot of cooked food on Shabbat eve <b>while it was still day, he may not cover it after dark.</b> However, if <b>one covered it</b> while it was still day <b>and it was uncovered</b> on Shabbat, <b>he is permitted to cover it</b> even on Shabbat. <b>One may fill a jug</b> with cold water on Shabbat <b>and place</b> it <b>beneath a pillow or a cushion</b> to prevent it from getting warm.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: It is permitted to insulate the cold</b> food on Shabbat to keep it cold. There is no concern that this will lead one to insulate hot food on Shabbat to keep it hot. <b>Rav Yosef said: What is</b> Shmuel <b>teaching us</b> with this statement? <b>We</b> already <b>learned</b> in our mishna: <b>One may fill a jug</b> with cold water on Shabbat <b>and place</b> it <b>beneath a pillow or a mattress</b> to prevent it from getting warm.
<b>Abaye said to him: He teaches us a great deal. As, if</b> it had been learned <b>from the mishna</b> alone, <b>I would have said</b> that the ruling that one is permitted to insulate cold food applies only to <b>something that is not ordinarily insulated</b> when it is hot. <b>However, something</b> that is <b>commonly insulated</b> when it is hot, <b>no,</b> it may not be insulated even when it is cold. Therefore, Shmuel <b>teaches us</b> that this is allowed even in the case of something which is commonly insulated when it is hot.
<b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: It is prohibited to insulate cold</b> food on Shabbat to keep it cold. The Gemara raises an objection: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permitted cold</b> food <b>to be insulated</b> on Shabbat? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> statement <b>was</b> made <b>before he heard</b> the ruling <b>of Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei; that</b> statement in the <i>baraita</i> <b>was</b> made <b>after he heard it. As</b> in <b>that</b> incident <b>where Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>sat and said: It is prohibited to insulate cold</b> food on Shabbat to keep it cold, <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said before him: Father permitted insulating cold</b> food on Shabbat. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said:</b> I retract my previous statement, as <b>the Elder,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>has already issued a ruling</b> on this topic, and I defer to his ruling.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Come and see how much they loved each other. Had Rabbi Yosei</b> still been <b>alive, he would</b> have been <b>subordinate</b> to <b>and sitting before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi as his student, <b>as Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, who took his father’s place</b> and was as great a Torah scholar as his father, was <b>subordinate</b> to <b>and sitting before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi as his student. <b>And,</b> nevertheless, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: The Elder has already issued a ruling</b> on this topic, and he deferred to Rabbi Yosei’s ruling.
<b>Rav Naḥman said to Daru, his slave: Insulate cold</b> food <b>for me</b> on Shabbat, so that it will not become warm, <b>and bring me water that a gentile cook [<i>kappeila</i>] heated</b> on a weekday, as the prohibition to eat food cooked by a gentile does not apply to water. When <b>Rabbi Ami heard</b> this, <b>he became angry. Rav Yosef said: What</b> is <b>the reason</b> that Rabbi Ami <b>become angry?</b> Rav Naḥman <b>acted in accordance with</b> the rulings of <b>his teachers;</b> in <b>one</b> matter <b>in accordance with</b> the ruling of <b>Rav, and</b> in <b>one</b> matter <b>in accordance with</b> the ruling of <b>Shmuel.</b>
The Gemara explains: In one matter <b>in accordance with</b> the ruling of <b>Shmuel, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: It is permitted to insulate cold</b> food on Shabbat to keep it cold. In one matter <b>in accordance with</b> the ruling of <b>Rav, as Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>Rav said: Anything that is eaten as it is, raw,</b> and cooking it is unnecessary, even if it was cooked <b>it is not</b> subject <b>to</b> the prohibition of food <b>cooked by gentiles.</b> Since water is commonly drunk uncooked, one may drink it even if it was boiled by a gentile.
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Ami became angry because <b>he held</b> that <b>an important person is different.</b> A distinguished person like Rav Naḥman should be stringent and distance himself from conduct that could be perceived, even mistakenly, as a prohibited act.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Although</b> the Sages <b>said</b> that <b>one may not insulate</b> hot food, <b>even in something that does not add heat after nightfall</b> on Shabbat, <b>if he comes to add</b> to the material in which he insulated the food on Shabbat eve, <b>he may add</b> to it even on Shabbat. <b>How</b> should <b>he do</b> it? <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: He takes the sheets</b> with which he insulated a pot <b>and places the heavy blankets,</b> which provide better insulation, in their place. <b>Or,</b> if he is concerned about excessive heat, <b>he takes the heavy blankets</b> in which the pot had been insulated <b>and places the</b> lighter <b>sheets</b> in their place.
<b>And likewise, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> in teaching an additional leniency, <b>said: They prohibited</b> insulating a pot on Shabbat to keep its contents warm when the food remains <b>only</b> in <b>the same urn</b> in which the water was boiled. <b>However, if one emptied</b> the water <b>from that urn into</b> another <b>urn, it is permitted</b> to insulate the second urn to keep the water warm. The reason for the ruling of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel is: It is prohibited to insulate a pot on Shabbat, due to concern lest one heat the food beforehand. <b>Now</b> that <b>he has</b> already taken steps to <b>cool</b> the water by pouring it from one urn to another, is there concern that he will <b>boil it</b> again on Shabbat?
And Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: If <b>he insulated</b> the pot <b>and covered</b> it <b>with something that may be moved on Shabbat, or if he insulated</b> it <b>with something that may not be moved on Shabbat</b> because it is set-aside <b>and covered</b> it <b>with something that may be moved on Shabbat, he may take</b> the pot to remove food <b>and return</b> it to its place and not be concerned.
However, if <b>he</b> both <b>insulated</b> it <b>and covered</b> it <b>with something that may not be moved on Shabbat, or if he insulated</b> it <b>in something that may be moved on Shabbat and covered it with something that may not be moved on Shabbat, if</b> the pot <b>was partially exposed, he may remove</b> the pot and the cover will fall on its own <b>and</b> then <b>return</b> it to its place. <b>And if</b> the pot was <b>not</b> partially exposed,

Daf 51b

<b>he may not remove</b> the pot <b>and</b> then <b>return</b> it to its place.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: The chaff of fine flax is like manure.</b> Therefore, one may not insulate food in it even on Shabbat eve.
<b>One may place a</b> copper <b>urn upon a</b> copper <b>urn, and</b> one may place <b>an</b> earthenware <b>pot upon an</b> earthenware <b>pot</b> because the lower utensil will not heat the upper one. <b>However,</b> one may <b>not</b> place <b>an</b> earthenware <b>pot upon a</b> copper <b>urn, or a</b> copper <b>urn upon an</b> earthenware <b>pot,</b> as in that case there is concern that the upper utensil will be heated by the lower one. <b>And one may seal the mouth</b> of a pot <b>with dough.</b> All of the above may <b>not</b> be undertaken <b>in order to heat</b> the water, <b>but only so that</b> its heat <b>will be maintained</b> and it will not cool down.
<b>And just as one may not insulate hot</b> food to keep it warm, <b>so too, one may not insulate cold</b> food to keep it cold. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permitted insulating cold</b> food on Shabbat.
<b>And one may neither crush snow nor hail on Shabbat so that its water will flow</b> and he will be able to drink it. That act involves creation of a new entity, water from ice, on Shabbat, which is prohibited. <b>However, he may place</b> the snow or the hail <b>into a cup or a dish</b> and allow it to melt on its own, <b>and he need not be concerned.</b>

Due to the mitzva to rest one’s animals on Shabbat, one’s animal may not go out into the public domain bearing a burden. However, an object designated to protect the animal or to prevent it from fleeing is not considered a burden; therefore, an animal bearing objects that serve that purpose may go out into the public domain.<br><br><strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna asks: <b>With what may an animal go out</b> into the public domain on Shabbat <b>and with what may it not go out? A camel may go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with an <i>afsar</i>, and a <i>naka</i></b> may go out <b>with a <i>ḥatam</i>, and a <i>luvdekim</i></b> may go out <b>with a <i>perumbiya</i>.</b> All these terms will be defined in the Gemara. <b>And a horse</b> may go out <b>with a chain</b> around its neck.
<b>And,</b> in general, <b>all</b> animals that typically <b>have a chain</b> around their necks when they go out to the public domain <b>may go out with a chain</b> on Shabbat <b>and may be pulled by the chain.</b>
If these chains contracted ritual impurity, <b>one may sprinkle</b> waters of purification <b>on them and immerse them in their place</b> on the animal, and they need not first be removed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Several terms in the mishna were not clear to the Sages, and the Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b><i>naka</i> with a <i>ḥatam</i>? Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: A white female camel</b> (<i>ge’onim</i>) <b>with an iron nose ring.</b> And what is the meaning of <b><i>luvdekim</i> with a <i>perumbiya</i>? Rav Huna said: A Libyan donkey with an iron halter.</b>
Having mentioned a Libyan donkey, the Gemara relates that <b>Levi</b> once <b>sent money to Bei Ḥozai to procure for himself a Libyan donkey,</b> which is reputed to be of superior quality. <b>They bound</b> his money, returned it, and <b>sent him barley, to say that the strides of a donkey</b> depend <b>on the barley</b> that it eats. If one provides his donkey with better feed, its performance will be as good as that of a Libyan donkey.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The students <b>switched</b> the details in the mishna <b>before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi and asked: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>this</b> animal going out into the public domain <b>with</b> that which is permitted <b>for that</b> animal? For example, may a white female camel go out with a bit or a camel with an iron nose ring?
The Gemara explains: The case of <b>a white female camel</b> going out <b>with a bit should not be a dilemma for you; since it is not</b> sufficiently <b>secured by</b> a bit, <b>it is</b> regarded as <b>a burden</b> with which the animal may not go out. The case <b>where</b> there <b>should be a dilemma for you</b> is that of <b>a camel</b> going out to the public domain <b>with a nose ring. What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in that case? The Gemara explains the dilemma: Is the <i>halakha</i> that <b>since a bit</b> alone <b>suffices</b> to secure a camel, an iron nose ring <b>is</b> considered <b>a burden? Or,</b> is the <i>halakha</i> <b>perhaps</b> that with regard to a device that provides <b>excessive security we do not say</b> that <b>it is a burden?</b>
<b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said before</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi that <b>so said father,</b> Rabbi Yosei: <b>Four animals</b> may <b>go out with a bit: The horse, and the mule, and the camel, and the donkey. What</b> does this list come <b>to exclude?</b> Is it <b>not</b> coming <b>to exclude a camel</b> going out <b>with a nose ring?</b> Apparently, the dilemma is resolved. The camel may go out only with a bit. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>No</b>, the list comes <b>to exclude a white female camel</b> going out <b>with a bit.</b>
<b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: A Libyan donkey and a camel may go out with a bit.</b> The Gemara notes that the question whether or not an animal may go out into the public domain with excessive security is <b>parallel</b> to a dispute between <b>the <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A non-domesticated animal may not go out with a collar. Ḥananya says: It may go out with a collar and with anything that secures it.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the case: <b>With what are we dealing</b> here? <b>If you say</b> that we are dealing <b>with a large non-domesticated animal, does a collar suffice for it?</b> Since it does not sufficiently secure the animal, it is considered a burden, and it is prohibited for the animal to go out with it on Shabbat. <b>Rather,</b> it must be dealing <b>with a small non-domesticated animal.</b> In that case, <b>doesn’t a collar suffice for it?</b> Why then does the anonymous first <i>tanna</i> hold that the animal may not go out with it?
<b>Rather, is it not</b> that <b>the</b> practical <b>difference between their</b> opinions <b>is</b> with regard to <b>a cat? The</b> anonymous <b>first <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>holds</b> that <b>since a small rope suffices</b> for the cat, a collar <b>is</b> considered <b>a burden</b> with which the cat may not go out into the public domain. <b>And Ḥananya holds</b> that with regard to a device that provides <b>excessive security, we do not say that it is a burden.</b> The <i>tanna’im</i> disagree whether or not a device that provides excessive security is considered a burden. The Gemara concludes: <b>Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya.</b> A device that provides excessive security is not considered a burden.
The Gemara relates that <b>Levi, son of Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya, and Rabba bar Rav Huna were</b> once <b>going</b> together <b>on a road. Levi’s donkey</b> on its own initiative <b>went ahead of the donkey of Rabba bar Rav Huna. Rabba bar Rav Huna was offended</b> because he was the greater Torah scholar, and he thought that Levi went first to assert that he considered himself the greater scholar. Levi <b>said</b> to himself: <b>I will say something to him, so that</b>

Daf 52a

<b>he will be placated</b> and will understand that it was not my intention to disrespect him. <b>He said to him: An</b> undisciplined <b>donkey whose conduct is wicked like this</b> one that I am riding, <b>what</b> is the ruling with regard <b>to</b> having it <b>go out with a halter on Shabbat?</b> Typically, in order to secure a donkey, a bit suffices and it does not require a halter. A halter constitutes excessive security. However, the question is whether or not a halter that provides excessive security for a wild donkey like this one is considered a burden with which it is prohibited to go out to the public domain on Shabbat. Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>said to him</b>: Even if the security is considered extraneous, <b>your father said the following in the name of Shmuel: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya,</b> who said that a device that provides excessive security is not considered a burden.
A Sage <b>of the school of Menashiya taught</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A goat in which one carved out</b> a hole <b>between its horns may go out with a bit on Shabbat.</b> Because the bit is inserted through the hole, it will not become detached. <b>Rav Yosef raised a dilemma: What</b> is the ruling in a case where <b>one inserted</b> the bit <b>through</b> the goat’s <b>beard?</b> The Gemara explains the dilemma: Is the <i>halakha</i> that <b>since, if</b> the goat attempts to <b>sever</b> itself <b>from</b> the bit, it <b>would</b> cause it <b>pain</b> because the bit is attached to its beard, and therefore <b>it will not come</b> to <b>sever</b> it and the bit will remain in place? <b>Or perhaps</b> is the <i>halakha</i> that <b>sometimes</b> the knot <b>will loosen and</b> the bit <b>will fall, and</b> the goat’s owner <b>will come to bring</b> the bit and carry it <b>four cubits in the public domain?</b> No resolution was found to this dilemma. <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
<b>We learned there</b> in a mishna: <b>And neither</b> may a cow go out <b>with a strap between its horns. Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said: Rav and Shmuel disagreed about this: One said: Whether</b> it was placed <b>for beauty,</b> as an ornament, or <b>whether</b> it was placed <b>to secure</b> the cow, it is <b>prohibited</b> for the cow to go out with the strap between its horns. <b>And</b> the other <b>one said: For beauty,</b> it is <b>prohibited; however,</b> if it was placed <b>to secure</b> the cow, it is <b>permitted.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: Conclude that Shmuel</b> is the <b>one who said</b> that if the strap was placed <b>for beauty it is prohibited; however,</b> if it was placed <b>to secure</b> the cow <b>it is permitted. As Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya:</b> A device that provides excessive security is not considered a burden. Therefore, an animal may go out on Shabbat with straps that provide excessive security.
<b>Abaye said to him: On the contrary</b>, <b>conclude that Shmuel</b> is the <b>one who said</b> that <b>whether</b> it was placed <b>for beauty,</b> as an ornament, or <b>whether</b> it was placed <b>to secure</b> the cow, <b>it is prohibited</b>. <b>As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The students <b>exchanged</b> the details in the mishna <b>before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi and asked: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>this</b> animal going out into the public domain <b>with</b> that which is permitted <b>for that</b> animal? And <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said before</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>So said father,</b> Rabbi Yosei: <b>Four animals</b> may <b>go out with a bit: The horse, the mule, and the camel, and the donkey.</b> Does this list <b>not</b> come <b>to exclude a camel</b> going out <b>with a nose ring,</b> as a nose ring provides excessive security beyond that required for a camel? Apparently, according to Shmuel, an animal may not go out on Shabbat with a device that provides excessive security, as it is considered a burden. Rav Yosef said to him: <b>Delete this</b> latter statement of Shmuel <b>due to that</b> first one.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see</b> that led you <b>to delete this</b> latter statement <b>due that</b> first one? <b>Delete that</b> first statement <b>due to this</b> latter one. The Gemara explains: The first statement is supported <b>as we find</b> that <b>Shmuel</b> is the <b>one who said : For beauty, it is prohibited; however,</b> if it was placed <b>to secure</b> the cow, <b>it is permitted, as it was stated</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said: Whether</b> the strap was placed <b>for beauty,</b> or <b>whether</b> it was placed <b>to secure</b> the cow, <b>it is prohibited. And Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: For beauty,</b> it is <b>prohibited; however,</b> if it was placed <b>to secure</b> the cow, it is <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>its owner tied</b> a red heifer <b>with its reins</b> that are attached to the bit, <b>it</b> remains <b>fit</b> for use in the purification ritual. <b>And if it should enter your mind</b> to say that a bit <b>is</b> considered <b>a burden</b>, why does a red heifer remain fit for use? <b>The Torah</b> explicitly <b>stated:</b> “Speak to the children of Israel, that they bring you a red heifer without defect, in which there is no blemish, and <b>upon which never came a yoke”</b> (Numbers 19:2). A red heifer is disqualified by a burden.
<b>Abaye said:</b> There, the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the case of a red heifer whose owner <b>is leading it from city to city.</b> When the animal is removed from its habitat, it requires additional security. In that case, tying the heifer with its reins is conventional rather than excessive security. Therefore, the bit is not considered a burden. <b>Rava said: A</b> red <b>heifer, whose monetary</b> value <b>is high, is different</b> and therefore secured more carefully than other cows. <b>Ravina said</b>: The <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a red heifer <b>that is rebellious</b> and headstrong. Therefore, it requires added security.
We learned in the mishna: <b>A horse</b> may go out <b>with a chain</b> around its neck, and so too, all animals that typically have chains around their necks when they go out to the public domain may go out with chains on Shabbat and may be pulled by the chains. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>May go out, and what is</b> the meaning of: <b>May be pulled? Rav Huna said:</b> These animals <b>may go out either</b> with the chain <b>wrapped</b> around their necks as an ornament, <b>or they may be pulled</b> by the chain. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> These animals <b>may go out pulled</b> by the chain; <b>however, they may not go out</b> with the chain <b>wrapped</b> around their necks as an ornament.
<b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: They may go out</b> with the chains loosely <b>wrapped</b> around their necks, so that if the need arises, the animals will be able <b>to be pulled</b> by their chains. <b>Rav Yosef said: I saw the calves of the house of Rav Huna go out</b> into the public domain <b>on Shabbat with their bits</b> and with the reins <b>wrapped around</b> their necks.
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: The mules of the house of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>go out</b> into the public domain <b>with their bits on Shabbat. A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Does this mean that the mules went out with their bits and reins <b>wrapped</b> around their necks; <b>or,</b> does it mean that they were <b>pulled</b> by the reins?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from the following incident: <b>When Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> The <b>mules [<i>molaot</i>] of the house of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>went out on Shabbat with their bits</b> with the reins <b>wrapped</b> around their necks.
<b>The Sages said before Rav Asi: That</b> statement <b>of Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda is not necessary. It</b> may be <b>derived from the</b> statement <b>of Rav Dimi. As, if it would enter your mind</b> to say <b>that Rav Dimi said</b> that the mules of the house of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi went out on Shabbat <b>pulled</b> by their bits, it is difficult. There is nothing novel in that statement, <b>as it</b> may be <b>derived from the</b> statement <b>that Rav Yehuda</b> said that <b>Shmuel said.</b>
<b>As Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The students <b>switched</b> the details in the mishna <b>before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, and asked: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>this</b> animal going out into the public domain <b>with</b> that which is permitted <b>for that</b> animal? And <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said before</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>So said father, four animals</b> may <b>go out with a bit: The horse, and the mule, and the camel, and the donkey.</b> Apparently, according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, a mule may go out on Shabbat pulled by its bit.
<b>Rav Asi said to them:</b> This statement of Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda <b>is necessary, as if</b> it <b>were derived from</b> the statement of <b>Rav Yehuda,</b> who related that which Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, said before Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, <b>I would have said</b> that Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei, <b>said</b> that <b>before him, and</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>did not accept it from him</b>. Therefore, <b>that</b> statement <b>of Rav Dimi teaches us</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi indeed accepted it from Rabbi Yishmael and his mules went out with their bits on Shabbat.
<b>And if</b> it had been derived only from the statement <b>of Rav Dimi, I would have said that this applies only</b> when the mule is <b>pulled</b> by its bit; <b>however,</b> if the reins <b>are</b> merely <b>wrapped</b> around the animal’s neck, <b>no,</b> the animal may not go out with it. Therefore, <b>that</b> statement <b>of Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yehuda teaches us</b> that the mules of the house of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi went out on Shabbat with their reins wrapped around their necks.
It was further taught in our mishna: If these chains contracted ritual impurity, <b>one may sprinkle</b> water of purification <b>on them and immerse them in their place</b> on the animal. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that</b> these chains <b>are fit to contract ritual impurity? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>A ring</b> worn by <b>a person is ritually impure. However, the ring of an animal, and</b> rings <b>of utensils, and all other rings</b> not worn by people

Daf 52b

are <b>ritually pure.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa said:</b> Our mishna is referring to ornaments that were <b>transformed from</b> their original designation for <b>a person’s adornment to</b> an ornament designated for <b>an animal’s adornment.</b> They had once belonged to a person who later affixed them in order to attach a strap to an animal. Their original ritual impurity does not cease when they are attached to the animal.
<b>And Rav Yosef said:</b> Animals’ rings can become ritually impure <b>since a person pulls his animal with them.</b> Consequently, they are considered utensils used by people. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The metal animal prod becomes ritually impure? What is the reason</b> that it becomes ritually impure even though it is an animal’s utensil? <b>Since a person subjugates</b> his animal <b>with it,</b> it is regarded as a utensil for use by a person; therefore, it can become ritually impure. <b>Here too</b>, with regard to chains, <b>since a person pulls</b> his animal <b>with them,</b> they are regarded as utensils for use by a person.
And we learned in our mishna: If the animals’ chains became ritually impure, <b>one may immerse them while they are in their place</b> on the animal, and they need not first be removed. The Gemara raises a question: <b>Isn’t this an obstruction</b> that renders the immersion invalid? The rings of the chain are firmly attached to the chain, and there is no room for the water of the ritual bath to completely surround the chain.
<b>Rabbi Ami said:</b> The mishna is referring to a case where <b>he struck</b> the rings of the chain with a hammer, widening them and thereby creating sufficient space to allow the water to surround the chain on all sides.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yosef. As, if</b> he held <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa,</b> who <b>said</b> that our mishna is referring to ornaments that were <b>transformed from</b> their original designation for <b>a person’s adornment</b> to an ornament designated for <b>an animal’s adornment,</b> and therefore they can be ritually impure with impurity contracted while it was still a person’s ornament, it is difficult. <b>Since he struck</b> the chain, <b>he performed an action</b> which altered <b>its</b> identity, <b>and the impurity would have ceased</b> even without immersion.
