<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>All vessels descend into their</b> state of <b>ritual impurity by means of thought.</b> Even though an unfinished vessel cannot become ritually impure, if the craftsman decided not to complete it, it immediately assumes the legal status of a completed vessel and can become ritually impure. <b>However, they only ascend from their</b> state of <b>ritual impurity by means of a change</b> resulting from an <b>action.</b> A ritually impure vessel, once it undergoes physical change, is no longer ritually impure. Hammering the rings is an action that effects physical change. Therefore, the chain should be ritually pure without immersion.
The Gemara rejects this argument: Actually, Rabbi Ami could interpret the mishna just as Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa did, as he <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>an action</b> performed <b>to enhance</b> a utensil <b>is not an action</b> capable of ridding that utensil of its ritual impurity, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> He <b>did not say</b> that <b>an action that effects a</b> physical <b>change</b> purifies a utensil of its ritual impurity with regard to an action performed <b>to enhance</b> a utensil; <b>rather,</b> he made his statement with regard to an action performed <b>to ruin</b> the utensil.
<b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>:</b> The mishna is referring to a case where the rings attached to the chain are well <b>spaced</b> so that the water completely surrounds the rings of the chain with no obstruction.
It was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>A certain disciple from the Upper Galilee asked Rabbi Eliezer: I heard that one distinguishes between</b> one type of <b>ring and</b> another type of <b>ring.</b> However, I do not know with regard to what <i>halakha</i> this distinction is made. Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to him: Perhaps you only heard</b> that distinction with regard <b>to the matter of Shabbat;</b> a ring for adornment may be moved on Shabbat and other rings may not. <b>As,</b> with regard <b>to the matter of ritual impurity, this</b> ring <b>and that</b> ring <b>are one</b> and the same, and there is no distinction between them.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>And</b> with regard <b>to the matter of ritual impurity, are this and that one</b> and the same? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>A ring</b> worn by <b>a person is ritually impure; however, the ring of an animal, and</b> that of <b>utensils, and all other rings</b> not worn by people <b>are ritually pure?</b> Apparently, a distinction is made between different types of rings with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity as well. The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>was saying</b> that statement <b>to</b> the disciple, <b>he too was saying to him</b> that with regard to ritual impurity there is no distinction between different types <b>of</b> rings worn by <b>a person.</b>
The Gemara raises another objection: <b>And</b> with regard <b>to</b> rings worn by <b>a person</b>, <b>are this and that one</b> and the same? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A ring that one fashioned</b> into a buckle at the end of a belt <b>to wear it around his waist, or</b> into a clasp <b>to tie</b> garments <b>between his shoulders, is ritually pure?</b> The Sages <b>only said</b> that a ring is <b>ritually impure</b> with regard to a ring <b>worn on a</b> person’s <b>finger.</b> Apparently, there is in fact a distinction between different rings worn by a person. The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>was saying</b> that statement <b>to</b> the disciple, <b>he too was saying to him</b> that there is no distinction between different types of rings worn on a person’s <b>finger.</b>
The Gemara raises yet another objection: <b>And</b> with regard <b>to</b> rings worn on a person’s <b>finger, are this and that one</b> and the same? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>A ring</b> made <b>of metal and its seal</b> is made <b>of coral, is ritually impure?</b> The primary component of the ring, metal, is the determining factor, and a metal utensil can become ritually impure. However, a ring that is made <b>of coral and its seal is</b> made <b>of metal is ritually pure.</b> Apparently, there is a distinction between different types of finger rings with regard to ritual impurity. The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>was saying</b> that statement <b>to</b> the disciple, <b>he too was saying to him</b> that there is no distinction between different types of rings <b>that</b> are made <b>entirely of metal.</b>
<b>And furthermore,</b> that same disciple <b>asked: I heard that one distinguishes between</b> one type of <b>needle and</b> another type of <b>needle.</b> Still, I do not know with regard to what <i>halakha</i> this distinction is made. Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to him: Perhaps you only heard</b> that distinction <b>with regard to Shabbat.</b> With regard to the prohibition of carrying from a private to a public domain, or vice versa, there is a distinction between a needle with an eye, for which one is liable to bring a sin-offering, and one without an eye, for which one is not. <b>As, if</b> you were to suggest that the distinction is <b>with regard to ritual impurity, this,</b> a needle with an eye, <b>and that,</b> a needle without an eye, <b>are one</b> and the same, and there is no distinction between them.
The Gemara raises an objection: <b>And</b> with regard <b>to the matter of ritual impurity, are this and that one</b> and the same? Are all needles alike? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>A needle whose eye or whose point was removed is ritually pure,</b> as it is no longer fit for use? Apparently, there is a distinction between an intact needle and a broken one with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity. The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>was saying</b> that statement <b>to</b> the disciple, he was referring <b>to a whole</b> needle. Indeed, there is no distinction between different types of whole needles with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity.
The Gemara raises another objection: <b>And with regard to whole</b> needles, <b>are this and that one</b> and the same? Is there no distinction between them? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>a needle that became rusty</b>; <b>if</b> the rust <b>inhibits the sewing,</b> the needle <b>is ritually pure; and if</b> it does <b>not</b> inhibit the sewing, <b>it is ritually impure. And the</b> Sages <b>of the school of Rabbi Yannai said: And that is</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the needle cannot become ritually impure not only when it is impossible to push the needle through the fabric, but even <b>when</b> the <b>mark</b> of rusty needle is <b>conspicuous</b> in the stitching. Apparently, there is a distinction between different types of whole needles. The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>was saying</b> that statement <b>to</b> the disciple, <b>he was saying to him</b> that there is no distinction between different types <b>of</b> needles that were <b>smoothed</b> and filed. He was not referring to rusty needles.
The Gemara raises yet another objection: <b>And with regard to smoothed</b> needles, <b>are this and that one</b> and the same? <b>Wasn’t it taught in</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A needle, whether it has an eye</b> and <b>whether it does not have an eye, may be moved on Shabbat? And we only said</b> that a needle <b>with an eye</b> is different <b>with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>ritual impurity.</b> Apparently, there is a distinction between different types of smoothed needles with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity.
The Gemara answers: <b>Didn’t Abaye</b> already <b>interpret</b> that <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava</b> as referring <b>to unfinished</b> needles? If a needle is unfinished, and it has not been perforated to create an eye, it cannot become ritually impure because it is not yet a utensil. However, if the needle is finished, whether it has an eye and is used for sewing, or it does not have an eye and is used as a pin, it is regarded as a utensil and therefore can become ritually impure.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A donkey may go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with a saddlecloth</b> that protects it from the cold <b>when it is tied to</b> the animal, and there is no room for concern lest it fall. <b>Rams may go out <i>levuvin</i>. Ewes may go out <i>sheḥuzot, kevulot,</i> and <i>kevunot</i></b>. All of these terms are discussed and explained in the Gemara. <b>She-goats may go out</b> with their udders <b>bound. Rabbi Yosei prohibits</b> the animals from going out <b>with all</b> of <b>these</b> items, as he considers them burdens, <b>except for the ewes that are <i>kevunot</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Goats may go out</b> on Shabbat with their udders <b>bound to dry</b> their milk supply and discontinue their lactation, in order to facilitate conception. In that case, they are tied with a tight, permanent knot, and there is no concern lest it fall in the public domain. <b>However,</b> they may <b>not</b> go out with their udders bound <b>to</b> conserve their <b>milk,</b> as in that case they are bound loosely.

Daf 53a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Shmuel said</b>: <b>And</b> with regard to the <i>halakha</i> taught in our mishna that a donkey may go out on Shabbat with its saddlecloth, <b>that</b> only applies to a case <b>where</b> it <b>was tied to</b> the animal <b>from Shabbat eve. Rav Naḥman said:</b> The wording of <b>our mishna is also precise</b> in support of Shmuel’s statement, <b>as it teaches</b> later in the chapter: <b>A donkey may not go out</b> into the public domain on Shabbat <b>with its saddlecloth when it is not tied to</b> its back.
The Gemara clarifies the meaning of that mishna: <b>What are the circumstances? If you say</b> that the later mishna is referring to a case where the saddlecloth <b>is not tied to</b> the animal <b>at all,</b> that is <b>obvious</b>. There is concern <b>lest</b> the saddlecloth <b>fall from</b> the animal <b>and</b> its owner will <b>come to bring it</b> and carry it four cubits in the public domain. <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case where the saddlecloth is presently tied to the animal, but <b>it was not tied from Shabbat eve? By inference,</b> conclude <b>that the first clause,</b> i.e., our mishna, which permits the animal to go out with its saddlecloth, is referring to a case where the saddlecloth <b>was tied to</b> the animal <b>from Shabbat eve.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is the correct understanding.
<b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A donkey may go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with its saddlecloth when it was tied to</b> the animal <b>from Shabbat eve, and</b> it may <b>not</b> go out <b>with the saddle, even though it was tied to</b> the animal <b>from Shabbat eve. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> The donkey may <b>even</b> go out <b>with its saddle when it was tied to</b> the animal <b>from Shabbat eve, provided that he does not tie</b> the <b>strap</b> with which the saddle is fastened around the donkey’s belly, <b>and provided that he does not pass a strap under</b> the animal’s <b>tail,</b> which is standard procedure when placing a burden on the animal.
<b>Rav Asi bar Natan raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Rav Ashi: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>placing a saddlecloth on a donkey on Shabbat</b> in a private domain in order to warm the donkey with no intention to take it into the public domain? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi <b>said to him: It is permitted.</b> Rav Asi bar Natan <b>said to him: What is the difference between this and a saddle</b>, which may not be moved on Shabbat? Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi <b>remained silent</b> and did not answer.
Rav Asi bar Natan thought that Rabbi Ḥiyya was of the opinion that even a saddle may be placed on a donkey on Shabbat. <b>He,</b> therefore, <b>raised an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A saddle that is on a donkey</b> on Shabbat, and its owner wishes to remove it, <b>he may not move it with his hand</b> to remove it; <b>rather, he walks</b> the animal <b>back and forth in the courtyard, and</b> the saddle <b>falls on its own. Now</b> even with regard <b>to removing</b> a saddle that is already on the animal’s back, <b>you said no,</b> one may not move it; is prohibiting one <b>from placing</b> the saddle on the animal <b>necessary?</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said to</b> Rav Asi: <b>Leave</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya, and do not raise an objection to his statement, as <b>he agrees with his teacher. As Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said: One may hang a basket</b> with fodder <b>around</b> the neck of <b>an animal on Shabbat, and</b> by means of an <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference<b>,</b> derive that one may place <b>a saddlecloth</b> on an animal’s back on Shabbat. What is the <i>a fortiori</i> inference? <b>Just as there,</b> placing the basket of fodder so that the animal can eat without bending down, <b>which is</b> done <b>for</b> the animal’s <b>pleasure, is permitted</b>; <b>here,</b> placing the saddlecloth, <b>which is</b> done to prevent the animal from <b>suffering</b> from the cold, <b>all the more so</b> should be permitted.
<b>Shmuel said: A saddlecloth is permitted;</b> however, <b>a basket</b> with fodder <b>is prohibited. Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef went and said the <i>halakha</i> of Rav before Shmuel.</b> Shmuel <b>said to him: If Abba,</b> Rav, actually <b>said that, he knows nothing at all about matters of Shabbat.</b>
<b>When Rabbi Zeira ascended</b> to Eretz Yisrael <b>he found Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet who sat and said to him in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: One may place a saddlecloth on a donkey on Shabbat.</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him:</b> You have spoken <b>well, and Aryokh explained</b> the matter <b>likewise in Babylonia.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Who is Aryokh?</b> It is <b>Shmuel. Didn’t Rav also say</b> that one may place a saddlecloth on a donkey on Shabbat? With regard to a saddlecloth they agree. Why then did Rabbi Zeira attribute the ruling specifically to Shmuel? <b>Rather, he heard</b> Rabbi Binyamin bar Yefet <b>conclude: However, one may not hang a basket</b> with fodder around the neck of an animal <b>on Shabbat.</b> It was that part of the statement that led him to say: You have spoken <b>well</b>, <b>and Aryokh explained</b> the matter <b>likewise in Babylonia.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>In any case, everyone agrees that a saddlecloth is permitted.</b> The question arises: <b>How is</b> a saddlecloth <b>different from a saddle,</b> which may not even be removed from the donkey? If the concern is for the animal’s suffering, why is it not permitted to remove the saddle? The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there, as it is possible for</b> the saddle <b>to fall on its own.</b> Therefore, there is no reason to permit its removal by hand.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> There is a distinction between the two cases: <b>Here,</b> where the Sages permitted placing a saddlecloth on a donkey on Shabbat, it is <b>to warm</b> the animal. <b>There,</b> where the Sages prohibited removing a saddle, it is <b>to cool</b> the animal. Placing the saddlecloth <b>to warm</b> the animal is permitted because otherwise <b>it</b> experiences <b>discomfort</b> from the cold. However, removing the saddle <b>to cool</b> the animal is prohibited because the animal <b>does not</b> experience <b>discomfort</b> from excessive heat. <b>And that is</b> the folk saying <b>that people say: A donkey, even in the</b> summer <b>season of Tammuz, is cold.</b> Therefore, seeing to the animal’s warmth is more important.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the <i>Tosefta</i> to those who prohibit placing a basket with fodder around an animal’s neck on Shabbat: <b>A horse may neither go out</b> into the public domain on Shabbat <b>with a fox’s tail</b> that is placed as a talisman to ward off the evil eye <b>nor with</b> a string of <b>red wool that is</b> hung <b>between its eyes</b> as an ornament. <b>Neither may a <i>zav</i> go out with his pouch</b> that prevents his clothes from becoming sullied from his emissions, <b>nor goats with a pouch that is on their udders</b> so that they will not be scratched by stones, <b>nor a cow with the muzzle that is on its mouth, nor foals with baskets</b> of fodder <b>that are around their mouths into the public domain. And an animal</b> may <b>neither</b> go out <b>with</b> metal <b>shoes that are on its feet, nor with an amulet</b> that is placed on the animal to promote its good health, <b>even if</b> the amulet <b>has proven effective. And this is a stricture</b> that applies <b>to animals beyond</b> the strictures that apply <b>to people,</b> as a person is permitted to go out into the public domain with an amulet that has proved effective.
<b>However,</b> an animal <b>may go out with a bandage that is on a wound, and with splints that are on a broken bone</b> so that it will heal properly, <b>and with the afterbirth hanging</b> from its womb. <b>And one may plug the bell</b> hanging <b>from</b> an animal’s <b>neck</b> to prevent it from ringing, <b>and</b> then the animal <b>may walk with it in the courtyard,</b> which is a private domain, but not in a public domain.
<b>In any case, it is taught</b> here: <b>Nor foals with baskets</b> of fodder <b>that are around their mouths into the public domain.</b> By inference: It is specifically <b>into the public domain</b> that they may <b>not</b> go with fodder baskets in their mouths; <b>however, in a courtyard,</b> they may <b>well</b> walk with a basket of fodder. <b>What? Is it not</b> referring <b>to large</b> foals around whose necks fodder baskets are hung <b>for</b> their <b>pleasure?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>No</b>, it is referring <b>to small</b> foals, <b>and</b> the baskets are hung <b>to</b> prevent their <b>discomfort.</b> The legs of a young foal are long and its neck is short. Consequently, eating from the ground is difficult. Hanging the fodder basket around its neck enables it to eat without bending down. The Gemara adds: <b>This is also precise</b> in the language of the <i>Tosefta</i>, <b>as it teaches</b> the case of the foals

Daf 53b

<b>similar to</b> the case of <b>an amulet</b> worn for healing purposes. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that this is the correct understanding.
The Gemara further examines the <i>baraita</i> cited earlier. <b>The Master said: Nor</b> may an animal go out <b>with an amulet</b> on Shabbat, <b>even if</b> the amulet <b>proved effective.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: One may <b>not</b> go out on Shabbat <b>with an amulet that has not proved effective?</b> By inference: If the amulet <b>proved effective,</b> he may <b>well</b> do so. The Gemara answers: <b>Here too</b>, it is referring to an amulet <b>that has not proved effective.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Doesn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach: Even if</b> the amulet <b>proved effective?</b> The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> is referring to an amulet that <b>proved effective for a person, and did not prove effective for an animal.</b> The Gemara wonders: <b>Is there</b> an amulet that <b>proved effective for a person and is not effective for an animal?</b> Healing an animal should be easier than healing a person. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> an amulet <b>aids a person, who is under</b> the protection of <b>an</b> advocate <b>angel [<i>mazal</i>];</b> however, <b>it does not aid an animal, which is not under</b> the protection of <b>an</b> advocate <b>angel.</b>
The Gemara poses a question: <b>If so,</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to an amulet that did not prove effective for an animal, but if the amulet proved effective, the animal may indeed go out into the public domain with it; <b>what</b> is the meaning of the phrase in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>And this is a stricture</b> that applies <b>to animals beyond</b> the strictures that apply <b>to people?</b> The <i>halakha</i> is the same with regard to both people and animals. If the amulet has proven effective, even an animal may go out with it on Shabbat. If it has not proven effective, even a person may not go out with it. The Gemara responds: <b>Do you hold</b> that <b>this</b> statement <b>is referring to an amulet? It is referring to a shoe;</b> an animal may not go out with a shoe on Shabbat, but a person may.
With regard to whether and to what extent the discomfort of animals is a factor taken into consideration on Shabbat, the Gemara says: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may smear</b> on <b>oil and scrape</b> off a scab on Shabbat <b>for a person, and one may not smear</b> on <b>oil and scrape</b> off a scab <b>for an animal. Is it not</b> referring here to a case <b>where there is a wound, and</b> he smears on oil <b>and</b> scrapes the scab <b>due to</b> the <b>discomfort</b> caused by the wound, and nevertheless it was permitted exclusively for a person and not for an animal? The Gemara rejects this argument: <b>No,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where the wound has</b> already <b>ceased</b> and healed, and he smears oil and scrapes <b>due to</b> the <b>pleasure</b> caused by the treatment.
The Gemara cites an additional proof: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which was taught in the following <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>an animal</b> suffering from heart <b>congestion</b> that restricts its <b>blood</b> supply and whose temperature has risen, <b>one may not stand it in water so that it will cool</b> off. However, with regard to <b>a person</b> suffering from heart <b>congestion</b> that restricts his <b>blood</b> supply, <b>one</b> may <b>stand him in water so that he will cool</b> off. Apparently, the suffering of an animal is of no concern. <b>Ulla said:</b> Here, the Sages issued <b>a decree</b> prohibiting all healing on Shabbat <b>due to the crushing of herbs</b> for medicinal purposes, which is prohibited by Torah law. The Sages prohibited cooling the animal in water lest one come to grind the ingredients used in the preparation of medicine.
<b>If so,</b> the same decree should <b>also</b> apply in the case of <b>a person.</b> It should be prohibited to stand a sick person in water to cool him off due to the rabbinic prohibition against engaging in healing on Shabbat. The Gemara answers: In the case of <b>a person, it appears as</b> if he entered the water merely <b>to cool</b> off, not necessarily to cure an illness.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so</b>, say in the case of <b>an animal as well</b> that <b>it appears as</b> if it entered the water merely <b>to cool</b> off<b>,</b> not necessarily to cure an illness. The Gemara answers: <b>An animal</b> does <b>not</b> typically enter the water on its own to <b>cool</b> off. Neither does one typically stand an animal in water to cool it off unless it serves some healing purpose. Apparently, due to a decree, the Sages were stringent and prohibited standing the animal in water even if it will die as a result.
The Gemara now asks: <b>Do we</b> really <b>issue a decree for an animal? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If an animal <b>were standing beyond the</b> Shabbat <b>limit,</b> a situation in which it is prohibited to go fetch it, <b>he may call</b> the animal <b>and it will come</b> to him on its own? <b>And we do not issue a decree</b> to prohibit calling the animal, <b>lest he come to bring it</b> himself. Apparently, the Sages did not issue a decree in a case where one could incur a loss and there is no actual transgression committed. Here too, it should not be prohibited to stand his animal in water due to a decree lest he come to grind herbs and thereby violate a Torah prohibition.
<b>And Ravina said:</b> No proof can be cited from this case, as here it is a situation <b>where</b> the animal’s Shabbat <b>limit was subsumed within</b> the <b>limit</b> of its owner. The animal strayed beyond its own Shabbat limit, which is determined by the Shabbat limit of the shepherd entrusted with its herding. However, the animal remained within the Shabbat limit of its owner, which extended beyond that of the shepherd. Consequently, the owner is permitted to call the animal so that it will return on its own. Even if he forgets and goes out to fetch the animal, he will not have gone beyond his Shabbat limit. The fact that the animal itself went beyond its Shabbat limit is of no concern.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The matter of the decree due to <b>crushing herbs is itself</b> subject to a dispute between <b>the <i>tanna’im</i>. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>an animal that ate vetch,</b> which caused a life-threatening case of constipation, <b>one may not run it</b> around <b>in the courtyard to loosen</b> its bowels due to the decree prohibiting healing. <b>Rabbi Oshaya deems</b> it <b>permitted.</b> Apparently, the <i>tanna’im</i> disagree whether or not healing is prohibited with regard to animals. The Gemara adds that <b>Rava taught:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Oshaya.</b>
<b>The Master said: Neither may a <i>zav</i> go out with his pouch,</b> which prevents his clothes from becoming sullied by his emissions, <b>nor goats with the pouch that is on their udders.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>: <b>Goats may go out with the pouch that is on their udders?</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a pouch <b>that is</b> tied <b>tightly</b> to the udder. It is permitted because there is no concern that the pouch will fall. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a pouch <b>that is not tightly</b> tied. It is prohibited because of the concern that the pouch will fall and a person will come to retrieve it.
<b>Rav Yosef said: Have you removed the <i>tanna’im</i> from the world?</b> This is subject to a disagreement between <b>the <i>tanna’im</i></b>, <b>as we learned</b> in our mishna: <b>She-goats may go out</b> with their udders <b>bound. Rabbi Yosei Rabbi Yosei prohibits</b> the animals from going out <b>with all</b> of <b>these</b> items, as he considers them burdens, <b>except for the ewes that are <i>kevunot</i>. Rabbi Yehuda says: Goats may go out</b> on Shabbat with their udders <b>bound to dry</b> their milk supply and discontinue their lactation in order to facilitate conception, as in that case, they are tied with a tight, permanent knot. <b>However,</b> they may <b>not</b> go out with their udders bound <b>to</b> conserve the <b>milk,</b> as in that case they are bound loosely. Apparently, there are <i>tanna’im</i> who rule leniently with regard to attaching pouches to the udders of goats and permit the practice, and others prohibit doing so.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: Both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> were taught <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and</b> nevertheless it is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where the goats are permitted to go out with a pouch on their udders, the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where it was done <b>to dry</b> their milk supply. <b>There,</b> where goats are prohibited to do so, the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where it was done <b>to</b> conserve <b>the milk</b>.
The Gemara adds: <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving the goats</b> belonging to the residents of <b>a house in Antioch whose udders were</b> especially <b>large</b> and they would drag along the ground. <b>And they made pouches for them so that their udders would not get scratched.</b>
The Gemara cites a related <i>baraita</i> in which the <b>Sages taught:</b> There was <b>an incident where one</b> man’s <b>wife died, and she left</b> him <b>a son to nurse</b>, <b>and he did not have</b> money to pay <b>the wages of a wet-nurse. And a miracle was performed on his behalf, and he developed breasts like the two breasts of a woman, and he nursed his son.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: Come and see how great this person is that a miracle</b> of <b>that</b> magnitude <b>was performed on his behalf. Abaye said to him: On the contrary, how dishonorable is this person that the order of creation was altered on his behalf.</b> A miracle was indeed performed on his behalf; however, it was performed in a demeaning and unpleasant manner.
<b>Rav Yehuda</b> added and <b>said: Come and see how difficult</b> it is to provide for <b>a person’s sustenance.</b> It is so difficult <b>that the order of creation had to be altered on</b> his <b>behalf,</b> which was apparently easier than providing him a source of financial support. <b>Rav Naḥman said: Know</b> that it is so, <b>as miracles are</b> often <b>performed</b> on a person’s behalf; <b>however,</b> it has <b>not</b> yet happened that <b>food was</b> miraculously <b>created</b> in a person’s home.
The Gemara relates another unusual story. <b>The Sages taught:</b> There was <b>an incident involving one man who married a one-armed woman, and he did not realize</b> that she was one-armed <b>until the day that she died. Rav said: Come and see how modest this woman was that her husband did not realize</b> this <b>about her. Rabbi Ḥiyya said to him: That is</b> typical <b>conduct</b> for <b>her,</b> as a woman typically covers herself. All the more so a one-armed woman makes sure to cover her defect. <b>Rather,</b> say: <b>How modest was this man that he did not recognize</b> this <b>in his wife.</b>
We learned in our mishna: <b>Rams may go out <i>levuvin</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b><i>levuvin</i>? Rav Huna said: Tied [<i>tutri</i>]</b> in pairs. The Gemara explains: <b>From where</b> may it <b>be inferred that this</b> word <b><i>levuvin</i> is a term of closeness? As it is written: “You have drawn me near [<i>libavtini</i>], my sister my bride”</b> (Song of Songs 4:9).
<b>Ulla said:</b> <i>Levuvin</i> refers to animal <b>hide that one ties over the hearts</b> [<i>lev</i>] of rams <b>so that wolves will not attack them</b>. The Gemara asks: Do <b>wolves attack rams</b> but <b>do not attack ewes?</b> Why is this protection provided only to males? The Gemara answers: <b>Because</b> the males <b>walk at the head of the flock.</b> The Gemara asks: Do <b>wolves attack the head of the flock</b> but <b>not the rear of the flock? Rather,</b> the wolves prey specifically on the rams <b>because they are plump</b>. The Gemara asks: <b>Are there no plump</b> ones <b>among the ewes? And furthermore, do</b> the wolves <b>know</b> how to distinguish <b>between these,</b> the plump ones, and <b>those,</b> the thin ones? <b>Rather,</b> the wolves prey specifically on the rams <b>because they raise their noses and walk while looking</b> to both sides. The wolves think that they are preparing to attack them.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b>: <i>Levuvin</i> refers to animal <b>hide that one ties under their male</b> organ <b>so that they will not mount the females. And from where</b> do we derive that meaning? <b>Because the latter clause states: Ewes may go out <i>sheḥuzot</i>. What is</b> the meaning of <b><i>sheḥuzot</i>?</b> It means <b>that they fasten [<i>she’oḥazin</i>] their tails</b> with animal hide <b>so that the males may mount them</b> more easily. It is reasonable to explain that <b>the first clause</b> refers to an action undertaken <b>so that the males will not mount the females, and the latter clause</b> to an action undertaken <b>so that the males will mount them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> may it <b>be inferred that this</b> word <b><i>sheḥuzot</i> is a term of exposure?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written</b> in the description of a wicked woman: <b>“And behold there met him a woman</b>

Daf 54a

<b>with the attire of a harlot [<i>shit zona</i>] and wily of heart”</b> (Proverbs 7:10). <i>Sheḥuzot</i> can be interpreted as an acronym of the words <i>shit zona</i>, attire of a harlot, with the letters <i>tav</i> and <i>ḥet</i>, which are similar in form, interchanged.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Ewes may go out <i>kevulot</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b><i>kevulot</i>?</b> It means <b>that they bind their tails down</b> with animal hide <b>so that the males will not mount them.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>From where</b> may it <b>be inferred that this</b> word <b><i>kavul</i> is a term</b> meaning <b>does not produce fruit? As it is written,</b> when Solomon gave a portion of land to Hiram, he complained: <b>“What cities are these which you have given me, my brother? And he called them the land of Kavul to this day”</b> (I Kings 9:13).
<b>What is</b> the meaning of <b>the land of Kavul? Rav Huna said: That the people</b> living <b>there were bound [<i>mekhubalin</i>]</b> and surrounded by <b>silver and gold. Rava said to him: If so, is that what is written:</b> “And Hiram came out of Tyre to see the cities which Solomon had given him, <b>and they pleased him not”</b> (I Kings 9:12)? Because the people there <b>were bound in silver and gold</b>, the cities <b>were not pleasing in his eyes?</b> Rav Huna <b>said to him: Yes</b>, indeed, it was precisely the abundant wealth that displeased Hiram. <b>Since</b> the people <b>were wealthy and delicate, they did not perform labor.</b> Hiram was seeking people whom he could enlist in the service of the king.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: It was a sandy [<i>ḥomton</i>] expanse</b> of land. <b>And why was it called Kavul?</b> It is <b>because the leg sinks into it up to the ankle [<i>kavla</i>]. And people say</b> in describing poor quality land: <b>Land</b> that is <b>bound [<i>mekhabela</i>]</b> shut, i.e., <b>that does not produce fruit</b>.
We learned in the mishna: Ewes may go out <b><i>kevunot</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b><i>kevunot</i>?</b> It is <b>that they covered [<i>mekhabnin</i>]</b> the animal <b>to</b> produce <b>fine wool.</b> Sheep were wrapped in cloth from the day they were born so that their wool would remain perfectly clean and it could be used in fashioning especially fine wool garments. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: The color of <b>a leprous sore</b> [<b><i>se’et</i></b>] <b>is like</b> that of <b>white wool.</b> The Gemara asked: <b>What is white wool? Rav Beivai bar Abaye said: Like the clean wool of a newborn</b> lamb, <b>which they cover</b> from birth <b>to</b> produce <b>fine wool.</b>
Our mishna continues: <b>And the she-goats may go out</b> with their udders <b>bound.</b> Rabbi Yosei prohibits doing so. Rabbi Yehuda distinguishes between a case where the udders were bound to dry the milk supply and a case where they were bound to conserve the milk. <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to the ruling in this dispute: <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b>
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who teach this <i>halakha</i> independent</b> of the mishna. <b>Rav said:</b> If the udders were bound <b>to dry</b> the milk supply <b>it is permitted, and not</b> if they were bound <b>to</b> conserve <b>the milk. And Shmuel said: Both this and that are prohibited.</b>
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who taught</b> this dispute <b>with regard to this</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>Goats may go out</b> with their udders <b>bound to dry</b> the milk supply <b>but not to</b> conserve <b>the milk. In the name of Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira they said: That is the <i>halakha</i>,</b> based on the letter of the law, <b>but who</b> can <b>cast lots</b> to determine by sight alone <b>which</b> udder is bound <b>to dry</b> the milk supply <b>and which</b> was bound <b>to</b> conserve <b>the milk? And since one cannot distinguish</b> between them, the Sages said: <b>Both this and that are prohibited. Shmuel said, and some say Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira.</b> In terms of practical <i>halakha</i>, according to all versions of the disagreement, Shmuel holds that it is prohibited in both cases. <b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the</b> anonymous <b>first <i>tanna</i></b> of the mishna. He permits goats to go out with their udders bound in all cases.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And with what may</b> an animal <b>not go out</b> into the public domain on Shabbat? <b>A camel may not go out with a saddlecloth, nor</b> may it go out <b><i>akud</i> or <i>ragul</i></b>, which are different ways of tying its legs together, as will be explained in the Gemara. <b>And likewise,</b> tying <b>all other animals</b> in those manners is prohibited.
And likewise, <b>one may not tie camels one to the other and pull</b> the lead camel, thereby pulling the others after it. <b>However, he</b> may <b>place the ropes</b> tied to each of the camels <b>in his hand and pull</b> them all, <b>provided that he does not intertwine</b> the ropes.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>A camel may not go out with a saddlecloth tied to its tail</b> alone. <b>However, it may go out with a saddlecloth tied to</b> both <b>its tail and its hump,</b> as in that case one can assume that the saddlecloth will not fall off. <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said: A</b> female <b>camel may go out with a saddlecloth tied to its afterbirth.</b> Because any movement of the saddlecloth will cause pain, the animal will not attempt to detach it. Therefore, there is no room for concern lest it fall.
We learned in the mishna: A camel may <b>not</b> go out <b><i>akud</i> or <i>ragul</i>. Rav Yehuda said: <i>Akud</i></b> means that <b>the</b> animal’s <b>foreleg and hind leg are bound together, similar to</b> the binding of <b>Isaac, son of Abraham,</b> with regard to whom the term <i>vaya’akod</i> is employed. <b><i>Ragul</i></b> means <b>that one may not bend</b> the lower part of <b>the foreleg onto the upper foreleg and tie it.</b> That was done so that the camel would have the use of only three legs and would be unable to run away.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b><i>Akud</i></b> means that the animal’s <b>two forelegs and two hind legs are bound together. <i>Ragul</i></b> means <b>that one may not bend</b> the lower part of <b>the foreleg onto the upper foreleg and tie it.</b> The Gemara answers: Rav Yehuda <b>holds in accordance with this <i>tanna</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b><i>Akud</i></b> means that either the animal’s <b>foreleg and hind leg or</b> its <b>two forelegs and two hind legs are bound together. <i>Ragul</i></b> means <b>that one may not bend</b> the lower part of <b>the foreleg onto the upper foreleg and tie it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> this <i>baraita</i> and Rav Yehuda’s statement <b>are still not the same. Granted, the first clause,</b> the first case of <i>akud</i>, <b>and the last clause,</b> the case of <i>ragul</i>, work out <b>well.</b> The <i>baraita</i> and the opinion of Rav Yehuda correspond. However, <b>the middle clause is difficult.</b> According to the <i>baraita</i>, when the animal’s two forelegs and two hind legs are bound together, that is also considered <i>akud</i>, contrary to Rav Yehuda’s opinion.
<b>Rather,</b> Rav Yehuda <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with this <i>tanna</i>,</b> who said in a <i>baraita</i>: <b><i>Akud</i></b> means that the animal’s <b>foreleg and hind leg are bound together, similar to</b> the binding of <b>Isaac, son of Abraham. <i>Ragul</i></b> means <b>that one may not bend</b> the lower part of <b>the foreleg onto the upper foreleg and tie it.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>And one may not tie camels</b> one to the other and pull the lead camel, thereby pulling the others after it. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Rav Ashi said: Because he appears like one going to the market [<i>ḥinga</i>]</b> to sell merchandise or to deliver a caravan of camels. In deference to Shabbat, one may not create that impression.
The mishna continues: <b>However, he</b> may <b>place the</b> ropes tied to each of the camels in his hand and pull them all, provided that he does not intertwine the ropes. <b>Rav Ashi said: This</b> prohibition <b>was taught</b> not with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat but <b>only with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of prohibited mixtures of <b>diverse kinds.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Diverse kinds of what? If you say</b> that it is referring to the prohibited mixture <b>of</b> the <b>diverse kinds of man</b> and animal, i.e., a person may not be tied to an animal, just as plowing with the diverse kinds of an ox and a donkey is prohibited, that is difficult. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>A person is permitted to plow and to pull</b> a wagon together <b>with all</b> animals, as the prohibition is limited to diverse kinds of animals?
<b>Rather,</b> the problem here is one of <b>diverse kinds of ropes.</b> If one rope is made of wool and another of linen, it is prohibited to intertwine them because that would create a forbidden mixture of the diverse kinds of wool and linen. <b>However,</b> this too is difficult, as, <b>wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who attaches</b> a swatch of wool and a swatch of linen <b>with a single stitch</b> or knot, <b>it is not</b> considered <b>a connection</b> with regard to the prohibition of diverse kinds? All the more so in this case, where the ropes are not tied together at all but are merely intertwined, it should not be considered a connection.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the problem here is one of <b>diverse kinds of ropes, and</b> the mishna <b>is saying as follows: Provided that he does not intertwine</b> the ropes <b>and tie</b> them together. Ropes that are intertwined and tied together constitute a double knot, which is considered a connection with regard to the prohibition of diverse kinds of wool and linen.
<b>Shmuel said</b> that there is another restriction that applies to pulling camels with ropes on Shabbat. It is only permitted <b>provided that a handbreadth of the rope does not hang below his hand</b> to avoid the appearance that he is carrying a rope in his hand on Shabbat. The Gemara raises an objection: <b>Didn’t</b> a Sage <b>of the school of Shmuel teach</b> a <i>baraita</i>: Provided that <b>two handbreadths</b> of the rope do not hang below his hand?
<b>Abaye said: Now that Shmuel said one handbreadth, and</b> a Sage <b>of the school of Shmuel taught two handbreadths</b>, it is reasonable to conclude that <b>Shmuel came to teach us the practical <i>halakha</i>.</b> Even though the <i>tanna’im</i> permitted pulling the camel as long as there is less than two handbreadths of rope hanging below his hand, in practice, one should be stringent and not leave even one handbreadth hanging.

Daf 54b

The Gemara raises an objection: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: This is only permitted <b>provided that he raises</b> the rope <b>one handbreadth from the ground?</b> Apparently, there is no restriction with regard to the length of rope that may hang below the person’s hand. The Gemara answers: <b>When this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught,</b> it was taught <b>with regard to the</b> length of <b>rope between</b> the camel and the person holding it. That part of the rope may not sag to the ground; rather, it must be raised at least one handbreadth so that it is clear that the rope is attached to the camel.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> This mishna lists additional objects with which an animal may not go out into the public domain on Shabbat: <b>A donkey may neither go out with the saddlecloth when it is not tied to</b> its back, <b>nor with a bell even if it is plugged</b> to prevent it from ringing, <b>nor with a ladder that is around its neck, nor with a strap that is around its leg.</b>
<b>And the roosters may not go out with strings and not with a strap on their feet,</b> which are tied there as a sign of ownership. <b>And the rams may not go out with a</b> small <b>wagon under their tails,</b> as it was common practice to put a small wagon under the tails of grown sheep so that the tail would not be injured by dragging on the ground.
<b>And ewes may not go out <i>ḥanunot</i>, nor may a calf go out with a <i>gimon</i>, nor may a cow</b> go out <b>with the skin of a hedgehog [<i>kupar</i>], nor with a strap between its horns.</b> The mishna relates that <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya’s cow would go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with a strap between its horns, contrary to the will of the Sages.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that a donkey may not go out on Shabbat with a saddlecloth if it was not tied to its back. The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason? As we stated</b> above, there is room for concern that when not secured, the saddlecloth is liable to fall off the animal’s back, and its owner may come to retrieve the saddlecloth in the public domain.
We also learned in the mishna: A donkey may <b>not</b> go out <b>with a bell even if it is plugged</b> to prevent it from ringing. The reason is <b>that</b> the animal’s owner <b>appears like one going to the market,</b> who adorns his donkey with bells in honor of market day.
It was also taught in the mishna: <b>Nor with a ladder that is around its neck. Rav Huna said:</b> This refers to a <b>device</b> tied to <b>the jaw. For what</b> purpose does the owner <b>do</b> so <b>to</b> the animal? <b>For</b> a circumstance <b>in which</b> the animal <b>has a wound</b>, <b>so that it does not chafe it again</b> and exacerbate the wound.
The mishna continues: <b>Nor with a strap that is around its leg.</b> The Gemara explains: What purpose does this strap serve? The owner <b>does</b> so <b>to</b> the animal to protect its <b>strides.</b> If its legs are slightly bent so that they knock against each other when the animal walks, a strap is tied there to prevent injury.
We learned further in the mishna: <b>And the roosters may not go out with strings.</b> For what purpose does the owner place the strings? <b>He does so to</b> the roosters as <b>a sign</b> indicating to whom they belong, <b>so that they will not be confused</b> with other roosters.
The mishna continues: <b>Nor with a strap</b> on their feet. The Gemara explains that the owner <b>does</b> so <b>to</b> the roosters <b>so that they will not break vessels.</b> When their legs are tied, they jump around less and cause less damage. The mishna teaches: <b>Rams may not go out with a</b> small <b>wagon</b> under their tails. The Gemara explains that these wagons were placed there <b>in order that their tails will not be injured.</b>
The mishna teaches: <b>And ewes may not go out <i>ḥanunot</i>.</b> The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ulla sat before Rav Ḥisda and he sat and he said: From when they shear</b> the wool off the animal, <b>they soak a</b> soft <b>swatch</b> of wool or some other material <b>in oil and place it on</b> the animal’s <b>forehead so that it will not catch cold</b> until its wool grows back. <i>Ḥanunot</i> refers to animals with those swatches. <b>Rav Ḥisda said to him: If so, you turned</b> the animal into the Exilarch, <b>Mar Ukva.</b> That is treatment fit for him, not for a shorn sheep.
<b>Rather, Rav Pappa bar Shmuel sat before Rav Ḥisda, and he sat and he said: At the time that</b> the animal <b>crouches to give birth,</b> those tending to the animal <b>soak two swatches</b> of wool <b>in oil, and place one on</b> the animal’s <b>forehead and the other on its womb so that it will be warmed.</b> <i>Ḥanunot</i> refers to animals with those swatches. <b>Rav Naḥman said to him: If so, you turned</b> the animal into <b>Yalta,</b> my wife, who descended from the house of the Exilarch. That is treatment fit for her, not for an animal.
<b>Rather, Rav Huna said: There is a certain tree in the cities</b> on the <b>sea</b> shore, <b>and <i>ḥanun</i> is its name.</b> Those tending to the animal <b>bring a wood chip</b> from the tree <b>and place it in</b> the animal’s <b>nose so that it will sneeze and the worms on its head will fall.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> not only ewes but also <b>rams</b> should be given this treatment. The Gemara answers: <b>Since the rams butt</b> heads <b>with each other,</b> the worms <b>fall in any event. Shimon the Nazirite said:</b> <i>Ḥanunot</i> is referring to animals into whose nose the <b>chip of a broom tree</b> would be placed.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> according to the explanation of <b>Rav Huna</b> that it is the chip taken from the <i>ḥanun</i> tree, <b>that is</b> why the mishna <b>teaches</b> the <i>halakha</i> employing the term <b><i>ḥanunot</i>. However, according to</b> the explanations proposed by <b>the</b> other <b>Sages, what is</b> the reason that the mishna employed the term <b><i>ḥanunot</i>?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Because we do something to</b> the animals that indicates that <b>we have mercy on them;</b> <i>hanunot</i> in the sense of merciful.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And a calf may not go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with a <i>gimon</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>A calf with a <i>gimon</i>? Rav Huna said</b>: <b>A small yoke</b> is placed on the calf in order to train it from an early age to bear a yoke. <b>Rabbi Elazar said: From where</b> is it <b>inferred that this</b> term <b><i>gimon</i> is a term of bending? As it is written: “Is it to bow down his head like a bulrush [<i>agmon</i>]”</b> (Isaiah 58:5). There is an etymological similarity between the words <i>gimon</i> and <i>agmon</i>.
The mishna continues: <b>And a cow</b> may <b>not</b> go out on Shabbat <b>with the skin of a hedgehog</b> placed over its udder. The Gemara explains <b>that</b> the owner <b>does</b> this <b>to</b> the cow <b>so that creeping animals will not suckle from it.</b>
It was also taught in the mishna: <b>And not with a strap that is between its horns.</b> The Gemara notes: <b>If</b> this is explained according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, whether</b> the strap was intended <b>as an ornament or whether</b> it was intended <b>to secure</b> the animal, <b>it is prohibited</b> for the cow to go out into the public domain with it. <b>If</b> this is explained according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel,</b> if the strap was intended <b>as an ornament, it is prohibited;</b> if it was intended <b>to secure</b> the animal, <b>it is permitted.</b>
The mishna relates that the <b>cow of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya</b> would go out on Shabbat with a strap between its horns, contrary to the will of the Sages. The Gemara asks: <b>Did</b> Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya <b>have</b> only <b>one cow? Didn’t Rav say, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya would tithe from his herds 12,000 calves each and every year?</b> There were 120, 000 calves born in his herds annually. There is no way, then, to speak of the cow of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.
The Gemara answers: <b>It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: The cow <b>was not his; rather,</b> it was <b>his neighbor’s. And because he did not protest her</b> conduct and tell her that doing so is prohibited the cow <b>was called by his name</b> to his discredit, as if it were his.
It was related that <b>Rav, and Rabbi Ḥanina, and Rabbi Yoḥanan, and Rav Ḥaviva taught</b> the statement cited below. The Gemara comments: <b>Throughout the order of <i>Moed</i>, wherever this pair</b> of Sages is mentioned, <b>exchange Rabbi Yoḥanan and insert Rabbi Yonatan</b> in his place. In any event, they said: <b>Anyone who</b> had <b>the capability to</b> effectively <b>protest</b> the sinful conduct of <b>the members of his household and did not protest,</b> he himself is <b>apprehended for</b> the sins of <b>the members of his household</b> and punished. If he is in a position to protest the sinful conduct of <b>the people of his town,</b> and he fails to do so, he is <b>apprehended for</b> the sins of <b>the people of his town.</b> If he is in a position to protest the sinful conduct of <b>the whole world,</b> and he fails to do so, <b>he</b> is <b>apprehended for</b> the sins of <b>the whole world.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said: And</b> the members <b>of the household of the Exilarch were apprehended</b> and punished <b>for</b> the sins of <b>the whole world.</b> Because their authority extends across the entire Jewish world, it is in their hands to ensure that nobody commit a transgression. <b>As</b> indicated by <b>that which Rabbi Ḥanina said: What is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written: “The Lord will enter into judgment with the Elders of His people and its princes</b>, saying: It is you who have eaten up the vineyard; the robbery of the poor is in your houses” (Isaiah 3:14)? The question arises: <b>If the princes sinned</b> by committing robbery,

Daf 55a

<b>what did the Elders,</b> i.e., the Sages of that generation, do that was considered a <b>sin? Rather, say:</b> God will enter into judgment <b>with the Elders because they did not protest</b> the sinful conduct of <b>the princes.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Yehuda was sitting before Shmuel</b> when <b>this woman came</b> and <b>cried before</b> Shmuel about an injustice that had been committed against her, <b>and</b> Shmuel <b>paid no attention to her.</b> Rav Yehuda <b>said to</b> Shmuel: <b>Doesn’t the Master hold</b> in accordance with the verse: <b>“Whoever stops his ears at the cry of the poor, he also shall cry himself, but shall not be heard”</b> (Proverbs 21:13)? He <b>said to him: Big-toothed one, your superior</b>, i.e., I, your teacher, <b>will be</b> punished <b>in cold water. The superior of your superior will be</b> punished <b>in hot water. Mar Ukva, who sits as president of the court,</b> is responsible for those matters.
And from where is it derived that this responsibility is incumbent upon the house of the Exilarch? <b>As it is written: “House of David, so says the Lord: Execute judgment in the morning, and deliver him that is robbed out of the hand of the oppressor, lest My fury go forth like fire, and burn so that none can quench it because of the evil of your doings”</b> (Jeremiah 21:12). The Exilarch is a direct descendant of the house of David.
With regard to the issue of reprimand, it was related that <b>Rabbi Zeira said to Rabbi Simon: Let the Master reprimand</b> the members of <b>the house of the Exilarch,</b> as Rabbi Simon had some influence over them. Rabbi Simon <b>said to him: They will not accept</b> reprimand <b>from me.</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: Let my master reprimand them even if they do not accept</b> it.
<b>As Rabbi Aḥa, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: Never did</b> a promise manifesting <b>a good attribute emerge from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He, and He</b> later <b>retracted it</b> and rendered it <b>evil, except</b> with regard to <b>this matter, as it is written: “And the Lord said to him: Go through the midst of the city, through the midst of Jerusalem, and set a mark [<i>tav</i>] upon the foreheads of the men that sigh and that cry on account of all the abominations that are done in her midst”</b> (Ezekiel 9:4).
<b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to</b> the angel <b>Gabriel: Go and inscribe a <i>tav</i> of ink on the foreheads of the righteous</b> as a sign <b>so that the angels of destruction will not have dominion over them. And</b> inscribe <b>a <i>tav</i> of blood on the foreheads of the wicked</b> as a sign <b>so that the angels of destruction will have dominion over them</b>.
<b>The attribute of justice said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, how are these different from those? He said to</b> that attribute: <b>These are full-fledged righteous</b> people <b>and those are full-fledged wicked</b> people. The attribute of justice <b>said to Him: Master of the Universe</b>, <b>it was in</b> the <b>hands</b> of the righteous <b>to protest</b> the conduct of the wicked, <b>and they did not protest.</b>
<b>He said to</b> that attribute: <b>It is revealed and known before Me that</b> even <b>had they protested the</b> conduct of the wicked, <b>they would not have accepted</b> the reprimand <b>from them.</b> They would have continued in their wicked ways. The attribute of justice <b>said before Him: Master of the Universe, if it is revealed before You</b> that their reprimand would have been ineffective, <b>is it revealed to them?</b> The Holy One, Blessed be He, retracted His promise to protect the righteous and decided that those who failed to protest would also be punished.
<b>And that is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written: “Slay utterly old and young, both maid, and little children, and women; but come not near any man upon whom is the mark; and begin at My Sanctuary”</b> (Ezekiel 9:6). <b>And it is written</b> in that same verse: <b>“Then they began with the elderly men who were before the house.” Rav Yosef taught: Read not: My Sanctuary [<i>mikdashi</i>], rather: Those sanctified to Me [<i>mekudashai</i>]. These are people who observed the whole Torah in its entirety from <i>alef</i> through <i>tav</i>. And immediately: “And, behold, six men came from the way of the higher gate, which lies toward the north, and every man with his weapon of destruction in his hand; and one man among them was clothed in linen, with a writer’s inkwell by his side; and they went in and stood beside the bronze altar”</b> (Ezekiel 9:2).
The Gemara asks: <b>Was there a bronze altar</b> in the Temple in the time of Ezekiel? Already in the days of Solomon there was only a stone altar. Rather, this should be understood as a figure of speech. <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to them: Begin from the place where they recite songs</b> of praise <b>before Me</b>. This is a reference to the Levites in the Temple whose musical instruments are made of bronze. <b>And who are the six men</b> mentioned here? <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Fury, Wrath, and Rage, and Destroyer, and Breaker, and Annihilator,</b> six angels of destruction.
The Gemara asks further: <b>And what is different</b> about the letter <b><i>tav</i>,</b> that it was inscribed on the foreheads of the righteous? <b>Rav said: <i>Tav</i></b> is the first letter of the word <b><i>tiḥye</i>, you shall live,</b> indicating that the righteous shall live. <b><i>Tav</i></b> is also the first letter of the word <b><i>tamut</i>, you shall die,</b> indicating that the wicked shall die. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> The letter <i>tav</i> is the first letter of the word <i>tama</i>, ceased, indicating that the <b>merit of the Patriarchs has ceased</b> and will not help the wicked. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The letter <i>tav</i> is the first letter of the word <i>taḥon</i>, will have mercy, indicating <b>that</b> due to <b>the merit of the Patriarchs</b> God <b>will have mercy</b> on the righteous.
<b>And Reish Lakish said:</b> The letter <b><i>tav</i></b> is <b>the last</b> letter <b>of the seal of the Holy One, Blessed be He,</b> as <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: The seal of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is truth [<i>emet</i>],</b> which ends with the letter <i>tav</i>. <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said:</b> The letter <i>tav</i> teaches that <b>these are people who observed the entire Torah from <i>alef</i> through <i>tav.</i></b>
With regard to the statement that the merit of the Patriarchs has ceased, the Gemara asks: <b>From when did the merit of the Patriarchs cease? Rav said: From the days of</b> the prophet <b>Hosea, son of Beeri, as it is stated:</b> “And now <b>I will uncover her lewdness in the sight of her lovers, and none shall deliver her out of My hand”</b> (Hosea 2:12). Israel will no longer be saved by the merit of the Patriarchs.
<b>And Shmuel said</b>: The merit of the Patriarchs ceased <b>since the days of Hazael, as it is stated: “And Hazael, king of Aram, oppressed Israel all the days of Jehoahaz”</b> (II Kings 13:22). <b>And it is written</b> there: <b>“And the Lord was gracious to them, and had compassion on them, and turned toward them because of His covenant with Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob and would not destroy them; neither has He till now cast them away from His presence”</b> (II Kings 13:23). That was the last time that the merit of the Patriarchs was mentioned.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> The merit of the Patriarchs ceased <b>since the days of Elijah</b> the Prophet<b>, as it is stated: “And it came to pass at the time of the evening sacrifice, that Elijah the Prophet came near and said, Lord, God of Abraham, Isaac, and Israel, let it be known this day that you are God in Israel, and that I am Your servant, and that I have done all these things at Your word”</b> (I Kings 18:36). By inference: Let it be known this day and not afterward because the merit of the Patriarchs will cease today.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The merit of the Patriarchs ceased <b>since the days of Hezekiah, as it is stated: “For the increase of the realm and for peace without end, upon the throne of David, and upon his kingdom to order it, and to establish it with judgment and with justice; from now and forever the zeal of the Lord of hosts performs this”</b> (Isaiah 9:6). That is to say, from this point on, the merit of the Patriarchs will not protect Israel, leaving only the zeal of the Lord.
The Gemara continues its discussion of punishment in general and the relationship between a person’s actions and the punishments meted out against him in particular: <b>Rav Ami said: There is no death without sin;</b> were a person not to sin, he would not die. <b>And there is no suffering without iniquity.</b>
The Gemara adduces proof to these assertions: <b>There is no death without sin, as it is written: “The soul that sins, it shall die. The son shall not bear the iniquity of the father, neither shall the father bear the iniquity of the son; the righteousness of the righteous shall be upon him, and the wickedness of the wicked shall be upon him”</b> (Ezekiel 18:20). A person dies only because of his own sins and not because of some preexistent sin. And <b>there is no suffering without iniquity, as it is written: “Then I will punish their transgression with the rod and their iniquity with strokes”</b> (Psalms 89:33).

Daf 55b

The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>The ministering angels said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, why did You penalize Adam, the first man, with</b> the <b>death</b> penalty? <b>He said to them: I gave him a simple mitzva, and he violated it. They said to Him: Didn’t Moses and Aaron, who observed the whole Torah in its entirety,</b> nevertheless <b>die?</b> The Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>said to them,</b> citing the verse: “All things come alike to all; <b>there is one event to the righteous and to the wicked; to the good</b> and to the clean, and to the unclean; to him who sacrifices, and to him who does not sacrifice; as is the good, so is the sinner; and he who swears, as he who fears an oath” (Ecclesiastes 9:2). Apparently, death is not dependent upon one’s actions. Everyone dies.
The Gemara answers: Rav Ami <b>stated</b> his position <b>in accordance with this <i>tanna</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Even Moses and Aaron died due to their sin, as it is stated:</b> “And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron: <b>Because you did not believe in Me</b>, to sanctify Me in the eyes of the children of Israel, therefore you shall not bring this congregation in to the land which I have given them” (Numbers 20:12). <b>Had you believed in Me</b> and spoken to the rock as commanded, <b>your time would not</b> yet <b>have come to leave the world.</b> Apparently, even Moses and Aaron died due to their sins.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from what was taught in the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>Four</b> people <b>died due to</b> Adam’s sin with <b>the serpent,</b> in the wake of which death was decreed upon all of mankind, although they themselves were free of sin. <b>And they are: Benjamin, son of Jacob; Amram, father of Moses; Yishai, father of David; and Kilab, son of David. And all of them</b> were learned through <b>tradition, except for Yishai, father of David, with regard to whom there is an explicit verse</b> interpreted homiletically, <b>as it is written: “And Absalom placed Amasa in charge of the army in place of Joab, and Amasa was the son of a man named Ithra the Israelite, who had taken to himself Abigail the daughter of Nahash, sister of Zeruiah, the mother of Joab”</b> (II Samuel 17:25).
The Gemara asks: <b>And was</b> Abigail <b>the daughter of Nahash? Wasn’t she the daughter of Yishai, as it is written:</b> “And Yishai begot his firstborn Eliab, and Abinadab the second, and Shimea the third, Nethanel the fourth, Raddai the fifth, Ozem the sixth, David the seventh: <b>and their sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail.</b> And the sons of Zeruiah: Abishai, and Joab, and Asahel, three. And Abigail bore Amasa; and the father of Amasa was Jether the Ishmaelite” (I Chronicles 2:13–17)? Apparently, Abigail was the daughter of Yishai. <b>Rather,</b> the verse states that Abigail was the daughter of Nahash in order to teach us that she was <b>the daughter of one who died on account of</b> Adam’s sin with <b>the serpent [<i>naḥash</i>],</b> though he himself was free of sin.
The Gemara now clarifies the matter: <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> that states that four people did not die due to their own sins? <b>If you say</b> that it is the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who taught the conversation between <b>the ministering angels</b> and God, it is difficult, <b>as weren’t there</b> also <b>Moses and Aaron</b> who did not die due to their own sins? <b>Rather, it must be Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar,</b> who holds that even Moses and Aaron died because of their own sins. <b>Learn from it</b> then that, in principle, he agrees that <b>there is death without sin and there is suffering without iniquity, and</b> this is a <b>conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rav Ami.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, it is a <b>conclusive refutation.</b>
Having mentioned the sins of some of the significant ancestors of the Jewish people, the Gemara now addresses several additional ancestors. <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: Anyone who says that Reuben sinned</b> with Bilhah <b>is nothing other than mistaken, as it is stated:</b> “And it came to pass, when Israel dwelt in that land, that Reuben went and lay with Bilhah his father’s concubine; and Israel heard of it. <b>Now the sons of Jacob were twelve”</b> (Genesis 35:22). The fact that the Torah stated the number of Jacob’s sons at that point in the narrative <b>teaches that,</b> even after the incident involving Bilhah, <b>all</b> of the brothers <b>were equal</b> in righteousness. Apparently, Reuben did not sin. <b>How</b> then <b>do I establish</b> the meaning of the verse: <b>“And he lay with Bilhah his father’s concubine”?</b> The plain understanding of the verse indicates sin. <b>This</b> verse <b>teaches that</b> Reuben <b>rearranged his father’s bed</b> in protest of Jacob’s placement of his bed in the tent of Bilhah and not in the tent of his mother Leah after the death of Rachel. <b>And the verse ascribes to him</b> liability for his action <b>as if he had</b> actually <b>lain with</b> Bilhah.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: This righteous person,</b> Reuben, <b>was saved from that sin</b> of adultery, <b>and that action did not come to</b> be performed by <b>him? Is it possible</b> that <b>his descendants are destined to stand on Mount Eival and say: “Cursed be he that lies with his father’s wife;</b> because he uncovers his father’s skirt. And all the people shall say, amen” (Deuteronomy 27:20), <b>and this sin will come to</b> be performed by <b>him?</b> Is it conceivable that the members of a tribe would curse their ancestor? <b>How</b> then <b>do I establish</b> the meaning of the verse: <b>“And he lay with Bilhah his father’s concubine”?</b> It is understood as follows: <b>He protested the affront to his mother. He said: If my mother’s sister</b> Rachel <b>was a rival to my mother, will my mother’s sister’s concubine be a rival to my mother? He</b> immediately <b>stood and rearranged her bed</b> so that Jacob would enter Leah’s tent.
<b><i>Aḥerim</i> say: He rearranged two beds, one of the Divine Presence and one of his father. And that is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written:</b> “Unstable as water, you shall not excel; because you went up to your father’s bed; <b>then you did defile it; he went up to my bed [<i>yetzu</i>’<i>i</i>]”</b> (Genesis 49:4). <b>Do not read it as <i>yetzu’i</i>,</b> in the singular; <b>rather, read it as <i>yetzu</i>’<i>ai</i>, my beds,</b> in the plural, referring to both the bed of his father and to the bed of the Divine Presence, which rests in the tents of the righteous.
The Gemara notes that the matter of Reuben’s innocence is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> As it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“Unstable [<i>paḥaz</i>] as water, you shall not excel.”</b> The Sages understood <i>paḥaz</i> as an acronym. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that it means: <b>You were impulsive [<i>pazta</i>], you were liable [<i>ḥavta</i>], and you acted contemptuously [<i>zalta</i>]. Rabbi Yehoshua says</b> that it means: <b>You trampled the law [<i>pasata al dat</i>], you sinned [<i>ḥatata</i>],</b> and <b>you were promiscuous [<i>zanita</i>]. Rabban Gamliel says:</b> The acronym does not refer to Reuben’s sin. It refers to his repentance: <b>You prayed [<i>pilalta</i>], you trembled</b> in fear <b>[<i>ḥalta</i>],</b> and <b>your prayer shone forth [<i>zarḥa</i>].</b>
<b>Rabban Gamliel said: We still need</b> the explanation of <b>the Modaite,</b> as <b>Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i said: Reverse</b> the order of the letters in <b>the word</b> <i>paḥaz</i> <b>and</b> then <b>interpret it homiletically: You shook [<i>zizata</i>], you recoiled</b> [<b><i>hirtata</i>];</b> the <i>ḥet</i> in <i>paḥaz</i> is interchanged with the letter <i>heh</i>, so that you would not sin, and <b>the sin flew [<i>parḥa</i>] from you.</b> Rabban Gamliel and Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i are of the opinion that Reuben did not sin. Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua held that he did. <b>Rava said, and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said:</b> Reverse the letters in <i>paḥaz</i> and interpret: <b>You remembered [<i>zakharta</i>] the punishment</b> for that offense, <b>you made yourself gravely ill [<i>ḥalita</i>]</b> in order to refrain from sinning, and <b>you</b> successfully <b>withdrew [<i>peirashta</i>] from sinning.</b>
The Gemara prefaces the following statements of Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani with a <b>mnemonic: Reuben, the sons of Eli, the sons of Samuel, David, Solomon, and Josiah.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: Anyone who says that the sons of Eli sinned is nothing other than mistaken, as it is written: “And the two sons of Eli, Hophni and Pinehas, were there priests of the Lord”</b> (I Samuel 1:3).
The Gemara explains: Rabbi Yonatan <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, as Rav said: Pinehas did not sin.</b> And the verse <b>juxtaposes Hophni to Pinehas; just as Pinehas did not sin, so too Hophni did not sin.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>How,</b> then, <b>do I establish</b> the meaning of the verse: “Now Eli was very old, and heard all that his sons did to all Israel; and <b>how they lay with the women</b> that assembled at the door of the Tent of Meeting” (I Samuel 2:22), which indicates otherwise? The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the sons of Eli <b>delayed</b> sacrificing <b>the bird-offerings</b> of women who had given birth, a pair of doves brought as part of the purification process, and this delay caused the women <b>not to go to their husbands</b> in timely fashion, <b>the verse ascribes to</b> Hophni and Pinehas liability <b>as if they had lain with them.</b> They were guilty of nothing more than negligence and carelessness.
The Gemara now examines <b>the matter itself</b> of Rav’s statement cited in the course of the previous discussion. <b>Rav said: Pinehas did not sin, as it is stated: “And Ahijah, the son of Ahitub, Ichabod’s brother, the son of Pinehas, the son of Eli, was the Lord’s priest</b> in Shiloh, wearing an ephod” (I Samuel 14:3). <b>Is it possible that sin came to</b> Pinehas’ <b>hand and,</b> nevertheless, <b>the verse traces the lineage</b> of his grandson, Ahijah, back <b>to him?</b>
<b>Wasn’t it was already stated</b> with regard to those who engage in promiscuous relations: <b>“The Lord will cut off from the man that does this, him that is awake and him that answers from the tents of Jacob, or any to present an offering to the Lord of hosts”</b> (Malachi 2:12). The Sages interpreted the verse homiletically: <b>If</b> the sinner is <b>an Israelite, he will not have</b> among his descendants <b>one who is</b> sharp and <b>awake among the Sages, or</b> even <b>one among</b> their <b>disciples who can answer</b> questions. <b>And if he is a priest, he will not have a son who will present a meal-offering.</b> If Pinehas had sons and grandsons serving as priests, <b>conclude from it that Pinehas did not sin.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>However, isn’t it written: “And how they lay [<i>yishkevun</i>]</b> with the women.” The verb <i>yishkevun</i> is in the plural, indicating that both sons were guilty. The Gemara answers: It <b>is written</b> without a <i>vav</i> so that it can be read as <b><i>yishkeven</i></b> in the singular, i.e., how he lay, indicating that only one of them sinned.
The Gemara asks further: <b>Isn’t it written</b> that Eli said: <b>“No, my sons [<i>banai</i>]; for it is not a good report</b> that I hear; you make the Lord’s people to transgress” (I Samuel 2:24). The fact that Eli referred to his sons in the plural indicates that they both sinned. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: It is written</b> in a manner that can be read as <b>my son [<i>beni</i>]</b> in the singular.
The Gemara raises another question: <b>Isn’t it written: “You make</b> the Lord’s people <b>to transgress [<i>ma’avirim</i>]</b> in the plural, indicating that both sons were guilty. <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> Here too, the word <b>is written</b> without a <i>yod</i> so that it can be read as: <b>You cause</b> the Lord’s people <b>to transgress [<i>ma’aviram</i>]</b> in the singular, indicating that only one of them sinned.
The Gemara raises one last challenge: <b>Isn’t it written:</b> “Now the sons of Eli were <b>scoundrels;</b> they knew not the Lord” (I Samuel 2:12), indicating that they were both sinners. The Gemara answers: <b>Since Pinehas should have protested Hophni’s</b> conduct, <b>but he did not protest, the verse ascribes to him</b> liability <b>as if he</b> too <b>had sinned.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: Anyone who says</b>

Daf 56a

<b>that the sons of Samuel sinned is nothing other than mistaken, as it is stated: “And it came to pass, when Samuel was old</b> that he made his sons judges over Israel…<b>And his sons walked not in his ways</b> but sought after unjust gain, and took bribes, and perverted justice” (I Samuel 8:1–3). By inference: <b>In his ways they did not walk,</b> however, <b>they did not sin either.</b> They were not the equals of their father, but they were not sinners.
<b>However, how</b> then <b>do I establish</b> the meaning of the verse: <b>“And they sought after unjust gain,”</b> indicating that they were sinners? It means <b>that they did not conduct</b> themselves <b>in accordance with the actions of their father. As Samuel the righteous would travel to all places</b> where the people of <b>Israel</b> were located <b>and</b> sit in <b>judgment in their towns, as it is stated: “And he went from year to year in circuit from Beth-El, and Gilgal, and Mitzpa, and judged Israel</b> in all those places” (I Samuel 7:16). <b>And,</b> however, <b>they did not do so</b> and travel from place to place. <b>Rather, they sat in their</b> own <b>cities in order to enhance the fees</b> collected <b>by their attendants and scribes.</b> Therefore, the verse ascribes to them liability as if they sinned by seeking ill-gotten gains and bribes.
The Gemara notes that this matter is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> As it was taught in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse states: <b>“And they sought after unjust gain.” Rabbi Meir says:</b> This means that <b>they vocally demanded their portions</b> of the tithe due them as Levites, abusing their position to the detriment of other Levites. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: They imposed</b> upon local <b>homeowners</b> to sell their <b>merchandise</b> and support them. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: They took an extra basket of tithes,</b> beyond that which was their due, <b>by force. Rabbi Yosei says: They took</b> only <b>the gifts</b> due them; however, they took them <b>by force.</b> They acted improperly, as a Levite is required to wait until he is given his gifts and may not take them.
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: Anyone who says that David sinned</b> with Bathsheba <b>is nothing other than mistaken, as it is stated: “And David succeeded in all his ways; and the Lord was with him”</b> (I Samuel 18:14). <b>Is it possible that sin came to his hand and</b> nevertheless <b>the Divine Presence was with him?</b>
<b>However, how</b> then <b>do I establish</b> the meaning of the rebuke of the prophet Nathan: <b>“Why have you despised the word of the Lord, to do that which is evil</b> in My sight? Uriah the Hittite you have smitten with the sword, and his wife you have taken to be your wife, and him you have slain with the sword of the children of Ammon” (II Samuel 12:9), indicating that David sinned? The Gemara answers: David <b>sought to do</b> evil and have relations with Bathsheba while she was still married to Uriah <b>but did not do</b> so.
<b>Rav said: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who descends from</b> the house of <b>David, seeks to teach</b> the verse <b>in favor of David.</b> With regard to that which is written: <b>“Why have you despised the commandment of the Lord to do evil,” Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: This evil</b> mentioned with regard to David <b>is different from all</b> other <b>evils in the Torah; as with regard to all</b> other <b>evils in the Torah, it is written: And he did</b> evil, <b>and here it is written: To do evil.</b> This unique phrase indicates that David <b>sought to do</b> evil <b>but did not</b> actually <b>do</b> so. His intentions were improper; however, his actions were proper.
That which is written: <b>“Uriah the Hittite you have smitten with the sword,”</b> means <b>that you could have judged him before the Sanhedrin</b> as one guilty of treason against the throne, <b>and you did not judge</b> him in that manner. Instead, you had him executed in a manner that deviated from the generally accepted principles of judgment.
