With regard to that which is written: <b>“And his wife you have taken to be your wife”;</b> it means that <b>you have</b> rights of <b>marriage with her,</b> as by law Bathsheba was already divorced from Uriah.
<b>As Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: Anyone who goes to a war</b> waged by the royal <b>house of David writes a</b> conditional <b>bill of divorce to his wife.</b> That was done to prevent a situation in which the soldier’s wife would be unable to remarry because the soldier did not return from battle and there were no witnesses to his fate. The conditional bill of divorce accorded her the status of a divorcee and freed her to remarry. <b>As it is stated: “And carry these ten cheeses to the captain of their thousand, and to your brothers bring greetings and take their pledge [<i>arubatam</i>]</b>” (I Samuel 17:18).
<b>What is</b> the meaning of <b><i>arubatam</i>? Rav Yosef taught:</b> It refers to <b>matters that are shared [<i>hame’oravim</i>] between him,</b> the husband, <b>and her,</b> the wife, i.e., marriage. The verse should be read: Take the bill of divorce that determines the status of the relationship between husband and wife. As, apparently, it was customary for men at war to send their wives a conditional divorce, since Uriah later died, Bathsheba retroactively assumed divorced status from the time that he set out to war. She was not forbidden to David.
With regard to that which is written: <b>“And him you have slain with the sword of the children of Ammon,”</b> it means: <b>Just as you are not punished for</b> soldiers killed by <b>the sword of the children of Ammon</b> in the course of the war, <b>so too you are not punished for</b> the death of <b>Uriah the Hittite.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> that David was not liable for the death of Uriah? Because Uriah <b>was a traitor against the throne. As he said to</b> David: <b>“And my lord Joab and the servants of my lord are encamped in the open fields”</b> (II Samuel 11:11). In the presence of the king, one may not refer to another as his lord. Doing so is treason.
<b>Rav said: When you analyze</b> the matter of <b>David, no</b> sin that he committed <b>is found in his</b> lifetime, <b>except for that</b> involving <b>Uriah. As it is written</b>: “Because David did that which was right in the eyes of the Lord, and turned not aside from any thing that He commanded him all the days of his life, <b>save only in the matter of Uriah the Hittite”</b> (I Kings 15:5).
<b>Abaye the Elder raised a contradiction between</b> one statement <b>of Rav and</b> another statement <b>of Rav: Did Rav</b> actually <b>say this? Didn’t Rav say: David accepted a</b> slanderous <b>report?</b> Just as it is prohibited to relate a slanderous report, it is similarly prohibited to accept it. This contradiction remains unresolved, and it is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara now examines <b>the matter itself</b> with regard to Rav’s statement cited in the course of the previous discussion. <b>Rav said: David accepted a slanderous report, as it is written</b> with regard to David’s search for a surviving son of Jonathan: <b>“And the king said to him,</b> to Ziba, Saul’s slave: <b>Where is he? And Ziba said to the king: Behold, he is in the house of Machir, the son of Ammiel, in Lo-Devar [<i>belo devar</i>]”</b> (II Samuel 9:4). Ziba indicated to David that Jonathan’s son was inconsequential, lacking any matter [<i>lo devar</i>] of Torah. <b>And it is written: “Then King</b> David <b>sent, and fetched him out of the house of Machir, the son of Ammiel, from Lo-Devar [<i>milo devar</i>]”</b> (II Samuel 9:5). That verse can be read that after sending for him, David found him filled with matters [<i>melo devar</i>] of Torah.
<b>Now, after</b> David <b>saw that</b> Ziba <b>was a liar, when</b> Ziba <b>once again slandered</b> Jonathan’s son, Mephibosheth, <b>why did David accept</b> his report? <b>As it is written</b> that when David fled from Absalom, he met Ziba: <b>“And the king said: And where is your master’s son? And Ziba said to the king: Behold, he is staying in Jerusalem,</b> as he said: Today shall the house of Israel restore to me the kingdom of my father” (II Samuel 16:3). <b>And from where do we</b> derive <b>that David accepted</b> Ziba’s slanderous report? <b>As it is written: “Then said the king</b> to Ziba: <b>Behold, all that belongs to Mephibosheth is yours. And Ziba said: I humbly beseech you that I may find favor in your sight,</b> my lord, <b>O king</b>” (II Samuel 16:4).
<b>And Shmuel said: David did not accept</b> Ziba’s <b>slanderous report</b> without substantiation. Rather, <b>he</b> himself <b>saw conspicuous matters in</b> Mephibosheth that indicated that Ziba was right. <b>As it is written: “And Mephibosheth, the son of Saul, came down to meet the king, and he had neither dressed his feet, nor trimmed his beard, nor washed his clothes</b> from the day the king departed until the day he came back in peace” (II Samuel 19:25). David thought that he was mourning the fact that he had returned in peace. <b>And it is written: “And it came to pass, when he came to Jerusalem to meet the king, and the king said to him: Why did you not go with me, Mephibosheth? And he answered: My lord, O king, my servant deceived me; for your servant said: I will saddle me a donkey, and I will ride on it, and go to the king; because lame is</b>

Daf 56b

<b>your servant. And he slandered your servant to my lord the king; but my lord the king is like an angel of God: Do therefore what is good in your eyes”</b> (II Samuel 19:26–28). <b>“And the king said to him: Why do you speak any more of your matters? I have said: You and Ziba shall divide the estate. And Mephibosheth said to the king: Let him even take all, seeing that my lord the king is come back in peace to his own house”</b> (II Samuel 19:30–31). Mephibosheth <b>said to</b> David as follows: <b>I</b> had hoped for your return, <b>saying: When will he come in peace, and</b> yet <b>you do this to me,</b> giving Ziba half of my estate? <b>It is not against you that I have grievances, but against He who brought you back in peace.</b> Mephibosheth’s own statement substantiates Ziba’s report about him.
<b>This is what is written: “And the son of Jonathan was Meriv-Baal”</b> (I Chronicles 8:34). The Gemara asks: <b>And was Meriv-Baal his name? Wasn’t his name Mephibosheth? However, since he entered into a quarrel [<i>meriva</i>] with his Master [<i>ba’al</i>],</b> i.e., God, and complained about God having saved David, <b>a Divine Voice emerged and said to him: Quarrelsome</b> one, <b>the son of a quarrelsome</b> one; you are just like your father, Saul. The Gemara explains: <b>Quarrelsome</b> one; <b>that which we</b> just <b>said</b> that Mephibosheth complained to God about His salvation of David. <b>The son of a quarrelsome</b> one; <b>as it is written: “And Saul came to a city of Amalek and quarreled in the valley”</b> (I Samuel 15:5). And <b>Rabbi Mani said:</b> Saul quarreled with God <b>with regard to matters of the valley,</b> saying: For the murder of even a single person, there is a commandment to break the neck of a heifer in a valley to atone for the crime (see Deuteronomy 21:1–9); why then must all these Amalekites be killed?
To the matter at hand: <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: When David said to Mephibosheth: You and Ziba shall divide the estate, a Divine Voice emerged and said to him: Rehoboam and Jeroboam shall divide the kingdom.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav</b> said: <b>Had David not accepted</b> Ziba’s <b>slanderous report</b> about Mephibosheth, <b>the kingdom of the house of David would not have been divided, Israel would not have worshipped idols</b> because of Jeroboam, <b>and we would not have been exiled from our land.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: Anyone who says that</b> King <b>Solomon sinned is nothing other than mistaken, as it is stated: “And his heart was not perfect with the Lord his God, as was the heart of David, his father”</b> (I Kings 11:4). By inference: Solomon’s heart <b>was not equal to the heart of David, his father;</b> however, <b>he also did not sin.</b>
<b>However, how</b> then <b>do I establish</b> the meaning of the verse: <b>“For it came to pass, when Solomon was old, that his wives turned away his heart after other gods”</b> (I Kings 11:4)? <b>That</b> verse is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Natan; as Rabbi Natan raised a contradiction</b> between the two parts of the verse. On the one hand, <b>it is written: “For it came to pass, when Solomon was old, that his wives turned away his heart</b> after other gods.” On the other hand, <b>isn’t it written:</b> “And his heart was not perfect with the Lord his God, <b>as was the heart of David his father,”</b> indicating that Solomon’s heart <b>was not equal to the heart of David his father;</b> however, <b>he also did not sin?</b> Rather, the verse <b>says as follows: For it came to pass, when Solomon was old, that his wives turned away his heart,</b> in an attempt to spur him to go <b>after other gods; however, he did not go</b> after them.
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t it written: “Then did Solomon build [<i>yivne</i>] an altar for Kemosh, the abomination of Moab,</b> in the hill that is before Jerusalem, and for Molech, the abomination of the children of Ammon” (I Kings 11:7), indicating that Solomon did in fact stray after idols? The Gemara answers: This can be understood to mean <b>that</b> Solomon <b>sought to build</b> an altar for idols <b>but did not build</b> it.
The Gemara objects: <b>But now</b> if that is the way to understand the future tense verb form <i>yivne</i>, what of another instance where the same form is employed: <b>“Then did Joshua build [<i>yivne</i>] an altar to the Lord God</b> of Israel in Mount Eival” (Joshua 8:30)? There too, would you say that Joshua <b>sought to build</b> an altar <b>but did not build</b> one? <b>Rather,</b> there, in the case of Joshua, it means that <b>he</b> actually <b>built it. Here too,</b> with regard to Solomon, it means that <b>he</b> actually <b>built</b> the altar.
<b>Rather,</b> this verse should be understood <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The verse states: <b>“And the altars that were before Jerusalem, which were on the right hand of the Mount of Olives, which Solomon the king of Israel had built for Ashtoret the abomination of the Zidonim,</b> and for Kemosh the abomination of Moab, and for Milkom the abomination of the children of Ammon, did the king defile” (II Kings 23:13). All these were destroyed by Josiah.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is it possible that</b> the righteous king <b>Asa came and did not destroy them,</b> and the righteous king <b>Jehosaphat</b> came <b>and did not destroy them until Josiah came and destroyed them? Didn’t Asa and Jehosaphat destroy all the idolatry in Eretz Yisrael? Rather,</b> the <b>verse juxtaposes the earlier ones,</b> i.e., Solomon, <b>to the later ones,</b> i.e., Josiah. <b>Just as the later ones,</b> Josiah, <b>did not effect</b> the destruction of the altars, as it was done by his predecessors, <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>the verse attributes</b> it <b>to him to praise</b> him as if he had destroyed all those altars, <b>so too, the earlier ones,</b> Solomon, <b>did not effect</b> the construction, <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>the verse attributes</b> it <b>to him to disgrace</b> him as he did not prevent their construction.
The Gemara raises another question. <b>Isn’t it written: “And Solomon did evil in the sight of the Lord”</b> (I Kings 11:6), clearly indicating that Solomon sinned? <b>Rather, since he should have protested against</b> the conduct of <b>his wives,</b> i.e., their involvement in idolatry, <b>but he did not protest, the verse ascribes to him</b> liability <b>as if he had sinned.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: It would have been preferable for that righteous man,</b> Solomon, <b>to be a servant</b> tasked with drawing water and hewing wood <b>for another matter,</b> i.e., idolatry, <b>and not</b> have the verse <b>write about him: “And he did evil in the sight of the Lord,”</b> even though he did not.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: When Solomon married Pharaoh’s daughter, she brought to him a thousand musical instruments and said to him: This is the way we do</b> it <b>for this idolatry, and this is the way we do</b> it <b>for that idolatry, and he did not protest</b> that talk.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: When Solomon married Pharaoh’s daughter,</b> the angel <b>Gabriel descended</b> from heaven <b>and implanted a reed into the sea, and a sandbar grew around it,</b> growing larger each year, <b>and upon it the great city of Rome was built,</b> which became God’s instrument to punish Israel.
<b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: On that very day that Jeroboam introduced two golden calves, one in Beth-El and the other in Dan, a single</b> small <b>hut was constructed,</b> which was the first house constructed there. <b>And that was</b> the inauguration of <b>Italy of Greece.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: Anyone who says that Josiah sinned is nothing other than mistaken, as it is stated: “And he did that which was right in the sight of the Lord, and walked in all the way of David his father,</b> and turned not aside to the right hand nor to the left” (II Kings 22:2). <b>However, how</b> then <b>do I establish</b> the meaning of the verse: <b>“And like him was there no king before him that returned</b> to the Lord with all his heart, and with all his soul, and with all his might, according to all the Torah of Moses; neither after him arose there any like him” (II Kings 23:25)? The verse states: Josiah returned to the Lord. Apparently, in his early days he was a sinner, and later he returned to God.
The Gemara answers: The reference here is not to repentance for actual sins that Josiah committed. Rather, in <b>every judgment that he issued from the age of eight,</b> when he was crowned, <b>until</b> the age of <b>eighteen,</b> he <b>returned</b> the money to the parties whom he judged liable, due to concern that in his youth he may not have judged the cases correctly. <b>And lest you say</b> that <b>he took from this</b> one, whom he exonerated, <b>and gave to that</b> one, whom he found culpable, therefore <b>the verse states:</b> Returned to the Lord <b>with all his might [<i>me’odo</i>],</b> i.e., with all his money. It means <b>that he gave</b> those he judged liable in his youth <b>from his own</b> money.
The Gemara notes that Rabbi Yonatan <b>disagrees with Rav, as Rav said: There is no greater penitent than Josiah in his generation, and</b> there is <b>one in our generation.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And who</b> is the great penitent in Rav’s generation? The Gemara answers: He is <b>Abba, father of Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba, and some say</b> it is <b>Aḥa, brother of Abba, father of Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba, as the Master said: Rabbi Abba and Aḥa were brothers.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: And there is another</b> great penitent <b>in our generation. And who is he?</b> He is <b>Okvan, son of Neḥemya the Exilarch. And that is</b> the one also known as <b>Natan <i>detzutzita</i>,</b> i.e., from whose head sparks emerged. <b>Rav Yosef said: I was</b> once <b>sitting at the lecture delivered on the Festival [<i>pirka</i>] and I was dozing. And I saw in a dream how</b> an angel <b>stretched out his hands and received</b> Natan <i>detzutzita</i>, demonstrating that his repentance was accepted.

Daf 57a

The mishna lists items that a woman may or may not carry into, or wear in the public domain on Shabbat. This depends on whether the particular object is considered an ornament, which she may wear, or merely a burden for the woman, which she may not. Even if it is considered an ornament, there is still concern that she might remove it and carry it in her hand in the public domain, which is prohibited by Torah law.<br><br><strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>With what</b> items may <b>a woman go out</b> into the public domain on Shabbat <b>and with what</b> items may <b>she not go out?</b>
<b>A woman may neither go out with strings of wool, nor with strings of flax, nor with strips</b> of any other materials that a woman braids <b>in</b> the hair of <b>her head. And</b> a woman <b>may not immerse</b> in a ritual bath <b>with them</b> in her hair <b>until she loosens them.</b> When the strings or strips are tight, the water cannot reach her hair unobstructed, invalidating her immersion.
<b>And,</b> likewise, a woman may <b>neither</b> go out <b>with</b> the ornament called <b><i>totefet</i>, nor with <i>sarvitin</i> that are not sewn</b> into her head covering, <b>nor with a <i>kavul</i> into the public domain.</b>
<b>And,</b> likewise, a woman may <b>neither</b> go out <b>with a city of gold</b> ornament, <b>nor with a <i>katla</i></b> ornament, <b>nor with nose rings, nor with a ring that has no seal on it, nor with a needle that is not perforated,</b> which are merely for decorative purposes.
<b>And if she</b> unwittingly <b>went out</b> wearing any of these, <b>she is not liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> According to Torah law, a woman is permitted to go out into the public domain wearing ornaments. However, the Sages decreed that a woman may not go out wearing certain ornaments, lest she remove them to show them to another and inadvertently carry them four cubits in the public domain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Immersion, who mentioned</b> anything about <b>that?</b> The mishna is dealing with the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, so why did it mention the <i>halakhot</i> of immersion?
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh</b> said: When the mishna <b>states</b> the <i>halakha</i>, it employs the style known as: <b>What is the reason.</b> The mention of immersion is an explanation, not a superfluous addition. The mishna should be understood as follows: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>a woman may neither go out with strings of wool nor with strings of flax?</b> It is <b>because the Sages said</b> that <b>on weekdays she may not immerse with them until she loosens them. And since on weekdays she may not immerse with them until she loosens them, on Shabbat she may not go out</b> with them, <b>lest</b> a situation requiring <b>immersion</b> for the purpose of a <b>mitzva come about, and she untie them, and come to carry them four cubits in the public domain.</b>
<b>Rav Kahana raised a dilemma before Rav:</b> With regard to strings made into <b>hollow chains, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is it permissible for women to go out into the public domain with them on Shabbat or not? It depends on whether they are considered an interposition to immersion. Rav <b>said to him: Woven, you say?</b> With regard to <b>anything woven, the Sages did not issue a decree.</b> Because water reaches the hair unobstructed, there is no need to loosen the hollow chain and there is no concern lest she carry it in the public domain. <b>It was also stated</b> that <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> With regard to <b>anything woven, the Sages did not issue a decree.</b>
<b>And some say</b> that <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said: I saw that my sisters are not particular about</b> removing <b>them,</b> and they bathe even with woven chains tied in their hair. Apparently, water reaches the hair. Therefore, the chain is not an interposition with regard to immersion.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> practical difference <b>is there between this version and that version</b> of the resolution of the dilemma?
The Gemara explains: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in a case <b>where</b> the chains <b>are dirty. According to this version,</b> in <b>which you said:</b> With regard to <b>anything woven, the Sages did not issue a decree, these too are woven. And according to that version,</b> in <b>which you said</b> that it is <b>due to</b> the fact that his sisters were not <b>particular;</b> in this case, <b>since they are dirty, she is particular about them</b> and will certainly remove them when she washes. Therefore, she is required to do so when immersing in a ritual bath as well.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna in tractate <i>Mikvaot</i>: <b>And these</b> are the objects that <b>interpose for a person: Strings of wool, and strings of flax, and the straps that are on the girls’ heads. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Strings <b>of wool and</b> strands <b>of hair do not interpose because the water reaches</b> the hair <b>through them. Rav Huna said: And we learned all these,</b> strings of wool and flax, in a case where they are used to tie the hair <b>on the girls’ heads.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef strongly objects to</b> this <i>halakha</i> of Rav Huna: <b>To exclude what</b> other places in the body did Rav Huna say this? <b>If you say</b> that it comes <b>to exclude</b> strings tied <b>to the neck, and</b> then, strings made <b>of what</b> material does it exclude? <b>If you say</b> that it comes <b>to exclude</b> strings <b>of wool, now,</b> the mishna stated that <b>soft</b> strings of wool <b>on top of</b> hair, which is relatively <b>hard, interpose</b> and invalidates the immersion. With regard to <b>soft</b> strings <b>on top of</b> the <b>soft</b> flesh of the neck, <b>is it necessary</b> to say that they interpose?
<b>Rather,</b> say that Rav Huna’s statement came <b>to exclude strings of flax.</b> A similar difficulty arises: <b>Now</b> the mishna stated that <b>hard</b> strings of wool <b>on top of</b> hair, which is <b>hard, interposes</b> and invalidates the immersion. If so, with regard to <b>hard</b> strings <b>on top of</b> the <b>soft</b> flesh of the neck, <b>is it necessary</b> to say that they interpose?
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef said, this is the reason that Rav Huna</b> restricts the concern for interposition to strings tied in her hair and not around her neck: <b>Because a woman does not strangle herself</b> when adorning herself with a string or straps around her neck. Therefore, she never tightens the strings or straps to the extent that water cannot reach the skin.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> the explanation of Rav Yosef from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The girls</b> may <b>go out</b> into the public domain on Shabbat <b>with strings in their ears.</b> Young girls would have their ears pierced, but earrings were not placed in their ears until they were older. Instead, they inserted strings so that the holes would not close. <b>However,</b> they may <b>not</b> go out <b>with straps</b> around <b>their necks. And if you say</b> that the principle: <b>A woman does not strangle herself,</b> is halakhically valid, <b>why</b> may they <b>not</b> go out into the public domain with <b>straps around their necks?</b> They are not tied tight and do not constitute an interposition that invalidates immersion.
Ravina said:

Daf 57b

<b>Here we are dealing with a broad, ornamented strap [<i>katla</i>]</b> hanging around the neck, to which a small bib is attached. <b>A woman does strangle herself</b> with a <i>katla</i> because the strap is broad and tightening it does not cause pain. She tightens it <b>because it pleases her that she will appear fleshy.</b> It was considered beautiful to have flesh protrude from the <i>katla</i>.
In the same mishna in tractate <i>Mikvaot</i>, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Strings <b>of wool and</b> strands <b>of hair do not interpose</b> and invalidate the immersion <b>because the water reaches through them.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda with regard to strands of hair.</b> However, the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with his opinion with regard to wool strings.
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> By saying that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is in accordance with Rav Yehuda, <b>by inference</b> the Rabbis <b>disagree</b> with regard to strands of hair. However, no opinion stating that strands of hair constitute an interposition is cited in the mishna.
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>had we not heard from the first <i>tanna</i> that he is speaking of strands of hair,</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>would also not have spoken</b> about them. Apparently, the first <i>tanna</i> prohibited strands of hair, and Rabbi Yehuda disagreed with him. Nevertheless, it could be explained otherwise. <b>And, perhaps he</b> prefaced what he <b>was saying</b> to the Rabbis with the phrase: <b>Just as. Just as you agree with me</b> that <b>strands of hair</b> do not interpose, <b>agree with me</b> that <b>strings of wool also</b> do not interpose. The fact that he mentioned strands of hair does not indicate a dispute; on the contrary, it is an attempt to establish a consensus with regard to the <i>halakha</i>.
Indeed, <b>it was stated</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The Rabbis agree with Rabbi Yehuda with regard to strands of hair.</b>
<b>This</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Strings of wool interpose. Strands of hair do not interpose. Rabbi Yehuda says: Both</b> strings <b>of wool and</b> strands <b>of hair do not interpose.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The language of <b>the mishna is also precise,</b> as we learned in a mishna in our chapter: <b>A woman may go out with strands of hair whether</b> they are <b>from her</b> own hair or <b>whether</b> they are <b>from</b> the hair of <b>another. Whose</b> opinion <b>is</b> expressed in this mishna? <b>If you say</b> that it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, even strings of wool</b> should <b>also</b> have been permitted. <b>Rather, is it not the</b> opinion of <b>the Rabbis; and conclude from it</b> that <b>with regard to strands of hair, they do not disagree?</b> The Gemara determines: Indeed, <b>conclude from it.</b>
The mishna said that a woman may <b>not</b> go out <b>with</b> the ornament called a <b><i>totefet</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is a <i>totefet</i>? Rav Yosef said: A packet of spices</b> to ward off the evil eye.
<b>Abaye said to him: And let</b> the legal status of <b>this</b> packet <b>be like</b> that of <b>an effective amulet,</b> whose effectiveness is proven, <b>and</b> it should <b>be permitted,</b> as an effective amulet may be moved on Shabbat.
<b>Rather, Rav Yehuda said in the name of Abaye:</b> A <i>totefet</i> is an <b><i>appuzainu</i>,</b> an ornament worn on the forehead. This opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A woman may go out with a gilded hairnet</b> worn to hold the hair in place, <b>and with the <i>totefet,</i> and with the <i>sarvitin</i> that are fastened to the hairnet,</b> since a woman would not remove her head covering to show her friend those ornaments.
And they said: <b>Which is a <i>totefet</i> and which is <i>sarvitin</i>? Rabbi Abbahu said: <i>Totefet</i> is that which goes around her</b> forehead <b>from ear to ear. <i>Sarvitin</i> are those</b> attached to the net <b>that reach</b> down <b>to her cheeks.</b>
<b>Rav Huna said: Poor women make</b> these ornaments <b>from</b> different <b>types of colored</b> materials. <b>Wealthy women make them of silver and of gold.</b>
We learned in the mishna that a woman may <b>not</b> go out with <b>a <i>kavul</i>. Rabbi Yannai said: This <i>kavul</i>, I do not know what it is. Is it the seal of a slave,</b> who would have a seal on his clothing identifying him as a slave, about <b>which we learned</b> in our mishna that it is prohibited, <b>but a cap of wool</b> that a woman places on her hair, she may <b>well</b> go out wearing it? <b>Or, perhaps we learned</b> in our mishna that going out with <b>a cap of wool</b> is prohibited <b>and all the more so</b> that going out with <b>the seal of a slave</b> is prohibited.
<b>Rabbi Abbahu said: It is reasonable</b> to say <b>in accordance with the one who said</b> that <b>we learned</b> about <b>a cap of wool</b> in the mishna. <b>And this</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A woman may go out with a <i>kavul</i> and with an <i>istema</i> to the courtyard</b> on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> She may <b>even</b> go out <b>with the <i>kavul</i> into the public domain. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar stated a principle: Anything that is</b> worn <b>beneath the hairnet,</b> a woman <b>may go out</b> into the public domain <b>with it,</b> since a woman will not uncover her hair even to show off an ornament while in the public domain. <b>Anything that is</b> worn <b>over the hairnet,</b> like an ornamental hat, a woman <b>may not go out with it.</b> From the context and proximity of the <i>halakha</i> dealing with <i>kavul</i> to the statement of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, apparently a <i>kavul</i> is a wool cap worn under the net.
Since <i>istema</i> was mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>, the Gemara asks: <b>What is an <i>istema</i>? Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> <i>Istema</i> is a <b><i>beizyunei</i>.</b> However, Rabbi Abbahu’s explanation employed a term from the Aramaic dialect spoken in Eretz Yisrael, which was not understood in Babylonia. Therefore, they asked there: <b>What is</b> a <b><i>beizyunei</i></b>? <b>Abaye said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It is a small hat or ribbon used to <b>gather hairs that protrude [<i>kalya paruḥei</i>]</b> from the headdress.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>three things were said with regard to an <i>istema</i>: There is no</b> prohibition of a mixture of <b>diverse kinds,</b> wool and linen, <b>in it.</b> Since it is made of hard felt and not woven together, the prohibition of diverse kinds does not apply to material of that kind. <b>And it does not become impure with</b> the ritual impurity of <b>leprosy.</b> Only woven garments can become impure with leprosy. <b>And</b> women <b>may not go out with it to the public domain</b> on Shabbat.
<b>In the name of Rabbi Shimon they said: Also,</b>

Daf 58a

the rabbinic decree prohibiting adorning brides with <b>bridal crowns</b> to commemorate the destruction of the Temple does <b>not</b> apply <b>to</b> an <i>istema</i>.
Earlier, the Gemara cited Rabbi Abbahu’s opinion that the <i>kavul</i> mentioned in the mishna, which one may not wear into the public domain on Shabbat, is a woolen cap. <b>And Shmuel said: It is the seal of a slave</b> that <b>we learned</b> about in the mishna. The Gemara asks: <b>And did Shmuel</b> actually <b>say this? Didn’t Shmuel say: A slave may go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with a seal that is around his neck but not with a seal that is on his clothes?</b> Apparently, Shmuel holds that one may go out into the public domain with a slave’s seal. How, then, could he say that <i>kavul</i> in the mishna, with which one may not go out into the public domain, is referring to the seal of a slave?
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This,</b> where Shmuel said that one may go out with a slave’s seal on Shabbat, <b>is</b> referring to a case <b>where his master made it for him.</b> The slave will not remove it because he fears his master. Therefore, there is no concern lest he carry it. However, <b>that,</b> where the mishna said that it is prohibited to go out with a <i>kavul</i>, which according to Shmuel is the seal of a slave, is referring to a case <b>where he made it for himself</b> to indicate to all who his master is so that he may enjoy his master’s protection. In that case, since it is dependent solely upon his discretion, there is concern lest he remove the seal and carry it. Therefore, the Sages prohibited going out with it into the public domain.
The Gemara asks: <b>In what</b> case <b>did you establish this</b> statement <b>of Shmuel?</b> It is in the case of a seal <b>that his master made for him.</b> If so, <b>why</b> may he <b>not</b> go out <b>with a seal on his clothes?</b> There too, since his master made it for him he will not remove it.
The Gemara answers: There the concern is that <b>perhaps</b> the seal <b>will be severed, and</b> the slave <b>will fear</b> his master <b>and fold</b> his cloak <b>and place it on his shoulders</b> so that his master will not see that he has no seal on his clothing. That concern is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef; as Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who goes out</b> into the public domain <b>with a cloak folded and resting on his shoulders on Shabbat is liable to bring a sin-offering.</b> That is not the manner in which one wears a garment; it is the manner in which one carries a burden.
<b>And</b> this is <b>like that which Shmuel said to Rav Ḥinnana bar Sheila: All of the Sages</b> affiliated with <b>the house of the Exilarch may not go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with sealed cloaks [<i>sarbal</i>],</b> i.e., garments with seals on them, <b>except for you, since</b> the people <b>of the Exilarch’s house are not particular with</b> regard to <b>you.</b> The Sages affiliated with the Exilarch were officially considered servants of the house and would wear the seal of the house of the Exilarch. Therefore, it was prohibited for them to go out into the public domain on Shabbat with a cloak bearing the Exilarch’s seal, lest the seal break and, in fear of the Exilarch, they remove the cloak, fold it, place it on their shoulders, and carry it on Shabbat. Only Rav Ḥinnana bar Sheila was permitted to go out with this seal on Shabbat since the people of the Exilarch’s house were not exacting with him. Even if he wore clothing with no seal, they would not consider it an act of insubordination against the Exilarch.
The Gemara discusses <b>the matter itself: Shmuel said</b> that <b>a slave may go out with a seal that is around his neck but not with a seal that is on his clothes.</b> That opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A slave may go out with a seal that is around his neck but not with a seal that is on his clothes.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from another <i>baraita</i>: <b>The slave may neither go out with a seal that is around his neck nor with a seal that is on his clothes</b> on Shabbat, and both <b>this and that cannot become ritually impure. And</b> he may <b>not</b> go out <b>with a bell that is</b> hung <b>around his neck; however, he may go out with a bell that is on his clothes,</b> and both <b>this and that can become ritually impure.</b>
<b>And an animal may neither go out with a seal that is around its neck, nor with a seal that is on its clothes, nor with a bell that is on its clothes, nor with a bell that is around its neck</b> since with regard to an animal these are considered burdens not ornaments. Both <b>this,</b> the seal, <b>and that,</b> the bell, <b>cannot become ritually impure</b> because animal ornaments and utensils do not fall into the category of objects that can become ritually impure. Apparently, it is even prohibited for a slave to go out with a seal around his neck, contrary to Shmuel’s opinion.
The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits going out, is referring to a case <b>where his master made him</b> the seal. Since he fears removing it, there is no concern that he will come to carry it. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i>, which prohibits going out, is referring to a case <b>where he made it for himself</b> and there is concern lest he come to remove it and carry it.
The Gemara rejects this resolution: <b>No,</b> both <b>this and that are</b> referring to a case <b>where his master made</b> it <b>for him.</b> The difference can be explained differently. <b>And here,</b> where it was prohibited, it is referring <b>to</b> a seal <b>of metal, and here,</b> where it was permitted, it is a seal <b>of clay. And as Rav Naḥman</b> said that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: With an object about which his master is particular, one may not go out</b> on Shabbat, lest it become detached from the garment, and fear of his master lead the slave to carry it in his hand. <b>With an object about which his master is not particular, one may go out with it.</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> to understand the <i>baraita</i> <b>from the fact that it teaches</b> there: <b>This</b> seal <b>and that</b> seal <b>cannot become ritually impure. Granted, if you say</b> it is referring to a <b>metal</b> seal, it is possible to understand the novel aspect of the <i>baraita</i> as follows: <b>These are the</b> objects <b>that cannot become ritually impure; however, their vessels</b> made of the same material <b>can become ritually impure.</b>
<b>However, if you say</b> that <b>we learned</b> with regard to seals <b>of clay,</b> can it be similarly inferred that <b>these</b> seals <b>are the</b> objects that <b>cannot become ritually impure; however, their vessels</b> made of the same material <b>can become ritually impure?</b>
<b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Vessels of stone, vessels of dung, and vessels of earth</b> that are not made into earthenware <b>can neither become ritually impure by Torah law nor by rabbinic law?</b> Apparently, even an actual vessel made of clay cannot become ritually impure. <b>Rather, learn from it</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is referring to utensils made <b>of metal.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from it.</b>
In that same <i>baraita</i> <b>the Master said</b> that the slave may <b>not</b> go out <b>with a bell that is around his neck, but he may go out with a bell that is on his clothes.</b>
The Gemara asks: With <b>a bell that is around his neck, why</b> may he <b>not</b> go out? It is due to concern <b>lest it be severed and he come to carry it.</b> If so, with <b>a bell on his clothes too, let us be concerned lest it be severed and he come to carry it.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> With a case <b>where</b> the bell <b>is woven into</b> the garment, <b>and</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, as Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> A<b>nything that is woven</b> into a garment, <b>the Sages did not issue a decree</b> prohibiting going out with it on Shabbat.
In the <i>baraita</i> cited earlier, it was taught that <b>the Master said: An animal may neither go out with a seal that is around its neck, nor with a seal that is on its clothes, nor with a bell that is on its clothes, nor with a bell that is around its neck.</b> Both <b>this and that cannot become ritually impure.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And does a bell of an animal not become ritually impure?</b> The Gemara proceeds to <b>raise a contradiction</b> from that which was taught in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>The bell of an animal</b> can become <b>ritually impure,</b>

Daf 58b

<b>and</b> the bell <b>of a door is ritually pure.</b> The door itself is not considered a vessel. It is considered part of the house, and therefore its status is like that of the house. The house is attached to the ground, and therefore it cannot become ritually impure. Everything connected to it, including the bell, assumes that status.
If one took the bell <b>of a door and converted it</b> into a bell <b>for an animal, it</b> can become <b>ritually impure;</b> however, if one took the bell <b>of an animal and converted it</b> into a bell <b>for a door, even though he attached it to the door and</b> even <b>fastened it with nails, it</b> can still become <b>ritually impure because all utensils descend into their</b> state of <b>ritual impurity by means of thought</b> alone, i.e., as a result of a decision to designate them for a specific purpose through which they will become susceptible to ritual impurity, they receive that status immediately. <b>However, they only ascend from their</b> state of <b>ritual impurity by means of an action</b> that effects physical <b>change</b> to the vessel itself. A change in designation alone is ineffective. This <i>baraita</i> states that an animal bell can become ritually impure, contrary to that which was taught in the previous <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, where it was taught that the bell can become ritually impure, is referring to a case <b>where it has a clapper [<i>inbal</i>]. That</b> <i>baraita</i>, where it was taught that the bell cannot become ritually impure, is referring to a case <b>where it does not have a clapper.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, this is difficult. <b>If</b> the bell <b>is a vessel,</b> then <b>even though it has no clapper</b> it should be susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>If it is not a vessel, does a clapper render it a vessel?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> the clapper can determine the bell’s status with regard to ritual impurity, <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said. As Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a metal vessel that produces sound is</b> considered a vessel and can become <b>ritually impure? As it is stated: “Every thing that passes through the fire, you shall make it pass through the fire,</b> and it shall be clean; nevertheless, it shall be purified with the water of sprinkling; and all that does not pass through the fire you shall make to go through water” (Numbers 31:23). And the Sages interpret the verse homiletically: Every thing [<i>davar</i>], <b>even speech [<i>dibbur</i>];</b> in other words, even an object that makes a sound you <b>shall pass through fire</b> to purify it because it is a vessel.
However, the matter can be clarified further. <b>In what</b> case <b>did you establish</b> the <i>baraita</i>; in the case of a bell <b>that does not have a clapper?</b> If so, <b>say the middle</b> clause of that <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> he may <b>not</b> go out <b>with a bell that is</b> hung <b>around his neck; however, he may go out with a bell that is on his clothes,</b> and both <b>this and that can become ritually impure. If</b> it is referring to a bell that <b>does not have a clapper, can it become ritually impure?</b>
The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who makes bells for the mortar</b> used to crush spices, <b>and for the cradle, and for mantles of</b> Torah <b>scrolls, and for coverings of small children,</b> if <b>they have a clapper they</b> can become <b>ritually impure,</b> and if <b>they do not have a clapper they are ritually pure</b> and cannot become impure. If after they became ritually impure <b>their clappers were removed, their ritual impurity still</b> remains <b>upon them.</b> Apparently, even with regard to bells used by people, the original existence of a clapper determines whether or not the bell is considered a vessel.
The Gemara answers: <b>This applies only to</b> the bells of <b>a small child, since they are placed</b> on <b>him to</b> produce <b>sound.</b> If the bell does not make a sound, it serves no purpose and, consequently, cannot become ritually impure. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>an adult,</b> the bell <b>is an ornament for him even though it does not have a clapper.</b>
It was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>the Master said:</b> If <b>their clappers were removed</b> after they became ritually impure, <b>their ritual impurity still</b> remains <b>upon them.</b> The Gemara wonders: <b>For what</b> use <b>are they suited</b> after their clappers are removed? They are essentially broken and should therefore become ritually pure. <b>Abaye said:</b> The reason that their impurity remains is <b>because a common person is able to replace</b> the clapper into the bell. According to Abaye, with regard to any vessel that comes apart, if a common person is capable of reassembling it and it does not require the expertise of a craftsman, it is not considered broken and its ritual impurity is not nullified.
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> to this explanation from that which was taught: The connection between <b>the bell and the clapper,</b> this <b>is a connection.</b> Therefore, if they are detached from each other, the bell should be considered broken.
And he adds: <b>And if you say that</b> when employing the term connection, <b>it is saying as follows: Even though it is not connected, it</b> has the legal status <b>as if it were connected. Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The connection between the different parts of <b>scissors</b> made <b>of</b> different <b>parts</b> that are made to come apart <b>and</b> the connection between <b>the blade of a</b> carpenter’s <b>plane,</b> which can be removed from its handle, and its handle <b>are</b> considered <b>a connection with regard to</b> contracting <b>ritual impurity?</b> If one part becomes ritually impure, the other parts become ritually impure as well. The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>However,</b> they are <b>not</b> considered <b>a connection with regard to</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the waters of a purification offering. When waters of purification are sprinkled on these implements in order to purify them from ritual impurity imparted by a corpse (see Numbers 19:17–19), the water must be sprinkled on each part individually.
The Gemara asks: <b>Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, there is a difficulty: <b>If</b> it is considered <b>a connection,</b> they should be considered connected <b>even</b> with regard <b>to sprinkling;</b> and <b>if</b> they are <b>not</b> considered <b>a connection,</b> they should <b>not</b> be so considered <b>even</b> with regard <b>to ritual impurity.</b>
<b>And Rabba said: By Torah law, when in use,</b> they are considered <b>a connection, both</b> with regard <b>to ritual impurity</b> and with regard <b>to sprinkling. And when not in use,</b> even if the parts are connected, since they are made to come apart and they are commonly dismantled, they are <b>neither</b> considered <b>a connection</b> with regard <b>to ritual impurity nor</b> with regard <b>to sprinkling. And</b> the Sages <b>issued a decree</b> that they should be considered a connection <b>with regard to ritual impurity</b> even <b>when not in use, due to ritual impurity when in use.</b> If one component becomes ritually impure, the other component becomes ritually impure as well. <b>And,</b> as a further stringency, they issued a decree that they should not be considered a connection <b>with regard to sprinkling</b> even <b>when in use, due to sprinkling when not in use.</b> The waters of purification must be sprinkled on each part individually. Nevertheless, this type of connection with regard to ritual impurity is only relevant when the two parts are actually connected. When the parts are separate, even if they can be reattached easily, the vessel is considered broken. This contradicts Abaye’s explanation.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> It should be explained differently:

Daf 59a

It is considered a vessel <b>since</b> a bell without a clapper <b>is suited to strike on earthenware</b> and produce a sound of similar quality to that produced by a clapper. If so, even when the clapper is removed, the bell may still be used for its original purpose.
<b>It was also stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> It is considered a vessel, <b>since</b> a bell without a clapper <b>is suited to strike on earthenware. Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It is considered a vessel, <b>since it is suited</b> for use <b>to give water to a child</b> to drink.
And with regard to the essence of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement, the Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Yoḥanan not require</b> that the vessel’s new usage must be <b>of the</b> same <b>type as the original labor</b> in order for it to retain its ritual impurity after it has undergone change? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: “Every bed on which a <i>zav</i> is lying is ritually impure <b>and every vessel on which he is sitting</b> shall be ritually impure” (Leviticus 15:4). <b>I might</b> have thought, based on this verse, that if one <b>overturned</b> a vessel the size of <b>a <i>se’a</i> and sat on it, or overturned</b> a vessel the size of <b>a half-<i>se’a</i> [<i>tarkav</i>] and sat on it,</b> the vessel <b>would become ritually impure.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: On which the <i>zav</i> is sitting,</b> i.e., <b>that which is designated for sitting, excluding that</b> vessel <b>with regard to which one says</b> to the <i>zav</i>: <b>Stand and we will perform our labor</b> with the vessel. In that case, because the vessel is primarily used for purposes other than sitting, it does not become ritually impure even when the <i>zav</i> sits on it.
There is a dispute between the <i>amora’im</i> on this matter: <b>Rabbi Elazar says: With regard to ritual impurity imparted by treading [<i>midras</i>],</b> i.e., the <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to a <i>zav</i> or to a menstruating woman who sits or lies down on an object, <b>one states</b> the principle: <b>Stand and we will perform our labor</b> to maintain the purity of the vessel. <b>However, one does not state with regard to one who is ritually impure due to a corpse: Stand and we will perform our labor</b> to maintain the purity of the vessel. In other words, an object that became ritually impure through contact with a corpse and was subsequently broken, since it is possible to use it for some other purpose, it remains a vessel and susceptible to ritual impurity. However, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even with regard to one who is ritually impure due to a corpse, one states</b> the principle: <b>Stand and we will perform our labor</b> to maintain the purity of the vessel. According to his opinion, a vessel that is no longer suited for its initial use, even though it serves another purpose, is considered broken. Therefore, the bell, since it is no longer suited for ringing, remains ritually pure according to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion, even though it remains suited for drinking water.
The Gemara answers: <b>Reverse the</b> opinions in the <b>first</b> dispute: It was not Rabbi Yoḥanan who gave that reason; it was Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina. The Gemara asks: <b>And what did you see that</b> led <b>you to reverse the first? Reverse the</b> opinions of Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar in the <b>latter</b> dispute, and avoid a contradiction in the statements of Rabbi Yoḥanan in that way.
The Gemara answers: That is <b>because we learned</b> elsewhere <b>that Rabbi Yoḥanan requires</b> that the vessel’s new use will be <b>of the</b> same <b>type as the original labor.</b> His opinion here is consistent with his opinion there. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The shoe of an animal,</b> if it is made <b>of metal,</b> can become <b>ritually impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> use by people <b>is it suited?</b> Vessels designated for animal use do not become ritually impure unless they have some use for people. <b>Rav said: It is suited</b> for use as a vessel from <b>which one could drink water in war</b> when there are no other available vessels. <b>And Rabbi Ḥanina said: It is suited</b> for use as a vessel from <b>which one could smear oil</b> on his body <b>during a war. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: When he flees from the battlefield he places it on his foot and runs over thorns and the thistles.</b> Apparently, the only use for the shoe of an animal that would render it capable of becoming ritually impure when used by a person is use of the same type as the original labor.
The Gemara asks parenthetically: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> the explanation of <b>Rav and</b> that of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in a case <b>where the sandal is repulsive</b> and dirty. In Rav’s opinion, since one would not drink water from it, it cannot become ritually impure. According to Rabbi Ḥanina, since one could still use it to spread oil on his body, it can become ritually impure.
What is the practical difference <b>between</b> the explanation of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and</b> that of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina? There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in a case <b>where</b> the shoe <b>is heavy.</b> It is suited for spreading oil; it is not suited for one to place on his foot. Therefore, it cannot become ritually impure according to Rabbi Yoḥanan.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And neither</b> may a woman go out on Shabbat to the public domain <b>with a city of gold.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of: <b>With a city of gold? Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Jerusalem of Gold,</b> a gold tiara engraved with a depiction of the city of Jerusalem,

Daf 59b

<b>like</b> the one <b>that Rabbi Akiva made for his wife.</b>
And on this subject, <b>the Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>A woman may not go out</b> into the public domain on Shabbat <b>with a city of gold</b> ornament. <b>And if she went out</b> with it into the public domain <b>she is liable to bring a sin-offering;</b> that is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: She may not go out</b> with it <i>ab initio</i>, <b>and if she went out she is exempt. And Rabbi Eliezer says: A woman may go out with a city of gold</b> ornament <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree? Rabbi Meir holds</b> that <b>it is</b> considered <b>a burden</b> and not an ornament, and one who carries a burden into the public domain is liable to bring a sin-offering. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>it is an ornament.</b> Why, then, did they prohibit going out into the public domain wearing it? They are concerned <b>lest she remove it, and show it</b> to another, <b>and come to carry it</b> in the public domain. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer holds: Whose manner is it to go out with a city of gold</b> ornament? Only <b>an important woman, and</b> in that case there is no concern, as <b>an important woman does not remove</b> ornaments <b>and show</b> them to others.
After discussing going out into the public domain on Shabbat with a city of gold ornament, the Gemara discusses other ornaments. There is a dispute among <i>amora’im</i> with regard to a <b><i>kelila</i>,</b> which is a tiara-like ornament. <b>Rav prohibited</b> going out with it, <b>and Shmuel permitted</b> doing so.
The Gemara sets the parameters of the disagreement: With a <i>kelila</i> made <b>of metal, everyone agrees that it is prohibited</b> to go out into the public domain. <b>Where they disagree</b> is in the case <b>of a woven</b> fabric inlaid with metal. One <b>Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds</b> that in that type of ornament <b>the metal is</b> the <b>primary</b> element, and it is prohibited. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Shmuel, <b>holds</b> that <b>the woven</b> fabric <b>is</b> the <b>primary</b> element, and it is consequently permitted.
<b>Rav Ashi taught</b> this disagreement with <b>a lenient</b> interpretation, as he said: With a <i>kelila</i> <b>of woven</b> fabric, <b>everyone agrees that it is permitted</b> to go out into the public domain. <b>Where they disagree</b> is in the case <b>of a metal</b> ornament. One <b>Sage,</b> Rav, <b>holds</b> that it is prohibited because there is concern <b>lest she remove it, and show it</b> to another, <b>and come to carry it</b> in the public domain. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Shmuel, <b>holds</b> that it is permitted. <b>Whose manner is to go out with a <i>kelila</i></b> ornament? Only <b>an important woman; and an important woman does not remove</b> ornaments <b>and show</b> them to others.
On the same topic, <b>Rav Shmuel bar bar Ḥana said to Rav Yosef</b> who, due to illness, forgot his learning: <b>You explicitly said to us in the name of Rav:</b> With regard to <b>a <i>kelila</i>,</b> it <b>is permitted</b> to go out into the public domain on Shabbat.
The Gemara relates that one day <b>they said to Rav: A great, tall man came to Neharde’a and he was limping. And he taught:</b> With <b>a <i>kelila</i>,</b> it <b>is permitted</b> to go out into the public domain on Shabbat. Rav <b>said: Who is a great, tall man who limps? Levi. Conclude from this that Rabbi Afes passed away and Rabbi Ḥanina is sitting at the head</b> of the yeshiva in Eretz Yisrael in his place. <b>And,</b> consequently, <b>Levi had no one before whom to sit</b> and study <b>and he came here.</b> As long as Rabbi Afes headed the yeshiva, Rabbi Ḥanina would sit outside the study hall. Entering the study hall would indicate that he accepted the authority of Rabbi Afes. Rabbi Ḥanina, who was a great man, refused to do so. In deference to Rabbi Ḥanina, Levi would sit with him as a colleague outside the study hall. When Levi arrived from Eretz Yisrael, it was clear that Rabbi Afes must have died. Levi, who considered himself Rabbi Ḥanina’s equal in terms of both scholarship and age, did not want to defer to Rabbi Ḥanina’s authority and decided to go to elsewhere, to Babylonia.
The Gemara asks: How did Rav arrive at that particular conclusion? <b>And perhaps Rabbi Ḥanina died and Rabbi Afes</b> remained <b>standing</b> in his position at the head of the yeshiva <b>as he stood</b> previously; <b>and Levi had no one with whom to sit</b> outside the study hall, <b>and</b> that is why <b>he came here?</b> The Gemara answers that that could not be the case for two reasons. First, <b>if it were so,</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina died, Levi</b> would have been <b>subject to</b> the authority of <b>Rabbi Afes.</b> It was only in deference to Rabbi Ḥanina that Levi did not enter the study hall. <b>And furthermore, it could not be that Rabbi Ḥanina</b> died and <b>did not reign</b> as head of the yeshiva, <b>as when Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>died, he said</b> in his dying testament: <b>Ḥanina, son of Rabbi Ḥama, shall sit at the head</b> of the yeshiva. <b>And of the righteous it is written: “You will decree a saying and it will be established for you,</b> and the light will shine on your ways” (Job 22:28). Since the statement that Rabbi Ḥanina will serve at the head of the yeshiva crossed the lips of a righteous person, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, it is inconceivable that it would not have been realized.
The Gemara returns to the subject of <i>kelila</i>. When <b>Levi taught in Neharde’a</b> that with the <b><i>kelila</i></b> ornament, one <b>is permitted</b> to go out into the public domain on Shabbat, <b>twenty-four</b> women wearing the <b><i>kelila</i></b> ornament <b>went out</b> into the public domain <b>from all of Neharde’a.</b> When <b>Rabba bar Avuh taught in Meḥoza that</b> the <b><i>kelila</i></b> ornament <b>is permitted, eighteen</b> women wearing the <b><i>kelila</i></b> ornament <b>went out from one alleyway.</b> Meḥoza was a wealthy mercantile city, and many women there owned precious jewelry.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav Shmuel said:</b> With a precious <b>gilded belt [<i>kamra</i>],</b> a woman <b>is permitted</b> to go out into the public domain on Shabbat. <b>Some say</b> that he was referring to a belt made <b>of woven</b> fabric and inlaid with gold. <b>And Rav Safra said:</b> It is permitted <b>just as</b> it is permitted <b>in the case of a gilded cloak.</b>
<b>And some say</b> that it is referring to a belt made entirely <b>of metal. And Rav Safra said:</b> It is permitted <b>just as</b> it is permitted to go out into the public domain on Shabbat with <b>the belt of kings</b> made entirely of gold.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> With regard to going out with <b>a gilded belt over</b> another <b>belt [<i>hemyana</i>], what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>He said to him: Two belts you said;</b> it is certainly uncommon to wear two belts. Therefore, one of them is a burden.
<b>Rav Ashi said: This short cloak; if it has</b> short <b>straps with which</b> to tie it, <b>it is permitted</b> to go out with it, and <b>if not, it is prohibited.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>And</b> a woman may <b>not</b> go out on Shabbat <b>with a <i>katla</i>.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>What is</b> a <b><i>katla</i>? A</b> type of <b>small bib</b> hung from the neck. The <b><i>nezamim</i></b> mentioned in the mishna with which a woman may not go out on Shabbat refer to <b>nose rings,</b> not earrings.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Nor with a ring that has no seal on it.</b> By inference: <b>If it does have a seal on it, she is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering. She is only exempt from bringing a sacrifice when she goes out with a ring that does not have a seal on it, which is an ornament; however, a ring with a seal on it, typically used by men for sealing documents, is considered a burden for a woman on Shabbat. <b>Apparently,</b> that ring <b>is not an ornament.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from a mishna in tractate <i>Kelim</i>: <b>Women’s ornaments</b> can become <b>ritually impure. And these are women’s ornaments: Bibs; earrings; and rings; and a ring whether it has a seal on it</b> or <b>whether it does not have a seal on it; and nose rings.</b> Apparently, even a ring that has a seal on it is considered a woman’s ornament.
<b>And Rabbi Zeira said:</b> This is <b>not difficult.</b> Rather, <b>this</b> ruling in our mishna, which distinguishes between a ring with a seal and a ring without a seal, <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya; that</b> ruling in the mishna in tractate <i>Kelim</i>, which does not distinguish between rings, <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If the ring were made <b>of metal and its seal</b> was made <b>of coral, it</b> can become <b>ritually impure</b> because the primary component of the ring is metal, a material that can become <b>ritually impure.</b> If the ring were made <b>of coral and its seal of metal, it is ritually pure</b> and cannot become ritually impure. <b>Rabbi Neḥemya deems it ritually impure, as Rabbi Neḥemya would say: With regard to a ring, follow its seal;</b> if the seal were made of material that can become ritually impure, the entire ring can become ritually impure, and if it were made of material that cannot become ritually impure, the entire ring remains pure. The same is true <b>with regard to a yoke</b> of an animal: <b>Follow its rods.</b> Rods are placed in the yoke to fasten it to the animal; the component material of the rods determines whether or not the entire yoke can become ritually impure.

Daf 60a

<b>With a hanging board, follow its nails,</b> upon which the objects hang. <b>With a ladder, follow its rungs. With a large scale, follow its chains</b> and not its baseplates. <b>And the Rabbis say,</b> with regard to all of these vessels, <b>everything follows the support.</b> The legal status of the object is not determined by the component of the vessel most significant in terms of function. It is determined by the component most significant in terms of structure. Therefore, according to Rabbi Neḥemya there is a distinction, even in the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, between a ring with a seal and a ring without a seal, as in his opinion the seal constitutes the primary function of the ring. However, the Rabbis hold with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity that the essential part of the ring is the ring itself, not the seal. Therefore, they permit going out into the public domain on Shabbat even with a ring that has a seal.
<b>Rava said:</b> This contradiction can be resolved in another manner. The <i>mishna</i> dealing with the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity <b>taught</b> with regard to the two types of rings <b>disjunctively,</b> i.e., referring to different circumstances: A ring <b>that has a seal on it</b> can become ritually impure because it <b>is a man’s ornament;</b> a ring <b>that does not have a seal on it</b> can become ritually impure because it <b>is a woman’s ornament.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> an additional resolution to the contradiction between the <i>mishnayot</i>: <b>Are you raising a contradiction</b> from the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>ritual impurity to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat?</b> The underlying principles of these areas of <i>halakha</i> are totally different. With regard to <b>ritual impurity, the Torah stated:</b> “All <b>vessels with which labor is done”</b> (Numbers 31:51), <b>and</b> a ring with a seal <b>is a vessel</b> and can therefore become ritually impure. However, with regard to <b>Shabbat, the Torah stated</b> that the prohibition is <b>due to</b> the fact that the object is <b>a burden.</b> Therefore, in a case where there is <b>not a seal on it,</b> it is <b>an ornament</b> and may be worn in the public domain. In a case where there is <b>a seal on it,</b> it is <b>a burden</b> and may not be worn.
We also learned in the mishna: <b>Nor with a needle that is not perforated.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> use <b>is that</b> type of needle <b>suited? Rav Yosef said: Since a woman gathers her hair</b> and pins it to her hairnet <b>with</b> the unperforated needle.
<b>Abaye said to him: And</b> if so, <b>let</b> the needle <b>be like a ritually pure garter and</b> consequently <b>be permitted.</b> There is a type of garter, a strap that ensures that a woman’s stockings will not fall, that cannot become ritually impure. A woman is permitted to go out into the public domain wearing it on Shabbat even if it is ornamented. For reasons of modesty, a woman will certainly not remove her garter or display it in the public domain. Similarly, with regard to the needle, the assumption is that a woman will not loosen her hair in the street.
<b>Rather, Rav Adda from</b> the city of <b>Naresh explained before Rav Yosef: Since a woman parts her hair with it.</b> The Gemara asks: On Shabbat, when it is prohibited to comb one’s hair, <b>for what</b> use <b>is this</b> needle <b>suited? Rava said: There is a gold plate on</b> the other <b>end</b> of the needle. <b>On a weekday, she</b> uses <b>it to part her hair. On Shabbat,</b> she inserts the needle into her head covering and <b>lays</b> the gold plate <b>against her forehead</b> for ornamental purposes.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A man may not go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with a spiked sandal,</b> as will be explained in the Gemara. <b>And</b> he may <b>not</b> go out <b>with a single</b> sandal <b>when there is no wound on his foot. And</b> he may <b>neither</b> go out <b>with phylacteries, nor with an amulet when it is not from an expert,</b> but rather it was written by someone who has not established a reputation as an expert in writing amulets that are effective for those who carry them. <b>And</b> he may <b>neither</b> go out <b>with <i>shiryon</i>, nor with a <i>kasda</i>, nor with <i>maggafayim</i>.</b> These terms will be explained in the Gemara. <b>And if he went out</b> into the public domain with any of these, <b>he is not liable to bring a sin-offering.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that the Sages prohibited going out with <b>a spiked sandal</b> on Shabbat?
<b>Shmuel said: They were</b> those who <b>eluded the decrees</b> of religious persecution, <b>and</b> after one of the wars <b>they were hiding in a cave. And</b> those hiding <b>said: One who</b> seeks to <b>enter</b> the cave <b>may enter, but one who</b> seeks to <b>leave</b> the cave <b>may not leave.</b> One leaving has no way to determine whether or not the enemy is lying in wait outside the cave. Therefore, leaving could reveal the presence of those hiding in the cave.
It happened that <b>the sandal of one of them</b> was <b>reversed,</b> the front of the sandal was in the back, and his footprints appeared like the steps of one leaving the cave. <b>They thought that one of them left and</b> feared that their <b>enemies saw him and were now coming upon them</b> to attack. In their panic, <b>they pushed one another and killed one another</b> in <b>greater</b> numbers <b>than</b> their <b>enemies had killed among them.</b> To commemorate this disaster that resulted from a spiked sandal, they prohibited going out into the public domain with it.
<b>Rabbi Elai ben Elazar says</b> that the reason for the decree was different. Once <b>they were sitting in a cave and heard the sound</b> of a spiked sandal <b>atop the cave. They thought that</b> their <b>enemies had come upon them. They pushed one another and killed one another</b> in <b>greater</b> numbers <b>than</b> their <b>enemies had killed among them.</b>
<b>Rami bar Yeḥezkel said</b> that the reason for the decree was different. <b>They were sitting in a synagogue and they heard the sound</b> of a spiked sandal <b>from behind the synagogue. They thought that</b> their <b>enemies had come upon them. They pushed one another, and killed one another</b> in <b>greater</b> numbers <b>than</b> their <b>enemies had killed</b> among <b>them.</b>
To commemorate that disaster which occurred due to a spiked sandal, <b>at that time they said: A person may not go out with a spiked sandal.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so, on a weekday it should also be prohibited.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When this incident occurred, it was on Shabbat.</b> Therefore, they issued the decree prohibiting the spiked sandal specifically in parallel circumstances. The Gemara challenges: If so, <b>on a Festival</b> wearing a spiked sandal should <b>be permitted. Why,</b> then, <b>did we learn</b> in the same mishna:

Daf 60b

<b>One may send garments</b> as a gift <b>on a Festival, whether they are sewn</b> or <b>whether they are not sewn,</b> because any object fit for any use on a Festival may be sent as a gift. <b>However,</b> one may <b>neither</b> send <b>a spiked sandal nor an unsewn shoe on a Festival,</b> since using them is prohibited. Apparently, one may not wear a spiked sandal on a Festival.
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> that the Sages prohibited wearing a spiked sandal <b>on Shabbat?</b> It is <b>because there is an assemblage</b> of people. <b>On a Festival too, there is an assemblage</b> of people. The Gemara asks: <b>On a communal fast day, there is an assemblage</b> of people; wearing a spiked sandal <b>should be prohibited</b> then, as well. The Gemara answers: <b>When this incident occurred, it was</b> on a day when there was <b>an assemblage of prohibition,</b> i.e., a day on which performing labor is prohibited. <b>Here,</b> a fast day, is a day when there is <b>an assemblage of permission,</b> a day on which performing labor is permitted, and the two are not comparable. However, extending the scope of commemorative decrees to apply to comparable situations, e.g., from Shabbat to the Festivals, is acceptable.
<b>And</b> this is true <b>even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akiva, who said</b> in the following case that a decree issued due to a specific set of circumstances is applied only to those specific circumstances. The ashes of the red heifer were once transported across the Jordan River in a boat. A source of ritual impurity was discovered at the bottom of the boat. The Sages sought to issue a decree prohibiting transport of the ashes of the red heifer over any body of water, sea or river, over a bridge, or in a boat. Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akiva said that decrees that are issued due to a specific event apply only to precisely those circumstances. Therefore, he said: <b>They only prohibited</b> transporting the ashes of a red heifer <b>in the Jordan</b> River <b>and in a boat, and like the incident that occurred.</b> However, even according to this approach, which limits restriction, <b>that applies only to the Jordan</b> River and not to other rivers. This is <b>because it is different from other rivers</b> in several respects, e.g., width and depth. <b>However, a Festival and Shabbat are similar to one another, as it was taught</b> in the mishna: <b>The</b> halakhic <b>difference between a Festival and Shabbat is only</b> with regard to preparation of <b>food.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that a spiked sandal is prohibited <b>only</b> when the nails were placed in the sandal <b>to strengthen</b> its form; <b>however,</b> if they were placed in the sandal <b>for beauty, it is permitted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with <b>how many</b> nails is it considered to be <b>for beauty? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Five on this</b> sandal <b>and five on that</b> one. <b>And Rabbi Ḥanina said: Seven on this</b> one <b>and seven on that</b> one.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to Rav Shemen bar Abba: I will explain</b> it <b>to you: According to my</b> opinion, when inserting nails for beauty, <b>two</b> are inserted <b>from here,</b> its outer side, one near the toes and one near the heel, <b>and two</b> are inserted <b>from there,</b> its inner side, one near the toes and one near the heel, <b>and one</b> is inserted <b>on its straps; and for Rabbi Ḥanina, three from here, and three from there, and one on its straps.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>For an uneven sandal,</b> whose soles are not straight, <b>one makes seven</b> nails on the bottom to straighten it, and it is then permitted for use on Shabbat; that is <b>the statement of Rabbi Natan. And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permits</b> straightening the sandal <b>with thirteen</b> nails.
The Gemara notes: <b>Granted, according to Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> there is no problem, <b>as he stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan. However, Rabbi Yoḥanan, in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>did he state</b> his opinion? Neither of the <i>tanna’im</i> agrees with his opinion. The Gemara answers: <b>He stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Nehorai, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Nehorai says:</b> With <b>five</b> nails inserted into the sole, it <b>is permitted</b> to go out into the public domain on Shabbat; <b>and</b> with <b>seven</b> nails, it is <b>prohibited</b> to go out into the public domain on Shabbat.
The Sage, <b>Ifa, said to Rabba bar bar Ḥana: You,</b> who are <b>students of Rabbi Yoḥanan, act in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan. We will act in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ḥanina.</b>
<b>Rav Huna raised a dilemma before Rav Ashi:</b> With a sandal that has <b>five</b> nails inserted into the sole, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to going out into the public domain? <b>He said to him: Even</b> with <b>seven</b> nails it <b>is permitted.</b> He asked further: With <b>nine, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>He said to him: Even</b> with <b>eight</b> it <b>is prohibited.</b>
<b>That shoemaker raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ami: If one sewed</b> the sole and attached it to the sandal <b>from within, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? May he go out into the public domain after inserting nails into it? Rabbi Ami <b>said to him: It is permitted, and I do not know the reason.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: And does the Master not know the reason?</b> It is obvious. <b>Since he sewed it from within,</b> it is no longer a sandal, <b>it is a shoe. With regard to a sandal, the Sages issued a decree; with regard to a shoe, the Sages did not issue a decree.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Zavda raised a dilemma before Rabbi Abba bar Avina:</b> If <b>he shaped</b> the nail <b>like tongs [<i>kelavus</i>]</b> by bending a nail with two sharp ends and sticking both ends into the sandal, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? May he go out into the public domain with it on Shabbat? <b>He said to him: It is permitted. It was also stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> If <b>he shaped it like tongs it is permitted.</b>
<b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> If <b>he covered</b> the <b>entire</b> sole <b>in nails, so that</b> contact with <b>the ground</b> will <b>not wear it away, it is permitted</b> to go out with that sandal on Shabbat, since it is no longer the spiked sandal with regard to which they issued a decree.
<b>It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Sheshet: A man may not go out with a spiked sandal, and may not walk with it</b> even <b>from house to house</b> within his courtyard, and may not <b>even</b> walk <b>from bed to bed</b> within his house. <b>However,</b> since the decree was issued with regard to circumstances identical to a specific incident, it only applies to wearing the sandal. Therefore, <b>one may carry</b> the sandal <b>to cover a vessel with it and to support the legs of the bed with it. And Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, prohibits</b> using it for other purposes as well. <b>If most of its nails fell out, and four or five remain in it, it is permitted</b> to go out with it. <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permits</b> going out into the public domain with the sandal, even if <b>up to seven</b> nails remain in it. <b>If he covered it with leather from beneath</b> the wood frame of the sandal <b>and inserted nails into it from above, it is permitted. If he made</b> the nail <b>like a tong, or</b> made one end flat <b>like a platter [<i>tas</i>], or</b> sharpened it <b>like a peg, or covered it entirely with nails so that</b> contact with <b>the ground</b> will <b>not wear it away, it is permitted</b> to go out with it.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>Tosefta</i> cited in support of Rav Sheshet’s opinion. <b>This</b> <i>Tosefta</i> <b>itself is difficult,</b> as it is self-contradictory. On the one hand <b>you said:</b> If <b>most of its nails fell out</b> it is permitted; apparently, that is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even though many</b> nails <b>remain in</b> the sole. <b>And,</b> however, <b>subsequently it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta,</i> without specifying the number of nails that were there from the outset: With <b>four or five</b> nails, <b>yes,</b> going out is permitted; however, with <b>more</b> nails, <b>no,</b> it is prohibited.
<b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> and it can be resolved as follows: <b>Here,</b> where it was permitted to go out wearing the sandal if the majority of nails fell out, it is referring to a case <b>where they were broken,</b> i.e., the heads of the nails were broken off while most of the nail remained embedded in the sole. In that case, it is clearly evident that most of the nails fell out. <b>Here,</b> where it was permitted only if four or five nails remain, it is referring to a case <b>where they were</b> totally <b>removed</b> and only the nails that remain in the shoe are visible.
The Gemara continues its detailed analysis of the <i>Tosefta</i>: It was taught that if most of the nails in the sandal came out and only <b>four or five</b> nails remain, it <b>is permitted</b> to go out wearing it. The Gemara asks: <b>Now,</b> if it was mentioned that when <b>five</b> nails remain, going out <b>is permitted, is it necessary</b> to mention <b>four? Rav Ḥisda said</b> that the <i>Tosefta</i> means: If <b>four</b> nails remain <b>from</b> the nails in <b>a small sandal, and</b> if <b>five</b> nails remain <b>from</b> the nails in <b>a large sandal,</b> going out is permitted.
It was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permits up to seven.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that for a sandal with an uneven sole, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permits up to thirteen?</b> The Gemara answers: An <b>uneven</b> sole <b>is different.</b> Since the nails are inserted for the purpose of straightening the sole, it does not have the legal status of a spiked sandal.
