The Gemara notes: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> new explanation that a sandal with an uneven sole has a different legal status, <b>for Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who stated, contrary to the opinions of the <i>tanna’im</i> in this <i>baraita</i>, that the number of nails permitted in each sandal is five, <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is also not difficult.</b> He could explain that a sandal with an <b>uneven</b> sole <b>is different</b> and requires additional nails. However, in the case of a sandal with an even sole, even the other <i>tanna’im</i> would not permit that many.
<b>Rav Mattana said, and some say Rav Aḥadvoi bar Mattana said</b> that <b>Rav Mattana said: The <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> who completely prohibited moving a spiked sandal. The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious.</b> Isn’t there a halakhic principle that in a dispute between <b>an individual and</b> the <b>many, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the</b> opinion of the <b>many?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say that the rationale for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, is</b> more <b>reasonable in this</b> case, and therefore the <i>halakha</i> should be ruled in accordance with his opinion. Rav Mattana <b>teaches us</b> that that is not the <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said: If not</b> for the fact <b>that they would call me: Babylonian who permits prohibitions, I would permit</b> the insertion of <b>many</b> nails <b>into</b> a spiked sandal. The Gemara asks: <b>And how many</b> nails would he have permitted? <b>In Pumbedita they said: Twenty-four</b> nails. <b>In Sura they said: Twenty-two. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: And</b> this is <b>your mnemonic</b> to remember which opinion was stated in Sura and which opinion was stated in Pumbedita: <b>Until</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>came from Pumbedita to Sura he lost two</b> nails from his shoe. Since the route that Rabbi Ḥiyya took from Pumbedita to Eretz Yisrael passed through Sura, one could say: Due to the rigors of the journey, two nails fell from the sandal of Rabbi Ḥiyya between Pumbedita and Sura.
It was taught in the mishna: <b>And</b> he may <b>not</b> go out <b>with a single</b> sandal <b>when there is no wound on his foot.</b>

Daf 61a

By inference: <b>If there is a wound on his foot, he may go out</b> with one sandal. In that case, <b>with</b> a sandal <b>on which of</b> his feet <b>does he go out? Rav Huna said:</b> With a sandal <b>on the</b> foot <b>that has a wound on it. Apparently, he holds: A sandal is made for the purpose</b> of avoiding <b>pain.</b> Typically, a person wears sandals only in order to avoid the pain of walking on stones and the like. When he is seen with only one sandal, it is clear that he is oblivious to that pain and the only reason that he is wearing the sandal is due to the wound on his foot. Consequently, no one will suspect that he went out wearing two sandals and that if he is wearing one, he must be carrying the other one.
<b>And Ḥiyya bar Rav said:</b> He goes out with a sandal <b>on the</b> foot <b>that does not have a wound on it. Apparently, he holds</b> that the sandal is <b>made for the purpose of</b> providing <b>comfort,</b> and he wears it on his healthy foot. <b>And</b> it does not arouse suspicion because, with regard to <b>that</b> foot <b>on which there is a wound, its wound indicates</b> that he is unable to wear a sandal on <b>that</b> foot, and it is clear that he left the other sandal at home.
The Gemara comments: <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan also holds that</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna,</b> which maintains that one only wears sandals to avoid pain, is correct. <b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan said to Rav Shemen bar Abba,</b> his attendant: <b>Give me my sandal. He gave him the right</b> sandal. <b>He said to him: You have rendered</b> this foot as one with <b>a wound.</b> In Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion, one must always put on his left shoe first. One who puts on the right shoe first is no longer permitted to put on the left shoe. By handing him his right sandal, he is forcing Rabbi Yoḥanan to go out with one sandal, leading onlookers to conclude that he has a wound on that foot. That incident corresponds to Rav Huna’s opinion that one wears the sandal on the wounded foot.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>And perhaps, he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav,</b> which maintains that one wears the sandal on the healthy foot, <b>and he is saying as follows:</b> By handing me my right shoe, <b>you have rendered</b> my left foot, on which I have no shoe, as one with <b>a wound.</b> No proof can be cited from that incident, as Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion cannot be ascertained from the exchange with his attendant.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his</b> regular line of <b>reasoning. As Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Just <b>as</b> one dons <b>phylacteries, so too,</b> one puts on <b>shoes. Just as phylacteries are</b> placed <b>on the left</b> arm, <b>so too,</b> when putting on <b>shoes</b> one begins <b>with the left</b> foot.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>When one puts on</b> his <b>shoes, he puts on the right shoe</b> first <b>and afterward puts on the left shoe.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: Now that it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in <b>this</b> manner, <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan stated</b> the <i>halakha</i> in <b>that</b> manner, <b>one</b> who <b>acted this way acted</b> properly, <b>and one who acted that way acted</b> properly, as each custom has a basis.
<b>Abaye said to him:</b> Why is the Gemara certain that Rabbi Yoḥanan disagrees with the <i>baraita</i>? <b>Perhaps Rabbi Yoḥanan had not heard this <i>baraita</i>, and had he heard it, he would have retracted</b> his opinion. <b>And</b> even <b>if he heard it,</b> perhaps he heard it <b>and held that the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with that mishna.</b> In any case, it is necessary to rule in accordance with one of the opinions.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: And one who fears Heaven fulfills both</b> opinions. <b>And who is this</b> God-fearing person? <b>Mar, son of Rabbana. How does he conduct</b> himself? <b>He puts on his right</b> shoe <b>and does not tie</b> the laces. <b>And</b> then <b>he puts on his left</b> shoe <b>and ties</b> it, <b>and</b> then afterward <b>ties</b> the laces <b>of his right</b> shoe. <b>Rav Ashi said: I saw that Rav Kahana was not particular</b> with regard to the order in which he put on his shoes.
After citing this excerpt from <i>Hilkhot Derekh Eretz</i> with regard to putting on shoes, the Gemara cites the entire matter. <b>The Sages taught: When one puts on</b> his <b>shoes, he puts on the right shoe</b> first <b>and afterward puts on the left shoe</b> because the right always takes precedence. <b>When he removes them, he removes the left and afterward he removes the right,</b> so that the right shoe will remain on the foot longer.
<b>When one washes</b> his feet, <b>he washes the right</b> first <b>and afterward he washes the left. And one who wishes to spread oil</b> on his feet <b>spreads oil on the right</b> first <b>and afterward spreads oil on the left. And one who wishes to spread oil on his entire body, spreads oil on his head first because it is the king of all his</b> other <b>limbs.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>And</b> he may <b>neither</b> go out <b>with phylacteries. Rav Safra said: Do not say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is only <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of the <b>one who said</b> that <b>Shabbat is not</b> an appropriate <b>time</b> to don <b>phylacteries,</b> i.e., it is prohibited to don phylacteries on Shabbat, and that is the reason that one may not go out into the public domain with them. <b>Rather, even according to the one who said</b> that <b>Shabbat is</b> an appropriate <b>time</b> to don <b>phylacteries, he may not go out</b> with them due to the concern <b>lest he come to carry them</b> in his hand <b>in the public domain,</b> which is prohibited by Torah law.
<b>And some teach</b> the statement of Rav Safra as referring <b>to the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>And if he went out</b> into the public domain with phylacteries <b>he is not liable to bring a sin-offering. Rav Safra said: Do not say that</b> this <i>halakha</i> is only <b>according to</b> the opinion of the <b>one who said</b> that <b>Shabbat is</b> an appropriate <b>time</b> to don <b>phylacteries,</b> and therefore he does not violate a Torah prohibition by going out into the public domain with phylacteries and is not liable to bring a sin-offering. <b>Rather, even according to</b> the opinion of <b>one who said that Shabbat is not</b> an appropriate <b>time</b> to don <b>phylacteries, he is not liable to bring a sin-offering. What is the reason</b> that he is exempt? Donning phylacteries is <b>performed in the manner of</b> wearing <b>a garment</b> or an ornament. Although one may not use phylacteries on Shabbat, there is no Torah prohibition against moving them.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Nor with an amulet when it is not from an expert. Rav Pappa said: Do not say</b> that the meaning of the mishna is that one may <b>only</b> go out with an amulet <b>if the person</b> who wrote it <b>is an expert and the amulet</b> has proven <b>effective. Rather, if the person</b> who wrote it <b>is an expert, even though the amulet</b> has <b>not</b> proven <b>effective,</b> he may go out with it.
The Gemara comments: The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches: Nor with an amulet when it is not from an expert, and it does not teach: When</b> the amulet <b>is not effective.</b> Apparently, it is sufficient if the writer of the amulet is an expert, even if the effectiveness of the amulet has not been proven. The Gemara comments: Indeed, <b>learn from it.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>What is an effective amulet?</b> It is <b>any</b> amulet <b>that healed</b> one person once, <b>and</b> healed him <b>again, and</b> healed him <b>a third</b> time. That is the criterion for an effective amulet, and it applies to <b>both a written amulet and an amulet of</b> herbal <b>roots; both</b> if it has proven effective in healing <b>a sick person who is dangerously</b> ill, <b>and</b> if it has proven effective in healing <b>a sick person who is not dangerously</b> ill. It is permitted to go out with these types of amulets on Shabbat.
And an amulet was <b>not</b> only permitted in a case <b>where</b> one has already <b>fallen</b> due to epilepsy and wears the amulet in order to prevent an additional fall. <b>Rather,</b> even if one has never fallen, and he wears the amulet so that he <b>will not</b> contract the illness and <b>fall,</b> he is permitted to go out with it on Shabbat is permitted.
<b>And he may tie and untie</b> it <b>even in the public domain, as long as he does not tie it</b>

Daf 61b

<b>to a bracelet or a ring and go out with it into the public domain.</b> The reason for the prohibition is <b>due to</b> the <b>appearance</b> of transgression, as, in that case, it appears that he is wearing the amulet strictly for ornamental purposes, which is prohibited.
With regard to the definition of an effective amulet as one which healed one person three times, the Gemara raises an objection. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Which is an effective amulet; any</b> amulet <b>that healed three people as one?</b>
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This,</b> where it was taught in the <i>baraita</i> that the amulet must have healed three different people, is referring <b>to proving the expertise of the man</b> who wrote it. Once his amulets have proven themselves by healing three different people stricken with different illnesses, clearly the one who wrote them is an expert. <b>That,</b> where it was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i> that even if the amulet healed one person three times, is referring <b>to proving that the amulet is effective</b> in fulfilling its designated purpose.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It is <b>obvious to me</b> in a case where <b>three amulets</b> were written <b>for three people</b> and effectively healed <b>each three times</b> that both <b>the man</b> who wrote them <b>is proven an expert and the amulet is proven effective.</b> Likewise, it is obvious to me that in the case of one who writes <b>three amulets for three people</b> and healed <b>each one time, the man is proven</b> to be <b>an expert;</b> however, <b>the amulet is not proven effective.</b> Similarly, if one wrote <b>one amulet for three people</b> and it healed them, <b>the amulet is proven effective,</b> while <b>the man</b> who wrote it <b>is not</b> thereby <b>proven an expert.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa raised a dilemma: Three amulets for one person, what</b> is the status of the amulet and the one who wrote it in that case? <b>The amulet is certainly not proven effective;</b> however, with regard to <b>the man</b> who wrote it, <b>is he proven an expert or is he not proven an expert?</b> This is the dilemma: <b>Do we say</b> that the person is an expert since <b>the amulet</b> that he wrote <b>healed</b> the person who was ill? <b>Or, perhaps</b> we say that <b>it was the fortune of that</b> sick <b>man who received</b> the influence of <b>the writing</b> of the amulet, but a different person would not be healed? The Gemara concludes: Let this dilemma <b>stand</b> unresolved.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Do amulets have an element of sanctity, or perhaps they have no element of sanctity?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> is this dilemma relevant? <b>If you say</b> it is relevant <b>with regard to rescuing them from fire</b> on Shabbat, there is a clear resolution to the dilemma. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> what was taught: <b>The blessings and the amulets, even though there are letters</b> of holy names <b>and many matters that are in the Torah</b> written in them, <b>one may not rescue them from the fire, and they burn in their place.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the dilemma is relevant with regard <b>to the matter of interment</b> of sacred documents. Must an amulet no longer in use be buried, or may it be discarded? However, with regard to the matter of interment as well, <b>come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from what was taught: If one of the names of God <b>was written</b> even <b>on the handles of the vessels and</b> even <b>on legs of the bed, he must cut off</b> the name <b>and bury it,</b> as one must be exacting with regard to the name of God, wherever it is written.
<b>Rather,</b> the dilemma was raised with regard to whether or not it is permitted <b>to enter the bathroom with them. What is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Do <b>they have sanctity, and it is</b> therefore <b>prohibited? Or, perhaps they have no sanctity, and it is permitted? Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from that which we learned in our mishna: <b>Nor with an amulet, when it is not from an expert.</b> By inference: <b>If it is from an expert, he may go out</b> with it.
<b>And, if you say</b> that <b>amulets have an element of sanctity, at times he will need</b> to go <b>to the bathroom,</b> will be required to remove the amulets, forget that he removed them, <b>and come to carry them four cubits in the public domain.</b> Since the mishna did not address these complications, apparently amulets do not have an element of sanctity in that regard and one may enter the bathroom with them. The Gemara rejects this: <b>With what we are dealing here? With an amulet</b> made <b>of</b> herbal <b>roots</b> that certainly has no sanctity.
The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: This is the case with regard to <b>both a written amulet and an amulet of</b> herbal <b>roots,</b> indicating that their <i>halakhot</i> are equal? <b>Rather, with what we are dealing here? With a person who is dangerously ill.</b> Because of the life-threatening situation, he is permitted to enter the bathroom with his amulet, despite the resulting degradation of the Holy Name. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in the same <i>baraita</i> that the <i>halakha</i> applies to <b>both a sick person who is dangerously</b> ill <b>and a sick person who is not dangerously</b> ill, indicating that they share the same status in this regard?
<b>Rather, since the amulet heals, even though he holds it in his hand,</b> he may <b>well</b> go out with it <b>too.</b> In terms of healing, there is no difference whether the amulet is hanging around his neck or whether it is in his hand; just as they permitted him to wear it around his neck on Shabbat, so too they permitted him to carry it in his hand.

Daf 62a

<b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya says</b> with regard to an amulet: <b>As long as he does not hold it in his hand and carry it four cubits in the public domain?</b> Apparently, even with regard to an amulet, there is a distinction between wearing it and carrying it.
<b>Rather, with what are we dealing here? With</b> an amulet that is <b>covered in leather.</b> Since the writing itself is covered, the name of God is not degraded when the amulet is brought into the bathroom with him.
The Gemara objects. There is writing on the scrolls of <b>phylacteries, which is covered in</b> the <b>leather</b> of boxes housing the scrolls, <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who enters a bathroom</b> while wearing phylacteries <b>must remove</b> the <b>phylacteries at a distance of four cubits and</b> only then <b>enter.</b> There is no halakhic difference whether or not the writing is covered.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>There,</b> with regard to phylacteries, the prohibition to enter the bathroom is not due to the sacred writing on the scrolls inside the phylacteries. Rather, it is <b>due to the</b> letter <b><i>shin</i></b> that protrudes from the leather of the boxes housing the scroll in the phylacteries of the head, <b>as Abaye said:</b> The source of the requirement of the <b><i>shin</i> of the phylacteries is a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai.</b> It is required by Torah law. <b>And, Abaye said:</b> The knot in the shape of the letter <b><i>dalet</i></b> in the straps <b>of the phylacteries</b> of the head <b>is a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai. And, Abaye said:</b> The <b>letter <i>yod</i> of the phylacteries is a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai.</b> It is due to those letters that one must safeguard the sanctity of the phylacteries and refrain from taking them into the bathroom.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And</b> he may <b>neither</b> go out <b>with <i>shiryon</i>, nor with a <i>kasda</i>, nor with <i>maggafayim</i>.</b> These terms were not understood, and therefore the Gemara explains them:
<b><i>Shiryon</i></b> is <b>a coat of mail [<i>zerada</i>],</b> armor made of scales. <b><i>Kasda</i>: Rav said</b> that it is <b>a leather hat [<i>sanvarta</i>]</b> worn under a metal helmet. <b><i>Maggafayim</i>: Rav said</b> they are <b>leg armor</b> worn beneath the knee.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A woman may neither go out</b> to the public domain <b>with a perforated needle,</b> i.e., a standard needle with an eye, <b>nor with a ring that has a seal on it, nor with a <i>kulyar</i>, nor with a <i>kovelet</i>,</b> the identity of which will be discussed in the Gemara, <b>nor with a flask of balsam oil.</b>
<b>And if she did go out</b> into the public domain, <b>she is liable to bring a sin-offering;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir,</b> who holds that in doing so she violated the Torah prohibition of carrying a burden in the public domain on Shabbat. <b>And the Rabbis exempt</b> one who goes out on Shabbat <b>with a <i>kovelet</i> and with a flask of balsam oil.</b> In their opinion, these are ornaments, and therefore they do not fundamentally violate the Torah prohibition of carrying in the public domain on Shabbat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to that which we learned in the mishna that a woman may not go out on Shabbat with a ring that has a seal, and by inference that she may go out with a ring without a seal, <b>Ulla said: And the reverse</b> of <b>these</b> <i>halakhot</i> is true <b>with regard to a man.</b> A man who wears a ring with a seal in the public domain is exempt. However, if he wears a ring without a seal, he is liable to bring a sin-offering as it is not considered an ornament for a man. Based on that statement, the Gemara concludes: <b>Apparently, Ulla holds</b> that <b>every object that is suitable for a man is not suitable for a woman, and an object that is suitable for a woman is not suitable for a man.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef raised an objection</b> from the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Shepherds may go out</b> on Shabbat <b>in</b> garments made of <b>sacks. And not</b> with regard to <b>the shepherds alone did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that they are permitted to go out in sacks on Shabbat; <b>rather, any person</b> may do so. <b>However,</b> the Sages taught the <i>halakha</i> with regard to shepherds because <b>it is the</b> standard <b>practice of shepherds to go out in sacks.</b> Apparently, although a sack is not a typical garment for most people, it is permitted even for one who is not a shepherd and would not generally wear it. Based on the same principle, although men do not generally wear women’s ornaments and women do not generally wear men’s ornaments, since occasionally a man might wear an ornament belonging to a woman or vice versa, each should be permitted to go out into the public domain with the ornament of the other.
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef said: Ulla holds</b> that <b>women are a people unto themselves.</b> The difference between the standard practice of men and women is greater than the difference between the standard practice of practitioners of different professions.
<b>Abaye raised an objection</b> to Rav Yosef’s statement from the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who finds phylacteries</b> outside of the city on Shabbat <b>should</b> don them and <b>bring them into</b> the city <b>one pair at a time.</b> This applies to <b>both a man and a woman. And if you say</b> that <b>women are a people unto themselves, isn’t</b> the mitzva to don phylacteries <b>a time-bound, positive mitzva,</b> as there are times when the mitzva to don phylacteries is not in effect? <b>And</b> the following is a halakhic principle: <b>Women are exempt from every time-bound, positive mitzva.</b> If, in fact, the clothing and ornaments of a man are not suitable for a woman under any circumstances, why is a woman permitted to don the phylacteries and bring them into the city on Shabbat? Shouldn’t that be considered a prohibited act of carrying?
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> with regard to phylacteries, <b>Rabbi Meir holds</b> that <b>night is an</b> appropriate <b>time</b> to don <b>phylacteries, and Shabbat</b> and Festivals are similarly <b>an</b> appropriate <b>time</b> to don <b>phylacteries.</b> Consequently, the mitzva of phylacteries is <b>a positive mitzva</b> that is <b>not time bound; and</b> in <b>every positive mitzva</b> that is <b>not time bound, women are obligated.</b> Therefore, women are permitted to don the phylacteries and bring them into the city.
With regard to Rabbi Meir’s ruling in the mishna that a woman is liable by Torah law if she goes out into the public domain wearing a ring with a seal, the Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t it</b> considered <b>carrying out in a backhanded manner?</b> A ring with a seal is not an ornament for a woman; it is an object like any other. One typically carries objects holding them in his hand. Wearing an object around one’s finger is atypical. There is no Torah prohibition violated when a labor is performed in an atypical manner.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that <b>we are dealing</b> in the mishna <b>with a woman who is a treasurer</b> for charity. A woman with that occupation typically wears a ring with a seal on her finger in order to perform her job. She does not, though, wear it as an ornament. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: You answered</b> and explained why, in the case of a <b>woman,</b> she would be liable to bring a sin-offering. However, in the case of a <b>man</b> who wore a ring without a seal, <b>what is there to say?</b> Why should he be liable?
<b>Rather, Rava said</b> that there is a different reason: <b>Sometimes a person gives his wife a ring that has a seal on it to take it to</b> his house and place it in <b>a box</b> for safekeeping, <b>and,</b> in order to ensure that she does not lose the ring, the woman <b>places it in on her hand,</b> i.e., on her finger, <b>until she reaches the box. And,</b> likewise, <b>sometimes a woman gives her husband a ring that does not have a seal on it to take it to a craftsman to repair it, and</b> the husband <b>places it on his hand,</b> i.e., on his finger, <b>until he reaches the craftsman.</b> The purpose of wearing these rings is not for ornamentation. Nevertheless, it is considered a typical manner of carrying them.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Nor with a <i>kulyar</i>, nor with a <i>kovelet</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> a <b><i>kulyar</i>? Rav said: A brooch</b> with which a woman fastens the collar of her garment. <b><i>Kovelet</i>: Rav said</b> that it is <b>a bundle of fragrant herbs [<i>pilon</i>]. And, similarly, Rav Asi said: A bundle of fragrant herbs.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A woman may not go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with a bundle of fragrant herbs, and if she did go out she is liable to bring a sin-offering,</b> as she violated a Torah prohibition; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: She may not go out</b> <i>ab initio</i>; <b>however, if she went out, she is exempt. Rabbi Eliezer says: A woman may go out with a bundle of fragrant herbs</b> even <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree? Rabbi Meir holds</b> that <b>it is a burden.</b> Therefore, one who takes it out into the public domain on Shabbat is liable to bring a sin-offering. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>it is an ornament.</b> Nevertheless, they prohibited going out with it <i>ab initio</i> due to concern <b>lest she remove</b> the bundle of herbs from its place, <b>and show it</b> to others, <b>and come to carry it</b> in the public domain. <b>And Rabbi Eliezer holds: Whose practice is it to place</b> fragrant herbs on herself? <b>A woman whose odor is foul.</b> But <b>a woman whose odor is foul does not remove and show</b> the bundle to others because, by doing so, her odor will be detected, a situation that she would prefer to avoid. <b>And,</b> therefore she <b>will not come to carry it four cubits in the public domain.</b>
This <i>baraita</i> cites the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, who permits, even <i>ab initio</i>, going out into the public domain with a bundle of herbs. The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer exempts</b> a woman who goes out on Shabbat <b>with a bundle of herbs and with a flask of balsam oil?</b> With regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, exempt means that although it is not prohibited by Torah law, it is prohibited <i>ab initio</i> by rabbinic law.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult.</b> When Rabbi Eliezer made <b>this</b> statement, it was <b>when he was addressing</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Meir.</b> When Rabbi Eliezer made <b>that</b> statement, it was <b>when he was addressing</b> the statement <b>of the Rabbis.</b> To clarify: <b>When he was addressing</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>she is liable to bring a sin-offering, he said to him</b> that she is <b>exempt</b> from bringing the sacrifice. <b>When he was addressing</b> the statement of <b>the Rabbis, who said</b> that she is <b>exempt but</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> <i>ab initio</i><b>, he said</b> that it is <b>permitted</b> even <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>

Daf 62b

<b>And</b> to <b>what</b> statement of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> is the Gemara referring? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A woman may not go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with a key that is in her hand, and if she went out she is liable to bring a sin-offering;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Eliezer exempts</b> a woman who goes out <b>with a bundle of fragrant herbs and with a flask of balsam oil [<i>palyaton</i>].</b>
The Gemara finds the statement of Rabbi Eliezer difficult: <b>A bundle of fragrant herbs; who mentioned</b> anything about <b>that?</b> Rabbi Meir did not mention a bundle of herbs; why did Rabbi Eliezer mention it in his response?
The Gemara answers that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is incomplete and it teaches the following: And likewise, with a bundle of fragrant herbs, and likewise with a flask of balsam oil she may not go out, and if she went out she is liable to bring a sin-offering;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Eliezer exempts in</b> the cases of <b>a bundle of fragrant herbs and a flask of balsam oil. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case <b>where</b> the vessels <b>have perfume in them; however,</b> in a case where <b>they do not have perfume in them, she is liable</b> for carrying the flask out into the public domain on Shabbat.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said: That is to say</b> that <b>one who carries out</b> a measure of <b>food</b> that is <b>less than the measure</b> that determines liability on Shabbat, but he does so <b>in a vessel, he is liable.</b> Although he is not liable for carrying the food out into the public domain, he is liable for carrying out the vessel. In that case, the vessel is not subordinate to the food, and therefore it is significant. <b>Since</b> the case of the flask <b>in which there is no perfume is comparable to</b> the case in which there is <b>less than the</b> required <b>measurement</b> of food <b>in a vessel, and it was taught</b> in the case of the flask that <b>she is liable</b> even though the fragrance of the perfume remains in the vessel, it stands to reason that one who carries a vessel containing less than a measure of food is also liable.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> That is no proof because, <b>in general, I would say to you</b> that <b>he is exempt</b> in a case where there is less than the measure that determines liability for food. <b>However, it is different here,</b> in the case of the empty flask of perfume <b>as,</b> in that case, <b>there is no substance</b> at all. Because the vessel is completely empty, he is liable for carrying the flask.
Related to the mention of perfume, the Gemara cites several statements. It is stated: “That drink wine in <i>mizrekei</i>, <b>and anoint themselves with the chief ointments;</b> but they are not grieved for the hurt of Joseph” (Amos 6:6). <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: “</b>The chief ointments” <b>is balsam oil.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef raised an objection</b> from the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Bava issued a decree on balsam oil as well,</b> prohibiting its use due to mourning over the destruction of the Temple, <b>and</b> the Sages <b>did not agree with him. And if you say</b> that balsam oil is the chief ointment cited in the verse, and the decree was issued <b>due to</b> the <b>pleasure</b> it provides, <b>why didn’t</b> the Sages <b>agree with his</b> decree? Doesn’t the verse criticize those who do not feel the pain of the people?
<b>Abaye said to him: And according to your reasoning, that which is written</b> in the same verse: <b>“That drink wine in <i>mizrekei</i>”; Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi</b> disagree over the meaning of the term <i>mizrekei</i>. <b>One said:</b> They are <b>multi-spouted vessels [<i>kenishkanin</i>],</b> wine vessels with spouts from which several people can drink at one time, <b>and one said that they throw [<i>mezarkin</i>] their cups to one another</b> in joy and jest. <b>Is that also prohibited? Didn’t Rabba bar Rav Huna visit the house of the Exilarch and</b> see the Exilarch <b>drink</b> from <b>a multi-spouted vessel, and</b> Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>did not say anything to him?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the principle is as follows: With regard to <b>any matter in which there is</b> an element of <b>pleasure and in which there is</b> an element of <b>joy, the Sages issued a decree</b> prohibiting it due to mourning over the destruction of the Temple. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a matter in which there is</b> an element of <b>pleasure and in which there is no</b> element of <b>joy, the Sages did not issue a decree.</b> Since there is no element of joy in balsam oil, even though it is precious and pleasurable, they did not issue a decree prohibiting it.
The Gemara interprets additional verses related to the critique of the leadership of Samaria. It is stated: <b>“That lie upon beds of ivory and stretch [<i>seruḥim</i>] upon their couches</b> and eat the lambs out of the flock and the calves out of the midst of the stall” (Amos 6:4). <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: This</b> term, <i>seruḥim</i>, interpreted homiletically, <b>teaches</b> that their sin was that <b>they would urinate before their beds</b> while <b>naked.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abbahu ridiculed that</b> interpretation: <b>If so,</b> that this is the meaning of the term <i>seruḥim</i>, <b>is this</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written: “Therefore now they shall go into exile at the head of the exiles</b> and the revelry of those <i>seruḥim</i> shall pass away” (Amos 6:7), <b>because they urinate before their beds</b> while <b>naked they will be exiled at the head of exiles?</b> Although doing so is revolting, a punishment so severe is certainly excessive.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> This verse is referring to a grave sin. <b>These are people who would eat and drink with each other, and join their beds to each other, and swap wives with each other, and defile their beds with semen that was not theirs.</b> That is the meaning of <i>seruḥim</i> upon their couches. For those severe transgressions they deserved to be exiled at the head of exiles.
On a related note, <b>Rabbi Abbahu said, and some say it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: Three matters bring a person to</b> a state of <b>poverty</b> as a divine punishment from Heaven: <b>One who urinates before his bed</b> while <b>naked, and one who demeans the ritual washing of the hands, and one whose wife curses him in his presence.</b>
The Gemara explains: With regard to <b>one who urinates before his bed</b> while <b>naked, Rava said: We only said this</b> prohibition in a case <b>where he turns his face toward his bed</b> and urinates toward it; <b>however,</b> if he turns his face and urinates <b>toward the outer</b> portion of the room, <b>we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b>
<b>And</b> where <b>one turns his face toward his bed, too, we only said this</b> prohibition in a case <b>where he urinates on the ground; however,</b> if he urinates <b>into a vessel, we have no</b> problem <b>with it</b> since that is not considered disgusting.
With regard to <b>one who demeans the ritual washing of the hands, Rava said: We only said</b> this statement in a case <b>where he does not wash his hands at all; however,</b> if <b>he washes</b> his hands <b>and does not wash</b> them with a significant amount of water, <b>we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And that is not</b> so, <b>as Rav Ḥisda said: I wash</b> my hands <b>with handfuls of water and</b> they <b>gave me</b> in reward <b>handfuls of prosperity.</b> Apparently, in order to garner the benefits of ritual washing of his hands, one should use a significant amount of water.
With regard to <b>one whose wife curses him in his presence, Rava said:</b> This is referring to a case where she curses him <b>over matters</b> relating to <b>her ornaments,</b> i.e., she complains that he does not provide her with jewelry. The Gemara comments: <b>And that applies only when he has</b> the resources to buy her jewelry <b>but does not do</b> so; however, if he does not have sufficient resources he need not be concerned.
Since the Gemara spoke of sins in the First Temple era, it continues to explain other verses with similar content. <b>Rava, son of Rav Ilai, interpreted</b> the following verse <b>homiletically. What is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written: “The Lord says because the daughters of Zion are haughty</b> and walk with outstretched necks and wanton eyes, walking and mincing as they go and making a tinkling with their feet” (Isaiah 3:16)?<br>“Because the daughters of Zion are haughty,” indicates <b>that they would walk with upright stature</b> and carry themselves in an immodest way.<br><b>“And walk with outstretched necks,”</b> indicates <b>that they would walk</b> in small steps, <b>heel to toe,</b> so onlookers would notice them.<br><b>“Wanton eyes,”</b> indicates <b>that they would fill their eyes with blue eye shadow and beckon.</b><br><b>“Walking and mincing [<i>tafof</i>] as they go,”</b> indicates <b>that the</b> wealthy women <b>would walk</b> a <b>tall</b> woman <b>alongside</b> a <b>short</b> one so that the tall woman would stand out. This is derived from the interchangeability of the letters <i>tet</i> and <i>tzadi</i>; <i>tzafo</i>, meaning, in this case, to be seen.<br><b>“Making a tinkling [<i>te’akasna</i>] with their feet,” Rabbi Yitzḥak from the school of Rabbi Ami said: This teaches that they would place myrrh and balsam in their shoes and would walk in the marketplaces of Jerusalem. And once they approached</b> a place where the <b>young men of Israel</b> were congregated, <b>they would stamp</b> their feet <b>on the ground and splash the perfume toward them and instill the evil inclination into them like venom of a viper [<i>ke’eres bakhos</i>].</b>
<b>What was their punishment</b> for these sins? <b>As Rabba bar Ulla taught: “And it shall come to pass that instead of a sweet smell, there shall be a stench;</b> and instead of a belt, a rope; and instead of well-set hair, baldness; and instead of a fine dress, a girding of sackcloth; instead of beauty, a brand” (Isaiah 3:24). <br>He explains: “And it shall come to pass that instead of a sweet smell there shall be a stench,” indicates that <b>the place that they would perfume became decaying sores.</b><br><b>“And instead of a sash, a rope [<i>nikpe</i>],”</b> indicates that <b>the place where they were girded with a sash became</b> covered with <b>many bruises</b> [<b><i>nekafim</i></b>].<br><b>“And instead of well-set hair, baldness,”</b> indicates that <b>the place where they would style</b> their hair <b>became bald</b> spots.<br><b>“And instead of a fine dress [<i>petigil</i>], a girding of sackcloth,”</b> indicates that the <b>orifices [<i>petaḥim</i>] that lead to pleasure [<i>gil</i>] will become</b> a place <b>for a girding of sackcloth.</b><br><b>“Instead of beauty, a brand [<i>ki</i>],” Rava said: That is</b> the popular expression <b>that people say: Instead of beauty, a sore [<i>kiva</i>].</b>
With regard to a different verse: <b>“The Lord will smite with a scab the crown of the head of the daughters of Zion</b> and the Lord will lay bare their secret parts” (Isaiah 3:17). And the Lord will smite with a scab the crown of the heads of the daughters of Zion; <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: This teaches that there was an outbreak of leprosy among them. It is written here, scab [<i>sippaḥ</i>], and it is written there,</b> among the types of leprosy: <b>“For a sore, and for a scab [<i>sappaḥat</i>],</b> and for a bright spot” (Leviticus 14:56).
With regard to the verse: <b>And the Lord will lay bare their secret parts [<i>pot’hen ye’areh</i>], Rav and Shmuel</b> disagree. <b>One says:</b> It means <b>that they,</b> i.e., their innards, <b>were poured out [<i>ye’areh</i>] like a jug. And one says: That their orifices [<i>pitḥeihen</i>] were</b> covered with hair as thick <b>as a forest [<i>ya’ar</i>].</b>
On the topic of the sins of Jerusalem and the abundance that existed before its destruction, <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: The people of Jerusalem were people of arrogance.</b> They would couch their crude behavior in euphemisms. <b>A person would say to another: On what did you dine today? Well-kneaded bread or bread that is not well-kneaded? On white wine or</b>

Daf 63a

<b>on black wine?</b> Sitting <b>on a wide divan or on a narrow divan? With a good friend or a bad friend? And Rav Ḥisda said: And all these</b> allude <b>to promiscuity.</b> These are all euphemisms for different types of women. Well-kneaded bread refers to a woman who is not a virgin; white wine refers to a fair-complexioned woman; a wide divan refers to a fat woman; a good friend refers to a good-looking woman.
On the topic of Jerusalem, <b>Raḥava said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: The logs of Jerusalem</b> used for fuel <b>were from</b> the <b>cinnamon</b> tree, <b>and when they would ignite them, their fragrance would waft through all of Eretz Yisrael. And since Jerusalem was destroyed, these</b> fragrant logs <b>were buried, and only a</b> sliver the size of a grain of <b>barley remains, and it is located in the treasury of [<i>gazzai</i>] Tzimtzemai the queen.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Just as it is prohibited for a woman to carry out certain items unique to a woman into the public domain, the Sages said that <b>a man may neither go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with a sword, nor with a bow, nor with a shield [<i>teris</i>], nor with an <i>alla</i>, nor with a spear. And if he</b> unwittingly <b>went out</b> with one of these weapons to the public domain <b>he is liable to bring a sin-offering.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says: These</b> weapons <b>are ornaments for him;</b> just as a man is permitted to go out into the public domain with other ornaments, he is permitted to go out with weapons.
<b>And the Rabbis say: They are nothing other than reprehensible</b> and in the future they will be eliminated, <b>as it is written: “And they shall beat their swords into plowshares and their spears into pruning hooks; nation will not raise sword against nation, neither will they learn war anymore”</b> (Isaiah 2:4).
With regard to women’s ornaments, they added that <b>a garter</b> placed on her leg to hold up stockings <b>is pure</b> and cannot become ritually impure as a utensil, <b>and she may</b> even <b>go out with it on Shabbat.</b>
However, <b>ankle chains,</b> which were also women’s ornaments, can become ritually <b>impure, and she may not go out with them on Shabbat.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the term <b><i>alla</i>?</b> It means <b>club [<i>kulpa</i>].</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: These</b> weapons <b>are ornaments for him. It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that elaborates on this subject: The Rabbis <b>said to Rabbi Eliezer: And since,</b> in your opinion, <b>they are ornaments for him, why are they</b> to be <b>eliminated in the messianic era? He said to them: They will not be needed</b> anymore, <b>as it is stated: “Nation will not raise sword against nation”</b> (Isaiah 2:4). The Gemara asks: <b>And let the weapons be merely for ornamental</b> purposes, even though they will not be needed for war. <b>Abaye said:</b> It is <b>just as in</b> the case of <b>a candle in the afternoon.</b> Since its light is not needed, it serves no ornamental purpose. Weapons, too; when not needed for war, they serve no ornamental purpose either.
<b>And</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>disagrees with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, as Shmuel said: The only difference between this world and the messianic era is subjugation of the exiles</b> to other kingdoms, from which the Jewish people will be released. However, in other respects, the world will remain as it is, <b>as it is written: “Because the poor will not cease from within the land”</b> (Deuteronomy 15:11). Society will not change, and wars will continue to be waged.
However, <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba</b> who disagrees with Shmuel. <b>As Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said: All of the prophets only prophesied with regard to the messianic era; however, with regard to the World-to-Come</b> it was stated: <b>“No eye sees, God, except You,</b> that which He will do for he that waits for Him” (Isaiah 64:3). What will be in the World-to-Come cannot be depicted even by means of prophecy.
<b>And some say</b> the disagreement between Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis was different. <b>They said to Rabbi Eliezer: Since</b> in your opinion <b>they are ornaments for him</b>, <b>why will they be eliminated in the messianic era? He said to them: Even in the messianic era they will not be eliminated. And that is</b> in accordance with <b>that which Shmuel</b> stated that the world will remain fundamentally the same, <b>and</b> he <b>disagrees with Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba.</b>
<b>Abaye said to Rav Dimi, and some say</b> it was <b>to Rav Avya, and some say Rav Yosef said to Rav Dimi, and some say</b> it was <b>to Rav Avya, and some say Abaye said to Rav Yosef: What is the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer who said: These</b> weapons <b>are ornaments for him? As it is written: “Gird your sword upon your thigh, mighty one, your glory and your splendor”</b> (Psalms 45:4), indicating that a sword is considered an ornament.
The Gemara relates that some time later <b>Rav Kahana said to Mar, son of Rav Huna:</b> Is that really a proof? <b>This</b> verse <b>is written in reference to matters of Torah</b> and should be interpreted as a metaphor. <b>He said to him:</b> Nevertheless, <b>a verse does not depart from its literal meaning,</b> although there may be additional homiletical interpretations.
<b>Rav Kahana said</b> about this: <b>When I was eighteen years old and</b> had already <b>learned the entire Talmud, and</b> yet <b>I did not know that a verse does not depart from its literal meaning until now.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Rav Kahana <b>teaching us</b> with that statement? The Gemara answers: He comes to teach <b>that a person should</b> first <b>learn and then understand</b> the rationale.
<b><i>Zarot</i></b> is a <b>mnemonic</b> acronym for Elazar [<i>zayin</i>], Reish Lakish [<i>reish</i>], and their students [<i>vav</i>, <i>tav</i>], the <i>amoraim</i> who interpreted the verse in Psalms cited above
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar said: Two Torah scholars who sharpen one another in <i>halakha</i>; the Holy One, Blessed be He,</b> ensures <b>success for them, as it is written: “And in your majesty [<i>vahadarkha</i>] prosper,</b> ride on, in behalf of truth and meekness and righteousness; and let your right hand teach you tremendous things” (Psalms 45:5). The Sages said: <br><b>Do not read “and your majesty [<i>vahadarkha</i>],” rather,</b> by changing some of the vocalization and the letters, read it as <b>and He will sharpen you [<i>veḥidedkha</i>],</b> and ultimately you will be successful. <br><b>Moreover, they</b> who act in that manner will <b>rise to prominence, as it is written: “Prosper, ride on.”</b> <br><b>I might have thought even</b> if one engages in the study of Torah <b>not for its own sake;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states: “On behalf of truth.”</b> <br><b>I might have thought</b> that one would be rewarded with prosperity even <b>if he became arrogant;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states: “Meekness</b> and <b>righteousness.”</b> <br><b>And if they do so</b> in the proper manner <b>they merit the Torah that was given with the right hand</b> of the Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>as it is written: “And let your right hand teach you tremendous things”</b> (Psalms 45:5).
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: They are rewarded with the matters stated with regard to the right</b> hand <b>of the Torah. As Rava bar Rav Sheila said and some say Rav Yosef bar Ḥama said</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet said: What is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written, “Length of days is in her right hand and in her left hand are riches and honor”</b> (Proverbs 3:16)? Is that to say, <b>however,</b> that <b>in her right</b> there <b>is length of days, but there are not riches and honor? Rather,</b> it means: <b>Those who relate to it with the</b> skilled <b>right</b> hand, i.e., who study Torah for its own sake and with proper intentions, <b>there is length of days and all the more so riches and honor</b> for them. Whereas, <b>those who relate to it with the</b> unskilled <b>left</b> hand, <b>there are riches and honor; there is not length of days.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Two Torah scholars who are agreeable to each other</b> when engaging <b>in</b> discussions of <b><i>halakha</i>, the Holy One, Blessed be He, listens to them, as it is stated: “Then they that feared the Lord spoke [<i>nidberu</i>]</b> one with another; and the Lord hearkened, and heard, and a book of remembrance was written before Him, for them that fear the Lord, and that think upon His name” (Malachi 3:16). <b>And</b> the term <b>speech</b> [<b><i>dibbur</i></b>] <b>means nothing other than calm, as it is stated: “He subdues [<i>yadber</i>] people under us”</b> (Psalms 47:4). He will cause the nations to submit to the Jewish people leading to a period of calm. Here too the term <i>dibbur</i> indicates calm and agreeability.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase in that verse: <b>“And that think upon His name”? Rabbi Ami said: Even if one</b> merely <b>planned to perform a mitzva, and</b> ultimately <b>due to circumstances beyond his control did not perform</b> that mitzva, <b>the verse ascribes him</b> credit <b>as if he performed it.</b>
The Gemara continues in praise of those who perform mitzvot: <b>Rav Ḥinnana bar Idi said: Anyone who performs a mitzva as it was commanded,</b> others <b>do not apprise him</b> of <b>bad tidings, as it is stated: “He who keeps the commandment shall know no evil thing”</b> (Ecclesiastes 8:5).
<b>Rav Asi, and some say Rabbi Ḥanina said: Even if the Holy One, Blessed be He, issued a decree, He</b> may <b>abrogate it, as it is stated: “For the word of the King has authority and who may say to Him: What do You do?”</b> (Ecclesiastes 8:4). <b>And,</b> although this indicates that even though the King, God, issued a decree, <b>juxtaposed to it</b> is the verse: <b>“He who guards the commandment shall know no evil thing”</b> (Ecclesiastes 8:5). For one who observes mitzvot properly, the decree is abrogated and he will know no evil.
<b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Two Torah scholars who listen to each other in</b> the discussion of <b><i>halakha</i>, the Holy One, Blessed be He, hears their voice, as it is stated: “You who dwell in gardens, the companions heed your voice, cause me to hear it”</b> (Song of Songs 8:13).
<b>And if they do not do so,</b> i.e., they do not listen to each other, <b>they cause the Divine Presence to depart from</b> among <b>Israel, as it is stated</b> in the following verse: <b>“Run away, my beloved, and be like</b> a gazelle or a young hart upon the mountains of spices” (Song of Songs 8:14).
<b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Two</b> individual <b>Torah scholars who,</b> while studying together, <b>cause one another to err [<i>madgilim</i>] in <i>halakha</i></b> [<i>Tosafot</i>], nevertheless, <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, loves them, as it is stated: “And his banner [<i>vediglo</i>] over me is love”</b> (Song of Songs 2:4). <b>Rava said: And that is</b> only true in a case <b>where they know the foundation of the law,</b> and their error resulted from the lack of more sophisticated knowledge. <b>And that is</b> only true in a case <b>where they do not have a prominent</b> person <b>in the city from whom</b> they could <b>learn</b> without error.
<b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: One who loans</b> another <b>money is greater than one who gives</b> him <b>charity. And the one who places</b> money <b>into</b> a common <b>purse,</b> i.e., one who enters into a partnership with a needy person, <b>is the greatest of them all,</b> since in that case the needy person is not embarrassed when receiving the assistance.
<b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said:</b> Even <b>if a Torah scholar is as vengeful and begrudging as a snake, wrap him</b> tightly around <b>your waist,</b> i.e., keep him close, because you will benefit from his Torah. On the other hand, even <b>if an <i>am ha’aretz</i> is righteous, do not dwell in his neighborhood,</b> as his righteousness does not compensate for the fact that he is ignorant.
<b>Rav Kahana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said, and some say Rav Asi said</b> that <b>Reish Lakish said, and some say Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Anyone who raises an evil dog within his home prevents kindness from</b> entering <b>into his home,</b> since poor people will hesitate to enter his house. As it is alluded to in the verse: <b>“To him that is afflicted [<i>lamas</i>],</b>

Daf 63b

<b>kindness from his friend</b> and awe of the Almighty will leave” (Job 6:14), <b>since in the Greek language they call a dog <i>lamas</i>. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> One who keeps an evil dog in his home <b>even divests himself of fear of Heaven, as it is stated</b> at the end of that verse: <b>“And awe of the Almighty will leave.”</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>A certain</b> pregnant <b>woman who entered to</b> use the oven in a <b>certain house to bake, the dog</b> in that house <b>barked at her, and her fetus was displaced. The owner of the house said to her: Do not be afraid because his teeth have been removed and his claws have been removed. She said to him: Take your goodness and throw it on the thorns.</b> Your encouragement is useless as the <b>fetus has already been displaced</b> and will certainly die.
On a related note, <b>Rav Huna said: What is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written: “Rejoice young man in your youth, and let your heart cheer you in the days of your youth, and walk in the ways of your heart and in the sight of your eyes; but know that for all these things God will bring you to judgment”</b> (Ecclesiastes 11:9)? <b>Until here,</b> “the sight of your eyes,” these are <b>the words of the evil inclination; from here on,</b> “but know that, etc.,” these are <b>the words of the good inclination.</b>
<b>Reish Lakish said: Until here,</b> the verse refers <b>to matters of Torah.</b> One is provided the opportunity to study and involve himself in the Torah and rejoice in its innovations; <b>from here on,</b> “but know that, etc.,” <b>it refers to good deeds.</b> One will ultimately stand trial for that which he studied and did not implement.
We learned in the mishna that <b>a garter is pure. Rav Yehuda said: Garter; that is a bracelet</b> worn on the arm.
<b>Rav Yosef raised an objection:</b> It is stated here that <b>a garter is pure and</b> a woman <b>may go out with it on Shabbat, while a bracelet is ritually impure.</b> It is mentioned explicitly in the verse enumerating the spoils of the war with the Midianites: “And we have brought the Lord’s offering, what every man has gotten, of jewels of gold, armlets, and bracelets, signet rings, earrings, and girdles, to make atonement for our souls before the Lord” (Numbers 31:50). Earlier in that chapter it is written with regard to the spoils: “Purify yourselves on the third day and on the seventh day both you and your captives” (Numbers 31:19). Apparently, a bracelet can become ritually impure.
<b>Rather, this is what</b> Rav Yehuda <b>is saying: A garter</b> on the leg <b>is in place of a bracelet</b> on the arm. It goes around the leg to hold a stocking in place just as a bracelet goes around the arm. However, unlike a bracelet, a garter cannot become ritually impure because it is not an ornament. It simply holds up the stocking.
The Gemara relates: <b>Ravin and Rav Huna were sitting before Rav Yirmeya. And Rav Yirmeya was sitting and dozing</b> as the two students conversed. <b>And Ravin sat and said:</b> The difference between a garter and ankle chains is that <b>a garter is</b> worn <b>on one</b> leg, <b>and ankle chains</b> are worn <b>on two</b> legs.
<b>Rav Huna said to him: These</b> garters <b>and those</b> ankle chains <b>are</b> both worn <b>on two</b> legs. <b>And</b> when she wears garters on both legs <b>they place a chain between them, and they become</b> vessels with the legal status equal to that of <b>ankle chains.</b>
And Ravin asked: <b>And</b> does <b>the chain that</b> is connected to <b>it render it a vessel?</b> If a garter without a chain is not considered a vessel, why would the addition of a chain render it a vessel that can become ritually impure?
<b>And if you say</b> the reason for this <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani, as Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a metal vessel</b> that <b>makes a sound is</b> considered a vessel and can become <b>ritually impure? As it is stated: “Every thing that passes through the fire, you shall make it pass through the fire,</b> and it shall be clean; nevertheless it shall be purified with the water of sprinkling; and all that does not pass through the fire you shall make to go through water” (Numbers 31:23). And the Sages interpret the verse homiletically: Every thing [<i>davar</i>], <b>even speech [<i>dibbur</i>];</b> in other words, even an object that makes a sound shall pass through fire to become purified because it is a vessel.
However, this case is not similar. <b>Granted, there, they require</b> the vessel <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>its sound and it performs an action.</b> However, <b>here, what action does</b> the chain <b>perform?</b> Although it creates a sound, the chain serves no purpose.
He said to him: <b>Here, too,</b> the <b>chain is performing a</b> purposeful <b>action,</b> as <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: There was one family in Jerusalem whose</b> daughters’ <b>strides were lengthy, and</b> as a result <b>their hymen</b> membranes <b>would fall</b> away. In order to solve this problem they made them ankle chains <b>and they hung a chain between them so that their strides would not be</b> so <b>large and,</b> indeed, <b>their hymen</b> membranes <b>would no</b> longer <b>fall</b> away. Meanwhile, <b>Rabbi Yirmeya awoke from their</b> voices <b>and said to them: Correct, and Rabbi Yoḥanan said likewise.</b>
On the topic of ritual impurity, the Gemara relates: <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he</b> said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a woven fabric of any size</b> can <b>become</b> ritually impure? It is derived <b>from the frontplate [<i>tzitz</i>]</b> of the High Priest, which is considered a vessel despite its small size.
<b>Abaye said to him: And is the frontplate a woven fabric? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The frontplate is</b> made <b>like a kind of</b> smooth <b>plate of gold, and</b> its <b>width is two fingerbreadths, and it encircles</b> the forehead <b>from ear to ear. And on it is written in two lines: <i>Yod heh</i>,</b> i.e., the Tetragrammaton, <b>above, and <i>kodesh lamed</i>,</b> i.e., sacred to, <b>below.</b> Thus, the words: Sacred to God, were written on the frontplate. In deference to the name of God, it would be written on the top line, and the words: Sacred to, on the line below.
<b>And Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: I saw it</b> in the Caesar’s treasury <b>in the city of Rome and Sacred to God was written on one line.</b> In any case, since the frontplate is a gold plate, how can it serve as a source for ritual impurity in fabrics?
<b>When Rav Dimi ascended to Neharde’a, he sent to</b> the yeshiva students: <b>The statements I said to you</b> with regard to woven fabrics of any size becoming ritually impure regardless of their size, <b>they are my mistake. However, this</b> is what <b>they said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: From where</b> is it derived <b>that an ornament of any size</b> can become <b>ritually impure?</b> It is derived <b>from the frontplate. And from where</b> is it derived <b>that a woven fabric of any size</b> can become <b>ritually impure?</b> It is derived <b>from</b> the verse: <b>“Or a garment</b> or leather or sack; any vessel with which any work is done must be put into water and it shall be unclean until evening, then it shall be clean” (Leviticus 11:32). From the extraneous phrase, “or a garment,” it is derived that any garment, regardless how small, falls into this category.
Similarly, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A woven fabric of any size</b> can become <b>ritually impure, and an ornament of any size</b> can become <b>ritually impure.</b> An object that is half <b>woven</b> fabric <b>and</b> half <b>ornament</b> of <b>any size</b> can become <b>ritually impure.</b> And <b>a sack is added</b> to the category of <b>garment; it</b> too <b>is ritually impure due to woven fabric.</b>
<b>Rava said</b> in explanation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>A woven fabric of any size is ritually impure</b> as derived <b>from</b> the phrase <b>“or a garment.” An ornament of any size is ritually impure,</b> as derived <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the frontplate. A woven fabric and an ornament of any size is ritually impure,</b> as derived <b>from</b> that which is stated: “And Moses and Elazar the priest took the gold from them, <b>all vessels with which labor is done”</b> (Numbers 31:51). Any object that can be utilized for any action falls into the category of: All vessels with which labor is done.
<b>One of the Sages said to Rava: That</b> verse <b>is written with regard to Midian.</b> There it is referring specifically to ritual impurity imparted by a corpse, and how is it possible to derive from that <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity in general?
<b>Rava said to him: He derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy

Daf 64a

<b>from</b> the word <b>vessel</b> written <b>there,</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity imparted by a corpse, and the word <b>vessel</b> written with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of other impurities.
It was taught in the <i>baraita</i> that <b>a sack is added</b> to the category of “<b>garment”; it</b> too <b>is ritually impure due to woven fabric.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that a garment is not a woven fabric?</b> Rather, the statement should be emended and <b>say as follows: A sack</b> made from goat hair <b>is added to the category of garment; even though it is not woven it</b> can nevertheless become <b>ritually impure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what is</b> a garment made of unwoven goat hair <b>suitable? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Since a poor person</b> occasionally <b>braids three</b> goat <b>hairs and hangs it on his daughter’s neck</b> as an ornament.
<b>The Sages taught</b> a detailed halakhic exposition of that verse in a different <i>baraita</i>. From the fact that the verse mentioned <b>sack, I have only</b> derived that <b>a</b> whole <b>sack</b> can become ritually impure. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include</b> even <b>reins [<i>kilkeli</i>] and a saddle band</b> fastened under the horse’s belly in the category of those objects that can become ritually impure? <b>The verse states: “Or sack”;</b> “or” teaches that the verse is referring to items similar to a sack as well. <b>I might</b> have thought, on that basis, <b>that I</b> should <b>include</b> even <b>the ropes and</b> measuring <b>cords. The verse states: “Sack,” just as a sack is spun and woven, so too, everything that is spun and woven</b> can become ritually impure. Ropes and measuring cords are not made from spun threads, and they are certainly not woven.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Now, it says with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse:</b> “And every garment <b>and all that is made of skins and all work of goats’</b> hair and all things made of wood <b>you shall purify”</b> (Numbers 31:20). This verse comes <b>to include reins and the band</b> under the horse’s belly within the category of: All work of goats’ hair. They too can become ritually impure.
I <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> would <b>include even the ropes and</b> thin <b>cords</b> in this category. The Gemara begins with a logical analysis. <b>And it</b> may be inferred <b>logically</b> to the contrary, that a rope cannot become impure. The verse <b>deemed impure</b> an object that came in contact <b>with a creeping animal, and it deemed impure</b> an object that came in contact <b>with a corpse. Just as when it rendered</b> an object <b>impure from</b> contact <b>with a creeping animal it only rendered impure</b> objects <b>spun and woven,</b> as stated above; <b>so too, when it rendered impure</b> an object from contact <b>with a corpse, it only rendered impure</b> objects <b>spun and woven.</b>
There is room to distinguish: Are these <b>indeed</b> comparable? <b>If</b> the Torah <b>was lenient with regard to the ritual impurity of</b> an object that came in contact <b>with a creeping animal, which is a less severe</b> form of impurity, saying that ropes do not become impure from contact with that form of ritual impurity, <b>will we be lenient with regard to ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse, which is</b> more <b>severe?</b> Perhaps, since impurity imparted by a corpse is more severe, even objects not woven and spun, e.g., ropes, become ritually impure from contact with it. Therefore, <b>the verse states garment and leather, garment and leather to</b> establish <b>a verbal analogy.</b>
The term <b>garment and leather is stated with regard to</b> ritual impurity imparted by <b>a creeping animal:</b> “And whatever any of them falls upon when they are dead will be impure whether it be any vessel of wood, or a garment, or leather, or sack, whatever vessel it be with which any work is done it must be put into water and it will be impure until evening, then it will be clean” (Leviticus 11:32). <b>And garment and leather is stated with regard to</b> ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse. Just as garment and leather stated with regard to a creeping animal only rendered impure</b> objects that are <b>spun and woven, so too, garment and leather stated with regard to a corpse only rendered impure</b> objects that are <b>spun and woven.</b>
Utilizing the same verbal analogy, one could say: <b>And just as garment and leather stated with regard to a corpse rendered impure any</b> object that is the <b>work of goats’</b> hair, <b>so too, garment and leather stated with regard to a creeping animal rendered impure any</b> object that is the <b>work of goats’</b> hair.
<b>I have only</b> derived from this verbal analogy that <b>an object that comes from goats</b> can become ritually impure; <b>from where</b> do I derive <b>to include an item that comes from a horse’s tail or from a cow’s tail? The verse states: Or a sack,</b> and anything like a sack, i.e., these other items as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t you</b> already <b>derive</b> ritual impurity with regard to <b>reins and a saddle band</b> from this verse? How can ritual impurity for items that come from a horse’s tail and a cow’s tail be derived from the same verse?
The Gemara answers: <b>That applies only before the verbal analogy was cited; now that the verbal analogy was cited,</b> the verse <b>is rendered extraneous.</b> The fact that any item that falls in the category of: “And all work of goats’ hair,” can become ritually impure is derived from the verbal analogy. Reins and a saddle bands are included in the category of work of goats’ hair. Therefore, they need not be derived from that phrase. Consequently, a different <i>halakha</i> can be derived from that extraneous phrase: Objects that come from a horse’s tail or a cow’s tail can become ritually impure.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And I have</b> derived that an object made from a horse’s tail can become impure <b>only with regard to a creeping animal;</b> however, <b>with regard to a corpse, from where</b> is this derived?
The Gemara begins with a logical analysis. <b>And it</b> may be inferred <b>logically</b> that this is so. The Torah <b>rendered impure</b> a sack that came into contact <b>with a corpse and rendered impure</b> a sack that came into contact <b>with a creeping animal. Just as when</b> the Torah <b>rendered</b> items that came into contact <b>with a creeping animal impure it made</b> the legal status of <b>that which comes from a horse’s tail and a cow’s tail equal to</b> the legal status of <b>that which is made from goats’</b> hair, i.e., that it contracts ritual impurity, <b>so too when</b> the Torah <b>rendered impure</b> items that came into contact <b>with a corpse, it made</b> the legal status of <b>that which comes from a horse’s tail and a cow’s tail equal to</b> the legal status of <b>that which is made from goats’</b> hair.
The Gemara rejects this: Are these <b>indeed</b> comparable? <b>If</b> the verse <b>added</b> additional objects <b>to</b> the category of <b>ritual impurity</b> that lasts until <b>nightfall,</b> e.g., the impurity imparted by a creeping animal, <b>which is extensive, will we add</b> additional objects <b>to</b> the category of <b>ritual impurity that lasts for seven days, which is limited</b> to the case of impurity from a corpse? The fact that items made of a horse’s tail or a cow’s tail are added to the already broad category of ritual impurity that lasts until nightfall is not necessarily an indication that they are to be added to the category of ritual impurity that lasts seven days.
<b>The verse states: Garment and leather, garment and leather to</b> establish <b>a verbal analogy. Garment and leather is stated with regard to</b> ritual impurity imparted by <b>a creeping animal, and garment and leather is stated with regard to</b> ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse. Just as</b> with regard to the <b>garment and leather stated in</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a creeping animal</b> the Torah <b>rendered</b> the legal status of <b>an item made from a horse’s tail or a cow’s tail equal to</b> the legal status of <b>that which is made from goats’</b> hair, <b>so too,</b> with regard to the <b>garment and leather stated in</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a corpse,</b> the Torah <b>rendered</b> the legal status of <b>an item made from a horse’s tail or a cow’s tail equal to</b> the legal status of <b>that which is made from goats’</b> hair.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> it must be that the words garment and leather are <b>free.</b> Those terms must be superfluous in their context. The Torah included those terms for the express purpose of establishing the verbal analogy. A verbal analogy that is based on otherwise extraneous terms cannot be logically refuted. <b>Because if</b> these terms are <b>not free,</b> the verbal analogy <b>can be refuted: What</b> is unique <b>to a creeping animal?</b> Its ritual impurity is stringent <b>in that</b> it <b>renders</b> objects <b>ritually impure</b> even <b>by means of</b> contact with <b>a lentil-bulk</b> of a creeping animal. That is not the case with regard to a corpse, which is less severe in that it renders objects ritually impure only by means of contact with an olive-bulk of a corpse. Unless the terms are free, the analogy can be refuted.
<b>Indeed [<i>la’ei</i>], they are free.</b> The Gemara proves that the terms garment and leather are extraneous in their context. <b>Now, since</b> ritual impurity from contact with <b>a creeping animal is juxtaposed to</b> ritual impurity from contact with <b>semen, as it is written:</b> “And whoever touches anything that is impure by the dead or a <b>man from whom semen is emitted”</b> (Leviticus 22:4), <b>and juxtaposed to that</b> is the verse: <b>“Or whoever touches any creeping animal</b> which makes him impure, or a person who may make him impure with any impurity that he has” (Leviticus 22:5). <b>And it is written</b> in the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of</b> the ritual impurity of <b>semen: “And every garment and every hide on which the semen is</b> must be washed with water and will be impure until evening” (Leviticus 15:17). Since the verses appear next to each other, the <i>halakhot</i> of each can be derived from the other. Consequently, the words <b>garment and leather, which the Torah wrote with regard to a creeping animal, why do I need</b> them? The relevant <i>halakha</i> could be derived from the <i>halakhot</i> of seminal impurity. <b>Learn from it</b> that garment and leather were mentioned <b>to render them free.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And still, it is free only from one side</b> of the verbal analogy. Although the terms garment and leather stated with regard to ritual impurity imparted by a creeping animal are extraneous in their context, and the relevant <i>halakha</i> could have been derived in another manner, those terms stated with regard to ritual impurity imparted by a corpse are not extraneous in their context. This verbal analogy is only free from one side. <b>It</b> works out <b>well according to the</b> opinion of the <b>one who said,</b> with regard to a verbal analogy that is <b>free from</b> only <b>one side, one can derive from it and cannot refute</b> it logically. <b>However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that <b>one can derive from</b> a verbal analogy of this kind <b>and one can refute</b> it logically, <b>what can be said?</b>
The Gemara answers: Garment and leather stated <b>with regard to</b> impurity imparted by a <b>corpse are also free. Now, since a corpse is juxtaposed with semen, as it is written: “And whoever touches anything that is impure by the dead or a man whose semen is emitted from him”</b> (Leviticus 22:4); <b>and it is stated with regard to semen: “And every garment and every hide”</b> (Leviticus 15:17); the terms <b>garment and leather, which the Torah wrote with regard to</b> ritual impurity imparted by <b>a corpse, why do I</b> need them? <b>Learn from it</b> that they are mentioned in order <b>to render them free.</b> These terms are extraneous in their context, and were written for the purpose of the verbal analogy with the <i>halakhot</i> of creeping animals.
The Gemara interprets verses written with regard to the Midianite war discussed above: <b>“And we have brought an offering before the Lord what every man has gotten of jewels of gold, chains, and bracelets, rings, <i>agil</i>, and <i>kumaz</i>,</b> to make atonement for our souls before the Lord” (Numbers 31:50). <b>Rabbi Elazar said: <i>Agil</i> is a mold</b> in the shape of a woman’s <b>breasts</b> worn over them as an ornament. <b><i>Kumaz</i> is a mold</b> in the shape <b>of the womb.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: If so, that is</b> the reason <b>that we translate</b> <i>kumaz</i> into Aramaic as <b><i>maḥokh</i>,</b> meaning <b>an item that leads to foolishness. Rabba said to him: This</b> meaning <b>is learned from the verse itself; <i>kumaz</i></b> is an acronym for: <b>Here [<i>kan</i>]</b> is the <b>place of [<i>mekom</i>] lewdness [<i>zimma</i>].</b>
Later in that chapter, it is written: <b>“And Moses was angry with the officers of the host,</b> the captains over thousands, and captains over hundreds, who came from the battle” (Numbers 31:14); <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said</b> that <b>Moses said to Israel: Perhaps you have returned to your original sinful</b> behavior, when you sinned with the daughters of Moab and Midian at Shittim? <b>They said to him: “Not one man of us is missing”</b> (Numbers 31:49), we remain as wholesome in deed as we were. <b>He said to them: If so, why</b> do you need <b>atonement?</b> The princes brought these ornaments to atone for their souls. <b>They said to him: If we have emerged from the grasps of</b> actual <b>transgression, we have not emerged from the grasps of thoughts</b> of transgression. <b>Immediately,</b> they decided: <b>“And we have brought an offering before the Lord.”</b>
The Sage <b>of the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: For what</b> reason <b>did Israel in that generation require atonement? Because</b>

Daf 64b

<b>they nourished their eyes from nakedness.</b>
With regard to the verse that lists the ornaments, <b>Rav Sheshet said: For what reason did the verse list outer ornaments,</b> i.e., a bracelet, <b>with inner ornaments,</b> i.e., a <i>kumaz</i>? <b>To tell you</b> that <b>anyone who gazes upon a woman’s little finger</b> is considered <b>as if he gazed upon her</b> naked <b>genitals.</b> The atonement was for the sin of looking.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna continues to discuss those items with which it is permitted to go out and those items with which it is prohibited to go out on Shabbat. <b>A woman may go out with strands of hair</b> that she put on her head, <b>whether</b> they are <b>from her own</b> hair that she made into a wig, <b>or whether</b> they are <b>from</b> the hair of <b>another, or whether they are from</b> the hair of <b>an animal.</b>
<b>And</b> a woman may go out <b>with</b> an ornament called <b><i>totefet</i>, and with <i>sarvitin</i> when they are sewn</b> and will not fall.
She may go out on Shabbat <b>with</b> a <b>woolen cap or with a wig to the courtyard,</b> although not to the public domain. <b>And</b> likewise she may go out <b>with a cloth that is in her ear, and with a cloth in her sandal, and with a cloth that she placed due to her menstrual</b> status.
She may go out on Shabbat <b>with pepper, or with a grain of salt, or anything placed in her mouth</b> for healing or for preventing bad odor, <b>as long as she does not put</b> these objects in her mouth <b>for the first time on Shabbat. And if it fell out she may not replace it.</b>
<b>A false tooth</b> as well as (Ramban) <b>a gold tooth, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permits</b> going out with it, <b>and the Rabbis prohibit</b> doing so.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that a woman may go out with different strands of hair. The Gemara comments: <b>And it is necessary</b> to cite all of the cases. <b>If</b> the mishna <b>taught us only</b> with regard to <b>her own</b> hair, I would have said that she may go out with it <b>because it is not repulsive,</b> as it is her own hair; therefore, there is no concern lest she come to remove the strands and carry them in the public domain. <b>However,</b> the hair <b>of another, which is repulsive</b> and a different color from hers, <b>say no,</b> she may not go out with it, due to concern lest she be embarrassed, remove it, and come to carry it in the public domain.
<b>And if</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> that she is permitted to go out with the hair <b>of another,</b> I would have said that she may go out with it because <b>it is</b> hair <b>of her own kind.</b> Therefore, it is not repulsive in her eyes and she will not come to remove it. <b>However,</b> the hair <b>of an animal,</b> since <b>it is not of her own kind, say no,</b> she may not go out with it due to concern lest she remove it. Therefore, <b>it is necessary</b> to cite all three cases.
<b>It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: It is permitted <b>as long as a girl does not go out with</b> the hair <b>of an elderly woman, and an elderly woman</b> does not go out <b>with</b> the hair <b>of a girl.</b>
