The Gemara challenges: <b>Granted,</b> the Gemara cited the case of <b>an elderly woman</b> who goes out <b>with</b> the hair <b>of a girl,</b> as it is a reasonable scenario because <b>it is flattering for her</b> to look young. <b>However, why</b> would <b>a girl</b> go out <b>with</b> the hair <b>of an elderly woman?</b> Since <b>it is demeaning for her</b> to appear elderly, it is an unlikely scenario. The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the mishna <b>taught</b> the case of <b>an elderly woman with</b> the hair <b>of a girl, it also taught</b> the improbable case of <b>a girl with</b> the hair <b>of an elderly woman.</b>
It was taught in the mishna that a woman may go out <b>with a woolen cap or with a wig to the courtyard. Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>all</b> ornaments and garments with <b>which the Sages prohibited going out into the public domain</b> on Shabbat, <b>it is</b> also <b>prohibited to go out with</b> them <b>into the courtyard</b> due to the concern lest she forget and go out to the street, <b>with the exception of a woolen cap and a wig.</b>
<b>Rabbi Anani bar Sason said in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: All</b> ornaments have the same legal status <b>as a woolen cap</b> and may be worn into the courtyard.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna that it is permitted to go out <b>with a woolen cap or a wig into the courtyard. Granted, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav</b> the matter works out <b>well,</b> as the mishna allows one to go out into a courtyard only with a woolen cap and a wig. <b>However, according to the opinion of Rabbi Anani bar Sason,</b> it is <b>difficult.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>In whose name did Rabbi Anani bar Sason say</b> his <i>halakha</i>? <b>In the name of Rabbi Yishmael bar Yosei, and Rabbi Yishmael bar Yosei is a <i>tanna</i> and,</b> as such, has the authority <b>to dispute</b> the determination in the mishna.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rav, what is different</b> about <b>these,</b> the woolen cap and the wig, that the mishna permitted going out into the courtyard with them? <b>Ulla said: So that she will not become unappealing to her husband.</b> That would be the result if all ornamentation was prohibited. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“And of her that is sick in her menstrual status [<i>niddata</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 15:33), <b>the Elders</b> of the <b>early</b> generations <b>said</b> that this verse comes to teach us that the menstruating woman should be distanced from her husband in all senses, like a person ostracized [<i>menudeh</i>] by the Sages. This includes <b>that she may not paint</b> her eyes <b>blue</b>, <b>and she may not rouge [<i>pokeset</i>]</b> her face, <b>and she may not adorn herself with colorful clothing. Until Rabbi Akiva came and taught: If</b> you do <b>so, you are making her unappealing to her husband, and her husband will</b> consequently <b>divorce her.</b> Therefore, extreme strictures should not be instituted. <b>Rather, what</b> is the meaning of that which <b>the verse states: “And of her that is sick in her menstrual status”? She shall remain</b> prohibited <b>in her menstrual status</b> even after the flow of blood has stopped <b>until she immerses in the water</b> of a ritual bath.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Wherever the Sages prohibited</b> an action <b>due to the appearance</b> of prohibition, <b>even in the innermost chambers,</b> where no one will see it, it <b>is prohibited.</b> When prohibiting an action, the Sages did not distinguish between different circumstances. They prohibited performing the action in all cases.
The Gemara raises an objection. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that an animal belonging to a Jew may <b>not</b> go out on Shabbat <b>with a bell</b> around its neck, <b>even though it is plugged</b> and makes no sound, due to the appearance of prohibition, as it appears as if he were taking the animal to the marketplace. <b>And it was taught in another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>He may plug the bell on</b> the animal’s <b>neck and walk with it in the courtyard.</b> Apparently, although the Sages prohibited this action due to the appearance of prohibition, they permitted it in the courtyard.
The Gemara answers: <b>It is</b> subject to a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> in this matter, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 65a

One whose clothes fell into water on a Festival may not dry them in the conventional manner; however, <b>he may spread them out in the sun, but not before the people,</b> who may suspect that he laundered his clothes on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Shimon prohibit</b> doing so even in a place concealed from view. Apparently, the Sages disagree whether or not an action prohibited due to the appearance of prohibition is prohibited everywhere.
We learned in the mishna that a woman may go out on Shabbat <b>with a cloth that is in her ear. Rami bar Yeḥezkel taught: And that is</b> specifically in a case <b>where</b> the cloth <b>is tied to her ear</b> and she will not come to carry it.
The mishna continues: A woman may go out <b>with a cloth that is in her sandal. Rami bar Yeḥezkel taught: And that is</b> specifically in a case <b>where</b> the cloth <b>is tied to her sandal.</b>
We learned in the mishna: A woman may go out <b>with a cloth that she placed due to her menstrual</b> flow. <b>Rami bar Ḥama considered saying that</b> it is permitted specifically in a case <b>where it is tied between her thighs. Rava said:</b> It is permitted <b>even though it is not tied to her; since it is repulsive, she will not come to carry it</b> even if it falls.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raised a dilemma before Rabbi Abba: If she made herself a handgrip</b> in which she could hold the cloth, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Since she does not have to touch the cloth with her bare hand, is there concern that she will come to carry it or not? <b>He said to him: It is permitted. It was also stated</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman bar Oshaya said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: If she made herself a handgrip it is permitted.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan went out with</b> a cloth in his ear <b>to the study hall</b> on Shabbat, <b>and his colleagues are in disagreement with him</b> and rule that it is prohibited to do so because it was not tied to his ear. <b>Rabbi Yannai went out with it,</b> a cloth in his ear, <b>to a <i>karmelit</i>,</b> an intermediate domain, neither public nor private. <b>And all</b> the Sages <b>of his generation are in disagreement with him.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rami bar Yeḥezkel teach: And that is</b> specifically in a case <b>where</b> the cloth <b>is tied to her ear?</b> How could these Sages ignore this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult; this,</b> where it was taught that certain Sages went out with a cloth, is in a case <b>where it was</b> stuck <b>tightly</b> in their ears. Therefore, it was permitted even though it was not tied. <b>That,</b> where Rami bar Yeḥezkel said that going out with a cloth is permitted only when it is tied, is in a case <b>where it was not</b> stuck <b>tightly</b> in his ear.
We learned in the mishna: A woman may go out <b>with pepper and with a grain of salt</b> in her mouth. The Gemara explains: She places <b>pepper</b> in her mouth <b>to</b> prevent <b>mouth odor and a grain of salt to</b> treat <b>a toothache.</b> With regard to that which we learned in the mishna: A woman may go out on Shabbat <b>with any thing that she places in her mouth:</b> This refers to <b>ginger</b> or, <b>alternatively,</b> to <b>cinnamon [<i>dartzona</i>].</b>
We learned in the mishna that the Sages disagree whether or not a woman may go out on Shabbat <b>with a false tooth</b> and <b>a gold tooth; Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permits </b>doing so <b>and the Rabbis prohibit</b> doing so. <b>Rabbi Zeira said: They only taught</b> the dispute with regard to a <b>gold</b> tooth. Since it is precious, she might remove it from her mouth to show her friends and come to carry it. <b>However, with regard to a silver</b> tooth, which is less precious, there is no concern that she will remove it from her mouth. <b>Everyone agrees that it is permitted. That</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a tooth made <b>of silver, everyone agrees</b> that it is <b>permitted.</b> With regard to a tooth <b>of gold, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>permits</b> going out with it <b>and the Rabbis prohibit</b> going out with it.
<b>Abaye said: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and Rabbi Eliezer, and Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar all hold that anything that makes her unappealing</b> when removed, <b>she will not come to</b> remove it and <b>show it</b> to others. Therefore, it is permitted for her to go out with it.
The Gemara elaborates: The opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi is <b>that which we</b> just <b>stated.</b> The opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> is <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer exempts</b> a woman who went out <b>with a bundle of fragrant herbs and with a flask of balsam oil,</b> since a woman whose odor is foul does not remove and show the bundle to others.
The opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> is <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar stated a principle: Anything that is</b> worn <b>beneath the net,</b> a woman <b>may go out</b> into the public domain <b>with it,</b> since a woman will not uncover her hair while in the public domain even to show off an ornament. <b>Anything that is</b> worn <b>over the net,</b> e.g., an ornamental hat, a woman <b>may not go out with it,</b> since there is concern that she will remove it and carry it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A woman <b>may go out with a <i>sela</i></b> coin <b>that</b> she ties <b>on a wound on her foot. The young girls may go out with strings, and even with</b> wood <b>chips that are in</b> the holes in <b>their ears</b> so that the holes will not seal. Young girls would have their ears pierced, but earrings were not placed in their ears until they were older. Jewish <b>women</b> in <b>Arab</b> countries <b>may go out veiled,</b> with a scarf covering their face, <b>and</b> Jewish <b>women</b> in <b>Media</b> may go out <b>with cloaks fastened</b> with stones. <b>And, any person</b> in any place is permitted to go out on Shabbat clothed in that way; <b>however, the Sages spoke in the present,</b> addressing prevalent situations. A woman <b>may fasten</b> her cloak <b>on a stone</b> by inserting a small stone and wrapping her cloak around it, as she would with a button. <b>And</b> likewise, she may do so <b>on a nut or on a coin, as long as she does not fasten</b> her cloak with them <b>on Shabbat <i>ab initio</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <b><i>tzinit</i></b> with regard to which the mishna taught that a woman may go out with a coin tied to it on Shabbat? The Gemara explains: It is <b>a wound on the sole of her foot.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different about a <i>sela</i>?</b> Why specifically is a coin placed on the wound? <b>If you say that any object that is hard is beneficial for her, make an earthenware</b> shard <b>for her</b> instead. <b>Rather,</b> it is beneficial <b>due to the rust</b> on the coin. If so, <b>make a</b> small silver <b>plate for her.</b> Why specifically a coin? <b>Rather</b> it is beneficial <b>due to the image</b> engraved on the coin. If so, <b>make her an unminted coin</b> and engrave an image on it. <b>Abaye said: Learn from it that all</b> these factors together <b>are beneficial for her.</b>
The mishna taught that <b>the</b> young <b>girls may go out with strings.</b> The Gemara relates that <b>Shmuel’s father did not allow his daughters to go out with strings, and did not allow them to lie next to each other, and he made ritual baths for them in the days of Nisan and mats</b> in the Euphrates River <b>in the days of Tishrei.</b> Since the water was shallow and the riverbed muddy, he placed mats on the riverbed so that they could immerse without getting dirty.
The Gemara analyzes the conduct of Shmuel’s father: <b>He did not allow them to go out with strings. Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that <b>the girls may go out with strings?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The</b> strings with which the <b>daughters of Shmuel’s father</b> went out <b>were colorful ones,</b> and he was concerned that because the strings were beautiful they would come to remove them to show them to others and carry them.
<b>He did not allow them to lie next to one another. Let us say that this supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna, as Rav Huna said: Women who rub against one another</b> motivated by sexual desire

Daf 65b

<b>are disqualified from</b> marrying into <b>the priesthood.</b> The act renders a woman a <i>zona.</i> It is prohibited for a priest to marry her (<i>Tosafot</i>).
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> that is not necessarily so. Perhaps the reason for Shmuel’s father’s insistence was because <b>he thought</b> to prevent them from lying next to one another <b>so that they</b> would <b>not become accustomed to</b> sleeping with <b>a foreign body,</b> which could stimulate sexual desire.
<b>And he made a ritual bath for them in the days of Nisan. This supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, as Rav said:</b> When <b>rain</b> falls <b>in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>the great witness</b> attesting to that fact <b>is the Euphrates,</b> as the water flow in the Euphrates increases after the rainy season. The rainfall in northern Babylonia, where the source of the Euphrates is located, is essentially parallel to the rainfall in Eretz Yisrael. The increased water flow of the Euphrates in the spring is the result of the rainfall in the winter. Shmuel’s father <b>held</b> that immersion in the Euphrates would not purify them. A river maintains its status as a river in terms of purification through immersion only if it is established <b>that the</b> rain water <b>that fell would not exceed the</b> naturally <b>flowing</b> spring water. In the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual baths, there are two manners of purification. The first is the immersion in a place where water is gathered, e.g., collected rainwater that does not flow and remains in place. The second is immersion in flowing waters in their natural state, e.g., a spring or a river. However, rainwater purifies only when it is collected; it does not purify when it is flowing.
<b>And he disagrees with</b> his son <b>Shmuel, as Shmuel said: The river is blessed from its riverbed</b> (<i>ge’onim</i>); the additional water in the river is not from rainfall but rather from subterranean sources. <b>And</b> this statement of Shmuel <b>disagrees with</b> another ruling that he <b>himself</b> issued, as <b>Shmuel said: The water purifies when flowing only</b> in <b>the Euphrates during the days of Tishrei alone.</b> Since rain does not fall in the summer, only then is it clear that the water is in fact river water.
We learned in the mishna: A woman <b>may fasten</b> her cloak <b>on a stone,</b> and on a nut, and on a coin, as long as she does not fasten her cloak with them <i>ab initio</i> on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t you say in the first clause</b> of this <i>halakha</i> in the mishna that a woman <b>may fasten,</b> indicating that she is permitted to do so even <i>ab initio</i>? How do you explain the contradiction? <b>Abaye said:</b> In <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna <b>we have arrived at</b> the case of <b>a coin,</b> one of the examples cited in the mishna. The <i>halakha</i> with regard to a coin is the exception. Because a coin is set-aside from use on Shabbat, one might conclude that it may not be used at all; nevertheless, it is only prohibited to fasten the cloak on the coin <i>ab initio</i> on Shabbat itself.
<b>Abaye raised a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a case where <b>a woman employs artifice</b> to circumvent the <i>halakha</i> <b>and fastens</b> her garment <b>on a nut</b> in order <b>to take</b> the nut <b>out</b> in a permissible fashion <b>to her young child</b> in the public domain <b>on Shabbat?</b>
The Gemara notes: This is a <b>dilemma according to the one who said that one may employ artifice</b> when there is a fire on Shabbat. One is permitted to wear several layers of garments to take them out of a burning house on Shabbat. And this is a <b>dilemma according to the one who said that one may not employ artifice</b> when there is a fire on Shabbat.
The Gemara elaborates: This is a <b>dilemma according to the one who said that one may employ artifice</b> when there is <b>a fire</b> on Shabbat, as the cases are distinct. Perhaps <b>there,</b> artifice <b>is</b> permitted <b>because if you do not permit</b> him to take the garments out of the burning house in that manner, <b>he will come to extinguish</b> the fire. <b>However, here, if you do not permit</b> the woman to employ artifice and take the nut out to her child in the public domain, <b>she will not come to take it out.</b>
<b>Or perhaps, even according to one who said that one may not employ artifice in</b> the case of <b>a fire,</b> there is a distinction between the cases. <b>There,</b> in the case of a fire, wearing garments <b>is the typical manner</b> in which one takes clothing out to the public domain. <b>However, here,</b> utilizing a nut as a button <b>is not the typical manner</b> in which one takes a nut out to the public domain. Since no Torah prohibition is violated by doing so, <b>say</b> that she may <b>well</b> employ artifice to take the nut out to her son. The Gemara concludes: <b>Let</b> this dilemma <b>stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One with an amputated leg may go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with his wooden leg,</b> as it has the legal status of a shoe; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>

Daf 66a

<b>And Rabbi Yosei prohibits</b> going out into the public domain with the wooden leg, since he does not consider it to have the legal status of a shoe.
<b>And if</b> the wooden leg <b>has a receptacle</b> for <b>pads,</b> a concave space at the top of the leg into which pads are placed to cushion the amputated leg, it assumes the status of a wooden vessel and can become <b>ritually impure.</b>
And <b>his supports,</b> which are shoes that one who had both of his feet amputated places on his knees in order to walk on his knees, if a <i>zav</i> wears them, they are subject to <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading.</b> A <i>zav</i> is a primary source of ritual impurity. If he touches a vessel it assumes first-degree ritual impurity status. However, vessels on which he treads, sits, lies, or leans become primary sources of ritual impurity, provided they are designated for that purpose. These supports are vessels designated for treading. <b>And one may go out with them</b> into the public domain <b>on Shabbat</b> since they have the legal status of shoes. <b>And one may enter the Temple courtyard with them.</b> Although, generally, wearing shoes in the Temple courtyard is prohibited, in this regard, the supports do not have the legal status of shoes.
However, if one who is crippled to the extent that he cannot walk at all sits on a chair that is attached to him, places supports on his hands, and propels himself along with his hands, <b>his chair and supports are</b> subject to <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading. And one may not go out with them on Shabbat, and one may not enter the Temple courtyard with them.</b>
<b><i>Loketamin</i>,</b> which will be explained in the Gemara, <b>are ritually pure</b> in the sense that they cannot become ritually impure because they are not vessels, <b>and one may not go out with them</b> on Shabbat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman: How did we learn</b> the dispute in our mishna? Does Rabbi Meir rule that the amputee may go out with a wooden leg and foot and Rabbi Yosei prohibits him from doing so? Or is it Rabbi Meir who prohibited him from doing so, and Rabbi Yosei’s opinion is the lenient one? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: I don’t know.</b> And Rava asked: <b>What is the <i>halakha</i></b> in this matter? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: I don’t know.</b>
<b>It was stated: Shmuel said</b> that the correct reading of the mishna is: <b>An amputee may not</b> go out, and Rabbi Yosei permits him to do so. <b>And, likewise, Rav Huna said</b> that the correct reading of the mishna is: <b>An amputee may not. Rav Yosef said: Since Shmuel said</b> that the correct reading of the mishna is: <b>An amputee may not, and Rav Huna said: An amputee may not, we will also learn</b> the mishna: <b>An amputee may not.</b>
<b>Rava bar Shira strongly objects to this:</b> And <b>did they not hear that Rav Ḥanan bar Rava taught</b> the mishna <b>to Ḥiyya bar Rav before Rav in a small room [<i>kituna</i>] in</b> the <b>school of Rav: An amputee may not go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with his wooden leg;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And Rabbi Yosei permits</b> going out with it. <b>And Rav signaled him</b> with a hand gesture to <b>reverse</b> the opinions, Rabbi Meir permits going out and Rabbi Yosei prohibits doing so. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: And the mnemonic</b> to remember which <i>tanna</i> permits and which <i>tanna</i> prohibits is <b><i>samekh samekh</i>.</b> The letter <i>samekh</i> appears both in the name Yosei and in the Hebrew word for prohibits [<i>oser</i>]. In that way, one remembers that Rabbi Yosei is the one who prohibits it.
The Gemara comments: <b>And even Shmuel,</b> who said that the correct reading of the mishna is: An amputee may not, and Rabbi Yosei permits it, <b>reversed</b> his opinion. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: The <i>ḥalitza</i> ceremony, which frees a childless widow from the obligation to enter into levirate marriage with her brother-in-law, involves the widow removing her brother-in-law’s sandal from his foot. If <b>she removed a sandal that is not his,</b> or <b>a wooden sandal, or</b> the sandal <b>of the left foot</b> that was <b>on</b> his <b>right</b> foot, <b>the <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid.</b>
<b>And we said: Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who holds that a wooden sandal is considered a shoe for this purpose? <b>Shmuel said: It is Rabbi Meir, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>An amputee may go out with his wooden leg,</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir,</b> and <b>Rabbi Yosei prohibits</b> doing so. Ultimately, Shmuel accepted Rav’s reading of the mishna.
<b>And Rav Huna also reversed</b> his opinion, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a plasterers’ sandal</b> worn by those who work with lime and would cover their leather shoes with a shoe woven from straw or reeds so that the leather shoes would not get ruined by the lime. If the plasterer is a <i>zav</i> and walks with his shoes covered, the shoe covering <b>is</b> subject to <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading,</b> as the legal status of that sandal is that of a shoe. <b>A woman may perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with it, and one may go out with it on Shabbat;</b> this is the <b>statement of Rabbi Akiva. And</b> the Rabbis <b>did not agree with him.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>they agreed with him? Rav Huna said</b> in resolution of this apparent contradiction: <b>Who is</b> the Sage whose opinion is referred to in the phrase: <b>They agreed with him?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Meir. And who is</b> the Sage whose opinion is referred to in the phrase: <b>They did not agree with him?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> Even Rav Huna accepted Rav’s reading of the mishna that Rabbi Yosei prohibits going out with a wooden leg.
<b>Rav Yosef said: Who is</b> the Sage whose opinion is referred to in the phrase: <b>They did not agree with</b> Rabbi Akiva? It is <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri. As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>A receptacle</b> made <b>of straw and a tube</b> made <b>of reeds, Rabbi Akiva deems</b> these vessels capable of becoming <b>ritually impure, and Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri deems</b> them <b>pure,</b> i.e., incapable of becoming ritually impure because they are not vessels. According to Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, straw objects are not considered vessels fit for use.
It was taught in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>the Master said: A plasterers’ sandal is</b> subject to <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading.</b> The Gemara asks: How could that be? These sandals <b>are not made for walking. Rav Aḥa bar Rav Ulla said:</b> They are used for walking, <b>as,</b> at times, <b>the plasterer walks in them until he reaches his house.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>And if</b> the wooden leg <b>has a receptacle for pads, it</b> is capable of becoming <b>ritually impure. Abaye said: It</b> is subject to <b>ritual impurity</b> due to contact with <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by a <b>corpse, and it is not</b> subject to <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading.</b> If a <i>zav</i> uses a wooden leg it merely assumes first-degree ritual impurity status, since he cannot lean all his weight on it. <b>Rava said:</b> The artificial foot <b>is even</b> subject to <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading.</b>
<b>Rava said: From where do I</b> derive to <b>say</b> this <i>halakha</i>? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>The wagon of a</b> small <b>child</b> utilized to teach him to walk (<i>Tosafot</i>) <b>is</b> subject to <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading,</b> since its purpose is to lean on it. <b>And Abaye said:</b> The two cases are not comparable. <b>There,</b> in the case of the wagon, <b>he leans</b> all his weight <b>on it; here,</b> in the case of the wooden leg, <b>he does not lean</b> all his weight <b>on it.</b>
<b>Abaye said: From where do I</b> derive to <b>say</b> this <i>halakha</i>? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A</b> walking <b>stick,</b> typically used by the <b>elderly, is pure,</b> i.e., incapable of becoming ritually impure <b>from any</b> form of ritual impurity. Apparently, an object upon which one does not lean all his weight is not subject to ritual impurity imparted by treading.
<b>And</b> how does <b>Rava</b> respond to this proof? He says that there is a distinction between the cases: <b>There,</b> in the case of a walking stick used by the elderly,

Daf 66b

<b>it is made</b> merely <b>to align his steps</b> and straighten his posture. He does not completely lean all his weight on it. <b>Here,</b> in the case of a wooden leg, <b>it is made to lean on, and</b> in fact <b>he leans</b> all his weight <b>on it.</b>
It was taught in the mishna that the supports of a <i>zav</i> and his chair <b>are</b> subject to <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading, and one may not go out with them on Shabbat, and one may not enter into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard with them.</b>
<b>The <i>tanna</i>,</b> who recited <i>mishnayot</i> <b>before Rabbi Yoḥanan, taught</b> the opposite <i>halakha</i> in the mishna: <b>One may enter into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard with them.</b>
Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: I teach that a woman may perform <i>ḥalitza</i> with</b> this support, as it has the legal status of a shoe in every sense, <b>and you say that one may enter</b> the Temple courtyard? <b>Teach</b> the mishna in the following manner: <b>One may not enter into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard with them.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b><i>loketamin</i> are pure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are <i>loketamin</i>? Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> They are wooden toys in the shape of a <b>donkey</b> one carried <b>on the shoulders,</b> creating the impression that the donkey is riding him. <b>Rava bar Pappa said:</b> They are <b>stilts</b> used to avoid getting dirty when walking in mud or for amusement. <b>Rava bar Rav Huna said: They are masks [<i>peramei</i>].</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Young <b>boys may go out on Shabbat with knots</b> as a folk remedy <b>and princes with bells. And any person</b> is permitted to go out on Shabbat with those objects; <b>however, the Sages spoke in the present,</b> addressing situations that were prevalent.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that young boys may go out on Shabbat with knots. The Gemara asks: <b>What are</b> these <b>knots? Adda Mari said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman bar Barukh said</b> that <b>Rav Ashi bar Avin said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said: They are garlands of</b> the <b>madder</b> plant that are tied for their medicinal qualities.
<b>Abaye said: Mother,</b> actually his foster mother, <b>said to me</b> about the healing properties of madder: <b>Three</b> garlands <b>maintain</b> the illness at its present state and prevent it from worsening, <b>five</b> garlands <b>heal</b> the illness, and <b>seven are effective even against sorcery.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: And that</b> benefit provided by the madder plant <b>is</b> specifically in a case <b>where</b> one on whom the knots were tied <b>does not look at the sun and the moon, and does not see rain, and hears neither the sound of</b> clanging <b>iron, nor the sound of the hen, nor the sound of footsteps. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> If that is the case, the remedial powers of <b>the madder fell in a pit,</b> i.e., if so many conditions exist, for all intents and purposes it provides no benefit at all.
The Gemara asks: If these knots in the madder plant have remedial qualities, <b>why specifically</b> were <b>boys</b> mentioned in the mishna? <b>Even girls</b> can benefit from the cure <b>as well.</b> By the same token, <b>why specifically</b> were <b>young</b> boys mentioned in the mishna? <b>Even adults</b> can benefit from the cure <b>as well.</b>
<b>Rather, what are</b> these <b>knots? Like that which Avin bar Huna said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said: A son who has longings for his father</b> and has a difficult time leaving him, the father <b>takes a strap from the right shoe and ties it on</b> the boy’s <b>left</b> arm as a talisman to help the child overcome his longings. These feelings are more common in small children and especially in boys for their fathers, as fathers were more involved in raising their sons than they were in raising their daughters. Therefore, the Sages allowed specifically young boys to go out with these knots. With regard to this practice, <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: And your mnemonic</b> for where to tie the strap <b>is phylacteries,</b> which are tied by the right hand on the left arm. <b>And the opposite,</b> tying the strap from the left shoe onto his right arm, <b>is dangerous</b> because it will exacerbate his longings.
On the topic of the use of various forms of healing and medicinal practices and their permissibility on Shabbat, the Gemara cites additional statements by that Sage on these topics. <b>Avin bar Huna said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said:</b> With regard to <b>overturning an</b> empty <b>cup</b> in which there had been hot water and placing it <b>on</b> one’s <b>navel</b> for healing purposes <b>on Shabbat,</b> he may <b>well</b> do so.
<b>And Avin bar Huna said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said: It is permissible to smear oil and salt</b> on oneself <b>on Shabbat.</b>
<b>As in this</b> case <b>of Rav Huna,</b> who departed <b>from the house of Rav, and Rav,</b> who departed <b>from the house of Rabbi Ḥiyya, and Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> who departed <b>from the house of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>when they were drunk,</b> the rabbi <b>would bring oil and salt and rub them on the palms of their hands and the soles of their feet and say: Just as this oil is clear, so let the wine of so-and-so, son of so-and-so,</b> his mother, <b>become clear.</b> In other words, let them become sober. <b>And if</b> he could <b>not</b> bring oil and salt, or if they did not work, <b>he would bring the sealing</b> clay <b>of a barrel and soak it in water and say: Just as this sealing</b> clay <b>is clear, so let the wine of so-and-so, son of so-and-so, become clear.</b>
<b>And Avin bar Huna said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said: It is permitted to strangle,</b> i.e., tightly bandage the neck of one whose vertebra was dislocated in order to reset it, <b>on Shabbat.</b>
<b>And Avin bar Huna said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said:</b> With regard to tightly <b>swaddling a baby</b> born <b>on Shabbat</b> in order to align any limbs that may have been dislocated in birth, one may <b>well</b> do so.
There were different versions with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Avin bar Huna. <b>Rav Pappa taught</b> two <i>halakhot</i> with regard to <b>children</b> in his name <b>and Rav Zevid taught</b> one <i>halakha</i> with regard to a <b>child</b> in his name. The Gemara explains: <b>Rav Pappa taught</b> two <i>halakhot</i> with regard to <b>children, and he taught both of them in</b> the name of <b>Avin bar Huna,</b> i.e., the <i>halakha</i> with regard to knots and the <i>halakha</i> with regard to swaddling. <b>Rav Zevid taught</b> one <i>halakha</i> with regard to a <b>child. The first,</b> with regard to knots, <b>he taught in</b> the name of <b>Avin bar Huna. And this,</b> with regard to swaddling, <b>he taught in</b> the name of <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana, as Rabba bar bar Ḥana said:</b> With regard to tightly <b>swaddling a baby on Shabbat,</b> one may <b>well</b> do so.
The Gemara cites additional statements said by Abaye in the name of the woman who raised him with regard to remedies. <b>Abaye said, Mother said to me: All incantations</b> that are repeated <b>are</b> intoned using <b>the name of the mother</b> of the one requiring the incantation, <b>and all knots</b> tied for the purpose of healing <b>are</b> tied <b>on the left.</b>
<b>And Abaye said, Mother said to me: All incantations</b> for <b>which</b> the number of times they must be intoned <b>is specified,</b> one recites them <b>as they are specified; and those</b> for <b>which</b> the number of times they must be intoned <b>is not specified,</b> one recites them <b>forty-one times.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may go out with a preservation stone,</b> which prevent miscarriages, <b>on Shabbat. They said in the name of Rabbi Meir</b> that one may go out <b>even with the counterweight of a preservation stone;</b> i.e., a stone or another object that was weighed against and found equivalent to the weight of the preservation stone, which is also effective. <b>And</b> this leniency applies <b>not</b> only to <b>a woman who miscarried</b> in the past and is concerned that she may miscarry again; <b>rather,</b> it applies even to a woman who never miscarried and is concerned <b>lest she miscarry</b> for the first time. <b>And</b> it applies <b>not</b> only to <b>a woman who</b> is aware that she <b>is pregnant; rather,</b> it applies even if a woman suspects that <b>she may become pregnant and miscarry. Rav Yeimar bar Shelamya said in the name of Abaye: And this</b> applies only <b>when</b> he happened upon an object <b>that was</b> found <b>equal</b> to the preservation stone when <b>he weighed</b> it against that stone, not when one alters the object to equal the weight of the preservation stone. <b>Abaye raised a dilemma:</b> With regard to a <b>counterweight to the counterweight,</b> i.e., one who finds an object and determines its weight by weighing it against the counterweight of the preservation stone, <b>what</b> is its legal status? May a woman go out into the public domain with it? The Gemara concludes: <b>Let</b> this dilemma <b>stand</b> unresolved.
<b>And Abaye said, Mother said to me: To</b> heal <b>a fever of one day, let one take a pale,</b> i.e., newly minted, <b>dinar and go to the salt</b> pools, <b>and weigh its weight in salt</b> against it, <b>and let him bind</b> the salt <b>to the opening of the neckline</b> of his garment <b>with a thread</b> made <b>of hair.</b>
<b>And if</b> this remedy is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let him sit at a crossroads, and when he sees a large ant carrying something, he should take</b> the ant <b>and place it in a copper tube, and close it with lead, and seal it with sixty seals, and shake it, and lift it, and say to it: Your burden is upon me and my burden,</b> my fever, <b>is upon you. Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Huna, said to Rav Ashi: And perhaps a</b> different <b>person</b> already <b>found</b> this ant <b>and</b> used <b>this</b> remedy to <b>end</b> his illness. In that case, by accepting the burden of the ant, he is bringing another’s illness upon himself. <b>Rather, let him say to</b> the ant: <b>My burden and your burden are upon you.</b>
<b>And if</b> that remedy is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let him take a new jug, and go to the river, and say to it: River, river, lend me a jug of water for a guest who happened</b> to come <b>to me. And let him turn it around his head seven times, and pour out</b> the water <b>behind him, and say to it: River, river, take</b> back <b>the water that you gave me because the guest who happened</b> to come <b>to me came on its day and left on its day.</b>
<b>Rav Huna said:</b>

Daf 67a

<b>For tertian fever,</b> which afflicts one every three days, <b>let one bring seven thorns from seven palm trees, and seven slivers from seven beams, and seven pegs from seven bridges, and seven</b> types of <b>ashes from seven ovens, and seven</b> types of <b>dust from seven door sockets,</b> the hole in which the hinge of the door revolves, <b>and seven</b> types of <b>tar from seven boats, and seven cumin seeds, and seven hairs from the beard of an old dog, and let him bind it to the opening of the neckline</b> of his garment <b>with a thread</b> made <b>of hair.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: For</b> healing a <b>burning fever, let one take a knife that is</b> made <b>entirely</b> of <b>iron,</b> including the handle, <b>and let him go to a place where there is a bush and tie a string of hair to it.</b>
On <b>the first day, let him carve</b> the bush <b>a little, and recite: “And an angel of the Lord appeared to him</b> in a flame of fire from within the bush and he looked and behold the bush was aflame in fire and the bush was not consumed” (Exodus 3:2). <b>On the following day, let him carve</b> the bush <b>a little</b> more <b>and recite: “And Moses said: I will turn aside now, and see</b> this great sight, why the bush is not burned” (Exodus 3:3). <b>On the following day, let him carve</b> the bush <b>a little</b> more <b>and recite: “And the Lord saw that he turned aside to see</b> and God called to him within the bush and said: Moses, Moses, and he said: Here I am” (Exodus 3:4).
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: And let him say: “And the Lord said: Do not come close,</b> take off your shoes from your feet, for the place on which you stand is holy ground” (Exodus 3:5). This verse is more suited to be recited as an incantation to cure a fever. <b>Rather, on the first day, let him recite</b> the first two verses: <b>“And an angel of the Lord appeared to him</b> in a flame of fire from within the bush and he looked and behold the bush was aflame in fire and the bush was not consumed,” as well as, <b>“And Moses said:</b> I will turn aside now and see.” <b>And on the following day, let him recite: “And the Lord saw that he turned aside to see.” And on the following day,</b> let him recite: <b>“And the Lord said: Do not come close,</b> take off your shoes from your feet, for the place on which you stand is holy ground” (Exodus 3:5).
<b>And when he carves</b> the bush, <b>let him lower</b> himself <b>and cut it</b> close to the ground, <b>and recite as follows: The bush, the bush; not because you are higher than all trees did the Holy One, Blessed be He, rest His Divine Presence upon you. Rather,</b> it is <b>because you are lower than all trees did the Holy One, Blessed be He, rested His Divine Presence upon you. And just as the fire saw Hananiah, Mishael, and Azariah and fled from before them, so too, let the fire</b> of the fever <b>see so-and-so, son of so-and-so,</b> his mother, <b>flee from before him.</b>
<b>For</b> healing <b>boils, let him recite as follows: Baz, Bazya, Mas, Masya, Kas, Kasya, Sharlai, and Amarlai, these are the angels who were sent from the land of Sodom and</b> this was all in order <b>to heal painful boils. Bazakh, Bazikh, Bazbazikh, Masmasikh, Kamon, Kamikh,</b> may <b>your appearance</b> remain <b>with you,</b> may <b>your appearance</b> remain <b>with you,</b> i.e., the boils should not grow redder. May <b>your place</b> remain <b>with you,</b> i.e., they should not spread, may <b>your,</b> the boils’, <b>seed be like one who is barren and like a mule that is not fruitful and does not multiply, so too, do not increase and do not multiply in the body of so-and-so, son of so-and-so.</b>
<b>For</b> healing <b>a wound, let him recite as follows: A drawn sword and a readied sling, its name shall not be ache, sickness, and pains.</b>
<b>To</b> be saved from <b>a demon, let him recite as follows: You were stopped up, stopped up you were. Cursed, broken, and excommunicated</b> be the demon called <b>bar Tit bar Tamei bar Tina as Shamgaz, Merigaz, and Istemai.</b>
<b>To</b> be saved from <b>the demon of the bathroom, let him recite as follows: On the head of a lion and on the nose of a lioness we found the demon</b> named <b>bar Shirika Panda. With a bed of leeks I felled him,</b> and <b>with the jaw of the donkey I struck him.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>princes</b> may go out <b>with bells,</b> and the same is true for anyone else. The Gemara asks: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who holds that all people of Israel are permitted to conduct themselves like princes with regard to going out with precious ornaments? <b>Rabbi Oshaya said: It is Rabbi Shimon, who said: All of Israel are princes.</b> Therefore, precious ornaments are suitable for every person of Israel. They will neither remove them to show to others nor will they remove them due to concern that people will think them pretentious. <b>Rava said:</b> The mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the bell is <b>woven into his garment,</b> obviating the concern lest he remove it, <b>and</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna is in accordance with <b>the statements of all</b> <i>tanna’im</i>, not merely the statement of Rabbi Shimon.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may go out</b> on Shabbat <b>with a locust egg, and with a fox tooth, and with a nail from the crucified, for</b> the purpose of <b>healing;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. The Rabbis prohibit</b> using these remedies <b>even during the week, due to the</b> prohibition of following the <b>ways of the Amorite.</b> These are superstitious beliefs and the customs of gentiles from which one must distance oneself.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that in Rabbi Meir’s opinion one may go out on Shabbat with a locust egg, and a fox tooth, and with a nail from the crucified as a talisman or a cure. The Gemara explains the nature of each: <b>One may go out with a locust egg, as they use it</b> as a talisman <b>to</b> cure an <b>earache; and with a fox tooth, as they use</b> it as a talisman <b>for sleep;</b> the tooth <b>of a live</b> fox <b>for one who sleeps</b> too much to wake him up, and the tooth <b>of a dead</b> fox <b>for one who</b> does <b>not sleep. And</b> one may go out <b>with a nail from the crucified, as they use</b> it as a talisman for curing <b>infection.</b>
We learned in the mishna that going out with those objects is permitted on Shabbat <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>healing;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> in the mishna, the Gemara cites <b>Abaye and Rava, who both said: Anything that contains an element of healing</b> and seems to be effective <b>does not contain</b> an element <b>of the</b> prohibition against following the <b>ways of the Amorite.</b> There is no cause for suspicion of one who engages in their practice, gentile or Jew.
The Gemara asks: Is that to say by inference that if it is <b>does not contain an element of healing, it does contain</b> an element <b>of the</b> prohibition against following the <b>ways of the Amorite? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A tree that sheds its fruit</b> prematurely, <b>one paints it and colors it with red paint and loads it with stones? Granted,</b> he is permitted <b>to load it with stones</b> because that action produces an actual benefit, i.e., he does that <b>so that its strength will weaken.</b> Sometimes a tree sheds its fruits prematurely due to excessive blossoming. Sustaining those blossoms taxes the tree, rendering it incapable of sustaining the fruits that grow from the blossoms. The stones were used to slightly weaken the tree when blossoming, thereby reducing the number of blossoms that the tree must nourish. <b>However, painting it with red paint, what healing is he performing</b> with that action?
The Gemara explains: He does so <b>so that people will see</b> the tree <b>and pray for mercy for it. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “And the leper in whom the plague is, his clothes shall be ripped and the hair of his head shall grow long and he will put a covering upon his upper lip <b>and will cry: Impure, impure”</b> (Leviticus 13:45). The leper publicizes the fact that he is ritually impure because <b>he must announce his pain to the masses, and the masses will pray for mercy on his</b> behalf. <b>Ravina said: In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>do we hang bunches of</b> unripe <b>dates on a palm tree</b> that casts off its dates? <b>According to that <i>tanna</i></b> who taught that one must publicize his pain to the masses.
<b>The <i>tanna</i> recited the chapter of</b> the <i>Tosefta</i> discussing the actions of <b>the Amorites before Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin.</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin <b>said to him: All those</b> enumerated there <b>contain</b> an element <b>of the</b> prohibition against following the <b>ways of the Amorite, except for these: One who has a bone in his throat brings</b> a bone <b>from the same species</b> as the bone that is stuck in his throat, <b>and places it on his skull, and says as follows: One by one descend and be swallowed, swallow and descend one by one. That does not contain</b> an element <b>of the</b> prohibition against following the <b>ways of the Amorite.</b>
<b>For a fish bone</b> stuck in the throat, <b>let him say as follows: You are stuck like a needle, locked as a shutter, go down, go down.</b>

Daf 67b

After some discussion of the ways of the Amorite, the Gemara cites additional statements from the Amorite chapter in the <i>Tosefta</i> and from other sources on this topic. <b>One who says: My fortune be fortunate [<i>gad gaddi</i>] and be not weary by day or by night;</b> that statement <b>contains an element of the ways of the Amorite. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> That is more severe than the ways of the Amorite, as <b><i>gad</i> is nothing other than a term of idolatry, as it is stated:</b> “And you that forsake the Lord, that forget My holy mountain, <b>that prepare a table for <i>Gad</i>,</b> and that offer mingled wine in full measure unto <i>Meni</i>” (Isaiah 65:11). <i>Gad gaddi</i> is a form of prayer to an idol.
One who requests that <b>he</b> be called <b>by</b> his wife’s <b>name and she</b> be called <b>by his name</b> for good fortune, his request <b>contains an element of the ways of the Amorite.</b>
One who says: <b>Let my barrels be strengthened [<i>donu danei</i>],</b> that <b>contains an element of the ways of the Amorite. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> That is more severe than the ways of the Amorite, as <b><i>Dan</i> is nothing other than a term of idol worship, as it is stated: “They that swear by the sin of Samaria and say: As your god <i>Dan</i> lives”</b> (Amos 8:14).
<b>One who</b> hears a raven calling and is concerned about a bad omen and <b>says to the raven: Scream, and</b> says <b>to the female raven: Whistle and turn your tail to me for the best;</b> those statements <b>contain an element of the ways of the Amorite.</b>
<b>One who says: Slaughter this rooster that calls out</b> in the <b>evening and</b> says: Slaughter this <b>chicken that calls out like a male</b> rooster; those statements <b>contain an element of the ways of the Amorite.</b>
One who says: <b>I will drink and leave over, I will drink and leave over,</b> so that his wine will increase; that statement <b>contains an element of the ways of the Amorite.</b>
<b>One who cracks eggs on a wall and smears</b> them <b>in front of the chicks;</b> that series of actions <b>contains an element of the ways of the Amorite.</b>
<b>And one who stirs</b> the pot <b>in front of chicks</b> as an auspicious practice so they do not die; that action <b>contains an element of the ways of the Amorite.</b>
<b>A woman who dances and counts</b> the chicks until she reaches the number of <b>seventy-one chicks, so they won’t die;</b> her action <b>contains an element of the ways of the Amorite.</b>
A woman <b>who dances to</b> ensure that the <b><i>kutaḥ</i>,</b> a spice made from whey salt and bread, that she is preparing will be successful, <b>and</b> a woman <b>who silences</b> bystanders <b>to</b> ensure that the <b>lentils</b> will cook properly, <b>and</b> a woman <b>who screams to</b> ensure that the <b>pearl barley</b> will cook properly; all these <b>contain an element of the ways of the Amorite.</b>
<b>A woman who urinates in front of her pot so it will cook quickly;</b> that action <b>contains an element of the ways of the Amorite.</b>
<b>But one may put a chip of mulberry</b> wood <b>and shards of glass in the pot so it will cook quickly,</b> as doing so is effective and not merely superstition. <b>And the Rabbis prohibit shards of glass</b> not due to superstition; rather, <b>due to</b> the <b>danger</b> involved if the glass is not strained out completely.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One</b> may <b>place a lump of salt into a candle so it will burn brightly;</b> that is effective and not merely for good fortune, so there is no element of the ways of the Amorites involved. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>one may put mud or clay under a candle so it will burn longer.</b>
<b>Rav Zutra said: He who covers an oil lamp or who uncovers a kerosene</b> lamp for no purpose <b>violates the prohibition: Do not destroy,</b> since by doing so the fuel burns more quickly.
One who says while drinking: <b>Wine and life to the mouth of the Sages,</b> this does <b>not fall into the category of the ways of the Amorite. There was an incident with Rabbi Akiva who made a banquet for his son, and over each and every cup he brought he said: Wine and life to the mouth of the Sages, wine and life to the mouth of the Sages and to the mouth of their students.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The Sages <b>stated a significant principle with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat: One who forgets the essence of Shabbat,</b> i.e., one who is entirely ignorant of the mitzva of Shabbat according to Torah law, <b>and performed numerous prohibited labors on multiple <i>Shabbatot</i>, is liable</b> to bring <b>only one sin-offering</b> for all those labors when he becomes aware that those actions were prohibited. <b>One who knows the essence of Shabbat</b> but forgets which day is Shabbat, i.e., one who lost track of the days of the week, <b>and performs numerous prohibited labors on multiple <i>Shabbatot</i> is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for each Shabbat</b> when he becomes aware that he performed those actions on Shabbat. <b>One who is aware that</b> the day <b>is Shabbat</b> but temporarily forgot that certain labors were prohibited <b>and performed numerous prohibited labors on multiple <i>Shabbatot</i> is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for each</b>

Daf 68a

<b>and every primary category of labor</b> that he performed. <b>One who performs numerous prohibited labors</b> subsumed under a <b>single</b> category <b>of labor is liable</b> to bring <b>only one sin-offering.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara attempts to clarify the language of the mishna and asks: <b>Why did</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> the phrase: <b>A significant principle? If you say</b> it is <b>because</b> of the following reason, it is problematic.<br>Here, because the <i>tanna</i> <b>wants to teach</b> in a mishna later in the chapter with regard to a matter that includes two <i>halakhot</i> employing the term: <b>Furthermore,</b> they stated <b>another principle;</b> therefore, in this mishna, which relates to a greater number of <i>halakhot</i>, he <b>taught</b> employing the term: <b>A significant principle.</b> <br><b>And with regard to the Sabbatical Year as well, because</b> in a later mishna (<i>Shevi’it</i> 7:2) the <i>tanna</i> <b>wants to teach: Furthermore, another principle,</b> at the beginning of the chapter he <b>taught</b> employing the phrase: <b>A significant principle.</b> There too, the choice of language is understood. <br><b>However, with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>tithes,</b> where the mishna (<i>Ma’asrot</i> 1:1) states two principles one after the other, the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> later in the same mishna: And furthermore, they stated <b>another principle, and</b> even so, at the beginning of the mishna the <i>tanna</i> <b>did not teach: A significant principle,</b> opting instead to say simply: They stated a principle.
<b>Rabbi Yosei bar Avin said</b> that the term: A significant principle, is not dependent on the existence of another principle; rather, it is dependent on the significance of the principle. Therefore, with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat and the Sabbatical Year, which include primary categories and subcategories,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in the mishna: <b>A significant</b> principle. With regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>tithes, which do not include primary categories and subcategories</b> and all its <i>halakhot</i> are on equal footing, <b>he did not teach</b> employing the term: <b>A significant principle.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according <b>to</b> the variant reading of the mishna taught by <b>bar Kappara, who taught</b> the phrase: <b>A significant principle, with regard to tithes, what primary categories and subcategories are there</b> with regard to tithes?
<b>Rather, isn’t this the reason</b> the Mishna employs the term: A significant principle; because it is significant relative to other principles? The scope of the materials whose use warrants <b>punishment for</b> desecrating <b>Shabbat is greater than</b> the scope of the materials whose use warrants punishment for desecrating <b>the Sabbatical Year. As</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat are</b> in effect <b>both with regard to</b> plants that are <b>detached</b> from the ground and <b>with regard to</b> those that are <b>attached, while</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the Sabbatical Year with regard to detached</b> plants, they <b>are not</b> in effect, but <b>with regard to attached</b> plants they <b>are</b> in effect. <b>And</b> the scope of the materials whose use warrants <b>punishment</b> for desecration <b>of the Sabbatical Year are greater than</b> the scope of the materials whose use warrants punishment for violating the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of tithes. As,</b> by Torah law, the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the Sabbatical Year are</b> in effect <b>both with regard to human food</b> and <b>with regard to animal food, while</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>tithes are</b> in effect <b>with regard to human food,</b> but <b>with regard to animal food</b> they <b>are not</b> in effect.
<b>And</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>bar Kappara, who taught</b> the phrase: <b>A significant principle, with regard to tithes</b> as well: <b>The</b> scope of the materials for which one warrants <b>punishment</b> for violating the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>tithes is greater than</b> the scope of the materials for which one warrants punishment for violating the <i>halakhot</i> of <b><i>pe’a</i>. As,</b> by rabbinic law, the obligation of <b>tithes is</b> in effect <b>with regard to</b> both <b>figs and vegetables, while</b> the obligation of <b><i>pe’a</i> is not</b> in effect <b>with regard to figs and vegetables. As we learned</b> in a mishna in tractate <i>Pe’a</i>: <b>They stated a principle with regard to <i>pe’a</i>: Anything that is food, and is protected, and grows from the ground, and is gathered as one, and one brings it in</b> to storage <b>to preserve is obligated in <i>pe’a</i>.</b>
The Gemara explains that which is excluded by each criterion in the mishna. <b>Food, to exclude the aftergrowths of woad [<i>satis</i>] and madder.</b> As these plants are used for dyeing and not for food, the obligation of <i>pe’a</i> does not apply to them. <b>And protected, to exclude ownerless</b> crops, which by definition are not protected. <b>And grows from the ground, to exclude truffles and mushrooms,</b> which, unlike other plants, do not draw sustenance from the ground. <b>And is gathered as one, to exclude</b> the <b>fig</b> tree whose fruit is gathered throughout an extended period, as the figs do not all ripen together. <b>And one brings it in</b> to storage <b>to preserve; to exclude vegetables,</b> which cannot be stored for lengthy periods.
<b>While, with regard to tithes, we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>They stated a principle with regard to tithes: Anything that is food, and is protected, and grows from the ground is obligated in tithes; we did not learn</b> with regard to tithes, the following criteria: <b>Gathered as one, and which one brings in</b> to storage <b>to preserve.</b> Apparently, figs and vegetables are obligated in tithes, making the scope of the materials obligated in tithes greater than the scope of those obligated in <i>pe’a</i>.
The mishna discusses an individual who forgets the very essence of Shabbat. The Gemara seeks to understand how a Jew could forget the very existence of Shabbat. It was <b>Rav and Shmuel who both said: Our mishna</b> is referring <b>to</b> both <b>a child who was taken captive among the gentiles</b> and never educated <b>and a convert who converted among the gentiles</b> and never learned the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat. <b>However,</b> one who once <b>knew</b> of the essence of Shabbat <b>and ultimately forgot is liable for each and every Shabbat,</b> as we learned in the mishna with regard to one who knows the essence of Shabbat. The Gemara seeks to clarify this approach. <b>We learned</b> in our mishna: <b>One who forgets the essence of Shabbat. Doesn’t</b> this phrase indicate <b>by inference that he was aware</b> of Shabbat <b>originally?</b> In order to forget one must have previously been aware. This poses a difficulty to the opinion of Rav and Shmuel. The Gemara refutes this: <b>No, what is</b> the meaning of: <b>One who forgets the essence of Shabbat? That the essence of Shabbat</b> was always <b>forgotten from him,</b> i.e., he never knew it.
The Gemara further asks: <b>However,</b> based on that understanding, in the case of <b>one who knew</b> the essence of Shabbat <b>and ultimately forgot, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is he <b>liable for each and every Shabbat?</b> If so, <b>instead of</b> the mishna <b>teaching</b> the next <i>halakha</i>: <b>One who knows the essence of Shabbat and performs many labors on multiple <i>Shabbatot</i></b> is <b>liable to</b> bring a sin-offering <b>for each and every Shabbat, let it teach: One who knew</b> the essence of Shabbat <b>and ultimately forgot and, all the more so, one</b> who knows the essence of Shabbat would be liable for each Shabbat. The Gemara answers: According to the opinion of Rav and Shmuel, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>One who knows the essence of Shabbat? One who</b> once <b>knew the essence of Shabbat and</b> has now <b>forgotten it.</b>

Daf 68b

The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>But</b> if <b>he did not forget</b> the essence of Shabbat, and he knows that today is Shabbat, <b>what</b> would the <i>halakha</i> be? Certainly he would be <b>liable for each and every prohibited labor.</b> If so, <b>instead of teaching</b> the <i>halakha</i>: <b>One who knows that it is Shabbat and performs many labors on multiple <i>Shabbatot</i> is liable for each and every labor, let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> the <i>halakha</i>: <b>One who knows the essence of Shabbat</b> is liable for each and every labor that he performs <b>and all the more so</b> that <b>one</b> who is aware that today is Shabbat would be liable for each labor. <b>Rather,</b> when <b>our mishna</b> refers to forgetting, it is referring to a case <b>where he knew and ultimately forgot. And</b> the case described by <b>Rav and Shmuel also</b> has the same legal status <b>as one who knew and ultimately forgot. And it was stated as follows:</b> It was <b>Rav and Shmuel who both said: Even a child who was taken captive among the gentiles and a convert who converted among the gentiles</b> have the same legal status <b>as one who knew and ultimately forgot, and</b> they are <b>liable</b> to bring a sin-offering for their unwitting transgression, even though they never learned about Shabbat.
<b>And</b> it was <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish who both said:</b> He is liable to bring a sin-offering <b>specifically</b> if <b>he knew</b> of the essence of Shabbat <b>and ultimately forgot. However, a child who was taken captive among the gentiles and a convert who converted among the gentiles</b> are <b>exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering. They have the legal status of one who performed the prohibited labor due to circumstances beyond his control. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>They stated a significant principle with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat: One who forgets the essence of Shabbat,</b> i.e., one who does not know that there is a mitzva of Shabbat in the Torah, <b>and performs many prohibited labors on multiple <i>Shabbatot</i> is liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering. <b>How so?</b> With regard to <b>a child who was taken captive among the gentiles and a convert who converted among the gentiles</b> and does not know the essence of Shabbat; <b>and</b> if <b>he performed many prohibited labors on multiple <i>Shabbatot,</i> he is only liable</b> to bring <b>one sin-offering</b> for all his unwitting transgressions. <b>And he is liable</b> to bring <b>one</b> sin-offering <b>for</b> all <b>the blood</b> he unwittingly ate before he learned of the prohibition; <b>and one</b> sin-offering <b>for</b> all <b>the forbidden fat</b> that he ate; <b>and</b> one <b>for</b> all the <b>idolatry</b> that he worshipped. <b>And Munbaz,</b> one of the Sages, <b>deems</b> him <b>exempt</b> from bringing any sacrifice.
<b>And Munbaz deliberated before Rabbi Akiva as follows: Since</b> one who commits a transgression <b>intentionally is called</b> a <b>sinner</b> in the Torah <b>and</b> one who commits a transgression <b>unwittingly is called</b> a <b>sinner, just as</b> one who commits the transgression <b>intentionally</b> is liable for punishment only in a case <b>where he had</b> prior <b>knowledge</b> that it was prohibited, <b>so too,</b> one who commits the transgression <b>unwittingly</b> is liable to bring a sin-offering only in a case <b>where he had</b> prior <b>knowledge.</b> However, the action of one who had no prior knowledge at all is not considered unwitting; rather, it has the same legal status as an action performed due to circumstances beyond one’s control, and he is completely exempt. <b>Rabbi Akiva said to him: I will elaborate upon your statement</b> and follow your reasoning to its logical conclusion and thereby test the validity of your reasoning. <b>If so, just as</b> one who commits the transgression <b>intentionally</b> is liable for punishment only in a case <b>where</b> he had <b>the awareness</b> that he was sinning <b>at the time</b> that he performed <b>the action, so too,</b> with regard to one who commits the transgression <b>unwittingly,</b> say that he is only liable to bring a sin-offering in a case <b>where he had awareness</b> that he was sinning <b>at the time</b> that he performed <b>the action.</b> If that is the case, it is no longer an unwitting transgression.
Munbaz <b>said to him: Yes,</b> there is nothing unusual about that. In my opinion it is correct <b>and all the more so</b> now that <b>you have elaborated</b> upon my statement. Awareness at the time that one is performing the action is one of the criteria of my definition of an unwitting transgression, as will be explained below. Rabbi Akiva <b>said to him: According to your statement,</b> since while performing the action one is aware that it is prohibited, his action <b>is not called unwitting; rather,</b> it is a full-fledged <b>intentional</b> transgression.
Returning to our issue: <b>In any case,</b> as an example of one who forgot the essence of Shabbat, <b>it was taught: How so? A child</b> who was taken captive. <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav and Shmuel</b> it works out <b>well,</b> as they consider the legal status of a child taken captive equal to that of one who unwittingly forgot the essence of Shabbat. <b>However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> who consider the legal status of a child taken captive equal to that of one who committed the action due to circumstances beyond his control and is therefore exempt, <b>it is difficult</b> because he is liable to bring a sin-offering according to the opinion of the Rabbis in the <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> could have <b>said to you: Isn’t there</b> the opinion of <b>Munbaz</b> who <b>deemed him exempt</b> in that case? <b>We stated</b> our opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Munbaz.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the rationale for</b> the opinion of <b>Munbaz?</b> Is it based entirely upon the fact that the Torah refers to sinners, both intentional and unwitting, as sinners? The Gemara explains that the source for the opinion of Munbaz is <b>as it is written:</b> “The native of the children of Israel, and the stranger who lives among them, <b>there shall be one law for you, for one who acts unwittingly”</b> (Numbers 15:29), <b>and adjacent to it</b> is the verse: <b>“And the person who acts with a high hand,</b> whether a native or a stranger, he blasphemes God, and that soul shall be cut off from the midst of his people” (Numbers 15:30). The Torah <b>juxtaposes unwitting</b> transgression <b>to intentional</b> transgression. <b>Just as</b> one who commits the transgression <b>intentionally</b> is only liable in a case <b>where he had</b> prior <b>knowledge, so too,</b> one who commits the transgression <b>unwittingly</b> is only liable in a case <b>where he had</b> prior <b>knowledge.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what do the Rabbis do with</b> the juxtaposition derived from <b>that</b> verse: <b>One law?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They require it for that which Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi taught his son.</b> It is written: <b>“There shall be one law for you, for one who acts unwittingly.” And it is written:</b>

Daf 69a

<b>“And if you err, and do not perform all these commandments</b> that God spoke to Moses” (Numbers 15:22). The Sages understood this verse as referring specifically to the laws of idolatry. <b>And it is written: “And the person who acts with a high hand,</b> he blasphemes God and that soul shall be cut off from the midst of his people” (Numbers 15:30), from which we learn that <b>all</b> the mitzvot <b>are</b> derived from this <b>juxtaposition to idolatry. Just as there,</b> with regard to idolatry, the reference is to <b>a matter which, for its intentional</b> violation, <b>one is liable to</b> be punished with <b><i>karet</i>,</b> as it is stated: “And that soul shall be cut off,” <b>and for its unwitting</b> violation <b>one is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering; so too, any matter that for its intentional</b> violation <b>one is liable to</b> be punished with <b><i>karet</i>, for its unwitting</b> violation <b>one is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> according to <b>Munbaz,</b> who holds that included in the category of an unwitting sinner is one who at the time of action was aware that it was prohibited; if he were fully aware, <b>in what</b> sense was his action <b>unwitting?</b> The Gemara answers: It is referring to a case <b>where he was unwitting with regard to the sacrifice.</b> He was aware that he was committing a transgression for which one is liable to be punished with <i>karet</i> when performed intentionally; however, he was unaware that he would be liable to bring a sin-offering if he performed the transgression unwittingly. Since he was not aware of all punishments and forms of atonement associated with that transgression, he is considered an unwitting sinner and is liable to bring a sin-offering. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what do <b>the Rabbis</b> who disagree with Munbaz hold? They hold: <b>Unwitting</b> with regard to <b>a sacrifice is not considered unwitting.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> lack of awareness with regard to <b>what</b> aspects of the prohibition renders the action <b>unwitting? Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It is an unwitting transgression <b>since he was unwitting with regard to</b> the fact that the punishment for his transgression is <b><i>karet</i>, even though he</b> was aware that his action was in violation of a Torah <b>prohibition,</b> and he performed the transgression <b>intentionally. And Reish Lakish said</b> that according to the Rabbis it is not considered unwitting <b>until he was unwitting with regard to</b> both the <b>prohibition and <i>karet</i>,</b> i.e., he was unaware that his action was prohibited by Torah law. <b>Rava said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish? The verse said:</b> “And if one soul shall sin by mistake from the common people, by performing one of God’s commandments <b>that may not be done, and he becomes guilty”</b> (Leviticus 4:27), indicating that it is not considered unwitting <b>until he was unwitting with regard to</b> the <b>prohibition and its concomitant <i>karet</i>.</b> The verse indicates that the individual was unaware that he violated “one of the commandments that may not be done,” i.e., that there is a Torah prohibition with regard to that action.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what does Rabbi Yoḥanan do with that verse</b> cited as proof <b>by Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He needs it for that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The phrase: <b>“From the common people”</b> (Leviticus 4:27) teaches that only some sinners, not all, bring sacrifices for their unwitting sins. It comes <b>to exclude an apostate.</b> When an apostate sins unwittingly, he is under no obligation to bring a sin-offering even after he repents. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Shimon:</b> This <i>halakha</i> is derived from the phrase in that verse: <b>“That may not be done, and he becomes guilty.” One who repents</b> due <b>to his awareness,</b> i.e., one who repents as soon as he becomes aware that he performed a transgression, <b>brings a sacrifice for his unwitting</b> transgression. However, one who does <b>not repent</b> due <b>to his awareness</b> that he sinned, e.g., an apostate who continues to sin even after he becomes aware that he committed a transgression, does not <b>bring an offering for his unwitting</b> action. Rabbi Yoḥanan understood the verse in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.
The Gemara cites proof from what <b>we learned</b> in a mishna: The number of <b>primary categories of prohibited labors</b> on Shabbat is <b>forty-less-one,</b> which the mishna proceeds to list. <b>And we discussed</b> this mishna: <b>Why do I need</b> this <b>tally</b> of forty-less-one? Isn’t merely listing the prohibited labors sufficient? <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The tally was included to teach <b>that if he performed all</b> of the prohibited labors <b>in</b> the course of <b>one lapse of awareness</b> during which he was unaware of the prohibition involved, <b>he is liable for each and every one.</b> Therefore, the mishna indicated that one could conceivably be liable to bring thirty-nine sin-offerings. Under what circumstances <b>can you find</b> a case where one would be liable for unwittingly violating all thirty-nine labors? It must be in a case where <b>with regard to Shabbat</b> his actions were <b>intentional,</b> as he was aware that it was Shabbat; <b>and</b> with regard to the prohibited <b>labors</b> his actions were <b>unwitting,</b> as he was unaware that these labors are prohibited on Shabbat.
<b>Granted,</b> according <b>to Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said: Once he was unwitting with regard to</b> the fact that the punishment for his transgression is <b><i>karet</i>, even though he</b> was aware that his action was in violation of a Torah <b>prohibition,</b> and he performed the transgression <b>intentionally,</b> he is considered to have sinned unwittingly, <b>you find</b> that possibility in a case <b>where he was aware that</b> performing labor on <b>Shabbat</b> involves violation of a Torah <b>prohibition,</b> but he was unaware that the punishment for violating that prohibition is <i>karet</i>. <b>However,</b> according <b>to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish, who said:</b> It is not considered unwitting <b>until he was unwitting with regard to</b> both the <b>prohibition and <i>karet</i>,</b> the result is that he is completely unaware of all the prohibited labors of Shabbat. If so, when Rabbi Yoḥanan said that the case where one would be liable to bring thirty-nine sin-offerings is one where with regard to Shabbat, his actions were intentional as he was aware that it was Shabbat, the question arises: With regard <b>to what</b> aspect <b>of Shabbat was he aware?</b> If he was completely unaware of all the labors prohibited on Shabbat, in what sense were his actions intentional with regard to Shabbat? The Gemara answers: <b>He was aware</b> of the <i>halakhot</i> of the prohibition of <b>Shabbat boundaries, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b> According to Rabbi Akiva, the prohibition to go beyond a certain distance outside the city limits on Shabbat is by Torah law and not merely a rabbinic decree.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>who taught this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>As the Sages taught:</b> If <b>one</b> acted <b>unwittingly</b> with regard to both <b>this,</b> the fact that it is Shabbat, <b>and that,</b> the specific prohibited labors, <b>that is</b> the case of <b>unwitting</b> transgression <b>stated in the Torah.</b> If <b>one</b> acted <b>intentionally</b> with regard to both <b>this and that, that is</b> the case of <b>intentional</b> transgression <b>stated in the Torah.</b> If <b>one</b> acted <b>unwittingly</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat and intentionally</b> with regard to <b>the labors,</b> i.e., he forgot that it was Shabbat, but he was aware that those labors are prohibited when it is Shabbat; <b>or</b> if <b>one</b> acted <b>unwittingly</b> with regard to <b>the labors and intentionally with regard to Shabbat,</b> i.e., he was unaware that these labors are prohibited, but he was aware that labor is prohibited on Shabbat, <b>or,</b> even if <b>he said: I know that this labor is prohibited</b> on Shabbat; <b>however, I do not know whether or not one is liable</b> to bring <b>a sacrifice for its</b> performance, he is <b>liable</b> to bring a sin-offering like anyone who sins unwittingly. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this <i>baraita</i>? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Munbaz,</b> who holds that one is considered an unwitting sinner even in a case where he was unwitting only with regard to the sacrifice.
<b>Abaye said: Everyone agrees with regard to an oath on a statement,</b> a case where one swore to prohibit or to obligate himself to perform an action, <b>that</b> the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: If he violates his oath <b>he is only liable</b> to bring an <b>offering if he was unwitting with regard to its prohibition,</b> i.e., he was unaware that it is prohibited by Torah law to violate an oath. The Gemara asks: To <b>whose</b> opinion is Abaye referring in the phrase: <b>Everyone agrees?</b> Certainly, it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> with regard to the opinion of the Rabbis in their dispute with Munbaz. Even though Rabbi Yoḥanan generally holds that the fact that one is unwitting with regard to <i>karet</i> is sufficient to render his action unwitting, the case of an oath is different. The Gemara asks: In the case of an oath, <b>it is obvious</b> that he would agree. <b>When Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that one need not be unwitting with regard to the prohibition, it is in a case <b>where there is</b> a prohibition punishable by <b><i>karet</i>; however, here, where there is no</b> punishment of <b><i>karet</i>,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan would <b>not</b> say so. Obviously, he agrees that one must be unwitting with regard to the prohibition. There appears to be nothing new in Abaye’s statement.
The Gemara explains: <b>It might enter your mind to say</b> the following: <b>Since the obligation</b> to bring <b>an offering</b> in the case of the oath <b>is a novel</b> <i>halakha</i>, <b>as</b> throughout <b>the whole Torah in its entirety we do not find a prohibition</b> for <b>whose</b> unwitting violation <b>one</b> is liable to bring <b>an offering</b> and for whose intentional violation is not punishable by <i>karet</i>; <b>and here, one</b> is liable to bring an offering for its unwitting violation, I might have said <b>that if he was unwitting,</b> i.e., unaware that he would be obligated, with regard to <b>the offering, let him be liable also</b> according to the Rabbis, who disagree with Munbaz.

Daf 69b

Therefore, Abaye <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is an unwitting</b> violation <b>of an oath on a statement</b> relating <b>to the past?</b> What is an example of one who unwittingly swore falsely with regard to an incident that occurred in the past? It cannot be a case where he forgot the incident, as in that case he is exempt from bringing an offering. It is a case <b>where if he said: I know that</b> taking <b>this</b> false <b>oath is prohibited, but I do not know whether or not one is liable to</b> bring <b>an offering for</b> swearing falsely, he is <b>liable</b> to bring an offering for an unwitting transgression. Apparently, with regard to an oath on a statement, unwitting with regard to the sacrifice renders the action unwitting. The Gemara rejects this: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is <b>this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Munbaz.</b> In his opinion, one who commits a transgression while unaware whether or not one is liable to bring an offering if he performs that transgression unwittingly is considered to have performed the transgression unwittingly.
