There is <b>another version</b> of the discussion of Abaye’s statement where, after quoting the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an oath on a statement, the question was raised: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is <b>this</b> mishna? <b>If you say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Munbaz,</b> that is <b>obvious: Now,</b> if <b>throughout the entire Torah where there is no novelty</b> in the obligation to bring an offering, <b>he said</b> that <b>unwitting with regard to an offering is considered unwitting; here,</b> where <b>there is a novelty</b> and the offering in the case of an oath on a statement is more significant than other sin-offerings, <b>certainly</b> unwitting with regard to the offering should be considered unwitting. <b>Rather, is it not</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and</b> this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of <b>Abaye?</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, it is <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
<b>And Abaye said: Everyone agrees</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i> that one is only liable</b> to add <b>a</b> payment of <b>one-fifth</b> the value of the <i>teruma</i> <b>for</b> eating <b>it</b> unwittingly <b>if he is unwitting with regard to its prohibition.</b> The Gemara asks: To <b>whose</b> opinion is Abaye referring in the phrase: <b>Everyone agrees?</b> Certainly, it is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> Even though, in general, he holds that unwitting with regard to <i>karet</i> is sufficient to render the action unwitting, the case of <i>teruma</i> is different. The Gemara asks: In the case of <i>teruma</i>, <b>it is obvious</b> that he would agree. <b>When Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that one need not be unwitting with regard to the prohibition, it is in a case <b>where there is</b> a prohibition punishable by <b><i>karet</i>;</b> however, here, <b>where there is no</b> punishment of <b><i>karet</i>,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan would <b>not</b> say so. The Gemara answers that nonetheless Abaye introduced a novel element: <b>Lest you say</b> that since one who intentionally eats <i>teruma</i> is subject to death at the hand of Heaven, perhaps <b>death stands in place of <i>karet</i>. And where he was unwitting with regard to</b> the punishment of <b>death</b> for this sin, <b>he should also be liable</b> to pay the added fifth as one who performed the transgression unwittingly because his case is analogous to one who is considered unwitting due to lack of awareness of <i>karet</i>. Therefore, <b>Abaye teaches us</b> that it is not so. <b>Rava said:</b> Indeed, <b>death stands in place of <i>karet</i> and the</b> added <b>one-fifth stands in place of a sacrifice.</b> One who is unwitting with regard to death at the hand of Heaven and the added fifth has the same legal status as one who is unwitting with regard to <i>karet</i> and an offering.
<b>Rav Huna said: One who was walking along the way or in the desert, and he does not know when Shabbat</b> occurs, <b>he counts six days</b> from the day that he realized that he lost track of Shabbat <b>and</b> then <b>observes one day</b> as Shabbat. <b>Ḥiyya bar Rav says: He</b> first <b>observes one day</b> as Shabbat and then <b>he counts six</b> weekdays. The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what do they disagree?</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rav Huna, <b>held:</b> It is <b>like the creation of the world,</b> weekdays followed by Shabbat. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Ḥiyya bar Rav, <b>held:</b> It is <b>like Adam, the first</b> man, who was created on the sixth day. He observed Shabbat followed by the six days of the week. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Ḥiyya bar Rav from a <i>baraita</i>: If a person <b>was walking along the way and does not know when Shabbat</b> occurs, <b>he observes one day for</b> every <b>six. What, does</b> this <b>not</b> mean that <b>he counts six and</b> then <b>observes one day</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rav Huna? The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> it could also mean that <b>he observes one day and</b> then <b>counts six.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if that is what the <i>baraita</i> meant, why employ the phrase: <b>He observes one day for six? It should have</b> stated: <b>He observes one day and counts six. And furthermore, it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>was walking along the way or</b> was <b>in the desert, and he does not know when Shabbat</b> occurs, <b>he counts six</b> days <b>and observes one day.</b> That is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Rav.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, it is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of Ḥiyya bar Rav.
<b>Rava said:</b> The person who lost track of Shabbat and treats one day a week as Shabbat, <b>each day he makes</b> enough food <b>to sustain himself, except for that day</b> which he designated as Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>And on that day let him die?</b> Rather, it means <b>that the day before he makes twice</b> the amount of food that he prepared on the other days <b>to sustain</b> him for that day and the following day. The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps the day before was</b> actually <b>Shabbat?</b> In that case, not only did he perform labor on Shabbat, but he also performed labor on Shabbat in preparation for a weekday. Rather, on <b>each and every day he makes</b> enough food <b>to sustain himself</b> for that day, <b>including</b> on <b>that day</b> that he designated as Shabbat. And if you ask: <b>And how is that day</b> which he designated as Shabbat <b>distinguishable</b> from the rest? It is distinguishable <b>by</b> means of <b>the <i>kiddush</i> and the <i>havdala</i></b> that he recites on that day.
<b>Rava said: If he had partial knowledge of the day on which he left,</b> i.e., he does not recall what day of the week it was but he does recall the number of days that passed since he left, every week <b>he can perform labor throughout the day</b> of his departure, since he certainly did not leave his house on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious,</b> and what novel element was introduced here? The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say, since he did not leave</b> on <b>Shabbat, he also did not leave on Friday, and this</b> person, <b>even if he left on Thursday, should be permitted to perform labor</b> for <b>two days,</b> the eighth day and the ninth day from his departure, the same day of the week that he left and the following day. Therefore, Rava <b>teaches us</b> that <b>at times one finds a convoy and happens to leave</b> on a journey even on Friday. Therefore, he is not permitted to perform labor on the day of the week following the day of his departure.
We learned in the mishna that there is a difference in <i>halakha</i> between <b>one who knows the essence of Shabbat</b> and one who does not know it. The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> in the Torah <b>are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: Two verses are written.</b> One states: <b>“And the children of Israel observed the Shabbat,</b> to perform the Shabbat through their generations, an everlasting covenant” (Exodus 31:16). <b>And it is written: “And you shall observe My <i>Shabbatot</i></b> and you shall revere My Sanctuary, I am God” (Leviticus 26:2). <b>How</b> is it that Shabbat is in the singular in one verse, while in the other it is in the plural [<i>Shabbatot</i>]? It should be understood as follows: <b>“And the children of Israel observed the Shabbat”: One observance for multiple <i>Shabbatot</i>.</b> If one commits several transgressions, in certain cases he is only liable to bring one sacrifice. <b>“And you shall observe My <i>Shabbatot</i>”: One observance for each and every Shabbat.</b> In certain cases, one is liable to bring a sin-offering for each time that he unwittingly desecrated Shabbat.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak strongly objects: On the contrary, the opposite is reasonable. “And the children of Israel observed the Shabbat”: One observance for each and every Shabbat. “And you shall observe My <i>Shabbatot</i>”: One observance for multiple <i>Shabbatot</i>.</b> In any case, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak also holds that the <i>halakha</i> of our mishna is derived from comparing and contrasting these two verses.
We learned in the mishna that there is a difference between <b>one who is aware that</b> the day <b>is Shabbat</b> and performs labor and one who forgets the essence of Shabbat and performs prohibited labors.

Daf 70a

The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>the former</b> clause, which states that he in only liable to bring one sin-offering for each Shabbat, <b>and the latter</b> clause, which states that he is liable for each and every primary category of labor that he performed? <b>Rav Safra said: Here,</b> where he is unaware that the day was Shabbat, when he realizes that he sinned, it is <b>due to awareness of Shabbat that he desists.</b> When he is told that it was Shabbat, he stops immediately. <b>And here,</b> where he is unaware that the labors are prohibited, it is <b>due to awareness of the labors that he desists.</b> When he is told that this labor is prohibited, he stops immediately. <b>Rav Naḥman said to</b> Rav Safra: <b>Does</b> he <b>desist due to Shabbat</b> for any reason <b>other than because</b> he knows that the <b>labors</b> are prohibited? If he did not know that the labor is prohibited, telling him that it is Shabbat would not cause him to desist. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>does</b> he <b>desist from</b> performing the <b>labors</b> when told that it is prohibited for any reason <b>other than because</b> he knows that it is <b>Shabbat?</b> If he did not know that it was Shabbat, there would be no reason for him to desist from labor. Ostensibly, attributing the distinction between the two parts of the mishna to what eventually became known to him in the different cases is incorrect. <b>Rather, Rav Naḥman said: The offering that the Torah obligated</b> him to bring; <b>for what</b> is he so obligated? It is for performing an <b>unwitting</b> transgression. <b>There,</b> where he was unaware that the day was Shabbat, he was <b>unwitting</b> with regard to <b>one</b> matter; <b>here,</b> where he was unaware of the prohibited labors, he was <b>unwitting</b> with regard to <b>multiple</b> matters, and he is liable to bring sin-offerings in accordance with the number of matters of which he was unaware.
We learned in the mishna that <b>one is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for each prohibited labor</b> that he performs on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive <b>the division of labors?</b> What is the source of the <i>halakha</i> that if one performs numerous prohibited labors on Shabbat in the course of one lapse of awareness, each prohibited labor is considered a separate offense with regard to punishment? <b>Shmuel said</b> that <b>the verse says:</b> “And you shall observe the Shabbat, for it is holy to you; <b>he who desecrates it shall surely die [<i>mot yumat</i>]”</b> (Exodus 31:14). We learn from the double language, <i>mot yumat</i>, that <b>the Torah amplified multiple deaths for a single desecration.</b> Although several violations were committed in the course of a single lapse of awareness, each is considered a separate offense with regard to punishment. The Gemara asks: <b>That</b> verse <b>was written with regard to intentional</b> transgression. The Gemara is seeking a source for multiple sacrifices brought for unwitting transgression. The Gemara answers: <b>If it does not</b> refer to <b>the matter</b> of <b>intentional</b> transgression, as the verse does not teach a <i>halakha</i> applicable to intentional acts, <b>as it was</b> already <b>written:</b> “Six days you shall perform work, and on the seventh day it shall be holy to you, a Shabbat of rest to God; <b>all who desecrate</b> it <b>shall die”</b> (Exodus 35:2), <b>refer it to the matter of unwitting</b> transgression. The verse teaches that that which was written with regard to the death penalty for desecration of Shabbat in general applies to all <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, including cases of unwitting transgression. <b>And what,</b> then, is the meaning of the term: <b>Shall die,</b> in the verse? Does it mean that one who commits an unwitting transgression is punishable by death? It means that <b>he shall die by</b> payment of <b>money.</b> Death is used in the sense of punishment; he will be forced to pay for numerous sacrifices to atone for his sins.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let him derive division of labors from where</b> it <b>was derived according to Rabbi Natan, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says</b> that it is written: <b>“You shall not kindle fire in all your dwellings on the day of Shabbat”</b> (Exodus 35:3). <b>Why does the verse state</b> this <i>halakha</i>? The prohibition against kindling is included in the general prohibition against performing labor on Shabbat. Rather, it should be understood as follows. <b>Since it is</b> already <b>stated: “And Moses gathered the entire assembly of the children of Israel</b> and said to them: <b>These are the things [<i>eleh hadevarim</i>]</b> that God has commanded to perform them. <b>Six days you shall perform work,</b> and on the seventh day it shall be holy to you, a Shabbat of rest to God” (Exodus 35:1–2), and Rabbi Natan derives as follows: “These are the things,” which refers to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, there are emphases in this phrase that are superfluous in the context of the verse. The Torah could have simply stated: This is a thing [<i>davar</i>]. When it states: <b>Things [<i>devarim</i>]</b> in the plural, it teaches at least two points. The addition of the definite article: <b>The things [<i>hadevarim</i>],</b> adds at least a third point. The numerological value of letters of the word <i>eleh</i>: <i>Alef</i>, one; <i>lamed</i>, thirty; and <i>heh</i>, five, is thirty-six. The total numerical value, three plus thirty-six, derived from the phrase: <b>“These are the things.”</b> This alludes to the <b>thirty-nine prohibited labors that were stated to Moses at Sinai.</b>
<b>I might have thought</b> that if <b>one performed them all in</b> the course of <b>one lapse of awareness,</b> forgetting that they are prohibited, he would be <b>liable</b> to bring only <b>one</b> sin-offering? Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “Six days you shall work, and on the seventh you shall rest; <b>in plowing time and in harvest time you shall rest”</b> (Exodus 34:21), indicating that there are prohibitions specific to both plowing and harvesting. <b>And still I</b> can <b>say: For plowing and for the harvesting he is liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings, as they were stated explicitly. <b>However, for</b> performing <b>all</b> the other prohibited labors, <b>he is liable for only one.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall not kindle fire</b> in all your dwellings on the day of Shabbat” (Exodus 35:3). This is derived in the following manner: <b>Kindling was</b> included <b>in the general</b> prohibition prohibiting all labors, <b>and why was it</b> singled <b>out</b> and prohibited explicitly? It was singled out in order <b>to equate</b> the other labors <b>to it and to tell you: Just as kindling is a primary category of prohibited labor, and one is liable for</b> performing <b>it on its own, so too,</b> with regard to <b>every primary category of prohibited labor, one is liable for</b> performing <b>it on its own.</b>
Rabbi Natan cited a source proving that there is liability for performance of each prohibited labor of Shabbat on its own. Why doesn’t Shmuel derive that <i>halakha</i> from the same source? The Gemara answers: <b>Shmuel holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who disagreed with Rabbi Natan’s interpretation of the verse, as Rabbi Yosei <b>said:</b> The prohibition against <b>kindling</b> on Shabbat <b>was</b> singled <b>out to</b> teach that one who lights a fire on Shabbat merely violates <b>a prohibition.</b> Performing other primary categories of prohibited labor is punishable by stoning or <i>karet</i>. In contrast, one who lights a fire on Shabbat has merely violated a prohibition, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The prohibition of <b>kindling was</b> singled <b>out as a prohibition;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei. Rabbi Natan says:</b> Kindling is like any other labor prohibited on Shabbat. <b>It was</b> singled <b>out to divide</b> the various labors and to establish liability for performance of each of them.
The Gemara raises an additional challenge to Shmuel’s opinion. If he holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei with regard to the explicit prohibition of kindling, <b>let him derive the division of labors from where Rabbi Yosei derives it. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei says,</b> it is stated: “Speak to the children of Israel, saying: A soul that sins in error, from all the commandments of God that may not be performed, <b>and performs from one of them [<i>me’aḥat me’hena</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 4:2). Rabbi Yosei interprets the verse that <b>at times one is liable</b> to bring <b>one</b> sin-offering <b>for all</b> of his transgressions, <b>and at times one is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for each and every</b> transgression. <b>And Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: What is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei?</b> He interprets the unique phrase employed in that verse: From one of these. The Torah could have merely stated: <b>One [<i>aḥat</i>].</b> Instead, it stated: <b>From one [<i>me’aḥat</i>].</b> It could have merely stated: <b>Them [<i>hena</i>].</b> Instead, it stated: <b>Of them [<i>me’hena</i>].</b> Rabbi Yosei derives that there are cases of <b>one</b> transgression <b>that,</b> with regard to punishment, <b>are them,</b> i.e., many. And there are cases of <b>them,</b> several transgressions, <b>that,</b> with regard to punishment, <b>are one.</b>
Furthermore: The term <b>one</b> refers to a full-fledged transgression of Shabbat, e.g., one who intended to and wrote a complete name, <b>Shimon.</b> The term <b>from one</b> refers to a case where he performed only part of the transgression, e.g., one who wrote

Daf 70b

only <b><i>shem</i>,</b> part of the word, the letters <i>shin</i> and <i>mem</i>, <b>from Shimon. Them</b> refers to one who performed <b>the primary categories of labor. Of them</b> refers to one who performed <b>subcategories</b> of prohibited labors. <b>One that is them</b> refers to one transgression with multiple punishments, as in a case where his action was <b>intentional</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat</b> in that he was aware that it was Shabbat, <b>and</b> his action <b>was unwitting</b> with regard to the <b>prohibited labors</b> in that he was unaware that the labors were prohibited. In that case, he is liable for each primary category of labor. <b>Them that are one</b> refers to several transgressions with one punishment, as in a case where his action was <b>unwitting</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat</b> in that he was unaware that it was Shabbat, <b>and</b> his action <b>was intentional</b> with regard to the <b>prohibited labors</b> in that he was aware that the labors were prohibited. In that case, he is liable to bring only one sin-offering. Apparently, Rabbi Yosei has a source for the division of Shabbat labors. Why doesn’t <b>Shmuel</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> from that source? The Gemara answers: Shmuel did <b>not derive one that is them and them that are one</b> from the verse.
<b>Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>if</b> a person had a <b>lapse of awareness of both this,</b> Shabbat, <b>and that,</b> a particular labor? <b>He said to him: He</b> had a <b>lapse of awareness</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat and is liable to</b> bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering. Rava said to him: <b>On the contrary, he</b> had a <b>lapse of awareness</b> with regard to <b>prohibited labors, and</b> he should be <b>liable for each and every</b> labor that he performed. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: We see, if</b> it is <b>due to awareness of Shabbat that he desists</b> from performing the labor when he is told what day it is, then, apparently, it was a <b>lapse of awareness</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat, and he is liable for only one. And if</b> it is <b>due to awareness of the prohibited labor that he desists,</b> then, apparently, it was a <b>lapse of awareness</b> with regard to the <b>labors and he is liable for each and every one. Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Does</b> he <b>desist due to Shabbat</b> for any reason <b>other than because</b> he knows that the <b>labors</b> are prohibited? <b>And</b> similarly, <b>does</b> he <b>desist from</b> performing the <b>labors</b> when told that it is prohibited for any reason <b>other than because</b> he knows that it is <b>Shabbat?</b> When one desists from labor when he is told that it is Shabbat, it is because he understands that the labor he is performing is prohibited on Shabbat. Similarly, when one desists from his labor when he is told that the labor is prohibited, it is because he understands that the day is Shabbat. <b>Rather, there is no difference</b> between the cases, and in both he is considered unwitting with regard to Shabbat.
The Gemara further discusses the matter from a different perspective. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna: The number of <b>primary categories of prohibited labors</b> on Shabbat is <b>forty-less-one,</b> which the mishna proceeds to list. <b>And we discussed</b> this mishna: <b>Why do I need</b> this <b>tally</b> of forty-less-one? Isn’t merely listing the prohibited labors sufficient? <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The tally was included to teach <b>that if he performed all</b> the prohibited labors <b>in</b> the course of <b>one lapse of awareness</b> during which he was unaware of the prohibition involved, <b>he is liable for each and every one. Granted, if you say</b> that one who had a <b>lapse of awareness of both this and that is liable for each and every one, it works out well. However, if you say</b> that since one who had a <b>lapse of awareness of this and that</b> had a <b>lapse of awareness</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat,</b> and <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering, under what circumstances <b>can you find</b> a case where one would be liable for unwittingly violating all thirty-nine labors? It must be in a case where, <b>with regard to Shabbat,</b> his actions were <b>intentional,</b> as he was aware that it was Shabbat, <b>and,</b> with regard to the prohibited <b>labors,</b> his actions were <b>unwitting,</b> as he was unaware that these labors were prohibited on Shabbat.
It works out <b>well if he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said: Once he was unwitting with regard to</b> the fact that the punishment for his transgression is <b><i>karet</i>, even though he</b> was aware that his action was in violation of a Torah <b>prohibition</b> and performed the transgression <b>intentionally,</b> he is considered to have sinned unwittingly. <b>You find</b> that possibility in a case <b>where he was aware that</b> performing labor on <b>Shabbat</b> involves violation of a Torah <b>prohibition,</b> but he was unaware that the punishment for violating that prohibition is <i>karet</i>. <b>However, if he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> who <b>said:</b> It is not considered unwitting <b>until he was unwitting with regard to</b> both the <b>prohibition and <i>karet</i>,</b> the result is that he is completely unaware of all the prohibited labors of Shabbat. The question then arises: With regard <b>to what</b> aspect of Shabbat was he aware? If he was completely unaware of all the labors prohibited on Shabbat, in what sense were his actions intentional with regard to Shabbat? The Gemara answers: <b>He was aware</b> of the <i>halakhot</i> of the prohibition of <b>Shabbat boundaries, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> who holds that that prohibition is by Torah law.
<b>Rava said:</b> One who <b>reaped and ground</b> grain in the measure of <b>a dried fig-bulk,</b> the measure that determines liability for the labors of reaping and grinding on Shabbat, while in performing those actions he was <b>unwitting</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat and intentional</b> with regard to the <b>prohibited labors.</b> He was unaware that it was Shabbat, but he was aware that the labors were prohibited. <b>And</b> he did not realize that he had sinned until he <b>again reaped and ground</b> grain in the measure of <b>a dried fig-bulk,</b> while in performing those actions he was <b>intentional</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat and unwitting</b> with regard to the <b>prohibited labors.</b> He was aware that it was Shabbat, but he was unaware that the labors were prohibited. <b>And</b> afterward <b>he became aware</b> that he had performed the labors of <b>reaping and grinding</b> while <b>unwitting</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat and intentional</b> with regard to the <b>prohibited labors.</b> He set aside a sin-offering to atone for his sin, based on the principle that he need set aside only one sin-offering even though he performed two primary categories of labor in the same lapse of awareness. <b>And</b> afterward <b>he became aware</b> that he had performed the labors of <b>reaping and grinding</b> while <b>intentional</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat and unwitting</b> with regard to the <b>prohibited labors.</b> For performing two categories of prohibited labor unwittingly, reaping and grinding, one should be liable to bring two sin-offerings.

Daf 71a

Nevertheless, in that case, the sin-offering that atoned for the unwitting act of <b>reaping,</b> which he performed when his action was unwitting with regard to Shabbat, <b>draws</b> with it atonement for the second unwitting act of <b>reaping,</b> which he performed when his action was unwitting with regard to the prohibited labor, and for which he also was liable to bring a sin-offering. <b>And</b> similarly, the sin-offering that atoned for the unwitting act of <b>grinding,</b> which he performed when his action was unwitting with regard to Shabbat, <b>draws</b> with it atonement for the unwitting act of <b>grinding,</b> which he performed when his action was unwitting with regard to the prohibited labor. Since the offering was sacrificed after he had committed both transgressions, he attains atonement with one sacrifice, even though he performed several forms of the transgression in a single lapse of awareness. <b>However,</b> if the order of events in that case was different in that <b>he became aware of reaping</b> performed when his action was <b>intentional</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat and</b> his action was <b>unwitting</b> with regard to <b>the prohibited labors,</b> and he set aside an offering to atone for his unwitting transgression, and only afterward he became aware that he had performed the labors of reaping and grinding when his actions were unwitting with regard to Shabbat, the sin-offering that he brings for the <b>reaping draws</b> with it atonement for the previous <b>reaping and</b> the <b>concomitant grinding.</b> As far as the lapse of awareness with regard to Shabbat is concerned, reaping and grinding are considered like one sin, and atonement for one atones for the other. <b>And the parallel grinding</b> that he performed together with the latter reaping <b>remains in its place,</b> i.e., he does not attain atonement for that transgression. When he becomes aware of it, he brings a separate offering for atonement.
<b>Abaye said: Grinding also draws</b> the latter <b>grinding</b> with it, as <b>the designation of grinding is one.</b> Since he attained atonement for one act of grinding, atonement is attained for the second act of grinding as well, as they were performed in one lapse of awareness, and he became aware only after the acts were completed. The Gemara asks: <b>And is Rava of</b> the opinion that atonement can be attained by means of <b>drawing? Wasn’t it stated</b> that there is a dispute with regard to that matter in a case where one unwittingly <b>ate two olive</b>-bulks <b>of forbidden fat in one lapse of awareness,</b> e.g., he ate two pieces of forbidden fat from different parts of an animal in the belief that they were permitted fat? One is liable to bring a sin-offering for that transgression. <b>And</b> in a case where <b>he became aware</b> that <b>one of</b> the olive-bulks was forbidden fat, <b>and then ate a</b> third <b>olive-bulk</b> while still in the midst <b>of the lapse of awareness of</b> the <b>second</b> piece of forbidden fat, i.e., he had not yet become aware that the second of the original olive-bulks was indeed prohibited and after eating the third olive-bulk, he became aware of both the second and the third pieces of fat. <b>Rava said:</b> If <b>he brought a sacrifice for</b> the <b>first, atonement is attained</b> for the transgressions of the <b>first and second</b> olive-bulks, since he ate both in one lapse of awareness. However, <b>atonement is not attained</b> for the <b>third</b> because awareness of the first olive-bulk interposes.
<b>If he brought a sacrifice for the third</b> after he became aware that he had sinned, <b>atonement is attained</b> for the transgressions of the <b>third and second,</b> since both were performed in one lapse of awareness. However, <b>atonement is not attained</b> for the transgression of the <b>first,</b> which occurred in a separate lapse of awareness. <b>If he brought a sacrifice for the middle one, atonement is attained for all,</b> since both the first and third olive-bulks have a lapse of awareness common with the second. <b>Abaye said: Even if he brought a sacrifice for</b> any <b>one of them, atonement is attained</b> for <b>all of them</b> by means of drawing. Since he attained atonement for one of the olive-bulks, that atonement draws with it atonement for the other olive-bulks with which it shared a lapse of awareness. In any case, apparently Rava is not of the opinion that atonement draws with it atonement. How, then, does he say that atonement for reaping draws with it atonement for other acts of reaping? The Gemara answers: <b>After he heard</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from Abaye</b>, <b>he adopted it.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If so,</b> if Rava accepts the principle of drawing, by that same principle <b>grinding should also draw</b> with it <b>grinding.</b> The Gemara answers: There is a difference. Although <b>he is of</b> the opinion that atonement can be attained by means of <b>drawing, he is not of</b> the opinion that atonement that was attained through <b>drawing</b> can draw additional atonement through <b>drawing.</b> Atonement for the initial transgression of grinding was only attained by means of being drawn by the atonement for reaping. Rava holds that it cannot then proceed to draw atonement for the latter act of grinding.
The Gemara comments: <b>A matter that</b> was <b>obvious to Abaye and Rava was a dilemma for Rabbi Zeira.</b> In a case where one’s action was intentional with regard to Shabbat and unwitting with regard to the labors, and in a case where one’s action was unwitting with regard to Shabbat and intentional with regard to the labors, he is liable to bring only one sin-offering for the unwitting violation of Shabbat. This was not obvious to Rabbi Zeira, <b>as Rabbi Zeira raised a dilemma before Rabbi Asi, and others say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raised a dilemma before Rabbi Zeira:</b> If <b>one reaped and ground</b> grain in the measure of <b>half a dried fig-bulk,</b> and his action was <b>unwitting with regard to Shabbat and intentional with regard to the prohibited labors.</b> He is certainly not liable by Torah law because he reaped and ground less than the minimum measure for liability. <b>And then he reaped or ground</b> grain in the amount of <b>half a dried fig-bulk</b> and his action was <b>intentional with regard to Shabbat and unwitting with regard to the prohibited labors, do they join</b> together to constitute the minimum measure that determines liability to bring a sin-offering when he becomes aware that he sinned? <b>He said to him:</b> They <b>are separate with regard to sin-offerings,</b> i.e., if one reaped and ground the minimum measure that determines liability, he is liable to bring two sin-offerings, <b>and</b> therefore <b>they do not join</b> together to constitute the minimum measure.
The Gemara asks: <b>And wherever they are separate with regard to sin-offerings,</b> do <b>they not join</b> together? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: If <b>one ate</b> one piece of <b>forbidden fat and</b> then ate another piece of <b>forbidden fat,</b> each larger than the measure for liability, <b>in one lapse of awareness, he is liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering? In the next case in the mishna, four items are listed. If one eats them unwittingly he is liable to bring a sin-offering. If <b>he ate forbidden fat, and blood, and <i>notar</i>,</b> sacrifices that remained after the time when they may be eaten has expired, <b>and <i>piggul</i>,</b> sacrifices that were invalidated due to inappropriate intent while being offered, <b>in one lapse of awareness, he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for each and every one. That is the stricture</b> that applies <b>to many types</b> of prohibitions relative <b>to one,</b> the same, <b>type. And this is the stricture of one type</b> relative <b>to many types: That if one ate half an olive</b>-bulk, <b>and then ate</b> another <b>half an olive</b>-bulk <b>from one type, he is liable</b> because the two half measures join to constitute a single measure. <b>And</b> if he ate two halves of an olive-bulk <b>from two types, he is exempt.</b>
<b>And we discussed</b> this mishna: When we learned of one who ate two halves of an olive-bulk <b>from one type,</b> was it <b>necessary to say</b> that he <b>is liable?</b> That is obvious. <b>And Reish Lakish said in the name of</b> the Sage, <b>bar Tutni: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where he ate</b> two halves of an olive-bulk <b>from two dishes,</b> where each half was prepared separately, <b>and this is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, who said</b> that <b>dishes separate.</b> One who eats two olive-bulks of prohibited food that was prepared in two different dishes in the course of one lapse of awareness is liable to bring a sin-offering for each one. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua stated</b> his opinion that dishes separate <b>both as a leniency and as a stricture,</b> and therefore one who ate two halves of an olive-bulk from two dishes would be exempt, the mishna <b>teaches us that</b> Rabbi Yehoshua <b>did not state</b> his opinion <b>as a leniency. He stated</b> his opinion <b>as a stricture.</b>
<b>But here,</b> where they are <b>separate</b> with regard to the number of <b>sin-offerings,</b> i.e., according to Rabbi Yehoshua one who eats an olive-bulk from each of the two dishes is liable to bring two sin-offerings, <b>and,</b> nevertheless, the two halves of an olive-bulk from the two dishes <b>join</b> together and constitute a full measure and render him liable to bring a sin-offering. Rabbi Zeira <b>said</b> to Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>The Master taught</b> Reish Lakish’s response <b>with regard to the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>and it is difficult for him. We taught</b> Reish Lakish’s response <b>with regard to the latter clause</b> of the mishna, <b>and it is not difficult for us.</b> When we learned in the latter clause of the mishna: One who ate two halves of an olive-bulk <b>from two types,</b> was it <b>necessary to say</b> that he <b>is exempt?</b> That is obvious. <b>Reish Lakish said in the name of bar Tutni: Actually,</b> it is referring even to a case where the prohibition was <b>from one type</b> of food. <b>And why</b> then <b>does</b> the mishna <b>call it two types?</b> Because <b>he eats it in</b> the <b>two</b> separate <b>dishes</b> in which it was prepared. <b>And</b> this ruling is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua, who said</b> that <b>dishes separate. And this teaches us</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua stated</b> his opinion that dishes separate <b>both as a leniency and as a stricture.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the latter</b> clause is referring to <b>one type</b> of food <b>and</b> a case where the two halves of an olive-bulk were prepared in <b>two dishes,</b> as explained above,

Daf 71b

<b>by inference, the first</b> clause in the mishna is referring to <b>one type</b> of food <b>and one dish.</b> The problem is then more difficult. In a case where one ate two halves of an olive-bulk <b>from one type</b> of food <b>and</b> in <b>one dish,</b> was it <b>necessary to say</b> that he is liable? That is obvious. <b>Rav Huna said: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where he had</b> a period of <b>awareness between</b> eating the two half olive-bulks. After eating the first half of an olive-bulk, he became aware that he had eaten food that was prohibited. Then he became unaware again and ate the second half of an olive-bulk. Although, with regard to sacrifices, awareness usually serves as a line of demarcation between unwitting transgressions performed prior to the period of awareness and unwitting transgressions performed thereafter, the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Gamliel who said: There is no awareness for half a measure.</b> Since one is not liable to bring a sacrifice for half a measure, the fact that one became aware between consumption of the two halves of an olive-bulk is of no significance and does not demarcate between the two half-measures with regard to liability to bring a sin-offering.
A dispute between <i>amora’im</i> <b>was stated: With regard to one who ate two olive</b>-bulks <b>of forbidden fat in one lapse of awareness, and became aware of</b> the transgression of eating the <b>first</b> olive-bulk, <b>and then became aware of</b> the transgression of eating the <b>second, Rabbi Yoḥanan said: He is liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings, one offering for each transgression. <b>And Reish Lakish said: He is liable</b> to bring <b>only one.</b> Both Sages cite proofs for their opinions. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that <b>he is liable</b> as it is stated: “And he shall offer <b>for his sin</b> that he sinned…<b>and he shall bring</b> the ox” (Leviticus 4:3-4), indicating that he is liable to bring a separate sacrifice for each sin. <b>And Reish Lakish said he is exempt,</b> as it is stated: “And the priest shall atone for him <b>from his sin, and it shall be forgiven for him”</b> (Leviticus 4:26), indicating that even if he atoned from his sin, i.e., for part of his sin and not all of his sin, the entire transgression is forgiven.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how can <b>Reish Lakish</b> say that one sin-offering is sufficient? <b>Isn’t it written: “For his sin</b>…<b>and he shall bring”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse refers to a case where he only became aware of the second sin <b>after</b> attaining <b>atonement</b> for the first. However, if he became aware prior to atonement, he is required to bring only one sin-offering. The Gemara asks: <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan, too,</b> how can he say that one is liable to bring two sin-offerings? <b>Isn’t it written: “From his sin, and it shall be forgiven for him?</b> The Gemara answers: According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>with what are we dealing here?</b> It is a case <b>where one ate an olive-bulk and a half, and he became aware of</b> his transgression of eating a single <b>olive-bulk, and then he ate another half of an olive</b>-bulk <b>in</b> the course of <b>the lapse of awareness of</b> the <b>second</b> half of an olive-bulk that he ate together with the whole olive-bulk. <b>Lest you say</b> that the two halves of an olive-bulk should <b>join together,</b> and he is liable to bring an additional sin-offering, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that in that case he is exempt because he has already atoned for part of his transgression.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> In the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish, <b>they disagree</b> in a case <b>where one became aware</b> of the second transgression <b>prior to designating</b> an animal for the first sin-offering, <b>and this is</b> the point over which <b>they disagree: That</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that periods of <b>awareness separate.</b> Since one became aware of his sins at two different stages, he is liable to bring two sin-offerings. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Reish Lakish, <b>holds</b> that only <b>designations</b> of animals for sacrifices <b>separate. However,</b> if one became aware of the second transgression <b>after designation</b> of the animal for the first sin-offering, <b>Reish Lakish agrees with Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings. <b>Or, perhaps they are disagreeing</b> in a case <b>where he became aware</b> of the second sin <b>after designating</b> an animal for the first sin-offering, <b>and this is</b> the point over which <b>they disagree: That</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>designations separate; and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Reish Lakish, <b>holds</b> that only <b>atonements separate.</b> Only after the sin-offering has been sacrificed on the altar and the sinner has obtained atonement can it be said that the sacrifice’s capacity to atone is spent and cannot atone for a sin of which he became aware afterward. <b>However,</b> if he became aware of the second sin <b>prior to designation</b> of the sacrifice, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan agrees with Reish Lakish</b> that <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering. <b>Or, perhaps,</b> the <b>dispute</b> between them is <b>both in this</b> case, before designation, <b>and in that</b> case, after designation.
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: It is reasonable</b> to say that <b>the dispute is both in this</b> case <b>and in that</b> case. <b>As, should it enter your mind</b> that <b>they disagree</b> only in a case where he became aware of the second sin <b>prior to designation</b> of an animal for the first sin-offering, <b>and</b> in a case where he became aware <b>after designation Reish Lakish agrees with Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings, then <b>rather than establishing the verse</b> that posed a difficulty to Reish Lakish’s opinion in a case where one became aware of the second sin <b>after atonement</b> for the first, <b>let him establish it</b> in a case where one became aware of the transgression <b>after designation</b> of an animal for the first sin-offering. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>if</b> you say that <b>they disagree</b> only in a case where he became aware of the second sin <b>after designation, and</b> in a case where he became aware <b>prior to designation Rabbi Yoḥanan agrees with Reish Lakish</b> that <b>he is only liable to</b> bring <b>one</b> sin-offering, then <b>rather than establishing the verse</b> that posed a difficulty to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion in a case where he ate <b>an olive-bulk and a half, let him establish it</b> in a case where he became aware of the transgression <b>prior to designation.</b>
Ravina does not accept this proof, as, in his opinion, it is flawed: <b>And perhaps there is uncertainty</b> with regard to this matter, <b>and he spoke</b> employing the style of: <b>If you wish to say. If you wish to say</b> that <b>they disagree</b> in a case where he became aware of the second sin <b>prior to designation,</b> then <b>how does Rabbi Yoḥanan establish the verse?</b> He establishes the verse in a case where one ate <b>an olive-bulk and a half. And if you wish to say they disagree</b> in a case where he became aware of the second sin <b>after designation,</b> then <b>how does Reish Lakish establish the verse?</b> He establishes the verse in a case where one became aware of the second sin <b>after</b> attaining <b>atonement.</b>
<b>Ulla said: According to the one who said</b> that in order to designate <b>a definite guilt-offering,</b> a sacrifice brought by one who committed a robbery, misused sacred objects, or had relations with a designated maidservant, one <b>does not require prior knowledge</b> that he definitely sinned,

Daf 72a

one who <b>had relations with a designated maidservant five times is only liable to</b> bring <b>one</b> guilt-offering, even if he became aware of his transgression between each instance of relations with her. Because awareness is insignificant with regard to this sacrifice, it does not demarcate in terms of the number of guilt-offerings that he is liable to bring. <b>Rav Hamnuna strongly objects to</b> this <i>halakha</i>: <b>But if</b> what you say is <b>so, one who had relations</b> with a designated maidservant, <b>and again had relations, and designated</b> an animal for the <b>offering, and said: Wait for me</b> before sacrificing the offering <b>until I have relations</b> again, so that the guilt-offering will atone for this transgression as well, would you say that the <b>same</b> applies in that case <b>too,</b> that <b>he is only liable to</b> bring <b>one</b> guilt-offering? Ulla <b>said to him: You referred</b> to <b>an action</b> performed <b>after designation</b> of an animal for the guilt-offering. <b>I did not say</b> that <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>an action</b> that was performed <b>after designation.</b>
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said:</b> According <b>to the one who said</b> that in order to designate <b>a definite guilt-offering one requires prior knowledge</b> that he definitely sinned, one who <b>had relations five times with a designated maidservant is liable to</b> bring a guilt-offering <b>for each and every one.</b> Because awareness is significant with regard to guilt-offerings, the awareness between the acts of cohabitation renders each a separate transgression. <b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Dimi: That is not so, as with regard to a <b>sin-offering for which we require prior knowledge, Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish disagree</b> whether or not awareness following an unwitting sin demarcates one transgression from another. Rav Dimi <b>was silent</b> and had no response. In an attempt to resolve the problem, Abaye <b>said to him: Perhaps you said</b> your statement with regard to <b>an act</b> that the sinner seeks to commit <b>after designating</b> an animal as a guilt-offering but wants to attain atonement for by means of that same designated sacrifice. That statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rav Hamnuna.</b> Rav Dimi remembered and <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>Yes,</b> that was what was originally stated.
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he cited several disputes concerning the <i>halakhot</i> of guilt-offerings and <b>said: Everyone agrees with regard to a designated maidservant, and everyone agrees with regard to a designated maidservant, and there is a dispute with regard to a designated maidservant.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Everyone agrees with regard to a designated maidservant; one is liable to</b> bring <b>only one</b> guilt-offering, even for many acts of cohabitation, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ulla.</b> Ulla said that since prior knowledge is not required for liability to bring a guilt-offering, even if one became aware of his transgression between each time he had relations, he brings only one sacrifice. <b>And everyone agrees with regard to a designated maidservant; one is liable for each and every</b> act of cohabitation, if it occurred after designation of an animal for a guilt-offering for the previous transgression, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Hamnuna. And there is a dispute with regard to a designated maidservant;</b> this refers <b>to the one who said</b> that, in order to designate <b>a definite guilt-offering, one requires prior knowledge</b> that he definitely sinned. In that case, the legal status of the guilt-offering is equal to that of the sin-offering and is the subject of <b>a dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> who disagree whether awareness between two unwitting transgressions demarcates and requires two offerings.
<b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to the <i>halakha</i> in the following case:

Daf 72b

<b>One who intended to lift</b> a plant <b>detached</b> from the ground on Shabbat <b>and</b> mistakenly <b>severed</b> a plant still <b>attached</b> to the ground, which under other circumstances constitutes performance of the prohibited labor of reaping, <b>is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering for his mistaken act, since he did not intend to perform an act of cutting. One who performs an action unawares [<i>mitasek</i>], i.e., he had no intention to perform the act at all, incurs no liability whatsoever. One who intended <b>to cut</b> a <b>detached</b> plant <b>and</b> unwittingly <b>severed</b> a plant still <b>attached</b> to the ground, <b>Rava said:</b> He too <b>is exempt. Abaye said: He is liable.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rava said</b> that <b>he is exempt because</b> he <b>did not intend</b> to perform an act of <b>prohibited severing.</b> He intended to perform an action completely permitted on Shabbat. He had no misconception with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat. It was merely a mistaken act. And <b>Abaye said</b> that <b>he is liable because he intended</b> to perform a <b>standard</b> act <b>of cutting.</b> Since he intended to perform that act, and he carried out his intent, the Torah characterizes it as unwitting and not as unawares.
<b>Rava said: From where do I</b> derive to <b>say this</b> opinion? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There is <b>a stricture</b> with regard to the prohibitions of <b>Shabbat</b> that is greater <b>than</b> the stricture with regard to <b>other mitzvot, and a stricture</b> with regard to <b>other mitzvot</b> that is greater <b>than</b> the stricture with regard to <b>Shabbat.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>A stricture</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat</b> that is greater <b>than</b> the stricture with regard to <b>other mitzvot</b> is <b>that,</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat, one who performed two</b> transgressions on Shabbat, even if he did so <b>in</b> the course of <b>one lapse of awareness, is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for each and every one, which is not</b> the case <b>in other mitzvot.</b> In other mitzvot, if an individual commits a transgression several times in the course of one lapse of awareness, he is liable to bring only one sin-offering. <b>And a stricture</b> with regard to <b>other mitzvot</b> that is greater <b>than</b> the stricture with regard to <b>Shabbat</b> is <b>that,</b> with regard to <b>other mitzvot,</b> one who performs an act <b>unwittingly without intent is liable, which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b>Shabbat.</b> Apparently, the phrase unwittingly without intent refers to the case disputed by Abaye and Rava. Therefore, this is proof for Rava’s opinion that, with regard to Shabbat, one who acts unawares, i.e., whose action resulted from involvement in another matter and who had no intention to perform an action that is prohibited, is not considered to have performed an unwitting act.
Before the Gemara discusses the <i>baraita</i> in the context of the dispute between Abaye and Rava, the Gemara analyzes its text. <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>A stricture</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat</b> that is greater <b>than</b> the stricture with regard to <b>other mitzvot</b> is <b>that,</b> with regard to <b>Shabbat, one who performed two</b> transgressions on Shabbat, even <b>in</b> the course of <b>one lapse of awareness, is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for each and every one, which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b>other mitzvot.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If you say that he</b> unwittingly <b>performed</b> acts of <b>reaping and grinding</b> on Shabbat, <b>the corresponding</b> situation with regard to <b>other mitzvot</b> is a case where <b>he ate forbidden fat and blood.</b> If so, there is no difference between Shabbat and other mitzvot. <b>Here</b> one <b>is liable to</b> bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings <b>and here</b> one <b>is liable to</b> bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings. <b>Rather, what are the circumstances</b> in <b>other mitzvot where he is liable to</b> bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering? It is in a case <b>where</b> he <b>ate forbidden fat and</b> again ate <b>forbidden fat</b> within one lapse of awareness. <b>The corresponding</b> situation with regard to <b>Shabbat</b> is a case where <b>one performed</b> an act of <b>reaping and</b> performed another act of <b>reaping</b> within one lapse of awareness. However, in that case too there is no difference between Shabbat and other mitzvot. <b>Here</b> one <b>is liable to</b> bring <b>one</b> sin-offering, <b>and here</b> one <b>is liable to</b> bring <b>one</b> sin-offering.
The Gemara explains: <b>Actually,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> one <b>performed</b> acts of <b>reaping and grinding. And what</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>Which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b>other mitzvot?</b> It is not referring to all mitzvot in general. It is referring to the prohibition of <b>idolatry,</b> which is comprised of separate component prohibitions, each of which incurs independent liability. This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ami, as Rabbi Ami said: One who sacrificed</b> to idolatry, <b>and burned</b> incense before it, <b>and poured</b> wine as a libation before it in the course of <b>one lapse of awareness is liable to</b> bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering. That is the ruling, even though, had he performed those rites separately, he would be liable to bring a sin-offering for each. That, then, is the stricture of other mitzvot relative to Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>In what</b> case <b>did you establish</b> the <i>baraita</i>, <b>in</b> the case of <b>idolatry?</b> If so, <b>state the latter</b> clause and determine whether that explanation applies there as well. The latter clause states: <b>A stricture</b> with regard to <b>other mitzvot</b> that is greater than the stricture with regard to Shabbat is <b>that,</b> with regard to <b>other mitzvot,</b> one who performs an act <b>unwittingly without intent is liable, which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b>Shabbat.</b> One who acts unawares with no intent to perform a prohibited act is not considered to have performed an unwitting act. <b>That</b> case of performing an act <b>unwittingly without intent with</b> regard to <b>idolatry, what are the circumstances? If you say</b> that it is referring to a case <b>where he thought</b> that <b>it was a synagogue and bowed to it,</b> and it turned out that he bowed to idolatry, he committed no transgression. Since <b>his heart was</b> directed <b>toward Heaven,</b> it is not even an unwitting transgression. <b>Rather,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where he saw a statue [<i>andarta</i>]</b> in the image of the king <b>and bowed to it. What are the circumstances? If</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>in which</b> he bowed because <b>he accepted</b> that image <b>upon himself as a god, he</b> worshipped idolatry <b>intentionally</b> and is not liable to bring a sin-offering. <b>And if he did not accept</b> that image <b>upon himself as a god</b> and bowed merely in deference to the monarch, <b>it is meaningless</b> and is not an act of idolatry.
<b>Rather,</b> it is referring to a case where one bowed <b>due to love</b> of someone who requested that he bow before the statue <b>and due to fear</b> of someone coercing him to do so. He is under the impression that unless he wholeheartedly has the intention to worship the idol, there is no prohibition involved. <b>This</b> works out <b>well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye, who said:</b> One who bows due to love or fear <b>is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering. <b>However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, who said:</b> One who bows due to love or fear <b>is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering, <b>what can be said?</b> According to Rava’s opinion, the problem remains. There is no case in which there is a difference between the ruling in the case of idolatry and the ruling in the case of Shabbat. <b>Rather,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where one says</b> to himself that this <b>is permitted.</b> He is under the impression that idolatry is permitted, and his unwitting act was the result of ignorance, not forgetfulness. The statement in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Which is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b>Shabbat,</b> is referring to one who was under the impression that performing labors on Shabbat is permitted. One <b>who</b> performs prohibited labors under those circumstances <b>is completely exempt.</b>
That conclusion contradicts another statement of Rava. With regard to one who is unaware of both the essence of Shabbat and the individual prohibited labors, <b>Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman only whether to deem him liable to</b> bring <b>one or whether to deem him liable to</b> bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings. <b>However,</b> the possibility <b>to exempt him completely</b> did <b>not</b> enter Rava’s mind. That explanation of the <i>baraita</i> is incompatible with Rava’s opinion.

Daf 73a

<b>Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> that the <b>first</b> clause of the <i>baraita</i> is dealing <b>with</b> the contrast between Shabbat and <b>idolatry, and the latter</b> clause of the <i>baraita</i> is dealing <b>with</b> contrasting Shabbat and <b>other mitzvot? And what are the circumstances</b> of: <b>Unwitting without intent, with</b> regard to <b>other mitzvot?</b> It is in a case <b>where</b> one <b>thought</b> that it <b>was</b> permitted <b>fat, and ate it,</b> and later discovered that it was forbidden fat. This is one example of other mitzvot where one is liable. <b>That is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b>Shabbat, where</b> he <b>is exempt, as</b> one who <b>intended to cut</b> a <b>detached</b> plant <b>and</b> unwittingly <b>severed</b> a plant still <b>attached</b> to the ground is <b>exempt. And</b> according to <b>Abaye</b>, who holds that he is liable in that case, <b>what are the circumstances</b> of: <b>Unwitting without intent,</b> with regard to other mitzvot? It is in a case <b>where</b> one had something in his mouth and <b>he thought it was spittle and swallowed it</b> with no intention to eat it, and it turned out to be forbidden fat that he swallowed. This is one example of other mitzvot, where he is liable. <b>That is not</b> the case <b>with</b> regard to <b>Shabbat,</b> where the phrase: He is <b>exempt,</b> is referring to the case of <b>one who intended to lift</b> a plant <b>detached</b> from the ground <b>and</b> mistakenly <b>severed</b> a plant still <b>attached</b> to the ground. In that case, even Abaye agrees that <b>he is exempt. However,</b> one who <b>intended to cut</b> a <b>detached</b> plant <b>and</b> unwittingly <b>severed</b> a plant still <b>attached</b> to the ground <b>is liable</b> since he intended to perform a standard act of cutting. Therefore, no proof can be cited from this <i>baraita</i>.
A similar dispute between Abaye and Rava <b>was stated.</b> In the case of <b>one who intended to throw</b> an object <b>two</b> cubits in the public domain, for which he would not be liable by Torah law, <b>and</b> it turned out that <b>he threw</b> it <b>four</b> cubits, in violation of the prohibition by Torah law against carrying an object four cubits in the public domain, <b>Rava said:</b> He is <b>exempt. Abaye said:</b> He is <b>liable.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rava said:</b> He is <b>exempt, as he does not intend</b> to execute <b>a throw</b> of <b>four</b> cubits, and, consequently, does not intend to perform a prohibited act. <b>Abaye said:</b> He is <b>liable, as he intends</b> to execute <b>a standard throw,</b> and ultimately a throw that traveled a prohibited distance was executed. Another dispute between them was stated. In the case of <b>one who thought</b> that he was in <b>the private domain</b> and threw an object more than four cubits, <b>and,</b> ultimately, <b>it was found</b> to be <b>the public domain, Rava said:</b> He is <b>exempt. And Abaye said:</b> He is <b>liable.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rava said:</b> He is <b>exempt,</b> as <b>he does not intend</b> to execute <b>a prohibited throw.</b> In a private domain, he may throw an object as far as he chooses. <b>And Abaye said:</b> He is <b>liable, as he intends</b> to execute <b>a standard throw.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And it is necessary</b> to mention these three disputes, despite their similarities, because each one teaches a unique element. <b>As, had</b> the Gemara <b>taught us</b> only <b>the first,</b> the case of one who intended to lift a plant detached from the ground and mistakenly severed a plant still attached to the ground, we would have said that it was only <b>in that</b> case that <b>Rava said</b> he is exempt, <b>as he does not intend</b> to perform an act of <b>prohibited severing.</b> He had no intention to perform an action that entails desecration of Shabbat. <b>However,</b> the ruling in the case of <b>one who intended to throw</b> an object <b>two</b> cubits in the public domain <b>and he threw</b> it <b>four</b> cubits would be more stringent, <b>as</b> an object <b>cannot be thrown four</b> cubits <b>without</b> being thrown <b>two cubits.</b> A throw of two cubits is a component part of the four-cubit throw. Consequently, <b>say</b> that in that case Rava <b>agrees with Abaye,</b> as he performed an act that has a prohibited dimension to it. <b>And, had</b> the Gemara <b>taught us</b> the dispute in <b>this</b> case of throwing two cubits as well, we would have said that it is only <b>in that</b> case that <b>Rava says</b> that he is exempt, <b>as he does not intend</b> to execute <b>a throw of four</b> cubits. A throw of fewer than four cubits does not constitute a transgression. <b>However,</b> in the case of <b>one who thought</b> that he was in <b>the private domain, and</b> ultimately <b>it was found</b> to be <b>the public domain where the individual intends</b> to execute <b>a throw</b> of <b>four</b> cubits, which is a prohibited distance, <b>say</b> that Rava <b>agrees with Abaye</b> that he is liable. Therefore, <b>it is necessary</b> to mention all three cases in which they disagree.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna: <b>The primary categories of labor are forty-less-one, and we discussed it</b> and asked: <b>Why do I need</b> this <b>tally</b> of forty-less-one? <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The tally was included to teach <b>that if one performed all of</b> the prohibited labors <b>in</b> the course of <b>one lapse of awareness</b> during which he was unaware of the prohibition involved, <b>he is liable for each and every one. Granted,</b> according <b>to Abaye, who said that in a</b> case <b>like that</b> one mentioned above, where one intended to throw an object two cubits and it traveled four cubits <b>he is liable, you find that</b> circumstance in a case where <b>he was aware that the prohibition of Shabbat</b> applies to certain labors, <b>and he was aware</b> that particular <b>labors were prohibited, and was mistaken with regard to measures.</b> He intended to perform an act involving less than the prohibited measure, and it turned out that the action he performed involved an amount equal to or greater than the prohibited measure. That is an unwitting act that renders him liable to bring a sin-offering, according to Abaye. <b>However, according to Rava, who said</b> that <b>he is exempt</b> in a case where one intended to throw an object two cubits and it traveled four cubits, in <b>what</b> circumstances <b>do you find that</b> he would be liable for each and every one? Is it in a case where, with regard to <b>Shabbat,</b> his actions were <b>intentional, and,</b> with regard to the <b>prohibited labors,</b> his actions were <b>unwitting?</b>
It works out <b>well if he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said: Once he was unwitting with regard to</b> the fact that the punishment for his transgression is <b><i>karet</i>, even though he</b> was aware that his action was in violation of a Torah <b>prohibition</b> and performed the transgression <b>intentionally,</b> he is considered to have sinned unwittingly. If he holds in accordance with that opinion, <b>you find</b> a case where one could be liable for each and every prohibited labor <b>when he was aware that</b> performing labor on <b>Shabbat</b> involves violation of a Torah <b>prohibition,</b> but he was unaware that the punishment for violating that prohibition is <i>karet</i>. <b>However, if he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> who <b>said:</b> It is not considered unwitting <b>until he was unwitting with regard to</b> both the <b>prohibition and <i>karet</i>,</b> the result is that he is completely unaware of all the prohibited labors of Shabbat. The question then arises: With regard <b>to what</b> aspect of Shabbat was he aware? If he was completely unaware of all the labors prohibited on Shabbat, in what sense were his actions intentional with regard to Shabbat? The Gemara answers: <b>He was aware</b> of the <i>halakhot</i> of the prohibition of <b>Shabbat boundaries, in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> who holds that this prohibition is by Torah law.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> This fundamental mishna enumerates those who perform the <b>primary categories of labor</b> prohibited on Shabbat, which number <b>forty-less-one.</b> They are grouped in accordance with their function: <b>One who sows, and one who plows, and one who reaps, and one who gathers</b> sheaves into a pile, <b>and one who threshes,</b> removing the kernel from the husk, <b>and one who winnows</b> threshed grain in the wind, and <b>one who selects</b> the inedible waste from the edible, and <b>one who grinds, and one who sifts</b> the flour in a sieve, <b>and one who kneads</b> dough, <b>and one who bakes.</b>
Additional primary categories of prohibited labor are the following: <b>One who shears wool,</b> and <b>one who whitens it, and one who combs</b> the fleece and straightens <b>it, and one who dyes it, and one who spins</b> the wool, <b>and one who stretches</b> the threads of the warp in the loom, <b>and one who constructs two meshes,</b> tying the threads of the warp to the base of the loom, <b>and one who weaves two threads, and one who severs two threads</b> for constructive purposes, and <b>one who ties</b> a knot, <b>and one who unties</b> a knot, <b>and one who sews two stitches</b> with a needle, as well as <b>one who tears</b> a fabric <b>in order to sew two stitches.</b>
<b>One who traps a deer,</b> or any living creature, and <b>one who slaughters it, and one who flays it,</b> and <b>one who salts its</b> hide, a step in the tanning process, <b>and one who tans its hide, and one who smooths it,</b> removing hairs and veins, <b>and one who cuts it</b> into measured parts.
<b>One who writes two letters and one who erases in order to write two letters. One who builds</b> a structure, <b>and one who dismantles</b> it, <b>one who extinguishes</b> a fire, <b>and one who kindles</b> a fire. <b>One who strikes</b> a blow <b>with a hammer</b> to complete the production process of a vessel (Rabbeinu Ḥananel), and <b>one who carries out</b> an object <b>from domain to domain.</b> All <b>these are primary categories of labor,</b> and they number <b>forty-less-one.</b>

Daf 73b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that the primary categories of labor number forty-less-one. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need</b> this <b>tally? Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The tally was included to teach <b>that if he performed all of</b> the prohibited labors <b>in</b> the course of <b>one lapse of awareness,</b> during which he was unaware of the prohibition involved, <b>he is liable for each and every one.</b>
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who sows, and one who plows.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Since, after all,</b> in terms of <b>plowing, one plows first</b> and only then sows, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> first <b>one who plows, and afterward let him teach one who sows.</b> The Gemara answers: The <b><i>tanna</i></b> ordered the mishna <b>based</b> on the practice <b>in Eretz Yisrael, where</b> they <b>sow first and then plow.</b> In Eretz Yisrael, the practice was to plow a second time after sowing to cover the seeds.
A <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught</b> with regard to the prohibited labor of sowing: <b>One who sows, and one who prunes</b> the branches of vines to accelerate their growth, <b>and one who plants, and one who bends</b> the branch of a vine or a tree into the ground so that it takes root while still attached to the trunk, <b>and one who grafts</b> the branch of one tree onto another have <b>all</b> performed <b>one</b> type of <b>labor,</b> as they all stimulate plant growth. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaching us?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>This teaches us</b> that <b>one who</b> unwittingly <b>performs numerous prohibited labors</b> subsumed under a <b>single</b> primary category <b>of labor,</b> like those listed in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>is liable to</b> bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering, since they are considered aspects of the same labor. <b>Rabbi Aḥa said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami said: One who prunes is liable for</b> the labor of <b>planting. And one who plants, and one who bends, and one who grafts is liable for</b> the labor of <b>sowing.</b> The Gemara is surprised at this: Is that to say that one who bends and one who grafts a branch, <b>for sowing, yes,</b> he is liable; <b>for planting, no,</b> he is <b>not</b> liable? These labors, performed on trees, are more similar to planting. Rather, <b>say</b> as follows: One is liable <b>even for sowing,</b> as with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat there is no difference between sowing and planting.
<b>Rav Kahana said:</b> One who <b>prunes</b> a tree <b>and needs the wood</b> that he hewed from the tree for fuel or some other purpose <b>is liable to</b> bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings: <b>One</b> sin-offering <b>due to</b> the labor of <b>reaping,</b> like anyone who severs an item from the ground for the purpose of harvesting the detached object, and <b>one</b> sin-offering <b>due to</b> the labor of <b>planting,</b> since he thereby stimulates growth of the plant. Similarly, <b>Rav Yosef said: One who reaps alfalfa is liable to</b> bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings: <b>One due to reaping,</b> since he is cutting the plant for animal feed, <b>and one due to planting,</b> since cutting stimulates the growth of the alfalfa. Similarly, <b>Abaye said: One who cuts beet leaves is liable to</b> bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings: <b>One due to reaping and one due to sowing.</b>
We learned in the mishna among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who plows.</b> A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the labor of plowing: <b>One who plows, and one who digs, and one who makes a furrow</b> in the ground have <b>all</b> performed <b>one</b> type of <b>labor. Rav Sheshet said: One who had a mound</b> of earth <b>and removed it in the house,</b> thereby evening the surface, <b>is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>building,</b> as he thereby engages in construction of the house. <b>In the field, he is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>plowing.</b> Similarly, <b>Rava said: One who had a hole and filled it, in the house he is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>building. In the field, he is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>plowing.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abba said: One who digs a hole on Shabbat and</b> digs the hole <b>only</b> because he <b>needs its dirt is exempt for</b> that act, which is not the labor of digging prohibited on Shabbat by Torah law. <b>And even according to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who <b>said</b> that in general one who performs <b>labor that is not necessary for its own sake,</b> i.e., he performs the labor for a purpose other than the direct result of that action, <b>is liable for it;</b> that ruling <b>applies only</b> to a purpose that is <b>constructive.</b> However, <b>this</b> purpose is <b>destructive,</b> as one performs an act that unnecessarily mars the surface of the ground. Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda would agree that in this case he is exempt.
<b>And</b> we learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who reaps. It was taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i> with regard to the labor of reaping: <b>One who reaps,</b> and <b>one who picks</b> grapes, <b>and one who harvests</b> dates, <b>and one who collects</b> olives, <b>and one who gathers</b> figs have <b>all</b> performed <b>one</b> type of <b>labor,</b> as they all involve picking fruit. <b>Rav Pappa said: One who threw a clod</b> of earth <b>at a palm tree and severed dates is liable to</b> bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings: <b>One due to severing,</b> which is a subcategory of the primary category of reaping; <b>and one for extracting,</b> which is a subcategory of the primary category of threshing, as he removes something edible, the date, from its cover, its cluster. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> In that case, one is exempt, since <b>that is not the</b> typical <b>manner of severing, and that is not the</b> typical <b>manner of extracting,</b> and one who performs a labor in an atypical manner is exempt.
<b>And</b> we learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who gathers. Rava said: One who gathers salt from salt pools is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>gathering,</b> as he gathers a substance from the field into a pile. <b>Abaye said:</b> That is not so, as the prohibition of <b>gathering</b> by Torah law applies <b>only to</b> produce <b>that grows from the ground.</b>
<b>And</b> we learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who threshes.</b> A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who threshes, and one who beats</b> flax to remove it from the hard cover of its stalk, <b>and one who strikes</b> a cotton plant to remove the cotton seeds have <b>all</b> performed <b>one</b> type of <b>labor.</b>
<b>And</b> we learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who winnows, and one who selects, and one who grinds, and one who sifts.</b> The Gemara asks: The prohibited labor of <b>winnowing is the same as</b> the prohibited labor of <b>selecting,</b> which <b>is the same as</b> the prohibited labor of <b>sifting.</b> They are all identical in the manner in which they are performed and have the same objective: Separating food from the accompanying waste. Why was it necessary to list them all? An answer was provided by <b>Abaye and Rava, who both said</b> and established a principle: <b>Any manner</b> of labor <b>that was</b> performed <b>in the Tabernacle,</b> for the purposes of the Tabernacle,

Daf 74a

<b>even though there is</b> a different labor <b>that is similar to it,</b> the mishna <b>enumerated it.</b> Every labor that was performed in the Tabernacle is significant. The Gemara asks: <b>And let him enumerate</b> the labor of <b>pounding as well,</b> as wheat was pounded to remove its outer kernel in the Tabernacle. <b>Abaye said:</b> The labor of pounding is not one of the essential stages in the baking of bread, <b>as paupers eat their bread without pounding</b> the wheat to remove the bran. Therefore, since the <i>tanna</i> enumerated threshing, there was no need to include pounding among the labors enumerated in the breadmaking process. <b>Rava said</b> a different explanation: <b>Who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> of <b>this</b> mishna? <b>It is Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who <b>said:</b> The <b>primary categories of labor are forty-less-one,</b> a number derived from a textual allusion. Therefore, the list cannot be expanded. <b>And had</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>enumerated pounding, there would be forty</b> labors rather than thirty-nine. The Gemara asks: <b>And let him take out one of these,</b> selecting or winnowing, <b>and insert pounding,</b> thereby leaving the number intact. <b>Rather,</b> the reason that the <i>tanna</i> did not include pounding <b>is clear, according to</b> the explanation of <b>Abaye.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the laws of selecting: <b>If there were</b> several <b>types of food before him,</b> and he wants to remove one or more from the mixture, <b>one selects and eats, selects and puts</b> aside. <b>And one may not select, and if one did select, he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying?</b> The end of this <i>baraita</i> contradicts the beginning. <b>Ulla said: It is saying as follows: One selects and eats</b> if he is doing so <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>that day,</b> Shabbat. <b>And</b> he <b>selects and puts</b> aside food <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>that day. And one may not select</b> for the purpose of <b>the next day. And if one did select</b> for the next day, <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering. Rav Ḥisda strongly objects to this</b> explanation: <b>And is it permitted to bake for that day, and is it permitted to cook for that day?</b> No other labor prohibited on Shabbat may be performed for the purpose of Shabbat, and the same should hold true for selecting.
<b>Rather, Rav Ḥisda said</b> it is to be understood as follows: <b>One selects and eats less than the measure</b> of a dried fig-bulk, which is the smallest amount for which one is liable by Torah law. One <b>selects and puts</b> aside <b>less than that measure. And one may not select the measure</b> of a dried fig-bulk, <b>and if one did select</b> that measure, <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering. Rav Yosef strongly objects to this</b> explanation: <b>And is it permitted to bake less than the measure for liability</b> <i>ab initio</i>? Although performing a prohibited labor on a minute measure does not engender liability, it is prohibited. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> cannot be interpreted as saying that one may <i>ab initio</i> select an amount that is less than the measure for liability. <b>Rather, Rav Yosef said: One selects and eats by hand, selects and put</b> aside <b>by hand.</b> However, <b>with a basket [<i>kanon</i>] or with a plate,</b> both of which are large, flat vessels used for sorting sizeable quantities, <b>one may not select</b> <i>ab initio</i>. <b>And if he did select, he is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering if he did so unwittingly. If he did so intentionally he is exempt from stoning. <b>However, it is prohibited. And one may not select with a sieve or with a sifter. And if he did select</b> with those utensils, <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b>
