<b>Rav Hamnuna strongly objects to this: Does</b> the mishna <b>teach anything</b> about <b>a basket or a plate?</b> Rav Yosef’s explanation is based on the addition of details that do not appear in the <i>baraita</i> either. <b>Rather, Rav Hamnuna said: One selects and eats</b> if he is removing <b>food from the waste,</b> and similarly, <b>selects and puts</b> aside if he is removing <b>food from the waste.</b> However, <b>one may not select waste from food, and if he did select</b> in that manner, <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> The typical method of selecting is the removal of waste from the food. An individual who alters the procedure is not liable. <b>Abaye strongly objects to this: Does</b> the mishna <b>teach anything</b> about <b>food from waste?</b> That detail is not mentioned in the <i>baraita</i> either. <b>Rather, Abaye said: One selects and eats</b> if he is removing food for <b>immediate</b> use, and similarly <b>one selects and puts</b> aside for <b>immediate</b> use. However, <b>one may not select for</b> use later <b>that same day. And if he did select, he is considered like one who selects for storage, and he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> This explanation requires no emendation of the mishna. It is merely an interpretation of the phrase: One selects and eats, as referring to selecting for immediate use. The Gemara relates that <b>the Sages stated</b> Abaye’s explanation of the <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rava. He said to them: Naḥmani,</b> Abaye, <b>spoke well.</b>
Until this point, the Gemara discussed selecting food from waste. The Gemara proceeds to discuss a different case. If <b>there were two types of foods before him, and he selected and ate</b> one type, <b>and selected and put</b> aside one type, <b>Rav Ashi taught:</b> He is <b>exempt. Rav Yirmeya from Difti taught:</b> He is <b>liable. Rav Ashi taught:</b> He is <b>exempt.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that in that case <b>he is liable?</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult: This,</b> where Rav Ashi said that he is exempt, is referring to a case where he selects <b>by</b> means of <b>a basket or a plate,</b> as that method of selecting is not considered expert work; and <b>that,</b> where the <i>baraita</i> said he is liable, is in a case where he selects <b>by</b> means of <b>a sieve or a sifter,</b> as that method of selecting is considered expert work.
The Gemara relates that <b>when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said: It was the Shabbat</b> of <b>Rav Beivai</b> to serve food to the students, <b>and Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi happened</b> to come to his house. <b>He placed before them a basket of fruits</b> without removing the leaves and the stems. <b>And I do not know whether</b> he did so <b>because he holds</b> that it <b>is prohibited</b> to select <b>food from waste</b> when it is not for immediate consumption, <b>or whether</b> he did so <b>because he intended to</b> show <b>generosity to</b> his guests by creating the impression that the basket was full. A fruit-filled basket conveys to the guests that there is plenty and that they may take as much as they wish. Therefore, there is no clear proof from this incident.
<b>Ḥizkiya said: One who selects lupines from their waste</b> after boiling them <b>is liable</b> for performing the prohibited labor of selecting. The Gemara asks: <b>Let us say,</b> based on this statement, that <b>Ḥizkiya holds</b> that even selecting <b>food from waste is prohibited.</b> The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Lupines are different,</b>

Daf 74b

<b>as they are boiled seven times. And, if one does not remove them</b> from the shells, they <b>rot.</b> Therefore, <b>it is considered like</b> removing <b>waste from food.</b> The rotting edible portion of the lupine causes the shell to reek. Removing the edible portion, therefore, has the legal status of removing waste.
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>And one who grinds. Rav Pappa said: One who chops beets</b> into small pieces on Shabbat <b>is liable due to</b> the prohibited labor of <b>grinding,</b> as the actions are similar. <b>Rav Menashe said: One who chops wood chips</b> for sawdust (Rambam) <b>is liable due to</b> the prohibited labor of <b>grinding. Rav Ashi said: If</b> he <b>is particular</b> in his chopping <b>with regard to the measurement,</b> i.e., he is careful to cut all the chips to a particular size, he is also <b>liable due to</b> the labor of <b>cutting.</b>
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>And one who kneads and one who bakes. Rav Pappa said: Our <i>tanna</i> left</b> out the labor of <b>cooking</b> the <b>spices</b> for dye, <b>which was</b> performed <b>in the Tabernacle, and included</b> the labor of <b>baking,</b> which was not performed in the construction of the Tabernacle. If, as stated above, all the primary categories of labor were derived from the labors in the Tabernacle, why did the <i>tanna</i> omit cooking? The Gemara answers: <b>Our <i>tanna</i> cited the sequence</b> of preparing <b>bread,</b> which was the underlying principle behind his organization of the primary categories of labor. He opened with plowing and concluded with the preparation of bread.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Rav Avira said: One who places a peg into an oven</b> to dry <b>is liable for</b> performing the labor of <b>cooking.</b> The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>he intends to strengthen the utensil,</b> as ultimately, the peg is hardened in the oven, in contrast to cooking in which the fire softens the item being cooked. Therefore, <b>he teaches us that</b> initially the wood <b>is softened</b> in the oven, <b>and</b> only <b>afterward it is hardened. Rabba bar Rav Huna said: One who boils pitch is liable for</b> performing the labor of <b>cooking.</b> The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>since it proceeds to harden</b> afterward, <b>say</b> that it is <b>not considered</b> cooking. One might think that since the pitch was hard before it was cooked and will ultimately be hard after it is cooked, boiling pitch is not considered cooking. Therefore, <b>he teaches us</b> that even a temporary change is considered cooking.
<b>Rava said: One who</b> unwittingly <b>crafted an</b> earthenware <b>barrel</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable to</b> bring <b>seven sin-offerings:</b> He crumbles the lumps of dirt; which is (1) grinding; (2) selects the stones from the dirt; (3) kneads the mortar; (4) cuts the mortar into pieces of a suitable size; (5) builds the mold; (6) kindles the fire, and then fires the earthenware vessel, which is (7) baking (<i>ge’onim</i>). One who crafts <b>an oven is liable for eight sin-offerings,</b> since in addition to those seven labors, he spreads another layer of mortar to finish the job, performing the prohibited labor of (8) smoothing. <b>Abaye said: One who</b> unwittingly <b>crafts a receptacle</b> from reeds on Shabbat <b>is liable to</b> bring <b>eleven sin-offerings.</b> In pruning the reeds, he performed both (1) reaping and (2) planting, as he stimulates growth of the remaining reeds. He (3) gathers the reeds; (4) selects them; (5) smooths and levels them; cuts them into small pieces, which is (6) grinding; and (7) cuts them to a particular measurement. When he begins weaving the reeds, he performs the labors of (8) stretching the warp; (9) constructing two meshes; and (10) weaving. Crafting the object as a whole constitutes (11) building (<i>ge’onim</i>). <b>And if he sews the mouth</b> of the receptacle, <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>thirteen sin-offerings</b> with the added labors of (12) sewing and (13) tying.
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who shears wool, and one who whitens it,</b> which are labors in the process of shearing and spinning wool. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who</b> unwittingly <b>spins wool</b> still attached <b>on the back of</b> an <b>animal on Shabbat is liable to</b> bring <b>three sin-offerings: One due to shearing,</b> since, in the process, some of the wool is detached from the sheep; <b>and one due to combing</b> the wool; <b>and one due to spinning. Rav Kahana said: This is not</b> a typical <b>manner of shearing, and this is not</b> a typical <b>manner of combing, and this is not</b> a typical <b>manner of spinning.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is that <b>not</b> a typical manner of spinning? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in the name</b> of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya</b> that the verse in the context of the work of the Tabernacle: “And all the women whose hearts lifted them with wisdom spun the goats” (Exodus 35:26) means that <b>they washed</b> the hair <b>on the goats, and they spun</b> it into threads <b>on the goats</b> themselves without first shearing the hair? <b>Apparently, spinning on the back of an animal is considered</b> a typical manner of <b>spinning.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Extraordinary wisdom is different.</b> Although certain individuals are capable of spinning wool that way, the typical person is not capable of performing that feat.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who</b> unwittingly <b>plucks</b> a large feather from <b>the wing</b> of a bird on Shabbat, <b>and who snips</b> the tip of the feather, <b>and who pulls out</b> the thin threads that comprise the feather <b>is liable to</b> bring <b>three sin-offerings. And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said</b> in explanation: One who <b>plucks</b> the wing <b>is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>shearing.</b> One who <b>snips</b> the tip of the feather <b>is liable due to cutting.</b> And one who <b>pulls out</b> the threads <b>is liable due to smoothing.</b>
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who ties and one who unties.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Where was</b> there <b>tying in the Tabernacle? Rava said: They tied</b> the <b>tents</b> of the Tabernacle <b>to the pegs.</b> The Gemara rejects this: And is that considered performance of the labor of <b>tying? That was tying</b> a knot <b>in order to untie</b> it. When the children of Israel departed from an encampment, they dismantled the Tabernacle, which involved untying all of the knots. One is not liable for tying a temporary knot on Shabbat. <b>Rather, Abaye said: As the weavers of curtains</b> for the Tabernacle, <b>when a thread would rip, they would tie it. Rava said to him: You have resolved</b> the problem with regard to the labor of <b>tying; however,</b> with regard to the labor of <b>untying, what can be said?</b> Where, in the construction of the Tabernacle, was the labor of untying performed? <b>And if you say that</b> it was performed <b>if one found two threads</b> with knots <b>tied next to each other, he untied one and</b> left one <b>tied; now, before a king of flesh and blood one would not do so,</b> as the curtain would look flawed, in the Tabernacle, <b>before the King of kings, the Holy One, Blessed be He,</b> would <b>one do so? Rather, Rava said, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Elai</b> said: <b>The trappers of <i>ḥilazon</i>,</b> whose blood was used in the Tabernacle as a dye, <b>tie and untie</b> their nets.
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>And one who sews two stitches.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>That does not endure;</b> two stitches will unravel immediately. A prohibited labor whose result is temporary is not considered a prohibited labor. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: That</b> has the legal status of a prohibited labor only in a case <b>where,</b> after sewing the stitches, <b>he tied them.</b> He tied a knot at each of the two ends of the thread so that the stitches would not unravel.
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who tears in order to sew two stitches.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Was there tearing in</b> the construction of <b>the Tabernacle?</b> The Gemara answers that it was <b>Rabba and Rabbi Zeira who both said</b> the following explanation:

Daf 75a

<b>As, when a curtain had a worm</b> which made a tear <b>in it, they would tear</b> the curtain further to lengthen the tear, <b>and</b> that enabled them to then <b>sew it</b> in a manner that obscured the tear.
<b>Rav Zutra bar Toviya said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who tightens the thread of a stitch on Shabbat is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> If two parts of a garment that were sewn together begin to separate, and one pulls the thread to reattach them, it is tantamount to having sewn them. The Gemara cites additional <i>halakhot</i> cited by Rav Zutra in the name of Rav. <b>And one who learns</b> even <b>one matter from a <i>magosh</i>,</b> a Persian priest, <b>is liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty. <b>And one who knows how to calculate astronomical seasons and</b> the movement of <b>constellations, and does not do so, one may not speak with him</b> because his actions are improper.
The Gemara proceeds to discuss the additional <i>halakhot</i> cited by Rav Zutra bar Toviya. With regard to the <b><i>magosh</i>, Rav and Shmuel</b> disagreed. <b>One said</b> that they are <b>sorcerers, while the other said</b> they are <b>heretics.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>Conclude that Rav</b> is the one <b>who said</b> that they are <b>heretics, as Rav Zutra bar Toviya said</b> that <b>Rav</b> said: <b>One who learns one matter from the <i>magosh</i> is liable to</b> receive the <b>death</b> penalty. <b>As, if it should enter your mind</b> that they are <b>sorcerers, wasn’t it written:</b> “When you come into the land which the Lord your God gives you, <b>you shall not learn to do</b> after the abominations of those nations. There shall not be found among you any one that makes his son or his daughter to pass through the fire, one that uses divination, a soothsayer, or an enchanter, or a sorcerer” (Deuteronomy 18:9–10)? And the Sages inferred: You shall not learn to do, <b>but you</b> may <b>learn to understand and to teach</b> the topic of sorcery. Apparently, merely learning about sorcery does not violate a prohibition. Only acting upon that learning is prohibited. Rav, who prohibited learning even a single matter from a <i>magosh</i>, must hold that they are heretics, not merely sorcerers. The Gemara states: Indeed, <b>conclude</b> that Rav is the one who said that they are heretics.
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said in the name of bar Kappara: Anyone who knows how to calculate astronomical seasons and</b> the movement of <b>constellations and does not do so, the verse says about him: “They do not take notice of the work of God, and they do not see His handiwork”</b> (Isaiah 5:12). And <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> there is <b>a mitzva</b> incumbent <b>upon a person to calculate astronomical seasons and</b> the movement of <b>constellations? As it was stated: “And you shall guard and perform, for it is your wisdom and understanding in the eyes of the nations”</b> (Deuteronomy 4:6). <b>What wisdom and understanding</b> is there in the Torah <b>that is in the eyes of the nations,</b> i.e., appreciated and recognized by all? <b>You must say: This is the calculation of astronomical seasons and</b> the movement of <b>constellations,</b> as the calculation of experts is witnessed by all.
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who traps a deer</b> or any other living creature. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who traps a <i>ḥilazon</i> and breaks its</b> shell to remove its blood for the dye <b>is liable to</b> bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering. He is not liable for breaking the shell. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: He is liable to</b> bring <b>two,</b> for performing the prohibited labors of trapping and for threshing, <b>as Rabbi Yehuda would say: The breaking of a <i>ḥilazon</i> is included</b> in the primary category of <b>threshing,</b> as its objective is to extract the matter that he desires from the shell that he does not. The Rabbis <b>said to him: Breaking</b> the shell <b>is not included</b> in the primary category of <b>threshing. Rava said: What is the rationale</b> for the opinion <b>of the Rabbis? They hold: Threshing</b> applies <b>only to</b> produce <b>that grows</b> from <b>the ground.</b> One who extracts other materials from their covering is exempt. The Gemara asks: Even if extracting blood is not considered threshing, <b>let him be liable for taking a life as well. Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where he broke its</b> shell after it was <b>dead.</b>
<b>Rava said: Even</b> if you <b>say that he broke it</b> when it was <b>alive,</b> he is exempt. Since he had no intention of killing the <i>ḥilazon</i>, he is considered as one who <b>is acting unawares with regard to taking a life.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Didn’t Abaye and Rava both say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who rules that an unintentional act is permitted, <b>agrees</b> that <b>in</b> a case of: <b>Cut off its head and will it not die,</b> one is liable? One who performs an action that will inevitably result in a prohibited labor cannot claim that he did not intend for his action to lead to that result. Lack of intention is only a valid claim when the result is merely possible, not inevitable. Since one who extracts blood from a <i>ḥilazon</i> inevitably takes its life, how can Rava claim that his action is unintentional? The Gemara answers: <b>Here it is different, as the longer</b> the <i>ḥilazon</i> <b>lives, the better</b> it is <b>for</b> the trapper, <b>so that its dye will become clear.</b> Dye extracted from a live <i>ḥilazon</i> is a higher quality than that which is extracted from a dead one. Rabbi Shimon agrees that one who performs an action with inevitable consequences is liable only in a case where the consequences are not contrary to his interests. Since he prefers that the <i>ḥilazon</i> remain alive as long as possible, he is not liable for the inevitable consequences.
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>And one who slaughters</b> an animal on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: As there was no slaughter necessary for construction of the Tabernacle, <b>one who slaughters</b> an animal, <b>due to what</b> prohibited labor is he <b>liable? Rav said:</b> He is liable <b>due to dyeing,</b> as in the course of the slaughter the hide is dyed with blood. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> He is liable <b>due to taking a life.</b>

Daf 75b

The Gemara wonders: Is that to say according to Rav, that <b>due to dyeing, yes,</b> he is liable; <b>due to taking a life, no,</b> he is exempt? Rather, emend Rav’s statement and <b>say:</b> He is liable <b>due to dyeing as well.</b> And <b>Rav said: I will say something</b> as an explanation <b>with regard to the statement I said,</b> so that <b>later generations will not come and laugh at me: In what</b> sense <b>is dyeing</b> a <b>desired</b> consequence <b>for him? It is desired that the area of the slaughter will be inundated</b> with <b>blood, so that people will see it</b> freshly dyed <b>and come to purchase</b> fresh meat <b>from him.</b> Therefore, the one slaughtering the animal also wants its neck dyed.
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>And one who salts it and one who tans it.</b> The Gemara asks: The prohibited labor of <b>salting is the same as</b> the prohibited labor of <b>tanning,</b> i.e., salting is a stage in the tanning process. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish both said: Remove one of them and replace</b> it with <b>drafting.</b> In their opinion, the labor of drafting, drawing lines on the hide to indicate where it should be cut, should replace salting in the list of thirty-nine labors. <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said: One who salts meat</b> on Shabbat to preserve it <b>is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>tanning. Rava said: There is no tanning</b> with regard to <b>food.</b> No action taken with food falls into this category. <b>Rav Ashi said: And even Rabba bar Rav Huna said</b> it falls into the category of tanning <b>only when he needs to</b> pack the meat for <b>a trip</b> and salts it thoroughly. <b>However, to</b> eat in <b>the house, a person does not render his food</b> inedible, tantamount to a piece of <b>wood.</b> In that case, he certainly would not salt the meat to a degree that would approximate tanning.
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>And one who smooths it and one who cuts it. Rabbi Aḥa bar Ḥanina said: One who rubs</b> the hide <b>between the pillars on Shabbat,</b> i.e., places the skin between pillars made for that purpose (Rav Hai Gaon) and rubs it between them, <b>is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>smoothing. Rav Ḥiyya bar Abba said: Rav Ashi told me three statements in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: One who planes the tops of posts on Shabbat</b> to make them even <b>is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>cutting,</b> due to his insistence that they all be equal. <b>One who spreads a bandage</b> onto a wound <b>on Shabbat is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>smoothing. And one who chisels a stone on Shabbat is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>striking</b> a blow <b>with a hammer,</b> as he thereby completes work on the stone. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Kisma said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: One who engraves a figure onto an</b> earthenware <b>vessel and one who blows</b> in order to craft <b>a glass vessel is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>striking</b> a blow <b>with a hammer. Rav Yehuda said: One who removes</b> protruding, irregular <b>threads from a cloak is liable due to</b> the labor of <b>striking</b> a blow <b>with a hammer. And that applies</b> only <b>if he is particular about them</b> and would not wear the garment until all protruding threads are removed. In that case, work on the garment is not complete until the threads are removed.
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>And one who writes two letters. The Sages taught: One who wrote one large letter, and in its space there is</b> room <b>to write two, is exempt,</b> as he wrote only one letter. However, <b>one who erased</b> one <b>large letter, and in its space there is</b> room <b>to write two, is liable. Rav Menaḥem, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: And that is a</b> greater <b>stricture with regard to erasing than with regard to writing.</b> Although greater stringency is usually accorded to creative acts, here the destructive act of erasing is more stringent. Although he erased only one letter, he made room for two, which is the essence of the prohibited labor.
We learned in the mishna, among those liable for performing primary categories of labor: <b>One who builds and one who dismantles; one who extinguishes and one who kindles; and one who strikes</b> a blow <b>with a hammer.</b> With regard to the labor of striking a blow with a hammer, it is <b>Rabba and Rabbi Zeira who both stated</b> a principle: One who performs <b>any</b> action on Shabbat <b>that contains</b> an element of <b>completion of work is liable for</b> the labor of <b>striking</b> a blow <b>with a hammer.</b>
The mishna concludes: <b>These are the primary categories of labor.</b> The Gemara explains that the emphasis on the word <b>these,</b> indicating these and no others, comes <b>to exclude</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who <b>renders one liable for</b> the performance of <b>a subcategory</b> of prohibited labor when performed <b>together with a primary category</b> under which it is subsumed. Rabbi Eliezer deems one who performs two prohibited labors, a primary category and its subcategory, liable to bring two sin-offerings. In his opinion, one who unwittingly performed all the labors in one lapse of awareness would be liable to bring more than thirty-nine sin-offerings. Therefore, the mishna emphasizes that there are only thirty-nine primary categories of prohibited labor, and one could not possibly be liable to bring a greater number of sacrifices. When the mishna repeats that the labors number forty-<b>less-one,</b> that is <b>to exclude</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> added <b>lining up</b> the threads of the warp <b>and beating</b> the threads of the woof to the list of primary categories of labor. <b>They said to him: Lining up</b> is a subcategory <b>subsumed under</b> the primary category of <b>stretching</b> the threads of the warp within the loom, since both involve arranging the threads of the warp. <b>Beating is subsumed under</b> the primary category of <b>weaving.</b> The mishna teaches that there are no more than thirty-nine primary categories of labor.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And they stated an additional principle</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat. <b>Anything fit to store,</b> in the sense that it is large enough to make it worthwhile to store for future use, <b>and</b> people typically <b>store</b> items <b>like it, and one carried it out</b> into a prohibited domain <b>on Shabbat, he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering for</b> that action. <b>And anything not fit to store and</b> people typically do <b>not store</b> items <b>like it,</b> since it is too insignificant to warrant storage, <b>and one carried it out on Shabbat, only the one who stores it is liable.</b> By storing the item, one indicates that the item is significant to him, even though it is not significant for the typical person. Therefore, he alone is liable for carrying it out into a prohibited domain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the principle in the mishna: <b>Anything fit to store,</b> the Gemara asks: <b>What does it</b> come <b>to exclude?</b> In the opinion of the <i>tanna</i>, what is not fit for storage? <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It comes <b>to exclude the blood of a menstruating woman. Mar Ukva said:</b> It comes <b>to exclude the wood of a tree designated for idolatry [<i>ashera</i>].</b> Since one may derive no benefit from a tree designated for idolatry, it has no monetary value. The Gemara explains these opinions: <b>The one who said</b> that <b>blood of a menstruating woman</b> is not fit for storage, <b>all the more so</b> that <b>the wood of an <i>ashera</i></b> is unfit, as, by Torah law, one is required to destroy it. However, according to <b>the one who said</b> that <b>the wood of an <i>ashera</i></b> is unfit for storage, <b>the blood of a menstruating woman</b> is fit, <b>as one stores it</b> to feed <b>to the cat.</b> Although it is not typically stored, it does have some use. <b>And the other,</b> who holds that the blood of a menstruating woman is not fit for any use, isn’t it fit for use as cat food? In his opinion, <b>since</b> feeding a person’s blood to an animal <b>weakens</b> that person, <b>one does not store it.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said:</b> All of <b>these</b> objective criteria mentioned in our mishna <b>are not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as, if</b> one would attempt to say that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, didn’t he say:</b> The Sages in the mishna <b>only stated all these</b> fixed <b>measures</b> for items carried out <b>with regard to those who store them?</b> Only one who stores those items is liable for carrying them. However, one who does not store the item, and for whom it is insignificant, is not liable even if that item met the measure for liability delineated in the mishna.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And anything not fit to store,</b> that is too insignificant to warrant storage, only one who stores it is liable for carrying it out.

Daf 76a

<b>Rabbi Elazar said: This</b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar stated a principle: Anything that is not fit to be stored and</b> people do <b>not</b> typically <b>store</b> items <b>like it, but it was deemed fit</b> to be stored <b>by this</b> person <b>and he stored it, and another</b> person <b>came and carried out</b> the object that was stored, <b>that</b> person who carried it out <b>is rendered liable by the thought of this</b> person who stored it. Once one person deemed it significant by means of thought and action, it is considered significant for all people. According to our mishna, however, only the person who stored the object is liable for carrying it out.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna lists the measures in which various substances are significant and generally stored. <b>One who carries out straw</b> in a measure <b>equivalent to a cow’s mouthful</b> is liable. The measure that determines liability for <b><i>etza</i></b> is <b>equivalent to a camel’s mouthful.</b> Because it is a coarser food, he must carry out a greater amount in order to be liable. The measure that determines liability for <b>ears of grain</b> is <b>equivalent to a lamb’s mouthful.</b> The measure that determines liability for <b>grass</b> is <b>equivalent to a goat’s mouthful,</b> which is smaller than that of a lamb. The measure that determines liability for <b>garlic leaves and onion leaves,</b> if they are <b>moist</b> and fit for human consumption, is <b>equivalent to a dried fig-bulk.</b> A dried fig-bulk is the standard measure for human food. If the garlic leaves and onion leaves are <b>dry,</b> the measure for liability is <b>equivalent to a goat’s mouthful. And none</b> of these substances <b>join</b> together <b>with one another</b> to constitute a measure for liability <b>because they are not equal in their measures.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara first asks: <b>What is <i>etza</i></b> mentioned in the mishna? <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> It is <b>straw of types of legumes. When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he said:</b> In the case of <b>one who carries out</b> a measure of <b>straw equivalent to a cow’s mouthful for a camel,</b> for which it is an insignificant measure, is his liability determined based on the measure that he carried out or based on the objective for which he carried it out? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> He is <b>liable. Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said:</b> He is <b>exempt. In the evening, Rabbi Yoḥanan said that;</b> however, <b>in the morning, he reversed</b> his opinion and agreed with Reish Lakish. <b>Rav Yosef said: He did well to reverse</b> his opinion, <b>since</b> that amount <b>is not suitable for a camel.</b> There is no liability for carrying out less than a camel’s mouthful for a camel. <b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>On the contrary,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s <b>original</b> statement that he is liable <b>is reasonable, as it is suitable for a cow.</b> He carried out a significant measure that is fit for use, and he is liable for carrying it out even though it is insignificant for a camel.
<b>Rather, when Ravin</b> later <b>came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, <b>he</b> transmitted a revised version of the dispute and <b>said:</b> With regard to <b>one who carries out</b> a measure <b>equivalent to a cow’s mouthful of straw for a camel, everyone agrees that he is liable. Where they disagree</b> is <b>in</b> a case of one who <b>carries</b> out a measure of <b><i>etza</i>,</b> which cows do not typically eat, <b>equivalent to a cow’s mouthful for</b> the purpose of feeding <b>a cow.</b> Here the question is more difficult. Clearly, if one were to carry out that measure for a camel, or for no particular purpose, he would be exempt. However, since he designated the food for a cow, for which it is a significant amount, perhaps he should be liable for carrying out.
<b>And the opposite was stated</b> in the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> He is <b>exempt. Reish Lakish said:</b> He is <b>liable.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> He is <b>exempt</b> because he holds that <b>eating under duress,</b> i.e., food that is not typically eaten but could be eaten if necessary, such as a cow eating <i>etza</i>, <b>is not considered eating. Reish Lakish said:</b> He <b>is liable</b> because he holds that <b>eating under duress is considered eating.</b>
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for <b>an ear of grain</b> is <b>equivalent to a lamb’s mouthful.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Its measure for liability is <b>equivalent to a dried fig-bulk?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>This,</b> a lamb’s mouthful, <b>and that,</b> a dried fig-bulk, <b>are one,</b> the same, <b>measure.</b>
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for one who carries out <b>garlic leaves and onion leaves,</b> if they are <b>moist,</b> is <b>equivalent to a dried fig-bulk.</b> If the garlic leaves and onion leaves are <b>dry,</b> the measure for liability is <b>equivalent to a goat’s mouthful. And none</b> of these substances <b>join</b> together <b>with one another</b> to constitute an amount for which one would be liable <b>because they are not equal in their measures. Rabbi Yosei bar Ḥanina said:</b> Substances that have a more lenient legal status and have a greater measure for liability <b>do not join together</b> with the substances <b>among them</b> whose legal status is <b>more stringent</b> and whose measure for liability is smaller. For example, one who carries out a goat’s mouthful of a mixture of straw, which is more lenient, and grass, which is more stringent, is exempt. <b>However,</b> substances whose status is more stringent, like grass, <b>join together</b> with the substances <b>among them</b> whose status is <b>more lenient,</b> like an ear of grain. One who carries out a lamb’s mouthful of a mixture of grass, which is more stringent, and an ear of grain, which is more lenient, is liable.
The Gemara questions this principle: <b>And do any</b> items <b>that are not equal in their measures join together?</b> Don’t their fundamental differences preclude any combination? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna that the opposite is true? <b>The garment</b> must be at least <b>three by three</b> handbreadths in order to become a primary source of ritual impurity by means of ritual impurity imparted by treading of a <i>zav</i>. <b>And the sack</b> made from goats’ hair must be at least <b>four by four</b> handbreadths. <b>And the</b> animal <b>hide</b> must be <b>five by five,</b> and a <b>mat</b> must be <b>six by six. And</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught about</b> the mishna: <b>The garment and the sack, the sack and the hide,</b> and <b>the hide and the mat join together with one another. And Rabbi Shimon said: What is the reason</b> that they join together? <b>Because</b> all the component materials <b>are fit to become ritually impure</b> through the ritual impurity imparted to <b>a seat</b> upon which a <i>zav</i> sits, as they can each be used to patch a saddle or saddlecloth. Since they are all suitable for the same use, they join together with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity. By inference: <b>The reason</b> they can combine is <b>because they are fit to become ritually impure</b> through the ritual impurity imparted to <b>a seat. However,</b> in a case where the combination <b>is</b> of several items <b>not fit to become ritually impure</b> through the ritual impurity imparted to <b>a seat, no,</b> they do not join together even to the more lenient, larger measure. Apparently, in general, items with different measures do not join together.
<b>Rava said:</b>

Daf 76b

<b>Here too,</b> since these substances are <b>suited</b> to be piled together in the <b>sample</b> of a merchant seeking to sell them, they join together with regard to carrying out on Shabbat as well.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who carries out</b> a measure of <b>foods</b> fit for human consumption <b>equivalent to</b> a <b>dried fig-bulk</b> into a domain where carrying is prohibited on Shabbat <b>is liable. And</b> all those foods <b>join together with one another</b> to constitute that amount <b>because they are equal in their measures.</b> This amount is calculated <b>without their shells, and their seeds, and their stems, and their bran,</b> the husk that comes off of the wheat kernel when pounded, <b>and their coarse bran</b> that remains in the flour. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> None of the shells are calculated, <b>except for the shells of lentils,</b> which join together with the lentils to comprise the measure for liability because <b>they are cooked</b> and eaten <b>with them.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>And do the bran and coarse bran</b> of cereals <b>not join together? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: Dough made from <b>five-quarters</b> of a <i>log</i> of <b>flour and</b> a bit <b>more obligates</b> one to separate <b><i>ḥalla</i>?</b> That amount includes <b>them,</b> the flour, <b>and their bran, and their coarse bran.</b> Apparently, bran and coarse bran join together with the flour to constitute the requisite measure. <b>Abaye said:</b> Bran joins together with the flour with regard to <i>ḥalla</i> and the making of bread, <b>since a pauper eats his loaf</b> made <b>from dough mixed with bran.</b> However, with regard to carrying out on Shabbat, the food items in question must be suitable for all people, since the measures are small and are calculated by their significance.
We learned in the mishna that shells do not join together to constitute the measure of food. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Except for the shells of lentils</b> because <b>they are cooked</b> and eaten <b>with them.</b> The Gemara asks: Is that to say that with <b>lentils, yes,</b> the shells do join together; but with <b>beans, no,</b> they do not? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Except for the shells of beans and lentils?</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult: This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that, according to Rabbi Yehuda, shells of beans join together with the beans, is referring <b>to new,</b> fresh beans. <b>That</b> mishna, which teaches that, according to Rabbi Yehuda, shells of beans do not join together with the beans, is referring <b>to old</b> beans. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do</b> the shells of <b>old</b> beans <b>not</b> join together? <b>Rabbi Abbahu said: Because</b> their shell fragments <b>look like flies in the dish;</b> people are repulsed by those shell fragments, they do not eat them and discard them.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who carries out</b> undiluted <b>wine</b> from a private domain to a public domain or vice versa is liable only for a measure <b>equivalent to</b> the wine typically <b>diluted in a cup.</b> Pure wine was diluted with water. The measure that determines liability for carrying out wine is a measure suitable to be diluted for a significant cup of wine. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>milk</b> is <b>equivalent to</b> that which is <b>swallowed</b> in one gulp. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>honey</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on a sore</b> caused by chafing. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>oil</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on a small limb.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>water</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to rub</b> and spread on <b>an eye bandage. And</b> the measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>all other liquids</b> is <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. <b>And</b> the measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>all waste water</b> is <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The measure that determines liability for <b>all</b> liquids is <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. He further stated: <b>And all these measures were only stated with regard to those who store them.</b> One indicates that he considers these liquids significant by storing them. One is only liable for carrying out an object that is significant to him. Others, for whom these measures are insignificant, are not liable for carrying them out.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: The measure that determines liability for carrying out wine is <b>equivalent to</b> the wine <b>diluted</b> for <b>a significant cup</b> of wine. The Gemara explains: <b>And what is</b> the <b>significant cup</b> of wine to which the <i>Tosefta</i> referred? It is <b>a cup of blessing.</b> And <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: A cup of blessing must have a quarter</b> of <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> of undiluted wine <b>in it, so that one will dilute it</b> with water, <b>and</b> the cup <b>will contain a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. The ratio of dilution is typically three parts water to one part wine.
<b>Rava said: We too</b>

Daf 77a

<b>learned</b> that in the mishna: <b>One who carries out</b> undiluted <b>wine</b> is only liable if he carries out a measure <b>equivalent to</b> the wine typically <b>diluted</b> for <b>a cup. And it was taught with regard to</b> the mishna: A measure <b>equivalent to</b> the wine <b>diluted</b> for <b>a significant cup</b> of wine. <b>And it was taught in the latter</b> clause of the mishna: <b>And</b> the measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>all other liquids</b> is <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. Since a quarter of a <i>log</i> is the significant measure for liquids, that is also the significant measure for diluted wine. <b>And Rava</b> is consistent with <b>his</b> line of <b>reasoning,</b> as <b>Rava said: Any wine that does not hold one</b> part wine diluted by <b>three</b> parts <b>water is not wine.</b> Wine must be sufficiently potent to be capable of being diluted with water three times its measure.
<b>Abaye said:</b> There are <b>two</b> possible <b>responses with regard to</b> this <b>matter. One, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Diluted wine,</b> which is used to determine the exact color of red, is <b>two parts water and one</b> part <b>wine from the wine of the Sharon.</b> Apparently, wine constitutes one-third and not one-quarter of the diluted cup. <b>And furthermore:</b> Rava’s opinion is that the measure that determines liability for carrying out wine is a measure that, when diluted, would equal a quarter of a <i>log</i>, i.e., a quarter of a quarter of a <i>log</i> of undiluted wine. Is it possible that the <b>water is in the jug and</b> yet <b>joins together</b> with the wine? The wine that he is carrying out is less than the required measure and is not fit for drinking.
<b>Rava said to him: That which you said that</b> the dilution ratio that determines the color red is <b>two parts water and one</b> part <b>wine, from the wine of the Sharon,</b> is no proof. <b>Wine of the Sharon</b> is <b>unique</b> in that it <b>is weak,</b> and therefore two parts of water are sufficient to dilute it. <b>Alternatively, there</b> the dilution ratio mentioned is <b>for</b> determining the <b>appearance</b> of the color red; <b>however, for</b> the purpose <b>of taste, more</b> water <b>is necessary. And that which you said:</b> Is it possible that the <b>water is in the jug and</b> yet <b>joins together</b> with the wine? <b>With regard to</b> the liability of carrying out on <b>Shabbat, we require an object that is significant, and this</b> quarter of a quarter of a <i>log</i> of wine <b>is also significant.</b>
A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>congealed</b> wine on Shabbat is <b>an olive-bulk;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Natan. Rav Yosef said: Rabbi Natan and Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said the same thing. Rabbi Natan’s</b> statement is <b>that which we</b> just <b>stated. And</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> is <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Six matters are among the leniencies of Beit Shammai and among the stringencies of Beit Hillel.</b> They include <b>the blood of a carcass. Beit Shammai deem</b> it <b>ritually pure,</b> as, in their opinion, only the flesh of a carcass imparts impurity; <b>and Beit Hillel deem</b> it <b>ritually impure. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said: Even when Beit Hillel deemed</b> it <b>impure, they deemed impure only</b> a measure of <b>blood that contains a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>, <b>since it can congeal and constitute an olive-bulk.</b> Rav Yosef draws a parallel between the two opinions. Both <i>tanna’im</i> agree that a quarter of a <i>log</i> of liquid congeals to the size of an olive-bulk.
<b>Abaye said: Perhaps that is not</b> the case, as <b>Rabbi Natan said</b> that <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>is required only here, with regard to wine,</b> which <b>is liquid; however, with regard to blood, which is viscous,</b> in order to produce an <b>olive-bulk</b> when congealed, <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>is not required.</b> Less than a quarter of a <i>log</i> of blood congeals into an olive-bulk. <b>Alternatively, Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, said that</b> in order to create a congealed <b>olive-bulk, a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>is sufficient only there, with regard to blood,</b> which is <b>viscous; however, wine,</b> which <b>is liquid,</b> in order to create a congealed <b>olive-bulk, more</b> than a <b>quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> of wine is required. <b>And,</b> therefore, even <b>when he carries out less than an olive-bulk</b> on Shabbat, <b>let him be liable.</b> There is no proof that the two tannaitic opinions are parallel.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>milk</b> is <b>equivalent to</b> that which is <b>swallowed [<i>kedei gemia</i>]</b> in one gulp. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Is the correct version of the mishna: <b><i>Kedei gemia</i></b> with an <i>alef</i> <b>or <i>kedei gemia</i></b> with an <i>ayin</i>? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> It should be written with an <i>alef</i> as we find in the Torah: “And he said: <b>Give me to swallow [<i>hagmi’ini</i></b> with an <i>alef</i> ] <b>please, a little water from your jug”</b> (Genesis 24:17).
<b>A</b> similar <b>dilemma</b> with regard to spelling <b>was raised before</b> the Sages.

Daf 77b

In the mishna at the end of the previous chapter we learned that the measure that determines liability for carrying out foods is calculated without their seeds [<i>garinin</i>]. Is the correct version <b><i>garinin</i></b> with an <i>alef</i> <b>or <i>garinin</i></b> with an <i>ayin</i>? <b>Rava bar Ulla said:</b> It is with an <i>ayin</i>, since it stems from the same root as: <b>“And it shall be subtracted [<i>venigra</i></b> with an <i>ayin</i>] <b>from your valuation”</b> (Leviticus 27:18).
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Do we describe dimming coals as <b><i>omemot</i></b> with an <i>alef</i> <b>or <i>omemot</i></b> with an <i>ayin</i>? <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi said:</b> It is written with an <i>ayin</i>, as it is stated: <b>“The cedars in the garden of God could not hide it [<i>amamuhu</i></b> with an <i>ayin</i>]” (Ezekiel 31:8).
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to closing the eyes of the dead, <b>did we learn</b> in the mishna <b><i>me’amtzin</i></b> with an <i>alef</i>, <b>or <i>me’amtzin</i></b> with an <i>ayin</i>? <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It is written with an <i>ayin</i> as it is stated: <b>“And closes [<i>ve’otzem</i></b> with an <i>ayin</i>] <b>his eyes from seeing evil”</b> (Isaiah 33:15).
With regard to carrying out milk, <b>the Sages taught:</b> One who carries out <b>the milk of an animal</b> on Shabbat is liable only for a measure <b>equivalent to</b> that which is <b>swallowed</b> in one gulp. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>a woman’s milk and the white of an egg</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on</b> the part of <b>an eye bandage</b> upon which the ointment is placed directly <b>on the wound.</b> And the aforementioned <b>eye bandage</b> must be <b>sufficiently</b> large to use it <b>to rub</b> both his eyes <b>with water. Rav Ashi raised a dilemma:</b> Is the measure that determines liability for the bandage <b>equivalent to</b> that with which water can be <b>rubbed</b> on both eyes, <b>or</b> is it <b>equivalent to</b> that which can be <b>held and rubbed?</b> Is the part of the bandage held in his hand when applying the bandage to his eyes also taken into account? No resolution was found for this dilemma. Therefore, <b>let it stand</b> unresolved.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>honey</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on a sore</b> caused by chafing. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: The precise measure is <b>equivalent to</b> that which is <b>placed on the opening of a sore,</b> i.e., on the wound itself. <b>Rav Ashi raised a dilemma:</b> Does the term <b>on a sore</b> mean the measure of honey spread <b>on the opening of the entire sore; or, perhaps</b> it means the measure spread <b>on the primary protuberance</b> of the <b>sore, to the exclusion of the surrounding</b> area upon which he does <b>not</b> spread honey? No resolution was found for this dilemma either. Therefore, <b>let it stand</b> unresolved.
On the subject of sores, the Gemara cites a statement referring to one of the methods for healing a sore. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Everything that the Holy One, Blessed be He, created in His world, He did not create anything for naught. He created a snail</b> as a remedy <b>for a sore; He created a fly</b> to be crushed and spread as a remedy <b>on a wasp</b> sting; He created a <b>mosquito</b> as a remedy <b>for a snake</b> bite; <b>and</b> He created the <b>snake</b> itself as a remedy <b>for a</b> skin <b>rash; and</b> He created <b>a gecko</b> as a remedy <b>for a scorpion</b> bite. The Gemara explains: <b>How does</b> one <b>implement</b> the remedy? <b>He brings</b> two geckos, <b>one black and one white, cooks them, and spreads</b> the resulting ointment on the affected area.
With regard to these creatures, the Gemara cites that which <b>our Sages taught: There are five dreads,</b> i.e., <b>dread</b> that <b>the weak</b> cast <b>over</b> the <b>mighty: The dread of the <i>mafgia</i>,</b> a small creature, <b>over the lion; the dread of the mosquito over the elephant; the dread of the gecko over the scorpion; the dread of the swallow over the eagle; the dread of the <i>kilbit</i>,</b> a small fish, <b>over a whale. Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: What</b> is <b>the verse</b> that alludes to these matters? As it is written: <b>“He that causes destruction [<i>shod</i>] to flash upon the mighty,</b> so that destruction comes upon the fortress” (Amos 5:9), which is interpreted as: He who lifts the downtrodden [<i>shadud</i>] over the mighty.
On the topic of the nature of the world, the Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Zeira found Rav Yehuda, who was standing at the entrance of his father-in-law’s house, and observed that he was in an</b> especially <b>cheerful mood. And</b> Rabbi Zeira understood that <b>were he to ask</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>about anything in the</b> entire <b>world, he would tell him</b> the answer. He therefore posed questions to him on a variety of topics unrelated to <i>halakha</i>. He asked: <b>Why do goats walk in front</b> of the flock <b>and then ewes</b> follow? <b>He said to him:</b> It <b>is</b> just <b>as</b> it was <b>in the creation of the world, which at first was dark and then light</b> followed. Goats, which are typically black, precede the ewes, which are typically white. And he asked: <b>Why are</b> the genitals of <b>these</b> ewes <b>covered</b> with a tail, <b>whereas these</b> goats <b>are exposed?</b> He answered: <b>These</b> ewes, whose wool <b>we</b> use to <b>cover ourselves,</b> are rewarded in that they are <b>covered; and those</b> goats, whose hair <b>we do not</b> use to <b>cover ourselves,</b> are <b>exposed.</b> And he asked: <b>Why is the camel’s tail short?</b> He answered: <b>Because</b> a camel <b>eats thorns,</b> and a long tail would become entangled in the thorns. And he asked: <b>Why is the ox’s tail long?</b> He answered: <b>Because</b> the ox <b>lives in a swamp and must fend off mosquitoes.</b>
He continued to ask: <b>Why is the grasshopper’s antenna soft?</b> He answered: <b>Because</b> it <b>lives in the plains</b> among the grass, <b>and if</b> the antenna <b>were hard it would break and</b> the <b>grasshopper would go blind.</b> When the grasshopper loses its antenna it is unable to move, <b>as Shmuel said: One who seeks to blind a grasshopper should remove its antenna.</b> And he asked: <b>Why does the chicken’s</b> lower <b>eyelid cover the upper one?</b> He answered: <b>Because</b> a chicken <b>lives on rafters</b> in houses, <b>and if the smoke</b> from the houses <b>were to enter</b> its eyes without the protection of the eyelid, it <b>would go blind.</b> He asked further: Why is a door called <b><i>dasha</i></b> in Aramaic? He said to him: It is an acronym for <b><i>derekh sham</i>,</b> which means through there. Why is a stair called <b><i>darga</i>?</b> He said to him: It is an acronym for <b><i>derekh gag</i>,</b> which means the way to the roof. Why are spices called <b><i>mitkolita</i>?</b> He said to him: It is an acronym for <b><i>matai tikhleh da</i>,</b> which means when will this be finished. Since spices are used sparingly, they last a long time. Why is a house called <b><i>beita</i>?</b> He said to him: It is an acronym for <b><i>bo ve’eitiv ba</i>,</b> which means come and I will sit in it. Why is a small house called <b><i>bikta</i>?</b> He said to him: It is an acronym for <b><i>bei akta</i>,</b> which means a narrow house.
A barrel is called <b><i>kufta</i>,</b> which is an acronym for <b><i>kuf vetiv</i>,</b> which means turn it over and sit. Bricks are called <b><i>livnei</i>,</b> which is an allusion to <b><i>livnei benei</i>,</b> which means for the children of children. A fence made of thorns is called <b><i>hutza</i></b> and Rav Yehuda said that it is merely a <b><i>ḥatzitza</i>,</b> which means partition, as opposed to a true fence. A jug used for drawing water is called a <b><i>ḥatzba</i> because it hews [<i>ḥotzev</i>] water from the river.</b> A small jug is called <b><i>kuza</i>,</b> alluding to <b><i>kazeh</i>,</b> which means: Give me one like that. Myrtle branches with which people dance at a wedding are called <b><i>shutita</i>,</b> an allusion to <b><i>shetuta</i>,</b> which means madness, as the frenzied dancing appears to be madness. The large vessel used for washing is called <b><i>meshikhla</i>,</b> which is an acronym for <b><i>mashei kula</i>,</b> which means: It washes all. A small vessel used for washing is called <b><i>mashkhilta</i>,</b> and Rav Yehuda explained that it is an acronym for <b><i>mashya kalta</i>,</b> which means: It washes the bride. A mortar is called <b><i>asita</i>,</b> alluding to <b><i>ḥasirta</i>,</b> which means lacking, since it has a large cavity. The pestle that is inserted into the mortar for pounding its contents is called <b><i>bukhna</i>,</b> which is an acronym for <b><i>bo ve’akkena</i>,</b> which means: Come and I will strike it.
An outer garment is called <b><i>levusha</i>,</b> which is an acronym for <b><i>lo busha</i>,</b> which means no shame, as one who is clothed is no longer ashamed. A broad outer garment is called <b><i>gelima</i>,</b> an allusion to the fact that, by wearing it, one <b>is transformed into</b> an amorphous <b>golem-like</b> figure, as his limbs are indistinguishable. A beautiful coat is termed <b><i>golta</i>,</b> which is an acronym for <b><i>geli ve’eitiv</i>,</b> which means reveal, remove the coat, and only then I will sit, so that the coat will not get dirty. A bed is called <b><i>purya</i>,</b> an allusion to the fact that people <b><i>parin veravin</i>,</b> which means procreate, <b>upon it.</b> An empty pit is called <b><i>bor zinka</i>,</b> which is an acronym for <b><i>bor ze naki</i>,</b> which means that this pit is empty of water. The head covering of Torah scholars is called <b><i>sudara</i>,</b> an acronym for <i>sod yareh</i>, which is a reference to the verse: <b>“The counsel of the Lord is with them who fear Him [<i>sod Hashem lire’av</i>]”</b> (Psalms 25:14). A palace is called <b><i>apadna</i>,</b> which is an acronym for <b><i>apitḥa dein</i>,</b> meaning: To this entrance all come. The Gemara cites an additional <i>baraita</i> related to the nature of the creatures. There are <b>three</b> creatures <b>that grow mightier with age, and they are</b> the <b>fish, and</b> the <b>snake, and the pig.</b>
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>oil</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on a small limb. The school of Rabbi Yannai said</b> it should be explained as follows: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>oil</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on</b> a <b>small limb of a day-old child.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>oil</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on a small limb and a day-old child. Does this not</b> mean: <b>A small limb</b> of <b>an adult and a large limb of a day-old child?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>The school of Rabbi Yannai</b> could have <b>said to you: No, this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>oil</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on a small limb,</b> and the small limb in question is that of a <b>day-old child.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>oil</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on a small limb and a day-old child;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. Rabbi Natan says: Equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on a small limb. Is it not that they disagree about</b> the following? <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar holds:</b> It refers to <b>a small limb of a small</b> child, and <b>Rabbi Natan holds:</b> The measure for liability is equivalent to that which is used to spread on <b>a small limb</b> of <b>an adult or a large limb</b> of <b>a child, but</b> for a measure equivalent to that which is used to spread on <b>a small limb of a day-old child, no,</b> one is exempt. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, everyone agrees</b> that for carrying out oil in a measure equivalent to that which is used to spread on <b>a small limb of a day-old child, no,</b> one is exempt,

Daf 78a

<b>and</b> the opinion of the school <b>of Rabbi Yannai</b> is <b>not</b> accepted. <b>And here,</b> in this <i>baraita</i>, <b>they disagree about this: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar holds: A small limb</b> of <b>an adult and a large limb</b> of <b>a day-old child are equal to one another, and Rabbi Natan holds:</b> For carrying out oil in a measure equivalent to that which is used to spread on <b>a small limb</b> of <b>an adult, yes,</b> one is liable; however, <b>a large limb</b> of <b>a day-old child, no,</b> he is exempt. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>in this</b> matter? <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says</b> explicitly: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>oil</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to</b> spread on <b>a small limb of a day-old child.</b>
We learned in the <i>mishna</i>: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>water</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to rub</b> and spread on <b>an eye bandage. Abaye said: Now, since,</b> with regard to <b>any substance that is</b> utilized for both <b>common and uncommon</b> uses, <b>the Sages,</b> in their ruling, <b>followed the common</b> usage even <b>as a leniency,</b> i.e., one is liable only for carrying out the larger measure. However, when a substance has different uses and one is <b>common and</b> the other is <b>common</b> as well, <b>the Sages,</b> in their ruling, <b>followed the common</b> use that leads <b>to a stringency,</b> i.e., one is liable for carrying out even the smaller amount.
Proof for this principle can be seen in the following examples. <b>Wine, its</b> use for <b>drinking is common</b> and <b>its</b> use for <b>healing is uncommon. The Sages,</b> in establishing the measure that determines liability for carrying out wine, <b>followed its</b> use for <b>drinking, which</b> is <b>common,</b> which led <b>to a leniency.</b> The amount of wine that one typically drinks is greater than the amount of wine used for healing. <b>Milk, its consumption is common</b> and <b>its</b> use for <b>healing is uncommon. The Sages,</b> in establishing the measure that determines liability for carrying out milk, <b>followed its consumption, which</b> is <b>common, as a leniency. Honey, its consumption is common</b> and <b>its</b> use for <b>healing is</b> also <b>common. The Sages,</b> in establishing the measure that determines liability for carrying out honey, <b>followed its</b> use for <b>healing,</b> the smaller amount, <b>as a stringency.</b>
<b>However, water, since its drinking is common</b> and <b>its</b> use for <b>healing is uncommon, what is the reason</b> that <b>the Sages followed its</b> use for <b>healing as a stringency?</b> Based on the above principle, the Sages should have determined the measure based on its use for drinking. <b>Abaye said: They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>in the Galilee</b> where they typically drink wine. There, water is used as commonly for healing as it is for drinking (<i>Tosafot</i>). <b>Rava said: Even</b> if you <b>say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>in the rest of the places</b> as well as in the Galilee, the use of water in treating the eye is common, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel, as Shmuel said: All liquids</b> placed on the eye effect a <b>cure and cloud</b> the vision, <b>except for water which cures and does not cloud</b> the vision.
We learned in the <i>mishna</i>: <b>And</b> the measure that determines liability for <b>all other liquids</b> is <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>blood and all types of liquids</b> on Shabbat is <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> The measure that determines liability for <b>blood</b> is less than that. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>blood</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to apply</b> to <b>one eye, as one applies</b> blood <b>to</b> heal <b>a wart on the eye.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> type of blood effects this cure? <b>The blood of a wild chicken. Rabbi Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>blood</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to apply</b> to <b>one eye, as one applies</b> blood <b>to</b> heal <b>a cataract. And what</b> type of blood effects this cure? <b>The blood of a bat. And a mnemonic</b> to ensure that <b>you</b> do not confuse these cures: <b>Inside for inside, outside for outside.</b> The blood of a bat, which lives in inhabited areas, for the cataract, which is inside the eye; the blood of a wild chicken, which lives outside inhabited areas, for the wart, which is external to the eye.
The Gemara cites a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>are these matters,</b> the measures for the substances in the mishna, <b>stated?</b> They were stated <b>with regard to one who carries them out</b> from one domain to another without ascribing special significance to them. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>one who stores</b> them, thereby ascribing significance to them, the ruling is that <b>he is liable</b> for carrying out <b>any measure. Rabbi Shimon says: In what</b> case <b>are these matters stated?</b> They were stated <b>with regard to one who stores</b> those amounts. <b>However, if one</b> merely <b>carries them out, he is liable only</b> if he carries out <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. <b>And the Rabbis agree with Rabbi Shimon with regard to one who carries out waste water to the public domain that</b> even when one merely carries it out, <b>the measure</b> that determines liability <b>is a quarter of</b> a <i>log</i>.
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>are these matters,</b> the measures for the substances in the mishna, <b>stated?</b> They were stated <b>with regard to one who carries them out</b> from one domain to another without ascribing special significance to them. <b>However, with regard to one who stores them,</b> he is liable for <b>any amount.</b> The Gemara is surprised at this: <b>Isn’t</b> the <b>one who stores</b> also the <b>one who carries out?</b> One is not liable for merely storing. He is liable only for carrying out the stored item. <b>Abaye said: With what are we dealing here?</b> With the case of <b>a student whose teacher said to him: Go and clear for me space for a meal,</b> and <b>he went and cleared</b> space <b>for him</b> and removed the items to another domain. If he cleared <b>an item</b> that is <b>significant to all, he is liable for</b> carrying <b>it</b> out. If he cleared <b>an item that is not significant to all,</b> then, <b>if his teacher had stored it, he is liable for</b> carrying <b>it</b> out, <b>and if</b> his teacher <b>had not</b> stored it, <b>he is not liable</b> for carrying it out, since the student is fulfilling his teacher’s wishes.
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>And the Rabbis agree with Rabbi Shimon with regard to one who carries out waste water to the public domain, that the measure</b> that determines liability <b>is a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> use <b>is waste water fit? Rabbi Yirmeya said: It</b> is used <b>to knead clay.</b> The Gemara asks: If that is its purpose, why is such a large amount required? <b>Was it not taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>clay</b> on Shabbat is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make an opening for</b> the bellows to be placed in <b>a crucible,</b> which is a much smaller measure? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. This,</b> where the measure for clay is equivalent to that which is used to make an opening for the bellows to be placed in <b>a crucible,</b> is referring to a case <b>where</b> it was already <b>kneaded; that,</b> where the measure for waste water is a quarter of a <i>log</i> to knead clay, is referring to a case <b>where it is not</b> yet <b>kneaded, as a person does not go to the trouble of kneading clay</b> just <b>to make an opening for</b> the bellows to be placed in <b>a crucible.</b> When carrying out water to knead clay, a large amount is required; however, clay that was already prepared is fit for use for smaller objects as well.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who carries out a rope</b> is liable in a measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to form an ear-shaped handle for a basket.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>reed grass</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make a loop for hanging a sifter or a sieve. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The measure for liability is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to take the measure of a shoe for a child,</b> as the reed is used to measure the size of the foot. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>paper</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write a tax receipt. And one who carries out a tax receipt</b> itself on Shabbat <b>is liable.</b>

Daf 78b

The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>paper</b> from which the writing has been <b>erased</b> and which can no longer be used for writing, is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to wrap around a small jar of perfume.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out animal <b>hide</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make an amulet.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b><i>dokhsostos</i>,</b> a layer of the animal hide, is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write a <i>mezuza</i>.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>parchment</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write</b> the <b>shortest portion</b> in the <b>phylacteries, which is</b> the portion of <b><i>Shema Yisrael</i>.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>ink</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write two letters.</b>
The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>blue eye shadow</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to paint one eye blue.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>glue</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on the top of a board</b> to catch birds. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>tar and sulfur</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used to seal a hole in a vessel and <b>to make a</b> small <b>hole</b> in that seal. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>wax</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on the opening of a small hole</b> to seal it. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>crushed earthenware</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to</b> knead and <b>make</b> from it <b>an opening for</b> the bellows to be placed in <b>a gold refiners’ crucible. Rabbi Yehuda says: Equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make a small tripod [<i>pitput</i>]</b> for the crucible. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>bran</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on the hole of a gold refiners’ crucible.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>lime</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread</b> as a depilatory on <b>the smallest of girls. Rabbi Yehuda says: Equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on</b> the hair that grows over <b>the temple</b> so that it will lie flat. <b>Rabbi Neḥemya says: Equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on the temple</b> to remove fine hairs.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the <i>mishna</i>: The measure that determines liability for carrying out a rope is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used to form an ear-shaped handle for a basket. The Gemara asks: In the case of <b>rope, too, let one be liable</b> for carrying out a measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make a loop for hanging a sifter or a sieve,</b> as he is with a reed. The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> rope is tough and would <b>cut grooves in the vessel, people do not make</b> loops from it. <b>The Sages taught:</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>hard palm leaves</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make an ear-shaped handle for an Egyptian wicker basket,</b> which is made from woven palm branches. <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say:</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>bast</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on the opening of a small funnel to filter the wine.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>fat</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to smear beneath a small cake. And how much is its measure? Equivalent to</b> the size of <b>a <i>sela</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Was it not taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that its measure is <b>equivalent to a dried fig?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This,</b> the width of a <i>sela</i>, <b>and that,</b> the volume of a dried fig, <b>are one measure.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>soft material</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make a small ball. And how much is its measure?</b> It is <b>like</b> the size of <b>a nut.</b>
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>paper</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write a tax receipt.</b> A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>How much</b> is the measure of <b>a tax receipt?</b> Enough to write <b>two letters</b> characteristic <b>of a tax receipt,</b> which are larger than regular letters. <b>And the</b> Gemara <b>raises a contradiction: One who carries out blank paper; if it has</b> space <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write two letters, he is liable, and</b> if <b>not, he is exempt.</b> That paper is smaller than a tax receipt. <b>Rav Sheshet said: What</b> are the <b>two letters</b> taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>? <b>Two letters of a tax receipt. Rava said:</b> The <i>Tosefta</i> can even be explained as referring to <b>two</b> standard-size <b>letters of ours and</b> blank <b>space</b> with which <b>to hold</b> the paper on which the text is written, <b>which is</b> the size of <b>a tax receipt.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection: One who carries out paper</b> from which the writing has been <b>erased or a</b> promissory <b>note</b> whose debt has been <b>repaid, if there is in its white</b> section, the space with no text, <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write two letters, or</b> if <b>the entire paper is equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to wrap around a small jar of perfume, he is liable; and if not,</b> if it is smaller, <b>he is exempt.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>Granted, according to Rav Sheshet,</b> who <b>said: What</b> are the <b>two letters</b> taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>, <b>two letters of a tax receipt,</b> it works out <b>well. However, according to Rava,</b> who <b>said: Two</b> standard-size <b>letters of ours and</b> blank <b>space</b> with which <b>to hold</b> the paper on which the text is written, <b>which is</b> the size of <b>a tax receipt, here,</b> on this paper or document, blank <b>space</b> with which <b>to hold</b> the paper <b>is not necessary,</b> as one can hold it on the erased part or on the text of the voided promissory note. Nevertheless, the measure for liability in the <i>Tosefta</i> for carrying out paper from which the writing was erased is no smaller. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, it is <b>difficult.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who carries out a tax receipt</b> on Shabbat <b>before he has shown it to the tax collector,</b> and he still needs it, <b>is liable</b> for carrying out on Shabbat. <b>Once he has shown it to the tax collector he is exempt,</b> as it has no significance. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even once he has shown it to the tax collector he is liable because there</b> will be a time when he <b>needs it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between their</b> opinions? <b>Abaye said: There is</b> a practical difference <b>between their</b> opinions with regard to <b>tax runners.</b> Occasionally, the tax collectors send inspectors after those who already passed the tax audit in order to verify that they indeed paid. In that case, even though one already showed it to the original tax collector, he will be required to produce it again. <b>Rava said: There is</b> a practical difference <b>between their</b> opinions with regard to <b>a senior tax collector and a junior tax collector.</b> Sometimes, when the first tax collector that one encounters is a minor official, he will need to keep the receipt with him and produce it if he encounters a more senior official. <b>Rav Ashi said: There is a difference between them</b> even in a case where there is just <b>one tax collector.</b> Nevertheless, it is to his advantage to keep it in his possession <b>because he needs</b> it <b>to show</b> it <b>to a second tax collector</b> whom he may encounter in the future, <b>as he says to</b> him: <b>Look, I am a man</b> trusted <b>by the tax collector.</b> The document in his possession proves that he is on good terms with the tax authorities.
<b>The Sages taught: One who carries out a promissory note</b> on Shabbat <b>before he repaid</b> the debt <b>is liable;</b> however, <b>once he repaid it, he is exempt. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even once he repaid</b> the debt, <b>he is liable</b> for carrying out the document <b>because he needs it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is <b>the</b> practical difference <b>between their</b> opinions? <b>Rav Yosef said: There is</b> a practical difference <b>between their</b> opinions with regard to the <i>halakha</i> whether or not it <b>is prohibited to keep a repaid</b> promissory <b>note</b> in one’s possession. <b>The Rabbis hold: It is prohibited to keep a repaid</b> promissory <b>note</b> in one’s possession, so that the creditor will not use it to collect the debt a second time. Since it is prohibited to keep a repaid promissory note, the document has no value. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda holds: It is permitted to keep a repaid</b> promissory <b>note</b> in one’s possession and use it as paper.
<b>Abaye said: Everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is prohibited to keep a repaid</b> promissory <b>note</b> in one’s possession, <b>and here</b> they disagree with regard to the question whether or not, in a case where a debtor <b>admits that he wrote a</b> promissory <b>note,</b> the creditor must <b>ratify it</b> in court. The <b>first <i>tanna</i> holds:</b> When a debtor <b>admits that he wrote a</b> promissory <b>note,</b> the creditor must <b>ratify it</b> in court to confirm that it is not a forgery. If it cannot be ratified, the debtor can claim that he already repaid the debt. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda holds:</b> When a debtor <b>admits that he wrote a</b> promissory <b>note,</b> the creditor <b>need not ratify it</b> in court and can collect his debt without ratification. The document is considered more reliable than the debtor’s claims. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of: <b>Before he repaid</b> the debt <b>and once he repaid it?</b>

Daf 79a

It means: <b>Until</b> the <b>debtor says: I repaid</b> the debt, or, <b>I did not repay</b> the debt. If the debtor says: I repaid the debt in the promissory note and there are no witnesses to ratify the document in court, the document has no value. That is the opinion of the Rabbis who hold that an unratified document cannot force a debtor to pay. According to Rabbi Yehuda, who holds that a document need not be ratified, the debtor’s claim that he repaid the debt is not accepted and the creditor can collect his debt with the unratified promissory note.
