<b>Rava said: Everyone agrees</b> that when a debtor <b>admits that he wrote a</b> promissory <b>note,</b> the creditor <b>must ratify it</b> in court. <b>And here,</b> it is with regard to the question whether or not <b>one writes a receipt</b> that <b>they disagree.</b> The <b>first <i>tanna</i> holds: One writes a receipt</b> for a promissory note that was repaid. Since the debtor has the receipt in his possession, the creditor may keep the note and use it as paper. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda holds: One does not write a receipt.</b> Therefore, the creditor is required to return the note to the debtor immediately upon repayment of the debt. It is in the interest of the debtor to destroy the document, and he has no reason to keep it. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The dispute is with regard to a case where the debtor carried out the promissory note into the public domain. Rabbi Yehuda said he is liable <b>because he needs</b> the repaid document <b>to show</b> it <b>to a second creditor, as he says to him: Look, I am a man who repays</b> his debts.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out animal <b>hide</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used to make an amulet. <b>Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman:</b> With regard to <b>one who carries out</b> animal <b>hide, how much</b> must he carry out on Shabbat in order to be liable? <b>He said to him,</b> it is <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out animal <b>hide</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make an amulet.</b> He raised another dilemma: With regard to one who <b>tans</b> that hide, <b>how much</b> must he tan in order to be liable? <b>He said to him:</b> It is <b>no different,</b> the same measure. He raised another dilemma: With regard to one who carries out animal hide <b>to tan it, how much</b> must he carry out on Shabbat in order to be liable? <b>He said to him:</b> It is <b>no different.</b>
<b>And from where do you</b> derive and <b>say</b> that there is no difference whether or not the hide one carries out is tanned? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who whitens, and one who combs, and one who dyes, and one who spins, the measure</b> of wool for which one is liable in performing those prohibited labors is <b>double the full</b> width of the <b>distance between the forefinger and the middle finger. And the measure</b> that determines liability for <b>one who weaves two threads</b> is <b>double the full</b> width of the <b>distance between the forefinger and the middle finger. Apparently, since</b> the wool <b>is designated for spinning, the measure</b> for which one is liable for whitening, combing, and dyeing is <b>equal</b> to the measure for which one is liable for weaving that <b>spun</b> thread. <b>Here too, since it is designated for tanning, its measure</b> that determines liability for carrying it out into the public domain is <b>equal</b> to the measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>tanned</b> hides. Rava raised another dilemma: With regard to one who carries out animal hide <b>and</b> has <b>no</b> intention <b>to tan it, how much</b> must he carry out on Shabbat in order to be liable? <b>He said to him:</b> It is <b>no different.</b>
Rava asked: <b>And</b> is there <b>no</b> halakhic <b>difference between</b> carrying out <b>tanned</b> hides <b>and</b> carrying out hides that are <b>not tanned? He raised an objection to him</b> based on a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who carries out herbs</b> that were <b>soaked</b> in water and ready for use as a dye is liable if he carried out a measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to dye a sample</b> the size of <b>a stopper for the shuttle</b> of a loom. <b>While</b> with regard to <b>herbs that were not soaked, we learned</b> in a mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>nutshells, and pomegranate peels,</b> and for carrying out <b>safflower, and madder,</b> which are herbs used as dyes, is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to dye a small cloth</b> to cover the <b>opening of a woman’s</b> hair <b>net.</b> Apparently, the measure for which one is liable for carrying out raw materials is greater than the measure for which one is liable for carrying out prepared dyes. The Gemara answers: <b>But wasn’t it stated with regard to that</b> mishna that <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said: Because a person does not</b> go to the <b>trouble to soak herbs</b> just <b>to dye a sample for</b> the <b>shuttle</b> of a loom? As a rule, there is no distinction between finished and unfinished products. The case of dye is different, as people do not typically prepare dyes in amounts that small. Therefore, even though that size is significant in and of itself, he is exempt for carrying them out.
He asked further: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>seeds of garden</b> plants <b>before one sowed them, we learned</b> in a mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>seeds of garden</b> plants is <b>less than a dried fig-bulk. Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says:</b> He is liable if he carries out <b>five</b> seeds. <b>While</b> with regard to carrying out seeds <b>after he sowed them, we learned</b> in a mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>manure</b> or <b>fine sand</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to fertilize</b> one <b>stalk of cabbage with it;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. And the Rabbis say:</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying it out is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to fertilize a leek.</b> Apparently, after the seed was sown, the measure for liability is one plant. Before it is sown, the measure is at least five. The Gemara answers: As a rule, there is no distinction between an object that was processed and one that was not. However, this case is different. <b>Wasn’t it stated with regard to that</b> <i>halakha</i> that there is a distinction between <b>this,</b> where one is liable for carrying out one plant, and the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> it <b>is</b> already <b>sown;</b> and <b>that,</b> where one is only liable for carrying out at least five, and the mishna is referring to a case <b>where it is not</b> yet <b>sown, because a person does not</b> go to the <b>trouble to carry out</b> just <b>one</b> seed <b>for sowing?</b>
He asked further: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>clay before one kneads it, it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And the Rabbis agree with Rabbi Shimon with regard to one who carries out waste water to the public domain, that the measure</b> that determines liability is <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. <b>And we discussed</b> this question: <b>For what</b> use <b>is waste water fit? Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> It is used <b>to knead clay.</b> Apparently, the measure that determines liability for the raw material is the amount kneaded with a quarter of a <i>log</i> of waste water to form clay. <b>While</b> with regard to clay <b>after one kneads it, it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>clay,</b> the measure for liability is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make an opening for</b> the bellows to be placed in <b>a crucible,</b> which is a small amount. The Gemara answers: <b>There too, it is as we stated: Because a person does not</b> go to the <b>trouble of kneading clay</b> just <b>to make an opening for</b> the bellows to be placed in <b>a crucible.</b>
In order to resolve the dilemma with regard to the measure that determines liability for carrying out an animal hide on Shabbat, the Gemara states: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>that Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ami said in the name</b> of <b>Ulla: There are three hides,</b> i.e., three stages in the process of tanning hides, and at each stage it is known by a different name: <b><i>Matza</i>, and <i>ḥifa</i>, and <i>diftera</i>. <i>Matza</i>, as per its plain meaning,</b> with no additives. It is <b>not salted, and not treated with flour, and not treated with gallnuts. And how much is the measure that determines liability for</b> carrying out that hide on Shabbat? <b>Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yehuda taught:</b> It is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to wrap around a small weight. And how</b> big is this small weight? <b>Abaye said: A quarter of a quarter</b> of a <i>litra</i> in the system of weights in use in <b>Pumbedita.</b>
<b><i>Ḥifa</i></b> is hide <b>that is salted, and not treated with flour, and not treated with gallnuts. And how much is the</b> measure that determines liability for carrying out that hide on Shabbat? <b>As we learned</b> in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out animal <b>hide</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make an amulet. <i>Diftera</i></b> is hide <b>that is salted, and treated with flour, and not treated with gallnuts. And how much is the measure that determines liability for</b> carrying out that hide on Shabbat? The measure that determines liability for carrying it out is <b>equivalent</b> to the amount which is used <b>to write a bill of divorce on it. In any case, it was taught</b> that before it is tanned the measure for liability is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to wrap around a small weight. And Abaye said: A quarter of a quarter</b> of a <i>litra</i> in the system of weights in use in <b>Pumbedita.</b> That is not the same as the measure that determines liability for a tanned hide, which is equivalent to that which is used to make an amulet. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> it is referring to <b>wet hide</b> just flayed that was left out to dry in the sun and is suitable only for wrapping around a weight (Rabbeinu Ḥananel). However, for carrying out hide that is tanned, his measure for liability is equivalent to that which is used to make an amulet.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>And didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>The garment</b> must be at least <b>three by three</b> handbreadths to become impure with ritual impurity <b>imparted by treading? And the sack</b> made from goat hair must be at least <b>four by four</b> handbreadths. <b>And the</b> animal <b>hide</b> must be <b>five by five,</b> and a <b>mat</b> must be <b>six by six.</b> Those are the minimum measures for becoming a primary source of ritual impurity by means of <b>both</b> ritual impurity <b>imparted by treading and</b> ritual impurity <b>imparted by a corpse. And it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i> <b>with regard to</b> that mishna: With regard to <b>the garment and the sack and the hide; like</b> the <b>measure for ritual impurity, so too is</b> the <b>measure for carrying out</b> on Shabbat. That is significantly larger than the measure for liability cited in the mishna for carrying out hide. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> <i>Tosefta</i> is referring to <b><i>kortovela</i>,</b> which is hide that was tanned in a manner that rendered it unfit for writing or wrapping. It is used for covering vessels and other similar uses (Rambam).

Daf 79b

We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>parchment</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write</b> the <b>shortest portion</b> in the phylacteries. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raised a contradiction</b> from that which was taught: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>parchment and <i>dokhsostos</i></b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write a <i>mezuza</i> on it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of <b><i>mezuza</i></b> in this context? It means those Torah portions of the <b><i>mezuza</i></b> that also appear <b>in the phylacteries.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And are the phylacteries called <i>mezuza</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The straps of the phylacteries,</b> when they are <b>with the phylacteries, render the hands ritually impure</b> as is the case with regard to contact with any sacred texts. When they <b>are on their own, they do not render the hands ritually impure. Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon: One who touches the strap</b> of the phylacteries remains <b>ritually pure</b> even if it is attached to the phylacteries, <b>unless he touches the</b> actual <b>box</b> of the phylacteries. <b>Rabbi Zakkai says in</b> Rabbi Shimon’s <b>name:</b> One remains <b>ritually pure until he touches the <i>mezuza</i> itself.</b> Apparently the Torah portions in phylacteries are called <i>mezuza</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from the fact that the latter clause</b> of the mishna <b>teaches:</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>parchment</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write</b> the <b>shortest portion</b> in the <b>phylacteries, which is</b> the portion of <b><i>Shema Yisrael</i>, by inference, in the first</b> clause of the mishna <b>we are dealing with a <i>mezuza</i> itself.</b> Rather, <b>this is what it teaches:</b> With regard to <b>parchment and <i>dokhsostos</i>, how much is the</b> measure that determines liability for carrying <b>them</b> out? The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b><i>dokhsostos</i></b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which one uses <b>to write a <i>mezuza</i> on it.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>parchment</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which one uses <b>to write on it</b> the <b>shortest passage that is in the phylacteries, which is <i>Shema Yisrael</i>.</b>
<b>Rav said: <i>Dokhsostos</i></b> has the same legal status <b>as parchment: Just</b> as <b>one may write</b> the portions of the <b>phylacteries on parchment, so too, one may write</b> the portions of the <b>phylacteries on <i>dokhsostos</i>.</b> The Gemara asks, <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>parchment</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write</b> the <b>shortest portion</b> in the <b>phylacteries, which is</b> the portion of <b><i>Shema Yisrael</i>.</b> By inference: <b>Parchment, yes,</b> the portions of the phylacteries may be written on it. <b><i>Dokhsostos</i>, no,</b> the portions of the phylacteries may not be written on it. The Gemara answers: That is no proof, as the mishna is referring <b>to</b> the optimal manner in which to fulfill the <b>mitzva,</b> i.e., writing the portions of the phylacteries on parchment. However, one fulfills the mitzva by writing on <i>dokhsostos</i> as well. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: It is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai</b> that the portions of the <b>phylacteries</b> are written <b>on parchment, and a <i>mezuza</i></b> is written <b>on <i>dokhsostos</i>.</b> When writing on <b>parchment,</b> one writes <b>on the side</b> of the hide that faced the <b>flesh;</b> on <b><i>dokhsostos</i>,</b> one writes <b>on the side</b> of the hide on which there was <b>hair.</b> This contradicts the opinion of Rav, who said that phylacteries may be written on <i>dokhsostos</i>. The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> is also referring <b>to</b> the optimal manner in which to fulfill the <b>mitzva.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that if one <b>deviated</b> and wrote on something else <b>it is invalid,</b> indicating that the portions of the phylacteries may not be written on anything other than parchment? The Gemara rejects this: This <i>baraita</i> is referring <b>to</b> a <b><i>mezuza</i>,</b> which is invalid if written on parchment. The Gemara asks: <b>But was it not taught</b> in a different <i>baraita</i>: <b>If one deviated in this,</b> phylacteries, <b>and that,</b> <i>mezuza</i>, <b>it is invalid?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>Both this and that</b> are referring to a <b><i>mezuza</i>, and this</b> additional invalidation <b>is</b> in a case <b>where one</b> deviated and <b>wrote it</b> on <b>parchment, on the side</b> that faced the <b>hair; or, alternatively,</b> where he deviated and wrote it on <b><i>dokhsostos</i>, on the side</b> that faced the <b>flesh. And, if you wish, say</b> instead: Actually, this and that are referring to phylacteries and a <i>mezuza</i>. However, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a case where <b>one deviated in this and that is</b> subject to <b>a tannaitic</b> dispute, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If one deviated in this and that it is invalid. Rabbi Aḥa deems it valid in the name of Rabbi Aḥai bar Ḥanina, and some say in the name of Rabbi Ya’akov, son of Rabbi Ḥanina. Rav Pappa said: Rav said</b> his statement in accordance with the opinion <b>of the <i>tanna</i> from the school</b> of <b>Menashe. As it was taught in the school of Menashe: If one wrote it on paper or on a cloth it is invalid.</b> However, if one wrote it <b>on parchment or on a hide that was treated with gallnuts [<i>gevil</i>] or on <i>dokhsostos</i> it is valid.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>If he wrote it;</b> wrote <b>what? If you say</b> that it is referring to a <b><i>mezuza</i>, do we write a <i>mezuza</i></b> on <b>parchment? Rather, isn’t</b> it referring to <b>phylacteries?</b> Apparently, as Rav said, there are Sages who hold that the portions of the phylacteries may be written on <i>dokhsostos</i>. The Gemara rejects this: <b>And according to your reasoning, do we write phylacteries</b> on <b><i>gevil</i>? Rather, that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught with regard to a Torah scroll.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Let us say</b> that the following <b>supports</b> the opinion of Rav: <b>Similarly, phylacteries that became tattered and a Torah scroll that became tattered, one may not make them into a <i>mezuza</i>,</b> despite the fact that identical Torah portions appear in all three. This is prohibited <b>because one does not downgrade from</b> a level of <b>greater sanctity,</b> i.e., a Torah scroll or phylacteries, <b>to</b> a level of <b>lesser sanctity,</b> i.e., a <i>mezuza</i>.
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that one may not do so is because <b>one does not downgrade.</b> However, <b>if</b> the <i>halakha</i> were that <b>one does downgrade,</b> one would <b>make</b> a <i>mezuza</i> from phylacteries. The Gemara elaborates: <b>On what is</b> the portion of the phylacteries <b>written?</b> Isn’t it written on <b><i>dokhsostos</i>?</b> This supports the opinion of Rav. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the portion of the phylacteries is written <b>on parchment.</b> The Gemara asks: If so, how could a <i>mezuza</i> be made from it? <b>Do we write a <i>mezuza</i></b> on <b>parchment?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If one wrote</b> a <i>mezuza</i> <b>on parchment,</b> or <b>on paper, or on a cloth, it is invalid. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Rabbi Meir would write it on parchment, as it is</b> thereby better <b>preserved.</b> Apparently, even a <i>mezuza</i> may be written on parchment, and there is no proof from the previous <i>baraita</i>. In reaction to the previous <i>baraita</i>, the Gemara comments: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> opinion that a <i>mezuza</i> may be written on both <i>dokhsostos</i> and parchment, <b>according to Rav, as well, do not say: <i>Dokhsostos</i></b> has the same legal status <b>as parchment</b> with regard to phylacteries; <b>rather, say: Parchment</b> has the same legal status <b>as <i>dokhsostos</i>. Just as on <i>dokhsostos</i>, one may write a <i>mezuza</i>, so too, on parchment, one may write a <i>mezuza</i>,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>ink</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to write</b> two letters.

Daf 80a

A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: The measure that determines liability for carrying out ink is equivalent to that which is used to write <b>two letters</b> when he carries out dried <b>ink, and two letters</b> when the ink is <b>in the quill,</b> and <b>two letters in the inkwell [<i>kalmarin</i>]. Rava raised a dilemma:</b> What is the <i>halakha</i> if one carried out sufficient ink to write <b>one letter</b> in the form of dried <b>ink,</b> and sufficient ink to write <b>one letter in the quill,</b> and sufficient ink to write <b>one letter in the inkwell?</b> Do they join together to constitute the measure for liability, or is each considered separately? No resolution was found for this dilemma. Therefore, <b>let it stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rava said: One who carried out</b> a measure of ink equivalent to that which is used to write <b>two letters</b> on Shabbat, <b>and he wrote</b> two letters <b>as he walked,</b> even though he did not place the written material in the public domain, he is <b>liable</b> for carrying out the ink. <b>Their writing is their placement.</b> He is liable even without placing the ink on the ground. <b>And Rava said: One who carried out</b> sufficient ink to write <b>one letter and he wrote it, and</b> then <b>proceeded to carry out</b> sufficient ink to write <b>one</b> more <b>letter and he wrote it,</b> is <b>exempt. What is the reason</b> that he is exempt? <b>At the time that he</b> carried out <b>the last</b> drop of ink, <b>he was lacking the first measure</b> of ink. The ink that he carried out first dried slightly in the interim and not enough remained to write one letter.
<b>And Rava said</b> with regard to a similar issue: <b>One who carried out half of a dried fig</b> on Shabbat <b>and placed it</b> in a different domain, <b>and proceeded to carry out</b> another <b>half of a dried fig and placed it,</b> the <b>first becomes as one that was snatched by a dog or burned and</b> he is <b>exempt,</b> as he did not carry out the measure of a dried fig for which he would be liable. The Gemara wonders: <b>And why</b> is he exempt; <b>isn’t</b> an entire dried fig <b>placed</b> together? Why isn’t he liable for carrying it out? The Gemara explains: <b>This is what</b> Rava <b>is saying: And if he lifted</b> the <b>first</b> half-fig <b>first before placement of</b> the <b>second,</b> i.e., the two half-figs were never placed together, the <b>first becomes as one that was snatched by a dog or burned and</b> he is <b>exempt. And Rava said: One who carried out half of a dried fig</b> on Shabbat <b>and placed it</b> in a different domain, <b>and proceeded to carry out</b> another <b>half of a dried fig and passed</b> the second half-fig <b>over</b> the already placed first half-fig, <b>is liable</b> even though they were never placed together. The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> is he liable? The second half-fig <b>did not come to rest.</b> The Gemara answers: It is referring to a case <b>where he passed</b> the second half-fig <b>within three</b> handbreadths of the first half-fig. The <i>halakha</i> is that objects less than three handbreadths apart are considered attached.
The Gemara asks: <b>And didn’t Rava</b> himself <b>say:</b> An object that passes <b>within three handbreadths</b> of the ground, according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, must come to rest atop some</b> defined place and if it does not it is not considered placed? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where Rava said that it must actually come to rest, it is referring to <b>one who throws</b> the object; <b>here,</b> where proximity alone is sufficient to render him liable, it is referring to <b>one who passes</b> an object in his hand, since he can place the object down at any point.
<b>The Sages taught: One who carried out half of a dried fig</b> into the public domain on Shabbat <b>and proceeded to carry out</b> another <b>half of a dried fig, within one lapse of awareness, is liable; within two lapses of awareness, he is exempt</b> because in neither lapse did he carry out a measure that would render him liable. <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> If he carried out the half-figs <b>within one lapse of awareness to one domain</b> he is <b>liable; to two domains he is exempt.</b> If he carried the two half-figs to two separate sections of the public domain, he is exempt because there is no permitted manner to unite the two halves. <b>Rabba said</b> with regard to Rabbi Yosei’s statement: <b>That is</b> only in a case <b>where there is</b> an area in which there is <b>liability to</b> bring a <b>sin-offering between them.</b> It only applies in a case where there is a private domain between the two sections of the public domain and carrying between them is prohibited by Torah law. <b>However,</b> if the two sections of the public domain were separated by <b>a <i>karmelit</i>, no,</b> he would not be exempt. In that case, there is no Torah prohibition against carrying between the two sections of the public domain through the <i>karmelit</i>, and by Torah law they are not considered separate.
<b>Abaye said: Even</b> if they were separated by <b>a <i>karmelit</i></b> it is not considered one domain, and he is exempt. <b>However,</b> if the two sections were separated by <b>a large beam, no,</b> they are not considered separate. <b>And Rava said: Even</b> if the two sections were separated by <b>a large beam,</b> according to Rabbi Yosei, they are considered separate and he is exempt. The Gemara comments: <b>And Rava follows his</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> stated elsewhere <b>as Rava said:</b> The definition of <b>domain</b> for <b>Shabbat is like</b> the definition of <b>domain</b> for <b>bills of divorce.</b> Just as with regard to bills of divorce, two areas separated by a beam are not considered one domain, so too, with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, they are not considered one domain.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>blue eye shadow</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to paint one eye blue.</b> The Gemara asks: How could the mishna say <b>one eye?</b> Women <b>do not paint</b> only one eye <b>blue. Rav Huna said: Because modest</b> women, who cover their faces with a veil, <b>paint</b> only the <b>one eye</b> that shows <b>blue.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> For carrying out <b>blue eye shadow, if</b> it is used <b>for healing,</b> the measure for liability is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to paint one eye blue; if</b> it is used <b>to adorn</b> the eye, the measure that determines liability for carrying out is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>for two eyes. Hillel, son of Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani, explained it: When this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught</b> it was in reference to <b>village women.</b> Because immodest behavior is less common there, women do not customarily cover their faces.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>wax</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on the opening of a small hole</b> to seal it. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Enough to place on the opening of a small hole</b> in a receptacle holding <b>wine.</b> The size of a hole that enables pouring wine is smaller than the size of the hole required when pouring more viscous liquids.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>glue</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on the top of a board [<i>shafshaf</i>].</b> The Sages <b>taught:</b> This means an amount <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on the top of a board that is</b> attached <b>to the top of a hunter’s rod.</b> Hunters would spread glue to trap the birds that land on the board.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>tar and sulfur</b> is equivalent to that which is used <b>to</b> seal a hole in a vessel and to <b>make a</b> small <b>hole</b> in that seal. Tar and sulfur were used to seal large cavities in jars. Holes were sometimes made in those seals. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: One is liable for carrying out a measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which can be used <b>to make</b> a large hole into <b>a small hole.</b>
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>crushed earthenware</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used to knead and make an opening for the bellows to be placed in a gold refiners’ crucible. Rabbi Yehuda says: An amount equivalent to that which is used to make a small tripod for the crucible. The Gemara wonders: <b>Is that to say that the measure</b> of Rabbi Yehuda <b>is greater? Don’t we maintain that the measure of the Rabbis is greater, as we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> with regard to reeds: The measure for liability is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to take the measure of a shoe for a child?</b> That is smaller than the measure determined by the Rabbis. The Gemara answers: Here too, <b>say</b> it does not mean sufficient material to make the entire tripod, but to <b>plaster the</b> cracks in the <b>small tripod of a small stove,</b> which requires a minimal amount of plaster.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>bran</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on the opening of a gold refiners’ crucible.</b>

Daf 80b

<b>The Sages taught: One who carries out hair</b> is liable in a measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to knead clay with it,</b> as hair would be mixed with clay to reinforce it. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>clay</b> is if it is sufficient <b>to make an opening for</b> the bellows to be placed in <b>a gold refiners’ crucible.</b>
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>lime</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread</b> as a depilatory on the smallest of girls. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: In a measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on the finger</b> of <b>the smallest of girls,</b> who would use lime to soften and pamper the skin. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> that initially, lime was used for a different purpose. It was used for <b>daughters of Israel who reached</b> physical <b>maturity, but had not</b> yet <b>reached the age</b> of maturity, and women who sought to remove hair for cosmetic purposes. <b>They would smear daughters of the poor with lime; they would smear daughters of the wealthy with fine flour; they would smear daughters of kings with <i>shemen hamor</i>, as it was stated:</b> “For so were the days of their anointing filled, <b>six months with <i>shemen hamor</i>”</b> (Esther 2:12). The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>shemen hamor</i>? Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya said: <i>Setaket</i>. Rav Yirmeya bar Abba said:</b> It is <b>olive oil</b> extracted from an olive <b>that</b> has <b>not</b> yet <b>reached a third</b> of its growth; the acidic oil is effective as a depilatory. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b><i>anfiknon</i></b> is <b>olive oil</b> from an olive <b>that has not reached a third</b> of its growth. <b>And why is it spread</b> on the body? Because <b>it removes the hair and pampers the skin.</b>
With regard to lime, the Gemara relates: <b>Rav Beivai had a daughter. He smeared her</b> with lime <b>limb by limb</b> and, as a result, she became so beautiful that when marrying her off, <b>he received four hundred <i>zuz</i></b> in gifts <b>for her</b> beyond her dowry. <b>There was a certain gentile in</b> Rav Beivai’s <b>neighborhood. He had a daughter</b> and wanted to do the same. <b>He smeared her</b> entire body with lime <b>at one time and she died. He said: Rav Beivai killed my daughter. Rav Naḥman said: Rav Beivai, who drinks beer, his daughters require</b> that they be <b>smeared</b> with lime, as beer causes hair growth; <b>we, who do not drink beer, our daughters do not require</b> that they be <b>smeared</b> with lime.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> An amount <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to spread on</b> the hair that grows over <b>the temple [<i>kilkul</i>]</b> so that it will lie flat. Rabbi Neḥemya says: An amount equivalent to that which is used to spread on the temple [<i>andifi</i>] to remove fine hairs. The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>kilkul</i> and what is <i>andifi</i>? Rav said: The temple and the area beneath the temple.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that the measure of Rabbi Yehuda is greater? Don’t we maintain that the measure of the Rabbis is greater?</b> The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda’s measure is <b>smaller than</b> that <b>of the Rabbis and greater than</b> the measure of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> where <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: The statement of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and his measure <b>appear</b> to be correct <b>with regard to dissolved lime, and the statement of Rabbi Neḥemya</b> appears to be correct <b>with regard to blocks of lime. And if it should enter your mind that</b> these terms refer to <b>the temple and the area beneath the temple, both</b> that which is spread on <b>this,</b> <i>kilkul</i>, <b>and</b> that which is spread on <b>that,</b> <i>andifi</i>, are referring to <b>dissolved lime. Rather, Rabbi Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>the school of Rabbi Ami said:</b> When Rav Neḥemya said <i>andifi</i> he meant <b><i>a’andifa</i>,</b> meaning the lime which was spread on the inside of earthenware vessels containing wine.
<b>Rav Kahana strongly objected to this: And does a person turn his money</b> into <b>a loss [<i>anparot</i>]?</b> In doing so, he ruins both the lime and the wine. <b>Rather, Rav Kahana said:</b> This lime is not placed inside the vessel, but it is used to make <b>markings</b> on the outside of the vessel to measure the contents of the vessel, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: In the Temple, <b>there were markings on the <i>hin</i></b> vessel to measure wine. These would indicate that when it is filled <b>to here,</b> that is the measure of wine required <b>for</b> the libation of the sacrifice of <b>an ox,</b> half a <i>hin</i>; when it is filled <b>to here,</b> the measure of wine required <b>for</b> the libation of the sacrifice of <b>a ram,</b> a third of a <i>hin</i>; when it is filled <b>to here,</b> the measure of wine required <b>for</b> the libation of the sacrifice of <b>a sheep,</b> a quarter of a <i>hin</i>. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>What is <i>andifa</i>?</b> It is <b>the forehead</b> upon which lime is smeared, not to remove hairs, but to pamper and soften the skin. Thick lime can be used for this purpose. <b>And</b> proof for that is cited from <b>a certain Galilean who happened to</b> come to <b>Babylonia, to whom they said: Stand</b> and <b>teach us</b> the esoteric <b>Act of the Divine Chariot [<i>Ma’aseh Merkava</i>]. He said to them: I will teach it to you as Rabbi Neḥemya taught</b> it <b>to his colleague. And a hornet emerged from the wall and stung him on his forehead [<i>andifi</i>] and he died.</b> Apparently, <i>andifi</i> means forehead. <b>And</b> with regard to the incident itself, <b>they said about him,</b> in a play on words: <b>From his own, that came to him [<i>min dilei da lei</i>].</b> He was punished for his arrogance in seeking to teach <i>Ma’aseh Merkava</i> publicly.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>earth</b> on Shabbat is <b>equivalent to the seal of large sacks;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b> Earth was used to seal the openings of sacks so that any tampering would be evident. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The measure for liability is much smaller, <b>equivalent to the seal of letters.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>manure and fine sand</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to fertilize</b> one <b>stalk of cabbage;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. And the Rabbis say:</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying it out is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to fertilize a leek,</b> which is less than that used for cabbage. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>coarse sand</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place on a full spoon of plaster.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>a reed</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make a quill. And if</b> the reed <b>was thick</b> and unfit for writing, <b>or</b> if it was <b>fragmented,</b> its measure for liability is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to cook an egg most easily</b> cooked, one that is already <b>beaten and placed in a stew pot.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>coarse sand</b> is equivalent to that which is used <b>to place on a full spoon of plaster.</b> A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: An amount <b>equivalent</b> to that which is <b>placed on the opening of a plasterer’s trowel,</b> and not on a spoon used for eating. The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who holds that <b>sand is beneficial for plaster</b> and is, therefore, mixed with it? <b>Rav Ḥisda said: It is Rabbi Yehuda, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In mourning the destruction of the Temple, <b>one may not plaster his house with plaster,</b> which is white, <b>unless he mixed straw or sand in it,</b> which will make the color off-white and less attractive. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Straw is permitted,</b> but <b>sand is prohibited because</b> when mixed with plaster it forms white <b>cement [<i>teraksid</i>].</b> Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda holds that sand is typically mixed with plaster. <b>Rava said: Even if you say that</b> our mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> who disagree with Rabbi Yehuda, we can say that <b>its ruination is its improvement.</b> Even though the Rabbis hold that mixing sand with plaster is not beneficial, since following the destruction of the Temple only partially ruined plaster may be used, adding sand to plaster enables its use.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>a reed</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make a quill.</b> The size of the quill was not specified. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: This refers to <b>a quill that reaches to the joints of one’s fingers. Rav Ashi raised a dilemma:</b> Is this referring to <b>the upper joint</b> of the fingers, <b>or the lower joint?</b> No resolution was found to this dilemma, and therefore <b>let it stand</b> unresolved.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And if</b> the reed <b>was thick</b> and unfit for writing, it is considered as fuel, and its measure for liability is equivalent to that which is used to cook a beaten egg. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Beaten</b> means beaten <b>in oil and placed in a stew pot. Mar, son of Ravina, said to his son: Have you heard what an egg</b> cooked <b>easily is? He said to him: The egg of a turtledove.</b> He asked his father: <b>What is the reason?</b> Is it <b>because</b> it <b>is small?</b> If so, <b>say</b> the egg <b>of a sparrow. He was silent</b> and had no explanation. He subsequently asked his father: <b>Have you heard</b> anything <b>about this? He said to him</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet said as follows:</b> This refers to <b>the egg of a chicken. And what</b> is the reason that <b>they call it an egg</b> cooked <b>easily?</b> Because <b>the Sages estimated</b> that <b>there is no egg easier to cook than the egg of a chicken.</b> He asked his father: <b>And what is different</b> about this measure? <b>All measures of</b> prohibited labors on <b>Shabbat</b> involving food are <b>a dried fig-bulk, and here</b> the measure is <b>like an egg</b> cooked easily? <b>He said to him</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said as follows:</b> He is liable for carrying out <b>a dried fig-bulk from an egg</b> cooked <b>easily,</b> not the entire egg.

Daf 81a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>a bone</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make a spoon. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> In a measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make from it a key.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>glass</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to scrape</b> and smooth <b>the top of a bobbin,</b> a sharpened stick used by weavers. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>a pebble or a stone</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to throw at a bird</b> to chase it away. <b>Rabbi Elazar bar Ya’akov says: Equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to throw at an animal,</b> which is larger.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that the measure of Rabbi Yehuda is greater? Don’t we maintain that the measure of the Rabbis is greater? Ulla said:</b> Rabbi Yehuda did not refer to the entire key, but to <b>the teeth of a key.</b> With regard to the above, the Gemara cites that which <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The teeth of a key are ritually pure,</b> and they cannot become impure when separate from the key, as they have no function on their own. However, if <b>one affixed them to a key, they</b> can become <b>ritually impure</b> as part of a utensil. <b>And</b> teeth <b>of a lock, even though one attached them to the door and affixed them with nails, are ritually pure, as anything attached to the ground has</b> the same legal status <b>as the ground</b> itself, which cannot become ritually impure.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>glass</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to scrape</b> and smooth the top of a bobbin. A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> that <i>halakha</i> in a <i>Tosefta</i> in a different manner: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>glass</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to cut two threads at once,</b> as a glass shard can be used in place of a knife.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>a pebble or a stone</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to throw at a bird</b> to chase it away. <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> ben Ya’akov says: Equivalent to that which is used to throw at an animal. <b>Rabbi Ya’akov said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And that is</b> only if the stone is large enough <b>that</b> the animal <b>feels it. And how much is the measure</b> of that stone? <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Ya’akov says: A weight of ten <i>zuz</i>.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Zunin entered the study hall</b> and <b>said to</b> the Sages: <b>My teachers,</b> with regard to <b>stones</b> that may be moved on Shabbat for wiping in <b>the bathroom, how much is their measure? They said to him:</b> Stones of only three sizes may be moved for that purpose: <b>An olive-bulk, a nut-bulk, and an egg-bulk. He said to them: And will he take scales [<i>turtani</i>] into</b> the bathroom to weigh each stone? <b>They were counted and the Sages concluded</b> that one need not measure the stones. He simply takes <b>a handful</b> of stones. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei says</b> the measure of bathroom stones is <b>an olive-bulk, a nut-bulk, and an egg-bulk. Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi Yosei, says in the name of his father:</b> One need not measure the stones. He simply takes <b>a handful</b> of stones.
<b>Our Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>with regard to Shabbat: Three sharpened stones may be taken into the bathroom. And what is their measure? Rabbi Meir says: A nut-bulk; Rabbi Yehuda says: An egg-bulk. Rafram bar Pappa said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Like</b> the <b>dispute here, so too,</b> there <b>is a dispute</b> between these Sages <b>with regard to</b> the minimum size of <b>a citron.</b> The Gemara is surprised at the comparison. Why does the Gemara cite this <i>baraita</i> as a mnemonic to recall the dispute about the size of a citron? <b>There,</b> with regard to a citron, it is <b>a mishna</b> that is known by all; <b>here</b> it is <b>a <i>baraita</i>,</b> which is more obscure and more likely to require a mnemonic and a comparison to a more popular source. <b>Rather,</b> the phrasing is reversed: <b>Like</b> the <b>dispute</b> with regard to <b>a citron, so too,</b> there <b>is a dispute here.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said: However,</b> one may <b>not</b> move <b>the <i>payis</i></b> for use in a bathroom. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b><i>payis</i>? Rabbi Zeira said:</b> It refers to <b>clods of Babylonian earth,</b> which is soft and flaky. <b>Rava said: It is prohibited to manipulate</b> the anus <b>with a stone on Shabbat</b> to help discharge bodily functions <b>in the manner</b> that <b>one manipulates</b> it <b>on weekdays. Mar Zutra strongly objected to this:</b> According to Rava, should one <b>endanger himself</b> by refraining from relieving himself? The Gemara explains: He meant he should do so <b>in an unusual manner</b> and not in the manner it is typically done. With regard to the size of stones, <b>Rabbi Yannai said: If</b> he has <b>a fixed place for a bathroom,</b> he may take <b>a handful</b> of stones; if he does not need them on Shabbat, he can use them on another occasion. <b>If</b> he does <b>not</b> have a fixed place he may bring in <b>an average size</b> stone, which is the size <b>of a small mortar</b> used <b>for</b> crushing <b>spices. Rav Sheshet said: If</b> the stone <b>has an indication on it</b> that it has already been used in the bathroom, <b>one is permitted</b> to move it for that purpose on Shabbat, regardless of its size.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection:</b> Is it permitted to wipe with a stone that was already used? Didn’t the Sages say: <b>Ten things bring a person to</b> suffer from <b>hemorrhoids and they are: One who eats the leaves of bulrushes, grape leaves, tendrils of grapevines, the palate and tongue of an animal,</b> as well as any other part of the animal which is not smooth and which has protrusions, <b>without salt, the spine of a fish, a salty fish that is not fully cooked, and one who drinks wine dregs, and one who cleans himself with lime and clay,</b> the materials from which earthenware is made, <b>and one who cleans himself with a stone with which another</b> person <b>has cleaned himself. And some say: One who suspends himself in the bathroom as well.</b> Apparently, using a previously used stone is dangerous to one’s health. The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where it is prohibited, is referring <b>to</b> a case where the stone is still <b>moist. Here,</b> where it is permitted, is referring <b>to</b> a case where the stone is <b>dry. And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>here,</b> where it is prohibited, is referring to <b>one side,</b> using the side that was already used; <b>here,</b> where it is permitted, is referring <b>to both sides,</b> using the other side of the same stone. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>this,</b> where it is permitted, is referring <b>to one’s own</b> stone, which he used to clean himself; <b>this,</b> where it is prohibited, is referring to <b>another</b> person’s stone, which poses a danger.
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef:</b> What is the ruling if <b>rain fell on</b> the stone <b>and</b> the indications that it had been used previously in the bathroom <b>were obscured?</b> The dilemma is: Is moving it permitted like a stone that is designated for use in the bathroom on Shabbat, or, is moving it prohibited since its indications were obscured and it might have the legal status of set-aside? Rav Yosef <b>said to him: If indication on them is apparent,</b> even though it is partially obscured, <b>it is permitted,</b> since the stone remains clear that it is designated for use in the bathroom.
<b>Rabba bar Rav Sheila raised a dilemma before Rav</b>

Daf 81b

<b>Ḥisda: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to taking</b> those stones <b>up with him to the roof</b> if his bathroom is there? Is it permitted or is it prohibited due to the exertion involved? <b>He said to him:</b> It is permitted; <b>great is human dignity as it overrides a prohibition in the Torah.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>Mareimar sat and stated this <i>halakha</i>. Ravina raised an objection to</b> the statement of <b>Mareimar</b> from a <i>baraita</i> where <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: A person may take a</b> wood <b>chip from</b> the ground <b>before him to</b> clean <b>his teeth</b> on Shabbat. <b>And the Rabbis say one may take</b> a wood chip <b>only from the animal’s trough,</b> which is already designated for the animal’s use, but not from wood on the ground, which is set-aside. Apparently, despite the fact that using the wood chip enhances human dignity, it is nevertheless prohibited due to the prohibition of set-aside. The Gemara rejects this: <b>How can you compare? There, a person determines</b> the <b>place for</b> his <b>meal.</b> Since he knows where he will eat he should have prepared toothpicks beforehand. <b>Here, does a person determine</b> the <b>place for a bathroom?</b> He relieves himself wherever he finds a discreet place to do so.
<b>Rav Huna said: It is prohibited to defecate in a plowed field on Shabbat.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for that prohibition? <b>If you say</b> it is <b>due to</b> the fact that in doing so he <b>treads</b> on the furrows and destroys them, it should be prohibited <b>even on weekdays. Rather,</b> it is <b>due to</b> the concern that he will clean himself with a clod of earth on which <b>grasses</b> have grown. <b>Didn’t Reish Lakish say</b> that <b>it is permitted to wipe with a stone upon which grasses have grown</b> even though the grasses will be detached as a result? <b>And</b> that is the <i>halakha</i> even though <b>one who</b> unwittingly <b>detaches</b> grasses <b>from it on Shabbat is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering. Rather,</b> the concern is <b>lest he take</b> a clod of earth <b>from</b> a <b>high</b> place, a pile of dirt, <b>and throw it to</b> a <b>low</b> place, into a hole in the ground. <b>And</b> in that case, he would <b>be liable due to that</b> which <b>Rabba</b> said, <b>as Rabba said:</b> If one <b>had a hole and filled it, in the house, he is liable due to</b> the prohibited labor of <b>building; in the field, he is liable due to plowing.</b>
With regard to <b>the matter itself, Reish Lakish said: It is permitted to wipe with a stone upon which grasses have grown. And one who detaches</b> grasses <b>from it</b> unwittingly <b>on Shabbat is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering. Rav Pappi said: Learn from that</b> which <b>Reish Lakish</b> said that <b>it is permitted to carry this perforated flowerpot</b> on Shabbat. <b>Rav Kahana strongly objects to this: If they said</b> that it is permitted to carry a stone with weeds on it <b>for a purpose, will they say</b> it is permitted to carry a flowerpot <b>for no purpose? Abaye said: Since</b> the topic of <b>a perforated pot has come to our hands, let us say something with regard to it:</b> If <b>it</b> had been <b>placed on the ground and one</b> lifted it and <b>placed it on top of pegs</b> on Shabbat, <b>he is liable for</b> the labor of <b>detaching.</b> The roots of the plant could have protruded through the holes to draw sustenance from the ground, and when one lifts it he detaches it from that sustenance. Similarly, if <b>it</b> had been <b>placed on pegs and one placed it on the ground, he is liable for</b> the labor of <b>planting.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: It is prohibited to wipe with an earthenware shard on Shabbat.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for that prohibition? <b>If you say</b> that it is <b>due to</b> the <b>danger</b> that he might injure himself with the sharp edges of the shard, it should be prohibited <b>also on weekdays. Rather,</b> it is <b>due to</b> the fact that it invites <b>witchcraft.</b> If so, he should <b>also not</b> do so <b>on weekdays. Rather,</b> the concern is <b>lest</b> he <b>remove hairs</b> with the earthenware shard. However, that is <b>an unintentional act,</b> which is permitted. <b>Rav Natan bar Oshaya said to</b> those who raised the question: <b>A great man said something, let us say a reason for it,</b> and explain Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement as follows: <b>It is not necessary</b> to say that it is <b>prohibited on a weekday</b> for the aforementioned reasons because he has the option of using a stone. <b>However, with regard to Shabbat</b> we would have said that <b>since</b> this shard <b>has the status of a utensil</b> and is not set-aside, he may <b>well</b> use it, as it is preferable to a stone, which is set-aside. Therefore, <b>he teaches us</b> that it is prohibited.
<b>Rava taught</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan ruled that it is prohibited <b>due to the removal of hairs, and he</b> raised <b>a difficulty</b> between <b>that</b> which <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said here and <b>that</b> which <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> said elsewhere. <b>Did Rabbi Yoḥanan say it is forbidden to wipe with an earthenware shard on Shabbat? Apparently,</b> he holds that <b>an unintentional act is prohibited. Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan state</b> a principle: <b>The <i>halakha</i></b> is ruled <b>in accordance with an unattributed mishna? And we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>A nazirite,</b> for whom it is prohibited to cut his hair, <b>may wash</b> his hair on a weekday with sand and natron <b>and separate</b> it with his fingers; <b>however, he may not comb</b> it, which would certainly pull out some hair. Apparently, the unintentional act of removing hair while shampooing is permitted. <b>Rather, it is clearly in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rav Natan bar Oshaya.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <b>witchcraft</b> involved with wiping with an earthenware shard? The Gemara explains: It is <b>as that</b> which transpired when <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna were going on a boat. A certain matron [<i>matronita</i>] said to them: Let me sit with you, and they did not let her sit. She said something,</b> an incantation of witchcraft, and <b>stopped the boat. They said something,</b> the Holy Name, and <b>freed it. She said to them: What will I do to you,</b> to enable me to harm you with witchcraft,

Daf 82a

<b>as you do not clean</b> yourselves <b>with an earthenware shard, and you do not kill lice on your garments, and you do not pull out a vegetable and eat it</b> before you untie <b>the bundle that was tied by the gardener?</b> This implies that all these actions carry with them the danger of witchcraft.
<b>Rav Huna said to his son Rabba: What is the reason that you are not</b> to be <b>found</b> among those who study <b>before Rav Ḥisda, whose <i>halakhot</i> are incisive?</b> Rabba <b>said to him:</b> For <b>what</b> purpose <b>should I go to him? When I go to him, he sits me down</b> and occupies me <b>in mundane matters</b> not related to Torah. For example, <b>he said to me: One who enters a bathroom should not sit down immediately and should not exert</b> himself <b>excessively</b> because <b>the rectum rests upon three teeth,</b> the muscles that hold it in place, and there is concern <b>lest the teeth of</b> the <b>rectum dislocate</b> through exertion <b>and he come to danger.</b> Rav Huna <b>said</b> to his son Rabba: <b>He is dealing with</b> matters crucial to <b>human life, and you say</b> that he is dealing <b>with mundane matters?</b> Now that I know what you meant, <b>all the more so go before him.</b>
The Gemara continues to discuss these <i>halakhot</i>. <b>Rav Huna said:</b> One who relieves himself and needs to wipe and <b>has before him a stone and an earthenware</b> shard, <b>wipes with the stone and does not wipe with the earthenware</b> shard, since he might injure himself. <b>And Rav Ḥisda said: He wipes with the earthenware</b> shard <b>and does not wipe with the stone,</b> which is set-aside. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If one had before him a stone and an earthenware</b> shard, <b>he wipes with the earthenware</b> shard <b>and does not wipe with the stone.</b> That is a <b>conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of <b>Rav Huna. Rafram bar Pappa explained it before Rav Ḥisda in accordance</b> with the opinion <b>of Rav Huna:</b> It is not referring to earthenware shards, but to <b>the</b> smooth <b>rims of vessels,</b> which pose no danger.
<b>There were before him a stone and grasses.</b> With regard to the preferred method to wipe on Shabbat, what is the ruling? There is a dispute between <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rav Hamnuna. One said: He wipes with the stone and does not wipe with the grasses; and one said: He wipes with the grasses and does not wipe with the stone.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who wipes with something flammable, his lower teeth,</b> which hold the intestines in place, <b>fall out.</b> How then, may one clean himself with grasses? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult: This,</b> where it is permitted, is referring <b>to moist</b> grass; <b>that,</b> where it is prohibited, is referring <b>to dry</b> grass.
The Gemara continues to discuss this topic. With regard to <b>one who needs to defecate and does not do so,</b> there is a dispute between <b>Rav Ḥisda and Ravina. One said: An evil spirit dominates him; and one said: An odor of filth dominates him. It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with the one who said</b> that <b>an odor of filth dominates him, as it was taught: One who needs to defecate and eats is comparable to an oven that was heated on top of its ashes; and that is the onset of an odor of filth.</b>
The Gemara continues to discuss the issue: <b>One who needed to defecate and is unable to do so, Rav Ḥisda said: He should stand and sit, stand and sit. Rav Ḥanan from Neharde’a said: He should move to the sides</b> and attempt to relieve himself in a different spot. <b>Rav Hamnuna said: He should manipulate with a stone in that place. And the Rabbis said: He should divert his thoughts</b> to other matters. <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: All the more so that when he diverts his thoughts he will not</b> be able to <b>defecate.</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to him: He should divert his thoughts from other matters,</b> and focus exclusively on his effort to relieve himself. <b>Rav Yirmeya from Difti said: I saw a certain Arab who stood and sat, stood and sat, until</b> it <b>poured</b> out of him <b>like a pot.</b> Apparently, that advice is effective.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who wishes to enter</b> and partake of <b>a regular meal</b> that will last for some time, <b>should pace</b> a distance of <b>four cubits ten times, and some say, ten cubits four times,</b> in order to expedite the movement of the bowels, <b>and defecate, and enter, and sit in his place.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One who carries out a shard of <b>earthenware</b> on Shabbat is liable if it is in a measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to place between one pillar and another</b> when piled on the ground to separate them; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says:</b> In a measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to stoke a fire with it. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> In a measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to hold a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>in it. Rabbi Meir said: Although there is no proof for the matter,</b> there is a biblical <b>allusion to</b> my opinion, as it is stated: “And He shall break it as a potter’s vessel is broken, smashing it without sparing; <b>and there shall not be found among its pieces a shard to rake fire on the hearth”</b> (Isaiah 30:14). <b>Rabbi Yosei said to him:</b> Is there <b>proof from there?</b> The verse concludes: <b>“And to extract water from the cistern,”</b> indicating that earthenware is significant if it is large enough to hold water.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Is <b>the measure</b> stated by <b>Rabbi Meir greater, or</b> is <b>the measure</b> stated by <b>Rabbi Yosei greater?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>It is reasonable</b> to say that <b>the measure</b> of <b>Rabbi Yosei is greater; however,</b> based on the <b>verse</b> it appears that <b>the measure</b> of <b>Rabbi Meir is greater. As, if it enters your mind</b> to say that <b>the measure</b> of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> with regard to the shard of earthenware <b>is greater,</b> would the prophet first <b>curse him</b> by saying that <b>a small vessel</b> will not be found, <b>and then curse him</b> by saying that <b>a larger vessel</b> will not be found? <b>Abaye said: The mishna is also</b> referring to a large shard of earthenware required <b>to stoke the fire of a large conflagration.</b> Even in the mishna, Rabbi Meir’s measure is larger.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yosei said to him:</b> Is there <b>proof from there?</b> He cites proof for his opinion from the conclusion of that same verse. The Gemara comments: <b>Rabbi Yosei spoke well to Rabbi Meir. And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Meir</b> address that proof? He explains that the verse <b>is stated</b> employing the style of: <b>There is no need.</b> It should be understood as follows: <b>There is no need</b> to say that <b>an item</b> that is <b>significant to people,</b> e.g., a large shard of earthenware to stoke a fire, <b>shall not be found, but even an item</b> that is <b>insignificant to people,</b> i.e., a shard to extract water, <b>shall not be found.</b> Therefore, the conclusion of the verse does not contradict Rabbi Meir’s opinion.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Akiva said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that idolatry, e.g.,</b> a statue of a deity<b>, transmits impurity</b> imparted <b>by carrying</b> even when the person who carries it does not come into contact with it<b>, just as</b> a <b>menstruating woman</b> does? <b>As it is stated: “</b>And you will defile the silver overlays of your statues<b>,</b> and the golden plating of your idols<b>, you will cast them away as you would a menstruating woman [<i>dava</i>], you will tell it, get out”</b> (Isaiah 30:22). <b>Just as a menstruating woman transmits impurity</b> imparted <b>by carrying, so too, idolatry transmits impurity</b> imparted <b>by carrying.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Since the <i>halakhot</i> of idolatry and the impurity it causes are beyond the scope of tractate <i>Shabbat</i>, the fundamentals of this <i>halakha</i> are cited from tractate <i>Avoda Zara</i>. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there: One whose house was adjacent to</b> a house of <b>idolatry,</b> sharing a common wall, <b>and</b> the dividing wall <b>fell, it is prohibited to rebuild it</b> as he would thereby have built a wall for idol worship. <b>What should one do? He moves four cubits into his own</b> land <b>and builds</b> the wall there.

Daf 82b

If the wall stood upon ground that <b>belonged to him and to the</b> house of <b>idolatry,</b> the area <b>is calculated as half and half</b> as far as moving into his property before rebuilding the wall, and one may build the wall four cubits from the middle of the wall. <b>Its stones and its wood and its dust</b> from the house of idolatry <b>transmit impurity like creeping animals,</b> and by rabbinic decree, one who touches them becomes impure like one who touches a creeping animal, <b>as it is stated:</b> “And you shall not bring an abomination into your house and become banned like it, <b>you shall utterly detest it [<i>shaketz teshaketzenu</i>]</b> and you shall utterly abhor it, for it is a banned object” (Deuteronomy 7:26). <i>Shaketz</i> is a term used with regard to creeping animals. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> Idolatry transmits impurity <b>like a menstruating woman, as it is stated: “You will cast them away as you would a menstruating woman [<i>dava</i>]”</b> (Isaiah 30:22). <b>Just as a menstruating woman transmits impurity</b> imparted <b>by carrying,</b> as one who moves a menstruating woman without touching her becomes impure, <b>so too, idolatry transmits impurity</b> imparted <b>by carrying. Rabba said</b> in explanation of that which <b>the verse said: “You will cast them away”: Make them foreign to you like a stranger.</b> The end of the same verse: <b>“You will tell it, get out”</b> means that under <b>no</b> circumstances can you <b>say to it, come in.</b>
<b>And</b> to the essence of the dispute, <b>Rabba said: With regard to</b> impurity imparted <b>by carrying, everyone agrees</b> that idol worship <b>transmits impurity, as it is juxtaposed to a menstruating woman</b> in the verse. <b>Where they argue,</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a very heavy stone.</b> There is a special law with regard to the ritual impurity of a <i>zav</i> and a menstruating woman. If they sit on an object, even if it is an object that cannot become ritually impure, and beneath that object is a vessel, even though the weight of the <i>zav</i> and the menstruating woman has no effect on the vessel, it becomes ritually impure. <b>Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that the impurity of idolatry is <b>like</b> the impurity of a <b>menstruating woman</b> in all respects; <b>just as a menstruating woman transmits impurity via a very heavy stone, so too, idolatry transmits impurity via a very heavy stone. And the Rabbis hold</b> that in this regard, the impurity of idolatry is <b>like</b> the impurity of <b>a creeping animal; just as a creeping animal does not transmit impurity via a very heavy stone, so too, idolatry does not transmit impurity via a very heavy stone.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according <b>to Rabbi Akiva,</b> who holds that the impurity of idolatry is similar to that of a menstruating woman in all respects, <b>for what <i>halakha</i> was it juxtaposed to a creeping animal?</b> The Gemara explains: In his opinion, it was not stated in reference to idolatry itself, but rather <b>to its accessories,</b> objects used for the purposes of idolatry. The Gemara asks further: <b>And according to the Rabbis, for what <i>halakha</i> was it juxtaposed to a menstruating woman? To</b> teach that it transmits impurity through <b>carrying. And</b> instead of juxtaposing idolatry to both a menstruating woman and to creeping animals, <b>let the Torah juxtapose it to an</b> animal <b>carcass,</b> which transmits impurity through carrying and does not transmit impurity via a very heavy stone, since according to the Rabbis the law is the same for idolatry. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so.</b> In that sense, juxtaposition to an animal carcass would suffice. <b>However,</b> the juxtaposition to a menstruating woman teaches: <b>Just as a menstruating woman</b> does <b>not</b> transmit impurity through <b>limbs,</b> as if the limb of a menstruating woman is supported by a vessel, the vessel does not become ritually impure (Ra’avad), <b>so too, idolatry does not</b> transmit impurity through <b>limbs,</b> as a severed part of an idol does not transmit impurity. The Gemara is puzzled by this: <b>But that which Rav Ḥama bar Guria raised as a dilemma: Does idolatry have</b> the capacity to transmit impurity through <b>limbs or does it not</b> have the capacity to transmit impurity through <b>limbs? Resolve</b> the dilemma <b>from this, as according to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, it does not</b> transmit impurity through <b>limbs.</b> And the Gemara replies: Although that is so, <b>Rav Ḥama bar Guria raised the dilemma in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> and the dilemma is unresolved.
<b>And</b> in another approach to this dispute, <b>Rabbi Elazar said: With regard to a very heavy stone, everyone agrees</b> that idolatry <b>does not transmit impurity</b> in that manner. <b>Where they disagree</b> is <b>with regard to</b> impurity imparted by <b>carrying. Rabbi Akiva holds</b> that the legal status of idolatry is <b>like</b> that of <b>a menstruating woman: Just as a menstruating woman transmits impurity through carrying, so too, idolatry transmits impurity through carrying. And the Rabbis hold</b> that the legal status of idolatry is <b>like</b> that of <b>a creeping animal: Just as a creeping animal does not transmit impurity through carrying, so too, idolatry does not transmit impurity through carrying.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Akiva’s</b> opinion, with regard <b>to what <i>halakha</i> was</b> idolatry <b>juxtaposed to a creeping animal?</b> The Gemara answers: With regard <b>to</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>its accessories</b> do not transmit impurity through carrying. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the Rabbis,</b> with regard <b>to what <i>halakha</i> was</b> idolatry <b>juxtaposed to a menstruating woman?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Just as a menstruating woman does not</b> transmit impurity <b>through</b> her <b>limbs, so too, idolatry does not</b> transmit impurity <b>through</b> its <b>limbs.</b>

Daf 83a

<b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> with regard <b>to what <i>halakha</i> was</b> idolatry <b>juxtaposed to a menstruating woman?</b> If it was to teach the <i>halakha</i> of impurity imparted by <b>carrying, let it be juxtaposed to an</b> animal <b>carcass</b> and not to a menstruating woman and creeping animals. The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, it is indeed so. However,</b> the juxtaposition to a menstruating woman teaches: <b>Just as a menstruating woman does not</b> transmit impurity <b>through</b> her <b>limbs,</b> as a menstruating woman who leans on an object by a single limb does not transmit impurity imparted by carrying (Ra’avad), <b>so too, an idol does not</b> transmit impurity <b>through</b> its <b>limbs,</b> and a section of an idol does not transmit impurity. The Gemara asks: <b>But that which Rav Ḥama bar Guria raised as a dilemma: Does idolatry have</b> the capacity to transmit impurity through <b>limbs or does it not</b> have the capacity to transmit impurity <b>through its limbs; resolve</b> the dilemma <b>from this, as according to both the Rabbis and Rabbi Akiva, it does not</b> transmit impurity <b>through limbs.</b> According to this explanation, Rabbi Akiva agrees with the Rabbis. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Rav Ḥama bar Guria taught in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rabba and raised the dilemma in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b>
The Gemara now clarifies the explanations of Rabba and Rabbi Elazar in light of other sources. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The ritual impurity of <b>idolatry</b> is <b>like</b> that of <b>a creeping animal, and</b> the ritual impurity of <b>its accessories</b> is <b>like</b> that of <b>a creeping animal. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The ritual impurity of <b>idolatry</b> is <b>like</b> that of <b>a menstruating woman, and</b> the ritual impurity of <b>its accessories</b> is <b>like</b> that of <b>a creeping animal. Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> it works out <b>well. However,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba, it is difficult.</b> The dispute between Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis in this <i>baraita</i> is whether idolatry is likened to a creeping animal and does not transmit impurity imparted by carrying or whether it is likened to a menstruating woman and it does transmit impurity imparted by carrying. According to Rabba, the Rabbis agree that it does transmit impurity imparted by carrying. <b>Rabba</b> could have <b>said to you: Is</b> the proof from this <i>baraita</i> <b>stronger than</b> the <b>mishna</b> in tractate <i>Avoda Zara</i>, <b>which taught: Its wood and stones and dirt transmit impurity like a creeping animal?</b> With regard to that mishna <b>we established: What</b> is the meaning of <b>like a creeping animal?</b> It means that it is like a creeping animal in the sense <b>that it does not transmit impurity by means of a very heavy stone. Here too,</b> the analogy to a creeping animal in the <i>baraita</i> is in the sense that <b>it does not transmit impurity via a very heavy stone.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from what we learned: <b>A gentile man and a gentile woman,</b> with regard to whom the Rabbis issued a decree that they transmit impurity like a <i>zav</i>, <b>idolatry and its accessories,</b> all transmit impurity. <b>They</b> transmit impurity, <b>and not their movement,</b> i.e., they do not transmit impurity to one who moves them. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> Both <b>they and their movement</b> transmit impurity. <b>Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the explanation of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> this works out <b>well; however,</b> according <b>to</b> the explanation of <b>Rabba, it is difficult. Rabba</b> could have <b>said to you: And according to your reasoning,</b> with regard to <b>a gentile man and a gentile woman as well,</b> do <b>they</b> transmit impurity <b>and their movement</b> does <b>not</b> transmit impurity? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“Speak to the children of Israel</b> and say to them, when any man has an emission from his body, his emission is impure” (Leviticus 15:2), by Torah law, only <b>the children of Israel become impure through</b> the <b>emission of a <i>zav</i>, and gentiles do not become impure through</b> the <b>emission of a <i>zav</i>? But</b> the Sages <b>decreed that they should be</b> considered <b>like a <i>zav</i> for all their</b> halakhic <b>matters.</b> Since gentiles have the legal status of a <i>zav</i>, they should transmit impurity through carrying. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> that states that gentiles do not transmit impurity through carrying is corrupted and must be emended.
<b>Rather, Rabba explains</b> and adds to the <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with his reasoning: A gentile man and a gentile woman</b> transmit impurity, <b>they and their movement and their very heavy stone.</b> And <b>idolatry</b> transmits impurity, <b>it and its movement but not its very heavy stone. Rabbi Akiva says: Idolatry</b> transmits impurity, <b>it and its movement and its very heavy stone. And Rabbi Elazar explains</b> and adds to the <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with his reasoning</b> as follows: <b>A gentile man and a gentile woman</b> transmit impurity, <b>they and their movement and their very heavy stone. Idolatry</b> transmits impurity, <b>it and not its movement. And Rabbi Akiva says: Idolatry</b> transmits impurity, <b>it and its movement.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi strongly objects to</b> this explanation: According to this explanation, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the word <b>they</b> in the context of this <i>baraita</i>? It would have been sufficient to say that their movement transmits impurity. The fact that the gentiles themselves are ritually impure is obvious. Apparently, the word they is emphasized in order to teach an additional <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said, this is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> With regard to <b>a gentile man and a gentile woman, whether they moved others or others moved them,</b> the others <b>are ritually impure.</b> The impurity of a gentile is like that of a <i>zav</i>, which is unique in that anything that a <i>zav</i> moves becomes impure even if he did not touch it directly. <b>Idolatry that moved others,</b> the others remain <b>ritually pure;</b> however, <b>others who moved it are ritually impure.</b> With regard to <b>its accessories, whether they moved others or others moved them,</b> the others remain <b>ritually pure. Rabbi Akiva says: A gentile man and a gentile woman and idolatry, whether they moved others or others moved them,</b> the others <b>are ritually impure. Its accessories, whether they moved others or others moved them,</b> the others remain <b>ritually pure.</b> According to this explanation, both the word they and the word movement, both of which appear in the <i>baraita</i>, are significant.
Rav Ashi’s explanation explains the <i>baraita</i>, but the Gemara questions the matter itself. With regard to <b>idolatry, granted,</b> a case <b>where others moved it</b> can be easily <b>found. However,</b> a case where the idolatry <b>moved others,</b> under what circumstances <b>can it be found?</b> How can an idol move another object? <b>Rami, son of Rav Yeiva, said,</b> a case like that is possible, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: In a case where <b>the <i>zav</i></b> sat <b>on</b> one <b>pan of a</b> balance <b>scale, and food and drinks</b> were <b>on</b> the <b>second pan,</b> if <b>the <i>zav</i> tipped</b> the scales, the food and drinks on the other pan <b>are ritually impure</b> because the <i>zav</i> moved them.

Daf 83b

Even an inanimate object can move a source of impurity in that way. And if the food and drink <b>tipped the scales, they</b> remain <b>ritually pure.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All impure items that move</b> other objects remain <b>pure,</b> meaning that an object does not become impure if moved by a source of impurity, <b>except for movement by a <i>zav</i>, which has no counterpart in the whole Torah in its entirety? Let us say</b> that this is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, as if</b> it were <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, there is also</b> the case of <b>idolatry.</b> In his opinion, idolatry also transmits impurity to an object by moving it. The Gemara answers: <b>Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, teach: <i>Zav</i> and everything similar to it.</b> According to Rabbi Akiva, just as a menstruating woman falls into that category, so too does an idol.
The dilemma that was cited incidental to an earlier discussion is examined here in depth. <b>Rav Ḥama bar Guria raised a dilemma: Does idolatry have</b> the capacity to transmit impurity through <b>limbs or does it not</b> have the capacity to transmit impurity <b>through limbs?</b> The Gemara narrows the parameters of the dilemma. In a situation <b>where a common</b> unskilled <b>person can restore it</b> to its original form, <b>do not raise the dilemma, as</b> in that case it is certainly <b>considered to be attached</b> and is not considered broken. The case <b>where you</b> could <b>raise the dilemma</b> is <b>where a common</b> unskilled <b>person cannot restore it</b> to its original form. <b>What</b> is the ruling in that case? The two sides of the dilemma are: Do we say that <b>since a common</b> unskilled <b>person cannot restore it,</b> it is <b>considered broken? Or perhaps</b> we say that <b>it is not lacking</b> anything? Idolatry can only be nullified by breaking it in a case where, as a result, it is incomplete. <b>And some raise this dilemma in</b> another <b>direction</b> based on a different assumption: In a situation <b>where a common</b> unskilled <b>person cannot restore it</b> to its original form, <b>do not raise the dilemma, as</b> in that case it is certainly <b>considered to be broken.
