When you</b> could <b>raise the dilemma</b> is in a situation <b>where a common</b> unskilled <b>person can restore it</b> to its original form. <b>What</b> is the ruling in that case? The two sides of the dilemma are: Do we say that <b>since a common</b> unskilled <b>person can restore it,</b> it is <b>considered attached? Or perhaps</b> we say that <b>at present, it is in pieces and permitted?</b> No resolution was found for either version of this dilemma. Therefore, <b>let it stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami raised a dilemma: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>idolatry</b> that is <b>less than an olive-bulk? Rav Yosef strongly objected to this:</b> With regard <b>to what</b> use was this dilemma raised? <b>If you say</b> it was raised with regard <b>to the matter of the prohibition</b> of idolatry, <b>let it only be</b> like <b>Zevuv, the Baal of Ekron,</b> which was the size and form of a fly, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: <b>“And they made Baal Berit into their god”</b> (Judges 8:33). The Sages said that <b>this is</b> referring to <b>Zevuv, the Baal of Ekron.</b> It <b>teaches that each and every</b> person <b>made an image of his god and placed it in his pocket. When he remembered it, he removed it from his pocket and embraced and kissed it.</b> Apparently, even idolatry the size of a fly falls under the rubric of the prohibition of idolatry. <b>Rather,</b> the dilemma is: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to the matter of impurity?</b> The two sides of the dilemma are as follows: <b>Since</b> an idol <b>is juxtaposed to a creeping animal, just as a creeping animal</b> transmits impurity when it is <b>a lentil-bulk, so too, idolatry</b> transmits impurity when it is <b>a lentil-bulk. Or perhaps</b> idolatry <b>is juxtaposed to a corpse,</b> and <b>just as a corpse</b> transmits impurity only <b>when</b> it is at least <b>an olive-bulk, so too, idolatry</b> transmits impurity only <b>when</b> it is at least <b>an olive-bulk.</b>
<b>Rav Avya said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabba bar Ulla</b> who said: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from <b>that</b> which <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Idolatry</b> that is <b>less than an olive-bulk has no impurity at all, as it is stated:</b> “And he brought out the <i>ashera</i> from the house of the Lord, outside Jerusalem, to the brook of Kidron, and burned it at the brook of Kidron, and stamped it into powder, <b>and cast its powder upon the graves of the common people”</b> (II Kings 23:6). <b>Just as a corpse</b> transmits impurity when it is <b>an olive-bulk, so too, idolatry</b> transmits impurity when it is <b>an olive-bulk.</b>
The Gemara now asks a general question: <b>And</b> according to <b>the Rabbis,</b> with regard <b>to what <i>halakha</i> was</b> idolatry <b>juxtaposed to a creeping animal?</b> The juxtaposition establishes that like a creeping animal, <b>it does not transmit impurity through carrying.</b> The juxtaposition <b>to a menstruating woman</b> establishes that like a menstruating woman, it has the capacity to transmit impurity through <b>limbs.</b> The juxtaposition <b>to a corpse</b> establishes that it <b>does not transmit impurity when</b> it is <b>a lentil-bulk.</b> The Gemara suggests: Let us <b>say</b> that all of these juxtapositions come <b>to</b> teach <b>a stringency.</b> With regard <b>to what <i>halakha</i> did the Torah juxtapose</b> idolatry <b>to a creeping animal?</b> It is <b>to</b> establish that it <b>transmits impurity when</b> it is <b>a lentil-bulk.</b> The juxtaposition of idolatry <b>to a menstruating woman</b> is <b>to</b> establish that it <b>transmits impurity via a very heavy stone;</b> and <b>the Torah juxtaposed</b> it <b>to a corpse to</b> establish that it <b>transmits impurity</b> imparted <b>by a tent,</b> all of which are stringencies that exist with regard to those types of impurity. The Gemara answers: <b>The impurity of idolatry is by rabbinic law. And</b> whenever there are two possibilities with regard to a rabbinic decree, <b>a leniency and a stringency, we juxtapose</b> to establish the <b>lenient</b> possibility, and <b>we do not juxtapose to</b> establish <b>the stringent</b> possibility.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> This is another mishna that digresses from the central topic of this tractate. It, too, is based on an allusion from the Bible. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that the ship is ritually pure,</b> in the sense that it cannot become impure? <b>As it is stated: “The way of a ship in the midst of the sea”</b> (Proverbs 30:19).
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The allusion in the mishna requires clarification. The verse appears to state the <b>obvious.</b> Of course <b>a ship is in the midst of the sea.</b> Rather, <b>this</b> verse <b>teaches us</b> an allusion that the legal status of a boat is <b>like</b> that of <b>the sea. Just as the sea is ritually pure</b> and cannot become impure, <b>so too, a boat is ritually pure</b> and cannot become impure. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Ḥananya says:</b> This <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a sack,</b> as the impurity of wooden vessels is likened to the impurity of a sack. <b>Just as a sack,</b> which can become ritually impure, <b>is carried</b> both <b>full and empty, so too, any</b> object that <b>is carried</b> both <b>full and empty</b> can become ritually impure. This is <b>to exclude a ship,</b> which <b>is not carried</b> on land <b>full and empty,</b> as due to its weight it cannot be carried full.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between</b> the two reasons? The halakhic ruling according to both is that a ship cannot become impure. The Gemara explains: <b>There is</b> a difference <b>between them</b> with regard to <b>a ship made from earthenware</b> or from any material other than wood. According to <b>the one who said</b> that it is derived from the verse: <b>“A ship in the midst of the sea,” this</b> boat is <b>also in the midst of the sea.</b> However, <b>according to the one who said</b> that it is derived from the <i>halakha</i> of a <b>sack,</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies only to <b>those</b> materials <b>that are written</b> in the same verse <b>together with sack</b> and are likened to it. <b>If it is carried</b> both <b>full and empty, yes,</b> it can become impure; and if it can <b>not</b> be carried both full and empty, <b>no,</b> it cannot become impure. <b>However, an earthenware ship</b> can become impure <b>even though it is not carried</b> both <b>full and empty.</b>
<b>Alternatively,</b> there is a difference between them regarding a <b>Jordan ship,</b> which is a small boat used on the Jordan River. <b>According to the one who said</b> that it is derived from the verse: <b>“A ship in the midst of the sea,” this is also a ship in the midst of the sea.</b> A river is pure like the sea and the boat will remain pure. <b>According to the one who said</b> that it is derived from the <i>halakha</i> of a sack, and in order to become impure it must be <b>carried full and empty, this is also carried</b> both <b>full and empty,</b> and can become ritually impure. <b>As Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akavya said: For what</b> reason did <b>they say that a Jordan ship can become impure? Because they load it on dry land</b> and carry it on land <b>and</b> then <b>lower it into the water.</b> It is carried on land when full. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: One should never prevent himself from</b> attending <b>the study hall for even one moment, as this mishna</b> which states that a Jordan ship can become ritually impure <b>was taught for several years in the study hall, but its reason was not revealed until Rabbi Ḥanina ben Akavya came and explained it.</b>
Following Rav’s statement, the Gemara cites that which <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: One should never prevent himself from</b> attending <b>the study hall or from</b> engaging in <b>matters of Torah, even at the moment of death, as it is stated: “This is the Torah: A person who dies in a tent”</b> (Numbers 19:14). That is an allusion to the fact that <b>even at the moment of death, one should engage in</b> the study of <b>Torah. Reish Lakish said: Matters of Torah only endure in a person who kills himself over</b> the Torah, one who is ready to devote all his efforts to it, <b>as it is stated: “This is the Torah: A person who dies in a tent,”</b> meaning that the Torah is only attained by one who kills himself in its tent. <b>Rava said:</b>

Daf 84a

<b>And</b> according <b>to Ḥananya,</b> who holds that a boat carried both full and empty can become ritually impure, is <b>carrying by oxen considered carrying?</b> He answered his own question. <b>Yes,</b> as <b>we learned</b> in a mishna: In terms of the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual purity and impurity, <b>there are three</b> distinct types of <b>wagons:</b> A wagon built <b>like a chair,</b> meaning closed on the sides, can become <b>ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>treading.</b> Since it is designated for sitting, it becomes impure if a <i>zav</i> sits on it, even if he does not touch it. A wagon built <b>like a bed</b> can become <b>ritually impure</b> with <b>impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse.</b> It contracts all types of impurity, except for impurity imparted by the treading of a <i>zav</i>. A wagon made <b>of stone,</b> whose bottom is netting, remains <b>ritually pure</b> and does not become impure <b>from any</b> type of impurity. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And if</b> in the stone wagon <b>there is</b> a <b>receptacle for pomegranates,</b> i.e., the holes are not large enough for a pomegranate to fall through, it is considered a utensil and it can become <b>impure with impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse.</b> Even though a stone wagon is not carried full, but is pulled by oxen, it can become ritually impure. Apparently, carrying by oxen is considered carrying.
By association, the Gemara now cites the second part of the mishna: With regard to laws of impurity, <b>there are three</b> types of <b>chests: A chest that opens from the side,</b> on which one can sit or lie, because it can be used for sitting, it can become <b>ritually impure</b> with <b>impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading</b> if a <i>zav</i> sits on it. Even if one needs to open the chest, a person can keep sitting on it. A chest that opens <b>from the top</b> does not become ritually impure with impurity imparted by treading because it cannot be opened with somebody on it. However, it can become impure <b>with impurity</b> imparted by <b>a corpse. And</b> a chest <b>that comes</b> in a very large <b>size,</b> and can hold more than forty <i>se’a</i>, remains <b>ritually pure</b> and does not become impure <b>from any</b> type of impurity.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to impurity imparted by <b>treading, an earthenware vessel is ritually pure.</b> If a <i>zav</i> sits on an earthenware vessel and does not touch the inside of it, it does not become impure. <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> That is <b>even</b> the status of <b>a ship.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying? Rav Zevid said</b> that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying the following:</b> According to the first <i>tanna</i>, with regard to impurity imparted by <b>treading, an earthenware vessel is ritually pure; however,</b> if the <i>zav</i> <b>touches</b> the vessel it becomes <b>impure. And an earthenware ship</b> can become <b>impure</b> with impurity imparted by the treading of a <i>zav</i>, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya. Rabbi Yosei says: Even a boat is ritually pure, in accordance with</b> the opinion of the <b><i>tanna</i></b> of <b>our</b> mishna. <b>Rav Pappa strongly objects to this</b> explanation: If so, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the word <b>even</b> employed by Rabbi Yosei, indicating that he is adding to the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i>? According to the above explanation, the first <i>tanna</i> says that a boat can become ritually impure and Rabbi Yosei says that it is pure. Rabbi Yosei is not adding to the previous opinion but disagreeing with it. <b>Rather, Rav Pappa said</b> that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying the following:</b> With regard to impurity imparted by <b>treading, an earthenware vessel is ritually pure, and</b> with regard to <b>its contact</b> with a source of ritual impurity, <b>it is impure. And</b> as far as <b>a wooden vessel</b> is concerned, with regard to <b>both its</b> impurity imparted by <b>treading and its contact</b> with a source of ritual impurity, it is <b>impure. And a Jordan ship is ritually pure in accordance with</b> the opinion of the <b><i>tanna</i></b> of <b>our</b> mishna. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Even the boat is impure</b> like other wooden vessels, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥananya.</b>
The Gemara questions what was stated: <b>And from where do we</b> derive that with regard to impurity imparted by <b>treading, an earthenware vessel is ritually pure? Ḥizkiya said:</b> It is <b>as the verse states: “And whoever touches his bed</b> shall wash his clothes, and bathe himself in water, and be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:5). The verse <b>juxtaposes his bed to himself. Just as he has</b> the possibility of <b>purification</b> through immersion <b>in a ritual bath, so too, his bed</b> is referring to a vessel that <b>has</b> the possibility of <b>purification in a ritual bath.</b> Since an impure earthenware vessel cannot be purified in a ritual bath, unlike other vessels, it does not become ritually impure when a <i>zav</i> lies on it.
Similarly, <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> that the verse states: “Every bed on which she lies all the days of her <i>zava</i> emission <b>shall be for her like the bed of her menstrual period”</b> (Leviticus 15:26). The verse <b>juxtaposes her bed to herself: Just as she has</b> the possibility of <b>purification in a ritual bath, so too, her bed</b> is referring to a vessel that <b>has</b> the possibility of <b>purification in a ritual bath.</b> This is <b>to the exclusion of an earthenware vessel, which does not have</b> the possibility of <b>purification in a ritual bath. Rabbi Ila strongly objects</b> to this from what we learned: <b>From where</b> is it derived that <b>a</b> reed <b>mat</b> becomes ritually impure <b>from</b> contact with <b>a corpse?</b>

Daf 84b

<b>And it is</b> derived through <b>an</b> <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference:</b> We know that small vessels do not become ritually impure through the impurity of a <i>zav</i> because they are not designated for sitting, and are too small for the <i>zav</i> to insert his finger into their airspace. <b>If small</b> earthenware <b>pitchers</b> remain <b>pure</b> and are not susceptible <b>to</b> the impurity of <b>a <i>zav</i>,</b> but they do <b>become ritually impure from</b> contact with <b>a corpse; is it not logical that a</b> reed <b>mat,</b> which contracts <b>impurity from a <i>zav</i>, will</b> become <b>ritually impure from</b> contact with <b>a corpse? And why</b> should the reed mat become impure? <b>Isn’t it</b> true that <b>it does not have</b> the possibility of <b>purification in a ritual bath? Rabbi Ḥanina said to him: There,</b> in the case of the mat, <b>it is different because there is</b> purification <b>in</b> other vessels <b>of its kind,</b> i.e., other wooden vessels that are made from materials that grow from the earth can be purified in a ritual bath.
Rabbi Ila <b>said to</b> Rabbi Ḥanina: <b>May the all-Merciful save us from this opinion.</b> Rabbi Ḥanina responded: <b>On the contrary, may the all-Merciful save us from your opinion. And what is the reason</b> that this is relevant? What is the significance of the fact that other vessels of its kind can be purified in a ritual bath if the vessel itself cannot be purified in a ritual bath? It is because <b>two verses are written.</b> In one verse <b>it is written: “And whoever touches his bed</b> shall wash his clothes, and bathe himself in water, and be impure until the evening” (Leviticus 15:5). The verse juxtaposes his bed to himself. Just as he has the possibility of purification through immersion in a ritual bath, so too, his bed has the possibility of purification in a ritual bath. This teaches that his bed has the same legal status as he does; in order for a bed on which a <i>zav</i> lies to be subject to the impurity imparted by lying, it must be immersible in a ritual bath. <b>And</b> in another verse <b>it is written: “Every bed on which the <i>zav</i> lies shall be impure;</b> and every vessel on which he sits shall be impure” (Leviticus 15:4). This verse includes all beds on which a <i>zav</i> might lie, even one that cannot be purified in a ritual bath. <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> two verses be reconciled? If <b>there is</b> purification <b>in</b> other vessels <b>of its kind, even though it</b> itself <b>does not have purification in a ritual bath,</b> it is subject to the impurity imparted by lying. However, if <b>there is no</b> purification <b>in</b> other vessels <b>of its kind,</b> the verse <b>juxtaposes his bed to himself.</b> Any vessel that is not like him in the sense that it cannot be purified in a ritual bath, is not subject to impurity imparted by lying.
<b>Rava said:</b> The fact that with regard to impurity imparted by <b>treading, an earthenware vessel is ritually pure</b> is derived <b>from here,</b> as it is stated: <b>“And any open vessel that does not have a sealed cover on it</b> becomes impure” (Numbers 19:15). By inference, if <b>there is a sealed cover on it, it is pure. Are we not dealing</b> even with a case <b>where one designated</b> the vessel <b>for</b> use by <b>his wife,</b> when she has the status of a <b>menstruating woman? And</b> even so, <b>the Torah states</b> that it is <b>ritually pure?</b> Apparently, an earthenware vessel with a sealed cover is not subject to impurity from any source.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The Gemara continues to discuss an additional <i>halakha</i> based on a biblical allusion. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> in <b>a garden bed that is six by six handbreadths, that one may plant five</b> different types of <b>seeds in it?</b> He may do so without violating the prohibition of sowing a mixture of diverse kinds of seeds in the following manner. One sows <b>four</b> types of plants <b>on</b> each of <b>the four sides of the garden bed and one in the middle.</b> There is an allusion to this in the text, <b>as it is stated: “For as the earth brings forth its growth, and as a garden causes its seeds to grow,</b> so will the Lord God cause justice and praise to spring forth before all the nations” (Isaiah 61:11). <b>Its seed,</b> in the singular, <b>is not stated; rather, its seeds,</b> written in the plural. Apparently, it is possible that several seeds may be planted in a small garden.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara questions this allusion: <b>From where is it inferred</b> that the verse refers to five types of seeds? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that it is derived as follows: <b>“For as the earth brings forth its growth”</b> indicates five types of seeds because <b>“brings forth”</b> represents <b>one</b> and <b>“its vegetation”</b> represents <b>one,</b> and <b>that</b> totals <b>two. “Its seeds,”</b> written in the plural, represents at least <b>two,</b> and <b>that</b> totals <b>four. “Cause to grow” is one</b> more. This verse includes terms connoting planting and seeds in a single garden bed that total <b>five</b> species of seeds.

Daf 85a

<b>And the Sages</b> have <b>an accepted</b> tradition <b>that five</b> seeds <b>in</b> a <b>six-</b>handbreadth space <b>do not draw sustenance from one another.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive <b>that</b> when <b>the Sages</b> have <b>an accepted</b> tradition it <b>is a</b> substantial <b>matter,</b> meaning that the tradition is reliable? <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “You shall not cross your neighbor’s border, which they of the old times have set</b> in your inheritance that you shall inherit” (Deuteronomy 19:14)? It means that <b>you shall not cross the border that the early</b> generations <b>set,</b> establishing the parameters necessary for each plant. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>The early</b> generations <b>set? Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which was written: “These are the sons of Seir the Horite who inhabit the land,</b> Lotan and Shoval and Zibeon and Ana” (Genesis 36:20)? <b>And is everyone</b> else <b>inhabitants of the heavens,</b> that it was necessary for the verse to emphasize that these inhabit the land? <b>Rather,</b> it means <b>that they were experts in the settlement of the land, as they would say: This</b> tract of land that is the <b>full</b> length <b>of a rod</b> is fit <b>for olive</b> trees; <b>this full</b> length <b>of a rod</b> is fit <b>for grapes, this full</b> length <b>of a rod</b> is fit <b>for figs. And</b> the members of this tribe were called <b>Horites [<i>ḥori</i>]</b> since <b>they smelled [<i>heriḥu</i>] the earth</b> to determine what is fit to be grown there. The allusion is based on a transposition of the letters <i>ḥet</i> and <i>reish</i>. <b>And</b> in explanation of why the early inhabitants of Seir were called <b>Hivites [<i>ḥivi</i>]</b> (see Genesis 36:2), <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> Because <b>they would taste the earth like a snake [<i>ḥivya</i>]</b> and determine what should be grown there according to the taste. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said</b> that they were called <b>Horites [<i>ḥori</i>]</b> because <b>they became free [<i>benei ḥorin</i>] of their possessions</b> when the children of Esau drove them from their lands. Their primary name was actually Hivites.
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> itself, <b>Rav Asi said:</b> The <b>garden bed</b> in the mishna whose area is six by six handbreadths is one whose <b>internal</b> area <b>is six</b> by six handbreadths <b>excluding</b> the area of <b>its boundaries,</b> which must be added to the total area. <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The internal</b> area <b>of a garden bed is six</b> by six handbreadths. The Gemara asks: <b>How much</b> is the size of <b>its boundaries?</b> The Gemara answers, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The <b>width</b> of the border <b>is like the width of a foot.</b> And <b>Rabbi Zeira said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabbi Ḥanina bar Pappa</b> who <b>said: What is the reason</b> for the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda? As it is written: “And you water it with your foot like a garden of herbs”</b> (Deuteronomy 11:10), meaning that <b>just as</b> one’s <b>foot is a handbreadth</b> wide, <b>so too, the boundary</b> between garden beds where one walks to water plants <b>is also a handbreadth</b> wide.
<b>Rav said:</b> When we learned in the mishna that one may plant five kinds of seeds within <b>a garden bed</b> without violating the prohibition of diverse kinds, <b>we learned this</b> with regard to a garden bed <b>in a desolate area</b> not surrounded by other plants. However, if the garden bed is among other garden beds, it is prohibited to plant that many species there because seeds from the different beds will intermingle. The Gemara asks: If the mishna is dealing with a solitary garden bed, <b>isn’t there space</b> in <b>the corners,</b> where more species of seeds could be planted without encountering the prohibition of diverse seeds? <b>The school</b> of <b>Rav taught in the name of Rav:</b> Rav’s statement is referring to a case <b>where one fills</b> the <b>corners</b> of the flowerbed with the five species of seeds, leaving no room in the corners for other varieties. The Gemara asks: <b>And let him plant on the outside and not fill up the inside,</b> to increase the different seed types instead of filling up the corners.

Daf 85b

Rather, Rav’s reasoning must be: It is <b>a decree lest one will fill the corners</b> after having first planted the garden bed, and thereby violate the prohibition of diverse kinds. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> why should that matter, the legal status of the garden bed <b>should merely be</b> like <b>a triangular [<i>rosh tor</i>]</b> plot of <b>vegetables. Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: If <b>a triangular</b> plot of <b>vegetables was protruding into another field, it is permitted;</b> there, it is not considered a prohibited mixture of diverse kinds, <b>because the end of the field is distinguishable.</b> Based on the shapes of the two fields where they intersect, the demarcation between them is clear. And the Gemara answers: <b>There is no</b> leniency with regard to a <b>triangular plot in a garden bed.</b> This allowance with regard to a triangular section of one field jutting into another field applies only to a large field where the triangular shape can clearly be attributed to a different field, but in a small garden bed where the seeds are adjacent to one another, it is impossible to distinguish between the seeds.
<b>And Shmuel said:</b> When we learned in the mishna that one may plant five kinds of seeds within a garden bed without violating the prohibition of diverse kinds, <b>we learned this</b> even with regard to <b>a garden bed among garden beds,</b> not only in a solitary bed. The Gemara asks: <b>Don’t the seeds become intermingled with one another?</b> The Gemara answers: It is referring to a case <b>where one inclines</b> one <b>row to here,</b> in one direction, <b>and</b> one <b>row to here,</b> in a different direction (<i>Me’iri</i>). In that way they do not appear intermingled.
<b>Ulla said: They raise a dilemma in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if <b>one opened a single furrow across its entirety?</b> Is it considered demarcation between the garden beds if one dug a furrow between two garden beds (<i>ge’onim</i>, <i>Tosafot</i>)? <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> The <b>intermingling</b> of these garden beds <b>comes and nullifies the row.</b> The furrow is not considered to be a demarcation between the beds. <b>Rav Asi said: Its intermingling does not disqualify the row. Ravina raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ashi</b> from a mishna: <b>One who plants two rows of cucumbers</b> and <b>two rows of gourds</b> and <b>two rows of Egyptian beans, it is permitted</b> because each of the species is distinct. However, if he plants <b>one row of cucumbers and one row of gourds and one row of Egyptian beans, it is prohibited</b> because in single rows there is no clear demarcation between the species. This indicates that a furrow between different species of seeds does not prevent intermingling between them. Rav Ashi replied: The case in that mishna is an exception. <b>Here, it is different because there are branches</b> that grow out from these species which become entangled with each other, nullifying the furrow between them. Other vegetables, whose branches do not become entangled, may be planted with a single furrow between them.
<b>Rav Kahana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who wishes to fill his entire garden with vegetables</b> and does not want to distance the rows of seeds from one another may <b>make a garden bed</b> that is <b>six by six</b> handbreadths <b>and make five circles inside it</b> (<i>ge’onim</i>, Rambam). He plants different species in the different circles <b>and fills its corners</b> with <b>whatever</b> additional species that <b>he wants.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Aren’t there</b> seeds <b>between</b> the circles, which intermingle with the species that are in the circles? <b>The school of Rabbi Yannai say</b> in response to this: This is referring to a case <b>where one leaves</b> the space <b>in between</b> them <b>barren</b> and does not plant there. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> He may fill the entire bed with seeds, and demarcate between the different types of seeds in the following manner. <b>If</b> the circles <b>were planted lengthwise, he plants</b> the seeds in between <b>widthwise;</b> and if the circles were planted <b>widthwise, he plants</b> the seeds in between <b>lengthwise. Ravina raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ashi:</b> We learned that <b>the work</b> space <b>of a vegetable</b> of one species, when planted with <b>a vegetable</b> of a different species, is <b>six handbreadths. And one views them</b>

Daf 86a

<b>as a</b> square <b>board.</b> All of the <i>halakhot</i> of planting various species were stated with regard to a square-shaped garden bed. By inference: When it is <b>like a</b> square <b>board, it is permitted;</b> and <b>when that is not</b> the case, it is <b>prohibited.</b> Planting different species in horizontal and vertical rows without a space between the species is ineffective, even with circles. Rav Ashi replied: When the <i>baraita</i> says a square board, it does not mean that the only way to demarcate between different species is when the rows are in that configuration. Rather, it is <b>to introduce a different leniency.</b> The <i>baraita</i> came <b>to permit a triangular plot that protrudes from it</b> into another field. This means that a triangular protrusion into another field is considered a conspicuous demarcation only if the bed was square; in that case, no additional measures are necessary.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna continues to cite a series of unrelated <i>halakhot</i> based upon biblical allusions. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> a woman who <b>discharges semen</b> even <b>on the third day</b> after relations <b>is ritually impure,</b> just like one who touches semen (see Leviticus 15:17)? Because the semen remains fit for insemination, it can transmit impurity, <b>as it is stated</b> prior to the revelation at Sinai: “And he said to the people, <b>prepare yourselves for three days,</b> do not approach a woman” (Exodus 19:15). This three-day separation period ensured that even a woman who discharged semen would be pure. The mishna cites another <i>halakha</i> based on a biblical allusion: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that one may wash the circumcision on the third day,</b> meaning the third day after the circumcision, even if <b>it occurs on Shabbat? As it is stated: “And it came to pass on the third day when they were in pain”</b> (Genesis 34:25). The pain of circumcision lasts at least three days, and as long as the child is in pain he is considered to be in danger. The mishna cites another <i>halakha</i> with an allusion in the Bible: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that one ties a scarlet strip</b> of wool <b>to the head of</b> the <b>scapegoat</b> that is dispatched to Azazel? <b>As it is stated: “If your sins be like scarlet, they will become white like snow”</b> (Isaiah 1:18). Since the goat is offered to atone for sins, red wool is tied to its horns. The mishna cites another allusion. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that smearing</b> oil on one’s body <b>is like drinking</b> and is similarly prohibited <b>on Yom Kippur? Although there is no proof for this, there is an allusion to it, as it is stated: “And it comes into his inward parts like water and like oil into his bones”</b> (Psalms 109:18). The verse appears to equate smearing oil on one’s body with drinking water.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments on the <i>halakhot</i> cited in the mishna: <b>The first clause</b> in the mishna with regard to discharged semen <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. The latter clause</b> in the mishna with regard to circumcision <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. As, if</b> one was to assert that the first clause is also <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, we heard him</b> say that in that case the woman is <b>ritually pure.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>He who does not establish</b> the mishna as reflecting the opinions of two <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> has a variant reading of the mishna; he <b>teaches</b> the <i>halakha</i> in <b>the first clause:</b> The woman is <b>ritually pure, and establishes the entire</b> mishna <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. And he who establishes</b> the mishna as reflecting the opinions of two <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> holds that the <b>first clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, and the latter clause is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya.</b>
The Gemara elaborates on the matter of a woman who discharges semen, citing that which <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A woman who <b>discharges semen</b> at any point <b>on the third day is ritually pure;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya. Rabbi Yishmael says:</b> Even on the third day she is ritually impure. In addition, the only relevant tally is the number of days. The number of twelve-hour periods of night and day that passed is not relevant. <b>Sometimes there are four</b> twelve-hour <b>periods</b> that elapsed between cohabitation and discharge. If she had relations just before nightfall on Wednesday and discharged on Friday night at the beginning of Shabbat, it is considered as if three days passed, meaning Wednesday, Thursday and Friday; and four twelve-hour periods, meaning Wednesday night, Thursday day, Thursday night and Friday day. <b>Sometimes there are five</b> twelve-hour <b>periods</b> that elapsed, in a case where she discharged semen at the end of Friday night. <b>Sometimes there are six</b> twelve-hour <b>periods</b> that elapsed, if she had relations at the beginning of Tuesday night and discharged at the end of the third day. <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that it is <b>always five</b> twelve-hour <b>periods. And if</b> she had relations after <b>part of the first period passed, she is given part of the sixth period</b> to complete the requisite five twelve-hour periods, so that sixty hours will have elapsed between cohabitation and discharge.
<b>The Rabbis said this before Rav Pappa, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Pappa</b> said this <b>to Rava: Granted, Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say</b> with regard to the revelation at Sinai that Moses <b>instituted separation</b> between husbands and wives <b>on</b> the <b>fifth</b> day of the week. Since everyone agrees that the Torah was given on Shabbat, husbands and wives were separated for two days. <b>And Rabbi Yishmael</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who <b>said</b> that Moses <b>instituted separation on</b> the <b>fourth</b> day of the week, meaning that husbands and wives were separated for three days. <b>However, in accordance with whose</b> opinion did <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> state his opinion? Ritual impurity, in this case, is not based on the passage of days but on the passage of twelve-hour periods, which do not correspond to either opinion mentioned with regard to the revelation at Sinai. The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> Rabbi Akiva holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> However, his understanding is based on that which <b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said: Moses ascended</b> Mount Sinai <b>early in the morning, and he descended early in the morning</b> and related to them the mitzva of separation.
The Gemara explains the source of this opinion: <b>He ascended</b> Mount Sinai <b>early in the morning, as it is written: “And Moses rose up early in the morning, and went up to Mount Sinai,</b> as the Lord had commanded him” (Exodus 34:4). And <b>he descended</b> the mountain <b>early in the morning, as it is written: “Go descend and you shall ascend together with Aaron”</b> (Exodus 19:24). The Torah <b>juxtaposes descent to ascent</b> to establish that <b>just as</b> Moses’ <b>ascent</b> was <b>early in the morning, so too,</b> his <b>descent</b> was <b>early in the morning.</b> Moses told the people to separate in the early morning so that there would be five complete periods of separation over the course of the three days.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why did he need to tell them</b> to separate during the morning hours? <b>Didn’t Rav Huna say: The Jewish people are holy and do not have relations during the day?</b> It was not necessary to command them until night. The Gemara replies: It was necessary to tell them in the morning, <b>as Rava said: If it was a dark house, it is permitted</b> to have relations during the day. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>Rava said,</b> and <b>some say</b> that <b>Rav Pappa</b> said: <b>A Torah scholar obscures</b> the light in the room <b>with his cloak and is</b> thereby <b>permitted</b> to have relations during the day. Therefore, it was necessary to command the people to separate even during the daytime hours.

Daf 86b

The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t</b> some of the people have status of <b>those who immersed themselves during the day</b> when they received the Torah? Some of the women immersed themselves on Shabbat evening to purify themselves from the discharge of semen. Even after immersion, the purification process is not complete until sunset. It was <b>Abaye bar Ravin and Rav Ḥanina bar Avin who both said</b> in response: <b>The Torah was given to those who immersed themselves during the day,</b> and that in no way diminishes the magnitude of the revelation. The Gemara relates that <b>Mareimar sat and stated this <i>halakha</i>. Ravina said to Mareimar: Did you say</b> that the Torah <b>was</b> actually <b>given</b> to those who immersed themselves during the day, <b>or did you say</b> that <b>it was fit</b> to be given to those who immersed themselves during the day, but, in reality, it was not? He <b>said to him: I said</b> that the Torah <b>was fit</b> to be given, but in actuality the nation was ritually pure, and the women did not discharge semen on the third day.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let them immerse</b> during <b>twilight</b> on Shabbat eve <b>and receive</b> the <b>Torah</b> just after that during <b>twilight.</b> Why was it necessary to delay revelation until Shabbat morning? <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said</b> that the verse said in that regard: <b>“From the first, I did not speak in concealment”</b> (Isaiah 48:16). God did not give the Torah under the cloak of night, but rather in the light of day. The Gemara asks: <b>And let them immerse themselves on Shabbat morning and receive the Torah on Shabbat morning.</b> In that case, according to all opinions, the period of separation could have begun one twelve-hour period later. <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said:</b> This was not done <b>so that</b> there would <b>not</b> be a situation where <b>these,</b> one segment of the people, <b>would be going to receive the Torah while those,</b> another segment of the people, <b>would be going to immerse themselves.</b> Optimally, the entire nation should go to receive the Torah together.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya, son of Rabbi Abba, said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: These are the statements of Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva. However, the Rabbis say: We require</b> that <b>six complete</b> twelve-hour <b>periods</b> elapse between cohabitation and discharge. If a woman discharged semen less than seventy-two hours after having relations, the semen renders her ritually impure. <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> over how long semen renders one ritually impure is only with regard to semen that <b>is discharged from a woman; however,</b> if it <b>is discharged from a man,</b> e.g., it was on a garment, <b>it is impure as long as it is moist,</b> regardless of how much time passed since its discharge. <b>Rav Sheshet raises an objection</b> based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah states: <b>“And every garment, and every hide on which there is semen</b> shall be immersed in water, and be impure until evening” (Leviticus 15:17). And the Sages taught: This <b>excludes semen which is foul. What, is it not</b> referring to semen <b>discharged from a man,</b> indicating that even moist semen becomes foul after a certain period of time and no longer transmits impurity? The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> this <i>halakha</i> is referring to semen <b>that was discharged from a woman.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa raised a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>semen of a Jew in the womb of a gentile woman?</b> Do we say that since <b>Jews are concerned about</b> fulfilling <b>mitzvot,</b> due to that concern, <b>their body</b> temperature <b>is hot</b> and semen that is not absorbed becomes foul faster, in contrast to <b>gentiles who are not concerned about</b> fulfilling <b>mitzvot</b> for whom that is <b>not</b> the case? <b>Or, perhaps, since</b> gentiles <b>eat detestable creatures and creeping animals their body</b> temperature <b>is</b> also <b>hot? And if you say that since</b> they <b>eat detestable creatures and creeping animals, their body</b> temperature <b>is hot,</b> another dilemma can be raised: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to semen of a Jew <b>in the womb of an animal?</b> Do we say that in <b>a woman, who has a</b> long <b>corridor [<i>perozdor</i>]</b> to her womb, the semen becomes <b>foul; but</b> in <b>an animal, which does not have</b> as long <b>a corridor,</b> it does <b>not? Or perhaps</b> it is <b>not different,</b> and the period of time that the semen renders one ritually impure is the same in both cases? No resolution was found for these dilemmas. Therefore, <b>let them stand</b> unresolved.
<b>The Sages taught: On the sixth</b> day <b>of the month</b> of Sivan, <b>the Ten Commandments were given to the Jewish people. Rabbi Yosei says: On the seventh</b> day <b>of</b> the month. <b>Rava said: Everyone agrees</b> that the Jews <b>came to the Sinai desert on the New Moon,</b> as <b>it is written here:</b> “In the third month after the children of Israel were gone forth out of the land of Egypt, <b>the same day came they into the wilderness of Sinai”</b> (Exodus 19:1), without elaborating what day it was. <b>And it is written there: “This month shall be to you the beginning of months;</b> it shall be the first month of the year to you” (Exodus 12:2). <b>Just as there,</b> the term “this” is referring to the <b>New Moon, so too, here</b> the term is referring to the <b>New Moon. And</b> similarly, <b>everyone agrees that the Torah was given to the Jewish people on Shabbat,</b> as <b>it is written here</b> in the Ten Commandments: <b>“Remember the Shabbat day to keep it holy”</b> (Exodus 20:8), <b>and it is written there: “And Moses said to the people: Remember this day,</b> in which you came out from Egypt, out of the house of bondage, for by strength of hand the Lord brought you out from this place; there shall be no leaven eaten” (Exodus 13:3). <b>Just as there,</b> the mitzva of remembrance was commanded <b>on the very day</b> of the Exodus, <b>so too, here</b> the mitzva of remembrance was commanded <b>on the very day</b> of Shabbat. <b>Where</b> Rabbi Yosei and the Sages <b>disagree</b> is <b>with regard to the determination of the month,</b> meaning which day of the week was established as the New Moon. <b>Rabbi Yosei held:</b> The <b>New Moon was established on the first day of the week, and on the first day of the week He did not say anything to them due to the weariness</b> caused by <b>the journey. On the second day of the week, He said to them: “And you shall be to Me a kingdom of priests</b> and a holy nation; these are the words that you shall speak to the children of Israel” (Exodus 19:6).

Daf 87a

<b>On the third</b> day of the week, God <b>said to them the mitzva of setting boundaries</b> around Mount Sinai. <b>On the fourth</b> day of the week, the husbands and wives <b>separated</b> from one another. <b>And the Rabbis hold: On the second</b> day <b>of the week</b> the <b>New Moon was established,</b> and <b>on the second</b> day <b>of the week</b> God <b>did not say anything to them due to the weariness</b> caused by <b>their journey. On the third</b> day of the week, God <b>said to them: “And you shall be to Me</b> a kingdom of priests and a holy nation; these are the words that you shall speak to the children of Israel” (Exodus 19:6). <b>On the fourth</b> day of the week, God <b>said to them the mitzva of setting boundaries</b> around Mount Sinai. <b>On the fifth</b> day of the week, the husbands and wives <b>separated</b> from one another. <b>The Gemara raises an objection:</b> Doesn’t the verse state: “And the Lord said to Moses: Go to the people <b>and sanctify them today and tomorrow</b> and let them wash their garments” (Exodus 19:10), indicating that the husbands and wives were separated for only two days? This is <b>difficult</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who said earlier that the separation was for three days.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> could have <b>said to you: Moses added one day</b> to the number of days that God commanded based <b>on his</b> own <b>perception, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Moses did three things</b> based <b>on his</b> own <b>perception, and the Holy One, Blessed be He, agreed with him. He added one day</b> to the days of separation before the revelation at Sinai based <b>on his</b> own <b>perception. And he</b> totally <b>separated from</b> his <b>wife</b> after the revelation at Sinai. <b>And he broke the tablets</b> following the sin of the Golden Calf.
The Gemara discusses these cases: <b>He added one day</b> based <b>on his</b> own <b>perception. What</b> source <b>did he interpret</b> that led him to do so? He reasoned that since the Holy One, Blessed be He, said: “Sanctify them <b>today and tomorrow,”</b> the juxtaposition of the two days teaches that <b>today</b> is <b>like tomorrow; just as tomorrow</b> the men and women will separate for that day <b>and</b> the <b>night</b> preceding <b>it, so too, today</b> requires separation for the day <b>and</b> the <b>night</b> preceding <b>it.</b> Since God spoke to him in the morning, <b>and the night of that day</b> already <b>passed,</b> Moses concluded: <b>Derive from it</b> that separation must be in effect for <b>two days besides that day.</b> Therefore, he extended the mitzva of separation by one day. <b>And from where do we</b> derive that <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, agreed with his</b> interpretation? It is derived from the fact that the <b>Divine Presence did not rest</b> upon Mount Sinai <b>until Shabbat morning,</b> as Moses had determined.
<b>And he</b> totally <b>separated from</b> his <b>wife</b> after the revelation at Sinai. <b>What</b> source <b>did he interpret</b> that led him to do so? <b>He reasoned an <i>a fortiori</i> inference by himself</b> and <b>said: If Israel, with whom the Divine Presence spoke only one time and</b> God <b>set a</b> specific <b>time for them</b> when the Divine Presence would be revealed, and yet <b>the Torah stated: “Prepare yourselves</b> for three days, <b>do not approach</b> a woman” (Exodus 19:15); <b>I, with whom the Divine Presence speaks all the time and</b> God <b>does not set a</b> specific <b>time for me, all the more so</b> that I must separate from my wife. <b>And from where do we</b> derive that <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, agreed with him? As it is written</b> after the revelation at Sinai: <b>“Go say to them: Return to your tents”</b> (Deuteronomy 5:26), meaning to your homes and wives. <b>And afterward it is written</b> that God told Moses: <b>“And you, stand here with Me”</b> (Deuteronomy 5:27), indicating that Moses was not allowed to return home, as he must constantly be prepared to receive the word of God. <b>And some say</b> a different source indicating that God agreed with his reasoning. When Aaron and Miriam criticized Moses’ separation from his wife, God said: <b>“With him do I speak mouth to mouth,</b> even manifestly, and not in dark speeches; and the similitude of the Lord does he behold; why then were you not afraid to speak against My servant, against Moses?” (Numbers 12:8). This indicates that God agreed with his reasoning.
And <b>he broke the tablets</b> following the sin of the Golden Calf. <b>What</b> source <b>did he interpret</b> that led him to do so? Moses <b>said: With</b> regard to the <b>Paschal</b> lamb, <b>which is</b> only <b>one of six hundred and thirteen mitzvot, the Torah stated:</b> “And the Lord said unto Moses and Aaron: This is the ordinance of the Paschal offering; <b>no alien shall eat of it”</b> (Exodus 12:43), referring not only to gentiles, but to apostate Jews as well. Regarding the tablets, which represented <b>the entire Torah, and Israel</b> at that moment were <b>apostates,</b> as they were worshipping the calf, <b>all the more so</b> are they not worthy of receiving the Torah. <b>And from where do we</b> derive that <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, agreed with his</b> reasoning? <b>As it is stated:</b> “The first tablets <b>which you broke [<i>asher shibarta</i>]”</b> (Exodus 34:1), <b>and Reish Lakish said:</b> The word <i>asher</i> is an allusion to the phrase: <b>May your strength be true [<i>yishar koḥakha</i></b>] <b>due to the fact that you broke</b> the tablets.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an additional difficulty from the verse: <b>“And be prepared for the third day,</b> for on the third day God will descend onto Mount Sinai before the eyes of the entire nation” (Exodus 19:11). This indicates that God said that the Torah would be given on the third day after two days of separation. This is <b>difficult</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Didn’t we say</b> that <b>Moses added one day</b> based <b>on his</b> own <b>perception? Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof against this from what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>. That which is stated in the Torah: “For on the <b>third</b> day,” means <b>the third</b> day <b>of the month and the third</b> day <b>of the week.</b> Apparently, the New Moon was on Sunday. This is <b>difficult</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The Rabbis</b> could have <b>said to you: Whose</b> is the opinion in <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>? It is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> Therefore, this <i>baraita</i> poses no difficulty to the opinion of the Rabbis.
According to the opinion of the Rabbis, that day was the <b>third</b> day of <b>what</b> reckoning? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is written: <b>“And Moses reported the words of the people to the Lord”</b> (Exodus 19:8). <b>And it is written</b> immediately thereafter: “And God said to Moses: Behold I will come to you in a thick cloud so that the people will hear when I speak with you, and they will also believe in you forever. <b>And Moses told the words of the people to the Lord”</b> (Exodus 19:9).
The Gemara asks: <b>What did the Holy One, Blessed be He, say to Moses, and what did Moses say to Israel, and what did Israel say to Moses, and what did Moses report to the Almighty?</b> The verses do not elaborate on the content of God’s command to Moses, which Moses then told the people and which they accepted. It must be that <b>this</b> refers to <b>the mitzva of setting boundaries,</b> which Moses told the people and which they accepted. He then went back and reported to God that the people accepted the mitzva; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: At first, he explained</b> the <b>punishment</b> and the hardship involved in receiving the Torah, <b>as it is written: “And Moses reported [</b><i>vayashev</i><b>],”</b> which is interpreted homiletically as: <b>Matters that shatter [</b><i>meshabbevin</i><b>]</b> (Rav Hai Gaon) <b>a person’s mind; and, ultimately, he explained its reward, as it is written: “And Moses told [</b><i>vayagged</i><b>],”</b> which is interpreted homiletically as: <b>Matters that draw a person’s heart like <i>aggada</i>. And some say</b> that <b>at first, he explained its reward, as it is written: “And Moses reported,”</b> which is interpreted homiletically as: <b>Matters that restore [<i>meshivin</i>]</b> and calm <b>a person’s mind; and ultimately, he explained its punishment, as it is written: “And Moses told,” matters that are as difficult for a person as wormwood [<i>gidin</i>].</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The <b>sixth</b> was <b>the sixth</b> day <b>of the month</b> and <b>the sixth</b> day <b>of the week.</b> This is also <b>difficult</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> is <b>also</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> But if so, according to the opinion of the Rabbis, that day was the <b>sixth</b> day of <b>what</b> reckoning? <b>Rava said:</b>

Daf 87b

the sixth day <b>from their encampment. Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said:</b> The sixth day <b>from</b> the start of <b>their journey.</b> They left Refidim and arrived and camped in the desert on the same Sunday. <b>And</b> Rava and Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov <b>disagree</b> with regard to the mitzva of <b>Shabbat</b> commanded to the Jewish people at <b>Mara, as it is written</b> in the fourth commandment: “Observe the Shabbat day to keep it holy <b>as the Lord your God commanded you”</b> (Deuteronomy 5:11). <b>And Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: As He commanded you in Mara,</b> as it is stated: “There He made for him a statute and an ordinance, and there He proved him” (Exodus 15:25). Their dispute was: One <b>Master held: They were commanded</b> about <b>Shabbat,</b> but <b>they were not commanded</b> about Shabbat <b>boundaries.</b> Therefore, it was permitted to travel from Refidim on Shabbat, because the restriction of Shabbat boundaries was not yet in effect. <b>And</b> one <b>Master held: They were also commanded</b> about the <b>boundaries,</b> and therefore, it was prohibited to leave Refidim on Shabbat.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an additional proof with regard to the day of the revelation at Sinai from what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: In the month of <b>Nisan during which</b> the <b>Jewish people left Egypt, on the fourteenth, they slaughtered their Paschal</b> lambs; <b>on the fifteenth, they left</b> Egypt; <b>and in the evening,</b> the <b>firstborn were stricken.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> to say that they were stricken <b>in the evening?</b> Was the Plague of the Firstborn after the Jews left Egypt? <b>Rather, say</b> that <b>the evening before, the firstborn were stricken. And that day was</b> the <b>fifth</b> day <b>of the week. From</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>fifteenth of Nisan</b> was a <b>Thursday,</b> the <b>New Moon</b> of <b>Iyyar</b> was <b>Shabbat,</b> as Nisan is typically thirty days long. <b>And</b> the <b>New Moon</b> of <b>Sivan</b> was on the <b>first</b> day <b>of the week,</b> as Iyyar is typically twenty-nine days long. This is <b>difficult</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that the New Moon of Sivan that year was on Monday.
The Gemara answers: <b>The Rabbis</b> could have <b>said to you</b> that <b>a day was added to Iyyar that year</b> and it was thirty days long. The New Moon was determined by testimony of witnesses who saw the new moon, together with astronomical calculations that the testimony was feasible. Therefore, Iyyar could be thirty days long. If that was the case, the New Moon of Sivan was on Monday. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an objection from what was taught in a different <i>baraita</i> that <b>they did not add a day</b> to Iyyar that year, as the Sages taught: In the month of <b>Nisan during which</b> the <b>Jewish people left Egypt, on the fourteenth, they slaughtered their Paschal</b> lambs; <b>on the fifteenth, they left</b> Egypt; <b>and in the evening,</b> the <b>firstborn were stricken.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Does it enter your mind</b> to say that they were stricken <b>in the evening?</b> Was the Plague of the Firstborn after the Jews left Egypt? <b>Rather, say</b> that <b>the evening before, the firstborn were stricken. And that day was</b> the <b>fifth</b> day <b>of the week. Nisan was complete,</b> i.e., it was thirty days long, <b>and</b> the New Moon of <b>Iyyar occurred on</b> a <b>Shabbat.</b>
<b>Iyyar was lacking,</b> i.e., it was twenty-nine days long, <b>and</b> the New Moon of <b>Sivan occurred</b> on the <b>first</b> day <b>of the week.</b> This is <b>difficult</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Whose</b> is the opinion in <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> Therefore, this <i>baraita</i> poses no difficulty to the opinion of the Rabbis.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a different proof from another verse, as it is stated: <b>“And they took their journey from Elim, and all the congregation of the children of Israel</b> came unto the wilderness of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai, <b>on the fifteenth day of the second month</b> after their departing out of the land of Egypt” (Exodus 16:1). <b>And that day was Shabbat, as it is written: “And in the morning, then you shall see the glory of the Lord;</b> for He has heard your murmurings against the Lord; and what are we, that you murmur against us?” (Exodus 16:7). The next day the glory of God was revealed, and He told them that in the afternoon the manna and quail would begin to fall, <b>and it is written: “Six days you shall gather it;</b> but on the seventh day is Sabbath, there shall be none in it” (Exodus 16:26). Apparently, the first six days after this command were weekdays on which the manna fell, and the fifteenth of Iyyar was Shabbat. <b>And from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>fifteenth of Iyyar</b> was <b>Shabbat,</b> the <b>New Moon</b> of <b>Sivan</b> was on the <b>first</b> day <b>of the week.</b> This is <b>difficult</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The Gemara answers: According to the Rabbis, <b>a day was added to Iyyar that year</b> and it was thirty days long. Therefore, the New Moon of Sivan was on Monday.
<b>Rav Ḥavivi from Ḥozena’a said to Rav Ashi: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a different proof from the following verse: <b>“And it came to pass in the first month in the second year, on the first day of the month, that the tabernacle was erected”</b> (Exodus 40:17). It <b>was taught: That day took ten crowns.</b> It was <b>the first</b> day <b>of Creation,</b> meaning Sunday, <b>the first</b> day <b>of</b> the offerings brought by the <b>princes, the first</b> day <b>of the priesthood, the first</b> day <b>of service</b> in the Temple, <b>the first</b> time <b>for the descent of fire</b> onto the altar, <b>the first</b> time that <b>consecrated</b> foods <b>were eaten, the first</b> day of <b>the resting of the Divine Presence</b> upon the Jewish people, <b>the first</b> day that <b>the Jewish people were blessed</b> by the priests, and <b>the first</b> day <b>of the prohibition</b> to bring offerings on <b>improvised altars.</b> Once the Tabernacle was erected, it was prohibited to offer sacrifices elsewhere. And it was the <b>first of the months. And from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>New Moon</b> of <b>Nisan</b> of <b>that year</b> was on <b>the first</b> day <b>of the week,</b> in <b>the previous year,</b> it was on <b>the fourth</b> day <b>of the week.</b>
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, <i>Aḥerim</i> <b>say: Between</b> the festival of <b>Assembly,</b> i.e., <i>Shavuot</i>, of one year and the festival of <b>Assembly</b> of the following year, <b>and</b> similarly, <b>between Rosh HaShana</b> of one year and <b>Rosh HaShana</b> of the following year, <b>there is only</b> a difference of <b>four days</b> of the week. <b>And if it was a leap year,</b> there is a difference of <b>five</b> days between them. There are three hundred and fifty four days in a year, which are divided into twelve months, six months that are thirty days long and six months that are twenty-nine days long. If the New Moon of Nisan was on Wednesday, the <b>New Moon</b> of <b>Iyyar was on Shabbat eve, and</b> the <b>New Moon</b> of <b>Sivan</b> was on <b>Shabbat.</b> This is <b>difficult both</b> according <b>to Rabbi Yosei,</b> who holds that the New Moon of Sivan was on Sunday, and according <b>to the Rabbis,</b> who hold it was on Monday. The Gemara answers: Both Rabbi Yosei and the Rabbis disagree with <i>Aḥerim</i>. According <b>to Rabbi Yosei, they established seven</b> months that were <b>lacking</b> in the first year, i.e., seven months that were twenty-nine days long,

Daf 88a

and according <b>to the Rabbis, they established eight</b> months that were <b>lacking.</b>
The Gemara cites another objection. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that <b>which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> in the anthology called <b><i>Seder Olam</i>:</b> In the month of <b>Nisan during which</b> the <b>Jewish people left Egypt, on the fourteenth they slaughtered their Paschal</b> lambs, <b>on the fifteenth</b> they <b>left</b> Egypt, <b>and that day was Shabbat eve. From</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>New Moon</b> of <b>Nisan</b> was on <b>Shabbat eve,</b> we can infer that the <b>New Moon</b> of <b>Iyyar</b> was on the <b>first</b> day <b>of the week, and</b> the New Moon of <b>Sivan</b> was <b>on</b> the <b>second</b> day <b>of the week.</b> This is <b>difficult</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who holds that the New Moon of Sivan was on Sunday. The Gemara answers that <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> could have <b>said to you: Whose</b> is the opinion in <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> the opinion of the <b>Rabbis.</b> Therefore, this <i>baraita</i> poses no difficulty to the opinion of the Rabbi Yosei.
The Gemara cites another objection: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> from that which was taught, that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: On the second</b> day of Sivan, <b>Moses ascended</b> Mount Sinai <b>and descended. On the third</b> day, <b>he ascended and descended. On the fourth</b> day, <b>he descended and did not ascend</b> Mount Sinai <b>again</b> until he was commanded along with all of the Jewish people. <b>And</b> the Gemara asks: How is it possible that he descended on the fourth day? <b>Since he did not ascend, from where did he descend? Rather,</b> this must be emended: <b>On the fourth</b> day, <b>he ascended and descended. On the fifth</b> day, <b>he built an altar and sacrificed an offering. On the sixth</b> day, <b>he had no time.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that not because</b> he received the <b>Torah</b> on the sixth day of the month? Apparently, this <i>baraita</i> supports the opinion of the Rabbis.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> he had no time <b>due to the burden of</b> preparing for <b>Shabbat.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>A Galilean taught,</b> while standing <b>above Rav Ḥisda: Blessed is the all-Merciful One, Who gave the threefold Torah:</b> Torah, Prophets, and Writings, <b>to the three-fold nation:</b> Priests, Levites, and Israelites, <b>by means of a third-</b>born: Moses, who followed Aaron and Miriam in birth order, <b>on the third day</b> of the separation of men and women, <b>in the third month:</b> Sivan. On <b>whose</b> opinion is this homily based? It is based on the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that the Torah was given on the third day of separation and not on the fourth day.
The Gemara cites additional homiletic interpretations on the topic of the revelation at Sinai. The Torah says, “And Moses brought forth the people out of the camp to meet God; <b>and they stood at the lowermost part of the mount”</b> (Exodus 19:17). <b>Rabbi Avdimi bar Ḥama bar Ḥasa said:</b> the Jewish people actually stood beneath the mountain, and the verse <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, overturned the mountain above</b> the Jews <b>like a tub, and said to them: If you accept the Torah, excellent, and if not, there will be your burial. Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: From here</b> there is <b>a substantial caveat to</b> the obligation to fulfill the <b>Torah.</b> The Jewish people can claim that they were coerced into accepting the Torah, and it is therefore not binding. <b>Rava said: Even so, they again accepted it</b> willingly <b>in the time of Ahasuerus, as it is written:</b> “The Jews <b>ordained, and took upon them,</b> and upon their seed, and upon all such as joined themselves unto them” (Esther 9:27), and he taught: The Jews <b>ordained what they had already taken upon themselves</b> through coercion at Sinai.
<b>Ḥizkiya said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “You caused sentence to be heard from heaven; the earth feared, and was silent”</b> (Psalms 76:9)? <b>If it was afraid, why was it silent; and if it was silent, why was it afraid? Rather,</b> the meaning is: <b>At first, it was afraid, and in the end, it was silent.</b> “You caused sentence to be heard from heaven” refers to the revelation at Sinai. <b>And why was</b> the earth <b>afraid?</b> It is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Reish Lakish, as Reish Lakish said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “And there was evening and there was morning, the sixth day”</b> (Genesis 1:31)? <b>Why do I require the superfluous</b> letter <b><i>heh</i>,</b> the definite article, which does not appear on any of the other days? It <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, established a condition with the act of Creation, and said to them: If Israel accepts the Torah</b> on the sixth day of Sivan, <b>you will exist; and if</b> they do <b>not</b> accept it, <b>I will return you to</b> the primordial state of <b>chaos and disorder.</b> Therefore, the earth was afraid until the Torah was given to Israel, lest it be returned to a state of chaos. Once the Jewish people accepted the Torah, the earth was calmed.
<b>Rabbi Simai taught: When Israel accorded precedence</b> to the declaration <b>“We will do”</b> over the declaration <b>“We will hear,” 600,000 ministering angels came</b> and <b>tied two crowns to each and every member of the Jewish people, one corresponding to “We will do” and one corresponding to “We will hear.” And when the people sinned</b> with the Golden Calf, <b>1,200,000 angels of destruction descended and removed them</b> from the people, <b>as it is stated</b> in the wake of the sin of the Golden Calf: <b>“And the children of Israel stripped themselves of their ornaments from Mount Horeb onward”</b> (Exodus 33:6). <b>Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: At Horeb they put on</b> their ornaments, <b>and at Horeb they removed</b> them. The source for this is: <b>At Horeb they put them on, as we have said; at Horeb they removed them, as it is written: “And the children of Israel stripped themselves</b> of their ornaments from Mount Horeb.” <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And Moses merited all</b> of these crowns <b>and took</b> them. What is the source for this? <b>Because juxtaposed to this</b> verse, it is stated: <b>“And Moses would take the tent [<i>ohel</i>]”</b> (Exodus 33:7). The word <i>ohel</i> is interpreted homiletically as an allusion to an aura or illumination [<i>hila</i>]. <b>Reish Lakish said: In the future, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will return them to us, as it is stated: “And the ransomed of the Lord shall return, and come with singing unto Zion, and everlasting joy shall be upon their heads”</b> (Isaiah 35:10). <b>The joy that</b> they <b>once</b> had will once again be <b>upon their heads.</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar said: When the Jewish people accorded precedence</b> to the declaration <b>“We will do”</b> over <b>“We will hear,” a Divine Voice emerged and said to them: Who revealed to my children this secret that the ministering angels use? As it is written: “Bless the Lord, you angels of His, you mighty in strength, that fulfill His word, hearkening unto the voice of His word”</b> (Psalms 103:20). <b>At first,</b> the angels <b>fulfill</b> His word, <b>and then</b> afterward they <b>hearken. Rabbi Ḥama, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “As an apple tree among the trees of the wood,</b> so is my beloved among the sons. Under its shadow I delighted to sit and its fruit was sweet to my taste” (Song of Songs 2:3)? <b>Why were the Jewish people likened to an apple tree?</b> It is <b>to tell you that just as this apple</b> tree, <b>its fruit</b> grows <b>before its leaves, so too, the Jewish people accorded precedence to “We will do” over “We will hear.”</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>a heretic saw that Rava was immersed in</b> studying <b><i>halakha</i>, and his fingers were beneath his leg and he was squeezing them, and his fingers were spurting blood.</b> Rava did not notice that he was bleeding because he was engrossed in study. The heretic <b>said to</b> Rava: You <b>impulsive nation, who accorded precedence to your mouths over your ears. You still bear your impulsiveness,</b> as you act without thinking. <b>You should listen first.</b> Then, <b>if you are capable</b> of fulfilling the commands, <b>accept</b> them. <b>And if not,</b> do <b>not accept</b> them. He <b>said to him:</b> About <b>us,</b>

Daf 88b

<b>who proceed wholeheartedly</b> and with integrity, <b>it is written: “The integrity of the upright will guide them”</b> (Proverbs 11:3), whereas <b>about those people who walk in deceit, it is written</b> at the end of the same verse: <b>“And the perverseness of the faithless will destroy them.”</b>
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥamani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “You have ravished my heart, my sister, my bride; you have ravished my heart with one of your eyes,</b> with one bead of your necklace” (Song of Songs 4:9)? <b>At first</b> when you, the Jewish people, merely accepted the Torah upon yourselves it was <b>with one of your eyes;</b> however, <b>when you</b> actually <b>perform</b> the mitzvot it will be <b>with both of your eyes. Ulla said</b> with regard to the sin of the Golden Calf: <b>Insolent is the bride who is promiscuous under her wedding canopy. Rav Mari, son of the daughter of Shmuel, said: What verse</b> alludes to this? <b>“While the king was still at his table my spikenard</b> gave off its fragrance” (Song of Songs 1:12). Its pleasant odor dissipated, leaving only an offensive odor. <b>Rav said:</b> Nevertheless, it is apparent from the verse that <b>the affection</b> of the Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>is still upon us, as it is written</b> euphemistically as “<b>gave off</b> its fragrance,” <b>and</b> the verse <b>did not write, it reeked.</b> And <b>the Sages taught: About</b> those who <b>are insulted and do not insult, who hear their shame and do not respond, who act out of love and are joyful in suffering, the verse says: “And they that love Him are as the sun going forth in its might”</b> (Judges 5:31).
With regard to the revelation at Sinai, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “The Lord gives the word; the women that proclaim the tidings are a great host”</b> (Psalms 68:12)? It means that <b>each and every utterance that emerged from the mouth of the Almighty divided into seventy languages,</b> a great host. And, similarly, <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> with regard to the verse: “Behold, is My word not like fire, declares the Lord, <b>and like a hammer that shatters a rock?”</b> (Jeremiah 23:29). <b>Just as this hammer breaks</b> a stone <b>into several fragments, so too, each and every utterance that emerged from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He, divided into seventy languages.</b> The Gemara continues in praise of the Torah. <b>Rav Ḥananel bar Pappa said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “Listen, for I will speak royal things,</b> and my lips will open with upright statements” (Proverbs 8:6)? <b>Why are matters of Torah likened to a king? To teach you</b> that <b>just as this king has</b> the power <b>to kill and to grant life, so too, matters of Torah have</b> the power <b>to kill and to grant life.</b>
And <b>that is</b> what <b>Rava said: To those who are right-handed in</b> their approach to Torah, and engage in its study with strength, good will, and sanctity, Torah is <b>a drug of life,</b> and <b>to those who are left-handed in</b> their approach to Torah, it is <b>a drug of death. Alternatively,</b> why are matters of Torah referred to as <b>royal?</b> Because <b>to each and every utterance that emerged from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He, two crowns are tied. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “My beloved is to me like a bundle of myrrh that lies between my breasts”</b> (Song of Songs 1:13)? <b>The Congregation of Israel said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, even though my beloved,</b> God, <b>causes me suffering and bitterness, He</b> still <b>lies between my breasts.</b> And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi interpreted the verse: <b>“My beloved is to me like a cluster [<i>eshkol</i>] of henna [<i>hakofer</i>] in the vineyards of [<i>karmei</i>] Ein Gedi”</b> (Song of Songs 1:14). <b>He, Whom everything [<i>shehakol</i>] is His, forgives [<i>mekhapper</i>] me for the sin of the kid [<i>gedi</i>],</b> i.e., the calf, <b>that I collected [<i>shekaramti</i>] for myself.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>From where</b> is it <b>inferred that</b> the word in <b>this</b> verse, <b><i>karmei</i>, is a term of gathering? Mar Zutra, son of Rav Naḥman, said</b> that it is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>A launderer’s chair upon which one gathers [<i>koremim</i>] the garments.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “His cheeks are as a bed of spices,</b> as banks of sweet herbs, his lips are lilies dripping with flowing myrrh” (Song of Songs 5:13)? It is interpreted homiletically: From <b>each and every utterance that emerged from</b> His cheeks, i.e., <b>the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He, the entire world was filled with fragrant spices. And since</b> the world <b>was</b> already <b>filled by the first utterance, where</b> was there room for the spices of <b>the second utterance</b> to <b>go? The Holy One, Blessed be He, brought forth wind from His treasuries and made the</b> spices <b>pass one at a time,</b> leaving room for the consequences of the next utterance. <b>As it is stated: “His lips are lilies [<i>shoshanim</i>] dripping with flowing myrrh.”</b> Each and every utterance resulted in flowing myrrh. <b>Do not read</b> the word in the verse as <b><i>shoshanim</i>; rather,</b> read it as <b><i>sheshonim</i>,</b> meaning repeat. Each repeat utterance produced its own fragrance.
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> From <b>each and every utterance that emerged from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He, the souls of the Jewish people left</b> their bodies, <b>as it is stated: “My soul departed when he spoke”</b> (Song of Songs 5:6). <b>And since their souls left</b> their bodies <b>from the first utterance, how did they receive the second utterance?</b> Rather, God <b>rained the dew</b> upon them <b>that, in the future, will revive the dead, and He revived them, as it is stated: “You, God, poured down a bountiful rain; when Your inheritance was weary You sustained it”</b> (Psalms 68:10). <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said:</b> With <b>each and every utterance that emerged from the mouth of the Holy One, Blessed be He, the Jewish people retreated</b> in fear <b>twelve <i>mil</i>, and the ministering angels walked them</b> back toward the mountain, <b>as it is stated: “The hosts of angels will scatter [<i>yidodun</i>]”</b> (Psalms 68:13). <b>Do not read</b> the word as <b><i>yidodun</i>,</b> meaning scattered; <b>rather,</b> read it as <b><i>yedadun</i>,</b> they walked them.
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: When Moses ascended on High</b> to receive the Torah, <b>the ministering angels said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, what is one born of a woman</b> doing here <b>among us?</b> The Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>said to them: He came to receive the Torah.</b> The angels <b>said before Him:</b> The Torah is a <b>hidden treasure that was concealed by You 974 generations before the creation of the world,</b> and <b>You seek to give it to flesh and blood?</b> As it is stated: “The word which He commanded to a thousand generations” (Psalms 105:8). Since the Torah, the word of God, was given to the twenty-sixth generation after Adam, the first man, the remaining 974 generations must have preceded the creation of the world. <b>“What is man that You are mindful of him and the son of man that You think of him?”</b> (Psalms 8:5). Rather, <b>“God our Lord, how glorious is Your name in all the earth that Your majesty is placed above the heavens”</b> (Psalms 8:2). The rightful place of God’s majesty, the Torah, is in the heavens.
<b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses: Provide them</b> with <b>an answer</b> as to why the Torah should be given to the people. Moses <b>said before Him: Master of the Universe, I am afraid lest they burn me with the breath of their mouths.</b> God <b>said to him: Grasp My throne of glory</b> for strength and protection, <b>and provide them</b> with <b>an answer.</b> And from where is this derived? <b>As it is stated: “He causes him to grasp the front of the throne, and spreads His cloud over it”</b> (Job 26:9), <b>and Rabbi Naḥum said:</b> This verse <b>teaches that God spread the radiance of His presence and His cloud over</b> Moses. Moses <b>said before Him: Master of the Universe, the Torah that You are giving me, what is written in it?</b> God said to him: <b>“I am the Lord your God Who brought you out of Egypt</b> from the house of bondage” (Exodus 20:2). Moses <b>said to</b> the angels: <b>Did you descend to Egypt? Were you enslaved to Pharaoh? Why should the Torah be yours? Again</b> Moses asked: <b>What</b> else <b>is written in it?</b> God said to him: <b>“You shall have no other gods</b> before Me” (Exodus 20:3). Moses said to the angels: <b>Do you dwell among the nations who worship</b>

Daf 89a

<b>idols</b> that you require this special warning? <b>Again</b> Moses asked: <b>What</b> else <b>is written in it?</b> The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him: <b>“Remember the Shabbat day to sanctify it”</b> (Exodus 20:8). Moses asked the angels: <b>Do you perform labor that you require rest</b> from it? <b>Again</b> Moses asked: <b>What</b> else <b>is written in it? “Do not take</b> the name of the Lord your God in vain” (Exodus 20:7), meaning that it is prohibited to swear falsely. Moses asked the angels: <b>Do you</b> conduct <b>business with one another</b> that may lead you to swear falsely? <b>Again</b> Moses asked: <b>What</b> else <b>is written in it?</b> The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to him: <b>“Honor your father and your mother”</b> (Exodus 20:12).
