Moses asked the angels: <b>Do you have a father or a mother</b> that would render the commandment to honor them relevant to you? <b>Again</b> Moses asked: <b>What</b> else <b>is written in it?</b> God said to him: <b>“You shall not murder, you shall not commit adultery, you shall not steal”</b> (Exodus 20:13) Moses asked the angels: <b>Is there jealousy among you,</b> or <b>is there an evil inclination within you</b> that would render these commandments relevant? <b>Immediately they agreed with the Holy One, Blessed be He,</b> that He made the right decision to give the Torah to the people, and <b>as it is stated: “God our Lord, how glorious is Your name in all the earth”</b> (Psalms 8:10), <b>while “that Your majesty is placed above the heavens” is not written</b> because the angels agreed with God that it is appropriate to give the Torah to the people on earth.
<b>Immediately, each and every one</b> of the angels <b>became an admirer</b> of Moses <b>and passed something to him, as it is stated: “You ascended on high, you took a captive, you took gifts on account of man,</b> and even among the rebellious also that the Lord God might dwell there” (Psalms 68:19). The meaning of the verse is: <b>In reward for</b> the fact <b>that they called you man,</b> you are not an angel and the Torah is applicable to you, <b>you took gifts</b> from the angels. And <b>even the Angel of Death gave him something,</b> as Moses told Aaron how to stop the plague, <b>as it is stated: “And he placed the incense, and he atoned for the people”</b> (Numbers 17:12). <b>And</b> the verse <b>says: “And he stood between the dead and the living,</b> and the plague was stopped” (Numbers 17:13). <b>If</b> it were <b>not that</b> the Angel of Death <b>told him</b> this remedy, <b>would he have known</b> it?
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: When Moses descended from</b> standing <b>before the Holy One, Blessed be He,</b> with the Torah, <b>Satan came and said before Him: Master of the Universe, where is the Torah?</b><br><b>He said to him: I have given it to the earth. He went to the earth,</b> and <b>said to it: Where is the Torah?</b> It <b>said to him:</b> I do not know, as only: <b>“God understands its way,</b> and He knows its place” (Job 28:23).<br><b>He went to the sea</b> and asked: Where is the Torah? <b>And</b> the sea <b>said to him: “It is not with me.”</b><br><b>He went to the depths</b> and asked: Where is the Torah? And the depths <b>said to him: “It is not within me.”</b> And from where is it derived that the sea and the depths answered him this way? <b>As it is stated: “The depth said: It is not within me, and the sea said: It is not with me”</b> (Job 28:14). <b>“Destruction and death said: We heard a rumor of it with our ears”</b> (Job 28:22).<br>Satan <b>returned and said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, I searched</b> for the Torah <b>throughout all the earth and did not find it.</b> He <b>said to him: Go to</b> Moses, <b>son of Amram.</b>
<b>He went to Moses</b> and <b>said to him: The Torah that the Holy One, Blessed be He, gave you, where is it?</b> Moses evaded the question and <b>said to him: And what am I that the Holy One, Blessed be He, would have given me the Torah?</b> I am unworthy. <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses: Moses, are you a fabricator?</b> Moses <b>said before Him: Master of the Universe, You have a hidden treasure in which You delight every day,</b> as it is stated: “And I was His delight every day, playing before Him at every moment” (Proverbs 8:30). <b>Should I take credit for myself</b> and say that You gave it to me? <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Moses: Since you belittled yourself,</b> the Torah <b>will be called by your name, as it is stated: “Remember the Torah of Moses My servant</b> to whom I commanded at Horeb laws and statutes for all of Israel” (Malachi 3:22).
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: When Moses ascended on High, he found the Holy One, Blessed be He, tying crowns to letters.</b> On the tops of certain letters there are ornamental crownlets. Moses said nothing, and God <b>said to him: Moses, is there no greeting in your city?</b> Do people not greet each other in your city? He <b>said before Him: Does a servant greet his master?</b> That would be disrespectful. He <b>said to him:</b> At least <b>you should have assisted Me</b> and wished Me success in My work. <b>Immediately</b> he <b>said to Him: “And now, may the power of the Lord be great as you have spoken”</b> (Numbers 14:17).
And <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “And the people saw that Moses delayed [<i>boshesh</i>]</b> to come down from the mount” (Exodus 32:1)? <b>Do not read</b> the word in the verse as <b><i>boshesh</i>; rather,</b> read it as <b><i>ba’u shesh</i>, six</b> hours <b>have arrived. When Moses ascended on High, he told</b> <b>the Jewish people: In forty days, at the beginning of six</b> hours, <b>I will come. After forty days, Satan came and brought confusion to the world</b> by means of a storm, and it was impossible to ascertain the time. Satan <b>said to</b> the Jews: <b>Where is your teacher Moses?</b> They <b>said to him: He ascended on High.</b> He <b>said to them: Six</b> hours <b>have arrived</b> and he has not yet come. Surely he won’t. <b>And they paid him no attention.</b> Satan said to them: Moses <b>died. And they paid him no attention.</b> Ultimately, <b>he showed them an image of his</b> death-<b>bed</b> and an image of Moses’ corpse in a cloud. <b>And that is what</b> the Jewish people <b>said to Aaron: “For this Moses, the man</b> who brought us up out of the land of Egypt, we know not what has become of him” (Exodus 32:1).
<b>One of the Sages said to Rav Kahana: Did you hear what</b> is the reason that the mountain was called <b>Mount Sinai?</b> Rav Kahana <b>said to him:</b> It is because it is <b>a mountain upon which miracles [<i>nissim</i>] were performed for the Jewish people.</b> The Sage said to him: If so, <b>it should have been</b> called <b>Mount Nisai,</b> the mountain of miracles. <b>Rather,</b> Rav Kahana said to him: It is <b>a mountain that was a good omen [<i>siman</i>] for the Jewish people.</b> The Sage said to him: If so, <b>it should have been</b> called <b>Har Simanai,</b> the mountain of omens. Rav Kahana <b>said to him: What is the reason</b> that <b>you do not frequent</b> the school where you can study <b>before Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son</b> of <b>Rav Yehoshua, who study <i>aggada</i>? As Rav Ḥisda and Rabba, son of Rav Huna, both said: What</b> is the reason it is called <b>Mount Sinai?</b> It is because it is <b>a mountain upon which hatred [<i>sina</i>] for the nations of the world descended</b> because they did not accept the Torah. <b>And that is what Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> The desert in which Israel remained for forty years <b>has five names.</b> Each name has a source and a rationale: <b>The Zin Desert,</b> because <b>the Jewish people were commanded [<i>nitztavu</i>] in it; the Kadesh Desert,</b> because <b>the Jewish people were sanctified [<i>nitkadshu</i>] in it. The Kedemot Desert,</b> because the <b>ancient</b> [<b><i>keduma</i></b>] Torah, which preceded the world, <b>was given in it. The Paran Desert,</b>

Daf 89b

because <b>the Jewish people were fruitful</b> [<b><i>paru</i></b>] <b>and multiplied in it; the Sinai Desert,</b> because <b>hatred descended upon the nations of the world on it,</b> on the mountain on which the Jewish people received the Torah. <b>And what is</b> the mountain’s true <b>name? Horeb is its name. And</b> that <b>disputes</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu said: Mount Sinai is its name. And why is it called Mount Horeb?</b> It is because <b>destruction [<i>ḥurba</i>] of the nations of the world descended upon it.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that one ties a scarlet strip</b> of wool to the scapegoat? As it says: “If your sins be like scarlet [<i>kashanim</i>], they will become white like snow” (Isaiah 1:18). The Gemara wonders at this: Why does the verse use the plural form: <b><i>Kashanim</i>? It should have</b> used the singular form: <b><i>Kashani</i>. Rabbi Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, said to the Jewish people:</b> Even <b>if your sins are</b> as numerous <b>as those years [<i>kashanim</i>] that have proceeded continuously from the six days of Creation until now, they will become white like snow. Rava taught: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written: “Go please and let us reason together, the Lord will say”</b> (Isaiah 1:18)? Why does the verse say: <b>Go please? It should have</b> said: <b>Come please.</b> And why does the verse say: <b>The Lord will say?</b> The prophet’s message is based on something that God already said. Therefore, the verse <b>should have</b> said: <b>God said.</b> Rather, the explanation of this verse is that <b>in the future</b> that will surely <b>come, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will say to the Jewish people: Go please to your Patriarchs, and they will rebuke you.</b>
<b>And</b> the Jewish people <b>will say before Him: Master of the Universe, to whom shall we go?</b> Shall we go <b>to Abraham, to whom You said: “Know certainly</b> that your seed shall be a stranger in a land that is not theirs, and shall serve them; and they shall afflict them four hundred years” (Genesis 15:13), <b>and he did not ask for mercy on our behalf?</b> Or perhaps we should go <b>to Isaac, who blessed Esau</b> and said: <b>“And it shall come to pass when you shall break loose,</b> that you shall shake his yoke from off your neck” (Genesis 27:40), <b>and he did not ask for mercy on our behalf.</b> Or perhaps we should go <b>to Jacob, to whom You said: “I will go down to Egypt with you”</b> (Genesis 46:4), <b>and he did not ask for mercy on our behalf.</b> And if so, <b>to whom shall we go?</b> Shall we go to our Patriarchs, who do not have mercy on us? Rather, <b>now God</b> Himself <b>says</b> what punishment we deserve. <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to them: Since you made yourselves dependent on Me, “If your sins be like scarlet, they will become white like snow.”</b>
Apropos the Jewish people assessing their forefathers, the Gemara cites a related teaching. <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yonatan said: What is</b> the meaning of that <b>which is written: “For You are our Father; for Abraham knows us not, and Israel does not acknowledge us; You, Lord, are our Father, our Redeemer, everlasting is Your name”</b> (Isaiah 63:16)? <b>In the future</b> that will surely <b>come, the Holy One, Blessed be He, will say to Abraham: Your children have sinned against Me.</b> Abraham will <b>say before Him: Master of the Universe,</b> if so, <b>let them be eradicated to sanctify Your name.</b> God <b>said: I will say it to Jacob.</b> Since he experienced <b>the pain of raising children,</b> perhaps <b>he will ask for mercy on their behalf.</b> He <b>said to</b> Jacob: <b>Your children have sinned.</b> Jacob <b>said before Him: Master of the Universe,</b> if so, <b>let them be eradicated to sanctify Your name.</b> The Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>said: There is no reason in elders and no wisdom in youth.</b> Neither Abraham nor Jacob knew how to respond properly. He <b>said to Isaac: Your children have sinned against Me.</b> Isaac <b>said before Him: Master of the Universe,</b> are they <b>my children and not Your children? At</b> Sinai, <b>when they accorded precedence to “We will do” over “We will listen” before You,</b> didn’t You <b>call them, “My son, My firstborn son</b> Israel” (Exodus 4:22)? <b>Now</b> that they have sinned, are they <b>my children and not Your children?</b>
<b>And furthermore, how much did they</b> actually <b>sin? How long is a person’s life? Seventy years. Subtract</b> the first <b>twenty</b> years of his life. One <b>is not punished for</b> sins committed then, as in heavenly matters, a person is only punished from age twenty. <b>Fifty</b> years <b>remain for them. Subtract twenty-five</b> years <b>of nights,</b> and <b>twenty-five</b> years <b>remain for them. Subtract twelve and a half</b> years during which <b>one prays and eats and</b> uses <b>the bathroom,</b> and <b>twelve and a half</b> years <b>remain for them. If You</b> can <b>endure them all</b> and forgive the sins committed during those years, <b>excellent. And if not, half</b> of the sins are <b>upon me</b> to bear <b>and half upon You. And if You say</b> that <b>all of them,</b> the sins of all twelve and a half years that remain, are <b>upon me, I sacrificed my soul before You</b> and You should forgive them due to my merit. The Jewish people <b>began to say</b> to Isaac: <b>You are our father.</b> Only Isaac defended the Jewish people as a father would and displayed compassion toward his children. <b>Isaac said to them: Before you praise me, praise the Holy One, Blessed be He. And Isaac points to the Holy One, Blessed be He, before their eyes. Immediately they lifted their eyes to the heavens and say: “You, Lord, are our Father, our Redeemer, everlasting is Your name.”</b>
And since the Gemara mentioned Jacob’s descent to Egypt, the Gemara cites that which <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Our father Jacob should have gone down to Egypt in iron chains</b> as would an exile against his will, as decreed by God and related to Abraham. <b>However, his merit caused him</b> to descend without suffering, <b>as it is written: “I drew them with cords of man, with bands of love, and I was to them as they that take off the yoke on their jaws, and I fed them gently”</b> (Hosea 11:4).
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> After an extended digression for a discussion of matters unrelated to the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, this mishna resumes treatment of the <i>halakhot</i> of carrying from domain to domain on Shabbat. <b>One who carries out wood</b> on Shabbat is liable for a measure <b>equivalent</b> to the amount of wood necessary <b>to cook an easily</b> cooked <b>egg.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>spices</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to season an easily</b> cooked <b>egg. And</b> all types of spices <b>join together with one another</b> to constitute the measure for liability. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>nutshells, pomegranate peels, safflower, and madder,</b> which are used to produce dyes, is <b>equivalent</b> to the amount that is used <b>to dye a small garment</b> placed <b>atop a</b> woman’s <b>hairnet.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>urine, natron, and <i>borit</i>, cimolian earth [<i>Kimoleya</i>], and potash,</b> all of which are abrasive materials used for laundry, is <b>equivalent</b> to the amount that is used <b>to launder a small garment</b> placed <b>atop a</b> woman’s <b>hairnet. And Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The measure that determines liability for these materials is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to remove a stain.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the measure of wood, the Gemara asks: Didn’t <b>we</b> already <b>learn it once?</b> As we learned in a mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>a reed</b> is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to make a quill. And if</b> the reed <b>was thick</b> and unfit for writing, <b>or</b> if it was <b>fragmented,</b> the measure that determines its liability is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to cook an egg most easily</b> cooked, one that is already <b>beaten and placed in a stew pot.</b> The measure of firewood is clearly delineated. The Gemara answers: Still, this mishna is necessary. <b>You might have said: There,</b> the measure of the crushed reed reflects the fact that <b>it is not suitable for anything</b> other than kindling. <b>However,</b> regarding <b>wood that is suitable to</b> be used <b>as a tooth of a key [<i>aklida</i>],</b> the measure that determines its liability should be <b>even any</b> small <b>amount.</b> Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that wood is typically designated for burning, and that determines the measure for liability for carrying out wood on Shabbat.
We learned in the mishna that all types of <b>spices</b> join together with one another to constitute the measure <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to season an easily</b> cooked <b>egg. The</b> Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from that which we learned elsewhere: <b>Spices,</b> which are prohibited due to <b>two or three</b> different <b>prohibitions,</b> e.g., one is prohibited due to <i>orla</i>, and one due to the prohibition of untithed produce, and they were all <b>of a single species</b> (<i>Tosafot</i>), <b>or</b> if they were <b>of three</b> different <b>species, are prohibited, and they join together with each other</b> to constitute a complete measure. <b>And Ḥizkiya said:</b>

Daf 90a

<b>They taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>in</b> the case of <b>sweet types, because they are fit</b> to be mixed together <b>to sweeten</b> the food in a <b>pot.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that they join together with one another is <b>that they are suitable to sweeten the</b> food in a <b>pot</b> together. <b>However,</b> if <b>that is not so,</b> then they <b>do not</b> join together with one another. Apparently, spices, in general, do not join together to constitute a complete measure. The Gemara answers: <b>Here, too,</b> the mishna is referring to a case where <b>they are suitable to sweeten</b> the food in a pot.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>nutshells, pomegranate peels, safflower and madder,</b> which are used to produce dyes, is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to dye a small garment</b> that is placed atop a woman’s hairnet. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raised a contradiction</b> from what we learned elsewhere in a mishna: <b>One who carries out herbs</b> that were <b>soaked</b> in water is liable if he carried out a measure <b>equivalent</b> to the amount used <b>to dye a sample</b> the size of a stopper, <b>for the shuttle</b> of a loom. This refers to a small swath of wool that a weaver places on the loom, as a color sample. The herbs were soaked in water because this was how they were prepared for use as dyes. Apparently, according to this Gemara, the measure for liability is not the amount used to dye a small garment. The Gemara replies: <b>Wasn’t it stated with regard to that</b> mishna that <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> In the case of soaked dyes, the measure for liability is smaller <b>because a person does not</b> go to the <b>trouble to soak herbs</b> just <b>to dye a sample for</b> the <b>shuttle</b> of a loom. He will only begin soaking herbs to dye a more significant garment. However, for herbs that are soaking and are ready for use as a dye, the measure for liability is smaller, i.e., sufficient to dye a sample.
The mishna mentioned abrasive materials used for laundry, among them <b>urine.</b> The Gemara clarifies the nature of the listed materials. The Sages <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The urine mentioned in the mishna is <b>urine that is up to forty days old.</b> After that, its acidity weakens, rendering it unsuitable for that purpose. With regard to the <b>natron,</b> the Sage <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: This refers to <b>Alexandrian natron</b> from the city in Egypt, <b>and not</b> to <b>natron</b> from <b>Anpantrin,</b> which is of a different quality. With regard to the <b><i>borit</i></b> mentioned in the mishna, <b>Rav Yehuda said: That is sand.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b><i>Borit</i> and sand?</b> Since both terms are listed, <i>borit</i> cannot be sand. <b>Rather, what is <i>borit</i>?</b> It is <b>sulphur.</b>
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> based on plants whose use is prohibited during the Sabbatical year. <b>They added</b> bulbs of <b>ornithogalum and wormwood, and <i>borit</i>, and aloe. And if it would enter your mind</b> to say that <i>borit</i> is <b>sulphur, is there sulphur</b> that is subject to the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of the Sabbatical year? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna that <b>this is the principle: Anything that has a root</b> and grows <b>is</b> subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the Sabbatical year, and</b> anything <b>that does not have a root is not</b> subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the Sabbatical year. Rather, what</b> is the <b><i>borit</i>?</b> It is <b>aloe.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And <i>borit</i> and aloe?</b> Since both terms are listed, <i>borit</i> cannot be aloe. <b>Rather,</b> there are <b>two types</b> of <b>aloe.</b> One of them is called <i>borit</i>.
With regard to the <b>cimolian earth</b> mentioned in the mishna, <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> This is the earth referred to as <b>pull out stick in [<i>shelof dotz</i>].</b> With regard to the <b><i>eshlag</i></b> mentioned in the mishna, <b>Shmuel said: I asked all of the seafarers</b> with regard to the identity of <i>eshlag</i>, <b>and they told me</b> that <b>it is called <i>shonana</i>, and</b> can be <b>found in the shell of the pearl, and is removed using an iron skewer.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>pepper</b> on Shabbat is <b>any amount.</b> Similarly, the measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>tar</b> is <b>any amount.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out various <b>kinds of perfumes and</b> various <b>kinds of metals</b> is <b>any amount.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>stones of the altar or earth of the altar,</b> sacred scrolls or their coverings that became tattered due to an insect called <b><i>mekek</i></b> that destroys <b>scrolls, and <i>mekek</i></b> that destroys <b>their coverings,</b> is <b>any amount. That</b> is because people <b>store them</b> in order <b>to bury them,</b> due to their sanctity, and accord significance to even a small measure of those items. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even one who carries out accessories of idolatry</b> on Shabbat is liable for carrying out <b>any amount, as it is stated: “And there shall cleave nothing of the proscribed items to your hand”</b> (Deuteronomy 13:18). Since even the smallest amount is prohibited and must be burned, any amount is significant.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> use <b>is any amount of pepper suited?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>For</b> dispelling <b>mouth odor. For what</b> use <b>is any amount of tar suited?</b> It is suited for curing a <b>headache.</b> We learned in the mishna that one is liable for carrying out <b>any amount</b> of various <b>kinds of perfumes</b> on Shabbat. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Even <b>one who carries out</b> an object with <b>a foul odor</b> on Shabbat for medicinal or similar purposes, is liable for carrying out <b>any amount.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>fine</b> perfumed <b>oil</b> is <b>any amount.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>purple dye</b> is <b>any amount.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>a virgin rosebud</b> on Shabbat is <b>one</b> bud.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out various <b>kinds of metals</b> is <b>any amount.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> use <b>is any amount of metal suited,</b> that it renders one liable for carrying it out? <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: Because</b> a small amount of iron <b>is fit to make a small nail.</b>
Since the Gemara is discussing the measure that determines liability for carrying out metal on Shabbat, it discusses the related <i>halakhot</i> of objects consecrated to the Temple. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who</b> vows without specifying an amount, and <b>says:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to donate <b>iron</b> to the Temple, <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say: He must</b> donate <b>no less than a cubit by a cubit</b> of iron. The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> use <b>is</b> metal that size <b>suited? Rav Yosef said: For a raven impediment.</b> The roof of the Temple was covered with iron surfaces with protruding nails to prevent ravens from perching there. <b>And some say</b> a slightly different version. <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say: He must</b> donate <b>no less than</b> the iron necessary for <b>a raven impediment. And how much</b> iron is that? <b>Rav Yosef said: A cubit by a cubit.</b> One who vows to donate <b>copper must</b> donate <b>no less than</b> the value of <b>a <i>ma’a</i> of silver. It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: One must</b> donate <b>no less than</b> the amount needed to forge <b>a small copper hook.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> Temple use <b>is</b> that <b>suited? Abaye said: They</b> use <b>it</b> to <b>scrape the wicks</b> from the candelabrum, <b>and clean</b> the <b>lamps</b> with it.
We learned in the mishna: The measure that determines liability for carrying out sacred scrolls or their coverings that became tattered due to an insect called <b><i>mekek</i></b> that destroys <b>scrolls, and</b> another type of <b><i>mekek</i></b> that destroys their <b>coverings,</b> is any amount. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> These insects, the <b><i>mekek</i></b> that destroys <b>scrolls,</b> the <b><i>tekhakh</i></b> that attacks <b>silk, and</b> the <b><i>ila</i></b> that eats <b>grapes, and</b> the <b><i>pe</i></b> that eats <b>figs, and</b> the <b><i>ha</i></b> that eats <b>pomegranates, all</b> pose <b>danger</b> to one who swallows them. The Gemara relates: <b>A certain student was sitting before Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> and <b>was eating figs.</b> The student <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>My teacher, are there thorns in figs?</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: The <i>pe</i> killed that</b> fellow. The insect in the fig had punctured the student’s throat.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who carries out a merchant’s basket, even if there are many types</b> of spices and jewelry <b>in it, is obligated</b> to bring <b>only one sin-offering,</b> because he performed only one act of carrying out. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>garden seeds</b> on Shabbat is <b>less than a fig-bulk. Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says:</b> The measure for liability is <b>five</b> seeds.

Daf 90b

The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>cucumber seeds</b> is <b>two</b> seeds because they are large and conspicuous. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>squash seeds</b> is <b>two</b> seeds. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>seeds of Egyptian beans</b> is <b>two.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>a live kosher locust</b> is <b>any amount.</b> For carrying out a <b>dead</b> kosher locust, which is edible, it is the same as any other food, <b>a fig-bulk.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out the locust called <b><i>tzipporet keramim</i>, whether dead or alive,</b> is <b>any amount;</b> this is because <b>one stores them for medicinal purposes</b> or as a talisman, which renders even a small quantity significant. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even one who carries out a live non-kosher locust</b> is liable for carrying out <b>any amount,</b> because <b>people store</b> locusts <b>for a child</b> who wants <b>to play with it.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna the measure that determines liability for carrying out garden seeds on Shabbat. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raised a contradiction</b> from what we learned: The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>compost and fine sand</b> on Shabbat is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to fertilize a cabbage stalk;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. And the Rabbis say: Equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to fertilize a</b> single <b>leek.</b> Even a single plant is a significant amount. <b>Rav Pappa said: This</b> smaller measure applies to a case where the seed <b>was</b> already <b>planted</b> and growing. In that case, one carries out manure to fertilize one plant. <b>That</b> larger measure applies to a case where the seed <b>was not</b> yet <b>planted, because a person does not</b> go to the <b>trouble to carry out a single seed for planting.</b>
With regard to what the mishna said about the measure for carrying out <b>cucumber</b> and squash <b>seeds, the Sages taught: One who carries out</b> date <b>pits</b> on Shabbat, <b>if</b> he did so in order <b>to plant,</b> he is liable for carrying out <b>two</b> pits. <b>If</b> he did so in order for the animals <b>to eat,</b> he is liable for carrying out <b>enough to fill a pig’s mouth. And how much is enough to fill a pig’s mouth? One</b> date pit. <b>If</b> he did so in order <b>to burn</b> the pits, the measure that determines liability is <b>equivalent</b> to that which is used <b>to cook an easily</b> cooked <b>egg. If</b> he carried them out in order to use them <b>to count,</b> the measure for liability is <b>two</b> pits. <b><i>Aḥerim</i> say</b> the measure for liability is <b>five</b> pits. A person is capable of keeping track of up to five items without help. <b>The Sages taught: One who carries out two hairs from a horse’s tail</b> or <b>from a cow’s tail</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable, since people store them to</b> use in <b>traps.</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>stiff hair of a pig</b> is <b>one</b> hair. It is significant because it is used to sew shoes. The measure that determines liability for carrying out <b>palm fronds</b> is <b>two</b> fronds, but the measure for <b>palm vines,</b> which are peeled off the frond and are thinner, is one vine.
We learned in the mishna: With regard to carrying out the locust called <b><i>tzipporet keramim</i>, whether dead or alive,</b> the measure for liability is <b>any amount.</b> This is because one stores them for medicinal purposes or as a talisman, which renders even one locust significant. The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>tzipporet keramim</i>? Rav said:</b> It is the locust called <b><i>palya biari</i>. Abaye said: And</b> it can be <b>found in a palm tree that</b> has only <b>one vine, and it is used</b> as a talisman <b>for wisdom.</b> One <b>eats its right half,</b> and <b>casts its left half into a copper tube, and seals it with sixty seals, and hangs it on his left arm. And</b> the <b>mnemonic</b> reminding <b>you</b> which half to eat and which half to hang on the arm is the verse: <b>“A wise heart to his right and a foolish heart to his left”</b> (Ecclesiastes 10:2). <b>And one</b> then <b>grows wise as much as he wants, and studies as much as he wants, and</b> then <b>eats the other half, as if</b> he does <b>not</b> do so, <b>his learning</b> will <b>be forgotten.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even one who carries out</b> a live non-kosher locust is liable for carrying out any amount, because people store locusts for play. The Gemara explains: <b>And</b> the <b>first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that people do <b>not</b> give children non-kosher locusts for play. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Due to the concern that <b>perhaps</b> the child <b>will eat it.</b> And the Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> it should <b>also</b> be prohibited to give a child a <b>kosher locust,</b> lest the child will eat it, <b>as</b> the Gemara related <b>that Rav Kahana stood before Rav and passed a</b> live <b>kosher locust near his mouth.</b> Rav <b>said to</b> Rav Kahana: <b>Put it down,</b> so that <b>people will not</b> mistakenly <b>say: He is eating it and violating</b> the prohibition <b>of “You shall not make yourselves detestable”</b> (Leviticus 11:43). Apparently, eating a kosher locust is prohibited while it is alive. <b>Rather,</b> even according to the unattributed mishna, there is no room for concern that a young child will eat a locust with which he is playing. The reason that the first <i>tanna</i> prohibits giving a non-kosher locust to a child for play is the concern that <b>perhaps it will die and he will eat it. And Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who permits giving a non-kosher locust to a child for play, does not share that concern. <b>If</b> the locust <b>dies,</b> the <b>child will eulogize it</b> and mourn its death, and certainly would not eat it.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who stores</b> a seed <b>for sowing, or as a sample, or for medicinal purposes and carried it out on Shabbat is liable</b> for carrying out <b>any amount.</b> By storing that measure, he indicates that it is significant to him. Therefore, he is liable for carrying it, despite the fact that what he carried out is less than the halakhic measure that determines liability for that item. <b>And any</b> other <b>person is only liable</b> for carrying it out on Shabbat <b>if</b> he carries out <b>its measure</b> for liability. If one stored the seed, carried it out, <b>and then brought it back in,</b> with no intention to utilize it for the specific purpose for which he stored it, <b>he is only liable if</b> he brought in <b>its measure</b> for liability (Rav Shmuel Strashun).
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Why does</b> the mishna <b>teach: One who stores</b> a seed for a specific purpose and carried it out? <b>Let</b> the mishna simply <b>teach: One who carries out</b> a seed <b>for planting, or as a sample, or for medicinal purposes is liable</b> for carrying out <b>any amount.</b> One is not liable for storing the seed. He is liable for carrying out less than the measure that determines liability because he attributed significance to that measure. <b>Abaye said: With what we are dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where one stored it</b> for a specific purpose <b>and forgot why he stored it, and now he carries it out</b> for <b>no</b> specific <b>purpose.</b>

Daf 91a

<b>Lest you say</b> that in doing so his original <b>intention is</b> completely <b>nullified,</b> since when he carries it out he is no longer conscious of the reason that he stored it, the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that <b>anyone who performs</b> an action with an object with which he had dealings in the past, <b>performs</b> the action <b>with the original</b> intention <b>in mind.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Rabbi Meir deemed liable one who carried out even a single wheat</b> seed for <b>sowing</b> on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: This is <b>obvious. We learned</b> in the mishna that the measure that determines liability for one who carries out seeds for sowing on Shabbat is <b>any amount.</b> Since the principle is that an unattributed mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir, clearly Rabbi Meir would deem him liable for carrying out one seed. He would even deem him liable for carrying out less than one seed. The Gemara answers that Shmuel’s statement was necessary. <b>Lest you say</b> that when the mishna employs the term <b>any amount</b> it is <b>to exclude</b> the standard measure for carrying out food on Shabbat, <b>a dried fig-</b>bulk; <b>and actually</b> one is <b>only liable if there is</b> at least <b>an olive-bulk</b> of whatever he is carrying out. Therefore, Shmuel <b>teaches us</b> that any amount refers to even a single seed. <b>Rav Yitzḥak the son</b> of <b>Rav Yehuda strongly objects to this: But now,</b> based on the approach that the measure of liability depends solely on the intention of the person carrying out the object and not on objective measures, <b>one who planned to carry out</b> the contents of <b>his entire house</b> at once, <b>so too, is he only liable when he carries it out</b> at once? The Gemara answers: There is no comparison. <b>There,</b> with regard to a person who plans to carry out the contents of his entire house, <b>his intention is</b> rendered <b>irrelevant by</b> the opinions of <b>all</b> other <b>people,</b> as most people do not conduct themselves in that manner.
We also learned in the mishna: <b>And any</b> other <b>person is only liable</b> for carrying it out on Shabbat <b>if</b> he carries out <b>its measure</b> for liability. The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna</b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar stated a principle: Anything that is not fit to be stored, and</b> therefore people do <b>not</b> typically <b>store</b> items <b>like it, but it was deemed fit</b> for storage <b>by this</b> person <b>and he stored it, and another</b> person <b>came and carried out</b> the object that was stored, <b>that</b> person, who carried it out, <b>is rendered liable by the thought of this</b> person, who stored it.
<b>Rava said</b> that <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> If <b>one carried out</b> on Shabbat a <b>dried fig-bulk</b> of seeds <b>for eating, and</b> along the way he <b>reconsidered</b> and decided to use them <b>for sowing;</b> or, <b>alternatively,</b> if one intended to carry them out <b>for sowing and reconsidered</b> and decided to use them <b>for eating, he is liable.</b> The Gemara wonders: This is <b>obvious.</b> Whichever way you view this case, he is clearly liable. <b>Go here</b> and examine his initial intention, <b>there is a measure</b> that determines liability; <b>and go here</b> and examine his ultimate intention, <b>there is a measure</b> that determines liability. The Gemara replies that Rav Naḥman’s statement teaches a novel concept. <b>Lest you say</b> that in order to be deemed liable for carrying out an object on Shabbat, <b>we require</b> that the <b>lifting and placing</b> of the object be performed <b>with a single,</b> identical, <b>intention, and that is not</b> the situation here, i.e., that the change in his intention transforms his action into two separate half-labors, therefore Rav Naḥman <b>teaches us</b> that it is considered a single prohibited act, and the person who performed it is liable.
On the basis of this <i>halakha</i>, <b>Rava raised a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>one who carried out half a dried fig-</b>bulk of seeds for the purpose of <b>sowing,</b> which is less than the measure that determines liability, and in the meantime the seeds became moist <b>and expanded</b> to a dried fig-bulk, <b>and</b> he <b>reconsidered</b> his plans <b>for</b> the dried fig-bulk of seeds and decided to use it <b>for eating, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The two sides of the dilemma are: <b>If you say</b> that <b>there,</b> in the first case, <b>he is liable</b> because <b>go here</b> and examine his initial intention, <b>there is a measure</b> that determines liability; <b>and go here</b> and examine his ultimate intention, <b>there is a measure</b> that determines liability; but <b>here,</b> in this case, <b>since at the time that he carried it out there was not a measure</b> that determines liability for one who carries out seeds for the purpose of <b>eating,</b> then <b>he</b> is <b>not liable. Or, perhaps,</b> since <b>had</b> he been <b>silent and had no intention with regard to</b> the seeds at all, <b>he</b> would be <b>liable</b> for the <b>intention</b> of carrying it out for the purpose of <b>sowing,</b> then <b>now too, he is liable</b> because, even based on his reconsidered intention, he completed the prohibited labor of carrying out.
<b>And if you say</b> that since <b>had</b> he been <b>silent and had no intention with regard to</b> the seeds at all, <b>he</b> would be <b>liable</b> for the <b>intention</b> of carrying it out for the purpose of <b>sowing, now too, he</b> is <b>liable,</b> if <b>he carried out</b> seeds in the measure <b>of a dried fig-bulk for</b> the purpose of <b>eating, and</b> they <b>shriveled</b> until there was less than that measure, <b>and he reconsidered</b> and decided to use them <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>sowing,</b> then <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Here, certainly had</b> he been <b>silent and had no intention with regard to</b> the seeds at all, for <b>the original intention he is not liable</b> because there remains less than the measure for liability; <b>or perhaps we follow</b> his intention at <b>present and he is liable. And if you say</b> that <b>we follow</b> his intention at <b>present, and he is liable,</b> the dilemma arises: If <b>one carried out a dried fig-bulk</b> of seeds <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>eating, and it shriveled</b> until there was less than that measure, <b>and then it expanded</b> to a fig-bulk, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Is there disqualification with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat?</b> Since at a certain point there was less than the measure that determines liability, he can no longer be held liable for carrying it out even if it expands. <b>Or,</b> perhaps <b>there is no disqualification with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat.</b> The crucial moments that determine liability for carrying an object are the moment that it is lifted and the moment that it is placed. At both of those junctures, the measure for liability was whole. No resolution was found to any of these dilemmas. Therefore, <b>let them stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rava raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman:</b> If <b>one threw an olive-bulk of <i>teruma</i> into an impure house, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara attempts to clarify the question. With regard <b>to what</b> matter was this dilemma raised? <b>If</b> it was raised <b>with regard to Shabbat,</b> the measure that <b>we require</b> to determine liability for carrying out is <b>a dried fig-bulk,</b> and an olive-bulk is smaller than that. And <b>if</b> it was raised with regard <b>to ritual impurity,</b> the measure that <b>we require</b> to determine impurity for <b>food</b> is at least <b>an egg-bulk,</b> and an olive-bulk is smaller than that as well. The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> this dilemma was raised <b>with regard to Shabbat. And</b> it is referring to a case <b>where there is less than an egg-bulk of food</b> in the house, <b>and this</b> olive-bulk that was thrown into the house <b>completes</b> the measure of the food in the house <b>to an egg-bulk.</b> The dilemma is: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> in that case? Is it <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the olive-bulk <b>joins together</b> with the food in the house <b>with regard to ritual impurity</b> that <b>he is also liable with regard to Shabbat? Or perhaps, all matters</b> concerning carrying out on <b>Shabbat require a dried fig-bulk</b> in order to be liable. Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: We</b> already <b>learned</b> the resolution to that dilemma in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Abba Shaul says:</b> The measure that determines liability for carrying out the wave-offering of <b>the two loaves</b> of bread <b>and the showbread</b> that were in the Temple <b>is a dried fig-bulk.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> is that their measure? <b>Let us say: From</b> the fact that <b>with regard to the matter of</b>

Daf 91b

disqualification of consecrated items due to <b>leaving</b> the Temple courtyard, the significant measure is <b>an olive-bulk,</b> as one who eats that measure of disqualified consecrated items is liable; <b>with regard to Shabbat,</b> its measure for liability should <b>also</b> be <b>an olive-bulk.</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>How can you make that comparison? There,</b> in the case of the consecrated items, <b>from</b> the moment <b>that he took it beyond the courtyard wall it was disqualified</b> due to the prohibition of <b>leaving.</b> However, with regard to <b>Shabbat, he is only liable when he takes it into the public domain,</b> which is far beyond the courtyard walls. <b>Here,</b> in the case where one threw <i>teruma</i> into the house on Shabbat, the prohibition of <b>Shabbat and</b> the <b>impurity</b> of the <i>teruma</i> <b>come simultaneously.</b> Since the olive-bulk is significant in terms of impurity, it is similarly significant with regard to Shabbat.
We learned in the mishna: If one stored the seed, carried it out, <b>and then brought it back in, he is only liable</b> if he brought in <b>its measure</b> for liability. The Gemara asks: This is <b>obvious.</b> By bringing it back into the house he indicates that he no longer considers it significant, and the object then assumes the legal status of an object belonging to anyone else. <b>Abaye said: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where he threw it into the storehouse and its place is</b> clearly <b>discernible</b> to the one who threw it, in that he knows where it landed. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>because its location is discernible</b> it <b>maintains its original status,</b> the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that <b>from</b> the fact <b>that he threw it into the storehouse,</b> he indicated that <b>he nullified</b> the object’s previous significance.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who carries out food</b> from his house on Shabbat <b>and placed it on the threshold</b> of the door, <b>whether he then carried it out</b> from the threshold into the public domain <b>or another person carried it out, he is exempt because he did not perform his prohibited labor</b> of carrying from domain to domain <b>all at once.</b> Similarly, if one <b>placed a basket that is full of fruit on the outer threshold,</b> which is in the public domain, and part of the basket remained inside, <b>even though most of</b> the <b>fruit</b> is <b>outside</b> in the public domain, he is <b>exempt until he carries out the entire basket.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara begins by asking: <b>What</b> is the nature of <b>this threshold</b> in terms of Shabbat? <b>If you say</b> that it is <b>a threshold</b> that has the legal status of <b>the public domain,</b> in that it does not extend above nine handbreadths, and its area is four by four handbreadths, and it is suitable for use by the multitudes, why is he <b>exempt? Didn’t he carry out</b> food <b>from the private domain to the public domain? Rather,</b> say that it is <b>a threshold</b> that has the legal status of <b>the private domain,</b> in that it extends above ten handbreadths, and its area is four by four handbreadths. In that case, why does the mishna say: <b>Whether he then carried it out</b> from the threshold into the public domain <b>or another person carried it out, he is exempt?</b> Why should he be exempt? <b>Didn’t he carry out</b> food <b>from the private domain to the public domain?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the mishna is referring to <b>a threshold</b> that is <b>a <i>karmelit</i>. And</b> it <b>teaches us the following: The reason</b> that he is exempt is due to the fact <b>that</b> the object <b>came to rest in a <i>karmelit</i>. However,</b> if the object <b>did not come to rest in a <i>karmelit</i>, he is liable</b> even if it passed through a <i>karmelit</i>. This comes to teach that <b>the mishna</b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>ben Azzai, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who carries out</b> an object <b>from a store,</b> which is a private domain, <b>to a plaza,</b> which is a public domain, <b>via a colonnade,</b> which is a <i>karmelit</i>, <b>is liable</b> because he lifted the object in a private domain and placed it in a public domain. <b>And ben Azzai</b> deems him <b>exempt</b> because, in his opinion, an exempt domain separates between the private and public domains.
We learned in the mishna: If one <b>placed a basket that is full of fruit</b> on the outer threshold, he is only liable if he carries out the entire basket. <b>Ḥizkiya said: They only taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to a basket full of cucumbers and gourds,</b> both of which are long. Part of each fruit remains inside even when most of the basket is in the public domain. <b>However,</b> if the basket was <b>full of mustard</b> seeds, <b>he is liable</b> for carrying out a measure of individual mustard seeds to the public domain. The Gemara concludes: <b>Apparently, he holds that the fusion</b> of several objects in a single <b>vessel is not considered fusion.</b> Even though several objects are in a single basket, they do not have the legal status of a single unit. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Even</b> if the basket were <b>full of mustard</b> seeds, <b>he is exempt. Apparently, he holds that the fusion</b> of several objects in a single <b>vessel is considered fusion.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The language of <b>the mishna</b> does <b>not precisely</b> correspond with the opinion of <b>Ḥizkiya, and</b> it does <b>not precisely</b> correspond with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> The Gemara explains: It does <b>not precisely</b> correspond with the opinion of <b>Ḥizkiya, as</b> the mishna <b>taught: Until he carries out the entire basket.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that he is liable is because he carried out <b>the entire basket. However,</b> if part of the basket remained inside, even if he carried out <b>all the fruit, he is exempt. Apparently,</b> the mishna <b>holds</b> that <b>fusion</b> of several objects in a single <b>vessel is considered fusion.</b> Since the vessel fuses the fruit into one entity, when part of the basket remains inside, by extension its fruit is also considered to have remained inside. And it does <b>not precisely</b> correspond with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, as</b> the mishna <b>taught: Even though most of</b> the <b>fruit</b> is <b>outside.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that he is exempt is because only <b>most of the fruit</b> is outside. <b>However,</b> if <b>all</b> the <b>fruit</b> were outside, then <b>even though</b> part of <b>the basket</b> remains <b>bound inside, he is liable. Apparently,</b> the mishna <b>holds</b> that <b>the fusion</b> of several objects in a single <b>vessel is not considered fusion.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> that is <b>difficult.</b> The inferences of the mishna are contradictory. The Gemara explains: <b>Ḥizkiya resolves</b> the contradiction in accordance <b>with his reasoning, and Rabbi Yoḥanan resolves</b> the contradiction in accordance <b>with his reasoning.</b> The Gemara elaborates: According to both of the Sages, the mishna is referring to two distinct cases. <b>Ḥizkiya resolves</b> the contradiction according <b>to his reasoning.</b> The phrase: <b>Until he carries out the entire basket; in what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in the case of <b>a basket full of cucumbers and gourds. However,</b> in the case of a basket <b>full of mustard</b> seeds, <b>he becomes as one who carried out the entire basket, and he is liable</b> for carrying out the mustard seeds. And <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan resolves</b> the contradiction according <b>to his reasoning:</b> When we learned: <b>Even though most of</b> the <b>fruit</b> is <b>outside,</b> he is exempt; <b>and</b> that ruling is true <b>not only</b> if he carried out <b>most</b> of the <b>fruit, but even</b> if he carried out <b>all the fruit</b> he is also <b>exempt, until he carries out the entire basket.</b>
<b>The Gemara raises an objection</b> from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who carries out the merchant’s basket</b> on Shabbat that contains different items, primarily spices, <b>and placed it on the outer threshold</b> of the house, <b>even though most of</b> the <b>types</b> of items in the basket are <b>outside, he is exempt until he carries out the entire basket. It</b> might <b>enter your mind</b> to say that this is referring to a basket full <b>of bundles</b> of different spices. That <b>is difficult</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Ḥizkiya,</b> as even though most of the bundles entered the public domain, he is exempt. The Gemara answers: <b>Ḥizkiya</b> could have <b>said to you: With what are we dealing here? With stalks [<i>urnasei</i>].</b> The spices are in the form of stalks that fill the entire length of the basket. As long as part of the basket remains inside, part of each stalk remains inside as well.
And <b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye</b> also <b>raised an objection</b> from that which we learned: <b>One who steals a purse on Shabbat is liable</b> for the theft. Based on the principle that one who is liable to receive two punishments receives the greater of the two, in this case one should be exempt from payment for the theft, since performing a prohibited labor on Shabbat is punishable by stoning. However, this case is different <b>because he was already liable for theft</b> as soon as he lifted the purse. This took place <b>before he came to</b> violate <b>the prohibition</b> of performing prohibited labor on <b>Shabbat</b> by carrying it into the public domain. However, if he did not lift the purse, but <b>was dragging</b> it on the ground <b>and exiting</b> the private domain, <b>he is exempt</b> from paying for the theft, <b>as</b> in that case, he is only liable for the theft when he drags the purse out of the owner’s property into the public domain. <b>The prohibition of theft and the prohibition of Shabbat</b> are violated <b>all at once.</b> For the purposes of this discussion: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> to say that <b>fusion</b> of several objects within a single <b>vessel is considered fusion,</b> in this case <b>the prohibition of theft precedes the prohibition of Shabbat.</b> At the moment that the mouth of the purse enters the public domain, he is liable for theft because it is as if the money inside had been carried out. With regard to Shabbat, he would not be liable until the entire purse entered the public domain.
The Gemara explains: <b>If</b> this is referring to a case <b>where he carried it out by way of its mouth, indeed that is so,</b> he would be liable for theft. However, <b>with what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where he carried it out by</b> the <b>underside</b> of the purse. Since none of the money is accessible until the entire purse is in the public domain, he violated the prohibitions simultaneously. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t there the area of the seam?</b> He could gain access to the money even if he dragged out the purse by way of its underside,

Daf 92a

<b>for if he wishes, he can tear</b> the seam <b>and take</b> the money. The Gemara answers: Here, it is referring <b>to</b> long <b>metal strips.</b> As long as the entire purse is not in the public domain, he did not acquire any of the long strips, and he is not liable for theft. The Gemara asks: <b>And since</b> the purse <b>has laces</b> to close its opening, to be liable for theft it is sufficient <b>that he carry it out so</b> that <b>its mouth</b> is in the public domain, as he can <b>untie</b> the straps <b>and remove</b> the contents of the purse. <b>And</b> since the <b>laces</b> remain <b>bound inside</b> the private domain, he is not yet liable for violating the prohibition of Shabbat. The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case where the purse <b>does not have laces. And if you wish, say</b> instead that it is referring to a case where <b>it has</b> laces, <b>and</b> the laces are <b>wound around</b> the purse.
There is a dispute between Abaye and Rava that parallels the dispute between Ḥizkiya and Rabbi Yoḥanan. <b>And, so too, Rava said: They only taught</b> in the mishna that one is exempt <b>with regard to</b> carrying out <b>a basket full of cucumbers and gourds. However,</b> for carrying out a basket <b>full of mustard</b> seeds, <b>he is liable. Apparently,</b> Rava <b>holds: fusion</b> of several objects in a single <b>vessel is not considered fusion. Abaye said: Even</b> if the basket is <b>full of mustard</b> seeds, <b>he is exempt. Apparently,</b> Abaye <b>holds: Fusion</b> of several objects in a single <b>vessel is considered fusion.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Abaye</b> later <b>assumed the opinion of Rava,</b> and <b>Rava assumed the opinion of Abaye. And a contradiction is raised</b> between one statement of <b>Abaye</b> and another statement of <b>Abaye; and a contradiction is raised</b> between one statement of <b>Rava</b> and another statement of <b>Rava.</b>
<b>As it was stated</b> that they disputed the matter of <b>one who carries out fruit into the public domain. Abaye said:</b> If he carried them out <b>in</b> his <b>hand, he is liable</b> even if the rest of his body remained in the private domain because fusion of several objects in his hand is not considered fusion. However, if he carried them out <b>in a vessel,</b> and part of the vessel remained in the private domain, <b>he is exempt. And Rava said:</b> If he carried them out <b>in</b> his <b>hand, he is exempt</b> because the legal status of his hand is determined by the status of the rest of the body. However, if he carried them out <b>in a vessel, he is liable.</b>
These are contrary to their opinions stated above. The Gemara answers: <b>Reverse</b> the opinions, and say that Rava was the one who said: If he carried it out <b>in his hand, he is liable.</b> The Gemara raises an objection. <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: In a case where <b>the homeowner extended his hand into the public domain, and</b> either <b>the poor person took</b> an object <b>from</b> the homeowner’s hand and placed it in the public domain, <b>or the poor person placed</b> an object <b>into</b> the homeowner’s hand and the homeowner <b>carried</b> the object <b>into</b> the private domain, <b>both are exempt.</b> Apparently, one is not liable if he merely moved an object in his hand into the public domain. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the mishna, it is referring to a case where his hand was <b>above three</b> handbreadths from the ground. The object in his hand, therefore, does not have the legal status of having been placed on the ground, and he is exempt. <b>Here,</b> it is referring to a case where his hand was <b>below three</b> handbreadths off the ground. Anything that is within three handbreadths off the ground has the legal status of having been placed on the ground.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who carries out</b> an object into the public domain on Shabbat, <b>whether</b> he carried it out <b>in his right</b> hand <b>or in his left</b> hand, whether he carried it <b>in his lap or on his shoulders, he is liable.</b> All of these are typical methods of carrying out an object, <b>as</b> this was the method of <b>carrying</b> the sacred vessels of the Tabernacle employed <b>by the sons of Kehat</b> in the desert. All labors prohibited on Shabbat are derived from the Tabernacle, including the prohibited labor of carrying out from domain to domain. But one who carries an object out <b>in an</b> unusual, <b>backhanded</b> manner, or <b>with his foot,</b> or <b>with his mouth,</b> or <b>with his elbow, with his ear,</b> or <b>with his hair,</b> or <b>with his belt [<i>punda</i>] whose opening</b> faced <b>downward,</b> or <b>between his belt and his cloak,</b> or <b>with the hem of his cloak,</b> or <b>with his shoe,</b> or <b>with his sandal, he is exempt</b> because <b>he did not carry</b> it <b>out in a manner</b> typical <b>of those who carry.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Elazar said: One who carries out a load</b> from the private domain to the public domain, even if he does so at a height <b>above ten handbreadths,</b> which is beyond the parameters of the public domain, <b>he is liable, as</b> this was the method of <b>carrying</b> utilized <b>by the sons of Kehat.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive that the method of <b>carrying</b> utilized <b>by the sons of Kehat</b> was above ten handbreadths? The Gemara answers: <b>For it is written</b> about the Levites’ carrying: “And the hangings of the courtyard, and the screen for the courtyard entrance which <b>surrounds the Tabernacle, and the altar,</b> and its cords for all of its service” (Numbers 3:26). This verse <b>juxtaposes</b> the <b>altar to the Tabernacle.</b> It is derived that <b>just as the Tabernacle</b> was <b>ten cubits</b> high, <b>so too,</b> the <b>altar</b> was <b>ten cubits high.</b> The verse that indicates otherwise: “And you shall make the altar…and its height should be three cubits” (Exodus 27:1), must be understood differently.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive that <b>the Tabernacle itself</b> was carried above ten handbreadths? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is written:</b> “And you shall make the boards for the Tabernacle out of acacia wood standing upright, <b>the length of a board shall be ten cubits”</b> (Exodus 26:15–16). <b>And it is written</b> with regard to the construction of the Tabernacle: <b>“And he spread the tent over the Tabernacle,</b> and he placed the cover for the tent on top of it as God commanded Moses” (Exodus 40:19). <b>And Rav said: Moses, our teacher, spread it</b> himself. <b>From here you</b> can <b>derive that the height of the Levites was ten cubits.</b> If Moses was capable of standing and spreading the cover over the tent by himself, he must have been at least ten cubits tall. Presumably, that was the height of the rest of the Levites as well. <b>And</b> they <b>learned</b> through tradition that <b>every burden that is carried with poles, one-third</b> of the burden <b>is above</b> the porter’s height, <b>and two-thirds are below</b> his height. <b>It is found,</b> then, <b>that</b> the altar <b>was very high,</b> as if they carried the altar on poles, the bottom of the altar was at least one-third of ten cubits, twenty handbreadths, off the ground.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that the Levites were not extraordinarily tall, and this can be derived from <b>the Ark</b> of the Covenant, <b>as the Master said:</b> The <b>Ark</b> itself was <b>nine</b> handbreadths tall as stated in the Torah, <b>and the Ark-cover</b> was one <b>handbreadth, for</b> a total of <b>ten. And</b> they <b>learned</b> through tradition that <b>every burden that is carried with poles, one-third</b> of the burden <b>is above</b> the porter’s height <b>and two-thirds are below</b> his height. <b>It is found,</b> then, <b>that</b> the bottom of the Ark <b>stood ten</b> handbreadths <b>above</b> the ground. The Gemara asks: <b>And let us derive</b> it <b>from Moses,</b> and why was the first proof insufficient? The Gemara answers: <b>Perhaps Moses</b> was <b>different</b> from the other Levites and taller than they were, as <b>the Master said: The Divine Presence only rests upon</b> a person who is <b>wise, mighty, wealthy, and tall.</b> Since the Divine Presence rested on Moses, he had to be tall.
<b>Rav said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: One who carries out a burden on his head on Shabbat is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, as the people of Hotzal do so.</b> They would typically carry burdens on their heads. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> do <b>the people of Hotzal</b> constitute <b>the majority of the world?</b> Even if in one place it is a typical method of carrying a burden, it remains an atypical method of carrying in the rest of the world. <b>Rather, if</b> this ruling <b>was stated, it was stated as follows. Rav said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya:</b> If <b>a resident of Hotzal carried out a burden on his head on Shabbat he is liable, as the people of his city do so.</b> The Gemara asks again: Even if the inhabitants of his city do this, <b>let his intention be</b> rendered <b>irrelevant by</b> the opinions of <b>all</b> other <b>people.</b> If an individual or small group of people conduct themselves in an atypical manner, their conduct is not rendered typical. Typical conduct is determined by the majority of people. <b>Rather, if</b> this <b>was stated, it was stated as follows. One who carries out a burden on his head is exempt.</b>

Daf 92b

<b>And if you say</b> that <b>the people of Hotzal do so</b> and therefore they should be liable, <b>their intention is</b> rendered <b>irrelevant by</b> the opinions of <b>all</b> other <b>people.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who intends to carry out</b> an object with the object <b>before him, and</b> as he was walking the object <b>came</b> to be carried <b>behind him, is exempt.</b> However, if he intended to carry it out <b>behind him and it came</b> to be carried <b>before him, he is liable. In truth they said: A woman who girded herself in a</b> pants-like <b><i>sinar</i></b> worn beneath the outer garments, <b>whether</b> she placed an object <b>before her or behind her,</b> and it came to be carried on the other side, <b>she is liable, as it is common</b> for the <i>sinar</i> <b>to be reversed. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even those</b> royal couriers, <b>who receive notes [<i>pittakin</i>],</b> carry those notes in their belts, and are not particular where on their belt they carry the notes (Rav Hai Gaon), are liable for carrying out the notes whether they carried them before them or behind them.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about the case of one who intended to carry an object <b>before him and it came</b> to be carried <b>behind him</b> that he is <b>exempt?</b> The reason is that <b>his intention was not realized.</b> Since he did not perform the act that he intended to perform, he is exempt. If so, then even in the case of one who intended to carry an object <b>behind him, and it came</b> to be carried <b>before him,</b> he should <b>also</b> be exempt because <b>his intention was not realized. Rabbi Elazar said:</b> This mishna <b>is disjointed,</b> in the sense that it cites the opinions of two different Sages. <b>He who taught this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>did not teach that</b> <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rava said: And what difficulty</b> is there here? <b>Perhaps</b> it can be explained as follows. With regard to one who intended to carry an object <b>before him, and it came</b> to be carried <b>behind him, this is the reason that he is exempt: He intended to</b> provide the object with <b>outstanding protection,</b> seeing it at all times, <b>and</b> ultimately <b>he managed</b> to provide the object with <b>reduced protection.</b> Since that was not his intention, it is not considered a prohibited labor and he is exempt. Whereas one who intended to carry an object <b>behind him, and it came</b> to be carried <b>before him, this is the reason he is liable: He intended to</b> provide the object with <b>reduced protection, and</b> ultimately <b>he managed</b> to provide the object with <b>outstanding protection.</b>
<b>Rather, what is the difficulty</b> here? It is the <b>inference</b> inferred from <b>the mishna</b> that is <b>difficult. One who intends to carry out</b> an object <b>before him, and</b> the object <b>came</b> to be carried <b>behind him, is exempt.</b> By inference: One who intends to carry out an object <b>behind him, and</b> indeed, the object <b>came</b> to be carried <b>behind him, is liable. Say</b> the <b>latter clause</b> of the mishna: One who intends to carry out an object <b>behind him, and it came</b> to be carried <b>before him, is</b> the case <b>where</b> he is <b>liable.</b> By inference: One who intends to carry out an object <b>behind him, and</b> indeed, the object <b>came</b> to be carried <b>behind him, is exempt.</b> The inference from the first clause contradicts the inference from the latter clause. <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> This mishna <b>is disjointed. He who taught this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>did not teach that</b> <i>halakha</i>.
<b>Rav Ashi said: What difficulty</b> is there here? <b>Perhaps</b> the mishna <b>is stating</b> the <i>halakha</i> utilizing the following didactic style: It was <b>not necessary,</b> and it should be understood as follows. <b>It was not necessary</b> to teach that a person who intended to carry the object <b>behind him, and it came</b> to be carried <b>behind him, is liable.</b> That is obvious <b>because his intention was realized. However, it was necessary for</b> the mishna to teach that <b>even</b> in a case where he intended to carry the object <b>behind him, and it came</b> to be carried <b>before him,</b> he is liable. <b>It would have entered your mind to say: Since his intention was not realized, he should not be liable.</b> Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us:</b> Since <b>he intended to</b> provide the object with <b>reduced protection, and</b> ultimately <b>he managed</b> to provide the object with <b>outstanding protection,</b> he is <b>liable.</b>
<b>And</b> the case where one intended to carry out the object <b>behind him, and it came</b> to be carried <b>behind him, is</b> the subject of a dispute between the <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who carried out coins in his money belt, and its opening was</b> facing <b>up, is liable</b> because this is the typical method of carrying coins. However, if one carried it out with <b>its opening</b> facing <b>down, Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> him <b>liable, and the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt. Rabbi Yehuda said to</b> the Rabbis: <b>Do you not agree</b> that in a case where one intends to carry the object <b>behind him, and it came</b> to be carried <b>behind him, that he is liable?</b> Apparently, one who intended to provide his object with reduced protection and realized that intention is liable. <b>And they said to him: And do you not agree</b> that <b>one</b> who carries out an object <b>in a backhanded manner or with his foot is exempt?</b> Apparently, carrying out an object in an atypical manner is not considered carrying.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda said: I said one thing</b> to the Rabbis in support of my opinion, <b>and they said one thing</b> to me. <b>I did not find a response to their statement, and they did not find a response to my statement. From</b> the fact <b>that he said to them: Do you not agree</b> that in a case where one intends to carry the object behind him, and it came to be carried behind him, he is liable? <b>Can it not be inferred that the Sages deem</b> one <b>exempt</b> in that case? Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis dispute this matter. The Gemara asks: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> from the fact <b>that</b> the Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda: <b>Do you not agree</b> that one who carries out an object in a backhanded manner is exempt, can it not <b>be inferred</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> one <b>liable,</b> even for carrying out in a backhanded manner? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to one who carries an object out <b>in a backhanded manner</b> or with <b>his foot, everyone agrees</b> that he is <b>exempt?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> should be understood as follows. With regard to one who intended to carry an object <b>behind him, and</b> the object <b>came</b> to be carried out <b>behind him, everyone agrees</b> that he is <b>liable.</b> With regard to one who carried out an object <b>in a backhanded manner</b> or with <b>his foot, everyone agrees</b> that he is <b>exempt. Where they disagree</b> is in a case where one carried coins <b>in his money belt with its opening</b> facing <b>down.</b> This <b>Master,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>likens it to</b> the case of one who intended to carry an object <b>behind him and</b> the object <b>came</b> to be carried out <b>behind him,</b> and deems him liable; <b>and</b> this <b>Master,</b> the Rabbis, <b>liken it</b> to the case of one who carried out an object <b>in a backhanded manner</b> or with <b>his foot,</b> and deems him exempt.
We learned in the mishna: <b>In truth they said: A woman who</b> girded herself in a pants-like <i>sinar</i>, whether she placed an object before her or behind her, and it came to be carried on the other side, she is liable. <b>It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: In <b>every</b> instance that the mishna employs the phrase: <b>In truth, that is the</b> undisputed <b><i>halakha</i>.</b> And we learned in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>even those who receive notes,</b> i.e., royal couriers who transmit messages, place notes in their belts, and are not particular about which side the note is on (Rav Hai Gaon), are liable for carrying out notes, whether they carry the notes out in front of them or behind them. <b>We learned</b> a different explanation: <b>Because the royal scribes do this,</b> they place their notes on all sides of their belts.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who carries a</b> large <b>mass out to the public domain</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable.</b> If <b>two carried it out</b> together, <b>they are exempt</b> because neither performed a complete prohibited labor. However, if <b>one</b> person <b>is unable to carry it out</b> alone, <b>and</b> therefore <b>two</b> people <b>carried it out, they are liable. And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> them <b>exempt</b> even in that case.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said, and some say</b> that <b>Abaye said</b> this, <b>and some say</b> that <b>it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>:</b> With regard to an action performed by two people, when <b>this</b> person <b>is capable</b> of performing it alone, <b>and that</b> person <b>is capable</b> of performing it alone, <b>Rabbi Meir deems</b> them <b>liable, and Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon deem</b> them <b>exempt.</b> If both <b>this</b> person <b>is incapable and that</b> person <b>is incapable</b> of performing the action alone, and therefore they performed it together, <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Meir deem</b> them <b>liable, and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> them <b>exempt.</b> If <b>this</b> person <b>is capable,</b> and <b>that</b> person <b>is incapable,</b> and they performed it together, <b>everyone agrees</b> that he is <b>liable.</b>
<b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who carries a</b> large <b>mass out to the public domain</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable.</b> If <b>two carried it out</b> together, <b>Rabbi Meir deems</b> them <b>liable, and Rabbi Yehuda says: If one is incapable of carrying it out, and two carried it out, they are liable. And if not,</b> if each person is capable of carrying it out himself, and nevertheless they carried it out together, <b>they are exempt. And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> them <b>exempt</b> even if neither was capable of performing the action alone. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? What is the biblical source of these <i>halakhot</i>? The Gemara answers that the source is <b>as our Sages taught</b> in <i>Torat Kohanim</i>, the halakhic midrash on Leviticus. It is written: “And if one person among the common people sins unwittingly <b>by performing it,</b> any one of God’s commandments not to be done, and be guilty” (Leviticus 4:27). The Gemara interpreted: “By performing it,” means that <b>one who performs</b> a transgression <b>in its entirety</b> is liable, <b>and not one who performs part of it. How so?</b> If <b>two</b> people <b>were holding a pitchfork and gathering</b> the stalks, or holding <b>a shuttle and weaving</b> the threads of the warp, or holding <b>a quill and writing,</b> or holding <b>a reed and carrying it out to the public domain,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought <b>they are liable,</b> therefore <b>the verse states: “By performing it.” One who performs</b> a transgression <b>in its entirety</b> is liable, <b>and not one who performs</b> only <b>part of it.</b>

Daf 93a

In contrast, if two people held <b>a round cake of figs,</b> which is too heavy for one person to carry, <b>and they carried</b> it <b>out to the public domain,</b> or if they held <b>a beam and carried</b> it <b>out to the public domain, Rabbi Yehuda says: If one</b> person <b>is incapable of carrying it out</b> alone, <b>and two</b> people <b>carried it out, they are liable. And if not,</b> if one person is capable of carrying it out alone, <b>they are exempt. Rabbi Shimon says: Even if</b> one person <b>is incapable of carrying it out</b> alone, <b>and two</b> people <b>carried it out, they are exempt. It is</b> with regard to <b>that</b> case that <b>it is stated: “By performing it”</b> (Leviticus 4:27), to establish a principle: <b>An individual who performs</b> a transgression <b>is liable, two</b> people <b>who perform</b> a transgression <b>are exempt.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: They disagree <b>over</b> the interpretation of <b>this verse: “And if one person among the common people sins unwittingly by performing it,</b> any one of God’s commandments not to be done, and be guilty” (Leviticus 4:27). <b>Rabbi Shimon holds: Three exclusionary</b> statements <b>are written</b> in this verse. It is as if it were written: <b>A person who sins, one who sins,</b> and <b>by performing it he sins.</b> The Torah could have conveyed the same meaning by saying simply: And if one of the common people. Apparently, the superfluous words in the verse are exclusionary and the verse should be understood as follows: A person, and not many people; one, and not two; by performing it, and not by two performing it. <b>One</b> of the terms comes <b>to exclude</b> from liability a case where each of the two people performs a part of the transgression, i.e., <b>this</b> person <b>lifts</b> an object from one domain, <b>and that</b> person <b>places it</b> in another domain. <b>And one</b> of the terms comes <b>to exclude</b> a case where <b>this</b> person <b>is capable</b> of performing the action alone, <b>and that</b> person <b>is</b> also <b>capable,</b> and the two of them perform the action together. <b>And one</b> of the terms comes <b>to exclude</b> even a case where <b>this</b> person <b>is incapable</b> of performing the action alone, <b>and that</b> person <b>is incapable</b> of performing the action alone. Since the two of them violated this prohibition together, they are both exempt.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda</b> holds: <b>One</b> of the terms comes <b>to exclude</b> a case where <b>this</b> person <b>lifts</b> an object, <b>and that person places</b> it, as he agrees that they are exempt in this case. <b>And one</b> of the terms comes <b>to exclude</b> a case where <b>this</b> person <b>is capable</b> of performing the action alone, <b>and that</b> person <b>is</b> also <b>capable. And one</b> of the terms comes <b>to exclude</b> the case of <b>an individual who performed</b> a transgression <b>in accordance with the ruling of a court.</b> If a court issued a mistaken ruling that a prohibited action is permitted, and an individual performed that action based on that ruling, he is exempt from bringing a sin-offering and is considered to have sinned due to circumstances beyond his control. <b>And Rabbi Shimon</b> holds that <b>an individual who performed</b> a transgression <b>in accordance with the ruling of a court is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering for his mistake. His action is not considered intentional, but falls into the category of an unwitting act.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who deems them liable in a case where each was capable of performing the act alone, interpret the third exclusionary term? The Gemara answers: <b>Is it written</b> in the verse: <b>A person who sins, one who sins,</b> and <b>by performing it he sins?</b> There are not three exclusionary terms in the verse. Only <b>two exclusionary</b> terms <b>are written,</b> as the words: “One person who sins,” constitutes a single phrase.
