Therefore, <b>one</b> term comes <b>to exclude</b> from liability a case where <b>this</b> person <b>lifts</b> an object, <b>and that</b> one <b>places</b> it; <b>and one</b> term comes <b>to exclude</b> an <b>individual who performed</b> a transgression <b>in accordance with the ruling of a court.</b>
We learned earlier that <b>the Master said:</b> In a case where <b>this</b> person <b>is capable,</b> and <b>this</b> person <b>is incapable,</b> and they performed it together, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>he is liable.</b> The Gemara seeks to clarify: <b>Which of them is liable? Rav Ḥisda said: The one who is capable</b> of performing the act alone is liable, <b>as if</b> it was <b>the one who is incapable</b> of performing the act alone that was liable, <b>what is he doing</b> that would render him liable? His efforts are inadequate to perform the task. <b>Rav Hamnuna said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: He is doing quite a bit, <b>as he is assisting him.</b> He <b>said to him:</b> The assistance provided by one who <b>assists</b> another to perform a task that the other could have performed himself <b>is insubstantial.</b>
<b>Rav Zevid said in the name of Rava: We, too, also learned</b> that <i>halakha</i> in a mishna, with regard to vessels upon which a <i>zav</i> lies or rides. By Torah law, any vessel designated for lying and riding, upon which a <i>zav</i> lies or rides, becomes impure even if the <i>zav</i> did not come into direct contact with it. If a <i>zav</i> <b>was sitting on a bed, and</b> there were <b>four garments beneath the</b> four <b>legs of the bed, they are</b> all <b>ritually impure.</b> The weight of the <i>zav</i> is considered to have rested on each of the garments <b>because</b> the bed <b>is incapable of standing on three</b> legs. <b>And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> the garments <b>ritually pure,</b> since only a portion of his weight rested on each garment. However, <b>if he was riding on an animal, and there were four garments beneath the legs of the animal, they are</b> all <b>ritually pure because</b> the animal <b>is capable of standing on three</b> legs. <b>And why</b> are the garments ritually pure? <b>Aren’t</b> the animal’s legs <b>assisting each other</b> in supporting the weight of the <i>zav</i>? <b>Is it not because we say:</b> An object <b>that assists</b> is <b>insubstantial?</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda of Diskarta said: Actually, I will say to you</b> that a person or an object <b>that assists is substantial. However,</b> it <b>is different here,</b> in this case, as the animal <b>lifted</b> its foot <b>completely.</b> The mishna is not discussing the case of an animal that could theoretically stand on three legs, but an actual situation where it completely lifted one of its feet and the fourth foot did not even assist in supporting the animal’s weight. The Gemara rejects the suggestion of Rav Yehuda of Diskarta. <b>And since it sometimes lifts this</b> foot <b>and sometimes lifts that</b> foot, <b>it should</b> have the legal status of <b>a <i>zav</i> who turns over. Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>a <i>zav</i> who was lying on five benches or on five money belts,</b> if he was lying <b>along their length, they are impure.</b> At different times, his entire body was lying on each of the benches or on each of the money belts. If he was lying <b>across their width, they are ritually pure</b> because at no point was his entire weight supported by one of the benches or the money belts. However, if <b>he slept</b> across their width, <b>there is uncertainty</b> whether or not, while sleeping, <b>he turned over on them.</b> This raises the possibility that, at some point, he lay along their length, and his entire weight was supported by one of the benches. Therefore, all of the benches <b>are impure.</b> A <i>zav</i> who moves his weight from one place to another renders all of those places ritually impure. Similarly, the fact that the animal lifts different legs is not sufficient for each to be considered as not assisting to support the weight of the <i>zav</i>.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> that the garments beneath the legs of the animal remain ritually pure <b>because we say:</b> An object <b>that assists</b> is <b>insubstantial?</b> Each foot merely assists in supporting the weight of the <i>zav</i>. Similarly, <b>Rav Pappi said in the name of Rava: We, too, also learned</b> support for this <i>halakha</i>,

Daf 93b

as we learned in a mishna, <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> If a <i>zav</i> was riding on an animal, and there was a garment beneath it, if he was riding <b>the horse,</b> he <b>renders</b> the garment <b>impure by means of</b> the horse’s <b>front legs.</b> Only then is it impure; if it was beneath the horse’s hind legs it is not. And if he was riding <b>the donkey,</b> he renders the garment impure <b>by means of</b> the donkey’s <b>hind legs.</b> Only then is it impure; if it was beneath the donkey’s front legs it is not. The reason for this distinction is that <b>a horse rests</b> primarily <b>on its front legs, and</b> a <b>donkey</b> rests primarily <b>on its hind legs. But why</b> should a garment beneath the hind legs of a horse or the front legs of a donkey remain ritually pure? <b>Don’t</b> the legs <b>assist each other? Is</b> the reason <b>not because we say</b> that <b>one who assists is insubstantial? Rav Ashi said: We, too, also learned</b> support for this <i>halakha</i> in a different mishna. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to a priest that stood in the Temple, and <b>one of his feet was on a vessel, and one of his feet was on the floor,</b> or <b>one of his feet was on a stone, and one of his feet was on the floor,</b> while performing priestly Temple rites; <b>we see, if the vessel was removed or the stone was removed,</b> whether <b>he would</b> still <b>be capable of standing on one foot</b> on the ground. If so, <b>his service is valid. And if</b> he could <b>not</b> stand on one foot, <b>his service is invalid.</b> Is he considered to be standing on the floor, in which case the service is valid, or is he not considered to be standing on the floor, in which case the service is invalid?
The Gemara asks: <b>And why,</b> if he would still be capable of standing on one foot, should it be valid? <b>Don’t</b> his legs <b>assist each other? Isn’t</b> the reason <b>because we say: One who assists is insubstantial? Ravina said: We, too, also learned</b> support for this in a different mishna. All service performed in the Temple must be performed with the right hand. If <b>he received</b> the blood <b>in his right</b> hand, <b>and his left</b> hand <b>assisted</b> his right hand, <b>his service is valid. And why</b> is his service valid? <b>Aren’t</b> his hands <b>assisting each other? Isn’t</b> the reason <b>because we say: One who assists is insubstantial?</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, learn <b>from this</b> that it is so.
<b>The Master said</b> in a <i>baraita</i> cited above: With regard to an action performed by two people, when <b>this</b> person <b>is capable</b> of performing it alone <b>and that</b> person <b>is capable</b> of performing it alone, <b>Rabbi Meir deems</b> them <b>liable. A dilemma was raised</b> before the students: <b>Do we require</b> a <b>measure</b> that determines liability <b>for this</b> person and a <b>measure</b> that determines liability <b>for that</b> one; <b>or perhaps one measure</b> that determines liability is sufficient <b>for them all? Rav Ḥisda and Rav Hamnuna</b> disagreed. <b>One said:</b> There must be a <b>measure</b> that determines liability <b>for this</b> person and a <b>measure</b> that determines liability <b>for that</b> one. <b>And one said: One measure</b> of liability is sufficient <b>for them all. Rav Pappa said in the name of Rava: We, too, also learned</b> a mishna in support of the opinion that one measure is sufficient. It states in the mishna in tractate <i>Zavim</i>: If a <i>zav</i> <b>was sitting on a bed, and</b> there were <b>four garments beneath the</b> four <b>legs of the bed, they are</b> all <b>ritually impure because</b> the bed <b>is incapable of standing on three</b> legs. <b>And why</b> should they be ritually impure? <b>Let them require a measure of</b> the weight of <b>a <i>zav</i> for this</b> garment <b>and a measure</b> of the weight <b>of a <i>zav</i> for that</b> garment. All the garments should only become impure if there was one <i>zav</i> on the bed for each garment. <b>Is it not because we say</b> that in order to make the garments impure <b>one measure</b> of impurity is sufficient <b>for them all?</b> Therefore, both parties are liable for one measure that determines liability.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: We, too, also learned</b> an additional support from a different source. With regard to <b>a deer that entered the house, and one</b> person <b>locked</b> the door <b>before it</b> on Shabbat and prevented it from exiting, <b>one is liable</b> for performing the prohibited labor of trapping on Shabbat. If <b>two</b> people <b>locked</b> the door, <b>they are exempt.</b> If <b>one is incapable of locking</b> the door alone, <b>and two</b> people <b>locked</b> it, <b>they are liable. And why</b> are they liable? <b>Let them require a measure of trapping for this</b> person <b>and a measure</b> of <b>trapping for that</b> person. <b>Is it not because we say</b> that <b>one measure</b> of trapping is sufficient <b>for them all? Ravina said: We, too, also learned</b> an additional support from a different source. With regard to <b>partners who stole</b> an animal <b>and slaughtered</b> it, <b>they are obligated</b> to pay four or five times its value, as stated in the Torah. <b>And why</b> are they liable? <b>Let them require a measure of slaughtering for this</b> one <b>and a measure</b> of <b>slaughtering for that</b> one. <b>Is it not because we say</b> that <b>one measure</b> of slaughtering is sufficient <b>for them all?</b>
<b>And Rav Ashi said: We, too, also learned</b> an additional support from a similar source. <b>Two</b> people <b>who carried out a weaver’s reed</b> on Shabbat <b>are liable. And why</b> are they liable? <b>Let them require a measure of carrying for this</b> one <b>and a measure</b> of <b>carrying for that</b> one. <b>Is it not because we say</b> that <b>one measure</b> of carrying is sufficient <b>for them all? Rav Aḥa, son</b> of <b>Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> This cannot serve as a proof, for <b>perhaps</b> the rod <b>has a</b> measure equivalent to that which is used <b>to cook an easily-cooked egg for this</b> one <b>and an easily-cooked egg for that</b> one. That is the measure that determines liability for carrying out wood on Shabbat. He answered him: <b>If so, let</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach us</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>an ordinary reed. What is different</b> here that led the <i>baraita</i> to teach the <i>halakha</i> specifically about a <b>weaver’s</b> reed? Rather, the <i>baraita</i> is certainly referring to a reed that is a single unit. Again Rav Aḥa rejects the proof: <b>And perhaps it has a</b> measure equivalent to that which is used <b>to weave a cloth for this</b> one <b>and to weave a cloth for that</b> one. That is the measure that determines liability. <b>Rather,</b> proof <b>cannot be learned from this</b> <i>baraita</i>.
The <i>tanna</i> who recited <i>mishnayot</i> in the study hall <b>taught before Rav Naḥman: Two</b> people <b>who carried out a weaver’s reed</b> on Shabbat <b>are exempt, and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> them <b>liable.</b> Rav Naḥman was surprised at this. He asked: <b>Toward where</b> are you facing? This is the diametric opposite of their opinions. <b>Rather, say</b> an emended <i>baraita</i>: <b>They are liable, and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> them <b>exempt.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who carries out foods less than the measure</b> that determines liability for carrying out food <b>in a vessel</b> on Shabbat <b>is exempt, even for</b> carrying out <b>the vessel, because the vessel is secondary to</b> the food inside it. Since one is not liable for carrying out the food, he is not liable for carrying out the vessel either. Similarly, one who carries out a <b>living</b> person <b>on a bed is exempt, even for</b> carrying out <b>the bed, because the bed is secondary to</b> the person. One who carries out <b>a corpse on a bed is liable. And similarly,</b> one who carries out <b>an olive-bulk of a corpse, or an olive-bulk of an animal carcass, or a lentil-bulk of a creeping animal,</b> which are the minimal measures of these items that transmit ritual impurity, <b>is liable. And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> him <b>exempt.</b> He holds that one is only liable for performing a prohibited labor for its own sake. One who carries out an object in order to bring it to its destination is liable. However, people carry out a corpse or an animal carcass only to be rid of them.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who carries out the measure</b> that determines liability for carrying out <b>foods in a vessel</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable for</b> carrying out <b>the food and exempt for</b> carrying out <b>the vessel. And if that vessel was needed by him</b> for another purpose, <b>he is liable even for</b> carrying out <b>the vessel.</b> The Gemara wonders with regard to the second <i>halakha</i>: Can we <b>conclude from it</b> that one who <b>eats two olive-bulks of forbidden fat in</b> the course of <b>one lapse of awareness is liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings? In that case, one who carries out a vessel with food inside it has performed two actions that fall under the rubric of one prohibited labor. Why should he be liable to bring two sin-offerings? <b>Rav Sheshet said: With what are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b>

Daf 94a

<b>one</b> acted <b>unwittingly</b> with regard <b>to the food and intentionally</b> with regard <b>to the vessel.</b> He is liable to bring a sin-offering for the food and to receive <i>karet</i> for the vessel. <b>Rav Ashi strongly objects to this. Didn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teach:</b> He is liable <b>even for the vessel?</b> Apparently, the liability for the food and the liability for the vessel are identical. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said:</b> This is referring to a case <b>where one</b> acted <b>unwittingly</b> both <b>with regard to this,</b> the food, <b>and with regard to that,</b> the vessel. <b>And he became aware</b> of one transgression, <b>and</b> then <b>he became aware</b> of the other transgression. And the ruling is dependent upon <b>the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish</b> cited above, with regard to the question whether or not one who unwittingly performed a single transgression twice and became aware of each separately is liable to bring two sin-offerings.
We learned in the mishna: One who carries out a <b>living</b> person <b>on a bed is exempt even for</b> carrying out <b>the bed.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>the mishna is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan and not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who carries out a domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, and fowl into the public domain</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable whether</b> they are <b>alive or whether</b> they are <b>slaughtered. Rabbi Natan says: For</b> carrying out <b>slaughtered</b> animals, he is <b>liable, and for</b> carrying out <b>live</b> animals, he is <b>exempt, because a living</b> being <b>carries itself.</b> A living being attempts to lighten the load of the person carrying it and thereby participates in the act of carrying. <b>Rava said:</b> The mishna can be understood <b>even</b> if <b>you say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. The Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Natan only as far as</b> the case of <b>a domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, and fowl</b> is concerned <b>because</b> they deaden their weight in an attempt to <b>free themselves</b> from the one carrying them. <b>However,</b> with regard to the fact <b>that a live person carries himself, even the Rabbis agree.</b> Therefore, one who carries a live person out is exempt.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said to Rava: And</b> with regard to that <b>which we learned</b> in a mishna that it is prohibited to sell work animals to gentiles, to prevent a situation where animals still belonging to a Jew would be lent to a gentile who would perform labor with them on Shabbat, but <b>ben Beteira permits</b> selling <b>a horse</b> to a gentile. <b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Ben Beteira permits</b> selling <b>a horse</b> for riding <b>because</b> the horse <b>is performing an act for which one is not liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> as riding a horse is not actually a prohibited labor. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Ben Beteira and Rabbi Natan said one,</b> the same, <b>thing.</b> They both hold that an animal with a rider on its back is not considered to be bearing a burden. <b>And if you say that the Rabbis only argue with Rabbi Natan</b> with regard to <b>a domesticated animal, an undomesticated animal, and fowl because they</b> deaden their weight in an attempt to <b>free themselves, why</b> did Rabbi Yoḥanan say <b>specifically</b> that <b>ben Beteira and Rabbi Natan</b> agree? <b>Didn’t you say</b> that in the case of a person riding a horse <b>even the Rabbis agree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that ben Beteira and Rabbi Natan said the same thing, he was referring to <b>a horse designated</b> specifically <b>for</b> carrying <b>fowl.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And is there a horse designated for</b> carrying <b>fowl?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, there is</b> the horse for carrying <b>a hunter’s falcons [<i>devei vayadan</i>].</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And Rabbi Natan agrees in</b> the case of a person who is <b>bound</b> because he is unable to lighten the load of the person carrying him. <b>Rav Adda bar Mattana said to Abaye: And</b> what of <b>those Persians who are</b> considered <b>as</b> if they were <b>bound</b> because they don heavy armor and always ride horses, <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Ben Beteira and Rabbi Natan said one thing</b> and permitted selling horses even to Persians? The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> with regard to the Persians, it is not that they are unable to dismount their horses. <b>It is arrogance that keeps them</b> from dismounting their horses. As proof, the Gemara relates: There was <b>that</b> Persian <b>officer [<i>pardashka</i>] at whom the king was angry, and</b> he <b>ran three parasangs on foot.</b> Apparently, even Persian horsemen are not considered bound and are capable of walking without their horses.
We learned in the mishna that according to the first <i>tanna</i>: One who carries out <b>a corpse on a bed is liable. And similarly,</b> one who carries out <b>an olive-bulk of a corpse,</b> or an olive-bulk of an animal carcass, or a lentil-bulk of a creeping animal is liable. Rabbi Shimon deems him exempt. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said, and Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: Rabbi Shimon would deem exempt</b>

Daf 94b

<b>even</b> one who <b>carries out a corpse to bury it. Rava said: And Rabbi Shimon agrees</b> that one who carries out <b>a hoe</b> on Shabbat <b>with which to dig or a Torah scroll from which to read</b> is <b>liable.</b> The Gemara asks: This is <b>obvious, as if those</b> acts of carrying out <b>are also</b> in the category of <b>a prohibited labor not necessary for its own sake</b> because the carrier’s intention is to dig or to read, <b>if so, according to Rabbi Shimon, how can you find</b> an act of carrying that would be considered <b>a prohibited labor necessary for its own sake?</b> The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, there is a novel element in Rava’s statement. <b>Lest you say</b> that Rabbi Shimon deems one liable <b>only</b> in a case <b>where</b> one carries out an object <b>for the sake</b> of the one carrying it, <b>as well as for its own sake,</b> for example, in a case <b>where</b> one carried out <b>a hoe</b> for its own sake, in order <b>to sharpen its blade, and</b> for the sake of the one carrying it, in order <b>to dig</b> with it, or one carried out <b>a Torah scroll</b> for its own sake, in order <b>to emend</b> it, <b>and</b> for the sake of the one carrying it, in order <b>to read from it;</b> therefore, Rava <b>teaches us</b> that Rabbi Shimon deems one liable for carrying out an object even when it is carried only for his own sake and not for the sake of the object.
The Gemara relates: There was <b>a corpse in</b> the city of <b>Derokera</b> and <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak permitted carrying it out into a <i>karmelit</i></b> on Shabbat because, for some reason, it could not remain where it was. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, brother of Mar, son</b> of <b>Rabbana, said to Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak: In accordance with whose</b> opinion did you permit moving the corpse to the <i>karmelit</i>? If it was <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, say that</b> in that case <b>Rabbi Shimon exempted</b> one <b>from</b> the <b>obligation</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering.</b> However, <b>there</b> remains <b>a rabbinic prohibition.</b> Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak <b>said to him: By God, have you entered into</b> an understanding of the matter? <b>Even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda it is permitted</b> to carry out the corpse, <b>as did I say</b> they may carry it out <b>to the public domain? I said</b> that it may be carried out <b>into a <i>karmelit</i>,</b> which is only prohibited by rabbinic law. With regard to prohibitions by rabbinic law, the principle states: <b>Great is human dignity, as it overrides a prohibition in the Torah:</b> “You shall not deviate from that which they tell you to the right or to the left” (Deuteronomy 17:11).
<b>We learned there</b> in a mishna discussing the <i>halakhot</i> of leprosy: <b>One who plucks</b> white hairs that are <b>signs of impurity, and</b> similarly <b>one who burned the unaffected skin</b> in the midst of a leprous sore in an attempt to purify himself, <b>violates a prohibition,</b> as it is stated: “Take heed [<i>hishamer</i>] in the plague of leprosy” (Deuteronomy 24:8). This ruling is based on the principle that the term <i>hishamer</i> indicates a prohibition. On this topic, <b>it was stated:</b> With regard to one who plucks <b>one of two</b> white hairs, everyone agrees that he is <b>liable</b> because a single hair remains, which is less than the measure that determines impurity, i.e., two hairs. It is with regard to one who plucks <b>one of three</b> white hairs that there is a dispute between the <i>amora’im</i>. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> He is <b>liable. Rav Sheshet said:</b> He is <b>exempt.</b> The Gemara elaborates. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> He is <b>liable</b> because <b>his actions were effective, as if another</b> hair <b>is removed,</b> the <b>impurity would cease.</b> He thereby hastened his purification and is in violation of the prohibition. <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> He is <b>exempt</b> because his actions were ineffective, as <b>now, in any case, the impurity is</b> intact even after he removed one hair. His act is ineffective, and therefore he does not violate the prohibition.
<b>Rav Sheshet said: From where do I</b> derive and <b>state</b> my opinion? I derive it <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>And similarly,</b> one who carries out <b>an olive-bulk of a corpse and an olive-bulk of an animal carcass is liable.</b> The Gemara elaborates: By inference, one who carries out <b>half an olive-bulk is exempt. What, is it not taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One who carries out <b>half an olive-bulk</b> of a corpse <b>is liable? Is it not</b> that the contradiction is resolved as follows? That <b>which was taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>He is liable,</b> is referring to a case where one <b>carried out half an olive-bulk from an olive-bulk.</b> Because less than an olive-bulk of the corpse remained, it is no longer a source of ritual impurity. <b>And</b> that <b>which we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>He is exempt,</b> is referring to a case where one <b>carried out half an olive-bulk from an olive-bulk and a half.</b> Since an entire olive-bulk remains, the source of impurity remains intact. <b>And Rav Naḥman</b> explains it differently. Both <b>this,</b> the one who carried out half an olive-bulk from an olive-bulk, <b>and that,</b> the one who carried out half an olive-bulk from an olive-bulk and a half, are <b>liable. And</b> that <b>which we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>He is exempt,</b> is referring to a case where one <b>carried out half an olive-bulk from a large corpse.</b> In that case, even Rav Naḥman agrees that his action was ineffective. Since he did not carry out a measure that determines liability, he is exempt.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who removes his fingernails with one another</b> on Shabbat without scissors, <b>or with his teeth, and the same</b> is true with regard to one who removes <b>his hair</b> with his hands, <b>and the same</b> is true with regard to <b>his mustache, and the same</b> is true with regard to <b>his beard, and the same</b> is true with regard to a woman <b>who braids her hair, and the same</b> is true with regard to one <b>who applies blue</b> eye shadow, <b>and the same</b> is true with regard to one <b>who applies blush, Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> them all <b>liable,</b> as they each performed a labor prohibited by Torah law. <b>And the Rabbis prohibited</b> performing all of these actions <b>due to rabbinic decree.</b> None of the actions constitute prohibited labors.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> is specifically with regard to a case where one removes his fingernails <b>by hand; however,</b> everyone agrees that one is <b>liable</b> if he removes them <b>with a utensil.</b> The Gemara asks: This is <b>obvious. We</b> explicitly <b>learned</b> the phrase: <b>With one another,</b> in the mishna. The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>the Rabbis also exempt</b> one who removes his fingernail <b>with a utensil,</b> i.e., because one is not interested in the removed nail, he did not perform the prohibited labor of shearing, <b>and that which was taught</b> in the mishna: <b>With one another,</b> is intended <b>to convey the far-reaching nature of Rabbi Eliezer’s</b> statement that one is liable even in a case where he removed his fingernails with one another; therefore, Rabbi Elazar <b>teaches us</b> that this is not so.
<b>And Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> is specifically with regard to one who removes fingernails <b>for himself; however,</b> with regard to one removing fingernails <b>for another, everyone agrees</b> that <b>he is exempt.</b> The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious. We</b> explicitly <b>learned</b> the phrase: <b>His fingernails,</b> in the mishna. The Gemara answers: <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> one <b>liable</b> for cutting <b>another’s</b> fingernails <b>as well, and that which was taught</b> in the mishna: <b>His fingernails,</b> is intended <b>to convey the far-reaching nature of the</b> statement of the <b>Rabbis</b> that one is exempt even in a case where he removes his own nails, and all the more so in a case where he removes another’s; therefore, Rabbi Elazar <b>teaches us</b> that everyone agrees that he is exempt when removing another’s nails.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And the same</b> is true with regard to one who removes <b>his hair</b> with his hands; Rabbi Eliezer deems him liable and the Rabbis deem him exempt. One of the Sages <b>taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One who removes</b> enough of his hair <b>to fill the opening of the scissors</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable. And how much</b> is enough <b>to fill the opening of the scissors? Rav Yehuda said: Two</b> hairs. The Gemara asks: <b>But was it not taught</b> later in that <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> with regard to the Torah prohibition against removing one’s hair and causing <b>baldness</b> as an expression of mourning the dead: “Nor make any baldness between your eyes for the dead” (Deuteronomy 14:1), one who removes <b>two</b> hairs is <b>liable?</b> Apparently, enough to fill the opening of a scissors is a different amount of hairs. The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that these are not two different measures. The <i>baraita</i> is saying: <b>And the same</b> is true <b>for baldness, two</b> is the measure.
<b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who removes</b> enough of his hair <b>to fill the opening of the scissors on Shabbat is liable. And how much</b> is enough <b>to fill the opening of the scissors?</b> It is <b>two</b> hairs. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> One is liable for removing even <b>one</b> hair. <b>And the Sages agree with Rabbi Eliezer</b> that <b>one</b> who <b>collects</b> and plucks <b>white</b> hairs <b>from among black</b> ones <b>is liable even</b> if he removed <b>a single</b> hair. His actions indicate that one hair is significant for him. <b>And this matter</b> of plucking white hairs <b>is prohibited</b> for men <b>even on weekdays, as it is stated:</b> “A woman shall not don a man’s clothes, <b>and a man shall not wear a woman’s garment”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:5). The Sages derive that any action typically performed by women for beautification is prohibited for men.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> With regard to <b>a fingernail, the majority of which has been severed,</b> and it is only connected to the finger by a small piece; <b>and</b> with regard to <b>shreds</b> of skin, <b>the majority of which have been severed</b> from the body; <b>by hand,</b> one <b>is permitted</b> to completely remove them on Shabbat. If he removes them <b>with a utensil, he is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> The Gemara wonders: <b>Is there any matter</b> where one who performs an action <b>with a utensil is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, and</b> if he performs that action <b>by hand, it is permitted <i>ab initio</i>,</b> and it is not even prohibited by rabbinic decree? The Gemara answers: <b>This is what</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar meant <b>to say:</b> If <b>the majority has been severed,</b> removing the rest <b>by hand is permitted.</b> If he removes the rest <b>with a utensil</b> he is <b>exempt,</b> but <b>it is prohibited</b> to do so <i>ab initio</i>. And if the <b>majority has not</b> yet <b>been severed,</b> if he removes the rest <b>by hand</b> he is <b>exempt,</b> but <b>it is prohibited</b> to do so <i>ab initio</i>. If he did so <b>with a utensil,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering. Rav Yehuda said: The <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar</b> in this matter. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And that is if the</b> partially severed portions of the fingernail <b>were severed facing upward</b> near the nail <b>and cause him pain;</b> in that case one may remove them <i>ab initio</i>.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And the same</b> is true with regard to a woman <b>who braids her hair,</b> and one who applies blue eye shadow, and one who applies blush; Rabbi Eliezer deems them liable by Torah law. The Gemara asks: <b>For</b> performance of <b>what</b> prohibited labor is a woman <b>who braids her hair,</b> or <b>who applies blue</b> eye shadow, <b>or who</b> applies <b>blush</b> on Shabbat <b>liable? Rabbi Avin said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> A woman <b>who braids her hair</b> is liable <b>due to weaving,</b> as braiding and weaving are similar actions. A woman <b>who applies blue</b> eye shadow is liable <b>due to writing.</b> A woman <b>who applies blush</b> is liable <b>due to spinning.</b> Women would make a string from a doughy substance and pass it over their faces to redden their complexion. <b>The Rabbis said before Rabbi Abbahu: And is that the</b> typical <b>manner of weaving, and is that the</b> typical <b>manner of writing, and is that the</b> typical <b>manner of spinning?</b> Rabbi Eliezer would certainly agree that one who performs a prohibited labor in an atypical manner is exempt. <b>Rather, Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> This matter was <b>explained to me</b> by <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> himself.

Daf 95a

A woman <b>who applies eye shadow</b> is liable <b>due to dyeing;</b> one <b>who braids her hair and applies blush</b> is liable due to the prohibition against <b>building.</b> The Gemara asks about this: <b>And is that the</b> typical <b>manner of building?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> braiding one’s hair is considered building, <b>as Rabbi Shimon ben Menasya taught</b> that the verse states: <b>“And the Lord God built the side</b> that He took from Adam into a woman” (Genesis 2:22), which <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, braided Eve’s</b> hair <b>and brought her to Adam.</b> From where is it derived that this is the meaning of built? It is <b>because in the islands of the sea they call braiding building. It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> With regard to a woman <b>who braids her hair</b> and <b>who applies eye shadow or blush</b> on Shabbat, if she did it <b>for herself, she is exempt;</b> if she did it <b>for another, she is liable.</b> This is because a woman cannot perform these actions for herself in as complete a fashion as she can for someone else. <b>And, so too, Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar would say in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: A woman may not apply rouge to her face</b> on Shabbat <b>because</b> by doing so <b>she is dyeing,</b> which is one of the prohibited labors on Shabbat.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who milks</b> an animal, <b>and one who sets milk</b> to curdle, <b>and one who makes cheese,</b> in the measure of a <b>dried fig-bulk, and one who sweeps</b> the house, <b>and one who sprinkles</b> water on the floor, <b>and one who removes honeycombs,</b> if he did so <b>unwittingly on Shabbat,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> If he did so <b>intentionally on a Festival, he receives forty</b> lashes; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. And the Rabbis say: Both this,</b> on Shabbat <b>and that,</b> on a Festival, these actions <b>are only</b> prohibited <b>due to a rabbinic decree,</b> not by Torah law. Therefore, one is neither liable to bring a sin-offering nor to receive lashes for performing those actions.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Naḥman bar Gurya happened</b> to come <b>to Neharde’a.</b> The students <b>asked him: For what</b> prohibited labor <b>is one who milks liable?</b> He <b>said to them: For milking. For what</b> prohibited labor <b>is one who sets milk</b> to curdle <b>liable?</b> He <b>said to them: For setting milk</b> to curdle. <b>For what is a person who makes cheese liable?</b> He <b>said to them: For making cheese.</b> They <b>said to him: Your teacher was a reed cutter in a swamp</b> who did not know how to explain the mishna to his students. <b>He came</b> and <b>asked</b> those questions <b>in the study hall.</b> They <b>said to him: One who milks is liable for</b> performing the prohibited labor of <b>extracting,</b> which is a subcategory of threshing, on Shabbat. This is because when one extracts milk from a cow it is similar to the act of threshing, where one removes the desired content from its covering. <b>One who sets milk is liable for</b> the prohibited labor of <b>selecting</b> because part of the milk is separated and made into congealed milk. And <b>one who makes cheese is liable for building</b> because the cheese within the milk assumes a solid form, which is similar to the process of building.
The <i>baraita</i> cited above taught: With regard to <b>one who sweeps</b> the house, and <b>one who sprinkles</b> water on the floor, <b>and one who removes honeycombs,</b> if he did so <b>unwittingly on Shabbat,</b> he is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b> If he did so <b>intentionally on a Festival, he receives forty</b> lashes; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Elazar said: What is the rationale for</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Eliezer?</b> His rationale is <b>as it is written:</b> “And he put forth the end of the rod that was in his hand <b>and dipped it in the honeycomb [<i>yarat hadevash</i>]”</b> (i Samuel 14:27). The Gemara wonders: <b>What does a forest [<i>ya’ar</i>] have to do with honey [<i>devash</i>]? Rather,</b> it comes <b>to tell you: Just as</b> with regard to <b>a forest, one who picks from</b> a tree <b>on Shabbat is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, so too,</b> with regard to <b>a honeycomb, one who removes</b> honey <b>from it on Shabbat is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Ameimar permitted sprinkling water in</b> the city of <b>Meḥoza. He said: What is the reason</b> that <b>the Rabbis said</b> it is prohibited to sprinkle water? It was due to concern <b>lest one come to smooth out holes</b> in an unpaved floor. <b>Here,</b> in Meḥoza, <b>there are no holes</b> in the floor because all the houses have stone floors. The Gemara also relates: <b>Rava Tosfa’a,</b> an expert on the <i>Tosefta</i>, <b>found that Ravina was suffering</b> on Shabbat <b>from</b> the dusty <b>hot air</b> in the house. <b>And some say</b> that <b>Mar Kashisha, son</b> of <b>Rava, found that Rav Ashi was suffering from the</b> dusty <b>hot air.</b> Mar Kashisha <b>said to</b> Rav Ashi: <b>And does my Master not hold</b> in accordance with <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>that was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who wishes to sprinkle</b> water on the floor of <b>his house on Shabbat,</b> where it is otherwise prohibited, <b>brings a large basin full of water, and washes his face in this corner,</b> then moves the basin and washes <b>his hands in this corner, his feet in this corner, and it will eventuate that the</b> floor of the entire <b>house is sprinkled by itself</b> from the water that splashed in a backhanded manner? Rav Ashi <b>said to him: It did not enter my mind</b> to employ that method.
One of the Sages <b>taught: A wise woman sprinkles</b> water on the floor of <b>her house on Shabbat</b> by washing different vessels in different parts of the house. <b>And now that we hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who maintains that it is permitted to perform an unintentional act on Shabbat, <b>it is permitted</b> to sweep and sprinkle water on the floor of a house on Shabbat <b>even <i>ab initio</i>,</b> because one’s intention is not to smooth the holes in the floor.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who severs</b> a leaf or a fruit <b>from</b> a plant growing in <b>a perforated flowerpot</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable,</b> as a plant in a flowerpot with holes in it has the legal status of a plant connected to the ground. Picking from it is prohibited due to reaping. <b>And</b> one who picks from an <b>imperforated</b> pot <b>is exempt,</b> but it is prohibited to do so <i>ab initio</i>. <b>And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> one who does so <b>exempt in</b> both <b>this,</b> the case of the perforated flowerpot, <b>and that,</b> the case of the imperforated flowerpot.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> Abaye raised a contradiction before Rava, and some say <b>it was</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Rav <b>who raised the contradiction before</b> Rav: <b>On the one hand,</b> we learned <b>in the mishna that</b> Rabbi Shimon deems <b>one</b> exempt in <b>both</b> this <b>case</b> and that <b>case.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Shimon equates <b>a</b> perforated <b>pot with</b> an imperforated <b>pot. And</b> they raised a contradiction: Rabbi Shimon says: The only difference between a perforated <b>pot</b> and an imperforated <b>pot</b>

Daf 95b

is with regard <b>to rendering seeds capable</b> of becoming ritually impure. Seeds that are in a perforated pot have the legal status of seeds planted in the ground and, as such, cannot become ritually impure. Seeds that are in an imperforated pot are considered detached from the ground and can become ritually impure. Apparently, in other areas of <i>halakha</i>, Rabbi Shimon holds that a plant in a perforated pot has the legal status of a plant in the ground (<i>Me’iri</i>). He <b>said to him: With</b> regard to <b>all matters</b> of <i>halakha</i>, <b>Rabbi Shimon equates</b> the status of a perforated pot <b>with</b> that of being <b>detached.</b> However, <b>the matter of impurity is different, as the Torah amplified purity with regard to seeds, as it is stated:</b> “And if anything falls from their carcasses <b>upon any sowing seed that is sown,</b> it is pure” (Leviticus 11:37). The repetitive language: “Any sowing seed that is sown” teaches that any seed that can be characterized as sowing, including one growing in a perforated pot, remains pure. However, in other areas of <i>halakha</i>, the status of a perforated pot is equal to that of an imperforated pot.
<b>A certain Elder raised a dilemma before Rabbi Zeira:</b> In a case where the <b>root</b> of a plant in a perforated pot is <b>opposite</b> the <b>hole, what</b> would <b>Rabbi Shimon say</b> in terms of whether or not it is considered attached to the ground? <b>He was silent and did not say anything to him.</b> The Gemara relates that <b>once</b> the same Elder <b>found</b> Rabbi Zeira, <b>who was sitting and saying: And Rabbi Shimon agrees that if the hole</b> in the flowerpot is large <b>enough to render it</b> ritually <b>pure,</b> i.e., unable to hold olives, it is considered attached to the earth with regard to Shabbat. He <b>said to him: Now, I raised a dilemma before you</b> as to Rabbi Shimon’s ruling in a case where the <b>root</b> is <b>opposite</b> the <b>hole, and you did not say anything to me.</b> With regard to a case where the root is not actually opposite the hole, but <b>its hole is large enough to render it pure, do you need to tell me</b> that the dilemma whether or not it is considered detached is unresolved? Rather, this must certainly be understood differently.
<b>Abaye said: And if</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Zeira</b> that Rabbi Shimon holds that a perforated pot is considered attached to the ground, <b>was stated, it was stated as follows: And Rabbi Shimon agrees that if</b> the pot <b>was perforated below</b> the level where it could hold <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>, it is no longer considered a vessel, and the plants are considered attached to the ground.
Apropos the purification of an earthenware vessel, the Gemara cites that <b>Rava said: Five measures</b> were stated with regard to holes <b>in an earthenware vessel:</b> If it <b>was perforated</b> with a small hole from which <b>liquid seeps, it is</b> no longer a vessel and is <b>ritually pure</b> in terms of the <b>impurity</b> of <b>a shard.</b> Certain shards of impure earthenware vessels remain impure if they can still be used. If it has a hole, even a small one that liquids can flow through, it can no longer transmit ritual impurity. However, <b>it remains a</b> complete <b>vessel in which to sanctify</b> the <b>purification waters</b> of the red heifer, which require a whole vessel. And if <b>it was perforated</b> with a hole large enough <b>to enable liquid to enter</b> the vessel, <b>it is ritually pure</b> in terms of <b>sanctifying the purification waters in it, but it remains a vessel</b> in terms <b>of rendering seeds in it capable</b> of becoming ritually impure. And if <b>it was perforated</b> with a hole the size of <b>a small root, it is ritually pure</b> in terms <b>of rendering seeds in it capable</b> of becoming ritually impure, <b>but it remains a vessel</b> that can become ritually impure in terms of <b>holding olives.</b> And if <b>it was perforated</b> with a hole large enough <b>to enable olives to go out, it is pure</b> in terms of the impurity of all other vessels that can <b>hold olives, but it remains a vessel</b> in terms of <b>holding pomegranates.</b> If the vessel is designated for use in holding pomegranates, it can become ritually impure because it is suitable for that use. If <b>it was perforated</b> with a hole large enough <b>to enable pomegranates to go out, it is ritually pure from any</b> type of impurity. <b>And if</b> the mouth of an earthenware vessel that is in a room with a corpse <b>is surrounded</b> by <b>a sealed cover,</b> it does not become ritually pure, even if its hole was large enough to enable a pomegranate to go out. It protects whatever is inside the vessel from contracting impurity, <b>unless the majority of</b> the vessel <b>is broken.</b>
<b>Rav Asi said: I heard</b> that with regard to <b>an earthenware vessel,</b> the <b>measure</b> of the hole that renders it unable to become ritually impure is large enough <b>to enable a pomegranate to go out. Rava said to him: Perhaps you only heard this</b> when <b>its</b> mouth <b>is surrounded</b> by <b>a sealed cover,</b> but an ordinary earthenware vessel becomes ritually pure with a hole big enough to enable an olive to go out. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t Rava</b> himself <b>the one</b> who <b>said</b> that an earthenware vessel that is <b>surrounded by a sealed cover</b> protects whatever is inside the vessel from contracting impurity <b>unless the majority of</b> the vessel <b>is broken?</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult.</b>

Daf 96a

<b>This</b> statement, that a hole must be large enough to enable a pomegranate to go out in order to purify the vessel, is referring to <b>large</b> vessels. <b>And this</b> statement, that teaches that a vessel is purified only when the majority of the vessel is broken, is referring <b>to small</b> vessels. <b>Rav Asi said</b> that <b>they teach</b> this <i>halakha</i>: With regard to <b>an earthenware vessel,</b> the <b>measure</b> of the hole that renders it unable to become ritually impure is large enough <b>to enable liquid to enter it. And they only said:</b> The measure of a small hole from which <b>liquid seeps,</b> with regard to the <b>impurity</b> of <b>a shard [<i>gistera</i>].</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? The Gemara answers that <b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Naḥman, said:</b> A shard is used as a plate beneath a perforated earthenware vessel. If the shard is also perforated and leaks, it is no longer of any use. <b>Because one does not say: Bring</b> another <b>shard to</b> seal the leak of a <b>shard,</b> but throws it out immediately.
<b>Ulla said: Two <i>amora’im</i> in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>disagree</b> about <b>this</b> topic: They are <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Avin, and Rabbi Yosei bar Zavda. One said:</b> The measure of a hole that purifies an earthenware vessel is large enough <b>to enable a pomegranate to go out. And one said:</b> The size of <b>a small root. And your mnemonic</b> to remember that neither holds that the measure is size of an olive is the expression: <b>Both one who increases and one who decreases.</b> They hold extreme positions in this dispute and eschew the intermediate position. <b>Rav Ḥinnana bar Kahana said</b> an intermediate position <b>in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: An earthenware vessel</b> becomes ritually pure with a hole <b>large enough to enable olives to go out. And Mar Kashisha, son of Rabba, concluded</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: And</b> vessels that have been perforated <b>are like dung vessels, and</b> so too, <b>stone vessels and earth vessels</b> that were not baked in a kiln, <b>which neither become impure by Torah law nor by rabbinic law. And,</b> as far as <b>the matter of</b> an earthenware vessel with <b>a sealed cover</b> in a room with a corpse, it maintains its impurity <b>until the majority of it is broken.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who throws</b> an object on Shabbat <b>from the private domain to the public domain</b> or <b>from the public domain to the private domain is liable.</b> However, one who throws an object <b>from the private domain to the</b> other <b>private domain, and</b> the object passes through <b>the public domain between</b> the two, <b>Rabbi Akiva deems him liable</b> for carrying into the public domain, <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt.</b>
<b>How so?</b> If there are <b>two balconies</b> [<b><i>gezuztra’ot</i></b>] that are private domains <b>opposite each other on</b> either side of <b>the public domain, one who passes or throws</b> an object <b>from</b> the one on <b>this</b> side <b>to the</b> one on <b>that</b> side <b>is exempt.</b> However, if the balconies <b>were on the same level</b> on the same side of the public thoroughfare, and the public domain separated the two, <b>one who passes</b> from one to the other <b>is liable, and one who throws is exempt, as that</b> method, passing, <b>was the service of the Levites</b> who carried the beams of the Tabernacle.
In the Tabernacle, <b>two wagons</b> along the same level stood <b>behind one another in the public domain,</b> and the Levites <b>passed the beams from one</b> wagon <b>to the other</b> through the public domain on the same side of a thoroughfare. <b>But they did not throw</b> from one wagon to another because the beams were heavy. Passing, which was performed in the Tabernacle, is prohibited. Throwing, which was not performed in the Tabernacle, is not prohibited.

Daf 96b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the main issue<b>,</b> the Gemara asks: <b>After all, throwing is a subcategory</b> of <b>carrying out. Where is</b> the primary category of prohibited labor of <b>carrying out itself written</b> in the Torah? Isn’t it necessary to clarify the primary category before discussing the subcategory? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: As the verse said: “And Moses commanded, and they passed a proclamation throughout the camp</b> saying: Neither man nor woman should perform any more work to contribute to the Sanctuary; and the people stopped bringing” (Exodus 36<b>:</b>6). According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, Moses commanded the people to cease bringing contributions in order to prevent them from bringing their contributions on Shabbat. He then explains<b>: Where was Moses sitting?</b> He was <b>in the camp of the Levites, and the Levites’ camp was the public domain. And he said to Israel: Do not carry out and bring</b> objects <b>from the private domain,</b> your camp, <b>to the public domain,</b> the camp of the Levites.
The Gemara asks: <b>And how do</b> you know that <b>he was standing</b> and commanding the people <b>on Shabbat? Perhaps he was standing during the week, and</b> Moses commanded the cessation of contributions <b>because the labor</b> of the Tabernacle <b>was completed,</b> since all the necessary material was already donated, <b>as it is written: “And the work was sufficient for them</b> for all of the work to perform it, and there was extra” (Exodus 36:7). Rather, <b>derive</b> this by means of a verbal analogy between <b>passing</b> mentioned in this context and <b>passing</b> mentioned with regard to <b>Yom Kippur.</b>
<b>It is written here,</b> with regard to the Tabernacle: <b>“And they passed a proclamation throughout the camp,” and it is written there,</b> with regard to Yom Kippur: <b>“And you shall pass a blast of a <i>shofar</i></b> on the tenth day of the seventh month, on Yom Kippur you shall sound a shofar throughout your land” (Leviticus 25:9). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the <i>shofar</i> of the Jubilee Year, passing is <b>on a day</b> on which it is <b>prohibited</b> to perform labor, <b>so too, here</b> passing is <b>on a day</b> on which it is <b>prohibited</b> to perform labor.
The Gemara asks: <b>We found</b> a source prohibiting <b>carrying out</b> from a private domain into the camp of the Levites. <b>From where do we</b> derive that <b>carrying in</b> is also considered a prohibited labor? The Gemara answers: <b>It is a logical inference. After all,</b> carrying is <b>from one domain to another,</b> so <b>what</b> difference <b>is</b> there <b>to me</b> whether it is <b>carrying out or carrying in?</b> Carrying from one domain to another is prohibited; the direction in which the object is carried makes no difference. <b>However, carrying out</b> is a <b>primary category,</b> while <b>carrying in</b> is a <b>subcategory,</b> as it is not stated explicitly in the biblical text.
The Gemara now questions the distinction between primary categories and subcategories of labor. <b>After all, one is liable for this,</b> carrying out, <b>and one is liable for that,</b> carrying in. <b>Why</b> is <b>this called</b> a <b>primary category, and why</b> is <b>this called a subcategory?</b> What is the point of the distinction?
The Gemara answers: The practical <b>ramification is that if one performs two</b> different <b>primary categories together,</b> or <b>alternatively,</b> if one performs <b>two subcategories</b> of two different primary categories <b>together, he is liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings. <b>And if one performs a primary category</b> of labor together <b>with its own subcategory, he is liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering.
The Gemara further asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who <b>renders one liable for</b> the performance of <b>a subcategory</b> of prohibited labor when performed <b>together with a primary category, why</b> is <b>this called</b> a <b>primary category, and why</b> is <b>this called a subcategory?</b> The Gemara answers: According to him, <b>that which was a significant labor in the Tabernacle is called a primary category; that which was not a significant labor in the Tabernacle is not called a primary category. Alternatively,</b> perhaps <b>that which is written</b> explicitly in the Torah <b>is called a primary category, and that which is not written</b> explicitly in the Torah <b>is called a subcategory.</b>
<b>And</b> as for the <i>halakha</i> <b>that we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who throws</b> an object on Shabbat a distance of <b>four cubits</b> in the public domain and it lands <b>on a wall,</b> if the wall was <b>higher than ten handbreadths,</b> it is <b>as if he threw it into the air,</b> and he is exempt. If the wall was <b>lower than ten handbreadths,</b> it is <b>as if he threw it onto the ground, and one who throws an object</b> a distance of <b>four cubits onto the ground</b> in the public domain <b>is liable.</b>
The Gemara asks: If <b>one threw</b> an object <b>four cubits in the public domain,</b> and it did not go from one domain to another, <b>from where do we</b> derive <b>that he is liable?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yoshiya said: Because the weavers of</b> the <b>tapestries</b> in the Tabernacle <b>throw their needles to each other</b> when they need to borrow the other’s needle. Throwing was a labor performed in the Tabernacle; therefore, one is liable for performing it. The Gemara wonders: <b>Why do weavers</b> need <b>needles? Rather,</b> emend the statement to say: <b>Because those who sewed</b> the <b>tapestries throw their needles to each other.</b>
The Gemara asks: Is it clear that they had to throw needles to each other? <b>Perhaps they sat next to each other.</b> The Gemara answers: It is clear that they kept their distance from each other. If they sat too close, <b>they would reach each other</b> and hurt one another <b>with</b> their <b>needles.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Perhaps,</b> even though they kept their distance, they <b>sat within four cubits</b> of each other, and they would not throw the needles farther than that. In the absence of proof of their sitting arrangement, this <i>halakha</i> cannot be derived from those who sewed the tapestries.
<b>Rather, Rav Ḥisda said:</b> Throwing an object four cubits in the public domain is prohibited <b>because the weavers of</b> the <b>tapestries</b> in the Tabernacle <b>threw the shuttle,</b> to which the thread of the warp was tied <b>on the tapestry.</b> Weaving entails throwing the thread of the warp through the threads of the woof. The Gemara asks: That is not actually throwing, <b>as didn’t</b> the weaver <b>hold</b> the end of the thread <b>in his hand?</b> One is not liable for throwing an object when part of it remains in his hand. Rather, this must be referring to <b>the final throw,</b> when the weaving was finished and the weaver released the thread from his hand.
The Gemara asks: <b>Doesn’t</b> the shuttle <b>go in an exempt domain?</b> The tapestry was less than four handbreadths wide, rendering it an exempt domain even though it is four cubits long. One who throws in an exempt domain is exempt. <b>Rather, it is because the weavers of tapestries throw the shuttle to those who</b> seek to <b>borrow</b> it from them. The Gemara asks: <b>But perhaps they sat next to each other?</b> The Gemara answers: That is impossible because <b>they would reach one another</b> and disturb one another when tightening the thread at <b>the end</b> of the tapestry.
The Gemara asks: <b>And perhaps they were</b> not in a straight line but <b>staggered.</b> That would enable the weavers to sit adjacent to each other without disturbing each other’s work. <b>And furthermore, did they borrow from each another? Wasn’t</b> the following <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> of the Sage <b>Luda?</b> The verse states: “And all the wise men who performed all of the work of the Sanctuary came, <b>each one from the work he was doing”</b> (Exodus 36:4). From that verse it is derived: Each <b>performed</b> the labor <b>from his own work, and they would not perform</b> the labor <b>from their friends’ work.</b> Each person had his own tools and did not need to borrow from others.
<b>And furthermore,</b> the Gemara asks: <b>Even</b> if the <i>halakha</i> of throwing was derived from here, <b>from where do we</b> derive that <b>one who carries</b> an object <b>four cubits in the public domain is liable?</b> Rather, apparently, this <i>halakha</i> is not derived from the labor performed in the construction of the Tabernacle. <b>Rather, all</b> the <i>halakhot</i> related to carrying <b>four cubits in the public domain are learned through tradition</b> and not derived from the text.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The wood gatherer</b> who was sentenced to death for desecrating Shabbat (see Numbers 15:33–36) <b>was one who carried four cubits in the public domain.</b> He was stoned for performing the prohibited labor of carrying. <b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: He was one who detached</b> still-growing branches. He was stoned for performing the prohibited labor of detaching. <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rabbi Ya’akov, said: He was one who gathered</b> sticks together into a pile.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> practical <b>ramification</b> of determining precisely which prohibited labor the wood gatherer performed? The Gemara answers: The ramification is <b>with regard to</b> the statement of <b>Rav, as Rav said: I found a hidden scroll in the house of Rabbi Ḥiyya. And in it, it is written</b> that <b>Isi ben Yehuda says:</b> The number of <b>primary categories of labor</b> prohibited on Shabbat is <b>forty-less-one. And if one performed all</b> of them <b>in</b> the course of <b>one lapse of awareness, he is liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering. The Gemara asks: <b>One and no more? We learned</b> in a mishna: The number of <b>primary categories of prohibited labors</b> on Shabbat is <b>forty-less-one,</b> which the mishna proceeds to list. <b>And we discussed</b> this mishna: <b>Why do I need</b> this <b>tally</b> of forty-less-one? <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The tally was included to teach <b>that if one performed all</b> the prohibited labors <b>in</b> the course of <b>one lapse of awareness,</b> during which he was unaware of the prohibition involved, <b>he is liable for each and every one.</b>
This citation from the hidden scroll cannot be accurate. Rather, emend this statement in the hidden scroll and <b>say</b> that <b>one is not liable for one</b> of them. There is a primary category of labor among the thirty-nine primary categories of prohibited labor whose violation does not incur the death penalty. The identity of this category that is not punishable by death was not specified.
<b>It is obvious to Rav Yehuda</b> that <b>one who carries</b> four cubits in the public domain <b>is liable</b> to receive the death penalty. <b>And it is obvious to</b> the <b><i>baraita</i></b> that <b>one who detaches is liable</b> to receive the death penalty. <b>And it is obvious to Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov</b> that <b>one who gathers is liable</b> to receive the death penalty. In other words, this <b>Master maintains:</b> With regard to <b>this</b> labor, <b>in any case, there is no uncertainty. And this Master maintains:</b> With regard to <b>that</b> labor, <b>in any case, there is no uncertainty.</b> Each Sage maintains that the prohibited labor that he attributed to the wood gatherer incurs the death penalty and is certainly not the labor referred to in the hidden scroll.
On the topic of the wood gatherer, the Gemara cites that which <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The wood gatherer</b> mentioned in the Torah was <b>Zelophehad, and it says: “And the children of Israel were in the desert and they found a man</b> gathering wood on the day of Shabbat” (Numbers 15:32), <b>and below,</b> in the appeal of the daughters of Zelophehad, <b>it is stated: “Our father died in the desert</b> and he was not among the company of them that gathered themselves together against the Lord in the company of Korah, but he died in his own sin, and he had no sons” (Numbers 27:3). <b>Just as below</b> the man in the desert is <b>Zelophehad, so too, here,</b> in the case of the wood gatherer, the unnamed man in the desert is <b>Zelophehad;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira said to him: Akiva, in either case you will be judged in the future</b> for this teaching. <b>If</b> the truth is <b>in accordance with your statement</b> that the wood gatherer was Zelophehad, <b>the Torah concealed</b> his identity, <b>and you reveal it. And if</b> it the truth is not in accordance with your statement, <b>you are</b> unjustly <b>slandering that righteous man.</b>

Daf 97a

The Gemara asks: <b>However, didn’t</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>derive</b> this by means of <b>a verbal analogy?</b> The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira <b>did not learn a verbal analogy.</b> Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira had no tradition of this verbal analogy from his teachers, and therefore he disagreed with Rabbi Akiva’s conclusion. The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> according to Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira, <b>from where was</b> Zelophehad’s liability derived? Why was he executed? The Gemara answers: Zelophehad was among those who <b>“presumed</b> to ascend to the top of the mountain” (Numbers 14:44) in the wake of the sin of the spies.
<b>On a similar note,</b> Rabbi Akiva revealed an additional matter not explicitly articulated in the Torah. <b>You say</b> that when Aaron and Miriam spoke against Moses, both Aaron and Miriam were struck with leprosy, as it written: <b>“And God became angry at them and He left,</b> and the cloud departed from above the tent, and behold, Miriam was leprous like snow. And Aaron turned toward Miriam, and behold, she was leprous” (Numbers 12:9–10). The verse’s statement that God became angry at both of them <b>teaches that Aaron, too, became leprous;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva. Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira said to him: Akiva, in either case you will be judged in the future</b> for this teaching. <b>If</b> the truth is <b>in accordance with your statement, the Torah concealed</b> Aaron’s punishment <b>and you reveal it. And if</b> the truth is not in accordance with your statement, <b>you are</b> unjustly <b>slandering that righteous man.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>However, didn’t</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>derive</b> this from the plural pronoun <b>them,</b> meaning that God was angry with both of them? The Gemara answers: God’s anger in <b>that</b> verse was manifest in <b>a mere rebuke,</b> not in leprosy. A <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, <b>who said</b> that <b>Aaron also became leprous, as it is written: “And Aaron turned toward Miriam, and behold, she was leprous”</b> (Numbers 12:10), and it was <b>taught:</b> This teaches <b>that he turned,</b> i.e., he was healed, <b>from his leprosy,</b> as he too had been afflicted.
On the topic of Miriam’s leprosy, the Gemara cites that which <b>Reish Lakish said: One who suspects the innocent</b> of indiscretion <b>is afflicted in his body, as it is written:</b> “And Moses answered and said: <b>But they will not believe me</b> and will not hearken to my voice, for they will say, God did not appear to you” (Exodus 4:1), <b>and it is revealed before the Holy One, Blessed be He, that the Jewish people would believe.</b> The Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>said to</b> Moses: <b>They are believers, the children of believers; and ultimately, you will not believe.</b>
<b>They are believers, as it is written: “And the people believed</b> once they heard that God had remembered the children of Israel, and that He saw their affliction, and they bowed and they prostrated” (Exodus 4:31). <b>The children of believers,</b> as it says with regard to Abraham our Patriarch: <b>“And he believed in God,</b> and He counted it for him as righteousness” (Genesis 15:6). <b>Ultimately, you will not believe, as it is stated:</b> “And God said to Moses and to Aaron: <b>Because you did not believe in Me</b> to sanctify Me in the eyes of the children of Israel” (Numbers 20:12). <b>From where</b> do we know that Moses <b>was afflicted</b> in his body? <b>As it is written: “And God said to him further: Bring your hand to your bosom,</b> and he brought his hand to his bosom and he took it out and behold, his hand was leprous like snow” (Exodus 4:6).
On this topic, <b>Rava said, and some say</b> that it was <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina,</b> who said: The divine <b>attribute of beneficence takes effect more quickly than the</b> divine <b>attribute of punishment.</b> From where is this derived? <b>While, with regard to the</b> divine <b>attribute of punishment, it is written, “And he took it out and behold, his hand was leprous like snow”</b> (Exodus 4:6), <b>with regard to the</b> divine <b>attribute of beneficence it is written:</b> “And He said: Return your hand to your bosom, and he returned his hand to his bosom <b>and he took it out from his bosom and behold, it had returned to be like his original flesh”</b> (Exodus 4:7). The Gemara analyzes this as follows: It was already <b>from his bosom</b> that <b>it returned to be like his original flesh.</b> Moses’ hand was healed even before he took his hand out.
The Gemara proceeds to discuss another miracle that transpired at that time. With regard to the verse, “And each man threw down his staff and they became serpents, <b>and Aaron’s staff swallowed their staffs”</b> (Exodus 7:12), <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> This was <b>a miracle within a miracle.</b> It was Aaron’s staff, not his serpent, that swallowed the other staffs.
We learned in the mishna that there is a dispute between Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis in a case where one threw an object <b>from the private domain to the</b> other <b>private domain</b> through the public domain between the two. Rabbi Akiva deems him liable, as one who threw an object from the private domain to the public domain, and the Rabbis deem him exempt.
<b>Rabba raised a dilemma</b> with regard to their dispute: <b>Are they disagreeing</b> with regard to a case where the object traveled <b>below ten</b> handbreadths from the ground? <b>And,</b> if so, <b>it is with regard to this</b> point <b>that they disagree: As this Master,</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>holds: We say</b> that <b>an object in airspace is considered at rest.</b> The object is considered as if it was actually placed in the public domain after being lifted from the private domain. <b>And this Master,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds: We do not say</b> that <b>an object in airspace is considered at rest. However,</b> with regard to a case where the object traveled <b>above ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, <b>everyone agrees</b> that one is <b>exempt, and we do not derive</b> the legal status of <b>throwing from</b> the legal status of <b>passing.</b> Although everyone agrees that one who passes an object from a private domain to another private domain via a public domain is liable, even if it was passed above ten handbreadths, as that was the service of the Levites, one who throws an object in that manner is exempt.
<b>Or perhaps, they are disagreeing</b> with regard to a case where the object traveled <b>above ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, and <b>it is with regard to this that they disagree: As this Master,</b> Rabbi Akiva, <b>holds: We derive</b> the legal status of <b>throwing from</b> the legal status of <b>passing.</b> Therefore, one who throws an object that passes through the airspace of a public domain higher than ten handbreadths from the ground is liable. <b>And this Master,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, <b>holds: We do not derive throwing from passing. However,</b> with regard to a case where the object traveled <b>beneath</b> the <b>ten</b> handbreadth airspace of the public domain, <b>everyone agrees</b> that he is <b>liable. What is the reason</b> for that? <b>An object in airspace is considered at rest.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: Rav Ḥisda had a dilemma</b> with regard to <b>this matter, and Rav Hamnuna resolved it for him from this</b> <i>baraita</i>: With regard to an object that travels <b>from the private domain to the</b> other <b>private domain, and it passes through the public domain itself, Rabbi Akiva deems</b> one <b>liable and the Rabbis deem</b> one <b>exempt. From the fact that it says</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Through the public domain itself, it is obvious</b> that it is <b>with regard to</b> a case where the object traveled below <b>ten</b> handbreadths from the ground <b>that they disagree.</b>
<b>And with regard to what</b> form of transfer is the <i>baraita</i> dealing? <b>If you say</b> it refers to <b>passing</b> an object in his hand, is it only when he passes it <b>below ten</b> handbreadths that <b>he is liable?</b> When he passes it <b>above ten</b> handbreadths <b>is he not liable? Didn’t Rabbi Elazar say: One who carries out a load</b> from a private domain to a public domain <b>above ten</b> handbreadths from the ground <b>is liable, as that was the</b> manner in which <b>the descendants of Kehat,</b> from whom we derived the laws of carrying, carried their <b>burden</b> in the Tabernacle? <b>Rather, isn’t</b> this <i>baraita</i> referring to a case <b>of throwing, and it is</b> in a case where the object travels <b>below ten</b> handbreadths from the ground <b>that one is liable,</b> and <b>above ten</b> handbreadths from the ground <b>one is not liable? Learn from it</b> that it is <b>with regard to</b> whether or not <b>an object in airspace is considered at rest</b> that <b>they disagree.</b> The Gemara summarizes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that this is the crux of their dispute.
<b>And</b> this conclusion <b>disagrees</b> with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, as Rabbi Elazar said: Rabbi Akiva deems</b> one <b>liable even</b> if the object travels <b>above ten</b> handbreadths. <b>And that</b> term that <b>was taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>the public domain itself,</b> is <b>to convey to you the far-reaching</b> nature of the opinion <b>of the Rabbis,</b> who deem one exempt even if the object traveled in the public domain itself, and all the more so if it traveled above ten handbreadths, which is no longer within the bounds of the public domain.
This opinion of Rabbi Elazar <b>disagrees</b> with the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥilkiya bar Tovi, as Rav Ḥilkiya bar Tovi said:</b> If the thrown object traveled <b>within three</b> handbreadths from the ground, <b>everyone agrees</b> that one is <b>liable</b> because the Sages established the principle of <i>lavud</i>. <i>Lavud</i> means that any object within three handbreadths of another object is considered to be attached to it. Therefore, an object that traveled within three handbreadths of the ground is considered to have come to a complete rest. If the thrown object traveled <b>above ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, <b>everyone agrees</b> that one is <b>exempt.</b> If the thrown object traveled <b>between three</b> handbreadths <b>and ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, <b>we have come to the dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Akiva and the Rabbis.</b>
<b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Within three</b> handbreadths of the ground, <b>everyone agrees</b> that one is <b>liable; above ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, <b>everyone agrees</b> that one is exempt by Torah law, and <b>it is only</b> prohibited <b>due to rabbinic decree.</b> The Sages prohibited throwing or passing an object from the private domain of one person set to the private domain of another person unless a joining of the courtyards is set. <b>And if both of</b> the private <b>domains were his it is permitted.</b> If the thrown object traveled <b>between three</b> handbreadths <b>and ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, <b>Rabbi Akiva deems</b> one <b>liable and the Sages deem</b> him <b>exempt.</b>
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> cited above: <b>And if both of</b> the private <b>domains were his,</b> i.e., they belonged to the same person, <b>it is permitted. Let us say</b> that this <b>is a conclusive refutation</b> of <b>Rav’s</b> opinion, <b>as</b> an amoraic dispute <b>was stated</b> with regard to the following case: Concerning <b>two houses on two</b> opposite <b>sides of the public domain,</b> even if they belong to the same person, <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: It is prohibited to throw</b> an object <b>from this</b> private domain <b>to that</b> private domain. <b>And Shmuel said: It is permitted to throw from this</b> private domain <b>to that</b> private domain. The Gemara rejects this and states: <b>Didn’t we</b> already <b>establish that</b> Rav’s statement is referring to a case <b>where one</b> of the houses <b>was elevated and one was low?</b> Due to the disparity in height, the concern is that <b>at times</b> the object <b>will fall</b> into the public domain, <b>and</b> one <b>will come to bring it</b> in from there and thereby violate a Torah prohibition.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said to Rav Hamnuna, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Hamnuna</b> said <b>to Rav Ḥisda:</b> From <b>where is this matter that the Sages stated: Any</b> objects <b>less than three</b> handbreadths apart <b>are considered to be <i>lavud</i>,</b> attached? <b>He said to him: Because it is impossible for the public domain to be made level with planes.</b> Since the space cannot be completely smooth, even the minor differences in the ground level throughout the public domain must be taken into consideration.
He asked him: <b>If so,</b> if that is the reason, objects within <b>three</b> handbreadths should <b>also</b> be considered <i>lavud</i>. Why is it that only objects within less than three handbreadths are considered attached? <b>And furthermore,</b> an inference can be made from <b>that which we learned</b> in the mishna with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>sukka</i>: If <b>one lowers the walls</b> of a <i>sukka</i> <b>from the top to the bottom, if</b> the bottom of the wall <b>is above three handbreadths</b> from the ground, the <i>sukka</i> <b>is invalid</b> because it is considered to be lacking walls. By inference, if one lowers the walls so that the bottom of the wall is <b>below three</b> handbreadths from the ground, it is <b>valid.</b> In this case, the rationale that it is impossible for the public domain to be made level does not apply.
He rejects this: <b>There, the reason</b> that a space larger than three handbreadths is not considered to be part of the wall is <b>because it,</b> i.e., the wall, <b>is a partition that goats pass through.</b> Therefore, it is a partition incapable of serving its function. Once a partition is below three handbreadths, it will obstruct the passage of the goats. Furthermore, according to this explanation, <b>it works out well</b> when the measure of three handbreadths is <b>below,</b> adjacent to the ground. If any more than three handbreadths of space are between the ground and the wall, it is not considered a wall. However, there are several <i>halakhot</i> in which <i>lavud</i> applies <b>above</b> and not near the ground, e.g., when the roofing of the <i>sukka</i> is not connected to the walls. <b>What,</b> then, <b>can be said</b> to explain that <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rather,</b> the conclusion is that the <i>halakha</i> which states that <b>anything that is less than three is considered to be <i>lavud</i> is a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>learned through tradition.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> a case in a <i>baraita</i> similar to the one discussed in the mishna: One who throws an object <b>from the public domain to the</b> other <b>public domain and</b> the object passes through <b>the private domain between</b> the two, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems him liable</b> for carrying into the private domain, <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt.</b> With regard to this, <b>Rav and Shmuel both said: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> him <b>liable only</b> if <b>the private domain</b> between the two public areas <b>is covered</b> with a roof. In that case, <b>we say</b> that <b>the house is considered full</b> and an object that passes through it is considered as if it landed upon an actual object. <b>However,</b> if the private domain <b>is not covered,</b> he <b>is not</b> liable even according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. On this topic, <b>Rav Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>would deem him liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings in this case, <b>one for carrying out</b> from the private domain into the second public domain, <b>and one for carrying in,</b> when the object initially entered the private domain.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Ḥana was sitting, and</b> the following point <b>was difficult for him:</b>

Daf 97b

<b>Is that to say</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> one <b>liable</b> for <b>a subcategory</b> of prohibited labor when performed <b>with a primary category</b> of prohibited labor? After all, carrying out and carrying in constitute a primary category of prohibited labor and its subcategory.
<b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that Shabbat is mentioned in the verse: “These are the things [<i>eleh hadevarim</i>] that God has commanded to perform them” (Exodus 35:1)? Several points are derived from the superfluous emphases in this verse. The Torah could simply have stated: This is a thing [<i>davar</i>]. When it states <b>things [<i>devarim</i>]</b> in the plural, it teaches at least two points. The addition of the definite article the in the term <b>the things [<i>hadevarim</i>]</b> adds at least a third point.
