The numerological value of letters of the word <i>eleh</i>, which are <i>alef</i>, one; <i>lamed</i>, thirty; and <i>heh</i>, five, is thirty-six. The phrase: <b>These are the things,</b> alludes to three plus thirty-six derivation, i.e., the <b>thirty-nine prohibited labors that were stated to Moses at Sinai.</b> Since Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi maintains that there are a fixed number of primary categories of labor, he would certainly hold a person liable for the primary categories but not for the subcategories. 
<b>Rav Yosef said to him: The Master taught</b> Rav Yehuda’s statement <b>with regard to this, and</b> consequently, <b>he</b> encounters <b>a difficulty.</b> One statement of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi contradicts another statement of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>We learn</b> the statement of Rav Yehuda <b>with regard to the</b> opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and</b> therefore <b>there is no difficulty for us.</b>
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to one who threw an object <b>from the private domain to the public domain, and it traveled four cubits in the public domain, Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> him <b>liable and the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Rabbi Yehuda would deem him liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings in this case, <b>one for carrying out</b> from the private domain into the public domain <b>and one for carrying</b> the object four cubits through the public domain. The Rabbis deem him exempt for carrying four cubits in the public domain. And it must be interpreted that way <b>because if it would enter your mind</b> to say that Rabbi Yehuda <b>deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to bring only <b>one</b> sin-offering, <b>by inference, the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>completely exempt.</b> How is that possible? Didn’t <b>he carry</b> an object out <b>from the private domain into the public domain?</b> This proof is rejected: <b>And from where</b> do you draw that conclusion? <b>Perhaps I could actually say to you</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> him <b>liable</b> to bring <b>one</b> sin-offering <b>and the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>completely exempt, and how do you find that</b> circumstance? In a case <b>where he said:</b> My intention is that <b>as soon it,</b> the object, <b>goes out into the public domain it will</b> immediately <b>come to rest.</b>
<b>And they disagree with regard to this: Rabbi Yehuda maintains</b> that <b>we say: An object in airspace is considered at rest, and</b> therefore <b>his intention was fulfilled.</b> As soon as the object enters the airspace of the public domain it is considered to have come to rest. <b>And the Rabbis maintain</b> that <b>we do not say: An object in airspace is considered at rest, and</b> therefore <b>his intention was not fulfilled</b> and he is exempt. <b>However, Rabbi Yehuda does not hold</b> one <b>liable</b> for <b>a subcategory</b> of labor performed together with <b>a primary category</b> of labor.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>It could not enter your mind</b> to say so, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda adds even lining up</b> the threads of the warp <b>and beating</b> the threads of the woof to the list of primary categories of labor. The Rabbis <b>said to him: Lining up</b> is a subcategory <b>subsumed under</b> the primary category of <b>stretching</b> the threads of the warp within the loom, and <b>beating is subsumed under</b> the primary category of <b>weaving. Is this not</b> referring to a case where <b>one performed both</b> lining up and beating <b>together, and learn from it</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda deems</b> one <b>liable</b> for both <b>a subcategory</b> and <b>a primary category</b> of labor when they are performed together?
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>And from where</b> do you draw that conclusion? <b>Perhaps</b> it is <b>actually</b> referring to a case where <b>one performed this</b> action <b>alone and this</b> action <b>alone, and Rabbi Yehuda does not deem</b> one <b>liable for a subcategory</b> of labor performed together with <b>a primary category</b> of labor. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis <b>disagree with regard to this. Rabbi Yehuda maintains</b> as follows: <b>These</b> actions of lining up and beating <b>are</b> additional <b>primary categories</b> of labor, <b>and the Rabbis maintain</b> as follows: <b>These are subcategories.</b>
<b>Know</b> that this is so, <b>as</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches: Rabbi Yehuda adds.</b> The Gemara explains this quote from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda meant that these are <b>primary categories</b> of labor, <b>what</b> is the meaning of: <b>He adds?</b> It means <b>he adds primary categories</b> of labor. <b>However, if you say</b> that he meant that these are <b>subcategories, what</b> is the meaning of: <b>He adds? It was also stated</b> that it was <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef who both said: Rabbi Yehuda deemed</b> him <b>liable</b> to bring <b>only one</b> sin-offering.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: And according to what originally entered our mind</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda deemed</b> him <b>liable</b> to bring <b>two</b> sin-offerings, how could he be liable for both carrying out from the private domain and for carrying four cubits in the public domain? <b>If one</b> only <b>wanted</b> the object to land <b>here</b> at the beginning of the public domain, <b>he did not want</b> it to land <b>here,</b> four cubits into the public domain. Conversely, <b>if one</b> only <b>wanted</b> the object to land <b>here,</b> four cubits into the public domain, <b>he did not want</b> it to land <b>here,</b> at the beginning of the public domain. Rav Ashi <b>said to</b> Ravina: It is possible in a case where <b>one says: Any place that it wants to</b> come to rest, let it come to <b>rest.</b> One indicated that his intention would be fulfilled wherever the thrown object lands.
Concerning throwing an object on Shabbat from one domain to another and within a single domain, the Gemara raises several issues with regard to intention when throwing. It is <b>obvious</b> that <b>one who intended to throw</b> an object <b>eight</b> cubits in a public domain <b>and</b> actually <b>threw</b> it only <b>four</b> cubits is liable <b>because</b> that case is similar to a case where <b>one wrote</b> the word <b><i>shem</i>,</b> the first two letters <b>of</b> the name <b>Shimon.</b> In the case of writing <i>shem</i>, the individual performed the prohibited labor of writing a two-letter word, even though he did not complete the word that he originally intended to write. The question is as follows: <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if <b>one intended to throw</b> an object <b>four</b> cubits <b>and threw</b> it <b>eight? Do we say he did</b> indeed <b>carry</b> the object, <b>or perhaps</b> we say that ultimately the object <b>did not land where he wanted</b> it to land? <b>But</b> is <b>that not</b> precisely what <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi,</b> as mentioned above? <b>And</b> Rav Ashi <b>said</b> in response that it is referring to a case <b>where one says: Any place that it wants to</b> come to rest, let it come to <b>rest.</b> In such a scenario one is liable, because he expressed the fact that he is contented with any labor that will be performed with the object.
Furthermore, the first case, which seems obvious, also requires clarification. <b>And that which you said,</b> that this is similar to a case where <b>one wrote</b> the word <b><i>shem</i>,</b> the first two letters <b>of</b> the name <b>Shimon, is</b> it in fact <b>similar? There, as long as</b> the letters of <b><i>shem</i>,</b> <i>shin</i> and <i>mem</i>, <b>are not written,</b> the name <b>Shimon cannot be written. Here,</b> where one intended to throw the object eight cubits and he threw it only four, is it true that <b>as long as it was not thrown four</b> cubits <b>it cannot be thrown eight?</b> An object can be thrown eight cubits without first landing after four cubits. The question remains unresolved.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to <b>one who throws</b> an object on Shabbat <b>from the public domain to the</b> other <b>public domain through the private domain, he is liable</b> if he throws an object a total of <b>four cubits</b> in both parts of the public domain.

Daf 98a

If he throws it <b>less than four cubits,</b> he is <b>exempt,</b> as he is neither liable for carrying from domain to domain nor for carrying in the public domain. The Gemara asks: <b>What is he teaching us</b> with this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>He is teaching us the following</b> two things. First, that <b>domains join</b> together; even though one public domain is separated from the other by a private domain, they are treated as one domain. <b>And</b> second, <b>that we do not say</b> that <b>an object in airspace is considered at rest.</b> The object is not considered to have landed in a private domain, and therefore the one who threw it is exempt.
<b>Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who carries</b> an object <b>four cubits in the covered public domain is exempt because it is not similar to the flags of</b> the camp of Israel in <b>the desert,</b> which were not covered. The Gemara wonders: <b>Is that so? Weren’t</b> the <b>wagons</b> on which they transported the beams of the Tabernacle <b>covered?</b> The beams formed a covering over the wagons. <b>And</b> even so, <b>Rav said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya:</b> The areas that were <b>beneath the wagons, and between them, and</b> on <b>their sides</b> are all considered to have been <b>the public domain.</b> Apparently, even a covered public domain, like the space beneath the wagons, has the legal status of a public domain. The Gemara answers: <b>When Rav said</b> that the space beneath the wagons had the legal status of a public domain, he was referring to when the beams were arranged <b>in stacks.</b> The beams did not cover the entire area of the wagon. There was space between the stacks.
The Gemara asks: <b>After all, how much was the length of</b> a <b>wagon?</b> It was <b>five cubits. How much was the width of</b> a <b>beam?</b> It was <b>a cubit and a half. How many</b> beams could one <b>place</b> on a wagon? One could place <b>three</b> stacks of beams, totaling four and a half cubits. If so, <b>half a cubit</b> of open space <b>remained. When the Master distributes</b> half a cubit <b>between</b> the stacks of beams <b>it is considered <i>lavud</i>,</b> attached, as the space between each stack was less than three handbreadths. The Gemara answers: <b>Do you maintain</b> that they <b>would place the beams on their width? They would place them on their depth,</b> which was one cubit wide, and therefore there was a greater distance between the rows.
The Gemara asks: <b>Ultimately, how much was the depth of a beam?</b> It was <b>one cubit. How many</b> stacks <b>would</b> they <b>place?</b> They would place <b>four</b> stacks. <b>One cubit</b> of open space <b>remained. When the Master distributes</b> one cubit <b>between</b> the four stacks of beams <b>it is considered <i>lavud</i>,</b> as two handbreadths separated each stack. The Gemara adds: <b>This</b> statement of Rav works out <b>well according to</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that <b>the beams</b> in the Tabernacle <b>were one cubit thick at the bottom,</b> and <b>they narrowed to a fingerbreadth as they reached the top.</b> According to that opinion, there was a space larger than three handbreadths at least between the tops of the beams, and therefore the area beneath that part of the wagon was not covered. <b>However, according to</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> that <b>just as they were one cubit thick at the bottom, so too,</b> the beams <b>were one cubit thick on top, what can be said?</b> In that case, the space between the stacks was less than three handbreadths, and area beneath the wagon had the legal status of a covered public domain.
<b>Rav Kahana said:</b> When we said that the underside of the wagon was considered to be a public domain, the statement was not referring to when the beams were stacked on them. When the wagon was empty and consisted of the <b>frames</b> that held the beams in place, beneath the wagon was an uncovered public domain. The Gemara asks: But <b>where would</b> they <b>place</b> the frames? <b>On top</b> of the <b>wagon</b> when the beams were already stacked on it and the <b>wagon itself was</b> already <b>covered</b> by the beams, as stated above (<i>ge’onim</i>).

Daf 98b

<b>Shmuel said:</b> It is referring <b>to</b> the <b>stakes</b> of the Tabernacle. Before the Levites would place the beams on the wagon, they would position the stakes, which were particularly narrow. Therefore, the space between them was greater than three handbreadths, and the area beneath the wagons was therefore considered an uncovered public domain (<i>ge’onim</i>).
<b>The Sages taught:</b> The Tabernacle <b>beams were one cubit thick at the bottom,</b> and <b>they narrowed to a fingerbreadth as they reached the top, as it is stated:</b> “And they shall match at the bottom, and together <b>they will be ended [<i>tamim</i>] at the top</b> toward a single ring; so shall it be for them both, they shall form the two corners” (Exodus 26:24). <b>And below,</b> when the children of Israel crossed the Jordan River, <b>it says:</b> “And those who went down toward the Sea of Arava at the Dead Sea <b>came to an end [<i>tamu</i>]”</b> (Joshua 3:16). <i>Tam</i> means finished or terminated. Here, too, the beams narrowed as they reached the top until they were virtually terminated; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Neḥemya says: Just as they were one cubit thick at the bottom, so too, they were one cubit thick at the top, as it is stated: Together.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t it written: <i>Tamim</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: Rabbi Neḥemya explains <b>that</b> this word teaches <b>that they should bring whole</b> beams <b>and they should not bring planks</b> and attach them. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the <b>other</b> opinion, Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, <b>isn’t it written: Together?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> comes to teach that <b>they should not be</b> positioned <b>askew from each other;</b> rather, they should be perfectly aligned.
The Gemara asks further: <b>Granted, according to the one who said: Just as they were one cubit thick at the bottom, so too, they were one cubit thick at the top,</b> it is understandable <b>why it is written: “And for the back of the Tabernacle westward you shall make six beams. And you shall make two beams for the corners</b> of the Tabernacle in the back” (Exodus 26:22–23). This means <b>that the width of these</b> beams <b>comes</b> and <b>covers the</b> remaining <b>thickness of those. However, according to the one who said</b> that <b>they were one cubit thick at the bottom and they narrowed to a fingerbreadth as they reached the top,</b> they would not be perfectly aligned, as at the corners <b>this</b> beam <b>goes in and this</b> beam <b>goes out.</b> Part of the beam would protrude out of the Tabernacle. The Gemara answers <b>that</b> it was not only the thickness of the beam that narrowed. <b>One pared</b> the width of the beams as well so they were sloped <b>like mountains</b> and did not protrude.
Following the dispute over the Tabernacle beams, the Gemara interprets other verses according to the two positions. It is written: <b>“And the middle bar in the midst of the beams</b> shall pass through from end to end” (Exodus 26:28). One of the Sages <b>taught:</b> It <b>stood by</b> means of <b>a miracle,</b> as this verse indicates that the middle bar was a single rod that ran along the length and width of the Tabernacle. The middle bar was miraculously bent through the beams on three sides.
The Gemara cites a verse with regard to the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Neḥemya: <b>“And you shall make the Tabernacle with ten curtains…the length of each curtain shall be twenty-eight cubits</b> and the width of each curtain four cubits; all the curtains shall have the same measurement” (Exodus 26:1–2). <b>Place their length,</b> i.e., the curtains’ length, <b>across the width</b> of the <b>Tabernacle. How much was</b> their length? It was <b>twenty-eight</b> cubits. <b>Subtract ten</b> cubits <b>for</b> the width of <b>the roof</b> of the Tabernacle, and <b>nine</b> cubits <b>remain on this side, and nine on that side.</b> According <b>to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that the beams narrowed to a fingerbreadth, <b>the cubit</b> of the <b>sockets was exposed,</b> as the beams were ten cubits high and the bottom cubit of the beams was placed in the sockets. According <b>to Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> the cubit at the top of the beams must be added to the overall width of the Tabernacle. In addition to the cubit of the sockets, a <b>cubit</b> of the <b>beams</b> themselves <b>was exposed.</b>
<b>Place their width,</b> i.e., the curtains’ width, <b>across the length</b> of the <b>Tabernacle. How much was</b> their width? It was <b>forty</b> cubits. <b>Subtract thirty</b> cubits <b>for</b> the length of <b>the</b> Tabernacle’s <b>roof</b> and <b>ten</b> cubits <b>remain.</b> According <b>to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that the beams narrowed to a fingerbreadth, the curtain hung down the western side of the Tabernacle and the <b>cubit</b> of the <b>sockets was covered.</b> According <b>to Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> the <b>cubit</b> of the <b>sockets</b> was <b>exposed.</b>
It is also written: <b>“And you shall make curtains from goat hair for a tent</b> over the Tabernacle; eleven curtains you shall make them. <b>The length of each curtain shall be thirty cubits</b> and the width of each curtain four cubits; each of the eleven curtains should have the same measurement” (Exodus 26:7–8). <b>Place their length across the width of</b> the <b>Tabernacle. How much was</b> their length? It was <b>thirty</b> cubits. <b>Subtract ten for</b> the width of <b>the roof</b> and <b>there will remain ten on this side and ten on that side.</b> According <b>to Rabbi Yehuda,</b> the <b>cubit</b> of the <b>sockets</b> was <b>covered.</b> According <b>to Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> the <b>cubit</b> of the <b>sockets</b> was <b>exposed.</b>
<b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>. The verse states, <b>“And the cubit on the one side, and the cubit on the other side of what remains</b> of the length of the curtains of the tent shall hang over the sides of the Tabernacle, on this side and on that side to cover it” (Exodus 26:13). What remains of the length of the curtains is <b>to cover the cubit of the sockets;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Neḥemya says:</b> It is <b>to cover the cubit of the beams. Place their width across the length</b> of the <b>Tabernacle. How much was</b> their width? It was <b>forty-four</b> cubits. <b>Subtract thirty for the roof,</b> and <b>fourteen remain. Subtract two for the doubling</b> of the sixth curtain, <b>as it is written: “And you shall double the sixth curtain over the front of the tent”</b> (Exodus 26:9), and <b>twelve remain.</b>
<b>Granted,</b> according <b>to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that the beams narrowed to a fingerbreadth, and therefore the top of the beams did not take up any of the width of the curtains, which enabled the curtain to cover the entire wall of the Tabernacle with part of the curtain on the ground, it is understandable why <b>it is written:</b> “And as for the overhanging part that remained from the curtains of the tent, <b>the half curtain that remained shall hang</b> over the back of the Tabernacle” (Exodus 26:12). <b>However,</b> according <b>to Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> who maintains that it is necessary for the width of the curtains to cover the thickness at the top of the beams, <b>what</b> is the meaning of the phrase <b>shall hang?</b> The Gemara answers: It means that <b>it will hang more than the others.</b> In his opinion, this curtain is two cubits longer than the other curtains covering the Tabernacle. With regard to this, <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: To what is the Tabernacle similar?</b> It is similar <b>to a woman walking in the marketplace with her skirts following after her.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> with regard to the construction of the Tabernacle: The bottoms of the <b>beams were grooved and the sockets were hollow,</b> and the grooves were inserted into the sockets to support the beams.

Daf 99a

Additionally, <b>the clasps in the loops,</b> which connected the curtains to one another, <b>looked like stars in the sky.</b>
<b>Our Sages taught:</b> The <b>bottom curtains</b> in the Tabernacle were made <b>of sky blue</b> wool, <b>and of purple</b> wool, <b>and of scarlet</b> wool, <b>and of fine linen; and</b> the <b>top</b> curtains were made <b>of goat hair,</b> even though that material is considered to be inferior and common. However, <b>the wisdom that was stated with regard to the top</b> curtains <b>was greater than that which was stated with regard to the bottom ones. This is because, with regard to the bottom</b> curtains, <b>it is written: “And every wise-hearted woman spun with her hands,</b> and they brought that which they had spun, the blue, and the purple, the scarlet, and the linen” (Exodus 35:25); <b>while with regard to the top</b> curtains, <b>it is written: “And all of the women whose hearts inspired them with wisdom spun the goats”</b> (Exodus 35:26). The phrase “whose hearts inspired them” suggests a greater degree of wisdom. Apparently, spinning the goat’s hair curtains required greater skill than spinning the various kinds of wool. <b>And</b> on a similar note, <b>it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in the name of Rabbi Neḥemya:</b> The hair <b>was rinsed on</b> the <b>goats, and it was</b> even <b>spun from the goats,</b> which required a great deal of skill.
We learned in the mishna with regard to <b>two balconies. Rav said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya:</b> With regard to the <b>wagons</b> on which the beams of the Tabernacle were transported, the areas <b>beneath them, and between them, and to their sides</b> are considered to be <b>the public domain. Abaye said:</b> The space <b>between</b> one <b>wagon</b> and <b>the wagon</b> alongside it equaled <b>the full length of a wagon. And how much</b> was <b>the length</b> of a <b>wagon?</b> It was <b>five cubits.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need</b> the wagon to be five cubits long? <b>Four and a half</b> cubits <b>would suffice</b> whether the beams were arranged in three stacks, each a cubit and a half wide, or four stacks, each one cubit wide. The Gemara answers: You need the wagon to be five cubits long <b>so</b> that space remains between <b>the beams and</b> they will <b>not be pressed</b> against each other.
<b>Rava said: The</b> area on the <b>sides of</b> the <b>wagon</b> between the wagon and the wheel and the thickness of the wheel together equaled <b>the full width of the wagon</b> (<i>Tosafot</i>). <b>And how much was the width of</b> the <b>wagon?</b> It was <b>two and a half cubits.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I need</b> the wagon to be two and a half cubits wide? <b>A cubit and a half would suffice.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>So</b> that <b>the beams would not teeter.</b> Ten-cubit beams on a one-and-a-half-cubit wide surface would be unstable.
The Gemara comments: <b>However,</b> with regard to the principle that <b>we maintain</b> that <b>a thoroughfare in the public domain is sixteen cubits</b> wide; <b>we who derive it from</b> the <b>Tabernacle</b> encounter a difficulty: The thoroughfare associated with the <b>Tabernacle was fifteen cubits</b> wide. When two wagons stood side by side, the width of the wagons plus the space between them and the space on their sides totaled fifteen cubits. The Gemara explains: <b>There was an extra cubit where a member of</b> the tribe <b>of Levi stood,</b> to ensure that <b>if</b> the <b>beams fell, he would take</b> hold of <b>them</b> and restore them to their stack. Therefore, the total width was no less than sixteen cubits.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>the bank</b> surrounding <b>a pit and the boulder that are ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, one who takes</b> an object from <b>them</b> to the public domain <b>and</b> similarly <b>one who places</b> an object from the public domain <b>atop them is liable</b> for carrying from one domain to another. If the height or width of the pit or the boulder is <b>less than that</b> height, ten handbreadths, <b>one is exempt</b> because the legal status of those protrusions is not distinct from that of the surrounding public domain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>to teach</b> in the mishna about the cases of <b>the bank of a pit and a boulder? Let</b> the mishna simply <b>teach</b> about <b>a pit and a boulder.</b> One could derive the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an object that is ten handbreadths high from the case of the boulder, and the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an object that is ten handbreadths deep from the pit. The fact that the mishna taught the case of the bank of a pit <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, as Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A pit and its bank join together to</b> constitute the total <b>ten</b> handbreadths. If the distance from the bottom of the pit to the top of its bank is ten handbreadths, it is considered a private domain, even though some of the ten handbreadths are above ground and some are below. <b>That</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>was also taught</b> in the following <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a pit in the public domain</b> that is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>deep and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, one may not fill</b> water <b>from it on Shabbat</b> because the pit itself is a private domain, and carrying water from the pit to the public domain is prohibited

Daf 99b

<b>unless they constructed a partition</b> around <b>it</b> that is <b>ten handbreadths high.</b> Everything within the partition is then considered a private domain, and one standing within the partition may draw water from the pit. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>one may only drink</b> water from the pit <b>on Shabbat if he inserts his head and most of his</b> body into the well. <b>And a pit and its bank join together to</b> constitute the total of <b>ten</b> handbreadths, as stated by Rabbi Yoḥanan.
<b>Rav Mordekhai raised a dilemma before Rava:</b> In a case where there is <b>a column in the public domain that is ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, and one threw</b> an object <b>and it landed atop</b> the column, <b>what</b> is the ruling? The two sides of the dilemma are: <b>Do we say</b> that the <b>lifting</b> from the public domain <b>was</b> performed <b>in a prohibited</b> manner and the <b>placing</b> in the private domain <b>was</b> performed <b>in a prohibited</b> manner, and therefore one is liable? <b>Or perhaps,</b> we say that <b>since</b> the object <b>comes from an exempt domain,</b> the one who threw the object would <b>not</b> be liable. Prior to landing on the column, the object traveled through the airspace above the public domain. The airspace of a public domain extends ten handbreadths from the ground. Beyond that point the airspace is an exempt domain.
Rava <b>said to</b> Rav Mordekhai: <b>It is our mishna</b> that states that one who places an object atop a boulder that is more than ten handbreadths high is liable. Rav Mordekhai <b>came</b> and <b>asked Rav Yosef</b> about the same dilemma: Rav Yosef <b>said to him: It is our mishna.</b> Rav Mordekhai <b>came</b> and <b>asked Abaye. He said to him: It is our mishna.</b> Rav Mordekhai <b>said to them: You are all spewing the same spittle.</b> None of you taught anything new. You repeat the same unsatisfactory answer.
<b>They said to</b> Rav Mordekhai: <b>And do you not hold</b> this to be correct? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> explicitly in the mishna: <b>One who takes</b> an object from <b>them, and one who places</b> an object <b>atop them is liable? He said to them: Perhaps the mishna</b> is referring <b>to a needle</b> that can be placed atop the column without passing through the exempt area above ten handbreadths, since it is so small and hardly takes up any space.
They said to him: With regard to <b>a needle, too, it is still impossible that it will not be raised somewhat</b> above the public domain. He answered them: It is possible <b>that</b> the boulder <b>has a protrusion</b> below ten handbreadths from the ground. Since the protrusion is not significant in and of itself, it has the legal status of a hole in the wall of a private domain. One who throws an object into it is liable, just like one who throws into the private domain itself. <b>Alternatively,</b> it is possible <b>that</b> the needle <b>is placed in a groove</b> that is below ten handbreadths from the ground. The needle did not enter the groove from above ten handbreadths. It passed directly into the groove, which is a private domain. Therefore, Rav Mordekhai’s dilemma is not resolved from the mishna.
<b>Rav Meyasha said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised a dilemma:</b> There is <b>a wall in the public domain</b> that is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and is not</b> quite <b>four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, and it surrounds a <i>karmelit</i> and renders</b> the area that it encloses <b>the private domain.</b> The wall serves as a partition of this private domain. <b>And</b> if <b>one threw</b> an object from the public domain <b>and it landed atop</b> the wall, <b>what is</b> the ruling? <b>Do we say: Since it is not four</b> handbreadths <b>wide it is an exempt domain,</b> and the one who threw the object is exempt? <b>Or perhaps</b> we say that <b>since it rendered</b> the <i>karmelit</i> <b>the private domain,</b> the wall together with the private domain <b>is considered to be filled.</b> Therefore, the object is considered to have landed on an area that is four handbreadths wide, and the one who threw the object is liable.
<b>Ulla said:</b> The fact that it is considered a private domain is derived by means of an <b><i>a fortiori</i> inference:</b> If this wall <b>creates a partition</b> that renders <b>other</b> areas surrounded by the wall a private domain, <b>all the more so</b> does it render <b>itself</b> a private domain. <b>It was also stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said, and so too, Rabbi Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> With regard to <b>a wall in the public domain</b> that is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and is not</b> quite <b>four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, and it surrounds a <i>karmelit</i> and renders</b> the area that it surrounds <b>the private domain,</b> if <b>one threw</b> an object from the public domain <b>and it landed atop</b> the wall, <b>he is liable.</b> If this wall <b>creates a partition</b> that renders <b>other</b> areas a private domain, <b>all the more so</b> does it render <b>itself</b> a private domain.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised a dilemma:</b> In a case where there is <b>a pit</b> that is <b>nine</b> handbreadths deep, <b>and one dug out a segment</b> of earth from the bottom of the pit <b>and</b> thereby <b>completed</b> the depth of the pit <b>to ten</b> handbreadths, and then he proceeded to throw the earth into the public domain, <b>what</b> is the ruling? The two sides to the dilemma are: Is it that the <b>lifting</b> of <b>the object and establishment of the</b> ten-handbreadth <b>partition came</b> about <b>simultaneously, and he is liable? Or</b> perhaps <b>he is not liable. And if you say: Since the partition was not ten</b> handbreadths deep <b>initially, he is not liable,</b> then in a case where there is <b>a pit</b> that is <b>ten</b> handbreadths deep, <b>and one placed a segment</b> of earth <b>into</b> the pit <b>and</b> thereby <b>minimized</b> its depth to less than ten handbreadths, nullifying its status as a private domain, <b>what</b> is the ruling? The two sides of the question are: Is it that <b>placement of the object and the elimination of the</b> ten-handbreadth <b>partition came</b> about <b>simultaneously,</b> and <b>he is liable?</b> Or perhaps, <b>he is not liable</b> because the partition was not intact throughout the performance of the action.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Resolve</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s dilemma <b>from his own</b> statement, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who throws</b> an object <b>four cubits</b> in the public domain and it hits <b>the wall above ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, which is an exempt domain, it is <b>as if he threw it in the air,</b> and he is exempt. If it was <b>below ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, it is <b>as if he threw it</b> and it landed <b>on the ground, and one who throws</b> an object <b>four cubits</b> and it lands <b>on the ground is liable. And we discussed it:</b> How could he be liable for carrying in that case? The object <b>did not come to rest</b> on the wall and there was no placement.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It is <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>a juicy cake of figs</b> that sticks to the wall when thrown against it that <b>we learned</b> in the mishna. The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> is one liable in that case? When the cake of figs sticks to the wall, <b>it reduces</b> the distance the figs traveled <b>from</b> the measure of <b>four cubits</b> that determines liability. If one threw the cake of figs at a distance of exactly four cubits from the wall, and, based on Rabbi Yoḥanan, the object becomes part of the wall, the distance that the cake of figs traveled is slightly less than four cubits, and therefore he should be exempt. Since Rabbi Yoḥanan did not take this into account, apparently, in his opinion, when the placement of the object and the elimination of the partition are simultaneous, one is liable.
The Gemara rejects this and says: The cases are not similar because <b>there,</b> in the case of the cake of figs, the one who threw it <b>does not nullify its</b> independent existence vis-à-vis the wall, as the food will eventually be removed from the wall. <b>Here,</b> in the case of the dirt in the pit, <b>one nullifies its</b> independent existence vis-à-vis the pit, and it eliminates the ten-handbreadth partition.
<b>Rava raised</b> a similar <b>dilemma:</b> In a case where one <b>threw a board and it landed on top of stakes</b> that are ten handbreadths high but not four handbreadths wide, <b>what</b> is the ruling? Once the board lands, the surface is ten handbreadths high and four handbreadths wide. The Gemara asks: <b>What is his dilemma?</b> Does his dilemma pertain to the ruling in a case where <b>the placement of the object and the establishment of the partition came about simultaneously? That is</b> precisely the dilemma raised <b>by Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b>
The Gemara answers: The case <b>where Rava raised a dilemma</b> is more complex. His dilemma is with regard to a case <b>where one threw a board and</b> there was <b>an object</b> resting <b>atop</b> the board. In that case, <b>what</b> is the ruling? The two sides of the dilemma are: <b>Since</b> the board and the object <b>come simultaneously,</b> the legal status is <b>similar</b> to a case where <b>the placement of the object and the establishment of the partition</b> came about simultaneously. The object and the board are a single unit that creates a partition when it lands, and therefore one is exempt. <b>Or perhaps</b> we say that <b>since it is impossible,</b> when they land, for the object <b>not to rise slightly and then land</b> because the object and the board are not connected, <b>it is like</b> the case where <b>the establishment of the partition</b> was completed <b>and the placement of the object</b> followed, and therefore one is liable. These dilemmas remain, and therefore <b>let it stand</b> unresolved.
Rava raised an issue related to the previous dilemmas, and before doing so he sought to clarify certain points. <b>Rava said: It is obvious to me</b> that if one poured <b>water onto water that is its placement,</b> and if one did so from one domain to another he is liable. If one placed <b>a nut onto water,</b>

Daf 100a

<b>it is not</b> considered <b>its placement.</b> However, <b>Rava raised a dilemma:</b> In a case where there is <b>a nut in a vessel and the vessel is floating on water, what</b> is the ruling? Is it permitted to lift the nut on Shabbat if one is in another domain? The two sides of the dilemma are: <b>Do we say</b> that <b>we go according to the</b> status of the <b>nut, and</b> it <b>is at rest</b> in the vessel? <b>Or perhaps we go according to</b> the status of the <b>vessel, and it is not at rest.</b> No resolution was found to this dilemma. Therefore, <b>let it stand</b> unresolved as well.
However, with regard to <b>oil</b> floating <b>on wine,</b> there is <b>a dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri and the Rabbis. As we learned</b> in a mishna: In the case of <b>oil floating on wine, and one who immersed himself during the day,</b> i.e., one who was impure, immersed himself in a ritual bath, but will not become completely pure until sunset, <b>touched the oil, he invalidated only</b> the <b>oil</b> and not the wine. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says:</b> With regard to <b>the two,</b> i.e., the oil and the wine, they are considered to have <b>a connection to each other.</b> Since he made the oil impure, the wine is also impure. Their dispute is whether or not the oil is considered to be placed atop the wine.
<b>Abaye said:</b> In the case of <b>a pit in the public domain</b> that is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>deep and</b> precisely <b>eight</b> handbreadths <b>wide, and one threw a mat into it, he is liable.</b> However, if <b>he divided</b> the pit <b>with a mat</b> that split it in two, each one slightly less than four handbreadths wide, <b>he is exempt</b> because neither part is considered a private domain. The Gemara comments: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye, for whom it is obvious</b> that <b>the mat eliminates the partition</b> of the pit, <b>all the more so that a segment</b> of dirt thrown into a pit that is ten handbreadths deep, rendering it less than ten handbreadths, <b>eliminates the partition,</b> and he has no dilemma with regard to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s case. According to <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, who raised a dilemma with regard to a segment</b> of dirt, <b>it is obvious that a mat does not eliminate the partition.</b>
<b>Abaye said:</b> With regard to <b>a pit in the public domain</b> that is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>deep and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide</b> and <b>filled with water,</b> and <b>one threw</b> an object <b>into it</b> on Shabbat, <b>one is liable</b> because the pit is considered a private domain. And if the pit was <b>filled with fruit and one threw</b> an object <b>into it, he is exempt. What is the reason</b> for the different rulings? <b>Water is not</b> significant enough to <b>eliminate the partition; fruit eliminates the partition. This was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who throws</b> an object <b>from the sea to the street or from the street to the sea is exempt</b> because the sea is considered a <i>karmelit</i>, and one is not liable according to Torah law in that case. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: If</b> the <b>area</b> in the sea <b>where he threw</b> it <b>is ten</b> handbreadths <b>deep and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, he is liable,</b> as he is considered as one who threw an object into a private domain. Apparently, the water in the sea does not eliminate the status of a private domain.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who throws</b> an object <b>four cubits</b> in the public domain, if the object hits <b>the wall above ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, which is an exempt domain, it is <b>as if one threw it in the air,</b> and he is exempt. If it hits the wall <b>below ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, it is <b>as if he threw it</b> and it landed <b>on the ground, and one who throws</b> an object <b>four cubits</b> and it lands <b>on the ground is liable.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that if one throws an object in the public domain a distance of four cubits and it hits a wall above ten handbreadths from the ground, he is liable if he threw it. The Gemara asks: <b>And we discussed it:</b> How could he be liable for carrying in that case? Since the object <b>did not come to rest</b> on the wall, there was no placement. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It is <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>a juicy cake of figs</b> that sticks to the wall when thrown against it that <b>we learned</b> in the mishna.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said:</b> If <b>one threw</b> a stone at a wall <b>above ten</b> handbreadths from the ground, <b>and it went and came to rest in a hole</b> in the wall <b>of any size</b> less than four handbreadths, <b>we have come to the dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis. According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said: One carves out</b> the space <b>to complete</b> it, <b>he is liable.</b> We complete the hole by conceptually carving it to four handbreadths because doing so is theoretically possible. Since the hole is considered ten handbreadths high and four handbreadths wide, one is liable for transferring an object from a public domain to a private one. <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, who say: One does not carve out</b> the space <b>to complete</b> it, the thrower <b>is not liable</b> because the hole is actually less than four handbreadths wide at present. <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one threw</b> an object <b>above ten</b> handbreadths, <b>and it went and came to rest in a small hole, Rabbi Meir deems</b> him <b>liable, while the Rabbis deem</b> him <b>exempt.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> In the case of <b>a mound</b> that is an inclined plane that gradually <b>attains</b> a height of <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>over</b> a horizontal space of <b>four</b> cubits, <b>and one threw</b> an object from the public domain and it <b>came to rest atop</b> that mound, <b>he is liable</b> because it is considered a partition. <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An alleyway that is level inside and becomes an inclined</b> or declined plane as it enters <b>the public domain,</b> which is higher or lower than the alleyway, <b>or</b> if the entrance to the alleyway is <b>level</b> when entering <b>the public domain and inside it</b> is <b>inclined, that alleyway requires neither a post</b> alongside its entrance <b>or a beam</b> across its entrance in order to distinguish it from the public domain because the incline itself is considered a partition. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel says:</b> In the case of a <b>mound</b> that gradually <b>attains</b> a height of <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>over</b> a horizontal space of <b>four</b> cubits, <b>and one threw</b> an object from the public domain and it <b>came to rest atop</b> that mound, <b>he is liable.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one threw</b> an object in the public domain, intending for it to land <b>within four cubits,</b> meaning that he had no intention of violating the Torah prohibition of carrying, <b>and</b> the object <b>rolled</b> and went <b>beyond four cubits, he is exempt.</b> However, if one threw an object with the intention of it landing <b>beyond four cubits, and</b> the object <b>rolled</b> back <b>within four cubits, he is liable</b> from when he originally threw the object.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that if one threw an object beyond four cubits and it rolled back within four cubits, he is liable. The Gemara asks: The object <b>did not come to rest</b> beyond four cubits, so how can the one who threw it be liable? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And that</b> liability was established <b>when</b> the object <b>came to rest atop something. That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one threw</b> an object <b>beyond four cubits and the wind blew it</b> while still in the air <b>and brought it</b> within four cubits, <b>he is exempt even though it,</b> i.e., the wind, <b>then brought it back out</b> because the object did not come to rest in the place where it was thrown. However, if <b>the wind seized it briefly</b> and it stayed on the ground for a brief period of time (<i>Tosafot</i>), <b>even though</b> the wind <b>then brought it in,</b> the individual <b>is liable.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> Despite the principle of <i>lavud</i>, which states that <b>within three</b> handbreadths of the ground an object is considered to be attached to it, <b>according to the Rabbis,</b> who maintain that an object in airspace is not considered at rest, the object <b>must come to rest atop something</b> to establish liability. The Gemara relates that <b>Mareimar sat and stated this <i>halakha</i>. Ravina said to Mareimar:</b>

Daf 100b

<b>Isn’t that</b> what we learned <b>in the mishna,</b> with regard to which <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: That</b> liability is <b>when it came to rest atop something,</b> which means that the object must actually land in order for the one who threw it to be liable. Mareimar <b>said to</b> Ravina: <b>Are you saying</b> it is a case of <b>rolling?</b> One cannot cite proof from a rolling object because <b>a rolling object will not ultimately come to rest. However,</b> with regard to <b>this</b> object, which passed within three handbreadths of the ground, I would say: <b>Since it will ultimately come to rest, even though</b> it has <b>not</b> yet <b>come to rest,</b> it <b>is</b> considered <b>as an object</b> that <b>came to rest.</b> Therefore, Rava <b>teaches us</b> that even in that case one is not liable until it actually comes to rest upon something.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who throws</b> an object <b>four cubits into the sea is exempt. If there was a swamp and the public domain passes through it, one who throws</b> an object <b>four cubits into it is liable</b> like one who carried four cubits in the public domain. <b>And how</b> deep <b>is</b> this <b>swamp?</b> It is <b>less than ten handbreadths</b> deep. In the case of <b>a swamp that the public domain passes through, one who throws</b> an object <b>four cubits into</b> the swamp <b>is liable.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>One of the Sages said to Rava: Granted, passing passing</b> is mentioned <b>twice</b> in the mishna; <b>this teaches us</b> that <b>passage under duress is considered passage,</b> but <b>usage under duress is not considered usage. But why do I need it</b> to mention <b>swamp swamp twice?</b> Rava answered him: <b>One</b> case <b>is</b> referring <b>to the summer, and one</b> case <b>is</b> referring <b>to the winter. And</b> both cases <b>are necessary, as had</b> the mishna <b>taught</b> only <b>one</b> mention of swamp, I would have said that <b>these matters,</b> i.e., cases indicating that passage under duress is considered passage, <b>apply</b> only <b>in the summer because people commonly</b> pass through the swamp <b>to cool themselves; however, in the winter</b> I would have thought that it would <b>not</b> be so. <b>And had</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> only the case of <b>winter,</b> I would have said that <b>since they are filthy</b> from mud anyway, <b>they do not mind</b> walking through the swamp, <b>but in the summer</b> it would <b>not</b> be so.
<b>Abaye said:</b> It is possible to explain this other way. It was <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to state swamp twice because <b>it would have entered your mind to say</b> that <b>these matters apply</b> specifically <b>where</b> the swamp <b>is not four cubits</b> wide because then people walk through the swamp and do not circumvent it, <b>but where</b> the swamp <b>is four cubits</b> wide, people <b>circumvent it.</b> Therefore, it was necessary to teach that people walk through swamps that are both narrow and wide.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> another explanation: It was <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to state swamp twice because <b>it would have entered your mind to say</b> that <b>these matters apply</b> specifically <b>where</b> the swamp is at least <b>four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>but where</b> the swamp <b>is not four</b> handbreadths wide, people <b>step over it</b> and do not walk through it. The Gemara comments: <b>And Rav Ashi</b> follows his own <b>reasoning, as Rav Ashi said: One who threw</b> an object <b>and it came to rest on one of the beams of a bridge is liable.</b> Even though the width of each beam is less than four handbreadths, it joins together with the other beams to form a single surface of the public domain <b>because</b> even though many people step over the beams, still <b>many people step on it.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who throws</b> an object <b>from the sea to dry land, or from dry land to the sea, or from the sea onto a boat, or from a boat into the sea, or from one boat to another is exempt</b> because the sea has the legal status of a <i>karmelit</i>. If <b>boats</b> are <b>tied together, one may carry</b> an object <b>from one to the other</b> on Shabbat. However, <b>if they are not tied, even though they are adjacent, one may not carry from one to the other.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was stated</b> that the Sages disagreed with regard to the manner in which one may draw seawater onto <b>a boat</b> on Shabbat. <b>Rav Huna said: One extends a projection of any size from</b> the side of the boat as a distinctive sign, <b>and fills</b> a receptacle with water from the sea. <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna say: One creates an area,</b> a frame <b>of four</b> by four handbreadths, <b>and fills</b> the water from inside it.
The Gemara explains: <b>Rav Huna,</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>one extends a projection of any size and fills</b> a receptacle with water, <b>maintains</b> that <b>we measure</b> the <b><i>karmelit</i> from the</b> sea <b>floor.</b> Since the sea itself is deeper than ten handbreadths, the boat is considered to be floating in the air, <b>and the air is an exempt domain,</b> as it is above ten handbreadths from the ground of the <i>karmelit</i>. <b>And by law</b> one <b>should not require a projection</b> because he is drawing water from an exempt domain into a private domain, which is permitted <i>ab initio</i>. <b>Rather,</b> the reason a projection is required is <b>so that he will have a distinctive sign</b> and not come to draw water from a <i>karmelit</i> into a private domain.
<b>Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna say: One creates an area,</b> a frame <b>of four</b> by four handbreadths, <b>and fills</b> a receptacle with water. <b>They maintain</b> that <b>we measure</b> the <b><i>karmelit</i> from the surface of the water,</b> and <b>the water</b> in the sea has a legal status <b>like</b> that of <b>solid land.</b> Therefore, <b>if one does not create an area of four</b> by four, <b>he will carry from a <i>karmelit</i> to the private domain.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman said to Rabba bar Avuh: And according to Rav Huna,</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>one extends a projection of any size from</b> the side of the boat <b>and fills</b> a receptacle with water, isn’t there room for concern that <b>at times when</b> the water <b>is not ten</b> handbreadths deep, <b>he will carry from a <i>karmelit</i> into the private domain?</b> He <b>said to him: We learned</b> through tradition that <b>a boat does not travel in</b> water that is <b>less than ten</b> handbreadths deep. He asks: Although <b>a boat has a protrusion</b> at its bow is more than ten handbreadths above the sea floor, the entire length of the boat is not necessarily that far above the bottom. <b>Rav Safra said: Those people who measure the depth of the water</b> with long poles <b>proceed before</b> the ship and ensure that that the water is at least ten handbreadths deep.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin: According to Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna, who say</b> that in order to draw water onto a boat on Shabbat <b>one creates an area of four</b> by four handbreadths <b>and fills</b> a receptacle, <b>how does he throw out his waste water? And if you say he pours it out in the same area</b> from which he draws water, the water that he subsequently draws from there will be <b>disgusting to him.</b> Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin answered him: <b>He pours it onto the side</b> of the <b>boat</b> from which it runs into the sea, and he does not pour it directly into the sea. The Gemara asks: Even so, <b>it is</b> accomplished by means of <b>his power.</b> Although he did not pour it directly, he caused the waste water to enter the sea. The Gemara answers: The Sages <b>did not issue a decree</b> to prohibit an action performed by <b>one’s power in a <i>karmelit</i>.</b> They only prohibited throwing an object directly. <b>And from where do you say</b> that this is so? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a <b>ship, one may neither carry from it into the sea, nor from the sea into it.</b>

Daf 101a

<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If the interior of the boat is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>deep and it is not ten</b> handbreadths <b>above</b> the surface of the water, <b>one may carry from it into the sea, but not from the sea into it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about carrying <b>from the sea into</b> the ship <b>that</b> one may <b>not</b> do so? Is it <b>because</b> in doing so <b>one is carrying from a <i>karmelit</i> into the private domain?</b> In carrying <b>from</b> the ship <b>into the sea, one is also carrying from the private domain into a <i>karmelit</i>. Rather, is it not</b> that from the ship to the sea is permitted because one throws the object onto <b>the edge</b> of the boat and it falls into the sea on its own, <b>and learn from it</b> that the Sages did <b>not issue a decree</b> prohibiting an action caused indirectly by <b>one’s power in a <i>karmelit</i>?</b> The Gemara summarizes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that this is so.
<b>Rav Huna said:</b> With regard to <b>those small boats of Meishan,</b> which are wide on top and narrow at the bottom, <b>one may carry in them only within four</b> cubits. Because they are less than four handbreadths wide at the bottom, they are not a private domain. <b>And we only said</b> this <i>halakha</i> in a case where the width of the boat does <b>not</b> reach <b>four</b> handbreadths <b>less than three</b> handbreadths from the bottom of the boat. <b>However, if</b> the width of the boat reaches <b>four</b> handbreadths <b>less than three</b> handbreadths from the bottom, <b>we do not have</b> this <i>halakha</i>, as those are considered full-fledged partitions which create a private domain. <b>And,</b> similarly, <b>if one fills</b> the bottom of the boat <b>with reeds and</b> thin <b>willow branches</b> up to the point where the boat reaches four handbreadths, <b>we do not have</b> this <i>halakha</i>. If there are ten handbreadths above the point where the boat reaches four handbreadths, it is a private domain.
<b>Rav Naḥman strongly objects to this: And let us say: Lower the partition.</b> The upper part of the raft is sufficiently wide and its partitions are sufficiently high; why not consider it as if the partitions of the boat descend from the top of the raft in a straight line to the bottom? <b>Was it not taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says: One who stuck a stick</b> into the ground <b>in the public domain, and</b> hung <b>a basket atop it</b> that is four by four handbreadths wide, and <b>threw</b> an object from the public domain <b>and it landed upon it, he is liable,</b> like one who carried an object into a private domain? <b>Apparently, we say: Lower the partition</b> of the basket and treat it as if it reaches the ground, creating a column that is considered a private domain. <b>Here, too, let us say: Lower the partition.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef strongly objects to this</b> statement of Rav Naḥman: <b>And</b> did <b>they not hear that</b> which <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said, and</b> there are those who <b>determined</b> that <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> was stated <b>in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya: And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And the Rabbis deem</b> one <b>exempt</b> in the case of a reed stuck in the ground of a public domain? Apparently, the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, is an individual opinion and was not accepted as <i>halakha</i>. <b>Abaye said to him: And do you not hold</b> the principle of extending partitions? <b>Was it not taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a column in the public domain</b> that is <b>ten</b> handbreadths <b>high and four</b> handbreadths <b>wide, and its base</b> is <b>not four</b> handbreadths wide, <b>and its narrowest</b> point <b>is</b> more than <b>three</b> handbreadths high; <b>and</b> if <b>one threw</b> an object from the public domain <b>and it came to rest atop</b> the column, <b>he is liable? Apparently, we say: Lower the partition.</b> Since the column’s uppermost section is sufficiently wide, its partitions are considered as if they extend to the ground. <b>Here, too,</b> say: <b>Lower the partition.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Are</b> the case of the basket and the case of the boat <b>comparable? There,</b> in the case of the basket, <b>it is a partition that goats pass through.</b> A partition that does not serve as a barrier is not considered a partition. <b>Here, it is a partition that goats do not pass through.</b> It is considered a partition. <b>Rav Aḥa, son</b> of <b>Rav Aḥa, said to Rav Ashi: In the case of a boat, too,</b> there is <b>the passage of fish,</b> as they can swim through the lowered partitions of the boat. <b>He said to him: Passage of fish is not considered passage</b> because it is not visible. <b>And from where do you say</b> that this is so? <b>As Rabbi Tavla raised a dilemma before Ravin:</b> With regard to <b>a hanging partition, what</b> is the ruling in terms of it <b>permitting</b> one to carry <b>in a ruin</b> when part of the building’s walls are still intact, and they are still considered partitions? Ravin <b>said to him: A hanging partition only permits</b> one to carry

Daf 101b

<b>in water. It is a leniency the Sages instituted in water</b> but not in other circumstances. <b>And why</b> were they lenient with regard to a hanging partition in water? <b>Isn’t there the passage of fish? Rather, learn from this</b> that <b>the passage of fish is not considered passage.</b>
We learned in the mishna: If <b>boats</b> are <b>tied together,</b> one may carry an object from one to the other on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious,</b> since these boats are like a single domain. <b>Rava said: This</b> mishna <b>was necessary only to permit</b> carrying from one boat to another via <b>a small boat that is between them.</b>
<b>Rav Safra said to him:</b> You, who are as great in this generation as <b>Moses, did you speak well? We learned</b> in the mishna that <b>one may carry</b> only <b>from one to the other,</b> not via a small boat. <b>Rather, Rav Safra said:</b> The mishna <b>was only necessary</b> to obligate one <b>to place an <i>eiruv</i>,</b> a joining of courtyards, between the two boats. Since the boats belong to different people, they must be joined to form a single domain in order to permit <b>carrying from one to the other, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>boats tied to one another, one places an <i>eiruv</i> and carries from one to the other.</b> If the ties between them <b>were severed,</b> the people on the boats <b>are prohibited</b> to carry from one to the other. If <b>they were then retied, whether unwittingly,</b> i.e., the one who retied them forgot that it was Shabbat, <b>whether intentionally, whether due to circumstances beyond one’s control, whether mistakenly,</b> the boats <b>are restored to their original permitted</b> status.
<b>And similarly,</b> in the case of <b>mats that are unfurled</b> to create a partition between two people <b>and the public domain, one places an <i>eiruv</i> and carries from one to the other.</b> If the mats <b>were furled,</b> the people on the boats <b>are prohibited</b> to carry from one to the other. If the mats <b>were then unfurled</b> again, <b>whether unwittingly, whether intentionally, whether due to circumstances beyond one’s control, whether mistakenly, they are restored to their original permitted</b> status. That is <b>because any partition that is established on Shabbat, whether unwittingly, whether intentionally, is considered a partition.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rav Naḥman say: They only taught</b> the principle that a partition established on Shabbat is considered a partition with regard <b>to throwing.</b> In that case, a partition creates a domain unto itself, and one who throws an object into it from another domain is liable. <b>However,</b> with regard <b>to carrying</b> within that domain, it is certainly <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>When</b> that statement of <b>Rav Naḥman was stated, it was stated</b> with regard to an act performed <b>intentionally.</b> One who intentionally establishes a partition is penalized and is not permitted to benefit from it. In principle, though, that partition is considered a full-fledged partition.
<b>Shmuel said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> that one may carry from one ship to another if they are tied together applies <b>even</b> if they were <b>tied with a string</b> used to close the neckline of <b>a cloak.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances? If</b> the string <b>is capable of holding</b> the ships together, it is <b>obvious</b> that carrying between the ships is permitted as they are tied together. However, <b>if</b> the string <b>is incapable of holding them, why</b> is it permitted?
The Gemara explains: <b>Actually,</b> it refers to a string that <b>can hold them, and Shmuel</b> said this <b>to exclude</b> this case <b>from his own statement. As we learned</b> in a mishna: If <b>one tied</b> a ship <b>with an item capable of holding it</b> and the end of that item was in a tent with a corpse, <b>it transmits impurity to</b> the ship. And if one tied it <b>with something that is incapable of holding it, it does not transmit impurity to</b> the ship. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> When the mishna refers to an item capable of holding it, it is referring to a case where <b>it is tied with an iron chain.</b> It was necessary for Shmuel to establish that although with regard to ritual impurity the <i>halakha</i> applies only to an iron chain, with regard to Shabbat the <i>halakha</i> applies to any item capable of holding the ships together. 
The reason that the <i>halakha</i> is different <b>with regard to impurity is as it is written:</b> “And whoever touches in the open field <b>one slain by sword,</b> or one who dies by himself, or a bone of a man, or a grave, shall be unclean seven days” (Numbers 19:16). The Sages derived from the phrase: One slain by sword that <b>a sword is like one slain,</b> i.e., a corpse. A metal instrument that comes into contact with a corpse assumes the same level of ritual impurity as the corpse itself, the ultimate primary source of ritual impurity. Therefore, it is only an iron chain in a tent with a corpse in it that can render a boat tied to the other end a primary source of ritual impurity. A string made of other materials cannot. <b>However, with regard to Shabbat, since</b> it is <b>capable of holding it</b> and it is <b>a mere distinctive sign</b> that is necessary, <b>even the string of a cloak</b> is sufficient.

Daf 102a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who</b> unwittingly <b>throws</b> an object from one domain to another or one who throws an object four cubits within the public domain, <b>and after</b> the object <b>left his hand he remembered</b> that he is in violation of a prohibition, if <b>another caught it,</b> or if <b>a dog caught it, or if it was burned, he is exempt.</b> Similarly, if <b>one threw</b> a rock on Shabbat <b>to inflict a wound on a person or on an animal,</b> for which one is liable to bring a sin-offering, <b>and he remembered</b> that he was in violation of a prohibition <b>before</b> the <b>wound was inflicted, he is exempt. This is the principle: All</b> who are <b>liable</b> to bring <b>sin-offerings are only liable if the beginning</b> of their action <b>and the conclusion</b> of their action <b>are unwitting.</b> However, if <b>the beginning</b> of one’s action was <b>unwitting and the conclusion</b> was <b>intentional,</b> as he became aware that he was in violation of a prohibition, or if <b>the beginning</b> of one’s action was <b>intentional and the conclusion</b> was <b>unwitting,</b> the individuals in both of these cases <b>are exempt until</b> both <b>the beginning and the conclusion are unwitting.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that if one throws an object unwittingly and then remembers that he was in violation of a prohibition, he is exempt if the object did not come to rest on the ground. The Gemara infers: If the object <b>comes to rest,</b> he is <b>liable.</b> The Gemara asks: Why is he liable? <b>Didn’t he remember</b> the prohibition before it landed, <b>and we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>All</b> who are <b>liable</b> to bring <b>sin-offerings are only liable if the beginning</b> of their action <b>and the conclusion</b> of their action <b>will be unwitting?</b> If one remembered before the act was complete, he should be exempt. <b>Rav Kahana said:</b> With regard to <b>the latter</b> clause of the mishna, <b>we have come</b> to a special case of <b>a bolt and a cord.</b> The bolt is connected to a cord that one holds in his hand, which renders him capable of retrieving the bolt before it lands. Therefore, in a case where the beginning was unwitting and the conclusion was intentional, one is exempt because he is still capable of changing the outcome of the action. However, in the first clause of the mishna, once the object left his hand the action is irreversible, and therefore it is an action whose beginning and conclusion are unwitting.
The Gemara asks: The case of <b>the bolt and the cord</b> is one where <b>one holds it in his hand.</b> Therefore, no act of throwing actually took place, and there is no liability to bring a sin-offering. The Gemara answers: The case of the bolt and the cord was not stated with regard to Shabbat. Rather, it was stated with regard to <b>one who intended to inflict a wound</b> by throwing an object tied to a rope. The Gemara asks: <b>This was also taught</b> explicitly in the mishna: If <b>one threw</b> a rock on Shabbat <b>to inflict a wound on a person or on an animal, and he remembered before</b> the <b>wound was inflicted, he is exempt. Rather, Rava said:</b> This principle was stated <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>carrying,</b> not throwing an object. Since one is holding the object the entire time while violating the prohibition, and is capable of letting it go at any time, this is a case whose beginning and conclusion are intentional.
The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t this principle that was taught, taught</b> with regard to <b>throwing</b> because that is the topic of the mishna? <b>Rather, Rava said: Two</b> separate matters <b>were taught</b> in the mishna. The first case is: <b>One who</b> unwittingly <b>throws</b> an object, <b>and after</b> the object <b>left his hand he remembered</b> that he was in violation of a prohibition. <b>Alternatively,</b> another case where one is exempt is: A case where <b>one did not remember and another caught it,</b> or <b>a dog caught it, or if it was burned, he is exempt.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The mishna <b>is incomplete, and it teaches the following: One who throws</b> a rock <b>and remembers</b> the violation <b>after it left his hand,</b> if <b>another caught it,</b> or if <b>a dog caught it, or if it was burned, he is exempt.</b> By inference, if the object <b>comes to rest,</b> he is <b>liable.</b> Rav Ashi adds: <b>In what</b> case <b>are these matters stated?</b> In a case <b>where one then forgot</b> again before the object came to rest. <b>However,</b> if <b>one did not then forget</b> again, <b>he is exempt because all</b> who are <b>liable</b> to bring <b>sin-offerings are liable only if the beginning</b> of their action <b>and the conclusion</b> of their action <b>are unwitting.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>this is the principle: All</b> who are <b>liable</b> to bring <b>sin-offerings</b> are only liable if the beginning of their action and the conclusion of their action are unwitting. <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> disputed this point. With regard to a case where one carried an object in the public domain <b>two cubits unwittingly,</b> and then became aware and carried it <b>two</b> more <b>cubits intentionally,</b> and <b>then</b> carried it <b>two</b> additional <b>cubits unwittingly,</b> and then placed the object, can this be characterized as a case in which the beginning of the action and the conclusion of the action are unwitting? <b>Rabba said: One is exempt. Rava said: One is liable.</b> 
The Gemara clarifies the two positions. <b>Rabba said: One is exempt.</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even according to Rabban Gamliel, who said: There is no awareness for half a measure,</b> and therefore he is liable. Since one is not liable to bring a sacrifice for a half-measure, the fact that he became aware between consumption of the two halves of an olive-bulk is of no significance. One’s awareness does not demarcate between the two half-measures of two cubits with regard to liability to bring a sin-offering. He only said so <b>there, when the measure</b> that determines liability <b>was completed, it was completed unwittingly. However, here,</b> when the measure is completed, it is completed <b>intentionally.</b> In that case, he would say <b>no,</b> he is not liable. The measure that determines liability for carrying in the public domain on Shabbat is four cubits. When the object reached four cubits, he was carrying the object intentionally.
The Gemara explains: <b>And in what</b> case was this stated? <b>If</b> it was stated <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>throwing,</b> the entire act was <b>unwitting</b> because when he became aware, there was nothing he could do to prevent the object from landing. <b>Rather,</b> it must have been <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>carrying.</b>
<b>Rava said: One is liable. Even according to the Rabbis, who said: There is awareness for half a measure,</b> and therefore he is exempt, they only said so <b>there,</b> where it is still <b>in his control</b> to complete or terminate the action. <b>But here,</b> where it is <b>not in his control</b> to affect the outcome, they would <b>not</b> say so and would deem him liable. <b>And in what</b> case was this stated? <b>If</b> it was stated <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>carrying,</b> the outcome is still <b>in his control. Rather,</b> it must have been <b>with regard to</b> a case of <b>throwing.</b> Apparently, Rabba and Rava do not disagree. They are discussing separate cases.
<b>Rabba said:</b> If <b>one</b> unwittingly <b>threw</b> an object from one domain to another or unwittingly threw an object four cubits in a public domain on Shabbat, <b>and it came to rest in the mouth of a dog or in a furnace, he is liable.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: If <b>another caught it,</b> or if <b>a dog caught it, or if it was burned, he is exempt?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the case of the mishna where one is exempt, <b>one did not intend</b> to throw it into the dog’s mouth. A dog came and snatched the object, preventing it from landing at its intended destination. Since the intention of the thrower was not realized, he is exempt. However, <b>here,</b> where Rabba said that the thrower is liable, <b>he intended</b> to throw the object into the dog’s mouth. He is liable because his intention was realized.
<b>Rav Beivai bar Abaye said: We also learned</b> support for that distinction in a mishna: <b>There is a person</b> who performs a single act of <b>eating</b> an olive-bulk of food, <b>and he is liable to bring four sin-offerings and one guilt-offering.</b> How so? This <i>halakha</i> applies to one who is <b>ritually impure who ate forbidden fat</b> that was <b><i>notar</i> from a consecrated offering,</b> i.e., it remained after the time when it may have been eaten expired, and this happened <b>on Yom Kippur.</b> The person who did this is liable to bring one sin-offering for eating consecrated food while impure, one for eating forbidden fat, one for eating <i>notar</i>, and one for eating on Yom Kippur. He is also liable to bring a guilt-offering for misuse of consecrated items.
<b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> There is one more sin-offering for which he may be liable. <b>In addition, if it was Shabbat and he carried</b> this olive-bulk of food from one domain to another <b>in his mouth, he is liable</b> for carrying out on Shabbat. The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Meir: Liability for the sin-offering that you added <b>is not</b> incurred <b>from</b> violation <b>of the</b> same <b>type</b> of prohibition. He is liable for carrying out the food, not for eating it. However, fundamentally, the Rabbis agree that one would be liable for carrying out in that case. The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> would one be liable? <b>That</b> carrying, which was done in one’s mouth, <b>is not the typical manner of carrying out. Rather,</b> it must be that <b>since he intended</b> to carry out the object in that manner, <b>his thought</b> renders his mouth a suitable <b>place</b> for placement of an object. <b>Here, too, since he intends</b> to throw the object into the dog’s mouth, <b>his thought</b> renders the dog’s mouth a suitable <b>place</b> for placement of an object, and he is liable for throwing it there.

Daf 102b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who builds</b> on Shabbat, thereby violating a prohibition in a primary category of prohibited labor, <b>how much</b> must <b>he build</b> to <b>be liable</b> to bring a sin-offering? The Sages said: <b>One who builds</b> is liable for building <b>any amount. And one who chisels, or strikes with a hammer or with an adze,</b> or <b>one who drills</b> a hole <b>of any size</b> on Shabbat, <b>is liable. This is the principle: Anyone who performs a</b> prohibited <b>labor and his labor endures on Shabbat is liable. And so too, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Even one who strikes an anvil with a sledgehammer during his labor</b> has performed a constructive act and <b>is liable, because he is as one who improves the labor</b> that he is performing.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>any</b> small <b>amount</b> of building, <b>for what</b> use <b>is it suited? Rabbi Yirmeya said: As a poor person digs a hole</b> in the floor of his house <b>in which to hide his coins.</b> Digging a hole in the floor of a house is an act of building. The <b>corresponding</b> situation <b>in the Tabernacle</b> was <b>as those who sewed curtains</b> in the Tabernacle <b>dug holes in which to hide their needles. Abaye said: Since</b> needles <b>rust</b> in the ground, <b>they did not do so.</b> The Gemara seeks a different example of small-scale building that is significant. <b>Rather,</b> an example is <b>that a poor person makes legs for a small stove to place a small pot on it.</b> The <b>corresponding</b> situation <b>in the Tabernacle</b> was with regard to <b>those who cooked herbs</b> used <b>to dye curtains, whose</b> dyeing <b>process was lacking</b> a small amount for completion. At that point, it was not worth the effort to cook a large quantity of dye, and so they would <b>make legs for a small stove upon which to place a small cauldron</b> to cook a small bit of dye to finish the job.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said: There is no poverty in a place of wealth.</b> In the Tabernacle, as in any public project, actions are not performed on a small scale or in parsimonious quantities; they were performed generously. Those who cooked dyes in the Tabernacle had no use for small crucibles. <b>Rather,</b> an example of significant small-scale building is <b>a homeowner who has a</b> small <b>hole in his house and seals it.</b> The <b>corresponding</b> situation <b>in the Tabernacle</b> was with regard to <b>a beam that was set upon by a worm</b> that bore a hole into it; one <b>pours lead into</b> the hole <b>and seals it.</b>
<b>Shmuel said:</b> If <b>one sets a stone</b> in place on Shabbat, i.e., he takes a building stone and fixes it in place on the ground on Shabbat, <b>he is liable</b> for performing the prohibited labor of building. The Gemara <b>raises an objection to this</b> from that which the Sages taught with regard to building on Shabbat. In a case where <b>one puts down a stone and</b> another <b>one places the mortar, the one who places the mortar is liable</b> for building. Apparently, the prohibition of building is only violated when mortar is added. Merely setting a stone in place is not enough to establish liability.
The Gemara answers: <b>And according to your</b> line of <b>reasoning, say the latter clause</b> of that mishna where we learn that <b>Rabbi Yosei says: And even</b> if <b>one lifted</b> the stone <b>and placed it on a top row of stones [<i>dimos</i>], he is liable</b> even without securing it with mortar. <b>Rather,</b> apparently, <b>there are three</b> different kinds of <b>building: Bottom</b> row, <b>middle</b> row, <b>and upper</b> row. <b>The bottom</b> row <b>requires setting</b> the stones in place <b>and dirt</b> to hold it in place. <b>The middle</b> row <b>requires mortar as well. The upper</b> row suffices <b>with mere placement.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>One who chisels</b> any amount is liable. The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>one who chisels, for which</b> primary category of prohibited labor <b>is he liable? Rav said:</b> He is liable <b>due to</b> the prohibited labor of <b>building. And Shmuel said:</b> He is liable <b>due to</b> the prohibited labor of <b>striking</b> a blow <b>with a hammer</b> to complete the production process of a vessel. They similarly disagreed with regard to <b>one who makes a hole in a chicken coop. Rav said:</b> He is liable <b>due to</b> the prohibited labor of <b>building. And Shmuel said:</b> He is liable <b>due to</b> the prohibited labor of <b>striking</b> a blow <b>with a hammer.</b> And similarly, with regard to <b>one who inserts a pin into the handle of a hoe</b> in order to secure the handle, <b>Rav said:</b> He is liable <b>due to</b> the prohibited labor of <b>building. And Shmuel said:</b> He is liable <b>due to</b> the prohibited labor of <b>striking</b> a blow <b>with a hammer.</b>
