However, <b>these,</b> the crippled, old, and sick deer, <b>are not likely to run away</b> and are therefore considered to be already trapped. The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that one who traps a <b>sick</b> deer <b>is liable</b>? <b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, in which a sick deer is not considered trapped and one who traps it is liable is referring to a deer that is <b>sick due to a fever,</b> which can still flee; <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, in which the deer is considered trapped and one who traps it is exempt is referring to a deer that is <b>sick with fatigue</b> and is incapable of fleeing.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who traps locusts, cicadas, hornets, or mosquitoes on Shabbat is liable.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say:</b> Not every insect is the same in this matter. If one traps <b>any</b> insect <b>whose species is</b> typically <b>trapped</b> for personal use, he is <b>liable, and</b> if one traps <b>any</b> insect <b>whose species is</b> typically <b>not trapped</b> for personal use, he is <b>exempt. It was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who traps locusts when there is dew is exempt.</b> Since it is cold at that time, the locusts are paralyzed. If one traps them <b>when it is hot, he is liable. Elazar ben Mehavai says: If</b> the locusts <b>were swarming, one is exempt</b> for trapping them, because no effort is necessary to apprehend them. <b>A dilemma was raised before them:</b> Does the statement of <b>Elazar ben Mehavai apply to the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>, ruling stringently that one is liable for trapping locusts even when there is dew unless they are swarming; or does it <b>apply to the latter</b> clause of the <i>baraita</i>, ruling leniently that one is exempt when trapping locusts, even in the heat when they are swarming? <b>Come and hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma based on a source that addresses the point explicitly: <b>One who traps locusts when there is dew is exempt;</b> one who traps locusts <b>when it is hot is liable. Elazar ben Mehavai says: Even when it is hot, if they were swarming, one is exempt.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a deer entered a house</b> on its own <b>and one locked</b> the door <b>before it, he is liable</b> for trapping. If <b>two</b> people <b>locked</b> the door, <b>they are exempt,</b> because neither performed a complete labor. If <b>one</b> person <b>is incapable of locking</b> the door <b>and two</b> people <b>locked it, they are liable</b> because that is the typical manner of performing that labor. <b>And Rabbi Shimon deems them exempt</b> as he holds that two people who perform a single labor are never liable by Torah law.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: One who traps a lion on Shabbat is not liable</b> for trapping <b>unless he traps it in its cage,</b> and until that point it is not considered trapped.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one person sat in the entrance</b> of a courtyard in which there is a deer, <b>but did not fill</b> the entire doorway, and <b>a second</b> person <b>sat and filled it, the second</b> person <b>is liable</b> because he completed the labor of trapping. However, if <b>the first person sat in the doorway and filled it, and a second person came and sat next to him, the first person is liable and the second is exempt even if the first person stood and went</b> away, leaving the second one to secure the deer. The mishna explains: <b>To what is this</b> second person’s action <b>similar? To one who locks his house to secure it, and it turns out a deer</b> that was trapped before Shabbat <b>is</b> also <b>secured inside it.</b> In that case, he is exempt even though he enhances security on the deer, because he did not trap the animal.

Daf 107a

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> If <b>a bird flew under the flaps of one’s clothing</b> on Shabbat and cannot get out<b>, he may sit and secure it until dark</b> and then take it<b>. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak raised an objection</b> based on that which we learned in the mishna<b>:</b> If <b>the first person sat in the doorway and filled it, and a second person came and sat next to him, the first person is liable and the second is exempt, even if the first person stood and went. What, does this not</b> mean here<b>,</b> as it does throughout tractate <i>Shabbat</i>, that he is <b>exempt</b> after the fact<b>,</b> but <b>it is prohibited</b> to do so <i>ab initio</i>? How then could Rav say one may sit and secure the bird <i>ab initio</i>? The Gemara rejects this<b>: No,</b> the statement in the mishna means that he is <b>exempt and</b> it is <b>permitted</b> <i>ab initio</i>. The Gemara adds<b>: So too, it is reasonable</b> to explain the mishna that way <b>from</b> the fact that it <b>was taught in the latter clause</b> of the mishna<b>: To what is this</b> second person’s action <b>similar? To one who locks his house to secure it, and it turns out a deer</b> that was trapped before Shabbat <b>is</b> also <b>secured inside it. By inference,</b> he is <b>exempt and</b> it is <b>permitted,</b> just like one who locks the door to his house<b>.</b> The Gemara concludes<b>:</b> Indeed<b>, learn from it</b> that it is so<b>.</b>
<b>Some say</b> a slightly different version. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: We too learned</b> support for Rav’s statement in the mishna: <b>Even if the first person stood and went, the first</b> person <b>is liable and the second is exempt. What, does this not</b> mean that he is <b>exempt, and it is permitted?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> he is <b>exempt and</b> it is <b>prohibited.</b> Rav Naḥman said: That is impossible, <b>from</b> the fact <b>that it is taught in the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>To what is this</b> second person’s action <b>similar? To one who locks his house to secure it and it turns out a deer</b> that was trapped before Shabbat <b>is</b> also <b>secured inside it. By inference,</b> he is <b>exempt and</b> it is <b>permitted,</b> just like one who locks the door to his house. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that it is so.
With regard to this issue <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>all exempt</b> rulings in the <i>halakhot</i> <b>of Shabbat,</b> although one who performs the action is <b>exempt</b> by Torah law, his action is <b>prohibited</b> by rabbinic law, <b>with the exception of these three</b> for which he is <b>exempt and</b> it is <b>permitted</b> to perform the action.<br><b>One is this</b> case of the deer. <b>And from what</b> source do we conclude that one is <b>exempt and</b> it is <b>permitted? From</b> the fact that it <b>was taught in the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>To what is this</b> second person’s action <b>similar? To one who locks his house to secure it and it turns out a deer</b> that was trapped before Shabbat <b>is</b> also <b>secured inside.</b> <br><b>And another</b> example where he is exempt and it is permitted is: <b>One who drains an abscess</b> containing pus <b>on Shabbat, if</b> he did so <b>to create a</b> permanent <b>opening in it, he is liable.</b> However, <b>if</b> he did so <b>to drain fluid from it, he is exempt. And from what</b> source do we conclude that one is <b>exempt and</b> it is <b>permitted? As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>A hand needle</b> used for sewing clothes may be moved on Shabbat <b>to remove a thorn.</b> Apparently, removing a thorn on Shabbat is permitted <i>ab initio</i> to the extent that one is even permitted to move a needle for that purpose. <br><b>And another</b> case is: <b>One who traps a snake on Shabbat, if</b> he <b>deals with it so that it will not bite him</b> and in doing so traps it, <b>he is exempt.</b> However, <b>if</b> he traps it <b>for medicinal</b> purposes, <b>he is liable. And from what</b> source do we conclude that one is <b>exempt and</b> it is <b>permitted? As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One may overturn a bowl on top of a lamp</b> <i>ab initio</i> on Shabbat <b>so that</b> the fire <b>will not take hold</b> in <b>the ceiling beam; and</b> similarly, one may overturn a bowl <b>on top of a child’s feces</b> so that he will not touch it and dirty himself, <b>and on top of a scorpion so it will not bite,</b> and the ruling is the same with regard to a snake.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to any of <b>the eight creeping animals mentioned in the Torah, one who traps them or wounds them</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable.</b> The Torah states: “The following shall be impure for you among the creeping animals that swarm upon the earth: The weasel, and the mouse, and the dab lizard of every variety; and the gecko, and the land-crocodile, and the lizard, and the skink, and the chameleon” (Leviticus 11:29–30). With regard to <b>other abominations and crawling things, one who wounds them is exempt. One who traps them for</b> a specific <b>need is liable;</b> one who traps them <b>for no</b> specific <b>need is exempt.</b> With regard to <b>animals or birds that are in his possession,</b> i.e., an animal that is domesticated and under someone’s control, <b>one who traps them is exempt; and,</b> however, <b>one who wounds them is liable.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it is taught</b> in the mishna: <b>One who wounds them is liable, by inference they have skins.</b> One is liable for inflicting a wound only when there is skin covering the flesh and the blood pools beneath it. <b>Who is</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who teaches this? <b>Shmuel said: It is Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri, as we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says: The eight creeping animals</b> that are listed in the Torah <b>have skins.</b> Their flesh transmits impurity, but their skin does not transmit impurity. The Rabbis say that both the skin and the flesh of some creeping animals transmit impurity. <b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav</b> said: <b>Even if you say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of the <b>Rabbis, the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri only with regard to the matter</b> of <b>impurity, as it is written</b> after the Torah lists the creeping animals: <b>“Those are for you the impure</b> among the creeping animals, whoever touches them when they are dead shall become impure until evening” (Leviticus 11:31). The Rabbis derive from the extraneous term: “Those are for you the impure,” <b>to include the</b> fact that the <b>skins of</b> the creatures in the second verse transmit impurity just <b>as their flesh</b> does. <b>However, with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat, even the Rabbis concede</b> that their skin is distinct from their flesh.
The Gemara asks: <b>And, with regard to Shabbat, they do not disagree? Wasn’t</b> the following <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>? <b>One who traps one of the eight creeping animals mentioned in the Torah</b> or <b>one who wounds them is liable;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri. And the Rabbis say:</b> The term <b>skin is</b> utilized <b>only</b>

Daf 107b

with regard to those animals <b>enumerated by the Sages</b> as having skin, since their skin is considered by the Sages to be similar to their flesh. The Gemara asks: <b>On the contrary, those that the Sages enumerated</b>, whose skin and flesh are equated, <b>do not have skins. And Abaye said: This is what</b> the <i>tanna</i> in the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Only those that the Sages did not enumerate have skin discrete from</b> their <b>flesh. Rava said to him: Doesn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>say</b> the opposite: <b>That those enumerated by the Sages</b> have skin discrete from their flesh? <b>Rather, Rava said: This is what</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Only the skin of those</b> animals <b>enumerated by the Sages transmits impurity like flesh.</b> The Gemara asks: Is that to say <b>by inference that Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri</b> holds that even the creeping animals <b>not enumerated by the Sages also transmit impurity? Isn’t</b> the opposite <b>taught,</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says:</b> The <b>eight creeping animals have skin</b> that <b>does not transmit impurity? Rav Adda bar Mattana said</b> to <b>resolve</b> it <b>this way: And the Rabbis say: With regard to impurity, those</b> animals <b>enumerated by</b> the <b>Sages do not have skin.</b> According to this explanation, Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri and the Rabbis disagree only with regard to the laws of impurity.
<b>But still,</b> is it clear that <b>they do not disagree with regard to the matter of Shabbat? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who traps one of the eight creeping animals mentioned in the Torah</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable,</b> as is <b>one who wounds them, if they are creeping animals that have skins? And what is</b> considered to be <b>an irreversible wound?</b> It is a wound where <b>the blood collects</b> in a single spot beneath the skin, <b>even if it does not emerge. Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri says:</b> The <b>eight creeping animals have skins.</b> Apparently, there is disagreement with regard to Shabbat as well.
<b>Rav Ashi said: Who is</b> the <b>first <i>tanna</i>?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who follows the texture</b> of the skin. He does not distinguish between those creeping animals whose skin is considered like flesh and those whose skin is discrete from the flesh as the verses may imply; rather, creeping animals are distinguished based on the texture of their skin, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Even though <b>the lizard</b> is mentioned in the verse, it has <b>the same</b> ruling <b>as the weasel</b> because the weasel has skin discrete from its flesh. <b>However, the Rabbis, who disagree with Rabbi Yoḥanan with regard to impurity, concede with regard to Shabbat</b> and hold that all creeping animals have skins. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, the</b> phrase in the <i>baraita</i>: This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri,</b> is difficult. <b>It should</b> have said: This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> ben Nuri <b>and those who disagree with him,</b> as the Rabbis who disagree with him with regard to impurity concede to him with regard to the laws of Shabbat. The Gemara responds: This is not difficult. Emend the <i>baraita</i> and <b>teach: The statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri and those who disagree with him.</b>
<b>Levi raised a dilemma before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that a wound is</b> defined as something <b>irreversible?</b> He answered him that it is derived <b>as it is written: “Can a Cushite change his skin, or a leopard its spots [<i>ḥavarburotav</i>]?”</b> (Jeremiah 13:23). The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> does <b><i>ḥavarburotav</i></b> mean? <b>If you say that they are spotted marks</b> on the leopard’s skin, <b>that</b> phrase: <b>Or a leopard its spots, should</b> have been: <b>Or a leopard its colors. Rather,</b> <i>ḥavarburotav</i> means wounds, and they are <b>similar to</b> the skin of <b>a Cushite: Just like the skin of a Cushite will not change</b> its color to white, <b>so too a wound</b> is something that <b>does not reverse.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>And</b> one who traps <b>other abominations</b> is exempt. The Gemara infers: If <b>one kills them</b> he is <b>liable.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who holds this opinion? <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: One who kills lice on Shabbat is akin to one who kills a camel on Shabbat.</b> Apparently, he is the Sage who holds that one is liable for killing any living creature. <b>Rav Yosef strongly objects to this:</b> Perhaps this is not so, as <b>the Rabbis disagree with Rabbi Eliezer only with regard to lice,</b> which <b>do not procreate. However,</b> with regard to <b>other abominations and crawling things that procreate, they do not disagree</b> with him.
<b>And</b> fundamentally <b>they both derived</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the reddened <b>ram</b> skins used to cover the Tabernacle. <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds</b> that liability for killing an animal on Shabbat exists only with regard to animals <b>like rams. Just as rams have their lives taken</b> and die, <b>so too,</b> one is liable for killing <b>any animal whose life is taken,</b> including lice. <b>And the Rabbis</b> also <b>hold</b> that liability for killing an animal on Shabbat exists only with regard to animals <b>like rams. Just as rams procreate, so too,</b> one is liable for killing <b>any</b> creature <b>that procreates.</b> One is not liable for killing lice, which do not procreate. <b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>And lice do not procreate? Didn’t the Master say: The Holy One, Blessed be He, sits and sustains</b> everything <b>from the horns of wild oxen to the eggs of lice?</b> Apparently, lice reproduce by laying eggs. Rav Yosef answered him: <b>There is a species</b> of insect <b>that is called lice eggs,</b> but lice themselves do not actually lay eggs.
Again he asked: <b>And wasn’t it taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that lists types of creeping animals: <b><i>Tefuyei</i>,</b> a type of insect, <b>and lice eggs?</b> He answered him: <b>There is a species</b> of insect <b>called lice eggs.</b> Again he asked: <b>And</b> still, there is the issue of <b>a flea, which procreates</b> according to all opinions, <b>and nevertheless, it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who traps a flea on Shabbat, Rabbi Eliezer deems him liable and Rabbi Yehoshua deems him exempt. Rav Ashi said: Are you raising a contradiction between trapping</b> with <b>killing? Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua disagree only</b> in <b>that</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that <b>one is liable</b> for trapping even <b>a species that is not typically trapped; and</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>holds</b> that one is <b>exempt</b> in that case. <b>However, with regard to killing, even Rabbi Yehoshua concedes</b> that one is liable.
We learned in the mishna that <b>one who traps</b> creeping animals <b>for</b> a specific <b>need is liable,</b> but one who traps them for no specific need is exempt. The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who holds this way? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: It is Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that for <b>a</b> prohibited <b>labor</b> performed <b>not for its own sake, one is exempt.</b>
<b>Some taught</b> the statement of Rav in reference <b>to this:</b> With regard to <b>one who drains an abscess</b> in a boil containing pus <b>on Shabbat, if</b> his intention is <b>to create an opening for it</b> he <b>is liable; if</b> his intention is <b>to remove pus from it he is exempt.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who holds this way? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: It is Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that for <b>a</b> prohibited <b>labor</b> performed <b>not for its own sake, one is exempt.</b>
<b>Some teach the statement of</b> Rav as referring <b>to this:</b> With regard to <b>one who traps a snake on Shabbat, if</b> he <b>engages</b> in <b>its</b> trapping <b>so it does not bite him, he is exempt; if</b> he does so <b>for medicinal</b> purposes <b>he is liable.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who holds this way? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: It is Rabbi Shimon, who said</b> that for <b>a</b> prohibited <b>labor</b> performed <b>not for its own sake, one is exempt.</b>
<b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>one who removes a fish from the sea, when</b> an area on the skin of the fish <b>has dried up the size of a <i>sela</i>,</b> he is <b>liable.</b> A fish in that condition cannot survive, and therefore the individual who removed it from the water is liable for killing it. <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Avin said:</b> That is so <b>as long as</b> the skin that dried is <b>between its fins. Rav Ashi said: Do not say</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies only in a case where <b>it actually dried. Rather,</b> it applies <b>even if</b> the fish has dried to the extent <b>that mucus has formed,</b> and if one were to touch that area it would stick to his fingers.
<b>Mar bar Hamdurei said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: One who reached his hand into the innards of an animal</b> on Shabbat <b>and detached a fetus that was in its womb is liable.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It does not make sense to consider the fetus as a full-fledged living creature. <b>Rava said: Bar Hamdurei explained</b> this <b>to me. Didn’t Rav Sheshet say: One</b> who <b>detaches hops</b> on Shabbat <b>from the shrubs and thorns</b> on which they are growing <b>is liable for uprooting an object from its</b> place of <b>growth? Here, too,</b> in the case of the fetus, <b>one is liable for uprooting an object from its</b> place of <b>growth. Abaye said: One who detached</b>

Daf 108a

<b>a mushroom from the handle of a pitcher</b> on Shabbat <b>is liable for uprooting an object from its</b> place of <b>growth. Rav Oshaya raised an objection</b> from that which we learned: <b>One who detaches</b> a plant on Shabbat <b>from a perforated flowerpot is liable, and</b> one who detaches a plant from <b>an imperforate</b> pot <b>is exempt.</b> A plant that grows in an imperforate pot is not considered connected to the ground. One who detaches it is not uprooting it from its place of growth. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> in the case of an imperforate pot, <b>that is not</b> the way a plant <b>grows.</b> Plants are generally planted in the ground; a plant in an imperforate pot is disconnected from the ground. Whereas <b>here,</b> in the case of a mushroom growing from the handle of a pitcher, <b>that is</b> the way <b>it grows.</b> The plant is considered connected to the ground.
We learned in the mishna: One who wounds <b>an animal or a bird</b> on Shabbat is liable. <b>Rav Huna said: One may write phylacteries on</b> the <b>skin of a kosher bird. Rav Yosef said: What is he teaching us</b> with this statement? If he is teaching us <b>that</b> a bird <b>has skin, we</b> already <b>learned</b> that: <b>One who wounds</b> an animal or a bird <b>is liable.</b> Since there is liability only if a wound forms beneath the skin, apparently a bird has skin. <b>Abaye said to him: He is teaching us many things, for if</b> I had only learned <b>from the mishna, I would have said</b> the following: <b>Since</b> the skin of a bird <b>has many holes</b> from which the feathers grow, one should <b>not</b> be allowed to write sacred matters on it. Therefore, <b>he teaches us as they say in the West,</b> i.e., in Eretz Yisrael: <b>Any hole over which ink passes</b> and does not penetrate it, <b>is not</b> considered <b>a hole</b> that invalidates the writing.
<b>Rabbi Zeira raised an objection</b> to the conclusion that the skin of a bird is considered skin. Didn’t we learn in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse: “And he shall rend it <b>by its wings</b> without creating a division, and the priest shall burn it upon the altar on the wood that is on the fire” (Leviticus 1:17), teaches that the priest <b>must prepare</b> even <b>the skin</b> to make it acceptable for the altar? That is not the case when animals are offered, as their skin is flayed before they are sacrificed. <b>And if it should enter your mind</b> that the skin of a bird <b>is skin, how does the verse include it</b> among that which the priest prepares for the altar? <b>Abaye said:</b> This is not difficult. Indeed, <b>it is skin, and</b> nevertheless, <b>the Torah includes it</b> as a biblical decree, specifying that the skin of a bird is sacrificed.
<b>Some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Zeira said: We, too, have also learned</b> support for this <i>halakha</i>: The verse: <b>“By its wings,”</b> comes <b>to include the skin. Granted, if you say</b> that the skin of a bird <b>is skin, that is</b> the reason that <b>the verse needs to</b> explicitly <b>include it.</b> The verse is teaching us that even though the bird’s skin is skin, it must still be sacrificed. <b>However, if you say</b> that the skin of a bird <b>is not skin, why is a verse necessary to include it?</b> Clearly, it is sacrificed. <b>Abaye said to him:</b> That is not proof. <b>Actually, I</b> can <b>say to you</b> that <b>it is not skin and,</b> nevertheless, <b>it must be</b> included in the verse. Had the skin of the bird not been specifically included, <b>it might have entered your mind to say</b> that <b>since there are many holes in it,</b> it is <b>repulsive</b> and unfit for the altar. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that it is sacrificed. There is no proof that the skin of a bird is considered skin.
<b>Mar, son</b> of <b>Ravina, raised a dilemma before Rav Naḥman bar Yitzhak: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>writing phylacteries on the skin of a kosher fish?</b> Rav Naḥman bar Yitzhak <b>said to him: If Elijah comes and says.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What does</b> the phrase: <b>If Elijah comes and says,</b> mean? What requires clarification? <b>If you say</b> that <b>whether</b> a fish <b>has skin or whether it does not have skin</b> requires clarification, <b>we see that it has skin. And furthermore, we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Fish bones and skin protect</b> the objects covered with them from becoming impure <b>under a tent</b> with a <b>corpse.</b> Since fish bones and skin do not contract impurity, they constitute a barrier to impurity. Apparently, fish have skin. <b>Rather, if Elijah comes and says whether its foul smell has ceased from it or whether its foul smell has not ceased from it.</b>
It was reported: <b>Shmuel and Karna were sitting on the bank of the Malka River. They saw that the water was rising and was murky.</b> Shmuel <b>said to Karna: A great man is coming from the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>and his intestines are aching, and the water is rising to greet him. Go sniff</b> out <b>his container,</b> i.e., see if he is a Torah scholar. Karna <b>went</b> and <b>found Rav,</b> who was the Sage that came from Eretz Yisrael, and he asked him several questions to test him. <b>He said to him: From where</b> is it derived <b>that one may write phylacteries only on the hide of a kosher animal?</b> Rav <b>said to him</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is <b>as it is written:</b> “And it shall be a sign for you on your arm, and a reminder between your eyes, <b>so that God’s Torah will be in your mouth”</b> (Exodus 13:9). Only hide <b>from those</b> animals <b>that are permitted</b> to be placed <b>in your mouth,</b> i.e., may be eaten, may be used for phylacteries. Karna then asked him: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> prohibited <b>blood is red?</b> Karna asked Rav this to determine which shades of menstrual blood are impure. Rav said to him that it is <b>as it is stated: “And the Moabites saw the water from afar, red like blood”</b> (II Kings 3:22).
Karna also asked: <b>From where</b> is derived <b>that circumcision is</b> performed <b>in that place?</b> Rav answered him: <b>It is stated here,</b> with regard to circumcision: “And on the eighth day he shall circumcise the flesh of <b>his foreskin [<i>orlato</i>]</b>” (Leviticus 12:3), <b>and it is stated there,</b> with regard to recently planted trees: “And when you come to the land and plant all types of fruit trees, and you shall count the fruit <b>thereof as forbidden [<i>orlato</i>];</b> three years shall it be as forbidden unto you, it shall not be eaten.” (Leviticus 19:23). <b>Just as there</b> the Torah is referring to a tree, which <b>is an item that bears fruit, here, too,</b> in the case of circumcision, <i>orla</i> is referring to <b>an item that bears fruit.</b> He asked him: <b>Say</b> that circumcision should be performed on <b>one’s heart, as it is written: “And you shall circumcise the foreskin of [<i>orlat</i>] your heart”</b> (Deuteronomy 10:16)? <b>Say</b> that circumcision should be performed on <b>one’s ear, as it is written: “Behold, their ear is dull [<i>areila</i>]</b> and they cannot listen” (Jeremiah 6:10)? Rav said to him: <b>One derives</b> the meaning of the <b>complete</b> form <b><i>orlato</i> from</b> another instance of the <b>complete</b> form <b><i>orlato</i>; and one does not derive</b> the <b>complete</b> form <b><i>orlato</i> from</b> the <b>incomplete</b> form <b><i>orlat,</i></b> which modifies another word, as is also the case with the word <i>areila</i>.
Since Rav understood that Karna came to test him, he <b>said to him: What is your name?</b> He told him: <b>Karna.</b> He <b>said to him: May it be the will</b> of God <b>that a horn [<i>karna</i>] will emerge in his eyes.</b>
<b>Ultimately,</b> Shmuel <b>brought him into his house. He fed him barley bread and small fried fish, and gave him beer to drink, and he did not show him the lavatory so he would suffer from diarrhea.</b> Shmuel was a doctor and he wanted to relieve Rav’s intestinal suffering by feeding him food that would relieve him. Since Rav was unaware of Shmuel’s intention, he became angry at him. <b>Rav cursed</b> Shmuel <b>and said: Whoever causes me suffering, let his children not survive.</b> Although Rav eventually discovered Shmuel’s good intentions, his curse was fulfilled, <b>and so it was</b> that Shmuel’s children did not survive long.
The Gemara comments: The issue mentioned above is in fact a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> It was asked in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that <i>circumcision</i></b> is performed <b>in that place?</b> It is <b>stated here,</b> in the case of circumcision, <b><i>orlato</i>. And</b> it is <b>stated there,</b> with regard to trees, <b><i>orlato</i>. Just as there</b> the Torah is referring to a tree, which <b>is an item that bears fruit, here too,</b> <i>orla</i> is referring to <b>an item that bears fruit;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya. Rabbi Natan says:</b> This verbal analogy <b><i>is not necessary</i></b>, <b>as it says: “And an uncircumcised man who does not circumcise the flesh of his foreskin [<i>orlato</i>],</b> his soul will be cut off from his nation, he has broken My covenant” (Genesis 17:14). From the fact that it says: An uncircumcised man, it is derived that circumcision is in the <b>place that distinguishes between a male and a female.</b>
The Gemara cites similar proofs. <b>The Sages taught: One may write phylacteries on the hide of a kosher domesticated animal, and on the hide of a kosher non-domesticated animal, and on the hides of their</b> unslaughtered <b>carcasses [<i>neveilot</i>], and</b> on the hides <b>of animals with a condition that will cause them to die within twelve months [<i>tereifot</i>]. And one may wrap</b> the parchment <b>with the hair of these</b> animals <b>and sew</b> them <b>with their sinews;</b> and it is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai that</b> the parchment of <b>phylacteries may be wrapped with the hair of these</b> animals <b>and sewn with their sinews. But one may not write on the hide of a non-kosher animal, or on the hide of a non-kosher undomesticated animal, and it goes without saying</b> that one may not write <b>on their skins</b> when they are <b><i>neveilot</i></b> or <b><i>tereifot</i>. And one may not wrap</b> the parchment <b>with the hair</b> of non-kosher animals, <b>nor may one sew</b> them <b>with their sinews.</b>
<b>And this question was asked by a Boethusian to Rabbi Yehoshua HaGarsi: From where</b> is it derived <b>that one may not write phylacteries on the hide of a non-kosher animal?</b> He said to him, it is <b>as it is written:</b> “<b>So that God’s Torah will be in your mouth.”</b> The Rabbis derived that one may write the passages only on <b>an item that is permitted</b> to be placed <b>in one’s mouth,</b> i.e., eaten. He said to him: <b>If</b> that is <b>so</b>, <b>on the skin of <i>neveilot</i> and <i>tereifot</i></b> coming from kosher animals, <b>one</b> should <b>not write</b> phylacteries, as they may not be eaten. <b>He said to him: I will tell you a parable. To what is this similar? To two people who were sentenced to death by the king. One was killed</b> by the <b>king</b> himself, <b>and one was killed</b> by an <b>executioner [<i>ispaklitor</i>]. Which one is</b> more <b>praiseworthy? You</b> must <b>say:</b> The one <b>that</b> the <b>king</b> himself <b>killed.</b> Therefore, an animal that died at the hands of Heaven and not by a human action is superior. He said to him: If so, <b>then</b> the <i>neveilot</i> and <i>tereifot</i> <b>should be eaten,</b> as they were killed by the king. <b>He said to him: The Torah said: “Do not eat any <i>neveila</i>”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:20) <b>and you say they should be eaten?</b> A Torah decree determines that they may not be eaten, but that does not mean they are inferior. The Boethusian <b>said to him: Well put [<i>kalos</i>].</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may not make brine [<i>hilmei</i>] on Shabbat,</b>

Daf 108b

<b>but one may make salt water and dip one’s bread in it, and place it in cooked food. Rabbi Yosei said: But isn’t it</b> still <b>brine, whether</b> it is <b>a large quantity or whether</b> it is <b>a small quantity? And this is</b> the type of <b>salt water that is permitted:</b> Salt water in which <b>one places oil initially into the water or into the salt.</b> This is salt water prepared not in the usual manner.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to that which was stated in the mishna, the Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>saying</b> with regard to the distinction between brine and salt water? <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: This is what he is saying: One may not prepare a large quantity of salt water,</b> brine, <b>on Shabbat, but one may prepare a small quantity of salt water.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yosei said: But isn’t it</b> still <b>brine whether</b> it is <b>a large quantity or a small quantity? A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: When <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> said that there is no difference between a large and small quantity of salt water, was his intention <b>to prohibit</b> preparing any salt water on Shabbat or <b>to permit</b> doing so? <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> His intention is <b>to permit</b> doing so, which is understood <b>from</b> the fact that the mishna <b>is not teaching: Rabbi Yosei prohibits. Rabba said to him: From</b> the fact <b>that it is taught in the latter</b> clause of the mishna: <b>And this is</b> the type of <b>salt water that is permitted, by inference, Rabbi Yosei</b> intended <b>to prohibit</b> preparing salt water. <b>Rather, Rabba said:</b> Rabbi Yosei intended <b>to prohibit</b> preparing any salt water on Shabbat. <b>And similarly, Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Rabbi Yosei’s intention was <b>to prohibit.</b>
<b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not prepare a large quantity of salt water to add to the pickled</b> vegetables <b>that are inside a</b> flat <b>earthenware shard</b> used for pickling [<b><i>gistera</i>]</b>. <b>However, one may prepare a small quantity of salt water and eat his bread with it and add it to cooked food. Rabbi Yosei said: Is it because this is a large quantity and this is a small quantity</b> that <b>this is prohibited and this is permitted?</b> People <b>will</b> learn from this and <b>say: A large</b> amount of <b>labor is prohibited</b> on Shabbat, but <b>a small</b> amount of <b>labor is permitted. Rather,</b> certainly <b>they are both prohibited. And this is</b> the type of <b>salt water that is permitted: One may place oil and salt</b> together <b>or oil and water</b> and then add salt to the mixture, <b>and</b> this <i>halakha</i> applies <b>provided one does not place water and salt</b> together <b><i>ab initio</i></b>.
<b>Strong, radish, and citron are a mnemonic</b> for the following <i>halakhot</i>.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda bar Ḥaviva taught: One may not prepare strong salt water</b> on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>What is strong salt water? Rabba and Rav Yosef bar Abba both said: Any</b> water <b>in which an egg can float.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> salt is in this salt water? <b>Abaye said: Two-thirds salt and one-third water.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> purpose is this salt water <b>prepared? Rabbi Abbahu said:</b> It is prepared <b>for fish brine [<i>muraisa</i>]<i>.</i></b> And <b>Rabbi Yehuda bar Ḥaviva taught</b> with regard to salting: <b>One may not salt a radish or an egg on Shabbat</b> because by salting them he performs a labor that improves them. <b>Rav Ḥizkiya said in the name of Abaye:</b> Preparing <b>a radish is prohibited, and</b> preparing <b>an egg is permitted. Rav Naḥman said: Initially, I would salt radishes</b> on Shabbat, as <b>I said: I am ruining it</b> by doing so, <b>as Shmuel said: Sharpness is good</b> for <b>radishes;</b> since salt reduces their sharpness, one who adds salt ruins the radish. However, <b>once I heard this, that when Ulla came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said</b> that <b>in the West,</b> i.e., Eretz Yisrael, <b>they salt many piles</b> of radishes throughout the week, I <b>do not salt</b> them on Shabbat anymore, but <b>I certainly dip</b> them in salt because that is not considered to be an improvement.
The Gemara cites that which <b>Rabbi Yehuda bar Ḥaviva taught</b> with regard to radishes and eggs: With regard to <b>a citron, a radish, and an egg, if it were not for their outer peel,</b> or egg white, <b>they would never emerge from the intestines,</b> because they are extremely hard to digest.
<b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said: No person has ever drowned in the Sea of Sodom,</b> the Dead Sea. Since there is so much salt, people easily float in it. <b>Rav Yosef said: Sodom is overturned and</b> Rav Dimi’s <b>statement is backward.</b> Is his statement saying that <b>it is a man who does not drown</b> in the Dead Sea, but <b>a plank sinks? Abaye said to him: He is saying</b> his statement utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary: It is not necessary</b> to mention <b>a plank</b> because it <b>does not sink in any</b> body of <b>water in the world. But even a man, who drowns in other</b> bodies of <b>water in the world, does not drown in the Sea of Sodom.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are</b> the <b>practical consequences</b> of this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara explains: This <i>halakha</i> is relevant in a case <b>of this</b> kind: <b>Ravin was walking after Rabbi Yirmeya on the shore of the Sea of Sodom.</b> Ravin <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>What is</b> the ruling? Is it permitted <b>to wash oneself with this water on Shabbat,</b> or perhaps it is prohibited because it has healing properties? Rabbi Yirmeya <b>said to him:</b> One may <b>well</b> do so.
Ravin asked another question: When one washes himself on Shabbat in water from the Dead Sea, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is it permitted for him to <b>close and open</b> his eyes in the water so that the water gets inside? Rabbi Yirmeya <b>said to him: That</b> case <b>I did not hear</b>; however, with regard to <b>a similar case,</b> placing wine in one’s eye on Shabbat, <b>I did hear. As Rabbi Zeira said, sometimes he said it in the name</b> of <b>Rav Mattana and sometimes he said it in the name of Mar Ukva, and they both said</b> it <b>in the name</b> of <b>Shmuel’s father and</b> in the name of <b>Levi: One</b> of them <b>said:</b> With regard to placing <b>wine inside the eye</b> on Shabbat, it <b>is prohibited</b> because it heals; <b>on the eye,</b> it <b>is permitted. And one</b> of them <b>said: Bland saliva,</b> saliva from one who has not eaten since waking, <b>even</b> placing it <b>on the eye</b> on Shabbat <b>is prohibited</b> because it is commonly used as medicine.
The Gemara comments: <b>Conclude that Shmuel’s father is the one who said</b> that placing <b>wine inside the eye is prohibited</b> but <b>on the eye is permitted, from</b> the fact <b>that Shmuel said: A person may soak his bread in wine and place it on his eye on Shabbat.</b> He said this after <b>he heard this</b> <i>halakha</i> from <b>whom?</b> Is it <b>not that he heard it from his father?</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>And according to your reasoning, that</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>which Shmuel said: It is prohibited</b> to place <b>bland saliva even on the eye</b> on Shabbat, he said this after <b>he heard this</b> <i>halakha</i> from <b>whom? If we say that he heard it from his father, then Levi,</b> who was cited together with Shmuel’s father in the list of those who stated the <i>halakhot</i>, <b>did</b> he himself <b>not say</b> even <b>one</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rather, one</b> <i>halakha</i> Shmuel <b>heard from his father, and one</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>he heard one from Levi, and we do not know which</b> he heard <b>from his father</b> and <b>which</b> he heard <b>from Levi.</b>
<b>Mar Ukva said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: One may soak eye salves from Shabbat eve and place</b> them <b>on his eyes on Shabbat, and</b> he <b>need not be concerned</b> that he is violating the prohibition against healing on Shabbat. The Gemara relates: <b>Bar Liva’ei was standing before Mar Ukva</b> on Shabbat. <b>He saw</b> Mar Ukva, <b>who was opening and closing</b> his eyes while applying a salve to them. Bar Liva’ei <b>said to him: Master Shmuel certainly did not permit</b> doing <b>all of this. Rabbi Yannai sent</b> a message <b>to Mar Ukva: Can the master send us some of Master Shmuel’s eye salves?</b> Mar Ukva <b>sent him</b> in response: <b>I will send</b> it <b>to you</b> so that <b>you do not say I am miserly, but</b> be aware that <b>this is what Shmuel said:</b> For healing the eyes, <b>better a drop of cold</b> water in the <b>morning and washing the hands and feet with hot water</b> in the <b>evening than all the eye salves in the world.</b> Follow these instructions and you will need nor other cures. <b>That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Mona said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda: Better a drop of cold</b> water in the <b>morning and washing the hands and feet</b> in the <b>evening than all the eye salves in the world.</b>
Apropos Rabbi Mona’s statement with regard to healing, the text cites what <b>he would say</b> about other matters that require special attention: <b>A hand</b> that touches the <b>eye should be severed</b> because it harms the eye. <b>A hand</b> that touches the <b>nose should be severed. A hand</b> that touches the <b>mouth should be severed. A hand</b> that touches the <b>ear should be severed. A hand</b> that touches one’s <b>wound should be severed. A hand</b> that touches one’s <b>member should be severed,</b> lest one arouse himself. <b>A hand</b> that touches one’s <b>anus should be severed,</b> lest one make himself ill. <b>A hand</b>

Daf 109a

that is placed <b>into a barrel</b> of beer <b>should be severed</b> because the beer will not ferment. <b>A hand</b> that frequently touches the eye <b>causes blindness. A hand</b> that frequently touches the ear <b>causes deafness. A hand</b> that touches the nose or mouth <b>causes polyps [<i>polypus</i>]. It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: She is a liberated</b> entity<b>, this</b> evil spirit that rests on one’s hands before they are washed in the morning, <b>and she refuses</b> to leave <b>until one washes his hands three times. Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> When <b>eye shadow</b> is placed on the eyes it <b>causes</b> the evil spirit called <b>the Daughter of the King to pass, and it stops tears and causes eyelashes to grow. That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Eye shadow causes the Daughter of the King to pass, and stops tears and causes eyelashes to grow.</b>
<b>And Mar Ukva said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Leaves</b> that are placed on the eye (Rabbeinu Ḥananel) <b>contain no element of healing,</b> and therefore one may place them on his eyes on Shabbat.<br><b>Rav Yosef said: Coriander contains no element of healing.</b><br><b>Rav Sheshet said: Hops contain no element of healing.</b><br><b>Rav Yosef said: Even for me,</b> who is blind, <b>coriander is harmful.</b> He overstated coriander’s inefficacy, asserting that it is in fact harmful.<br><b>Rav Sheshet said: Arugula even for me,</b> despite my blindness, <b>is beneficial.</b><br><b>And Mar Ukva</b> also <b>said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: All types of hops may</b> be eaten on Shabbat <b>except for <i>teruza</i>,</b> which is used exclusively for medicinal purposes.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: Melon juice,</b> which is beneficial for the intestines, <b>may be</b> strained and drunk on Shabbat (<i>ge’onim</i>). <b>The juice of <i>pipuim</i>,</b> which are a type of vegetable (Rashba), <b>may not be</b> drunk on Shabbat. The Gemara relates: <b>Ze’iri’s wife made</b> melon juice <b>for Ḥiyya bar Ashi and he did not consume</b> it. <b>She said to him: I made it for your Rabbi,</b> Ze’iri, <b>and he ate</b> it, <b>and you do not eat</b> it? The Gemara explains: <b>Ze’iri</b> followed <b>his own reasoning</b> in permitting this drink, <b>as Ze’iri said: One may place clear wine and clear water into a strainer</b> used to strain dregs from wine <b>on Shabbat without concern. Apparently, since</b> the wine and water <b>are drunk</b> even with what little dregs may remain, <b>one is doing nothing</b> to improve them. <b>Here, too, since</b> melon juice <b>is consumed this way</b>, without being strained and for non-medical purposes, <b>one is doing nothing</b> and it is permitted.
<b>And Mar Ukva</b> also <b>said: One whose hand or foot was wounded may immerse it in wine</b> on Shabbat to stop the flow of blood, <b>and he need not be concerned</b> that he is violating the prohibition against healing on Shabbat. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: With regard to <b>vinegar, what</b> is the ruling? May one immerse a wound in it? <b>Rav Hillel said to Rav Ashi: When we were in Rav Kahana’s house they said</b> that <b>vinegar is not</b> permitted, as it is considered actual medicine. <b>Rava said: And these people from Meḥoza, since they are delicate, even wine heals them.</b> Therefore, they may not immerse their wounds in wine.
The Gemara relates: <b>Ravina happened</b> to come <b>to the house of Rav Ashi. He saw that a donkey stepped on the back of</b> Rav Ashi’s <b>foot, and</b> Rav Ashi <b>sat and immersed</b> his foot <b>in vinegar</b> on Shabbat. Ravina <b>said to</b> Rav Ashi: <b>Does</b> the <b>Master not hold</b> according to <b>that</b> which <b>Rav Hillel stated,</b> that <b>vinegar</b> is <b>not</b> permitted? <b>He said to him: The back of the hand and the back of the foot are different</b> because their wounds are dangerous.
<b>Some say</b> that Ravina <b>saw that</b> Rav Ashi <b>immersed</b> his foot <b>in wine.</b> Ravina <b>said to him: Does</b> the <b>Master not hold</b> according to <b>that</b> which <b>Rava said: These people from Meḥoza, since they are delicate, even wine heals them? And</b> the <b>Master is also delicate.</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to him: The back of the hand and the back of the foot are different, as Rav Adda bar Mattana said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> A wound on <b>the back of the hand or the back of the foot is like a fatal wound, and one may desecrate Shabbat for it.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: On Shabbat, <b>one may bathe in</b> the therapeutic hot springs of the <b>waters of Gerar, in the waters of Ḥamatan, in the waters of Asya, and in the waters of Tiberias; however,</b> one may <b>not</b> bathe <b>in the Great Sea,</b> namely, the Mediterranean sea, <b>nor in water</b> in which flax was <b>soaked, nor in the Sea of Sodom,</b> because people bathe in those bodies of water only for medicinal purposes.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> based on that which was taught in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may bathe in the waters of Tiberias</b> on Shabbat <b>and in the Great Sea; but</b> one may <b>not</b> bathe <b>in water</b> in which flax <b>was soaked, nor in the Sea of Sodom.</b> This is <b>difficult</b> because in the first <i>baraita</i> the Sages prohibit bathing in <b>the Great Sea,</b> and in this <i>baraita</i> they permit bathing in <b>the Great Sea.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> because <b>this</b> <i>baraita,</i> which permits bathing in the Great Sea, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who deems all seas equal. <b>That</b> <i>baraita,</i> which prohibits bathing there, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that the Great Sea is unlike other seas. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>All seas</b> purify <b>like a ritual bath [<i>mikve</i>], as it is stated:</b> “And God called the dry land earth, <b>and the gathering together of the waters [<i>mikve</i>] He called seas”</b> (Genesis 1:10); this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> Only <b>the Great Sea</b> purifies <b>like a ritual bath, and</b> the verse <b>states seas only</b> because <b>there are many seas in</b> the Great Sea, not because all seas purify.
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: All seas purify</b> like a ritual bath. They actually purify even more than a ritual bath, as they purify even <b>when</b> they are <b>flowing.</b> Immersion in a sea is purifying not only when its waters are still, but even when they are flowing. That is not the case with a ritual bath, whose waters only purify when still. <b>And</b> sea water <b>is invalid for</b> purifying <b><i>zavim</i> and lepers and for sanctifying purification water</b> to mix the ashes of the red heifer <b>with it.</b> Those cases require spring water. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak strongly objects to this</b> explanation:

Daf 109b

<b>Say that they disagree</b> over the status of the Mediterranean Sea <b>with regard to impurity and purity,</b> but <b>with regard to Shabbat did you hear</b> that they disagree? <b>Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> The contradiction between the two <i>baraitot</i> is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which prohibits bathing in the Mediterranean, is referring to a case <b>where one remained</b> in the water and thereby indicated that he bathed in the Mediterranean for its curative effects. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits bathing, is referring to a case where <b>one did not remain</b> in the water, and thereby indicated that he bathed in the Mediterranean for non-medical purposes.
The Gemara asks: <b>And how did you establish</b> this <b>last</b> <i>baraita</i>? Do you say that it is referring to a case where <b>one did not remain</b> in the water? <b>If</b> it is referring to a case where <b>one did not remain</b> in the water, it would be permitted to bathe <b>even in water</b> in which flax was <b>soaked, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may bathe</b> on Shabbat <b>in the waters of Tiberias, and in water</b> in which flax was <b>soaked, and in the Sodom Sea, and</b> this is <b>even though one has wounds on his head</b> that are healed by bathing in these waters. <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In a case <b>where one did not remain</b> in the water, since it appears that he entered the water to cool himself. <b>However,</b> if <b>one remained</b> in the water it is <b>prohibited.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the contradiction between the <i>baraita</i> that permits bathing in <b>the Great Sea</b> on Shabbat and the <i>baraita</i> that prohibits bathing in <b>the Great Sea</b> on Shabbat is <b>not difficult.</b> There is a distinction between the two. <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits doing so, is referring <b>to</b> the <b>pure water in it,</b> i.e., the area in the Great Sea in which one bathes for pleasure during the week. <b>That</b> <i>baraita,</i> which prohibits bathing, is referring <b>to</b> the <b>polluted water in it,</b> which people enter only for medicinal purposes. <b>And</b> with regard to the contradiction between one statement with regard to the <b>water</b> in which flax was <b>soaked</b> and the other statement about <b>water</b> in which flax was <b>soaked,</b> it is <b>also not difficult.</b> There is a distinction between the two statements. <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which prohibits bathing on Shabbat in water in which flax was soaked, is referring to a case <b>where one remained</b> in the water and thereby indicated that he was bathing for medicinal purposes. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits bathing on Shabbat in water in which flax was soaked, is referring to a case where <b>one did not remain</b> there. It is permitted to bathe in that water for non-medical purposes.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may not eat <i>eizoveyon</i> on Shabbat because healthy people do not eat it,</b> and therefore it is clear that anyone eating it is doing so for its medicinal value. <b>However, one may eat</b> a plant called <b><i>yo’ezer</i> and may drink <i>abuvro’e</i>.</b> Furthermore, <b>all</b> types of <b>food</b> that healthy people eat <b>may be eaten by a person</b> even <b>for medicinal</b> purposes. <b>And one may drink</b> all <b>drinks except for water from palm trees and a <i>kos ikarin</i> because they are</b> known as a remedy for <b>jaundice.</b> Therefore, it is prohibited to drink them on Shabbat for curative purposes. <b>However, one may drink palm tree water</b> on Shabbat <b>in order</b> to quench <b>his thirst, and one may smear <i>ikarin</i> oil</b> on himself <b>for non-medical purposes.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> Unspecified <b>hyssop</b> mentioned in the Torah is called <b><i>abarta bar hamag</i></b> in Babylonia, and <b><i>eizoveyon</i></b> is called <b><i>abarta bar hing</i>. Ulla said:</b> The hyssop mentioned in the Torah is <b>white sage.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>Ulla happened</b> to come <b>to the house of Rav Shmuel bar Yehuda. They brought white sage before him. He said: This is the hyssop that is written in the Torah. Rav Pappi said:</b> Hyssop is the root called <b><i>shumeshuk</i>. Rav Yirmeya of Difti said: In accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Pappi it is reasonable, as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>The mitzva of hyssop</b> is that one take <b>three branches each with three stems, and <i>shumeshuk</i> is</b> the species <b>that is found with that</b> configuration of three stems on each of its branches. The Gemara says: <b>For what purpose do</b> people <b>eat it?</b> It is eaten <b>for</b> curing <b>intestinal worms. And with what is it eaten?</b> It is eaten <b>with seven black dates. From what do</b> worms <b>come into being</b> in the intestines? They come into being <b>from</b> eating <b>barley flour from a vessel that held</b> the flour <b>for forty days</b> since it was ground.
We learned in the mishna: <b>However, one may eat</b> the <b><i>yo’ezer</i></b> plant. The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>yo’ezer</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: It is the vegetable known as <b><i>potnak</i></b>. <b>For what is it eaten?</b> It is eaten <b>to</b> cure <b>liver worms. With what is it eaten?</b> It is eaten with <b>seven white dates. From what do</b> worms <b>come into being</b> in the liver? <b>From</b> eating <b>raw meat with water on an empty</b> stomach, <b>and from</b> eating <b>fatty meat on an empty</b> stomach, <b>and from</b> eating <b>ox meat on an empty</b> stomach, <b>and from</b> eating <b>nuts on an empty</b> stomach, <b>and from eating fenugreek shoots on an empty</b> stomach <b>and drinking water thereafter.</b>
<b>And if</b> one has liver worms but does <b>not</b> have any <i>potnak</i> handy, or if one has taken <i>potnak</i> and it did not help, <b>he should swallow white cress. And if</b> he does <b>not</b> have that or if it did not help him, <b>he should sit in fast, and take fatty meat and place it on coals and suck</b> the <b>bone and swallow vinegar. And some say:</b> One should <b>not</b> drink <b>vinegar because it is harmful to the liver. And if</b> none of those options are available, <b>let</b> one <b>take the sawdust that was scraped</b> from the shell <b>of a thorn bush from top to bottom, and not from bottom to top,</b> as <b>perhaps</b> then the worms <b>will come out through his mouth. And let</b> one then <b>boil</b> the scrapings <b>in beer at twilight and the next day close his nostrils and drink</b> it. <b>And when he defecates, he should defecate on the trunk of a palm tree.</b>
We learned the mishna: <b>And one may drink <i>abuvro’e</i></b> on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>abuvro’e</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: It is the plant known as <b><i>ḥumtareya.</i></b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>ḥumtareya</i>?</b> It is that which is called <b>the lonely staff.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> purpose <b>is it used?</b> It is used <b>for</b> one who drank <b>exposed</b> water from which we suspect a snake drank and left behind its venom. <b>And if</b> one does <b>not</b> have the lonely staff, or if it was ineffective, <b>let</b> him <b>take five roses and five cups of beer and cook them together until there is a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> of liquid <b>and</b> then <b>drink</b> it.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Aḥadvoi bar Ami’s mother made</b> this remedy <b>for a certain man</b> who had drunk exposed water suspected of having venom in it. She took <b>one rose and one cup of beer</b> and <b>she boiled</b> them. <b>She gave it to him to drink, and lit the oven, and swept out the coals, and placed a brick inside it</b> on which he could sit and not get burned. <b>And something</b> that appeared <b>like a green leaf emerged,</b> i.e., he vomited the venom.
<b>Rav Avya said:</b> The remedy for one who has swallowed venom is to drink <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>of milk from a white goat. Rav Huna bar Yehuda said: Let</b> one <b>bring a sweet citron and make a hole in it, and fill it with honey, and place it among burning coals, and eat it. Rabbi Ḥanina said: Urine that is forty days old</b> is an effective remedy for several maladies: <b>A very small cupful</b> is beneficial in treating <b>a hornet</b> sting. <b>A quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> is beneficial in treating <b>a scorpion</b> bite. <b>Half a <i>log</i></b> is effective in treating one who drank <b>exposed</b> water. <b>A <i>log</i> is even effective</b> in counteracting <b>witchcraft. Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Water in which spinach was boiled <b>[<i>anigron</i>]</b>, <b>and</b> water in which <i>banagri</i> grass was boiled <b>[<i>avangar</i>]</b>, <b>and balsam are effective for both</b> one who drank <b>exposed</b> water <b>and</b> as an antidote <b>for witchcraft.</b>
<b>One who swallowed a snake should be fed hops in salt, and</b> then he should be made to <b>run</b> a distance of <b>three <i>mil</i>.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi saw a person who swallowed a snake,</b> and Rav Ashi <b>appeared</b> to that person <b>as a horseman.</b> Rav Shimi <b>fed him hops with salt and made him run in front of him for three <i>mil</i>, and</b> the snake <b>came out of him in pieces. Some say</b> that <b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi</b> was the one who <b>swallowed a snake,</b> and <b>Elijah came</b> and <b>appeared to</b> Rav Ashi <b>as a horseman. He fed him hops with salt and made him run in front of him for three <i>mil</i>, and</b> the snake <b>came out of him in pieces. One who was bitten by a snake should have the fetus of a white donkey brought</b> to him<b>, and it should be torn open and placed on</b> the snakebite. The Gemara says: <b>And this applies</b> only when the mother does <b>not</b> have a <b>condition that will cause it to die within twelve months</b> [<b><i>tereifa</i>].</b> The Gemara relates: There was <b>a certain</b>

Daf 110a

Jewish <b>official</b> in <b>Pumbedita that was bitten by a snake. There were thirteen white donkeys in Pumbedita</b> and <b>they tore them all</b> open <b>and they were found to be <i>tereifot</i>. There was one</b> donkey <b>on the other side</b> of <b>Pumbedita,</b> and <b>until they went to bring it, a lion ate it. Abaye said to them:</b> Since all of these things have happened, <b>perhaps a snake of the Rabbis bit him, for which there is no cure, as it is written:</b> “One that digs a pit will fall into it, and <b>one who breaches a fence will be bitten by a snake</b>” (Ecclesiastes 10:8). Perhaps this person violated a rabbinic decree, also known as a fence, and was bitten by a snake as punishment. That bite has no cure. <b>They said to him: Yes, my teacher,</b> it is so, <b>as when Rav died Rav Yitzḥak bar Bisna ruled that one may not bring myrtle and</b> palm <b>branches to a wedding hall to</b> accompany <b>bells, and he went</b> and <b>brought myrtle and</b> palm <b>branches to the wedding hall with bells.</b> Therefore, <b>a snake bit him. And</b> it is reported that ultimately the official <b>died.</b>
The Gemara cites additional information about the dangers posed by snakes and how to deal with them. <b>One whom a snake encircled should descend into water and place a basket on</b> his <b>head and remove</b> the snake slowly <b>from him</b> into the basket. <b>And once the snake goes into</b> the basket, <b>let</b> him <b>throw it into the water and climb and emerge. One at whom a snake is angry</b> and is being pursued by a snake, <b>if he has another with him, let</b> him <b>ride him four cubits. And if not, let</b> him <b>jump</b> over <b>a ditch. And if not, let</b> him <b>cross a river. And at night let</b> him <b>place his bed on four barrels and sleep</b> outside beneath <b>the stars. And let</b> one <b>bring four cats and let</b> one <b>tie them to the four legs of the bed. And let</b> one <b>bring twigs and branches and throw them there so that when</b> the cats <b>hear the sound</b> of the snake crawling <b>they will eat it. One who is being pursued</b> by a snake, <b>let</b> him <b>run in sand</b> because a snake cannot move as quickly in sand as a person can.
<b>A woman who is seen</b> by <b>a snake and does not know whether it has directed his attention</b> toward <b>her or whether it has not directed his attention</b> toward <b>her, she should remove her garment and throw it before</b> the snake. <b>If</b> the snake <b>wraps itself in</b> the garments, it is an indication that <b>it has directed his attention</b> toward <b>her; and if not,</b> it is an indication that <b>it has not directed his attention</b> toward <b>her.</b>
<b>What is her remedy</b> so the snake will leave her alone? <b>She should have relations</b> with her husband <b>before</b> the snake. <b>Some say:</b> If she has relations in front of the snake, <b>all the more so that its desire will become stronger. Rather, she should take from her hair and her nails and throw them at</b> the snake, <b>and say</b> the following <b>to it</b> as an incantation: <b>I am a menstruating woman [<i>dishtana</i>]. A woman whom a snake has entered, let them spread her legs and place her on two barrels, and let them bring fatty meat and throw it onto coals. And let them bring her a bowl of cress and fragrant wine and place them there and mix them together. And</b> she should <b>take tongs in her hand, as when</b> the snake <b>smells</b> the <b>fragrance</b> it <b>emerges. And</b> then one <b>should take</b> the snake <b>and burn it in the fire, as if</b> it is <b>not</b> burned, <b>it will come back onto her.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>All</b> types of <b>food</b> that healthy people eat may be eaten by one eating them for medicinal purposes on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: The phrase: <b>All foods, what</b> does it come <b>to include?</b> The Gemara answers: It comes <b>to include spleen for</b> healing <b>teeth</b> and <b>vetch for</b> healing <b>intestines,</b> although they are not common foods. We also learned in the mishna: And one may drink all <b>drinks</b> on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: The phrase: <b>All drinks, what</b> does it come <b>to include?</b> The Gemara answers: It comes <b>to include</b> mixing <b>water in which capers have soaked, with vinegar. Ravina said to Rava: What</b> is the ruling with regard to <b>drinking urine on Shabbat?</b> Rava <b>said to him: We</b> already <b>learned</b> in the mishna: <b>One may drink all drinks, and people do not drink urine</b> and is not considered a drink. It is only consumed for medical purposes and is therefore prohibited.
We learned in the mishna: One may drink anything on Shabbat <b>except for palm tree water [<i>mei dekalim</i>].</b> It was <b>taught</b> slightly differently in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Water that stabs [<i>mei dekarim</i>].</b> The Gemara explains: <b>The one who taught water that stabs</b> means <b>that the</b> waters <b>pierce the gall bladder; and the one who said palm tree water</b> means <b>that they come from two palm trees.</b> In order to explain <b>what palm tree water</b> is, <b>Rabba bar Beruna said: There are two palm trees in Eretz Yisrael, and a spring of water emerges from between them. The first cup</b> one drinks of this water <b>loosens</b> the intestines, <b>another</b> cup <b>causes diarrhea, and another,</b> a third cup, <b>just as it entered</b> as water, <b>so</b> too <b>it emerges. Ulla said: For me, I drink Babylonian beer, and</b> it <b>is more effective than</b> palm tree water in causing diarrhea. The Gemara comments: <b>And this is</b> true. It is effective for the stomach when the person who drinks it <b>has not become accustomed to</b> beer <b>for forty days.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> Water that stabs is <b>Egyptian <i>zitom</i>,</b> which is made from <b>one-third barley, and one-third saffron, and one-third salt. Rav Pappa said:</b> It is <b>one-third wheat, and one-third saffron, and one-third salt and cumin. And</b> this is <b>your mnemonic</b> to remember which said <i>zitom</i> is made from barley: A basket which is called <b><i>sisanei</i>,</b> a word with two <i>samekhs.</i> This word alludes to the fact that Rav Yosef, who has a <i>samekh</i> in his name, is the one who says that Egyptian <i>zitom</i> is made from barley [<i>se’orim</i>], which has the letter <i>sin. Sin</i> is interchangeable with <i>samekh</i>. <b>And one</b> should <b>drink it between Passover and <i>Shavuot</i>. For one whose</b> intestines <b>are blocked,</b> it will <b>loosen</b> his intestines and cure <b>him; and</b> for one <b>whose</b> bowels are <b>loose,</b> it will <b>block him</b> and cure him as well<b>.</b>
<b>And</b> we also learned about a <b><i>kos ikarin</i></b> in the mishna. The Gemara asks: <b>What is a <i>kos ikarin</i>? Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Let</b> one <b>bring the weight of a <i>zuz</i> of Alexandrian gum, and a weight of a <i>zuz</i> of alum, and a weight of a <i>zuz</i> of garden saffron, and let</b> one <b>grind them together.</b> The procedure <b>for</b> treating <b>a <i>zava</i></b> is that she should drink these <b>three</b> ingredients <b>with wine,</b> and she will be cured of her emission <b>and will not become barren. For</b> treating <b>jaundice</b> one should drink <b>two</b> of these ingredients <b>with beer; however, one will become sterile</b> from it. It was said that <b>for</b> treating <b>a <i>zava</i>,</b> she should drink these <b>three</b> ingredients <b>with wine</b> and she will be healed from her emission <b>and will not become barren. And if</b> it is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let one bring three</b>

Daf 110b

<b>vessels full of Persian onions, and boil them in wine, and give it to her to drink. And we say to her: Stop</b> emitting <b>your discharge. And if</b> that is <b>not</b> effective, <b>seat her</b> at a <b>crossroads, and she should take a cup of wine in her hand, and let a person come from behind her and frighten her and say to her: Stop</b> emitting <b>your discharge. And if</b> this is also <b>not</b> effective, <b>bring</b> her <b>a fistful [<i>buna</i>] of cumin, and a fistful of saffron, and a fistful of fenugreek, and cook</b> them <b>in wine, and give it to her to drink, and say to her: Stop</b> emitting <b>your discharge. And if</b> this is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let one bring sixty barrel seals, soak them, and then spread it</b> on her <b>and say to her: Stop</b> emitting <b>your discharge. And if</b> this is also does <b>not</b> effective, <b>let one bring <i>pashtina</i>,</b> a type of grass, <b>boil it in wine, and then spread it</b> on her <b>and say to her: Stop</b> emitting <b>your discharge. And if</b> this is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let one bring a thistle</b> that grows <b>on Roman thorns and burn it, and place its</b> ashes <b>in rags from linen clothing in the summer and in rags from cotton clothing in the winter.</b>
<b>And if</b> this is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let one dig seven pits and burn young</b> grape <b>shoots in them</b> from vines that are <b><i>orla</i>, and place a cup of wine in her hand and raise her up from that</b> pit <b>and sit her in</b> another pit, <b>and raise her from that</b> pit <b>and sit her in this</b> pit, <b>and raise her from that</b> pit <b>and sit her in this</b> other pit. <b>And each and every</b> time <b>say to her: Stop</b> emitting <b>your discharge. And if</b> this is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let one bring fine flour and place it on the bottom half of her</b> body <b>and say to her: Stop</b> emitting <b>your discharge. And if</b> this is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let</b> one <b>bring an ostrich egg and burn it, and place its</b> ashes <b>in linen rags during the summer, and in cotton rags during the winter. And if</b> this is also <b>not</b> effective, <b>let</b> one <b>open a barrel of wine for her,</b> and let her drink it. <b>And if</b> this is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let</b> one <b>hold a barley</b> grain <b>that is found in the dung of a white donkey. If she holds it for one day</b> her discharge <b>will cease for two days; and if she holds it for two days it will cease for three days, and if she holds it for three days it will cease forever.</b>
The Gemara states: <b>For jaundice,</b> one should drink <b>two</b> of the three ingredients mentioned together <b>with beer, and one becomes sterile</b> from it. The Gemara continues to discuss this remedy: <b>And if</b> one does <b>not</b> have these ingredients, i.e., Alexandrian gum, saffron, and alum, or if the remedy did not work, <b>let</b> one <b>bring the head of a salted <i>shibuta</i></b> fish <b>and boil it in beer and drink</b> it. <b>And if</b> this is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let</b> one <b>bring grasshopper brine</b> and drink it. <b>And if one does not have grasshopper brine, let</b> one <b>bring brine</b> of <b>small birds, and enter the bathhouse, and smear himself</b> with it. <b>And if there is no bathhouse, have him stand between the oven and the wall</b> and sweat out his disease. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who seeks to warm</b> this patient up <b>should wrap him</b> tightly <b>in his sheet. Rav Aḥa bar Yosef was sick with</b> this disease, <b>and Rav Kahana performed this</b> remedy <b>for him and he was healed.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>And if</b> this remedy is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let</b> one <b>bring three vessels of Persian dates, and three vessels of dripping wax [<i>kira</i>], and three vessels of red aloe, and boil them in beer and drink</b> it. <b>And if</b> this remedy is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let</b> one <b>bring a donkey foal, and shave the middle of its head, and let blood from the</b> donkey’s <b>forehead, and place it on his</b> own <b>head. And he should take care</b> not to let the blood enter <b>his eyes lest it blind him. And if</b> this is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let</b> one <b>bring a pickled ram’s head and boil it in beer and drink</b> it. <b>And if</b> this is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let</b> him <b>bring a striped something else,</b> i.e., a pig, <b>and tear it open and place it on his heart. And if</b> this is <b>not</b> effective, <b>let</b> him <b>bring leeks from the middle of the row,</b> which are very sharp.
It is reported that <b>a certain Arab was sick with</b> jaundice. <b>He said to the gardener: Take my cloak and give me a row of leeks</b> in exchange. The gardener <b>gave him</b> the row <b>and he ate it.</b> The Arab <b>said to</b> the gardener: <b>Lend me your cloak and I will sleep in it for a short while.</b> The gardener gave it to him and <b>he wrapped himself in it and slept. When he got hot and stood up</b> pieces <b>fell from</b> the cloak <b>bit by bit</b> because the cloak had become very hot from the Arab’s sweat. The Arab tricked the gardener, who ultimately received nothing.
The Gemara discussed the remedy <b>for jaundice,</b> saying that one should drink <b>two</b> of the ingredients mentioned together <b>with beer, and one becomes sterile</b> from it. The Gemara asks: <b>And is it permitted</b> to cause sterility? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that castration of a man is prohibited? The verse states:</b> “Those whose testicles are bruised, or crushed, or torn, or cut, shall not be offered to the Lord, <b>and you shall not do this in your land”</b> (Leviticus 22:24), meaning that <b>you shall not do it to yourselves;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina.</b> Apparently, it is prohibited to castrate a man. The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> prohibition <b>applies</b> only in a case <b>where one intends</b> to castrate. <b>Here,</b> in the cure for jaundice, the sterility <b>happens on its own,</b> incidental to the treatment. Proof is cited from that which <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who seeks to castrate a rooster should remove its comb and it will become castrated on its own.</b> Incidental castration is permitted. The Gemara rejects the proof. <b>Didn’t Rav Ashi say: It is arrogance that it assumes</b> when it has its comb, and when the comb is removed it becomes depressed and no longer procreates. However, it is not actually castrated. <b>Rather,</b> apparently this remedy for jaundice is permitted only for <b>one who is castrated</b> and for whom causing sterility is not a concern.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b>

Daf 111a

<b>Everyone agrees that one who leavens</b> a meal-offering <b>after one who</b> already <b>leavened it is liable</b> for the additional leavening, <b>as it is stated: “It shall not be baked leavened”</b> (Leviticus 6:10), and it is also stated: “No offering that you sacrifice to God <b>shall be made with leaven”</b> (Leviticus 2:11). The Sages interpreted this to mean that one is liable for every act of leavening performed on a Temple offering. Similarly, everyone agrees <b>that one who castrates after one who castrates is liable, as it is stated: “Those whose testicles are bruised, or crushed, or torn, or cut</b>, shall not be offered to the Lord, and you shall not do this in your land” (Leviticus 22:24). Presumably, <b>if one is liable</b> when the seminal vesicles <b>are cut,</b> when the testicles <b>are detached</b> altogether <b>all the more so</b> one is liable. <b>Rather,</b> this comes to <b>include</b> that one who <b>detaches after one who cuts is liable.</b> Apparently, one is liable for sterilizing one who is already castrated. <b>Rather,</b> we must say that it is permitted to use a remedy that causes sterility <b>in an old man</b> who is no longer capable of procreating.
The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say</b> with regard to remedies that restore procreative ability: <b>These have restored me to my youth?</b> Apparently, even an elderly man can procreate with the proper remedy. <b>Rather,</b> the remedy for jaundice was discussed with regard <b>to a woman,</b> who is not commanded to reproduce. The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka,</b> who <b>said:</b> The mitzva is incumbent <b>on both of them,</b> the man and the woman, as <b>it states: “And God blessed them and</b> God <b>said to them: Be fruitful and multiply</b> and fill the earth and conquer it” (Genesis 1:28), <b>what is there to say?</b> How could a woman use this remedy? In his opinion a woman is also commanded to procreate. The Gemara answers: In his opinion, this remedy may be used for <b>an elderly woman or, alternatively, for a barren woman.</b> He would agree that there is no prohibition to cause infertility in a woman who cannot conceive.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who is concerned</b> about pain <b>in his teeth may not sip vinegar through them</b> on Shabbat for medicinal purposes: <b>however, he may dip</b> his food in vinegar <b>in his</b> usual <b>manner</b> and eat it, <b>and if he is healed</b> by the vinegar, <b>he is healed. One who is concerned</b> about pain <b>in his loins may not smear wine and vinegar</b> on them on Shabbat because that is a medical treatment. <b>However, one may smear oil</b> on them. <b>However,</b> one may <b>not</b> use <b>rose oil,</b> which is very expensive and used exclusively as a cure. However, <b>princes may smear</b> with <b>rose oil</b> on <b>their wounds</b> on Shabbat <b>because it is their usual manner to smear</b> rose oil on themselves <b>during the week</b> for pleasure. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: All of the Jewish people are princes,</b> and it is permitted for them to smear rose oil on themselves on Shabbat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Aḥa Arikha,</b> so named for his height as the word <i>arikha</i> literally means long in Aramaic, <b>who is</b> also known as <b>Rav Aha bar Pappa, raised a contradiction before Rabbi Abbahu: We learned</b> in the mishna that <b>one who is concerned</b> about pain <b>in his teeth may not sip vinegar through</b> them on Shabbat. <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>vinegar is beneficial for teeth? Isn’t it written: “Like vinegar to the teeth, and like smoke to the eyes,</b> so is the lazy one to those who send him” (Proverbs 10:26)? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as there is a distinction. <b>This</b> verse, which indicates that vinegar is harmful for teeth, is referring <b>to fruit vinegar. The</b> mishna, which indicates that vinegar is beneficial for teeth, is referring <b>to</b> wine <b>vinegar. And if you wish, say</b> instead that both <b>this and that</b> are referring <b>to</b> wine <b>vinegar.</b> In that case, the distinction is as follows: <b>The</b> mishna, which states that vinegar is beneficial for teeth, is referring to a situation in which <b>there is a wound</b> in the teeth. <b>That</b> verse, which indicates that it is harmful for teeth, is referring to a situation in which <b>there is not a wound</b> in the teeth. The Gemara explains: Where <b>there is a wound,</b> vinegar <b>heals</b>; where <b>there is not a wound,</b> it <b>weakens</b> the teeth.
We learned in the mishna: <b>One may not sip vinegar through</b> his teeth on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the prohibition to sip vinegar on Shabbat means that <b>one may not sip and spit</b> it <b>out; however, one may sip and swallow</b> it? <b>Abaye said: When we learned</b> this ruling in <b>the mishna, we learned</b> it with regard to the case of <b>one who sips and spits</b> it <b>out.
