Rava said: Even if you say</b> that the mishna prohibits sipping vinegar even in a case where <b>one sips and swallows</b> it, there is still a distinction. <b>Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> permits sipping vinegar <b>before dipping</b> one’s food in it, as he appears to be doing so for pleasure. <b>Here,</b> the mishna prohibits sipping vinegar <b>after dipping,</b> when it is clear that one is doing so for medicinal purposes.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let us say</b> that <b>since before dipping it,</b> sipping it <b>is permitted, after dipping it</b> sipping it <b>is also permitted. As we heard that Rava accepts</b> the principle of <b>since.</b> The principle of since is illustrated in the following example: The Sages discussed whether one may immerse himself in a ritual bath on Shabbat, even though immersion is similar to repairing oneself through purification and is therefore prohibited. The conclusion of that discussion was that immersion is permitted because it appears as if the individual is bathing for pleasure. On the other hand, immersion is prohibited on Yom Kippur, as bathing for pleasure is prohibited then.
<b>Rava said: There is nothing that is permitted on Shabbat and prohibited on Yom Kippur.</b> The principle is: <b>Since</b> it is <b>permitted on Shabbat, it is also permitted on Yom Kippur.</b> Although the reason to permit bathing on Shabbat does not apply on Yom Kippur, Rava nonetheless permits it due to the principle of since. The decrees of the Sages should be applied equally to whatever degree possible, without making distinctions for particular cases. Here, too, in the case of sipping vinegar, since it is permitted to sip vinegar before dipping food, it should also be permitted to sip vinegar after dipping food.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rava retracted that</b> statement and prohibited sipping vinegar. The Gemara asks: <b>From where</b> can it be determined <b>that he retracted that</b> statement? <b>Perhaps he retracted this</b> statement with regard to immersion in a ritual bath on Yom Kippur. The Gemara answers: <b>It does not enter your mind</b> to say so, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All obligated in immersions immerse in their</b> usual <b>manner, both on</b> the <b>Ninth of Av and on Yom Kippur.</b> Rava certainly does not dispute this <i>baraita</i>.
We learned in the mishna: <b>One who is concerned</b> about pain <b>in his loins</b> may not smear rose oil on them on Shabbat, and Rabbi Shimon permits doing so. <b>Rabbi Abba bar Zavda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> The Gemara is surprised at this: <b>Is that to say that Rav holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon? Didn’t Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya say</b> the following <b>in the name of Rav?</b> With regard to <b>this</b> cloth <b>stopper</b> inserted into the spout <b>of a barrel,</b>

Daf 111b

<b>it is prohibited to insert</b> it <b>tightly on a Festival</b> due to the prohibited labor of wringing. Doesn’t Rabbi Shimon permit performing an unintentional act from which a prohibited labor may ensue? The Gemara answers: <b>In that</b> case, <b>even Rabbi Shimon concedes</b> that it is prohibited, <b>as it was Abaye and Rava who both said: Rabbi Shimon concedes in</b> instances categorized as: <b>Cut off its head and it shall not die.</b> This category refers to situations where the ensuing prohibited labor is inevitable. In those kinds of cases, one is liable even according to Rabbi Shimon. Since stuffing a cloth into a barrel will inevitably lead to wringing wine from it, Rabbi Shimon concedes that doing so is forbidden.
The Gemara asks again: <b>Didn’t Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi say</b> that <b>Rav said</b> explicitly: The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and Rav Ḥanan bar Ami</b> said that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. And Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin taught</b> the same tradition <b>without</b> mentioning the names of the <b>men</b> who cited the statements, but cited it directly: <b>Rav said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, and Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. Rather, Rava said: I and the lion of the group explained</b> this. <b>And</b> the Gemara asks: <b>And who is</b> the lion of the group? It is <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin.</b> He and Rava explained: The <b><i>halakha</i> is</b> indeed <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> but <b>not for his reason.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> exactly is the meaning of the statement: The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> but <b>not for his reason? If we say</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who permits</b> smearing rose oil, but <b>not for his reason, because Rabbi Shimon holds</b> that rose oil <b>heals, and Rav holds</b> that it <b>does not heal,</b> which is why he permits smearing it on Shabbat, then <b>does Rav hold</b> that rose oil <b>does not heal? From</b> the fact <b>that it is taught: Princes smear rose [<i>vered</i>] oil on their wounds; by inference,</b> it <b>heals. Rather,</b> it means: The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who <b>permits</b> rose oil, <b>but not for his reason. As Rabbi Shimon holds</b> that <b>although</b> rose oil <b>is uncommon</b> and expensive, and anyone who sees one smearing it realizes that it is for medicinal purposes, nevertheless, it is <b>permitted. And Rav holds</b> that <b>if</b> rose oil <b>is common</b> in a given place, <b>yes,</b> one may smear it on himself; <b>however, if</b> it is <b>not common</b> there, it is <b>not</b> permitted. <b>And in Rav’s place, roses were common,</b> and that is why he permitted smearing with rose oil on Shabbat. However, in a place where rose oil is uncommon, he concedes to the Rabbis, who prohibited doing so.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>And these are knots for which one is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering if one tied them on Shabbat: <b>A camel driver’s knot and a sailor’s knot,</b> both of which are meant to be permanent. <b>And just as one is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for tying these</b> knots, <b>so too, he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>for untying them. Rabbi Meir says</b> a principle: <b>For</b> tying <b>any knot that one can untie with one of his hands, one is not liable</b> to bring a sin-offering, because a loose knot of that sort is not considered permanent even if that was his intention.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What are a camel driver’s knot and a sailor’s knot? If you say</b> that these are <b>a knot that</b> one uses to <b>tie</b> a strap <b>to the</b> camel’s <b>nose ring</b> in order to pull it <b>and a knot that</b> one uses <b>to tie</b> a rope <b>to the ring</b> [<i>isterida</i>] <b>fixed to the bow of a ship</b> when the ship is docked, then <b>these knots are not</b> meant <b>to be permanent,</b> as they are periodically untied. <b>Rather,</b> a camel driver’s knot is <b>the knot</b> that fixes the <b>nose ring itself</b> in the camel’s nose, and the sailor’s knot is <b>the knot</b> that fixes the <b>ring itself</b> to the ship. These knots are never untied and are permanent.
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Meir says</b> a principle: For tying <b>any knot</b> that one can untie with one of his hands, one is not liable for tying it. <b>Rav Aḥadvoy, brother of Mar Aḥa, raised a dilemma:</b> With regard to tying <b>a bow, what is</b> the ruling <b>according to Rabbi Meir?</b> Is it permitted to tie it tightly on Shabbat or not? The dilemma is: Is <b>the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir</b> merely that <b>because one can untie</b> the knot <b>with one of his hands</b> it is not considered a permanent knot, <b>and this</b> bow <b>too, he can untie it</b> with one of his hands and therefore he would not be liable for tying on Shabbat? <b>Or perhaps the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir is because</b> typically a knot that can be untied with one hand <b>is not</b> particularly <b>tight, and this</b> bow <b>is tight</b> and therefore it is prohibited to tie it on Shabbat. This dilemma is not resolved, and the Gemara concludes: <b>Let it stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>You have knots for which one is not liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>as</b> one is liable for tying <b>a camel driver’s knot and a sailor’s knot;</b> however, it is nevertheless prohibited to tie them. <b>A woman may tie</b> closed the <b>opening of her robe</b> with straps, <b>as well as</b> the <b>strings of her hairnet and</b> the laces <b>of her girdle,</b> i.e., a wide belt tied with laces. One may <b>also</b> tie the <b>straps</b> of <b>a shoe</b> or <b>a sandal, as well as</b> the spouts of <b>wine</b> or <b>oil jugs.</b> One may <b>also</b> tie a garment over <b>a pot of meat. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: One may tie</b> a rope across an entrance <b>before an animal so that it will not go out.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>This</b> matter <b>itself is difficult,</b> as there is an internal contradiction in the mishna. On the one hand, <b>you said</b> that <b>there are knots for which one is not liable</b> to bring a sin-offering <b>as</b> he is for tying <b>a camel driver’s knot and a sailor’s knot,</b> which would seem to indicate that although <b>there is no</b> Torah <b>liability, there is a</b> rabbinic <b>prohibition. And then it was taught that a woman may tie the opening of her robe,</b> indicating that doing so is permitted <b>even <i>ab initio</i>.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: There are knots for which one is not liable</b> to bring a sin-offering for tying them on Shabbat <b>as</b> he is for tying <b>a camel driver’s knot and a sailor’s knot. And which are these?</b>

Daf 112a

<b>A knot</b> with which one <b>ties</b> a strap <b>to the</b> camel’s <b>nose ring and a knot</b> with which one <b>ties</b> a rope <b>to the ring fixed to the bow of a ship,</b> with regard to <b>liability</b> to bring a sin-offering, there is <b>none; however, there is a</b> rabbinic <b>prohibition. And there are</b> knots <b>that are permitted</b> to <b>be</b> tied on Shabbat <b><i>ab initio</i>. And which are these?</b> The knot that a woman uses to <b>tie the opening of her robe.</b>
We learned in the mishna: A woman may tie <b>the opening of her robe</b> on Shabbat. The Gemara states: This is <b>obvious,</b> as the knot is meant to be untied and is therefore not permanent. The Gemara explains: <b>It is only necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where the robe has two laces</b> with which to tie the opening. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>one of them</b> may <b>become void</b> because the woman can remove the garment even with one string, leaving the one not untied a permanent knot, <b>it</b> therefore <b>teaches us</b> that neither knot is considered permanent.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And</b> a woman may tie the <b>strings of her hairnet</b> on Shabbat. The Gemara states: This is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara clarifies the matter: <b>It was only necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where</b> the hairnet is tied <b>loosely on her</b> head. <b>Lest you say</b> that <b>she</b> sometimes <b>removes it</b> without untying it and the knots remain, <b>the mishna teaches us</b> that <b>a woman is protective of her hair</b> and avoids pulling it out, <b>and</b> therefore <b>she unties</b> the hairnet to avoid damaging her hair.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And</b> it is permitted to tie the <b>straps of a shoe</b> or <b>a sandal</b> on Shabbat. <b>It was stated</b> with regard to <b>one who untied</b> the <b>straps of a shoe</b> or <b>a sandal: One</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>taught</b> that one who did so on Shabbat is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering; and it was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> that <b>one is exempt</b> by Torah law, <b>and</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> to untie those straps <i>ab initio</i>; <b>and it was taught in another</b> <i>baraita</i> that <b>it is permitted</b> to untie these knots <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> This is <b>difficult,</b> as there is a contradiction between one statement with regard to <b>a shoe</b> and another statement with regard to the straps of <b>a shoe;</b> and this is <b>difficult,</b> as there is a contradiction between one statement with regard to the straps of <b>a sandal</b> and another statement with regard to the straps of <b>a sandal.</b>
The Gemara explains: The apparent contradiction between one statement with regard to <b>a shoe</b> and the other statement with regard to <b>a shoe is not difficult,</b> as <b>that <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that one is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, is referring to a shoemaker’s</b> knot, which is permanent as it holds the shoe together. The <i>baraita</i> that states that <b>he is exempt</b> by Torah law <b>and</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> by rabbinic decree is referring <b>to</b> the shoe worn by <b>Sages,</b> as they often tie their shoes loosely so they can easily put on and remove their shoes. The <i>baraita</i> that teaches that it is <b>permitted</b> to tie shoes <b><i>ab initio</i> is referring to</b> such knots used by <b>the residents of</b> the city of <b>Meḥoza,</b> who are meticulous in their dress and who tie and untie their shoes every day.
Similarly, the contradiction between one statement with regard to the straps of <b>a sandal</b> and the other statement with regard to the straps of <b>a sandal is not difficult,</b> as <b>that</b> <i>baraita,</i> <b>which teaches</b> that one is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, is referring to Arab</b> sandals, for <b>which shoemakers tie</b> permanent knots. And the <i>baraita</i> that teaches that <b>he is exempt</b> by Torah law <b>and</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> by rabbinic decree <b>is referring to straps that they,</b> i.e., ordinary people, <b>tie.</b> The <i>baraita</i> that teaches that it is <b>permitted</b> to tie and untie the straps of a sandal <b><i>ab initio</i> is referring to a sandal</b> shared by <b>two</b> people <b>who</b> alternate <b>going out</b> at different times. They untie and retie the straps each time to ensure that the sandals will fit properly, <b>like</b> the sandals of <b>Rav Yehuda; as Rav Yehuda, brother of Rav Sala Ḥasida, had a pair of sandals,</b> and <b>sometimes he would go out</b> wearing them and <b>sometimes his child would go out</b> wearing them. Rav Yehuda <b>came before Abaye</b> and <b>said to him: What</b> is the ruling <b>in</b> a case <b>of this kind?</b> May I tie the straps on Shabbat? Abaye <b>said to</b> him: Doing so renders you <b>liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b>
Rav Yehuda <b>said to</b> him: <b>Now,</b> even if your ruling in that case had been that one is <b>exempt</b> by Torah law <b>but</b> it is still <b>prohibited</b> by rabbinic law, it <b>would be difficult for me,</b> and <b>you say to me</b> that the ruling is that one is <b>liable to bring a sin-offering.</b> Abaye asked him: <b>What is the reason</b> for that difficulty? Rav Yehuda <b>said to</b> him: <b>Because on weekdays too I sometimes go out</b> wearing them <b>and sometimes my child goes out</b> wearing them. Abaye <b>said to him: If so, it is permitted</b> to untie the straps <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya was walking after Rabbi Abbahu in a <i>karmelit</i></b> on Shabbat when <b>the strap of his sandal tore.</b> Rabbi Yirmeya <b>said to</b> Rabbi Abbahu: <b>What should I do to it?</b> Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him: Take a moist reed fit for animal consumption and wrap it around</b> the sandal to fasten it. And the Gemara relates: <b>Abaye was standing before Rav Yosef</b> on Shabbat when <b>the strap</b> of <b>his</b> sandal <b>tore.</b> Abaye <b>said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>What should I do with it?</b> He <b>said to him: Leave it</b> and do not move it. Abaye said to him: <b>How is this</b> case <b>different from</b> that of <b>Rabbi Yirmeya?</b> He answered him: <b>There</b> the sandal would <b>not</b> have been <b>protected; here</b> it will be <b>protected.</b> Abaye said to him: <b>But it</b> remains <b>a utensil</b> and may therefore be moved on Shabbat, <b>as if I so desire, I can switch it from the right</b> foot <b>to the left</b> foot and wear it. Rav Yosef <b>said to</b> him: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that Rabbi Yoḥanan explains</b> the matter <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> as will be explained, <b>conclude from it</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> Therefore, a torn sandal is not considered to be a utensil even if it were switched, i.e., turned around.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is that</b> opinion of Rabbi Yehuda? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A sandal</b> that was ritually impure, <b>whose two ears</b> that hold the straps <b>or whose two straps</b> (<i>ge’onim</i>) <b>broke, or whose entire sole was removed,</b> becomes <b>ritually pure</b> because it is no longer a utensil. However, if only <b>one of its ears or one of its straps</b> broke, <b>or</b> if only <b>most</b> but not all <b>of its sole was removed,</b> it remains <b>impure. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If the <b>inner</b> strap <b>broke</b> it remains <b>impure,</b> because the outer strap can still be used. If <b>the outer</b> strap <b>broke</b> it is rendered <b>pure. And Ulla, and some say Rabba bar bar Ḥana, said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Like</b> there is a <b>dispute with regard to ritual impurity, so too,</b> there is a <b>dispute with regard to Shabbat,</b> i.e., whether or not it is permitted to wear such a sandal on Shabbat. <b>However,</b> there is <b>no</b> dispute <b>with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b>
<b>And we discussed</b> this issue: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is the statement of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan? If you say</b> that it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> and the <i>baraita</i> is explained as follows: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that it is a utensil with regard to ritual impurity, it is also a utensil with regard to Shabbat, but</b> it is <b>not</b> considered <b>a utensil with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>.</b> However, <b>didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>If she removed the left</b> shoe, which was <b>on the right</b> foot of her brother-in-law, <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid?</b> Apparently, a woman can perform <i>ḥalitza</i> even when the shoe is on the wrong foot, and it is not deemed unfit for <i>ḥalitza</i>. <b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion must be in <b>accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> and is saying the following: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that with regard to impurity it is not a utensil, with regard to Shabbat it is also not a utensil. However,</b> that is <b>not</b> the case <b>with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> for which <b>it is a utensil.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Say that we said</b> that if <b>she removed the left</b> shoe which was <b>on the right</b> foot, <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid,</b> that applies only in a case <b>where it</b> is fit as <b>a utensil for its usual purpose,</b> i.e., it can be used as footwear. However, <b>here it is not</b> fit as <b>a utensil for its usual purpose, as Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> If <b>the outer</b> strap of the sandal <b>tore,</b> the sandal is rendered <b>ritually pure. Apparently,</b> according to Rabbi Yehuda, <b>it is not a utensil.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement is difficult according to both opinions. The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> his opinion is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda;</b> however, emend his statement and <b>say</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan said: <b>And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i> as well. And this teaches us that when we say</b> that if <b>she removed the left</b> shoe that was <b>on the right</b> foot <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid,</b> that is only in a case <b>where</b>

Daf 112b

it is <b>fit as</b> a utensil for its usual purpose, <b>i.e., it can be used as footwear.</b> However, here it is not <b>fit as</b> a utensil for its usual purpose.
The Gemara asks: <b>Did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> in fact <b>say that</b> the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabbi Yehuda, who says that if the outer strap broke the sandal becomes pure? <b>Didn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with an unattributed mishna? And we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>A sandal that</b> became ritually impure with impurity imparted by the treading of a <i>zav</i>, and <b>one of its ears broke and he repaired it,</b> this sandal is still <b>impure</b> with ritual impurity imparted by <b>treading,</b> since a broken ear does not render the sandal useless and it remains a utensil. If the <b>second</b> ear <b>broke and he repaired it, it is ritually pure</b> in the sense that it no longer <b>renders</b> other objects <b>ritually impure</b> in the same way a vessel that became a primary source of ritual impurity by means of impurity imparted by <b>treading</b> does, since when both ears tear it is no longer a utensil. <b>However, it is</b> itself <b>ritually impure</b> with ritual impurity imparted by <b>treading</b> due to <b>contact</b> with a vessel that is impure, i.e., contact with itself. Since the sandal now has only one torn ear, it is still considered a utensil which is capable of contracting impurity, and it is as if it contracted impurity from itself in its previous state. <b>Is</b> this statement <b>not</b> an indication that <b>there is no difference</b> whether it was the <b>inner</b> strap <b>or</b> the <b>outer</b> strap that broke, as no single ear that breaks terminates the sandal’s use? This contradicts Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> this mishna is referring <b>specifically</b> to the <b>inner</b> strap. When the inner strap breaks, even Rabbi Yehuda concedes that the sandal remains ritually impure. The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> if the <b>outer</b> strap breaks, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is it that the sandal is <b>pure? If so, instead of teaching:</b> If the <b>second</b> ear <b>broke and he repaired it, it is ritually pure</b> in the sense that it no longer <b>renders</b> other objects <b>ritually impure</b> as a vessel that became a primary source of ritual impurity by means of impurity imparted by <b>treading; however, it is</b> itself <b>ritually impure</b> due to <b>contact</b> with a vessel that is impure due to contact with an object that became ritually impure with impurity imparted by <b>treading, let him make a distinction</b> within the case <b>itself: In what</b> case <b>was this statement said?</b> In a case <b>where</b> the <b>inner</b> strap <b>breaks. However,</b> if the <b>outer</b> strap breaks, the sandal becomes <b>ritually pure. Rav Yitzḥak ben Yosef said: Let our mishna</b> be interpreted as referring <b>to a sandal that has four ears and four straps,</b> and it can be explained that when it says that the second one broke, it was referring to the second outer one. It is worthwhile to interpret it this way so as <b>not to break,</b> i.e., contradict, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement.</b>
<b>When Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he related that <b>Rav Ḥanan bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance</b> with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say this? From</b> the fact <b>that Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> provided an <b>explanation in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, conclude from it that he holds</b> that the <i>halakha</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>They are</b> different <b><i>amora’im</i></b> who made their statements <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b>
The Gemara cites another discussion related to the previous <i>halakha</i>. <b>We learned there</b> in a mishna in tractate <i>Kelim</i>: <b>All</b> ritually impure wooden <b>utensils belonging to</b> ordinary <b>homeowners</b> become pure through breaking the utensil if they have holes <b>the size of pomegranates. Ḥizkiya asked: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> when a utensil <b>was perforated</b> with a hole large enough <b>for an olive to emerge, and he sealed it, and then it was perforated again</b> with a hole large enough <b>for an olive to emerge, and he sealed it,</b> and this went on <b>until</b> the total area of all the holes <b>completed</b> a space large enough for <b>a pomegranate to emerge?</b> In other words, do we say that because the sum of the areas of all the holes adds up to the size of a pomegranate, the utensil is pure, or do we say that since the previous hole was filled before the next hole was formed, the utensil remains ritually impure?
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> his student, <b>said to him: Master, you taught us</b> that with regard to a <b>sandal that</b> became ritually impure by impurity imparted by the treading of a <i>zav</i>, and <b>one of its ears broke and he repaired it,</b> this sandal remains <b>ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>treading.</b> If <b>the second</b> ear <b>broke and he repaired it,</b> the sandal is <b>ritually pure</b> in the sense that it no longer renders other objects ritually impure in the same way a vessel that became a primary source of ritual impurity by means of impurity imparted by <b>treading</b> does. <b>However,</b> it is itself <b>ritually impure</b> with ritual impurity imparted by <b>treading</b> due to <b>contact</b> with a vessel that is impure, i.e., contact with itself. <b>And we said to you: What is different</b> when <b>the first</b> ear breaks that the sandal remains impure? It is <b>because</b> the <b>second one</b> is <b>intact. So too,</b> when the <b>second</b> ear breaks, <b>the first one is repaired,</b> and there is only one torn ear.
<b>And you said to us</b> in <b>this</b> regard that the reason the sandal is pure is because <b>a new face has arrived here.</b> The legal status of the sandal with the two repaired ears is not that of the original sandal; it is a new sandal. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to a utensil that was perforated several times and sealed each time, let us say with regard to the sandal as well that <b>a new face has arrived here,</b> and it is ritually pure because the repaired sandal is a new entity and not the original sandal.
Ḥizkiya was so impressed by Rabbi Yoḥanan’s comment that <b>he exclaimed about him: This is not a human being,</b> but an angel. <b>Some say</b> that he said: <b>This is an</b> ideal <b>human being.</b> On a similar note, <b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rava bar Zimuna said: If the early</b> generations <b>are</b> characterized as <b>sons of angels, we are the sons of men. And if the early</b> generations <b>are</b> characterized as <b>the sons of men, we are akin to donkeys. And</b> I do <b>not</b> mean that we are <b>akin to</b> either <b>the donkey of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Dosa or</b> the donkey of <b>Rabbi Pinḥas ben Yair,</b> who were both extraordinarily intelligent donkeys; <b>rather,</b> we are <b>akin to other</b> typical <b>donkeys.</b>
<b>And</b> we learned in the mishna: It is permitted to tie the spouts of <b>wine or oil jugs.</b> The Gemara says: This is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara explains: It is <b>only necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where it,</b> the jug, <b>has two ears,</b> i.e., two spouts. <b>Lest you say: One of them, he voids it consequently defining</b> the knot on that opening permanent and therefore prohibited, <b>it teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
We also learned in the mishna that it is even permitted to tie a garment to cover <b>a pot of meat.</b> The Gemara says: This is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara explains: It is <b>only necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> a case <b>where it has a string</b> with which one could open a flap and empty the food. <b>Lest you say</b> that since a single opening usually suffices <b>he voids</b> the knot with which he ties the garment, <b>it teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
We also learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: One may tie</b> a rope across an entrance before an animal so that it will not go out. The Gemara says: This is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara explains: It is <b>only necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where</b> the entrance <b>has two ropes. Lest you say</b>

Daf 113a

that <b>one of</b> the knots <b>one voids,</b> because he can enable the animal to go out, albeit with difficulty, after untying one knot, therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that both are considered temporary knots, and it is permitted to tie them. <b>Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov. Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: If you rule the <b><i>halakha</i></b> in accordance with his opinion, does that mean, <b>by inference,</b> that the Rabbis <b>disagree,</b> or perhaps is there no dispute and everyone accepts the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov? Rav Yosef <b>said to him: What difference is there to you</b> whether or not the Rabbis disagree? In either case, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov. Abaye answered Rav Yosef using a folk expression: Is it simply <b>learn the lesson,</b> let <b>it be</b> like <b>a song?</b> In other words, is it sufficient to simply parrot the halakhic ruling? Rather, it is necessary to examine the issue to understand it, even if it does not yield a practical halakhic difference.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may tie a bucket with a belt</b> on Shabbat, as he will certainly not leave it tied to the bucket, and therefore it is not a permanent knot. <b>But</b> one may <b>not</b> tie a bucket <b>with a rope. Rabbi Yehuda permits</b> doing so. <b>Rabbi Yehuda stated a principle:</b> With regard to <b>any knot that is not permanent, one is not liable</b> for tying <b>it.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that according to the first <i>tanna</i>, it is prohibited to tie a rope to a bucket on Shabbat, and Rabbi Yehuda permits doing so. The Gemara asks: <b>A rope of what</b> kind? <b>If you say</b> it is referring to <b>a standard rope,</b> does <b>Rabbi Yehuda permit</b> doing so? <b>It is a permanent knot. Rather,</b> it is referring to <b>a weaver’s rope;</b> since the weaver needs it for his work, he will untie it after Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>we issue a decree</b> prohibiting <b>a weaver’s rope due to a standard rope, and Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that <b>we do not issue a decree?</b>
The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the rope of a bucket that was severed</b> on Shabbat, <b>one may not tie it</b> with a regular knot; <b>rather, he</b> may <b>tie a bow. And Rabbi Yehuda says: One may wrap a hollow belt around it or a sash as long as he does not tie it into a bow.</b>
This is <b>difficult,</b> as there is a contradiction between one statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> and another statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> as in the <i>baraita</i> he issued a decree prohibiting tying a bow due to tying a knot, and in the mishna he issued no decree. And this is also <b>difficult,</b> as there is a contradiction between one statement of the <b>Rabbis</b> and another statement of the <b>Rabbis,</b> as in the <i>baraita</i> they do not issue a decree and in the mishna they do issue a decree.
The Gemara responds: The contradiction between one statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> and the other statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as they are of the opinion that <b>a rope may be confused with</b> another <b>rope.</b> Therefore, the Rabbis issued a decree prohibiting a weaver’s rope, because if it were permitted one might mistakenly come to tie a standard rope. However, <b>a bow is not confused with a knot,</b> and therefore they did not issue a decree prohibiting a bow. The contradiction between one statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> and the other statement <b>of Rabbi Yehuda</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>there,</b> where he prohibited tying a bow, it is <b>not because a bow may be confused with a knot,</b> but <b>because,</b> in his opinion, <b>a bow itself is a</b> full-fledged <b>knot</b> and is not prohibited due to a decree.
<b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said: A person may bring a rope from inside his house</b> on Shabbat <b>and tie</b> one end of <b>it to a cow and</b> the other end <b>to a trough.</b> That is not considered a permanent knot, because he will certainly untie the rope. <b>Rabbi Aḥa Arikha,</b> who was nicknamed Rabbi Aḥa the Long, due to his height, <b>who is</b> also called <b>Rabbi Aḥa bar Pappa, raised an objection to Rabbi Abba</b> from the <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a rope that is</b> tied <b>to the trough, one may tie it to a cow, and</b> a rope that is tied <b>to the cow one may tie it to a trough, provided that one does not bring a rope from inside his house and tie it to the cow and to the trough.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> where they permitted it, it is referring to <b>a weaver’s rope,</b> which will certainly be untied.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: A weaver’s tools may be moved on Shabbat. They raised a dilemma before Rav Yehuda: What</b> is the ruling with regard to <b>the upper beam and the lower beam</b> of the weaver’s loom? Does this leniency apply to them? Rav Yehuda did not provide a clear answer. He said: <b>Yes and no, and</b> the matter was <b>uncertain to him. It was stated: Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: A weaver’s tools may be moved on Shabbat, even</b> the <b>upper beam and the lower beam, but not the posts.</b>
<b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman: What is different</b> about the <b>posts that</b> one may <b>not</b> carry them? <b>If we say</b> it is because <b>one makes holes</b> when removing the post from the ground, <b>holes</b> come into <b>being on their own</b> and that is not prohibited, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who stores a turnip or radish</b> in the ground <b>beneath a vine</b> for safekeeping, <b>if some of its leaves were exposed,</b> making it possible to grab the turnip or the radish and pull it out of the ground, <b>he need not be concerned, neither due to diverse kinds,</b> i.e., that he violated the prohibition of planting food crops in a vineyard, as there was no intent to plant them, <b>nor due to</b> concern that he violated the prohibition against working the land during <b>the Sabbatical Year, nor due to tithes,</b> i.e., that it would be considered as if he picked it from the ground and would be obligated to tithe it, <b>and they may be taken</b> from the ground <b>on Shabbat.</b> Apparently, the Rabbis do not prohibit doing so due to concern that one will thereby create a hole.
Rav Naḥman answered him: The cases are not comparable. <b>In a field one will not come to fill holes;</b> however, <b>here,</b> where the holes are created <b>in the house,</b> the concern is that one may <b>come to smooth out</b> the <b>holes.</b> Therefore, the Rabbis prohibited it. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yehuda bar Liva’ei:</b> With regard to <b>weaver’s tools, such as the upper beam and the lower beam</b> of the loom, <b>what</b> is the ruling in terms of <b>carrying them on Shabbat?</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to him: One may not carry them.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan asked him: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? Rabbi Yehuda bar Liva’ei answered: <b>Because they are not</b> usually <b>carried</b> even during the week, as they are extremely heavy and are considered fixed in place. Therefore, the Sages prohibited carrying them on Shabbat.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may fold the garments</b> after removing them <b>even four or five times, and one may make the beds from Shabbat evening</b> in preparation <b>for Shabbat</b> day, <b>but not from Shabbat</b> in preparation <b>for the conclusion of Shabbat,</b> since one may not perform an action on Shabbat that is preparation for a weekday. <b>Rabbi Yishmael says: One may fold the garments and make the beds from Yom Kippur</b> in preparation <b>for Shabbat</b> if Yom Kippur occurs on Friday. <b>And the fats</b> of the offerings that were sacrificed on <b>Shabbat are offered on Yom Kippur, but not those of Yom Kippur on Shabbat,</b> because the sanctity of Shabbat is greater than the sanctity of Yom Kippur. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: Neither are</b> the fats <b>of</b> the offerings sacrificed on <b>Shabbat offered on Yom Kippur, nor are those of Yom Kippur offered on Shabbat.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Sages in <b>the school of Rabbi Yanai said: They only taught</b> that it is permitted <b>when one person</b> is folding the garments alone on Shabbat; <b>however, when two people</b> are folding the garments together, <b>no,</b> they may not do so, because when two people fold garments it is tantamount to repairing the garment. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>when a single person</b> is folding the garments, <b>we only said</b> it is permitted <b>when</b> he is folding a <b>new</b> garment, which is suitable to be worn even if it were not folded; <b>however,</b> with regard to <b>old</b> garments, <b>no,</b> he may not do so. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>new</b> garments, <b>we only said</b> that one may fold the garments <b>when</b> they are <b>white; however, when</b> they are <b>colored, no,</b> one may not do so. <b>And</b> with regard to white garments, <b>we only said</b> it is permitted to fold them on Shabbat when <b>one does not have</b> garments <b>into</b> which <b>one</b> could <b>change; however,</b> if <b>one has</b> other garments <b>into</b> which he could <b>change,</b> he may <b>not</b> fold them.
And <b>it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: The members <b>of Rabban Gamliel’s household did not</b> even <b>fold their white garments because they had</b> others <b>into</b> which they could <b>change. Rav Huna said: If one has</b> new garments <b>into</b> which he could <b>change</b> on Shabbat, <b>he will change</b> into those garments; <b>and if one does not have</b> garments <b>into</b> which he could <b>change, he</b> lets <b>his garments hang down</b> before Shabbat to beautify himself in deference to Shabbat as it used to be the custom of wealthy people to wear their clothes loosely. <b>Rav Safra strongly objects to this: Doesn’t this appear as haughtiness?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since every day</b> he <b>does not do</b> so, <b>and now</b> in honor of Shabbat <b>he is doing so, it does not appear as haughtiness.</b> Rather it is apparent that he is acting in deference to Shabbat.
On a related note, the Gemara cites what we learned with regard to the following passage: “If you keep your feet from breaking, from pursuing your affairs on My holy day, and you call Shabbat a delight, the Lord’s holy day honorable, <b>and you honor it by not going your own way,</b> from attending to your affairs and speaking idle words” (Isaiah 58:13). The Rabbis derived from the words <b>“and you honor it” that your dress on Shabbat should not be like your dress during the week, as Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> would <b>refer to his clothing as my honor,</b> indicating that appropriate clothing is a form of deference. The words <b>“going your own way”</b> mean <b>that your walking on Shabbat should not be like your walking during the week. “From attending to your affairs”</b> means it <b>is prohibited</b> to deal with <b>your</b> weekday <b>affairs</b> and to speak about them on Shabbat. However, <b>affairs of Heaven,</b> i.e., those pertaining to mitzvot, <b>are permitted. “And speaking idle words”</b>

Daf 113b

means <b>that your speech on Shabbat should not be like your speech during the week,</b> i.e., one should not discuss his weekday affairs on Shabbat. However, it is only <b>speech</b> that they said is <b>prohibited,</b> whereas merely <b>contemplating</b> weekday affairs <b>is permitted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, all of these</b> directives, <b>fine,</b> they are understood. <b>However, what is</b> the meaning of the following phrase: <b>That your walking on Shabbat should not be like your walking during the week?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is in accordance with that</b> which <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said, and some say that Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said:</b> If <b>one were walking on Shabbat and came upon a stream of water</b> and had to cross it, <b>if</b> the stream is narrow and <b>one could place his first foot</b> down on the other side <b>before raising</b> the <b>second one, it is permitted</b> to cross it; <b>and if</b> it is <b>not</b> possible and one must jump to cross it, <b>it is prohibited.</b> That is the type of walking that is not permitted on Shabbat.
<b>Rava strongly objects to this:</b> Since we have said that one’s walking on Shabbat should not be like his walking during the week, and jumping constitutes prohibited walking, if one encounters a stream on Shabbat, <b>what should he do</b> to cross to the other side? If <b>he circumvents</b> the stream, <b>he is increasing</b> the distance that he is <b>walking</b> and exerting extra effort on Shabbat. If <b>he walks through</b> the water, <b>sometimes his clothes will absorb water and he will come to wring them out.</b> What then should he do? <b>Rather, in this</b> case, <b>since it is not possible</b> to cross any other way, he may <b>well</b> cross it, i.e., it is permitted for him to jump over the stream. Therefore, <b>rather</b> say that walking that is defined as characteristic of weekday walking involves taking large steps. <b>As Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei: What is</b> the ruling with regard to <b>taking large steps on Shabbat?</b> That is what the Gemara meant when it used the phrase: Your walking during the week. Rabbi Yishmael <b>said to him: And during the week are</b> large steps <b>permitted? As I say: A large step takes</b> away <b>one five-hundredth of a person’s eyesight.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> his eyesight <b>is restored to him during <i>kiddush</i> on</b> Shabbat <b>evening.</b>
And <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yosei: What is</b> the ruling with regard to <b>eating earth</b> for medicinal purposes <b>on Shabbat?</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>said to him: And during the week is it permitted</b> to eat soil? <b>As I say: Even during the week it is prohibited because it is harmful. Rabbi Ami said: Anyone who eats the dust of Babylonia, it is as if he is eating the flesh of his ancestors</b> buried there. <b>And some say: It is as if he eats abominations and creeping creatures, as it is written: “And He wiped out all that existed</b> on the face of the earth, from humans to animals, to creeping creatures to the birds in the sky, and they were wiped off the land” (Genesis 7:23).
Apropos dead residue in the ground, <b>Reish Lakish said: Why is</b> Babylonia <b>called Shinar?</b> It is <b>because all those who died in</b> the <b>Flood were deposited there [<i>ninaru lesham</i>]. Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Why is</b> Babylonia <b>called Metzula?</b> It is <b>because all those who died in</b> the <b>Flood sank there [<i>nitztalelu lesham</i>].</b> The Gemara asks: We said that <b>some say</b> that if one eats dirt from Babylonia, it is <b>as if he eats abominations and creeping creatures. However, certainly their</b> bodies <b>have</b> putrefied and <b>decomposed,</b> and therefore they are no longer prohibited. Rather, <b>since</b> soil <b>is harmful, the Sages issued a decree</b> not to eat it. The decree was not issued due to the prohibition of eating creeping creatures; rather, it was issued <b>because a certain person ate soil</b> for medicinal purposes <b>and</b> also <b>ate cress.</b> The cress took root in the soil that was inside him and began to grow. <b>And the cress punctured his heart and he died.</b>
The Gemara continues to discuss Shabbat. Naomi advised Ruth: <b>“And you shall bathe, and anoint yourself, and put on your robes,</b> and go down to the threshing floor. Do not make yourself known to the man until he has finished eating and drinking” (Ruth 3:3). <b>Rabbi Elazar said: These</b> robes <b>are Shabbat garments</b> that Naomi told her to wear in honor of the occasion. Apropos the book of Ruth, the Gemara cites additional statements of Rabbi Elazar with regard to Ruth: <b>“Give to the wise one and he will become wiser;</b> let the righteous one know and he will learn more” (Proverbs 9:9). <b>Rabbi Elazar said: This</b> refers to <b>Ruth the Moabite and Samuel of Rama,</b> who received advice and added to it with their wisdom.
The Gemara elaborates. <b>Whereas Naomi said to Ruth: “And you shall bathe, and anoint yourself, and put on your robes, and go down to the threshing floor,” but with regard to</b> Ruth <b>herself it is written, “And she went down to the threshing floor”</b> (Ruth 3:6), <b>and</b> only <b>afterward does it say, “And she did according to all that her mother-in-law commanded her.”</b> Ruth decided to anoint herself at the threshing floor and not on the road so that people would not meet her on the way there and suspect her of immorality. <b>Whereas Eli said to Samuel:</b> “Go and <b>lie down and if He calls you, you say: Speak, Lord, for Your servant is listening”</b> (I Samuel 3:9), <b>but with regard to</b> Samuel <b>himself it is written: “And the Lord came and stood, and He called like He did the other times: Samuel, Samuel. And Samuel said: Speak, for Your servant is listening”</b> (I Samuel 3:10), <b>and he did not say: Speak, Lord,</b> since he would not assume it was God speaking to him until he was sure of it.
And the verse in Ruth states: <b>“And she went, and she came, and she collected in the field</b> after the harvesters” (Ruth 2:3). <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> This verse teaches <b>that she went and came, went and came, until she found suitable people with whom to walk.</b> It also says: <b>“And Boaz said to his youth who was standing over the harvesters: To whom does this young woman belong?”</b> (Ruth 2:5). This is surprising: <b>And was it Boaz’s habit to inquire about a young woman? Rabbi Elazar said: He saw in her a matter of wisdom</b> and Torah, and that is why he asked about her. What he saw was that <b>she collected two stalks,</b> but <b>she did not collect three stalks.</b> She thereby acted in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> that three stalks lying together are not considered to be gleanings left for the poor; rather, they remain in the possession of the owner of the field.
<b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: He saw a matter of modesty in her</b> when she was collecting stalks. She picked stalks that were <b>upright</b> while she was <b>standing,</b> and stalks that had <b>fallen</b> she picked while <b>sitting;</b> due to her modesty she did not bend over to take them. It also says: “And Boaz said to Ruth: Do you hear, my daughter? Do not go to glean in another field and do not leave from here, <b>but cling to my maidens”</b> (Ruth 2:8). This is also surprising. <b>And was it Boaz’s habit to cling to women? Rabbi Elazar said: Since he saw “And Orpah kissed her mother-in-law and Ruth clung to her”</b> (Ruth 1:14), <b>he said: It is permitted to cling to</b> a woman like this.
It also says: <b>“And Boaz said to her at mealtime: Come here [<i>halom</i>]</b> and eat from the bread and dip your bread in vinegar. And she sat beside the harvesters and he gave her roasted grain and she ate, and she was satiated, and she left some over” (Ruth 2:14). <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> interpreted this and <b>said</b> that <b>he hinted to her</b> prophetically: <b>In the future the kingdom of David will come from you, as it is written with regard to it,</b> i.e., the kingdom of David: <b>“Here,” as it is stated: “And King David came and sat before God and said: Who am I, Lord, God, and who is my family that You have brought me to here [<i>halom</i>]?”</b> (II Samuel 7:18). With regard to his saying: <b>“And dip your bread in vinegar”</b> (Ruth 2:14), <b>Rabbi Elazar said: From here</b> we see <b>that vinegar</b> is <b>good</b> to have <b>in hot weather.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said</b> that <b>he hinted to her: A son will come from you in the future whose actions will be</b> as <b>sharp as vinegar, and who is he?</b> King <b>Manasseh. “And she sat beside the harvesters.” Rabbi Elazar said with regard to this: Beside the harvesters, and not among the harvesters. He hinted to her that the kingdom of David will be divided in the future</b> and her children will not always be in the center of Israel.
It also says in the verse: “And he gave her roasted grain and she ate, and she was satiated, and she left some over.” The Gemara explains: <b>“And he gave her roasted grain and she ate”;</b> this is also interpreted as a prophetic message. <b>Rabbi Elazar said: “And she ate”</b> was fulfilled by her children’s children <b>in the days of David; “And she was satiated”</b> was fulfilled <b>in the days of Solomon; “And she left some over”</b> was fulfilled <b>in the days of Hezekiah. And some say</b> that there is a different interpretation: <b>“And she ate,”</b> was fulfilled <b>in the days of David and Solomon; “And she was satiated,”</b> was fulfilled <b>in the days of Hezekiah; “And she left some over”</b> was fulfilled <b>in the days of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>As the Master said: Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi’s <b>horsekeeper [<i>ahuriyarei</i>] was richer than the king</b> of Persia. <b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: “And she ate,” in this world; “and she was satiated,” in the days of the Messiah; “and she left some over,” in the future,</b> at the end of days.
It was mentioned earlier that Rabbi Yoḥanan called his clothing his honor. The Gemara cites the interpretation of the verse that speaks about the downfall of the king of Assyria: “Therefore, the Lord, the Lord of hosts, will send leanness to his fat ones <b>and under his honor He will burn a burning like a burning fire”</b> (Isaiah 10:16).<br><b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: “And under his honor,” but not his actual honor.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> follows <b>his own reasoning,</b> for he <b>called his clothing my honor,</b> which means that the bodies of the king of Assyria’s soldiers were burned. However, their garments were miraculously not burned.
<b>Rabbi Elazar said: “And under his honor”</b> means <b>in place of his actual honor.</b> That is to say, their bodies were burned. Since, in Rabbi Elazar’s opinion, the word under means in the place of, the verse accordingly means that in the place of his honor, i.e., the body, there remain ashes.<br><b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Naḥmani said: Under his honor</b> means beneath his flesh, <b>similar to the burning of the sons of Aaron. Just as there,</b> i.e., the burning of Aaron’s sons, <b>the soul burned while</b> the <b>body</b> remained <b>intact, so too here,</b> i.e., the burning of Assyrian soldiers, <b>the soul burned while</b> the <b>body</b> remained <b>intact.</b>
<b>Rabbi Aḥa bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b>

Daf 114a

<b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that changing clothes</b> is a display of honor? <b>As it is stated: “And he will remove his garments and will don other garments,</b> and he will bring the ashes outside of the camp to a pure location” (Leviticus 6:4). <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: The Torah taught you etiquette. The clothes in which one prepared food for his master, one does not</b> wear <b>to pour his master wine.</b> Since cooking makes one’s clothes dirty, he should wear fresh clothes when serving his master.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: It is disgraceful for a Torah scholar to go out to the marketplace in patched shoes.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rabbi Aḥa bar Ḥanina go out</b> in patched shoes? <b>Rabbi Aḥa, son of Rav Naḥman, said:</b> They only prohibited patched shoes <b>if there is a patch upon a patch.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: A Torah scholar on whose clothes a fat stain is found is liable</b> to receive the <b>death</b> penalty, <b>as it is stated: “All those who hate me love death”</b> (Proverbs 8:36), and the Sages said: <b>Do not read: Those who hate me [<i>mesanai</i>]. Rather,</b> read: <b>Those who cause me to be hated [<i>masniai</i>].</b> Those who cause people to hate the Torah by creating the impression that those who study Torah are unclean deserve the death penalty. <b>Ravina said:</b> A fat stain [<i>revav</i>] was not stated, but rather <b>a bloodstain [<i>revad</i>] was stated</b> (Rabbeinu Ḥananel), which is a greater disgrace. The Gemara adds: <b>They did not disagree</b> over the <i>halakha</i>. Rather, the dispute is whether <b>that</b> which we learned concerning stains on a Torah scholar’s clothes refers <b>to an overgarment</b> that people wear over the rest of their clothes, while <b>that</b> which we learned with regard to a bloodstain refers <b>to an undergarment,</b> where a bloodstain is disgraceful but other types of spots are not.
<b>And</b> similarly, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: That which is written: “As My servant Isaiah went naked and barefoot</b> for three years” (Isaiah 20:3), is not to be understood literally. Rather, <b>naked</b> means that he wore <b>tattered clothing, and barefoot</b> means that he walked <b>with patched shoes.</b>
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there: A fat stain on</b> a donkey’s <b>saddle interposes, i.e.,</b> if the saddle becomes impure, its immersion in a ritual bath is invalid unless the stain is removed. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> A stain interposes only when it is as large <b>as an Italian <i>issar</i></b> but not smaller. <b>And</b> if there were a fat stain <b>on clothing on one side, it does not interpose,</b> but if the stain is <b>on both sides it interposes. Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael: It interposes even on one side.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ḥanina:</b> Is a stain on a <b>saddle</b> an interposition even if it is <b>on just one side, or</b> only if it is <b>on both sides?</b> Rabbi Ḥanina <b>said to him: That, I did not hear</b> explicitly. However, <b>I heard</b> something <b>similar to it. As we learned</b> in that same mishna that <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> A garment belonging to <b>builders [<i>banna’in</i>]</b> is considered to have an interposition if it has a stain <b>on one side, and that of an ignoramus,</b> who is not meticulous, is considered to have an interposition when the stain is <b>on both sides. And</b> certainly a donkey’s <b>saddle cannot be more important than the garment of an <i>am ha’aretz</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> are the <b>builders</b> mentioned here? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: These are Torah scholars, who are engaged in building the world all of their days. And</b> with regard to this, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Who is a Torah scholar</b> of whom the Sages said <b>that one</b> must <b>return a lost object to him based on visual identification,</b> even if he does not provide an identifying sign for it? <b>That is one who makes sure his upper undergarment is turned inward</b> so that the uneven stitching is not visible. This means that he conducts himself like a Torah scholar in all his ways, even in matters of cleanliness and order (Maharsha). On a related note, the Gemara adds that which <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Who is a Torah scholar who</b> may be <b>appointed</b> as a <b>leader of the community? This is one who is asked</b> about <b>matters of <i>halakha</i> on any topic and he</b> is able to <b>answer, and even</b> if he were asked about <b>tractate <i>Kalla</i>,</b> a tractate that few have mastered.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Who is the Torah scholar for whom the inhabitants of his city are commanded to perform his labor for him? This is one who sets his own matters aside and engages in matters of Heaven.</b> It is therefore fitting for the community to support him. <b>And that applies only to exerting themselves</b> to provide him with <b>his bread,</b> as it is appropriate that they sustain him. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Who is</b> included in the category of <b>a Torah scholar? Anyone who is asked</b> about the <b><i>halakha</i> with regard to any topic and</b> is able to <b>state it.</b> And they say: <b>What are the practical consequences</b> of this question? It is <b>to appoint him a leader of the community. If</b> he is an expert <b>in a single tractate,</b> they appoint him as a leader <b>in his place; if</b> he is an expert <b>in all of his learning,</b> they appoint him <b>as the head of the yeshiva.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said: These</b> garments of the <i>banna’in</i> mentioned in the mishna are <b>the clothes of the bath attendants [<i>ulairin</i>] that come from a country overseas,</b> on which stains are apparent, and these men are meticulous about their cleanliness. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that these are white garments? Didn’t Rabbi Yannai say to his sons: My sons, do not bury me in white garments nor in black garments.</b> Not in <b>white, lest I not be acquitted</b> in judgment, <b>and I will be</b> among the wicked <b>like a groom among mourners.</b> And not in <b>black, lest I be acquitted</b> in judgment, <b>and I will be</b> among the righteous <b>like a mourner among grooms. Rather,</b> bury me <b>in the clothes of the bath attendants who come from a country overseas,</b> which are neither black nor white. <b>Apparently, these</b> clothes of the bath attendants <b>are red.</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as a distinction can be made. When Rabbi Yannai indicates that they are red, <b>that</b> is referring <b>to overgarments;</b> the statement of Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish that indicated that they are white, <b>that</b> is referring <b>to undergarments.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yishmael says: One may fold</b> clothes and make beds on Yom Kippur for Shabbat if Yom Kippur occurs on Friday, and the fats of the sacrifices that were brought on Shabbat were offered on Yom Kippur that occurs on Sunday. The verse <b>“The burnt-offering of Shabbat on its Shabbat,</b> besides the daily offering and its libation” (Numbers 28:10) <b>taught, with regard to the fats of Shabbat, that</b> they <b>are offered on Yom Kippur,</b> because Yom Kippur is also called Shabbat, and the verse indicates that the Shabbat offering is offered on another Shabbat. I <b>might</b> have thought <b>even</b> the fats <b>from Yom Kippur</b> offerings could be sacrificed <b>on Shabbat;</b> therefore, <b>the verse states “on its Shabbat”</b> to specify that it is not so; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> that when the verse says: <b>“The burnt-offering of Shabbat on its Shabbat,”</b> it teaches <b>that</b> the <b>fats of Shabbat are offered on a Festival</b> that occurs on the following day. <b>I might</b> have thought that they could <b>even</b> be offered <b>on Yom Kippur</b> that occurred on the day after Shabbat. Therefore, <b>the verse states “on its Shabbat”</b> and not on another one.
<b>When you</b> analyze the matter you <b>will find</b> that you can <b>say that, in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yishmael, vows and free-will offerings are offered on a Festival.</b> If sacrifices that fulfill vows can be postponed to a weekday but are nevertheless brought on a Festival, certainly fats from Shabbat can be offered on a Festival that follows it. <b>And the verse is needed to</b> permit offering Shabbat fats on <b>Yom Kippur</b> that follows it. However, <b>according to Rabbi Akiva vows and free-will offerings are not brought on a Festival, and</b> therefore <b>the verse is needed to permit</b> sacrificing the fats from Shabbat <b>on a Festival</b> that follows it, but on Yom Kippur it is prohibited. <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b>

Daf 114b

<b>When I was in Babylonia, I said</b> with regard to <b>that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>Yom Kippur occurred</b> on <b>Shabbat eve, they would not sound</b> the <i>shofar</i> as they did every Friday to herald the start of Shabbat; <b>and</b> if Yom Kippur occurred <b>at the conclusion of Shabbat, they would not recite <i>havdala</i></b> to mark the end of the sanctity of Shabbat and the start of the sanctity of Yom Kippur, is <b>a statement</b> accepted by <b>all. When I went</b> to Eretz Yisrael, <b>I found Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, who sat and said:</b> This <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> as it equates the sanctity of Yom Kippur with that of Shabbat. <b>As, if</b> you say that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, then, since</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>said</b> that <b>fats from Shabbat are offered on Yom Kippur, let them sound</b> the <i>shofar</i> <b>so that</b> the priests <b>will know</b> that <b>the fats from Shabbat are offered on Yom Kippur</b> and they may begin offering them (Rav Hai Gaon). <b>And I said to him:</b> You cannot prove this from here, because <b>priests are vigilant</b> and can be trusted to know this on their own, and there is no need to sound the <i>shofar</i>.
<b>Mar Kashisha,</b> the <b>son</b> of <b>Rav Ḥisda, said to Rav Ashi: Do we say</b> that <b>priests are vigilant</b> in that regard? <b>Didn’t we learn in</b> a mishna that <b>three</b> blasts were sounded in the Temple on Friday <b>to stop the people from work,</b> and <b>three</b> more were sounded <b>to demarcate between sacred and profane?</b> Apparently, even priests required the blasts to alert them to the beginning and end of Shabbat. The Gemara answers: <b>As Abaye said</b> in a different context, that certain matters were undertaken <b>for the rest of the people in Jerusalem, so too here,</b> these blasts were sounded <b>for the rest of the people in Jerusalem</b> and not for the priests.
The Gemara asks: In any event, <b>Let them sound</b> the <i>shofar</i> <b>so that they will know that trimming the vegetables,</b> i.e., removing the leaf heads from vegetables in preparation for cutting them, <b>is permitted from the</b> late <b>afternoon and onward.</b> On Yom Kippur, it is permitted, starting at a certain point of the day, to prepare vegetables for the meal following the fast. However, this is not permitted on Shabbat, when it is prohibited to perform any action in preparation for the weekdays after Shabbat. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> This is <b>because a rabbinic prohibition [<i>shevut</i>] is not overridden</b> in order <b>to permit</b> another action. Although sounding the <i>shofar</i> is not prohibited by Torah law on Shabbat, it is prohibited by rabbinic law on Shabbat and Yom Kippur, and this prohibition is not overridden to permit another action.
<b>And Rav Sheisha, son</b> of <b>Rav Idi, said: The Sages permitted</b> doing so for <b>an immediate rabbinic prohibition,</b> e.g., sounding the <i>shofar</i> to permit prohibited actions immediately. <b>They did not permit</b> doing so for <b>a</b> more <b>remote rabbinic prohibition,</b> such as trimming vegetables, which is allowed only beginning late in the afternoon, several hours after the start of Yom Kippur (Rabbeinu Ḥananel).
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> did <b>they permit</b> doing so for <b>an immediate rabbinic prohibition? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna that if <b>a Festival occurs on Shabbat eve, one sounds</b> the <i>shofar</i> to announce that Shabbat has begun, <b>but one does not recite <i>havdala</i></b> over wine to mark the conclusion of the Festival, because the sanctity of Shabbat is greater than the sanctity of the Festival? And if a Festival occurs at <b>the conclusion of Shabbat, one recites <i>havdala</i></b> to demarcate between the sanctity of Shabbat and the sanctity of the Festival, <b>but one does not sound</b> the <i>shofar</i>. <b>And why</b> does one not sound the <i>shofar</i>? <b>Let them sound</b> the <i>shofar</i> at the beginning of the Festival, <b>so that</b> people <b>will know that slaughtering is permitted immediately</b> on the Festival, although it was prohibited on Shabbat. <b>Rather, it is clear</b> that this must be explained <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yosef,</b> who says that a rabbinic prohibition is not overridden to permit the performance of actions that were prohibited.
With regard to trimming vegetables on Yom Kippur, the Gemara cites that which <b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said, and some say Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Huna said:</b> If <b>Yom Kippur occurs on Shabbat, trimming vegetables is prohibited. Rav Mana said: It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived that <b>on Yom Kippur that occurs on Shabbat trimming vegetables is prohibited? The verse states: “A solemn rest [<i>shabbaton</i>],</b> a holy Shabbat unto the Lord” (Exodus 16:23), which means that there is an obligation to issue a <b>rabbinic prohibition</b> on this day. Issue a rabbinic prohibition <b>for what</b> activity? <b>If you say</b> this refers to prohibiting actual <b>labor, isn’t it written</b> explicitly: “But the seventh day is Shabbat for the Lord your God; <b>you shall not perform any labor”</b> (Exodus 20:9)? <b>Rather, does</b> it not refer to <b>trimming vegetables,</b> which is prohibited on Shabbat even though it is not a full-fledged prohibited labor? The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it</b> that trimming vegetables is prohibited.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> If <b>Yom Kippur occurs on Shabbat, trimming vegetables is permitted.</b> The Gemara <b>raised an objection</b> from what we learned in the <i>baraita</i> cited earlier: <b>From where</b> is it derived that <b>on Yom Kippur that occurs on Shabbat trimming vegetables is prohibited? The verse states: “A solemn rest [<i>shabbaton</i>],</b> a holy Shabbat unto the Lord” (Exodus 16:23), which means that there is an obligation to issue a <b>rabbinic prohibition</b> on this day. Issue a rabbinic prohibition <b>for what</b> activity? <b>If you say</b> this refers to prohibiting actual <b>labor, isn’t it written</b> explicitly: “But the seventh day is Shabbat for the Lord your God; <b>you shall not perform any labor”</b> (Exodus 20:9)? <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to <b>trimming vegetables,</b> which is prohibited on Shabbat? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> that is not; rather, solemn rest <b>actually</b> refers <b>to labor.</b> It is a positive commandment to rest on Shabbat. Although the verse says explicitly: “But the seventh day is Shabbat for the Lord your God; you shall not perform any labor,” this adds that one who performs a prohibited labor <b>violates</b> both <b>a positive mitzva and a prohibition.</b>
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If <b>Yom Kippur occurs on Shabbat,</b>

Daf 115a

<b>trimming vegetables is permitted. And Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> If <b>Yom Kippur occurs on</b> a <b>weekday, one may crack nuts and remove pomegranate seeds from</b> the late <b>afternoon and onward,</b> because doing so involves no actual labor and <b>due to anxiety,</b> i.e., if a person does not know that there is food prepared for when the fast ends, he suffers more during the final hours of the day (Rabbi Zeraḥia HaLevi). The Gemara relates: The members of <b>Rav Yehuda’s house would trim cabbage.</b> The members of <b>Rabba’s house would scrub gourds. Once</b> Rabba <b>saw</b> that <b>they were doing</b> this <b>early,</b> before the late afternoon, <b>he said to them: A letter came from the West,</b> i.e., from Eretz Yisrael, <b>in the name</b> of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> saying that doing so is <b>prohibited.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>all sacred writings, one may rescue them from the fire</b> on Shabbat, <b>whether they are read</b> in public, e.g., Torah or Prophets scrolls, <b>or whether they are not read</b> in public, e.g., Writings scrolls. This ruling applies <b>even though they were written in any</b> foreign <b>language.</b> According to the Rabbis, those scrolls are not read in public, but they are still sacred and require burial. <b>And why</b> does <b>one not read</b> the Writings on Shabbat? <b>Due to suspension</b> of Torah study <b>in the study hall.</b> People came to the study hall at specific times on Shabbat to hear words of <i>halakha,</i> and other texts were not allowed at those times.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> debated the status of sacred writings <b>written in</b> Aramaic <b>translation or in any</b> other <b>language. Rav Huna said: One may not rescue them from the fire</b> on Shabbat. <b>And Rav Ḥisda said: One may rescue them from the fire</b> on Shabbat. The Gemara adds: <b>According to the one who said</b> that sacred writings written in other languages <b>may be read, everybody agrees</b> that <b>one may rescue</b> them. <b>Where they argue</b> is <b>according to the one who said that they may not be read. Rav Huna said: One may not rescue</b> them, <b>as they may not be read.</b> Whereas <b>Rav Ḥisda said: One may rescue</b> them <b>due to disgrace to sacred writings</b> that will result. <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: With regard to <b>all sacred writings, one may rescue them from the fire</b> on Shabbat <b>whether they are read</b> in public <b>or whether they are not read</b> in public, <b>even if they are written in any</b> foreign <b>language. What, is it not</b> that the phrase: <b>“That they are read”</b> is referring to the books of the <b>Prophets, and</b> the phrase: <b>“That they are not read”</b> is referring to the <b>Writings? Even though these are</b> books <b>written in any</b> foreign <b>language, which may not be read, it is taught that one may save them.</b> This then is <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Huna.</b>
<b>Rav Huna</b> could have <b>said to you: And</b> do <b>you understand</b> the mishna that way? <b>Say the latter clause</b> of the mishna, which states: They <b>require burial.</b> This is unnecessary, as <b>now,</b> that it was mentioned that <b>we rescue them</b> from the fire, <b>is it necessary</b> to say that they require <b>burial? Rather,</b> the mishna must be emended. <b>Rav Huna reconciles</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with his reasoning, and Rav Ḥisda reconciles</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with his reasoning. Rav Huna reconciles</b> this <b>in accordance with his reasoning: Whether they are read</b> is referring to the <b>Prophets, and whether they are not read</b> is referring to the <b>Writings. In what</b> case <b>is</b> this <b>statement said? It is</b> in a case <b>where they are written in the holy tongue, but</b> if they are not written in Hebrew but <b>in any</b> other <b>language,</b> they are <b>not rescued</b> from the fire on Shabbat, <b>and even so, they require burial. Rav Ḥisda reconciles</b> the mishna <b>in accordance with his reasoning: Whether they are read</b> is referring to the <b>Prophets, and whether they are not read</b> is referring to the <b>Writings, even if they are written in any language</b> other than Hebrew, they are <b>also rescued. And this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: And even the decayed</b> sections of parchment <b>require burial.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>they were written in</b> Aramaic <b>translation</b> or in <b>any language</b> other than Hebrew, <b>they are rescued from the fire</b> on Shabbat. And this is a <b>conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of <b>Rav Huna,</b> who states that these are not rescued. <b>Rav Huna</b> could have <b>said to you: This <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that sacred writings not written in Hebrew <b>may be read,</b> whereas Rav Huna stated his ruling in accordance with the opinion of the <i>tanna</i> who holds that they may not be read, and therefore may not be rescued. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof from that which was taught in a different <i>baraita</i>: Sacred writings that <b>were written</b> in <b>Coptic,</b> Egyptian; <b>Median; <i>Ivrit</i>,</b> i.e., ancient Hebrew script; <b>Eilamitic;</b> or <b>Greek are rescued from the fire</b> on Shabbat, <b>even though they may not be read.</b> This is a <b>conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of <b>Rav Huna,</b> who holds that they are not rescued. <b>Rav Huna</b> could have <b>said to you: This is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im,</i> as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>they were written in</b> Aramaic <b>translation or in any language</b> other than Hebrew, <b>one may rescue them from the fire</b> on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: One may not rescue them from the fire.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yosei said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving</b> my <b>father, Ḥalafta, who went to the esteemed Rabban Gamliel</b> of Yavne in <b>Tiberias, where he found him sitting at the table of Yoḥanan HaNazuf and in his hand</b> there was <b>a translation of the book of Job, and he was reading</b> from <b>it.</b> Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Rabban Gamliel of Yavne: <b>I remember Rabban Gamliel, your father’s father, who was standing on top of a step on the Temple Mount. And they brought before him a translation of the book of Job, and he said to the builder: Bury this</b> book <b>under the course of bricks.</b> When he heard of that incident, Rabban Gamliel of Yavne <b>ordered that it</b> be buried <b>and he buried it. Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says</b> that on the Temple Mount <b>they overturned a large bowl of mortar on it. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said:</b> There are <b>two responses to this</b> that prove that it did not happen: <b>One, from where would they get mortar on the Temple Mount?</b> Construction on the Temple Mount was performed with other materials, not with mortar. <b>And furthermore, is it permitted to</b> actively <b>destroy</b> even sacred writings that are not read, <b>with one’s hands? Rather,</b> at the very least <b>they leave them in a neglected place,</b> where they are likely to decompose quickly, <b>and they decay on their own.</b> The Gemara seeks to clarify: <b>Who are</b> the <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> who dispute this <i>halakha</i> according to Rav Huna?

Daf 115b

<b>If we say</b> it is the <b>first <i>tanna</i></b> who disagrees with <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> that is not necessarily so, <b>and perhaps they are disagreeing about this: This Master,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that books written in other languages <b>may be read; and this Master,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that <b>they may not be read,</b> and their dispute is unrelated to the dispute between Rav Huna and Rav Ḥisda. <b>Rather,</b> it is the dispute between <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> and <b>the</b> first <b><i>tanna</i>,</b> who spoke <b>about</b> books written in <b>Coptic.</b> According to that <i>tanna</i>, even books that may not be read are rescued, whereas Rabbi Yosei holds that they are not rescued.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The blessings</b> that are written <b>and the amulets, even though there are the letters of the Name</b> of God <b>in them</b> and <b>matters that</b> appear <b>in the Torah</b> are mentioned in them, they <b>are not rescued from the fire; rather, they burn in their place, they and the names</b> of God contained therein. <b>From here</b> the Sages <b>said: Writers of blessings</b> are <b>like burners of Torah</b> scrolls, as it is prohibited to rescue these texts from the fire on Shabbat even though it is likely that they will be destroyed. There was <b>an incident involving one who was writing</b> pages with blessings <b>in Sidon. They came and informed Rabbi Yishmael</b> of his actions, <b>and Rabbi Yishmael went to examine him</b> to determine if the report was true. <b>When</b> Rabbi Yishmael <b>was ascending the ladder</b> to confront him, the scribe <b>sensed his</b> presence, <b>took a bundle [<i>tomos</i>] of blessings, and submerged it in a basin of water</b> to conceal it from Rabbi Yishmael. <b>And in these words Rabbi Yishmael said to him:</b> The <b>punishment</b> for <b>the latter</b> action is <b>greater than</b> the punishment for <b>the former.</b> Although it is prohibited to write blessings, destroying them is a greater violation.
<b>The Exilarch raised a dilemma before Rabba bar Rav Huna:</b> If the sacred scrolls <b>were written in</b> yellow-tinged <b>arsenic, or red paint, in gum, or in iron sulfate,</b> types of ink which may not be used to write Torah scrolls; however, the scrolls were written properly <b>in the holy tongue,</b> does <b>one rescue them from the fire</b> on Shabbat <b>or does one not rescue</b> them? The Gemara adds: This <b>dilemma is raised according to the one who said</b> that <b>one rescues</b> sacred writings written in other languages; and this <b>dilemma is raised according to the one who said</b> that <b>one does not rescue</b> them. The Gemara elaborates. This <b>dilemma is raised according to the one who said</b> that <b>one does not rescue</b> them: Perhaps <b>that applies</b> specifically in a case <b>where</b> they <b>are written in</b> Aramaic <b>translation and in any</b> foreign <b>language; however, here, where they are written in the holy tongue, one rescues</b> them. <b>Or perhaps even according to the one who said</b> that <b>one rescues</b> them, <b>that applies</b> specifically in a case <b>where</b> they <b>are written in ink that endures; however, here, since</b> the script <b>does not endure,</b> they are <b>not</b> rescued. Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>said to him: One does not rescue them.</b> The Exilarch said to him: <b>Didn’t Rav Hamnuna teach</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>that one saves them.</b> Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>said to him: If it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>it was taught,</b> and I retract my statement. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <i>baraita</i> that <b>was taught</b> on this matter? <b>Rav Ashi said, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The only</b> difference <b>between</b> the <b>books</b> of the Bible <b>and the Megilla</b> of Esther <b>is that</b> the <b>books are written in any language</b> and are valid, <b>and the Megilla</b> is only valid <b>if it is written in Assyrian script,</b> the familiar square Hebrew script, <b>on a</b> parchment <b>scroll, and in ink.</b> Apparently, other sacred books need not be written in ink.
