<b>Matters</b> of Torah <b>that people do not ascertain unless they misunderstand them are in your hands;</b> therefore, <b>be a chief over us.</b> It is stated later on in that passage: <b>“He will rise [<i>yissa</i>] on that day, saying, I will not be a ruler</b> while in my house there is no bread and no garment, you shall not appoint me as chief of the people” (Isaiah 3:7). <b>The term rise [<i>yissa</i>] means nothing other than an oath, as it says: “Do not raise [<i>tissa</i>] the name of the Lord</b> your God in vain” (Exodus 20:17). <b>I will not be a ruler,</b> means: <b>I will not be one of those who close themselves up in the study hall,</b> as I do not regularly do so, <b>while in my house there is no bread and no garment, for I have neither Bible nor Mishna nor Gemara in my hands.</b> According to this explanation, there were people of faith who truthfully admitted that they did not study Torah, even during the time of the destruction of Jerusalem. The Gemara rejects this: <b>And from what</b> do you conclude that this admission was due to their faithfulness? <b>Perhaps it is different</b> in that case, <b>as had he told them: I studied</b> Torah, <b>they would have said to him: Tell us</b> what you studied. As he would not know to respond, he would have no choice other than to admit that he did not study. The Gemara rejects this: That is not difficult, as <b>he could have</b> at least <b>said he learned and forgot.</b> The Gemara asks: Therefore, <b>what</b> is: <b>I will not be a ruler?</b> It means that he is telling the truth and although he could have lied, he admits that he did <b>not</b> study Torah <b>at all.</b> The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where it was taught that they were faithful, that was <b>with regard to matters of Torah;</b> whereas <b>here,</b> where it was taught that there were no more people of faith in Jerusalem, that was <b>with regard to</b> matters of <b>business.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may rescue a basket full of loaves</b> and the like from a fire on Shabbat, <b>even if there is</b> food for <b>one hundred meals in it. And</b> one may rescue <b>a round</b> cake <b>of dried figs,</b> even though it is very large, <b>and</b> one may rescue <b>a barrel</b> full <b>of wine. And one may</b> even <b>say to others: Come and rescue for yourselves. And if</b> the people who rescue with him were <b>clever, they make a calculation with him after Shabbat</b> in order to receive payment for the items that they rescued.
<b>To where may one rescue</b> items moved from the fire? One may do so <b>to a courtyard</b> where an <b><i>eiruv</i></b> was established, and it is permitted to carry. <b>Ben Beteira says:</b> One may do so <b>even to</b> a courtyard <b>where an eiruv</b> was <b>not</b> established. <b>And one may carry there all the utensils, and put on all</b> the garments <b>that he can wear, and one may wrap all</b> the cloths <b>that he can wrap</b> around himself in order to rescue his property. <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> One may put on only <b>eighteen garments</b> at once, as people sometimes wear that number of garments, but not more. However, <b>one may again put on</b> that number of garments <b>and carry</b> it <b>out. And he may say to others: Come and rescue with me.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Wasn’t it taught in the first clause,</b> i.e., the preceding mishna, that one may rescue <b>three meals and no more? Rav Huna said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. This</b> current mishna permitted rescuing a greater amount <b>when one comes to rescue</b> a basket or round cake of figs; <b>that</b> previous mishna permitted rescuing food for only three meals in a case where <b>one comes to collect</b> the food. <b>When one comes to rescue, he may rescue everything; when one comes to collect, he may collect food for only three meals.</b> However, <b>Rabbi Abba bar Zavda said</b> that <b>Rav said: Both this and that</b> are referring to a case <b>where one comes to collect, and</b> this is <b>not difficult. This</b> current mishna permitted rescuing a greater amount when one moves the objects <b>to the same courtyard; that,</b> the previous mishna, permitted saving food for only three meals when one transfers it <b>to a different courtyard. Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, raised a dilemma:</b> If <b>one spread his cloak</b> on the ground <b>and collected and placed</b> objects in the cloak, <b>and collected and placed</b> objects inside it, <b>what</b> is the ruling? Is he <b>considered as one who comes to rescue or</b> is he <b>like one who comes to collect?</b>
The Gemara attempts to resolve the dilemma <b>from that which Rava said: Rav Sheizvi misled Rav Ḥisda, and</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>taught</b> (Rabbeinu Ḥananel) a <i>halakha</i> with regard to a barrel that breaks on a roof, and added: And it is permitted <b>provided that one does not bring a vessel that holds more than three meals. Conclude from</b> the fact that Rava said that Rav Ḥisda’s restriction of the amount that can be rescued to food sufficient for three meals is mistaken, that one who takes a large amount all at once is <b>like one who comes to rescue, and</b> he may <b>well</b> do so. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said to Rava: What is the error</b> in Rav Ḥisda’s statement? Perhaps it is actually prohibited. He <b>said to him, as it is taught: Provided that he does not bring another vessel</b> and place it on the ground to <b>catch</b> the liquid, <b>another vessel and attach</b> the vessel next to the roof. Apparently <b>it is another vessel that one may not</b> bring, <b>but in that</b> same <b>vessel, one may rescue as much as he wants,</b> and the Sages did not establish a maximum size for the vessel.
<b>And</b> we learned in the mishna that one is permitted to rescue <b>a round</b> cake <b>of dried figs</b> from a fire, and one may even say to others: Come and rescue for yourselves. And if the people who rescue with him are clever, they make a calculation with him after Shabbat. The Gemara is surprised at this: <b>What is</b> the mention of <b>a calculation doing</b> here? <b>Aren’t they acquiring</b> food <b>from ownerless</b> property? What calculation is necessary here? Whatever they rescue is theirs, and they do not need to return it to the original owner. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: They taught an attribute of piety here.</b> These are pious people. They want to return the objects to their owner even though they are not legally obligated to do so, and they were permitted to receive payment for their efforts. <b>Rava said:</b> And do <b>pious</b> people <b>take payment</b> for work they do on <b>Shabbat? Rather, Rava said: Here, we are dealing with one who is Heaven-fearing</b> but not completely pious. <b>And</b> it is <b>uncomfortable for him to benefit from</b> the property of <b>others, and it is also uncomfortable for him to exert</b> himself <b>for free. And this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: And if they are clever and know that in a situation of this kind it is not</b> technically <b>payment for Shabbat</b> labor, and it is permitted because they are only receiving a small portion of the value of the objects that they rescued, <b>they</b> may <b>make a calculation with him after Shabbat.</b>
We learned in the mishna that one may say to others: Come and rescue for yourselves. We also learned: <b>And to where may one rescue</b> the food? According to the first <i>tanna</i>, one may rescue to a courtyard in which an <i>eiruv</i> was established. According to ben Beteira, one may rescue even to a courtyard in which an <i>eiruv</i> was not established. The Gemara asks: <b>What is different here,</b> with regard to rescuing food, <b>that it is taught</b> that one may say to others: Come and rescue <b>for yourselves, and what is different here,</b> with regard to rescuing clothing, <b>that it is taught</b> that one may say to others: Come and rescue <b>with me?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>With regard to food, it taught: For yourselves, because only food for three meals is suited for him,</b> and only others can benefit from the rest. <b>However, with regard to</b> the <b>garments, it is taught: With me, because it is suited for him</b> to continue rescuing garments <b>all day,</b> since he is permitted to wear other clothes.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one wants to rescue objects from a fire and there are many garments there, he <b>may wear</b> them, and <b>take</b> them <b>out</b> to a safe place, <b>and remove</b> them there, <b>and return</b> to the fire, <b>and wear</b> other clothes, <b>and take</b> them <b>out and remove</b> them. <b>And</b> he may <b>even</b> do so <b>all day long;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> One may wear only <b>eighteen garments, and these are</b> the <b>eighteen garments: A cloak [<i>miktoren</i>], a cape [<i>unkali</i>],</b> a broad garment worn on one’s shoulders, <b>and a</b> large hollow <b>belt</b> worn over the clothes, <b>a wide linen garment [<i>kalbus</i>], and a robe</b> worn against the skin, <b>a robe</b> wrapped above, <b>and a kerchief</b> on one’s head, <b>and two straps,</b> i.e., belts, <b>and two shoes, and two socks [<i>anpilaot</i>], and two</b> tall <b>boots [<i>pargod</i>], and a belt around one’s loins</b> over the robe, <b>and a hat on one’s head, and a scarf around one’s neck.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas says: One may spread out a</b> moist <b>goat’s hide over a box, a chest, or a closet that caught fire, because</b> the fire <b>singes</b> and does not burn it. The fire does not burn the wet goat’s hide but merely singes it, and by doing so the wooden vessels are preserved. <b>And one may establish a barrier</b> against the fire <b>with all vessels, both full and empty, so that the fire will not pass. Rabbi Yosei prohibits</b> using <b>new earthenware vessels full of water, because they cannot withstand</b> the heat of <b>the fire and they</b> will <b>burst and extinguish the fire,</b> and it is prohibited to cause the fire to be extinguished on Shabbat even indirectly.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> If <b>a garment caught fire on one side, one may place water on its other side, and if</b> as a result the fire <b>is extinguished, it is extinguished.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based on the following <i>Tosefta</i>: If <b>a garment caught fire on one side, one may stretch it</b> out <b>and cover himself with it, and if</b> the fire <b>is extinguished, it is extinguished. And so too,</b> if <b>a Torah scroll caught fire, one may open it and read it, and if</b> the fire <b>is extinguished, it is extinguished.</b> Apparently, it is prohibited to actually pour water, but one may perform a permitted act that will incidentally extinguish.

Daf 120b

The Gemara answers: <b>It</b> was Rav <b>who said</b> his statement <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas</b> in the mishna.
The Gemara asks: <b>Say</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas said</b> it is permitted to place the goat’s hide on the burning item <b>because it singes</b> and does not burn; <b>did he say</b> it is permitted to <b>indirectly cause</b> the fire to <b>extinguish?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas permitted that as well, and we learn this <b>from that which is taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> in the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yosei prohibits</b> using <b>new earthenware vessels</b> that are <b>full of water,</b> because <b>they cannot withstand the fire and</b> will <b>burst and extinguish the fire.</b> This proves <b>by inference that the first <i>tanna</i>,</b> Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas, <b>permits</b> it.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to <b>a candle that is atop a board, one shakes the board and</b> the candle <b>falls, and if it is extinguished, it is extinguished. The</b> Sages of the <b>school of Rabbi Yannai said: They only taught</b> that this is permitted in a case <b>where one forgets</b> the candle atop the board when Shabbat began. <b>However,</b> in a case <b>where one places</b> it there, the board <b>becomes a base for a prohibited object</b> and may not be moved.
<b>It was taught:</b> With regard to <b>a candle behind a door, one may open and shut</b> the door <b>in his</b> usual <b>manner, and if it is extinguished, it is extinguished. Rav would curse one</b> who did so. <b>Ravina said to Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava,</b> said <b>to Rav Ashi: What is the reason</b> that <b>Rav cursed</b> and reprimanded <b>one</b> who did so? <b>If you say</b> it is <b>because Rav holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> that it is prohibited to perform an unintentional act from which a prohibited labor could ensue, <b>and</b> the <b><i>tanna</i> taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> that it is permitted to perform an unintentional act in those circumstances; <b>because Rav holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, he curses anyone who teaches</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon?</b> They rely on the ruling of a <i>tanna</i>, whose opinion is legitimate.
He <b>said to him: In this</b> case, <b>even Rabbi Shimon concedes</b> that it is prohibited, <b>as it was Abaye and Rava who both said</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon concedes in a case of: Cut off its head, will it not die?</b> In an instance where the unintentional act leads to an inevitable prohibited consequence, even Rabbi Shimon agrees that the person who performs the unintentional act is liable.
<b>Rav Yehuda said: A person opens a door opposite a fire on Shabbat.</b> The Gemara relates that <b>Abaye would curse</b> anyone who did <b>so.</b> The Gemara clarifies: <b>With what are we dealing? If you say</b> this is referring to a case where <b>a typical wind</b> is blowing outside, <b>what is the reason of the one</b> who <b>prohibits</b> opening the door? A typical wind will neither fan nor extinguish the fire. And <b>if</b> it is referring to a case where <b>an atypical wind</b> is blowing outside, <b>what is the reason of the one who permits</b> opening the door? The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it is referring to the case of <b>a typical wind.</b> However, one <b>Sage,</b> Abaye, <b>holds</b> that <b>we issue a decree</b> prohibiting to open the door in the case of a typical wind due to a case of an atypical wind, <b>and</b> the other <b>Sage,</b> Rav Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not issue</b> that <b>decree.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>one may establish a barrier</b> with all earthenware vessels, and Rabbi Yosei prohibits using new earthenware vessels. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>indirect extinguishing is permitted</b> on Shabbat, <b>and Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b>indirect extinguishing is prohibited? Didn’t we hear them</b> state <b>the opposite, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may establish a barrier with empty vessels, and with full ones that do not typically break. And these are full</b> vessels <b>that do not typically break; metal vessels. Rabbi Yosei says: Even</b> earthenware <b>vessels</b> from <b>the village of Shiḥin and vessels from the village of Ḥananya do not typically break.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Yosei’s opinion is more lenient than the opinions of the Rabbis. <b>And if you say: Reverse the</b> attribution of opinions in the <b>mishna</b> and attribute Rabbi Yosei’s opinion to the Rabbis, and say that <b>Rabbi Yosei is saying</b> his statement in <b>the <i>baraita</i> in accordance with</b> the opinion of the Rabbis, although he himself disagrees and permits using all vessels. But <b>can you reverse</b> the mishna? <b>Didn’t Rabba bar Taḥalifa say in the name of Rav: Who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> who <b>teaches</b> that <b>indirect extinguishing is prohibited?</b> It is <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b>
<b>Rather, actually, do not reverse</b> the attribution of the opinions in the mishna, <b>and the entire <i>baraita</i> is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, and it is incomplete and is teaching the following: One may establish a barrier with empty vessels and full ones that do not typically break. And these are vessels that do not typically break: Metal vessels; and vessels</b> from <b>the village of Shiḥin and vessels</b> from <b>the village of Ḥananya also do not typically break, as Rabbi Yosei says: Even vessels</b> from <b>the village of Shiḥin and vessels</b> from <b>the village of Ḥananya do not typically break.</b>
The conclusion is that Rabbi Yosei prohibits indirect extinguishing, and the Rabbis permit it. The Gemara <b>raises a contradiction between</b> one statement of <b>the Rabbis</b> and a second statement of <b>the Rabbis; and</b> it <b>raises a contradiction between</b> one statement of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> and a second statement of <b>Rabbi Yosei. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>If</b> one <b>had a</b> sacred <b>name</b> of God <b>written on his skin he may neither wash</b> it in water lest it be erased, <b>nor may he smear</b> it with oil, <b>nor may he stand in a place of filth</b> because it is disrespectful of God’s name. <b>If an immersion of mitzva happened to</b> present itself, <b>he wraps a reed over</b> God’s name <b>and</b> then <b>descends and immerses. Rabbi Yosei says: Actually, he descends and immerses in his</b> usual <b>manner,</b> even if it is not an immersion of mitzva, <b>provided that he does not rub</b> the spot and erase the name. Apparently, Rabbi Yosei’s opinion is more lenient than that of the Sages with regard to indirectly causing a prohibited outcome.
The Gemara answers: <b>It is different there</b> because <b>the verse says:</b> “And you shall break down their altars, and you shall smash their pillars, and their sacred trees, and burn with fire, and the graven images of their gods you shall hew down <b>and you shall destroy their name from that place. You shall not do so to the Lord your God”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:3–4). From the prohibition: “You shall not do so,” Rabbi Yosei derives that actually <b>doing so is that which is prohibited; indirectly causing</b> that result <b>is permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, here too,</b> with regard to Shabbat, <b>it is written:</b> “And the seventh day is Shabbat for the Lord your God, <b>you shall not perform any labor”</b> (Exodus 20:9). And here, too, one could derive: <b>Performance is that which is prohibited; indirectly causing</b> a prohibited action <b>is permitted.</b> The Gemara answers: Actually, Rabbi Yosei maintains there is no prohibition in indirectly causing a fire to be extinguished; however, <b>since a person is agitated about his property, if you permit him</b> to indirectly extinguish the fire, <b>he will come to extinguish</b> it directly.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, there is a contradiction</b> between one statement <b>of the Rabbis</b> and another statement <b>of the Rabbis: If</b> in the case of a fire, <b>where a person is agitated about his property,</b> nevertheless, the Rabbis hold that indirect extinguishing <b>is permitted; here,</b> in the case of erasing God’s name, <b>all the more so</b> it should be permitted to indirectly cause erasure of God’s name. Why did the Rabbis in the <i>baraita</i> issue a stringent ruling in this matter?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>And</b> how can <b>you understand</b> it that way? <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>this reed</b> with which God’s name is covered while immersing according to the Rabbis? <b>If</b> it is <b>firmly attached, it is an interposition; if it is not firmly attached, the water enters</b> and erases the name. The Gemara questions this: If the concern is with regard to an <b>interposition, derive</b> that <b>it</b> is an interposition in any case <b>due to</b> the <b>ink</b> on his skin. The Gemara answers: This is referring to <b>moist</b> ink that does not interpose, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>blood, and ink,</b> and <b>honey, and milk</b> on a person’s skin, when they are <b>dry,</b> they <b>interpose</b> during immersion; when they are <b>moist,</b> they <b>do not interpose.</b> The Gemara continues: <b>Nevertheless,</b> it is <b>difficult:</b> Why do the Rabbis require wrapping a reed around God’s name?
<b>Rather, Rava bar Rav Sheila said</b> that <b>this is the reasoning of the Rabbis: They hold</b> that <b>it is prohibited</b> for a person <b>to stand before the name</b> of God while <b>naked,</b> and therefore there must be a barrier between one’s naked body and the name. The Gemara asks: Is that to say <b>by inference</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b>it is permitted to stand before the name</b> while <b>naked?</b> The Gemara answers: No, he does not allow doing so; however, he does not require that the name be covered with a reed. It is sufficient for <b>one to place his hand over</b> the name.
The Gemara asks: If so, according <b>to the Rabbis</b> it should <b>also</b> be sufficient for <b>one to place his hand over it.</b> The Gemara explains: The Rabbis are concerned because <b>sometimes one</b> will <b>forget and remove</b> his hand. The Gemara asks: Shouldn’t <b>Rabbi Yosei also</b> be concerned because <b>sometimes one</b> will <b>forget and remove</b> his hand? <b>Rather, if there is a reed</b> available, Rabbi Yosei <b>indeed</b> concedes that one covers God’s name with it. However, <b>with what</b> situation <b>are we dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case in which one would have <b>to seek a reed.</b> In that case, <b>the Rabbis hold</b>

Daf 121a

that performing <b>immersion at its</b> designated <b>time is not a mitzva, and we seek</b> a reed to wrap around God’s name even if it means postponing immersion to the next day, <b>and Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b>immersion at its</b> designated <b>time is a mitzva, and</b> therefore <b>we do not seek</b> a reed, since immersion cannot be postponed.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Yosei hold</b> that <b>immersion at its</b> designated <b>time is a mitzva? Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a <i>zav</i> and a <i>zava</i>, a male and female leper, one who has relations with a menstruating woman, and a person impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse, their immersion is during the day.</b> They immerse at the designated time even on Yom Kippur, when bathing is prohibited. <b>A menstruating woman and a woman after childbirth immerse at night. A man who has had a seminal emission immerses</b> at any point <b>during the entire day</b> after the emission. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: From</b> the time that he recited <b>the afternoon prayer and on he does not immerse.</b> Since he already recited the afternoon prayer, he waits until after Yom Kippur to immerse, and then recites the evening prayer in a state of purity. Apparently, Rabbi Yosei holds that immersion at the designated time is not a mitzva. The Gemara rejects this: In <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> the reference is not to the Rabbi Yosei most commonly cited in tannaitic literature without a patronymic, Rabbi Yosei ben Ḥalafta, but it <b>is</b> to <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, who said: Her latest immersion is sufficient.</b> A woman who is uncertain with regard to the correct time for her immersion need not immerse multiple times. She may postpone her immersion until a time when she will be certain to fulfill her obligation, even though it might not be immersion at the designated time.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a gentile comes to extinguish</b> a Jew’s fire on Shabbat, <b>one may not say to him: Extinguish, and: Do not extinguish, because</b> responsibility for <b>his rest is not</b> incumbent <b>upon</b> the Jew. <b>However,</b> if <b>a</b> Jewish <b>child comes to extinguish</b> a fire on Shabbat, <b>they do not listen to him</b> and allow him to extinguish it, even though he is not yet obligated in mitzva observance, <b>because</b> responsibility for <b>his rest is</b> incumbent <b>upon</b> the Jew.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Ami said:</b> During <b>a fire, the</b> Sages <b>permitted to say</b> in the presence of gentiles: <b>Anyone who extinguishes</b> the fire <b>will not lose,</b> so that the gentiles will come and extinguish the fire; it is only prohibited to tell gentiles to do so explicitly. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that the mishna <b>supports his</b> statement: If <b>a gentile comes to extinguish</b> a Jew’s fire on Shabbat, <b>one may not say to him: Extinguish, and: Do not extinguish, because</b> responsibility for <b>his rest is not</b> incumbent <b>upon</b> the Jew. It can be inferred from the language of the mishna: <b>It is</b> a direct command, e.g., <b>extinguish, that we may not say to him; however, anyone who extinguishes will not lose, we</b> may <b>tell him,</b> which supports Rabbi Ami’s statement. The Gemara rejects this. <b>Say</b> the <b>latter</b> clause of the mishna: <b>Do not extinguish, we do not tell him.</b> It can be inferred that <b>neither do we say to him: Anyone who extinguishes will not lose. Rather, nothing can be inferred from this</b> mishna.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>There was an incident that a fire ignited</b> on Shabbat <b>in the courtyard of Yosef ben Simai in</b> a place called <b>Shiḥin. And men came from the fortress [<i>gistera</i>] of Tzippori to extinguish</b> the fire, <b>because he was a steward [<i>apotropos</i>] of the king</b> and they wanted to help him. <b>However,</b> Yosef ben Simai <b>would not allow them</b> to extinguish the fire <b>in deference to Shabbat; and a miracle transpired for him and rain fell and extinguished</b> the fire. <b>That evening</b> after Shabbat <b>he sent two <i>sela</i> to each one of</b> the soldiers who came to his aid, <b>and fifty to their commander [<i>iparkhos</i>]. And when the Sages heard about this, they said: He need not</b> have prevented them from extinguishing the fire, <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna: If <b>a gentile comes to extinguish</b> a Jew’s fire on Shabbat, <b>one may not say to him: Extinguish, and: Do not extinguish, because</b> responsibility for <b>his rest is not</b> incumbent <b>upon</b> the Jew; rather, the gentile may do as he pleases.
We learned in the mishna: <b>However,</b> if <b>a</b> Jewish <b>child comes to extinguish</b> a fire on Shabbat, <b>they do not listen to him</b> and allow him to extinguish it, even though he is not yet obligated in mitzva observance, <b>because</b> responsibility for <b>his rest is</b> incumbent <b>upon</b> the Jew. The Gemara seeks to conclude: <b>Learn</b> from <b>this</b> that <b>a child who eats</b> meat from <b>unslaughtered animals</b> or violates other prohibitions, <b>the court is commanded to prevent him</b> from eating it. This mishna would resolve a dilemma that arose regarding that issue. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This mishna is referring to <b>a child who is acting with</b> the intention of fulfilling <b>his father’s will,</b> and therefore one is obligated to prevent him from doing so. However, if a child sins of his own volition, one is not obligated to prevent him from doing so. The Gemara asks: If so, the case <b>with regard to a gentile</b> in the mishna must be interpreted in a <b>similar</b> manner as referring to a case where <b>he is acting with</b> the intention to fulfill the <b>will</b> of <b>a Jew. Is</b> that <b>permitted?</b> It is prohibited to derive benefit from an action performed by a gentile for a Jew on Shabbat. The Gemara responds: This is not the case; <b>the gentile</b> is <b>acting of his own volition.</b> Because he is paid for extinguishing the fire he is not doing so in order to help the Jew.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may overturn a bowl on top of a lamp so that</b> fire <b>will not take hold in the</b> ceiling <b>beam</b> on Shabbat. <b>And</b> similarly, one may overturn a bowl <b>on top of a child’s feces</b> inside the house so he will not touch it and dirty himself, <b>and on top of a scorpion so that it will not bite. Rabbi Yehuda said: An incident came before Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai in</b> his village of <b>Arav,</b> where a person covered a scorpion on Shabbat, <b>and</b> Rabban Yoḥanan <b>said: I am concerned</b> that <b>he</b> is liable to bring <b>a sin-offering</b> because he might have violated a Torah prohibition.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Yehuda and Rav Yirmeya bar Abba and Rav Ḥanan bar Rava happened to come to the house of Avin from</b> a place called <b>Nashikiya. For Rav Yehuda and Rav Yirmeya bar Abba,</b>

Daf 121b

<b>they brought beds for them</b> to sit on, whereas <b>for Rav Ḥanan bar Rava, they did not bring</b> one <b>for him.</b> Rav Ḥanan was insulted and got angry at his host. <b>He found</b> Rabbi Avin <b>teaching his son</b> the mishna and saying: <b>And</b> one may place a bowl <b>on top of the feces of a child due to the child</b> so that he will not touch it and dirty himself. Rav Ḥanan <b>said to him: Avin the fool is teaching his son folly; aren’t</b> the feces <b>themselves prepared</b> as food <b>for dogs?</b> An object that is fit for consumption by a dog may be carried, so why need one cover the feces if he can remove them? <b>And if you say</b> these feces <b>were not prepared for</b> that use <b>from yesterday,</b> that would not prohibit moving them. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>rivers that flow and springs that gush,</b> they do not have specific Shabbat boundaries, but <b>they</b> may be used anywhere and their boundaries <b>are like the feet of all people</b> who draw from them. Even though the water was not within the boundaries when Shabbat began, since the nature of flowing water is to move from place to place, it is as if they were prepared for this purpose. So too, here, since a child will relieve himself in any place, it is as if it was prepared from before Shabbat.
Rabbi Avin asked: <b>And how, then, should I teach it to him?</b> Rav Ḥanan answered: <b>Say,</b> one may place a bowl <b>on top of chicken feces due to a child.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And derive</b> that <b>it</b> is permitted to remove the feces <b>because it is</b> like <b>a chamber pot of feces,</b> which may be moved out of the room because it is disgusting. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>a chamber pot of feces together with the vessel, yes,</b> it may be moved; but feces <b>itself, no,</b> it may not be moved. What about <b>that mouse that was found among the spices [<i>isperamaki</i>]</b> of <b>Rav Ashi, and he said to</b> his servants: <b>Take it by its tail and remove it?</b> Apparently, a disgusting object may be moved even without a vessel. Rather, we must say that the feces were <b>in the garbage</b> dump, and since the feces were not before the household members it was only permitted to conceal them, not to move them. The Gemara asks: <b>And what is a child doing in the garbage</b> dump in the public domain? It is not adjacent to the house; how would the child get there? The Gemara answers that the feces were not in the garbage dump but were <b>in the courtyard.</b> The Gemara rejects this: <b>In the courtyard, it is also</b> considered <b>a chamber pot of feces</b> and may be moved. Rather, it is referring to <b>a garbage</b> dump <b>that is in the courtyard,</b> to which the child sometimes has access. Feces in a place designated for garbage are no more disgusting than their surroundings, and therefore it is prohibited to move the feces.
<b>And</b> we also learned in the mishna that one may cover <b>a scorpion</b> with a bowl on Shabbat so <b>that it will not bite. Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: All harmful creatures are killed on Shabbat. Rav Yosef raised an objection to this</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: <b>Five</b> creatures <b>may be killed</b> even <b>on Shabbat, and they are: The</b> poisonous <b>fly that is in the land of Egypt, and the hornet that is in Ninveh, and the scorpion that is in Ḥadyab, and the snake that is in Eretz Yisrael, and a mad dog in any place.</b> The Gemara clarifies this: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this <i>baraita</i>? <b>If you say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, didn’t he say</b> that <b>one is liable for a</b> prohibited <b>labor that is not needed for its own sake,</b> and it is therefore prohibited to kill even these creatures? <b>Rather, is it not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, and these are those</b> creatures <b>that it is permitted</b> to kill; <b>others, no,</b> it is <b>not</b> permitted to kill?
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said: And who will say to us that this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is accurate? Perhaps it is corrupted,</b> and an objection cannot be raised from it. <b>Rav Yosef said: I taught</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>and raised an objection from it, and I will answer it</b> as follows: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi permitted killing all harmful creatures on Shabbat <b>when they are running after him;</b> as in that case the danger is real, <b>and</b> therefore it is permitted to kill them according to <b>all opinions.</b>
The <b><i>tanna</i></b> who recited tannaitic literature <b>before Rava bar Rav Huna taught</b> a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who kills snakes and scorpions on Shabbat, the spirit of</b> the <b>pious is not pleased with him.</b> Rava bar Rav Huna <b>said to him: And</b> with regard to <b>those pious, the spirit of the Sages is not pleased with them,</b> as snakes and scorpions harm people. The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> this statement <b>disagrees</b> with the opinion of <b>Rav Huna,</b> for <b>Rav Huna saw a person killing a hornet</b> on Shabbat and <b>said to him: Have you finished killing all</b> the hornets? This indicates that he was not pleased with him.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One who <b>snakes and scorpions happened</b> before him, if he <b>killed them, it is clear that they happened</b> before <b>him</b> in order for him <b>to kill them.</b> If <b>he did not kill them it is clear that they happened</b> before <b>him</b> in order for them <b>to kill him, but a miracle from heaven transpired for him</b> and he was saved. <b>Ulla said, and some say</b> it was <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana</b> who said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> This is referring to <b>when they were touching</b> and brushing up against him (Rabbeinu Ḥananel), as in that case if they cause him no harm, it is surely a miracle that saved him.
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said: One time, a</b> snake <b>fell into the study hall</b> on Shabbat, <b>and a Nabatean [<i>Nivati</i>] stood and killed it. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>said: One of its type killed it.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: When Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi said: <b>One of its type killed it,</b> did he mean that <b>he acted properly or not? Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from that which was related about <b>Rabbi Abba, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, and Rabbi Zeira,</b> who <b>were sitting in the courtyard of Rabbi Yannai’s house. A matter emerged from among them,</b> and <b>they raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yannai: What is</b> the ruling with regard <b>to killing snakes and scorpions on Shabbat? He said to them: I would kill a hornet, all the more so</b> would I kill <b>a snake or a scorpion,</b> as they are more dangerous and it is permitted to kill them. The Gemara rejects this: There is no conclusive proof from this, as <b>perhaps</b> it is only permitted when one steps on it <b>innocently</b> as he is walking, so that it does not appear to others that he intended to step on it. <b>As Rav Yehuda said:</b> With regard to <b>spittle</b> on Shabbat, one may <b>trample it innocently</b> and need not be concerned about the prohibitions of smoothing or leveling holes. <b>And Rav Sheshet said:</b> With regard to <b>a snake, one may trample it innocently. And Rav Ketina said:</b> With regard to <b>a scorpion, one may trample it innocently.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Abba bar Marta,</b> who <b>is Abba bar Manyomi, owed money to</b> members of the <b>Exilarch’s household. They brought him</b> to the house of the Exilarch on Shabbat and <b>they tormented him</b> to force him to pay. <b>There was spittle</b> there. <b>The Exilarch said to</b> the members of his household: <b>Bring me a vessel and place it over</b> the spittle so that people will not step on it. Abba bar Manyomi <b>said to them: You need not</b> do so, <b>as Rav Yehuda said as follows:</b> With regard to <b>spittle,</b> one may <b>trample it innocently.</b> The Exilarch <b>said to</b> the members of his household: <b>He is a Torah scholar, leave him</b> alone.
Apropos Rabbi Abba bar Kahana, the Gemara cites additional statements of his. <b>Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said:</b> With regard to the <b>candlesticks of the house of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>it is permitted to move them on Shabbat.</b> It was not clear what the nature of these candlesticks was, and <b>Rabbi Zeira said to him:</b> Is this referring <b>to</b> candlesticks that are small, which <b>are moved with one hand, or</b> even <b>to</b> those that are moved <b>with two hands?</b>

Daf 122a

Rabbi Abba bar Kahana <b>said to him:</b> They are <b>like those from your father’s house,</b> which are large (<i>Tosafot</i>).
<b>And Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: The sedan chairs of the house of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>may be moved on Shabbat. Rabbi Zeira said to</b> Rabbi Abba bar Kahana: Are you referring to sedan chairs <b>that can be moved by one person or</b> those that can be only moved <b>by two people? He said to him:</b> They are <b>like those from your father’s house.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Abba bar Kahana said: Rabbi Ḥanina permitted</b> the members <b>of the household of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>to drink wine</b> transported <b>in a gentile’s wagons</b> even though the wine was sealed only <b>with one seal.</b> He was not concerned that perhaps the gentile may have opened the barrel and poured wine libations to idolatry from it or touched it, which would prohibit drinking it. Rabbi Abba bar Kahana adds: <b>And I do not know if</b> that is <b>because</b> Rabbi Ḥanina <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who permits drinking wine from a gentile that was protected by a single seal, <b>or</b> if it was because the gentile would not dare to open these specific casks <b>due fear of the household of the <i>Nasi</i>,</b> but in general Rabbi Ḥanina prohibited drinking wine protected by a single seal.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a gentile kindled a lamp</b> on Shabbat for his own purposes, <b>a Jew</b> also <b>uses its light; and if</b> the gentile kindled it <b>for a Jew,</b> the Sages <b>prohibited</b> to utilize its light. Similarly, if a gentile <b>drew water</b> from a well in the public domain <b>to give his animal to drink, a Jew gives</b> his own animal <b>to drink after him</b> from the same water; <b>and if</b> he drew the water initially <b>for</b> the benefit of <b>a Jew, it is prohibited</b> for a Jew to give his animal to drink from that water. Similarly, if <b>a gentile made a ramp</b> on Shabbat <b>to disembark</b> from a ship, <b>a Jew disembarks after him; and if</b> he made the ramp <b>for a Jew,</b> it is <b>prohibited.</b> There was <b>an incident</b> in which <b>Rabban Gamliel and the Elders were traveling on a ship and a gentile made a ramp</b> on Shabbat in order <b>to disembark</b> from the ship <b>on it; and Rabban Gamliel and the Elders disembarked on it</b> as well.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara comments: <b>And it was necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> in all these cases. <b>As, had it taught us</b> only the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a lamp,</b> I would have said that this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>because</b> the light of <b>a lamp for one is</b> the light of <b>a lamp for one hundred</b> people. There is no need to kindle multiple lamps for multiple people; the light of one candle suffices for many. Therefore, it is permitted to use the light of a lamp kindled by a gentile. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>water,</b> there is room <b>to issue a decree</b> against benefitting from the gentile’s efforts, <b>lest one come to increase</b> the amount of water he draws <b>for a Jew,</b> even without stating that intention. The Gemara asks: <b>And why do I need</b> the mishna to mention that it is permitted to use <b>the ramp?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It taught us</b> the case of the ramp to cite <b>the incident</b> involving <b>Rabban Gamliel and the Elders</b> to indicate that they followed this ruling in practice.
<b>The Sages taught:</b> If <b>a gentile collected grass</b> on Shabbat for himself, in order to feed his animal, <b>a Jew may feed</b> his own animal <b>after him, and if</b> he collected it <b>for the benefit of a Jew,</b> it is <b>prohibited.</b> If he <b>drew water to give his animal to drink, a Jew may give</b> water to his own animal <b>to drink after him, and if</b> he drew it <b>for the benefit of a Jew</b> it is <b>prohibited. In what</b> case <b>is</b> this <b>statement,</b> that if the gentile acted for himself it is permitted for a Jew to benefit, <b>said?</b> When the gentile <b>does not know him; however,</b> if the gentile <b>knows him, it is prohibited,</b> as in that case, he certainly intended to benefit his Jewish acquaintance as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rav Huna say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: One may position his animal over grass on Shabbat,</b> even grass that is growing in the ground, and there is no concern lest he detach the grass and feed the animal; <b>however,</b> he may <b>not</b> position the animal <b>over</b> an item that is <b>set aside on Shabbat,</b> since there is concern lest one lift the item with his hand. The grass that the gentile collects for himself is certainly set aside, so why may the Jew feed it to his animal? The Gemara answers: Indeed, a Jew may not position his animal over the grass that a gentile picked; he may only <b>position it in before</b> the grass at a distance, <b>and</b> the animal <b>goes</b> on its own <b>and eats.</b>
We learned above that <b>the Master said: In what</b> case <b>is</b> this <b>statement,</b> that if the gentile acted for himself it is permitted for a Jew to benefit, <b>said?</b> When the gentile <b>does not know him; however,</b> if the gentile <b>knows him, it is prohibited.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>However,</b> in the incident involving <b>Rabban Gamliel</b> and the ship, it is a case where the gentile <b>knows him</b> as they traveled together on the ship. <b>Abaye said:</b> The action was <b>not</b> performed <b>in</b> Rabban Gamliel’s <b>presence,</b> and since the gentile had not seen him he intended to make it only for himself. <b>Rava said: Even if you say</b> that the gentile made the ramp <b>in his presence,</b> that is irrelevant because <b>a lamp for one is a lamp for one hundred;</b> similarly, with regard to a ramp, once the gentile constructs it for his own use it can be used by others with no further adjustments.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rava’s statement based on the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Rabban Gamliel said to them: Since he made it not in our presence, we will disembark on it.</b> Rabban Gamliel made use of the ramp only for this reason, contrary to Rava’s explanation. The Gemara rejects this: <b>Say</b> the <i>Tosefta</i> in an emended form: Rabban Gamliel said to them: <b>Since he made it, we will disembark on it.</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from another <i>baraita</i> with regard to the dispute between Abaye and Rava: With regard to <b>a city where</b> both <b>Jews and gentiles live and there was a bathhouse in it</b> in which <b>there is bathing on Shabbat, if the majority</b> of the city’s residents are <b>gentiles, it is permitted to bathe in</b> the bathhouse <b>immediately</b> after Shabbat because the bathhouse was heated on Shabbat to serve the gentiles. However, <b>if</b> there is <b>a majority of Jews</b> in the city, <b>one waits</b> after Shabbat <b>for</b> a period of <b>time sufficient for them to heat the hot water</b> so as not to benefit from prohibited labor performed on Shabbat. Apparently, even when an action is not performed in the presence of a Jew, there is concern that it may have been performed for the benefit of Jews. The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>There,</b> in the case of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>when they heat</b> the water, <b>they heat it with the majority</b> of the city’s inhabitants <b>in mind,</b> and the owner of the bathhouse sets the heating schedule to service the majority.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the following <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a lamp kindled at a banquet</b> in which several people are participating, <b>if the majority</b> of those present are <b>gentiles it is permitted</b> for a Jew <b>to utilize its light,</b> and <b>if the majority</b> of those present are <b>Jews it is prohibited,</b> as in that case, the lamp was certainly lit for the Jews’ benefit. If those present are <b>half</b> Jews <b>and half</b> gentiles, <b>it is prohibited.</b> Since they are participating in the same banquet, the gentile certainly knows the Jew. Why, then, is it permitted for a Jew to utilize the light of the lamp even when the majority of those present are gentiles? The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>There, too, when they kindle</b> the lamp,

Daf 122b

<b>they kindle it with the majority</b> of the those present at the banquet <b>in mind.</b> When the majority of those present are gentiles, it is permitted.
The Gemara relates that <b>Shmuel happened</b> to come <b>to the house of Avin Toran. A certain gentile came</b> and <b>kindled a lamp. Shmuel turned his face back</b> away from the lamp in order to avoid benefitting from the light. <b>When</b> Shmuel <b>saw</b> that the gentile <b>brought a document and was reading</b> it, <b>he said: He kindled it with his</b> own benefit <b>in mind. He turned his face back toward the lamp.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All vessels may be moved on Shabbat, and their doors,</b> which are part of these vessels, along <b>with them, even if they were dismantled on Shabbat, as</b> the doors of these vessels <b>are unlike the doors of the house.</b> It is prohibited to make use of the doors of a house on Shabbat, even if they were removed from the entrance, <b>because they are not prepared</b> from before Shabbat.
Likewise <b>a person may move a mallet,</b> which is generally used for labor prohibited on Shabbat, <b>to crack nuts with it.</b> Likewise, one may move <b>an axe,</b> a tool generally used to chop wood, <b>to cut a cake of figs with it.</b> So too, one may move <b>a saw to cut cheese with it.</b> Similarly, one may move <b>a spade to scoop dried figs with it.</b>
One may also move <b>a winnowing shovel and a pitchfork,</b> both of which are designated for use with crops in a barn, <b>to place</b> food <b>on it for a child.</b> One is likewise permitted to take a <b>reed or a shuttle</b> from a spindle, ordinarily used for weaving, in order <b>to insert it</b> into food like a fork. One is permitted to move an ordinary <b>hand needle</b> used for sewing clothes <b>to extract a thorn with it, and</b> one may move <b>a sack maker’s</b> needle <b>to open the door with it.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states: <b>All vessels may be moved, and even if they were dismantled on Shabbat.</b> Should we learn from here that there is only a question with regard to vessels which were dismantled on Shabbat, <b>and</b> that <b>there is no need</b> to mention vessels detached <b>during the week,</b> as it is certainly permitted to carry them on Shabbat?
<b>On the contrary,</b> if they were dismantled <b>on Shabbat</b> it can be said that the parts of the vessel <b>were prepared</b> for use at the onset of Shabbat, <b>due to</b> their being attached to <b>their original</b> vessels from which they were removed. However, if they were detached <b>during the week,</b> at the onset of Shabbat they would <b>not</b> have been <b>prepared</b> for use, <b>due to</b> their being detached from <b>their original</b> vessels from which they were removed.
<b>Abaye said</b> that <b>this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: All vessels may be moved on Shabbat along with their doors. And even if they came apart during the week, they may be moved on Shabbat.</b>
<b>The Sages taught:</b> With regard to <b>the door of a chest,</b> or <b>of a box,</b> or <b>of a closet, one may remove</b> them from their hinges on Shabbat, <b>but he may not restore</b> them to their original places. <b>And</b> with regard to the door of <b>a chicken coop,</b> one may neither <b>move</b> it <b>nor restore</b> it to its place.
<b>Granted,</b> in the case of <b>a chicken coop</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>holds: Since</b> the coop <b>is attached to the ground, there is</b> a prohibition against <b>building on the ground</b> and <b>there is</b> a prohibition against <b>dismantling on the ground.</b> Consequently, when one dismantles or restores the door he has performed the prohibited labor of building. <b>However,</b> in the case of the door <b>of a chest,</b> or <b>a box,</b> or <b>a closet, what does he hold?</b>
<b>If</b> the tanna <b>holds</b> that <b>there is</b> a prohibition against <b>building with regard to vessels,</b> then <b>there is</b> also a prohibition against <b>dismantling with regard to vessels</b> and it should be prohibited to remove the door. <b>And if there is no</b> prohibition against <b>dismantling with regard to vessels</b> and it is permitted to remove the door, then there should also be <b>no</b> prohibition against <b>building with regard to vessels.</b> Why, then, is it prohibited to restore a door to its original place?
<b>Abaye said: Actually, he holds that there is</b> a prohibition against <b>building with regard to vessels and there is</b> also a prohibition against <b>dismantling with regard to vessels.</b> To resolve the difficulty, emend the text. Rather than saying: One may remove them, <b>it is saying:</b> The doors of a chest, or a box, or a closet <b>that were</b> already <b>removed</b> may not be restored.
<b>Rava said to him:</b> There are <b>two</b> possible <b>responses</b> with which your statement can be rejected. <b>One</b> is that <b>it is taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may remove</b> them, <i>ab initio</i>. <b>And furthermore, what is</b> the meaning of: <b>But one may not restore</b> them? According to your emendation, what is the meaning of the word, but, in this context? <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The <i>tanna</i> holds that <b>there is no</b> prohibition against <b>building with regard to vessels and there is no</b> prohibition against <b>dismantling with regard to vessels, and</b> so why did the <i>tanna</i> rule one may not restore the door? It is due to <b>a decree lest one fix</b> it firmly in place in the manner of a full-fledged prohibited labor, completing the production process of a vessel.
The mishna states: <b>A person may take a mallet</b> on Shabbat in order to crack nuts with it. <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> The type of hammer in this case is <b>a hammer</b> designated <b>for nuts to crack nuts with it, but blacksmiths’</b> hammers, <b>no,</b> they may not be used.
That <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that using <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>prohibited</b> use, <b>even for the purpose</b> of utilizing the object <b>itself</b> to perform a permitted action, is <b>prohibited.</b>
<b>Rabba said to him: But if</b> what you say is <b>so,</b> how do you reconcile this with <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna in which <b>it is taught: And a winnowing shovel or a pitchfork</b> in order <b>to place</b> food <b>for a child on it; are a winnowing shovel and a pitchfork designated for</b> use by <b>a child? Rather, Rabba said:</b> The mishna should be interpreted as follows: One may use <b>a blacksmiths’ hammer</b> on Shabbat <b>to crack nuts with it.</b>
The <i>tanna</i> <b>holds:</b>

Daf 123a

Using <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for a prohibited</b> use, <b>for the purpose</b> of utilizing the object <b>itself</b> to perform a permitted action, is <b>permitted.</b>
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba</b> from the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>A mortar, if it</b> still <b>has garlic in it, one may move it</b> on Shabbat, <b>and if not, one may not move it.</b> Apparently, under no circumstances may a mortar be used, even for an action that is generally permitted on Shabbat, because the mortar’s primary function is prohibited.
Rabba <b>said to him:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya, who says: A vessel may not be moved</b> on Shabbat <b>except for the purpose of its</b> designated <b>use.</b>
Abaye <b>raised</b> another <b>objection</b> to Rabba’s opinion. We learned in a mishna that <b>Beit Shammai say: One may not take a</b> large <b>pestle</b> from a mortar, which is typically used for a prohibited action, in order <b>to cut meat on it</b> for the purpose of a Festival. <b>And Beit Hillel permit</b> doing so due to the mitzva of rejoicing on the Festival. <b>And everyone agrees</b> that <b>if one cut meat on it</b> for the purpose of the Festival, <b>that it is</b> then <b>prohibited to move it</b> because there is no further need for it on the Festival. Apparently, it is prohibited to use an object whose primary function is for a prohibited use, even to perform a permitted action.
Initially, Rabba <b>thought to respond to</b> Abaye’s objection by saying that this mishna, too, is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> that a vessel may only be moved on Shabbat for the purpose of its designated use. However, he changed his mind <b>once he heard that</b> which <b>Rav Ḥinana bar Shelemya said in the name of Rav: Everyone agrees in the case of launderers’ pins, presses, and clothing rods</b> (<i>Arukh</i>), that <b>since</b> one <b>is particular about them</b> to ensure that they remain intact, he <b>designates a place for them</b> and does not move them for other purposes. Therefore, everyone agrees that it is prohibited to move them. <b>Here, too,</b> the mortar and pestle are specifically designated for a particular use and <b>one designates a place for them;</b> therefore, it is prohibited to move them.
<b>It was stated</b> that there was another amoraic dispute on this topic. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba</b> said that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> It was with regard to <b>the hammer of goldsmiths that we learned</b> it may be used to crack nuts. Although the goldsmith is particular about ensuring that the hammer remains smooth and avoids using it for any purpose other than its particular use, nevertheless, it was allowed to be used for other permitted actions. <b>Rav Shemen bar Abba said:</b> It was with regard to <b>the hammer of spice merchants that we learned</b> it may be used to crack nuts.
The Gemara explains: <b>The one who said</b> it is permitted to crack nuts on Shabbat using <b>the hammer of spice merchants, all the more so</b> that it is permitted to use a hammer typically used by <b>goldsmiths.</b> However, <b>the one who said</b> that it is only permitted to use a hammer used by <b>goldsmiths, but</b> with regard to the hammer <b>of spice merchants,</b> the merchant <b>is particular about it</b> and would not allow it to be used for cracking nuts. Use for other purposes would cause the hammer to absorb foreign smells, which would ruin the spices.
And we learned in the mishna: one may move <b>a reed or a shuttle [<i>karkar</i>]</b> in order to stick it into food. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>an unripe fig that one buried in straw</b> to accelerate its ripening, <b>and</b> likewise with regard to <b>a cake that one buried in coals</b> in order to heat it, <b>if part of it is exposed, it is permitted to move it</b> on Shabbat. <b>And if not,</b> and it was completely covered, <b>it is prohibited to move it</b> lest one come to carry straw or coals, which are set-aside, along with it. It is prohibited for one to move set-aside objects or to cause them to be moved.
<b>Rabbi Elazar ben Tadai says: One may insert a reed or a shuttle</b> into an unripe fig or a cake that is buried in coals to remove it from its place, <b>and</b> the straw and the coals <b>are shaken off on their own. Rav Naḥman says: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Tadai.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say that Rav Naḥman holds: Moving</b> an object <b>in an atypical manner is not</b> considered to be a bona fide act of <b>moving</b> and is permitted on Shabbat? <b>Didn’t Rav Naḥman say: This radish</b> that was buried in the dirt to protect it, if it was inserted <b>from the top to bottom,</b> i.e., the wider part of the radish is closer to the surface and the narrower part is farther, it is <b>permitted</b> to remove it from the dirt. If it was inserted <b>from bottom to top,</b> and the wider part was farther from the surface, <b>it is prohibited</b> because he thereby moves the dirt. Apparently, Rav Naḥman prohibits moving set-aside items even if one does so in an atypical manner. The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Naḥman reversed</b> his opinion with regard to <b>that</b> <i>halakha</i> of the radish.
We learned in the mishna: One is permitted to take <b>an</b> ordinary <b>hand needle</b> used for sewing clothes <b>to extract</b> a thorn <b>with it. Rava, son of Rabba, sent</b> the following question <b>to Rav Yosef: Let our teacher teach us:</b> With regard to a <b>needle whose eye or point was removed, what is its</b> legal status, i.e., is moving it on Shabbat permitted?
Rav Yosef <b>said to him: You</b> already <b>learned</b> the answer to that question in the mishna: One is permitted to take <b>an</b> ordinary <b>hand needle</b> used for sewing clothes <b>to extract a thorn with it. And what does the thorn</b> that is stuck in his flesh <b>care whether</b> the needle <b>has an eye or whether it does not have an eye?</b> Since the needle is suited for that purpose, it is permitted to move it.
Rava, son of Rabba, <b>raised an objection to</b> Rav Yosef from that which we learned in a mishna: A ritually impure <b>needle whose eye or point was removed</b> becomes <b>ritually pure,</b> because its status as a vessel is negated. Since it is no longer considered a vessel, why would it be permitted to move it?
<b>Abaye said: Are you raising a contradiction from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>ritual impurity to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat?</b> With regard to <b>ritual impurity, we require a functional utensil</b> for it to become ritually impure or to retain impurity, and anything which is not functional is ritually pure. However, <b>with regard to Shabbat we require something that is fit</b> for use, <b>and this too is fit to extract</b> a <b>thorn with it,</b> and therefore, its legal status is that of a utensil and moving it is permitted.
<b>Rava said:</b> The one <b>who raises the objection, raises the objection well. From</b> the fact that <b>with regard to ritual impurity it is not</b> considered <b>a utensil, with regard to Shabbat, it is also not</b> considered <b>a utensil,</b> and if it is not a utensil it may not be moved on Shabbat.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection to</b> the opinion of Rava based on what was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A needle, whether it is perforated or whether it is not perforated, it is permitted to move it on Shabbat. And they said</b> that the status of a <b>perforated</b> needle is different <b>only with regard to ritual impurity alone.</b>
<b>Abaye interpreted it according to the opinion of Rava:</b> In this mishna, <b>we are dealing with unfinished</b> needles. <b>Sometimes one decides</b> to <b>render them a utensil</b> for other purposes without perforating them. <b>However,</b> in a case <b>where its eye or its point was removed</b> from the finished needle, its status as a vessel was negated, since <b>a person throws it among the junk [<i>gerutaot</i>].</b>
With regard to the matter of <b>aligning the</b> limbs of an <b>infant</b> on Shabbat when it is necessary to do so, <b>Rav Naḥman prohibits</b> doing so on Shabbat, due to concern that it is similar to the prohibited labor of completing the production process of a vessel, <b>and Rav Sheshet permits</b> doing so. <b>Rav Naḥman says: From where do I say</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>As we learned in a mishna: One may not make</b>

Daf 123b

<b><i>afiktoizin</i>,</b> a drug to induce vomiting, <b>on Shabbat.</b> Apparently, actions associated with treating the body on Shabbat are prohibited. <b>And Rav Sheshet</b> explains: <b>There,</b> with regard to a drug to induce vomiting, drinking <b>it</b> for any reason other than medicinal purposes <b>is atypical. Here,</b> aligning the limbs of an infant is <b>typical</b> conduct not undertaken solely for medicinal purposes.
<b>Rav Sheshet said: From where do I say</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>As we learned</b> in the mishna: One is permitted to take <b>an</b> ordinary <b>hand needle</b> used for sewing clothes <b>to extract a thorn with it.</b> Apparently, some curative actions are permitted and there is no concern that they are similar to completing the production process of a vessel. <b>And Rav Naḥman</b> objects: That is no proof, as <b>there,</b> the thorn <b>is</b> merely <b>deposited</b> in the skin and it is not an organic part of the body. Removing a foreign object from the body effects no fundamental change in the body. <b>Here,</b> in the case of aligning the limbs, <b>it is not</b> merely tending to a foreign object <b>deposited</b> in the body; rather it involves effecting a fundamental change in the body itself, which is both a curative act and one similar to completing the production process.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A reed</b> that is used <b>for</b> turning <b>olives</b> in a bundle, <b>if there is a</b> cork-like <b>knot at the top of it,</b> it <b>can become ritually impure</b> as a vessel, <b>and if not,</b> it <b>cannot become ritually impure,</b> because it is not a vessel. <b>In either case, it may be moved on Shabbat</b> for use in a permitted action.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> would this reed become impure? <b>It is</b> in the category of <b>flat wooden vessels</b> without a receptacle, <b>and</b> the governing principle in that case is: <b>Flat wooden vessels do not become ritually impure. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>We require</b> an object <b>similar</b> to <b>a sack.</b> The <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity are derived from the sack mentioned in the Torah as an example of an item that can become ritually impure. If it lacks a receptacle, it is unlike that sack and it cannot become ritually impure. To explain this <i>halakha</i>, the Gemara cites that which was <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in the name of Rabbi Neḥemya: At the time that one turns over the olives</b> with the reed, <b>he turns over</b> the reed <b>and sees inside it.</b> There is a small cavity at the end of the reed near the knot. He looks there to ascertain whether it has filled with oil, which would indicate that the olives are ready to be placed in the olive press. That cavity is a type of small receptacle, which renders the reed fit to become ritually impure.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Yosei says: All utensils may be moved</b> on Shabbat <b>except for a large saw and the blade of a plow.</b> Since they must be sharp and ready for use and there is concern that they might be damaged, one sets them aside from his consciousness and they may not be used for any other purpose.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Naḥman says: A launderer’s sprinkler</b> is considered to be <b>like the blade of a plow.</b> Moving it is prohibited on Shabbat because one sets it aside from use out of concern that it might be damaged.
<b>Abaye says: A shoemaker’s knife, and a butcher’s knife, and a carpenter’s drawknife</b> are considered to be <b>like the blade of a plow,</b> because their owners set them aside from use out of concern that they might be damaged.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>Initially, they would say</b> that only <b>three utensils may be moved on Shabbat: A knife for</b> cutting <b>a cake of</b> dried <b>figs, and a</b> combined <b>spoon and fork</b> (<i>ge’onim</i>) to clean the <b>filth [<i>zuhama listeran</i>] of a pot, and a small knife that is on the table.</b> Each of these items is required for eating and may be used, and it had been prohibited to move any other utensil. However, over the generations, when the Rabbis saw that Jewish people were vigilant in observing the prohibitions of Shabbat, <b>they permitted, and then they permitted</b> again, <b>and then they permitted</b> again, <b>until they said</b> in the last mishna: <b>All utensils may be moved on Shabbat except for a large saw and the blade of a plow.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> are the stages described in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>They permitted, and then they permitted, and then they permitted?</b>
<b>Abaye says:</b> Initially, <b>they permitted</b> moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>permitted</b> use, <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself</b> to perform a permitted action. <b>And then they permitted</b> moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>permitted</b> use, <b>for the purpose of</b> sitting in or utilizing <b>its place. And then they permitted</b> moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>prohibited</b> use, <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself</b> to perform a permitted action, <b>yes;</b> however, <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, no. And still,</b> utensils that can be held <b>in one of his hands, yes,</b> they may be moved; however, utensils that can only be held <b>in his two hands, no,</b> they may not be moved, in order to signify that there is a prohibition to move certain items. This prohibition remained intact <b>until they said: All utensils may be moved on Shabbat, and even</b> those that can only be held <b>in both hands.</b>
<b>Rava said to him: After all, it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>They permitted, what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if it is <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself,</b> and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if it is <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place;</b> why introduce distinctions that are not explicitly stated in the <i>Tosefta</i>? <b>Rather, Rava said</b> that it should be explained as follows: Initially, <b>they permitted</b> moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>permitted</b> use, <b>both for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself and for the purpose of</b> sitting in or utilizing <b>its place. And then they permitted</b> moving that object <b>from the sun into the shade. And then they permitted</b> moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>prohibited</b> use, <b>both for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself and for the purpose of</b> sitting in or utilizing <b>its place, yes;</b> however, moving that object <b>from the sun into the shade, no,</b> they did not permit it. <b>And still,</b> utensils that can be carried <b>by one person, yes,</b> they may be moved; however, utensils that can only be carried <b>by two people, no,</b> they may not be moved. This prohibition remained intact <b>until they said: All utensils may be moved on Shabbat, and even</b> those that can only be carried <b>by two people.</b>
<b>Abaye raised a challenge</b> to Rava’s opinion from that which was taught: With regard to <b>a mortar, if it has garlic in it, one may move it</b> on Shabbat, <b>and if not, one may not move it</b> on Shabbat. According to Rava’s opinion that all utensils may be moved, why is it prohibited to move the mortar? Rava responded: <b>With what we are dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case of moving the mortar <b>from the sun to the shade.</b> Abaye <b>raised a challenge</b> to Rava’s opinion from that which was taught: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <b>agree</b> that <b>if one cut meat on it</b> for the purpose of a Festival <b>that</b> it is then <b>prohibited to move it</b> because there is no further need for it on the Festival. According to Rava’s opinion, all utensils may be moved. He answered him: <b>Here, too,</b> we are dealing with a case of moving the mortar <b>from the sun to the shade.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: This mishna was taught in the days of Nehemiah, son of Hacaliah,</b> a period when many stringent decrees were issued with regard to Shabbat prohibitions, <b>as it is written: “In those days I saw in Judea some treading winepresses on Shabbat and bringing in heaps</b> of grain and lading donkeys with them; as also wine, grapes, figs, and all manner of burdens which are brought into Jerusalem on the Shabbat day. I forewarned them on that day when they sold food” (Nehemiah 13:15). Since the people treated the sanctity of Shabbat with disdain, Nehemiah instituted many stringencies with regard to all the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat in order to educate the people to observe Shabbat.
<b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The <i>mishnayot</i> that deal with the topics of <b>rods, poles, the thick end [<i>gelostera</i>]</b> of the bolt in a door lock, <b>and a mortar were all</b> taught <b>before permission</b> to move <b>utensils</b> on Shabbat was adopted. At that time, moving most utensils was still prohibited and only a small number of utensils whose primary function was for a permitted use were permitted to be moved. The Gemara cites the relevant <i>mishnayot</i>.
<b>Rods:</b> Golden rods were placed between the loaves of showbread in the Temple to support the loaves and to aerate them. At that time, moving the rods was prohibited because they were considered to be set-aside, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Neither arranging the rods nor moving them overrides</b> the prohibition of set-aside on <b>Shabbat.</b>
And the source for the matter of <b>poles is as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>There were thin, smooth poles</b> in the Temple, <b>and</b> every Passover eve <b>one places</b> the pole <b>on his shoulder and on the shoulder of another, and suspends</b> the Paschal lamb on it <b>and flays</b> its hide. And <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> With regard to <b>the fourteenth</b> of Nisan, the day that the Paschal lamb is sacrificed, <b>that occurred on Shabbat,</b> they would not use the poles, as a conspicuous reminder that it was Shabbat. Instead, <b>one places</b>

Daf 124a

<b>his hand on the shoulder of another, and the other’s hand on his shoulder, and suspends</b> the lamb <b>and flays</b> its hide.
The source for the <b>thick end</b> of a bolt is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>a bolt</b> used in a door lock <b>which has a thick end at the head</b> of the bolt, <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says: One may drag it from this doorway and hang it in another</b> doorway <b>on Shabbat,</b> but he may not move it with his hands, because it was considered to be set-aside. <b>Rabbi Tarfon says: It is like all the</b> other <b>utensils and may be moved in a courtyard.</b>
The case of <b>a mortar</b> is <b>that which we said</b> above. <b>Rabba said: From what</b> does that conclusion ensue? <b>Perhaps, actually I</b> could <b>say to you</b> that these <i>mishnayot</i> <b>were taught after permission</b> to move <b>utensils</b> on Shabbat was adopted, and nevertheless, the prohibitions can be understood. With regard to the <b>rods</b> for the showbread, <b>what is the reason</b> that they are used? They are used <b>due to concern</b> that the bread will <b>decay. In that brief</b> period until the conclusion of Shabbat <b>it will not decay.</b> With regard to <b>poles,</b> why may they not be used on Passover eve? It is prohibited because <b>it is possible</b> to flay the lamb <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar.</b> Use of the pole is superfluous, and therefore it is set-aside.
In the case of <b>the thick end</b> of the bolt in the door, why was it prohibited to move it by hand? It was prohibited <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yanai, as Rabbi Yanai says: We are dealing with a courtyard</b> for which a joining of courtyards [<i>eiruv</i>] was not established. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua holds</b> that <b>inside the doorway is</b> considered to be <b>like inside</b> the house, <b>and</b> therefore, <b>he is moving utensils</b> of the <b>houses in the courtyard.</b> Since there is no joining of the courtyards, one may not move a vessel from the house to the courtyard. <b>And Rabbi Tarfon holds</b> that <b>inside the doorway is</b> considered to be <b>like outside</b> the house, <b>and therefore, he is moving utensils</b> of the <b>courtyard in the courtyard,</b> which is permitted.
With regard to <b>a mortar,</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> who holds that a vessel may only be moved on Shabbat for the purpose of its designated use.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All vessels may be moved for a</b> specific <b>purpose and not for a</b> specific <b>purpose. Rabbi Neḥemya says:</b> Vessels <b>may only be moved for a</b> specific <b>purpose.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>For a</b> specific <b>purpose, and what is</b> the meaning of: <b>Not for a</b> specific <b>purpose?</b>
<b>Rabba said: For a</b> specific <b>purpose</b> means: Moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>permitted</b> use <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself. Not for a</b> specific <b>purpose</b> means: Moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>permitted</b> use <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place. And</b> an object <b>whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>prohibited</b> use, <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself, yes,</b> it is permitted; <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, no,</b> it is prohibited. <b>And Rabbi Neḥemya came to say: And even an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>permitted</b> use, moving it <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself, yes; for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, no. Rava said to him: Do you call for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, not for a</b> specific <b>purpose?</b> It is for a purpose.
<b>Rather, Rava said: For a</b> specific <b>purpose</b> means: Moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>permitted</b> use <b>both for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself and for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place. Not for a</b> specific <b>purpose</b> means: Moving it <b>even from the sun to the shade. And an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>prohibited</b> use, <b>both for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself and for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, yes,</b> it is permitted; moving it <b>from the sun to the shade, no,</b> it is prohibited. <b>And Rabbi Neḥemya came to say: Even an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>permitted</b> use, moving it <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself and for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, yes,</b> it is permitted; moving it <b>from the sun to the shade, no,</b> it is prohibited.
It is told that <b>Rav Safra and Rav Aḥa bar Huna and Rav Huna bar Ḥanina sat</b> together <b>and they sat and they said: According to Rabba’s</b> explanation <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya</b> that it is prohibited to move an object whose primary function is for a permitted use for the purpose of utilizing its place, <b>these</b> empty <b>bowls, how do we carry</b> them? <b>Rav Safra said to them:</b> You may move them, <b>just as is</b> the case of a <b>chamber pot</b> containing waste that may be moved because it is disgusting.
<b>Abaye said</b> this same matter <b>to Rabba: According to the Master’s</b> explanation <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya, these</b> empty <b>bowls, how do we carry</b> them? He <b>said to him: Our colleague Rav Safra interpreted it: Just as is</b> the case of a <b>chamber pot.</b>
<b>Abaye raised an objection</b> to Rava’s opinion from that which was taught: With regard to <b>a mortar, if it has garlic in it, one may move it</b> on Shabbat, <b>and if not, one may not move it</b> on Shabbat. According to Rava’s opinion that all utensils may be moved, why is it prohibited to move the mortar? Rava responded: <b>With what we are dealing here?</b> We are dealing with a case of moving the mortar <b>from the sun to the shade,</b> which Rava prohibited. <b>Abaye raised an objection</b> to Rava’s opinion from that which was taught: Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel <b>agree</b> that <b>if one cut meat on it</b> for the purpose of the Festival <b>that</b> it is then <b>prohibited to move it</b> because there is no further need for it on the Festival. According to Rava’s opinion, all utensils may be moved. He answered him: <b>Here, too,</b> we are dealing with a case of moving the mortar <b>from the sun to the shade.</b>
<b>And</b> Abaye raised another objection with regard to <b>that which we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One may not prop a pot with a piece of wood, and so too,</b> one may not prop <b>a door</b> on a piece of wood. <b>Isn’t a piece of wood on a Festival an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>permitted</b> use, since it is permitted to move it to light an oven? <b>Apparently,</b> there is an opinion that moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>permitted</b> use, <b>both for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself and for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place</b> is <b>prohibited,</b> and according to Rabba, even Rabbi Neḥemya does not hold that this is so. Rava answers: <b>There, what is the reason</b> for the prohibition? It is <b>because on Shabbat it is an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>prohibited</b> use. Since the wood is set aside from use on Shabbat, the Sages issued <b>a decree</b> prohibiting moving it <b>on a Festival, due to Shabbat.</b>
<b>And if you say:</b> Moving the wood should be <b>permitted on Shabbat itself because an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>prohibited</b> use <b>is permitted both for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself and for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place,</b> that assertion is rejected. <b>This</b> ruling, which permits moving an object whose primary use is prohibited, <b>applies</b> only in a case <b>where the status of a vessel applies to it; in a case where the status of a vessel does not apply to it, no,</b> it is prohibited.
