The Gemara asks: <b>And do we issue decrees</b> prohibiting actions on Festivals due to the fact that they are prohibited on Shabbat? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>One may drop fruits</b> from the roof <b>through a skylight on a Festival, but not on Shabbat.</b> Apparently, the Sages do not prohibit on a Festival all of the actions that are prohibited on Shabbat.
The Gemara asks on the contrary: <b>And do we not issue decrees</b> on a Festival due to Shabbat? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>The only</b> difference <b>between a Festival and Shabbat is</b> with regard to the preparation of <b>food alone.</b> In all other matters the Sages established that the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat and Festivals are the same.
<b>Rav Yosef says:</b> This is <b>not difficult. This</b> mishna, which rules that it is prohibited, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer; that</b> mishna, which rules that it is permitted, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is prohibited to slaughter a mother animal and its offspring on the same day, as it is stated: “You shall not slaughter it and its offspring both in one day” (Leviticus 22:28). With regard to <b>it and its offspring that fell into a pit</b> on a Festival, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: One may raise the first in order to slaughter it, and</b> then <b>slaughter it; and</b> with regard to <b>the second one, one may provide it sustenance in its place</b> in the pit <b>so that it will not die. Rabbi Yehoshua says: One may raise the first in order to slaughter it, and</b> then reconsider and <b>not slaughter it, and</b> then <b>employ artifice</b> and say that he reconsidered and wants to slaughter the other, <b>and raise the second. If he</b> so <b>desires, he slaughters this</b> one; <b>if he</b> so <b>desires, he slaughters that</b> one. Apparently, Rabbi Yehoshua permits certain actions on a Festival due to financial considerations, and does not issue decrees in those cases.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>From what</b> does that conclusion ensue? <b>Perhaps Rabbi Eliezer only stated</b> that he may not raise the second animal <b>there,</b> in a case <b>where it is possible to</b> save the animal by <b>feeding</b> it in the pit; <b>however,</b> in a case <b>where it is impossible to</b> save it by <b>feeding</b> it in the pit, <b>no,</b> he would permit raising the animal.
<b>Alternatively, Rabbi Yehoshua only said</b> that he may raise the second animal in a case <b>where it is possible to employ artifice; however,</b> in a case <b>where it is not possible to employ artifice, no,</b> he would not permit doing so.
<b>Rather Rav Pappa said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. This</b> mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, and that</b> mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel. As we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Beit Shammai say:</b>

Daf 124b

<b>One may neither carry a child nor a <i>lulav</i> nor a Torah scroll out to the public domain</b> on a Festival, <b>and Beit Hillel permit</b> doing so. Beit Hillel permit carrying objects from one domain to another on a Festival for purposes other than preparing food.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Say that you heard Beit Shammai</b> prohibit <b>carrying out</b> an object from one domain to another; <b>did you hear</b> that they prohibited <b>moving</b> an object? The Gemara rejects that distinction: <b>And isn’t</b> the prohibition of <b>moving itself</b> a decree issued <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b>carrying out?</b> One who prohibits carrying out certainly prohibits moving an object as well.
The Gemara adds: <b>And even Rav holds</b> in accordance with <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> of <b>Rava, as Rav said:</b> Moving <b>a hoe</b> so <b>that</b> it will <b>not be stolen; that is</b> an example of <b>moving</b> an object <b>not for a</b> specific <b>purpose, and</b> it <b>is prohibited.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that it is prohibited <b>is</b> that it is moved <b>so it will not be stolen; however, for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself and for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place,</b> it is <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rav Kahana happen</b> to come <b>to the house of Rav, and</b> he <b>said: Bring a net for Kahana</b> so that he may <b>sit on</b> it? <b>Is that not to say that</b> with regard to <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function is prohibited, for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself, yes,</b> it is permitted to move it; and <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, no,</b> it is prohibited?
The Gemara answers that <b>this is what he said to them: Remove</b> the <b>net from before Kahana.</b> That is a case of moving for the purpose of utilizing its place. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead: <b>There,</b> it was a case of moving the object <b>from the sun to the shade,</b> as it was in a place where it could have been damaged. One might have mistakenly concluded that this was the reason that they were moving the net. Rav specified that the net was being moved for the purpose of utilizing the object itself, not to indicate that moving it for the purpose of utilizing its place is prohibited, but to indicate that moving from the sun to the shade is prohibited.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Mari bar Raḥel, had felt cushions in the sun</b> on Shabbat. Rav Mari <b>came before Rava</b> and <b>said to him: What is</b> the ruling with regard <b>to carrying them?</b> Rava <b>said to him: It is permitted.</b> Rav Mari said to Rava: <b>I have others,</b> and I do not need these cushions specifically. Rava said to him: Even so, these cushions are <b>suitable for guests.</b> Rav Mari said to him: <b>I also have</b> others <b>for guests and therefore</b> would be moving the cushions so that they would not be ruined in the sun. Rava <b>said to him: You have revealed your opinion</b> that <b>you hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabba. For everyone</b> else, <b>it is permitted</b> to move the cushions in this situation; however, <b>for you, it is prohibited,</b> as it is inappropriate to permit one to perform an action that he considers prohibited.
<b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>brooms</b> made <b>of fine wool</b> garments, <b>it is permitted to move them on Shabbat</b> because it is permitted to use them. <b>However,</b> brooms made <b>of date-palm</b> fronds, <b>no,</b> they may not be moved. It is prohibited to fill holes in the ground.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> It is permitted to move <b>even</b> those made <b>of date-palm</b> fronds. The Gemara asks: <b>With what are we dealing? If you say</b> that this is referring to moving it <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself and for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, would Rav say</b> a broom made <b>of date-palm</b> fronds, <b>no,</b> it may not be moved? <b>Doesn’t Rav hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava? Rather,</b> this is referring to moving the broom <b>from the sun to the shade,</b> and that these brooms are in a place where they can be damaged. However, it is still puzzling: <b>In this</b> case, <b>would Rabbi Elazar say</b> that <b>even</b> brooms made <b>from date-palm</b> fronds may be moved? The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> this is referring to moving them <b>from the sun,</b> where they will be damaged, <b>to the shade.</b> Emend this and <b>say: And so too, Rabbi Elazar said,</b> like Rav, that it is prohibited.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All vessels that may be moved on Shabbat, their shards may be moved along with them, as long as they are suited for some purpose.</b>
<b>Shards of a</b> large <b>bowl</b> may be used <b>to cover the mouth of a barrel. Shards of</b> a <b>glass</b> vessel may be used <b>to cover the mouth of a cruse.</b>
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda <b>says: As long as they are suited for a purpose similar to their</b> original <b>use. Shards of a</b> large <b>bowl</b> must be suited <b>to pour soup into them, and shards of a glass</b> vessel must be suited <b>to pour oil into them.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> in the mishna is only with regard to a case <b>where</b> the vessels <b>broke on Shabbat eve, as this Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that if they are suited for a purpose <b>similar to their</b> original <b>use, yes,</b> it is permitted, and for <b>some other use, no,</b> it is prohibited. <b>And this Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>hold: Even</b> if they are suited <b>for some other use,</b> it is also permitted.
<b>But</b> if the vessels <b>broke on Shabbat, everyone agrees they are permitted.</b> The reason for this is <b>since they were</b> designated for Shabbat use and consequently considered <b>prepared</b> at the onset of Shabbat <b>due to their original</b> vessels, <b>it is permitted</b> to move the shards as well.
<b>Rav Zutrai raised an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may kindle</b> a fire on a Festival <b>with</b> whole <b>vessels, but one may not kindle</b> a fire <b>with shards of vessels.</b>
The Gemara seeks to clarify: Vessels <b>that were broken when? If you say</b> that <b>they were broken before the Festival,</b> why is it prohibited to light a fire with them? <b>They are</b> pieces of <b>ordinary wood. Isn’t</b> this referring to a case where they broke <b>on the Festival, and it is taught: One may kindle</b> a fire on a Festival <b>with</b> whole <b>vessels, but one may not kindle</b> a fire <b>with shards of vessels.</b> The legal status of a vessel broken on a Festival, and all the more so one broken on Shabbat, is more stringent, not less.
<b>Rather, if it was stated, it was stated as follows. Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> in the mishna is only with regard to a case <b>where</b> the vessels <b>broke on Shabbat, as this Sage,</b> the Rabbis, <b>holds it was prepared</b> before Shabbat as part of the original vessel, <b>and this Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that <b>it</b> is an item that <b>came into being</b> on Shabbat. Since they were not shards before Shabbat, they are a new entity and are set-aside. <b>However,</b> if they were broken <b>from before</b> the onset of <b>Shabbat everyone agrees</b> that it is <b>permitted</b> to move them, <b>since they were prepared to</b> serve some <b>function while it was still day,</b> before the onset of Shabbat.
With regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of Festivals, <b>it was taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may kindle</b> a fire <b>with</b> whole <b>vessels, but one may not kindle</b> a fire <b>with shards of vessels. And it was taught</b> in the <b>other</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>Just as one may kindle</b> a fire <b>with vessels, so</b> too, <b>one may kindle</b> a fire <b>with shards of vessels. And it was taught</b> in yet <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may neither kindle</b> a fire <b>with vessels nor with shards of vessels.</b>
The Gemara resolves the apparent contradiction between the <i>baraitot</i>: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which distinguishes between vessels and broken vessels, <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that there is a prohibition of set-aside on a Festival. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits kindling with both vessels and shards, <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who holds that there is no prohibition of set-aside on a Festival. <b>This</b> third <i>baraita</i>, which prohibits kindling with both vessels and shards, <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Neḥemya,</b> who prohibits moving a vessel for any purpose other than its designated function.
<b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> With regard to <b>these bricks that remained from the building</b> after construction was completed, <b>it is permitted to move them</b> on Shabbat, because <b>they are suited</b> for one <b>to sit on them.</b> And if <b>one arranged them</b> in a pile, he <b>certainly</b> thereby <b>set them aside</b> from his consciousness, and it is prohibited to move them.
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>a small earthenware</b> shard, it <b>is permitted to move</b> it on Shabbat <b>in the courtyard,</b> because there are vessels there that need to be covered; <b>but in a <i>karmelit</i>, no,</b> one may not move it, because typically there are no vessels there and there would be no use for the shard. <b>And Rav Naḥman himself said: Even in a <i>karmelit</i></b> it is permitted, <b>but in the public domain, no,</b> it is prohibited. <b>And Rava said: Even in the public domain,</b> it is permitted.
<b>And Rava follows his</b> regular line of <b>reasoning, as Rava was walking in the street of Meḥoza</b> and <b>his shoes became dirty with clay. His servant came, took</b> a shard of <b>earthenware</b> from the street, <b>and wiped</b> the clay off. <b>The Sages raised</b> their <b>voice at him</b> to reprimand him. Rava <b>said: Is it not enough</b> for them that <b>they did not learn,</b> but <b>they are also teaching</b> others? <b>If</b> the shard <b>was in a courtyard, wouldn’t it be suited to cover a vessel with it? Here too,</b> the shard <b>is also suited to me,</b> and moving it should not be prohibited.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>the</b> clay <b>seal of a jug that was broken, it is permitted to move</b> it <b>on Shabbat. That was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the</b> clay <b>seal that was broken, it is permitted to move it, and its shards are permitted to be carried on Shabbat. And one may not break a shard from it to cover a vessel with it or to support the legs of a bed with it. And if one threw it into the garbage</b> dump, <b>it is prohibited</b> to move it because he set it aside from his consciousness.
<b>Rav Pappa strongly objects to this: If</b> that is <b>so,</b> if <b>one throws his cloak</b> into the garbage dump, would you <b>also</b> say that <b>it is prohibited</b> to move it because it is set-aside? Isn’t the cloak still fit for use, and its status is not dependent on his intention? <b>Rather, Rav Pappa said:</b>Rav Mari bar Raḥel, had felt 

Daf 125a

<b>If one threw</b> the clay seal of a jug <b>into the garbage dump while it is</b> still <b>day,</b> before Shabbat, <b>it is prohibited</b> to move it on Shabbat because he indicated that he set it aside from use.
<b>Bar Hamduri said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>shreds</b> of reeds that separated <b>from a mat, it is permitted to move them on Shabbat.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Rava said: Bar Hamduri explained</b> it <b>to me:</b> The <b>mat itself, for what</b> use <b>is</b> it <b>suited?</b> It is suited <b>to cover dirt with it. These</b> shreds, <b>too, are suited to cover filth with them.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>the remains of cloaks [<i>perozemiyyot</i>], it is prohibited to move them on Shabbat. Abaye said:</b> This is referring to <b>small rags that do not have</b> an area of <b>three by three</b> fingerbreadths, <b>that are neither suited</b> for use <b>by the poor nor by the wealthy.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: The <b>shards of an old oven</b> may be moved in a courtyard on Shabbat <b>like all of the vessels that may be moved in a courtyard</b> on Shabbat; this is the <b>statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says: They may not be moved. Rabbi Yosei testified in the name of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov about shards of an old oven that may be moved on Shabbat, and about its cover, which does not require a handle.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do they disagree? Abaye said:</b> It is with regard to shards <b>when they serve some function but do not serve a function similar to their own</b> original function that <b>they disagree. And Rabbi Yehuda follows his</b> own line of <b>reasoning, and Rabbi Meir follows his</b> own line of <b>reasoning,</b> as they differed in the mishna.
<b>Rava strongly objects to this: If so,</b> instead <b>of disagreeing with regard to shards of an oven, let them disagree with regard to ordinary shards.</b> Why is the dispute specifically with regard to an oven?
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> It is <b>with regard to shards of this</b> particular <b>oven that they disagree, as we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to a clay oven that is not attached to the ground with mortar in the standard manner, but rather, <b>one placed it over the mouth of a pit or over the mouth of a cistern, and he placed a stone there</b> between the wall of the pit and the oven to secure the oven in place, <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If one heats</b> the oven <b>from beneath</b> the oven, inside the pit, <b>and</b> the oven <b>is</b> thereby <b>heated at the top,</b> the oven serves its standard function; it is a full-fledged utensil and it can become <b>ritually impure. And if</b> it is <b>not</b> attached so tightly that it is heated at the top, it is <b>ritually pure,</b> because it is not a full-fledged vessel. <b>And the Rabbis say: Since it can be heated in some manner,</b> it can become <b>ritually impure,</b> because it serves its standard purpose.
<b>And with regard to what do they disagree?</b> It is <b>with regard to this verse:</b> “And everything upon which any part of their carcass falls shall be impure; <b>whether oven, or stove, it shall be broken in pieces; they are impure, and they shall be impure to you” (</b>Leviticus 11:35). <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds:</b> An oven that <b>lacks smashing,</b> i.e., it is whole and can be broken, can become <b>impure.</b> One <b>that does not lack smashing,</b> but it is situated in a place where it is not completely effective, is considered broken and is <b>pure,</b> i.e., it cannot become ritually impure. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that the verse comes to add: <b>“They shall be impure to you,” in any case,</b> under any circumstances.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the Rabbis, too, isn’t it written:</b> “They <b>shall be broken into pieces,”</b> and why don’t they interpret the verse in the same way that Rabbi Yehuda does? The Gemara explains: The Rabbis understand <b>this</b> verse <b>from another direction, as it could have entered your mind to say: Since he attached it to the ground,</b> its legal status is <b>like that of the ground itself,</b> and anything attached to the ground cannot become impure. Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that since it is possible to detach it from the ground, it is indeed impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Yehuda, <b>too, isn’t it written: “They shall be impure to you”?</b> The Gemara answers: He understood <b>that</b> verse <b>in accordance with</b> that which <b>Rav Yehuda</b> said that <b>Shmuel said, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis <b>is</b> specifically <b>with regard to the first lighting.</b> The first lighting transforms an earthenware oven that did not yet completely dry into a vessel. <b>However, with regard to the second lighting</b> they do not disagree, <b>even</b> if it was <b>hanging around a camel’s neck;</b> since it had already been fired up once, it is impure.
<b>Ulla says: And</b> with regard to <b>the first lighting</b> according <b>to the Rabbis, even</b> if it was <b>hanging around a camel’s neck,</b> since it had already been fired up once it is a full-fledged oven and is impure.
<b>Rav Ashi strongly objects to this</b> line of reasoning: <b>If so, instead of disagreeing with regard to the shards of an oven, let them disagree with regard to the oven itself. Now the oven itself, according to Rabbi Yehuda, is not</b> considered <b>a vessel;</b> therefore, to say that <b>its broken pieces</b> are not vessels, <b>is it necessary?</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said: Actually, it is as we said initially,</b> that it is referring to shards of any oven, <b>and</b> with which <b>he crafts a ceramic board [<i>tapka</i>], and Rabbi Meir is speaking in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda:</b> According <b>to my</b> opinion, it is permitted to move <b>even</b> shards that <b>serve</b> any <b>purpose. However, according to your</b> opinion, <b>agree with me at least that in a case of this sort, it is a function</b> similar to their own original function. The shards can be used for baking.
<b>And Rabbi Yehuda</b> says: It is <b>not similar. There,</b> in the case of an intact oven, <b>its firing is from within. Here,</b> with regard to the shard, <b>its firing is from without. There,</b> in the case of an intact oven, it bakes <b>standing; here,</b> it does <b>not</b> bake <b>standing.</b> Therefore, its function is not similar to its original function.
In that same <i>Tosefta</i> where <b>Rabbi Yosei testified in the name of Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov about shards of an old oven that may be moved on Shabbat, and about its cover, which does not require a handle,</b> and which is considered a vessel and may be moved as is, <b>Ravina says: In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>do we now move the oven covers</b> in <b>the city of Meḥasya that do not have handles? In accordance with whose</b> opinion is it? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A stone that is in a gourd</b> used to draw water <b>[<i>kiruya</i>], if they fill it</b> with water <b>and</b> the stone <b>does not fall, one may fill with it</b> on Shabbat, <b>and if not,</b> and the stone does fall, <b>one may not fill with it.</b>

Daf 125b

With regard to <b>a</b> vine <b>branch that is tied to a pitcher, one may fill</b> water <b>with it on Shabbat</b> because the branch became part of the vessel.
With regard to <b>a window shutter, Rabbi Eliezer says: When it is tied</b> to <b>and hanging</b> from the window, i.e., it is not touching the ground, <b>one may shutter</b> the window <b>with it,</b> because it is not considered building; <b>and if not,</b> i.e., it is touching the ground, <b>one may not shutter</b> the window <b>with it. And the Rabbis say: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>one may shutter with it.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there:</b> In the case of <b>a stone that is atop a barrel</b> and one wants to open the barrel, <b>he tilts</b> the barrel <b>on its side and</b> the stone <b>falls. Rabba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ami said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: They only taught</b> this in a case <b>where one forgets</b> the stone atop the barrel; <b>however,</b> in a case <b>where one places</b> the stone atop the barrel intentionally, the barrel <b>becomes a base for a prohibited object,</b> and it is therefore prohibited to move the barrel. <b>And Rav Yosef</b> said that <b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: They only taught</b> this in a case <b>where one forgets</b> it; <b>however,</b> in a case <b>where one places</b> it there, the stone <b>becomes a cover for the barrel</b> and it is permitted to use it like other barrel covers.
<b>Rabba said: We raise an objection to our <i>halakha</i></b> from the mishna: With regard to <b>a stone that is in a gourd</b> used to draw water, <b>if they fill it</b> with water <b>and</b> the stone <b>does not fall, one may fill with it</b> on Shabbat. Apparently, if the stone is designated for a purpose, it is no longer set-aside. He rejects the proof: <b>And that is not so,</b> as these cases are not comparable. <b>There,</b> in the case of the stone in the gourd, <b>since one attached</b> it to the gourd, <b>he rendered</b> the stone <b>a wall</b> of the gourd and part of the vessel, unlike in the case of the stone atop the barrel.
<b>Rav Yosef said: And we raise an objection to our <i>halakha</i></b> from the mishna: <b>And if not,</b> and the stone does fall, <b>one may not fill with it.</b> A stone that is not attached is not considered to be part of the vessel and is therefore set-aside. He rejects the proof. <b>And that is not so,</b> as these cases are not comparable. <b>There, since he did not attach</b> the stone to the gourd, <b>he negates its</b> status as a part of the vessel and it remains set-aside.
The Gemara explains: <b>With regard to what do they disagree? One Sage,</b> Rabba, <b>holds</b> that <b>we require an action</b> to change the status of a stone or another set-aside object into a vessel, <b>and one Sage,</b> Rav Yosef, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not require an action.</b>
<b>And they,</b> Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Asi, <b>follow their</b> regular line of <b>reasoning, as when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia he said that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said, and some say that</b> it was <b>Rabbi Zeira</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: Once Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>went to one place and found a course of</b> building <b>stones, and</b> he <b>said to his students: Go out and think</b> that you are designating these stones for Shabbat <b>so that we may sit on them tomorrow</b> on Shabbat, <b>and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>did not require them</b> to perform <b>an action</b> with those stones. Thought alone was sufficient.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> That is not what happened. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>required them</b> to perform <b>an action</b> to designate the stones. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> action <b>did he say to them</b> to perform? <b>Rabbi Ami said</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to them: Go out and arrange</b> the stones. <b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>he said to them: Go out and rub</b> the mortar off of <b>them.</b> Rabbi Ami requires a more significant action to render the stones a vessel.
<b>It was stated</b> that there was a dispute with regard to this matter. <b>Rabbi Yosei ben Shaul said: It was a</b> new <b>stack of beams,</b> not stones. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Shaul said: It was the sounding pole of a ship</b> used to determine the depth of the water. <b>The one who said</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi permitted sitting on a ship’s <b>sounding pole, all the more so</b> he permitted doing so in the case of <b>beams. And</b> with regard to <b>the one who said</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi permitted sitting on a stack of <b>beams, but</b> in the case of the <b>sounding pole</b> he would prohibit doing so because it is set-aside due to monetary loss, as he is <b>particular about it</b> that it will not become warped and damaged.
We learned in the mishna: With regard to <b>a</b> vine <b>branch that is tied</b> to a pitcher, one may fill water with it on Shabbat. The Gemara infers: If it is <b>tied, yes,</b> it is permitted; if it is <b>not tied, no,</b> it is prohibited. <b>Let us say that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b>
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>hard branches of a palm</b> tree <b>that one cut for firewood</b> or for construction, <b>and</b> then <b>he reconsidered their</b> designation and decided to use them <b>for sitting, he must tie</b> the branches together on Shabbat eve so that they will not be set-aside. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: He need not tie</b> them together, and nevertheless, it is permitted to move them. According to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, cut wood need not be specially prepared to be used on Shabbat.
<b>Rav Sheshet says: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, with what are we dealing here? With</b> a case where the shoot is still <b>connected to its origin,</b> the vine. The Gemara asks: <b>If so, he is making use</b> of an item that <b>is attached to the ground,</b> and the Sages issued a decree prohibiting the use of any plant attached to the ground. The Gemara answers: This is referring to a branch attached to the vine <b>below three</b> handbreadths off the ground. A vine attached to the ground below three handbreadths off the ground was not prohibited in that decree, just as it is permitted to make use of tree roots adjacent to the ground. <b>Rav Ashi said: Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that it is referring <b>to a</b> branch that <b>is detached,</b> nevertheless, its use is prohibited due to the <b>decree lest one cut</b> and straighten the branch to prepare it for use with the bucket. Therefore, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel teaches that there is no need for concern.
We learned in the mishna that Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis dispute the case of <b>a window shutter</b> and in what manner one is permitted to shutter a window on Shabbat. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Everyone agrees that one may not construct a temporary tent on a Festival</b> for the <b>first time, and needless to say,</b> one may not do so <b>on Shabbat.</b> The <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree only</b> with regard to <b>adding</b> to an existing tent, <b>as Rabbi Eliezer says: One may not add</b> to an existing structure <b>on a Festival, and needless to say,</b> one may not do so <b>on Shabbat. And the Rabbis say: One may add</b> to a temporary structure <b>on Shabbat, and needless to say,</b> one may do so <b>on a Festival.</b>
We learned in the mishna that the Rabbis say: Both in this case and in that case one may shutter with it. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>Both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case, in this context? <b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that <b>Rav Kahana said:</b>

Daf 126a

<b>Both</b> if it is <b>tied and</b> if it is <b>not</b> tied it is permitted, <b>and that is</b> only <b>if it is prepared</b> for this purpose beforehand.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to</b> Rabbi Abba: <b>And let the Master say</b> it in this way: <b>Both if it is hanging and if it is not hanging, and that is</b> only <b>if it is tied, as Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Like the dispute here</b> with regard to the window shutter, <b>so too</b> is the <b>dispute with regard to a bolt that was dragged,</b> which refers to a pole that was stuck through a hole in the door and into the ground in order to hold the door in place. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>a bolt that is dragged,</b> which is not a part of the door itself but is attached to it and is dragged on the ground, <b>one locks with it in the Temple</b> on Shabbat, because the rabbinic decrees are not in effect in the Temple, <b>but not in the</b> rest of the <b>country</b> outside the Temple. <b>And</b> a bolt <b>that is placed</b> alongside the door and not attached, <b>here,</b> in the Temple, <b>and there,</b> outside the Temple, it is <b>prohibited</b> to lock with it on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One that was placed</b> is permitted <b>in the Temple and one that is dragged</b> is permitted even <b>in the</b> rest of the <b>country.</b>
<b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is a bolt that is dragged that one locks with it in the Temple but not in the</b> rest of the <b>country? Any</b> bolt <b>that is tied and hangs</b> from the door <b>and</b> one of <b>its edges reaches the ground. Rabbi Yehuda says: That is permitted even in the</b> rest of the <b>country. Rather, what is prohibited in the</b> rest of the <b>country? Any</b> bolt <b>that is neither tied nor hung, and one removes it</b> from the door <b>and places it in a corner.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua bar Abba said in the name of Ulla: Who is</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>who taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a bolt that is dragged?</b> The <i>tanna</i> <b>is Rabbi Eliezer,</b> whose opinion in this case is identical to his opinion in the mishna with regard to the window shutter. It is certainly referring to a shutter that is attached. If it is not attached, Rabbi Eliezer holds that it is prohibited for use even in the Temple.
Rabbi Abba <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>It is I who say</b> that this case is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: With regard to <b>a reed that the homeowner installed to open and lock</b> the door <b>with it</b> like a bolt, <b>when it is tied and hanging in the entrance, one may open and lock</b> the door <b>with it</b> on Shabbat, and when it is <b>not tied and hanging, one may not open and lock</b> the door <b>with it. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> If it was <b>prepared</b> for that use, it is permitted to use it <b>even if it is not tied.</b> There is an opinion that holds that a bolt need not be attached, and preparation is sufficient to permit its use.
<b>Rav Yehuda bar Sheilat said</b> that <b>Rav Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> in this case <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>Did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> really <b>say this? Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>All covers of vessels</b>

Daf 126b

<b>that have a handle may be moved on Shabbat. And Rav Yehuda bar Sheila said</b> that <b>Rav Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And that is</b> specifically when <b>the status of a vessel applies to them,</b> i.e., when the cover itself is suited for use as a vessel. This is contrary to the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, who holds that preparation alone is sufficient.
<b>And if you say: Here, too,</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel is referring to a case where <b>the status of a vessel applies to</b> the reed, <b>does Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel require</b> that <b>the status of a vessel apply</b> to it? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>hard branches of a palm</b> tree <b>that one cut for firewood</b> or for construction <b>and</b> then <b>he reconsidered their</b> designation and decided to use them <b>for sitting, he must tie</b> the branches together on Shabbat eve so that they will not be set-aside. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: He need not tie</b> them together, and nevertheless, it is permitted to move them. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel does not require that one render it a vessel. Thought is sufficient.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel <b>in one</b> matter <b>and disagrees with him in one</b> matter.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak taught at the entrance of the</b> house <b>of the Exilarch:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> in the matter of a window shutter. <b>Rav Amram raised an objection</b> from that we learned explicitly in a mishna: <b>And from their statements</b> and their actions, <b>we derived that one may seal</b> a window, <b>and measure, and tie</b> a knot <b>on Shabbat.</b> Apparently, one may shutter the window under any circumstances, not only when the shutter was prepared for use, as Rabbi Eliezer said.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Amram: <b>What is your opinion,</b> that the proof is decisive because it <b>was taught</b> in the mishna <b>unattributed</b> and the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with an unattributed mishna? The mishna with regard to <b>a bolt that is dragged is also</b> an <b>unattributed</b> mishna. The <i>halakha</i> should be in accordance with that mishna as well. The Gemara concludes: <b>And even so, an action is greater.</b> Even though the two <i>mishnayot</i> are of equal weight, since one of them not only cites an unattributed opinion but also relates an incident where the Sages shuttered a window, that source is decisive.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All covers of vessels that have a handle may be moved on Shabbat. Rabbi Yosei said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> In the case of <b>a cover for the ground,</b> i.e., the cover of a pit; <b>however, with regard to covers of vessels, both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case, even if they do not have handles, <b>they may be moved on Shabbat.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda bar Sheila said</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: And this applies</b> specifically when <b>the status of a vessel applies to them</b> and they are suited for some use. The Gemara adds: <b>Everyone holds</b> that with regard to <b>a cover for the ground, if it has a handle, yes,</b> it is permitted to move it, and <b>if not, no,</b> it is prohibited to move it; with regard to <b>a cover of a vessel, even if it does not have a handle,</b> it is permitted to move it.
<b>When they disagree</b> in the mishna, it is with regard to <b>vessels that one attached to the ground. This Sage,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that <b>we issue a decree</b> according to which it is prohibited to move the cover of a vessel attached to the ground due to the concern that one will move a cover for the ground itself, <b>and that Sage,</b> Rabbi Yosei, <b>holds</b> that <b>we do not issue a decree.</b>
<b>Another version</b> of this statement: <b>When they disagree</b> in the mishna, it is with regard to <b>the cover of an oven; this Sage likens it to a cover for the ground, and this Sage likens it to a cover of a vessel.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> On Shabbat<b>, one</b> may <b>move even four or five baskets of straw and</b> baskets <b>of produce, due to the guests,</b> who require that place to sit<b>, and due to suspension</b> of Torah study in <b>the study hall,</b> where space is required to seat the students<b>. However,</b> one may <b>not</b> move these items to create space in <b>the storeroom.</b>
<b>One</b> may <b>move ritually pure <i>teruma</i>,</b> although it may only be eaten by a priest; <b>and doubtfully tithed produce</b> [<b><i>demai</i></b>], which may not be eaten until tithes are separated from it due to concern that an <i>am ha’aretz</i> did not separate its tithes; and <b>first tithe whose <i>teruma</i></b> of the tithe <b>has</b> already <b>been taken</b> and given to priests; <b>and second tithe and consecrated items that were redeemed; and</b> even <b>dry lupine,</b> which is not fit for consumption by a person, <b>because it is goat food.</b>
<b>However,</b> one may <b>neither</b> move <b>untithed produce, nor first tithe whose <i>teruma</i> has not been taken, nor second tithe and consecrated items that were not redeemed, nor</b> raw <b>arum and</b> raw <b>mustard,</b> as all of these items are not fit for consumption and are therefore set aside. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel permits</b> moving <b>in</b> the case of <b>arum because it is food</b> for <b>ravens.</b>
With regard to <b>bundles of straw, and bundles of wood, and bundles of twigs, if one prepared them</b> on Shabbat eve <b>for animal food, one may move them. And if not, one may not move them.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Now</b> that the mishna stated that <b>one</b> may <b>move five</b> baskets, <b>is</b> mentioning <b>four</b> baskets <b>necessary?</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The mishna means that one may move <b>four</b> out <b>of five</b> baskets, but not all of them. <b>Some say:</b> It is permitted to move <b>four</b> baskets <b>from a small storeroom and five</b> baskets <b>from a large storeroom.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> then is the meaning of: <b>However,</b> one may <b>not</b> move these items to create space in <b>the storeroom?</b> It means that <b>one may not</b> use <b>the storeroom</b> for the <b>first time.</b> If he has never taken supplies from this storeroom, he may not begin moving baskets from it. <b>And whose</b> opinion is cited in this mishna? It is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who is</b> of the opinion that this constitutes a prohibition of <b>set-aside.</b> The contents of a storeroom that was never used are set-aside.
<b>And Shmuel says:</b> The difficulty in the mishna should be explained as a figure of speech: <b>Four and five,</b>

Daf 127a

<b>as people</b> who are not so precise in their formulation <b>say:</b> Four or five. <b>And if one</b> so <b>desires, he may clear even more. And what</b> then is the meaning of: <b>However,</b> one may <b>not</b> move these items to create space in <b>the storeroom?</b> It means <b>that one may not finish</b> moving the baskets out of the <b>entire</b> storeroom, <b>lest he come to level</b> the floor by filling the <b>holes. However, one may begin</b> removing baskets from the storeroom. <b>And whose</b> opinion is cited in this mishna? It is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who is not</b> of the opinion that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not</b> use <b>the storeroom</b> for the <b>first time.</b> If one has never taken supplies from this storeroom, he may not begin moving baskets from it. <b>However, he makes a path in it, so that he will</b> be able to <b>enter and exit.</b> The Gemara asks: He <b>makes a path in it? Did you not say: One may not</b> use <b>the storeroom</b> for the <b>first time?</b> The Gemara answers that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying as follows: He makes a path in it</b> by moving baskets <b>with his feet, as he enters</b> the storehouse <b>and as he exits.</b> He may not move the basket with his hand.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>piled grain, if one had started</b> to take grain from the pile <b>on Shabbat eve, it is permitted to satisfy his needs from it on Shabbat, and if not, it is prohibited to satisfy his needs from it on Shabbat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon. Rabbi Aḥa permits</b> doing so in any case. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>On the contrary;</b> it is Rabbi Shimon who is lenient with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of set-aside. <b>Rather,</b> emend the <i>baraita</i> and <b>say:</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Aḥa. Rabbi Shimon permits</b> doing so in any case.
<b>It was taught: How much is</b> the <b>measure of piled grain</b> needed to confer the legal status of a storeroom? <b>A half-kor. Rav Naḥumi bar Zekharya raised a dilemma before Abaye:</b> The <b>measure of piled grain, how much</b> is it? Abaye said to him that <b>they said: The measure of piled grain is a half-<i>kor</i>.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>These four or five baskets, which</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>stated</b> in the mishna, is he saying the following: <b>Four or five baskets, yes,</b> one may move them, <b>more</b> baskets, <b>no,</b> one may not move them? This would indicate <b>that it is preferable to minimize</b> the <b>walking</b> distance because fewer baskets results in less walking in and out of the storeroom. <b>Or perhaps it is preferable to minimize</b> the size of the <b>burden</b> by carrying smaller baskets, as long as the total measure of all that one carries does not exceed the capacity of five large baskets?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma, <b>as one</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>taught: One</b> may <b>move even four or five baskets</b> containing <b>jugs of oil and jugs of wine. And it was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: One may move them even <b>in ten and in fifteen</b> baskets. <b>What, is it not that</b> the two <i>baraitot</i> <b>disagree</b> concerning <b>the following</b> matter, <b>as this Sage</b> in the first <i>baraita</i> <b>holds</b> that <b>it is preferable to minimize</b> the <b>walking</b> distance by moving fewer, heavier baskets, <b>and this Sage</b> in the second <i>baraita</i> <b>holds</b> that <b>it is preferable to minimize</b> the size of the <b>burden</b> by moving lighter baskets over the course of several trips.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>No, everyone agrees that it is preferable to minimize</b> the <b>walking</b> distance. <b>And do you hold</b> that: <b>In ten and in fifteen, is referring to baskets? It is referring to jugs,</b> and there is no dispute between the <i>baraitot</i>. <b>And</b> this is <b>not difficult: This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which spoke of moving five, is referring to a case <b>in which</b> the jugs <b>are taken one by one in</b> each <b>basket. And that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which speaks of moving ten, is referring to a case <b>in which</b> the jugs <b>are taken two by two in</b> each basket. <b>And that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which speaks of moving fifteen, is referring to a case <b>in which</b> the jugs <b>are taken three by three,</b> e.g., in the case of <b>the small jugs of Harpanya.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>These four or five baskets, which</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>stated</b> in the mishna, is he saying that one may move only four or five baskets <b>even though he has many guests? Or perhaps, it is all according to</b> the number <b>of guests,</b> and if there are more guests one may move more baskets. <b>And if you say it is all according to the</b> number of <b>guests,</b> does <b>one man move</b> the baskets to make room <b>for all of them, or perhaps each and every man moves</b> a basket to make room <b>for himself?</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from that which <b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥiyya said: Once Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>went to a certain place and saw</b> that the <b>place was</b> too <b>crowded for the students. And he went to the field and found a field full of bundles</b> of grain, <b>and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>cleared the bundles</b> from <b>the whole field in its entirety. Conclude from it</b> that the quantity that can be moved <b>is all according to the</b> number of <b>guests.</b>
<b>And Rav Yosef said</b> that <b>Rav Hoshaya said: Once Rabbi Ḥiyya went to a certain place and saw</b> that the <b>place was</b> too <b>crowded for the students. And he went to the field and found a field full of bundles</b> of grain, <b>and Rabbi Ḥiyya cleared the bundles</b> from <b>the whole field in its entirety. Conclude from it</b> that the quantity that can be moved <b>is all according to the</b> number of <b>guests.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>And still you have a dilemma.</b> Does <b>one man move</b> the baskets to make room <b>for all of them, or perhaps each and every man moves</b> baskets to make room <b>for himself?</b>
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this question. We learned: <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>cleared the bundles.</b> Apparently, one person moved the bundles to make room for the others. The Gemara rejects the proof: <b>And according to your reasoning,</b> your opinion, do you think <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, the spiritual leader of his generation, <b>cleared the bundles himself? Rather, he ordered</b> others to do so, <b>and</b> he thereby <b>cleared the bundles. And actually, each and every one moves</b> a bundle to make room <b>for himself.</b>
We learned in the mishna: One may move baskets of produce <b>due to the guests</b> and in order to prevent the suspension of Torah study in the study hall. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Hospitality</b> toward <b>guests is as great as rising early</b> to go <b>to the study hall, as</b> the mishna equates them <b>and teaches: Due to the guests and due to suspension of</b> Torah study in <b>the study hall. And Rav Dimi from Neharde’a says:</b> Hospitality toward guests is <b>greater than rising early to the study hall, as it teaches: Due to the guests, and</b> only <b>afterward: And due to suspension of</b> Torah study in <b>the study hall. Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> on a related note: <b>Hospitality</b> toward <b>guests is greater than receiving the Divine Presence, as</b> when Abraham invited his guests <b>it is written: “And he said: Lord, if now I have found favor in Your sight, please pass not</b> from Your servant” (Genesis 18:3). Abraham requested that God, the Divine Presence, wait for him while he tended to his guests appropriately. <b>Rabbi Elazar said: Come and see that the attribute of the Holy One, Blessed be He, is not like that of flesh and blood. The attribute of flesh and blood</b> people is such that <b>a less significant</b> person <b>is unable to say to a more significant</b> person: <b>Wait until I come to you, while with regard to the Holy One, Blessed be He, it is written: “And he said: Lord, if now I have found favor</b> in Your sight, please pass not from Your servant.” Abraham requested that God wait for him due to his guests.
<b>Rav Yehuda bar Sheila said</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> There are <b>six matters a person enjoys</b> the <b>profits of in this world, and</b> nevertheless <b>the principal exists for him for the World-to-Come, and they are: Hospitality</b> toward <b>guests, and visiting</b> the <b>sick, and consideration</b> during <b>prayer,</b> and <b>rising early to the study hall, and one who raises his sons to</b> engage <b>in Torah study, and one who judges another favorably,</b> giving him the benefit of the doubt.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? And did we not learn</b> in a mishna: <b>These</b> are the <b>matters that a person does them and enjoys their profits in this world, and</b> nevertheless <b>the principal exists for him for the World-to-Come, and they are: Honoring one’s father and mother, and acts of loving kindness, and bringing peace between a person and another, and Torah study is equal to all of them.</b> By inference: <b>These</b> matters, <b>yes,</b> one enjoys their profits in this world and the principal exists for him in the World-to-Come; <b>other matters, no.</b>

Daf 127b

The Gemara answers: <b>These too,</b> hospitality toward guests and visiting the sick, <b>are in the category of acts of loving-kindness. A different version</b> of that answer: <b>These</b> matters on the longer list <b>are attributable to those,</b> the matters on the shorter list.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who judges another favorably is himself judged favorably. And there was an incident</b> involving <b>a certain person who descended from the Upper Galilee and was hired</b> to work <b>for a certain homeowner in the South</b> for <b>three years. On the eve of the Day of Atonement, he said to</b> the homeowner: <b>Give me my wages, and I will go and feed my wife and children.</b> The homeowner <b>said to him: I have no money. He said to him:</b> In that case, <b>give me</b> my wages in the form of <b>produce. He said to him: I have none.</b> The worker said to him: <b>Give me</b> my wages in the form of <b>land.</b> The homeowner said to him: <b>I have none.</b> The worker said to him: <b>Give me</b> my wages in the form of <b>animals. He said to him: I have none.</b> The worker said to him: <b>Give me cushions and blankets.</b> He said to him: <b>I have none.</b> The worker <b>slung his tools</b> over his shoulder <b>behind him and went to his home in anguish.</b>
<b>After the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>the homeowner took</b> the worker’s <b>wages in his hand, along with a burden</b> that required <b>three donkeys, one</b> laden <b>with food, one</b> laden <b>with drink, and one</b> laden <b>with types of sweets, and went to the</b> worker’s <b>home. After they ate and drank,</b> the homeowner <b>gave him his wages.</b>
The homeowner <b>said to him: When you said to me: Give me my wages, and I said: I have no money, of what did you suspect me?</b> Why did you not suspect me of trying to avoid paying you? The worker answered, <b>I said: Perhaps the opportunity to purchase merchandise [<i>perakmatya</i>] inexpensively presented itself, and you purchased</b> it <b>with</b> the money that you owed me, and therefore you had no money available. The homeowner asked: <b>And when you said to me: Give me animals, and I said: I have no animals, of what did you suspect me?</b> The worker answered: <b>I said: Perhaps</b> the animals <b>are hired to others.</b> The homeowner asked: <b>When you said to me: Give me land, and I said: I have no land, of what did you suspect me?</b> The worker answered: <b>I said: Perhaps</b> the land <b>is leased to others,</b> and you cannot take the land from the lessees. The homeowner asked: <b>And when</b> you said to me: Give me produce, and <b>I said: I have no produce, of what did you suspect me?</b> The worker answered: <b>I said: Perhaps they are not tithed,</b> and that was why you could not give them to me. The homeowner asked: <b>And when I said: I have no cushions or blankets, of what did you suspect me?</b> The worker answered: <b>I said: Perhaps he consecrated all his property to Heaven</b> and therefore has nothing available at present.
The homeowner <b>said to him:</b> I swear by <b>the</b> Temple <b>service</b> that <b>it was so.</b> I had no money available at the time because I <b>vowed</b> and consecrated <b>all my property on account of Hyrcanus, my son, who did not engage in Torah</b> study. The homeowner sought to avoid leaving an inheritance for his son. <b>And when I came to my colleagues in the South,</b> the Sages of that generation, <b>they dissolved all my vows.</b> At that point, the homeowner had immediately gone to pay his worker. Now the homeowner said: <b>And you, just as you judged favorably,</b> so <b>may God judge you favorably.</b>
On a similar note, the Gemara relates that <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident involving a certain pious man who redeemed a young Jewish woman</b> from captivity. When they arrived <b>at the inn he had her lie beneath his feet. The next day, he descended, and immersed</b> in a ritual bath to purify himself before Torah study and prayer, <b>and taught his students.</b> This conduct could arouse suspicion that the pious man kept the maiden for himself, as immersion in the morning is customary for men who have experienced a seminal emission by engaging in sexual relations.
<b>And</b> the pious man <b>said to</b> his students: <b>When I had her lie beneath my feet, of what did you suspect me?</b> They said to him: <b>We said: Perhaps there is a student among us whose</b> conduct <b>is not established</b> before <b>the rabbi,</b> and he wanted to make certain that this student would not inappropriately accost the young woman. Therefore, the rabbi kept the woman close by.
He said to them: <b>When I descended and immersed, of what did you suspect me?</b> They answered: <b>Perhaps due to the exertion of travel, a</b> seminal <b>emission befell the rabbi. He said to them:</b> I swear <b>by the</b> Temple <b>service</b> that <b>it was so. And you, just as you judged</b> me <b>favorably,</b> so <b>may God judge you favorably.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> a similar <i>baraita</i>: <b>Once</b> there was <b>a certain matter needed by Torah scholars.</b> They wanted to discuss an issue <b>with a certain matron whose</b> company was kept <b>by all the prominent</b> people <b>of Rome.</b> The Torah scholars wanted to address the government on behalf of the Jewish people, and they sought the matron’s advice. <b>They said: Who will go? Rabbi Yehoshua said to them: I shall go.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua and his students went</b> to her. <b>When he arrived</b> with his students <b>at the entrance of her house, he removed his phylacteries at a distance of four cubits</b> from the door, <b>and entered, and locked the door before them. After he emerged, he descended and immersed</b> in a ritual bath, <b>and taught his students.</b> Here too, this was conduct that could arouse suspicion that something improper transpired.
<b>And he said to</b> his students: <b>When I removed the phylacteries, of what did you suspect me?</b> They said to him, <b>we said: The rabbi must hold</b> that <b>sacred items may not enter a place of impurity.</b> Therefore, it would have been inappropriate to enter the house with phylacteries.
He asked: <b>When I locked</b> the door, <b>of what did you suspect me?</b> They said to him: <b>We said: Perhaps there is a</b> discreet <b>royal matter</b> that must be discussed <b>between him and her</b> and should not be revealed.
Rabbi Yehoshua asked: <b>When I descended and immersed, of what did you suspect me?</b> They said to him, <b>we said: Perhaps a bit of spittle sprayed from her mouth onto the rabbi’s clothes.</b> The Sages decreed that the legal status of a gentile is like that of a <i>zav</i>; their bodily fluids transmit ritual impurity. Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to them:</b> I swear <b>by the</b> Temple <b>service</b> that <b>it was so. And you, just as you judged favorably,</b> so <b>may God judge you favorably.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>One</b> may <b>move ritually pure <i>teruma</i></b> on Shabbat. The Gemara objects: That is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It is necessary</b> to teach this <b>only</b> in a case <b>in which it is placed in Israelite hands. Lest you say: Since it is not suitable for</b> the Israelite to eat, he is <b>prohibited</b> to move it on Shabbat; therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that <b>since it is suitable for</b> a <b>priest</b> to eat, one may <b>well</b> move it on Shabbat.
<b>And</b> we also learned in the mishna: One may move <b>doubtfully tithed produce.</b> The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>doubtfully tithed produce,</b> why may one move it? <b>It is not suitable for him</b> to eat. The Gemara answers: <b>Since if he</b> so <b>desires,</b> he may <b>renounce</b> all <b>his property,</b> declaring it ownerless, <b>and he</b> would then <b>be poor, and</b> the doubtfully tithed produce would be <b>suitable for him, now too it is suitable for him.</b> A pauper may eat doubtfully tithed produce, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>One</b> may <b>feed the poor doubtfully tithed produce and soldiers [<i>akhsanya</i>] doubtfully tithed produce. And Rav Huna said</b> that <b>it was taught: Beit Shammai say: One</b> may <b>neither feed the poor doubtfully tithed produce nor</b> feed <b>soldiers doubtfully tithed produce. And Beit Hillel say: One</b> may <b>feed the poor doubtfully tithed produce and</b> feed <b>soldiers doubtfully tithed produce.</b> The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel.
We learned in the mishna: And one may move <b>first tithe whose</b> teruma of the tithe <b>has</b> already <b>been taken.</b> The Gemara poses a question: <b>It is obvious</b> that if the <i>teruma</i> was already tithed it is non-sacred produce in every sense. The Gemara explains: <b>It was necessary</b> to teach this <b><i>halakha</i> only in</b> the following case: A Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest while the grain was still <b>on the stalks and brought it to the threshing floor, and before the grain was threshed, the <i>teruma</i> of the tithes was taken and the <i>teruma gedola</i> was not taken.</b>
<b>And</b> the above mentioned <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Abbahu, as Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Reish Lakish said:</b> With regard to <b>first tithe, in a case in which</b> the Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest while the grain was still <b>on the stalks, one is exempt from separating <i>teruma gedola from it</i>, as it is stated: “And you shall set apart from it a gift for the Lord, even a tenth part of the tithe”</b> (Numbers 18:26). By inference: <b>A tenth part of the tithe,</b> i.e., the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, <b>I,</b> God, <b>said to you</b> that you must take, <b>and not both <i>teruma gedola</i> and the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye: If so, even if</b> the Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest after the kernels of grain were removed from the stalks and placed <b>in a pile,</b> the Levite should <b>also be exempt</b> from taking <i>teruma gedola.</i> Abaye <b>said to him: With regard to your</b> claim, <b>the verse states: “From all that is given to you, you shall set apart</b> that which is the Lord’s <b><i>teruma</i>”</b> (Numbers 18:29). God’s <i>teruma,</i> i.e., <i>teruma gedola,</i> must be taken from all the Levites’ gifts.
The Gemara asks: <b>What did you see</b> that led you to require <i>teruma gedola</i> from first tithe that was taken from grain in piles, and not from first tithe that was taken from grain on stalks? Abaye answers: <b>This,</b> stalks that were threshed and placed into piles, are completely processed and <b>have become grain, and that,</b> grains that have remained on the stalk, <b>have not</b> yet <b>become grain.</b> The verse states the following with regard to <i>teruma gedola</i>: “The first of your grain” (Deuteronomy 18:4) is given to the priest. Once it is considered grain, the rights of the priest take effect and the Levite is required to separate <i>teruma gedola.</i>
We learned in the mishna: One may move second tithe that was redeemed. The Gemara asks: This is obvious. The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> <b>only in</b> a case where the consecrated property was not completely redeemed, i.e., <b>where one gave</b> payment for <b>the principal,</b> the value of the tithe, <b>but he did not give</b> payment for <b>the fifth</b> that he must add when redeeming items that he consecrated. <b>And</b> the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that failure to add <b>the fifth does not invalidate</b> the redemption, and the second tithe assumes non-sacred status from the moment that one pays the principal.
<b>And</b> we learned in the mishna: One may move even <b>dry lupine,</b> which is not fit for consumption by a person, because it is goat food. The Gemara comments: This applies <b>only</b> when lupine is <b>dry. However,</b> when it is <b>moist, no</b> it is prohibited to move it. <b>What is the reason</b> for this prohibition? <b>Since</b> lupine <b>is</b> extremely <b>bitter</b> when wet, an animal <b>will not eat</b> it.

Daf 128a

We learned in the mishna: <b>However,</b> one may <b>not</b> move <b>untithed produce</b> on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: This is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It was only necessary</b> to teach this <b><i>halakha</i></b> with regard to a case in which the produce is permitted by Torah law, but is considered <b>untithed produce</b> only <b>by rabbinic law. What are the circumstances?</b> It is referring to a case where the produce grew <b>in an unperforated flowerpot. The legal status of produce that grows in an unperforated flowerpot</b> is not like that of produce that grows in the ground.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Nor</b> may one move <b>first tithe</b> from which <i>teruma</i> has not been taken. The Gemara asks: This is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>It was only necessary</b> for the mishna to teach this <i>halakha</i> for a case <b>in which</b> the Levite <b>preceded</b> the priest after the kernels of grain were placed <b>in a pile, where first tithe was taken and <i>teruma gedola</i> was not taken. Lest you say concerning this case, as Rav Pappa said to Abaye,</b> here too, the produce should be exempt from the obligation to separate <i>teruma gedola,</i> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>teaches us as</b> Abaye <b>responded</b> to Rav Pappa: There is a difference between the case in which the grain was on the stalks and the case in which the grain was in a pile.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Nor</b> may one move <b>second tithe</b> and consecrated items that were not redeemed. The Gemara asks: This is <b>obvious. It was only necessary</b> for the mishna to teach this <i>halakha</i> with regard to a case <b>where they were redeemed but not redeemed properly.</b> When the mishna lists the <b>second tithe,</b> it is referring to <b>that which was redeemed with an unminted coin [<i>asimon</i>],</b> i.e., a silver bullion that had not been engraved. <b>And God,</b> in the Torah, <b>states</b> in the case of second tithe: <b>“And bind up [<i>vetzarta</i>] the money in your hand”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:25). The Sages interpreted this as follows: <i>Vetzarta</i> is <b>money that has a form [<i>tzura</i>]</b> engraved <b>upon it.</b> When the mishna lists <b>consecrated property,</b> it is referring to <b>that which was redeemed</b> by exchanging it <b>for land instead of money. And God,</b> in the Torah, <b>states</b> with regard to this: <b>He will give the money “and it will be assured to him”</b> (Leviticus 27:19). Money and not land may be used in redeeming consecrated property.
We learned in the mishna: <b>Nor</b> may one move <b>arum</b> on Shabbat. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One may move squill</b> on Shabbat <b>because it is food for deer and mustard because it is food for doves. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: One may even move glass shards because they are food for ostriches.</b>
<b>Rabbi Natan said to</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel: <b>If</b> that is <b>so,</b> even <b>bundles of grapevines one should</b> be permitted to <b>move because</b> they are <b>food for elephants.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel</b> responded: <b>Ostriches are common,</b> whereas <b>elephants are not common.</b>
<b>Ameimar said: And</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel permits moving glass shards <b>only</b> in a case <b>where one has ostriches. Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: However, with regard to</b> that <b>which Rabbi Natan said to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel: If</b> that is <b>so,</b> even <b>bundles of grapevines one should</b> be permitted to <b>move because</b> they are <b>food for elephants. If one has elephants, why</b> would he <b>not</b> feed them? The relevant criterion to permit moving the animal food is not whether or not one owns an elephant, but <b>rather</b> whether or not the food is <b>suitable</b> as food for elephants. <b>Here too,</b> in the case of glass shards, the criterion is whether or not they are <b>suitable</b> as food for ostriches, not whether or not one owns an ostrich.
<b>Abaye said: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, Rabbi Shimon, Rabbi Yishmael, and Rabbi Akiva all hold</b> that <b>all Jewish people are princes.</b> There is nothing that is unsuitable for them due to its extravagance. How do we know that all of them hold this position?
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel: From that which we said</b> in the mishna, that it is permitted to move arum, this is because arum is food for ravens, and it is as if every Jew owns ravens.
<b>Rabbi Shimon: As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>Princes may smear rose oil on their wounds</b> on Shabbat, <b>as it is the way of princes to smear</b> it on <b>during the week,</b> even without the purpose of healing a wound. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: All the Jewish people are princes,</b> and it is permitted for them to smear themselves with rose oil on Shabbat.
<b>Rabbi Yishmael and Rabbi Akiva: From that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One from whom</b> his creditors <b>were demanding repayment</b> of a debt <b>of a thousand</b> times <b>one hundred</b> dinar <b>[<i>maneh</i>] and he was wearing a cloak [<i>itztela</i>] worth one hundred</b> times <b>one hundred</b> dinar, <b>they strip him</b> of that cloak and sell it, <b>and dress him with a cloak worthy of him</b> based on his wealth. <b>It was taught in the name of Rabbi Yishmael, and it was taught in the name of Rabbi Akiva: All the Jewish people are worthy of that</b> more expensive <b>cloak,</b> and it cannot be said that one is unworthy of it. Rather, the coat is treated like any other vital garment. The principle that one need not sell his vital garments to pay off a debt applies to it.
We learned in the mishna: With regard to <b>bundles of straw, and bundles</b> of wood, and bundles of twigs, if one prepared them on Shabbat eve for animal food, one may move them. If not, one may not move them. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i>: With regard to <b>bundles of straw, and bundles of wood, and bundles of twigs, if one prepared them</b> on Shabbat eve <b>for animal food, one may move them. And if not, one may not move them. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Bundles that are taken in one hand,</b> it is <b>permitted to move them,</b> as no exertion is involved. However, if they can only be taken <b>in two hands,</b> it <b>is prohibited to move them.</b>
With regard to <b>bundles of savory, hyssop, and thyme,</b> fragrant plants suitable as food for people, <b>if one brought them in for</b> use as <b>firewood, he may not supply himself from them on Shabbat</b> for food. If he brought them in <b>for</b> use as <b>food for animals,</b> he too <b>may supply himself from them on Shabbat.</b>
<b>And one may pick</b> them <b>with</b> his <b>hand and eat, as long as he does not pick</b> them <b>with a vessel. And one may crush</b> and remove the seeds with his hand <b>and eat</b> them, <b>as long as he does not crush a lot with a vessel;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And the Rabbis say: One may crush</b> them only <b>with the ends of his fingers,</b> in an atypical manner, <b>as long as he does not crush a lot with his hand in the manner that he does during the week.</b>
<b>And</b> that <b>too is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to <i>amita</i>, and with regard to rue [<i>peigam</i>], and with regard to all the other types of spices.</b> The Sages asked: <b>What is <i>amita</i>?</b> They answered: It is <b>mint [<i>ninya</i>].</b> What is <b><i>sia</i>? Rav Yehuda says: <i>Sia</i> is savory. <i>Ezov</i> is hyssop. <i>Koranit</i> is called <i>koranita</i>,</b> i.e., it is not known to us by any other name.
The Gemara asks: <b>The one who came</b> to sell and <b>said to them: Who wants <i>koranita</i>? And he was found</b> to be selling <b>thyme.</b> Therefore, we see that <i>koranita</i> is in fact a plant that is known to us. <b>Rather,</b> it should be explained: <b><i>Sia</i></b> is <b>savory, <i>ezov</i></b> is <b>hyssop,</b> and <b><i>koranita</i></b> is <b>thyme.</b>
<b>It was stated: It is permitted to move salted meat on Shabbat,</b> as it is fit for consumption. With regard to <b>unsalted meat, Rav Huna said: It is permitted to move it. Rav Ḥisda said: It is prohibited to move it.</b>
The Gemara asks: Did <b>Rav Huna say</b> that <b>it is permitted to move it? Wasn’t Rav Huna a student of Rav, and Rav holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who is</b> of the opinion that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside</b> for salted meat? How could Rav Huna disagree with the opinion of his teacher?
The Gemara answers: <b>With regard to</b> a food item <b>set aside from eating,</b> Rav <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> that it may not be eaten. With regard to an item <b>set aside from moving, he holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who is not of the opinion that there is a prohibition of set-aside, and moving it is permitted.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: It is prohibited to move</b> unsalted meat on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Rav Yitzḥak bar Ami happen</b> to come <b>to Rav Ḥisda’s house, and he saw</b> the meat <b>of that duck?</b> He saw <b>that they were moving it from the sun to the shade</b> so that it would not spoil. <b>And Rav Ḥisda said</b> to the members of his household: <b>We see</b> a case of <b>monetary loss here.</b> One must make certain that the meat does not stay in the sun and spoil. Apparently, Rav Ḥisda holds that it is permitted to move inedible meat. The Gemara answers: The meat of a <b>duck is different, as it is fit to</b> be eaten as <b>raw meat.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>salted fish, it is permitted to move it</b> on Shabbat. With regard to <b>unsalted fish, it is prohibited to move it. Meat, both unsalted</b> meat <b>and salted</b> meat, <b>it is permitted to carry it. And this unattributed</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b>
<b>The Sages taught: One may move bones</b> on Shabbat, <b>because</b> they are <b>food for dogs.</b>

Daf 128b

With regard to <b>swollen meat</b> that began to putrefy, it is permitted to move it <b>because it is food for non-domesticated animals.</b> With regard to <b>exposed water,</b> from which a snake might have drunk and into which it injected its venom, it is permitted to move it <b>because it is suitable for a cat,</b> which is somewhat immune to snake venom. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says:</b> Exposed water <b>itself may not be kept due to the danger</b> that one may inadvertently drink it.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may overturn a basket in front of the chicks</b> so that <b>they can climb on and climb off</b> of it. Likewise, with regard to <b>a hen that fled</b> that one seeks to retrieve, <b>one may push it</b> even with his hands <b>until it reenters</b> the house.
<b>One may help calves and foals to walk,</b> and likewise <b>a woman may help her son to walk. Rabbi Yehuda said: When</b> is it permitted? <b>When</b> her son <b>picks one</b> foot <b>up and puts one</b> foot <b>down</b> by himself. <b>However, if</b> her son <b>were dragging</b> both his feet, <b>it would be prohibited</b> because it would be like carrying him in the public domain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>an animal that fell into an aqueduct, one brings cushions and blankets,</b> and throws them into the water ditch, <b>and places them beneath</b> the animal in the aqueduct. <b>And if</b> the animal thereby <b>emerges, it emerges.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>Tosefta</i>: With regard to <b>an animal that fell into an aqueduct</b> on Shabbat, <b>one provides it with sustenance in its place so that it will not die.</b> This implies that providing it with <b>sustenance, yes,</b> that is permitted, providing it with <b>cushions and blankets, no,</b> that it is prohibited.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as there is room to distinguish between the cases. <b>This,</b> the <i>Tosefta</i> in which it was taught that one provides the animal with sustenance, is referring to a case where <b>it is possible to provide</b> it with <b>sustenance. That,</b> the mishna in which Rav said that one brings cushions and blankets, is referring to a case where <b>it is impossible to provide</b> it with <b>sustenance.</b> Where <b>it is possible to provide</b> it with <b>sustenance, yes,</b> he does so. <b>And if</b> it is <b>not</b> possible to provide it with sustenance, <b>he brings cushions and blankets and places them beneath</b> the animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>Does he not,</b> by placing the cushions and blankets, <b>negate a vessel’s preparedness?</b> The cushions and blankets are no longer fit for their designated use on Shabbat, and this negation of their designated use is similar to the prohibited labor of dismantling. The Gemara answers: Rav <b>holds</b> that <b>negating a vessel’s preparedness</b> is prohibited <b>by rabbinic law. Causing a living creature to suffer</b> is <b>a Torah</b> prohibition. <b>And</b> a matter prohibited by <b>Torah law comes and overrides</b> a matter prohibited <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
We learned in the mishna: With regard to <b>a hen that fled</b> that one seeks to retrieve, he may push it back to its place. By inference: <b>Push</b> the hen, <b>yes,</b> it is permitted, <b>help</b> it <b>to walk, no,</b> it is prohibited. The Gemara comments: <b>We</b> already <b>learned this, as the Sages taught: One may help domesticated animals, non-domesticated animals, and fowl walk in the courtyard</b> on Shabbat, <b>but not hens.</b>
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>a hen, what</b> is the <b>reason</b> that one may <b>not</b> help it walk? <b>Abaye says:</b> It is prohibited <b>because</b> the hen <b>lifts itself</b> off the ground. As a result, one actually carries it.
<b>It was taught</b> in <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may help domesticated animals, non-domesticated animals, and fowl walk in the courtyard, but not in the public domain. And a woman may help her son walk in the public domain, and, needless to say,</b> it is permitted <b>in the courtyard. And it was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not lift domesticated animals, non-domesticated animals, and fowl</b> off the ground <b>in the courtyard, but one may push them so that they will enter.</b>
The Gemara first seeks to clarify the second <i>baraita</i>. <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>itself is difficult.</b> On the one hand, <b>you said</b> that <b>one may not lift,</b> from which it may be inferred, <b>however,</b> that <b>one may help it walk. Then you said: Push, yes,</b> it is permitted, <b>help walk, no,</b> it is prohibited. <b>Abaye said: The latter clause,</b> which states that one may not help it walk, <b>we came to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of a <b>hen,</b> which, as mentioned above, one may not help it walk.
Having mentioned moving the hen, the Gemara cites that which <b>Abaye said: One who slaughters a hen should force its legs into the ground, or alternatively lift it</b> entirely into the air. Failure to do so leads to the concern <b>lest</b> the hen <b>place its claws into the ground</b> and convulse during the slaughter <b>and dislocate the signs,</b> the trachea and gullet. This would invalidate the slaughter and render the hen an unslaughtered animal carcass.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may not birth an animal on a Festival,</b> and all the more one may not birth it on Shabbat. <b>However, one may assist it</b> to give birth. <b>And one may birth a woman</b> even <b>on Shabbat, and call a midwife for her</b> to travel <b>from place to place,</b> even when the midwife’s travel involves the desecration of Shabbat. <b>And one may desecrate Shabbat for</b> a woman giving birth. <b>And one may tie the umbilical cord</b> of a child born on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: One may even cut</b> the umbilical cord. <b>And all the requirements of circumcision may be performed</b> for a baby whose eighth day of life occurs <b>on Shabbat.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>How may one assist</b> in the birth of an animal? <b>Rav Yehuda said: One holds the newborn so that it will not fall to the ground. Rav Naḥman says: One presses the flesh</b> around the womb <b>so that the newborn will emerge.</b>
<b>It was taught in</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda: How may one assist</b> in the birth of an animal? <b>One holds the newborn so that it will not fall to the ground, and he blows into its nostrils</b> to remove mucus obstructing the air passages, enabling the offspring to breathe, <b>and he places</b> the mother’s <b>teat into its mouth so that it will suckle.</b>
<b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: We would have mercy on kosher animals on a Festival,</b> to help the offspring. The Gemara asks: <b>How does</b> one have mercy? <b>Abaye said:</b> If the mother does not draw her offspring near and tend to it, <b>one may bring a lump of salt and place</b> it <b>in the</b> animal’s <b>womb, so that</b> it will suffer, <b>remember its suffering</b> while giving birth, <b>and have mercy on</b> the offspring. And <b>one may pour fluids of the afterbirth on</b> the offspring <b>so that</b> the mother <b>will smell it and have mercy on it,</b> her offspring. <b>And</b> this may be done <b>specifically</b> for a <b>kosher</b> animal, <b>but</b> for a <b>non-kosher</b> animal, <b>no,</b> it may not be done.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> one may not do so for <b>a non-kosher</b> animal? The Gemara answers: <b>A non-kosher</b> animal <b>does not distance its offspring, and if it does distance its offspring, it will not draw</b> it <b>near</b> again. No purpose is served by taking these steps with a non-kosher animal.
