We learned in the mishna: <b>And one may birth a woman</b> even when that involves the desecration of Shabbat The Gemara asks: <b>After all, it was taught</b> explicitly in the mishna: <b>And one may birth a woman</b> even <b>on Shabbat, and call a midwife for her</b> to travel <b>from place to place.</b> The phrase: <b>And one may desecrate Shabbat for</b> a woman giving birth, <b>what</b> does it come <b>to include?</b> All the possible acts of desecrating Shabbat for the birthing woman were already listed.
The Gemara answers: It comes <b>to include that which the Sages taught</b> with regard to this issue: <b>If</b> a woman giving birth <b>were</b> to <b>need a lamp, her friend lights the lamp for her</b> on Shabbat. <b>And if she were to need oil, her friend brings her oil</b> via the public domain in an atypical manner, carrying it <b>in</b> the palm of her <b>hand</b> but not in a vessel. <b>And if</b> the oil that her friend brings <b>in</b> her <b>hand is not enough, she brings</b> oil <b>in her hair. And if</b> oil that she brings <b>in</b> her <b>hair is not enough, she brings</b> oil <b>for her</b> in the typical manner, <b>in a vessel.</b>
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>If</b> a woman giving birth <b>were to need a lamp, her friend</b> would <b>light the lamp for her</b> on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: This is <b>obvious.</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> to teach this <i>halakha</i> <b>only in the case of a blind</b> woman giving birth. <b>Lest you say: Since she cannot see</b> even with the light <b>it is prohibited</b> to bring a lamp for her, <b>it teaches us</b> that lighting the lamp is permitted to <b>settle her mind.</b> The blind woman <b>thinks: If there is something</b> that needs to be done in the course of childbirth, the lamp will enable my <b>friend to see and she will do</b> it <b>for me.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>And if she needed oil,</b> her friend brings her oil in her hair. The Gemara asks: What good is this advice? <b>Derive</b> that <b>it</b> is prohibited <b>due to</b> the prohibited labor of <b>wringing.</b> The friend will need to wring her hair in order to extract the oil for the birthing woman.
It was <b>Rabba and Rav Yosef who both said: There is no</b> prohibition of <b>wringing with regard to hair,</b> since hair does not absorb liquids like other materials. <b>Rav Ashi said: Even if you say</b> that <b>there is</b> a prohibition of <b>wringing with regard to hair,</b> here the friend does not actually bring the oil in her hair. Rather, <b>she brings it in a vessel</b> tied <b>through her hair.</b> She does this because <b>as much</b> as <b>it is possible to change</b> the manner in which one performs a labor that is being done to save a life, <b>we change it.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>a woman in childbirth, as long as the womb is open, whether she said: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, or <b>whether she did not say: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, <b>one desecrates Shabbat for her.</b> Generally, a woman in childbirth is in danger, and prohibited labors may be performed in life-threatening circumstances.
Once <b>the womb closed</b> after birth, <b>whether</b> the woman who gave birth <b>said:</b>

Daf 129a

<b>I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, or <b>whether she did not say: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, <b>one does not desecrate Shabbat for her.</b>
<b>That is</b> how <b>Rav Ashi taught it. This is</b> how <b>Mar Zutra taught it: Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to <b>a woman in childbirth, as long as the womb is open, whether she said: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, or <b>whether she did not say: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, <b>one desecrates Shabbat for her.</b> Once <b>the womb closed</b> after birth, if <b>she said: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, <b>one desecrates Shabbat for her.</b> If <b>she did not say: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, and all the more so if she said: I do not need Shabbat to be desecrated, <b>one does not desecrate Shabbat for her.</b>
<b>Ravina said to Mareimar:</b> Since <b>Mar Zutra teaches leniently, and Rav Ashi teaches stringently, in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is the <i>halakha</i>?</b> Mareimar <b>said to him: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Mar Zutra,</b> based on the following principle: In cases of <b>uncertainty</b> concerning <b>a life-threatening</b> situation, the <i>halakha</i> <b>is lenient.</b>
With regard to the matter of the open womb, the Gemara asks: <b>From when is</b> it considered that <b>the opening of the womb</b> has begun? <b>Abaye says:</b> It begins <b>from when</b> the woman <b>sits on the travailing chair. Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> It begins <b>from when the blood flows and descends; and others say when her friends</b> need to <b>carry her by her arms,</b> as she can no longer walk on her own.
The Gemara asks: <b>Until when</b> does <b>the opening of the womb</b> continue? <b>Abaye said:</b> It lasts <b>three days. Rava said in the name of Rav Yehuda:</b> It lasts <b>seven</b> days. <b>And others say:</b> It lasts <b>thirty</b> days.
The Sages of <b>Neharde’a say:</b> For <b>a woman in childbirth,</b> there are halakhic distinctions between <b>three, seven, and thirty</b> days after she gives birth. The Gemara elaborates: During the first <b>three</b> days after birth, <b>whether she said: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, or <b>whether she did not say: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, <b>one desecrates Shabbat for her.</b> Between three and <b>seven</b> days after birth, if <b>she said: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, <b>one desecrates Shabbat for her.</b> If <b>she did not say: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, <b>one does not desecrate Shabbat for her.</b> Between seven and <b>thirty</b> days after birth, <b>even</b> if <b>she said: I need</b> Shabbat to be desecrated, <b>one does not desecrate Shabbat for her; however, we perform</b> all necessary prohibited labors <b>by means of a gentile.</b>
This ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rav Ulla, son of Rav Ilai,</b> who <b>said: All needs</b> of a sick person whose life is not in danger <b>are performed by means of a gentile on Shabbat. And</b> this ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Hamnuna, as Rav Hamnuna says:</b> With regard to <b>a matter in which there is no danger,</b> but only potential illness, <b>one says to the gentile</b> to perform the act, <b>and</b> the gentile <b>performs</b> the act.
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> For <b>a woman in childbirth,</b> there is a <i>halakha</i> of <b>thirty days.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> was this stated? The Sages of <b>Neharde’a say:</b> It was stated <b>with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>immersion.</b> A woman does not purify herself through ritual immersion within thirty days of giving birth because she is in a weakened state and susceptible to catching cold.
<b>Rava said: We say</b> that the ruling that she does not immerse during that period applies <b>only when her husband is not with her. However,</b> if <b>her husband is with her, her husband warms her</b> by engaging in relations with her, and she is not susceptible to catching cold, <b>as</b> is illustrated <b>in this</b> incident involving <b>the daughter of Rav Ḥisda,</b> Rava’s wife. She <b>immersed within thirty days</b> of giving birth, <b>not in the presence of her husband, and caught cold, and</b> afterward <b>they brought her</b> funeral <b>bier after Rava to Pumbedita.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: One builds a fire for a woman in childbirth on Shabbat during the rainy season.</b> The Sages <b>thought</b> to infer <b>from here</b> the following: <b>For a woman in childbirth, yes,</b> one builds a fire; <b>for sick people, no, he</b> does not build a fire. <b>In the rainy season, yes,</b> one builds a fire; <b>in the summer, no, he</b> does not build a fire. <b>And</b> the Gemara concludes: <b>That is not</b> the case. <b>There is no difference</b> between <b>a woman in childbirth and a sick person, and there is no difference between the rainy season and the summer.</b> In all of these cases one may build a fire on Shabbat. This conclusion emerges <b>from that which was stated: Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> With regard to one who <b>let blood and caught cold, one makes a fire for him even during the season of Tammuz,</b> i.e., the summer. Failure to do so could result in serious illness.
The Gemara relates that after <b>Shmuel</b> underwent bloodletting, <b>they broke for him a</b> wooden <b>armchair</b> made <b>of teak [<i>shaga</i>]</b> to build a fire. Similarly, for the sake of <b>Rav Yehuda they broke</b> a wooden <b>table</b> made <b>of ebony [<i>yavna</i>], and for Rabba they broke a bench.</b> They needed to build a fire due to the potential danger to Rabba. Since they could not find firewood, they kindled the fire with the furniture.
<b>And Abaye said to Rabba:</b> In breaking the bench, <b>didn’t the Master violate</b> the prohibition, <b>“Do not destroy”</b> (Deuteronomy 20:19)? It is prohibited to destroy objects of value. Rabba <b>said to him: Do not destroy</b> also with regard to destruction <b>of my body.</b> Preventing illness and danger <b>is preferable to me.</b>
With regard to the danger of bloodletting, the Gemara cites that which <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: One should always sell the beams of his house and purchase shoes for his feet</b> with the proceeds, as shoes protect him from stepping on obstacles and from catching cold. <b>If he let blood and has nothing to eat</b> after the bloodletting, <b>he should</b> even <b>sell the shoes on his feet, and from</b> the proceeds <b>provide the needs of a meal.</b> After bloodletting, a meal is more crucial to one’s well-being than shoes are.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are</b> these special <b>needs of a meal? Rav said:</b> It is referring to <b>meat. And Shmuel said:</b> It is referring to <b>wine.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>Rav says:</b> It is referring to <b>meat</b> because <b>the soul replaces the soul,</b> i.e., the meat replenishes the person’s strength. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> It is referring to <b>wine</b> because <b>the red replaces the red,</b> i.e., red wine substitutes for red blood.
<b>A mnemonic</b> for the names of the Sages cited in the following discussion is the word <b><i>shenimsar</i>;</b> <i>shin</i> for Shmuel, <i>nun</i> for Rabbi Yoḥanan, <i>mem</i> for Rav Naḥman, <i>samekh</i> for Rav Yosef, <i>reish</i> for Rava.
The Gemara relates the following about bloodletting and drinking wine. <b>Shmuel, on the day</b> on which he <b>would perform the practice</b> of bloodletting, <b>they</b> would <b>prepare for him</b> a dish of <b>cooked spleen. Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> would <b>drink</b> wine after bloodletting <b>until the odor emerged from his ears. And Rav Naḥman</b> would <b>drink until his spleen floated</b> in wine. <b>Rav Yosef</b> would <b>drink until</b> the wine <b>would emerge from the bloodletting incision. Rava would search</b> for <b>wine</b> that was sufficiently aged such <b>that three leaves</b> had already grown over three years on the vine from which the grapes were picked (Rashash).
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzhak said to the Sages: I beg of you, on the day</b> that you undergo <b>bloodletting, tell your households,</b> your wives: <b>Naḥman</b> bar Yitzhak <b>happened</b> to come <b>to</b> visit <b>us.</b> Due to the visit of the important guest, the women will prepare a large meal. The husbands will eat well, recover from the lost blood, and avoid endangering themselves.
<b>And</b> Rav Naḥman bar Yitzhak said: <b>All types of artifice</b> that come at the expense of others <b>are prohibited except for this artifice, which is permitted. One who performed the practice</b> of bloodletting <b>and it is not possible for him</b> to purchase food due to lack of means, <b>let him take a worn <i>zuz</i></b> coin <b>and go to seven stores.</b> In each store, he tastes the wine as one who seeks to buy wine would. After tasting, he hands the <i>zuz</i> to the storekeeper, who will not accept it because it is worn. He then proceeds to do the same in all the stores <b>until he has tasted the measure of a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> of wine. <b>And if</b> doing so <b>is not</b> possible, <b>let him eat seven black dates and smear oil on his temple and lie in the sun.</b>
The Gemara relates: The gentile scholar, <b>Ablat, found Shmuel lying in the sun.</b> Ablat <b>said to</b> Shmuel: <b>Wise man of the Jews,</b> a matter that is <b>evil, can it become good?</b> Are there any circumstances in which the heat of the sun, which is harmful, can be beneficial? Shmuel <b>said to him: It</b> happens on <b>a day of bloodletting,</b> for which the heat of the sun is beneficial.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> actually, <b>that is not</b> what occurred. <b>Rather, there is a day on which the sun is beneficial</b> more than <b>the entire year,</b> and that is <b>the day on which the Tammuz solstice,</b> the longest day of the year, occurs. <b>And Shmuel thought: I will not reveal</b> this remedy <b>to him.</b>
<b>Indifferent, in wind, taste, waited</b> are a <b>mnemonic</b> for the following matters. It was <b>Rav and Shmuel who both said: Anyone who is indifferent</b> and not vigilant with regard to <b>the meal</b> eaten after <b>bloodletting, they are indifferent</b> with regard to providing <b>his food from the Heavens. And they say</b> in the name of Heaven: <b>He took no pity on his life, will I take pity on him?</b>
Similarly, it was <b>Rav and Shmuel who both said: One who performs the practice</b> of bloodletting <b>should not sit where the wind is blowing,</b> due to the concern that <b>perhaps the blood letter let</b> too much blood from <b>him and established</b> the amount of remaining blood <b>at a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i>. <b>And</b> there is concern <b>the wind will come and draw out</b> a little more blood <b>from him, and he will be endangered.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Shmuel would customarily perform the practice</b> of bloodletting <b>in a house</b> whose walls were <b>seven and a half bricks thick. One day he performed</b> bloodletting <b>and felt himself</b> weakened. <b>He examined</b> and discovered that <b>one half-brick was lacking</b> from the thickness of the walls. The resultant chill caused his weakness.
It was <b>Rav and Shmuel who both said: One who performs the practice of bloodletting should taste something and then go outside, since if he does not taste anything, if he encounters a corpse, his face will turn green. If he encounters one who killed a person, he will die. If he encounters</b>

Daf 129b

<b>something else,</b> a euphemism for a pig, <b>it is harmful with regard to something else,</b> a euphemism for leprosy.
It was <b>Rav and Shmuel who both said:</b> With regard to <b>one who performs the practice</b> of bloodletting, <b>let him wait a bit and then let him rise, as the Master said:</b> There are <b>five matters</b> that render one <b>closer to death than life, and they are these:</b> If <b>one ate and</b> immediately <b>rose,</b> if <b>one drank and rose,</b> if <b>one slept and</b> immediately <b>rose,</b> if <b>one let blood and rose,</b> if <b>one engaged in</b> conjugal <b>relations and rose.</b>
<b>Shmuel said: The interval for bloodletting</b> is <b>every thirty days. And during the</b> middle <b>periods</b> of one’s life, <b>he should decrease</b> the frequency of bloodletting; <b>and during the</b> later <b>periods, he should decrease</b> its frequency <b>again.</b>
<b>And Shmuel said: The times for bloodletting</b> are <b>the first</b> day <b>of the week, the fourth</b> day of the week <b>and Shabbat eve. However,</b> on the <b>second and the fifth</b> days of the week, <b>no,</b> one should not let blood, <b>as the Master said:</b> Only <b>one who has the merit of</b> his <b>ancestors</b> and relies on it <b>should let blood on</b> the <b>second and on the fifth</b> days of the week, <b>as the court on High,</b> in the heavens, <b>and the court below are equal.</b> The courts in the cities convene on Mondays and Thursdays, as does the heavenly court. Letting blood on a day of judgment is dangerous. If one is judged unfavorably all his blood could flow out.
The Gemara explains: <b>On the third day of the week, what is the reason</b> that one does <b>not</b> let blood? It is <b>because</b> the planet <b>Mars is dominant during the even</b> hours. Since it is a planet of blood, and the even hours are a bad omen, that combination gives cause for concern. The Gemara asks: On <b>Shabbat eve,</b> Mars <b>also dominates during the even</b> hours. The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the <b>multitudes have</b> already become <b>accustomed to</b> letting blood on Shabbat eve, the verse: <b>“The Lord protects the simple-hearted”</b> (Psalms 116:6) applies in this case.
Similarly, <b>Shmuel says:</b> On <b>the fourth</b> day of the week that <b>is the fourth day</b> of the month; on <b>the fourth</b> day of the week that <b>is the fourteenth</b> of the month; on <b>the fourth</b> day of the week that <b>is the twenty-fourth</b> of the month; and on <b>the fourth</b> day of the week after which <b>there are not four</b> days remaining in the month <b>it is dangerous</b> to let blood.
Bloodletting on <b>the New Moon and</b> on the <b>second</b> day of the month causes <b>weakness;</b> bloodletting on the <b>third</b> day of the month leads to <b>danger.</b> Bloodletting on <b>the eve of a Festival</b> causes <b>weakness;</b> bloodletting on <b>the eve of the festival of <i>Shavuot</i></b> leads to <b>danger. And the Sages issued a decree</b> prohibiting bloodletting <b>on the eve of every Festival due to the festival</b> of <b><i>Shavuot</i>. On</b> <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>an evil spirit named <i>Tibbuaḥ</i>,</b> from the Hebrew word meaning slaughter, <b>emerges, as had the Jewish people not accepted the Torah</b> on the festival of <i>Shavuot</i>, <i>Tibbuaḥ</i> <b>would have slaughtered their flesh and their blood.</b> Consequently, it remains a dangerous day.
<b>Shmuel said:</b> If <b>one ate wheat and</b> afterward <b>let blood, he only let that wheat.</b> The bloodletting was ineffective as the wheat replaced any blood that was let. <b>And this</b> ineffectiveness <b>applies</b> only if he let blood <b>to cure</b> an illness; <b>however, to relieve</b> discomfort, bloodletting after eating wheat <b>relieves</b> one’s discomfort.
<b>One who lets blood</b> should engage in <b>drinking immediately;</b> he should not engage in <b>eating until</b> the time that it takes to walk <b>half a <i>mil</i></b> has elapsed.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: When they said that one should engage in <b>drinking immediately,</b> does that mean that drinking immediately is <b>beneficial; however, thereafter, it is injurious? Or perhaps,</b> thereafter <b>it is neither injurious nor beneficial.</b> No resolution is found for this dilemma, therefore <b>it stands</b> unresolved.
Similarly, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: When they said one should not engage in <b>eating until</b> the time that it takes to walk <b>half a <i>mil</i></b> has elapsed, does that mean <b>that</b> only at that time <b>it is beneficial,</b> however, <b>after that</b> time <b>or before that</b> time <b>it is injurious? Or perhaps,</b> before and after that time <b>it is neither injurious nor beneficial.</b> No resolution is found for this dilemma, therefore <b>it</b> too <b>stands</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav</b> would <b>announce: One hundred bloodlettings for a <i>zuz</i>;</b> cutting the hair on <b>one hundred heads for a <i>zuz</i>;</b> grooming <b>one hundred moustaches</b> does <b>not</b> cost <b>anything</b> (<i>ge’onim</i>). Blood letters typically served as barbers as well and did not charge for grooming a moustache. If one hundred men happened to arrive one day to have their moustaches groomed, the barber would work all day without receiving any pay. <b>Rav Yosef said: When we were</b> students <b>in Rav Huna’s school,</b> on <b>a day when the Sages were sluggish</b> in their studies, <b>they would say: Today is the day of the moustaches, and I did not know what they were saying.</b> Now that I heard Rav’s statement, I understand that they meant that it was a day without purpose.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And one may tie the umbilical cord</b> of a child born on Shabbat. <b>The Sages taught</b> similarly in the <i>Tosefta</i> and even added to it: <b>One may tie the umbilical cord</b> of a child born on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Yosei said: One may even cut</b> the umbilical cord. <b>And one may insulate the placenta</b> as a healing remedy <b>so as to warm the newborn. Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: Princesses insulate</b> the placenta <b>in mugs of oil; the daughters of the wealthy</b> do so <b>in combed wool; the daughters of the poor in</b> soft <b>rags.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said</b> that <b>Rav said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> that it is even permitted to cut the umbilical cord on Shabbat.
<b>And Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said</b> that <b>Rav said: The Rabbis concede to Rabbi Yosei with regard to the umbilical cord</b> attached to <b>twin babies that one may cut</b> it on Shabbat. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? In that case, leaving the cord attached is dangerous. <b>Since</b> the attached twins will try to <b>disengage from each other,</b> they could potentially rip each other’s cords.
<b>And Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said</b> that <b>Rav said: Everything stated in the passage of rebuke</b> (Ezekiel 16) <b>one may perform for a woman in childbirth on Shabbat.</b> Since that chapter speaks of the dangerous birth of an abandoned child, for all other children, these issues should be addressed. <b>As it is stated</b> there: <b>“And as for your birth, on the day you were born, your navel was not cut, and you were not washed in water for cleansing, and you were not salted, nor were you swaddled”</b> (Ezekiel 16:4).
The Gemara explains: <b>“And as for your birth, on the day you were born”; from here</b> it is derived <b>that one delivers the newborn on Shabbat. “Your navel was not cut”; from here</b> it is derived <b>that one cuts the umbilical cord on Shabbat. “And you were not washed in water for cleansing”; from here</b> it is derived <b>that one washes the newborn on Shabbat. “And you were not salted”; from here</b> it is derived <b>that one salts the newborn on Shabbat. “Nor were you swaddled”; from here</b> it is derived <b>that one swaddles the newborn on Shabbat.</b>

Daf 130a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> As a continuation to the discussion at the end of the previous chapter, which mentioned circumcision in the context of a discussion of the <i>halakhot</i> of childbirth on Shabbat, the mishna continues to address the <i>halakhot</i> of circumcision. <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: If he did not bring an implement</b> for circumcising the child <b>on Shabbat eve, he brings it on Shabbat</b> itself <b>uncovered</b> so that it will be clear to all that he is bringing a circumcision scalpel. <b>And in</b> times of <b>danger,</b> when decrees of persecution prohibit Jews from circumcising their children, <b>one covers it in the presence of witnesses</b> who can testify that he transported the scalpel to perform a mitzva.
<b>And furthermore, Rabbi Eliezer said</b> with regard to this issue: <b>One</b> may even <b>cut down trees to prepare charcoal</b> in order <b>to fashion iron tools</b> for the purpose of circumcision.
Rabbi Eliezer’s approach was not universally accepted, and <b>a principle was stated by Rabbi Akiva: Any prohibited labor that can be performed on Shabbat eve does not override Shabbat,</b> including transporting the circumcision scalpel. However, any prohibited labor involved in the mitzva of <b>circumcision</b> itself <b>that cannot be performed on Shabbat eve overrides Shabbat.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Is <b>the reason for Rabbi Eliezer’s</b> opinion that the scalpel must be uncovered <b>due to affection for the mitzva</b> and the desire to publicize it, <b>or perhaps</b> it is <b>due to</b> avoiding <b>suspicion?</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> practical <b>difference is there</b> between the two reasons suggested for Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion? The Gemara answers: The difference is with regard to the question of whether or not it is permitted <b>to bring</b> the scalpel <b>covered in the presence of witnesses</b> who are aware that one is bringing the scalpel for the purpose of circumcision. <b>If you say</b> the reason is <b>due to affection for the mitzva,</b> then if it is <b>uncovered, yes,</b> there is a display of affection for the mitzva. If it is <b>covered, no,</b> there is no display of affection. <b>However, if you say</b> the reason for this ruling is <b>due to</b> avoiding <b>suspicion, even</b> if it is <b>covered</b> he may <b>well</b> do so, because the witnesses are aware that a circumcision will be performed. <b>What</b> is the resolution of this dilemma?
<b>It was stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Levi said: Rabbi Eliezer only stated</b> this ruling <b>to</b> express <b>affection for the mitzva. That</b> opinion <b>was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If a child is to be circumcised on Shabbat and they failed to bring the scalpel on Shabbat eve, <b>one brings it</b> on Shabbat <b>uncovered,</b> but <b>he does not bring it covered;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. Rav Ashi said:</b> The language of <b>the mishna is also precise</b> in support of this opinion, <b>as it teaches: And in a time of danger he covers it in the presence of witnesses.</b> By inference, <b>in</b> a time of <b>danger, yes,</b> he covers it; when it is <b>not</b> a time of <b>danger, no,</b> he does not cover it. <b>Conclude from this</b> that the scalpel is uncovered <b>due to affection for the mitzva.</b> The Gemara states: Indeed, <b>conclude from this.</b>
<b>It was taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>He brings</b> the scalpel <b>uncovered, and he does not bring it covered;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer. Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: In a time of danger they would customarily bring</b> the scalpel <b>covered in the presence of witnesses.</b>
With regard to these witnesses, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>The</b> necessary <b>witnesses that he is saying,</b> do they include <b>he</b> who is bringing the scalpel <b>and one</b> other witness? <b>Or perhaps</b> they include <b>he</b> who brought the scalpel <b>and two</b> other witnesses to testify on his behalf.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma from the language of the mishna, which stated: <b>And in</b> times of <b>danger he covers it in the presence of witnesses. Granted, if you say</b> it is referring to <b>him and two</b> other witnesses, <b>it</b> works out <b>well;</b> the wording is appropriate. <b>However, if you say</b> it is referring to <b>him and one</b> other witness, <b>what</b> is to be made of the use of the term <b>witnesses</b> in the plural when there is only one other witness? The Gemara refutes this proof: They may still be called witnesses, in the plural, because <b>they,</b> i.e., he and the other witness, <b>are fit to testify elsewhere.</b>
We learned in our mishna: <b>And furthermore, Rabbi Eliezer said:</b> One may even cut down trees to prepare charcoal for the purpose of circumcision on Shabbat. With regard to this issue, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In the locale of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> where they would follow his ruling, <b>they would</b> even <b>cut down trees</b> on Shabbat <b>to prepare charcoal</b> from it in order <b>to fashion iron</b> tools with which to circumcise a child <b>on Shabbat.</b> On a related note, the <i>baraita</i> relates: <b>In the locale of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili they would eat poultry meat in milk,</b> as Rabbi Yosei HaGelili held that the prohibition of meat in milk does not include poultry.
The Gemara relates: <b>Levi happened</b> to come <b>to the house of Yosef the hunter. They served him the head of a peacock [<i>tavsa</i>] in milk</b> and <b>he did not eat. When</b> Levi <b>came before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, the latter <b>said to him: Why did you not excommunicate</b> these people who eat poultry in milk, contrary to the decree of the Sages? Levi <b>said to him: It was</b> in <b>the locale</b> of <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira, and I said: Perhaps he taught them</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili,</b> who permits the eating of poultry meat in milk. Given the possibility that their rabbi rules that it is permitted, I cannot come and prohibit it, and I certainly cannot excommunicate them for it.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna, <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili says: It is stated</b> in the verse: <b>“You shall not eat anything that dies of itself;</b> to the stranger at your gates you may give it, that he may eat it; or you may sell it to a foreigner; for you are a holy people to the Lord your God” (Deuteronomy 14:21), <b>and it is stated</b> later in the same verse: <b>“You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk.”</b> From the juxtaposition of the two issues it is derived: <b>That which is prohibited due to</b> the prohibition against eating an <b>unslaughtered animal, it is prohibited to cook</b> it <b>in milk.</b> The prohibition against cooking a creature in milk is not limited to only a kid. If so, with regard to <b>poultry, which is prohibited due to</b> the prohibition against eating an <b>unslaughtered animal,</b> I <b>might</b> have thought <b>it should be prohibited to cook</b> it <b>in milk; therefore, the verse states: “In its mother’s milk.”</b> This <b>excludes poultry, which does not have mother’s milk</b> and is therefore not included in the prohibition.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: There was one city in Eretz Yisrael where they would act in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> with regard to circumcision, <b>and they would die at their appointed time</b> and not earlier, as a reward for their affection for this mitzva. <b>And not only that, but on one occasion the wicked empire,</b> Rome, <b>issued a decree against the Jewish people</b> prohibiting <b>circumcision; but against that city it did not</b> issue the <b>decree.</b>
Apropos affection for the mitzva of circumcision, the Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> in which <b>it was taught</b> that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Every mitzva that</b> the Jews initially <b>accepted upon themselves with joy, such as circumcision, as it is written: “I rejoice at Your word as one who finds great spoil”</b> (Psalms 119:162), and as the Sages explained, this “word” refers to the mitzva of circumcision, over which they rejoiced, <b>they still perform</b> it <b>with joy. And every mitzva that</b> the Jews initially <b>accepted upon themselves with contentiousness</b> and regret, <b>such as</b> the prohibition against <b>incestuous relations, as it is written: “And Moses heard the people weeping, family by family”</b> (Numbers 11:10), and as the Sages interpreted homiletically: They wept <b>over matters</b> pertaining to <b>their families,</b> as they were prohibited at that time from marrying family members, <b>they still perform with contentiousness.</b> The fact is <b>that there is no marriage contract</b> and wedding <b>in which contentiousness does not arise,</b> as there is inevitably some conflict between the parties. The <i>baraita</i> asserts that this is because, initially, the Jews did not accept the laws governing marriage and family relationships willingly.
<b>It was taught in</b> a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says</b> in praise of the observance of the mitzva of circumcision: <b>Any mitzva for which the Jews sacrificed their lives at the time of the decrees of the</b> wicked <b>empire, such as</b> the prohibition of <b>idolatry and</b> the mitzva of <b>circumcision, is still steadfastly observed. And any mitzva for which the Jews did not sacrifice their lives at the time of the decrees of the</b> wicked <b>empire, such as phylacteries, is still casually observed,</b> meaning that they are not as careful in its fulfillment as they should be.
The Gemara cites proof that the mitzva of phylacteries was not fulfilled properly at the time of the decrees, based upon an incident related to the following <i>halakha</i>. <b>As Rabbi Yannai said:</b> Donning <b>phylacteries requires a clean body like</b> that of <b>Elisha, Man of Wings. What is</b> included in the requirement to have a clean body? <b>Abaye said: That one may not pass wind in them. Rava said: That one may not sleep in them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And why did they call him Elisha, Man of Wings? Because on one occasion the wicked empire</b> of Rome <b>issued a decree against the Jewish people that,</b> as punishment, <b>they would pierce the brain of anyone who dons phylacteries on his head.</b> Nevertheless, <b>Elisha would don them and</b> defiantly <b>go out to the marketplace.</b> One day, <b>an official</b> who was appointed to enforce the decree <b>saw him.</b> Elisha <b>ran</b> away <b>from him, and</b> the official <b>ran after him. When</b> the official <b>reached him,</b> Elisha <b>removed</b> the phylacteries <b>from his head and held them in his hand.</b> The officer <b>asked him: What is in your hand?</b> Elisha <b>said to him:</b> It is merely <b>a dove’s wings.</b> A miracle took place: <b>He opened his hand, and,</b> indeed, it <b>was found</b> to be <b>a dove’s wings. Therefore,</b> in commemoration of this miracle, <b>they</b> would <b>call him</b> Elisha, <b>Man of Wings.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is different</b> about <b>a dove’s wings,</b> that Elisha specifically <b>told him</b> that he was holding the wings of a dove <b>and he did not tell him</b> he was holding the wings of <b>other birds?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Because the congregation of Israel is likened to a dove, as it is stated:</b> “You shall shine as <b>the wings of a dove covered with silver and her pinions with yellow gold”</b> (Psalms 68:14). <b>Just as a dove</b> has only <b>its wings to protect it, so too, the Jewish people have</b> only <b>mitzvot to protect them.</b> Apparently, Elisha Man of Wings was vigilant in fulfilling the mitzva of phylacteries in the face of the decree, whereas the rest of the people were not.
<b>Rabbi Abba bar Rav Adda said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said</b> as follows: <b>On one occasion</b> they were supposed to circumcise a baby on Shabbat, and <b>they forgot and did not bring a scalpel</b> with which to circumcise him <b>on Shabbat eve, and they brought it on Shabbat via roofs and via courtyards,</b>

Daf 130b

<b>contrary to the wishes of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> Even though the roofs and courtyards were not halakhically joined in a manner where it would be permitted to carry from one to the other, the Rabbis permitted carrying the scalpel in this manner.
<b>Rav Yosef strongly objects to this: Contrary to the wishes of Rabbi Eliezer? On the contrary, it is Rabbi Eliezer who permits</b> this, as he permits carrying the scalpel even through the public domain. <b>And if you say</b> that it means <b>contrary to the wishes of Rabbi Eliezer, who permits</b> carrying <b>even in the public domain, but in accordance with the wishes of the Rabbis,</b> who <b>prohibited</b> carrying <b>via the public domain and</b> only <b>permitted</b> carrying <b>via roofs, via courtyards and enclosures,</b> that is also difficult. <b>And is it permitted</b> according to the opinion of the Rabbis? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Just as one may not bring</b> the circumcision knife <b>via the public domain, so too, one may not bring it via roofs, via enclosures, or via courtyards?</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said:</b> It means <b>contrary to the wishes of Rabbi Eliezer and his disputants, but in accordance with the wishes of Rabbi Shimon. As we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Roofs, enclosures, and courtyards are all</b> considered as <b>one domain with regard to vessels that rested inside them</b> at the beginning of Shabbat. Therefore, it is permitted to carry vessels that rested inside one to another. However, they are <b>not</b> considered the same domain <b>with regard to vessels that rested inside the house</b> at the beginning of Shabbat. If the homeowners did not join the courtyard by means of an <i>eiruv</i>, it is prohibited to carry vessels from their houses to the courtyard. Even if the houses in a courtyard were joined, it is prohibited to carry from the courtyard to an enclosure unless they were joined by means of an <i>eiruv</i>. In any case, there are circumstances in which Rabbi Shimon allows carrying via roofs, courtyards, and enclosures.
<b>Rabbi Zeira raised a dilemma before Rabbi Asi: An alleyway</b> whose residents <b>did not merge</b> together, <b>what is</b> its legal status with regard <b>to carrying</b> items <b>in all of it</b> according to Rabbi Shimon? Rabbi Zeira explains the dilemma: <b>Do we say</b> that <b>it is like a courtyard,</b> and <b>just as</b> with regard to <b>a courtyard, even though they did not join</b> the houses in it together and despite the fact that it is prohibited to carry out items from the houses to the courtyard, <b>it is</b> nonetheless <b>permitted to carry in all of it?</b> Therefore, in <b>this</b> alleyway <b>too, even though they did not merge</b> together, <b>it is permitted to carry in all of it</b> despite the fact that it is prohibited to carry items into the alleyway. <b>Or, perhaps</b> an alleyway is <b>not similar</b> in this regard <b>to a courtyard,</b> as a <b>courtyard has four partitions,</b> whereas <b>this,</b> the alleyway, <b>does not have four partitions,</b> but only three. <b>Alternatively,</b> there may be a different reason for the inferior status of an alleyway in this regard: <b>A courtyard has residents</b> and can therefore be considered like a house, which would allow carrying within it, whereas <b>this</b> alleyway <b>does not have residents.</b> Rabbi Asi <b>was silent and did not say anything to him,</b> as he was unable to provide a satisfactory response.
<b>On another occasion</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>found</b> Rabbi Asi <b>sitting and saying: Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish said in the name of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: One time they forgot and did not bring a scalpel on Shabbat eve</b> for the purpose of circumcising a child on Shabbat, <b>and they brought it on Shabbat, and the matter was difficult</b> in the eyes of <b>the Rabbis: How can they abandon the words of the Rabbis,</b> who prohibit doing so, <b>and act in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer?</b> Why did they find this difficult? <b>One</b> reason was <b>that Rabbi Eliezer was a <i>Shammuti</i>,</b> i.e., a follower of the views of Beit Shammai (Jerusalem Talmud), and the <i>halakha</i> is generally in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel in their disputes with Beit Shammai. <b>And furthermore,</b> there is a general rule that in a dispute between <b>an individual and</b> the <b>many,</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the many.</b> Here too, the <i>halakha</i> should certainly be in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis, who disagree with Rabbi Eliezer.
<b>And Rabbi Oshaya said: I asked Rabbi Yehuda the Cutter,</b> i.e., the circumcisor, <b>and he told me</b> that this incident occurred in <b>an alleyway</b> whose residents <b>did not merge</b> together, <b>and they brought</b> the scalpel <b>from this end</b> of the alleyway <b>to that end,</b> where the baby was. That concludes Rabbi Asi’s account of the event. Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> Rabbi Asi: Since you related that story without expressing any reservations, it appears that <b>the Master</b> must <b>hold</b> that with regard to <b>an alleyway</b> whose residents <b>did not merge</b> together, <b>it is permitted to carry in all of it. And</b> Rabbi Asi <b>said to him: Yes,</b> that is the <i>halakha</i>. Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: But on a</b> different <b>occasion I raised a dilemma</b> on this matter <b>before you and you did not say so to me. Perhaps in the course</b> of your studies <b>your knowledge was restored to you? He said to him: Yes, in the course</b> of my studies <b>my knowledge was restored to me,</b> and I remembered this <i>halakha</i>.
With regard to the very same <i>halakha</i>, <b>it was stated</b> as a principle that <b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that <b>Rav said: An alleyway that was not merged</b> by the residents of the courtyards that open into it, <b>it is only permitted to carry in it</b> within <b>four cubits.</b>
<b>Abaye said: This</b> halakhic <b>matter was stated by Rabbi Zeira, and he did not explain it.</b> It remained enigmatic <b>until Rabba bar Avuh came and explained it. As Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> With regard to <b>an alleyway that was not merged</b> by the residents of the courtyards that open into it, if they <b>joined the courtyards with the houses,</b> i.e., the homeowners within each courtyard joined together and are therefore permitted to carry within the courtyards themselves, <b>it is only permitted to carry in it within four cubits,</b> as in an intermediate domain [<i>karmelit</i>]. However, if they <b>did not join the courtyards with the houses</b> and it is prohibited to carry within the courtyards, <b>it is permitted to carry in the entire</b> alleyway.
<b>Rav Ḥanina Ḥoza’a said to Rabba: What is different</b> about a case <b>where</b> they <b>joined the courtyards with the houses?</b> Is it <b>because</b> the <b>courtyards were detached and became</b> like <b>houses? And Rav follows his</b> regular line of <b>reasoning,</b> for <b>Rav said: An alleyway can only be made</b> into <b>a permitted</b> area for carrying <b>by means of a sidepole and a crossbeam,</b> which is the standard <i>halakha</i> in a closed alleyway, <b>if there are</b>

Daf 131a

<b>houses and courtyards open to it,</b> and each courtyard contains at least two houses, and there are at least two courtyards. <b>And here, there are houses</b> but <b>there are no courtyards,</b> and therefore the standard <i>halakhot</i> of a closed alleyway do not apply. However, if that is the case, <b>when they did not join</b> the courtyards with the houses <b>too, let us consider these houses as though they were sealed,</b> because their residents may not carry from their houses into the courtyards, and the houses should be considered irrelevant. Therefore, in that case too, <b>there are courtyards</b> but <b>there are no houses.</b>
The Gemara answers: In that case <b>it is possible for them to renounce all of their property rights</b> and transfer them <b>to one</b> person. Just as the residents of a courtyard can join together, thereby rendering it permitted to carry in the courtyard, they can also relinquish their property rights to a single resident. In that way, it is considered as though there is only one inhabited house in the courtyard, and it is therefore permitted to carry within the courtyard as well as between that particular house and the courtyard. The Gemara rejects this answer: <b>Ultimately,</b> even in that case, <b>there is</b> one <b>house,</b> yet <b>there are not</b> multiple <b>houses,</b> as it is possible to relinquish one’s privileges to only one homeowner and not to two. This would fail to meet the minimum requirement of two houses for the area to be considered a courtyard.
The Gemara answers: <b>It is possible</b> to resolve this: <b>From morning until midday</b> they can relinquish their rights <b>to one,</b> and <b>from midday until evening</b> they can relinquish their rights <b>to another,</b> and as a result there will be two houses. The Gemara rejects this answer: <b>Ultimately, at the time when this</b> house <b>has</b> the ownership rights, <b>that</b> house <b>does not have</b> them, as at any point in time there is only one house from which it is permitted to carry into the courtyard. <b>Rather, Rav Ashi said:</b> The explanation that there are no houses and courtyards here is rejected, and the explanation is: <b>What caused the courtyards to be prohibited?</b> It is the presence of the <b>houses.</b> Had there been no houses, it would have been permitted to carry from the courtyards into the alleyway, since they are one domain according to Rabbi Shimon. <b>And</b> here, it is considered as though <b>there are no</b> houses. Therefore, it is permitted to carry in the alleyway.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Rabbi Eliezer did not say</b> with regard <b>to all</b> mitzvot that <b>actions that facilitate</b> performance of <b>a mitzva override Shabbat.</b> This is not a fixed principle with regard to preparations for all mitzvot. Rather, each case must be considered on its own merits, and proof must be cited that this principle applies to a specific mitzva. <b>As the two loaves</b> offered on the festival of <i>Shavuot</i> <b>are an obligation of</b> that <b>day, and Rabbi Eliezer only learned</b> that the activities that facilitate <b>their</b> sacrifice override Shabbat <b>from a</b> special <b>verbal analogy. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that the actions that facilitate</b> the offering of <b>the two loaves override Shabbat?</b> The term <b>bringing is stated</b> in the verse <b>with regard to the <i>omer</i></b> offering, <b>and</b> the term <b>bringing is stated with regard to the two loaves. Just as</b> in the case of <b>the bringing stated with regard to the <i>omer</i>,</b> all the <b>actions that facilitate</b> its offering <b>override Shabbat,</b> as the reaping of the <i>omer</i>, which facilitates its offering, overrides Shabbat, <b>so too,</b> in the case of <b>the bringing stated with regard to the two loaves, actions that facilitate</b> its offering <b>override Shabbat.</b>
With regard to this verbal analogy the Gemara comments: It must be that those terms are <b>free,</b> i.e., they are superfluous in their context and therefore available for the purpose of establishing a verbal analogy. <b>As, if they are not free,</b> the verbal analogy <b>can be</b> logically <b>refuted,</b> as it is possible to say: <b>What</b> is unique <b>to the <i>omer</i>? That if one found reaped</b> barley <b>one must</b> nevertheless <b>reap</b> more barley for the sake of the mitzva. Can <b>you say</b> the same with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>the two loaves,</b> where it is taught that <b>if one found reaped</b> grain <b>one need not reap</b> additional grain for the sacrifice? Apparently, the <i>halakhot</i> of the offering of the two loaves are not parallel to those of the <i>omer</i>. The same might be true with regard to actions that facilitate the performance of the mitzva. <b>In truth,</b> the verse <b>is free</b> for establishing the verbal analogy. The Gemara explains: <b>Since the verse</b> already <b>states:</b> “When you come to the land that I am giving to you, and you reap its harvest, <b>then you shall bring the sheaf [<i>omer</i>], the first of your harvest to the priest”</b> (Leviticus 23:10), when the verse restates, “And you shall count for yourselves from the morrow after the day of rest, <b>from the day you have brought</b> the sheaf of the waving, seven whole weeks they shall be” (Leviticus 23:15), <b>why do I</b> need this repetition? <b>Conclude from this</b> that the additional statement is there <b>to</b> render the term “bringing” <b>free</b> for establishing a verbal analogy.
<b>And</b> yet there is <b>still</b> a difficulty: The verbal analogy <b>is free</b> only <b>from one side,</b> as only the verse that mentions bringing in the context of the <i>omer</i> offering is superfluous in its context, <b>and we heard Rabbi Eliezer, who said</b> with regard to a verbal analogy that it is only <b>free from one side,</b> that <b>one</b> can <b>derive</b> from it, <b>and one</b> can also <b>refute</b> it logically. The Gemara answers: There is a superfluous usage of the term with regard to the two loaves as well, as in the verse: “From your dwelling places you shall bring the loaves of waving of two tenth parts of an ephah; they shall be of fine flour, they shall be baked with leaven for first-fruits unto the Lord” (Leviticus 23:17) the phrase: <b>“You shall bring” is an amplification.</b> Since it was mentioned in the previous verse it is superfluous in its context. Consequently, the verbal analogy is available from both sides.
The Gemara poses a question with regard to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement: Rabbi Eliezer did not say with regard to all mitzvot that actions that facilitate performance of a mitzva override Shabbat; <b>to exclude</b> actions that facilitate the performance of <b>what</b> mitzva was he referring?<br><b>If you say</b> that it was <b>to exclude</b> actions that facilitate the performance of the mitzva of taking the <b>palm branch [<i>lulav</i>]</b> and the other three species on the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The mitzva of <b><i>lulav</i> and all its facilitators override Shabbat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer?</b><br><b>Rather,</b> say that it comes <b>to exclude</b> the mitzva to dwell in a <b><i>sukka</i></b> on <i>Sukkot</i>. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The mitzva of <b><i>sukka</i> and all its facilitators override Shabbat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer?</b><br><b>Rather,</b> say that it comes <b>to exclude</b> the mitzva to eat <b><i>matza</i></b> on Passover. <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The mitzva of <b><i>matza</i> and all its facilitators override Shabbat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer?</b><br><b>Rather,</b> say that it comes <b>to exclude</b> the mitzva to sound the <b><i>shofar</i></b> on Rosh HaShana. <b>But wasn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The mitzva of <b><i>shofar</i> and all its facilitators override Shabbat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer?</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> The statement of Rabbi Yoḥanan comes <b>to exclude</b> attaching <b>ritual fringes to his garment and</b> affixing <b>a <i>mezuza</i> to the doorway,</b> which do not override Shabbat. The Gemara notes that <b>that was also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And they,</b> Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis, <b>agree that if one attached ritual fringes to his garment</b> on Shabbat, <b>and</b> similarly, if <b>one affixed a <i>mezuza</i> to his doorway</b> on Shabbat, <b>that he is liable.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that Rabbi Eliezer concedes that actions that facilitate the performance of these mitzvot do not override Shabbat? <b>Rav Yosef said: Because they have no fixed time</b> and these mitzvot need not be performed on Shabbat. <b>Abaye said to him: On the contrary, from</b> the fact <b>that they have no fixed time,</b>

Daf 131b

it can be said that <b>each and every moment is its</b> proper <b>time.</b> The obligation to fulfill the mitzva is perpetual and one may not neglect it. Why should it be prohibited for him to perform actions that facilitate the performance of the mitzva on Shabbat? <b>Rather, Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rav Yitzḥak said, and some say</b> that he said that <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said:</b> The actions that facilitate the performance of these mitzvot do not override Shabbat, <b>since one can render</b> the relevant objects <b>ownerless.</b> One is only required to perform these mitzvot if the objects, i.e., the garment and the house, belong to him. If he renders them ownerless, he is no longer obligated to perform these mitzvot.
It was taught that <b>the Master said</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The mitzva of <b><i>lulav</i> and all its facilitators override Shabbat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> The Gemara poses a question: <b>From where does Rabbi Eliezer</b> derive <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>If</b> you say he derives it <b>from</b> the mitzvot of the <b><i>omer</i> and the two loaves,</b> whose facilitators override Shabbat, this can be refuted by saying that the performance of facilitating actions is permitted on Shabbat in these cases <b>because they are for the necessities of</b> Temple service to God on <b>High,</b> as they are connected to the sacrificial service, which proceeds even on Shabbat. <b>Rather,</b> we can say that he derives it from the fact that <b>the verse states:</b> “And you shall take for yourselves <b>on the</b> first <b>day,</b> the fruit of goodly trees, branches of palm trees, boughs of thick-leaved trees, and willows of the river, and you shall rejoice before the Lord your God seven days” (Leviticus 23:40), from which he infers: <b>“On the</b> first <b>day,”</b> meaning that one is obligated to take it on the first day <b>even</b> if it occurs <b>on Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>And with regard to what <i>halakha</i></b> is this emphasis stated? In what way would the laws of Shabbat have prohibited fulfilling the mitzva of <i>lulav</i>? <b>If you say</b> that it comes <b>to</b> permit <b>moving</b> the <i>lulav</i> despite the prohibition against moving set-aside items, <b>is a verse required in order to permit moving</b> the <i>lulav</i>? The prohibition to move items that are set-aside is not a Torah prohibition. The Torah would not come to permit an action prohibited by the Sages. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that the verse is coming to permit violation of Shabbat prohibitions <b>for</b> the <b>facilitators of</b> the <i>lulav</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> who disagree with Rabbi Eliezer understand the verse’s emphasis that the mitzva must be performed on that day? The Gemara answers: According to the Rabbis, <b>that</b> expression in the verse <b>is necessary</b> to teach that this mitzva must be performed <b>by day and not by night.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where does Rabbi Eliezer</b> derive that this mitzva must be performed <b>by day and not by night?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He derives</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the phrase: <b>“And you shall rejoice before the Lord your God seven days,”</b> as this indicates that the mitzva applies during <b>the days and not the nights.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> respond to this? The Gemara answers: The previous derivation <b>was necessary</b> because <b>it might have entered your mind to say</b> that <b>we should derive</b> the <b>seven days</b> stated here <b>from</b> the seven days stated with regard to <b><i>sukka</i>,</b> and say: <b>Just as there,</b> the mitzva of <i>sukka</i> applies not only during <b>the days</b> but <b>even the nights, so too here,</b> the mitzva of <i>lulav</i> applies not only during <b>the days</b> but <b>even the nights.</b> Therefore, the derivation <b>teaches us</b> that the mitzva only applies during the day based upon the original expression: “On the first day.”
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to Rabbi Eliezer’s approach, <b>let the Torah write</b> this principle only <b>with regard to <i>lulav</i>, and let these,</b> the mitzva of the <i>omer</i> and similar cases, <b>be derived from it.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Because</b> the analogy <b>can be refuted. What</b> is unique <b>about <i>lulav</i>? That it requires four species,</b> as the Torah demands that three other species be taken along with the <i>lulav</i>. Therefore, <i>lulav</i> cannot serve as a paradigm for other mitzvot that do not share this characteristic.
Earlier, it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The mitzva of <b><i>sukka</i> and all its facilitators override Shabbat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Rabbi Eliezer</b> derive <b>this</b> matter? <b>If</b> you say he derives it <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b><i>omer</i> and the two loaves,</b> this can be refuted by saying that the performance of facilitators is permitted on Shabbat in these cases <b>as</b> these are <b>the necessities of</b> Temple service to God on <b>High. If</b> you say he derives it <b>from the</b> <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b><i>lulav</i>,</b> this too can be refuted, <b>as</b> <i>lulav</i> <b>requires four species</b> and therefore has special significance.
<b>Rather,</b> he <b>derived</b> it through the following verbal analogy based upon the expression <b>“seven days,”</b> which is stated with regard to both the mitzva of <i>sukka</i> and the mitzva of <b><i>lulav</i>. Just as below,</b> with regard to the mitzva of <i>lulav</i>, <b>its facilitators override Shabbat, so too here,</b> with regard to the mitzva of <i>sukka</i>, <b>its facilitators override Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And let the Torah write only</b> that actions that facilitate the performance of the mitzva override the <i>halakhot</i> of Shabbat, <b>and let us bring these</b> other mitzvot <b>and derive</b> their <i>halakhot</i> <b>from</b> <i>sukka</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>Because</b> this suggestion <b>can be refuted: What</b> is unique about the mitzva of <b><i>sukka</i>? That it applies during the nights</b> just <b>as</b> it applies <b>during the days,</b> whereas the others apply only during the day.
Earlier it was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The mitzva of <b><i>matza</i> and all its facilitators override Shabbat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Rabbi Eliezer</b> derive <b>this</b> matter? <b>If</b> you say he derives it <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b><i>omer</i> and the two loaves,</b> this can be refuted, <b>as</b> these are <b>the necessities of</b> Temple service to God on <b>High. If</b> you say he derives it <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b><i>lulav</i>,</b> this too can be refuted, <b>as it requires four species. If</b> you say he derives it <b>from</b> the precedent of <b><i>sukka</i>,</b> this too can be refuted, <b>as it applies during the nights</b> just <b>as</b> it applies <b>during the days.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>derived</b> it by means of a verbal analogy based upon the word <b>fifteenth</b> stated with regard to the mitzva of <i>matza</i>, and the word <b>fifteenth</b> stated with regard to <b>the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>: Just as below,</b> with regard to the mitzva to dwell in a <i>sukka</i> on the festival of <i>Sukkot</i>, which is on the fifteenth of the month, <b>its facilitators override Shabbat, so too here,</b> with regard to the mitzva to eat <i>matza</i> on the fifteenth of the month, <b>its facilitators override Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And let the Torah write</b> this principle <b>with regard to <i>matza</i>, and let us bring these</b> other mitzvot <b>and derive</b> their <i>halakhot</i> <b>from</b> <i>matza</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>Because</b> this suggestion <b>can be refuted: What</b> is unique about the mitzva of <b><i>matza</i>? That it applies to women as it does to men.</b> It is therefore different from the other mitzvot under discussion, which only apply to men.
It was also taught in the <i>baraita</i>: The mitzva of <b><i>shofar</i> and all its facilitators override Shabbat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Rabbi Eliezer</b> derive <b>this</b> matter? <b>If</b> you say he derives it <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b><i>omer</i> and the two loaves,</b> this can be refuted, <b>as</b> these are <b>the necessities of</b> Temple service to God on <b>High. If</b> you say he derives it <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b><i>lulav</i>,</b> this too can be refuted, <b>as it requires four species. If</b> you say he derives it <b>from</b> the precedent of <b><i>sukka</i>,</b> this too can be refuted, <b>as it applies during the nights</b> just <b>as</b> it applies <b>during the days. If</b> you say he derives it <b>from <i>matza</i>,</b> this too can be refuted, <b>as it applies to women</b> just <b>as</b> it applies <b>to men. Rather,</b> Rabbi Eliezer derives it from the fact that <b>the verse stated:</b> “And in the seventh month, on the first of the month, a holy calling it shall be to you; any prohibited labor of work you shall not perform; <b>a day of sounding the <i>shofar</i> it shall be for you”</b> (Numbers 29:1). The verse’s emphasis that the <i>shofar</i> must be sounded <b>on that day</b> teaches us that it applies <b>even on Shabbat.</b>
<b>And for what</b> purpose was this emphasized? <b>If you say</b> it is in order <b>to</b> permit <b>sounding</b> the <i>shofar</i>, this <b>has</b> already <b>been taught</b> by one of the Sages <b>of the school of Shmuel</b> with regard to the verse that prohibits performing prohibited labor on Festivals: <b>“Any prohibited labor of work you shall not perform”</b> (Numbers 29:1), which comes <b>to exclude</b> from the category of prohibited labors <b>the sounding of the <i>shofar</i> and the removal of bread</b> from the oven, <b>which are skills and not labors. Rather,</b> it is necessary <b>to</b> teach with regard to <b>actions that facilitate</b> the performance of the mitzva.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis</b> understand the verse’s emphasis that the mitzva must be performed on that day? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> expression in the verse <b>is necessary</b> according to the Rabbis in order to teach that this mitzva must be performed <b>by day and not by night.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And from where does Rabbi Eliezer</b> derive that this mitzva must be performed <b>by day and not by night?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He derives</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the verse with regard to the laws of the Jubilee Year: “And you shall pass a <i>shofar</i> of sounding in the seventh month, on the tenth of the month, <b>on the Day of Atonement you shall pass a <i>shofar</i> throughout your land”</b> (Leviticus 25:9), <b>and</b> the laws of all instances of sounding the <i>shofar</i> during the seventh month <b>are derived from each other.</b> Therefore, just as on Yom Kippur the <i>shofar</i> is sounded during the day, as emphasized by the fact that the verse uses the phrase Day of Atonement, the same applies on Rosh HaShana.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to Rabbi Eliezer’s approach, <b>let the Torah write</b> this principle only <b>with regard to <i>shofar</i>, and let us bring these</b> other mitzvot <b>and derive</b> their <i>halakhot</i> <b>from</b> <i>shofar</i>. The Gemara answers: <b>From the sounding of the <i>shofar</i> of Rosh HaShana,</b> the principle that actions that facilitate the performance of a mitzva override Shabbat <b>cannot be derived,</b> because it has special significance in that <b>it introduces the remembrances of the Jewish people before their Father in heaven. From the sounding of the <i>shofar</i> of Yom Kippur,</b> the principle that actions that facilitate the performance of a mitzva override Shabbat <b>cannot be derived,</b> as this <i>shofar</i> sounding also has special significance, as <b>the Master said: Once the court sounds the <i>shofar</i></b> on Yom Kippur in the Jubilee Year, the declaration of freedom applies at once. <b>Slaves</b> may <b>take leave</b> of their masters and go <b>to their homes, and fields</b> that had been sold <b>return to their</b> ancestral <b>owners.</b> Therefore, other mitzvot cannot be derived from the sounding of the <i>shofar</i> of Yom Kippur.
Earlier it was taught that <b>the Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: The mitzva of <b>circumcision and all its facilitators override Shabbat;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where does Rabbi Eliezer</b> derive <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>If he derives it from all of</b> the other mitzvot cited above, we can refute it, <b>as we have</b> already <b>said</b> that each one of them includes a unique aspect of severity or significance. <b>And furthermore,</b> there is another difficulty: <b>What</b> is unique about <b>these</b> mitzvot

Daf 132a

in each, <b>as if its time passed, it is void,</b> unlike the mitzva of circumcision, which can be fulfilled at a later date if the child is not circumcised on the eighth day. <b>Rather, this is the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer, as the verse says: “And on the eighth day the flesh of his foreskin shall be circumcised”</b> (Leviticus 12:3), indicating that he is circumcised on the eighth day <b>even</b> if it falls <b>on Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And let the Torah write</b> this principle only <b>with regard to</b> the mitzva of <b>circumcision, and let these</b> other mitzvot <b>come and derive</b> their <i>halakhot</i> <b>from it.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Because</b> this suggestion <b>can be refuted: What</b> is unique about the mitzva of <b>circumcision? That thirteen covenants were established over it,</b> as the word covenant is mentioned thirteen times in the passage dealing with the circumcision of Abraham (Genesis 17). Owing to its great significance, other mitzvot cannot be derived from it.
The Gemara departs from the facilitators of circumcision to the <i>halakha</i> of circumcision itself and asks: <b>The Rabbis only disagree with</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>with regard to actions that facilitate circumcision,</b> which, in their view, do not override Shabbat; <b>however,</b> with regard to <b>circumcision itself, everyone agrees</b> that it <b>overrides Shabbat. From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? <b>Ulla said:</b> This is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, but there is no biblical basis for it. <b>And so too, Rabbi Yitzḥak said:</b> It is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from that which was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that saving a life overrides Shabbat? Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says</b> it is derived from the mitzva of circumcision: <b>Just as circumcision, which</b> pertains to only <b>one of a person’s limbs, overrides Shabbat,</b> all the more so it is an <b><i>a fortiori</i> inference</b> that <b>saving a life,</b> which is a mitzva that pertains to the entire person, <b>overrides Shabbat.</b>
<b>And if it should enter your mind</b> to say that circumcision may be performed on Shabbat based on a <b><i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>is an <i>a fortiori</i> inference derived from a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai? <b>Wasn’t it taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i> that an <i>a fortiori</i> inference cannot be derived from a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai? Rabbi Akiva sought to derive that a nazirite who comes into contact with a quarter <i>log</i> of blood from a corpse becomes ritually impure and is required to shave his hair. He sought to do this based on an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from the <i>halakha</i> of the bone from a dead person the size of a grain of barley, as he had a received tradition that a nazirite is required to shave his hair due to that contact. <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya said to him: Akiva,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a bone the size of a</b> grain of <b>barley transmits ritual impurity is a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, <b>and</b> you would derive from it that <b>a quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>of blood</b> transmits ritual impurity based upon <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference, and one does not derive an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai. The <i>Tosefta</i> explicitly states that Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya himself derived an <i>a fortiori</i> inference from the <i>halakha</i> of circumcision on Shabbat. Clearly, then, it is derived from the Torah itself and not from a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai.
<b>Rather, Rabbi Elazar said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> is <b>derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between the word <b>sign</b> that appears with regard to circumcision: “And you shall be circumcised in the flesh of your foreskin; and it shall be a sign of the covenant between Me and you” (Genesis 17:11), and <b>sign</b> that appears with regard to Shabbat: “However, you shall keep My <i>Shabbatot</i>, for it is a sign between Me and you throughout your generations” (Exodus 31:13). From this verbal analogy, it is derived that circumcision, which is a sign, may be performed even on Shabbat, which is itself a sign.
The Gemara asks: <b>But if</b> what you say is <b>so, phylacteries, with regard to which</b> the term <b>sign is</b> also <b>written:</b> “And it shall be for a sign on your hand and for frontlets between your eyes” (Exodus 13:16), <b>should</b> also <b>override Shabbat,</b> and they should be donned on that day.
<b>Rather,</b> this principle is <b>derived</b> by means of a different verbal analogy from the word <b>covenant</b> that appears with regard to circumcision: “And you shall be circumcised in the flesh of your foreskin; and it shall be a sign of the covenant between Me and you” (Genesis 17:11), and the word <b>covenant</b> that appears with regard to Shabbat: “The children of Israel shall keep the Shabbat, to observe the Shabbat throughout their generations for a perpetual covenant” (Exodus 31:16).
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If this is so, then the circumcision of <b>an adult</b> should also be permitted on Shabbat and it should not be limited to a child on the eighth day, <b>as</b> the term <b>covenant is written with regard to him</b> as well, as it applies to any Jewish male not yet circumcised. Therefore, <b>let</b> his circumcision <b>override Shabbat.</b> The <i>halakha</i>, however, is that only circumcision at its proper time on the eighth day overrides Shabbat.
<b>Rather,</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived</b> by means of a verbal analogy between the word <b>generations</b> that appears with regard to Shabbat: “Throughout their generations for a perpetual covenant” (Exodus 31:16), and the word <b>generations</b> that appears with regard to circumcision: “And I shall establish My covenant between Me and you, and between your seed after you throughout their generations, for an everlasting covenant” (Genesis 17:7).
The Gemara asks: If so, <b>let ritual fringes</b> too, <b>with regard to which</b> the term <b>generations is</b> also <b>written, override Shabbat,</b> and it should be permitted to affix ritual fringes to a garment on Shabbat.
<b>Rather, Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> This <i>halakha</i> is derived not from one common word alone, but <b>one derives</b> it based upon the three words <b>sign, covenant, and generations</b> that appear with regard to circumcision, <b>from sign, covenant, and generations</b> that appear with regard to Shabbat, <b>to the exclusion of these,</b> i.e., ritual fringes and phylacteries, <b>that with regard to each of them, one</b> of these <b>is written</b> but not all three words together.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The verse says:</b> “And <b>on the</b> eighth day…shall be circumcised” (Leviticus 12:3), which means that the child is circumcised <b>on the</b> eighth <b>day</b> whenever it occurs, <b>even on Shabbat.</b>
<b>Reish Lakish said to Rabbi Yoḥanan: But if</b> what you say is <b>so,</b> then, with regard to <b>those lacking atonement,</b> such as a <i>zav</i> or a healed leper, who must after their immersion still bring an atonement offering in order to complete their purification process, <b>with regard to whom</b> the term <b>on the day is</b> also <b>written,</b> as in the verse: “And on the eighth day he shall take two he-lambs without blemish, and one ewe-lamb of the first year without blemish” (Leviticus 14:10), sacrificing their atonement offerings <b>should also override Shabbat.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan responded: <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary</b> to teach that the sacrifice must be brought <b>during the day and not at night.</b>
Reish Lakish asked: <b>This</b> verse with regard to the mitzva of circumcision <b>is also necessary</b> to teach that circumcision must be performed <b>during the day and not at night.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan replied: <b>That</b> is derived <b>from</b> a different verse, which states: “And <b>he that is eight days old</b> shall be circumcised among you throughout your generations” (Genesis 17:12). That circumcision must take place during the day is derived from that verse.
Reish Lakish says: <b>That</b> matter, that the atonement offering must be sacrificed during the day, can <b>also</b> be derived <b>from</b> a different verse, as it is stated: “This is the law of the burnt-offering, of the meal-offering, and of the sin-offering, and of the guilt-offering, and of the consecration-offering, and of the sacrifice of the peace-offerings; which the Lord commanded Moses at Mount Sinai <b>on the day He commanded</b> the children of Israel to present their offerings to the Lord in the wilderness of Sinai” (Leviticus 7:37–38), and from here <b>it is derived</b> that all offerings are sacrificed by day and not at night.
The Gemara answers: <b>Although</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived from: “On the day He commanded,”</b> an additional source <b>is necessary</b> for those lacking atonement. <b>It might have entered your mind to say</b> that <b>since the Torah shows him mercy</b> by allowing him <b>to bring</b> an offering <b>of poverty,</b> as if one cannot afford to sacrifice the regular atonement offering, the Torah enables him to sacrifice a less costly one, <b>let him also bring it at night,</b> as perhaps the Torah shows him mercy and allows him to hasten his atonement. Therefore, <b>it teaches us</b> that he too must bring his offering only by day and not at night.
<b>Ravina strongly objects to this</b> reasoning: <b>But if</b> what you say is <b>so,</b> that the Torah has compassion on a person lacking atonement and is lenient with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of the atonement offering, <b>a non-priest should be fit</b> to sacrifice <b>them, and</b> similarly, a priest who is <b>an acute mourner,</b> i.e., one whose relative died that same day and has not yet been buried, <b>should be fit to</b> sacrifice <b>them.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>The verse has restored this.</b> The additional verse that teaches that even one lacking atonement must sacrifice during the day, also teaches that the Torah was lenient with regard to this offering only in the ways explicitly stated in the Torah.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov said:</b> There is a different proof from the Torah that circumcision is performed even on Shabbat, for <b>the verse said:</b> “On the <b>eighth</b> day,” underscoring that circumcision is performed specifically on the <b>eighth</b> day and indicating that it is performed <b>even on Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>This</b> usage of the term <b>eighth is necessary to exclude</b> the <b>seventh</b> day, i.e., a child may not be circumcised before the eighth day. The Gemara answers: The fact that one may not circumcise on the <b>seventh</b> day <b>is derived</b> from a different verse, as it is stated: “And <b>he that is eight days old</b> shall be circumcised among you throughout your generations” (Genesis 17:12).
The Gemara raises a further difficulty: Both verses are <b>still necessary, one to exclude</b> the <b>seventh</b> day <b>and one to exclude</b> the <b>ninth</b> day. <b>As if</b> it were derived <b>from one</b> verse alone, <b>I would have said: It is</b> on the <b>seventh</b> day that one may not circumcise, since <b>the time</b> to circumcise this child <b>has not</b> yet <b>arrived</b> and the obligation of circumcision is not yet in effect; <b>however, from</b> the <b>eighth</b> day <b>and onward is its time,</b> and therefore it is permissible to postpone a circumcision until the ninth day. No answer was found to this question, and the Gemara concludes: <b>Rather,</b> the derivation <b>is clear according to Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b>
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov,</b> as the <i>tanna</i> interprets the phrase: “On the <b>eighth</b> day <b>he shall be circumcised”</b> to mean that the circumcision must be performed <b>even on Shabbat. And how do I fulfill</b> the prohibition against performing prohibited labor explicit in the Torah in the verse: “And you shall guard the Shabbat, for it is holy to you; <b>he who desecrates it shall surely die”</b> (Exodus 31:14)? That is referring <b>to other prohibited labors besides circumcision.</b> The <i>tanna</i> questions his previous statement: <b>Or perhaps that is not</b> the case, and the prohibition of performing prohibited labor on Shabbat includes <b>even circumcision, and,</b> on the contrary, <b>how do I fulfill</b> the verse: “On the <b>eighth</b> day <b>he shall be circumcised”?</b> It applies when the eighth day is any day <b>other than Shabbat. The verse states: “On the day,”</b> meaning on that very day when he turns eight days old, <b>even on Shabbat.</b> The <i>tanna</i> of this <i>baraita</i> rejects Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov’s proof and accepts Rabbi Yoḥanan’s assertion that the phrase “On the day” conclusively establishes that circumcision is performed even on Shabbat.
With regard to this <i>baraita</i>, <b>Rava said: Initially, what</b> did <b>this <i>tanna</i></b> find <b>acceptable, and ultimately, what</b> did <b>he</b> find <b>difficult?</b> Initially he suggested that: “On the eighth day he shall be circumcised” is a valid source for the fact that circumcision overrides Shabbat, but ultimately, he deemed that difficult and turned to an alternative source, yet provided no reason, neither for his initial statement nor for his second statement.
Rather, we can explain that <b>this is what he is saying:</b> “On the <b>eighth</b> day <b>he shall be circumcised”</b> applies <b>even on Shabbat. And how do I fulfill: “He who desecrates it shall surely die”?</b> That is referring to the <b>other prohibited labors besides circumcision; however, circumcision overrides</b> Shabbat.
<b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>It is</b> derived by means of <b>an <i>a fortiori</i> inference: Just as leprosy, which overrides the</b> Temple <b>service,</b> as a priest who is a leper may not serve in the Temple and it is prohibited to cut off the symptoms of leprosy,

Daf 132b

<b>and</b> the Temple <b>service overrides Shabbat,</b> as Shabbat offerings are sacrificed at their appointed time, and nevertheless <b>circumcision overrides</b> leprosy, i.e., if there were symptoms of leprosy on the foreskin of the baby, one circumcises the child even though he thereby violates the prohibition to cut off symptoms of leprosy; therefore, with regard to <b>Shabbat, which is overridden by the</b> Temple <b>service, is it not logical that circumcision,</b> which is so stringent that it overrides leprosy, <b>overrides</b> Shabbat as well? This was the <i>tanna’s</i> reasoning at the outset.
