<b>What, is it not that this</b> is the matter with regard to which <b>they disagree? That</b> this <b>Master holds</b> that the animal <b>is</b> considered <b>alive</b> and therefore its slaughter is effective, as is the case with regard to all pure animals, <b>while</b> this <b>Master,</b> the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>holds</b> that it <b>is</b> considered <b>dead.</b>
<b>Rava said: If so, instead of disagreeing over</b> the issue of <b>impurity and purity, let them disagree over</b> the issue of <b>eating,</b> i.e., whether it is permitted to eat this offspring after it is slaughtered. Since they did not dispute this point, their disagreement must revolve around a different factor.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is</b> considered <b>dead,</b> yet <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, hold</b> that it has the legal status <b>like</b> that of <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> an animal with a condition that will cause it to die within twelve months. With regard to a <b><i>tereifa</i>, is it not that even though it is</b> considered <b>dead</b> from the perspective of <i>halakha</i> because there is no possibility of long-term survival, nevertheless, if it is slaughtered, <b>its slaughter purifies it?</b> It does not cause ritual impurity like an unslaughtered animal, even though it may not be eaten. <b>Here too, it is no different. And the Rabbis,</b> who do not accept this claim, say: <b>It is not similar to a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> since <b>a <i>tereifa</i> had a period of fitness</b> before it became a <i>tereifa</i>. However, <b>this</b> animal that was born after eight months of pregnancy <b>did not</b> ever <b>have a period of fitness.</b>
<b>And if you say:</b> With regard to an animal that was a <b><i>tereifa</i> from the womb</b> and was born in that condition, <b>what is there to say?</b> It too never had a period of fitness. There is a distinction between the cases. <b>There,</b> with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, <b>there is slaughter in its type; here,</b> with regard to a stillborn, <b>there is no slaughter in its type,</b> as there is no circumstance where slaughter of a stillborn animal is appropriate.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Do the Rabbis disagree with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> who holds that any animal that survived for eight days after birth is presumed viable, <b>or not? If you say</b> that they <b>disagree,</b> the dilemma is: <b>Is</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> in accordance with his</b> opinion, <b>or is</b> the <b><i>halakha</i> not in accordance with his</b> opinion?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> proof from that which we learned: With regard to a <b>calf that was born on a Festival, one may slaughter</b> it <b>on</b> the <b>Festival.</b> Apparently, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel’s opinion is not accepted, and one need not wait eight days after the animal is born. The Gemara refutes this: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> It is a case in <b>which one is certain that its months</b> of gestation <b>were completed,</b> and therefore, it is certainly not stillborn.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> another proof from that which we learned: Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, who disagreed with regard to whether or not it is permitted to inspect firstborn animals for blemishes on a Festival, <b>agree that if</b> a firstborn animal <b>was born with its blemish, it is</b> considered <b>prepared</b> for use on the Festival. It is not deemed set-aside and an expert may examine it to determine whether or not it is a permanent blemish. Apparently, a firstborn animal may be slaughtered on the day of its birth. The Gemara refutes this proof as well: It is a case in <b>which one is certain that its months</b> of gestation <b>were completed,</b> and it is certainly not stillborn.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution to the dilemma, <b>as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> in this matter <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel.</b> Nonetheless, from the fact that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> was ruled in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <b>by inference,</b> the Sages <b>disagree</b> with his ruling. The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from this</b> the resolution to both dilemmas raised above.
<b>Abaye said:</b> With regard to a baby less than thirty days old that <b>fell off a roof or was eaten by a lion, everyone agrees</b> that <b>he is</b> considered to have been <b>alive;</b> it was a viable baby that died in the accident. <b>Where they disagree is</b> in a case where the baby <b>yawned,</b> i.e., breathed momentarily after birth, <b>and</b> then immediately <b>died.</b> This <b>Master,</b> the Rabbis, <b>hold:</b> The baby <b>is</b> considered to have been <b>living,</b> since it was born alive; <b>and</b> this <b>Master holds: It is</b> considered to have been born <b>dead</b> until it lives a month after its birth.
<b>What</b> practical <b>difference is there</b> whether or not the baby is considered to have been alive? The difference is <b>to exempt</b> the child’s mother <b>from levirate marriage.</b> If a man died with no children, and his wife was pregnant and a viable child was born, the woman is exempt from levirate marriage; however, if the child was born dead, the man is considered to have died childless, and his widow is obligated in levirate marriage.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: Is that to say that if the child <b>fell off a roof or was eaten by a lion, everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is</b> considered to have been <b>alive? Didn’t Rav Pappa and Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, happen</b> to come <b>to the house of the son of Rav Idi bar Avin, and he prepared for them a third-born calf on the seventh day</b> after its birth. <b>And they said to him: Had you waited</b> to slaughter <b>it until the evening, we would have eaten from it. Now</b> that you did not wait, <b>we shall not eat from it.</b> Apparently, if a calf is slaughtered before it was alive for eight days and definitely viable, suspicion that it is stillborn remains; the same is true of a child who dies from an accident within thirty days of birth.
<b>Rather,</b> Abaye’s statement must be reformulated: <b>When</b> the baby <b>yawned and died, everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is</b> considered to have been <b>dead</b> from the outset. <b>Where they disagree is in</b> a case <b>when it fell off a roof or was eaten by a lion:</b> This <b>Master,</b> Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, <b>holds: It is</b> considered to have been <b>dead; and</b> this <b>Master holds</b> that since it did not die on its own, <b>it is</b> considered to have been <b>alive.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>A baby was born to the son of Rav Dimi bar Yosef. Within thirty days</b> the baby <b>died. He sat</b> and <b>mourned over him. His father,</b> Rav Dimi bar Yosef, <b>said to him:</b> Are you mourning because <b>you wish to partake of the delicacies fed to mourners?</b> The <i>halakha</i> deems a child that dies before thirty days stillborn, and one does not mourn over it. <b>He said to him: I am certain that its months</b> of gestation <b>were completed.</b>
The Gemara similarly relates that <b>Rav Ashi happened</b> to come <b>to Rav Kahana’s house. A matter befell him,</b> i.e., his child died <b>within thirty days</b> of its birth. Rav Ashi <b>saw him</b> and observed <b>that he was sitting and mourning over him. He said to him: Doesn’t the Master hold</b> in accordance with <b>that which Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel,</b> that only a child who lived for thirty days is not considered stillborn? <b>He said to him: I am certain that its months</b> of gestation <b>were completed</b> and he is not to be considered a stillborn.
<b>It was stated</b> that the Sages discussed the following question: What is the ruling in a case where a baby <b>died within thirty days</b> after birth, leaving its mother a childless widow, <b>and</b> before they decided whether or not she was obligated in levirate marriage, <b>she stood and was betrothed</b> to another? <b>Ravina said in the name of Rava:</b>

Daf 136b

<b>If she is the wife of an Israelite,</b> meaning she became betrothed to an Israelite, who may marry a woman who has undergone <i>ḥalitza</i>, <b>she performs <i>ḥalitza</i></b> due to uncertainty. Given that the child may have been stillborn and therefore never considered alive, in which case she would be obligated to undergo levirate marriage or perform <i>ḥalitza</i>, by performing <i>ḥalitza</i>, she removes any doubt and can remain with her new husband. However, <b>if she is the wife of a priest, she does not perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> as if she were to perform <i>ḥalitza</i> she would be prohibited to her husband the priest. Since there are those who hold that that the baby is considered alive from the moment of its birth, based on that opinion, she is exempt from performing <i>ḥalitza</i>, after the fact.
<b>Rav Sherevya said in the name</b> of <b>Rava: Both this,</b> the woman married to an Israelite, <b>and that,</b> the woman married to a priest, <b>perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> as the prohibition against marrying a woman not released from her bond of levirate marriage is a stringent one, and the fact that her husband is a priest is not taken into consideration.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Sherevya: In the evening Rava</b> indeed <b>said so,</b> as you said; however, <b>in the morning he retracted</b> his statement, and that is what I cited. Rav Sherevya, however, did not accept this explanation, and said: <b>Did you permit</b> the wife of a priest without <i>ḥalitza</i>, despite the fact that Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel deems the baby stillborn unless he survives to the age of thirty days? Since you have violated his ruling, <b>may it be</b> God’s <b>will that you</b> continue along this path and <b>permit</b> the eating of <b>forbidden fat.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda permits</b> circumcising a hermaphrodite on Shabbat. <b>Rav Sheizvi said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Not with regard to all</b> matters <b>did Rabbi Yehuda say</b> that <b>a hermaphrodite is</b> considered <b>a male;</b> it was only with regard to circumcision, <b>as if you say so,</b> that the legal status of a hermaphrodite is that of a male in every sense, then even <b>with regard to</b> vows of <b>valuation, he should be valuated.</b>
<b>And from where do we</b> derive <b>that he is not valuated? As it was taught</b> in the <i>Sifra</i>, the halakhic midrash on Leviticus, with regard to the verse: “Then your valuation shall be for <b>the male</b> from the age of twenty years until the age of sixty years, your valuation shall be fifty shekel of silver, after the shekel of the Sanctuary” (Leviticus 27:3). The Sages inferred: “The male” means the definite male <b>but not a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite.</b> I <b>might</b> have thought that these <b>shall not be</b> valuated according to <b>the valuation of a man, but shall be</b> valuated according to <b>the valuation of a woman.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “The male,”</b> and in the following verse: <b>“And if she is a female,</b> then your valuation shall be thirty shekels” (Leviticus 27:4), indicating: Only <b>a definite male</b> or <b>a definite female, but not a <i>tumtum</i> or a hermaphrodite,</b> which are categorized as neither male nor female.

Daf 137a

<b>And an unattributed</b> <i>halakha</i> cited in the <b><i>Sifra</i></b> generally reflects the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: We too also learned</b> in a mishna that Rabbi Yehuda does not consider a hermaphrodite to be a male in every sense. The Sages disagreed over sanctification of the waters of a purification offering, i.e., the placing of the ashes of the red heifer in potable, running spring water: <b>Everyone is fit to sanctify</b> the waters of a purification offering, <b>except for a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor. Rabbi Yehuda deems a minor fit, but deems a woman and a hermaphrodite unfit.</b> Apparently, Rabbi Yehuda does not consider the legal status of a hermaphrodite to be like that of a male. The Gemara concludes: <b>Conclude from this.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>circumcision,</b> with regard to which Rabbi Yehuda categorizes a hermaphrodite as a male in regard to its laws? The Gemara answers that it is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is written:</b> “This is My covenant which you shall keep, between Me and you and your seed after you: <b>Circumcise for yourselves every male”</b> (Genesis 17:10), and he interprets the phrase “every male” as an amplification including anyone who could possibly be included in the category of a male.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who had two babies</b> to circumcise, <b>one</b> of whom he needed <b>to circumcise</b> on the day <b>after Shabbat, and one</b> of whom he needed <b>to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the one</b> that should have been circumcised <b>after Shabbat on Shabbat, he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering, because he performed the prohibited labor of causing a wound not in the framework of performing a mitzva, as no obligation yet exists to circumcise the child.
If there were two babies, <b>one to circumcise on Shabbat eve, and one to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the one</b> that he should have circumcised on <b>Shabbat eve on Shabbat, Rabbi Eliezer deems him liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> as circumcision after its appointed time does not override Shabbat. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him; since he intended to perform a mitzva, and despite his error in fact performed a mitzva, he is exempt from bringing a sin-offering.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> There is a dispute among the <i>amora’im</i> with regard to the correct version of our mishna, based on an early dispute of the <i>tanna’im</i>: <b>Rav Huna teaches</b> the first clause of the mishna as stating: <b>Liable,</b> whereas <b>Rav Yehuda teaches</b> the first clause as stating: <b>Exempt.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>Rav Huna taught</b> the first clause as stating: <b>Liable,</b> based on that which <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar said: Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua did not disagree with regard to one who had two babies, one to circumcise on Shabbat and one to circumcise after Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the one</b> who should have been circumcised <b>after Shabbat on Shabbat;</b> in that case, everyone agrees <b>that he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering.
<b>With regard to what did they disagree? With regard to one who had two babies, one to circumcise on Shabbat eve and one to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the one</b> who should have been circumcised on <b>Shabbat eve on Shabbat, as Rabbi Eliezer renders him liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering</b> for this unwitting transgression, <b>and Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him.
<b>And both of them only derived it from idolatry,</b> where the Torah details the <i>halakhot</i> of bringing a sin-offering for an unwitting transgression. <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds:</b> The law of every unwitting transgression is <b>like</b> that of <b>idolatry. Just as</b> with regard to <b>idolatry the Torah stated: Do not perform</b> certain activities, <b>and when one performs</b> them unwittingly, he is <b>liable</b> to bring a sin-offering, <b>here too it is no different,</b> and since he transgressed the prohibition, he is liable to bring a sin-offering.
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua</b> holds: <b>There, where</b> the unwitting transgression was <b>not</b> performed in order to fulfill <b>a mitzva,</b> one is liable to bring a sin-offering. <b>Here,</b> his intention was to perform <b>a mitzva,</b> and one who unwittingly violates a prohibition in the course of attempting to fulfill a mitzva is exempt from bringing a sin-offering. This is according to the opinion of Rav Huna, based on the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.
<b>Rav Yehuda taught</b> the first clause as stating: <b>Exempt,</b> based on that which <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir said: Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua did not disagree over one who had two babies</b> to circumcise, <b>one to circumcise on Shabbat eve and one to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the one</b> who should have been circumcised on <b>Shabbat eve on Shabbat;</b> in that case, everyone agrees <b>that he is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering, as that circumcision fulfilled a mitzva.
<b>With regard to what did they disagree? With regard to one who had two babies, one to circumcise after Shabbat and one to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the one</b> who should have been circumcised <b>after Shabbat on Shabbat, as Rabbi Eliezer deems him liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, and Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him.
<b>And</b> the Gemara notes here too that <b>both of them only derived it from idolatry. Rabbi Eliezer holds:</b> The <i>halakha</i> of every unwitting transgression sin <b>is like</b> that of <b>idolatry: Just as</b> with regard to <b>idolatry the Torah stated: Do not perform</b> certain activities, <b>and when one performs</b> them unwittingly he is <b>liable</b> to bring a sin-offering, <b>here too it is no different,</b> and since he violated the prohibition, he is liable to bring a sin-offering.
<b>And Rabbi Yehoshua</b> holds: <b>There,</b> with regard to idolatry, one is liable to bring a sin-offering when he performs the transgression, because <b>he is not preoccupied</b> with the performance of a <b>mitzva. Here, he is preoccupied</b> with the performance of a <b>mitzva,</b> and anyone who unwittingly transgresses a prohibition while preoccupied with a mitzva is exempt from bringing a sin-offering.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya taught</b> another version of the same dispute between the <i>tanna’im</i>: <b>Rabbi Meir would say</b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua did not disagree over one who had two babies, one to circumcise on Shabbat eve and one to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the one</b> who should have been circumcised <b>on Shabbat eve on Shabbat;</b> in that case, everyone agrees <b>that he is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering.
<b>With regard to what did they disagree? With regard to one who had two babies</b> to circumcise, <b>one to circumcise after Shabbat and one to circumcise on Shabbat, and he forgot and circumcised the one</b> who should have been circumcised <b>after Shabbat on Shabbat, Rabbi Eliezer deems him liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, and Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him.
The Gemara expresses surprise at this last version: <b>Now,</b> after all, in <b>the latter clause, where he did not perform a mitzva, Rabbi Yehoshua exempts</b> him; <b>in the first clause, where he performed a mitzva, does Rabbi Yehoshua deem him liable?</b>
<b>In the school of Rabbi Yannai they say: The first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a unique situation, <b>where</b> the circumcisor <b>first</b> unwittingly <b>circumcised</b> the baby who should have been circumcised <b>on Shabbat on Shabbat eve.</b> In that case, <b>Shabbat</b> is <b>not given to be overridden</b> at all, since the baby who was supposed to be circumcised on Shabbat was already circumcised. In the <b>latter clause,</b> however, the circumcision was performed in a situation where <b>Shabbat</b> is <b>given to be overridden.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana</b> that this explanation is difficult: <b>In the first clause too, Shabbat</b> is <b>given to be overridden with regard to babies in general,</b> as it is permitted to circumcise a baby whose eighth day occurs on Shabbat. He replied: That is indeed so; <b>however, with regard to this person,</b> Shabbat is <b>not given</b> to be overridden, as there is no longer any child who is supposed to be circumcised on Shabbat. Therefore, if he unwittingly performed a circumcision on Shabbat, he is not considered to have unwittingly performed a transgression while preoccupied with the performance of a mitzva.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Although <b>a child is</b> generally <b>circumcised at eight</b> days, as the verse states: “And on the eighth day, the flesh of his foreskin shall be circumcised” (Leviticus 12:3), nevertheless, at times he is circumcised <b>at nine</b> days, at times <b>at ten</b> days, <b>at eleven</b> days, <b>and at twelve</b> days, <b>no earlier and no later.</b>
<b>How so? In his</b> usual <b>manner,</b> a child is circumcised <b>at eight</b> days. If <b>he was born at twilight</b> and it is therefore uncertain on which day he was born, <b>he is circumcised at nine</b> days, as his circumcision is postponed due to that uncertainty, as perhaps the eighth day from his birth has not yet arrived. If he was born <b>at twilight on Shabbat eve,</b> he is not circumcised on the following Shabbat, due to the uncertainty whether it is the eighth or ninth day since his birth, and only a circumcision definitely performed at the appointed time overrides Shabbat. Rather, he is circumcised on Sunday, and the result is that <b>he is circumcised at ten</b> days.
If there was <b>a Festival after</b> that <b>Shabbat,</b> he is not circumcised on the Festival either, and <b>he is circumcised at eleven</b> days. And if that Shabbat was followed by <b>two days of Rosh HaShana,</b> the result is that <b>he is circumcised at twelve</b> days.
The mishna states another <i>halakha</i>: With regard to <b>a sick child, one does not circumcise him until he becomes healthy.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that one does not circumcise a sick baby until he becomes healthy. <b>Shmuel said:</b> A baby that was sick and had a high fever, and subsequently <b>the fever left him, one gives him a full seven</b> days <b>to heal</b> before circumcising him.
With regard to this issue, <b>a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>Do we require,</b> during the recovery period, to wait <b>from</b> the <b>time</b> the seven days begin <b>to</b> the exact same <b>time</b> seven days later, i.e., seven complete, twenty-four-hour periods, or is it enough to wait seven days without taking into account the time of day?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a solution to this from that <b>which</b> the Sage <b>Luda taught: The day of his healing is like the day of his birth. What, is it not</b> that <b>just as</b> from <b>the day of his birth we need not</b> wait <b>from</b> the <b>time</b> he is born <b>to</b> the same <b>time</b> on the eighth day to circumcise him, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>the day of his healing, we need not</b> wait <b>from</b> the <b>time</b> he heals <b>to</b> the same <b>time</b> seven days later?
The Gemara refutes this: <b>No, the day of his healing is superior to the day of his birth. While</b> from <b>the day of his birth</b> until circumcision <b>we need not</b> wait <b>from time to time,</b> from <b>the day of his healing we need</b> to wait seven complete days <b>from time to time.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>These are the shreds</b> of flesh <b>that invalidate the circumcision</b> if they are not cut. The essential element of circumcision is the removal of <b>the flesh that covers most of the corona,</b> and a child that was not circumcised in this manner is considered uncircumcised, <b>and he does not eat <i>teruma</i>.</b>
<b>And if</b> he was properly circumcised but <b>he was fleshy,</b> and it appears as though he has not been properly circumcised, the circumcisor should <b>correct it</b> by circumcising more than necessary, to avoid the <b>appearance</b> of transgression, so he will not appear uncircumcised.

Daf 137b

If <b>one circumcised but did not uncover</b> the flesh at <b>the</b> area of the <b>circumcision</b> by folding back the thin membrane beneath the foreskin, <b>it is as if he had not circumcised.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Avina said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> When the mishna said most of the corona, they meant <b>the flesh that covers most of the height of the corona,</b> as well as most of its circumference.
We learned in the mishna: <b>If</b> the baby <b>was fleshy,</b> the circumcisor corrects the circumcision so that it will not appear uncircumcised. <b>Shmuel said: A child who is encumbered with flesh, one examines him,</b> and <b>as long as when</b> his limb <b>hardens he looks circumcised, one need not circumcise</b> him again. <b>And if not,</b> meaning he does not appear circumcised even then, <b>one must circumcise</b> him again.
<b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i></b> that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A child who is encumbered with flesh, one examines him,</b> and <b>as long as when it hardens it does not appear circumcised, one needs to circumcise him</b> again, <b>and if not, one need not circumcise him</b> again.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between these</b> two formulations? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> in a case where he <b>appears</b> circumcised but <b>does not appear</b> fully circumcised. According to Shmuel, in order to avoid an additional circumcision, one must appear fully circumcised, and this state is insufficient. According to Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel, only one who appears uncircumcised requires further circumcision; this partial circumcision is adequate.
We learned in the mishna: If <b>he circumcised</b> a child <b>but did not uncover</b> the area of the circumcision, it is as if he did not circumcise him. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>Tosefta</i> that <b>one who circumcises</b> a child <b>recites: Who has made us holy through His commandments, and commanded us concerning circumcision. The father of the</b> circumcised <b>child recites: Who has made us holy through His commandments, and commanded us to bring him into the covenant of Abraham, our father. Those standing</b> there <b>recite: Just as he has entered into the covenant, so may he enter into Torah, marriage, and good deeds.</b>
<b>And the one who recites the</b> additional <b>blessing says: Who made the beloved one holy from the womb, marked the decree in his flesh, and gave his descendants the seal and the sign of the holy covenant. Therefore, as a reward for this, the living God, our Portion, commanded to deliver the beloved of our flesh from destruction, for the sake of His covenant that He set in our flesh. Blessed are You, Lord, Who establishes the covenant.</b>
<b>One who circumcises converts says: Blessed are You, Lord, our God, King of the universe, Who made us holy with His commandments, and commanded us concerning circumcision. And the one who recites the</b> additional <b>blessing recites: Who has made us holy with His commandments, and commanded us to circumcise converts, and to drip from them covenantal blood, as were it not for the blood of the covenant, the heaven and earth would not be sustained, as it is stated: “If My covenant would not be with day and night, the ordinances of heaven and earth I would not have placed”</b> (Jeremiah 33:25), which is interpreted to mean that were it not for the covenant of circumcision that is manifest both day and night, the world would cease to exist. He concludes the blessing with the phrase: <b>Blessed are You, Lord, Who establishes the covenant.</b>
When a Jew buys a Canaanite slave, he is obligated to circumcise the slave, as the slave is partially entering the covenant of the Jewish people. <b>One who circumcises slaves recites</b> a blessing: <b>Who made us holy with His commandments, and commanded us concerning circumcision. And the one who recites the additional blessings says</b> a blessing similar to those mentioned above: <b>Who made us holy with His commandments, and commanded us to circumcise slaves, and to drip from them covenantal blood, as were it not for the blood of the covenant the heaven and earth would not be sustained, as it is stated: “If My covenant would not be with day and night, the ordinances of heaven and earth I would not have placed”</b> (Jeremiah 33:25). <b>Blessed are You, Lord, Who establishes the covenant.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: One may suspend</b> and stretch over a base <b>the strainer</b> through which sediment is filtered from wine, <b>on a Festival. And one may place</b> wine <b>through</b> a strainer that was already <b>suspended</b> the day before; however, one may not suspend the strainer <b>on Shabbat. And the Rabbis say: One may not suspend the strainer on a Festival, and one may not place</b> wine for filtering <b>through a suspended</b> strainer <b>on Shabbat; however, one may place</b> wine <b>through a suspended</b> strainer <b>on a Festival.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to Rabbi Eliezer’s position: <b>Now, Rabbi Eliezer</b> holds that <b>we may not</b> even <b>add</b> to <b>a temporary tent</b> on Shabbat; could it be that <b>to make</b> a tent <b>is permitted <i>ab initio</i>?</b> Stretching a strainer over a base, which Rabbi Eliezer permits, is comparable to making a tent.
The Gemara explains the question: <b>What is</b> this opinion of Rabbi Eliezer’s? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>a window shutter</b> used to cover a skylight, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: When it is tied</b> to <b>and hanging</b> from the window, i.e., it is not touching the ground, <b>one may shutter</b> the window <b>with it, and if not, one may not shutter</b> the window <b>with it. And the Rabbis say: Both</b> in <b>this</b> case <b>and</b> in <b>that</b> case <b>one may shutter with it.</b>
<b>And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Everyone agrees that one may not construct a temporary tent on a Festival</b> for the <b>first time, and needless to say,</b> one may not do so <b>on Shabbat.</b> The <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree only</b> with regard to <b>adding</b> to an existing tent, <b>as Rabbi Eliezer says: One may not add</b> to an existing structure <b>on a Festival, and needless to say,</b> one may not do so <b>on Shabbat. And the Rabbis say: One may add</b> to the temporary structure <b>on Shabbat, and needless to say,</b> one may do so <b>on a Festival.</b>
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Eliezer indeed holds that the suspension of a strainer constitutes a prohibited labor. However, <b>Rabbi Eliezer holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> with regard to actions that facilitate preparation of food on a Festival, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The only</b> difference <b>between a Festival and Shabbat</b> is with regard to the preparation of <b>food alone.</b> It is permitted to perform labors for the purpose of food preparation on a Festival, but not on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Yehuda permits even actions that facilitate food preparation</b> on a Festival, e.g., fixing utensils with which food is prepared on the Festival. Similarly, Rabbi Eliezer permits the suspension of a strainer, which would otherwise constitute a prohibited labor, in order to prepare wine for use on the Festival.
The Gemara asks: <b>Say that we heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> permits labors that are otherwise prohibited if they <b>pertain to actions that facilitate</b> food preparation <b>that cannot be performed on the eve of the Festival;</b> however, <b>with regard to actions that facilitate</b> food preparation <b>that can be performed on the eve of the Festival, did you hear</b> that <b>he</b> permits doing so?
The Gemara answers: The leniency <b>of Rabbi Eliezer exceeds that of Rabbi Yehuda.</b> Unlike Rabbi Yehuda, Rabbi Eliezer does not distinguish between actions that facilitate food preparation that can and those that cannot be performed on the eve of the Festival.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> One may not suspend the strainer on a Festival. <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If <b>he suspended</b> a strainer unwittingly, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> If <b>he suspended</b> it, <b>he is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> like anyone who unwittingly performs a labor prohibited by Torah law on Shabbat.
<b>Abaye said to him: But if</b> that is <b>so,</b> that an action of that sort constitutes performance of the prohibited labor of building by Torah law, then if <b>one suspended a jug on a peg, is he also liable</b> for building a tent?

Daf 138a

<b>Rather, Abaye said: It is a rabbinic</b> decree issued so <b>that one will not conduct</b> himself on Shabbat <b>in the manner that he conducts</b> himself <b>during the week.</b>
<b>Abaye would consolidate the principles of the <i>baraitot</i></b> pertaining to the construction of a tent on Shabbat <b>and teach:</b> With regard to <b>a large wineskin, a</b> wine <b>strainer, a canopy</b> hung over a bed, <b>and a folding chair</b> whose cover is detached from its legs, <b>one may not assemble</b> them due to the prohibition against making a temporary tent. <b>If one did</b> so unwittingly, <b>he is exempt</b> by Torah law from bringing a sin-offering, <b>but</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> by rabbinic decree. With regard to <b>permanent tents, one may not make</b> them, <b>and if he did</b> so, <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering</b> for performing the prohibited labor of building. <b>However,</b> with regard to <b>a bed, and a folding chair [<i>teraskal</i>]</b> whose cover is attached to its legs, <b>and a</b> collapsible <b>toilet, it is permissible to open them <i>ab initio</i>,</b> since they are prepared for use from before Shabbat.
We also learned in the mishna: <b>One may not place</b> wine for filtering even <b>into</b> a <b>suspended</b> strainer <b>on Shabbat. A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: If <b>one strained</b> wine, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Kahana said:</b> If <b>one strained</b> wine, <b>he is liable to</b> bring <b>a sin-offering.</b>
<b>Rav Sheshet strongly objects to this: Is there something for which the Rabbis render one liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering and Rabbi Eliezer permits</b> its performance <b><i>ab initio</i>?</b> Extreme differences of opinion of that kind are rarely found in one mishna.
<b>Rav Yosef strongly objects to</b> this question: <b>Why not? Isn’t</b> there an analogous dispute with regard to a woman who wears <b>a city of gold</b> ornament from one domain to another on Shabbat, <b>as Rabbi Meir renders</b> her <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, and Rabbi Eliezer permits</b> it even <b><i>ab initio</i>?</b>
<b>What is</b> that dispute? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A woman may not go out</b> into the public domain on Shabbat <b>with a city of gold</b> ornament. <b>And if she did go out</b> with it into the public domain, <b>she is liable to bring a sin-offering;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. And the Rabbis say: She may not go out</b> with it <i>ab initio</i>, <b>and if she went out, she is exempt. And Rabbi Eliezer says: A woman may go out with a city of gold</b> ornament <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> Apparently, there is precedent for a dispute in which one opinion maintains that an action incurs liability to bring a sin-offering, while another opinion rules that it is permitted <i>ab initio</i>.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Do you hold that Rabbi Eliezer is relating to</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Meir, who said</b> that <b>she is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering? He is relating to</b> the statement of <b>the Rabbis, who said one is exempt but it is prohibited, and he said to them</b> that he holds that it is <b>permitted <i>ab initio</i>.</b> Had there not been the intermediate opinion of the Rabbis, an argument with such extreme opinions would not have been possible.
The Gemara asks: One is liable to bring a sin-offering for straining. <b>Due to</b> performance of <b>what</b> category of prohibited labor <b>do we forewarn him? Rabba said:</b> It is <b>for</b> the category of <b>selecting,</b> as one is selecting the wine from the sediment. <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> It is <b>for</b> the category of <b>sifting,</b> as straining is similar to sifting flour in a sifter, which is a form of selecting.
<b>Rabba said: According to my opinion, it is reasonable. What is the manner of one who selects?</b> He <b>takes</b> the <b>food and leaves the refuse; here too,</b> when straining wine, <b>one takes the food and leaves the refuse.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira said: According to my opinion,</b> that this is not typical selection but rather a specific type of selection, <b>it is reasonable,</b> as <b>what is the manner of sifting?</b> The <b>refuse</b> remains <b>atop</b> the sifter <b>and the food is below. Here too,</b> when straining wine, the <b>refuse</b> remains <b>atop</b> the strainer <b>and the food is below.</b>
<b>Rami bar Yeḥezkel taught:</b> With regard to <b>a doubled cloak, one may not make</b> a covering on Shabbat by taking the cloak and placing it over a rope and extending the two sides in order to form something similar to a canopy beneath which one could lie (<i>ge’onim</i>; Rif). <b>And if one made</b> it, <b>he is exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering by Torah law, <b>but it is prohibited</b> by rabbinic decree. If <b>there was a string or a cord wrapped around it</b> before Shabbat, and the cloak was attached to the string while folded, <b>it is permitted to</b> spread it and <b>stretch it <i>ab initio</i>.</b>
On a related issue, <b>Rav Kahana raised a dilemma before Rav:</b> In the case of <b>a canopy, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is it permitted to spread it on Shabbat? <b>He said to him: Even a bed is prohibited.</b> Rav Kahana asked: With regard to <b>a bed, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>He said to him: Even a canopy is permitted.</b> Rav Kahana again asked: In the case of <b>a bed and a canopy, what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>He said to him: A canopy is prohibited, and a bed is permitted.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> this is <b>not difficult,</b> as the responses do not in fact contradict one another. Rather, <b>when he said: Even a bed is prohibited,</b> this is referring to folding beds <b>like those of the Carmanians.</b> Unfolding them is considered like making a tent. <b>When he said: Even a canopy is permitted,</b> this is referring to spreading the canopy in the manner explained by <b>Rami bar Yeḥezkel.</b> The canopy was bound by a string from before Shabbat. When he said: <b>A canopy is prohibited, and a bed is permitted,</b> this is referring to beds and canopies <b>like ours,</b> which do not fold. A bed of that kind involves no building. However, spreading canopies is performed in a manner similar to constructing a tent.
<b>Rav Yosef said: I saw the canopies of the house of Rav Huna that were spread out in the evening, and in the morning they were cast off and lying</b> on the ground. This indicates that it is permitted to dismantle and spread them on Shabbat.
<b>Rav said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya:</b> With regard to <b>a curtain, it is permitted to spread it, and it is permitted to dismantle it.</b> Since a curtain has no roof, neither action constitutes establishing a tent.
<b>And Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Ḥiyya:</b>

Daf 138b

With regard to <b>a bridegroom’s canopy,</b> which has no roof but is entirely sloped, <b>it is permitted to spread it and it is permitted to dismantle it</b> on Shabbat.
<b>Rav Sheshet, son of Rav Idi, said: We only said</b> that it is permitted in a case where <b>its roof is not a handbreadth</b> wide; <b>however,</b> if <b>its roof is a handbreadth</b> wide, <b>it is prohibited.</b> Furthermore, even <b>when its roof is not a handbreadth</b> wide, <b>we only said</b> that it is permitted <b>where there is not</b> the width of <b>a handbreadth within three</b> handbreadths <b>of its roof; however, if it</b> expands to the width of <b>a handbreadth within three</b> handbreadths <b>of its roof, it is prohibited. And we only stated</b> that it is permitted <b>where there is not in its incline</b> the width of <b>a handbreadth; however,</b> if <b>there is in its incline</b> the width of <b>a handbreadth, it is prohibited.</b> This <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the principle that <b>the inclines of tents,</b> even though they are not actual roofs, <b>are considered like tents. And we only said</b> that this canopy is permitted <b>where</b> no part of the canopy <b>descends</b> to <b>a handbreadth</b> below the bed; <b>however,</b> if part of the canopy <b>descends</b> to <b>a handbreadth</b> below the bed, <b>it is prohibited,</b> as the bed itself becomes a roof, and the curtain is considered a wall.
<b>And Rav Sheshet, son</b> of <b>Rav Idi,</b> also <b>said:</b> Wearing <b>this felt hat is permitted</b> on Shabbat, even though it has a wide brim and is similar to a tent. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Wasn’t it stated</b> elsewhere that <b>it is prohibited</b> to wear <b>a felt hat</b> on Shabbat? The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult: This</b> latter statement, which prohibited wearing the hat, is referring to a case <b>where its</b> brim <b>has</b> the width of <b>a handbreadth</b> wide and is similar to a tent. <b>That</b> statement by Rav Sheshet, which permits wearing the hat, is referring to a case <b>where its</b> brim <b>does not have</b> the width of <b>a handbreadth.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But if</b> that is <b>so,</b> if <b>one extended</b> his <b>cloak a handbreadth</b> beyond his head, would you <b>also</b> say <b>that he is liable</b> for making a tent? <b>Rather,</b> this is <b>not difficult.</b> The reason the hat is prohibited is not due to making a tent, but due to concern that the wind might blow the cap off one’s head and he will come to carry it by hand. The conflicting statements can be resolved as follows: <b>This</b> statement of Rav Sheshet, which permits wearing the hat, is referring to a case <b>where it is</b> fitted <b>firmly</b> on his head. <b>That</b> statement, which prohibits wearing the hat, is referring to a case <b>where it is not</b> fitted <b>firmly.</b>
<b>Rami bar Yeḥezkel sent to Rav Huna: Say to us, please, those excellent statements that you said to us in the name</b> of <b>Rav, two with regard to</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>Shabbat, and one with regard to the Torah.</b>
Rav Huna <b>sent to him</b> in response: With regard to <b>that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>It is permitted to spread a large wineskin</b> and suspend it <b>by its straps on Shabbat, Rav said: They only taught</b> that it is permitted if it is performed <b>by two people</b> together. They do not stretch the wineskin like a tent; rather, they place it without stretching it. <b>However, it is prohibited for one person</b> to do so by himself, due to the concern that he may establish a tent of sorts.
<b>Abaye said: And it is prohibited</b> to spread <b>a canopy</b> on Shabbat <b>even with ten people.</b> The reason for this is that <b>it is impossible that it will not be stretched a bit</b> for a certain period of time, which would establish a temporary tent.
<b>And the other</b> <i>halakha</i> with regard to Shabbat, <b>what</b> is it? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a stove, one of whose legs fell, it is permitted to move it</b> on Shabbat. Since it remains a vessel, it may be moved if it is taking up a space that is needed. However, if <b>two</b> of its legs fell, <b>it is prohibited,</b> since it is then a broken vessel. <b>Rav said: Even</b> if only <b>one</b> leg fell, <b>it is also prohibited</b> to handle it, due to <b>a decree lest one fasten</b> the leg in place forcefully and be liable for preparing a vessel for use.
With regard to <b>Torah,</b> Rav Huna related <b>that Rav said: The Torah is destined to be forgotten from the Jewish people. It is stated</b> at the conclusion of the curses in the Torah’s reproof: <b>“And the Lord will make your plagues astonishing,</b> and the plagues of your seed, great plagues of long continuance, and evil diseases of long continuance” (Deuteronomy 28:59). <b>This</b> term of <b>astonishment,</b> mentioned in the verse in addition to the explicit punishments, <b>I do not know what it is.</b> But <b>when</b> the verse <b>states</b> elsewhere: <b>“Therefore, behold, I will continue to astonish this people with wondrous astonishment,</b> and the wisdom of its wise will be lost, and the understanding of its men of understanding shall be hidden” (Isaiah 29:14), you must <b>say: This astonishment</b> is referring to forgetting the <b>Torah.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> a similar idea in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>When our Sages entered the vineyard in Yavne, they said: The Torah is destined to be forgotten from the Jewish people,</b> as <b>it is stated: “Behold, days are approaching, says the Lord God, and I will send forth a hunger in the land, not a hunger for bread and not a thirst for water, but for hearing the words of the Lord”</b> (Amos 8:11). <b>And it states: “And they will drift from sea to sea, and from north to east they will roam to find the word of the Lord, but they will not find it”</b> (Amos 8:12).
“The word of the Lord” in this context bears many meanings. <b>“The word of the Lord”; that is <i>halakha</i>. “The word of the Lord”; that is the end</b> of days. <b>“The word of the Lord”; that is prophecy.</b> All these will be lost from the Jewish people.
<b>And what</b> is the meaning of: <b>“They will roam to find the word of the Lord,</b> but they will not find it”? <b>They said: It is destined that a woman will take a loaf of <i>teruma</i></b> bread <b>and circulate among the synagogues and study halls to ascertain whether it is ritually impure or whether it is ritually pure, and there</b> will be <b>none</b> who <b>understands.</b>
The Gemara asks: How is it possible that they will be unable to understand <b>whether</b> the loaf <b>is ritually pure or whether it is ritually impure? It is explicitly written</b> in the Torah <b>with regard to this: “All food that is eaten</b> upon which water falls shall contract impurity, and all liquid drunk in any vessel shall contract impurity” (Leviticus 11:34). There can be no doubt as to the question of whether or not the loaf can become impure. <b>Rather,</b> the Gemara explains: The woman seeks <b>to ascertain whether it</b> assumes <b>first-</b>degree ritual impurity status <b>or whether it</b> assumes second-degree ritual impurity status; <b>and there</b> will be <b>none</b> who <b>understands.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>That too is an</b> explicit <b>mishna,</b> and how is it that none will know an explicit mishna? <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: If <b>the</b> carcass of a <b>creeping animal was found in</b> the airspace of <b>an oven, the bread inside it</b> assumes <b>second-</b>degree ritual impurity status, <b>as the</b> creeping animal, which is a primary source of impurity, renders the <b>oven</b> impure with <b>first-</b>degree ritual impurity. The oven then renders the bread impure with second-degree ritual impurity.
The Gemara responds: <b>They are uncertain</b> with regard to <b>that which Rav Adda bar Ahava said to Rava: Let us view this oven as one filled with impurity, and</b> the <b>bread will</b> then assume <b>first-</b>degree ritual impurity status. In other words, the legal status of food in the airspace of an earthenware vessel that also has the carcass of a creeping animal in its airspace is that of food that came into contact with the creeping animal, even if the food does not come into contact with the carcass of a creeping animal.
<b>He said to him</b> that <b>we do not say: Let us view the oven as one filled</b> with <b>ritual impurity, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> think that <b>all vessels should become ritually impure in the airspace of an earthenware vessel</b> that has the carcass of a creeping animal in its airspace; therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And any earthenware vessel in which any of them falls, <b>all that is in it shall be impure,</b> and you shall break it. <b>All food that is eaten,</b> upon which water comes, shall be impure; and all drink that may be drunk, in any vessel, shall be impure” (Leviticus 11:33–34). The <i>baraita</i> learns from the juxtaposition of these verses that <b>foods become ritually impure in the airspace of earthenware vessels, but vessels do not become ritually impure in the airspace of earthenware vessels.</b> Apparently, the airspace of an oven is not considered filled with the impurity of the carcass of a creeping animal. If that were the case, even vessels would become ritually impure.
An opposing view <b>was taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says: Heaven forfend that the Torah should be forgotten from the Jewish people, as it is stated:</b> “And this song shall answer to him as a witness, <b>for it shall not be forgotten from his seed”</b> (Deuteronomy 31:21). <b>Rather, how do I explain: “They will roam to find the word of God, but they will not find it”?</b> It means <b>that they will not find</b>

Daf 139a

<b>clear <i>halakha</i> and clear teaching together,</b> but rather there will be disputes among the Sages.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei ben Elisha says: If you see a generation that many troubles are befalling it, go and examine the judges of Israel.</b> Perhaps their sins are the cause, <b>as any calamity that comes to the world comes due to the judges of Israel</b> acting corruptly, <b>as it is stated: “Please hear this, heads of the house of Jacob, and officers of the house of Israel, who abhor justice and pervert all equity, who build up Zion with blood, and Jerusalem with iniquity. Their heads they judge for bribes, and their priests teach for hire, and their prophets divine for money; yet they lean upon the Lord,</b> saying: Is not the Lord in our midst? No evil shall befall us” (Micah 3:9–11).
The Gemara comments: <b>They are wicked, but they placed their trust in the One Who spoke and the world came into being,</b> the Almighty. <b>Therefore, the Holy One, Blessed be He, brings upon them three calamities corresponding to the three transgressions</b> for which <b>they are responsible,</b> as <b>it is stated</b> in the following verse: <b>“Therefore, because of you, Zion shall be plowed as a field, and Jerusalem shall become heaps, and the Temple Mount as the high places of a forest”</b> (Micah 3:12).
<b>And the Holy One, Blessed be He, will not rest His Divine Presence on the Jewish people until evil judges and officers shall be eliminated from the Jewish people, as it is stated: “And I will turn My hand upon you, and I will purge away your dross as with lye, and I will remove all your alloy. And I will restore your judges as at first, and your counselors as at the beginning;</b> afterward you shall be called the city of righteousness, a faithful city” (Isaiah 1:25–26).
<b>Ulla said: Jerusalem will be redeemed only through righteousness, as it is stated: “Zion will be redeemed with justice and those who return to her with righteousness”</b> (Isaiah 1:27).
<b>Rav Pappa said: If the arrogant will cease</b> to exist, <b>the</b> Persian <b>fire priests will cease</b> to exist as well. <b>If the</b> deceitful <b>judges</b> will <b>cease</b> to exist, <b>the royal officers [<i>gazirpatei</i>]</b> and taskmasters <b>will cease</b> to exist.
He explains: <b>If the arrogant will cease, the</b> Persian <b>fire priests will cease, as it is written: “And I will purge away your dross</b> [<b><i>sigayikh</i></b>] <b>as with lye,</b> and I will remove all your alloy [<i>bedilayikh</i>].” This teaches that when the conceited and haughty [<i>sigim</i>] are purged, the priests of fire, who are separated [<i>muvdalim</i>] from the fear of God, will also cease.
He said: <b>If the</b> deceitful <b>judges cease, the royal officers</b> and taskmasters will <b>cease, as it is written: “The Lord has removed your judgment, cast out your enemy”</b> (Zephaniah 3:15).
<b>Rabbi Mallai said in the name of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon: What is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written: “The Lord has broken the staff of the wicked, the rod of the rulers”</b> (Isaiah 14:5)? He explains: <b>“The Lord has broken the staff of the wicked”; these are the judges who have become staffs for their attendants.</b> The attendants abuse people, and the judges provide the attendants with legal backing and moral support. <b>“The rod of the rulers”; these are the Torah scholars</b> who are members of <b>the families of the judges.</b> These Torah scholars assist their relatives, the judges, conceal their faults. <b>Mar Zutra said: These are the Torah scholars who teach communal <i>halakhot</i> to ignorant judges.</b> They teach ignorant judges just enough Torah and modes of conduct to prevent the people from realizing how ignorant they are, enabling them to maintain their positions.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Mallai said in the name of Reish Lakish: What is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written: “For your hands are defiled with blood, and your fingers with iniquity; your lips have spoken lies, your tongue utters wickedness”</b> (Isaiah 59:3)?
He explains: <b>“For your hands are defiled with blood”; these are the judges</b> who take bribes in their hands. <b>“And your fingers with iniquity”; these are the scribes of the judges,</b> who write falsehood with their fingers. <b>“Your lips have spoken lies”; these are the legal advisors. “Your tongue utters wickedness”; these are the litigants</b> themselves.
<b>And Rabbi Mallai said in the name of Rabbi Yitzḥak from Migdal: From the day that Joseph took leave from his brothers, he did not sample a taste of wine, as it is written:</b> “They shall be on the head of Joseph, <b>and on the crown of the head of he who was separated [<i>nezir</i>] from his brothers”</b> (Genesis 49:26). The language of the verse alludes to the fact that Joseph conducted himself like a nazirite and abstained from wine.
<b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Ḥanina, said:</b> Joseph’s brothers <b>too did not sample the taste of wine</b> during the intervening period, due to their remorse, <b>as it is written: “And they drank and became drunk with him”</b> (Genesis 43:34). <b>By inference: Until now there was no drunkenness,</b> as they abstained from drinking. <b>And the other</b> Sage, Rabbi Mallai, holds: <b>It was drunkenness</b> of <b>which there was none; however, there was drinking</b> on the part of the brothers during the intervening years.
<b>And Rabbi Mallai said:</b> It is stated in the verse: “And the anger of the Lord was kindled against Moses, and He said: Is there not Aaron your brother the Levite, I know that he can surely speak, and also behold, he is coming out to greet you, and he will see you and be glad in his heart” (Exodus 4:14). Rabbi Mallai taught that <b>as reward for</b> Aaron’s lack of jealousy at seeing his brother Moses rise to greatness, as it is stated: <b>“And he will see you and be glad in his heart,” he merited</b> to become the High Priest, and <b>for the breastplate of judgment</b> to rest <b>on his heart.</b>
The Gemara returns to the laws of a canopy. <b>The inhabitants of</b> the town of <b>Bashkar sent to Levi: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to spreading <b>a canopy</b> on Shabbat? Additionally, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>hops in a vineyard?</b> Do they constitute a prohibited mixture of diverse kinds? Finally, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to one who <b>died on a Festival?</b> How can the people attend to his burial?
<b>As</b> the messenger <b>was going</b> with the question, <b>Levi died. Shmuel said to Rav Menashya: If you are wise</b> and able to respond, <b>send them</b> answers to their questions. <b>He sent them:</b> With regard to <b>a canopy, we reviewed all aspects of</b> the matter of the <b>canopy, and we did not find any permissible aspect.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And let him send them</b> that it can be permitted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rami bar Yeḥezkel.</b> The Gemara answers: He did not want to reveal that leniency to them, <b>because they are not</b> well versed <b>in Torah,</b> and they would not distinguish between permitted and prohibited methods of spreading the canopy.
He also told them: <b>Hops in a vineyard are</b> a forbidden <b>mixture</b> of diverse kinds. The Gemara asks: <b>And let him send them</b> the message that it is permitted <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Tarfon, as it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: With regard to <b>hops, Rabbi Tarfon says:</b> They do <b>not</b> constitute a prohibited mixture of <b>food crops in a vineyard, and the Rabbis say:</b> They constitute a forbidden mixture of <b>food crops in a vineyard. And we maintain</b> that <b>anyone who is lenient</b> with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of diverse kinds <b>in Eretz</b> Yisrael, even if the <i>halakha</i> is not ruled in accordance with his opinion, <b>the <i>halakha</i> is</b> ruled <b>in accordance with his</b> opinion <b>outside</b> of <b>Eretz</b> Yisrael, where the <i>halakhot</i> of diverse kinds apply only by rabbinic law. The Gemara explains: He did not reveal this leniency to them, <b>because they were not</b> well versed in <b>Torah.</b>
With regard to the matter of hops in a vineyard, the Gemara relates that <b>Rav would announce: One who seeks to sow hops in a vineyard, let him sow.</b> In contrast, <b>Rav Amram Ḥasida</b> would <b>administer lashes for</b> sowing hops in a vineyard.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Mesharshiya would give a <i>peruta</i> to a gentile child, and</b> the child would <b>sow</b> hops <b>for him.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And let him give</b> the <i>peruta</i> <b>to a Jewish child,</b> who is also not obligated in mitzva observance. The Gemara answers: <b>He</b> may <b>come to continue</b> this habit and violate the prohibition as an adult. The Gemara asks: <b>And let him give</b> the <i>peruta</i> <b>to an adult gentile.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He</b> may <b>come to confuse</b> him <b>with a Jew.</b>
With regard to a person who <b>died</b> on a Festival, <b>he sent them</b> in response: If a person <b>died</b> on a Festival, <b>neither Jews nor Arameans,</b> i.e., gentiles, <b>should attend to his</b> burial, <b>neither on the first day of a Festival, nor on the second day of a Festival</b> observed in the Diaspora.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rabbi Yehuda bar Sheilat say</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi said: There was an incident in the synagogue</b> of the settlement of <b>Maon on a Festival adjacent to Shabbat.</b> A person died,

Daf 139b

<b>and I do not know whether</b> the Festival occurred <b>before</b> Shabbat <b>or after</b> Shabbat. <b>And they came before Rabbi Yoḥanan, and he said to them: Let gentiles attend to his</b> burial.
<b>And</b> likewise, <b>Rava said:</b> If a person <b>died on the first day of a Festival, gentiles may attend to his</b> burial; <b>on the second day of a Festival</b> observed in the Diaspora, <b>Jews may attend to his</b> burial. <b>And</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even on the second day of the festival of Rosh HaShana, which is not so with regard to an egg.</b> With regard to an egg laid on the Festival, the two days of Rosh HaShana are considered one long day that cannot be disconnected. Therefore, in contrast to other two-day Festivals in the Diaspora, use of an egg laid on the first day of Rosh HaShana is prohibited on the second day. However, in deference to the dead, the Sages were lenient with regard to burial on the second day of Rosh HaShana. Why then did Rav Menashya prohibit the inhabitants of Bashkar from attending to the burial on a Festival? The Gemara answers: <b>Because they were not</b> well versed in <b>Torah.</b>
<b>Rabbi Avin bar Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gureya said: A person may wrap himself in a canopy and in its straps and go out to the public domain on Shabbat, and he need not be concerned</b> about violating the prohibited act of carrying out a burden.
The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the straps <b>different from that</b> which <b>Rav Huna</b> said? <b>As Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: One who goes out</b> unwittingly to the public domain <b>on Shabbat with a</b> four-cornered <b>garment that does not have the requisite ritual fringes attached is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> because the remaining fringes are not an integral part of the garment. Since they do not fulfill the mitzva, they are considered a burden that may not be carried into the public domain on Shabbat. The Gemara answers: There is a distinction between the cases. <b>Ritual fringes are significant relative to a garment and are not negated.</b> They are considered an independent entity that may not be carried out into the public domain. <b>These</b> straps of a canopy <b>are not significant and are negated.</b>
<b>Rabba bar Rav Huna said:</b> According to the Rabbis, who prohibit suspending a strainer on a Festival, <b>a person</b> may nevertheless <b>employ artifice</b> and circumvent the prohibition against suspending <b>a strainer</b> by taking it <b>on a Festival</b> and <b>suspending it</b> for the purpose of <b>pomegranates in it,</b> which is permitted. Once the strainer is suspended, he may <b>suspend it</b> in order to filter <b>sediment</b> from the wine, as even the Rabbis hold that on a Festival it is permitted to do this straining through a strainer that is already suspended. <b>Rav Ashi said: And this</b> is only permitted provided <b>that he</b> actually <b>suspended pomegranates in it</b> before using it to strain wine. It must be obvious to all that he used the strainer in a permitted manner.
The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> that <i>halakha</i> <b>different from that which was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may begin brewing beer during</b> the intermediate days of <b>a Festival for the purpose of</b> using it on <b>the Festival.</b> If it is <b>not for the purpose of the Festival, it is prohibited.</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> <b>both</b> with regard to <b>date beer and</b> with regard to <b>barley beer.</b> And <b>even though they have old</b> beer, <b>one may employ artifice and</b> say that he wishes to <b>drink from the new,</b> and that he is making beer on the intermediate days of the Festival for that purpose. Apparently, it is permitted to employ artifice even without actively demonstrating that one is performing the action for a permitted purpose. This contradicts the opinion of Rav Ashi.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> with regard to beer, <b>the matter is not evident.</b> When people see someone starting to brew beer, they have no way of knowing whether or not he has beer at home, and consequently, whether or not the action itself is prohibited in that case. However, <b>here,</b> with regard to a strainer, <b>the matter is evident,</b> as people see him suspending a strainer for wine, which is prohibited.
On the topic of artifice, the Gemara relates that <b>the Rabbis said to Rav Ashi: Master, observe this Torah scholar, and Rav Huna ben Rabbi Ḥayon is his name, and some say</b> that <b>his name is Rav Huna, son of Rabbi Ḥalvan, who took a slice of garlic and placed it in the spout of a barrel, and said: I intend to store it.</b> He thereby stopped the spout on Shabbat. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>he went and slept in a ferry</b> on the river, and the ferryman sailed the ferry across the river, <b>and he</b> thereby <b>crossed to the other side and inspected the fruit</b> of his vineyard. He said: <b>I intend to sleep.</b> In this way, he crosses the river by boat on Shabbat, which is a prohibited activity.
Rav Ashi <b>said to them: Are you speaking of artifice? This is artifice</b> employed to circumvent <b>a rabbinic</b> prohibition, <b>and a Torah scholar will not come to perform</b> the action <b><i>ab initio</i></b> without artifice. Therefore, there is no reason to prohibit him from doing so.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may pour water over sediment</b> that is in a strainer on Shabbat <b>so that it will become clear</b> and clean. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>one may filter wine through cloths and through an Egyptian basket</b> made from palm leaves. Since these liquids are drinkable even without filtering, doing so does not violate the prohibition of selecting.
<b>And</b> likewise, <b>one may place an egg in a mustard strainer</b> in order to separate the yolk from the egg-white, <b>and one may prepare <i>anumlin</i>,</b> a wine-based drink, <b>on Shabbat. Rabbi Yehuda says: On Shabbat</b> one may only make <i>anumlin</i> in a small <b>cup; on a Festival, in a</b> larger <b>vessel; and on the intermediate days of a Festival,</b> one may even prepare it <b>in a barrel. Rabbi Tzadok says:</b> There is no objective principle; rather, <b>it is all according to the</b> number of <b>guests;</b> if they are numerous, one may prepare a larger quantity of <i>anumlin</i>.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Ze’iri said: A person may place clear wine and clear water into a strainer on Shabbat, and he need not be concerned</b> over the prohibition of selecting, as the wine is drinkable even without this filtering. <b>However,</b> doing so with <b>murky</b> liquids, <b>no,</b> one may not strain them.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A person may stir a barrel of wine,</b> mixing <b>its wine and its sediment, and place it in a strainer on Shabbat, and he need not be concerned.</b> Apparently, it is permitted to place even murky wine in a strainer. <b>Ze’iri explained that</b> <i>baraita</i> and resolved the difficulty: <b>That was taught</b> with regard to wine <b>between the presses,</b> when the wine has yet to ferment and will remain murky even after filtering.
We learned in the mishna: <b>One may filter wine through cloths</b> on Shabbat. <b>Rav Shimi bar Ḥiyya said:</b> This is permitted <b>provided one does not make an indentation</b> in the cloth, making it into a receptacle, as one must diverge from the usual, weekday manner of performing this activity.
We also learned in the mishna: <b>And</b> it is permitted to filter wine on Shabbat <b>through an Egyptian basket. Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> the following caveat to that statement: It is permitted <b>provided one does not lift</b> the basket <b>a handbreadth from the bottom of the</b> lower <b>vessel.</b> This ensures that one performs the activity in an atypical manner (Rabbeinu Yona).
<b>Rav said: It is permitted</b> to place <b>this cover</b> that has holes for filtering <b>over half a barrel,</b> but <b>it is prohibited</b> to spread it <b>over the entire barrel,</b> in order that it not appear as though one is using it as a filter (Rabbeinu Ḥananel).
<b>Rav Pappa said: A person may not attach a bundle of straw to the mouth of a barrel’s spigot, because it appears like a strainer.</b>
The Gemara relates: The members <b>of Rav Pappa’s household would carefully pour beer from one vessel to another</b> so that the dregs from one vessel would not pass to the other. <b>Rav Aḥa from Difti said to Ravina: But there are the</b> final <b>drops,</b> which remain when one pours the beer into another vessel. When pouring the final drops from the dregs left in the vessel, one is in violation of the prohibition of selecting. He replied: In Rav Pappa’s house they would leave the final drops in the first vessel together with the dregs. They would not attempt to separate them, as <b>the last drops were not significant to the household of Rav Pappa,</b> because beer was always readily available in his house.
<b>And</b> we further learned in the mishna: <b>One may place an egg in</b> a mustard <b>strainer</b> on Shabbat in order to separate the yolk from the egg-white. The Sage, <b>Ya’akov Korḥa, taught</b> a reason for this:

Daf 140a

<b>Because it is only made to</b> enhance the <b>color</b> of the food. That does not negate the egg-white as significant food in the sense that it would be considered waste, and therefore, no actual selection is performed.
<b>It is stated:</b> With regard to <b>mustard that one kneaded on Shabbat eve, on the following day,</b> Shabbat, <b>Rav said: One may dissolve it</b> in wine or water <b>with a vessel, but not with</b> his <b>hand,</b> as using a vessel diverges from the normal method of preparation.
<b>Shmuel said to him:</b> Why may he not dissolve it <b>with</b> his <b>hand? Is that to say that he dissolves it with</b> his <b>hand every day?</b> If it is prepared in that manner, <b>it is donkey food.</b> Certainly dissolving by hand is not the manner in which mustard is prepared during the week. Therefore, dissolving mustard with a vessel should not be permitted on Shabbat. <b>Rather, Shmuel said</b> the opposite: <b>He may dissolve it with</b> his <b>hand</b> as a divergence from the typical method of preparation, <b>but he may not dissolve it</b> in the usual manner, <b>with a vessel.</b>
<b>It is stated</b> that <i>amora’im</i> from Eretz Yisrael also disputed this issue, as <b>Rabbi Elazar said: Both this and that,</b> dissolving by hand and with a vessel, <b>are prohibited;</b> while <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Both this and that are permitted. Abaye and Rava both said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the lenient opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b>
Subsequently, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan stood</b> and adopted <b>the opinion</b> of <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> and prohibited both methods of dissolving. <b>Rabbi Elazar stood</b> and adopted <b>the opinion</b> of <b>Shmuel,</b> who prohibited using a vessel but permitted it by hand. Given these stances, <b>Abaye and Rava both said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who prohibited both methods.
The Gemara relates: <b>Abaye’s mother,</b> actually his foster mother, <b>prepared</b> mustard <b>for him, and he did not eat</b> it. <b>Ze’eira’s wife prepared</b> mustard <b>for Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi,</b> her husband’s student, <b>and he did not eat</b> it. <b>She said to him: I made</b> this <b>for your rabbi and he ate</b> it, <b>and you do not eat</b> it? <b>Rava bar Shabba said: I was standing before Ravina, and they stirred</b> mustard <b>for him with the inner part of the garlic, and he ate</b> it.
<b>Mar Zutra said: The <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with any of these statements. Rather, it is in accordance with this</b> one, <b>as it was stated: Mustard that one kneaded on Shabbat eve, on the following day he may dissolve it either by hand or with a vessel, and he may place honey in it. And</b> when he dissolves it <b>he may not beat</b> it forcefully as would a craftsman, <b>but</b> he may <b>mix</b> it gently.
<b>Cress that one ground on Shabbat eve, on the following day he may place oil and vinegar in it, and add <i>amita</i> into</b> the mixture, <b>and he may not beat</b> it, <b>but</b> he may <b>mix</b> it. Similarly, <b>garlic that one crushed on Shabbat eve, on the following day, he may place beans and grits in it, and he may not pound, but mix, and he may add <i>amita</i> into</b> the mixture. The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>amita</i>?</b> The Gemara answers: It is <b>mint. Abaye said: Learn from this</b> that adding <b>mint is beneficial for cress.</b>
We also learned in the mishna: <b>One may prepare <i>anumlin</i> on Shabbat. The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may prepare <i>anumlin</i> on Shabbat. However, one may not prepare <i>aluntit</i>.</b> The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>And what is <i>anumlin</i> and what is <i>aluntit</i>? <i>Anumlin</i></b> is a drink, which is a mixture of <b>wine, honey, and pepper. <i>Aluntit</i></b> is a mixture of <b>aged wine and clear water and balsam, which they prepare</b> for use after bathing in <b>a bathhouse to cool down</b> from the heat of the bathhouse. It is prohibited to prepare it on Shabbat because it is a form of remedy.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> On <b>one occasion, I followed Mar Ukva into a bathhouse. When I exited, he came</b> and <b>gave me one cup of</b> this <b>wine to drink, and I felt</b> its chill <b>from the hairs on my head</b> down <b>to the toenails on my feet. And if he had given me another cup to drink,</b> and if I would have survived it, <b>I would have feared a reduction of my merit in the World-to-Come.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t Mar Ukva drink</b> this wine <b>every day?</b> How was he not harmed? The Gemara answers: <b>Mar Ukva was different, as</b> he <b>grew accustomed to it.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may not soak asafoetida in lukewarm water</b> to prepare a medicinal drink from it; <b>however, one may place</b> it <b>into vinegar</b> like a standard spice. <b>And one may not soak vetches</b> in water in order to separate them from their chaff, <b>nor rub them</b> by hand so as to remove their chaff. <b>However, one may place</b> them <b>into a sieve or into a basket,</b> and if the chaff gets removed, so be it.
<b>One may not sift straw in a sieve, and</b> similarly, <b>one may not place it on a high place so that that the chaff</b> blows away in the wind; <b>however, one may take</b> the straw <b>in a sieve and place it into the trough</b> of an animal, and one need not be concerned if the chaff is removed in the process.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>If one</b> unwittingly <b>soaked</b> asafoetida on Shabbat, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Adda from</b> the city of <b>Naresh interpreted it before Rav Yosef: If one soaked</b> it, <b>he is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering.</b>
<b>Abaye said to him: But if that is so,</b> if <b>one soaked a piece of meat in water,</b> would you <b>also</b> say <b>that he is liable?</b> No cooking was performed at all. <b>Rather, Abaye said:</b> It is prohibited <b>by rabbinic decree,</b> so <b>that one will not conduct</b> himself on Shabbat <b>in the manner in which he conducts</b> himself <b>during the week.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised a dilemma before Rabbi Yannai: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard <b>to soaking asafoetida in cold water</b> on Shabbat? Rabbi Yannai <b>said to him: It is prohibited.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan asked: <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>One may not soak asafoetida in lukewarm</b> water, indicating that <b>it is permitted</b> to soak it <b>in cold</b> water?
Rabbi Yannai <b>said to him: If so, that</b> is the difference <b>between my</b> knowledge <b>and yours,</b> as I am able to analyze the <i>halakha</i> more profoundly. In this case, the mishna is not a reliable source, as <b>the mishna</b> expresses <b>an individual</b> opinion. <b>As it was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One may neither soak asafoetida in hot</b> water <b>nor in cold</b> water. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: In hot</b> water it is <b>prohibited; in cold</b> water it is <b>permitted.</b> The mishna that does not prohibit cold water is in accordance with the individual opinion of Rabbi Yosei, but the <i>halakha</i> is not ruled based on that opinion.
The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> purpose <b>is</b> soaked asafoetida <b>prepared?</b> The Gemara answers: As a cure <b>for heaviness of the heart.</b> One who feels a pain in his heart drinks asafoetida. The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Aḥa bar Yosef felt heaviness in</b> his <b>heart. He came before Mar Ukva</b> to ask his advice. Mar Ukva <b>said to him: Go drink</b> the weight of <b>three shekels of asafoetida in three days. He went and drank on Thursday and Shabbat eve. In the morning, he went</b> and <b>asked in the study hall</b> if he could drink it on Shabbat. <b>They said to him:</b> The Sage <b>from the school</b> of <b>Rav Adda taught, and others say,</b> that the Sage <b>from the school</b> of <b>Mar bar Rav Adda taught: A person may drink</b> asafoetida on Shabbat, even <b>a <i>kav</i> or two <i>kav</i>, and he need not be concerned</b> about the decree prohibiting medicine, because asafoetida is drunk by healthy people as well.
Rav Aḥa bar Yosef <b>said to them:</b> With regard <b>to drinking, I have no dilemma. When I raised a dilemma,</b> it is with regard <b>to soaking</b> asafoetida; <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Avin said to them: There was an incident</b> that happened <b>with me, and I came</b> and <b>asked</b> that question <b>to Rav Adda bar Ahava, and he did not have</b> an answer for it. <b>I came</b> and <b>asked Rav Huna, and he said</b> that <b>this is what Rav is saying: One may soak</b> asafoetida <b>in cold water and place</b> it <b>in the sun</b> to warm it so it will be fit to drink.
The Gemara asks: Was Rav’s ruling <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>the one who permitted</b> soaking asafoetida in cold water? The Gemara answers: His ruling could be <b>even according to</b> the opinion of <b>the one who prohibited</b> doing so; <b>this</b> prohibition <b>applies only when he had not drunk</b> asafoetida <b>at all; however, here, since he drank</b> it <b>on Thursday and on Shabbat eve, if he does not drink on Shabbat he</b> would thereby be <b>endangered.</b> Therefore, he is permitted even to soak the asafoetida.
The Gemara relates another incident involving Rav Aḥa bar Yosef: <b>Rav Aḥa bar Yosef was walking</b> and <b>leaning on the shoulder of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak, his sister’s son.</b> Rav Aḥa <b>said to him: When we arrive at Rav Safra’s house, bring me in. When they arrived,</b> Rav Naḥman <b>brought him in.</b> Rav Aḥa then <b>raised a dilemma before</b> Rav Safra: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> pertaining <b>to rubbing</b> and thereby softening <b>a linen shirt</b> that is hard after being laundered <b>on Shabbat?</b> Does <b>one intend to soften the shirt, and one may well</b> do so? <b>Or perhaps he intends to generate whiteness</b> in the shirt, <b>and it is prohibited?</b> Rav Safra <b>said to him: He intends to soften, and one may well</b> do so.
<b>When</b> Rav Aḥa <b>emerged</b> and <b>came</b> from Rav Safra’s house, Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: What dilemma did the Master raise before</b> Rav Safra? Rav Aḥa <b>said to him: I raised</b> the following <b>dilemma before him: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> pertaining <b>to rubbing</b> and thereby softening <b>a linen shirt on Shabbat, and he said to me: One may well</b> do so.
Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak asked: <b>And let the Master raise</b> the same <b>dilemma</b> with regard to rubbing a <b>scarf.</b> He replied: <b>I did not raise the dilemma</b> with regard to a <b>scarf, as I raised it before Rav Huna. And he resolved it for me</b> and said that it is permitted (Rif).
Rav Naḥman asked him: <b>And let the Master resolve</b> the dilemma with regard to a shirt <b>from</b> Rav Huna’s ruling with regard to <b>a scarf.</b> Rav Aḥa <b>said to him:</b> There is a difference between the cases: <b>There,</b> in the case of a shirt, <b>it appears that one is generating whiteness,</b> whereas <b>here,</b> in the case of a scarf, <b>it does not appear that one is generating whiteness,</b> as people are not so particular with the whiteness of a scarf, and one’s intention is undoubtedly to soften it.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> With regard to <b>this linen shirt,</b>

Daf 140b
