<b>to remove it from the reed</b> upon which it is hanging <b>is permitted;</b> however, to remove <b>the reed from it is prohibited.</b> Since the reed is not a vessel, it is set-aside. <b>Rava said: And if it is</b> hung on <b>a weaver’s vessel, it is permitted</b> to remove the vessel as well. Although its primary function is for a prohibited labor, since it is a vessel, it may be moved.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: This bundle of vegetables, if it is suitable for animal food, it is permitted to move it</b> on Shabbat, <b>but if not, it is prohibited</b> to move it.
<b>Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said</b> as follows: In the case of <b>this hook,</b> if it is used for hanging <b>meat, it is permitted to move it,</b> as it is also suitable for other uses. However, if it is a hook for hanging <b>fish, it is prohibited</b> to move it, because it smells bad (Rabbeinu Ḥananel) and is used exclusively for fish.
<b>Rav Ketina said: One who stands</b> on a board <b>in the middle of a bed,</b> it is <b>as though he were standing on the stomach of a woman.</b> Just as he would certainly injure the woman, he will certainly break the bed (<i>ge’onim</i>). The Gemara comments: <b>And it is not</b> a correct <b>matter,</b> and it is not accepted as <i>halakha</i>.
On the topic of the bundle of vegetables, the Gemara cites additional advice on similar issues that <b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> to poor scholars experiencing difficulty earning a livelihood: <b>A student of a Torah academy who buys vegetables should buy long ones. A bundle is a bundle,</b> and they have a standard thickness at a standard price. <b>However, the</b> addition of <b>length</b> comes <b>on its own</b> for free.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda</b> also <b>said: A student of a Torah academy who buys reeds should buy long ones,</b> since <b>a bundle is a bundle.</b> Bundles of reeds have a standard thickness, <b>but the length</b> comes <b>on its own</b> for free.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda</b> further <b>said: A student of a Torah academy who does not have much bread should not eat a vegetable, because it whets</b> the appetite. <b>And Rav Ḥisda said: I neither ate a vegetable in my</b> state of <b>poverty, nor did I eat a vegetable in my</b> state of <b>wealth. In my poverty,</b> I did not eat a vegetable <b>because it whets</b> the appetite. <b>In my wealth,</b> I did not eat a vegetable <b>because I said: Where a vegetable enters, let meat and fish enter</b> instead.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda said: A student of a Torah academy who does not have much bread should not cut it into thin slices;</b> rather, he should eat what he has in one helping. <b>And Rav Ḥisda said: A student of a Torah academy who does not have much bread should not break</b> it for guests. <b>What is the reason? As he will not do so in a generous manner. And Rav Ḥisda said: Originally, I would not break</b> bread <b>until I placed my hand in the entire dish</b> to assure <b>that I found</b> that there was enough bread <b>to meet my needs.</b>
<b>And Rav Ḥisda</b> also <b>said: One who is able to eat barley bread and</b> nevertheless <b>eats wheat</b> bread <b>violates the prohibition against</b> wanton <b>destruction.</b> One who wastes resources is comparable to one who destroys items of value. <b>And Rav Pappa said: One who is able to drink beer and</b> nevertheless <b>drinks wine violates the prohibition against</b> wanton <b>destruction.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And this is not</b> a correct <b>matter,</b> as <b>the prohibition against destruction of one’s body takes precedence.</b> It is preferable for one to care for his body by eating higher quality food than to conserve his money.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda said: A student of a Torah academy who has no oil should wash,</b> i.e., smear himself, <b>with ditch water,</b> as the scum that accumulates in it is as useful as oil.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda said: A student of a Torah academy who buys meat should buy from the neck [<i>unka</i>], as there are three types of meat</b> there.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda said: A student of a Torah academy who buys a linen shirt [<i>kitonita</i>] should buy</b> it <b>from</b> those who work by <b>the river Abba, and should wash it every thirty days, so that it will last him for the twelve months of the year. And I guarantee</b> that the shirt will remain in good shape. The Gemara comments: <b>What is</b> the meaning of <b><i>kitonita</i>? A fine class [<i>kita</i>],</b> as fine clothing provide one entry into a well-dressed class of people.
<b>And Rav Ḥisda said: A student of a Torah academy should not sit on a new mat, as</b> its dampness <b>ruins his garments.</b>
<b>And Rav Ḥisda said: A student of a Torah academy should not give his clothes to his host to wash for him, as</b> that is <b>not proper behavior, for</b> the host <b>might see something on it,</b> such as signs of a seminal emission, <b>and he will be demeaned</b> in the eyes of his host.
After citing Rav Ḥisda’s recommendations to students, the Gemara cites his advice to his daughters. <b>Rav Ḥisda said to his daughters: Be modest before your husbands; do not eat bread before your husbands,</b> lest you eat too much and be demeaned in their eyes.
Similarly, he advised: <b>Do not eat vegetables at night,</b> as vegetables cause bad breath. <b>Do not eat dates at night and do not drink beer at night,</b> as these loosen the bowels. <b>And do not relieve</b> yourself <b>in the place where your husbands relieve</b> themselves, so that they will not be revolted by you.
<b>And when a person calls at the door</b> seeking to enter, <b>do not say: Who is it,</b> in the masculine form, <b>but</b> rather: <b>Who is it,</b> in the feminine form. Avoid creating the impression that you have dealings with other men.
In order to demonstrate the value of modesty to his daughters, Rav Ḥisda <b>held a pearl in one hand and a clod of earth in the other. The pearl he showed them</b> immediately, <b>and the clod of earth, he did not show them until they were upset</b> due to their curiosity, <b>and then he showed it to them.</b> This taught them that a concealed object is more attractive than one on display, even if it is less valuable.
We learned in the mishna: <b>One may not soak vetches</b> in water in order to separate them from their chaff. However, one may take the straw in a sieve and place it into the trough of an animal. The Gemara comments: <b>The mishna</b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this <i>tanna</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: One may not look at a sieve at all</b> on Shabbat, lest one come to violate the prohibited labor of selecting.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may sweep</b> hay <b>from before an animal that is being fattened, and one may move</b> hay <b>to the sides for an animal that grazes</b> on its own in the field (Rabbeinu Ḥananel); this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Dosa. And the Rabbis prohibit</b> doing so. <b>One may take</b> hay <b>from before this animal and place it before that animal on Shabbat.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Do <b>the Rabbis,</b> who are stringent, <b>disagree with the first clause</b> of Rabbi Dosa’s statement, <b>or</b> do <b>they disagree with the latter</b> clause of the mishna, <b>or</b> do <b>they disagree with both</b> clauses?
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from that which <b>was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> With regard to <b>both this,</b> hay placed before an animal set aside for fattening, <b>and that,</b> hay placed before an animal that grazes on its own, <b>one may not move</b> it <b>to the sides.</b> Apparently, the Rabbis rule stringently in both cases.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> is <b>with regard to a trough</b> formed <b>in the ground; however, with regard to a trough which is a vessel, everyone agrees that it is permitted.</b> The Gemara expresses surprise: <b>Is there anyone who permits</b> doing so in <b>a trough</b> formed in <b>the ground? Isn’t one leveling holes</b> and thereby performing the prohibited labors of building or plowing? <b>Rather, if it was stated, it was stated as follows: Rav Ḥisda said:</b> This <b>dispute</b> applies only <b>to a trough that is a vessel; however, with regard to a trough</b> formed in <b>the ground, everyone agrees that it is prohibited,</b> due to the concern lest one level holes.
We also learned in the mishna: <b>One may take</b> hay <b>from before</b> this <b>animal</b> and place it before that animal. <b>It was taught in one</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may take</b> hay <b>from before an animal whose mouth is fine and place it before an animal whose mouth is foul. And it was taught in another</b> <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may take</b> hay <b>from before an animal whose mouth is foul and place it in front of an animal whose mouth is fine.</b> There is an apparent contradiction between the two <i>baraitot</i>.
<b>Abaye said:</b> Both <b>this</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>and that</b> <i>baraita</i> hold that <b>one may take</b> hay <b>from before a donkey</b> and place it <b>before an ox.</b> However, <b>one may not take</b> hay <b>from before an ox</b> and place it <b>before a donkey.</b> The formulation of the <i>baraitot</i> can be explained as follows: <b>That which was taught: One may take</b> hay <b>from before an animal whose mouth is fine,</b> is referring to <b>a donkey,</b> and the reason the <i>baraita</i> says its mouth is fine is <b>because it has no spittle.</b> Therefore, the donkey does not dampen the remaining hay with its saliva. <b>And</b> the statement: <b>And one may place it before an animal whose mouth is foul,</b> is referring to <b>a cow,</b>

Daf 141a

<b>which has spittle.</b>
<b>And that which was taught</b> in the other <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may take</b> hay <b>from before an animal whose mouth is foul,</b> is referring to <b>a donkey.</b> Its mouth is foul <b>because it does not discern</b> between different foods <b>and</b> it <b>eats</b> everything. <b>And</b> the statement: <b>One may place it before an animal whose mouth is fine,</b> is referring <b>to a cow, which discerns</b> between different foods <b>and</b> only then <b>it eats.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>straw that is on top of a bed,</b> if a person wishes to lie on it, <b>he may not move it with his hand</b> to smooth it, as the straw is set aside for kindling; <b>rather, he may move it with his body.</b> Since moving straw with one’s body is not the usual manner, it is permitted. <b>And if</b> the straw <b>was</b> designated as <b>animal food, or a pillow or sheet was on it,</b> which would clearly indicate that the straw was placed on the bed so one could sleep on it, the straw is not considered set-aside, and <b>one may move it</b> even <b>with his hand.</b>
<b>A press which belongs to a homeowner, one may loosen it</b> on Shabbat. This press is used to dry and press clothing after laundering. One loosens it to remove clothing from it. <b>However, one may not press</b> clothing with it on Shabbat. <b>And</b> in the case of a press that <b>belongs to a launderer,</b> which is made specifically for pressing and requires professional expertise for its operation, <b>one may not touch it. Rabbi Yehuda says: If</b> the launderer’s press <b>was loosened</b> somewhat <b>on Shabbat eve, he may loosen it completely</b> on Shabbat <b>and remove</b> the garment.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to moving items that are set aside, the Gemara cites that which <b>Rav Naḥman said: This radish,</b> which was buried in the earth, if it was buried <b>from top to bottom,</b> with its wide end at the top and its narrow end at the bottom, <b>it is permitted</b> to remove it on Shabbat. When the radish is buried in that manner, one does not move the earth when he removes the radish. However, if the radish was buried in the earth <b>from bottom to top,</b> with the wide end at the bottom, <b>it is prohibited.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Abba said: They say</b> in <b>the school of Rav: We already learned</b> in the mishna that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman:</b> With regard to <b>straw on top of a bed, one may not move it with his hand, but he may move it with his body. And if it is animal food, or a pillow or sheet is on it, he may move it</b> even <b>with his hand. Conclude from here</b> that <b>moving</b> an item <b>in an atypical manner is not considered moving.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>conclude from here</b> that this is indeed the case.
The Gemara cites a somewhat similar case. <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> In the case of <b>these peppers, crushing them one by one with the handle of a knife is permitted.</b> However, crushing <b>two</b> at a time <b>is prohibited,</b> because it appears to be a prohibited labor. <b>Rava said: Since he alters</b> the manner in which he performs this activity, <b>even</b> crushing <b>many</b> at a time <b>is also</b> permitted.
<b>Rav Yehuda</b> also <b>said: One who bathes in water should first dry himself</b> immediately upon exiting, <b>and then ascend</b> to the coast, <b>lest he come to carry</b> the remaining drops of water on his body <b>four cubits in a <i>karmelit</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if there is a concern about carrying water, there should be concern <b>when one descends</b> into the water <b>as well.</b> In that case, <b>his force propels</b> water <b>four cubits</b> into the river, <b>and</b> it should be <b>prohibited.</b> The Gemara answers: With regard to movement that results from <b>his force in a <i>karmelit</i>,</b> the Sages <b>did not</b> issue a <b>decree.</b> Since one does not directly propel the water, but the water moves only as an extension of his motion, and since the river is a <i>karmelit</i>, and the prohibition to carry there is only a rabbinic law, the Sages did not issue a decree for one who descends into the water.
In a similar decree, <b>Abaye said, and some say</b> that it was stated by <b>Rav Yehuda:</b> If one has <b>mud on his foot, he may wipe it on the ground</b> on Shabbat, <b>but he may not wipe it on a wall.</b>
<b>Rava said: What is the reason</b> that he may <b>not</b> wipe it off <b>on a wall?</b> Is it <b>because it appears like building,</b> as he is adding plaster to the wall? <b>That is the building of a field laborer,</b> which is not an actual building. There is no concern in that case because in adding plaster to that building, one does not perform the prohibited labor of building.
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> On the contrary, <b>He may wipe it on a wall, but he may not wipe it on the ground.</b> This is due to the concern <b>lest one come to level holes</b> in the ground while wiping his foot.
<b>It is stated</b> that other <i>amora’im</i> disputed this issue. <b>Mar, son of Ravina, said: Both this,</b> wiping the mud on a wall, <b>and that,</b> wiping the mud on the ground, <b>are prohibited. Rav Pappa said: Both this and that are permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Mar, son of Ravina, with what may he wipe</b> his foot? The Gemara answers: Even according to his opinion, there is a permitted manner to clean his foot; <b>he wipes it on a beam</b> on the ground.
<b>Rava said: A person should not sit</b> on Shabbat right <b>at the entrance</b> to a closed alleyway where <b>a side post</b> is placed as a symbolic partition enabling one to carry inside the alleyway. The reason for this is that <b>perhaps an object will roll</b> into the public domain <b>and one will come to get it,</b> as there is no conspicuous demarcation between inside and outside the alleyway.
<b>And Rava</b> also <b>said</b> a similar decree: <b>A person may not position a barrel</b> on a dirt floor, <b>lest he come to level holes</b> in the ground while smoothing the surface upon which he is positioning the barrel.
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>Rava said: A person may not stuff a rag into the mouth of a jug [<i>shisha</i>]</b> on Shabbat, <b>lest he come to</b> violate the prohibition of <b>squeezing</b> liquid from the cloth.
<b>Rav Kahana said:</b> With regard to <b>mortar that is on one’s garment</b> on Shabbat, <b>one may rub it</b> off <b>from the inside, but one may not rub it</b> off <b>from the outside,</b> because that is comparable to the prohibited labor of laundering.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from that which we learned: With regard to <b>mortar that is on one’s shoe, he may scrape it</b> off <b>with the back of a knife</b> as a departure from the typical manner of scraping. <b>And</b> mortar <b>which is on one’s clothes, he may scrape</b> off <b>with his fingernail, as long as he does not rub it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What, is it not</b> saying <b>that he may not rub</b> it <b>at all?</b> The Gemara rejects that premise: <b>No,</b> it is saying <b>that he may not rub</b> it <b>from the outside, rather from the inside.</b>
<b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yannai said: One may scrape</b> mud off of <b>a new shoe</b> on Shabbat, <b>but not</b> off of <b>an old</b> shoe, because a layer of the shoe will be removed, which constitutes the prohibited labor of smoothing.

Daf 141b

<b>With what does one scrape it off? Rabbi Abahu said: With the back of a knife,</b> which is a departure from the typical manner of doing so.
<b>A certain Elder said to</b> Rabbi Abbahu: <b>Delete your</b> teaching <b>before this</b> statement <b>taught by Rabbi Ḥiyya: One may not scrape</b> at all; <b>neither a new shoe nor an old shoe, and one may not smear oil on one’s foot while it is inside the shoe or inside the sandal,</b> as the oil is absorbed by the leather of the shoe and strengthens it, which constitutes performance of the prohibited labor of tanning. <b>However, one may smear oil on his foot</b> in the typical manner <b>and place</b> it afterward <b>in a shoe or in a sandal,</b> and he need not be concerned that this oil will enhance the shoe leather. <b>And he may</b> likewise <b>smear oil on his entire body with oil and roll on a leather carpet, and</b> he need <b>not be concerned.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: They only taught</b> this in a case where he does so in order <b>to polish</b> the carpet. <b>But</b> if he does so <b>to tan</b> the carpet, <b>it is prohibited.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty: If he does so <b>to tan</b> the leather, it is <b>obvious</b> that it is prohibited, as tanning is a labor prohibited by Torah law. <b>And furthermore:</b> If he does so in order <b>to polish it, is there an opinion that permits</b> one to perform this act intentionally on Shabbat <i>ab initio</i>?
<b>Rather, if it was stated, it was stated as follows: Rav Ḥisda said: They only taught</b> that it is permitted to do so on Shabbat in a case where one smears <b>a measure</b> sufficient only <b>to polish it; however,</b> if one smears <b>a measure</b> sufficient <b>to tan it, it is prohibited,</b> even if he did not intend to tan the leather.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A small</b> person <b>may not go out in</b> a too <b>large shoe,</b> due to concern lest the shoe fall off and he will come to carry it in the public domain; <b>but he may go out in</b> a too <b>large cloak.</b> Even if it does not fit him properly, it will certainly not fall off.
<b>And a woman may not go out</b> on Shabbat <b>in a shoe that is torn on top,</b> lest she be mocked, remove it, and carry it on Shabbat. <b>And</b> a shoe of that kind <b>may not be used to perform <i>ḥalitza</i>,</b> as it is not a suitable shoe. <i>Ḥalitza</i> is performed by a widow bound in a levirate bond with her brother-in-law. <b>However, if she performed <i>ḥalitza</i></b> with it, <b>her <i>ḥalitza</i> is valid,</b> since ultimately it is a shoe.
<b>And one may not go out</b> on Shabbat wearing <b>a new shoe,</b> due to the concern that it will not fit properly, and then one will remove it and carry it. The Gemara comments: In <b>what case</b> did <b>they say</b> that one may not wear a new <b>shoe?</b> They said this <b>with regard to a woman’s shoe,</b> as women are very particular about having their shoes fit properly.
<b>Bar Kappara taught: They only taught</b> that she may not go out wearing a new shoe on Shabbat <b>if she did not</b> yet <b>go out</b> wearing <b>it for any</b> length of <b>time while</b> it was still <b>day. However, if she went out</b> wearing <b>it on Shabbat eve,</b> at which point she would have ascertained if it fits her, she is <b>permitted</b> to go out wearing it on Shabbat.
<b>One</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>taught: One may remove a shoe from the</b> shoemaker’s <b>last,</b> the frame on which a shoe is shaped, on Shabbat. <b>And another</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>taught</b> the opposite: <b>One may not remove it.</b> The Gemara explains that this is <b>not difficult: This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which prohibits doing so, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> and <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which permits doing so, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> Rabbi Eliezer and the Rabbis dispute the applicability of the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual purity and impurity in a similar case.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: <b>A shoe that</b> remains <b>on a last, Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> it <b>pure,</b> i.e., unable to become impure, as in his opinion the shoe is not yet complete, and therefore it is not yet a vessel and cannot become impure. <b>And the Rabbis deem it</b> capable of becoming <b>impure,</b> as in their opinion, the shoe is completed, and any vessel whose work is complete can become ritually impure. Correspondingly, the Rabbis, who hold that a shoe on a last is a completed vessel, hold that it may be moved on Shabbat. Rabbi Eliezer, who holds that it is an incomplete vessel, holds that it may not be moved.
The Gemara poses a question: <b>It works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rava, who said:</b> Moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function is for a prohibited</b> use, <b>whether for the purpose</b> of utilizing the object <b>itself</b> to perform a permitted action <b>or for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, is permitted. It is well</b> understood that one may move the last slightly while removing the shoe, since removing the shoe is considered utilizing the last’s place.
<b>However, according to Abaye,</b> who <b>said</b> that <b>for the purpose</b> of utilizing the object <b>itself</b> to perform a permitted action, <b>it is permitted;</b> however, <b>for the purpose of utilizing its place, it is prohibited, what can be said?</b> It is prohibited to move the last, which is clearly a utensil whose primary function is for a prohibited use. How is it possible to remove the shoe without moving the last?
The Gemara answers: <b>With what are we dealing here?</b> It is <b>with</b> a shoe placed <b>loosely</b> on the last, so the shoe can be removed without moving the last. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If it was loose, it is permitted.</b>
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> it is permitted is only <b>because it is loose; however,</b> if it is <b>not loose, no,</b> it is prohibited. <b>It works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Abaye,</b> who <b>said</b> that moving <b>an object</b> whose primary <b>function</b> is <b>for</b> a <b>prohibited</b> use <b>for the purpose</b> of utilizing the object <b>itself</b> to perform a permitted action <b>it is permitted;</b> however, <b>for the purpose of utilizing its place, it is prohibited</b> to move it. <b>It is well</b> understood that it is prohibited to move the last if the shoe is tightly attached to it.
<b>However, according to Rava, who said</b> that moving <b>an object whose</b> primary <b>function</b> is <b>for a prohibited</b> use, <b>whether for the purpose</b> of utilizing the object <b>itself</b> to perform a permitted action <b>or for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, is permitted, why</b> discuss <b>specifically</b> a case where it is <b>loose? Even if it were not loose,</b> it should <b>also</b> be permitted to move it.
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda in the name of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> and it is not a clarification of the opinion of the Rabbis. Although Rabbi Eliezer holds that the shoe is not yet completed, nevertheless, Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer that it is permitted to carry it. <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: If it was</b> already <b>loose</b> and no longer requires a last, <b>it is permitted</b> to move it, since it is a completed vessel and no longer needs the last to shape it.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>A person may take his son</b> in his hands on Shabbat, <b>and</b> even though there <b>is a stone,</b> which is a set-aside item, <b>in</b> the child’s <b>hand,</b> it is not prohibited to pick up the child. <b>And</b> it is permissible to take <b>a basket with a stone inside it</b> on Shabbat. <b>And one may move ritually impure <i>teruma</i>,</b> which may not be eaten and is set-aside, <b>with ritually pure</b> <i>teruma,</i> <b>as well as with non-sacred</b> produce.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One may even lift</b> a measure of <i>teruma</i> that was nullified from <b>a mixture of one hundred</b> measures of non-sacred produce <b>and one</b> measure of <i>teruma.</i> When a measure of <i>teruma</i> is mixed with non-sacred produce, if the non-sacred produce is one hundred times the measure of <i>teruma,</i> the <i>teruma</i> is nullified. However, the Sages instituted that one must remove an amount equivalent to that measure of <i>teruma</i> and give it to a priest. The remainder is considered non-sacred produce. Rabbi Yehuda permits removing that measure on Shabbat to render the mixture permitted to eat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rava said:</b> If one <b>carried out a living baby</b> to the public domain on Shabbat, <b>and</b> the baby had <b>a purse</b> that <b>was hanging</b> around <b>his neck, he is liable for</b> carrying out <b>the purse.</b> However, one who carried out <b>a dead baby, with a purse hanging</b> around <b>his neck, is exempt.</b>
Rava said: If one <b>carried out a living baby</b> to the public domain on Shabbat, <b>and a purse was hanging</b> around the baby’s <b>neck, he is liable for</b> carrying out <b>the purse.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And let him be liable for</b> carrying out the <b>baby as well.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Rava holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Natan, who said: A living being carries itself.</b> Therefore, one who carries a living being from one domain to another is not liable.
The Gemara asks: <b>And let</b> the <b>purse be negated relative to</b> the <b>baby;</b> and he should be exempt for carrying out the purse as well. <b>Didn’t we learn in a mishna:</b> One who carries out a <b>living</b> person <b>on a bed is exempt even for</b> carrying out <b>the bed, because the bed is secondary to</b> the person? The same should be said with regard to the purse, relative to the baby.
The Gemara answers: In a case where <b>a bed</b> is <b>relative to a living being,</b> the living being <b>negates it,</b> as the bed is needed to carry the person and is secondary to him. However, in a case where <b>a purse</b> is <b>relative to a baby,</b> the baby does <b>not negate it,</b> since it is independently significant.
And Rava said: One who carried out <b>a dead baby with a purse hanging</b> around the baby’s <b>neck is exempt.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And let him be liable for</b> carrying out the <b>baby.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rava holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said:</b> With regard to <b>any labor that is not needed for its own sake, one is exempt for</b> performing <b>it</b> on Shabbat. One who carries out a corpse does not do so because he needs it; rather, he does so for the sake of the corpse, i.e., to bury it or to move it from a degrading place. Therefore, he has not performed a labor prohibited by Torah law. Similarly, he is also exempt for carrying out the purse because due to his distress and mourning he negates the purse, as it is insignificant relative to the baby.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>A person may take his son</b> in his hands on Shabbat; <b>and</b> this is permitted even though there <b>is a stone in</b> the child’s <b>hand.</b> As it can be inferred from this mishna that the stone is negated relative to the child, why, then, is he liable in the case of a purse hanging around a live baby’s neck? Let the purse be negated relative to the baby. The Sages <b>of the school of Rabbi Yannai say:</b> You cannot infer from this mishna that the stone is negated and therefore it is permitted to move it. Rather, the mishna is referring <b>to a baby who has longings for his father.</b> It is permitted for the father to move the stone because if the father does not lift him, the baby might take ill.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b>

Daf 142a

<b>why</b> does the mishna refer <b>specifically</b> to moving <b>a stone?</b> The same should hold true <b>even</b> for <b>a dinar, as well. Why,</b> then, <b>did Rava say: They only taught</b> this in a case where the child has <b>a stone</b> in his hand; <b>however,</b> if the child has <b>a dinar</b> in his hand, it is <b>prohibited</b> to lift the child? The Gemara answers: Actually, lifting the child with a dinar should also be permitted. However, the Sages issued a decree prohibiting lifting the child with a dinar because with regard to a <b>stone, if it falls, his father will not come to bring</b> it. However, with regard to <b>a dinar, if it falls, his father will come to bring it.</b>
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rava: On Shabbat, one who carries out his clothes</b> to the public domain while they are <b>folded and placed on his shoulder, and his sandals</b> on his feet <b>and his rings in his hand,</b> not on his fingers, <b>is liable. And if he was wearing them, he is exempt</b> for all of them, as they are negated relative to him.
<b>One who carries out a person with his garments on him, and his sandals on his feet, and his rings on</b> the fingers of <b>his hands,</b> i.e., wearing all of his clothes and jewelry in the typical manner, <b>is exempt, whereas if he carried them out as they are,</b> i.e., the person was holding his clothes in his hands, <b>he is liable</b> for carrying out the clothes, just as Rava said.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And</b> it is permissible to take <b>a basket with a stone inside it</b> on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> may he do so? The <b>basket should be a base for a prohibited object,</b> and a base for a prohibited object is set-aside and may not be moved on Shabbat. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: Here, we are dealing with a basket full of fruit.</b> The basket is a base for permitted items as well, not only a base for the stone. The Gemara asks: Why may he move the basket and the stone? There is an alternative. <b>And let him throw the fruit and throw</b> the <b>stone</b> out of the basket, <b>and take</b> the fruit <b>in his hands,</b> and there will be no need to move the stone. The Gemara answers: <b>As Rabbi Elai</b> said that <b>Rav said</b> in a different context: It is referring <b>to fruits that become soiled</b> and ruined. <b>Here, too,</b> it is referring <b>to fruits that become soiled</b> and ruined if he throws them down.
The Gemara asks a question: <b>And let him shake them</b> until the stone is on one side of the basket, enabling him to throw the stone out of the basket. <b>Rav Hiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rava said: Here, we are dealing with a broken basket</b> with a hole, in which the <b>stone serves as a side of the basket</b> by sealing the hole. Therefore, he cannot throw it out of the basket.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And one may move</b> ritually impure <b><i>teruma</i></b> with ritually pure <i>teruma</i><b>. Rav Ḥisda said: They only taught</b> this in a case <b>where</b> the <b>pure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>is on the bottom and</b> the <b>impure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>is on the top.</b> In that case, if one wants to reach the pure <i>teruma,</i> there is no alternative to taking the impure <i>teruma</i> as well. <b>However,</b> if the <b>pure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>is on the top and the impure</b> <i>teruma <b>is</b></i> <b>on the bottom, he takes the pure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>and leaves the impure</b> <i>teruma.</i>
The Gemara asks a question: <b>And when</b> the <b>pure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>is on the bottom too, let him throw</b> the impure fruit, <b>and take</b> the pure fruit. <b>Rabbi Elai said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It is referring <b>to fruits that become soiled</b> and ruined, which cannot be thrown from the basket.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of Rav Ḥisda: <b>One may move impure <i>teruma</i> with the pure</b> <i>teruma</i> <b>and with the non-sacred produce, whether the pure is on the top and the impure is on the bottom, or whether the impure is on the top and the pure is on the bottom.</b> This is <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the statement of <b>Rav Hisda.</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Ḥisda</b> could have <b>said to you: The mishna,</b> which, according to Rav Ḥisda, permits moving the impure <i>teruma</i> with the pure <i>teruma</i> only when the pure <i>teruma</i> is on top, is referring to a case where he needs the basket <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself,</b> i.e., he wants to eat the fruit. The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case where he needs the basket <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place,</b> i.e., he wants to move the basket in order to vacate its place, in which case he may move it even if it contains impure <i>teruma</i> exclusively.
The Gemara asks: <b>What impelled Rav Ḥisda to establish the mishna</b> as referring specifically to a case where he needs the basket <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the object <b>itself?</b> Why can’t he explain the mishna as referring to any case?
<b>Rava said: The mishna</b> is <b>precise in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rav Ḥisda, <b>as it is taught in the latter clause,</b> the next mishna: With regard to <b>coins that are on a cushion, he shakes the cushion and</b> the coins <b>fall. And Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> They <b>only taught</b> that he may shake the cushion in a case where it is <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the cushion <b>itself. However,</b> if he needs it <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, he may move it,</b> even though the coins <b>are still on it. And from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause</b> of the mishna is referring to a case where he needs the cushion <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the cushion <b>itself, the first clause, too,</b> is referring to a case where he needs the basket <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the basket <b>itself.</b>
We learned in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One may even lift</b> a measure of <i>teruma</i> that was nullified from a mixture of one hundred measures of non-sacred produce and one measure of <i>teruma.</i> The Gemara asks: <b>And why</b> is it permitted? <b>Isn’t he rendering</b> the produce <b>fit</b> for consumption? The Sages issued a decree prohibiting the performance of any action that renders an item fit for use on Shabbat.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who <b>said: <i>Teruma</i></b> is considered as if it is <b>placed in its pure</b> unadulterated <b>state.</b> By lifting the measure of <i>teruma,</i> one does not render the rest of the mixture fit for consumption. It is considered as if the measure of <i>teruma</i> never intermingled with the rest of the produce and the measure that he lifted from the produce is the measure that fell into the produce.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna: A <b><i>se’a</i></b> of <b><i>teruma</i> that fell into less than one hundred</b> <i>se’a</i> of non-sacred produce causes it to become a prohibited <b>mixture.</b> The <i>teruma</i> is not nullified by the non-sacred produce. <b>And</b> then, if a <i>se’a</i> <b>from the mixture fell into a different place</b> with non-sacred produce, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The <i>se’a</i> from the original mixture <b>renders it a</b> prohibited <b>mixture</b> in the same way that <b>definite <i>teruma</i></b> would. This is due to the concern that the same <i>se’a</i> of <i>teruma</i> that fell into the first mixture never intermingled with the produce and subsequently fell into the second mixture. Therefore, it requires nullification like unadulterated <i>teruma.</i>
<b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The <i>se’a</i> from the original prohibited <b>mixture only renders</b> the second one <b>a</b> prohibited <b>mixture according to</b> the <b>proportion</b> of <i>teruma</i> in the entire mixture. In other words, the percentage of <i>teruma</i> in each <i>se’a</i> of the original mixture is representative of the percentage of <i>teruma</i> in the entire mixture. Only that measure of <i>teruma</i> need be nullified. Rabbi Eliezer’s opinion that the <i>teruma</i> in the mixture is not considered mixed, and it is considered as if it was placed in its pure unadulterated state, corresponds to Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion that by lifting the measure of <i>teruma,</i> one does not render the rest of the mixture fit for consumption.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Say that you heard</b> that Rabbi Eliezer expresses his opinion in this matter <b>to</b> rule <b>stringently. Did you hear</b> him express his opinion <b>to</b> rule <b>leniently?</b> He expressed concern lest the fallen <i>teruma</i> might not have intermingled with the non-sacred produce in the first mixture, and therefore, the second mixture is prohibited. However, he does not consider this a certainty.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>stated his</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as we learned</b> in a mishna: If a <b><i>se’a</i></b> of <b><i>teruma</i> fell into one hundred</b> <i>se’a</i> of non-sacred produce, <b>and he did not manage to lift</b> that <i>se’a</i> from the mixture <b>until another</b> <i>se’a</i> of <i>teruma</i> <b>fell</b> into the mixture, <b>this</b> entire mixture <b>is prohibited.</b> This is because two <i>se’a</i> of <i>teruma</i> are mixed with one hundred <i>se’a</i> of non-sacred produce. <b>And Rabbi Shimon permits</b> the mixture. Rabbi Shimon holds that the first <i>se’a</i> that fell into the produce is not mixed with it; it is placed in its unadulterated state. When the second <i>se’a</i> falls, it is also placed in its unadulterated state, and the two <i>se’a</i> do not join together.
The Gemara rejects this comparison: <b>And from what</b> does that conclusion ensue? <b>Perhaps there, they are disagreeing with regard to this: That the first <i>tanna</i> holds: Even though</b> two <i>se’a</i> of <i>teruma</i> <b>fell one after another, it is as</b> though <b>they fell at once, and this</b> <i>se’a</i> of <i>teruma</i> <b>fell into fifty</b> <i>se’a</i> of non-sacred produce, <b>and this</b> <i>se’a</i> of <i>teruma</i> <b>fell into fifty</b> <i>se’a</i> of non-sacred produce, which are insufficient to nullify <i>teruma.</i> <b>And Rabbi Shimon holds: The first</b> <i>se’a</i> <b>was nullified</b> immediately when it fell <b>into one hundred</b> <i>se’a,</i> <b>and this</b> <i>se’a</i> <b>will be nullified in one hundred and one</b> <i>se’a.</i> There is no connection between this dispute and the opinion that by lifting the measure of <i>teruma,</i> one does not render the rest of the mixture fit for consumption.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>stated his</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar. As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says:</b> One need not lift a <i>se’a</i> from the mixture in order to render it permitted to eat. It is sufficient if <b>he casts his eyes on this side</b> of the mixture and decides to separate a <i>se’a</i> from the produce on that side, <b>and he eats from a different side</b> of the mixture and physically separates the <i>se’a</i> later. Lifting a <i>se’a</i> from the mixture does not render the mixture fit for consumption, as it is permitted to partake from the mixture even without removing a <i>se’a</i><b>.</b> That is the rationale for Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar?

Daf 142b

<b>Doesn’t he disagree with him? As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: One may lift</b> a measure of <i>teruma</i> that was nullified from <b>a mixture of one hundred</b> measures of non-sacred produce <b>and one</b> measure of <i>teruma.</i> <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: One casts his eyes on this side</b> of the mixture and decides to separate a <i>se’a</i> from the produce on that side, <b>and he eats from a different side</b> of the mixture.
The Gemara rejects this: Fundamentally, the two <i>tanna’im</i> agree, but the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda is more far-reaching than</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar.</b> Rabbi Yehuda says that since thought is sufficient, lifting the <i>se’a</i> does not render the produce fit for consumption, and it is preferable if he lifts the <i>se’a</i> even on Shabbat.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>a stone,</b> which is set-aside on Shabbat and may not be moved, that was placed <b>on the mouth of a barrel, one tilts</b> the barrel <b>on its side, and</b> the stone <b>falls. If</b> the barrel <b>was among</b> other <b>barrels,</b> and the other barrels might break if the stone falls on them, <b>he lifts</b> the barrel to distance it from the other barrels, <b>and</b> then <b>tilts it on its side, and</b> the stone <b>falls.</b>
With regard to <b>coins that are on a cushion, he shakes the cushion and</b> the coins <b>fall. If there was bird dung</b> (<i>Arukh</i>) <b>on</b> the cushion, <b>he wipes it with a rag,</b> but he may not wash it with water because of the prohibition against laundering. If the cushion <b>was</b> made <b>of leather,</b> and laundering is not a concern, <b>he places water on it until</b> the bird dung <b>ceases.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Huna said</b> that <b>Rav said: They only taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to a stone in a case <b>where one forgets</b> the stone on the barrel. <b>However, if he places</b> the stone on the barrel, the barrel <b>becomes a base for a prohibited object,</b> which itself may not be moved throughout Shabbat.
We learned in the mishna: <b>If</b> the barrel <b>was among</b> other <b>barrels,</b> he lifts the barrel and then tilts it on its side, and the stone falls. The Gemara asks: <b>Who is</b> the <b><i>tanna</i></b> who holds <b>that any place that there is a prohibited</b> item <b>and a permitted</b> item, <b>we</b> may <b>exert</b> ourselves <b>for the permitted</b> item, but <b>we</b> may <b>not exert</b> ourselves <b>for the prohibited</b> item? One must exert himself to lift the barrel, and he may not remove the stone, although doing so would minimize his exertion.
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: It is Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. As we learned</b> in a mishna: With regard to <b>one who selects legumes on a Festival,</b> separating edible and inedible, <b>Beit Shammai say: He selects food and eats</b> it immediately and leaves the waste. <b>And Beit Hillel say: He selects in his usual manner,</b> and may even remove the waste and leave the food, <b>in his lap or in a large vessel.</b>
<b>And it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel said: In what</b> case <b>are these matters,</b> the dispute between Beit Shammai and Beit Hillel, <b>stated:</b> In a case <b>where the</b> quantity of the <b>food is greater than the</b> quantity of the <b>waste. However, if</b> the quantity of the <b>waste is greater than the</b> quantity of the <b>food, everyone agrees</b> that <b>one selects</b> the <b>food</b> to avoid the exertion involved in removing the waste, which itself may not be moved. The same is true here. He moves the barrel and not the stone, which is like waste.
The Gemara asks: <b>And here,</b> in the case of the barrel, <b>isn’t it comparable to</b> a case where <b>the food</b> is <b>greater than the waste,</b> as the barrel, which is food, is bigger and heavier than the stone. In addition, it is easier to move the stone. Nevertheless, he is not permitted to do so, in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel.
The Gemara answers: <b>Here, too, since if he wants to take</b> the wine, the <b>wine cannot be taken until he removes the stone,</b> the legal status of the stone is <b>like</b> that of <b>waste</b> which is <b>greater</b> in quantity <b>than the food,</b> and it cannot be likened to the case of selecting. In this case, he is unable to move the barrel without moving the stone.
We learned in the mishna: <b>If</b> the barrel <b>was among</b> other <b>barrels, he lifts</b> the barrel. <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i><b>: Rabbi Yosei says:</b> If <b>the barrel was placed in a storeroom</b> amongst other barrels, <b>or</b> if <b>glass vessels were placed beneath it,</b> preventing him from tilting the barrel and letting the stone fall, <b>he lifts</b> the barrel and moves it <b>to a different place, and he tilts it on its side, and</b> the stone <b>falls. And</b> then <b>he takes from</b> the barrel <b>what he needs, and restores</b> the barrel <b>to its place.</b>
We learned in the mishna: With regard to <b>coins that are on a cushion,</b> he shakes the cushion and the coins fall. <b>Rav Hiyya bar Ashi said</b> that <b>Rav said: They only taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> with regard to a case <b>where one forgets</b> the coins on the cushion; <b>however, if he places</b> the coins on the cushion, the cushion <b>becomes a base for a prohibited object</b> and may not be moved at all.
<b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: They only taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> that one shakes the cushion and the coins fall, when he needs the cushion <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the cushion <b>itself; but</b> if he needs it <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, he moves</b> the cushion <b>with</b> the coins <b>still on it. And likewise, Hiyya bar Rav from Difti taught</b> in a <i>baraita:</i> <b>They only taught</b> the <i>halakha</i> that one shakes the cushion and the coins fall, when he needs the cushion <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing the cushion <b>itself, but</b> if he needs it <b>for the purpose of</b> utilizing <b>its place, he moves</b> the cushion <b>with</b> the coins <b>still on it.</b>
We learned in the mishna: With regard to <b>coins that are on a cushion, he shakes</b> the cushion and the coins fall. <br><b>Rabbi Oshaya said:</b> If <b>one forgot a purse</b> of money <b>in the courtyard</b> on Shabbat eve, and he remembers it on Shabbat and wants to bring it into the house, <b>he places a loaf</b> of bread <b>or a baby on it and moves it.</b> The purse becomes a base for a permitted object and may be moved. <br><b>Rav Yitzhak said:</b> If <b>one forgot a brick in the courtyard, he places a loaf</b> of bread <b>or a baby on it and moves it.</b> <br><b>Rabbi Yehuda bar Sheila said</b> that <b>Rabbi Asi said: Once, they forgot a saddlebag [<i>diskaya</i>] full of coins in a main street, and they came and asked Rabbi Yoḥanan, and he said to them: Place a loaf or a baby on it, and move it.</b>
<b>Mar Zutra said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with all these statements in</b> the case of one who <b>forgets.</b> However, if one intentionally left an object, even a valuable object, on Shabbat eve, he may not employ artifice and move it the following day. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> If <b>one forgot,</b> he may <b>also not</b> employ artifice, <b>and they only stated</b> that movement by means of <b>a loaf or a baby for</b> the purposes of moving <b>a corpse alone.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Abaye</b> would <b>place a spoon on bundles</b> of produce, so that he would be able to move the bundles because of the spoon. <b>Rava</b> would <b>place a knife on a</b> slaughtered <b>young dove and move it. Rav Yosef said</b> mockingly: <b>How sharp is the <i>halakha</i> of children? Say</b> that <b>the Sages stated</b> this <i>halakha</i> only in a case <b>where one forgets,</b> but <b>did they say</b> that one may do so <b><i>ab initio</i>?</b>
<b>Abaye</b> explained his actions and <b>said: If not</b> for the fact that <b>I am an important person, why</b> would <b>I</b> need to place <b>a spoon on</b> the <b>bundles? Aren’t</b> the bundles themselves <b>suited to lean upon?</b> I could have carried the bundles without the spoon.
Similarly, <b>Rava said: If not</b> for the fact that <b>I am an important person, why</b> would <b>I</b> need to place <b>a knife on a young dove? Isn’t</b> the young dove itself <b>suited</b> to be eaten as <b>raw meat?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>The reason</b> that it is permitted to move the slaughtered dove <b>is</b> because <b>it is suited</b> to be eaten by a person as <b>raw meat;</b> but if <b>it is not suited</b> to be eaten by a person as <b>raw meat, no,</b> it may not be moved. <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>Rava holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> that on Shabbat it is prohibited to move food that was originally designated for human consumption and is now only suited for animal consumption?
<b>Didn’t Rava say to his attendant</b> on a Festival: <b>Roast a duck for me, and throw its intestines to the cat.</b> Moving the duck’s intestines was permitted in order to feed the cat. Similarly, moving the dove should have been permitted not because it is raw meat fit for consumption by a person, but because it is suited for consumption by a dog.

Daf 143a

The Gemara answers: <b>There, since</b> the intestines <b>will putrefy</b> as time passes, they are <b>on his mind from yesterday.</b> Since Shabbat eve, he has had in mind to feed them to the cat.
The Gemara adds: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> to say <b>that Rava holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, as Rava taught: A woman may not enter the wood storehouse to take a</b> wooden <b>poker</b> to stoke a fire on a Festival. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>a poker that broke, it is prohibited to kindle</b> a fire with <b>it on a Festival, as one may kindle</b> a fire on a Festival <b>with vessels</b> that may be moved, <b>but one may not kindle</b> a fire <b>with broken vessels</b> that broke during the Festival. They are set-aside and prohibited. <b>Conclude from it</b> that Rava ruled in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of set-aside.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Beit Shammai say: One</b> may <b>clear bones and shells</b> left from the Shabbat meal <b>from the table</b> with his hand. <b>And Beit Hillel say: One</b> may <b>remove the entire board [<i>tavla</i>]</b> that is the table surface <b>and shake</b> the bones and shells off of <b>it,</b> but he may not lift them with his hand because they are set-aside and may not be moved.
<b>One</b> may <b>clear</b> bread <b>crumbs from the table,</b> even if they are <b>less than an olive-bulk, and pea and lentil pods.</b> Even though it is not fit for human consumption, it may be moved <b>because it is animal fodder.</b>
With regard to <b>a sponge, if it has leather</b> as <b>a handle, one may wipe</b> the table <b>with it, and if not, one may not wipe</b> the table <b>with it</b> lest he come to squeeze liquid from it. <b>And the Rabbis say: Both this,</b> a dry sponge with a handle, <b>and that,</b> one without a handle, <b>may be moved on Shabbat and it does not become ritually impure.</b> A sponge is not among the substances that can become ritually impure, neither by Torah law nor by rabbinic decree.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> Reverse the two opinions, as <b>we have only Beit Shammai in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who prohibits moving set-aside items, <b>and Beit Hillel in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> who permits doing so.
We learned in the mishna: <b>One</b> may <b>clear</b> bread <b>crumbs from the table.</b> The Gemara comments: This <b>supports</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, as Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> With regard to <b>crumbs that are less than an olive-bulk, it is prohibited to destroy them by hand</b> in deference to the food.
We learned in the mishna: One may clear <b>pea</b> and lentil <b>pods</b> from the table on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>Whose</b> opinion <b>is it</b> in the mishna? It is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who is not</b> of the opinion that there is a prohibition of <b>set-aside.</b>
<b>Say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: With regard to <b>a sponge, if it has leather</b> as <b>a handle, one may wipe</b> the table <b>with it, and if not, one may not wipe</b> the table <b>with it. We have arrived at</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who <b>said: An unintentional act is prohibited,</b> as he certainly does not intend to squeeze liquid from the sponge.
The Gemara answers: <b>In that</b> case, <b>even Rabbi Shimon agrees</b> that it is prohibited, <b>as it is Abaye and Rava who both say: Rabbi Shimon agrees in</b> a case of: <b>Cut off its head will it not die,</b> i.e., inevitable consequences. When the prohibited outcome that ensues from the unintentional action is inevitable, Rabbi Shimon agrees that it is prohibited. Squeezing liquid from a sponge is an inevitable consequence.
With regard to <b>those pits of Aramean dates,</b> which are low quality and occasionally fed to animals, <b>it is permitted to move</b> the pits <b>since</b> they <b>are fit</b> for use <b>due to their origin,</b> i.e., the dates that were prepared as animal feed beforehand. <b>And</b> moving pits <b>of Persian</b> dates <b>is prohibited.</b> Since those dates are high quality and are not prepared for animals, their pits, too, are not prepared for that use.
The Gemara relates that <b>Shmuel</b> would <b>carry them along with bread.</b> The letters <b><i>shin</i>, <i>resh</i>, <i>nun</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>peh</i>, <i>zayin</i></b> are <b>a mnemonic</b> of the Sages whose opinions are cited below: Shmuel, Rabba, Huna, Ameimar, Sheshet, Pappa, Zekharya. The Gemara comments: <b>Shmuel’s</b> statement is consistent <b>with his reasoning, as Shmuel said: A man may perform all his needs with bread.</b> As long as the bread remains edible, he need not be concerned that he is treating the bread contemptuously.
<b>Rabba would move them along with a pitcher of water. Rav Huna, son</b> of <b>Rav Yehoshua, would render them a chamber pot with excrement.</b> The Sages permitted moving repulsive vessels. Here, too, he would collect all the date pits and then move them out because they were disgusting. <b>Rav Ashi said to Ameimar: And may one create a chamber pot with excrement <i>ab initio</i>?</b> Although the Sages permitted moving a container of excrement, they did not permit creating one <i>ab initio</i> so that it would be permitted to move it.
<b>Rav Sheshet would dispose of</b> the pits <b>with his tongue. Rav Pappa would dispose of them behind the divan</b> on which he sat while eating because he did not want to move them in another manner. <b>They said about Rabbi Zekharya ben Avkolas that he would turn his face</b> toward the <b>back of the divan and dispose of them.</b>

Daf 143b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> From <b>a barrel</b> of wine or oil <b>that broke</b> on Shabbat, <b>one may rescue from it food</b> sufficient for <b>three meals, and</b> one may also <b>say to others: Come and rescue</b> food <b>for yourselves.</b> This applies <b>provided that one does not soak up</b> the wine or oil with a sponge or rag, due to the prohibition of squeezing. <b>One may not squeeze fruits</b> on Shabbat in order <b>to extract liquids from them. And if</b> liquids <b>seeped out on their own, it is prohibited</b> to use them on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If</b> the fruits were designated <b>for eating,</b> the liquid <b>that seeps from them</b> on Shabbat <b>is permitted.</b> There is no concern lest one purposely squeeze liquids from fruit that is designated for eating. <b>And if</b> the fruits were originally designated <b>for liquids,</b> the liquids <b>that seep from them</b> on Shabbat <b>are prohibited.</b> In the case of <b>honeycombs that one crushed on Shabbat eve, and</b> honey and wax <b>seeped</b> from them <b>on their own</b> on Shabbat, <b>they are prohibited, and Rabbi Eliezer permits</b> using them.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>It was taught</b> in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One may not soak up wine and</b> one <b>may not collect oil</b> in his hand, so <b>that one will not conduct</b> himself on Shabbat <b>in the manner that he conducts</b> himself <b>during the week. The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one’s fruit was scattered in a courtyard</b> on Shabbat, <b>one may collect them from hand to hand,</b> a little at a time, <b>and eat</b> them immediately. <b>However,</b> one may <b>not</b> collect them <b>into a basket or into a box,</b> so <b>that one will not conduct</b> himself on Shabbat <b>in the manner that he conducts</b> himself <b>during the week.</b>
We learned in the mishna: <b>One may not squeeze fruit</b> on Shabbat, and the liquid that seeps from fruit on its own is prohibited. Rabbi Yehuda, however, distinguishes between fruit that is designated for eating, in which case the liquid that seeps out on its own is permitted, and fruit that is designated for juicing, in which case the liquid that seeps out on its own on Shabbat is prohibited. <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: Rabbi Yehuda concedes to the Rabbis with regard to olives and grapes.</b> Even if they were designated for eating, the liquid that seeps from them on its own on Shabbat is prohibited. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Since they are</b> generally used <b>for squeezing, one had in mind</b> from the outset that these would serve that purpose as well, even if he designated them for eating. <b>And Ulla</b> said that <b>Rav said: Rabbi Yehuda was in disagreement even with regard to olives and grapes. And Rabbi Yoḥanan said: The <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda with regard to other fruits, and the <i>halakha</i> is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda with regard to olives and grapes.</b>
<b>Rabba said</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said</b> as follows: <b>Rabbi Yehuda would concede to the Rabbis with regard to olives and grapes, and the Rabbis would concede to Rabbi Yehuda with regard to other fruit.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Abba:</b> If it is true that they agree with each other, <b>with regard to what do they disagree? He said to him: When you find</b> it, i.e., examine this matter and you will find areas in which they disagree. <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: It stands to reason that they disagree with regard to mulberries and pomegranates,</b> which have intermediate status, between olives and grapes, which are always considered designated for juicing, and other fruits, which are not.
<b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>olives from which one squeezed oil and grapes from which one squeezed wine</b> before Shabbat (<i>Tosafot</i>), and <b>he</b> subsequently <b>brought them into</b> his house, <b>whether</b> he brought them in <b>for</b> use as <b>food or whether</b> he brought them in <b>for</b> use of their <b>liquids, that which seeps from them</b> on its own on Shabbat <b>is prohibited.</b> However, with regard to <b>mulberries from which one squeezed water,</b> i.e., juice, <b>and pomegranates from which one squeezed wine,</b> i.e., pomegranate juice, <b>and he brought them into</b> the house, if he originally <b>brought them in for</b> use as <b>food, what seeps from them is permitted. And</b> if he brought them in <b>for</b> use of their <b>liquids, and</b> similarly, if he brought them in <b>without specifying</b> his intention, <b>what seeps from them is prohibited.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. And the Rabbis say: Whether</b> he brought them into the house <b>for</b> use as <b>food or whether</b> he brought them in <b>for</b> use of their <b>liquids, what seeps from them is prohibited.</b>
The Gemara questions this <i>baraita</i>: <b>And does Rabbi Yehuda maintain that</b> in the case of <b>undesignated</b> fruit that was not designated for a specific purpose, the liquid that seeps on its own <b>is prohibited? Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna: <b>A woman’s milk</b> is considered a liquid and therefore <b>renders</b> food susceptible to <b>ritual impurity,</b> whether the milk was expressed <b>volitionally and</b> whether it was expressed <b>unvolitionally?</b> On the other hand, <b>milk of an animal only renders</b> food susceptible to <b>ritual impurity</b> if it was milked <b>volitionally</b> but not if it drips out on its own.
<b>Rabbi Akiva said: It is an <i>a fortiori</i> inference</b> that this is incorrect: <b>Just as a woman’s milk, which is intended only for young</b> children, is considered a liquid and <b>renders</b> food susceptible to <b>ritual impurity</b> both if the milk is expressed <b>volitionally and</b> if it is expressed <b>unvolitionally, the milk of an animal, which is intended for both young and old, is it not logical that it should render</b> food susceptible to <b>ritual impurity, both</b> if it was expressed <b>volitionally and</b> if it was expressed <b>unvolitionally? They said to him</b> that this <i>a fortiori</i> inference can be refuted in the following way: <b>If a woman’s milk</b> renders food susceptible to <b>ritual impurity</b> even when the milk was expressed <b>unvolitionally, as</b> the status of <b>the blood of her wound is</b> also that of a liquid that renders food susceptible to <b>ritual impurity,</b> that does not mean that <b>the milk of an animal</b> renders food susceptible to <b>ritual impurity</b>

Daf 144a

if it was expressed <b>unintentionally, as the blood of its wound is ritually pure,</b> meaning that it does not render food susceptible to ritual impurity. Rabbi Akiva <b>said to them: I am</b> more <b>stringent with regard to milk than with regard to blood, as</b> if <b>one milks</b> an animal <b>for medicinal purposes,</b> the milk renders food susceptible to <b>ritual impurity, and</b> if <b>one lets</b> blood <b>for medicinal purposes,</b> the status of the blood is not that of a liquid and is <b>ritually pure,</b> in the sense that it does not render food susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>They said to him:</b> The case of <b>baskets of olives and grapes will prove</b> that there is a difference between liquids that emerge of his own volition and those that do not, <b>as liquid that seeps from them volitionally</b> renders food susceptible to <b>ritual impurity.</b> However, liquid that seeps from them <b>unvolitionally is ritually pure,</b> i.e., it does not render food susceptible to ritual impurity. Apparently, liquid renders food susceptible to ritual impurity only if it emerged of its own volition.
The Gemara analyzes the terms of that mishna: <b>What, is it not</b> true that the term <b>volitionally</b> is referring to a situation where one <b>is pleased</b> with the emergence of liquids, <b>and</b> the term <b>unvolitionally</b> is referring <b>to</b> an <b>indeterminate</b> situation, where he expressed no preference? This leads to a conclusion with regard to our original topic of discussion. <b>Just as</b> in the case of <b>olives and grapes, which are</b> primarily <b>designated for squeezing</b> in order to extract oil and wine respectively, if liquid leaked from them <b>unvolitionally,</b> in the sense that one did not intend for the liquid to emerge, <b>it has no</b> significance and does not render food susceptible to ritual impurity; in the case of <b>mulberries and pomegranates, which are not</b> typically <b>designated for squeezing, is it not all the more so</b> that liquid that seeps from them unvolitionally does not render food susceptible to ritual impurity?
The Gemara refutes this argument: <b>No,</b> the term <b>volitionally</b> is referring even to a situation where one’s preference <b>is indeterminate,</b> and the term <b>unvolitionally</b> is referring to a situation where <b>one revealed his mind-set</b> explicitly and <b>said: I am not pleased</b> if liquid emerges. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>baskets of olives and grapes are different; since</b> the liquid that leaks from them <b>stands to be lost, one renounces it from the outset.</b> No proof can be cited from this mishna. Generally speaking, however, the legal status of liquids that are not designated to be lost from the outset is that of liquids, even if one did not express pleasure with their emergence.
<b>We have found</b> in the <i>baraita</i> cited above that <b>Rabbi Yehuda conceded to the Rabbis with regard to olives and grapes,</b> that liquid that seeps from them on its own on Shabbat, both volitionally and unvolitionally, is prohibited during Shabbat. <b>From where do we</b> conclude that <b>the Rabbis concede to Rabbi Yehuda with regard to other fruits</b> and distinguish between fruits designated for eating and those designated for juicing? <b>As it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may squeeze</b>

Daf 144b

<b>plums and quinces and crab apples. However,</b> one may <b>not</b> squeeze <b>pomegranates,</b> because they are typically squeezed for their juice, as people <b>from the house of Menashya bar Menaḥem would squeeze pomegranates</b> during the week. Apparently, the Rabbis concede to Rabbi Yehuda with regard to fruits other than pomegranates and mulberries.
The Gemara objects: <b>And from where</b> is it ascertained that this <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of the Rabbis? Perhaps it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>And let</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>also be</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda: Say that you heard</b> that according to <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> juice that <b>seeped out on its own</b> is permitted; <b>did you hear</b> that <b>squeezing</b> it is permitted <b><i>ab initio</i>? Rather, what have you to say? Since they are not</b> fruits that are generally <b>designated for squeezing,</b> it is permitted to squeeze them <b>even <i>ab initio</i>.</b> That being the case, <b>even if you say</b> the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> the same reasoning applies: <b>Since they are not</b> generally <b>designated for squeezing,</b> it is permitted to squeeze them <b>even <i>ab initio</i>.</b> Even the Rabbis would permit squeezing fruits such as plums, quinces, and crab apples. Since the <i>baraita</i> does not permit squeezing pomegranates, <b>learn from it</b> that the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> The Gemara concludes: Indeed, <b>learn from it.</b>
It was taught in the <i>baraita</i> cited above that people <b>from the house of Menashya bar Menaḥem would squeeze pomegranates</b> on weekdays. This indicates that it is typical for people to squeeze pomegranates, and therefore it is prohibited to do so on Shabbat. <b>Rav Naḥman said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the practice of the people <b>from the house of Menashya bar Menaḥem.</b> In other words, squeezing pomegranates is considered typical, and therefore it is prohibited on Shabbat.
<b>Rava said to Rav Naḥman:</b> Is <b>Menashya ben Menaḥem a <i>tanna</i></b> that you say the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his opinion? <b>And if you say</b> that Rav Naḥman meant that the <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with this <i>tanna</i>, who held in accordance with</b> the practice of the people <b>from</b> the house of <b>Menashya ben Menaḥem,</b> there is still room to ask: Does it make sense that <b>because he held in accordance with</b> the practice of the people from the house of <b>Menashya ben Menaḥem, the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with his opinion?</b> Does <b>Menashya ben Menaḥem</b> constitute <b>the majority of the world?</b> Since most people do not squeeze pomegranates, the practice of the people from the house of Menashya ben Menaḥem should be irrelevant relative to the typical practice of others.
Rav Naḥman answered: <b>Yes,</b> in cases of this kind, halakhic rulings are based even on practices that are not universal, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna that addresses the prohibition of diverse kinds, particularly forbidden food crops in a vineyard. With regard to one who <b>maintains thorns in a vineyard, Rabbi Eliezer says: He rendered</b> the crops a <b>forbidden</b> mixture of food crops in a vineyard. <b>And the Rabbis say: Only</b> a crop <b>that people</b> typically <b>maintain renders</b> a vineyard <b>forbidden. And Rabbi Ḥanina said: What is the reason for</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer? Because in Arabia they maintain the thorns of the fields</b> to feed them <b>to their camels.</b> There, thorns are treated as a bona fide crop. According to this opinion, since thorns are maintained in one place, they are considered to be significant everywhere. The same reasoning applies to the issue of juicing pomegranates.
The Gemara rejects this answer: <b>Is this comparable? Arabia</b> is <b>a place,</b> and a custom practiced in an entire country is significant. <b>Here,</b> with regard to the practice of the house of Menashya bar Menaḥem, who was an individual, <b>his opinion</b> is rendered <b>irrelevant by</b> the opinions of <b>all other men.</b>
<b>Rather, this is the reason</b> for Rav Naḥman’s statement: It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Ḥisda,</b> as <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> In the case of <b>beets that one squeezed and</b> then <b>placed</b> their juice <b>in a ritual bath,</b> the juice <b>invalidates the ritual bath</b> if it causes a <b>change of appearance.</b> Any liquid that causes the water of a ritual bath to change color invalidates the ritual bath. Rav Ḥisda elaborated: <b>Aren’t</b> beets typically <b>not designated for squeezing? Rather, what have you to say? Since he ascribed it significance, it is</b> considered <b>a liquid. Here, too,</b> with regard to pomegranates, <b>since he ascribed it significance, it is</b> considered <b>a liquid.</b> Even if one person ascribes significance to a liquid, it assumes for him the status of a liquid and is prohibited on Shabbat.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> that the reason Rav Ḥisda ruled that beet juice invalidates the ritual bath is <b>because it is something with which one may not make a ritual bath <i>ab initio</i>,</b> and there is a principle: <b>Anything with which one may not make a ritual bath <i>ab initio</i>,</b> i.e., anything other than water, snow, or ice, <b>invalidates the ritual bath</b> if it causes a <b>change of appearance,</b> even if it does not have the legal status of a liquid.
<b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there,</b> in tractate <i>Mikvaot</i>: If <b>wine or vinegar or</b> olive <b>discharge,</b> i.e., the liquid that comes from olives but is not oil, <b>fell into</b> a ritual bath <b>and changed its appearance,</b> the ritual bath is <b>invalid.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i></b> who holds <b>that</b> olive <b>discharge is</b> considered <b>liquid? Abaye said: It is Rabbi Ya’akov, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Ya’akov says:</b> The legal status of olive <b>discharge is like</b> that of <b>a liquid. And what</b> is the <b>reason</b> the Sages <b>said that</b> olive <b>discharge that emerges at the outset,</b> before one begins to press the olives for their oil, <b>is ritually pure,</b> meaning that it does not render food susceptible to ritual impurity? It is not because the olive discharge is not considered a liquid but <b>because he does not want its existence;</b> the owner would prefer that the olive discharge not yet emerge and instead emerge together with and mix with the oil.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The legal status of olive <b>discharge is not like</b> that of <b>a liquid. And what</b> is the <b>reason</b> the Sages <b>said that the</b> olive <b>sap that emerges from the bale of the olive press</b> after the olives were pressed <b>is</b> capable of rendering foods susceptible to become <b>ritually impure? Because it is impossible</b> that <b>it</b> will <b>not</b> contain <b>drops of oil</b> that come with it from the olives.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between them?</b> They both agree that olive discharge that emerges at the outset is incapable of rendering food susceptible to ritual impurity and that olive discharge that emerges from the bale of the olive press is capable of rendering food susceptible to ritual impurity. The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> a practical difference <b>between them</b> with regard to olive discharge <b>that comes after extensive pressing;</b> according to Rabbi Ya’akov, it is considered a liquid and renders food susceptible to ritual impurity, and according to Rabbi Shimon, it is not a liquid and does not render food susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>Rava said:</b> The reason that olive discharge invalidates a ritual bath is not because it is a liquid, but rather, <b>because it is something with which one may not make a ritual bath</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>and it</b> therefore <b>invalidates a ritual bath</b> if it causes a <b>change of appearance.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Shmuel said: A person may squeeze a cluster of grapes</b> on Shabbat <b>into a pot</b> with food in it, and it is not considered squeezing a liquid but rather adding one food to another; <b>however,</b> he may <b>not</b> squeeze the liquid <b>into an</b> empty <b>bowl. Rav Ḥisda said: From the statement of our Rabbi,</b> Shmuel, <b>we learn</b> that <b>one may milk a goat into a pot</b> of food on Shabbat, because it is not considered to be the manner of squeezing that is prohibited as a subcategory of the labor of threshing; <b>however,</b> one may <b>not</b> do so <b>into an</b> empty <b>bowl.</b> The Gemara deduces: <b>Apparently, he holds</b> that <b>liquid that comes into food</b> is not considered liquid, but rather, <b>it is food.</b>
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raised an objection</b> from the following mishna: In the case of <b>a <i>zav</i> who milks a goat, the milk is ritually impure</b> whether or not the <i>zav</i> actually touched it, as a <i>zav</i> renders items ritually impure simply by moving them, or being moved by them, even without direct contact. <b>And if you say</b> that <b>liquid that comes</b> directly <b>into food is food</b> and not liquid, in the case of one who milked directly into a pot of food, the milk should be considered food. The <i>halakha</i> is that food cannot become ritually impure unless it is rendered susceptible to ritual impurity through contact with a liquid. <b>With what</b> liquid was this milk <b>rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity?
The Gemara answers: <b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> in a different context, that a particular statement is referring to <b>the</b> first <b>drop, which is smeared on the top of the teat</b> in order to moisten it and facilitate nursing or milking, <b>here too,</b> it is rendered susceptible to ritual impurity by means <b>of the drop which is smeared on the top of the teat.</b> This drop was not intended to fall into the pot of food and is therefore considered a liquid and renders the food susceptible to ritual impurity.
<b>Ravina raised an objection</b> based on what we learned in another mishna: In the case of <b>one who is ritually impure</b> with impurity imparted by <b>a corpse who squeezed olives or grapes</b>

Daf 145a

in the <b>exact</b> amount of <b>an egg-bulk,</b> the liquid <b>is ritually pure.</b> Even though the ritually impure individual touched the food, less than an egg-bulk of food cannot become ritually impure. Once the first drop of liquid is squeezed out, less than an egg-bulk of food remains, and it cannot render the liquid impure. By inference, if he squeezed <b>more than an egg-bulk,</b> the liquid <b>is ritually impure. And if you say</b> that <b>liquid that comes into food is</b> considered <b>food, in what</b> manner was this liquid <b>rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity? <b>He raised the objection and he resolved it:</b> It is referring to a case <b>where</b> one <b>squeezes into an</b> empty <b>bowl,</b> in which case the juice is considered a liquid.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> The question of whether liquid squeezed directly from one food into another is considered liquid or food is <b>parallel to</b> the following dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b> We learned in a mishna: In the case of <b>one who smooths</b> bread before baking it <b>by</b> squeezing <b>grapes</b> onto it, the bread <b>was not rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: It was rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. <b>What, do they not disagree about this?</b> One <b>Sage held that liquid that comes into food is food,</b> and therefore it cannot render bread susceptible to ritual impurity, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage held</b> that <b>it is not food</b> but rather a liquid, and therefore it renders the bread susceptible to ritual impurity.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> that the disputes are not necessarily parallel; it can be explained that <b>everyone agrees that liquid that comes into food is not food, and here they disagree with regard to liquid that goes to waste,</b> as the liquid that dripped onto the bread eventually evaporates due to the heat of the oven. One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>held</b> that <b>it is</b> nonetheless <b>a liquid</b> and therefore can render the bread susceptible to ritual impurity, <b>and</b> one <b>Sage held that it is not a liquid. And</b> they disagree in <b>the dispute between these <i>tanna’im</i>, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who cuts olives with soiled,</b> i.e., ritually impure, <b>hands,</b> the olives <b>are rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity through the liquid that comes from them, and his hands render the olives ritually impure. If he cut them in order <b>to dip them in salt,</b> the olives <b>are not rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity, because if that liquid emerged from the olives against the owner’s will, the liquid cannot render food susceptible to ritual impurity.
If he was cutting in order <b>to ascertain whether his olives have reached</b> the stage of ripeness at which they are fit <b>to be harvested or not, they are not rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: They are rendered susceptible</b> to ritual impurity. <b>What, do they not disagree with regard to this?</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yehuda, <b>held</b> that <b>liquid</b> that emerges when one tests the olives but <b>which stands to</b> go to <b>waste, is liquid</b> and renders food susceptible to ritual impurity; <b>and</b> one <b>Sage held that it is not liquid</b> and does not render food susceptible to ritual impurity.
