But <b>these,</b> the souls of the middling people, <b>have rest, and these,</b> the souls of the wicked, <b>do not have rest. Rav Mari said:</b> Even the bodies of <b>the righteous will</b> not be preserved and will <b>become dust, as it is written: “And the dust returns to the earth as it was”</b> (Ecclesiastes 12:7).
The Gemara cites a related story: <b>The diggers who were digging in Rav Naḥman’s land</b> came upon a grave, and <b>Rav Aḥai bar Yoshiya,</b> who was buried there, <b>rebuked them. They came and said to Rav Naḥman: A</b> deceased <b>person</b> just <b>rebuked us.</b> Rav Naḥman <b>came and said to</b> the person buried there: <b>Who is the Master,</b> i.e., who are you? He <b>said to him: I am Aḥai bar Yoshiya.</b> Rav Naḥman <b>said to him:</b> How has your body been preserved? <b>Didn’t Rav Mari say</b> that <b>the righteous will turn to dust?</b> Rav Aḥai <b>said to him: And who is Mari, whom I do not know?</b> Why should I be concerned about what he says? Rav Naḥman <b>said to him:</b> Even without Rav Mari’s statement, <b>there is an</b> explicit <b>verse which is written: “And the dust will return to the earth as it was”</b> (Ecclesiastes 12:7).
Rav Aḥai <b>said to him: Whoever taught you</b> the book of <b>Ecclesiastes did not teach you</b> the book of <b>Proverbs, for it is written</b> in Proverbs: “A tranquil heart is the life of the flesh, <b>but envy is the rotting of the bones”</b> (Proverbs 14:30). This means that <b>anyone who has envy in his heart</b> during his lifetime, <b>his bones rot</b> in the grave, and <b>anyone who does not have envy in his heart, his bones do not rot.</b>
Rav Naḥman <b>touched him</b> and <b>saw that he had substance.</b> Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: Let the Master arise</b> and come <b>into my house.</b> Rav Aḥai <b>said to him: You have revealed</b> that <b>you have not even studied Prophets,</b> and it is not just the Writings of which you are ignorant, <b>for it is written: “And you shall know that I am the Lord when I open up your graves</b> and lift you up from your graves, My nation” (Ezekiel 37:13). As long as the dead have not been instructed to leave their graves, leaving of their own accord is prohibited.
Rav Naḥman once again asked Rav Aḥai about the preservation of the flesh, and <b>he said: But it is written: “For you are dust and you shall return to dust”</b> (Genesis 3:19), so why has your body not turned into dust? He <b>said to him: That</b> verse applies to the righteous only <b>one hour before the resurrection of the dead,</b> so that they, too, may be created anew (Maharsha).
<b>A certain apostate</b> once <b>said to Rabbi Abbahu: You say</b> that <b>the souls of the righteous are stored beneath the Throne of Glory,</b> but if so, <b>how did the oracle woman raise up Samuel using necromancy</b> if his soul was no longer in this world? Rabbi Abbahu <b>said to him: There, it was within twelve months</b> of his death, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: For <b>a full twelve months</b> a deceased person’s <b>body remains and his soul ascends and descends,</b> such that it is sometimes in this world with its body. <b>After twelve months, the body ceases</b> to exist

Daf 153a

<b>and his soul ascends</b> to its place beneath the Throne of Glory, <b>and does not descend anymore.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda, son of Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat, said in the name of Rav: From a person’s eulogy it is apparent whether or not he has a share in the World-to-Come.</b> If the listeners are pained and brought to tears during the eulogy, it is clear that the person was righteous. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? Didn’t Rav say to Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat: Stir</b> the hearts of those gathered <b>during</b> my <b>eulogy, for I will be standing there</b> and listening to your words? Even a person as great as Rav needed to give instructions about his eulogy. The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> for <b>this</b> statement, which maintains that those who merit a share in the World-to-Come can be identified by their eulogies, is referring to a situation in which <b>they</b> attempt to <b>stir</b> the listener <b>and he is stirred;</b> while <b>that</b> statement is referring to a situation in which <b>they</b> attempt to <b>stir</b> the listener <b>and he is not stirred.</b> That is an indication that the deceased person was not righteous.
<b>Abaye said to Rabba: In the case of the Master,</b> i.e., Rabba, <b>whom all of the inhabitants of</b> his city, <b>Pumbedita, hate, who will be stirred during his eulogy? He said to him: It is sufficient for me</b> if <b>you and Rabba bar Rav Ḥanan</b> are stirred.
<b>Rabbi Elazar raised a dilemma</b> before <b>Rav: Which</b> type of person <b>has a share in the World-to-Come?</b> He <b>said to him:</b> We can derive this from the verse: <b>“And your ears shall hear a word behind you, saying: This is the path, walk on it, when you turn to the right or to the left”</b> (Isaiah 30:21). In other words, if people eulogize one by saying that others should follow in his path, he must have a share in the World-to-Come. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina said: Anyone with whom our Rabbis are pleased</b> has a share in the World-to-Come. In interpreting the verse: <b>“And the eulogizers walk about the marketplace”</b> (Ecclesiastes 12:5), <b>the people of the Galilee say: Do things</b> that you will want people to say at your eulogy <b>in front of your bier. The people of Judea say: Do things</b> that you want people to say at your eulogy <b>behind your bier.</b> The Gemara remarks: <b>And they do not disagree;</b> this <b>Sage</b> expressed it according to the norm <b>in his place, and</b> this <b>Sage</b> expressed it differently according to the norm <b>in his place.</b> The custom in the Galilee was that the eulogizers would stand before the bier and the custom in Judea was that eulogizers would stand behind the bier.
<b>We learned there</b> in a mishna that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Repent one day before your death. Rabbi Eliezer’s students asked him: But does a person know the day</b> on which <b>he will die? He said to them: All the more so</b> this is a good piece of advice, and <b>one should repent today lest he die tomorrow; and</b> by following this advice <b>one will spend his entire life in</b> a state of <b>repentance. And</b> King <b>Solomon also said in his wisdom: “At all times your clothes should be white, and oil shall not be absent from upon your head”</b> (Ecclesiastes 9:8), meaning that a person always needs to be prepared.
Similarly, <b>Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said</b> the following story as <b>a parable</b> to this lesson: The situation is comparable <b>to a king who invited his servants to a feast and did not set a time for them</b> to come. <b>The wise among them adorned themselves and sat at the entrance to the king’s house. They said: Is the king’s house missing anything</b> necessary for the feast? Certainly the king could invite them at any moment. <b>The fools among them went to</b> attend to <b>their work</b> and <b>said: Is there such thing as a feast without</b> the <b>toil</b> of preparing for it? While the feast is being prepared, we will attend to other matters.
<b>Suddenly, the king requested</b> that <b>his servants</b> come to the feast. <b>The wise among them entered before him adorned</b> in their finest clothes, <b>and the fools entered before him dirty. The king was happy to greet</b> the <b>wise ones and angry to greet</b> the <b>fools.</b> The king <b>said: These</b> wise servants <b>who adorned themselves for the feast shall sit and eat and drink,</b> but <b>these</b> fools <b>who did not adorn themselves for the feast shall stand and watch.</b> There is a similar outcome for people who think that their day of death and judgment is far away and do not prepare themselves for it.
<b>Rabbi Meir’s son-in-law said in the name of Rabbi Meir:</b> If the punishment for those who did not prepare themselves in advance was merely to stand and watch, it would not be severe enough because <b>they also look like servants</b> at the feast, which is not such a disgraceful punishment. <b>Rather, these and these,</b> both groups of people, <b>sit</b> at the feast. <b>These</b> wise and righteous people <b>eat, and these</b> wicked fools <b>are hungry; these</b> righteous people <b>drink, and these</b> wicked people <b>are thirsty, as it is stated:</b> “Therefore, <b>thus said the Lord,</b> God: <b>Behold, My servants shall eat and you shall be hungry; behold, My servants shall drink and you shall be thirsty;</b> behold, My servants shall rejoice and you shall be ashamed. <b>Behold, My servants shall sing from a joyous heart and you shall scream from a pained heart”</b> (Isaiah 65:13–14).
<b>Alternatively,</b> the verse quoted above can be interpreted in the following way: <b>“At all times let your clothes be white”; this</b> is clothing that contains <b>ritual fringes [<i>tzitzit</i>],</b> which are white. <b>“And oil shall not be absent from upon your head”; these</b> words hint to <b>phylacteries,</b> which are worn on the head.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One</b> who was traveling on Shabbat eve and <b>night fell,</b> and Shabbat began while he was still <b>en route, gives his</b> money <b>pouch to a gentile</b> traveling with him. <b>And if there is no gentile with him he places it on the donkey.</b> Once <b>he reached the outer courtyard</b> of the city, where belongings can be securely placed, <b>he takes the vessels that may be moved on Shabbat</b> off the donkey. With regard to the vessels <b>that may not be moved on Shabbat, he unties the ropes</b> that attach his bags to the donkey, <b>and the bags</b> of vessels <b>fall on their own.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna: One who was traveling on Shabbat eve and night fell, and Shabbat began while he was still en route, gives his money pouch to a gentile. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that <b>the Sages permitted him to give his pouch to a gentile?</b> Is it not prohibited for a Jew to ask a gentile to perform a prohibited labor on Shabbat? The Gemara answers: <b>The Sages maintain</b> that <b>a person does not restrain himself</b> when faced with losing <b>his money. If you do not permit him</b> to give his pouch to a gentile, <b>he will come to carry four cubits in a public domain,</b> thereby violating a Torah prohibition.
<b>Rava said:</b> This allowance to give the pouch to a gentile is <b>specifically</b> with regard to <b>his</b> own <b>pouch, but</b> in the case of <b>a lost object</b> that he found, <b>no,</b> it was not permitted. The Gemara asks: That is <b>obvious,</b> as <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>His pouch,</b> and nothing else. The Gemara answers: Rava specified this <b>lest you say</b> that <b>the same is true even</b> with regard to <b>a lost object,</b> that one may give it to a gentile on Shabbat, and <b>the</b> mishna <b>taught</b> the case of <b>his pouch</b> merely because it is the <b>manner</b> in <b>which the matter</b> typically occurs. Therefore, Rava <b>teaches us</b> that the mishna is in fact establishing a <i>halakha</i> restricted to his pouch. The Gemara comments: <b>And we only said</b> that this allowance does not apply to a lost object when <b>it did not come into his possession</b> before Shabbat. <b>However,</b> if the object already <b>came into his possession</b> before Shabbat, <b>its</b> legal status is <b>like</b> that of <b>his pouch.</b>
<b>Some state</b> this dilemma in a different manner. <b>Rava raised a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>a lost object that came into his possession</b> before Shabbat, <b>what is</b> the ruling? Is the <i>halakha</i> that <b>since it</b> already <b>came into his possession, its</b> legal status is <b>like</b> that of <b>his pouch? Or perhaps, since he did not exert</b> himself to acquire <b>it, its</b> legal status is <b>not like</b> that of <b>his pouch.</b> Since he expended no effort, he would be capable of restraining himself even when faced with losing it. Therefore, there is no need for the Sages to permit him to give it to a gentile. The Gemara concludes: <b>Let</b> this dilemma <b>stand</b> unresolved.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And if there is no gentile with him</b> he places it on the donkey. The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> is specifically because <b>there is no gentile with him;</b> if <b>there is a gentile with him, he gives it to the gentile</b> and does not place it on a donkey. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: With regard to <b>a donkey</b> belonging to a Jew, <b>you are commanded with regard to its rest</b> on Shabbat. With regard to <b>a gentile, you are not commanded with regard to his rest</b> and no Torah prohibition is being violated.
The Gemara teaches an additional <i>halakha</i>: If there was no gentile with him but there was <b>a donkey, a deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor,</b> meaning someone under thirteen years old, <b>one places it on the donkey,</b> but <b>one neither gives it to the deaf-mute, nor the imbecile, nor the minor. What is the reason</b> for this? Although they are not obligated to fulfill mitzvot, <b>these</b> are <b>people,</b> but <b>this</b> donkey <b>is not a person.</b> It is preferable to place it on the donkey rather than give it to a person. And if <b>a deaf-mute and an imbecile</b> were with him, he gives it to <b>the imbecile.</b> If <b>an imbecile and a minor</b> were with him, he gives it to <b>the imbecile.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised</b> before the Sages: If <b>a deaf-mute and a minor</b> were with him, <b>what</b> is the ruling? To whom does he give his pouch? The Gemara answers: <b>According to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer you have no dilemma.</b> Rabbi Eliezer holds that a deaf-mute has a greater degree of halakhic intelligence than does a minor, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer: The <i>teruma</i> of a deaf-mute</b> that he separated from his produce

Daf 153b

<b>does not vacate</b> its sanctified status and assume <b>non-sacred</b> status <b>because his</b> status with regard to halakhic intelligence <b>is uncertain.</b> According to Rabbi Eliezer, a deaf-mute apparently has a degree of halakhic intelligence, and therefore has a greater obligation in mitzvot than a minor.
<b>When you raise this dilemma,</b> the issue <b>is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, as we learned</b> in a mishna: There are <b>five</b> categories of people who <b>may not separate <i>teruma</i></b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>and if they separated <i>teruma</i>, their <i>teruma</i> is not</b> considered <b><i>teruma</i>. They are: A deaf-mute, an imbecile, and a minor, and one who separates <i>teruma</i></b> from produce <b>that is not his; and a gentile who separated <i>teruma</i></b> from the produce <b>of a Jew, even with his permission, his <i>teruma</i> is not</b> considered <b><i>teruma</i></b> because a gentile cannot be appointed as an agent to separate <i>teruma</i>, and all the more so he cannot separate <i>teruma</i> on his own. The deaf-mute and the minor have the same legal status according to the Rabbis; therefore, a dilemma arises as to which of them should receive the pouch on Shabbat.
<b>What</b> should one do? Should <b>he give it to the deaf-mute</b> because <b>the minor</b> will eventually <b>reach the stage of</b> halakhic <b>intelligence,</b> when he will be obligated to observe the mitzvot, and it is preferable that he not become accustomed to desecrating Shabbat? <b>Or perhaps he</b> should <b>give it to the minor,</b> because if he is allowed to give it to the <b>deaf-mute,</b> onlookers <b>will mistake him for an adult with</b> halakhic <b>intelligence</b> and conclude that it is permitted to give his pouch to an adult? In that case it would be preferable to give the pouch to a minor, as it is clear that he is not obligated in mitzvot. Regarding this <i>halakha</i>, <b>some say</b> that <b>he gives it to the deaf-mute</b> and <b>some say</b> that <b>he gives it to the minor,</b> and no definitive conclusion was reached.
The Gemara asks: If <b>there is neither a gentile nor a donkey nor a deaf-mute nor an imbecile nor a minor there, what</b> should one do? <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said: There was another manner</b> of dealing with this situation, <b>and the Sages did not want to reveal it.</b> The Gemara asks: To <b>what</b> was Rabbi Yitzḥak referring when he said: <b>There was another manner?</b> The Gemara answers: The alternative is to <b>move</b> the pouch in increments, <b>each less than four cubits,</b> and thereby carry the object in the public domain without violating a Torah prohibition. The Gemara asks: <b>Why didn’t the Sages want to reveal this</b> alternative? The Gemara answers that it is <b>due to</b> the verse: <b>“It is the glory of God to conceal a thing; but the glory of kings is to search out a matter”</b> (Proverbs 25:2). <b>And here, what glory of God is there</b> in concealing this option? The Gemara answers: If one were to move the pouch in this manner, there is concern <b>lest</b> he <b>come to carry</b> the object <b>four cubits in the public domain.</b>
The ruling that one should give his pouch to a gentile rather than carry in increments each less than four cubits was among the eighteen decrees issued in accordance with the position of Beit Shammai, enumerated in the first chapter of tractate <i>Shabbat</i>. Sages of later generations disagreed with regard to these eighteen decrees: <b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: On that day they</b> measured with <b>a large <i>se’a</i></b> measurement, i.e., they did well to issue these decrees, which construct a fence around the Torah to prevent its violation. <b>Rabbi Yehoshua said: On that very day they</b> measured with <b>a minimal <i>se’a</i>,</b> i.e., because these decrees are difficult to observe, they not only will lead people to violate the decrees, but to violate Torah prohibitions as well.
<b>It was taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: The Sages articulated <b>a parable</b> to illustrate the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer. To what is</b> this <b>matter similar?</b> It is similar <b>to a basket full of squash and gourds into which a person places mustard seeds.</b> Just as the basket also <b>holds</b> the mustard, the decree will also endure. They also articulated <b>a parable</b> to illustrate the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua: To what is</b> this <b>matter similar?</b> It is similar <b>to a large bowl full of honey into which</b> one <b>places pomegranates and walnuts.</b> Just as the bowl <b>expels</b> the honey from inside it, so too, the decree will cause Torah prohibitions to be violated.
We learned in the mishna that <b>the Master said:</b> When <b>there is no gentile with him, one places</b> the pouch <b>on the donkey.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t he</b> thereby <b>driving a</b> laden <b>animal? And the Torah stated:</b> “And the seventh day is Shabbat for the Lord your God, <b>you shall not perform any manner of labor,</b> neither you, nor your son, nor your daughter, nor your slave, nor your maidservant, nor your animal, nor your stranger that is within your gates” (Exodus 20:10). He is causing the prohibited labors of carrying from domain to domain and of carrying in the public domain by placing the pouch on his donkey on Shabbat.
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said: One places</b> the pouch <b>on</b> the donkey <b>as it is walking,</b> because in doing so he does not commit a full-fledged violation of the Torah prohibition against carrying out from domain to domain on Shabbat. A full-fledged violation consists of lifting and placing the object. Because the animal was already walking when the pouch was placed on it, the animal performed no lifting. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t it impossible</b> that the animal <b>will not stand</b> in its place at some point after it begins walking, either in order <b>to urinate or to defecate, and</b> when it begins walking again <b>there is</b> both an act of <b>lifting and</b> an act of <b>placing</b> performed by the donkey. The Gemara answers: There is a solution to that problem. <b>When</b> the donkey <b>is walking, one places</b> the pouch <b>on it,</b> and <b>when it stands, he removes it.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> one could <b>even</b> place the pouch <b>on another</b> Jew <b>as well,</b> as there would be neither lifting nor placing.
<b>Rav Pappa said: Any</b> action <b>that</b> if one performs it <b>by himself, he is liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering</b> for it, if he performed it <b>by means of another,</b> he is <b>exempt but</b> it is still <b>prohibited</b> for him to do so. And <b>any</b> action <b>that</b> if performed by means of <b>another,</b> he is <b>exempt</b> from bringing a sin-offering <b>but</b> it is still <b>prohibited</b> for him to do so, performing the action <b>by means of his donkey is permitted <i>ab initio</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> One who was traveling on Shabbat eve and <b>his package was resting on his shoulder</b> as night fell, <b>he runs beneath it,</b> i.e., with his package on his shoulder, <b>until he reaches his home.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>Specifically,</b> one <b>runs</b> until he reaches home; <b>however,</b> walking <b>a little bit</b> at a time, <b>no,</b> he may not do so.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Since,</b> when walking in the usual manner, <b>he has no conspicuous</b> reminder that it is Shabbat, there is concern lest <b>he come to</b> perform the acts of <b>lifting and placing</b> by stopping to rest on his way home. The Gemara asks: <b>Ultimately, when he reaches his home, it is impossible that</b> he will <b>not</b> stop and <b>stand a bit, and</b> at that point, <b>he</b> will have performed the prohibited labor of <b>carrying</b> the package <b>from the public domain into the private domain</b> of his house. The Gemara answers: This is referring to a case in which he does not place the package in the typical manner when he reaches his home. Rather, <b>he throws it</b> down <b>in an unusual manner.</b> Since he did not perform the action in the typical manner, it is not prohibited by Torah law.
With regard to the topic of driving a donkey on Shabbat, the Gemara cites that which <b>Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> With regard to <b>one who drives his</b> laden <b>animal on Shabbat,</b> if he does so <b>unwittingly, he is liable</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering,</b> and if he does so <b>intentionally, he is liable</b> to be executed by <b>stoning.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for this ruling? <b>Rava said that the verse states: “You shall not perform any manner of labor, neither you…nor your animal”</b> (Exodus 20:10). From this he derived: <b>His animal</b> is <b>similar to himself; just as he,</b> if he performed a prohibited labor on Shabbat <b>unwittingly, he is liable</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering,</b> and if he did so <b>intentionally, he is liable</b> to be executed by <b>stoning, so too,</b> if he performed a prohibited labor by means of <b>his animal,</b> if he did so <b>unwittingly, he is liable</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering,</b> and if he did so <b>intentionally, he is liable</b> to be executed by <b>stoning.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> There are <b>two</b> possible <b>responses</b> with which this <b>statement</b> can be rejected. <b>One</b> is, <b>as it is written: “You shall have one law [<i>Torah</i>] for him that does unwittingly…</b>and for the proselyte who resides among them. <b>But the soul that does with a high hand,</b> whether he be home-born or a stranger, he blasphemes the Lord; and that soul shall be cut off from among his people” (Numbers 15:29–30). This verse is referring to one who worships idolatry unwittingly. <b>The entire Torah is juxtaposed to idolatry,</b> and from that juxtaposition it is derived: <b>Just as</b> in the case of <b>idolatry</b> one is liable only <b>when he performs an action with his body,</b> i.e., himself, <b>here too,</b> in the case of Shabbat, he is liable <b>only if he performs an action with his body,</b> i.e., himself. He is not liable for an action performed by his animal.
<b>And furthermore,</b> with regard to the statement that if he drove the laden donkey he is liable to be executed by stoning, <b>we learned</b> in a mishna that enumerates those who are executed by stoning: <b>One who desecrates Shabbat by</b> performing <b>a matter that for its unwitting</b> performance one is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, and for its intentional</b> performance one is <b>liable</b> to be executed by <b>stoning. By inference, there is</b> another <b>matter,</b> another prohibition, <b>that for which its unwitting</b> performance one is <b>not liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, and for which its intentional</b> performance one is <b>not liable to be executed by stoning.</b>
<b>And what is that</b> Torah prohibition? Is it not the <b>prohibition</b> of <b>driving a</b> laden <b>animal?</b> Apparently, driving a laden animal and other labors performed by means of animals on Shabbat are not punishable by stoning, even though they are prohibited by Torah law. The Gemara rejects this second proof. <b>No,</b> this is not necessarily so. It is possible that the mishna is referring to the prohibition of Shabbat <b>limits, and</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva,</b> who holds that it is a Torah prohibition but that one is neither liable to bring a sin-offering for violating it unwittingly, nor is he liable to be executed by stoning for violating it intentionally. <b>And</b> likewise, it may refer to the prohibition of <b>kindling</b> a fire on Shabbat <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> who holds that it is not punishable by stoning but by lashes, like other prohibitions.

Daf 154a

<b>Rav Zevid taught</b> this <b>as follows. Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> With regard to <b>one who drives his</b> laden <b>animal on Shabbat,</b> if he does so <b>unwittingly, he is not liable</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering,</b> and if he does so <b>intentionally, he is liable</b> to be executed by <b>stoning.</b>
<b>Rava raised an objection</b> based on that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who desecrates Shabbat by</b> performing <b>a matter that for its unwitting</b> performance one is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> then <b>for its intentional</b> performance one is <b>liable</b> to be executed by <b>stoning.</b> The Gemara explains: By inference, for <b>a matter that for its unwitting</b> performance one is <b>not liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, for its intentional</b> performance one is <b>not liable</b> to be executed by <b>stoning.</b> This contradicts Rami bar Ḥama’s statement.
The Gemara answers: <b>Was it taught</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: By inference, for a matter that for its unwitting performance one is <b>not liable</b> to bring a sin-offering, for its intentional performance one is not liable to be executed by stoning? The <i>baraita</i> can be understood differently, <b>and this is what it is saying:</b> With regard to <b>a matter that for its unwitting</b> performance one is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, for its intentional</b> performance one is always <b>liable</b> to be executed by <b>stoning.</b> However, <b>there is</b> also <b>a matter that for its unwitting</b> performance one is <b>not liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering,</b> and nevertheless, <b>for its intentional</b> performance one is <b>liable to be executed by stoning. And what is that</b> case? It is the case of <b>driving a</b> laden <b>animal.</b>
<b>Rava, the brother of Rav Mari bar Raḥel,</b> cites a different opinion with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of driving a laden animal on Shabbat, <b>and some say</b> that he was <b>the father of Rav Mari bar Raḥel</b> and stated this <i>halakha</i>. As an aside, the Gemara comments: <b>According to the latter version</b> above, that Rava was the father of Rav Mari bar Raḥel, the fact <b>that Rav</b> needed to <b>validate</b> the status of <b>Rav Mari bar Raḥel and</b> only then <b>appoint him as an official [<i>pursei</i>] of Babylonia is difficult.</b> This incident teaches that Rav Mari bar Raḥel’s father was not Jewish, and before he could be appointed his status required validation through the fact that his mother was Jewish. If Rav Mari bar Raḥel’s father was a sage named Rava, why was it necessary to validate his status by means of his mother’s lineage? The Gemara answers: <b>Perhaps there were two</b> people named <b>Mari bar Raḥel.</b> One was the son of a convert and a Jewish mother, and the other was the son of a Sage named Rava.
In any event, that Sage <b>taught his <i>halakha</i> in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan to exempt</b> one who drives a laden animal, as <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: One who drives a</b> laden <b>animal on Shabbat is exempt from any</b> punishment.
The Gemara explains: For driving the animal <b>unwittingly, he is not liable</b> to bring a <b>sin-offering</b> because <b>all of</b> the prohibitions in <b>the Torah were juxtaposed to</b> the prohibition of <b>idolatry,</b> from which the principle is derived that one is liable only for actions that he himself performed. And for driving the animal <b>intentionally, he is also not liable</b> to be executed by stoning, <b>as we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>One who desecrates Shabbat by</b> performing <b>a matter that for its unwitting</b> performance one is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, and for its intentional</b> performance one is <b>liable to be executed by stoning.</b> By inference, for <b>a matter that for its unwitting</b> performance one is <b>not liable</b> to bring <b>a sin-offering, for its intentional</b> performance one is <b>not liable</b> to be executed by <b>stoning.</b>
And similarly, <b>he is not</b> even <b>liable</b> to be flogged <b>for</b> violating a Torah <b>prohibition</b> for which the punishment is lashes. Even though the Torah explicitly warns against performing labor on Shabbat, <b>it is a prohibition that was</b> fundamentally <b>given,</b> not as a standard prohibition punishable by lashes, but rather <b>as a warning of court-imposed capital punishment, and</b> for <b>any prohibition that was given as a warning of court-imposed capital punishment,</b> if the death penalty is not imposed for any reason, <b>one is not flogged for its</b> violation.

Daf 154b

<b>And even according to the one who said</b> that <b>one is flogged</b> for violating a prohibition that was given as a warning of court-imposed capital punishment, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to driving a laden animal can be derived by means of an inference from the language of the verse. <b>Let the Torah write: “You shall not perform any manner of labor…and</b> neither shall <b>your animal.” Why do I need</b> the superfluous word <b>you</b> in the phrase: You and your animal? Rather it is to teach that <b>it is he</b> himself <b>who is liable</b> for performing a prohibited labor on Shabbat; however, for a prohibited labor performed by <b>his animal, he is not liable.</b>
We learned in the mishna: Once <b>he reached the outer courtyard,</b> he may untie the ropes that attach his bags to the donkey, <b>and the bags</b> of vessels that may not be moved on Shabbat fall on their own. <b>Rav Huna said:</b> If <b>one’s animal was laden with glass vessels,</b> which would break if he let them fall to the ground, <b>he may bring cushions and blankets and place</b> them <b>beneath</b> the animal <b>and untie the ropes and</b> let <b>the bags fall</b> onto the cushions.
The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary to unload glass vessels in so complicated a manner? <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>He takes the vessels that may be moved on Shabbat</b> off the donkey? As glass vessels fall into that category, why not simply remove the glass vessels and then untie the bags?
The Gemara answers: <b>When Rav Huna stated</b> this <i>halakha</i>, he was referring <b>to the horns of a blood letter, which are not suitable</b> for any other purpose and are therefore set-aside on Shabbat due to prohibition and repulsiveness. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t he</b> thereby <b>negating a vessel’s preparedness?</b> Initially, the cushion was available for any use. Since it now has the set-aside vessels on it, the cushion, too, may no longer be moved. The Sages ruled that one may not place a vessel in a circumstance that will render it prohibited to move. The Gemara answers: This mishna is referring <b>to small bundles</b> of glass vessels that will not break if the cushions are subsequently removed from beneath them.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> based on that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one’s animal was laden with untithed produce and chunks of</b> glass [<i>ashashiot</i>], <b>one unties the ropes and the bags fall</b> on their own, <b>even though they break.</b> Apparently, placing cushions beneath the animal is prohibited. The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is not referring to vessels but rather <b>to chunks [<i>kulsa</i>] of glass</b> that are designated to be broken so that they can be melted and crafted into vessels. The Gemara adds: The language of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>also precise, as it teaches</b> that chunks are <b>similar</b> to <b>untithed produce: Just as untithed produce is not fit for his</b> use, <b>here too,</b> the chunks <b>are also not fit for his</b> use.
The Gemara explains: <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the phrase: <b>Even though they break?</b> If the mishna is indeed referring to chunks of glass, they are designated to be broken. Rather, <b>lest you say</b> that the Sages <b>were also concerned</b> about a <b>minimal loss,</b> as certainly some small slivers of glass will be lost when the chunks fall and break, the <i>tanna</i> in the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that the Sages did not consider minimal loss a reason significant enough to permit carrying the prohibited glass.
<b>It was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yoḥai says:</b> If <b>one’s animal was loaded with a burden of</b> untithed <b>grain, he may place his head beneath</b> the pile <b>and move it to a different side</b> of the animal, <b>and it falls by itself.</b> The Sages prohibited moving set-aside objects in the typical manner, but there is no concern about doing so in an unusual manner.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabban Gamliel’s donkey was laden with honey and he did not want to unload</b> the donkey <b>until the conclusion of Shabbat. At the conclusion of Shabbat,</b> the donkey <b>died</b> of fatigue. The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>He takes the vessels that may be moved</b> on Shabbat off the donkey? Why, then, did Rabban Gamliel not unload the honey? The Gemara answers: This is a case <b>where the honey had spoiled.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> use <b>is spoiled honey suited?</b> Why did Rabban Gamliel bring it? The Gemara answers: It can be used <b>to</b> rub on <b>the wounds of camels.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> let Rabban Gamliel <b>untie</b> the <b>ropes and</b> the <b>bags will fall</b> on their own. The Gemara answers: It was due to the concern that <b>the jugs</b> containing the honey would <b>crack.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> let <b>him bring cushions and blankets and place them beneath</b> the jugs. The Gemara answers: He was concerned lest <b>they become soiled and he</b> would thereby <b>negate the vessel’s preparedness,</b> i.e., the cushions and blankets would be rendered unusable. The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t there</b> the matter of <b>the suffering of a living creature?</b> He should suffer monetary loss rather than cause the animal to suffer. The Gemara answers: Rabban Gamliel <b>holds</b> that causing <b>a living creature to suffer</b> is prohibited not by Torah law but rather <b>by rabbinic law.</b> Therefore, he need not suffer monetary loss due to the rabbinic prohibition (Ramban).
The Gemara relates: <b>Abaye found Rabba sliding his son on the back of a donkey</b> on Shabbat to entertain him. <b>He said to him: The Master is making use of living creatures</b> on Shabbat, and the Sages prohibited doing so. Rabba <b>said to him:</b> I placed my son on the side of the donkey, and as <b>they are sides, the Sages did not issue a decree</b> prohibiting making use of <b>them. From where do you say</b> that this is so? <b>As we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>One may untie</b> the <b>ropes and the bags fall</b> on their own. What, <b>is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where one attached</b> the bags by means of <b><i>guvalaki</i>,</b> where the bags are strapped to the animal and the only way to loosen them involves leaning against the sides of animal in order to unstrap them? <b>That is</b> because it is a case of making use of the <b>sides, and the Sages did not issue a decree prohibiting making use</b> of an animal’s <b>sides.</b>
Abaye answered: <b>No,</b> this is a case <b>where one attached</b> the bags by means of <b><i>agalavki</i>,</b> i.e., where the bags were not tightly strapped to the animal, but rather attached by means of a hook. In such a case, <b>there is</b> no need to make use of <b>the sides</b> of the animal in order to unhook the strap. <b>Alternatively,</b> the bags were tied to the sides of the animal <b>with a rope,</b> which could likewise be untied with ease and without leaning against the animal.
Abaye <b>raised an objection to</b> Rabba’s opinion based on that which was taught in a mishna: A <i>sukka</i> that had <b>two</b> of its walls on the ground, built <b>by a person, and one</b> wall <b>on a tree</b> is <b>valid</b> and can be used to fulfill the mitzva of <i>sukka</i>. <b>However, one may not enter it on the festival</b> day of <i>Sukkot</i> because it is prohibited to use trees rooted in the ground on Shabbat or a Festival. <b>What,</b> is this <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where one carved</b> a hole <b>in the tree</b> and inserted a beam into the hole for support, in which case <b>these are sides</b> of the tree that are being used, and apparently, using the <b>sides</b> of the tree is <b>prohibited?</b>
Rabba rejected this: <b>No,</b> it is referring to a case <b>where one bent the tree</b> over <b>and placed the roofing atop it, as</b> in that case, <b>he is making use of the tree</b> itself and not its sides. Abaye asked: <b>If so, say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If there are <b>three</b> walls built <b>by a person and one on a tree,</b> it is a <b>valid</b> <i>sukka</i> <b>and one may enter it on a Festival. And if one bent a tree</b> and placed the roofing atop it, <b>why may one enter it on a Festival?</b>
Rabba rejected this question: <b>Rather, what</b> would you say? Making use of <b>sides is prohibited.</b> If so, the same problem still exists, why is the <i>sukka</i> fit for use in the latter case? <b>Ultimately, why may one enter it on a Festival? Rather, there</b> it is referring to a case <b>where the branches [<i>gavaza</i>] are spread out and where one made the tree itself into a wall,</b> not where he leaned a wall against it. The language of the mishna <b>is also precise.</b> The wall may not be used if it is an integral part of the <i>sukka</i>, meaning that it is one of the three required walls. However, if it serves as a fourth wall, one may use the <i>sukka</i> on a Festival <b>as it is taught</b> that <b>this is the principle:</b> In <b>any</b> case where <b>if the tree was taken</b> the <i>sukka</i> would still <b>be able to stand, one may enter it on a Festival.</b> Then it is clear that the walls are not leaning against the tree; rather, the tree itself serves as a wall. The Gemara says in summary: <b>Learn from here</b> that this is so.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that these <i>amora’im</i> disagree in a dispute <b>parallel</b> to a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> with regard to making use of the sides of a tree, as it was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One may not enter</b> a <i>sukka</i> whose walls are leaning against a tree <b>on a Festival. Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Meir: One may enter it on a Festival. What, is it not that they are disagreeing about this</b> issue, <b>as this Master,</b> meaning the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that making use of the <b>sides is prohibited, and this Master,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that <b>they are permitted?</b>
<b>Abaye said: No. Everyone agrees</b> that the <b>sides are prohibited, and it is</b> with regard to the <b>sides of the sides,</b> i.e., not a wall leaning against the tree itself, but a wall that is supported by a beam that is placed in the hole carved in the tree, that <b>they disagree. This Master,</b> meaning the Rabbis, <b>holds</b> that the <b>sides of the sides are prohibited, and this Master,</b> Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that the <b>sides of the sides are permitted.</b>
<b>Rava said: The one who prohibited</b> making use of the <b>sides also prohibited</b> making use of the <b>sides of the sides,</b> and <b>the one who permitted</b> making use of the <b>sides also permitted</b> making use of the <b>sides of the sides. Rav Mesharshiyya raised an objection</b> to the opinion of Rava: If one <b>drove</b>

Daf 155a

<b>a stake in a tree and hung a</b> four<b>-</b>by<b>-</b>four handbreadth <b>basket from it</b> into which he placed the food for his joining of the Shabbat boundaries, if the basket was <b>above ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> It is prohibited for him to take the bread from the basket on Shabbat, because the basket’s area and height render it a private domain, and he is standing in a different domain. If the basket was <b>below ten handbreadths</b> from the ground, <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b>
The Gemara examines this statement: <b>The reason</b> for this distinction between above and below ten handbreadths is specifically because <b>he drove a stake into a tree</b> and hung the basket from it. <b>However,</b> if <b>he did not drive</b> a stake into a tree, but tied the basket to the tree itself, <b>even</b> if it was <b>below ten handbreadths</b> from the ground <b>his <i>eiruv</i> is not a</b> valid <b><i>eiruv</i>.</b> If he were to take the bread from the basket he would be making use of the sides of the tree, which is prohibited on Shabbat. <b>And isn’t</b> it the case that <b>this</b> is the <b><i>tanna</i> who prohibits using</b> the <b>sides</b> of the tree, <b>and</b> nevertheless, <b>he permits using</b> the <b>sides of the sides,</b> contrary to Rava’s opinion?
<b>Rav Pappa said: Here, we are dealing with a</b> narrow-mouthed <b>basket</b> that is tightly tied to the tree. Since it is difficult to remove anything from it, <b>when he takes the</b> bread for the <b><i>eiruv</i> he moves the tree, and he is</b> thereby <b>using the</b> sides of the <b>tree itself</b> and not the sides of the sides of the tree. The Gemara concludes: <b>And the <i>halakha</i></b> is that use of the <b>sides</b> of a tree or an animal <b>is prohibited</b> on Shabbat, but use of the <b>sides of the sides is permitted.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: Now that you said</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is that use of the <b>sides is prohibited,</b> with regard to <b>this ladder</b> that one climbs to an <b>elevated</b> area, <b>a person may not lean it against the palm tree</b> itself <b>because it is</b> considered use of the <b>sides</b> of the tree on Shabbat. <b>Rather, he should lean it on stakes</b> that are <b>external</b> to the trunk of <b>the palm tree. And when</b> one <b>climbs</b> the ladder, <b>he should not place his foot on the stakes. Rather, he should place it on the rungs</b> of the ladder because it is prohibited to use the sides of the tree.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may untie <i>peki’in</i> of grain before an animal</b> on Shabbat, <b>and one may spread the <i>kifin</i> but not the <i>zirin</i>.</b> These terms will be explained in the Gemara. <b>One may not crush hay or carobs before an animal</b> on Shabbat in order to facilitate its eating. He may do so <b>neither</b> for a <b>small</b> animal <b>[<i>daka</i>] nor</b> for a <b>large</b> one. <b>Rabbi Yehuda permits</b> to do so <b>with carobs for a small</b> animal, because it can swallow the hard carobs only with difficulty.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Huna said: They are</b> called <b><i>peki’in</i></b> and <b>they are</b> also called <b><i>kifin</i>.</b> The difference between them is that <b><i>peki’in</i></b> are tied with <b>two</b> knots, whereas <b><i>kifin</i></b> are tied with <b>three. <i>Zirin</i>,</b> which may not be moved on Shabbat, are bundles <b>of cedar</b> branches eaten by animals when the branches are small and moist. <b>And this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: One may untie <i>peki’in</i> of grain before an animal and spread</b> them, <b>and the same is true for <i>kifin</i>, but not</b> for <b><i>zirin</i>,</b> which <b>one</b> may <b>neither spread nor untie. Rav Ḥisda said: What is the reason</b> for the opinion of <b>Rav Huna? He holds</b> that with regard <b>to exerting</b> oneself <b>with food</b> on Shabbat, <b>one may exert</b> himself; however, with regard <b>to rendering food</b> edible, <b>one</b> may <b>not render</b> it so. Bundles of crops which are fit for animal consumption in their present state may be further prepared on Shabbat. Cedar branches cannot be eaten when bound together; therefore, one may not exert himself to untie them and render them edible on Shabbat.
<b>Rav Yehuda</b> understood the mishna differently and <b>said: They are</b> called <b><i>peki’in</i> and they are</b> also called <b><i>zirin</i>.</b> The difference between them is that <b><i>peki’in</i></b> are tied with <b>two</b> knots, whereas <b><i>zirin</i></b> are tied with <b>three. <i>Kifin</i></b> are bundles <b>of cedar</b> branches. <b>And this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying: One may untie <i>peki’in</i> of grain before an animal; however,</b> with regard to <b>spreading them, no,</b> he may not spread them. <b>And</b> with regard to <b><i>kifin</i>, one</b> may <b>also spread them. However,</b> that is <b>not</b> the case with regard to <b><i>zirin</i>,</b> as it is prohibited to <b>spread</b> them, and it is <b>only</b> permitted <b>to untie</b> them. <b>Rava said: What is the reason</b> for <b>Rav Yehuda’s</b> opinion? <b>He holds</b> the opposite of Rav Huna’s opinion. He holds that with regard to <b>rendering food</b> edible, <b>one</b> may <b>render</b> it so; however, with regard to <b>exerting</b> oneself on Shabbat <b>with food</b> that is already in an edible state, <b>one</b> may <b>not exert</b> himself.
<b>We learned</b> in the mishna: <b>One may not crush hay or carobs before an animal</b> on Shabbat in order to facilitate its eating. He may do so <b>neither</b> for a <b>small</b> animal <b>nor</b> for a <b>large</b> one. <b>Is this not</b> referring to <b>carobs</b> that are <b>similar to hay? Just as</b> it is referring to <b>hay that is soft, so too,</b> it is referring to <b>carobs that are soft. Apparently, we do not exert</b> ourselves <b>with food.</b> Since the carobs are suitable for animal consumption without being crushed, it is prohibited to exert oneself and crush them. <b>And</b> this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of <b>Rav Huna.</b>
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Huna</b> could have <b>said to you: No,</b> the mishna is referring to <b>hay</b> that is <b>similar to carobs. Just as</b> it is referring to <b>carobs that are hard, so too,</b> it is referring to <b>hay that is hard</b> and crushing it renders it edible. The Gemara asks: <b>How is it</b> possible <b>to find</b> hay that is so hard that an animal cannot eat it? The Gemara answers: It is referring <b>to young donkeys,</b> that can only eat hay that is crushed well.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from that which we learned in the continuation of the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yehuda permits</b> crushing <b>carobs for a small</b> animal. The Gemara infers: <b>For a small</b> animal, <b>yes,</b> it is permitted; <b>for a large one, no,</b> it is not permitted. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that the <b>first <i>tanna</i> holds:</b> One may <b>not exert</b> himself <b>with food</b> on Shabbat, but with regard to <b>rendering</b> food edible, <b>one</b> may <b>render</b> food edible, <b>that</b> explains <b>that which Rabbi Yehuda</b> said in response: Feeding <b>carobs to a small animal is also</b> a case of <b>rendering food</b> edible because the animal cannot eat hard carobs. <b>However, if you say</b> that the <b>first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that with regard to <b>rendering</b> food edible, <b>one</b> may <b>not render</b> food edible on Shabbat, but with regard to <b>exerting</b> oneself <b>with food, one</b> may <b>exert</b> himself, then <b>Rabbi Yehuda, who permits</b> crushing <b>carobs for a small</b> animal, <b>all the more so</b> he should permit crushing carobs <b>for a large</b> one. If carobs are suitable for consumption by a small animal, all the more so are they suitable for consumption by a large animal.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Do you hold that</b> the small animal <b>[<i>daka</i>]</b> mentioned here is referring to <b>an actual small</b> animal? No; rather, <b>what</b> is the meaning of <b><i>daka</i></b> here? It is referring to a <b>large</b> animal. <b>And what</b> is the reason that the mishna <b>calls it <i>daka</i>? Because it is particular [<i>dayka</i>] about</b> its <b>food.</b> Since this animal can eat uncrushed carobs when there is no alternative, one may exert himself and crush them for it.
The Gemara asks: From the fact <b>that it is taught in the first clause</b> of the mishna: <b>Neither</b> for a <b>small</b> animal <b>nor</b> for a <b>large</b> animal, <b>it can be inferred</b> that when <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> said <b><i>daka</i>, he meant an actual small</b> animal. The Gemara was unable to answer to find an answer to this question and it remains <b>difficult.</b> Nonetheless, Rav Huna’s opinion was not refuted.
Therefore, <b>come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from that which we learned in another mishna: <b>One may chop</b>

Daf 155b

<b>pumpkins before an animal and an</b> animal <b>carcass before dogs. Is this not</b> referring to <b>pumpkins</b> that are <b>similar to an</b> animal <b>carcass? Just as an</b> animal <b>carcass is soft, so too,</b> the <b>pumpkins</b> referred to here <b>are soft. Apparently, one</b> may <b>exert</b> himself <b>with food, and</b> this is a <b>conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda.</b> The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Yehuda</b> could have <b>said to you: No,</b> the mishna is referring to an animal <b>carcass</b> that is <b>similar to pumpkins. Just as</b> the reference is to <b>pumpkins that are hard, so too,</b> the reference is to an animal <b>carcass that is hard,</b> and chopping it renders it edible. The Gemara asks: <b>And how is it</b> possible <b>to find</b> an animal carcass that is so hard that another animal cannot eat it? The Gemara answers: The mishna is referring to <b>elephant flesh. Alternatively,</b> it can be explained that the mishna is referring to more common animal meat placed <b>before puppies</b> that can eat only chopped meat.
<b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from <b>that which Rav Ḥanan of Neharde’a taught: One</b> may <b>crumble straw and alfalfa</b> on Shabbat <b>and mix</b> the two together, and the animal then eats the straw because it is mixed with the alfalfa. <b>Apparently, one</b> may <b>exert</b> himself <b>with food</b> on Shabbat. The Gemara rejects this proof: No, the <b>straw</b> mentioned here is <b>rotten straw</b> that requires special preparation to render it suitable for animal consumption, and <b>alfalfa</b> is taught with regard to <b>young donkeys</b> who can only eat it in small pieces.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may not forcibly overfeed a camel</b> on Shabbat <b>and one may not force-feed</b> it, even if in doing so he does not overfeed the camel. <b>However, one may place food into its mouth. And</b> the mishna makes a distinction, which will be explained in the Gemara, between two manners of placing food in the mouths of cattle. <b>One may not</b> place food in <b>the</b> mouths of <b>calves</b> on Shabbat in the manner of <b><i>hamra’a</i>, but one may</b> do so in the manner of <b><i>halata</i>. And one may force-feed chickens. And one may add water to bran</b> used as animal feed, <b>but one may not knead</b> the mixture. <b>And one may not place water before bees or before doves in a dove-cote,</b> because they are capable of finding their own food; <b>however, one may place</b> water <b>before geese and chickens and before hardisian [<i>hardeisiyyot</i>] doves.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> We learned in the mishna that one may not forcibly overfeed a camel on Shabbat. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> meaning of: <b>One may not forcibly overfeed? Rav Yehuda said: One may not</b> feed a camel to the point that <b>it creates a trough inside of its stomach.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is there</b> the possibility of feeding a camel <b>in that manner?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes; and as Rav Yirmeya of Difti said: I saw</b> an <b>Arab who fed</b> his camel <b>a <i>kor</i></b> of food <b>and loaded it</b> with another <b><i>kor</i></b> on its back.
We learned in the mishna: <b>One may not</b> place food in the mouths of calves on Shabbat in the manner of <b><i>hamra’a</i>,</b> but one may do so in the manner of <i>halata</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>Which is <i>hamra’a</i> and which is <i>halata</i>? Rav Yehuda said: <i>Hamra’a</i></b> is positioning food <b>into a place</b> in the animal’s throat <b>from which it cannot return</b> and expel the food. <b><i>Halata</i></b> is positioning food <b>into a place</b> in the animal’s mouth <b>from which it can return</b> and expel the food. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: Both this and that</b> refer to positioning food <b>into a place from which</b> the animal <b>cannot return</b> and expel the food; <b>however,</b> the difference between them is that in <b><i>hamra’a</i></b> the food is placed <b>with a vessel,</b> whereas <b>in <i>halata</i></b> the food is placed <b>by hand.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef raised an objection</b> from that which was taught in the <i>Tosefta</i>: <b>One may force-feed [<i>mehalketin</i>] chickens, and needless to say, one may <i>malkitin</i>. And one may not <i>malkitin</i> doves in a dove-cote or doves in an attic, and needless to say, one may not force-feed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is <i>mehalketin</i> and what is <i>malkitin</i>? If you say</b> that <b><i>mehalketin</i></b> means <b>that one feeds</b> the bird <b>by hand</b> and <b><i>malkitin</i></b> means <b>that one throws</b> the food <b>before them, by inference, throwing food before doves in a dove-cote or</b> before <b>doves in an attic is also not</b> permitted. But why would that be prohibited?
<b>Rather, is it not</b> that <b><i>mehalketin</i></b> means positioning food <b>into a place from which</b> the bird <b>cannot return</b> and expel the food, and <b><i>malkitin</i></b> means positioning food <b>into a place from which it can return</b> and expel the food? Therefore, <i>mehalketin</i> in the case of birds is similar to <i>halata</i> into a camel’s mouth, which the mishna permitted. <b>By inference,</b> the <b><i>hamra’a</i></b> prohibited in the mishna is performed <b>with a vessel, and</b> this poses <b>a conclusive refutation</b> to the opinion <b>of Rav Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rav Yehuda</b> could have <b>said to you: Actually, <i>mehalketin</i></b> means <b>that one feeds</b> the bird <b>by hand,</b> and <b><i>malkitin</i></b> mean <b>that one throws</b> the food <b>before them. And that which was difficult for you: Is throwing</b> food <b>before doves in a dove-cote or doves in an attic also not</b> permitted on Shabbat? This is not difficult because with regard to <b>these</b> chickens and geese that were mentioned, sole responsibility for <b>their sustenance</b> is incumbent <b>upon you</b> as they are incapable of providing for themselves. <b>However,</b> in the case of <b>these</b> doves, responsibility for <b>their sustenance</b> is <b>not</b> incumbent <b>upon you,</b> and therefore, it is prohibited to place food before them, <b>as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may place sustenance before a dog</b> on Shabbat, <b>but one may not place sustenance before a pig. And what</b> is the <b>difference between this and that?</b> In <b>this</b> case of the dog, responsibility <b>for its sustenance is</b> incumbent <b>upon you, and</b> in <b>that</b> case of the pig, responsibility <b>for its sustenance is not</b> incumbent <b>upon you,</b> as no Jew raises pigs.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The language of <b>the mishna is also precise</b> in support of this explanation, as we learn: <b>And one may not place water before bees or before doves in a dove-cote</b> because they are capable of finding their own food; <b>however, one may place</b> water <b>before geese and chickens and before hardisian doves. What is the reason</b> for this distinction? <b>Is it not because</b> for <b>these,</b> geese and chickens, responsibility for <b>their sustenance</b> is incumbent <b>upon you, and</b> for <b>those,</b> bees and doves, responsibility for <b>their sustenance</b> is <b>not</b> incumbent <b>upon you?</b>
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>And according to your reasoning, why</b> did the mishna cite a case <b>specifically</b> involving <b>water? Even wheat and barley</b> should <b>also not</b> be permitted. <b>Rather,</b> the reason for the distinction between the <i>halakhot</i> is that <b>water is different because it is found in a lake</b> or in other reservoirs, and therefore one need not exert himself to provide water for bees and doves. That is not the case with the rest of their food.
Returning to the discussion of feeding dogs, the Gemara cites additional statements on the topic. <b>Rabbi Yona taught at the entrance to the house of the <i>Nasi</i>: What is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written: “The righteous man takes knowledge of the cause of the poor”</b> (Proverbs 29:7)? <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, knows that for a dog, its sustenance is scarce</b> and they are not fed sufficiently. <b>Therefore, its food remains in its intestines for three days</b> so that the dog will be sustained by that food, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna dealing with the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity: After an animal eats flesh from a corpse, <b>how long does its food remain in its intestines</b> undigested <b>and</b> therefore <b>ritually impure? In</b> the case of <b>a dog</b> it is for <b>three twenty-four hour periods, and for fowl and fish,</b> who digest their food quickly, it is <b>the equivalent</b> of <b>the</b> time it takes <b>for</b> the flesh <b>to fall into the fire and be consumed</b> by the fire.
<b>Rav Hamnuna said: Learn from it:</b> It is <b>the way of the world,</b> i.e., proper conduct, <b>to throw a piece of meat before a dog,</b> as even the Holy One, Blessed be He, concerns Himself with the dog’s sustenance. The Gemara asks: <b>And how much food</b> should one give to a dog? <b>Rav Mari said:</b> Give it the equivalent of <b>the measure of its ear and</b> strike it immediately <b>thereafter with a staff</b> so that the dog will not grow attached to the one who fed it. <b>This applies</b> specifically when one is <b>in the field, but in the city,</b> one should <b>not</b> give anything to a dog because the dog <b>will be drawn</b> to follow him and remain with him. <b>Rav Pappa said: There is no</b> creature <b>poorer than a dog, and no</b> creature <b>richer than a pig,</b> as pigs will eat anything, and people provide them with plentiful amounts of food.
With regard to the halakhic ruling, a <i>baraita</i> <b>was taught in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Yehuda: What is <i>hamra’a</i> and what is <i>halata</i>? <i>Hamra’a</i></b> is when a person forcibly <b>lays</b> the animal on the ground <b>and forces its mouth open and feeds it vetch and water simultaneously</b> so that the animal will be unable to expel it. <b><i>Halata</i></b> is when <b>one feeds</b> the animal while it is <b>standing and gives it to drink</b> while it is <b>standing,</b> i.e., gives it food and drink in the usual manner, <b>and one gives it vetch separately and water separately,</b> to augment what the animal eats on its own.
We learned in the mishna: <b>And one may force-feed chickens,</b> and one may add water to bran, but one may not knead the mixture. <b>Abaye said: I said this before my Master,</b> Rabba: <b>Whose</b> opinion is it in <b>the mishna? And he said to me: It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda, as it was taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one person places flour and</b> another <b>one places water into it, the latter is liable</b> to bring a sin-offering for performing the prohibited labor of kneading. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda says: One is only liable</b> when he actually <b>kneads</b> the flour and water together. He is not liable for merely adding water to the flour. This is similar to the ruling of the mishna that one may pour water into the bran but may not knead the mixture.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Perhaps Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda only stated</b> that actual kneading is required to be liable for performing the prohibited labor of kneading <b>in</b> the case of <b>flour, which can be kneaded; however,</b> in the case of <b>bran, which cannot be kneaded</b> into a dough, <b>even Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda</b> would <b>concede</b> that it is prohibited, even if one does not actually knead the mixture. The Gemara rejects this statement: It should <b>not enter your mind</b> to explain it that way, <b>as it was taught explicitly</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not place water into bran</b> on Shabbat; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Yosei bar Yehuda says: One may place water into bran.</b>
<b>The Sages taught:</b> On Shabbat, <b>one may not knead</b> sweet <b>flour</b> made from unripe grain that was dried in an oven, <b>and some say: One may knead</b> it. The Gemara asks: <b>Whose is</b> the opinion introduced as: <b>And some say? Rav Ḥisda said:</b>

Daf 156a

<b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda. And this</b> leniency <b>applies only</b> in a case <b>where one alters</b> the way that he kneads. The Gemara asks: <b>How does one alter</b> the manner in which he kneads? <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> One does not knead the dough all at once but rather <b>a little bit at a time.</b>
It was also taught: <b>And they agree that one may mix the <i>shatit</i>,</b> roasted barley to which honey is added, <b>on Shabbat, and drink Egyptian beer,</b> as it is not considered to be for medicinal purposes. The Gemara asks: <b>Didn’t you say: One may not knead?</b> That contradicts the statement that they agree that it is permitted to stir the <i>shatit</i>. The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as there is a distinction between the cases. <b>This</b> dispute with regard to <i>shatit</i> is referring <b>to</b> mixing a <b>thick</b> mixture, which is similar to kneading. However, <b>that</b> statement where they agree that mixing is permitted is referring <b>to</b> a <b>soft,</b> thin mixture that cannot be kneaded. <b>And</b> all of <b>these</b> statements are referring to a case <b>where one alters</b> the way he kneads or stirs.
The Gemara asks: <b>How does one alter</b> the manner in which he performs these actions? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> On a <b>weekday one</b> first <b>places the vinegar</b> in a vessel <b>and then places the <i>shatit</i>. On Shabbat one</b> first <b>places the <i>shatit</i> and then places the vinegar.</b> The Gemara relates that <b>Levi, son of Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya, found the one who kneads in his parents’ home kneading</b> bran on Shabbat <b>and feeding it to his ox. He kicked him</b> so that he would stop. When <b>his father came</b> and <b>found him,</b> he <b>said to him: This</b> is what <b>your mother’s father said in the name of Rav.</b> The Gemara interjects: <b>And who is</b> his mother’s father? It is <b>Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba,</b> who said: <b>One may knead but not feed</b> animals, <b>and</b> a calf <b>that does not take</b> the food <b>with its tongue may be fed</b> on Shabbat. <b>And this applies</b> only <b>when one alters</b> the manner in which he does so.
The Gemara asks: <b>How does one alter</b> the manner in which he does so? <b>Rav Yeimar bar Shelamya said in the name of Abaye:</b> One moves the ladle or stirring utensil in the directions of <b>warp and woof.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Isn’t</b> it the case that <b>it will not mix well,</b> so what is the point of stirring it that way? <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> It means that <b>one pours it into</b> another <b>vessel</b> and in the process it is mixed.
<b>It was written in Ze’eiri’s notebook: I said before my rabbi, and</b> the Gemara asks: <b>And who is</b> his rabbi? It is <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya.</b> And Ze’eiri said before him: <b>What is</b> the ruling? Is it permitted <b>to knead</b> on Shabbat? <b>He said:</b> It is <b>prohibited. What is</b> the ruling with regard to <b>emptying</b> food from a vessel before one animal to place it before another animal? <b>He said:</b> It is <b>permitted. Rav Menashya said:</b> Placing <b>one</b> trough <b>before one</b> animal or <b>two</b> troughs <b>before two</b> animals, one may <b>well</b> do so. Placing <b>three</b> troughs <b>before two</b> animals <b>is prohibited,</b> because it is considered to be superfluous labor as he is bringing the animals more food than they need. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> It is permitted to add <b>a <i>kav</i></b> of additional food <b>or even two <i>kav</i>. Ulla said:</b> One may add <b>a <i>kor</i> or even two <i>kor</i></b> and there is no need for concern.
<b>It was written in Levi’s notebook: I said before my rabbi, and</b> the Gemara asks: <b>And who is</b> his rabbi? It is <b>our holy Rabbi,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi. Levi spoke <b>about</b> the fact that <b>people would knead <i>shatit</i> in Babylonia, and my rabbi, and who is it, our holy Rabbi, cried</b> in protest over the fact that <b>people would knead <i>shatit</i>. And</b> there was <b>no one who listened to him, and he did not have the power to prohibit</b> it <b>due to</b> the people’s reliance on the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who permitted doing so.
After citing relevant <i>halakhot</i> written in the notebooks of various Sages, the Gemara relates that <b>it was written in Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi’s notebook: One who</b> was born <b>on the first day of the week,</b> Sunday, <b>will be a person and there will not be one in him.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the meaning of the phrase: <b>There will not be one in him? If you say</b> that <b>there is not one</b> quality <b>for the best,</b> that cannot be, <b>as Rav Ashi said: I was</b> born <b>on the first day of the week,</b> and one cannot say that there was nothing good about him. <b>Rather,</b> it must mean that <b>there is not one</b> quality <b>for the worst. Didn’t Rav Ashi say: I and Dimi bar Kakuzta were</b> both born <b>on the first day of the week. I</b> became <b>a king,</b> the head of a yeshiva, <b>and he became the head of</b> a gang of <b>thieves,</b> clearly a negative quality. <b>Rather,</b> one born on a Sunday <b>is either completely for the best or completely for the worst. What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because</b> both <b>light and darkness were created</b> on the first day of Creation.
<b>One who was</b> born <b>on the second day of the week,</b> Monday, <b>will be a short-tempered person. What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because on that day,</b> the second day of Creation, <b>the</b> upper and lower <b>waters were divided.</b> Therefore, it is a day of contentiousness. <br> <b>One who was</b> born <b>on the third day of the week will be a rich man and a promiscuous</b> person. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because on that day,</b> the third day, <b>vegetation was created.</b> It grows abundantly but is also mixed together without boundaries between the grass and the plants. <br><b>One who was</b> born <b>on the fourth day of the week will be a wise and enlightened person. What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because the</b> heavenly <b>lights were hung</b> in the heavens <b>on that day,</b> and wisdom is likened to light.
<b>One who was</b> born <b>on the fifth day of the week will be a person who performs acts of kindness. What is the reason</b> for this? It is <b>because on that day the fish and fowl were created,</b> and they do not receive their sustenance by performing work for people. They are sustained by the kindness of God alone. <br><b>One who was</b> born <b>on the sixth day of the week will be a seeker. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said</b> that this means that he will be <b>one who seeks out mitzvot,</b> as most of the activity on Friday involves preparation for Shabbat. <br><b>One who was</b> born <b>on Shabbat will die on Shabbat, because they desecrated the great day of Shabbat on his</b> behalf. <b>Rava bar Rav Sheila said: And he will be called a</b> person of <b>great sanctity</b> because he was born on the sacred day of Shabbat.
<b>Rabbi Ḥanina said to</b> his students who heard all this: <b>Go</b> and <b>tell the son of Leiva’i,</b> Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi: <b>It is not the constellation of the day</b> of the week <b>that determines</b> a person’s nature; <b>rather,</b> it is <b>the constellation of the hour</b> that <b>determines</b> his nature. <br><b>One who was</b> born <b>under</b> the influence of <b>the sun will be a radiant person; he will eat from his own</b> resources <b>and drink from his own</b> resources, <b>and his secrets will be exposed. If he steals he will not succeed,</b> because he will be like the sun that shines and is revealed to all. <br><b>One who was</b> born <b>under</b> the influence of <b>Venus will be a rich and promiscuous person. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>Because fire was born</b> during the hour of Venus, he will be subject the fire of the evil inclination, which burns perpetually. <br><b>One who was</b> born <b>under</b> the influence of <b>Mercury will be an enlightened and expert man, because</b> Mercury <b>is the sun’s scribe,</b> as it is closest to the sun. <br><b>One who was</b> born <b>under</b> the influence of <b>the moon will be a man who suffers pains, who builds and destroys, and destroys and builds.</b> He will be a man <b>who eats not from his own</b> resources <b>and drinks not from his own</b> resources, <b>and whose secrets are hidden. If he steals he will succeed,</b> as he is like the moon that constantly changes form, whose light is not its own, and who is at times exposed and at times hidden. <br><b>One who was</b> born <b>under</b> the influence of <b>Saturn will be a man whose thoughts are for naught. And some say</b> that <b>everything that</b> others <b>think about him</b> and plan to do to him <b>is for naught.</b> <br> <b>One who was</b> born <b>under</b> the influence of <b>Jupiter [<i>tzedek</i>] will be a just</b> person <b>[<i>tzadkan</i>]. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: And just</b> in this context means just <b>in</b> the performance of <b>mitzvot.</b> <br><b>One who was</b> born <b>under</b> the influence of <b>Mars will be one who spills blood. Rav Ashi said:</b> He will be <b>either a blood letter, or a thief, or a slaughterer</b> of animals, <b>or a circumciser. Rabba said: I was</b> born <b>under</b> the influence of <b>Mars</b> and I do not perform any of those activities. <b>Abaye said: My Master also punishes and kills</b> as a judge.
<b>It was stated</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says: A constellation makes one wise</b> and <b>a constellation makes one wealthy, and there is a constellation for the Jewish people</b> that influences them. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: There is no constellation for the Jewish people</b> that influences them. The Jewish people are not subject to the influence of astrology. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan follows his</b> own <b>reasoning,</b> as <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that there is no constellation for the Jewish people? As it is stated: “Thus said the Lord: Learn not the way of the nations, and be not dismayed at the signs of heaven; for the nations are dismayed at them”</b> (Jeremiah 10:2). <b>The nations will be dismayed</b> by them, <b>but not the Jewish people.</b>
<b>And Rav also holds</b> that <b>there is no constellation for the Jewish people, as Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: From where</b> is it derived <b>that there is no constellation for the Jewish people? As it is stated</b> with regard to Abraham: <b>“And He brought him outside,</b> and said: Look now toward heaven, and count the stars, if you are able to count them; and He said unto him: So shall your offspring be” (Genesis 15:5). The Sages derived from this that <b>Abraham said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe,</b> “Behold, You have given me no offspring, and <b>one born in my house is to be my heir”</b> (Genesis 15:3). The Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>said to him: No.</b> “And, behold, the word of the Lord came to him, saying: This man shall not be your heir; <b>rather, one that will come forth from your own innards shall be your heir”</b> (Genesis 15:4).
Abraham <b>said before Him: Master of the Universe, I looked at my astrological</b> map, <b>and</b> according to the configuration of my constellations <b>I am not fit to have a son.</b> The Holy One, Blessed be He, <b>said to him: Emerge from your astrology,</b> as the verse states: “And He brought him outside,” <b>as there is no constellation for Israel. What is your thinking?</b>

Daf 156b

Is it <b>because Jupiter is</b> situated <b>in the west</b> that you cannot have children? <b>I will restore</b> it <b>and establish</b> it <b>in the east. And that is</b> the meaning of <b>that which is written</b> with regard to Abraham: <b>“Who has raised up one from the east, he will call justice [<i>tzedek</i>] to his steps [<i>leraglo</i>].</b> He gives nations before him, and makes him rule over kings; his sword makes them as the dust, his bow as the driven stubble” (Isaiah 41:2). God established Jupiter [<i>tzedek</i>] in the east on behalf of [<i>leraglo</i>] Abraham.
<b>And from</b> that which transpired to <b>Shmuel,</b> one can <b>also</b> conclude that <b>there is no constellation for the Jewish people.</b> The Gemara relates that <b>Shmuel and</b> the gentile sage <b>Ablet were sitting, and</b> they saw <b>these people were going to the lake. Ablet said to Shmuel: This person will go and he will not return,</b> because <b>a snake will bite him and he will die. Shmuel said to him: If he is a Jew, he will go and come back. As they were sitting</b> for a while, the person they discussed <b>went</b> away <b>and</b> then <b>returned.</b>
<b>Ablet stood up, threw down</b> the person’s <b>burden, and inside he found a snake cut and cast in two pieces. Shmuel said to him: What did you do</b> to merit being saved from death? The person <b>said to him: Every day we all take bread</b> together <b>and eat</b> from the bread. <b>Today, there was one of us who did not have bread,</b> and when it came time to gather the bread, <b>he was embarrassed</b> because he did not have any to give. <b>I said to</b> the others: <b>I will go and take</b> the bread. <b>When I came to</b> the person who did not have bread, <b>I rendered myself as one who was taking from him so that he would not be embarrassed.</b> Shmuel <b>said to him: You performed a mitzva. Shmuel went out and taught</b> based on this incident that even though it is written: <b>“And charity will save from death”</b> (Proverbs 10:2), it does <b>not</b> only mean that it will save a person <b>from an unusual death but</b> even <b>from death itself.</b>
<b>And from</b> that which transpired to <b>Rabbi Akiva as well</b> it can be derived that <b>there is no constellation for the Jewish people, as Rabbi Akiva had a daughter, and Chaldean</b> astrologers <b>told him</b> that <b>on the same day that she enters the wedding canopy, a snake will bite her and she will die. She was very worried about this. On that day,</b> her wedding day, <b>she took</b> the ornamental <b>pin</b> from her hair <b>and stuck it</b> into a hole <b>in the wall</b> for safekeeping, and <b>it happened</b> that it <b>entered</b> directly <b>into the eye of the snake. In the morning, when she took</b> the pin, <b>the snake was pulled and came out with it.</b>
<b>Her father</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>said to her: What did you do</b> to merit being saved from the snake? She told him: <b>In the evening a poor person came and knocked on the door, and everyone was preoccupied with the feast and nobody heard him. I stood</b> and <b>took the portion that you had given me</b> and <b>gave it to him.</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>said to her: You performed a mitzva,</b> and you were saved in its merit. <b>Rabbi Akiva went out and taught</b> based on this incident that even though it is written: <b>“And charity will save from death”</b> (Proverbs 10:2), it does <b>not</b> mean that it will save a person only <b>from an unusual death, but</b> even <b>from death itself.</b>
<b>And from</b> that which transpired to <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak as well</b> it can be derived that <b>there is no constellation for the Jewish people, As Chaldean</b> astrologers <b>told Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak’s mother: Your son will be a thief. She did not allow him</b> to <b>uncover his head. She said to</b> her son: <b>Cover your head so that the fear of Heaven will be upon you, and pray for</b> Divine <b>mercy. He did not know why she said</b> this <b>to him. One day he was sitting and studying beneath a palm tree</b> that did not belong to him, and <b>the cloak fell off of his head. He lifted his eyes</b> and <b>saw the palm tree. He was overcome by impulse</b> and <b>he climbed up and detached a bunch of dates with his teeth.</b> Apparently, he had an inborn inclination to steal, but was able to overcome that inclination with proper education and prayer.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One may cut the pumpkins before an animal</b> on Shabbat, as long as they were picked prior to Shabbat. <b>And</b> likewise one may cut <b>an</b> animal <b>carcass before the dogs</b> on Shabbat. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: If it was not</b> already <b>a carcass,</b> i.e., it was not dead, <b>prior to Shabbat, it is prohibited</b> to cut it or even move it on Shabbat <b>because it is not prepared</b> for use on Shabbat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> A dispute between the <i>amora’im</i> with regard to the prohibition of set-aside on Shabbat <b>was stated. <i>Ayin</i>, <i>reish</i>, <i>lamed</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>ḥet</i>, <i>zayin</i></b> is a <b>mnemonic</b> for the names of the <i>amora’im</i> who stated the following <i>halakhot</i>. <b>Ulla said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that there is a prohibition of set-aside on Shabbat. <b>And Shmuel said:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i> is in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b>
